title: Giants vs. Eagles: What to Watch
description: Matchup to Watch: Eli Manning vs. The BlitzEli Manning takes a lot of time to adjust plays at the line of scrimmage, and that has caused some delay penalties and miscommunication. Coach Tom Coughlin has expressed his concern about too much "chess game." Coughlin and the offensive coordinator Kevin Gilbride said the Eagles blitz even more than before, and that was plenty. Should Manning dither further when presented with such challenges, the Giants could lose again to their N.F.C. East rival.

title: Trick or Treat in Stillwater
description: STILLWATER, Okla. -- There is plenty of orange and black at Boone Pickens Stadium.

title: Trick or Treat in Stillwater
description: STILLWATER, Okla.  There is plenty of orange and black at Boone Pickens Stadium.

title: In Race for Governor, Brown Is Hard to Ignore
description: The job of California governor is a political plum. Its occupant becomes an instant household name across the country, attracts worldwide attention and is typically considered a potential candidate for president. Yet with Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Franciscos departure from the race Friday, the Democrats now have no major candidates officially in the running for the job in 2010.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about an academic reassessment that challenges what is known about the 1415 Battle of Agincourt in France, where an exhausted English army defeated heavily armed French nobles, gave an outdated name for the academic institution where Kelly DeVries, an authority on medieval warfare who was quoted, is a professor of history. It is Loyola University Maryland; until Sept. 25, it had been Loyola College in Maryland.

title: Mandates and Affordability
description: If Congress approves health care reform, virtually all Americans will be required to buy health insurance or pay a penalty. That raises a fundamental question: Will the policies be affordable?

title: Family Baggage From the Oval Office
description: There may soon be a refreshing addition to the nations presidential historic sites: Billy Carters gas station in Plains, Ga. This is where the self-proclaimed redneck brother of the 39th president happily drank beer, expounded raffishly to the international media, and hosted Libyan officials who hired him to lobby an embarrassed Carter administration. I have more influence over members of the U.S. Senate than I do over Billy, President Jimmy Carter once despaired at news of his brothers caperings.

title: Recession, Revolution and a Leaner Times
description: IN his autobiography The Good Times, Russell Baker described the Times newsroom he joined in 1954 as comically overstaffed. Baker, a Pulitzer Prize-winning Washington reporter and columnist, quoted a colleagues explanation for all the idle reporters playing bridge and working crossword puzzles:

title: More Poetry, Please
description: More and more lately, I find people asking me: What do you think President Obama really believes about this or that issue? I find that odd. How is it that a president who has taken on so many big issues, with very specific policies  and has even been awarded a Nobel Prize for all the hopes he has kindled  still has so many people asking what he really believes?

description: Moorestown, N.J.

description: Somerset, Va.

description: Atlanta

title: A Final Verdict on the Presidential Salute
description: FOR nearly three decades, Ive felt conflicted about presidential salutes. After all, my United States Marine Corps instructors drilled into me the idea that you never salute without a cover which, in civilian, meant without a hat.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about demonstrations that call for a reduction in carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere to 350 parts per million, which some prominent scientists consider the limit to avoid disruptions from global warming, misstated the job at the Environmental Defense Fund formerly held by Michael Oppenheimer, a Princeton University scientist, who said it would be a herculean accomplishment to hold those levels below 450 parts per million. It was chief scientist, not scientist.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 11 about the revival of Bye Bye Birdie misstated the age of Lee Adams, who wrote the music. He is 85, not 75.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about electric-motorcycle racing misstated the cost to compete with one racebike, the KillaCycle. It is $20,000 a year, not $120,000.

title: Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Report
description: And Then There Was One | You never want to ignore Jerry Brown. With the departure of San Franciscos mayor, Gavin Newsom, from the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, the 71-year-old state attorney general becomes the presumptive nominee, explains Daniel Weintraub. Perhaps its not a surprise: Every California governor in the past half century has been either a veteran state officeholder or a celebrity. Mr. Brown is both.

title: Highlights From Sunday's Bay Area Report
description: And Then There Was One | You never want to ignore Jerry Brown. With the departure of San Francisco's mayor, Gavin Newsom, from the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, the 71-year-old state attorney general becomes the presumptive nominee, explains Daniel Weintraub. Perhaps it's not a surprise: Every California governor in the past half century has been either a veteran state officeholder or a celebrity. Mr. Brown is both.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner misstated the brides relationship to Melania Trump. She is a stepdaughter, not the stepdaughter.

title: Sabathia to Start Game 4; Burnett Lined Up for 5
description: PHILADELPHIA  When C.C. Sabathia started on three days rest in the American League Championship Series, he was still throwing 95 miles an hour in the eighth inning. Sabathia earned the victory in Game 4 that night, and he has a chance to repeat the feat on Sunday at Citizens Bank Park.

description: PHILADELPHIA - When C.C. Sabathia started on three days' rest in the American League Championship Series, he was still throwing 95 miles an hour in the eighth inning. Sabathia earned the victory in Game 4 that night, and he has a chance to repeat the feat on Sunday at Citizens Bank Park.

title: Corrections
description: The Living In article and a map last Sunday about Castleton Corners, Staten Island, misstated part of the local name for Interstate 278. It is the Staten Island Expressway, not Parkway.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Sunday about the sculptor Ruth Duckworth omitted part of the name of one of the colleges for which she completed monumental bronze sculptures in the last decade. It is Lewis & Clark Community College in Godfrey, Ill.  not Lewis and Clark College. (There is a Lewis & Clark College in Portland, Ore.)

title: College Football Replay: Oct.31
description: A view of the day in college football, full of touchdown catches (and interceptions).

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the use of historical news events to drive plot developments in the television drama Mad Men misspelled the surname of the president of the Ossining Historical Society, who is an unofficial props and location consultant for the show (the main character lives in Ossining, N.Y.). He is Norman MacDonald, not McDonald.

title: No Need to Wait for Pickens
description: STILLWATER, Okla. - At the end of the first quarter of Saturday night's game between No. 3 Texas and No. 13 Oklahoma State, there was a dash for the men's restroom on the suite level of Boone Pickens Stadium.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Medill Innocence Project, in which students at Northwestern Universitys journalism school scrutinize the work of prosecutors and the police, misstated part of the name of a group at the universitys law school that has worked with the students. It is the Center on Wrongful Convictions, not the Center for Wrongful Convictions.

title: Corrections
description: The Chess column last Sunday, about unpopular openings, misidentified the first move in the Sokolsky opening, one of those considered bad. It is 1 b4, not 1 g4.

title: Former Cornhusker Sells Outland Trophy at Auction
description: Aaron Taylors career at Nebraska was successful by any measure. He helped the Cornhuskers win three national titles, was an all-American as a center and a guard and won the Outland Trophy as the nations best interior lineman in 1997.

title: Former Cornhusker Sells Outland Trophy at Auction
description: Aaron Taylor's career at Nebraska was successful by any measure. He helped the Cornhuskers win three national titles, was an all-American as a center and a guard and won the Outland Trophy as the nation's best interior lineman in 1997.

title: Not Your Ordinary Wedding Band
description: Wedding bands have been a source of embarrassment for those forced to play in them. The Dexter Lake Club Band has neatly subverted this construction by the simple expediency of creating a band that actually rocks.

title: Getting Dirty Greasing the Wheels for Friends
description: In the Atlantic Diner in Queens on an afternoon two years ago, you could hear the sounds of a man peeling open the tin can around his soul. Tony Seminerio was a member of the State Assembly from Queens. Hell do you a favor, get you a contract, what do you need, let me make a call for you, I know that junior commissioner who can send bursts of government cash into the sky  why, hes a dear friend. Just hire me, Tony Seminerio. Send the money to my consulting company. If you dont, I hate you, youre no good.

title: In War-Torn Liberia, Women Making Do
description: IF you walked into a room full of sex slaves, you might not expect to find role models. Unless youve already seen Danai Guriras new drama, Eclipsed.

title: A Heroic Doctor, a Global Scourge
description: My Sunday column is about obstetric fistula, a horrendous childbirth injury that rarely gets attention or treatment because the victims are the most voiceless of the voiceless. Dr. Lewis Wall, the hero of the column, taught me about fistulas years ago, and so I've been writing about them periodically since my first column on the topic back in 2002.

title: Albert York, Reclusive Landscape Painter, Dies at 80
description: Albert York, a painter of small, mysterious landscapes who shunned the art world yet had a fervent following within it, died Tuesday in Southampton, N.Y. He was 80 and lived in Water Mill, N.Y.

title: Search Continues for 9 Missing After Military Crash Off San Diego
description: LOS ANGELES  Rescue teams continued searching on Saturday for seven Coast Guard members and two Marines whose aircraft collided off the coast of San Diego on Thursday night.

title: Lionel Davidson, British Writer of Well-Traveled Thrillers, Dies at 87
description: Lionel Davidson, a noted British thriller writer whose novels brought to life far-flung settings like Prague, Tibet, Israel and Siberia, died on Oct. 21 at his home in London. He was 87.

title: Peter Shellem, Investigative Reporter Who Wrote About Wrongful Convictions, Dies at 49
description: Peter Shellem, whose relentless digging into dusty court records, erroneous crime-lab reports and coerced confessions during his 23 years as a reporter for The Patriot-News in Harrisburg, Pa., led to the release of five wrongly convicted prisoners, died Oct. 24 at his home in Gardners, Pa. He was 49.

title: An End to Columbia's Winning Streak
description: Columbia High School, which had been on a roll with eight straight wins dating back to last year, lost to West Essex, 12-15, on Halloween night.

title: N.H.L. Scores: Isles Crush Sabres. Does a Sleeping Giant Stir?
description: Eleven games on Halloween, but perhaps nothing scarier that whats happening on Long Island. Three games ago the Islanders were doormats with one regulation win to their credit. But then they beat the Rangers, got two points off the Capitals  and on Saturday night they obliterated Buffalo as if the Sabres were one of those scale-model Tokyos in an old monster movie. Something humungous may be awakening in the trackless depths off the East Coast, a Godzilla in blue and orange. Home teams listed first:

title: Chapel Housing 9/11 Remains Is Set Afire
description: The inside of a temporary structure where the remains of those who did not survive the burning World Trade Center towers on Sept. 11, 2001, was itself set aflame on Saturday morning. A 26-year-old man was arrested.

title: Officials Detail 5-Hour Gap Between Detectives D.W.I. Crash and Blood Test
description: One day after the arrest of an off-duty police detective on charges he killed a pedestrian while driving drunk, the authorities provided more details about the five-hour gap between the accident and the time the police were able to obtain a sample of the detectives blood, saying the detectives case was processed more quickly than is normal in such cases.

description: The Knicks season showed fraying edges and frustration at the core even before their home opener. That arrived Saturday and ended with revitalized hope but also another loss in its own embarrassing fashion.

title: Westbrook and Manningham Are Out
description: Brian Westbrook of the Eagles, the veteran running back who often plays well against the Giants, did not dress for Sundays game at Lincoln Financial Field because of a concussion sustained in the previous game. What Is Johnsons Future in Kansas City?
description: The Kansas City Chiefs are off this week, but will return to the field next Sunday against Jacksonville without running back Larry Johnson. In an agreement reached with the team and announced Saturday night, Johnson, who was suspended for two weeks by the Chiefs, will lose just one week of pay, around $300,000. What happens to Johnson once the suspension ends, though, remains an open question.

title: Everyones a Drummer for This Hybrid Group
description: Even before the concert by the Hong Kong Chinese Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, a steady rush of rattling, whirring sounds, audible in the lobby, emanated from the auditorium. On entering the hall, every member of the audience was given a small Chinese hand drum with beads attached to two strings on the sides. By twirling the drum in your hand, you could produce a loud stream of rat-a-tats.

title: Major University in Russia Eases Fears on Rules
description: MOSCOW  The authorities at St. Petersburg State University issued a statement last week announcing that researchers in the humanities and social sciences would not be required to submit to an export-control screening before publishing their work overseas, easing fears that new procedures would constrain academic freedom.

title: Across a Field of Red, Six Couples Move to the Beat of a Romantic Heart
description: To begin his companys second program at City Center on Friday night Christopher Wheeldon went back to basics with Continuum. Part of his trilogy of dances set to mysterious, prickly music of Gyorgy Ligeti, the work was created for the San Francisco Ballet in 2002  the same year Mr. Wheeldon choreographed Morphoses and one year after the premiere of his breakthrough Polyphonia. In Continuum he shows how experimentation begins and ends with the body, and as with all of his most enchanting ballets, there is a sense, wistful and profound, that one is leaving an old world and entering a new one.

title: Memories of 9/11 Endure for Warships Crew
description: ABOARD U.S.S. NEW YORK, off New York  They were schoolchildren mostly, but also construction workers, police officers and military members, when two planes slammed into the World Trade Center eight years ago.

title: No Regrets From Manuel, Just Decisions
description: PHILADELPHIA  Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel nodded along as a reporter asked about a recent strategic decision. He was paying close attention, or at least seemed to be, when he heard, After sleeping on it, did you come up with the same answer today?

title: This Is It Is Tops at the U.S. Box Office, but Not Thrillingly So
description: LOS ANGELES  Sonys much-hyped Michael Jackson documentary, This Is It, failed to thrill a mega audience in North America, selling a solid if unspectacular $21.3 million in tickets over the weekend, for a five-day total of about $32.5 million.

title: Gilbert Finds Surprises in Familiar Orchestra Fare
description: By all rights the concert the New York Philharmonic presented at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night could have been a drowsy walk-through. After all it was not supposed to happen. The Philharmonic intended to spend the end of October in Havana, where it had been invited to perform. When that trip was canceled, after the State Department refused permission for moneyed patrons to tag along, the orchestra filled the gap in its schedule with concerts at home.

description: John Grisham had some story ideas that he didnt think could sustain full-length narrative. So he did what he customarily does: whatever he wants to. Was anyone at Doubleday going to argue with that?

An intensely watched Congressional race here that has become a battleground over the future of the Republican Party took another surprising turn on Sunday, when the Republican candidate  who ended her campaign a day earlier  announced that she was endorsing the Democrat.

All are well-known paintings and drawings by tried-and-true artists carrying estimates as low as sellers are willing to go.

title: Wheelchairs, a Debutant and One Old Lady Round Out the Field
description: Kurt Fearnley, a 28-year-old Australian, won the mens wheelchair race in Sundays New York City Marathon in 1 hour 35 minutes 58 seconds. Krige Schabort, 46, of Cedartown, Ga., finished second in the same time. The actual difference was 15-hundredths of a second in a race of 26 miles 385 yards.

title: Sundays News of Hockey, 11/1/09: O.H.L Players Skull Fractured by Check Into Boards
description: The Kitchener Rangers rookie Ben Fanelli remains in the intensive care unit at Hamilton General Hospital in critical but stable condition with a skull fracture after falling heavily into the boards during an O.H.L. game on Friday night. Fanelli, 16, went face-first into the boards after being checked from behind by Eries Michael Liambas. He was airlifted to Hamilton General after medical personnel tended to him on the ice for half an hour. Liambas was given a boarding major and a game misconduct on the play. O.H.L. Commissioner David Branch, who has led a movement to cut down on head injuries in hockey by outlawing all checks to the head, said he had not yet decided whether the hit on Fanelli warranted a suspension.

title: Sunday's News of Hockey, 11/1/09: O.H.L Player's Skull Fractured by Check Into Boards
description: The Kitchener Rangers rookie Ben Fanelli remains in the intensive care unit at Hamilton General Hospital in critical but stable condition with a skull fracture after falling heavily into the boards during an O.H.L. game on Friday night. Fanelli, 16, went face-first into the boards after being checked from behind by Erie's Michael Liambas. He was airlifted to Hamilton General after medical personnel tended to him on the ice for half an hour. Liambas was given a boarding major and a game misconduct on the play. O.H.L. Commissioner David Branch, who has led a movement to cut down on head injuries in hockey by outlawing all checks to the head, said he had not yet decided whether the hit on Fanelli warranted a suspension.

title: Heres What Being Busy in Russia Sounds Like
description: What you learn from You Cannot Start Without Me  Valery Gergiev, Maestro: that Mr. Gergiev is one busy guy.

title: Did the Stimulus Work?
description: Many economists attribute the rise in the gross domestic product in the third quarter to the $787 billion federal stimulus package approved in February. But skeptics say the growth may be short-lived because government efforts to encourage consumer spending like the cash for clunkers program are expiring. At the same time, unemployment is still rising, though the Obama administration says 650,000 jobs have been created or saved by the stimulus funds.

title: Reverberations of a Trial and Its Shocking Aftermath
description: This case has it all, someone will often say about a particularly gruesome or scandalous court proceeding  the O. J. Simpson trial, for instance, or anything involving John Gotti Jr. But you wont find a case with more all than the one nearly a century ago surrounding an Atlanta pencil factory superintendent named Leo Frank. It is mesmerizingly recreated and explored Monday on PBS in The People v. Leo Frank, a film by Ben Loeterman that even those already familiar with this ugly piece of history are likely to find unsettling.

title: From a Humble Artisan, the Races Crowning Glory
description: Jane Muhrcke has been a part of the New York City Marathon longer than have Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island. Long before the race grew out of Central Park and expanded to include all five boroughs, Muhrcke was entrenched in its inner circle.

title: Democrats Strive to Hold Governor Posts
description: NEWARK  President Obama swept into New Jersey on Sunday, pleading with his supporters to summon up the enthusiasm they poured into his election last November and deliver a victory for Gov. Jon S. Corzine.

title: Grand Visions for a Faded Bronx Boulevard
description: Decaying freeways, high-speed trains, levees, bicycle lanes  ever since Hurricane Katrina, infrastructure has been the hot topic among architects and architectural curators across the country. The chatter only grew louder after the Obama administration unveiled its economic stimulus package, igniting hopes of a major national transformation. Intersections: The Grand Concourse Beyond 100, which opened at the Bronx Museum of the Arts on Sunday, is the latest show to pick up on this trend.

title: Up for Auction
description: In a chastened auction season, buyers will find traditional works intended to appeal to todays more conservative tastes, with prices topping out at $12 million.

title: Out of Race, Karzai Rival Is Harsh Critic of Election
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans last presidential challenger, Abdullah Abdullah, dropped out of the race on Sunday, accusing the government of profound corruption and electoral fraud even as the Obama administration rallied around President Hamid Karzai.

title: An Application to Help Scrub Those Regrettable Photos From Facebook
description: You there, you who dressed as a sexy panther this Halloween, and are now clicking through the weekends photos on Facebook. Whats a hungover cat to do?

title: Columnist Quits After Newsday Starts Charging for Its Web Site
description: There arent many journalists walking away from paying jobs these days. With news organizations struggling and newsroom jobs disappearing, each week brings new calls from writers and editors who believe their flagging employers should save themselves by charging for Internet access.

title: Opposition in Iran Urges Continuing Challenge
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As Iran prepares for a major commemorative rally on Wednesday, the leaders of the opposition movement called over the weekend for a renewed challenge to the government, setting the stage for a possible showdown between protesters and the police.

description: Seymour Fromer, who with his wife, Rebecca, opened a museum in California that eventually came to hold one of the largest collections of Judaica in North America, including archives documenting the history of Jews in the American West, died Oct. 25 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 87.

description: COPN, Honduras  On the morning that the Honduran president was deposed, Flavia Cueva roused a wedding party of 30 and whisked them out of her jungle eco-resort. Still hazy from the previous nights party, which involved a mariachi band, fireworks and a shaman-led wedding ceremony held above ancient Mayan limestone ruins, the partyers made a hasty exit.

title: Many in U.S. Want Texting at the Wheel to Be Illegal
description: Nearly all Americans say sending a text message while driving should be illegal, and about half say texting while behind the wheel should be punished at least as harshly as drunken driving, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Philadelphians Reap Rewards from New Yorks Trash
description: MORRISVILLE, Pa.  There has been plenty of trash-talking this past week by fans of the Yankees and Phillies. But for years, New Yorkers have been quietly doing more than talking trash about Philadelphians: Theyve been sending it, about 2,500 tons daily, to mega-landfills in Philadelphias northern suburbs.

title: Mother of Canadian Singer Killed by Coyotes Asks That the Animals Be Spared
description: Even in a country with a lot of wilderness, it was a shocking death. Taylor Josephine Stephanie Luciow, a promising 19-year-old folk singer from Toronto who performed under the name Taylor Mitchell, was attacked by two coyotes as she set out for a hike in Cape Breton Highlands National Park, one of Eastern Canadas leading tourist destinations. She died late Tuesday night in Halifax, where she had been airlifted for treatment.

title: Creditors Back CITs Bankruptcy
description: As the CIT Group sought desperately to avoid bankruptcy this summer, it argued that being forced into Chapter 11 protection would spell disaster for its customers: a wide swath of the nations small and midsize businesses who rely on the 101-year-old company for financing.

title: Oregon and Coach Are Over Opener
description: As the sun rose in Eugene on Saturday, a man wearing the head of the University of Oregons duck mascot traversed the lines of fans gathered for ESPNs College GameDay broadcast.

title: With Karzai, U.S. Faces Weak Partner in Time of War
description: WASHINGTON  With the White Houses reluctant embrace on Sunday of Hamid Karzai as the winner of Afghanistans suddenly moot presidential runoff, President Obama now faces a new complication: enabling a badly tarnished partner to regain enough legitimacy to help the United States find the way out of an eight-year-old war.

title: Energy Producer Reaches Buyout Deal
description: Denbury Resources, an oil and natural gas producer based in Plano, Tex., said it would buy Encore Acquisition for about $4.5 billion, including the assumption of debt.

title: In Playoffs, Tell-All Scouting Book Helps Guide Yankees
description: PHILADELPHIA  Joe Girardi has a bulky blue binder that he carries into the dugout for every game that he manages with the Yankees. It is filled with more than 200 pages of scouting reports, statistics and his observations.

title: Not New, but Improved
description: Meet Stella.

title: When Texting Kills, Britain Offers Path to Prison
description: OXFORD, England  Inside the imposing British Crown Court here, Phillipa Curtis, 22, and her parents cried as she was remanded for 21 months to a high-security womens prison, for killing someone much like herself. The victim was Victoria McBryde, an up-and-coming university-trained fashion designer.

title: Pollsters Report Latest Figures as Election Day Approaches
description: It may be an off year for elections, but there are still a lot of races on Tuesday. The big contests are the governors elections in New Jersey and Virginia, but there will be voting for mayors in several big cities, some states have referendums or ballot initiatives and there are a couple of vacant Congressional seats to be filled.

title: With Some Coaching, Bloomberg Learns to Bite His Tongue
description: For years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called City Councilwoman Letitia James Trish, even though she is known as Tish and corrected him again and again. When the mayor spoke to her, his body language spoke volumes, she said: He would look up, down, around, anywhere but at her face.

title: Inspiration for a New Crop of U.S. Runners
description: When Alberto Salazar crossed the finish line to win his third straight New York City Marathon 27 years ago, he did not think about who was coming behind him.

title: On Assignment: New York City Marathon
description: Most years Fred R. Conrad is assigned to photograph the New York City Marathon and he has covered it from various vantage points along the 26.2-mile race that winds through all five boroughs. In the past, he focused the lens of his 4x5 camera on the Achilles Track Club Freedom Team, taking black and white portraits of this group of disabled war veterans. Last year, the marathon fell just two days before the election, and he shot runners emblazoned with political flair and slogans.

title: Between Football and Baseball Stadiums in Philadelphia, a Mingling Most Rare
description: PHILADELPHIA  For a few hours Sunday, the center of the noisy sporting rivalry between New York and Philadelphia was a pair of neighboring stadiums and the parking lots that adjoin them.

title: Off-Year Races May Provide Insight
description: WASHINGTON  One year after the election of President Obama, a handful of off-year political contests  including governors races in New Jersey and Virginia and a Congressional race in upstate New York  offer some clues about how Americans are viewing Mr. Obama, as well as an early measure of the landscape for next years midterm elections.

title: For Mayoral Candidates, One Final Push to Rally Voters
description: As their aides fretted over the prospect of low turnout at the polls, the candidates for New York City mayor delivered last-minute appeals to voters on Sunday, with Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. urging New Yorkers to reject an incumbent who thinks hes above democracy, and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg asking for a third term to keep making progress.

title: Educational Video Games Mix Cool With Purpose
description: One of KC Phillipss favorite video games is the Xbox shoot-em-up Halo, because, he says, his dad taught him how to play it when he was younger.

title: Turner Entertainment Sees the Broadcast Networks as Its Fattest Target
description: If there is a fault line between the big but shrinking broadcast networks and the small but growing cable networks, it would run right through Steve Koonins office in Atlanta.

title: Children Watch More TV Than Ever
description: If there is a practical limit to the amount of television a child can watch, we have not yet discovered it. Nielsen reported last week that children ages 2 to 5 spent nearly 25 hours a week watching television, the highest figure on record. They spent an additional seven weekly hours watching DVDs, playing video games, and watching TiVo-style time-shifted television.

title: With Payroll Tax, Feeling the Effects of an M.T.A. Bailout Plan
description: For subway and bus riders in New York, a $1.9 billion bailout in May from Albany meant that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority did not have to drastically cut service and raise fares.

title: Neil Simon Flop May Be a Case of the Missing Wow
description: Neil Simon was the crossover comedy king of Broadway and Hollywood for three decades, beginning when Barefoot in the Park and three other major shows overlapped in New York in the 1960s.

title: Once a Young Turk, Now Challenged by One
description: Albert Vann built his legend in Brooklyn from the ground up, first as an outspoken community leader during a fight with the teachers union in Ocean Hill and Brownsville in the late 1960s. By the early 1980s, he had transformed from a rebel assemblyman into a political power broker and a leader among black politicians who labored outside traditional Democratic politics.

title: Sisterly Bonds, Tight Enough to Strangle
description: By their nature people are talkers, says Breda, one of three sisters presiding over a mad, mostly tea-less tea party in The New Electric Ballroom, a comedy written and directed by the singular Irish playwright Enda Walsh that opened on Sunday night at St. Anns Warehouse. You cant deny that, she continues in an agonized, breathless mumble. You can, but youd be affirming what youre arguing against, and what would the point of that be? No point.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Thursday, about the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, misstated the rank of the top American commander in Afghanistan, Stanley McChrystal. He is a general, not a lieutenant general.

title: How the Kenyans Take On New York
description: Everything was upside down. The favored Kenyan and the preferred American were both out of contention. And now an afterthought, a last-second replacement, was at the front of the New York City Marathon.

description: The 35-page, eight-count indictment filed by federal prosecutors names a lone defendant: Joseph L. Bruno, the former president of the State Senate and former Republican majority leader.

title: On the Ballot: Parkland and Inmate Volunteerism
description: New York voters will be asked to consider two amendments to the State Constitution on Tuesday: One would approve a power line being built in the Adirondack Park; the other would allow prisoners of state correctional facilities to perform volunteer work for nonprofit groups.

title: For Galleon Executive, Swagger in the Spotlight
description: For Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire hedge fund manager charged with trading on inside information, legal problems are nothing new.

title: Soft Real Estate Market Is a Key Ingredient at Brooklyn Brewery
description: Less than two years ago, the Brooklyn Brewery found itself in a bind that had squeezed many companies out of New York. It wanted to expand, but the rapid gentrification of its neighborhood, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, had pushed rents beyond what it could afford.

title: If Fox Is Partisan, It Is Not Alone
description: The Obama White Houses decision to challenge Fox News appears driven equally by strategy and frustration. It is also a test case for politicians in both parties.

title: Comcast Said to Be Close to Gaining NBC Universal
description: General Electric and the cable giant Comcast have moved closer to a deal giving control of NBC Universal to Comcast, and a formal announcement could be made sometime next week, people briefed on the talks said Sunday.

title: At Marathon Fluids Station, Days of Planning Precede Minutes of Chaos
description: At seven places along the New York City Marathon course, just past someone holding a large sign reading Professional Athlete Fluids, a Sunday mornings calm was briefly interrupted by chaos.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the New Orleans mayors race misstated the name of a radio program co-hosted by John Slade, who said he did not plan to vote for any candidate who is a businessman. It is Showtime in the Afternoon  not Talking Black and Talking Back, which is a slogan for the radio station.

title: U.S.S. New York Crew Recalls Its Own 9/11 Ties
description: ABOARD U.S.S. NEW YORK, off New York  Most were middle school students, but some were construction workers, police officers or members of the military when two planes slammed into the World Trade Center eight years ago.

title: Too Little of a Good Thing
description: The good news is that the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, a k a the Obama stimulus plan, is working just about the way textbook macroeconomics said it would. But thats also the bad news  because the same textbook analysis says that the stimulus was far too small given the scale of our economic problems. Unless something changes drastically, were looking at many years of high unemployment.

title: If Fox Is Partisan, It Is Not Alone
description: The Obama White Houses decision to challenge Fox News appears driven equally by strategy and frustration. It is also a test case for politicians in both parties.

title: Threes Company
description: Most American elections arent particularly competitive. So an off-year election cycle with only a few important offices at stake doesnt have any business being interesting.

title: Recorded Calls to Voters From Brooklyn Bishop Praise a Democratic Leader
description: In an unusually overt step into politics by a religious leader, the Roman Catholic bishop of Brooklyn is urging voters, via robocalls, to support Vito J. Lopez, an assemblyman and the Brooklyn Democratic boss, whose hand-picked candidate is in a tough race for a City Council seat.

title: Lottery Numbers
Six Tests for Equality and Fairness
description: Political battles this fall in six different parts of the country could have a profound impact on whether the United States will extend the promise of equal rights to those who are not allowed to marry simply because they are the same sex as their partner.

title: The Court and Your Savings
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments Monday in a case about mutual funds and high management fees. Mutual funds are the main vehicle Americans use to save for retirement, and excessive mutual fund fees are another way an underregulated financial industry has been enriching itself at the expense of the general public.

title: Cape Wind
description: After eight years of arduous state and federal environmental reviews, the promoters of Cape Wind, a wind energy project off the Massachusetts coast, had every reason to believe that they were home free. Then the Wampanoag tribes asked the Interior Department to declare all of Nantucket Sound, where the 130 wind turbines would be built, a traditional cultural property and, they hoped, block construction.

title: Memphis
description: If I had to name the best short story in the form of a song lyric, I suspect the winner would be Chuck Berrys Memphis, Tennessee, first released as a B-side in 1959. Lately, it has been haunting me  the metrical precision of the lyrics, its emotional realism and, of course, the revelation in the penultimate line. You know the one: that this is a fathers mournful love song to his daughter, Marie, who is only 6 years old.

title: Fiscal Blood on the Tracks
description: LIKE a tsunami that follows an undersea earthquake, collateral damage from the collapse of credit markets is about to strike the millions of daily transit riders in Americas biggest cities. Public transit agencies in cities including New York, Atlanta, San Francisco and Washington are under pressure to surrender $2 billion from their budgets because financial institutions have spotted a chance to gain a windfall from complicated tax-shelter deals known as leasebacks.

title: Yankees Seem Determined Not to Use Fourth Starting Pitcher
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Yankees seem very likely to finish the World Series having used only three starting pitchers, especially after Manager Joe Girardi announced Sunday that A. J. Burnett would start Game 5 on short rest.

title: Corrections

Bradley Kaplan, who was listed as a director of the documentary and as an executive producer of it for Maysles Films, is also a producer for Maysles Films.

title: North Korea Presses U.S. to Agree to Bilateral Talks
description: SEOUL  North Korea has again pressed the United States for a decision about starting bilateral talks, with a diplomat warning Monday that the North was ready to go our own way with its nuclear weapons program.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about nonprofit green organizations spinning off for-profit enterprises referred incorrectly to the status of one organization. As the article noted elsewhere, SmartRoofs is a for-profit enterprise developed by a nonprofit group; it is not a nonprofit itself.

title: 23 Private College Presidents Made More Than $1 Million
description: The presidents of the nations major private research universities were paid a median compensation of $627,750 in the 2007-8 fiscal year  a 5.5 percent increase from the previous year  according to The Chronicle of Higher Education annual executive compensation survey.

title: Yankees Pull Away in the Ninth and in Series
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Yankees were so different nine years ago, when they won their last World Series, so different and yet somehow the same. They revolve now around a constellation of imported superstars with extravagant contracts, primarily Alex Rodriguez. But their grinding ethos is unchanged.

title: Ciscos Run of Spending
description: Cisco, the computer networking giant, has spent the last decade acquiring rivals and buying back stock. Its time to acknowledge that this strategy isnt working. Investors who bought Ciscos shares a decade ago have received no return on their investment.

title: What We Learned, Week 8: A Day for the Have-Nots
description: It is a good thing for the N.F.L. that parity died the year before the salary cap does, or everyone would blame the absence of the cap for the parody of parity. Three undefeated teams entered the weekend, along with 11 teams that had two or fewer victories. But near the midpoint of the season, the N.F.L. took a few tentative steps toward reverting to form. title: Don Ivan Punchatz, Fantasy Illustrator, Dies at 73
description: Don Ivan Punchatz, whose surreal art was splashed on popular horror and science-fiction paperbacks, magazines and the first Star Wars film poster, influencing a generation of illustrators, died on Oct. 22 near his home in Arlington, Tex. He was 73.

title: The Mighty Mariano
description: Mariano Rivera said the Yankees do not have a "one-man show" in their bullpen. While that is true, the Yankees do have a one-man show in postseason save situations. In those spots, Rivera's show is as overpowering as any in baseball.

title: Michael Goldsmith, Who Raised Awareness of A.L.S., Dies at 58
description: Michael Goldsmith, who battled amyotrophic lateral sclerosis  Lou Gehrigs disease  and was honored in Yankee Stadium on July 4 on the 70th anniversary of Gehrigs classic farewell speech, died Sunday. He was 58.

title: Week 8: Eagles Overwhelm Giants
description: The Giants fell behind early at Philadelphia and never recovered, losing by 40-17. It was their third defeat in a row after a 5-0 start.

title: Week 8: Dolphins Beat Jets, Again
description: The Dolphins' Ted Ginn Jr. had two long kickoff returns for touchdowns in a 30-25 victory, spoiling a strong defensive effort by the Jets.

title: Dance Award Winners
description: The winners of the 52nd Dance Magazine Awards have been announced. Allegra Kent, former New York City Ballet principal; Ohad Naharin, artistic director of Batsheva Dance; Sara Rudner, director of dance at Sarah Lawrence College; and Jason Samuels Smith, a tap dancer and choreographer, will be honored at a ceremony on Nov. 9 at Florence Gould Hall in Manhattan, an event that is open to the public and will include performances by dancers from New York City Ballet and Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet and the tapper Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards, among others.

title: Mad Max and thor Round Out Principals
description: Charlize Theron, below, will join the British actor Tom Hardy in the fourth installment of the Mad Max post-apocalyptic franchise, according to Variety. Filming is scheduled to begin in August in Australia, but whether Mel Gibson, who played the title character in the first three films, will return or if Mr. Hardy will take over as Max is unclear. And the films producer-director, George Miller, who is also serving as screenwriter, is keeping details of the script close to the leather vest. ... Anthony Hopkins has been cast in Kenneth Branaghs Thor, the film adaptation of the Marvel comic book, Variety reported. Marvel Studios expects to begin production in January, with Mr. Hopkins playing Odin, Thors father; Natalie Portman as Thors beloved, Jane Foster; and Chris Hemsworth in the title role.

title: Grants Made to Benefit Young Dancers
description: American Ballet Theater has received a $500,000 matching grant from the Arison Arts Foundation, the ballet company has announced. The grant will help cover a fellowship for one dancer each year as part of a new partnership between ABT II and YoungArts, a national organization that supports 17- and 18-year-olds in the visual, literary and performing arts. Since 1996 eight American Ballet Theater dancers have been supported through the YoungArts program, Rachel Moore, the companys executive director and herself a YoungArts scholarship winner, said in a statement. Continued support is crucial to the future of young artists. The grant will also be used to support American Ballet Theaters other preprofessional programs, including the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School and apprentices in the corps de ballet.

title: Footnotes
description: President Obama signed into law on Friday a bill increasing the budgets of the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities by $12.5 million each. The increase, passed in the House and Senate on Thursday, set the budgets for each agency at $167.5 million. ... The 59E59 Theaters will feature the playwright Alan Ayckbourn in a discussion Nov. 15 about his career and the intricacies of his writing. Details and tickets are at 59e59.org.

title: In the Wings
description: Irish Repertory Theater has announced a one-week extension of The Emperor Jones, the Eugene ONeill drama starring John Douglas Thompson, below, in the title role and directed by Ciaran OReilly. Performances at the West 22nd Street theater in Chelsea are now through Dec. 6. ... Lee Blessing, A. R. Gurney, Tina Howe  and Marsha Norman will participate in the Cherry Lane Theaters master-class series on artists, their processes and their inspirations. The classes begin on Monday with the actress Tyne Daly. Information: cherrylanetheatre.org. ... Lincoln Centers LCT3 initiative, devoted to producing the work of new artists and developing new audiences, has filled out its 2009-10 season with the New York premiere of Graceland, by Ellen Fairey and directed by Henry Wishcamper (May 3 to 29) and the premiere of On the Levee, a musical play conceived and directed by Lear deBessonet, with a book by Marcus Gardley and music and lyrics by Todd Almond (June 14 to July 10). The works will be presented at the Duke on 42nd Street.

title: An Ill Elton John Delays Concerts
description: Elton John, 62, has postponed more concert dates because of E. coli and influenza, Agence France-Presse reported. After canceling the final dates of his Red Piano world tour in Britain and Ireland, Mr. John delayed concerts with Billy Joel scheduled this week in Seattle and Portland, Ore., as well. The two performers had already postponed concert dates on the American leg of their tour when Mr. Joel, 60, was ordered to rest after reporting flulike symptoms and fatigue. Mr. John is reportedly recovering in a London hospital, with no word on when he might return to work.

title: 19th-Century Letters, 21st-Century Price
description: Sothebys of London has sold a collection of racy letters written by Lord Byron, below, for $455,466, more than $150,000 above the estimate and a record price for letters by a British Romantic poet. According to BBC News, an anonymous bidder bought the 71 pages of letters and fragments, dating from 1808, which include details of an affair with a servant girl and a disparaging reference to William Wordsworth. The documents came from the library of Archibald Primrose, prime minister from 1894 to 1895. Gabriel Heaton, a Sothebys specialist in British literature and history, told the BBC that the letters, to Byrons close friend the Rev. Francis Hodgson, offered a wonderful opportunity to reveal aspects of Lord Byrons character that were either unknown or long forgotten.

title: Lupus Drug Shows Promise in New Trial
description: The debilitating disease called lupus has been a graveyard for pharmaceutical companies in recent years. One drug after another has had setbacks or outright failures in clinical trials.

title: At Mile 19, a Runner From Texas Is Resuscitated by Firefighters
description: A 51-year-old runner from Texas who collapsed and stopped breathing near Mile 19 of the New York City Marathon on Sunday was resuscitated on the street by a group of firefighters, the authorities said.

title: U.S. Offers Alphabet Soup of Innovation Prizes

description: Cisco, the computer networking giant, has spent the last decade acquiring rivals and buying back stock. But investors who bought Cisco's shares a decade ago have received no return on their investment, Breakingviews says, and it's time to acknowledge that this strategy isn't working.

title: Quirky Play Leads to Lidges Unraveling
description: PHILADELPHIA  Brad Lidge has been around long enough to enjoy a perfect season and also blow some big save opportunities. But he had never been involved in a play quite like the one that preceded his unraveling in the ninth inning.

title: Quirky Play Leads to Lidge's Unraveling
description: PHILADELPHIA - Brad Lidge has been around long enough to enjoy a perfect season and also blow some big save opportunities. But he had never been involved in a play quite like the one that preceded his unraveling in the ninth inning. So unfamiliar with it, Lidge did not even know what his responsibilities were supposed to be. With the score tied and two outs in the ninth, the Phillies were in a shift to the right side of the infield with Mark Teixeira at the plate batting left-handed, and Johnny Damon on first base after a classic nine-pitch at-bat single. Damon stole second base and third baseman Pedro Feliz had to take the throw from the catcher, leaving third base barren of defenders. (Watch the video of the play here.) So, what should Lidge have done? Cover third base? Back up the plate when the catcher covers third? Stand and watch? Run over too late? "To be honest, that's not something you really go over a lot," Lidge said. "I don't know who's supposed to cover third on that. It's kind of a weird play. No one ends up being there and it kind of ends up being a foot race, and he's faster than I am and he got there before I did." Damon saw the empty bag beckoning and sprinted to it. Lidge reacted off the mound too late, and now he had a runner on third base with two outs. What followed were three Yankees runs and a 7-4 victory that put them on the verge of their 27th World Series championship. "He's a heads-up player, and he was able to take an extra base there, which was obviously pretty big," Lidge said. Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel said catcher Carlos Ruiz should have covered, and shortstop Jimmy Rollins said he was at fault for not reminding Lidge to be wary of the play. Clearly the Phillies were in a defensive formation in which not everyone knew all the contingencies. But Lidge did know one thing. He had gotten two quick outs and looked strong. He still had a chance to get out of the inning after it all happened, and he did not claim to be flustered or distracted by it afterward. Still, the results were disastrous. Lidge hit Teixeira with a fastball that rode inside, and with runners at first and third, Alex Rodriguez drilled a fastball into the left-field corner, scoring Damon to give the Yankees a 5-4 lead. Lidge was asked if he was hesitant to throw sliders to Rodriguez with Damon at third, concerned perhaps that one of them might get away and allow Damon to score on a wild pitch. He said he was not. In fact, breaking balls were impending. "We would have gone to sliders real soon," he said. "I probably should have done it sooner."

title: An Artist Who Makes the Viewer Work
description: LONDON | In July 1961, on Londons South Bank, Gustav Metzger put on a gas mask, rubber gloves and a hard hat and proceeded to spray hydrochloric acid in elaborate patterns all over three large screens of white, black and red nylon. Filmed up close, the quick melting and tearing away of fabric is beautiful, disturbing and captivating. Seen from 10 feet away, it looks like a hazmat worker messing around with tattered, ripped sheets.

title: An Artist Who Makes the Viewer Work
description: LONDON | In July 1961, on London's South Bank, Gustav Metzger put on a gas mask, rubber gloves and a hard hat and proceeded to spray hydrochloric acid in elaborate patterns all over three large screens of white, black and red nylon. Filmed up close, the quick melting and tearing away of fabric is beautiful, disturbing and captivating. Seen from 10 feet away, it looks like a hazmat worker messing around with tattered, ripped sheets.

title: Not So Random After All
description: The random coin toss must be one of society's most frequently used decision-making mechanisms. We use the coin toss to choose which movie to see, to determine team positions in major sporting events, to divvy up household chores, and even name cities. But it may be that the the random coin toss isn't so random. A 2007 study found that a vigorously flipped coin is likely to land on the same side it started on at least 51 percent of the time, possibly more depending on the person doing the flipping. (HT: Chris Blattman)

title: Bay Bridge Is Open
description: At 9:20 a.m., twenty minutes after the bridge opened this morning, I drove across the span from the East Bay. Some drivers flew by, as if their pent-up demand for bridge access was what was fueling their cars, not gasoline. Others, like me, drove tentatively, politely, not wanting to jinx the long-awaited opening. That's all one needs today-to be the car in the first accident today on the bridge.

But the air of optimism and expectation is not hanging over bloggers. Although as the law currently sits, citizen journalists and bloggers seem eligible for the same protections, some are worried about an amendment from Sen. Charles Schumer that would leave them behind. Writing in Mediashift.org, Rob Arcamona said:

title: 'Merchant of Venice' and 'Winter's Tale' Are Next for Shakespeare in the Park
description: You got Leontes in my Shylock! You got Hermione in my Portia! For its next season of Shakespeare in the Park, the Public Theater plans to attract audiences -- one hopes without perplexing its performers -- by staging two of the Bard's plays in repertory with the same company of actors. On Monday, the Public said that it would mount productions of "The Merchant of Venice" and "The Winter's Tale" that would run from June 9 through Aug. 1. Daniel Sullivan (who recently directed the Public's production of "Twelfth Night") is to direct "The Merchant of Venice," about a moneylender's notorious bargain, and Michael Greif ("Next to Normal," "Grey Gardens," "Rent") will direct "The Winter's Tale," the courtly romantic comedy containing the stage direction "Exit, pursued by a bear." The Public has previously staged repertory Shakespeare productions, including "Henry IV" Parts I and II in 1991, and a condensed version of the "Henry VI" plays and "Richard III," called "The War of the Roses," in 1971. Casting for the company that will perform "The Merchant of Venice" and "The Winter's Tale," including the bear, was not announced.

title: The Day: Waiting for the Swine Flu Vaccine
description: Swine flu vaccine is dribbling into the three towns, slowly and seemingly randomly. Some doctors have it; some don't. Maplewood township has it, and Millburn township doesn't. In South Orange, the township will be vaccinating adults, then older children, at clinics scheduled for next Monday and Tuesday. Maplewood ran a clinic yesterday. Hundreds of parents in Millburn waited hours on Saturday to get their children vaccinated at the office of Dr. Donald N. Cotler, a pediatrician. Here is Susan Feinstein's report from the vaccination line.

title: Top French Literary Prize Is Awarded
description: The novelist and playwright Marie NDiaye became the first woman in a decade and the first black woman ever to win the Prix Goncourt, the annual literary prize, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. NDiaye, who is of French and Senegalese descent, was awarded the prize on Monday for her book "Trois Femmes Puissantes" ("Three Powerful Women"), a three-part novel about various characters who struggle with transitions between Europe and Africa. In an interview with Agence France-Presse, Ms. NDiaye, who is 42, said that she did not see any symbolism in her victory. "I have never thought of it in those terms: 'black woman' and 'Goncourt'. I find it impossible to see things that way," she said. The author, who was raised by her mother in Pithiviers, a town south of Paris, and did not travel to Africa until she was in her 20s, added: "I grew up in a world that was 100-percent French. My African roots don't mean much, except that people know of them because of the color of my skin and my name." The prize comes with a ceremonial award of about $15.

title: Dancing, and Running, in the Streets
description: Andy Perez flew from Seattle to Brooklyn to scramble eggs. Mr. Perez, 52, an executive at a technology startup, has been in charge of cracking shells and whipping yolks at the same New York City Marathon cheering party in Fort Greene for more than two decades. He moved from Brooklyn to Seattle 15 years ago and hasn't missed a marathon party yet.

title: Guerrilla Marketing | A Hostage Store in Stockholm
description: Throughout her career, the Swedish designer Ann Sofie Back has embraced bad taste. Her ripped, stitched, tattered and generally askew aesthetic has been inspired by everything from Wildensteinesque plastic surgery to Lindsay Lohan's lack of underwear. As a result, the designer is no stranger to "worst dressed" lists. "My stuff has ended up on the Fashion Police site a few times," says Back, who recently moved back to Stockholm after 12 years in London. To pay for her style transgressions - and to boost her hometown profile - Back has introduced a new take on the guerrilla store concept: a hostage store.

title: Monday Puzzle: The Case of the Mixed-Up Princes(s)
description: Mate selection. Perhaps the most difficult choice that we have to make in our lives: one that affects our future happiness more than any other. What young person has not had fantasies of finding his or her perfect life-partner? How does that translate into making a perfect or even good choice amongst the real potential mates available to you? Wouldn't it be nice to have a technique, a magic bullet, that guaranteed you the highest probability of making your best choice?

title: Analysis: Lidge and Chamberlain, Pitch by Pitch

Four batters later, it was Brad Lidge who needed one more strike to keep the score tied with his team coming up.

title: Banksy Mural About Graffiti Is Tagged With, Yes, Graffiti
description: By the time a local council in south London completed its vote on the preservation of a mural by the street artist Banksy, the majority decision to keep the artwork was a moot point: vandals had already covered the mural in graffiti. BBC News reported that 93 percent of the 250 local residents who participated in the vote, which ended on Saturday, said that the Sutton Council should keep the work: a painting of a punk with spiky hair trying to assemble a slogan from the contents of an Ikea-style box, which appeared on a wall earlier this fall. Though the council generally has a zero-tolerance policy on graffiti, Councilor Colin Hall told the BBC: We believe in democracy and wanted local people to decide what should happen to the Banksy. Sadly someone decided to take it into their own hands. He added: The image actually criticized mindless graffiti so perhaps it isnt surprising that the sort of people who do that sort of thing should attack it.

description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which youll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals on a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: E.P.A. Lawyers Challenge Cap and Trade for Climate
description: When an economist at the Environmental Protection Agency rejected the Obama administrations stance on global warming by writing an unsolicited report challenging the scientific consensus on greenhouse dangers, groups fighting restrictions on greenhouse gases hailed him as a courageous maverick. Climate campaigners said he was irrelevant and ill informed.

title: CBS Finds Some Super Bowl Sales Success
description: Not so long ago, it seemed that CBS was getting the fuzzy end of the lollipop when the networks turn came up in the rotation to broadcast the Super Bowl. The recession affected advertisers interest in this years game, and there were indications that Super Bowl XLIV, to be played on Feb. 7, 2010, could be even harder hit.

title: Hardy Canadians Give Torch a Ride
description: The Olympic torch has been in Canada only since Friday and already it has traveled by skateboard, canoe, wheelchair, float plane and mountain bike. And on Sunday, it got on a surfboard. The air temperatures were in the 40s, meaning the water was bone-chilling.

NEW YORK, off New York  Petty Officer Second Class Nathaniel Mitchell was working to navigate the narrow passageways when he first stepped on board this ship, the extra bulk of his bags making the task all the more onerous. As he squeezed through one of the heavy metal hatches that segment the ship, he was surprised by a voice he had not heard in years.

title: Lies, Damn Lies, Statistics and Soccernomics
description: In their new book Soccernomics, to be published in the United States on Tuesday, the author Simon Kuper and the economist Stefan Szymanski do for soccer what Moneyball did for baseball. It puts the game under an analytical microscrope using statistics, economics, psychology and intuition to try and transform a dogmatic sport.

title: The Cost of College: Graphing Tuition Prices and Other Expenses
description: Overview | How do the costs of two-year, four-year, public and private colleges vary and compare? What factors have fueled the community college enrollment boom? In this lesson, students analyze the rise in tuition costs and consider the implication of the economy on the costs of college. They compare and investigate college education costs and create graphs to represent the data, then research and graph their own anticipated college costs.

title: Hospitals Cite Worry on Fees in Health Bill

description: Patients with heart disease are at greater risk of dying if they are depressed. And both depression and heart disease are characterized, among other things, by low levels of omega-3 fatty acids.

title: How Posted Calories Affect Food Orders
description: Just a few weeks ago, independent researchers reported that New York Citys ground-breaking calorie labeling law had had absolutely no effect on the caloric content of meals bought at chain restaurants in poor neighborhoods. Last week, city health officials delivered a more upbeat assessment, saying New Yorkers ordered fewer calories at four chains  Au Bon Pain, KFC, McDonalds and Starbucks  after the law went into effect last year.

title: Coping With, and Without, Health Insurance
description: Even as the Senate and the House move toward completion of their respective health care bills, many Americans continue to struggle with an insurance system they often find baffling and frustrating. In the latest installment of Patient Voices by the multimedia producer Karen Barrow, six men and women talk about the difficult choices they must make in seeking and paying for health care. Listen to Patient Voices and share your thoughts in the comments section.

title: S.F. Bike Plan: The Wait Continues
description: In recent years, there has been an explosion in the number of bicycle lanes in cities large and small throughout the Bay Area.

title: Chickpeas: The Mediterraneans Most Versatile Legume
description: Of all the many types of beans that I work with, chickpeas (also called garbanzos), the key ingredient in hummus, are the most versatile. They are good cold or hot, at home in a stew, soup or casserole, or without adornment in a salad or pasta. This legume has been cultivated in the Mediterranean for thousands of years, and I dont know of a country in that region where chickpeas dont figure in the cuisine.

title: Searching for Themes in the M.&A. Market
description: Despite some recent activity, the figures for mergers and acquisitions in October are not particularly good. According to Dealogic, M.&A. activity in the United States was down 46 percent from September to October. These figures show not only a continued M.&A. slumber, but a deal market with few building blocks for any upward trends to build upon.

title: What Makes Germans Laugh? Not 30 Rock
description: In the United States, 30 Rock is regarded as a rapid-fire comedy whose ratings havent yet caught up with its awards and critical accolades. In Germany, its just another show that nobody watches. On Sunday night, the debut showing of 30 Rock on the German channel ZDFNeo earned a 0.0 rating, The Hollywood Reporter said, meaning it was watched by fewer than 5,000 people. The channel, which is owned by the German broadcaster ZDF, was recently given a makeover in an attempt to attract more young male viewers, and its showings of 30 Rock (along with series like Miami Vice and The Sentinel) were central to that mission. It was unclear if viewers there would be more or less receptive to a 30 Rock episode in which Liz Lemon accidentally sells NBC to a group of German investors.

title: In Utrecht, a Cartoon Rabbit and a Film Festival
description: UTRECHT | One of the great exports of Utrecht, a historic city well worth a day trip from Amsterdam, is a cartoon character: the Dick Bruna-drawn Nijntje the Rabbit. Shes known as Miffy in English, and in Utrecht a statue stands in a square named after her, the Nijntjepleintje.

Ovechkin becomes the first hockey player IMG will represent since the company dropped its hockey department in 2006 as part of a general shift out of representation in team sports.

title: Biden Stumps in Contested Upstate Race
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y.  Vice President Joseph R. Biden rolled through this rural military town on Monday, becoming the latest political heavyweight to weigh in on the bitter contest here for an open Congressional seat that has deepened divisions in the Republican Party.

description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden ventured into upstate New Yorks raucous 23rd Congressional District on Monday, in a campaign stop for Bill Owens, the Democratic candidate whose campaign has been utterly overshadowed by a divisive feud on the Republican/conservative sides of the ticket.

description: Some people swim with dolphins. I swim with dogs.

title: 23 Private College Presidents Made More Than $1 Million
description: My colleague Tamar Lewin writes in todays Times that the presidents of the nations major private research universities were paid a median compensation of $627,750 in the 2007-8 fiscal year  a 5.5 percent increase from the previous year.

title: Winners and Losers of Cap-and-Trade
description: A new study from PointCarbon, a carbon market research firm, indicates that ExxonMobil would face an annual outlay of $5.9 billion to purchase carbon allowances under the terms of the Kerry-Boxer cap-and-trade bill, while electricity giants like Exelon and Pacific Gas and Electric would emerge as financial winners, because they rely heavily on diversified, low-emission fleets that include nuclear reactors and hydro dams.

title: Christopher Wheeldon: The Future of Dance
description: To the Editor:

title: Life as a Depressed Parent
description: Over at the Momversation this week, Heather Armstrong of Dooce.com is leading a candid talk about depression. She has been extremely open over the years about the postpartum emotional crash that led her to a psychiatric hospital. Her fellow bloggers on the video  Alice Bradley, of finslippy.com, Mindy Roberts of themommyblog.net and Danny Evans of DadGoneMad.com  have been somewhat less public about their suffering, and their conversation about what Bradley calls being filled with crushing despair is a moving one.

title: New Conductors: A Measure for a Maestro
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Road Grime Can Be a Beautiful Thing
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The Posies Driven Dirty Tour is a hot rod and custom car show in motion, traveling each year from the Posies Rods and Customs shop in Hummelstown, Pa., to the Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) automotive trade show (Tuesday through Friday) in Las Vegas.

title: Readers Deal With Robocalls in Sundry Ways
description: Howard Schneiders Complaint Box on the technoharassment of political robocalls drew sympathetic comments from readers who had strategies about how to avoid the unwanted communication  unlisted numbers, caller ID, and simply not picking up landlines.

title: Favre Harnesses Emotions in Return to Lambeau
description: In the days leading to Favreageddon, Troy Aikman, the Hall of Fame quarterback who analyzed the Vikings-Packers game for Fox television, predicted that Favre would be highly emotional in his return to Lambeau Field, but would feel right at home once play began.

title: Belbin and Agosto Return to Top Form; Lysacek Finishes Second
description: Things appear to be back on track for 2006 Olympic ice dancing silver medalists Tanith Belbin and Ben Agosto of the United States.

title: Art Buyers Bullish on Lehman Brothers Collection
description: A fire sale of artwork that once belonged to Lehman Brothers, the investment services company whose bankruptcy in September 2008 augured months of worldwide economic turmoil, raised $1.35 million at an auction Sunday, which is, at least, a start toward the billions in debt that the company left behind. In a news release, the auction house Freemans, which conducted the sale in Philadelphia, said that all of the 280 lots offered, consisting of works from Lehman Brothers offices in New York, Massachusetts and Delaware, were sold. Among the top sellers were a Roy Lichtenstein I Love Liberty print, which sold for $49,000; a set of 10 prints by Louis Lozowick that sold for $94,000; and a Georges Schreiber painting of the Financial District, which once hung in the companys New York boardroom, for $20,000. (All sales figures include a 25 percent buyers premium on the first $20,000 hammer price and an additional 20 percent on the balance.) Freemans plans future sales of Lehman Brothers artworks on Dec. 6 and Feb. 12.

title: Adaptec Chief Is Likely to Be Ousted From Board
description: After a long-running proxy battle, the activist shareholder Warren Lichtenstein said Monday that his hedge fund, Steel Partners II, had amassed enough support to remove Adaptecs chief executive, Sundi Sundaresh, from the board of the data storage company.

title: Laugh It Up
description: Catch up with the latest in downtown comedy-nerdery tonight, when WitStream, a funny-people-Twitter-aggregate, sponsors a show at Comix. (Yes, Twitter-aggregating is one part of what it takes to make it in comedy these days.) The lineup includes Michael Ian Black, Michael Showalter, Morgan Murphy (a writer for Jimmy Fallon), Pete Holmes and more. If youre truly humor-besotted, check out Leo Allens show Whiplash at the UCB afterward; its where all the local talent and executives who love them go.

title: News of the Weird
description: Pimps, prostitutes, crackheads, criminals and weirdos  thats what tonights readings have in common. At Bluestockings, Eric Ferrara, a fourth-generation New Yorker, shares his  Guide to Gangsters, Murderers and Weirdos of New Yorks Lower East Side,  about the origins of mafiosos like Bugsy Siegel. And at the Barnes & Noble in Union Square, Augusten Burroughs offers his tales of perverse holiday woe in  You Better Not Cry: Stories for Christmas.  Thanksgivings right around the corner, after all.

title: Day of the Dead
description: To celebrate Da de los Muertos  the Mexican Day of the Dead (today is All Souls Day)  head to St. Marks Church-in-the-Bowery for music and other performances. Or to Mayahuel, the dark, sexy tequila bar, for a special menu of all-you-can-drink cocktails and small plates for $50. Bring a date.

title: Mount Holyoke College Names New President
description: Lynn Pasquerella, the provost of the University of Hartford, will become the 18th president of Mount Holyoke College this summer, succeeding Joanne Creighton, who has held the post since 1996.

title: 10 New Ticket Machines Open at Grand Central
description: Its a scene stolen from the nightmares of New York commuters: Thanksgiving Day, the evening rush, and youre trying to catch a train for dinner in the suburbs. You make it to Grand Central Terminal with 10 minutes to spare (phew!)  but no ticket.

title: Why Falling Back Is Better Than Springing Forward
description: Yesterday we gained an hour, thanks to the end of daylight saving time. I love this transition out of daylight saving time during the fall, but I hate the transition into daylight saving time during the spring, when we lose an hour. And new research shows there is good reason for this preference: people are much less likely to get hurt at work when they fall backward than when they spring forward.

title: Court Declines Case of Klansmen in 64 Slayings
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday said it would not review a case arising from the 1964 kidnapping and killing of two black teenagers along the Mississippi-Louisiana border, an episode that continues to stir legal debate as it stokes memories of the ugliest racism.

title: What Were Reading
description: In The New Yorker, Jonathan Gold of LA Weekly gets his due with a six-page profile (for subscribers only). Gold drives twenty thousand miles a year in search of food. I go into a fugue state, like the Aboriginal dreamtime, when you go on long aimless walks in the Outback, he says, Thats how I feel on the endless streets of Los Angeles County.

title: Still Zapping Through Commercials? Decoder Wants to Know
description: In todays New York Times, Bill Carter writes:

title: Candidates Religion Is Point of Contention in Queens Race
description: Dan Halloran, the Republican candidate for a City Council seat in northeastern Queens, actively practices Theodism, a neo-pagan faith which attempts to reconstruct the pre-Christian tribal religions of the European Germanic people.

title: No More Sir Allen: Stanford Loses Knighthood
description: The jailed Texas financier R. Allen Stanford is being stripped of his knighthood in the Caribbean nation of Antigua and Barbuda, the head of the government panel that approves the awards said Monday.

title: BlogTalk: Countdown to Election Day
description: With less than 24 hours to go before votes are cast in several races around the country, the blogs are sizzling with chatter about New Yorks 23rd Congressional District election, and about how much it will mean for the Republican and Democratic parties.

title: Performa 09 | Food for Thought
Clinton Denies Easing Pressure on Israel
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco  Struggling to stem protests from the Arab world, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday reiterated that the Obama administration still wanted Israel to freeze construction of Jewish settlements, even if it regarded Israels compromise offer as unprecedented.

title: Giants Early Schedule: Too Easy?
description: N.F.L. coaches and players like to say that all opponents are the same, that a win against the 2009 Raiders is no different than a win against the 1972 Dolphins.

title: On Nova, Theories of How the Apes Became Us
description: Heres some cheery news: that global warming thing everyone is so worried about is actually going to make us all a lot smarter. Unfortunately, its also going to leave us with heads the size of basketballs.

title: Beethoven and Mendelssohns Scribbles for the Ages Enhance Juilliard Trove
description: The Juilliard School has finished the construction of a secure archival storage space for its collection of valuable music manuscripts, and you have to hope that the designers left a little extra room in the shoulders and hips. For at a concert-lecture event celebrating its completion  and with it, the completion of the schools three-year, $200 million renovation and expansion  at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening, Juilliard is to announce the acquisition of two additional manuscripts, and there appear to be more to come.

title: Sorry, Ive Got to Go Save My Brain
description: A FEW months ago, my daughter Zoe came home from college and showed me a little word game she was playing on her iPhone.

title: Let Scientists Write Drug Laws, Says Fired British Expert
description: David Nutt, a professor of pharmacology who was forced to resign on Friday as the head of an independent panel of experts set up to advise the British government on drug policy, accused Prime Minister Gordon Brown of overstating the dangers of cannabis and ecstasy to impress voters and suggested that drug laws should be written by scientists, not politicians.

title: Health Bill Worse Than Terrorist, Republican Says
description: The House is moving toward a health care showdown later in the week, and if comments by Representative Virginia Foxx are any indication, things might get a little rough.

title: Panel Tries to Speed Warrant Process in Drunken-Driving Cases
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said on Monday that he had convened a committee to look at ways to speed the process of getting warrants for blood from individuals who refuse breath tests after they have been arrested on suspicion of driving drunk.

title: Morgan Stanley Thinks Big With Loan for CF Bid
description: Morgan Stanleys agreement to lend $2.5 billion to back  CF Industries Holdings hostile bid for Terra Industries, a rival fertilizer maker, is the biggest leveraged loan commitment by a single bank this year, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Telling Numbers for Brighton Beach Memoirs': Poor Sales Despite Good Buzz
description: Last weeks box-office grosses for Broadway shows have just been released, and they provide another data point regarding the demise of the Brighton Beach Memoirs revival on Sunday.

title: Processed Foods and Depression
description: The BBC is reporting on a study that links processed food and depression. (Hat tip: Kerri Conan.)

title: The Morning Skate: Another Headshot, Gretzkys Money and Plantes TV Special
description: Are the N.H.L.s rules and standards at odds with player safety?

title: Patient Voices: Coping With and Without Insurance
description: Much of the debate about health care reform focuses on people who dont have insurance. But as Karen Barrow explores during the latest Patient Voices series, even people with insurance coverage are struggling with bills, confusing policies and red tape.

title: A Southern Mirrored Window
description: The Help, a novel about the relationships between African-American maids and their white employers in 1960s Mississippi, has the classic elements of a crowd pleaser: it features several feisty women enmeshed in a page-turning plot, clear villains and a bit of a history lesson.

title: Giving Sight by Therapy With Genes
description: By the time Corey Haas was 7, the retinal disease he was born with had already stolen much of his vision. He always clung to me or my wife, said Coreys father, Ethan Haas.

title: As the Thermometer Falls, Man Cave Dcor Is Warming Up
description: COOLER temperatures often drive people indoors, but not everyone is disappointed by the change of seasons.
