Douglas Wright, an architect with Hart Howerton, a firm based in New York and San Francisco, said many of his male clients look forward to hibernating in man caves  cozy, masculine dens where they can pursue interests like spectator sports, woodworking or billiards.

title: Natural Disaster Insurance: Do You Need It?
description: With the news media filled with stories lately about natural disasters like earthquakes, hurricanes and wildfires, many consumers may be wondering when to purchase additional insurance to protect their homes from Mother Nature. My husband and I certainly have been concerned with the topic since moving to California this year.

title: Just the Basics (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS: Panel Warns That Without New Direction, Epidemic Will Remain Out of Control at 50
description: Unless there is a drastic change in approach, the AIDS epidemic will still be out of control on its 50th anniversary in 2031, a panel of AIDS experts predicted in an analysis being published Tuesday in the journal Health Affairs.

title: A Mission to Mars (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Negotiating Table for Next Years Rates
description: Travel management companies are in the midst of negotiating next years hotel and airline rates on behalf of their corporate clients, an annual ritual that was thrown into turmoil last fall when the economy collapsed, dragging down business travel with it.

title: Excerpt: 'V'
description: The ABC science fiction series about alien visitors is based on the 1980s show of the same name.

title: Neighbor Says Police Knew About Rapists House
description: The police in Cleveland were notified repeatedly about violence in the house of a convicted rapist where the decomposed bodies of six women were found last week, a neighbor said Monday.

title: Critics' Picks: 'The Verdict'
description: A. O. Scott reviews Sidney Lumet's film about an alcoholic trial lawyer on a medical malpractice case.

title: Tumors That Vanish (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: They Came From Beyond, Sexy and Media Savvy
description: A crowd gathers to gawk at a huge spaceship that has appeared in the sky over Manhattan. The bottom of the ship turns into a screen ( la Blade Runner) showing the leader of the alien visitors. She announces that they mean us no harm, that they just need some water and a mineral common and abundant on Earth before they shove off.

title: A Life Apart, Without a Home, Friends or Regrets
description: My goal is equanimity, he said. Im not pursuing what the world calls success.

title: An Honest Days Work From Vienna
description: AS a child growing up in Vienna, Carlo Huber would sometimes accompany his father, Rupert E. Huber, to wine bars and heurigen, informal little buffets where Viennese wine estates sold their own produce. When his father had an especially pleasing glass, Mr. Huber recalled, he would exclaim, Das ist ein ehrlicher wein!  That is an honest wine.

title: Russia Tries, Once Again, to Rein in Vodka Habit
description: MYTISHCHI, Russia  It was late on a Monday afternoon at the drunk tank in this Moscow suburb, but it could have been any day, at any hour, at any similar facility across this land. People would come. They always do. Such is Russias ruinous penchant for the bottle  and the challenge facing a new government policy to curb it.

title: The Obama the Campaign Knew
description: One year after Barack Obama was voted into the White House, does the public want to relive the marathon 21-month campaign that began long before the snows of Iowa and New Hampshire and churned on through the seemingly endless calendar of primaries and the general election? After useful campaign books by Richard Wolffe (Renegade: The Making of a President) and Dan Balz and Haynes Johnson (The Battle for America 2008: The Story of an Extraordinary Election), is there anything illuminating left to say about the long, winding road to his historic victory?

title: Stanley Works to Acquire Black & Decker
description: Two leading tool and equipment makers, Stanley Works and Black & Decker, said Monday afternoon that they had agreed to merge in an all-stock transaction that they valued at about $4.5 billion.

title: Shopping With Douglas Wright
description: It runs the gamut, from beautiful mens rooms down to the nitty-gritty of workbenches and tools, Douglas Wright said of the spaces his clients have increasingly been requesting in recent years.

title: U.S. Options and the Karzai Brothers
description: Updated, Nov. 3, 10:20 a.m. | Vanda Felbab-Brown expands on the idea of stronger coercion. Scroll down to read her additional comments.

title: Health Bill Worse Than a Terrorist, N.C. Lawmaker Says
description: Carl Hulse, our chief Congressional correspondent, reported just a short while ago on our sib-blog, Prescriptions, that remarks made on Monday by a North Carolina lawmaker may signal the tenor of a rumble looming when Republicans and Democrats in the House debate the health care overhaul later this week.

title: Performa 09: In the Beginning, an Old Testament Feast
description: With its benefit dinner Friday night, Performa 09, the performance art biennial that gets underway in earnest Monday, definitely established a hard act to follow. Perhaps not for itself, but at least for the event planners of the world. Organized by Jennifer Rubell, the daughter of the collectors Donald and Mera Rubell and an experienced event planner herself, the evening was modestly titled Creation. It melded installation art, happenings and performance art with various Old Testament overtones, while laying waste to the prolonged ordeal that is the benefit-dining experience.

title: Making a Phillies Fan: Patience and Luzinski
description: We invited readers to share their stories of how they became fans of the Yankees or the Phillies, and we will highlight entries as the World Series continues. Below, Lee Barber, 48, of Leesburg, Va., writes that the Phillies 1980 World Series victory over the Kansas City Royals, which she celebrated while attending college in Missouri, was worth the wait.

title: Fathers Gain Respect From Experts (and Mothers)
description: It used to irk Melissa Calapini when her 3-year-old daughter, Haley, hung around her father while he fixed his cars. Ms. Calapini thought there were more enriching things the little girl could be doing with her time.

title: Cant We Retire the Business Card?
description: I have a stash of business cards that Ive collected over the years at networking events, meetings, happy hours, etc. At this point, I could probably build a house out of all of the cards Ive saved. Im not typically a hoarder (well, maybe a little), but I just cant bring myself to throw them out.

title: Bear Stearns Manager Asks Judge for Acquittal
description: Matthew Tannin, one of two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers on trial on charges of securities fraud, has asked the judge to acquit him on all charges, claiming prosecutors have insufficient evidence.

title: And So to the Park: Winters Tale and The Merchant of Venice
description: You got Leontes in my Shylock! You got Hermione in my Portia! For its next season of Shakespeare in the Park, the Public Theater plans to attract audiences  you hope without perplexing its performers  by staging two of the authors plays in repertory with the same company of actors. On Monday the Public said it would mount productions of The Merchant of Venice and The Winters Tale, to run from June 9 through Aug. 1. Daniel Sullivan, top right (who recently directed the Publics production of Twelfth Night), will direct The Merchant of Venice, about a moneylenders notorious bargain, and Michael Greif, right (of the Publics Romeo and Juliet, as well as Broadways Next to Normal), will direct The Winters Tale, the courtly romantic comedy containing the stage direction Exit, pursued by a bear. The Public has previously staged Shakespeare in repertory, including Henry IV Parts 1 and 2 in 1991, and a condensed version of the Henry VI plays and Richard III, called The War of the Roses, in 1971. Casting for the company that will perform The Merchant of Venice and The Winters Tale, including the bear, was not announced.

title: Uh-Oh, Sponsor Change for Family Guy Special
description: Fox will be deleting the computer references and adding a sneak preview of the coming film Sherlock Holmes to next Sundays comedy special starring two of the voices of Family Guy, Seth MacFarlane and Alex Borstein. The network indicated on Saturday that the Warner Brothers Sherlock Holmes movie, scheduled to open on Christmas Day, would replace Microsoft for the special, which is titled Family Guy Presents: Seth & Alexs Almost Live Comedy Show. In lieu of traditional commercial breaks, the special was to incorporate references to the Microsoft Windows 7 operating system into the script. But when Microsoft employees attended a taping of the special last month, they didnt like what they heard  namely, Mr. MacFarlanes sometimes outrageous humor. The company announced that the program was not a fit with the Windows 7 brand, sending Fox scrambling to sign up another sponsor. The special will now include a sneak peek at the film, Fox said.

title: World Series Makes Everyone Desperate
description: Opposite Foxs coverage of Game 4 of the World Series, which dominated the ratings on Sunday, Desperate Housewives helped give ABC a narrow second-place finish for the night. According to Nielsens estimates, Desperate Housewives delivered 13.8 million viewers, far more than CBSs new medical show, Three Rivers (7.7 million), in the same 9 p.m. time slot. The two networks were more evenly matched at 8, as CBSs Amazing Race (11.1 million) outpaced ABCs Extreme Makeover: Home Edition (10.8 million), and at 10 when ABCs Brothers & Sisters (9.4 million) edged ahead of CBSs Cold Case (8.6 million). Final audience figures for the World Series game were not available on Monday, although preliminary estimates show that more than 20 million tuned in. NBC remained well behind in fourth.

title: French Literary Prize Is Awarded
description: The novelist and playwright Marie NDiaye became the first woman in a decade and the first black woman ever to win the Prix Goncourt, the annual literary prize, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. NDiaye, right, who is of French and Senegalese descent, won on Monday for her book Trois Femmes Puissantes (Three Powerful Women), a three-part novel about characters who struggle with transitions between Europe and Africa. In an interview with Agence France-Presse, Ms. NDiaye, 42, said that she did not see any symbolism in her victory. I have never thought of it in those terms: black woman and Goncourt. I find it impossible to see things that way, she said. The author, who was raised by her mother in Pithiviers, south of Paris, and did not travel to Africa until she was in her 20s, added: I grew up in a world that was 100 percent French. My African roots dont mean much, except that people know of them because of the color of my skin and my name. The prize comes with a ceremonial award of about $15.

title: Footnotes
description: The New York Public Library said on Monday that it was acquiring the papers of the author E. Annie Proulx, whose works include The Shipping News and Brokeback Mountain, and that the writer and artist Hilary Knight, who illustrated the Eloise series of childrens books, had donated his papers to the library as well. The announcement was to be made officially at the 2009 Library Lions gala, which was paying tribute on Monday night to Ms. Proulx and Mr. Knight, as well as David Smith, a reference librarian; Julia Chang, its supervising librarian for childrens programs; and Janice Moore-Smith, a career specialist at the library.

title: Lehman Brothers Art Makes Buyers Bullish
description: A fire sale of artwork that once belonged to Lehman Brothers, the investment services company whose bankruptcy in September 2008 augured months of worldwide economic turmoil, raised $1.35 million at an auction on Sunday, which is, at least, a start toward the billions in debt that the company left behind. In a news release the auction house Freemans, which conducted the sale, top right, in Philadelphia, said that all 280 lots offered, consisting of works from Lehman Brothers offices in New York, Massachusetts and Delaware, were sold. Among the top sellers were a Roy Lichtenstein I Love Liberty print, which brought $49,000; a set of 10 prints by Louis Lozowick, which went for $94,000; and a Georges Schreiber painting of Manhattans financial district for $20,000. (All sales figures include a 25 percent buyers premium on the first $20,000 of the hammer price and an additional 20 percent on the balance.) Freemans plans future sales of Lehman Brothers artworks on Dec. 6 and Feb. 12.

title: Street Artist Tagged With, Yes, Graffiti
description: By the time a council in South London completed its vote on the preservation of a mural by the street artist Banksy, the decision to keep the artwork was beside the point: vandals had already covered the mural in graffiti. BBC News reported that 93 percent of the 250 local residents who participated in the vote, which ended on Saturday, said that the Sutton Council should keep the work that appeared on a wall this fall: a painting of a punk with spiky hair trying to assemble a slogan from the contents of a box branded with an Ikea-like name. Though the council generally has a zero-tolerance policy on graffiti, Councilor Colin Hall told the BBC: We believe in democracy and wanted local people to decide what should happen to the Banksy. Sadly someone decided to take it into their own hands. He added: The image actually criticized mindless graffiti, so perhaps it isnt surprising that the sort of people who do that sort of thing should attack it.

title: Travels in Cyberspace: The Monday Report
description: The AMC show Mad Men certainly seems to have an affinity for the travel industry. Last years plotline involved an attempt by the Sterling Cooper agency to win an airlines lucrative business. This year, the famed hotelier, Conrad Hilton, turns up as a key character  one who approaches Don Draper about taking Hilton Hotels on as an account and then slowly insinuates himself into the admans life.

title: One Voting Machine Vendor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Domesticity, Strait-Laced With Dry Wit
description: I always thought that the Keen Companys mission statement  that it produces sincere plays  could be improved to sincerity forever, to borrow a title from a Mac Wellman comedy. But that would be glib and maybe a little insincere, and the thing about the artists at the Keen is that unlike most every other theater, which cooks up a mission statement to sell an image, they actually mean it.

title: Paying More Attention to Fathers
description: When it comes to raising children, most of the focus is on mothers. But a growing body of research shows that fathers play an essential, if often undervalued, role in a childs development, as Laurie Tarkan explores in todays Science Times. She writes:

title: In Iowa, Second Thoughts on Obama
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Iowa  Pauline McAreavy voted for President Obama. From the moment she first saw him two years ago, she was smitten by his speeches and sold on his promise of change. She switched parties to support him in the Iowa caucuses, donated money and opened her home to a pair of young campaign workers.

title: Clinton derangement syndrome
description: Oh, dear. In my previous post I used the example of Clinton-era growth to argue that even growth in the mid-3s wouldnt be enough to bring unemployment down anywhere near quickly enough. And sure enough, many of the comments are along the lines of Clinton doesnt deserve credit for the growth or It was all the tech bubble.

title: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Nov. 2
description: Pictures of the Day opens with a photograph of people identifying victims of a suicide bomber in a commercial district in Pakistan. The explosion killed at least 35 people and apparently targeted military personnel (Slide 1). In the slums of Rio de Janeiro, where a young student died during a shootout between the police and drug dealers last week, children protested (Slide 6) and celebrations in Haiti marked the Day of the Dead in Belladre (Slide 8). In New York, the U.S.S. New York swept under the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Monday morning. Before docking in Midtown, it paused at the World Trade Center site (Slide 10 and Slide 11).

title: U.S. Unlikely to Recoup Auto Investments, Report Says
description: DETROIT  A government report released Monday concludes that taxpayers will probably never recoup all  or even close to all  of the $67 billion that the Treasury Department lent to General Motors and Chrysler in the last year to prevent their collapse.

title: Sending Drugs to Specific Spots in a Tiny Cage
description: For years, biomedical engineers have been trying to develop ways to deliver tiny amounts of a drug to a specific target  anticancer compounds directly to tumors, for example. Much of the work involves microscale capsules or other hollow structures with openings that can be controlled from outside the body.

title: A Scripted Bloomberg Goes Off Script Momentarily
description: For months now, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has managed to be on his best campaign behavior, displaying an unusually agreeable disposition, and avoiding saying something untoward or inappropriate.

title: No saving grace
description: Brad DeLong catches Allan Meltzer claiming that theres something nonsensical about the Obama administration making estimates of jobs saved thanks to its policies. But its not just Meltzer  Greg Mankiw has done the same thing.

title: By Any Other Name, You May Not Fly
description: TWO weeks ago, I suggested here that I would rather get whacked upside the head with a baseball bat than have to visit either my state motor vehicle office or the passport office to make sure that the name on my drivers license and passport was exactly the same on all my travel documents.

title: Sampling Whitman and Art From the Civil War
description: An article on the Arts page in the Westchester section on Sunday about an exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art on Walt Whitman and American Art of the Civil War Era misidentified the institution that loaned two paintings by Sanford Gifford to the museum. "Camp of the Seventh Regiment, near Frederick, Maryland, in July 1863" and "Baltimore, 1862 - Twilight" are on loan from the New York State Military Museum and Veterans Research Center, not the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: The Role of Air Pressure in Starting a Landslide
description: Rain can set off landslides, as can earthquakes. But what about air? More precisely, what about the weight of air, better known as atmospheric pressure?

title: A Venerable Ensembles Performance, Filtered Through a Halls Odd Acoustics
description: The Mozarteum Orchestra Salzburg, founded in 1841, is just a year older than the New York Philharmonic, but with its avowed specialty  music of the Viennese Classical era  this ensemble makes the conservative Philharmonic look like a wild-eyed new-music band. Still, the Salzburg group is updating its repertory: in one series this season it is focusing on the music of John Adams and Luciano Berio, as well as on Schubert and Schumann.

title: Worst Idea of 2009
description: In my column on Thursday, I included the following observation about some Wall Street products:

title: Back to Iowa
description: At the place where the presidential candidacy of Barack Obama first took life, it appears that the coalition he built in 2008 is showing at least some signs of fraying.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Verdict
description: This week, A. O. Scott looks at Sidney Lumets 1982 film The Verdict. It follows a tarnished lawyer (Paul Newman) who seeks to redeem his reputation by winning a malpractice case. The standard courtroom drama story is given a dark twist with a screenplay by David Mamet. The Verdict, Mr. Scott says, leaves you with the sense that justice can prevail, but when it does, its too little, too late, and it cant compensate for the harm thats already been done. Please share your thoughts on The Verdict and other favorite courtroom dramas.

title: Beethoven, and Plenty of It, in a Worldwide Sonata Tour
description: The Austrian pianist and composer Carl Czerny thought that Beethovens Piano Sonata in E flat (Op. 7) should have been nicknamed Appassionata instead of the Sonata in F minor (Op. 57). Till Fellner, an excellent Vienna-born pianist, illuminated the dramatic hues of the Opus 7 Sonata on Friday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in its PianoForte series.

title: Schools vs. Guns in Afghanistan
description: In his Thursday column, Nick argued that building schools and educating people in Afghanistan and Pakistan would do more to stabilize these societies than military interventions. In response, a number of U.S. servicemen wrote in with their own stories about education as an effective counterinsurgency measure. One of the most detailed came from Lt. Col. Michael Fenzel. We post it here with his permission.

title: Office Gossip Strategies
description: Whats the gossip in your office? Whats the gossip doing to your office? And what are the best strategies for gossips or antigossips to employ in the office?

title: Afghan Fiasco
description: Opinionland has had little positive to say about the failed presidential run-off in Afghanistan, which ran off the road over the weekend when candidate Abdullah Abdullah withdrew, leaving the field to President Hamid Karzai, who earlier today was declared the official winner.

title: A Shot in the Arm
description: Q. Why do some people get a sore arm at the site of a flu vaccine injection while others do not?

title: Obama Lifts Ban on Visitors With H.I.V.
description: Fulfilling a campaign promise, on Friday the president moved to end a 22-year-long restriction he said was rooted in fear rather than fact.

title: Geek Chic | Retail Therapy With Style Savvy
description: Whats more fun, working in fashion or pretending that you do with Style Savvy, a new video game that was released today? Tough call. For the past week, The Moment has been geeking out with a demo copy, and were somewhat embarrassed to admit the Nintendo DSi game is more fun than it has any right to be: you play a young, eager, fashion-forward girl trying to take the Horatio Alger route from retail sales assistant to world-famous stylist and entrepreneur.

title: Prisoners of War and Sex in Liberia
description: NEW HAVEN  Subjugation and corruption are the grim options available to the women of Eclipsed, a new play by Danai Gurira (In the Continuum) at the Yale Repertory Theater here. Set in 2003 during the Liberian civil war, the play focuses on four women held captive by the brutal leader of a rebel faction fighting against the government.

title: CRE and the CRA
description: Zombies, zombies, everywhere. One of the enduring myths of the financial crisis has been the claim that it was the result of (a) Fannie and Freddie (b) the Community Reinvestment Act, which forced poor, helpless bankers to make loans to you-know-who. Its a myth that wont go away  I get asked about it almost every time I give a public lecture  even though it has been extensively debunked. (See, e.g., here.)

title: Russians Comment on Ways to Curb the Use of Alcohol
description: MOSCOW  How hard will it be for the Russian government to reduce the countrys alcohol consumption? The New York Times asked readers of its Russian-language blog on livejournal.com for their thoughts.

title: A Tribute to Nashville (Altmans, not Partons)
description: A satire of a satire made with love: if that description of the revue Daryl Glenn and Jo Lynn Burks Play and Sing Robert Altmans Nashville sounds self-contradictory (how many satires emanate from love?), it evokes the heartfelt nostalgia of a popular little show that has been playing at the Metropolitan Room on the first Sunday each month.

title: Can You Believe How Mean Office Gossip Can Be?
description: Could adults gossiping in the office be more devious than the teenagers in Gossip Girl?

title: A One-Man Band Plays Left-Coast Rock
description: Were Mount Eerie, from Anacortes, Washington, said Phil Elverum, a compact, penitent-looking man with an electric guitar. His audience, on Sunday night at Le Poisson Rouge, cheered at him. Yes, he said. Thank you. Its a beautiful place.

title: A Marathon Run in the Slow Lane
description: After a 10-kilometer road race this summer, a friend apologized for missing me at the finish line. The truth was, she hadnt lost me in the crowd. She just didnt wait long enough.

title: Running at the Back of the Pack
description: For the past five and a half months, Ive been writing about training for my first marathon. My goal was to get off the couch, run consistently and complete a fall marathon.

title: A Breathing Technique Offers Help for People With Asthma
description: I dont often write about alternative remedies for serious medical conditions. Most have little more than anecdotal support, and few have been found effective in well-designed clinical trials. Such trials randomly assign patients to one of two or more treatments and, wherever possible, assess the results without telling either the patients or evaluators who received which treatment.

title: Gene Therapy: Before and After
description: A child navigating an obstacle course test, first using only his untreated right eye, and then with his left eye, which received a gene therapy treatment three months before.

title: Consumer Reports Opines on Electronics
description: While many videophiles dismiss the magazines findings, the fact is that millions of Americans rely on Consumer Reports evaluations of electronics to help them with their purchase decisions.

title: Employment Looks Better
description: For those convinced the economy cannot be improving, job numbers are Exhibit No. 1. The expectation (according to a Bloomberg survey of economists) is that employment fell by 175,000 in October in the United States. (We get the number, or at least the first estimate of it, on Friday.)

title: Bruno Corruption Trial Opens
description: ALBANY  The corruption trial of Joseph L. Bruno, the former Senate majority leader, opened in federal court here on Monday, with a whos who of state lawmakers and lobbyists expected to take the stand over the next few weeks.

title: Collecting Headlines Funnier Than This
description: Headlines in the satirical weekly newspaper The Onion tend to function both as punch line and setup, in that order. They are the heart of the paper, and not only the first thing anybody reads, but also, unlike headlines in real newspapers all over the world, the first things to be written. The staff devotes the first two days of every week to composing headlines, then assigns the articles that will run beneath them and provide a body of supporting jokes.

title: Quandary With Mammograms: Get a Screening, or Just Skip It?
description: Here we go again. Another study raises questions about the benefits of mammograms, and another set of confusing statements issue forth from experts.

title: Anti-Odor Silver Exits Textiles in the Wash
description: When it comes to killing bacteria, fungi and the like, silver is a thing of beauty. Silver ions are such effective antimicrobial agents, in fact, that there are now hundreds of consumer products that contain small amounts of the metal, in the form of nanoparticles that release ions slowly over time.

title: Feinberg Says Pay Caps May Cause Some to Leave
description: Kenneth R. Feinberg, the Treasury Departments special master for executive pay, acknowledged Monday that his decisions to cut executive compensation could encourage talented employees to leave seven companies that received tens of billions of dollars in government bailout money.

title: A Powerful Identity, a Vanishing Diagnosis
description: It is one of the most intriguing labels in psychiatry. Children with Aspergers syndrome, a mild form of autism, are socially awkward and often physically clumsy, but many are verbal prodigies, speaking in complex sentences at early ages, reading newspapers fluently by age 5 or 6 and acquiring expertise in some preferred topic  stegosaurs, clipper ships, Interstate highways  that will astonish adults and bore their playmates to tears.

title: U.S. Unlikely to Recoup Auto Bailouts, G.A.O. Says
description: A government report released Monday concludes that taxpayers will probably never recoup all  or even close to all  of the $67 billion that the Treasury Department lent to General Motors and Chrysler in the last year to prevent their collapse, Nick Bunkley of The New York Times reports from Detroit.

title: Mt. Kilimanjaro Ice Cap Continues Rapid Retreat
description: The ice atop Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania has continued to retreat rapidly, declining 26 percent since 2000, scientists say in a new report.

title: Creationism, Minus a Young Earth, Emerges in the Islamic World
description: AMHERST, Mass.  Creationism is growing in the Muslim world, from Turkey to Pakistan to Indonesia, international academics said last month as they gathered here to discuss the topic.

title: Hubbells, Promising Young Ice Dancers, Swap Coaches
description: The Olympic season coaching carousel continues in skating.

title: In the Mediterranean, Killer Tsunamis From an Ancient Eruption
description: The massive eruption of the Thera volcano in the Aegean Sea more than 3,000 years ago produced killer waves that raced across hundreds of miles of the Eastern Mediterranean to inundate the area that is now Israel and probably other coastal sites, a team of scientists has found.

title: Now Showing | Design, and Plenty of It
description: This is a busy week for design exhibitions. Opening on Tuesday at the Wright auction house in Chicago is Timeless, a collection of objects by Constantin and Laurene Boym. For the show, the New York-based Boyms, who won a 2009 National Design Award for their quirky, witty products, render everyday objects like tables and bottles in bronze, giving them a permanence they might not otherwise have.

title: On Our Radar
description: 1) The Washington Posts gloomy take on the Senate climate bill.

title: You Cant Judge a Seatmate by His Foot-Stomping
description: I LOVE flying. Maybe thats because I go into it with the expectation that Im going to be delayed. Once I get through security, I go to the bar, ask for a wine, order some death-defying foods and then do some work, until my flight arrives.

title: Kerik Moved Out of Jails Mental Health Unit
description: WHITE PLAINS  Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City former police commissioner, was transferred out of a special mental health unit in a Westchester County jail on Monday after psychiatric officials determined that he was psychologically stable.

title: Justices Scrutinize Adviser Pay
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday appeared reluctant to allow judges to take on a major role in policing the compensation of mutual fund investment advisers. But some justices nonetheless suggested that pay arrangements could be so outsized that the courts may have to step in.

title: Huge Audience for World Series Game, but N.F.L. Still Reigns
description: The question of the most popular sport on television has been long answered, but football put an exclamation point on it Sunday when a regular season N.F.L. game was far more watched than Game 4 of the World Series.

title: Schwab to Offer Commission-Free E.T.F.s
description: Charles Schwab said Monday that it was entering the exchange-traded fund business, with the introduction of eight new funds that undercut several competing E.T.F.s on fees. But to top it all off, investors with Schwab accounts can buy and sell the funds free.

title: Researcher Behind the Drug Gleevec
description: Dr. Brian J. Druker, 54, an oncologist at Oregon Health and Sciences University and a Howard Hughes Medical Investigator, is one of three winners this year of the Lasker-DeBakey Clinical Medical Research Award, often called the American Nobel Prize. Dr. Druker shared the honor with Nicholas B. Lydon, a former researcher for Novartis, and Charles L. Sawyers of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, for the development of molecularly targeted treatments for chronic myeloid leukemia, converting a fatal cancer into a manageable chronic condition. Here is an edited version of a conversation that took place last month in New York:

title: Times Responds on Reporters Kidnapping
description: Several Web sites repeated Monday erroneous allegations that The New York Times had paid a ransom in the case of its reporter David Rohde, held by the Taliban for seven months. Bloggers also accused The Times of hypocrisy in reporting on a British couple kidnapped by Somali pirates while keeping quiet Mr. Rohdes kidnapping.

title: Understanding Your Credit
description: The government requires the credit bureaus to provide free copies of your credit reports once a year, but not credit scores or monitoring. Yet some companies offer free reports and scores on their Web sites, often to entice customers to sign up for monitoring. And not all scores are created equal  many free scores are meant as a guide for consumers and are not actually used by lenders to assess your creditworthiness.

title: With Series Fever, Steroids Issue Fades to the Past
description: Aided by his bat and an astute apology, Alex Rodriguez is ending the baseball season not as a former steroids user but as a home run hero. In the process, he may be clearing a path forward for himself and his much-maligned sport.

title: On Assignment: New York City Marathon
description: Most years Fred R. Conrad is assigned to photograph the New York City Marathon and he has covered it from various vantage points along the 26.2-mile race that winds through all five boroughs. In the past, he focused the lens of his 45 camera on the Achilles Track Club Freedom Team, taking black and white portraits of this group of disabled war veterans. Last year, the marathon fell just two days before the election, and he shot runners emblazoned with political flair and slogans.

title: Jets Special-Teams Woes
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets special-teams coordinator, Mike Westhoff, made a rare Monday media appearance, in order to explain how his unit yielded a pair of return touchdowns to Ted Ginn Jr. in a loss Sunday to Miami.

title: Where the Swearing Is All About the Context
description: MEXICO CITY  Two teenage girls slurped iced coffee drinks at a sidewalk cafe the other afternoon and chatted away about boys, clothes, their weekend plans, whatever seemed to pop into their heads. They were clearly friends, but repeatedly referred to each other with a Spanish word meaning ox or steer or stupid.

title: New Yorkers Have Their Say
description: Residents in five New York City boroughs speak out about their choice for mayor and what matters most this election.

title: Supreme Court Addresses Pay of Fund Advisers
description: The Supreme Court on Monday appeared reluctant to allow judges to take on a major role in policing the compensation of mutual fund investment advisers. But some justices nonetheless suggested that pay arrangements could be so outsized that the courts may have to step in, Adam Liptak of The New York Times reports from Washington.

title: Jets Look for Answers From Uneven Performances
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Throughout the Jets locker room Monday, the answers did not match the record. The rookie quarterback Mark Sanchez sounded giddy. Linebacker Bart Scott remained defiant. Player after player expressed satisfaction with his respective individual or unit performances halfway through this season.

title: Video: In Iowa, Obama One Year After
description: To mark the one-year anniversary of the historic election of Barack Obama, we went back to the place where his campaign took life: Iowa.

title: Date Set for Oral Arguments in Polanski Case
description: Let the arguments begin: a California appeals court in Los Angeles has scheduled oral arguments in its review of Roman Polanskis three-decade-old sex case for Dec. 10.

title: Iran: Reformist Newspaper Is Closed
description: The authorities on Monday shut down a reformist daily newspaper, Sarmayeh, on charges of repeated violations of the press law, the official news agency IRNA reported. No details were disclosed about the violations attributed to the newspaper, which has been critical of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejads economic policies.

title: Karadzic Promises to Attend War Crimes Trial Tuesday
description: PARIS  Radovan Karadzic was absent again on Monday, the third day of his trial, but he sent a letter to the chief judge of the international war crimes tribunal hearing his case saying that he would be pleased to attend on Tuesday.

title: E. Coli Kills 2 and Sickens Many; Focus Is on Beef
description: Two people, one from New Hampshire and another from upstate New York, have died after eating ground beef that may be responsible for an E. coli outbreak linked to illness in more than two dozen people.

title: Mayoral Campaigns Look Skyward, and Everywhere Else, for the Keys to Victory
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs campaign, having spent $100 million or more on ads and outreach, would love to be able to buy a 60-degree day. The higher the temperature, the thinking goes among Mr. Bloombergs staff, the wider the margin of victory.

title: Suburbs Are Seen as Key in New Jersey Race
description: PARAMUS, N.J.  Finishing his morning coffee with three friends  like him, all retirees and registered Republicans  Leonard Reisner let it slip that he would be voting to re-elect Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic incumbent governor.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,346 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

title: Biden Stumps in a Race Steeped in Ideology
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y.  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. threw the heft of the White House behind the Democratic candidate on Monday in a race for a vacant Congressional seat that both Democrats and Republicans view as significant tests of their political fortunes.

title: House Harder on Drug Makers Than Senate
description: The health care bill that the full House may take up later this week is much tougher on the drug industry than what the Senate is considering. And that could prove one of the challenges for lawmakers when the legislation eventually reaches a House-Senate conference committee.

title: Little Buzz for Thompson? Call It Larry Doby Syndrome
description: Win or lose on Tuesday  and the poll gods are not smiling upon him  William C. Thompson Jr. will no longer have to struggle with what might be called Larry Doby Syndrome.

title: Forest Evashevski, Who Coached Iowa to Two Rose Bowl Titles, Dies at 91
description: Forest Evashevski, who revitalized a long-dismal football program at the University of Iowa and coached the Hawkeyes to two Rose Bowl championships in the 1950s, died Friday in Petoskey, Mich. He was 91.

title: Happy Ending
description: In the spring of 2004 I took a flight from my home near Greenville, S.C., to New York to visit my dying step-grandmother. We had been close, and it would be one of the last times I would get to see her. As the flight was about to land, it abruptly ascended and headed toward the Empire State Building. The passengers on the plane became quiet; the aura of 9/11 was hanging in the air.

title: Cellphones, Texts and Lovers
description: Since April 2007, New York magazine has posted online sex diaries. People send in personal accounts of their nighttime quests and conquests. Some of the diaries are unusual and sad. Theres a laid-off banker who drinks herself into oblivion and wakes up in the beds of unfamiliar men. Theres an African-American securities trader who flies around the country on weekends to meet with couples seeking interracial sex. (He meets one Midwestern couple at a T.G.I. Fridays.)

title: Scandal at Tower of London Over Treatment of Female Beefeater
description: LONDON  For centuries, the jailers at the Tower of London known as Beefeaters had a grim reputation. Guarding three Tudor queens who were beheaded and dispatching numerous others who had fallen foul of royal favor to the gallows or the scaffold, they helped make the towers bloodstained history.

title: Economy Is Focus at End of New York Mayor Race
description: On the eve of Tuesdays election, the top two mayoral candidates put aside their bitter arguments over term limits, campaign spending and the citys schools to try to reassure voters about a more pressing worry: the economy.

title: 2010 to Come in Plain and Fancy Versions
description: IN less than two months, a new year will arrive, along with a new decade. Each year in the current decade has been spoken the long way, as in two thousand nine, rather than the short way, as in twenty oh nine (or even twenty ought nine).

title: Gores Dual Role: Advocate and Investor
description: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Al Gore thought he had spotted a winner last year when a small California firm sought financing for an energy-saving technology from the venture capital firm where Mr. Gore is a partner.

title: No Rough Edges on Stanleys Deal for Black & Decker
description: Leave it to the tool industry to engineer something like the perfect deal. The $3.5 billion Stanley Works purchase of Black & Decker, one of Stanleys main competitors for hardware and hand tools, leaves almost nothing for investors in the two companies to complain about. The combination would create a powerhouse with $8.4 billion in sales. If only deal-making was always this simple.

title: States Are Pondering Fraud Suits Against Banks
description: PHOENIX  Newly empowered by the Supreme Court, the attorneys general of several states hit hard by the housing collapse are exploring consumer fraud suits against major mortgage lenders.

title: To Some, Winner Is Not American Enough
description: As soon as Mebrahtom Keflezighi, better known as Meb, won the New York City Marathon on Sunday, an uncommon sports dispute erupted online, fraught with racial and nationalistic components: Should Keflezighis triumph count as an American victory?

title: Bloggingheads: Public Option Kabuki?
description: Tim Fernholz, left, of The American Prospect and Matt Lewis of Politics Daily debate whether the public option will be in the final Senate bill.

title: For Girardi and Manuel, Three Days Rest Is the Right Call, and So Is Four
description: Philadelphia

title: GlobalFoundries Chairman to Take Leave, Then Resign
description: Hector Ruiz, the former chief executive of Advanced Micro Devices, will step down as chairman of GlobalFoundries, the chip maker spun off from A.M.D. last year, the company said on Monday.

title: Troy Smith, Founder of Sonic, Dies at 87
description: Troy N. Smith Sr., who turned ordering a hamburger by speaking into a microphone from a parked car into a national habit, died last Monday in Oklahoma City, Okla. He was 87.

title: Lack of Paid Sick Days May Worsen Flu Pandemic
description: Public health experts worried about the spread of the H1N1 flu are raising concerns that workers who deal with the public, like waiters and child care employees, are jeopardizing others by reporting to work sick because they do not get paid for days they miss for illness.

title: Fed Leaders Meet Bankers to Stress Limits on Pay
description: The heads of the nations largest banks were summoned by Federal Reserve officials on Monday to discuss what is perhaps the most contentious issue of the post-bailout era: pay.

title: Appeals Court Rejects Suit by Canadian Man Over Detention and Torture Claim
description: A federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled on Monday that Maher Arar, a Canadian man who claimed that American officials sent him to Syria in 2002 to be tortured, cannot sue for damages because Congress has not authorized such suits.

title: Costly Free Credit Reports
description: Federal law guarantees free credit reports each year, but many consumers who got theirs from FreeCreditReport.com unintentionally paid for an expensive credit monitoring service.

title: Ethics Panel Investigates Free Tickets for Paterson
description: The State Commission on Public Integrity has begun a preliminary inquiry into the solicitation of free tickets for the opening game of the World Series by aides to Gov. David A. Paterson, an administration spokesman confirmed on Monday.

title: A Free Credit Score Followed by a Monthly Bill
description: On television its hard to miss the wildly popular band of slackers singing ruefully from a shabby apartment or while waiting tables in pirate regalia. The ruined credit that led to their financial misfortune might have been sparkling if only theyd tracked their status on freecreditreport.com.

title: U.S. to Allow G.M. to Use Federal Loans to Invest in Delphi
description: DETROIT The federal government has granted General Motors permission to use $2.8 billion in borrowed money to help its former parts division, the Delphi Corporation, G.M. said in a regulatory filing on Monday.

title: Could You Keep Up?
description: Imagine you are on a treadmill at your local gym. You push the up arrow again and again, increasing your speed until you reach the machines maximum, 12 miles per hour. Thats a pace of five minutes per mile.

title: The Man Who Opened the Gate
description: Twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the columnist Roger Cohen describes how a former East German border guard kept that fateful night peaceful, rather than filled with bloodshed.

title: Two Views of Bruno Are Presented at His Trial
description: ALBANY  The corruption trial of Joseph L. Bruno, the former State Senate majority leader, opened in federal district court here on Monday, with a whos who of state lawmakers and lobbyists expected to take the stand over the next few weeks.

title: Slumping Giants Are Struggling to Communicate
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants defensive end Justin Tuck was blunt Monday when he expanded on comments made Sunday by middle linebacker Antonio Pierce about how the defense had a communication problem during a 40-17 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: U.S. to Pay $1.2 Million to 5 Detainees Over Abuse Lawsuit
description: The federal government is paying $1.2 million to settle the cases of five Muslim immigrants who sued over their detention and treatment in a Brooklyn jail after 9/11, when hundreds of noncitizens were rounded up and held for months before being cleared of links to terrorism and deported.

title: Nov. 3 Election Information
description: New York

title: A Glimpse of the Future?
description: President Obama made an appearance in Florida last week that should have gotten more attention. At a time when many Americans are apprehensive about the state of the economy and uncertain about the nations long-term prospects, Mr. Obama delivered an upbeat speech that offered a glimpse of a broader overall vision and a practical way forward on the crucial issues of energy and jobs.

title: New Advice on Swine Flu for Pregnant Women
description: One dose of swine flu vaccine protects pregnant women against the flu, but children under 10 still need two doses, federal officials said Monday, announcing further results of clinical trials of the vaccine.

title: It Knows Where You Are, and What Youre Looking For
description: Big Web companies and start-ups alike are scrambling to create the best applications to allow users to search for surrounding businesses and events from a mobile phone. Loopt, a service that lets people find their friends on the go, is now entering the crowded field.

title: Democrats Say House Bill Cuts Premiums for Many
description: WASHINGTON  As the House moved toward climactic votes on legislation to remake the health care system, the Congressional Budget Office said Monday that middle-income families might be required to pay 15 percent to 18 percent of their income on insurance premiums and co-payments under the proposal.

title: One of the Three Green Rs
description: Todays puzzle features a clever quote by a governor whose name tucks neatly into opposite corners of the grid. Crossword constructors like a name like that. Designers of campaign placards do too, being able to neatly stack one name atop the other. In presidential races, FORD DOLE was a good pairing. EISENHOWER NIXON wasnt, but using IKE and DICK solved that problem.

title: Joba Chamberlain Braces for Renewed Talk About His Role With Yankees
description: PHILADELPHIA  Giving up the tying home run with two outs in the bottom of the eighth inning of Game 4 was not the way Joba Chamberlain wanted to get his first World Series victory. But often when a late-inning reliever is the winner, it is because he did something wrong.

title: Detectives Alcohol Level Was 2  Times Legal Limit
description: The New York City police detective who has been charged with killing a woman while driving drunk early Friday morning had a blood alcohol level more than double the legal limit, according to a law enforcement official.

title: Lament on the Fading Culture of the Printed Word
description: Over the years, how many people have read Joan Didions pointed, moody, celebrated essays and come to New York in the hope of writing some of their own? The path of those would-be writers is patently stubborn, given the tone Ms. Didion strikes in the essay so many name as their favorite, Goodbye to All That. It is a famous elegy for the passing of youth, but also a catalog of Manhattans enervating clichs, and, implicitly, a rejection of the New York literary scene she inhabited.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about President Obamas announcing the end of a ban on travel to the United States by people who test positive for HIV misidentified the document Mr. Obama was shown signing. It was the Ryan White H.I.V./AIDS Treatment Extension Act of 2009, which provides medical and support services for those with H.I.V./AIDS; it was not the order ending the travel ban.

title: Corrections
description: The Talking Business column on Saturday, about the National Hockey Leagues refusal to sell the Phoenix Coyotes franchise to a Canadian who would relocate it to Ontario, misidentified the North Carolina city that received a team under the N.H.L.s so-called Southern strategy of the 1990s. It was Raleigh, not Charlotte.

title: Election Day
description: Councilwoman Diana Reyna, a Democrat from City Council District 34 in Brooklyn, is battling two formidable foes in Tuesdays election. One is a vengeful Democratic Party boss, who rails about her independence, and the other is the Roman Catholic bishop of Brooklyn, who has made robocalls supporting the party boss.

title: The Mayors Bad Investment
description: MEMO to the 108th mayor of New York, Michael R. Bloomberg: You didnt have to do it. You didnt need to set a new national campaign spending record. You didnt have to become a one-man stimulus program, employing costly campaign consultants, ad producers and all those volunteers. You didnt need that barrage of television ads, those wasteful glossy mailings or maddening robocalls.

title: Helping Spin Gold From a Pile of Garbage
description: Raj Kottamasu, 29, is a community coordinator for Freshkills Park, which is built above the Fresh Kills Landfill in Staten Island. Raised in West Bloomfield, Mich., he is the only member of his family who is not a doctor and thus describes himself as a black sheep.

title: A Game 5 Dedication to Michael Goldsmith
description: In a quick and touching reaction, Major League Baseball paid tribute during Monday nights World Series game to Michael Goldsmith, the law professor who died Sunday of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

title: Toolmaker Deal Ends a 28-Year Courtship
description: For nearly three decades, Stanley Works and Black & Decker, two of the most recognizable names in home improvement, have talked about combining through a merger.

title: Goldman Eyes Tax Credits Fannie Mae Doesnt Need
description: WASHINGTON  It could be yet another opportunity for Goldman Sachs to come out a winner from the financial crisis that it helped create, but the Treasury Department appears poised to squash it.

title: Dean Foods Cautions on Outlook
description: The Dean Foods Company, the dairy processor, said Monday fourth-quarter earnings might fall more than analysts estimate amid rising prices for raw milk.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about Citigroup misstated the terms under which Sanford I. Weill, the companys former chief executive, left it in 2003. Mr. Weill retired; he did not resign.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday showing the standings for the Bowl Championship Series misidentified Iowas next college football opponent. Iowa is to play Northwestern on Saturday  not Indiana, which it beat last Saturday, 42-24.

title: Corrections
World Series Game 5 Final: Phillies 8, Yankees 6
description: Times reporters David Waldstein, Ben Shpigel, Tyler Kepner, Jack Curry and Richard Sandomir provided updates and analysis during Game 5 of the Yankees-Phillies World Series in Philadelphia.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, schedule information on Saturday with an article about performances of music by the composer Herbert Howells in New York this month misstated the date of a concert at Trinity Church that included his Requiem. As the article noted, the concert was scheduled for last night not tonight.

title: San Franciscans Will Vote on Streets Touch of Flash
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Can neon save a neighborhood?

title: Recalling 96, Torre Empathizes With Girardi
description: PHILADELPHIA  Joe Torre thought his nervousness would subside, but it hounded him for hours. Needing one win with the Yankees to secure his first World Series ring in 1996, Torre remembered sitting in his office and being unable to relax. He had not been antsy about managing in the postseason, so he was surprised at how jittery he was.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about major art auctions in New York this week and next misidentified one of the sellers said to be offering works at Sothebys sale of Impressionist and Modern art on Wednesday night. He is Louis Reijtenbagh, a Dutch financier  not Matthias Rickenbach, a Swiss lawyer.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Tuesday about an experimental strategy for community-wide testing and treatment for H.I.V. misstated an indicator of illness. Generally, doctors begin drug treatment when the number of CD4 cells, the white blood cells attacked by the virus, drops to 350 per cubic millimeter of blood or lower  not per milliliter. The article also referred incorrectly to a white plastic stick used in rapid H.I.V. screening. The stick, tipped with filter paper, collects antibodies from liquid secreted by gum tissue; it does not collect cells from the lining of the mouth.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday about Elmer Winter, co-founder of the temporary agency Manpower Inc., misstated his date of death. It was Thursday, Oct. 22  not Thursday, Oct. 29.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary about the photographer Roy DeCarava misstated part of the title of a photograph of his from 1952. It is Man Coming Up Subway Stairs, not Man Comin Up Subway Stairs.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Senate Pressing Insurers on the Amount of Premiums They Spend on Care
description: The health insurance industry likes to cite figures showing that 87 cents of every dollar in premiums is spent on medical claims.

title: Perhaps a Point Guard Feud
description: New Orleans Coach Byron Scott brushed aside a verbal altercation between Hornets point guard Chris Paul and Rajon Rondo, the Boston Celtics point guard.

title: Voices From the Boroughs: Port Richmond, Staten Island
description: Interminable waits for the ferry. Endless road repair projects. Astronomical tolls.

title: Voices From the Boroughs: Flushing, Queens
description: Popularity has been a double-edged sword in Flushing, Queens, one of the citys most diverse neighborhoods. Business owners welcome the droves of people who descend on its downtown sidewalks in search of scarves, massages and melons, as well as ginseng that can run a few hundred dollars an ounce.

title: Voices From the Boroughs: Bay Ridge, Brooklyn
description: There are roughly six registered Democrats for every Republican in the city, but in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, Republicans are not hard to find.

title: Lottery Numbers
Browns Say General Manager Kokinis Is Out
description: The Cleveland Browns announced late Monday night that the first-year general manager George Kokinis was no longer working for the team, following a day of reports that he had been fired. The Browns denied the juicy part of the reports that Kokinis had been escorted out of the building. Kokinis was Coach Eric Manginis hand-picked choice to be the G.M., and the order of their hiring indicates who had the real power in the franchise: Mangini, not Kokinis. It was Kokinis who took the fall for the Browns 1-7 start. For this he left the Ravens and Ozzie Newsomes well-oiled scouting and personnel machine?

title: Mistakes Are Making a Difference in the World Series
description: PHILADELPHIA  Home plate is still 17 inches wide and the pitching rubber stands 60 feet 6 inches away. Ninety feet separate the bases. Baseballs sacred measurements have not changed this postseason, even if other things have for the Yankees opponents.

title: Mount Holyoke Names New President
description: Lynn Pasquerella, the provost of the University of Hartford, will become the 18th president of Mount Holyoke College this summer, succeeding Joanne Creighton, who has held the post since 1996. Ms. Pasquerella, who graduated from Mount Holyoke in 1980 before earning her doctorate in philosophy from Brown, spent almost two decades as a professor of philosophy at the University of Rhode Island, before becoming associate dean, then dean, of the graduate school there. She joined the University of Hartford in 2008.

title: Some Fans See Enemies Behind Every Microphone
description: If Facebook, blogs and other inventions of the Internet age had existed in the 1950s, would someone have created an IHateVinScully.com Web site to grouse about his bias as a Dodgers announcer during the Yankees-Brooklyn World Series that he called? Or how about a site called ShutUpMelAllen.com to gripe about his supposed pinstriped preference when he was calling some of that same series?

title: President Karzais Second Term
description: We regret the decision by Afghanistans opposition leader, Abdullah Abdullah, to withdraw from this weeks runoff election for the presidency. After President Hamid Karzais supporters tried to steal the first-round vote, Mr. Abdullah had strong reason to mistrust the process. But Afghan voters deserved another chance. And Afghanistans government  under assault from the Taliban and its own corruption and incompetence  desperately needed the legitimacy of a cleaner vote.

title: Freedom of the Press
description: The Obama administration and Congress appear to be moving toward agreement on a federal shield law, which would protect reporters who refuse to reveal confidential sources. The bill that is emerging is not perfect, but it would help ensure that Americans get the information they need about the workings of government, business and other institutions that affect their lives.

title: The Halliburton Loophole
description: Among the many dubious provisions in the 2005 energy bill was one dubbed the Halliburton loophole, which was inserted at the behest of  you guessed it  then-Vice President Dick Cheney, a former chief executive of Halliburton.

title: Eating Right, for a Green Planet
description: To the Editor:

title: My Brother the Yankee Fan
description: To the Editor:

title: Monsantos Practices
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Without a Cellphone
description: To the Editor:

title: Help Small Businesses Hire Again
description: West Chester, Pa.

title: Before They Vote, New Yorkers Have Their Say
description: The two major candidates vying in Tuesdays mayoral election have spent tens of millions of dollars flooding television, radio and mailboxes with ads and fliers, many of them attacking each others record and integrity. But voters across New York City say they care less about the attacks between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his Democratic opponent, Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., and more about issues big and small, like soaring rents, congested streets, parking tickets and a lack of garbage cans. In the days before the election, reporters for The New York Times went to three neighborhoods to talk to people about the concerns they want City Hall to address.

title: John Burns Q. and A. on Karzai, Corruption and Afghanistan
description: John Burns, the chief foreign correspondent for The New York Times, is answering questions about a New York Times article about Ahmed Wali Karzai, the brother of Afghan President Hamid Karzai. Ahmed Wali Karzai, who is accused of having ties to the nations opium trade, has been on the C.I.A. payroll since 2001, according to the article.

title: Questions Lacking in the Postgame Q. and A.
description: Fox needs a question coach for Mark Grace. One of the failings of many sideline/stadium reporters is that they do not jot down good, solid, clear questions to ask the stars of a game.

title: Phillies Send Series Back to the Bronx
description: PHILADELPHIA  The championship was in the Yankees grasp on Monday night, and a reminder loomed over their heads at Citizens Bank Park before Game 5 of the World Series. As they lounged in their clubhouse, rolls of protective plastic wrap hung above their lockers.

title: Best Buy Prepares for the Post-DVD Era
description: Best Buy sells a lot of DVDs, but it is taking another step to get ready for the day when that business shifts online.

title: Yo Jude: Computer Backup Plan
description: Backing up your computer is easier than ever.

title: Must You Vote?
description: The Issue

title: William J. Gaynor Elected Mayor of New York
description: Wednesday, Nov. 3, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Phillies Stay Alive
description: Chase Utley and Cliff Lee powered the Phillies past the Yankees, 8-6. The Yankees now take a three-games-to-two lead back to the Bronx.

title: Timeless Sports Final Moments
description: PHILADELPHIA  At the heart of baseballs beauty is that anything is possible until the final out. There is no clock, no ticking away of the season. In theory, it could last forever. Nothing proves this better than the end of the World Series.

title: Week 8 Quick Hits: Losing Owen Daniels
description: Andy Benoit has been writing the N.F.L. preview book series Touchdown since age 11. He is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

title: Word of the Day | apogee
description: apogee  \a-p-()je\  noun

title: 3 Contests on Election Day Could Signal Political Winds
description: WASHINGTON  In this supposedly quiet off-year election, three contests taking place Tuesday are filling the void. Voters in New Jersey and Virginia will elect governors, while voters in upstate New York are filling a vacant House seat in a race with national implications.

title: Facebook Farms
description: WHO are playing FarmVille?

title: After Not Finishing Game 5, Victorino Ready for Game 6
description: PHILADELPHIA  Anyone who saw a dismayed Shane Victorino pleading with his manager when he was taken out of Game 5 in the eighth inning Monday night may be a little surprised to know that no one in the Phillies clubhouse was happier after the game than he was.

title: Mary Travers Memorial Is Scheduled for Nov. 9
description: A memorial celebration of the life and music of the folk singer Mary Travers will be held at 7 p.m. on Monday at Riverside Church.

title: Teixeira Struggling to Find His Swing in Postseason
description: PHILADELPHIA  Mark Teixeira swung at Ryan Madsons changeup, missed it, then tried to return to the Yankees dugout after making the final out of Game 5 of the World Series. But Teixeiras march was briefly interrupted because he bumped into Carlos Ruiz, the Phillies catcher. Nothing is going right for Teixeira these days.

title: News Quiz | November 3, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Knicks Rediscover Hughes and Find a Win
description: Starters became reserves, veterans were dusted off and everything was new again. The Knicks, in search of another fresh start, tried one more new look Monday night: winners.

title: For Keflezighi, Its Wait, Wait, Win
description: For all of Meb Keflezighis preparation and strategizing, his bid to win the New York City Marathon almost came undone before he reached the starting line.

title: The M-16 Argument Heats Up, Again
description: Second of Two Parts

title: Ford Posts an Unexpected Profit of $997 Million
description: While its crosstown rivals stumbled through bankruptcy this summer, the Ford Motor Company pressed its advantage, and delivered surprising news on Monday that its cost-cutting efforts and improving sales helped it earn nearly $1 billion in the third quarter, The New York Timess Bill Vlasic reported.

title: Stanley and Black & Decker: The Perfect Deal?
description: Leave it to the tool industry to engineer something like the perfect deal. The $3.5 billion Stanley Works purchase of Black & Decker, one of Stanleys main competitors for hardware and hand tools, leaves almost nothing for investors in the two companies to complain about, Breakingviews says. The combination would create a powerhouse with $8.4 billion in sales. If only deal-making was always this simple.

title: BetOnSports Founder to Serve 4 Years
description: The founder of the online gambling site BetOnSports.com was sentenced Monday to more than four years in prison, ending a prosecution of one of the worlds largest offshore sports gambling companies.

title: In Myer, Shades of TPG Deals Past?
description: David Bonderman has achieved another impressive return for an investment in a department store chain.  TPG Capital, the private equity firm he oversees, has quadrupled its original investment of 500 million Australian dollars ($450 million) in Myer, the Australian retailer, in just over three years.

title: Law Firm Seeks Dissolution as Lawyer Investigated
description: A prominent and politically connected South Florida lawyer was being investigated by his own firm for financial irregularities in an investment business that led his law partner to seek dissolution Monday.

title: Cisco Enters China Cable Market With DVN Deal
description: Cisco Systems said Monday it would buy the set-top box business of DVN, a digital cable technology company in China, for up to $44.5 million.

title: Karzai Vows Corruption Fight, but Avoids Details
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai, in his first speech since he was declared the winner of the much disputed presidential election, said Tuesday that he wanted to tackle corruption but made no specific commitments to reorganizing his administration.

title: Kraft Results Could Help Its Case With Cadbury
description: Kraft Foods will need to show progress in cutting costs and improving organic revenue when it reports earnings on Tuesday, in a bid to convince Cadbury shareholders it is a viable deal partner, Reuters said.

title: Peets Swallows Diedrich Coffee for $213 Million
description: Peets Coffee & Tea, the coffee chain retailer, said Monday it would buy the wholesale roaster and distributor Diedrich Coffee for $213 million in a move to enter the rapidly growing single-cup coffee market.

title: States Are Pondering Fraud Suits Against Banks
description: Newly empowered by the Supreme Court, the attorneys general of several states hit hard by the housing collapse are exploring consumer fraud suits against major mortgage lenders.

title: China Extends Dragnet in Xinjiang Region
description: BEIJING  Four months after ethnic rioting in western Chinas Xinjiang region killed nearly 200 people, security officials there have started a fresh dragnet to track down accused rioters and other so-called terrorist elements, a state-run regional newspaper reported Tuesday.

title: Gores Dual Role in Spotlight: Advocate and Investor
description: Former Vice President Al Gore thought he had spotted a winner last year when a small California firm sought financing for an energy-saving technology from the venture capital firm where Mr. Gore is a partner.

title: Chinese Movie Studio Eyes N.Y.S.E. Listing
description: A third leading Chinese movie studio is aiming for a listing  this time on the New York Stock Exchange  as the countrys entertainment companies turn to the capital markets to raise funds.

title: Deleb
description: A portmanteau term for (d)ead c(eleb)rities.

title: It Knows Where You Are, and What Youre Seeking
description: Big Web companies and start-ups alike are scrambling to create the best applications to allow users to search for surrounding businesses and events from a mobile phone. Loopt, a service that lets people find their friends on the go, is now entering the crowded field.

title: Ex-Broker Pleads Guilty in Dreier Ponzi Case
description: A former broker pleaded guilty on Monday to criminal charges of helping Marc S. Dreier, the Ponzi scheme operator, defraud hedge funds by selling millions of dollars of fictitious debt, Reuters reported.

title: Frits Seegers Gives Notice at Barclays
description: Barclays announced a shake-up of its management structure on Tuesday inlcuding the surprise departure of Frits Seegers as head of the banks global retail and commercial banking.

title: Tiger Teams Up to Start Private Equity Firm
description: Tiger Management, the hedge funds founder Julian Robertson, and Emil Henry Jr. have teamed up to start a private equity firm that will specialize in infrastructure deals in North America and Europe, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Bank of New York Unit Buys Stake in Siguler Guff
description: Bank of New York Mellons asset management unit on Monday said it bought a 20 percent stake in the private equity firm Siguler Guff & Company, The Associated Press reported. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Former Enron Executive Sentenced to Probation
description: Kevin Howard, Enrons former broadband finance chief, has received one years probation, including nine months home confinement, for falsifying company books.

title: TPG Pays $500 Million for Valerus Stake
description: TPG, the private equity firm, has agreed to pay $500 million for a majority stake in Valerus Compression Services, a Houston-based maker of equipment used to process natural gas.

title: Goldmans Plan for Fannies Credits May Trip Up
description: It could be yet another opportunity for Goldman Sachs to come out a winner from the financial crisis that it helped create, but the Treasury Department appears poised to squash it.

title: N.Y. Pension Aims $1 Billion at Hedge Funds
description: The New York State Pension Fund is pouring money back into hedge funds, planning to invest more than $1 billion by the end of the year, Crains New York Business reported.

title: Bank of America Said to Extend Search to N.Y.-Based C.E.O.s
description: Bank of America broadened its search for a chief executive officer to include candidates who want to live in New York, acknowledging the banks biggest units are no longer based in its home of Charlotte, N.C., Bloomberg News reported.

title: Shares Regain Modestly on Manufacturing Uptick
description: Shares showed modest gains on Monday, the first day of trading since the market took one of its steepest plunges in months. Signs that manufacturing in the United States was on a path to recovery helped buoy shares.

title: What Do Good Teachers Need to Know?
description: The Secretary of Education, Arne Duncan, wants to see revolutionary changes made to teacher training programs. How do you think teachers should be trained?An Op-Ed by the director of teacher education at Williams College proposes how to make the changes that Secretary Duncan called for, including this idea:

title: New Loss at UBS, but Business Is Improving
description: UBS, Switzerlands biggest bank, reported a fourth consecutive quarterly loss Tuesday because of accounting charges but said business was improving, Julia Werdigier writes in The New York Times.

title: Summit: To Buy or Be Bought?
description: At time when many small independent film studios are struggling to stay in business, Summit Entertainment, the start-up studio behind the Twilight franchise, is hoping to take its business to the next level by expanding.

title: Fed Leaders Meet Bankers to Stress Limits on Pay
description: The heads of the largest U.S. banks were summoned by Federal Reserve officials on Monday to discuss what is perhaps the most contentious issue of the post-bailout era: pay.

title: Celebrating Light at the Palacio de Cristal
description: So subtle are the installations by the Belgian artist Jolle Tuerlinckx in Madrids Palacio de Cristal (Parque de El Buen Retiro; 34-91-574-6614; free admission), that on entering the gorgeous light-filled glass pavilion, you might not even notice them.

title: N. Korea Says It Has More Bomb-Grade Plutonium
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea put further pressure on the United States to start bilateral talks by declaring on Tuesday that it had completed reprocessing its spent nuclear fuel for use in a bomb.

title: Justices Scrutinize Adviser Pay
description: The Supreme Court on Monday appeared reluctant to allow judges to take on a major role in policing the compensation of mutual fund investment advisers. But some justices nonetheless suggested that pay arrangements could be so outsized that the courts may have to step in, The New York Timess Adam Liptak reported.

title: U.S. to Allow G.M. to Use Loans to Invest in Delphi
description: The federal government has granted General Motors permission to use $2.8 billion in borrowed money to help its former parts division, the Delphi Corporation, G.M. said in a regulatory filing on Monday, Nick Bunkley writes in The New York Times.

title: Toolmaker Deal Ends a 28-Year Courtship
description: For nearly three decades, Stanley Works and Black & Decker, two of the most recognizable names in home improvement, have talked about combining through a merger, The New York Timess Michael J. de la Merced and Zachary Kouwe write.

title: Equatorial Guinea Frees British Mercenary
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Equatorial Guinea said Tuesday that it had pardoned Simon Mann, a former British special forces officer jailed last year for plotting to overthrow the countrys president in a conspiracy that seemed as much a throwback to the continents past as a catalog of bungles.

title: European Union Reform Moves Ahead
description: PRAGUE  A landmark agreement aimed at giving the European Union a global stature on par with major powers like the United States and China cleared its last major hurdle on Tuesday.

title: Lloyds and R.B.S. Announce Major Shake-Up
description: In a major shuffle of the British banking sector on Tuesday, Lloyds Banking Group announced plans to keep the government from taking a majority stake, while Royal Bank of Scotland said it would give up even more control. Both banks were forced by the European Union to sell large parts of their businesses to comply with competition regulation, Julia Werdigier reported in The New York Times.

title: An Entrepreneurial Life
description: I just celebrated my 30th anniversary. One wife, three kids, 10 business start-ups, five business successes, five business misfires. I started my company the year before I got married, right out of school. I have come to realize over the years that I have not had a normal life. Thats because I am not normal; I am an entrepreneur.

title: G.M. Board Expected to Decide Fate of Opel
description: The board of General Motors is expected to decide Tuesday the fate of Opel and Vauxhall, ending more than a year of uncertainty surrounding its business and restructuring in Europe and the United States, The Associated Press reported.

title: Free Online Sperm and Its Perils
description: Todays idea: Priced out of expensive regulated sperm banks, prospective parents are turning to a booming gray market in unregulated sperm donation, an article says. Let us count the ways this may not be a good idea.

title: Almost Famous | Fischerspooner
description: I went to see Madonnas dress rehearsal at the O2 arena in London. It was so boring because she didnt make any mistakes, announced Casey Spooner, one part of the electroclash (remember that?) duo Fischerspooner onstage at MoMA on Sunday evening as part of Performa 2009. Between the Worlds, the groups three-hour performance supporting their newest album, Entertainment, celebrated the imperfections and rawness of a dress rehearsal. The audience literally entered through the back stage, getting a close-up of the dancers shimmying into their different D.I.Y. showgirl outfits: leotards accessorized with colorful knee pads, ripped-up gowns and silver running suits that looked liked they were issued from NASA.But it was Spooner who stole the show with his getups  from corsets to Kabuki  and his snarky running commentary. The singer arrived onstage in a bolero jacket and slicked back platinum hair  for a band that seems stuck in the 80s, this seemed to be a subtle homage to Adam Ant. As he serpentined through his dancers, a veritable hall of mirrors and racks of clothes, he faced the room full of arty hipsters as if he were making his debut to a crowd of 50,000 at the Meadowlands. In fact, the whole performance, snafus and all, was about superstardom. There was the de rigueur talk of the current queen of all things pop, Lady Gaga, and of course the former king of pop, Michael Jackson  at one point Spooner changed into a silver sequined suit and black hat, looking like he stepped out of the This Is It documentary.

title: Sampler: Water Plan, Dellums Debt, Camping at the Mall
description: Water Deal | The state Legislature moved closer to a water deal for the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta after the Senate approved a $9.9 billion bond bill for building new dams and other reforms.

title: Want a Stronger Democracy? Invest in Education
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: Toyota Engineers Flowers to Offset Production Pollution
description: Toyota has gone to some extreme lengths to offset the carbon dioxide emissions produced by its Tsutsumi plant in Toyota City, Japan, where it builds the Prius hybrid.

title: With Trick-or-Treating Over, Candy Invades Office Cubicles
description: This week, surely, tops the year in terms of the number of calories hauled into the office by workers: calories in the form of leftover Halloween candy.
