Snickers, candy corn, Swedish fish, Sour Patch Kids, Whoppers, M&Ms, Junior Mints. Fun size, snack size, miniatures. Even now, on Tuesday, this plastic-wrapped bounty remains plentiful in the cubicles of the city.

title: Berkshire Bets on U.S. With a Railroad Purchase
description: Update | 11:06 a.m. Berkshire Hathaway, the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, said on Tuesday that it planned to buy the 77.4 percent of Burlington Northern Santa Fe it did not already own for $26 billion in cash and stock, in the largest deal in Berkshire history.

title: What to Watch Tuesday: Aliens, Anthropologists and Politicians
description: ABC, already the network of Lost and FlashForward, adds another speculative drama to its schedule with V (8 p.m.), an updated version of the 1980s show about allegedly friendly aliens who appear in the sky over earths major cities. In a concession to the high cost of interstellar fuel, they bring 29 ships this time, instead of 50 as they did in the original.

title: How Credit Freezes Protect Your Identity
description: In Tuesdays paper, I wrote about FreeCreditReport.com and its credit monitoring service. Several critics and consumers see its up-to-the-minute reports on changes in your credit report as overkill.

description: And now, the moment New Yorkers have all been waiting for, maybe  the final Tip Sheet of the 2009 campaign.

title: Al Gores Climate Choice
description: Former Vice President Al Gores third book centering on global warming is out. Titled Our Choice: A Plan to Solve the Climate Crisis, it centers on the same mantra at the core of his message for years now  that the only missing link holding back action is political will. The book is mainly a heavily illustrated guide to the technologies and policies that could, in Mr. Gores view, limit climate dangers. Nuclear is largely out, capturing and burying carbon dioxide is somewhat in. Gains in energy efficiency are a vital stepping stone, he says, along with vastly expanded deployment of renewable energy sources and improved storage and grid components to make sure the power is available where and when its needed.

title: Friendsourcing the Quest for iPhone Apps
description: Recently, I asked a friend to show me his favorite new iPhone apps. He shrugged and said he didnt have any. He said it was too hard to find ones he wanted, and he didnt want to pay for anything he might not like.

description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

description: With Election Day looming here, President Obama took time on Monday to both congratulate and admonish Afghan President Hamid Karzai, now the official winner of the disputed election there.

description: Media highlights from Tuesdays edition of The New York Times:

title: Johnson & Johnson Plans Cuts
description: In what had already been a year of drastic job cuts in the drug industry, the health care giant Johnson & Johnson said Tuesday that it would eliminate 6 to 7 percent of its worldwide work force  about 7,000 to 8,200 jobs  as part of a corporate revamping.

description: PARIS  The former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic appeared in court Tuesday for the first time since the start of his war-crimes trial and repeatedly asked the judges to give him more time to prepare his defense. Until he was ready, he said, he could not participate in his trial.

description: Andrew Leonard asks when Im going to blow my top over Obamas statement that now is the time to get serious about reducing debt. Um, never?

title: Qian Xuesen, Father of Chinas Space Program, Dies at 98
description: BEIJING  Qian Xuesen, a brilliant rocket scientist who single-handedly led Chinas space and military rocketry efforts after he was drummed out of the United States during the redbaiting of the McCarthy era, died on Saturday in Beijing. He was 98.

title: Presidents Arts Committee Names 25 Members
description: An eclectic roster of artists and entertainment industry figures were named to the Presidents Committee on the Arts and Humanities, the White House announced on Monday evening. Among the 25 people who were named by President Obama as members to the committee were the talent agent Bryan Lourd, the managing director and co-chairman of Creative Artists Agency; the actors Sarah Jessica Parker and Edward Norton; the cellist Yo-Yo Ma; and Teresa Heinz Kerry, the philanthropist and wife of Senator John Kerry. Also named were the actors Kerry Washington, Forest Whitaker and Alfre Woodard; the director George C. Wolfe; Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue magazine; Damian Woetzel, the former New York City Ballet dancer; and the architect Thom Mayne. In September, the committee, which works with federal cultural agencies and in the private and public sectors to further the White Houses cultural objectives, named George Stevens Jr. and Margo Lion its co-chairs and Mary Schmidt Campbell its vice chairwoman.

title: Races to Watch Across the Nation
description: It may be an off-year election, but there are a few important races for both Republicans and Democrats. Whether the results suggest that President Obama has lost influence and electoral pull heading into the 2010 midterm elections  or offer Republican conservatives a map for consolidating their base against a more moderate wing of the party  remains to be seen.

title: Making Solar Power Mobile Power
description: In his work with the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Todd Myers has seen the importance of having mobile electricity supplies firsthand.

description: My colleague Clifford Levy reports in Tuesdays New York Times that the Russian government is trying, once again, to find some way of addressing the alarming fact that Russians consume roughly 4.75 gallons of pure alcohol a person annually, more than double the level that the World Health Organization considers a health threat.

title: Och-Ziff Earnings Beat Expectations
description: Och-Ziff Capital Management Group, the big publicly-traded hedge fund run by Daniel Och, said distributable earnings for the third quarter fell 35 percent on lower assets under management, but results topped Wall Street forecasts.

title: Letter: Hotel Haggling
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column, $855 a Night? Can We Talk? (Nov. 1): The name of the game here is: It never hurts to ask.

title: From the Pound to the Big Top
description: While every performer in the Big Apple Circus is a joy to watch, some are cuter than others. Among those are the nine crafty dogs that race around the ring, leap through the air and dance on two legs. Its quite an act, particularly for a group of animals that might have met a grim fate had they not been rescued by their trainer, Luciano Anastasini.

title: Letter: Argentine Attractions
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column In Latin America, Luxe Costs Less (Oct. 25): Even though Buenos Aires is not new on the less expensive luxury list, it still offers surprises. The last time I went, I found Miravida Soho, a recently restored 1930s mansion that has been turned into a small hotel and wine bar. It was probably the nicest hotel experience I have had in ages.

title: Correction: Singapores New Breed of Bar
description: A map last Sunday with the Heads Up column, about new bars and clubs in the Dempsey Hill neighborhood of Singapore, misstated part of the name of one of the bars. As the article correctly noted, it is the White Rabbit, not the Wild Rabbit.

description: The Philadelphia transit systems largest union went on strike early Tuesday morning, crippling travel in the city.

description: Case Study is a bimonthly posting on all things alcoholic by Toby Cecchini, Ts spirits columnist.

description: At the Museum of the California Academy of Sciences, designed by Renzo Piano.

title: Circumstances of Kokiniss Exit in Question
description: Even in the often tortured history of the Cleveland Browns, the last 48 hours seem to have redefined dysfunction, with the first-year general manager George Kokinis leaving the franchise Monday, just halfway through the season. New details emerged Tuesday morning about whether Kokinis was fired or forced to resign, which is intriguing because the Browns are still paying millions to other fired former executives like Phil Savage and Romeo Crennel.

title: Of China, Texas and Green Jobs
description: When a coalition of investors and wind developers from the United States and China announced plans for a large-scale wind project in West Texas last week, many of our readers expressed outrage that a portion of the financing might well come from the $22 billion set aside in the economic stimulus package for clean energy projects  and green jobs.

title: N.H.L. Scores: Coyotes, Out of Bankruptcy, Draw Record Low Crowd
description: Three games on Monday, but the most interesting aspect of the evening is the attendance figures for the three games in question.

title: Esther Hautzig, Author of Wartime Survival Tale, Dies at 79
description: Esther Hautzig, an author of childrens books whose true-life tale of surviving World War II in the labor camps of Siberia, told in a guileless teenagers voice, became a classic of young peoples literature, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Electronic Billboards on Mid-Market: SF Voters To Decide Today
description: San Francisco voters today are deciding on Proposition D, a ballot measure that, if passed, would allow electronic signs on a neglected two-block stretch of Market Street.

title: Sparanos Two-Point Confusion
description: When Dolphins Coach Tony Sparano decided to go for a 2-point conversion after Miami took a 30-19 lead against the Jets on Sunday, it didnt seem to make sense. With 8:48 left, an extra point would have forced the Jets to score two touchdowns to take the lead. When Miami failed to convert, the Jets had the chance to tie the score with one touchdown (with a 2-point conversion) and a field goal.

title: For Sale: One Humanity-Wasting Robot, Answers to the Name Terminator
description: Someday, as the movie and television series predicts, the Terminator robots will become powerful enough to reduce the world to a pile of scrap metal and ash. But for now, they just need new owners. Variety reported that the Halcyon Company, which owns the rights to the Terminator movies and related assets, plans to sell the franchise at an auction in January as it goes through bankruptcy. When Halcyon purchased the Terminator property for $30 million in 2007, it became the latest in a series of owners that previously included the producer Gale Anne Hurd and the now-defunct production company Carolco. Though the latest entry in the film series, Terminator: Salvation, grossed $369 million worldwide on budget of $200 million, Halcyon filed suit in August against a hedge fund that had provided the money to buy the series rights, saying that a backer at the fund engaged in fraudulent dealings, and filed for Chapter 11 in September. The companys founders, Derek Anderson and Victor Kubicek, told a bankruptcy court that the Terminator franchise was worth $70 million. In a satirical blog post, Joss Whedon, the creator of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, said he would pay $10,000 for the series, proposing such new ideas as a Terminator of the Rings fantasy film and a Terminator musical.

title: The Online Price War Over Books Has a Fresh Twist (Or Two)
description: Update | 2:04 p.m. In an e-mailed statement, Amy Lester, a spokeswoman for Walmart.com, said: We remain committed to offering our customers the lowest prices online at Walmart.com, and will continue to adjust our pricing accordingly and as needed on these books.

title: Madoffs Accountant Pleads Guilty in Scheme
description: A guilty plea on Tuesday by Bernard L. Madoffs longtime accountant indicates that the criminal investigation of the Madoff fraud may be heading in a new direction  away from securities fraud and toward criminal tax cases.

title: Making Room for Dad
description: Men should want to be more involved fathers, yes. But women have to let them.

title: Obama echoing Gordon Brown?
description: Were seeing a measure of disenchantment with Barack Obama, even among Democrats. Today the Times has a piece about that sentiment in Iowa, the New York Review of Books has a Gary Wills piece that is admiring but suggests that he become a one-term president, and environmentalists have a full-page ad in the NYT today decrying his interior departments decision to allow a wolf kill. You see the same thing in the poll numbers and hear it in water cooler conversations.

title: A Lawyers Untimely Death Rattles Courthouse
description: In a city of $750-per-hour lawyers and sophisticated criminals, Russell Paisley was the everymans attorney. He roamed the halls of New York courthouses, taking on any and every type of case, often representing clients without thick pocketbooks. He was a well-respected and well-liked figure among judges, court officers, his colleagues and many others working in the citys courthouses. To them, he was one of the faces of an important, yet all too often overlooked cog in the citys criminal justice system.

Was this a proud team that staved off defeat in its own stadium, only to become the backdrop to a heroic Yankees triumph in the Bronx? Or did the Phillies set themselves up for a comeback for the ages?

title: Colbert Decides to Sponsor Fast-Moving Billboards

According to The Associated Press, after the teams largest annual cash sponsor, DSB Bank NV, went into bankruptcy in October, Colbert stepped in.

title: Health Care Abroad: Taiwan
description: William Hsiao is a professor of economics at the Harvard School of Public Health and co-author of the 2004 book Getting Health Reform Right. He served as a health care adviser to the Taiwan government in the 1990s, when officials decided to reform that countrys health care system and to introduce universal coverage. He spoke with Anne Underwood, a freelance writer.

description: From Louise Story, a DealBook colleague:

title: A Fresh Twist in the Price War Over Books
description: The online price war that broke out last month between heavyweight retailers Wal-Mart, Amazon and Target took a new turn on Tuesday when Amazon chose to extend its $9 price tag on three hardcover books that were officially released Nov. 3. Originally, the price war extended only to certain books that had to be purchased online before their official release date. Now, its continuing  on Amazon, at least  after the books are published.

title: They Overshot

title: N.F.L. Seeks Congressional Help on Drug Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., took the unusual step Tuesday of asking Congress to change federal labor laws to prevent states from interfering with the leagues efforts to enforce its banned substances policy.

title: Leasing the New Jersey Turnpike

And its more, I guess it is more, it is more trick-or-treater friendly in this administration than it used to be the Bush-Cheney administration. Remember what happened  the trick-or-treaters would come and then Dick Cheney would turn his wolfhounds loose on the kids.

title: Premature Births Are Fueling Higher Rates of Infant Mortality in U.S., Report Says
description: High rates of premature birth are the main reason the United States has higher infant mortality than do many other rich countries, government researchers reported Tuesday in their first detailed analysis of a longstanding problem.

title: Israel Says Hamas Test-Fired Rocket
description: JERUSALEM  Israels military intelligence chief said Tuesday that Hamas militants in Gaza recently test-fired a rocket that flew 37 miles into the sea, a development that would put the environs of Tel Aviv within range and would attest to the success of Hamas in rebuilding and even improving its military abilities since Israels devastating three-week offensive in Gaza last winter.

title: Mordida
description: A Mexican euphemism for a bribe literally, a bite.

title: The Evening Snack Tradition
description: A few months ago, my wife, Jackie, and I spent a few days in Turin and Milan. The itinerary was chosen after consulting a very useful opera website, which lists opera performances worldwide  even in one-horse towns with tiny, two-production opera seasons  and gives links to theater websites so that you can have a stab at buying tickets. Besides being hot and humid in late June, the two cities have something important in common: generous snacks with after-work cocktails.

title: Real Madrid Fans Generational Divide
description: MADRID  When he wasnt mumbling Spanish obscenities to himself, the distinguished-looking older gentleman sitting next to me at the Santiago Bernabeu on Saturday cried out: A Kak! A Kak!

title: Madoffs Accountant Pleads Guilty in Scheme
description: Bernard L. Madoffs longtime accountant pleaded guilty on Tuesday to deliberately producing the rubber-stamp audits that helped Mr. Madoff conceal his enormous Ponzi scheme from regulators for nearly 20 years, The New York Timess Diana B. Henriques reports.

title: What Issues Should the Next Mayor Address First?
description: In the days before the election, reporters for The New York Times went to the five boroughs to talk to people about the concerns they want City Hall to address. The issues they raised were big and small, like soaring rents, congested streets, parking tickets and a lack of garbage cans. Voters in Port Richmond said that Staten Island felt like the forgotten borough, and they lamented the lack of public transportation options. In Flushing, Queens, residents complained about congestion and trash. And in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, there was a chorus of complaints that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is running the city like a business.

title: From Smart Meters to Smart Thermostats
description: As utilities install more smart meters in homes, more companies are offering services that tap the devices ability to give consumers information about their electricity use.

title: Nearly 60 Colleges Charge $50,000 or More
description: Update | 2:41 p.m. See below for a fuller list of schools that the Chronicle counts as new to what it calls the $50K Club, and what those colleges charge, as well as a roll call of those that were already there.

title: The Digital Fog of War
description: In his latest A Soldier Writes column, Capt. Tim Hsia considers the telecommunications and computer equipment made available to United States forces in Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: Some Stimulus Here, Some Stimulus There
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Touring a College in the Rain, and Drawing Some Preliminary Conclusions
description: I want to go to a school with a quad like this, Nicole said, wiping the raindrops away from her face. Its gorgeous even in the pouring rain.

title: Olympic Preview: Canada, U.S. Womens Hockey Teams to Meet in Four Nations Cup
description: Sneak previews can be fun, especially if they involve storied womens ice hockey rivals such as Canada and the United States.

title: Classical Theater of Harlem Founders to Step Down
description: Alfred Preisser and Christopher McElroen, who founded the Classical Theater of Harlem and made it a home for the likes of Samuel Beckett, Euripides, Shakespeare and Melvin Van Peebles, will leave that Off Broadway theater company this month. In a news release, Mr. Preisser, who served as its artistic director, and Mr. McElroen, who has been its executive director, said they created the Classical Theater of Harlem in 1999 to nurture a new, young and culturally diverse theater audience, and to produce theater that truly reflects the diversity of New York. During that time, the company has staged acclaimed productions of Waiting for Godot, Marat/Sade, Medea, King Lear and Aint Supposed to Die a Natural Death, Mr. Van Peebless 1971 Broadway musical. It has won several Audelco, Obie and Lucille Lortel Awards as well as a Drama Desk Award, and has featured actors like Andr De Shields and Wendell Pierce. In a statement, Mr. Preisser and Mr. McElroen said they were confident the company would continue to thrive, but did not name their successors.

title: Inside Out | Bathrooms Are Rooms, Too
description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

title: Transcript: Hamid Karzais Acceptance Speech
description: A rough translation by The New York Times of Afhgan President Hamid Karzai's acceptance speech.

title: Cisco and EMC Form Venture to Serve Data Centers
description: Cisco Systems took another step to expand its computer hardware businesses on Tuesday by forming a broad partnership with EMC, a maker of storage equipment and software.

title: Chrysler, Lagging Rivals, to Unveil Recovery Plan
description: DETROIT  Chrysler will introduce its five-year plan for revival on Wednesday, including a streamlined product lineup that it hopes will win back buyers.

title: Making Health Care Better
description: I.

title: Wall Street Journal to Hire About a Dozen Reporters to Cover Local News in New York
description: The Wall Street Journal plans to hire a small local news staff in New York, covering traditional city desk beats like courthouses, City Hall and the state capital, according to people briefed on the plans.

title: Gossip of the Cyclers, and Other News of the Wheel
description: Robert Center was speeding down Broadway, his head down over the handlebars, his body curved for minimum wind resistance. His eyes may have strayed from the path in front of him to the road beneath him  for a second, maybe longer  when suddenly and without warning, he slammed headlong into a coal cart and was killed.

title: Utley Is Chasing History With His Homers
description: Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia containing statistics for every player and team in major league history, and box scores, splits and game logs back to 1954.

title: An Economists Prescription for Aiding Small Business
description: Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Moodys Economy.com, has been an increasingly prominent economic voice since the nations financial storm began to gather. Today he writes on the Op-Ed page of The Times that Washingtons efforts to restart the economy have focused too much on large multinational companies to the neglect of small business, historically a major engine of job creation.

title: Kroenke Flirts With 30 Percent Ownership of Arsenal
description: Stan Kroenke owned more shares in the Arsenal soccer club than any other individual. Now, the American businessman has inched closer to the threshold that would force him to make an offer to buy the English club outright.

title: 2 Big Deals and the Search for an M.&A. Market
description: Updated with clarification | Nov. 4, 10:00 a.m. What a difference a day makes. Just on Monday in Searching for Themes in the M.&A. Market, I reviewed the dreary figures and transactions in the mergers and acquisitions market last month and noted the absence of discernable trends.

title: In Iran, From Heroes to State Enemies
description: CAIRO  Mohsen Mirdamadi had been applauded as a hero by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini for helping to lead the takeover of the United States Embassy in Iran 30 years ago Wednesday.

title: Manager of Queens Composer Is Sentenced for Fraud
description: Peter Maxwell Davies, the British composer who holds the title of master of the queens music, said that he was delighted after his former manager was sentenced to 18 months in prison for defrauding him of more than $800,000, The Times of London reported. Michael Arnold, who managed Mr. Daviess business affairs for more than 30 years, was arrested in 2007 and charged in October 2008 with false accounting; he admitted last year to having stolen the money, much of which is believed to have been spent on online gambling. Mr. Davies, who has been honored this year with a global series of concerts celebrating his 75th birthday, said he had stopped composing for a few weeks and had to borrow money from friends after learning of the fraud. On Monday, after the sentence was announced, he said he was glad the episode was over, adding: I may even set it all to music. Who knows? That would be the ultimate revenge.

title: Who Receives Sick Leave?
description: With the H1N1 pandemic raging across the nation, public health experts are voicing concern that many American workers do not receive paid sick leave  and may feel economic pressures to report to work even when they have the flu. This, public experts fear, might help spread H1N1, which is also known as swine flu.

title: Where the Bad 80s Has a Niche
description: YEARS ago, my clique habituated a Lower East Side restaurant called Hat (translated from El Sombrero for N.Y.C. natives). The enchiladas were O.K.; the main attractions were the cheap margaritas, the salsa jukebox and the nervy, unreasonable mood of the place, largely delivered by the indifferent goth waitress who always wore an enormous black turban. Hat was an oasis of counterculture that soothed feelings of general alienation and dismay by ramping them up a bit, into a pleasingly marginal sense of being beyond the strangling grip of the mainstream.

title: Orszag: To Reduce Deficit, Range of Options Being Considered
description: President Obamas budget director said in a speech on Tuesday that the White House economic team is considering a range of options so the president can keep his promise to reduce federal budget deficits by the end of his term to half of the level he inherited.

title: A Good Word for Big Farms
description: On Slate, Tracie McMillan argues that while small farms might have a romantic appeal to those who believe in sustainable agriculture, a worker might be better off at a large-scale farm.

title: Mom Always Liked You Best
description: The notion that parents cherish all their children equally  or at least say they do  is so entrenched in our culture that colleagues warned Karl Pillemer, a gerontologist at Cornell University embarking on the first of many studies of family favoritism, that his research would prove futile. No mother, they insisted, would admit to caring more for one son or daughter than another.

title: Hughes Likes the View From the High Road
description: Larry Hughes had been down this road before: shunned, discarded, frustrated and confused. But where he once exercised his vocal cords, Hughes this time exercised patience.

title: Tiffanys Temporary Parisian Home
description: PARIS | Its fitting that the first exhibition in France devoted to the great American designer Louis Comfort Tiffany would take place in the intimate Muse de Luxembourg (19, Rue de Vaugirard; 33-1-42-34-25-95; www.museeduluxembourg.fr)  a place where Tiffany probably would felt very much at home.

title: Vain Glorious | Frdric Malles New Madison Avenue Shop
description: Frdric Malles new Upper East Side store  his first free-standing location in the states  is much like his fragrances: refined and multilayered. Nestled in a former doctors office at 898 Madison Avenue, the jewel-box boutique was designed by the French architect Patrick Naggar, who drew inspiration from the buildings storied Art Deco exterior. Malle first spotted 898 Madison while studying art at New York University 25 years ago. Ive always loved the swirling facade, he says. Its reminiscent of Hoffmanns Viennese pavilion. Alongside 1930s French art, objets and furniture from Malles own collection (including a desk and chairs his grandfather commissioned from the atelier of Jules Leleu) are elements common to all of the perfumers shops, including futuristic-looking smelling columns, refrigerated display cases, photographs of his noses and bookshelves containing Malles archive of 18 fragrances. Also available: his new home collection, comprised of candles, rubber incense (sheets of recyclable rubber infused with scent) and the Fleur Mcanique, a red-cube wonder that diffuses the aroma of fresh flowers into the air. A specially designed venting system ensures that shoppers dont experience olfactory overload.Editions de Parfums Frdric Malle, 898 Madison Avenue; (212) 249-7941.

title: Answers About Your Bad Investing Behavior  Part 2
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which youll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals on a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Utley Muscles Into Rare Company
description: PHILADELPHIA  Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel used to say that Kirby Puckett was his favorite player. And then he met Chase Utley.

title: Report: Reducing Emissions Growth in Emerging Economies Could Be Cheap
description: How much would it cost to stop increasing greenhouse gas emissions in Mexico? According to a new study from the World Bank, not very much.

title: Inevitable Chaos': More 30 Rock in Germany
description: In fairness to the folks at 30 Rock (whose jokes we often try to pass off as our own), one more reason why its premiere on the German television channel ZDFNeo went unwatched could be because the show is already broadcast on German TNT.

title: Performa 09: Gooaaaaallll!
description: Viewers may have leaped intermittently to their feet at the finale of Symphony n.1 at Performance Space 122 on Monday night, but it was mostly to fend off dozens of careering soccer balls. Part of Performa 09, the performance art biennial, the piece was a collaboration between the Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson and Alterazioni Video, an Italian collective. Mr. Kjartansson was present only on video while he continues to represent Iceland in an extended painting performance at the Venice Biennale. The Alterazionistas turned out to be five young men wearing tuxedoes of erratic fit.

title: Guns, Butter or Both? Debating Troops vs. Development in Afghanistan
description: Overview | What actions can help mend and secure the situation in the war-torn nation of Afghanistan? In this lesson, students consider a proposal to build more schools in Afghanistan rather than sending more troops to secure the struggling nation, then conduct research and present their policy recommendations in a debate.

title: Quick Enough to Swat a Bat
description: How quick is Spurs guard Manu Ginobili? Well, now we know hes quick enough to swat a bat out of midair. On Saturday night the Spurs-Kings game had just been delayed for the second time because of a bat swooping across the floor when Ginobili slapped the bat out of midair, picked it up and handed it to an arena worker for disposal. The video of the incident has become an Internet hit and PETA weighed in with its displeasure.

title: Americas Cup Morass to Be Continued
description: For die-hards still closely monitoring the state of the Americas Cup, it promises to be another argumentative week, with the latest appeal about to be filed and the defender and the challenger headed back to New York State Supreme Court on Wednesday.

title: Gas Station to Home
description: Juerg Judin, an art dealer and collector, spent three years renovating this former midcentury gas station in the Schneberg district in Berlin.

title: Bloomberg Wins 3rd Term as Mayor in Unexpectedly Close Race
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pulled out a narrow re-election victory on Tuesday, as voters angry over his maneuver to undo the citys term limits law and his extravagant campaign spending provided an unexpected lift to his vastly underfinanced challenger, William C. Thompson Jr.

title: Booking Hotels for Less
description: Travelers had their own ideas for booking the cheapest hotel room, based on comments to Sundays Practical Traveler column, which tested four booking methods across a range of hotels in New York City.

title: End to a Fight Over Skype May Be Near
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The bitter battle over the future of the Internet calling service Skype appears to be nearing an end.

title: Disneys Green Initiative Takes Another Step
description: From the image-burnishment department: Trumpeting the benefit to gorillas in Africa and North American songbirds  not to mention Andean spectacled bear and yellow-tailed woolly monkey in Peru  Disney on Tuesday said it would pump $7 million into forest-protection projects in the Amazon, the Congo River Basin and the United States.

title: Did the Crisis Change Anything?
description: Economic growth may have returned this past quarter, but at a small conference at the Barclays office in Midtown Manhattan this morning, Aaron Gurwitz, the managing director of the banks investment and product office, said investors had not gotten over the havoc wreaked by the financial crisis last fall.

title: The Original Economics Hip-Hop Hero
description: Move over, Russ Roberts. The first economist hip-hop hero was Alexander Hamilton, former Treasury secretary.

title: BPA in Canned Food
description: Heres Naomi Starkman on Civil Eats, reporting on findings by Consumer Reports (original story here, subscription required) about BPA in canned goods. Definitely not good news for anyone, even those of us who make minimal use of same. But for the moment, it appears were looking at boxed tomatoes. (And the word organic apparently buys you no protection here.)

title: Election Day 2009
description: Scenes from polling places and last-minute campaign stops around the country.

title: Gemischter Satz
description: In my column in Wednesdays newspaper, Ive written about some gorgeous Austrian wines that are newly available in the United States. What makes these wines so unusual? They come from vineyards within the city limits of Vienna.

title: Gallinari Rests His Arms in Knicks First Victory of the Season
description: If the N.B.A. season were to end today, the Knicks would have one victory to be proud of  a 117 to 111 win over the Hornets on Monday behind David Lees 28 points and Al Harringtons 24, not to mention Larry Hughess cool 20. Lucky for New York the team has 78 more games to improve its win total. And Danilo Gallinari will have plenty of time to bolster his already robust long-range stats.

title: In Berlin, a Renovated Gas Station
description: Berlin

title: Merkel Marks Wall Anniversary
description: WASHINGTON Angela Merkel, who rose from the ruins of the Communist East to serve as chancellor of a united Germany, the most populous country in Western Europe, paid tribute to American support for her country in an address to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday, and offered America some support of her own in the effort to deny todays Iran a nuclear bomb.

title: Properties for $1.1 Million
description: A bungalow near Minneapolis, a house in Indianapolis and a hacienda-style house in Spicewood, Tex.

title: Short-Term Fixes Sought in Mideast
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco  For the last seven months, the Obama administration has labored in vain to bring the Israelis and the Palestinians together, pushing for a loose quid pro quo under which Israel would freeze construction of Jewish settlements while its Arab neighbors undertook diplomatic steps to bolster Israels confidence in its security.

title: Disney Invests In Saving Forests
description: Post updated, 11/3, 8:11 p.m.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) Jittery companies stash cash.

title: Despite Buffett Bid, More Rail Deals Seem Unlikely
description: Warren E. Buffetts $26 billion deal for Burlington Northern Santa Fe helped bolster railroad stocks on Tuesday, partly as investors consider the possibility of similar deals to come. But analysts seem to agree that the chances of another huge railroad buyout remain pretty low.

title: The Influence of Claude Lvi-Strauss
description: As my colleague Edward Rothstein writes in his obituary of Claude Lvi-Strauss, whose death at the age of 100 was announced on Tuesday, the great anthropologist was a profound influence even on his critics. One of the many French thinkers who felt the impact of his books was the sociologist Pierre Bourdieu, who explained in the television interview excerpted below that he had read the works of Mr. Lvi-Strauss as a sort of practical anti-racist manifesto.

title: BlogTalk: Its All Over But the Counting
description: In the world of political blogs, todays most important election is the one being played out in New Yorks 23rd Congressional District. Its probably no exaggeration to say that this is the race that belongs to the blogs and to the Internet more than any other taking place around the country today.

title: What You Get for ... $1.1 Million
description: EDINA, MINN.

title: Speedskaters Get Unlikely Hero: Stephen Colbert
description: Into U.S. Speedskatings bleak financial picture, a hero appeared from out of the blue. About a week ago, Stephen Colbert, host of Comedy Centrals Colbert Report, read about the team losing its major sponsor when the Dutch bank DSB went bankrupt. That left a $300,000 hole in U.S. Speedskatings budget just a few months before the Olympics.

title: Bleak News for Colleges, Too
description: While parents may be depressed by the news that 58 colleges now charge more than $50,000 a year, the news isnt much better for the colleges themselves.

title: Insider to Lead Los Angeles Police
description: LOS ANGELES  Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa on Tuesday named Deputy Chief Charlie Beck, a savvy insider and a respected veteran of the Los Angeles Police Department, as the successor to the departing chief of police, William J. Bratton.

title: Obama Puts Spotlight on Education Grants
description: The White House intends to use the first anniversary of President Obamas election to showcase his education agenda.

title: Toyota Acceleration Problem Is Still Unresolved
description: Toyota said on Tuesday that a press release it issued on Monday was not intended to give the impression that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration had cleared 3.8 million of its vehicles of having an unintended acceleration defect.

title: Weekend Vaccination Clinics Begin Saturday
description: Beginning Saturday, middle and high school students can receive free swine flu vaccinations at weekend clinics throughout the city, health department officials said on Tuesday.

title: Looking Beyond the City for Growth
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y.  Among supermarkets, Fairway Market, the popular Manhattan-based food emporium, is a destination retailer.

title: Two Actors, Many Guises and a Skewed Greek Play
description: Love Child, which Primary Stages opened at the 59E59 Theaters in October 2008, has returned to Off Broadway. It opened on Saturday night at New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton; (212) 239-6200. Following are excerpts from Neil Genzlinger's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 30, 2008.

title: Is Al Gore Getting Rich Off of the Green Movement?
description: Former Vice-President Al Gore is both an advocate of measures to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and a prominent investor in green technology. In his role as a partner at Silicon Valley venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, Mr. Gore is in a position to hear from entrepreneurs coming up with ideas to solve the very issues that he has helped to identify.

title: Dream On | Sarah Silverman Meets Carl Jung
description: In 1914, after falling out of favor with Freud, C.J. Jung lost his mind. Some scholars say he lost it by design, cultivating a psychic crisis to plumb the depths of his unconscious. The Red Book, an illustrated manual of the Swiss shrinks inner world, is the product of all that plumbing.

title: Analyst: Insurers Neednt Fear Public Option
description: Maybe the insurance companies have less to fear from a government-run health plan than they think.

title: Buffetts Record of Buying Railroad Stocks
description: Warren E. Buffetts investments in railroads are relatively recent. In fact, it was not until 2006 that Mr. Buffetts holding company, Berkshire Hathaway, began building a stake in the industry. Despite the economic downturn, Mr. Buffett continued to build his position in many of the major railroads in the United States  concentrating most of his investment in Burlington Northern Santa Fe, which he agreed to acquired fully on Tuesday for $26 billion in cash and stock.

title: Gender Identity in Kids
description: The magazine Time Out Kids this month is all about sex and your children. Called A Comprehensive Guide for Progressive Sex Ed for Kids 12 and Under, it starts with the assumption that we all want to raise children who will be so comfortable with their sexuality that they wont need how-to-guides like this one.

title: M-16 vs. AK-47: Iraqi Viewpoints
description: Baghdad: To get another perspective on the debate about the reliability of the American militarys M-16 assault rifle, we asked some Iraqi soldiers in Baghdad. They have recently been issued M-16s to replace their old AK-47s.

title: Green Bean Salad With Chickpeas and Mushrooms
description: A far cry from cafeteria-style three-bean salad, this fresh, lively dish is a mixture of crunch and softness, bright colors and earth tones.

title: Senator Schumers Fix for Freecreditreport.com
description: In my article today about Freecreditreport.com and its credit monitoring service, I told of how the Federal Trade Commission had been trying for years to get the company to improve its disclosures. The commission (and, it turns out, many New York Times readers who commented on the article) believe that the company doesnt make it clear enough that before you get your free credit report from the site, you first have to sign up for the monitoring service at $14.95 a month.

title: Redgrave Uncorsets a Relative Long Gone
description: Lynn Redgrave explores the life of her maternal grandmother through the prism of her own in her reflective new solo show, Nightingale, which opened Tuesday night at City Center, courtesy of Manhattan Theater Club. Sound cozy? Well, any expectations that this will be a sentimental journey should immediately be deferred.

title: Theme Parks Confront Flu Jitters
description: FOR many Americans, the fear of swine flu has made everyday acts like going to work, going to school or getting on a plane feel fraught with danger  even more so since President Obama recently declared swine flu a national emergency.

title: Eloise Moves to the New York Public Library
description: Eloise, one of the famous residents of the Plaza Hotel, is finding a new home in the New York Public Library.

title: Making a Yankees Fan: It Was All About Location
description: We invited readers to share their stories of how they became fans of the Yankees or the Phillies, and we will highlight entries as the World Series continues. Below, Jim Norchi, 61, of Pittsfield, Mass., writes that the Yankees home was his home, too.

title: Chair for Sale: Runs Well, Low Miles
description: The bid on the famous DWI Recliner from Proctor, Minn., was up to $6,300 Tuesday afternoon, with two days left to the eBay auction.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Nov. 3
description: Todays show opens with the tangled mess of a deadly train crash in Pakistan (Slide 1). In neighboring Afghanistan, American troops rushed for cover in the Pech Valley of Kunar Province amid an ambush by Taliban fighters (Slides 2 and 3). Back in the United States, public officials joined their constituents at the polls in New York (Slides 10 and 11), New Jersey (Slide 12) and elsewhere. And we end the presentation with the puzzling case of hair loss among two bears at a zoo in Germany (Slide 14).

title: AT&T Declares Color War on Verizon
description: AT&T, the giant company with $124 billion in annual sales, has filed a federal lawsuit against its rival, Verizon. The issue: coloring, of the sort that you do in kindergarten.

title: Irans Leader Faults U.S. Arrogance in Nuclear Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, lashed out at the United States in a speech on Tuesday, criticizing what he called an arrogant American attitude toward nuclear talks and saying the Obama administration had not followed through on its promises of change.

title: What It Took to Sell a Book
description: My colleague Dwight Garner kicked off this blog two and a half years ago with a slide show of advertisements that hed discovered in old copies of the Book Review. After that, his posts on vintage book ads became a semi-regular feature in Paper Cuts. And today his book on the subject hits stores: Read Me: A Century of Classic American Book Advertisements.

title: Wall Street Journal to Add a New York Report
description: The Wall Street Journal plans to assemble a local news staff in New York, continuing to expand beyond its historic focus on business news by adding traditional city desk beats like courthouses, City Hall and the state capital.

title: Submit Questions for A.C. Milans Clarence Seedorf
description: After a difficult start to the season, A.C. Milan has begun to climb the Italian Serie A table and earn impressive results in Europe, restoring the faith of the Rossoneri supporters and the confidence of the players.

title: Radovan Karadzics Defense, the First Draft
description: On Tuesday in The Hague, my colleague Marlise Simons reports, the wartime leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, finally appeared at his trial  but only to argue once again that he needed more time to prepare his defense against a list of grave charges, including genocide.

title: For Judges Standing By, a Quiet Election Day
description: There were plenty of people in the Manhattan training office of the New York City Board of Elections. There was lots of chatting and reading of newspapers and eating of chips and playing of Scrabble.

title: Q&A: Napa and Sonoma in December
description: Q.

title: On Our Radar
description: 1.) Al Gores climate choice.

title: At the National Trust
description: Richard Moe, the president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, is stepping down after 17 years in the post, the trust announced on Tuesday. Mr. Moe, 72, said he would stay on until a successor was named, which he expects will be by spring. During his tenure, the trust helped prevent Disney from building a theme park in the historic Northern Piedmont region of Virginia; championed the restoration of Lincolns cottage in Washington; encouraged the purchase at auction of the threatened Farnsworth House by Mies van der Rohe in Plano, Ill.; and focused on preserving the Gulf Coast after Hurricane Katrina. I think we broadened the mission here significantly, Mr. Moe said in a telephone interview, adding, Preservation is much more on the American agenda than it was several decades ago.

title: World Series Is Winner
description: Game 5 of the World Series led Fox to a first-place finish on Monday night but ABC was a close second. Although Nielsens final ratings for the live baseball broadcast were not immediately available, preliminary estimates show it drew similar numbers as Saturdays game, which earned 15.4 million viewers when final ratings were released. On ABC, a two-hour episode of Dancing With the Stars garnered an average of 16.2 million viewers, followed by Castle (9.7 million). CBS was third, drawing its largest audiences with the comedies Two and a Half Men (13.6 million) and The Big Bang Theory (12.7 million). NBC was fourth.

title: A Composer Is Avenged
description: Peter Maxwell Davies, the British composer who holds the title of master of the queens music, said that he was delighted after his former manager was sentenced to 18 months in prison for defrauding him of more than $800,000, The Times of London reported. Michael Arnold, who managed Mr. Daviess business affairs for more than 30 years, was arrested in 2007 and charged in October 2008 with false accounting; he admitted last year to having stolen the money. Mr. Davies, who has been honored this year with a global series of concerts marking his 75th birthday, said that he had stopped composing for a few weeks and had to borrow money from friends after learning of the fraud. On Monday, after the sentence was announced, he said he was glad the episode was over, adding: I may even set it all to music. Who knows? That would be the ultimate revenge.

title: More Cat-And-Mouse in the Book Price Wars
description: The online price war that broke out last month among Wal-Mart, Amazon and Target took a new turn on Tuesday with Wal-Mart continuing to play the penny game. At first, Amazon appeared to be the low-price player when it extended its $9 price tag to three hardcover books that were officially released Nov. 3. Amazon had originally offered that price in response to price-cutting by Wal-Mart on its Web site for preorders of 10 titles that included the three that were released Tuesday: Ford County by John Grisham, The Lacuna by Barbara Kingsolver and Kindred in Death by J. D. Robb. As of Tuesday morning, Amazon still had those titles priced at $9 while Wal-Mart, which had offered them on preorder at $8.98, and Target, which had offered preorders for $8.99, had raised their prices. At Walmart.com, for example, Ford County was selling for $12, while The Lacuna was $13.50. At Target.com, The Lacuna was on sale for $18.89 and Kindred in Death was $17. But by late morning, Amazon had raised its prices  The Lacuna and Kindred in Death, for example, were offered for $13.50  while Walmart.com had cut them again. All three novels that went on sale Tuesday were on sale at Walmart.com for $8.99, but by the afternoon, Walmart.com had raised its prices to just one penny lower than the price for the three titles on Amazon. In an e-mailed statement, a spokeswoman for Walmart.com said that it would continue to adjust our pricing accordingly and as needed on these books.

title: Arguments on Polanski Scheduled in California
description: A California appeals court in Los Angeles has scheduled oral arguments for Dec. 10 in its review of Roman Polanskis three-decade-old sex-abuse case. Mr. Polanski and his lawyers have been asking the court to clear the way for consideration of claims that his case was tainted by judicial and prosecutorial misconduct, even though he has been a fugitive since 1978. Prosecutors have argued that Mr. Polanski, because of his fugitive status, has no standing to challenge his conviction. Mr. Polanski remains under arrest in Switzerland awaiting possible extradition to face sentencing in the United States. The appeals court could clear the way for a review of misconduct in the case, or could stand aside while the authorities here await his return.

title: Robots for Adoption
description: Someday, as the movie and television series predicts, the Terminator robots, above, will become powerful enough to reduce the world to a pile of scrap metal and ash. But for now, they just need new owners. Variety reported that the Halcyon Company, which owns the rights to the Terminator movies and other related assets, plans to sell the franchise at an auction in January as it goes through bankruptcy. When Halcyon purchased the Terminator property for $30 million in 2007, it became the latest in a series of owners that previously included the producer Gale Anne Hurd and the production company Carolco, now defunct. The most recent entry in the film series, Terminator: Salvation, grossed $369 million worldwide on a budget of $200 million. The companys founders, Derek Anderson and Victor Kubicek, told a bankruptcy court that the Terminator franchise was worth $70 million.

title: Presidents Arts Group Names 25 Members
description: An eclectic roster of artists and entertainment industry figures were named to the Presidents Committee on the Arts and Humanities, the White House announced on Monday evening. Among the 25 committee members selected by President Obama were the talent agent Bryan Lourd, managing director and co-chairman of Creative Artists Agency; the actors Sarah Jessica Parker (top right) and Edward Norton; the cellist Yo-Yo Ma (top left); and Teresa Heinz Kerry, the philanthropist and wife of Senator John Kerry. Also named were the actors Kerry Washington, Forest Whitaker and Alfre Woodard; the director George C. Wolfe (above right); Anna Wintour (above left) of Vogue; Damian Woetzel, the former New York City Ballet dancer; and the architect Thom Mayne.

title: Harlem Theater Founders to Resign
description: Alfred Preisser and Christopher McElroen, who founded the Classical Theater of Harlem and made it a home for the likes of Samuel Beckett, Euripides, Shakespeare and Melvin Van Peebles, will leave that Off Broadway theater company this month. In a news release, Mr. Preisser, who served as its artistic director, and Mr. McElroen, who has been its executive director, said that they created the Classical Theater of Harlem in 1999 to nurture a new, young, and culturally diverse theater audience.

title: What Cole Hamels Really Meant
description: It has become another knock on Cole Hamels, the Phillies beleaguered left-hander who won the World Series most valuable player award last fall and has struggled this postseason. After Game 3, Hamels said, I cant wait for it to end. Its been mentally draining. And all sorts of people  including, perhaps, his teammate Brett Myers  have interpreted that as Hamels quitting on the season.

title: Trying to Find Meaning in a Bolt From the Blue
description: In the wispy documentary Act of God, survivors of lightning strikes find metaphysical meaning in meteorological phenomena. The writer Paul Auster begs to differ.

title: Performa 09 | Alterazioni Video and Ragnar Kjartansson
description: Adventurous audiences know to expect some intentionally elusive, off-kilter fare from Performa, the three-week biennial currently in its third edition in New York. But the Italian collective of Alterazioni Video and Ragnar Kjartansson offered something at least nominally classifiable in its free performance for a packed audience at Performance Space 122 on Monday evening: a concert. Specifically, Symphony n. 1, billed as a live and multimedia piece based on joy, infinite profound joy.

title: More Tech for Older People
description: Last Thursdays print and online article on tech solutions for older adults struck a chord with many readers, a number of whom wrote that the suggestions proved helpful in their quest to get their parents connected to the Internet.

title: A Year After Obamas Election, How Do You Feel?
description: One year ago, we asked NYTimes.com readers for a single word to describe their mood about the presidential election. The response was overwhelming (73,400 words) and varied widely, with hopeful and anxious as the top choices.

title: Million Dollar Quartet to Move Into the Nederlander
description: The next tenant for Broadways Nederlander Theater was announced late Tuesday afternoon: The new musical Million Dollar Quartet, based on a 1956 recording session that brought together Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins, and Elvis Presley.

title: One Year In
description: Voters are voting today, and most pundits are punditing about what the races mean, especially what the big three  in New Jersey, Virginia and upstate New York  will say about Obama.

title: A Return That Came Sooner, Not Later
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra seems to be conducting a series of experiments to determine whether absence does, in fact, make the heart grow fonder. Its own music director, James Levine, is said to be testing the patience of the Boston audience with his particular brand of new-music programming, but this season he has been sidelined after surgery for a herniated disc. How fond his audience will be when he returns remains to be seen. But in the meantime, the orchestra ran a second, slightly more complicated test on Monday evening, when it performed at Carnegie Hall with Lorin Maazel on the podium.

title: Hitching a Star to the Stardom of Cole Porter
description: Forty-five years after his death, Cole Porter has never truly left town. His songs are a staple of Manhattans cabaret scene: one performer finished a tribute at the Algonquin last month, while two others just opened shows that prominently feature his work.

title: Achy, Breaky Heart but a Stiff Upper Lip
description: This is a song for anyone with a broken heart, Charlie Fink sang to start the set by his band, Noah and the Whale, at the Mercury Lounge on Monday. It was the first of three nights at the club for this English band. His voice was calm, and so was the music, a Celtic-tinged ballad with fingerpicking and fiddle. But it was the outward calm of depression, not of serenity.

title: Creating Dialogue From Body Language
description: In La Danse: The Paris Opera Ballet, his 36th documentary in more than 40 years, Frederick Wiseman takes his camera into the stately and elegant Palais Garnier in Paris, observing rehearsals, staff meetings and, finally, performances of seven dances, including classics like The Nutcracker and spiky new work by younger choreographers. To say that the film, sumptuous in its length and graceful in its rhythm, is a feast for ballet lovers is to state the obvious and also to sell Mr. Wisemans achievement a bit short. Yes, this is one of the finest dance films ever made, but theres more to it than that.

title: Wonders of Science at the Golden Gate
description: SAN FRANCISCO  What should we expect from a science museum? Do we want to be carefully tutored in a scientific discipline? Do we seek to be entertained in a vaguely enlightening way? Do we hope to be urged to adopt particular policies or practices? My own desire is simpler than any of these, though far less often encountered. I hope for wonder.

title: Religions Role in the Climate Challenge
description: A remarkable conclave of leading figures from nine of the worlds major religions is under way at Windsor Castle in Britain, under the auspices of Prince Philip and the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon. Called Many Heavens, One Earth, the meeting is intended to generate commitments for actions by religious organizations, congregants and countries that could reduce emissions of greenhouse gases or otherwise limit the human impact on the environment.

title: Wheres the Agency? Freemans Shop Is No More
description: Cliff Freeman & Partners, one of the most successful New York advertising agencies of the 1980s and 1990s, is no more.

title: G.M. Decides to Keep Opel Instead of Selling It
description: Update | 5:57 p.m. The new board of General Motors reversed course late Tuesday afternoon on the anticipated sale of the Opel division in Europe and decided that G.M. would retain the business and restructure Opel itself.

title: G.M. Decides to Keep Opel, Its European Unit
description: DETROIT  The new board of General Motors reversed course Tuesday on the planned sale of its Opel division in Europe and decided that G.M. would retain and reorganize the business itself.

title: G.M. to Retain Opel
description: Update | 6:34 p.m.  General Motors has confirmed that it will keep Opel and restructure the business itself, reports The Timess Bill Vlasic. This was deemed to be the most stable and least costly approach for securing Opel/Vauxhalls long-term future, Fritz Henderson, G.M.s chief executive, said in a statement issued Tuesday evening.

title: House Passes Gaza Measure After Dueling Critiques
description: The House on Tuesday approved a nonbinding resolution rebuking a United Nations report on last winters conflict in Gaza, after architects of both the U.N. report and the House resolution recently criticized the others work as inaccurate.

title: Its Nearly a Wrap for Hollywood Power Lunches at Orso
description: LOS ANGELES  Late last week the buzz around the tables at Orso, a film industry hangout since it opened here 20 years ago, was about, of all things, the imminent demise of Orso.

title: Hard Drive Full? Archive Some Photos
description: The My Pictures folder on my Mac notebook holds a whopping 47.39 gigabytes of images. Its nice to have so many photos of people, places and trips  except for the unfortunate fact that they consume about one quarter of my total hard drive space. And I am running very short on storage these days.

title: A White House Chef Who Wears Two Hats
description: WASHINGTON

title: App of the Week: 1Casts News-Video Aggregator
description: Getting TV news on your phone is a tricky business, as most mobile broadcastrs require a Wi-Fi connection. Thats not really mobile TV, thats hot spot TV.

title: A Renovation in Krakow That Evokes Its History
description: A duplex apartment in Krakow's city center is on the market for 1.4 million Polish zloty ($478,000).

title: House Hunting in ... Krakow, Poland
description: A DUPLEX APARTMENT IN KRAKOWS CITY CENTER

title: Iraq Signs Contract to Develop Oil Field
description: BAGHDAD  Iraq formally signed a contract with a consortium of foreign oil companies Tuesday to develop its largest oil field.

title: Wartime Chinas Elegant Enigma
description: The only thing Oriental about me, Soong Mei-ling once wrote, is my face.

title: Chrysler May Put On a New Badge
description: Chrysler is scheduled to detail its five-year sales plan Wednesday during a six-hour conference call with reporters. (Will bathroom breaks be permitted?) The automaker is getting ready to reinvent itself with a fresh look, and the first tweak could come in the form of a sleek new logo.

title: Democrats Near Deal on Abortion Coverage
description: Struggling to finish their big health care legislation, House Democratic leaders signaled Tuesday that they were prepared to make several changes to the bill to satisfy abortion opponents, including many Democrats, who had threatened to block it.

title: Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin to Host the Oscars
description: There will be dual hosts at the upcoming Academy Awards. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences just announced that Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin will co-host the event.

title: Someones in the Kitchen With Michelle: The Secret Ingredient Is Politics
description: WASHINGTON

title: Lower Wine Prices and a New Chef for Cru
description: Cru is lowering prices on its famous wine list by 30 percent across the board, said Robert Bohr, a partner in the restaurant. The prices will be cut by the end the week. And in two weeks the restaurant will have a menu from its new chef, Todd Macdonald.

title: 3 Yemeni Officials, Along With Guards, Killed in Ambush
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Gunmen ambushed a government motorcade in the eastern Yemeni province of Hadramawt on Tuesday, killing three top provincial officials and three guards in an attack that had all the hallmarks of Al Qaedas regional arm.

title: Time Inc. Layoffs Begin at Sports Illustrated
description: Layoffs have begun at Time Inc. Approximately 15 to 20 sales and marketing employees were dismissed from Time Inc.s news group tonight, largely from Sports Illustrated, according to a Time Inc. executive who asked not to be named as the company had not given authorization to discuss the matter.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,347 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

title: Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin to Host the Oscars
description: There will be dual hosts at the next Academy Awards. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences just announced that Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin will co-host the event.

title: Live Blogging Election Night
description: The Caucus will be keeping tabs on election developments across the country tonight. Refresh the page often for the latest updates.

title: Postcards From the Edge: Tocquevilles Letters Home
description: Alexis de Tocqueville, the author of the landmark Democracy in America, was in many ways a typical Frenchman. Practically the minute he got off the boat, in Newport, R.I., on May 9, 1831, he started making generalizations: the only thing Americans really care about is making money. American women are good homemakers but boring wives. Southern men care more about honor than Northerners do. Americans drink no wine but stuff themselves with stupefying amounts of food.

title: Tuesdays News of Hockey, 11/3/09: Flames in H1N1 Vaccination Kerfuffle
description: Controversy flares in Alberta after Ken King, president of the Calgary Flames, reveals that the teams players and their families received swine flu vaccinations at an undisclosed location on Friday through the intercession of the provinces health services board. The news comes as residents across Alberta have had to wait in lines or were unable to get H1N1 vaccination shots.

title: Same Street, Different World: Sesame Turns 40
description: IT is almost too perfect that the first African-American president of the United States was elected in time for the 40th anniversary of Sesame Street. The world is finally beginning to look the way that the PBS show always made it out to be.

title: Cookbooks as Edible Adventures
description: LONG before Internet avatars, home cooks knew the way to self-transformation: cookbooks. Bonding with a new one means assuming a new identity, if only for a week or two.

title: China Approves Disney Theme Park in Shanghai
description: LOS ANGELES  After a courtship of about 20 years, the Walt Disney Company has won approval from the central government of China to build a Disneyland-style theme park in Shanghai, Robert A. Iger, Disneys chief executive, said Tuesday.

title: The Last Empress
description: Chapter 1

title: Groups Press U.S. and China on Carbon
description: BEIJING  Three prominent American research organizations that are pushing for greater cooperation between the Obama administration and China on the issue of climate change say the two governments should make a priority of supporting the use of carbon capture technology and the creation of a market for carbon.

title: Africas Diamond Trade Under Scrutiny
description: JOHANNESBURG  The viability of an effort endorsed by the United Nations to halt the trading of the so-called blood diamonds that have fueled conflicts across Africa is on the line this week, and the test case is Zimbabwe.

title: Student, 20, Jumps to His Death at N.Y.U.
description: A 20-year old student at New York University apparently took his own life on Tuesday morning, reviving concerns about the high number of suicides there in recent years.

title: Fraud Accusations Against Florida Lawyer Set Off a Race to Return His Donations
description: MIAMI  Scott Rothstein relished his flashy persona  the spiky hair, the Ferrari, the multi-million-dollar mansion. He was Bronx raised, Fort Lauderdale rich, and the politicians, charities and businesses that accepted his money rarely asked where it came from.

title: Lloyds and Royal Bank of Scotland Given More Aid
description: LONDON  A year after the financial crisis nearly upended the British banking industry, two major lenders here were thrown a second financial lifeline by the government on Tuesday and ordered to shrink their businesses.

title: An Obama Relative Living in China Tells of His Own Journey of Self-Discovery
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Maybe it is the easy smile. Or perhaps the eyes, at once self-assured and searching. When Mark Okoth Obama Ndesandjo walks into the room, the similarities with President Obama, with whom he shares a father, are unmistakable if hard to pinpoint.

title: New York City Goes to the Polls
description: The Times's Michael Powell takes a look at some of the issues motivating residents to vote.

title: At Viacom, Profit Rises Primarily on Cutbacks
description: Viacom, the media company that controls MTV and Paramount Pictures, said its profit rose in the third quarter, but it was a performance achieved through cutting costs and shedding workers.

title: Chinese Trial Reveals Vast Web of Corruption
description: CHONGQING, China  Wen Qiang had a fondness for Louis Vuitton belts, fossilized dinosaur eggs and B-list pop stars. For a public employee in charge of the local judiciary, he also had a lot of money: nearly $3 million that investigators found buried beneath a fish pond.

title: Health Bills Aim a Light on Doctors Conflicts
description: As part of the health care overhaul under consideration by Congress, lawmakers have included so-called sunshine provisions intended to shed light on the financial relationships between the medical industry and doctors.

title: Health Care Debate Focuses on Legal Immigrants
description: The debate over health care for illegal immigrants continues to percolate in Congress despite the Obama administrations efforts to put it to rest, with lawmakers in both houses also wrangling over how much coverage to provide for immigrants who have settled in the country legally.

title: Perhaps Some Pastries With Your Baubles? This Madison Avenue Boutique Can Help
description: Franois Payard, who closed his cafe, ptisserie and bistro on the Upper East Side in June, has taken his talents to Mauboussin, the Parisian jewelry boutique on Madison Avenue, where he has opened a chocolate cafe on the fourth floor.

title: Drop Those Chopsticks! Sushi Is Finger Food, He Says
description: Using chopsticks to eat sushi? Wrong, wrong, wrong, says Trevor Corson, the author of The Story of Sushi (originally published as The Zen of Fish, Harper Perennial, 2008). Mr. Corson, standing above, who calls himself a sushi concierge, is holding classes at Jewel Bako in the East Village to show Americans how to navigate the sushi bar as Japanese connoisseurs do.

title: Off the Menu
description: Open Now

title: Have a Sip of Seasonal Fruit
description: Hotlips Sodas from the Pacific Northwest do not make good for you promises, as some sodas do these days. They are made from fruit harvested in season and are lightly carbonated, sweetened with cane sugar and tarted up with a little organic lemon juice. Some flavors have a little murky fruit pulp in them.

title: House Bill Would Assure Workers Paid Sick Days
description: In an effort to rein in the spread of the H1N1 flu, Representative George Miller, the chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, introduced legislation on Tuesday that would guarantee five paid sick days for workers sent home by their employers with a contagious illness.

title: Recipe: Butternut Squash and Roasted Apple Soup
description: Adapted from Sam Kass

title: The Daddy of All Rivals: Martinez Is Back
description: Apparently it is not just my own hyper sense of the bizarre that is stimulated by the presence of Petey.

title: Through a Glass Less Darkly
description: In the fall of 1982, with a long recession ending but the unemployment rate heading toward 10 percent, The New York Times ran an article titled The Recovery That Wont Start.

title: Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin to Host the Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  The coming Oscar show will have a pair of hosts who are not so much matched as deliberately mismatched: Steve Martin, the versatile comic, and Alec Baldwin, a straight man who sometimes reaches for a laugh.

title: Pakistanis Seek Blame for Bombing
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  It has been a week since the bomb exploded at the womens market here, but people still talk about the images of its aftermath: womens bodies, naked and broken. A hand with hennaed nails. An arm still wearing bracelets.

title: What to Make of a Big Deal Gone Sour
description: Early Tuesday, Suzanne Wasserman walked into the polling place on 18th Street at First Avenue in Manhattan, then voted in a flash, a straight Democratic ticket. And yes, she knew that it would take a colossal upset for her candidate, William C. Thompson Jr., to beat Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Buffetts Bet on Trains
description: Updated, Nov. 4, 11:25 a.m. | Joining our discussion this morning are: T.J. Stiles, a biographer of Cornelius Vanderbilt; Jean Strouse, author of Morgan, American Financier; and Charles R. Morris, a former banker and the author of The Sages: Warren Buffett, George Soros, Paul Volcker and the Maelstrom of Markets.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian
description: JOAQUIN BACA has cooked Asian-flavored noodles with David Chang at the Momofuku restaurants and has lived in the Philippines, Bolivia and Uruguay. But his roots are Texan, and he has never lost his touch with American comfort food: barbecued ribs, corn bread, chicken-fried steak.

title: Civil Rights Groups Push for Public Option
description: Correction| 6:13 p.m., Nov. 5 An earlier version of this article gave the wrong age for the Urban League. It has been corrected below.

title: Calendar
description: Fish Market as Art

title: The Ultimate Consolation Prize
description: Mickey Mantle was crying. When Bobby Richardson flashes back to how Bill Mazeroskis game-ending homer vaulted the Pittsburgh Pirates over the Yankees in the 1960 World Series, he remembers that Mantle wept. Richardson stared at his friend and teammate because he had never seen Mantle so distraught.

title: Iraq Swears by Bomb Detector U.S. Sees as Useless
description: BAGHDAD  Despite major bombings that have rattled the nation, and fears of rising violence as American troops withdraw, Iraqs security forces have been relying on a device to detect bombs and weapons that the United States military and technical experts say is useless.

title: Congress Poised to Keep Homebuyers Tax Credit
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate and House are poised to agree on a compromise measure to extend unemployment benefits that also would expand a popular $8,000 tax credit for homebuyers, despite a recent government report on extensive mistakes and suspected fraud in the program.

title: In the Shadow of Yankee Stadium, an Off Year
description: By all reckoning, this should be the moment Saeed Alawy was waiting for. His shop, Pin Stripe Collectibles, sits just beyond the right field wall of the new Yankee Stadium, where Game 6 of the World Series will be played Wednesday night.

title: Damon Proves Toughest Out by Hitting It Fair and Foul
description: Johnny Damon stood on second base with two outs in the ninth inning of Game 5 and told Phillies third baseman Pedro Feliz not to worry about him.

title: Sluggish Pace of Integration Still Echoes
description: The World Series between the Yankees and the Phillies has developed into an intricate matchup, with all sorts of revealing contrasts and surprises.

title: The Matter of Phillies Closer Is Reopened to Question
description: Philadelphia Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel has referred to Brad Lidge as our closer no fewer than 900 times over the last two months, even on days Lidge does not even leave the bullpen bench to warm up while Ryan Madson pitches in a save situation.

title: East River Commuter Ferry Service Could Be Halted, Again
description: For almost two years, city officials have extolled a proposal for a five-borough network of ferries, an ambitious plan that the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, said would make New York a shining example of urban sustainability for cities all over the world.

title: Buffett Bets Big on Railroads Future
description: Americas best-known investor, Warren E. Buffett, is making his biggest bet yet on the nations economic future by buying, of all things, a railroad.

title: The Earl Would Approve
description: LATELY, foods at the thrifty end of the dining spectrum have been reworked, renewed and sometimes completely reimagined: fried chicken, pizza and hamburgers have never tasted better.

title: Harry Carson on Concussions
description: Harry Carson, the Hall of Fame middle linebacker for the Giants, said he had about 10 concussions when he played for the team in the 1970s and 80s.

title: Flu Shots for Students Begin Saturday
description: Beginning Saturday, middle and high school students can receive free swine flu vaccinations at weekend clinics throughout the city, health department officials said on Tuesday.

title: A Pentagon Contract Revives Jobs at Oshkosh
description: OSHKOSH, Wis.  United States Patent No. 5,820,150, for a particular design of independent truck suspension, is just one of the dozens of patents the Oshkosh Corporation has filed in recent years. But as the military shifts its focus to Afghanistan from Iraq, that single invention is proving to be worth billions of dollars to the company and a potential lifesaver for American troops in Afghanistan.

title: Hop Off the Wheel and Taste Paris
description: LE RELAIS DE VENISE LENTRECTE is a mouthful of a restaurant that opened a few months ago in a canyon at Lexington Avenue and 52nd Street, convenient mostly to hotel guests and hamsters on the Midtown professional wheel. It has no real menu to speak of. There is only salad and steak frites. Some wine to drink and a dessert after. Women in French maid outfits serve the stuff as if they were characters in an early Preston Sturges film. And you know what? Its terrific.

title: Chief Factor in Mayors Race: Bloomberg Influence
description: The White House switchboard lit up with calls from Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs emissaries several weeks ago with a message that was polite but firm: The mayor is going to win re-election, they said. We think the president should stay out of the race.

title: Difficulties for Prosecutors in Trial of Sect Leader
description: ELDORADO, Tex.  A year and a half after the state authorities raided a fundamentalist Mormon ranch here, the first of a half-dozen leaders of the sect has gone on trial on charges that he had sex with an under-age girl who state officials assert was one of several wives assigned to him by church elders.

title: The Wild, the Innocent and the Springsteen Album Concerts
description: On tour this fall, Bruce Springsteen has been playing complete albums from his back catalog: for his shows last month bidding farewell to Giants Stadium, for example, he did Born to Run, Darkness on the Edge of Town and Born in the U.S.A. But thats not all. On Tuesday Mr. Springsteen announced on his Web site that this weekend at Madison Square Garden he will be running through The Wild, the Innocent and the E Street Shuffle (Saturdays show) and The River (Sunday) in their entirety, both for the first time.

title: Honduras: Vote Postponed on Deal to End Crisis
description: Congressional leaders decided Tuesday to delay a vote on an accord signed last week that would restore the ousted president, Manuel Zelaya, and end the countrys four-month-old crisis. The leaders decided not to call Congress out of recess to vote on the agreement and requested opinions on it from the Supreme Court and the attorney general. Foreign governments have said they will not recognize the presidential election on Nov. 29 unless Mr. Zelaya is reinstated first.

title: Toyota Pulls Out of Formula One
description: Update | 1:01 p.m.

title: Kraft Earns $826 Million but Cuts Its Sales Forecast
description: Kraft Foods, the nations largest food manufacturer, reported quarterly profits that beat analysts expectations on Thursday, but at the same time cut its forecast for full-year revenue growth.

title: G.O.P. Counters With a Health Plan of Its Own
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans have come up with an answer to Speaker Nancy Pelosi, drafting an alternative health care bill that would reward states for reducing the number of uninsured, limit damages in medical malpractice lawsuits and allow small businesses to band together and buy insurance exempt from most state regulation.

title: Outline of Republicans Health Care Vision
