description: A draft of health care legislation by Republicans in Congress would make these changes in the insurance market:

title: Zenyattas Chance to Dazzle in Cup Classic
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  Team Zenyatta got together the other night: the mares owners, Jerry and Ann Moss; her trainer, John Shirreffs, and his wife, Dottie, who manages the Mosses stables; and her rider, Mike Smith. They asked each other if they really wanted to do this, to throw their undefeated girl into the deepest end of the pool to take on the most accomplished boys in the thoroughbred world in the $5 million Breeders Cup Classic.

title: License to Wonder
description: In the wake of my column last week about how the faces you make when speaking different languages might affect your mood, several people wrote and accused me of speculating. I admit it! Indeed, I said as much in the piece.

title: No Walk in the Park: For Obama One Year Later, Its the Slog of Governance
description: WASHINGTON  For a president elevated to power on the back of history, the tears and euphoria of Grant Park feel like a thousand years ago. It has been just one year, of course, since Barack Obamas election, a year since that moment when supporters felt everything was possible amid lofty talk of remaking this nation and determined chants of Yes, we can.

title: Profile of Virginia Voters
description: Results of exit polls conducted Tuesday in the race for Virginia governor between R. Creigh Deeds and Robert F. McDonnell.

title: Profile of New York City Voters
description: Results of exit polls conducted Tuesday in the race for New York City mayor between Michael R. Bloomberg and William C. Thompson Jr.

title: Profile of New Jersey Voters
description: Results of exit polls conducted Tuesday in the race for New Jersey governor between Jon S. Corzine, Christopher J. Christie and Christopher J. Daggett.

title: Lottery Numbers
Record Seasonal Flu Shots Are Expected in U.S.
description: The United States will probably set a record for seasonal flu shots this winter, but there is continuing frustration over the slow rollout of swine flu shots, federal health officials said Tuesday.

title: Shes Your Lover Now
description: My review this week is of a newish French place on Lexington Avenue and 52nd Street called Le Relais de Venise LEntrecte. Its the first American outpost of a Paris institution (some would say tourist trap) that serves nothing but salad and steak frites. This is its great charm. The restaurant fights mightily against the tyranny of choice that so infects the world of restaurants in New York City. As David Carr  a media monster and Diners Journal consigliere  said in the place one night, leaning back in his chair and just getting started on the subject: There are zero conversational hideyholes in this menu. Im glad were friends and have something to talk about. Have you been to the restaurant? Do you want to go? Tell us what you think below. Keep it clean. There are children present.

title: A Vast Web of Crime
description: In the city of Chongqing, China, a mass public trial has exposed the unseemly relationship between gangsters, police officers and bureaucrats.

title: Foreboding Cartoons?
description: The arrangement of black squares in this grid is unique, which I like. It makes the solving experience feel fresher since the words interlock and flow in directions a bit different from the norm.

title: Democrats Fear: No Health Bill in 2009
description: Congressional Democrats and the White House seem increasingly nervous about the prospect that major health care legislation will not be completed by the end of this year.

title: Toyota Exits Formula One
description: From our colleagues at Formula One:

title: Illinois Curb on Minors Abortions Nears
description: CHICAGO  Illinois officials are expected to decide Wednesday when to begin enforcing a state law requiring doctors to notify a parent of anyone under 18 who seeks an abortion. The decision could prove to be a concluding chapter in the states debate, more than a quarter-century old, over parental notification.

title: For a Mens Body Lotion, a Rugged Messenger
description: IN a new television spot for Vaseline Men body and face lotion, Michael Strahan, the former New York Giants defensive end who stars on the Fox series Brothers, demonstrates a 15-minute workout in a hotel room, including push-ups and lateral jumps over rolled-up towels. Afterward, Mr. Strahan rubs lotion on his Popeye forearm.

title: European Puck: Is Foppa Headed to Russia?
description: Russian news outlets reported on Tuesday that Peter Forsberg, the 36-year-old Swedish superstar, was on the verge of signing with the K.H.L. champions Ak Bars Kazan, adding to the intrigue over which club in which country Forsberg would land as he continues his comeback from chronic foot and ankle problems.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The exit polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left election stations throughout New York City, New Jersey and Virginia on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission inspector general, H. David Kotz, into Bernard L. Madoffs decades-long Ponzi scheme erroneously included one former S.E.C. chairman on a list of ex-chairmen interviewed by Mr. Kotz as part of his inquiry. Although he interviewed Arthur Levitt, William Donaldson and Christopher Cox, he did not interview Harvey Pitt. The error was repeated in a picture caption with the continuation of the article.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a third-quarter expansion in the nations gross domestic product defined G.D.P. incorrectly. It is the governments broadest measure of total goods and services produced  not the broadest measure of the governments goods and services produced.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a decision by federal health officials to release the last of the national stockpile of liquid pediatric Tamiflu misstated the amount of time it would take the Indian company Cipla Ltd. to offer the United States a generic replacement. It is three to four months, not four to six weeks. (While Cipla has finished testing the powder used in capsules to ensure that the generic and brand-name versions are equivalent, its tests on the powder used in liquid suspensions are expected to take several months.)

title: In Virginia, McDonnell Ends Democrats Streak
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Robert F. McDonnell, a Republican and a former state attorney general, won a decisive victory in Virginias governors race Tuesday, a stark reversal of fortune for Democrats who have held control in Richmond for the past eight years.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Tuesday about Daryl Glenn and Jo Lynn Burks Play and Sing Robert Altmans Nashville, at the Metropolitan Room, misspelled the surname of a singer and songwriter who performed some of her own songs in the film Nashville. She is Ronee Blakley, not Blakely.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the success of the best-selling novel The Help, which included a comment from a co-owner of Rainy Day Books, an independent bookstore in Kansas, misidentified the town in which the store is located. It is Fairway, Kan., not Fairview.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about creationism and evolution in the Islamic world included an erroneous example for how views on these subjects might differ between countries with Shiite and Sunni majorities. The population in Iraq is majority Shiite, not Sunni, so that country is not a proper contrast with Iran, which also has a Shiite majority.

title: Pakistanis View Market Blast With Disbelief
description: Even for Peshawar, a city that has long been pummeled by violent attacks, the bombing in the Meena market last week felt different; the violence was aimed not at soldiers or the police, but at poor women and children.

title: Picked From a Lineup, on a Whiff of Evidence
description: HOUSTON  A dogs sniff helped put Curvis Bickham in jail for eight months. Now that the case against him has been dropped, he wants to tell the world that the investigative technique that justified his arrest smells to high heaven.

title: Corrections
description: The Second Opinion column on Tuesday, about new findings that raise questions about mammography, omitted part of the affiliation of Dr. Otis Brawley, who said the medical profession had overstated the benefits of cancer screening. He is chief medical officer of the American Cancer Society  not just the society.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday with an article about academics on Facebook misspelled the given name of a Princeton professor with 1,938 Facebook fans (at the time the article went to press). He is Cornel West, not Cornell.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Rivera in Familiar Postseason Position
description: Joe Girardi said Tuesday that Mariano Rivera would be available to pitch more than one inning of Game 6 on Wednesday, which could have the effect of shortening the game to 21 outs for the Yankees, considering how reliable Rivera normally is.

title: Tax Cuts and Recoveries
description: One big question about the 1983-84 economic boom (a boom I mention in my Wednesday column) is: Was it the tax cut?

title: From Abandoned Brewery to Piazza, Philly-Style
description: PHILADELPHIA  When Bart Blatstein, a local strip-mall developer, acquired an abandoned brewery a few miles from Center City nearly a decade ago, the artists who had gravitated to the surrounding area in search of cheap housing feared he would plop an unwanted big-box shopping center into their gritty Northern Liberties neighborhood.

title: Mayor Holds Onto Seat in Pittsburgh
description: Mayor Luke Ravenstahl of Pittsburgh won a resounding victory on Tuesday for his first full term.

title: Exit Polls and Exit, Corzine
description: America  or least a few pockets of it  went to the polls on Tuesday, yet the politician facing the greatest test wasnt on the ballot anywhere. So, did President Obama win or lose? Neither, according to a bunch of exit polls.

title: Some Sense on Defense Spending
description: Presidents, and those aspiring to be presidents, routinely promise to reform the defense procurement process. And defense contractors, their lobbyists and the military services routinely ensure that never happens.

title: Protection for Investors
description: Another day, another test of Congresss will to reform the financial system.

title: Driving Without English
description: Police officers giving drivers $204 tickets for not speaking English? It sounds like a rejected Monty Python sketch. Except the grim reality is that it has happened at least 39 times in Dallas since January 2007, according to The Dallas Morning News. At least six officers in several different patrol divisions wrote the tickets, each time citing a driver for violating a law that does not exist. All but one of the drivers were Hispanic.

title: Questions for a Trade Official
description: When Islam Siddiqui appears for his Senate confirmation, possibly as early as next week, it will be time for some tough questions.

title: The Lessons of the Good Teacher
description: To the Editor:

title: Nation-Building at Home: A Call for Sacrifice
description: To the Editor:

title: Christianity and Islam: An Egyptian View
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Are You Calling a Narcissist, Rush?
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Best Allies Money Can Buy
description: In 2003, I was on a trip to Iraq and had arranged an appointment in the Green Zone with a member of the then-Iraqi Governing Council. Security was tight. I was with my Iraqi translator, a middle-aged man who had once been a teacher. When we arrived at the council, after a long walk, I showed my ID to two young uniformed U.S. soldiers. They told me to wait, went inside and out came a man wearing civilian clothes, one of those fishing vests and an Australian bush hat.

title: A Job Too Big for One Man
description: IN the year since his election, as he has since he first appeared on the national stage, Barack Obama has embodied the fundamental paradoxes of race in America: that we live in a still racially fragmented society; that we share a public culture with an outsized black presence, but that in the privacy of homes and neighborhoods we are more segregated than in the Jim Crow era; that we worship more fervently than any other advanced nation, in churches and synagogues that define our separate ethnic identities and differences, to gods proclaiming the unity of mankind. Why are we this strange way? Is President Obama the ultimate expression of our peculiarities? Has he made a difference? Can he? Will he?

title: The Year of Living Postracially
description: ONE year ago today, we officially became a postracial society. Fifty-three percent of the voters opted for the candidate who would be the first president of African descent, and in doing so eradicated racism forever.

title: Menino Coasts to Fifth Term as Boston Mayor
description: BOSTON  Mayor Thomas M. Menino easily won an unprecedented fifth term on Tuesday, relying on his popularity to neutralize charges that the city needed a change.

title: Small Business Goes to Washington
Degas Pastel Is Highlight of a Tepid Christies Sale
description: French and Italian could be heard throughout Christies salesroom Tuesday night as the fall auction season began unsteadily: While there were some strong prices, there also expensive failures.

title: Riding the Rails at a High Price
description: What does Warren E. Buffett see in railroads? Berkshire Hathaway, his investment company, is paying a big premium for Burlington Northern Santa Fe. Mr. Buffett says he thinks the business of transporting goods around the country is ready to rebound. But investors may want to delay hitching a ride on his caboose.

title: Freedom From the Tyranny of Choice
description: Easy meals are what you want in this complicated time, right? Sam Sifton has one solution: Le Relais de Venise LEntrecte, an assault on the tyranny of choice, because it serves only a few things: salad, steak and fries. The beef is fine, he writes, the fries rate high on the crazy-good scale and the whole experience is a perfect midweek dinner with a friend. For more casual outings, visit the sandwich shops that Oliver Strand scouted out: Barros Luco for Chilean monsters like the beef empanada al horno; the Crosby Connection for classic New York monsters like the meatball hoagie; and the tiny Saltie in Williamsburg for outsize ambition. Run by three veterans of Marlow & Sons and Diner, its a high-achiever: the bread is baked in-house, the ice cream is made from scratch, and the sandwiches, like the vegetarian Clean Slate  quinoa and hummus with pickled vegetables, sauerkraut and yogurt in blistered naan  are culturally fearless.

title: Culinary History
description: Curious about the history of the New York chophouse? William Grimes, a former restaurant critic of The New York Times, breaks it down along with other tidbits like the oyster stalls and lobster palaces that were once dining mainstays in his new book, Appetite City: A Culinary History of New York. This vivid and vastly entertaining history, Dawn Drzal writes in her review, chronicles the citys transformation from a Dutch village at the edge of the wilderness to what he sees as the most diverse restaurant city in the world. Mr. Grimes reads from it tonight at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. For more arcana, head to the Union Square Barnes & Noble for a reading by John Hodgman, the veteran resident expert.

title: Stiff Upper Lip
description: The English band Noah and the Whale closes out its three-night run at Mercury Lounge tonight. They prize the stoicism of the British folk tradition, along with its fiddle tunes and vocal harmonies, without ruling out rock possibilities, writes Jon Pareles. Aching, unresolved, unironic heartbreak is at the core of their songs, but its not overly emo: the singer, Charlie Fink, can sound like Lou Reed or Conor Oberst, and when they let loose, theres psychedelic jamming and Springsteen-like antheming. Go Brittania.

title: Dave Bing Wins Election to Full Term as Detroit Mayor
description: On Tuesday night, Dave Bing, a former National Basketball Association, star, won a full term for a job some people had wondered aloud why he would even wish for: mayor of Detroit, with a budget deficit of nearly $300 million, a dismal unemployment rate and a school system so troubled that an emergency financial manager has been called in.

title: Conservative Loses Upstate House Race in Blow to Right
description: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y.  Democrats won a special election in New York States northernmost Congressional district Tuesday, a setback for national conservatives who heavily promoted a third candidate in what became an intense debate over the direction of the Republican Party.

title: Microsoft Simplifies a Cluttered MSN
description: Three months after Yahoo revamped its home page, Microsoft will begin doing the same on Wednesday with the MSN portal.

title: Phys Ed: Why Doesnt Exercise Lead to Weight Loss?
description: For some time, researchers have been finding that people who exercise dont necessarily lose weight. A study published online in September in The British Journal of Sports Medicine was the latest to report apparently disappointing slimming results. In the study, 58 obese people completed 12 weeks of supervised aerobic training without changing their diets. The group lost an average of a little more than seven pounds, and many lost barely half that.

title: Showcase: Meet Richard Nixon
description: Richard Nixon, a 65-year-old retired Atlantic City firefighter, lives in Brigantine, N.J, with his wife. He said his name made him the subject of many jokes over 30 years in the firehouse, but it never got too vicious or mean spirited.

title: Three Women Named to Board of Education
description: Thursday, Nov. 4, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: In October, Signs of Life at Retailers
description: October was far and away the best month American retailers have had since consumers put the brakes on spending last autumn. Major categories had robust sales growth for the first time in more than a year, new figures show.

title: A New Mayor for Miami
description: MIAMI  Toms Regalado easily defeated Joe Sanchez on Tuesday to become Miamis next mayor, after promising voters a back to basics approach focused on improving city services and reining in developers.

title: Pakistan Backs Off Amnesty Bill
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani government said Tuesday that it would not push an amnesty bill that would shield political leaders from corruption cases, a day after its closest political allies withdrew their support.

title: Pakistanis Seek Blame for Bombing
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  It has been a week since the bomb exploded at the womens market here, but people still talk about the images of its aftermath: womens bodies, naked and broken. A hand with hennaed nails. An arm still wearing bracelets.

title: Mayor No Longer Seems Invincible
description: For the first time in years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg finds himself governing New York City from a most unaccustomed vantage point: Vulnerability.

title: For the Phillies, Charted Ground
description: The Philadelphia Phillies burden remains formidable: to complete a comeback from a 3-1 deficit in the World Series, they must win Games 6 and 7 on the road. Nevertheless, they would not be the first team to pull it off.

title: Now Starring, Off Broadway and in the Peloton
description: EVEN on a bike, Mark-Paul Gosselaar cant always ride away from his rsum.

title: Dogs, Forensic Science and Scent Lineups
description: The story in todays Times about dog-scent lineups describes a controversial forensic method of using trained dogs to link suspects suspect to crimes through scent lineups. The practice has come under criticism  in part because of the potential for cross-contamination of scents and bias affecting the result, either intentionally or through the dogs perception of the humans attention to the container with the suspects scent in it.

title: Bloombergs Victory Speech
description: Below is the text of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs victory speech on Thursday night, delivered at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers in Midtown Manhattan, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Looking Smart
description: WHO is Danny Clark?

title: Bloomberg Wins Election
description: Incumbent Michael R. Bloomberg's acceptance speech.

title: N.H.L. Scores: What Happened to the Original Six?
description: Five games on Tuesday night, with five of the so-called Original Six in action. Late last summer, this season was being touted in some quarters as being all about the Original Six teams. But as the pucks were dropped on Tuesday, Detroit, Boston, Montreal and Toronto were all suffering; the Rangers, who had started strong, were slumping; and the only team not playing, Chicago, was the only old club consistently living up to its billing.

title: Sought-After Speaker, With Script Outlines From Eli Lilly
description: In the first half of this year, the drug giant Eli Lilly paid 3,971 doctors and other medical professionals an average of about $11,230 each. The payments were for participating in an average of 12 speaking or consulting engagements during those six months, according to a company spokeswoman.

title: G.O.P. Wins Two Key Governors Races; Bloomberg Prevails in a Close Contest
description: Republicans swept contests for governor in New Jersey and Virginia on Tuesday as voters went to the polls filled with economic uncertainty, dealing President Obama a setback and building momentum for a Republican comeback attempt in next years midterm Congressional elections.

title: Word of the Day | functionary
description: functionary  \fN(k)-sh-ner-e\  noun

title: A Year After Dousing, Republicans Hope Rekindled
description: WASHINGTON  The Republican victories in the races for New Jersey and Virginia governors put the party in a stronger position to turn back the political wave President Obama unleashed last year, setting the stage for Republicans to raise money, recruit candidates and ride the excitement of an energized base as the party heads into next years midterm elections.

title: Riding the Rails at a High Price?
description: What does Warren E. Buffett see in railroads? Berkshire Hathaway, his investment company, is paying a big premium for Burlington Northern Santa Fe, Breakingviews says. Mr. Buffett says he thinks the business of transporting goods around the country is ready to rebound. But investors may want to delay hitching a ride on his caboose.

title: Race for Seattle Mayor Is Too Close to Call
description: SEATTLE  Early returns in the contest for mayor of Seattle showed a tight race, with Mike McGinn, an environmentalist, holding a narrow lead over Joe Mallahan, a businessman.

title: Californias Democrat Is Elected to Congress
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Lt. Gov. John Garamendi of California, a Democrat, easily won election to Congress on Tuesday night, outpolling a little-known Republican in a suburban and largely liberal district east of San Francisco.

title: News Quiz | November 4, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Early Vote Favors Domestic Partner Law
description: SEATTLE  Early returns showed voters in Washington narrowly approving a ballot measure that would expand legal protections for domestic partners.

title: Italy Convicts 23 Americans for C.I.A. Renditions
description: MILAN  In a landmark ruling, an Italian judge on Wednesday convicted a base chief for the Central Intelligence Agency and 22 other Americans, almost all C.I.A. operatives, of kidnapping a Muslim cleric from the streets of Milan in 2003.

title: At Johnson & Johnson, Merger-style Savings
description: Johnson & Johnson has found merger-size savings  in itself. The health care giant will eliminate about 8,000 jobs. But the benefits are likely to be as fleeting as the cuts accompanying most giant pharmaceutical mergers, Breakingviews says. That is because it is increasingly tough to find new drugs to replace lost revenue as sales of old products run down.

title: 10gen Takes $3.4 Million
description: 10gen, the open-source database start-up, has obtained $3.4 million in a second-round of funding, led by Flybridge Capital Partners, VentureBeat reported.

title: Buffett Said to Join Goldman Bid for Tax Credits
description: Just because Warren E. Buffett has been working on his railroad, doesnt mean hes taken his eye off other investment opportunities.

title: Morgan Stanley Said to Shop Around C.I.C.C. Stake
description: Morgan Stanley is soliciting bids for its stake in China International Capital Corporation, the first Sino-foreign investment bank, three people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

title: Global Banking Fears Lead to Mixed Results
description: Wall Street wobbled on Tuesday amid indications that the global economy, particularly the banking sector, might be more frail than investors had believed. But positive sales reports from automakers stoked investors hopes in the final hours of trading, The New York Timess Javier C. Hernandez.

title: Bloombergs Campaign Spending Hampers Returns
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pulled out a narrow re-election victory on Tuesday, undermined in part, it seems, by the billionaire founder of Bloomberg L.P.s extravagant campaign spending against his vastly underfinanced challenger, William C. Thompson Jr.

title: End of Fight Over Skype May Be Near
description: The bitter battle over the future of the Internet calling service Skype appears to be nearing an end.

title: Cisco and EMC Form Venture to Serve Data Centers
description: Cisco Systems took another step to expand its computer hardware businesses on Tuesday by forming a broad partnership with EMC, a maker of storage equipment and software.

title: Rajaratnam Said to Plan to Keep Sri Lanka Assets
description: Raj Rajaratnam, the biggest investor in Sri Lankas stock market, has no immediate plans to sell his holdings in the south Asian nation after insider-trading charges in the United States, a person familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

title: Troop Deaths in Afghanistan Stir Outcry in Britain
description: This article is by Alissa J. Rubin, John F. Burns and Taimoor Shah.

title: Delphi Names New Board Members
description: Update | 7:32 a.m. Delphi, the auto-parts maker that emerged from a four-year bankruptcy in October, on Wednesday announced the appointment of its new board members, led by the retired chief executive of Dupont, John A. Krol, as chairman.

title: Landrys O.K.s $1.2 Billion Management Buyout
description: The chairman and chief executive of Landrys Restaurants finally got what he was after Tuesday, as the restaurant owners board approved his $1.2 billion all-cash offer to buy the company.

title: Attacking Corzines Wall St. Ties, Christie Wins Race
description: While Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs use of his personal wealth in his campaign for a third term in New York put a heavy dent in his margin of victory, Gov. Jon S. Corzines ties to business appeared to have helped unseat him entirely in New Jersey.

title: Hedge Funds to See Less Seed Money
description: Despite reports of a surge in new hedge funds in 2009, those seeking to hang up their own shingle may be disappointed by a report that says institutional investors plan to allocate 44 percent less in seed capital for the rest of the year.

title: Now Pay-Per-Viewing | The Ace for Adults
description: What at most hotels is a dirty (and lucrative) little secret, Ace Hotels has turned into another opportunity to explore the zeitgeist. The Portland-based chainlet recently announced it has struck a deal with Butt magazine, the pink-papered gay quarterly, to curate 16 homoerotic films for the video-on-demand service at its New York and Palm Springs, Calif., properties. Selected by the Butt staff writer Adam Baran, the video selections will include a range of rare and historic adult movies  some in 3-D!  that are in keeping with the magazines mission: to make titillation a cultural experience. A fixture in shops like Opening Ceremony, Butt regularly features the notable (Edmund White, Gus Van Sant) and the anonymous (Angel the Dominican carpenter) in various states of undress, which makes the Ace partnership no surprise. Since its start, the brand has aligned itself with independent tastemakers: Pearls Plus, Surface to Air, Arkitip, Doc Martens and Crush Fanzine are a few current collaborators keeping Ace among the avant-garde.

title: Thinheritance
description: The notion that eating habits and body image might be passed down from parent to child.

title: Blackstones Graham Packaging Eyes I.P.O.
description: The Blackstone Group is once again planning to bring its long-held Graham Packaging to market.

title: Preserved With Lasers
description: Images of laser scans of old monuments by a Scottish team.

title: Novartis Pays $125 Million for Tianyuan Stake
description: Novartis, the Swiss drug giant, said Wednesday it had agreed to pay $125 million for an 85 percent stake in the Chinese vaccine maker Zhejiang Tianyuan Bio-Pharmaceutical.

title: Dissidents Mass in Tehran to Subvert an Anti-U.S. Rally
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Irans beleaguered opposition movement struggled to reassert itself on Wednesday, as tens of thousands of protesters braved police beatings and clouds of tear gas on the sidelines of a major, government-sponsored anti-American rally.

title: Apollo Increases Its Bet on Harrahs
description: Apollo Management is doubling down on Harrahs Entertainment, but fellow private equity investors in the casino giant wont be following suit, The New York Post reported.

title: Atlantas Race for Mayor Heads to a Runoff
description: In Atlanta, Mary Norwood, the frontrunner whose success has raised the possibility that the city could elect a white mayor for the first time since 1973, was headed for a runoff on Dec. 1.

title: Buffett Bets Big on Railroads Future
description: Americas best-known investor, Warren E. Buffett, is making his biggest bet yet on the nations economic future by buying, of all things, a railroad.

title: Fill in the Blank: 10 Things ______ Should Never Do
description: In a post on the Youre the Boss blog, Bruce Buschel writes Part One of a list of 100 Things Restaurant Staffers Should Never Do. What would you include if you were to create a list called Ten Things Parents Should Never Do or Friends Should Never Do? Fill in the blank with the role of your choice  whether siblings, boyfriends, substitute teachers or anything else. Herewith is a modest list of dos and donts for servers at the seafood restaurant I am building, begins this post. Here are the first five on his list:

title: S.E.C. Taps Hedge Fund Counsel to Lead Unit
description: Amid continuing reports of insider trading and Ponzi schemes linked to hedge funds, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday it had named Norm Champ, a hedge fund general counsel, to lead its New York examinations group.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, Nov. 4
description: Highlights from media coverage in todays New York Times:

title: Week 8 QB Ratings: Favre Rising and Eli Falling
description: Luis DeLoureiro, a self-described schlep who is using a geeky Web site as a way to work through an early midlife crisis, is building a better passer rating. His complete ratings, including comparisons to each players traditional rating, are available at NFLStatAnalysis.net:

title: Berlin Wall Returns, in Human Form
description: BERLIN | At 8:27 p.m. on Nov. 9, 1989, the Berlin Wall was breached, parting the Iron Curtain to the joy of both East Berliners and the rest of the world.

title: Buying a Business Instead of Starting One
description: Sam was typical of many aspiring entrepreneurs. He had a paper route as a kid and worked for several companies as a young man, including J.C. Penney, where he discovered a passion for retail. After college and a stint in the armed services, he decided to pursue the path of business ownership. Rather than start a business from scratch, he borrowed $20,000 from his father-in-law, added it to $5,000 he had in savings and bought an existing franchise location, a Ben Franklin general merchandise store.

title: Claude Lvi-Strauss
description: Photographs by the anthropologist.

title: A Setback in Maine for Gay Marriage, but Medical Marijuana Law Expands
description: In a stinging setback for the national gay-rights movement, Maine voters narrowly decided to repeal the states new law allowing same-sex marriage.

title: BofAs General Counsel Wasnt Legal, Report Says
description: Adding another a layer of complication to Bank of Americas legal woes surrounding its deal to buy Merrill Lynch, the Charlotte, N.C. banks general counsel at the time the deal was being signed wasnt authorized to practice law, The New York Post reported.

title: Kraft Says It Wont Overpay for Cadbury
description: Kraft Foods said it would not overpay for the British chocolatier Cadbury on Tuesday after disappointing investors by posting weaker-than-expected quarterly revenue and cutting its full-year sales forecast.

title: The 7 Survival Habits of Byzantium
description: Todays idea: The Byzantine Empire, which outlasted the western Roman Empire by centuries, points the way to preserving Pax Americana now, a historian says  through diplomacy and subterfuge rather than full-scale war.

title: Blankfein and Dimon Met Feinberg Before Pay Cuts
description: Lloyd Blankfein and Jamie Dimon, the chief executive officers of Goldman Sachs Group and JPMorgan Chase, met Kenneth Feinberg as the Obama administrations paymaster prepared to consider proposals from seven bailed-out companies, government documents show.

title: Inside the Beltway, With Baby Aboard
description: Buses are a frugal travelers best friend  cheap, ubiquitous and reliable. Except when theyre not, and then theyre a nemesis  slow and unpredictable. Things get worse when you factor in a seatmate, who might intrude on your personal space, insist on chitchatting or, most horrific of all, scream, squirm and throw Cheerios on the floor.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Adam Langer
description: Adam Langer is a novelist and the author of a memoir, My Fathers Bonus March.

title: Amazon Video vs. Netflix: Which Will Prevail?
description: Which business model for watching movies online will be the winner? Paying upwards of $8 a month for unlimited and instant online access to an older catalog of films and TV shows from a company like Netflix? Or paying $2 to $3 a film for access to newer releases from a service like Amazons Video on Demand?

title: Clinton Backs Peace Talks Before Israeli Settlement Freeze
description: CAIRO  Winding up a Middle East tour, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton repeated on Wednesday that while the Obama administration rejects the legitimacy of Israeli settlement expansion, it nonetheless believes that Israeli-Palestinian negotiations should precede a permanent freeze on such construction.

title: Scripps to Buy Control of Travel Channel
description: Update | Nov. 5, 8:21 a.m. Scripps Networks said Thursday that it was buying a controlling stake in the Travel Channel, in a deal valuing the network at $975 million. It will own 65 percent of a new joint venture controlling Travel Channel, while current parent Cox Communications will own 35 percent.

title: Sampler: New Congressman, No Market Street Signs and Shark Travels
description: New Rep | Democratic Lt. Gov. John Garamendi will fill the congressional seat in the East Bay vacated by Rep. Ellen Tauscher.

title: Socit Gnrale Profit More Than Doubles
description: Socit Gnrale, the French bank, reported Wednesday that its third-quarter profit more than doubled, making it the latest big international lender to benefit from a strong rebound in financial markets.

title: In a World of Automatics, a Rare Shift for Mazda
description: The Mazdaspeed 3 has a stylish exterior, a punchy turbocharged 4-cylinder engine and a transmission certain to strike fear into the hearts of many American drivers. You get a lot of car for your money with a Mazdaspeed 3, but no amount of checked option boxes or dealer haggling will get you an automatic transmission.

title: Brooklyn Woman Finds Counterfeit Penny Made of Gold
description: One afternoon in March 2007, Jack Daws stepped up to a newsstand in Los Angeles International Airport with a handful of change, including a counterfeit penny made of 18-karat gold that Mr. Daws, a Seattle artist, had fashioned. He carefully put the counterfeit penny, dated 1970, down on the counter, counted out enough change to pay $11.90 for a Hustler magazine and left.

title: Toyota Pulling Out of Formula One to Cut Costs
description: TOKYO  Toyota announced Wednesday that it would give up its prized Formula One racing team in an effort to slash costs, refocus the company on green cars and turn a profit amid continued weakness in the auto sector.

title: Germans Frustrated Over G.M. Keeping Opel
description: Feeling jilted after six months of negotiations, German officials reacted angrily Wednesday to General Motors decision to keep its European business, Opel, rather than sell a majority stake to a consortium backed by Berlin, The New York Timess Nelson D. Schwartz, David Jolly and Bill Vlasic reported.

title: What to Watch Wednesday: Bill Cosby, Johnny Mercer, Ed Begley Jr.
description: Coach Taylors difficult first season at East Dillon takes a turn for the better when a star player is dropped in his lap on Friday Night Lights (DirecTV Channel 101, 9 p.m.).

title: A Daddy-Daughter Day Trip to Washington, D.C.
description: Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler, takes his daughter (and 20 pounds of baby gear) to Washington, D.C., to test his abilities as a road-tripping, jet-setting, world-roaming dad.

title: Saber Slingin in the Rain
description: Video | Gene Kelly et al get the Star Wars treatment:

title: Israeli Navy Captures Arms Shipment
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli Navy commandos seized a cargo ship early Wednesday in the Mediterranean Sea that Israeli officials said was carrying rockets and ammunition bound for Hezbollah militants.

title: The Vagaries of Estimating Cap-and-Trades Impact on Consumers
description: Since the Waxman-Markey climate and energy bill emerged in draft form early this year, a wide variety of reports from think tanks, nonprofits, universities and consultants have emerged  all attempting to project its impact on employment, electricity prices and gross domestic product.

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Wednesday morning.

title: Interactive: Assessing Barack Obama
description: A year after Barack Obama was elected president, he is juggling many of the issues that defined his candidacy  and then some. He is in the middle of lengthy debate over whether to expand the war in Afghanistan, and he continues to press for an overhaul of the health care system. While it will be years before it is possible to gauge the success of his governing agenda, Times reporters in an interactive feature offer assessments of his record on some of the issues so far.

title: Bloombergs Influence May Be Diminished
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs strikingly thin margin of victory in Tuesdays election could affect his influence. He ended election night in possession of a surprisingly modest margin of victory, five percentage points  far narrower than pollsters had predicted and with 100,000 fewer votes than he won in 2005. Voters seemed irritated by the term limits extension and his vast campaign spending.

title: Canine Fill-In
description: Teachers: Your response to this new exercise was so enthusiastic that, from now on, well publish one a week. You can find them all here compiled by their new category name, Fill-In.

title: Stocks Lose Steam at Close on Wall Street
description: The Dow Jones industrial average erased almost all of a 156-point rally after the House of Representatives passed a bill to curb rate increases on credit cards, touching off concern about bank earnings. The news outweighed investor optimism after the Federal Reserve said it planned to keep interest rates at a record low.

title: Outlook Not So Good on Jay Lenos Psychic Sit-Down
description: This week, Jay Leno set off a fresh round of speculation about the future of his prime time Jay Leno Show with an interview in Broadcasting & Cable magazine. (Among other things, Mr. Leno told Broadcasting & Cable that he would have preferred to remain in an 11:30 p.m. slot, adding, I think its too soon to say whether I regret anything or not.)

title: Wins and Losses on Tuesday Night
description: Republican victories in two races for governor were tempered by a loss in a G.O.P. stronghold in upstate New York.

title: A Look Under the Hood at Coverage of Bloombergs Run
description: Politics has a way of reminding us that the conventional wisdom, while widely held, is not always wise.

title: Tight End Boss Has Been a Big Plus for the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Giants have lurched through a three-game losing streak, it has become easy to see their flaws. Among them are interceptions thrown by quarterback Eli Manning, confused coverage in the secondary and poor tackling on defense and special teams.

title: Now Accessorizing | House of Waris
description: Waris Ahluwalias obsession with birds began at the Raphael Hotel in Paris  in the bathroom of Room 502, to be exact. I fell in love with a bird on the wallpaper, he says. (The hotel made a cameo in his friend Wes Andersons prequel to The Darjeeling Limited.) And I realized that birds could be the perfect way to explore the fine, detailed work of enameling and pav. He designed six avian jewels under his House of Waris label and named them after famous love-seeking literary characters. Libert, the diamond and gold peacock shown here, is $3,800 at Barneys New York.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: More Layoff Plans Trickle Out at Time Inc.
description: With Time Warner earnings in, Time Inc. is starting to reveal details about planned layoffs.

title: Red Shoes Stirs Martin Scorseses Cinematic Passion
description: When Martin Scorsese gets excited about something, boy, does he get excited. In between wrapping up work on a new film, Shutter Island, and starting production on an HBO series, Boardwalk Empire, Mr. Scorsese has found time for another passion project: extolling the virtues of a newly restored print of The Red Shoes, Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburgers classic 1948 film about the intersecting desires of a young dancer, an aspiring composer and an unrelenting ballet impresario.

title: Getting Very Skinny
description: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: A lot of people have been noticing that President Obama is getting very skinny. Have you noticed this? And he is thin. If it wasnt for his ears hed weigh less than 100 pounds.

title: 16 Foreign Countries
description: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: In his first year in office, President Obama has traveled to 16 foreign countries, more than any other president in history. Bush only traveled to 11, but most of those were just different parts from the Its a Small World ride.

title: China Approves Disney Theme Park in Shanghai
description: The initial resort, with a mix of shopping areas, hotels and a Magic Kingdom-style theme park, will sprawl across 1,000 acres of the citys Pudong district  with the theme park occupying about 100 of those acres. It would be a little bigger than Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., and on par with the parks in Paris and Tokyo. It is expected to open in five or six years. Read the full story.

title: A Big, Red Nose
description: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Do you believe its been a year since Barack Obama was elected president? Amazing, huh? Well, actually, theres been some changes. His new slogan is now, Yes, we can, but dont hold your breath.

title: Oh, My Goodness
description: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: I kind of wish Al Gore had been with us last night to kind of help out with the audience last night because, oh, my goodness. Over the course of the show the climate went from bad to worse.

title: Terra Rejects CFs Latest Bid
description: The seemingly never-ending battle between the fertilizer makers CF Industries and Terra Industries will live on for another day after Terra rejected CFs latest takeover attempt on Wednesday, saying the offer was inadequate, opportunistic and not in the best interests of Terra and its shareholders.

title: When He Saw the Signs
description: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on NBC: A year ago today, Barack Obama was elected president. Its been a year, can you believe that? Yeah. A lots happened. Yeah. In one short year, Obamas slogan has gone from, Yes, we can, to Wow, this is freakin hard.

title: The Telltale Signs of Chinese Drywall
description: With the news from federal investigators last week that imported Chinese drywall has higher levels of some chemicals than domestic versions, heres how to tell if your home has the imported drywall.

title: Gay Rights Rebuke May Change Approach
description: They had far more money and volunteers, and geography was on their side, given that New England has been more accepting of same-sex marriage than any other region of the country. Yet gay rights supporters suffered a crushing loss when voters decided to repeal Maines new law allowing gay men and lesbians to wed, setting back a movement that had made remarkable progress nationally this year.

title: Republicans Bask in Glow of Victories in N.J. and Va.
description: Savoring their victories in gubernatorial contests in New Jersey and Virginia, Republicans were trying on Wednesday morning to build momentum, in a time of economic concern, for a strong challenge to President Obamas party in next years midterm Congressional elections.

title: No Surprises Among Giants Injuries
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Wednesdays prepractice injury report for the Giants offered no surprises. But that list sometimes leaves off players who do not practice, so the update Wednesday afternoon may be more comprehensive.

title: Groups Push U.S. and China on Carbon Capture and Storage Technology
description: Three prominent American research organizations that are pushing for greater cooperation between the Obama administration and China on the issue of climate change say the two governments should make a priority of supporting the use of carbon capture technology and the creation of a market for carbon.

title: Voters Roll Back Democratic Gains in New York Suburbs
description: Voters in two of New York Citys wealthiest suburbs, where Democrats had established a stronghold in recent elections, shocked the incumbents by backing virtual unknowns in contests that left one three-term county executive defeated, and another, a former rising star, hanging on for his political life.

title: Following Up on Whether We Must Vote
description: On yesterdays post about whether we should support nonpartisan efforts to get people to vote, some comments accuse me of elitism (No. 52), of being against universal suffrage (No. 26) and disdaining the poor, young and nonwhite (No. 99)  charges I repudiate utterly. But the way to muster those with whom we have fellow-feeling is not by some vague admonition to vote, not by some airy appeal to good citizenship, but by proposing ways to make their lives  our lives  better, or, as I wrote early in yesterdays post: by rallying support for a person or a policy you esteem.

title: The Recession and the Paradox of Thrift
description: Update | 7:40 p.m.

title: Michael Jackson Takes It to the Top
description: After dominating record sales for four months, Michael Jackson is finally at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. Michael Jacksons This Is It, the companion album to the new movie  Epic, the label, is being careful not to call it a soundtrack, since it is mostly made up of old hits  sold 373,100 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Although Jackson has sold more than 5.6 million albums since his death in June, most of those titles have been too old to count on the Billboard 200, the standard album chart. But This Is It is a new title, and it becomes Jacksons sixth No. 1; the film was the top box office draw last week, taking in $32.5 million in its first five days in the United States.

title: Bloggers Back Behind the Shield?
description: Decoder wrote a bit about bloggers being left out of the federal shield law as the bill went through the process in a series of negotiations, but a spokesman for Senator Charles Schumer sent along a message that citizen journalists and bloggers would now be part of the legislation under consideration.

title: Claude Lvi-Strauss, 100, Dies; Altered Western Views of the Primitive
description: Claude Lvi-Strauss, the French anthropologist whose revolutionary studies of what was once called primitive man transformed Western understanding of the nature of culture, custom and civilization, has died at 100.

title: State Accuses Intel in an Antitrust Suit
description: In 2005, Michael S. Dells namesake company was getting pounded. His competitors were selling personal computers and servers built on cheap, popular and powerful chips from Advanced Micro Devices, while Mr. Dell had stuck loyally with slower chips from Intel.

title: 11th Cleveland Victim Confirmed and First Is Identified
description: CLEVELAND  The number of women found dead in the home of a convicted sex offender here rose to 11 on Wednesday, and the police announced their first identification of one of the victims.

title: Perfume, Soap, Fillings and Platinum, but Not Guns
description: BaghdadThe magic wand bomb detector has become a familiar, if controversial, sight on the streets of Iraq, as Rod Nordland writes.

title: Not All Is Rotten in Denmark: Hamlet Recoups
description: The current Broadway production of Hamlet no longer needs to concern itself with borrowers or lenders  the play has fully recouped its costs, its publicists said on Wednesday. In a news release, press representatives for Hamlet, which began previews at the Broadhurst Theater on Sept. 12 and opened on Oct. 6, said that it had earned back its initial Broadway capitalization of $2.5 million as of the week ending Nov. 1. The play, directed by Michael Grandage, is the latest in a series of hits that have transferred to Broadway from the Donmar Warehouse in London, which also yielded Frost/Nixon and Mary Stuart. The success of Hamlet might also have something to do with its star, Jude Law, who plays the melancholy Danish prince, and who has admirably held his own in a celebrity-filled season of Broadway neighbors like Daniel Craig and Sienna Miller. The limited run of Hamlet is to end on Dec. 6.

title: What Were Reading
description: Michael Psilakis works with local ingredients  in Crete.

title: U.S. Diplomat Meets Myanmars Top Dissident and Urges Junta to Work With Her
description: BANGKOK  A senior American diplomat who completed a rare visit to Myanmar on Wednesday said that Washington would improve relations with the nation if its military government embraced reconciliation with Myanmars democratic opposition.

title: Partys Over: A New Tone for Chrysler
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  The old Chrysler was famous for its aggressive marketing and auto-show stunts, like running a cattle drive down the streets of Detroit to publicize a new pickup.

title: The Best Credit Card Sign-Up Bonus Ever?
description: As Gary Leff reported in his View from the Wing blog, British Airways and Chase Card Services will soon be offering 100,000 miles to people who sign up for the British Airways Visa Signature card, possibly the most lucrative credit card sign-up bonus ever and equivalent to two round-trip coach tickets from North America to London.

title: U.N. Set to Endorse Inquiry Into Possible War Crimes in Gaza
description: UNITED NATIONS  The General Assembly is preparing to approve a resolution that would endorse a United Nations report calling on both Israel and the Palestinians to investigate possible war crimes in the Gaza Strip within three months.

description: I.

title: In-store | The Campana Brothers for Lacoste
description: This season Lacoste has teamed up with Fernando and Humberto Campana, better known as the Campana brothers, the Brazilian-born dynamic duo of design who are renowned for their furniture creations made from discarded materials (and the odd stuffed animal). During the Paris mens collections in June, Fernando and Humberto escorted us through an elaborate jungle presentation staged inside a stunning Parisian maison that featured their kooky crocodile creations.

title: Time Inc. Files to Cut 280 Jobs in New York
description: Time Inc. has filed with the New York State Department of Labor to give notice that it has planned 280 layoffs in the state between Nov. 2 and Jan. 31.

title: Travel Deals: Tours to Borneo
description: Borneo, an island between the South China and Java Seas, is one of the most biologically diverse places in the world, full of dense rain forests and rare wildlife. Friendly Planet Travel, a tour operator based outside Philadelphia, is offering a 15-Day Borneo Adventure for $2,899, including airfare, accommodations, some meals and guided tours.

title: Pettitte Falls Short for the Hall of Fame
description: Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia containing statistics for every player and team in major league history, and box scores, splits and game logs back to 1954.

title: Grant Could Assist Acquisition of Poets Papers
description: The papers of the poet Siegfried Sassoon are likely headed to Cambridge University following a grant from a British national fund for emergency acquisitions, BBC News reported. On Wednesday, the National Heritage Memorial Fund in Britain said that it would give about $900,000 toward the purchase of Sassoons archives, which includes notebooks he kept on the Western Front during World War I, as well as correspondence, poetry books, photographs and love letters to his wife, Hester. Sassoon, who dealt with the human toll of war in poems like They and Suicide in the Trenches, volunteered for military service just before Britains entrance into World War I, and was a decorated soldier before he refused to return to duty in 1917. (A manuscript of his statement of refusal is among the items contained in the archive.) In June, several authors including Sebastian Faulks and Sassoons official biographer, Max Egremont, started a campaign to acquire the poets papers following the death of Sassoons son George in 2006. With the grant, Cambridge is about $180,000 short of the estates asking price of about $2 million for the archive.

title: Kosegare
description: The name given to a network of young farmers in Japan used to mean, farmers son.

title: Time Inc. Closes Fortune Small Business
description: Although several Time Inc. executives were told that no magazines were to be closed in its cost-cutting efforts, Time Warner has decided to shut down FSB, formerly known as Fortune Small Business.

title: The Beatles Have Something Else to Sell You
description: If, when the Beatles released the remastered versions of their albums in September, you withstood the pressure to buy the stereo and mono boxed sets that contained their entire catalogs, your patience is about to be rewarded, sort of. Apple Corps Ltd. and EMI Music said that they were releasing a limited edition USB drive that contains the stereo versions of the Beatles albums, as well as the bonus materials that were included in their re-release, including short documentary films about the creation of the studio albums, photos and expanded liner notes. For the tech heads, the companies said that the audio files on the 16-gigabyte drives were in FLAC 44.1 Khz 24 bit and MP3 320 Kbps formats, and compatible with PC and Mac. For the people holding the credit cards, they said the drives would be sold at the Beatles online store for $279.99 and would be released in North America on Dec. 8. The USB drives design is presumably intended to evoke the Apple Corps. logo, and not the rotten fruit tossed by the villainous Apple Bonkers in Yellow Submarine.

title: OLED TV Waits in the Wings
description: Anyone whos seen an OLED TV display will be forgiven for thinking that theyve wasted their money on an LCD or plasma set. A picture created using OLED technology is simply extraordinary, with deep, rich blacks and an extremely sharp image.

description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Where Room and Board Is Nearing $16,000 a Year
description: This is clearly emerging as watch your wallet week on The Choice.

title: S.E.C. Chief Wants Better Shareholder Voting
description: Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, called on corporate America on Wednesday to upgrade its proxy voting practices to ensure shareholders a greater voice in governing the companies they own.

title: EBay Starts a Fashion Magazine
description: When the beautiful people list their favorite shops, eBay might not be on the tip of their tongues, but eBay hopes to change that.

title: White House Plays Down Election Results
description: President Obama loves elections.

title: On Comic-Con Web Site, a Tribute to a Founder
description: The Web site of Comic-Con International, usually a welter of whiz-bang graphics and news about the fan world, was topped on Friday by a simple black-and-white snapshot of Sheldon Dorfthe kind of fan who has fans. Mr. Dorf, a founder of San Diegos annual Comic-Con fantasy convention, died on Tuesday at 76, according to The San Diego Union-Tribune.

title: Alec Baldwin: We Have Work to Do in Germany
description: Alec Baldwin wasnt saying much on Tuesday night about his newly announced gig as co-host of the Academy Awards. (I just got lucky, went his ritualistic response to almost any inquiry he got about it during a screening event of The Red Shoes at the DGA Theater.) But as soon as we said the words 30 Rock and Germany to him, he knew what we were talking about.

title: Groups Urge Opening of Vacant Condos to the Poor
description: In Downtown Brooklyn, the be@schermerhorn condominiums had a sleek facade with a fancy fitness center, an on-site parking garage and coffee bar among its many amenities. But this was before the recession hit and condo projects that the real estate market had in abundance were left in limbo.

title: Barred for Drugs, Horse Trainers Return to Track
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  In 2007, Kentucky racing officials found cobra venom, a powerful painkiller, in the barn of Patrick Biancone, a horse trainer with prestigious victories from Hong Kong to France. He was barred from the sport for a year. Steve Asmussen, the nations leading trainer, served a six-month suspension in 2006 after one of his horses failed a drug test in Louisiana, and is appealing another six-month suspension handed down in Texas for another medication violation.

title: Legislature Passes Historic Water Deal
description: As Colin Sullivan, Greenwires West Coast correspondent reports, the all-night session that started in the state Senate and ended in the Assembly authorized, among other things, an $11.14 billion bond issue to finance water projects.

title: Fiorina Will Challenge Boxer in Senate Race
description: Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard who became a campaign adviser to Senator John McCains presidential bid, is formally announcing on Wednesday that she plans to run for the United States Senate.

title: Answers About New York City Politics
description: Here is the first set of answers from Bruce F. Berg, a professor and the author of New York City Politics: Governing Gotham, (Rutgers University Press).

description: The Republican renaissance has begun.

description: Motherlode would not exist without you and your comments. That is where the real conversation happens, and where all the wisdom is shared.

title: Playwright and Director in a Single Hair Shirt
description: PLAYWRIGHTS can easily run into challenges when they direct their own work. Its hard to be objective when scenes arent clicking, dialogue is dragging, or actors question the play. But for Kenneth Lonergan the last few weeks of directing his drama The Starry Messenger have included moments of frustration and hope that go beyond the usual bumps of steering a new piece toward opening night.

title: Good Sport: Creating Handbooks About Athletics
description: Overview | Why do people challenge themselves to participate in endurance sporting events? How can athletes-in-training keep their bodies healthy and injury-free? How do athletics engage and affect the body? In this lesson, students consider New York City Marathon runners and apply the principles of perseverance, endurance, health and training to other sports.

title: Kouchner Urges Stronger Afghan Role for Europe
description: PARIS  Europe should take the opportunity of a new Afghan administration to coordinate its policies on Afghanistan and not wait for Washington to make all the decisions, the French foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner, said on Wednesday.

title: S.E.C. Likely to Charge More People in Galleon Case
description: Update | 4:56 p.m. The Securities and Exchange Commission is likely to bring charges against additional defendants in its wide-ranging insider-trading case against Raj Rajaratnam, left, and his hedge fund firm, the Galleon Group, an agency lawyer said at a court hearing on Wednesday.

title: Should India Worry About Jobs?
description: MYSORE, India - American economists and policy makers are not alone in worrying about where jobs will come from in the future.

title: What Are the Best Childrens Museums in the Bay Area?
description: When I take my kids to museums, I remember Joan Didion writing about her then 7-year-old daughter running to a Georgia OKeeffe canvas at Chicago Institute of Art. In my mind, I conflated that essay with Ms. Didions on the old Getty Museum in Malibu and imagined the young girl running among the antiquities. No lines. No rules. No faux interactivity. Just going where her interests took her.

title: Economists Concur on Threat of Warming
description: A New York University School of Law survey found near unanimity among 144 top economists that global warming threatens the United States economy and that a cap-and-trade system of carbon regulation will spur energy efficiency and innovation.

description: House Republicans put forward their version of health care legislation on Tuesday, and Democrats immediately slammed it as too little, too late.

title: Video of Protests in Iran on Anniversary of Embassy Seizure
description: As state-sponsored demonstrations in Iran on Wednesday marked the 30th anniversary of the seizure of the United States Embassy in Tehran by militants, a fresh wave of anti-government protests shook the streets of the capital and other cities across the country.

title: Some Plays Can Twinkle Without Stars
description: WE live in a blockbuster age, when bigger is widely assumed to be better, or at least more important. Despite the clear failures of banks deemed too big to fail, it appears regulation will not stem the flow of steroids in the financial industry. The top-grossing movies have become a regular feature of news reports, encouraging Hollywoods natural affection for megahits. We can now anxiously compare the growing totals of our Internet intimates on Facebook.

title: Some Familiar Names Give Way to the New Faces
description: The N.B.A. has its own circle of life: as new blood enters the league, players must leave in order to make room. Look closely at the league rosters and youll notice a few familiar names that are nowhere to be found. Some have migrated to Europe to continue their careers. Others are waiting by the phone, hoping to nab one of the few roster spots that remain. A few have hung em up for good, and are now in search of a good rocking chair.

Doctorows novel Ragtime, arriving immigrants troop through an abstract, high-vaulted structure that evokes Ellis Island. So when it came time to arrange a photo shoot of the creative team behind the show, which opens Nov. 15 at the Neil Simon Theater, the real Ellis Island seemed the logical place to go.

title: A New Comments Tool for At War
description: Since we launched the At War blog in August, we have tried to encourage and cultivate lively and informative discussions with you, our readers. From week to week we have been thrilled with your responses on our posts and regular features, such as Ask John Burns and Capt. Tim Hsias A Soldier Writes columns. With your comments, you have created one of the most important aspects of the blog: an incredibly engaging and enlightening conversation.

Breeders Cup Organizers
Plan More Reforms

In the waiting area, called the Tranquillity Room, a waterfall cascades down one wall. A client may have a pedicure or facial before entering a softly lighted space where a plastic surgeon performs laser Fraxel treatment or some other minimally invasive procedure that would cost twice as much in a harried doctors office.

title: Update: Fortune Small Business Lays Off 11, Not 1

title: North American Origins for the Falklands Wolf
description: The Falklands wolf has puzzled evolutionary biologists since Charles Darwin first encountered it during the voyage of the Beagle in the 1830s. It was the only native land mammal on the Falkland Islands, which are 300 miles off the coast of Argentina. No one knew how it got there or what mainland animals it was descended from  and it did not help that the wolf was hunted to extinction by 1876.

But even center officials were surprised by the findings in their own report: that those businesses play a significant role in the economy.

title: Im not sure what the moral of this is, but
description: David Leohnardt unearths a Times article from 1982 that warned that we might never have a decent recovery. OK, although Im with Calculated Risk: were really in a liquidity trap now, which means that its much harder for the Fed to turn things around.

title: What Did the Election Mean?
description: Updated, Nov. 5, 11:30 a.m. | Amy Walter, editor in chief of the The Hotline, has joined the discussion.

title: Statoil Sells U.S. Oil Interest to Chinese Company
description: Update | 3:43 p.m. Statoil, the Norwegian energy giant, said Wednesday that it had sold a partial interest in some of its American energy development leases to the China National Offshore Oil Corporation, known as Cnooc. It is the first time that a Chinese company would take an ownership interest in energy assets in the United States.

title: Creative Confections for Woodwinds and Strings
description: Devoting a program to Minimalist and microtonal compositions could easily amount to an egghead agenda; leave it to the American Modern Ensemble to make it a party instead. Arriving concertgoers at the Galapagos Art Space in Dumbo, Brooklyn, for a program titled m&ms: microtones & minimalism on Tuesday night were greeted with martini glasses filled with complimentary M&M candies. Flyers and announcements hawked the American Modern-tini, a custom-made concoction. (Diligence urged sampling; common sense dictated otherwise.)

title: One Artist Journeys Down Anothers Road
description: LONDON | Ed Ruscha, an artist very familiar with the road culture of America, has dedicated a new project to the 1957 novel that brought that subject to the masses: Jack Kerouacs On the Road.

title: How Did Barca Fare in Russian Test?
description: Rubin Kazan has Barcelonas number. The Russian champion held the European champion to a goalless draw in sub-freezing temperatures in the Tatar capital, a week after upsetting the Blaugrana in Spain.

title: Technology Squeezes Jobs at Outsourcers, Too
description: From our colleagues at Economix:

title: Evocations of Chinese Life and Traditions, the Real and the Imagined
description: You might have thought that the ambitious, idiosyncratic program of Chinese music the Kronos Quartet and the pipa virtuoso Wu Man presented at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening was part of Carnegie Halls Ancient Paths, Modern Voices celebration of Chinese culture. But you would have been wrong. Instead the concert was part of the series Perspectives: Kronos Quartet.

title: Mikes Banished, Natural Sound Returns to City Opera
description: The New York City Opera  missing in action through the 2008-9 season as it grappled with a debilitating deficit and a chaotic leadership crisis  returns on Thursday evening with American Voices, a gala program at its extensively renovated home, the David H. Koch Theater. There is no doubt what the main question hovering over the proceedings will be: How are the acoustics of the renovated hall?

title: The Morning Skate: Star Injuries, N.H.L. Attendance and the Flames Boogie-Woogie Flu Shots
description: The Rangers lost in Vancouver last night, dropping a 4-1 decision to a team missing three of its best players due to injury, goalie Roberto Luongo and forwards Daniel Sedin and Pavol Demitra. But the Canucks are not alone. Throughout the N.H.L., many of the top players in the league have been shelved long term for assorted medical reasons.

title: Lives Gently Unscrolled Across a Stage
description: Bringing a painting to life is an idea that crops up from time to time in dance. Usually, though, the choreographer needs to invent a narrative to animate the frozen-in-time moment of the image and bring its characters to life. But not in The Feast of Han Xizai from the Han Tang Yuefu Music and Dance Ensemble of Taiwan, which opened Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Based on a Tang dynasty scroll painting by Gu Hongzhong, the dance doesnt exactly tell a story.

title: European Puck: 100 Days Till Vancouver
description: The countdown is on. One hundred days from Wednesday the 2010 Winter Games will open in Vancouver (although it is 101 days until the womens tournament starts off the Games ice hockey program), so with a nod to the International Ice Hockey Federations Olympics page, heres a roundup of the latest Olympic hockey news.

title: Photo of the Week
description: A dancer at Caru cu Bere, a beautifully restored neo-Gothic beer hall, in Bucharests reviving Lipscani district.

title: New Yorker Writers Book on Mass Extinctions Sells to Holt
description: Elizabeth Kolbert, the New Yorker writer, has sold a new book about mass extinctions to Henry Holt & Co. Holt paid a mid-six-figure advance for the book, which started life as a New Yorker article and is scheduled for publication in fall 2012.

title: Still Bouncing Off the Fun House Walls
description: The disembodied voice, sounding like God with a hangover, lets us know in detail what we are about to receive. Ladies and gentlemen, the voice rumbles by way of a preshow announcement for Richard Foremans Idiot Savant, a play that is some kind of wonderful. In the course of this evenings performance the following objects will appear onstage.

title: The Concierge | The Blind Date
description: Christine Muhlke, T Magazines food editor and de facto concierge, is at your service. Have a dining or imbibing quandary for her? Leave your question in the comments section below.

title: Reading the Election Tea Leaves
description: David Brooks: Gail, I love elections generally and this one was perfect. It cut through the great illusion of political life. The great illusion is that American politics is divided between people who read The Huffington Post on the one hand and people who listen to Rush and Glenn Beck on the other. We all know intellectually that this is not the case but its hard to keep it in mind day to day.

title: Alto Alentejo, Unsung but Not for Long
description: IN 2002, Doug Smith was bored. Korakia Pensione, his Mediterranean-style boutique hotel in Palm Springs, Calif., that attracted a celebrity crowd like Annie Leibovitz, Gore Vidal and Brice Marden, pretty much ran itself. Mr. Smith was looking for a new project  a grand fixer-upper in an exotic locale  where he could show off his well-honed style and settle into a life of rustic ease with his new wife, Josie.

title: Staten Island Elects Its First Black Council Member
description: Staten Island has long been unique in this racially diverse city: a borough where whites constitute the vast majority. But over the last few decades and particularly in recent years, people of other races have been increasingly calling the island home.

title: Will the Phillies Change Their Lineup?
description: The easy answer to the question, will the Phillies change their lineup? is no way, no chance, not at all.

title: On Baseball with Jack Curry
description: Either the Yankees will win the World Series, or the Phillies will force a dramatic Game 7. The Times's Jack Curry and Jane Bornemeier discuss how each of the scenarios may play out.

title: President of New York City Transit Resigns
description: Howard H. Roberts Jr., the avuncular boss of New York Citys buses and subways, resigned Wednesday after a tenure of two and a half years.

title: A Bountiful Buzz
description: A new type of visitor came to the National Mall this year, flitting past monuments and museums in favor of trees, flowers and plants. But this wasnt just some horticultural tour; no, this was work. Each day they were abuzz, gathering and pollinating before returning home to modest quarters with tremendous security near Lafayette Park.

title: Assessing Election Day 2009
description: The Timess Adam Nagourney reports on what the elections might mean for the national political landscape.

title: Stardust Memories: Woody Allen Puts This Ingmar Bergman Nonsense to Rest
description: Finally, some closure on the most important cinematic question of the moment (at least in our minds): Did Woody Allen and Ingmar Bergman ever share any meaningful interactions? The answer comes to us via the Woodman himself.

title: Kerik Expected to Accept Prison Term in Corruption Case
description: Bernard B. Kerik, New York Citys former police commissioner, is expected to plead guilty on Thursday to a single conspiracy charge in an agreement that would resolve the three pending federal criminal trials he faces in New York and Washington, people with knowledge of the matter said Wednesday. The deal, they say, could send him to jail for almost three years.

title: Readers Digest Closes Rick Warren Magazine
description: Less than a year after starting a hybrid magazine and membership organization, the Readers Digest Association and the minister Rick Warren said Wednesday that they were pulling the plug.

title: Competing Rallies in Irans Streets
description: It was a day of scattered protests and violence across central Tehran, as the country marked the 30th anniversary of the takeover of the United States Embassy/

title: Mavizen TTX02: Plug-and-Play Racing for the People
description: LAS VEGAS  It may seem strange for Azhar Hussain to introduce the electric racing motorcycle built by his London-based company, Mavizen, here at the SEMA Show. This is, after all, a convention for aftermarket parts for hot rods, tuners and pickup trucks on 26-inch wheels. But thats the point: the Mavizen TTX02 is almost entirely aftermarket.

title: How (Not) to Calm a Child on a Plane
description: Johanna Stein, a TV writer, who describes herself as a first time parent and long-time neurotic, read my post about the mother and child who were escorted off a Southwest flight last week, and sent me an essay she wrote about being that parent  the kind whose child wont stop screaming.

title: Maine Event
description: Progressive opinionators are trying to decipher the meaning of the vote yesterday in Maine to repeal the states new law permitting gay marriage, a vote that was expected to be close but one that gay-marriage proponents expected to win.

title: BlogTalk: And Now, a Word From the North Country
description: The hardest fought race yesterday for the political right was no doubt the one to decide the congressional representative in New York States 23rd District.

title: New Run for The Temperamentals at New World Stages
description: The critically praised Off Broadway production of The Temperamentals, a play about the early gay rights movement in America that had two sold-out runs this year, will transfer this winter to New World Stages, the producers announced on Wednesday. The production stars Thomas Jay Ryan (Henry Fool) as Harry Hay, who helped build the Mattachine Society gay rights organization in the 1950s, and Michael Urie (Marc St. James on Ugly Betty) as his lover Rudi Gernreich, who became a prominent fashion designer. Both men will reprise their roles at New World Stages, on W. 50th St. The producers are talking to the three other actors from the original production about returning as well. Previews are scheduled to start Feb. 18, with an opening night on Feb. 28. The specific theater to be used at New World Stages is still under discussion. Daryl Roth and Stacy Shane are producing the new play, which is by Jon Marans and directed by Jonathan Silverstein.

title: Off the Wall: White House Drops Painting
description: Update | 5:29 p.m. As Heidi Klum repeatedly and sternly intones on Project Runway, speaking of the fashion world: One day youre in and the next day  youre out. The same might be said of art, even, it turns out, at the White House. ARTnews has reported that the White House has quietly de-listed a painting by Alma W. Thomas that it chose last month, among some 45 pieces borrowed from several Washington museums, to decorate the private White House residence and the West and East Wings.

title: Gossip Girl Episode Draws Criticism from Parents Group
description: A coming episode of the CWs headliner series, Gossip Girl, has drawn the ire of the Parents Television Council, leading it to call on local affiliates of the network to pre-empt the episode, which is scheduled to be broadcast Nov. 9.

title: Fete Accompli | Mr. Chows 30th Anniversary
description: What: Michael and Eva Chows blowout to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Upper East Side chapter of the Mr. Chow empire.

title: Obama Uses Malias Test Scores as a Teaching Example
description: MADISON, Wis.  President Obama marked the first anniversary of his election on Wednesday by calling on states to toughen their education standards  and wound up calling on parents to toughen theirs, too, as he confessed that his 11-year-old daughter, Malia, recently got a 73 on her science test.

title: Intel's Antitrust History
