description: Intel has been the target of antitrust investigations and lawsuits from around the world. A look at the cases that the world's largest chip maker has battled for years.

title: Video: The Good, the Bad and the Elections
description: In a new video, Adam Nagourney, The Timess national political correspondent, discusses the possible meaning of the recent elections in Virginia, New Jersey and New York for the landscape shifting into the midterm elections of next year. It was a good day for Republicans, but not necessarily a great day.

title: Frank Seeks Stricter Derivatives Bill
description: Representative Barney Frank, the chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, is seeking stricter legislation for privately traded derivatives, and he wants to make it harder for banks to avoid trading the contracts on exchanges.

title: Correction
description: The two organizations calling for more research into geoengineering but stipulating that it should not take the place of emissions-cutting efforts are the American Meteorological Society and the U.K. Royal Society; a previous version of the story incorrectly stated that the former of the two organizations was the American Geophysical Union.

title: Modifying a Christmas Wish
description: In promising that Democrats would soon finish their big health care legislation, Senator Tom Harkin has done everything but put on a Santa Claus costume.

title: A Place to Put Your Apps
description: Last week, I reviewed not one, but three new phones. Youd think that would be enough for a while, but fall is peak season for new mobile devices, and another major release  Motorolas Droid  is upon us this week.

title: Home Green Home: Fireplace Inserts
description: Tom Zeller Jr., editor of the Green Inc. blog, had an energy-efficient fireplace insert installed.

title: Scots Aim Lasers at Landmarks
description: EDINBURGH  Come April a small team of experts from the Glasgow School of Art and the government heritage entity Historic Scotland will fly to South Dakota at the behest of an organization called CyArk and the United States National Park Service. They will make laser scans and computer models of Mount Rushmore.

title: Ciscos Results Offer More Hope to Tech Industry
description: Cisco Systems, the computer networking giant, supplied more evidence on Wednesday that technology sales were recovering along with the global economy.

title: Ramsay Takes On Amateur Cooks
description: On Media Decoder, a look at Gordon Ramsays new culinary show for amateur cooks.

title: Off the Wall: White House Drops Painting
description: At ArtsBeat, Randy Kennedy notes that the White House has decided against keeping a painting by Alma Thomas for display. Its selection had generated a bit of controversy. Read the full post.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Nov. 4
description: Emotions ran high on Wednesday in Iran, where crowds gathered on the 30th anniversary of the takeover of the United States Embassy. Tens of thousands of protesters braved police beatings and tear gas on the sidelines of a government-sponsored rally with an anti-American theme (Slides 1, 2, 3 and 4). In Moscow, meanwhile, Russian nationalists gathered outside the Kremlin for National Unity Day, which was created in 2005 to replace the traditional celebration of the Bolsheviks rise to power (Slide 6). The plight of child laborers drew attention in New Delhi, where activists and government officials raided a workshop (Slide 7). And Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York was spotted entering City Hall a day after his narrow re-election victory (Slide 12).

title: The White Houses Other Foodmakers
description: While White House chefs help make food policy and promote healthy eating on Iron Chef America, the White House carpenter is making honey. Check out the audio slide show.

title: 11/4/09: O.H.L. Suspends Player for Rest of Season
description: The Ontario Hockey League has suspended the Erie player Michael Liambas for the rest of the regular season and playoffs for checking into the end boards Kitchener defenseman Ben Fanelli, a hit that resulted in Fanelli, 16, being airlifted to a Hamilton hospital with skull and facial fractures. The check occurred on Friday; Fanellis condition was upgraded on Tuesday from critical but stable to serious but stable.

title: Small Business Goes to Washington (Part 2)
description: As we reported last night, Senator Tom Harkins hearing in the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee on small-business insurance costs wasnt the only small-business game in Washington on Wednesday. The liberal Main Street Alliance, along with the Consumers Union, U.S. PIRG, and the Small Business Majority, sent 134 small-business owners from 26 states to Capitol Hill to mingle with legislators and the press.

title: The Very Quiet Season of Michael Vick
description: The biggest headline from the preseason has been little more than a footnote in the games that count. The Philadelphia Eagles did not need the publicity when they signed Michael Vick. What they needed, so they thought, was someone who could conduct a Wildcat offense. But in five games this season, their man for that job has rushed for just 25 yards on 11 carries, and completed only 2 for 6 passes for 6 yards.

title: Going Tribal in Afghanistan
description: In Washington, the debate over Afghanistan seems to center around two broad ideas: counterinsurgency versus counterterrorism. Should the United States add troops for a more population-centric strategy, as Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal advocates? Or should it use a less ground-heavy approach, disrupting Al Qaeda with Special Operation Forces and unmanned drones, as Vice President Joseph Biden argues?

title: Martinez Has a History in Elimination Games
description: When Pedro Martinez took the mound on Wednesday night at Yankee Stadium, it was the sixth time he was pitching in a postseason game in which a loss would send his team home for the winter.

title: Adults Told to Hold Off Getting Seasonal Flu Vaccine
description: Healthy, nonelderly adults in New York should not seek vaccination for seasonal flu until the supply of vaccine increases, city health department officials said Wednesday.

title: No Deal for Ticket Scalper
description: A man arrested outside Yankee Stadium last Thursday apparently thought he had a get-out-of-jail-free card in the form of World Series tickets.

title: Fox News Takes Tuesday Night
description: On an off-year election night of local victories for Republicans in New Jersey and Virginia, the Fox News Channel had large gains in viewership, Nielsen ratings showed on Wednesday.

title: Revenue and Profit Declines at Time Warner
description: Time Warner, the media conglomerate that was once the worlds largest but has lately slimmed down by shedding some businesses, said both revenue and profits declined in the recent quarter.

title: Building With Whole Trees
description: STODDARD, Wis.

title: Costumes for Designers
description: The New York Design Center Masquerade Ball held last week was that rare New York party in which shop talk was not paramount.

title: Grant Could Help Acquire Poets Papers
description: The papers of the poet Siegfried Sassoon are probably headed to Cambridge University thanks to a grant from a British national fund for emergency acquisitions, BBC News reported. On Wednesday the National Heritage Memorial Fund in Britain said that it would give about $900,000 toward the purchase of Sassoons archives, which include notebooks he kept on the Western Front during World War I, as well as correspondence, poetry books, photographs and love letters to his wife, Hester. Sassoon, who dealt with the human toll of war in poems like They and Suicide in the Trenches, volunteered for military service just before Britain entered World War I, and he was a decorated soldier before he refused to return to duty in 1917. In June several authors, including Sebastian Faulks and Sassoons official biographer, Max Egremont, started a campaign to acquire Sassoons papers after the death of his son, George, in 2006. With the grant, Cambridge is about $180,000 short of the estates asking price of nearly $2 million for the archive.

title: Not All Is Rotten in Denmark: hamlet Recoups
description: The current Broadway production of Hamlet no longer needs to concern itself with borrowers or lenders  the play has fully recouped its costs, its publicists said on Wednesday. In a news release, press representatives for Hamlet, which began previews at the Broadhurst Theater on Sept. 12 and opened on Oct. 6, said that it had earned back its initial Broadway capitalization of $2.5 million as of the week ending Nov. 1. The play, directed by Michael Grandage, is the latest in a series of hits that have moved to Broadway from the Donmar Warehouse in London, which also yielded Frost/Nixon and Mary Stuart. The success of Hamlet might also have something to do with its star, Jude Law, who plays the melancholy Danish prince (above with Geraldine James), and who has held his own in a celebrity-filled season of Broadway neighbors like Daniel Craig, Hugh Jackman and Sienna Miller. The limited run of Hamlet is to end on Dec. 6.

title: The Beatles Have Something Else to Sell
description: If, when the Beatles released the remastered versions of their albums in September, you withstood the pressure to buy the stereo and mono boxed sets that contained their entire catalogs, your patience is about to be rewarded, sort of. Apple Corps Ltd. and EMI Music said they were releasing a limited-edition USB hard drive that contains the stereo versions of the Beatles albums, as well as the bonus materials that were included in their rerelease, including short documentary films about the creation of the studio albums, photos and expanded liner notes. For the tech heads, the companies said that the audio files on the 16-gigabyte drives were in FLAC 44.1 Khz 24 bit and MP3 320 Kbps formats, and compatible with PC and Mac. For people holding credit cards, the drives will be sold at the Beatles online store for $279.99 and will be released in North America on Dec. 8. The USB drives green apple design, above, is presumably intended to evoke the Apple Corps logo and not the rotten fruit tossed by the villainous Apple Bonkers in Yellow Submarine.

title: Footnote
description: The next tenant for Broadways Nederlander Theater was announced late Tuesday: The new musical Million Dollar Quartet, based on a 1956 recording session that brought together Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins and Elvis Presley. Preview performances are to begin on March 13, and opening night will be sometime in April. The show, now running in Chicago, will be directed by Eric Schaeffer and includes a book by Colin Escott and Floyd Mutrux. Casting is underway.

title: ABCs V Rises to Top Spot in Ratings
description: ABCs new science-fiction series, V, a remake of the 1983 mini-series, opened to strong ratings on Tuesday, leading the night over all in the advertiser-favored demographic of adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsens estimates, 13.9 million total viewers tuned in, helping make V one of the highest-rated new series this fall. That ABC show trailed CBSs NCIS in its 8 p.m. slot, however, in total viewers (19.4 million) as CBS won the nights largest audiences over all, leading the 9 and 10 p.m. hours with NCIS: Los Angeles (15 million) and The Good Wife (12.2 million). ABC was runner-up, garnering 14.5 million at 9 for Dancing With the Stars, but only 7.6 million for The Forgotten at 10. NBC earned third place with a two-hour installment of The Biggest Loser (9 million), followed by The Jay Leno Show (5.9 million).

title: Michael Jackson Takes It to the Top
description: After dominating record sales for four months, Michael Jackson is finally at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. Michael Jacksons This Is It, above, the companion album to the new movie, sold 373,100 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Although Jackson has sold more than 5.6 million albums since his death in June, most of those titles have been too old to count on the Billboard 200, the standard album chart. But This Is It is a new title, and it becomes Jacksons sixth No. 1. The film was the top box-office draw last week, taking in $32.5 million in its first five days in the United States. Also on this weeks album chart, Creeds comeback, Full Circle (Wind-Up), opened at No. 2 with 110,000, and Taylor Swifts Fearless (Big Machine), rereleased in a deluxe package, jumped four spots to No. 3 with 109,000. Rod Stewarts new album, Soulbook (J), a collection of covers of classic soul songs, bowed at No. 4 with 84,000 copies sold. Trans-Siberian Orchestras latest holiday album, Night Castle (Atlantic), opened at No. 5 with 83,000, and Stings new Christmas-themed album, If on a Winters Night ... (Deutsche Grammophon), sold 80,000 copies to debut at No. 6.

title: Book on Mass Extinction Is Bought by Holt
description: Elizabeth Kolbert, a writer at The New Yorker, has sold a new book about mass extinctions to Henry Holt & Company. Holt paid a mid-six-figure advance for the book, which began as an article in The New Yorker and is scheduled for publication in fall 2012. Stephen Rubin, the new president and publisher of Holt, announced the acquisition on Wednesday, just two days after he started his job. Mr. Rubin was most recently publisher at large at Random House. Ms. Kolbert moves to Holt from Bloomsbury, which published her previous book, Field Notes From a Catastrophe, in 2006. Her editor, Gillian Blake, is now at Holt and acquired the new book, The Sixth Extinction, an intellectual and natural history of various species. Ms. Blake said she had been talking to Ms. Kolbert about the subject of extinctions for years. The idea of mass extinctions as the next step after talking about the perils of global warming is the most crucial subject, Ms. Blake said.

title: The Off-Off-Year Elections
description: Tuesdays vote  particularly the election of Republican governors in New Jersey and Virginia  has produced heated predictions about the revived power of Republican social conservatism and the declining fortunes of Barack Obama and his 2008 coalition.

title: Payments in Ivory Coast Dumping Case at Risk, Lawyer Says
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Thousands of victims of one of the worst toxic dumping scandals in years could lose their hard-won settlement thanks to maneuverings by a shadowy but influential figure in Ivory Coast, where the dumping occurred, the victims lawyer said Wednesday.

title: How to Respond to Debt Resolution Service Ads
description: I recently received a personal and confidential notice in the mail from the debt resolution department at a California law firm offering to help me restructure a debt I dont actually have (or hope I dont have) to a lower monthly payment. The letter urged me to call a toll-free number as soon as possible if I wanted to take advantage of the offer.

title: Republicans Win 2 Council Races in Queens
description: Republicans picked up two City Council seats in Queens on Tuesday, defeating Democratic opponents, both Asian-American, who had survived grueling primaries. The hard-fought races were among the most expensive Council contests this year, in large part because the primaries had drawn numerous contenders.

title: Ask Big Bird a Question
description: Tuesday, Nov. 10, will mark the 40th anniversary of Sesame Street, the PBS standby that taught multiple generations to read and count and gave many children perhaps their earliest glimpses of multicultural community.

title: In China, an Apartment Renovation Presents New Challenges
description: Dalian, China

title: Red Bulls Boss Speaks
description: The phone call came early Wednesday morning.

title: Light, Birds, Action! Cunningham and Company in Rehearsal
description: Most of the dancers in the ballet paintings of Degas arent dancing. Theyre stretching, resting, recovering, waiting, watching; and in several paintings there is a white-haired old man in charge, a ballet master whose name, Jules Perrot, remains bigger than those of any of the performers he is supervising. That situation came vividly back to mind as I watched Tacita Deans Craneway Event.

title: Some TVs Go Directly Online for Streaming Movies
description: For more than a decade, tech and media companies have wrestled with how to deliver digitized movies directly over the Internet to consumers: how do you get the copy-protected files from the computer to the big screen in the living room?

title: Game 6 Lineups
description: The lineups for Game 6 of the World Series are in and Shane Victorino is playing center field and batting second as usual. Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel said Victorinos bruised finger was fine. The designated hitter is Raul Ibanez.

title: Firing Bullets of Data at Cozy Anti-Science
description: I always say that electricity is a fantastic invention, the British economist Michael Lipton once told Michael Specter, whose bristling new book, Denialism, explores the dangerous ways in which scientific progress can be misunderstood. But if the first two products had been the electric chair and the cattle prod, Mr. Lipton continued, I doubt that most consumers would have seen the point.

title: Safety Agency Rebukes Toyota Over Floor-Mat Issue
description: In a highly unusual move for an agency that prefers low-profile discussions, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has publicly rebuked Toyota, accusing it of putting out inaccurate and misleading information about the unintended acceleration problem that could affect 3.8 million of its vehicles.

title: Denialism
description: The most blatant forms of denialism are rarely malevolent; they combine decency, a fear of change, and the misguided desire to do good  for our health, our families, and the world. That is why so many physicians dismiss the idea that a patient's race can, and often should, be used as a tool for better diagnoses and treatment. Similar motivations  in other words, wishful thinking  have helped drive the growing national obsession with organic food. We want our food to taste good, but also to be safe and healthy. That's natural. Food is more than a meal, it's about history, culture, and a common set of rituals. We put food in the mouths of our children; it is the glue that unites families and communities. And because we don't see our food until we eat it, any fear attached to it takes on greater resonance.

title: What Your Phone Might Do for You Two Years From Now
description: By now we can probably all agree that the iPhone is the Model T, the Sputnik, the Lawrence Taylor of the mobile technology realm. We are still waiting for the offenses to adapt, the competition to catch up.

title: Victorino Remains in Lineup
description: Shane Victorino vowed two nights ago that a bruised right index finger would not prevent him from starting in center field Wednesday night. True to his word, Victorino was in the Phillies lineup after assuring Manager Charlie Manuel that he could swing and throw without discomfort. An errant fastball by A.J. Burnett drilled Victorino in the first inning of Game 5, causing the finer to swell. But X-rays did not show a fracture.

title: From London, an Example of Fakery Done Right
description: On some deals declarer will make his contract if he can guess what to do. Then the defenses job is to paint a false picture of the distribution, hoping that declarer will guess wrong.

title: Galleon Moves Its Portfolios to Nearly All Cash
description: The Galleon Group has converted nearly all of its hedge funds into cash, as the firm seeks return money to its investors in light of its founders arrest on insider trading charges, according to a letter to investors obtained by DealBook.

title: For Thrillers, Glenn Beck Is Becoming New Oprah
description: Virtually every novelist in America fantasizes about being picked to appear on Oprah Winfreys talk show. But now an increasing number of writers have discovered a new champion: Glenn Beck, the outspoken media darling of populist conservatism.

title: Satellite Radio for iPhone and iPod Touch
description: Sirius XM Radio, always on the lookout for ways to attract fee-paying younger subscribers, is now after the Apple crowd.

title: Tech Is Back. And This Time, Its Personal.
description: Today we released our redesigned online Personal Tech section. The old version wasnt bad, but we thought we could do better. That means more video, easier navigation and more places to read about products and then research them with the help of our product-review partner, CNet.

title: Milans No. 10 Responds to Times Readers
description: A day after he played in A.C. Milans 1-1 draw with Real Madrid in the UEFA Champions League, Clarence Seedorf answered readers questions from Milan. This is the the third edition of Seedorfs monthly discussion with Times readers. You can read earlier discussions here.

title: A Cheap Deadbolt Is No Bargain
description: DONT forget to lock up  its a sound practice, yet something many people forget to do, resulting in millions of break-ins nationwide every year, according to the National Crime Prevention Council, a nonprofit organization in Washington.

title: Chryslers Five-Year Plan in Six Bullet Points
description: Chrysler delivered an epic press conference/Web cast Wednesday to detail its five-year plan, including coming products. Here is the essential information in six bullet points:

title: Older Bypass Method Is Best, a Study Shows
description: For decades, bypass surgery, in which surgeons improve blood flow to the heart by sewing new blood vessels to get around blocked ones, was done the same way. The heart was stopped while blood was pumped through a heart-lung machine to do the hearts work.

title: Karzais Top Rival Denounces Afghanistans New Government
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The erstwhile rival to President Hamid Karzai in the presidential elections second round held a news conference on Wednesday in which he denounced Mr. Karzais newly anointed administration as illegal and said that the government would be unable to cope with the problems facing Afghanistan, including security and corruption.

title: Other Voyages in the Shadow of Lvi-Strauss
description: His most celebrated work, Tristes Tropiques, begins with the words I hate traveling and explorers. But what made the anthropologist and philosopher Claude Lvi-Strauss one of the great intellectuals of the 20th century was precisely his eagerness to explore  not just remote jungles and isolated societies, but also the far reaches of the human mind.

title: Better-Than-Expected Profit Is Reported by News Corp.
description: The News Corporation reported an unexpected rise in profit on Wednesday, driven by its cable channels, particularly Fox News, and its movie studio.

title: After Mickeys Makeover, Less Mr. Nice Guy
description: LOS ANGELES  For decades, the Walt Disney Company has largely kept Mickey Mouse frozen under glass, fearful that even the tiniest tinkering might tarnish the brand and upend his $5 billion or so in annual merchandise sales. One false move and Disney could have New Coke on its hands.

title: Pogue & Friends 2009 Holiday Guide
description: The Times's personal technology columnist, David Pogue, teams up with travel columnist Michelle Higgins to share their favorite travel gadgets.

title: Home, Alone
description: Leslie Williams lives in what was once her dream home. But it was also where her 14-year relationship ended.

title: Australia Puts Its Refugee Problem on a Remote Island, Behind Razor Wire
description: CHRISTMAS ISLAND, Australia  Deep in the jungle on this small island lost in the Indian Ocean, Australias new $370 million refugee detention center reaches its full power after its lights come on at dusk. Bracketed by rain forest, steep cliffs and the sea, it rises from the enveloping darkness and becomes visible from the islands only inhabited corner, about 10 miles away.

title: Getting Serious About Your House and the Market
description: WHEN Matthew White, a landscape architect, decided two years ago to sell his 1,300-square-foot apartment in Philadelphia, he knew real estate prices were plummeting. Nevertheless, he thought he could get $760,000, about what he had paid two years earlier, because he had made many improvements to the space, an airy penthouse with two verdant terraces.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,348 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 902 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

title: C.C. Sabathia Is Ready for a Possible Game 7
description: C.C. Sabathia will watch Game 6 between the Yankees and the Phillies a little differently than his teammates. If the Yankees do not beat the Phillies Wednesday, Sabathia must be ready to start a Game 7 on Thursday.

title: Seeking a Right to Carol in the Classroom
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If Merry Susan Hyatt has her way, every public school pupil in California will have the voter-approved right to sing Joy to the World in the classroom.

title: Yankees Win 2009 World Series
description: Times reporters David Waldstein, Tyler Kepner, Ben Shpigel, Jack Curry and Richard Sandomir provided updates and analysis during Game 6 of the Yankees-Phillies World Series in the Bronx.

title: Week 9 in Fantasy Football Matchups
description: The Brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 9. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below. Also, scroll down for reading tips from the Fantasy Football Librarian.

title: Beauty at the Ball
description: MY clams are not in place, the pregnant mermaid in the ladies room at the New York Design Center Masquerade Ball was saying, adjusting the homemade shell-and-string brassiere she was wearing over her clingy gown. Her long red hair was a magnificent Venus-rising mane, intertwined with seashells, and a blue-green fish tail trailed fetchingly from underneath her skirt. But her bra was somewhat askew and so was her extremely protuberant belly.

title: A City of Mixed Emotions Observes Calvins 500th
description: GENEVA  On a recent afternoon, stagehands prepared the Protestant meeting hall on the Place de la Fusterie for a musical, The Calvin Generation, to be performed there that evening. Springtime for Calvin?

title: A Dream Home Undone by Divorce
description: WELCOME to home interrupted, Leslie Williams said, opening the door to what appeared to be just the opposite: a bright TriBeCa loft with near-lapidary finishes.

title: A Health Care Protest, by Invitation
description: House Democrats are bracing for a potential invasion of protesters in the Capitol complex on Thursday after Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, urged opponents of the Democrats health care legislation to come to Washington to make their voices heard.

title: You Call That Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Forester-Architect
description: Roald Gundersen, who founded Gundersen Design in 1991 and built his first house in the forest 10 miles east of the Mississippi River and 150 miles northwest of Madison two years later, has made a career of working with trees.

title: Where the Boys Arent
description: MAN on the premises!

title: The Gospel According to Sister Parish
description: Sister Parish, the influential American decorator who started working during the Great Depression and died in 1994, was an originator of what came to be known as the American country style, featuring much painted white furniture and homey elements like patchwork quilts, stenciled floors and mattress ticking pillows. Though Mrs. Parish herself was something of an autocrat, her ideas were eminently sensible, reflecting the very basic principle that the people in a room are more important than the objects in it. Call it humanistic decorating.

title: Some Wall Street Year-End Bonuses Could Hit Pre-Downturn Highs
description: Now is the time of year when a Wall Streeters fancy turns, not so lightly, to thoughts of bonuses.

title: Q&A: What the Goats Bones Knew
description: Artware Editions, a West Village gallery that produces objects designed by visual artists, recently introduced limited-edition Bone Cutlery by John Gerrard, an Irish artist whose show Directions opens Nov. 5 at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington.

title: Wine, Held Stylishly Aloft
description: The Grapevine Wine Rack, designed by Ran Lerner for Umbra, is both sculptural and practical. Made of clear acrylic, it could create the impression from afar  especially after a few drinks  that your wine is levitating. But the rack, which is just over 15 inches tall and tapers slightly toward the top, securely holds six standard-size bottles.

title: App of the Week: Mobile TV That Needs No Hot Spot
description: Getting TV news on your phone is a tricky business, as most mobile broadcasters require a Wi-Fi connection. Thats not really mobile TV, thats hot-spot TV.

title: Audiobook Choices for the iPod
description: Q. What companies sell audiobooks for the iPod Touch besides iTunes? Are there fees involved?

title: From Germanys Army, Luxury
description: When Darin Montgomery, the founder of Urbancase design studio in Seattle, spotted a surplus military blanket at a flea market on a visit to Berlin two years ago, he was struck by the beauty of its utilitarian gray-brown wool.

title: Radio Program Interrupted? Bookmark It and Return Later
description: If you are a fan of NPR, you probably have run into this minor frustration: you are, say, heavily into a Car Talk discussion on how to repair a radiator when you suddenly have to pick up the children and pop in a Hannah Montana CD. By the time you get home, you have forgotten what it was you wanted to listen to.

title: A Living Room, Discounted
description: Furniture from the 1930s and 40s will be up to 70 percent off at Antiqueria Tribeca through Nov. 8 (a set of six dining chairs attributed to Dorothy Draper, originally $12,000, will be $3,600); 129 Duane Street (Church Street), (212) 227-7500, antiqueria.com.

title: Restructuring Luxury at Versace
description: I AM a survivor, the designer Donatella Versace said matter-of-factly during a recent blitz of New York, a visit that made it appear little had changed in the world of the occupationally fabulous.

title: A Camera Delivers the Joys of Auto Pilot
description: I usually think of superzoom cameras as ideal for vacations. I just didnt know how exemplary until I packed a Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ35, with an 18X zoom lens ($399, $322 at Amazon), for a trip to Vienna a couple of weeks ago.

title: Democrats to Use Election to Push Agenda in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Blaming election setbacks on a drop in voter enthusiasm, Congressional Democrats said Wednesday that losses in governors races in Virginia and New Jersey  and a striking House win in New York  should give new urgency to their legislative agenda, including a sweeping health care overhaul.

title: Report Faults Parole System in Abduction
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The California inspector general issued a scathing report on Wednesday on the states handling of the parolee who has been charged with kidnapping, raping and imprisoning Jaycee Dugard for 18 years in Antioch, Calif.

title: S.E.C. Likely to Charge More People in Galleon Case
description: Prosecutors indicated Wednesday they intend to bring charges against additional defendants in the wide-ranging insider-trading case against Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group, and five others.

title: In TriBeCa, a Face-Off Over City Tax Breaks and Rents
description: The special city tax breaks that the owner of a large apartment complex in TriBeCa received from 2004 to 2006 could hardly be described as a windfall  $17,879.42 for a cluster of buildings in Lower Manhattan worth tens of millions of dollars.

title: Reports Show Conflicting Number of Jobs Attributed to Stimulus Money
description: In June, the federal government spent $1,047 in stimulus money to buy a rider mower from the Toro Company to cut the grass at the Fayetteville National Cemetery in Arkansas. Now, a report on the governments stimulus Web site improbably claims that that single lawn mower sale helped save or create 50 jobs.

title: Stripping Bare the Body
description: To the Editor:

title: Resignations Point to New Woes for Players Union
description: The N.H.L. Players Association is facing an uncertain future after another round of upheaval with the resignation of its interim director, outside counsel and six-member advisory board.

title: Eagles Westbrook Is Set to Play Against Cowboys
description: Brian Westbrook is set to return from his latest injury when the Philadelphia Eagles host the Dallas Cowboys in a matchup of the top two teams in the National Football Conference East on Sunday.

title: California Water Overhaul Caps Use
description: LOS ANGELES  California lawmakers on Wednesday approved a series of bills that would vastly overhaul the states troubled water system. The water package is the most comprehensive to emerge from the state since the 1960s, when California last upgraded its system for what was a far smaller population of users.

title: The Voters Barked. Now What?
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Michael Ronis, Manhattan Chef, Dies at 60
description: Michael Ronis, who helped conceive Carmines, an Italian restaurant that lures masses of New Yorkers and out-of-towners to Times Square and the Upper West Side with gargantuan portions and moderate prices, died last Thursday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 60 and lived in Stamford.

title: Senate Approves More Jobless Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted unanimously Wednesday to offer up to 20 more weeks of unemployment benefits to those who have been out of work a long time, after weeks of delay in which hundreds of thousands of Americans exhausted their government aid.

title: Costs Surge for Medical Devices, but Benefits Are Opaque
description: When makers of heart defibrillators wanted Medicare to vastly expand the types of patients eligible to receive the devices, which can cost upward of $25,000, agency officials were skeptical. It was not clear how many of those patients would actually need a defibrillator, a device that can deliver a life-saving shock to restore a faltering heart to normal rhythm.

title: An Old Pro Delivers at the New Stadium
description: Sometimes it sounds presumptuous to use the name World Series for what is technically the baseball championship of the United States and Canada.

title: New Show Displays Garden Glasnost
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

title: Perceptions Changed, but Rodriguez Hasnt
description: Alex Rodriguezs first act as a World Series champion was to raise his arms and jump for joy. As soon as Shane Victorino made the Phillies final out, Rodriguez ran toward the throng of Yankees teammates in the middle of Yankee Stadium and threw himself into the pack.

title: In Postseason, There Is Only One Rivera
description: Mariano Rivera began warming up in the bottom of the seventh inning, earlier than he would during the regular season. But it was the perfect time for Rivera to do it in the postseason, especially because it was a postseason that he could end. Rivera was preparing to celebrate.

title: Three Injured Giants Are Making Progress
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Three key members of the Giants defense reported progress in their recoveries from injuries Wednesday and expressed hope that they could play soon.

title: Adults Dorm
description: Residences for women offer safe, affordable housing but no co-ed sleepovers.

title: There Are Now 100,000 Apps for That
description: When Timothy Cook, Apples chief operating officer, remarked that people are just trying to catch up with the first iPhone that was announced two years ago, and we have long since moved beyond that, during the companys most recent earnings release, he may have had a point.

title: The Hospital of the Future
description: In The New York Times Magazine on Sunday, economics columnist David Leonhardt poses one of the more disturbing questions of the health care debate: If politicians cannot fix Americas fragmented, ailing health care system, who will? Physicians have reshaped medicine in the past, Mr. Leonhardt argues, and a few  like Dr. Brent James, chief quality officer of Intermountain Healthcare in Salt Lake City  already are leading the way to the future. Read the full article, and share your thoughts in the comments section.

title: In Surprise Move, Casino Magnate Abandons Bid for Aqueduct Racetrack
description: Stephen A. Wynn, the Las Vegas gambling impresario, on Wednesday dropped out of the bidding to revive the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens with 4,500 electronic slot machines, just two days before competing operators were to deliver their final offers for the complex.

title: Bus and Subway President Quits in M.T.A. Shake-Up
description: The avuncular chief of New York Citys buses and subways, Howard H. Roberts Jr., resigned on Wednesday after the new leadership at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority asked him to step down.

title: 53 Indicted on Drug Charges in Sweep of 2 Bronx Housing Projects
description: Less than a mile from Yankee Stadium, two gangs had the run of adjacent public housing projects in the Bronx, openly running heroin and crack cocaine trafficking rings, the authorities said.

title: Modeling and All That Came After
description: I FIRST met Lon Bing in Pasadena, in 1998, while working on an article about Rudi Gernreich, the California revolutionary who had shocked the world with his topless bathing suit. Ms. Bing, a model in the 1960s, had not worn the famous suit; that distinction belonged to Peggy Moffitt, who also saw herself as the keeper of Gernreichs legacy.

title: House Haggles Over Abortion in Health Care Bill
description: WASHINGTON  House Democratic leaders struggled Wednesday to strike a deal that would restrict the use of federal money to pay for abortions under sweeping health care legislation headed for debate on the House floor this week.

title: Committee Allows a Break on Certain Auditing Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Legislation that its supporters say would provide greater protection to investors sailed through a House committee on Wednesday, but not before the lawmakers added a provision to ease new auditing standards for small and medium-size companies.

title: Christie Pledges Fight on Taxes and Business Rules
description: Governor-elect Christopher J. Christie of New Jersey, basking in praise from Republicans who hailed him as the partys new star, said Wednesday that he would move quickly to suspend new regulations on business and find ways to lower crushing property taxes, the nations highest.

title: Fresh Idea From Recycle Bin
description: THE green movement in fashion, in which designers do go on about hugging the planet with their biodynamic cotton henleys, would appear to be at odds with the pop up shop movement in fashion, in which the very same designers open temporary stores, lavishly redecorate them and then, when they close a few weeks later, toss all the fixtures, lights and displays to the curb.

title: The Morning After, Democrats Regret Lost Chances to Win
description: As the cheering dies down over at William C. Thompson Jr.s headquarters, where close almost passed for victory on Tuesday evening, New Yorks Democrats are left to consider a colder reality:

title: Magazine by a Best-Selling Minister Closes
description: Less than a year after starting a hybrid magazine and paid membership organization, the Rev. Rick Warren and the Readers Digest Association said Wednesday that they were pulling the plug.

title: Pentagon Expected to Request More War Funding
description: WASHINGTON  The nations top military officer said Wednesday that he expected the Pentagon to ask Congress in the next few months for emergency financing to support the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, even though President Obama has pledged to end the Bush administration practice of paying for the conflicts with so-called supplemental funds that are outside the normal Defense Department budget.

title: Mayor Mends Fences After Slim Victory
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, stung by an election outcome that revealed resentment over his undoing of the term limits law and his extravagant campaign spending, moved quickly Wednesday to strike a conciliatory tone as he reached out to the Democratic establishment that backed his opponent in the mayors race.

title: Questions on Accuracy Delay Much-Awaited F.H.A. Audit
description: A much-anticipated audit of the Federal Housing Administration was abruptly postponed just before it was supposed to be made public, after questions arose about its accuracy.

title: A Dozen Things to Remember, or Maybe Just Forget, About the Election of 2009
description: It was, for New Yorkers, something of a civic embarrassment  spectacularly few people turning out to vote in a citywide election for mayor and a host of other significant offices. And it was, for Michael R. Bloomberg, something of a financial bust  spectacular amounts of money spent only to ultimately garner the most modest electoral mandate in nearly a century.

title: Correction: Preserving a Modernist Way of Life
description: An article on Aug. 27 about the preservation of Modernist houses on Cape Cod referred incompletely to the restoration of the Kugel House, built in 1970 in Wellfleet, Mass. Besides the work done by Peter McMahon, who designs and builds houses, Fox Diehl Architects of Manhattan was also involved in the restoration. The firm acted pro bono as the architects of record, doing research and reviewing the restoration drawings with the first owners of the house to ensure that the work was faithful to the original. This correction was delayed for research.

title: In 1968, Tigers Beat the Odds and the Cardinals Gibson in Game 7
description: The odds were heavily stacked against a Phillies comeback in the World Series after they fell down by three games to one. The Yankees were the 20th team to take such a lead with the final two games at home, and only three of those teams had lost the Series.

title: Energized G.O.P. Looks to Avoid Party Feud
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans emerged from Tuesdays elections energized by victories in Virginia and New Jersey, but their leaders immediately began maneuvering to avoid a prolonged battle with conservative activists over what the party stands for and how to regain power.

title: Oceans Apart
description: Digging through the closet in a panicked state, I cant find my uniform, my boots, my boonie cap, or my rifle. I know the bus is leaving; Im supposed to be on it. Im deploying to Iraq again.

title: Fiorina Formally Announces a Hinted-At Candidacy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As the dust settled from Tuesdays elections, one of next years potentially bruising campaigns came into focus on Wednesday as Carly Fiorina, a former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard and a Republican, declared her candidacy for the Senate seat long held by Barbara Boxer, a Democrat.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 25 about the new Frederick Wiseman film La Danse misstated the date of its theatrical release. It opened on Wednesday; it does not open this coming Wednesday, Nov. 11.

title: A Grotesque Romance
description: Patrick Blindauer often has something extra going on in his crosswords, and todays was no exception. I wont say outright whats up until later in the post. For any of you who are still struggling, I encourage you to stick with it. Theres an amusing and clever payoff lurking when you figure it out.

title: Bloggingheads: 'Mad Men' and J.F.K.
description: Emily Bazelon, left, and Hanna Rosin, both of Double X, discuss how "Mad Men" portrayed the Kennedy assassination.

title: Not Just Another Plaque on the Wall
description: Elijah McNally started rooting for the Yankees in 2004, when he was 6 years old. Back then, the Yankees were only a year removed from a World Series appearance, and another championship seemed just around the corner.

title: Cheers and Jeers Blended With Pride
description: The menu at El Nuevo Caridad features the Pedro Martinez  chicken stew, white rice, red beans, avocado salad and water. It costs $14. The Alex Rodriguez comes with chicken stew, rice and beans, too. But it also has fried plantains, a smoothie and cheesecake, and costs $18.

title: Restaurant Review: Banh Mi Doner Kebabs, Hanoi
description: Over the last year or so, the Vietnamese banh mi sandwich has taken New York by storm, elevating the once humble pork and pickled vegetable sandwich to heights of gastronomic chic. In Hanoi, however, the typical banh mi (which translates simply as bread in Vietnamese and is written in English as banh my in Hanoi) is a pedestrian fried egg or pt sandwich with a few slices of cucumber or a light smearing of chili sauce.

title: Nation Is Facing Vaccine Shortage for Seasonal Flu
description: Even though the regular flu season has yet to start, the nation is facing a severe shortage of seasonal flu vaccine as well as swine flu vaccine.

title: Bijags, a Tranquil Haven in a Troubled Land
description: SOME tropical destinations have long since been discovered and made familiar; others may yet be found, by a few anyway, but are unlikely to change much anytime soon. Too much separates us from them, in culture, space and time.

title: Tastes of Newly Fashionable Valparaso, Chile
description: ON a July afternoon in the Chilean port city of Valparaso, in the middle of the South American winter, I sat in the sunlit dining room at La Concepcin, drinking a tart-sweet pisco sour and cutting into a perfectly seared and salted piece of grouper.

title: Artists Lead the Way in the Oltrarno District of Florence
description: ON a midsummer afternoon in the courtyard of a former convent, a musical performance illustrated the shape of changes taking hold in the Oltrarno district of Florence. Using a pair of traditional items (a cello and a loom), a duo fashioned an entirely new sound  something like ambient electronica, only earthier  which issued into the twilight and drew enthusiastic reactions from onlookers.

title: Hotel Review: Commune by the Great Wall, Near Beijing
description: THE BASICS

title: James Up Next as Knicks Impress No One
description: The Knicks top priority this season, other than hoarding salary-cap space for LeBron James, is to impress LeBron James. They need him to believe they can be respectable, competitive and worthy of his presence when free agency opens in July.

title: Budget Monitor Says G.O.P. Bill Leaves Many Uninsured
description: The Congressional Budget Office said on Wednesday that an alternative health care bill put forward by House Republicans would have little impact in extending health benefits to the roughly 30 million uninsured Americans, but would reduce average insurance premium costs for people who have coverage.

title: Lottery Numbers
Fox Wins Election Night Ratings on Cable
description: An off-year election night of Republican victories in New Jersey and Virginia proved to be a big winner for the Fox News Channel, Nielsen ratings showed Wednesday.

title: 36 Hours in Nashville
description: NASHVILLE isnt nicknamed Music City for nothing. Singers, songwriters and pickers  not to mention their toe-tapping admirers  have been pouring into the Tennessee capital for decades. Yes, the citys rhinestone-studded past still glimmers, especially downtown, where youll find Hatch Show Print, the legendary poster shop, Ryman Auditorium, home to the original Grand Ole Opry stage, and a slew of honky-tonk joints. But theres more to Nashville than country music, especially in the once-sleepy neighborhoods that now beat to a different rhythm. Districts like East Nashville and 12 South thrive with lively bars, stylish restaurants and a young, eclectic crop of music makers, churning out everything from bluegrass to punkabilly.

title: A Powerful Idea on Youth Violence
description: As a former beat cop, Ron Huberman, the new chief of public schools in Chicago, learned long ago that violence among young urban people could not be solved simply by hauling ever larger numbers of children off to jail.

title: In Prague, Toasts to the Velvet Revolution
description: THERE will be sirens, the menacing growls of attack dogs and blinding searchlights. But this time the terror will be prerecorded, a staged reminder that in this part of Europe, free speech once had a terrible price tag.

title: Classical Music Takes Center Stage at the White House
description: WASHINGTON  Wednesday was classical music day at the White House. The festivities and performances were sponsored by the Presidents Committee on the Arts and the Humanities, created by executive order in 1982. The first lady serves as honorary chairwoman of the committee, and Michelle Obama, fully embracing that function, has created a White House Music Series.

title: Take the Shot
description: The swine flu vaccine has encountered a remarkably mixed reception. Some people are railing against their doctors about the vaccines scarcity while others are waiting hours in line for their shots. But a surprisingly large number of people  even some health care workers  are holding back because they fear the vaccine or dont view the virus as all that great a threat.

title: U.S.S. Missouri
description: The rising sun over the Koolau Mountains cast a glow upon the ballistic missiles planted on the lawn of a submarine museum at the edge of Pearl Harbor, throwing long shadows across the water. They pointed at the bone-white memorial to the U.S.S. Arizona and, just beyond it, at the still-floating battleship Missouri, about to leave her pier.

title: The Political Map After the 09 Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dogs Intelligence
description: To the Editor:

title: Prompting From the Wings
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Older Americans: The View From AARP
description: To the Editor:

title: Hark! The Voters Speak!
description: Cincinnati

title: Unhealthy America
description: The moment of truth for health care is at hand, and the distortion that perhaps gets the most traction is this:

title: Finally, an Authentic G.O.P.
description: Alexandria, Va.

title: Relax, Democrats
description: TO hear Republicans tell it, Tuesdays elections, in which their candidates captured the governorships of Virginia and New Jersey, were a repudiation of President Obama and indicated a voter shift toward their party. They should calm themselves down. The results dont show this and, in fact, suggest some rather daunting challenges for the Republicans.

title: Justices, in Aftermath of 2 Murder Cases, Hear Claims of a Process Gone Wrong
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments Wednesday in two cases involving claims that the criminal justice system had gone badly awry.

title: Thousands Failed to Vote, for Just as Many Reasons
description: New Yorkers by the tens of thousands failed to vote on Tuesday. And their reasons and excuses for not doing so numbered almost as many  apathy, absent-mindedness, willful protest and, for a great number, a belief that their vote just wouldnt count in a race that was not supposed to be in doubt.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Paris public bicycle rental systems problems with theft and vandalism referred imprecisely to the cost of the specially designed bikes. While each bike costs about $3,500 at current exchange rates when the systems startup and maintenance expenses are included, the manufacturing cost of each bike is about $1,050.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a bomb detection device used by the Iraqi security forces that is considered useless and costly by the American military misstated the surname of the leader of ATSC (UK) Ltd., the London-based company that has sold hundreds of the devices to Iraqs Interior Ministry. He is Jim McCormick, not Mitchell.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: William Belton, Self-Taught Ornithologist, Dies at 95
description: Once upon a time, every tweet had an actual bird attached. If that bird happened to live in southern Brazil, a region whose rich avian life was long undocumented, chances are good that it was stalked repeatedly  and its tweets, coos and whistles recorded patiently  by William Belton.

title: Saudi Arabia: Attackers Kill Border Guard
description: A Saudi border guard was killed and 10 were wounded Wednesday when gunmen from Yemen opened fire, the state-run Saudi Press Agency reported. The attack appeared to be the first on Saudi Arabia by the Houthi rebels, who have fought intermittently against the Yemeni government for more than five years, analysts said. The Houthis issued a statement saying they took control of the Jebel Dukhan area where the attack took place because Saudi Arabia had allowed the Yemeni Army to use the area for attacks on Houthis.

title: Using Marijuana Stores to Market Food
description: AFTER Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced in March that he would end the Bush administration practice of frequently raiding medical marijuana dispensaries, the dispensaries have been growing, appropriately enough, like weeds.

title: Britain: Conservatives Back Off Treaty Vote
description: A day after the Lisbon Treaty to strengthen the European Union cleared its last major hurdle, the leader of the British Conservatives, David Cameron, announced Wednesday that he would not hold a referendum on the accord if he became prime minister. Mr. Cameron had earlier promised to hold a referendum, but that was before it became clear that all 27 member countries would agree to the treaty. A made-up referendum might make people feel better for five minutes, he said in a speech in London, but my job is to put together a plan that lasts five years.

title: The Vote for Mayor, Block by Block
description: Mayor Bloomberg won re-election, but voters were less enthusiastic about him than the last time he ran in 2005.

title: Best Health Care in the World?
description: My Thursday column takes aim at one of the main arguments of the opponents of health reform, that we shouldnt mess with the best health care system in the world. Its a remarkably common delusion in the United States, while I almost never run into foreigners who would want to adopt the American system.

title: Delaware Laws, Helpful to Arms Trafficker, to Be Scrutinized
description: A Russian businessman who investigators say is the worlds largest arms trafficker used secret corporations formed in Delaware and other states to finance his activities. Now, the states business and tax practices are coming under Congressional scrutiny at a hearing on Thursday.

title: Offer Incentives, but Carefully
description: Frank A. DAmelio may be worth the $6 million of compensation he received last year as chief financial officer for Pfizer. But its questionable for the drug company to also pay him a $1.2 million bonus  half in cash and half in stock  for his role in acquiring its rival Wyeth. Rewarding executives for going shopping is daft.

title: Will the Yankees Victory Favor Wall St.s Bulls?
description: Update | 11:56 p.m. Wall Street should be happy that the New York Yankees won the World Series  and not just because the team is from New York. A coincidental sports indicator shows that a Yankee victory in the series has historically been bullish for the stock market.

title: Gustaf Mahler Unveils a New Philharmonic
description: Friday, Nov. 5, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: USAA: An Insurance Club That Just Got Bigger
Report Says Big Buyouts Are Likelier to Default
description: Apparently, bigger isnt always better  especially on Wall Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the legal problems of Raj Rajaratnam, a hedge fund manager charged with trading on inside information, misstated an arbitration panels damage award to Mr. Rajaratnam and Gary Rosenbach, another Galleon executive, on their claim that they were misled by the creators and promoters of a tax shelter later disallowed by the Internal Revenue Service. Although the panel found that $10 million in damages and interest was due and that John Schrier, a lawyer and accountant who recommended the shelter, was 50 percent responsible, it did not award damages from Mr. Schrier, who was not a party to the arbitration. Mr. Schrier and KPMG, his former employer, had already settled a related lawsuit on undisclosed terms, denying wrongdoing. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to Mr. Schriers role in the tax shelter. He helped market the tax shelter to Mr. Rajaratnam and Mr. Rosenbach; he did not create it.

title: George Naope, Master of Sacred Hula, Dies at 81
description: George Naope, whose mastery of the hula  the flowing, pantomimic dance of Hawaii  and its lilting chants made him a last link between an ancient ritual and modern entertainment, died on Oct. 26 at his home in Hilo, Hawaii. He was 81.

title: Back on Top, Yankees Add a 27th Title
description: A sliver of time for other teams is an epoch for the Yankees, who define themselves by championships. For eight seasons, they led the majors in victories, payroll and drama. They built a ballpark, created a network and expanded their brand around the globe. But they did not win the World Series.

title: Martinez Without Magic in Finale
description: In the shadow of his famed mango tree, survival skills came naturally to Pedro Martinez. His family slept on the floor of a tin-roofed house, two, sometimes three to a mattress. Instead of a bat, he would swing a broomstick. Instead of a ball, he would throw balled-up socks.

title: Corrections
description: The two photographs in the Transactions column on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday were reversed. The top picture showed the building for sale or lease at 438 West 51st Street, Manhattan, and the bottom picture showed the building that was recently sold at 205 West 88th Street, Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: The Really column on Oct. 20, about the claim that garlic can ward off a cold, omitted the source for the study it cited in support of garlics benefits. It was performed by Peter Josling, a British researcher who also runs a Web site promoting garlic supplements.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q&A column on Tuesday about why some people get a sore arm at the site of a flu vaccine injection while others do not referred incorrectly to Dr. E. Yoko Furuya, assistant director of epidemiology at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center. Dr. Furuya is a woman.

title: Francisco Ayala, a Spanish Novelist and Literary Scholar, Dies at 103
description: Francisco Ayala, an eminent Spanish novelist whose work explored societies in which there is much despotism and little benevolence, died on Tuesday at his home in Madrid. He was 103.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a proposal to remove Aspergers syndrome from the next edition of psychiatrys diagnostic manual misstated the educational affiliation for Temple Grandin, a well-known American with autism. She is a professor of animal science at Colorado State University, not the University of Colorado.

title: Prices Far Surpass Estimates at Sothebys Auction
description: In an Impressionist and modern art sale that had all the right ingredients  quality, value and variety  Sothebys salesroom was teeming on Wednesday night with a United Nations of enthusiastic bidders from Latin America, China, the United States, Russia and elsewhere in Europe.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about the theater impresario John Kenley gave the wrong year for a production of Picnic in which Mr. Kenley cast the football star Joe Namath. It was 1979, after Mr. Namath had retired from football  not 1971, when he was still near the height of his career as quarterback of the New York Jets.

title: A Celebration, Washington Heights Style
description: As Champagne celebrations go, the best one after the Yankees won the World Series might have been the one on the sidewalk of 191st Street in Washington Heights.

title: Can You Get the Flu From Mickey?
description: WHOM do you know who has been affected by the H1N1 virus, or Swine Flu?

title: South Korea Pension Buys 40 Grosvenor Place
description: South Koreas national pension fund said Thursday it had agreed to buy two office buildings in central London as part of a plan to increase investments in overseas properties, the news service Yonhap reported.

title: Word of the Day | dilate
description: dilate  \di-lat, di-\  verb

title: U.N. to Relocate 600 Workers Temporarily
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United Nations office in Afghanistan has decided to send about 600 of its foreign staff members out of the country in the wake of an attack last week on one of its guesthouses while more secure housing is found, a spokesman said Thursday.

title: Answers About Investor Behavior  Part 3
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which youll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals on a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Matsui Leaves a Lasting World Series Memory
description: Hideki Matsui does not know if he will ever play another game for the Yankees. The Yankees do not know if he will, either. If Matsui has played his final game with the team, he left the biggest stage in baseball in the same way he moved across it for seven seasons: professionally and exceptionally.

title: News Quiz | November 5, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: U.N. Relocates Foreign Staff in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United Nations mission in Afghanistan announced plans on Thursday to relocate hundreds of foreign staff members, sending some out of the country, in the wake of a lethal attack on its workers at a guesthouse last week.

title: Shopping for Gold
description: A young couple shopped for gold in Kadhimiya, under the watchful eye of the mother-in-law.

title: Value Line Pays $45 Million to Settle Fraud Case
description: The investment adviser Value Line, two former executives and an affiliated broker-dealer agreed on Wednesday to pay $45 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission fraud case.

title: Champions Again, Yankees Thoughts Turn to The Boss
description: George Steinbrenner always relied on Reggie Jackson to produce for him when he played for the Yankees, and Wednesday Jackson came though again, this time with an accurate and comforting prediction.

title: Australian Toll Road Firm Rejects $6.2 Billion Bid
description: Transurban Group, Australias biggest toll road operator, rejected an unsolicited 6.8 billion-Australian-dollar ($6.2 billion) takeover offer from Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, Bloomberg News reported.

title: French Minister Calls British Tories Pathetic
description: PARIS  In an unusual spat that may foretell choppy relations across the English Channel, a French government minister attacked Britains opposition Conservatives months before an election, calling their policy on Europe pathetic and reflecting a bizarre sense of autism.

title: Evergrande Leaps in First Day of Trading
description: Evergrande Real Estate Group, the largest Chinese developer by third-quarter sales, rose as much as 20 percent on its trading debut in Hong Kong, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Big Buyouts Seen as Likelier to Default
description: Apparently, bigger isnt always better  especially on Wall Street.

title: Och-Ziff Tipped to Reap from Rebound, Goldman Says
description: It seems that Goldman Sachs likes the looks of Och-Ziff Managements prospects.

title: Goldman Books Return in Sale of Shineway Stake
description: Goldman Sachs has agreed to sell half of its holding in Shineway Group, the Chinese meat processor that was among the first leveraged buyout targets in the country by a group of foreign investors, Reuters reported, citing sources with direct knowledge of the matter.

title: Now Showing | Dysfashional
description: The world needs another fashion exhibition like Valentino needs another pug. But Dysfashional, which opened this week at the Passage du Dsir in Paris, gives hope that despite the surfeit of recent shows, the subject matter may still have some bite. Although the shows curators, Luca Marchetti and Emanuele Quinz, have tapped designers like Raf Simons, Hussein Chalayan and Gaspard Yurkievich to contribute, the pair has chosen not to exhibit clothing, preferring instead to focus on the ideas and spectacle that surround fashion. Explains Marchetti, Dysfashional tackles the seemingly frivolous yet vital realm of fashion by examining the approach of designers and artists from various backgrounds, bringing us closer to a world in which the protagonists are not the objects but the creative process itself.

title: Should C.E.O.s Be Rewarded for Dealmaking?
description: Frank A. DAmelio may be worth the $6 million of compensation he received last year as chief financial officer for Pfizer. But, Breakingviews says, its questionable for the drug company to also pay him a $1.2 million bonus  half in cash and half in stock  for his role in acquiring its rival Wyeth. Rewarding executives for going shopping is crazy, the publication suggests.

title: For Kraft, What Price Cadbury?
description: Kraft, the Oreo-to-Cheez Whiz conglomerate, beat profit estimates for the third quarter but lowered its sales forecast for the year. That highlights the charms of Cadbury, the faster-growing British confectioner Kraft is circling. But Kraft would still struggle to justify making a hostile bid higher than its current offer, Breakingviews argues.

title: Martinez Not in Mood to Talk
description: A crowd of reporters was waiting outside the Phillies clubhouse late Wednesday night, maybe 15 minutes after the game, when someone said that Pedro Martinez had just left and was walking toward the Yankee Stadium exit. It seemed bizarre  why would Martinez be leaving before his teammates (Shane Victorino, for one, didnt know he was already gone), and before speaking to the news media? .

title: Non-Fire Night
description: Health and safety inspired bonfire-less bonfire night celebrations.

title: Should Gay Couples Be Allowed to Marry?
description: A Maine state law permitting same-sex marriage was repealed at the polls on Tuesday. What, if anything, do you think the Maine vote says about the national mind-set about gay marriage?On Wednesday, Abby Goodnough reported on the efforts to promote same-sex marriage to voters in Maine and what the outcome of the vote might suggest:

title: Winston & Strawn Hires Nixon Peabody P.E. Team
description: Looking to crack the New York private equity market, law firm Winston & Strawn has nabbed a group of eight lawyers led by Dominick DeChiara from rival Nixon Peabody, to launch a core deal team in the city.

title: Stocks Lose Steam at Close on Wall Street
description: The Dow Jones industrial average erased almost all of a 156-point rally after the House of Representatives passed a bill to curb rate increases on credit cards, touching off concern about bank earnings. The news outweighed investor optimism after the Federal Reserve said it planned to keep interest rates at a record low, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Sequoia Puts $6.5 Million into Eventbrite
description: Eventbrite, the online event management and ticketing site, has landed $6.5 million in fresh funding, led by a new investor, Sequoia Capital, TechCrunch reported.

title: AOL Dents Time Warner Ahead of Spinoff
description: Time Warners third-quarter results make it abundantly clear why the media conglomerate cant wait to get rid of AOL.

title: Riding the Roads as the Romans Do
description: How do Romans get that extra kick between espressos? They hop on a Vespa, take a deep breath and plunge into the citys famously chaotic traffic. If the idea makes your hair stand on end, renting one of the motor scooters may not be for you. But if you know your way around on two wheels back home, once you get going, youll find there is an elaborate code of order on the roads.

title: Solid Results for One Dealmaker: Cisco
description: Cisco Systems, the computer networking giant that has been on a bit of a shopping spree of late, supplied more evidence on Wednesday that technology sales were recovering along with the global economy.

title: Google Offers Users a Peek at Stored Data
description: Update 2:25 PM Adds Comments From More Privacy Advocates

title: Is Dodd on Collision Course Over Banking Bill?
description: Legislation being prepared by the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Christopher J. Dodd, would redraw how the financial system is regulated and could pit the Senate against the House and the Obama administration, which have backed distinctly different plans to overhaul the financial system, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Committee Allows a Break on Certain Auditing Rules
description: Legislation that its supporters say would provide greater protection to investors sailed through a House committee on Wednesday, but not before the lawmakers added a provision to ease new auditing standards for small and medium-size companies, The New York Timess Stephen Labaton reported.

title: Matsui Goes Wild, and So Do His Fans in Japan
description: TOKYO  For many Japanese, Hideki Matsui is a man of contradictions  a towering hulk with a sensitive heart, a player of fierce self-discipline known for lewd jokes and a national hero who refuses to play for his country at international tournaments, much to the chagrin of his home fans.

title: Some Wall St. Bonuses May Hit Pre-Crisis Highs
description: Now is the time of year when a Wall Streeters fancy turns to thoughts of bonuses.

title: Cuomo Files Antitrust Suit Against Intel
description: In 2005, Michael S. Dells namesake company was getting pounded. His competitors were selling personal computers and servers built on cheap, popular and powerful chips from Advanced Micro Devices, while Mr. Dell had stuck loyally with slower chips from Intel.

title: On-Q-ity Lands $21 Million
description: On-Q-ity, a new cancer diagnostics business, announced that it has raised $21 million in venture capital. The round was led by Mohr Davidow Ventures and included Bessemer Ventures, Physic Ventures and Northgate Capital.

title: Will the Real Larry Summers Please Stand Up?
description: There seems to be little doubt that Lawrence H. Summers is a polarizing figure.

title: Is This the Droid Youre Looking For?
description: The latest hotly-anticipated app phone  a term David Pogue Twit-sourced  is the Motorola Droid. It runs on Verizon and Googles Android operating system (the 2.0 version) and the design, Pogue writes, screams Star Wars, if not Darth Vader. Its jet-black, all sharp angles and industrial-looking edges. Its super-fast, with good audio quality, a pull-out screen and a stellar GPS. The Droid may not be an iPhone killer, Pogue writes, but it is a killer phone. Get it starting tomorrow for $200 after a $100 rebate (Pogues tip: Get it at Best Buy, where you get the rebate on the spot) and play with it in your man cave.

title: Home Green Home: Burning Wisely
description: The following is the latest in a series exploring the ways Americans are improving the efficiency and reducing the footprint of their homes. Green Inc. readers are encouraged to share their thoughts and experiences in the comments section, or by sending e-mail messages to greeninc@nytimes.com.

title: Unpublishable Name
description: The Canadian band ****** Up , led by a bearded, jowly  and surprisingly jolly  singer named Pink Eyes, builds an ecosystem of gorgeous guitar harmony and ambient texture inside the gray rhythmic world of stomping eighth-note punk, writes Ben Ratliff. So: theyre lovelier than they may seem. This will be especially true tonight, when they play the entirety of their latest, critically-beloved album, The Chemistry of Common Life, at the Brooklyn Masonic Temple with the help of special guests Andrew W.K. and Vivian Girls. Come early for the openers Titus Andronicus.

title: Idiot Savant at the Public
description: Idiot Savant,  the latest from the long-running downtown auteur Richard Foreman, stars Willem Dafoe in the title role, and allows its actors to speculate at length about what it means to be in a play about an idiot savant, and whether theyre idiots for even talking about it. Classic Foreman, writes Ben Brantley, but amped up by Dafoe, who wears a costume that is unequal parts samurai warrior, 17th-century French courtier and contemporary businessman, and brings a stars bright idiosyncrasy to the part. It raises the humor and humanity to heights rarely felt in a Foreman work, Brantley writes. Get your tickets now; its at the Public.

title: Obama in China: Breaking the Exchange-Rate Deadlock
description: Simon Johnson, a professor of entrepreneurship at M.I.T.s Sloan School of Management, is the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

title: Indonesia Officials Resign in Graft Scandal
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  After mounting pressure from the public and the news media, two senior law enforcement officials suspected of trying to undermine the countrys respected anticorruption agency were forced to resign Thursday.

title: Panasonic Makes $4.4 Billion Offer for Sanyo
description: Panasonic said Thursday that it had begun a tender offer to take over a smaller rival, Sanyo Electric, for an estimated 402 billion yen ($4.4 billion), moving closer to creating one of the worlds biggest electronics makers.

title: Man Group Profit Beats Forecast
description: Man Group, the British hedge fund firm, reported higher-than-expected profits, helped by an uptick in fund performance and a rebound in assets, confirming it is recovering from the industrys toughest period on record.

title: Does Technology Devalue Old People?
description: Todays idea: The same technological progress that enables our society to keep an ever-larger percentage of old folks bodies going has simultaneously reduced the value of the minds within those bodies, a blogger says. What to do?

title: And What If Oracle Drops Sun Deal?
description: If Oracle decides to walk away from its $7.4 billion bid to buy Sun Microsystems, it may be no big deal for Oracle, but it could end up being a big problem for Sun, Forbes notes.

title: E.U. Faces Tricky Decision on Oracle Deal
description: The European Commission must decide in coming days whether to issue formal charges against Oracles $7.4 billion offer to acquire Sun Microsystems  and neither of its options looks appealing, The New York Timess James Kanter writes.

title: Speed Read for Thursday, Nov. 5
description: Highlights from media coverage in The New York Times on Thursday:

title: Week 9 Game Probabilities, and a Forecast for Giants-Chargers
description: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior. His team rankings can be found here. )

title: When Will the S.E.C. Ever Admit They Made a Mistake?
description: That was the headline  in ALL CAPS  of a e-mail message I received recently from a lawyer named Robert W. Pearce. Mr. Pearces client, Steven J. Wilson, was one of the two men I wrote about in late June who had been accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of taking part in a small-time stock-manipulation scheme  and who, after five years of investigation and various legal proceedings, had been found not guilty in trials that lasted literally days.

title: Fed Sees No Need to Raise Interest Rates Soon
description: The Federal Reserve signaled on Wednesday it was not close to raising interest rates, saying that the economy remained weak even though the recession appeared to be over, Edmund L. Andrews writes in The New York Times.

title: European Bankers Defend Industrys Profit and Pay
description: It is not exactly like Gordon Gekko and his greed is good speech from the movie Wall Street, but an increasing number of top European bankers are speaking up in moral tones in defense of their industrys practices and paychecks, Julila Werdigier writes in The New York Times.

title: Avoiding Theme Parks
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below:

title: International Prosecutor to Seek Inquiry Into Kenya Violence
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Members of the political elite in Kenya, a nation where top leaders have long escaped prosecution for corruption and other crimes, could now face an international investigation into the violence that shook the country after disputed elections last year.

title: Judge Dismisses Suit Stemming From Staten Island Ferry Crash
description: He said he was yet another victim of one of the worst transportation disasters in New York history, the 2003 Staten Island ferry crash that killed 11 people and badly injured many more.

title: BNP and Commerzbank Earnings Part Ways
description: The earnings of two European banks, BNP Paribas and Commerzbank, painted a stark contrast between the winners and losers of the financial crisis a little over a year after Lehman Brothers fell.

title: Sampler: Maine Lessons, Burning Rules, Christmas Songs
description: Senate Race | Carly Fiorinas formal announcement yesterday that she is running for the Republican nomination to challenge Barbara Boxers seat in the U.S. Senate will be another test of the American principle that anyone can seek political office, writes the Los Angeles Times columnist Michael Hiltzik.

title: In Surprise Move, Wynn Drops Racetrack Bid
description: Stephen A. Wynn, the Las Vegas gambling impresario, on Wednesday dropped out of the bidding to revive the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens with 4,500 electronic slot machines, just two days before competing operators were to deliver their final offers for the complex, Charles V. Bagli of The New York Times reported.

title: Bank of England Adds $40 Billion to Stimulus
description: The Bank of England decided Thursday to inject 25 billion more into the economy to try to spur a recovery after surprising data showed the recession in Britain had dragged into the autumn, Julia Werdigier reported in The New York Times.

title: Health Care History 101
description: In an article about health care in this weekends Times Magazine, I allude to several histories of medical care. They were recommended by Dr. Brent James, the chief quality officer at Intermountain Healthcare, a network of hospitals and clinics in Utah and Idaho that President Obama and others have described as a model for health reform. Dr. James and Intermountain are the subject of much of the article.

title: That Fiat Got a Hemi? Nope, but It Still Has 725 HP
description: LAS VEGAS  Now that Chryslers chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, has laid out the companys five-year survival plan, its not so unnatural to associate Chryslers iconic Hemi engine with anything wearing a Fiat badge.
