At least it didnt seem so when walking the miles of aisles at the annual SEMA.Show.

title: UBS Hit With Fine for Unauthorized Trading
description: Regulators in Britain fined UBS 8 million on Thursday after finding that employees at the Swiss banks wealth management unit in London had carried out unauthorized trading on at least 39 customer accounts, David Jolly writes in The New York Times.

title: When Will the S.E.C. Ever Admit They Made a Mistake?
description: From Joe Nocera at Executive Suite:

title: Update: Scripps to Buy Control of Travel Channel
description: Scripps Networks said Thursday that it was buying a controlling stake in the Travel Channel, in a deal valuing the network at $975 million. It will own 65 percent of a new joint venture controlling the Travel Channel, while its current parent, Cox Communications, will own 35 percent. Read More>>

title: Using Prizes to Drive Energy Innovation
description: Can prize competitions propel energy and climate technology the way they have space technology? The recent proliferation of contests with ample rewards suggests that many people think they can.

title: Can Pets Get Swine Flu?
description: Readers recently asked the Consults blog whether cats, dogs and other pets could get sick from swine flu:

title: What to Watch Thursday: Housewives and an Ikea Field Trip
description: The Real Housewives of Orange County (Bravo, 10 p.m.), the mothership of the Real Housewives franchise, begins its fifth season and just as in the recently concluded Atlanta season, the economy is taking its toll. Or, as Jeana so poignantly puts it, Ive had my own special challenges with not making the same income and having the same expenses.

title: Two Held in Killings of Russian Lawyer, Reporter
description: MOSCOW  Two young people identified as ultranationalists will face charges in the January shooting that killed a crusading lawyer and a reporter, an attack that cast a pall over Russias dwindling circle of human rights activists.

title: The Early Word: Post-Mortems
description: O.K., so Election Day is behind us. The Yankees won the World Series. Whats next?

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading (and watching) on Thursday morning.

title: 100 Things Restaurant Staffers Should Never Do (Part 2)
description: This is the second half of the 100 dos and donts from last weeks post. Again, this list is for one particular restaurant, mine, which is under construction in Bridgehampton, N.Y., and will, with any luck, open this spring. I realize that every deli needs a wisecracking waiter, most pizza joints can handle heavy metal, and burgers always taste better when delivered by a server with tattoos and tongue piercing(s).

title: Favorite Yankees World Series Moment: Tell Us Your Story
description: Whats your favorite moment from the Yankees history in the World Series? We want to hear from you. Tell us your story in the comments section below and well highlight some of them over the next few days. Please include your full name, age and hometown.

title: Exploring the Details of 2 Notable Deals
description: Update | Nov. 6, 10:13 a.m. The acquisition agreements for Stanley Works combination with Black & Decker and Berkshire Hathaways takeover of Burlington Northern Santa Fe have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and they both reinforce the themes that I highlighted on Tuesday in 2 Big Deals and the Search for an M.&A. Market.

title: Mayor Tries to Project Conciliation, and Authority
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, stung by an election outcome that revealed resentment over his undoing of the term limits law and his extravagant campaign spending, moved quickly Wednesday to strike a conciliatory tone as he reached out to the Democratic establishment that backed his opponent in the mayors race.

title: California Water Deal: Too Watered Down?
description: Peter H. Gleick, president of the Pacific Institute and one of the countrys leading experts on water issues, can barely contain his lack of enthusiasm for the deal struck in Sacramento early Wednesday. Below is his take; please weigh in with yours.

title: To Get to Sesame Street, Hang a Left, Says One Blogger
description: Updated | 12:29 p.m. In her Arts & Leisure essay on the 40th anniversary of Sesame Street, Alessandra Stanley writes that that long-running childrens program is still a messianic show, but the mission has shifted to the more immediate concerns of pediatricians and progressive parents.

title: Pogue & Friends 2009 Travel Holiday Guide
description: The Timess personal technology columnist, David Pogue, teams up with travel columnist Michelle Higgins to share their favorite travel gadgets. Watch the video.

title: Unleashing Lifes Wild Things
description: A FEW weekends ago I sat near the back of the biggest theater in my local multiplex, part of a packed house watching Spike Jonzes Where the Wild Things Are. The film had just opened to reviews that ranged from grouchy to ecstatic, and to quite a bit of hand wringing about its dark, sad, scary or otherwise non-child-appropriate content. There was a lot of speculation too about the size, composition and receptivity of the audience. Would children embrace it? Would adults be scared off? Who was this movie  so melancholy in its whimsy, so rueful in its sentiment  really meant for?

title: 14 People Charged in Insider Trading Case
description: Update | 6:21 p.m. The New York Timess Alex Berenson provides more details of this developing case. DealBook has been updating this post with documents from the case.

title: Weekly Popcast: Weezer, Amerie and Geoff Muldaur
description: This week: Ben Ratliff reviews Raditude by the California alt-rock group Weezer; Jon Pareles discusses In Love & War by the R&B singer Amerie; and the blues-folk guitarist Geoff Muldaur performs live and talks with Ben Sisario about his new album Geoff Muldaur and the Texas Sheiks. Sia Michel is the host.

title: More Than McCardell
description: Resort collections have become such a big part of the fashion scene, almost losing their original purpose, that I was struck by the novelty of Caroline Rennolds Milbanks new book, Resort Fashion, Style in Sun-Drenched Climates (Rizzoli: $65).

title: Agrium Raises Its Hostile Bid for CF Industries
description: Update | 12:39 p.m. The nearly yearlong takeover battle involving three fertilizer makers  Agrium, CF Industries and Terra Industries  may be moving toward its final stages. On Thursday, Agrium made what it said was its best and final offer for CF Industries.

title: N.H.L. Scores: Without Ovechkin, Caps Lose in Newark
description: Six games on Wednesday night, with the big question among them asking how Washington would do without Alex Ovechkin, sidelined with an upper-body injury after an innocent collision with Raffi Torres last Sunday. Home teams listed first:

title: Schumer Seeks to Block Stimulus Money for Chinese-Backed Texas Wind Farm
description: Post updated 2:30 p.m.

title: A Rebel Stronghold in Myanmar on Alert
description: MONG HPEN, Myanmar  Conquering armies of centuries past avoided this remote, mountainous area along the present-day border with China, a place once described by a British colonial official as an unpenetrated enclave of savage hills.

title: Retailers Report Sales Increases
description: Of all the retailers hurt by the recession, no group has been pummeled as badly as luxury chains. For months, high-end stores have posted double-digit declines, even as other types of retailers have begun clawing their way toward sales gains.

title: Outsiders Are In
description: Where have all the outlaws gone? Not your everyday miscreants  the world has enough of those  but baddies who were revered as much as feared: Robin Hood, Marius Jacob, Blackbeard, Calamity Jane. Theres something refreshingly anachronistic about these old-school brigands, and their appeal is not lost on todays artists. The indie rock band the Decemberists have populated an entire songbook with bandit queens, neer-do-wells and murderous rakes. And noirish biopics like Public Enemies reveal that not only are we perpetually captivated by outlaws, but their daring and style also seem increasingly remote from the present &#8212 no ones casting Marion Cotillard to play Ruth Madoff.

title: Thursday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Minor Leagues Scoreboard
description: THE SCOREBOARDWednesdayA.H.L.Adirondack 4, at Bridgeport 2Binghamton 2, at Albany 0Hershey 5, at Lowell 2Chicago 4, at Milwaukee 3At Rockford 5, San Antonio 3The roundup is hereThe standings are hereECHLAt Toledo 5, Kalamazoo 4 OTAt Charlotte 4, Florida 4 SOAt Utah 5, Idaho 2Stockton 3, at Ontario 2The standings are here

title: No Doubt Sues Maker of Guitar Hero Video Games
description: Courtney Love threatened to do it, but Gwen Stefani actually went there: Ms. Stefani and her band, No Doubt, have sued the makers of the Guitar Hero video game franchise, saying that their latest entry in the series misuses the likenesses of the group members, Reuters reported.

title: Always the Same Thing
description: Maybe the most interesting thing about the reader reaction to this weeks review of Le Relais de Venise is the number of people who report themselves excited by the idea that they dont have to think about what to order when they go there. The restaurant only serves salad, steak and fries. (Maybe the least interesting is the gastrohipster outrage that such a restaurant would merit review in The Times.)

title: Junior Leagues Scoreboard
description: WednesdayQ.M.J.H.L.At Saint John 3, Halifax 2Victoriaville 5, at Drummondville 1Lewiston 5, at Montreal 4The roundup is hereThe standings are hereO.H.L.Barrie 6, at Owen Sound 1Peterborough 4, at Belleville 3 SOThe Colts/Attack recap is here, and the Petes/Bulls recap is hereThe standings are hereW.H.L.Moose Jaw 6, at Prince Albert 5 SOAt Regina 7, at Medicine Hat 4At Saskatoon 2, Swift Current 1At Calgary 3, Edmonton 2At Lethbridge 3, Everett 2At Kelowna 5, Prince George 4 SOVancouver 4, at Portland 0At Spokane 5, Chilliwack 5The roundup is hereThe standings are hereU.S.H.L.No games scheduledThe standings are here

title: Ausra Sells Planned Plant to First Solar
description: Ausra is continuing its exit from the business of building solar-power plants, announcing on Wednesday that it has sold a planned California solar farm to First Solar.

title: Think Your Bus Is Slow? Try Losing to a Tricycle
description: The new chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has pledged to bring faster speeds and better reliability to the citys overtaxed bus fleet. A report out Thursday shows hes got his work cut out for him.

title: Fannie Mae to Allow Borrowers to Lease Homes
description: WASHINGTON  Some homeowners who face foreclosure may be able to stay as tenants in their houses for the time being, even if they forfeit ownership, under a program announced on Thursday by Fannie Mae.

title: Raising Boise States Profile
description: While the Boise State football team does all it can on the field to try to show it belongs in the conversation for the B.C.S. title, its conference is trying a different tactic.

title: Rules on Modified Corn Skirted, Study Says
description: As many as 25 percent of the American farmers growing genetically engineered corn are no longer complying with federal rules intended to maintain the resistance of the crops to damage from insects, according to a report Thursday from an advocacy group.

title: The Shifting Definitions of Merit in Admissions
description: All this week on The Timess home page, in a featured called Talk to The Times, I am answering select reader questions about admissions in much the way a roster of outside experts does in the Guidance Office on The Choice. (In fact, regular readers of this blog will notice that Ive turned to some familiar names for help with some of my answers.)

title: Bloomberg Builds a Staff for BusinessWeek
description: The staff at Bloomberg BusinessWeek is slowly coming together.

title: To This Day, Chair Umpire Has No Answer for McEnroe
description: Answer the question. The question, jerk!

title: What You Need to Know About Ulcers
description: Dr. Mae F. Go is a gastroenterologist and associate professor of medicine at the University of Utah School of Medicine in Salt Lake City. She has treated and researched ulcer disease for more than 20 years.

title: Gilded-Age Monuments and Secrets
description: THE Metropolitan Museum of Arts exhibition of the sculpture of Augustus Saint-Gaudens, rich with the work of one of the key figures in the American Renaissance, ends next Sunday. A running theme in the show  indeed, in Saint-Gaudenss entire life  is his enduring friendship with the architect Stanford White. As it happens, they were interested in delights not only artistic, but earthly.

title: Selected Studies: Peptic Ulcers
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit clinicaltrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: If They Stop, Well Stop, Murdoch Says of MSNBC-Fox Feud
description: Rupert Murdoch says News Corporation will resume its truce with General Electric  if MSNBC stops slinging mud at Mr. Murdochs Fox News Channel.

title: Boyle Moves Mountains for Slumdog Millionaire Follow-Up
description: Choosing ones next movie project after winning Academy Awards for best director and best film doesnt always come quickly  just ask James Cameron  but Danny Boyle, whose film Slumdog Millionaire won eight Oscars in February, has figured out his follow-up. Variety reported that Mr. Boyle (whose films also include Trainspotting and 28 Days Later) will next direct 127 Hours, a biographical film about the mountaineer Aron Lee Ralston. Mr. Ralston made headlines in 2003 when, in his exploration of Robbers Roost in southeastern Utah, an 800-pound boulder fell on his right hand and crushed it; after being trapped for several days, he sawed off the trapped arm and hiked to his rescue. The project is expected to reunite Mr. Boyle with his Slumdog Millionaire screenwriter Simon Beaufoy and producer Christian Colson. Production is expected to begin next year; no casting has yet been announced.

title: Idiot Savant
description: Photos from Richard Foremans new show at the Public Theater.

title: Conductor Slatkin Recovering After Heart Attack
description: Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, told The Detroit Free Press that he felt lucky to be alive after having emergency surgery on Sunday to unblock a clogged artery. Mr. Slatkin, 65, the former music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, had a heart attack while conducting the Rotterdam Philharmonic in the Netherlands, and is now resting in a hospital there after undergoing an angioplasty and stent procedure. In an e-mail exchange with The Free Press, Mr. Slatkin wrote that he experienced chest pains earlier in the week but dismissed them as indigestion. At the Sunday concert, he wrote: I started having trouble with chest pain and I was sweating more than usual. Again, I thought it would go away but it stuck around. I sort of collapsed in the dressing room and a medical team from the hall was sent in. Five minutes later I was in an ambulance on the way to the hospital. He added that he was scheduled to fly to Prague later that night, and it is very possible that I might not have survived that long. The Detroit Symphony Orchestra told The Free Press that Mr. Slatkin is still scheduled to conduct the orchestra in Detroit this month, but contingency plans are being made in case he is unable to perform.

title: European Puck: Forsberg Hunt Intensifies
description: Whither Peter Forsberg?

title: Bagna Cauda, 1960
description: Nearly 50 years ago, just before Julia Child unleashed a torrent of whisk-intensive French dishes on a nation of canned-string-bean devotees and a decade before Marcella Hazan would introduce us to northern Italian wonders like risotto and frittata, The Timess food editor, Craig Claiborne, was ushering groundbreaking recipes into the paper at an astonishing rate. He wrote about lebkuchen, Chinese spareribs, navarin dagneau and even an obscure Piedmontese peasant staple called bagna cauda.

title: Over in Washington
description: Monologue |  Aired Wednesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Over in Washington, President Obama called and congratulated Republican Bob McDonnell today after he won the governorship in Virginia. Obama then moved Virginia to the bottom of the swine flu vaccine waiting list.

title: Mapping the Sites of Con Eds Stray Voltage
description: New Yorkers can use interactive online maps to gather a vast amount of information about their neighborhoods, from how many bars they contain to where the nearest subway and bus stops are. Now they can find out how many light poles have been electrified.

title: He Changed the Law
description: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Well, the Democratic Party has a new slogan. What happened?

title: Bad Year for Democrats
description: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Youre here on a very special night, ladies and gentlemen. The entire balcony here at the Ed Sullivan Theater tonight is filled with defeated Democrats. Yeah, buddy!

title: Yes to Medical Marijuana
description: Monologue |  Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Yesterday was election day and the people of New Jersey elected a new governor. Thats right. Yeah, and I dont know how he did it, but congratulations to newly elected New Jersey Governor Hamid Karzai.

title: Trade Unions Decline Around the World
description: Weve written before about the declining influence (and popularity) of trade unions in the United States. How are they faring elsewhere in the developed world?

title: 1960: Bagna Cauda
description: This recipe appeared in an article in The Times by Craig Claiborne. The sauce is timeless, but you may want to update the selection of vegetables.

title: Audi TTS to Take on Pikes Peak, Without a Driver
description: The 12.4-mile Pikes Peak International Hill Climb up winding mountain roads near Colorado Springs, Colo., dates to 1916, and winners, driving just about anything on wheels in a wide variety of classes, have included Mario Andretti and Al Unser. Its safe to say that the competition has never been won by a car driving itself, but Chris Gerdes, a professor of mechanical engineering at Stanford, is out to change that.

title: TPG and Pension Plan to Buy IMS Health
description: IMS Health, a health care data company, said Thursday that it had agreed to be acquired by the private equity firm TPG and Canada Pension Plan for $4 billion in cash.

title: On the Hill, Protesters Chant Kill the Bill
description: Thousands of opponents of the Democrats health care legislation are gathered outside the Capitol, for a noon news conference and rally led by Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, and the chants are already under way, echoing across the Mall.

title: Palestinian Leader Says He Will Retire
description: Update | 2:06 p.m. The Israeli newspaper Haaretz reports:

title: No. 1 Omission From Top 10 Book List: Women
description: The trade publication Publishers Weekly likely wanted to provoke discussion with its annual list of the years best books, but not like this. In its issue of Nov. 2, Publishers Weekly compiled its PW Top 10, a decidedly subjective ranking of the best fiction and non-fiction published in 2009, including the biography Cheever: A Life by Blake Bailey; the novel Await Your Reply by Dan Chaon; and the graphic novel Stitches by David Small. But as The Guardian reports, the ranking has drawn protests from a womens literary group, which notes that there are no female writers on the list.

title: Protesters of Health Care Reform Chant Kill the Bill
description: Thousands of opponents of the Democrats health care legislation are gathered outside the Capitol, for a noon news conference and rally led by Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, and the chants are already underway, echoing across the Mall.

title: Teutonic Plates | Berlins Gastro Get-Togethers
description: Before the Berlin wall came down in 1989, the two Germanys each had their own culinary history. Spicy Russian stew in the East, maultaschen and sauerkraut in the West. This weekend, a couple of international gourmands are pitting the two sides against one another, inviting the culinarily curious to engage in a little exercise of gastro politics. Saturday, Sunday and Monday  the three nights leading up to the 20th anniversary of the fall of the wall  the writer and part-time Berlin resident Caroline Hobkinson, along with the Cordon Bleu-trained pastry chef Rachel Khoo, are hosting 30-euro, five-course dinners in an apartment just 50 yards from the old wall.

title: Kerik Pleads Guilty in Corruption Case
description: Updated, 12:45 p.m. | Bernard B. Kerik, a former New York police commissioner, pleaded guilty to eight felonies in a Federal District Court in White Plains on Thursday morning. Mr. Kerik, who will be sentenced in February, faces 27 to 33 months in prison.

title: PBS Ombudsman Responds to Pox News Parody on Sesame Street
description: Earlier on Thursday, we noted a Sesame Street segment that had upset conservative bloggers with its reference to a trashy news channel called Pox News, which seemed to be a satire on Fox News.

title: Holding Back the Ulcer Bug
description: Gastroenterologist Dr. Nimish Vakil is a clinical professor at the University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health in Madison who helped write the American College of Gastroenterologys practice guidelines for managing upper abdominal pain or discomfort. Dr. Vakil has also served as a consultant to multiple pharmaceutical companies, including the makers of acid-blocking pills.

title: Travel Deals: An Affordable Weekend in Fort Lauderdale
description: Dreading the start of winter? This week, Travelzoo.com, a travel deals publisher, is featuring Fort Lauderdale as its Destination of the Week, with discounts on airfare, hotels and activities. Heres how to turn those deals into an affordable long weekend.

title: Team Unity Around the Camp Fire
description: Alison Lacey is a 6-foot senior point guard for Iowa State. Alison, whose hometown is Canberra, Australia, is a communications studies major and, like she did last season, will give The Quad an inside look at the Cyclones this year.

title: What to Ask About Peptic Ulcers
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Helping Our Children With Stress
description: Every year the American Psychological Association takes our emotional temperature with its report titled Stress in America.

title: 14 Charged With Insider Trading in Galleon Case
description: After weeks of speculation on Wall Street, prosecutors brought a fresh round of insider trading charges on Thursday that left no doubt they were aiming at hedge funds and the networks of market gossip that are endemic on trading floors.

title: Two More Billys for Broadway
description: Poor Mrs. Elliot may be gone to heaven, but somehow, she keeps reproducing. On Thursday, the producers of Billy Elliot the Musical said two more actors would be joining its Broadway cast to portray the title role. Dayton Tavares, 13, who has played the character in the musicals Sydney and Melbourne casts, will become the sixth member of the Broadway Billy club, and Liam Redhead, 14, a student of the National Ballet School in Toronto, will become the seventh, the shows publicists said in a news release. Additionally, Tommy Batchelor, who is leaving the Broadway cast to play Billy in the shows Chicago production, will play his final New York performance on Dec. 11. The Broadway role was originated by David Alvarez, Kiril Kulish and Trent Kowalik, who won Tony Awards for their performances. Starting dates for Mr. Tavares and Mr. Redhead were not announced.

title: The New Face of Ulcer Disease
description: When a former first lady, Barbara Bush, was rushed to a Houston emergency room late last year with terrible pain from a perforated ulcer in her stomach, she was in many ways the typical face of ulcer disease today in the United States. The source of Mrs. Bushs trouble was not Helicobacter pylori, the notorious ulcer-instigating bacterium. Instead, as is true in a rising proportion of ulcer cases, the culprit was pain medications.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) Nicholas Kristof on health care misconceptions.

title: Obama Courts House Democrats Before Vote
description: In a last-minute exercise of presidential hand-holding, President Obama plans to travel to Capitol Hill on Friday morning to meet with House Democrats, one day before they vote on his highest domestic priority: a bill to overhaul the nations health care system.

title: Karadzic Gets Delay, and Lawyer, in War Crimes Trial
description: PARIS  Judges ordered Thursday that a lawyer be imposed on Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader on trial in The Hague for war crimes and genocide, but halted the trial until March 1, to give a lawyer time to get ready.

title: Vintage Baseball
description: This post may be of interest only to baseball fans, Yankees fans and New Yorkers. So be it. When your team wins the World Series perhaps that is license for a bit of self-indulgence.

title: Readers Ask: Ulcers
description: Update | Nov. 9 10:16 a.m. Thank you for your questions on ulcers; Dr. Abraham is no longer taking questions, but see her responses in:

title: Derek Jeter to Appear on Letterman
description: Derek Jeter will appear on The Late Show with David Letterman Thursday night to discuss winning another World Series championship with the Yankees. He will be joined by Jorge Posada, Andy Pettitte and Hideki Matsui. Since Letterman asked Commissioner Bud Selig if he had ever used steroids last week, maybe he will ask Jeter about Minka Kelly.

title: Training and Trusting Local Forces
description: When my company commander hesitantly asked me about taking my platoon on a joint patrol I sensed that something was wrong. My commander at the time, Capt. Scott Cheney, never asked me to do something; he was the commander, and his authority was absolute.

description: News from the big man, the skinny man, the skinny mans mom, and the chef:

title: India Restricts Media on Visit by Dalai Lama
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian government moved Thursday to restrict media coverage of the Dalai Lamas trip next week to a disputed Himalayan region, a visit that has become a sore point between India and China at a time when diplomatic relations are already fraying between the Asian giants.

title: Expedia Eliminates Phone Charge
description: Expedia, the large online travel agency, is eliminating its $20 booking fee for travel reservations made by phone.

title: Pregame Huddle: Expect the Unexpected
description: The surprising Iowa Hawkeyes are looking to stay undefeated, while Duke and North Carolina take their rivalry off the hard court.

title: Texting as a Health Tool for Teenagers
description: Gina (not her real name) had been born with a defect in her liver, with ducts so damaged and narrow that the bile could not drain. In the first year of her life, she underwent two urgent operations. The first was an unsuccessful effort to convert a loop of intestine into a drainage system for her bile; the second was a lifesaving liver transplant.

title: Texting for Better Health
description: Text messaging is widely viewed as an annoying and sometimes risky teen distraction. But new research suggests it can be a useful tool for encouraging teenagers to take regular medication, Dr. Pauline W. Chen reports today in the Doctor and Patient column.

title: Medical Apps for the iPhone
description: Last week, I spoke at the TED MED conference. It's like the much higher-profile TED conference (you can read about it on my blog), but under different management and, of course, dedicated to healthcare topics.

title: Iraqis Again Fail to Approve Election Law
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi Parliament failed again on Thursday to approve a law to regulate a national election in January, deepening doubts about whether the nation can hold the vote on schedule.

title: Medical Apps for the iPhone
description: Last week, I spoke at the TED MED conference. Its like the much higher-profile TED conference (you can read about it here), but under different management and, of course, dedicated to healthcare topics.

title: Answers About New York City Politics, Part 2
description: Here is the second set of responses from Bruce F. Berg, a professor and the author of New York City Politics: Governing Gotham (Rutgers University Press), about city politics and the 2009 elections.

title: Obama Announces Endorsements for Health Care Bill
description: President Obama made a surprise appearance at the daily White House press briefing on Thursday afternoon to announce that the nations leading advocacy group for the elderly as well as the largest doctors organization have endorsed the current health care plan being considered in Congress.

description: The late-night competition resumed with the shows back from repeat weeks and the results were more of the same  with a small exception:

title: Graceful Interchanges, Now Doubling as Civic Sculpture
description: NEW YORKERS maintain that Los Angeles is a city with no center. But Angelenos argue that the city of freeways has its core in the Stack, a tower of overpasses  the first four-level connector interchange, according to the California Transportation Department  where the Pasadena, Harbor, Hollywood and Santa Ana freeways intersect.

title: Shake Shack to Open in Miami
description: The Shake Shack empire will expand to Miami next year, making it the first Danny Meyer restaurant outside of New York, according to his Union Square Hospitality Group. No firm date yet, but it will go up on Lincoln Road.

title: Follow the Money, and the History
description: For bankers and brokers, Wall Street is not so much a place as perhaps a dream (or, last year, a nightmare): a churning pool of risk, debt, credit, and information that is best realized in the physical world as the blinking screen of a Bloomberg terminal. But for ordinary New Yorkers, Wall Street is a neighborhood, a neck of the citys woods that more or less runs from ground zero to Battery Park. There, one finds the aorta of the nations financial heart, of course, but also shops and cafes and bits of history.

title: Can Eventbrite Shine in Ticketmasters World?
description: For big rock concerts and sporting events held in huge venues, Ticketmaster dominates the landscape. For the kind of event you might find promoted with a flier on a telephone pole, theres a budding start-up called Eventbrite.

title: Going Beyond the Book Report With Literature Exhibits
description: Overview | Where do authors find inspiration? How can objects reveal and represent theme and character in an authors work? How can creative assignments elicit understanding of literature in different ways from direct analysis? In this lesson, students consider the ways the author Orhan Pamuk uses objects as inspiration in his novel, The Museum of Innocence, and create museum exhibits to reflect the themes, characters and plot lines of works they are currently studying in class.

title: Saudis Strike Yemeni Rebels Along Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi warplanes bombed a group of Yemeni rebels late Wednesday on the countries remote border, a day after the rebels overran a strategic hilltop and killed a Saudi border guard.

title: Hiking Hong Kong? Tis the Season
description: You get a very different perspective on Hong Kong if you get out of the city  and doing so is surprisingly easy. Indeed, hiking is a very popular pastime for Hong Kongers who want to substitute a bit of real jungle for the concrete.

title: Snapshots From Hardlucksville
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Details on Fridays Yankee Parade and Ceremony
description: The Yankees return to the Canyon of Heroes for the first time since 2000 on Friday morning, when they will float up Broadway in a ticker-tape parade and share their 27th World Series victory with fans in Lower Manhattan.

title: Ida Forms in Southwest Caribbean
description: On Wednesday afternoon, TD11 formed just off the northern coast of Panama. It doesnt appear to have come from an easterly wave, but rather a persistent area of convection that sat and festered for a week or so. At such a low latitude, it takes quite a while for the Coriolis effect to influence the circulation of a low pressure. Later on Wednesday, an aircraft found that it had sustained winds high enough to warrant upgrading it to Tropical Storm Ida. On Thursday morning, it was again upgraded to Hurricane Ida (3rd hurricane of the season), with sustained winds of 65kts and a central pressure of 987mb. Its presently located right on the east-central Nicaraguan coast and looks well-organized for being so close to land.

title: Obamas Remarks on the A.M.A. and AARP Endorsements
description: Following is a transcript of President Obama's remarks on Thursday in which he announced that the AARP and the American Medical Association have endorsed the current health care legislation in Congress, as released by the White House:

title: Trailer Premiere: The White Ribbon
description: Today we are showing the trailer  for Michael Hanekes latest film, The White Ribbon. The drama, set on the eve of World War I, examines a group of families living in a village in northern Germany and a series of crimes that shake up the community. Manohla Dargis called the film, which won the Palme dOr at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival, a meticulous examination of patriarchal domination. In an Arts & Leisure piece, Stuart Klawans writes about  the ways in which the film anticipates Nazism.

title: Marketing Madness: Coal for Children
description: The coloring book below, intended to teach children about the coal industry, was published by the public relations arm of the West Virginia Coal Association.

title: Where Do These Yankee Champions Rank?
description: With three rounds of playoffs, one of them a best-of-five series, the modern postseason is designed to ensure that the best team in baseball only wins the World Series a small percentage of the time. This randomness inherent in the playoffs is the games built-in remedy for its competitive balance woes, and has felled four different Yankee squads this decade that posted the games best record but fell short of a title. Yet while the last Yankees club to bring home a championship, the 87-win 2000 team, reinforced the notion that the postseason is a crapshoot, the 2009 edition offers a different lesson: sometimes, just being really, really good is indeed good enough to win it all.

title: The Plethore LC-750, a Canadian Supercar
description: LAS VEGAS  When you think Canada, you think supercar, non?

title: Q&A: New York City for a Teenage Visitor
description: Q.

title: A Chaminade Moment for LeMoyne
description: LeMoynes 82-79 victory over Syracuse on Tuesday was stunning in its own right.

title: The lost generation
description: Matthew Yglesias catches Eugene Fama making a strange assertion:

title: The Cat Who Got Swine Flu
description: A few days after two members of an Ames, Iowa, family came down with the flu, they noticed their 13-year-old cat wasnt feeling too well either. The cat has since become the first documented case of a feline with the new H1N1 virus, commonly called swine flu.

title: Melissa Johnson and Timothy Lagasse
description: MELISSA JOHNSON is known for her sardonic humor and love of dark, gory films and burlesque. So no one was more surprised than she when she fell for an endlessly upbeat designer and fabricator of puppets who spends his days on the sets of childrens television shows like Sesame Street and Between the Lions.

title: 11/5/09: Blue Jackets in Jeopardy, Chamber of Commerce Report Says
description: A report commissioned by the Columbus business community adds the Blue Jackets to the list of N.H.L. teams on the financial brink, The Columbus Dispatch reports on Thursday.

title: Gee-yonc
description: Nickname given to Lady Gaga after filming the music video for Beyoncs single, Video Phone.

title: U.S. Readies Jobless Aid and Help on Homes
description: WASHINGTON  In separate actions to address Americans continuing economic hardship, the government moved Thursday to assist long-unemployed workers and struggling businesses, as well as home buyers and homeowners facing foreclosure.

title: Thailand Recalls Its Ambassador to Cambodia
description: BANGKOK  The Thai government announced Thursday that it was recalling its ambassador to Cambodia to protest Cambodias appointment of Thaksin Shinawatra, who was ousted as Thailands prime minister, to a high-profile position. The moves put new strains on already tense relations between the countries.

title: Sugar High at Haunch of Venison
description: Topless women holding cocktail trays with bite-size servings of creamy cake by Creative Edges Bob Spiegel provided some of the insane sugar rush of last nights dessert feast at Christies Haunch of Venison gallery. The art-world scenesters pounced with hypoglycemic glee on layered sweets designed by four Manhattan pastry chefs, who collaborated with four New York artists for an event commissioned by Kreemart, an organization that lets artists explore desserts as a medium (we kid you not), for the American Patrons of the Tate Museum in London.

title: New York City Transit Gets New President
description: The New York City bus and subway system got a new leader on Thursday, as transit officials hope to move ahead with new technology while grappling with budget cuts and serious concerns about long-term financing.

title: Pinnacle of the Past, Just $2.1 Million
description: MY mission today is to offer my clear-eyed take on the Bugatti Veyron 16.4 Grand Sport. But the price keeps getting in the way.

title: Treating the Pain Epidemic
description: Chronic pain affects more than 70 million Americans, which makes it more widespread than heart disease, cancer and diabetes combined. It costs the economy more than $100 billion per year. So why dont more doctors and researchers take it seriously?

title: Governor Puts Same-Sex Marriage on Legislative Agenda
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson has included gay marriage on the agenda of an extraordinary session he is calling for Tuesday, administration officials said Thursday.

title: More Rules for Restaurant Staffers
description: Bruce Buschels back on the Youre the Boss blog with Part 2 of his 100 Things Restaurant Staffers Should Never Do post. Mr. Buschel is opening a restaurant in Bridgehampton, N.Y., his first. He knows something about publicity. Part 1 of his list of rules for staffers blew up on the Web last week in the manner of one of those articles about gay penguins or how to train your husband or indignities suffered by people of privilege. It was e-mailed, blogged, tweeted and retweeted, debated and hated and loved.

title: A Hybrid Stakes Out High Ground
description: FOR every smartly realized hybrid like the Toyota Prius or Ford Fusion, there has been one whose combination of price, economy and practicality doesnt quite add up.

title: House Democrats Seek Allies for Health Care Vote
description: WASHINGTON  House Democratic leaders worked furiously on Thursday to secure the final votes for weekend approval of a sweeping health care overhaul as President Obama threw his weight behind the lobbying effort and Republicans dug in against the health plan.

title: Profile in Style: Cynthia Rowley
description: The designer makes high-spirited fashion -- but that's nothing compared to her exuberant family life.

title: Already Depleted Nets Wearing Thin
description: The Nets faced an uphill struggle this season after purging their payroll during the off-season. That trek is not any less steep with a medical roll call of early injuries.

title: Top Palestinian Rules Out Race for Re-election
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, warned on Thursday that he would not seek re-election, the latest sign that the Obama administrations drive to broker a Middle East peace accord, one of President Obamas key foreign policy goals, has fallen into disarray.

title: Rajaratnams Travel Restrictions Are Loosened
description: The Galleon Groups founder, Raj Rajaratnam, who has been charged with insider trading, can now travel around the United States so long as he informs prosecutors beforehand, a Manhattan federal judge ruled at a hearing of Thursday afternoon.

title: Segregation as Social Progress
description: One of the hazards (or joys, depending on how you look at it) of being a journalist is that you end up on a lot of mailing lists. And so it was that a post I once wrote about the transgender wage gap earned me an influx of e-mail about transgender issues  including an invitation to check out a site that wrote about financial advice for transgender people.

title: Casting News for Next Fall, Love, Loss and What I Wore, and More
description: Updated | 4:22 p.m.  So much theater news today that we have to deliver it in bullet-point form:

title: Bank of New York Chief Shuns BofAs Top Job
description: Robert P. Kelly, chief executive of Bank of New York Mellon, told his senior managers on Thursday that he was not interested in taking the top job at Bank of America, defusing speculation that he would leave his current post.

title: Quiet on the Waterfront
description: WHO Chris Hallweaver, 52, a marketing consultant, and his wife, Betsy, 52, a school administrator in Yarmouth, Me.

title: Meet the Parents, Again
description: My boyfriends parents always show up on our vacations. When we went to Washington, they visited. When we went camping, guess who stayed at the local hotel? Ive talked with my boyfriend, but he says: They always come at this time of year, or They had their vacation planned before ours. How can I talk to his mother without upsetting her?

title: Air Quality Is Now an Inside Job
description: WHEN the Ecology Center, a nonprofit environmental advocacy group, released its 2009 guide to toxic chemicals in cars in September, the results held a pleasant surprise. For the first time since the center began rating vehicle interiors in 2007, a car built in the United States by a Detroit automaker had the lowest levels of toxic chemicals among all the models evaluated.

title: Officer Is Arraigned on Drunken Driving Charges
description: Updated, 4:20 p.m. | An off-duty police officer arrested after his vehicle struck and killed a woman in Brooklyn on Sept. 27 was arraigned on vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving charges Thursday morning, following a grand jury indictment.

title: A Historic River Town Where the West Began
description: Marietta, Ohio  A DEEP current of history runs through this quiet town of 15,000 nestled in the arms of the Ohio and Muskingum Rivers. Indians first left their mark here, in great earthen burial mounds. Then, as the first chartered city in the Northwest Territory, Marietta felt the nations initial footprints as it strode west.

title: Lobsters That Got Away, and Those That Didnt
description: WESTPORT, Mass.  IN this little town on the south coast, people like me  summer folk  are known as skukes. Ive never met anyone who knows the real derivation of the term, but its not a compliment. Skukes are annoying because they drive up the price of real estate and because they do for fun what year-rounders do for a living. Take lobstering, for example. Most of the summer there was a local man at the town dock selling lobsters for a very reasonable $4.99 a pound. Skukishly, I thought I would be more enterprising and try to catch my own. My goal was by the end of the summer to hear my family complain: What? Lobster again?

title: Davis Considering a Future in Football?
description: Glen Davis, the Celtics forward also known as Big Baby, has always had a larger profile than his on-the-court production has warranted. That was one of the things that made it so interesting to see him play a vital role during Bostons playoff push last season. Averaging 15.8 points a game in Kevin Garnetts absence, Davis showed that he could be a viable N.B.A. player despite being on the short side (hes at 69) for a power forward.

title: From Poland, a Light but Creamy Soup
description: My husband, Andy, and I went to Poland in September to visit some of his relatives, and they took us to the mountain region of Zakopane to a guesthouse that includes both breakfast and dinner. Traditionally, Poles eat simply for breakfast and dinner, often a spread of bread, cheese and meat to make sandwiches. Lunch is the large, hot meal. But at this guesthouse, dinner is more akin to lunch, with a first course of soup followed by a main meat dish served with potatoes and either a slaw of carrots or cabbage.

title: Chefs Descend on Caymans
description: The Cayman Islands arent exactly a culinary destination like New York or Paris, but during one week in January, thats where youll find some of the best chefs in America.

title: A Ray of Sonnenschein for German 30 Rock
description: After its first broadcast on the German channel ZDFNeo drew a rating of 0.0, 30 Rock had nowhere to go but up. And up it did go: The Hollywood Reporter reported that a second showing of the NBC screwball comedy on Wednesday saw a ratings increase of at least 500 percent: an average of 30,000 viewers tuned in this time. The series is also shown on German TNT.

title: Mass Shooting at Fort Hood
description: Update | 9:15 p.m. At a news conference outside Fort Hood the base commander, Lt. Gen. Robert Cone, just revealed that earlier reports that the suspected gunman, Major Nidal Hasan, had been killed were incorrect. Major Hasan was wounded but remains alive, Lt. Gen. Cone said, adding that he is in custody and his death is not imminent. He added that 12 people, not 11, had been killed by whom the military authorities now describe as a single gunman.

title: The Waterpod Artist Heads for the Roof
description: Now that shes gotten her sea legs, Mary Mattingly, an artist who spent her summer living on an eco-art-barge floating around the city, is looking to move on up (to the sky). Ms. Mattingly has proposed that her next project, called Air Ship Air City, be installed atop the Metropolitan Exchange Building, a seven-story design and research cooperative in downtown Brooklyn, whose members have given the initial green light to the idea, according to the Brooklyn Paper. The plans for the structure include a chicken coop  the barge, the Waterpod, was home to four chickens  a research lab, hanging gardens, potential living quarters (called the Flock House) and a communal area featuring outdoor couches that Ms. Mattingly envisions as a sort of human nest.

title: Donning Anew the Miniskirt of a Predator
description: IN the seven seasons Heather Locklear spent on Melrose Place, the vintage-1990s Fox soap opera, she was synonymous with ruthlessness, deviousness and hemlines that rose as high as prime-time television would allow.

title: After Setbacks, Small Successes for Gene Therapy
description: Not long ago, gene therapy seemed troubled by insurmountable difficulties. After decades of hype and dashed hopes, many who once embraced the idea of correcting genetic disorders by giving people new genes all but gave up the idea.

title: Buy Me Some Curry and Cracker Jack
description: If there is a single shrine to honor Hideki Matsui in New York City, it is located on a grimy corner in the garment center at 237 West 38th street.

title: Screening: Many Doctors Do Unneeded Pap Smears, Study Finds
description: Many doctors are performing unnecessary Pap smears, ignoring guidelines issued by major medical organizations and adding to health care costs, a survey of physicians has found.

title: Breeders Cup Picks for Friday
description: The Breeders Cup begins Friday at Santa Anita Park with six races. Combined with Saturdays eight races, the weekend purse is more than $25.5 million. Here are Joe Drapes selections for Fridays card, which will be shown on ESPN2, all times Eastern.

title: Follow the Money, and the History
description: For bankers and brokers, Wall Street is not so much a place as perhaps a dream (or, last year, a nightmare): a churning pool of risk, debt, credit and information that is best realized in the physical world as the blinking screen of a Bloomberg terminal. But for ordinary New Yorkers, Wall Street is a neighborhood that more or less runs from ground zero to Battery Park. There, one finds the aorta of the nations financial heart, of course, but also shops and cafes and bits of history.

title: The Morning Skate: David Branchs Harsh Decision
description: Wednesdays decision by O.H.L. President David Branch to suspend the Erie Otters Michael Liambas for the balance of the season for his board check on Kitchener Rangers defenseman Ben Fanelli last Friday continues to reverberate loudly around the hockey world, and almost every reaction deems the punishment to be harsh.

title: Fate of Spider-Man Musical Could Be Determined on Friday
description: The producers of the multimillion-dollar Broadway musical project Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark, have scheduled a meeting in Manhattan on Friday with the director Julie Taymor and other members of the creative team to discuss the future of the show, two executives involved in the production said Thursday. A spokesman for the producers confirmed the meeting but declined to discuss the agenda.

title: The Motorola Droid
description: David Pogue discusses the new smartphone from Motorola, the Droid, on CNBC.

title: A Contrary Indicator on M.B.A.s and Stocks
description: Fewer Harvard M.B.A. graduates took jobs on Wall Street this year than in the past as a result of the sharp contraction in the financial services industry. But for Ray Soifer, a former banking analyst and Harvard Business School alumnus, the reduced number of graduates flocking to Wall Street isnt a bad thing. In fact, it may actually be a positive signal for the market.

title: Theater Listings: Nov. 6  12
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Green and Pony Cars on the Same Stage at SEMA Show
description: LAS VEGAS  The automotive aftermarket parts and accessories industry, which holds its biggest gathering here in early November each year at the Specialty Equipment Market Associations trade show, would appear to be still alive, if not quite as well as it used to be.

title: Explaining Why Mom or Dad Cant Play
description: What to do when a parent is out of commission? How to explain that to a toddler?

title: As Luck Would Have It ...
description: FIVE days a week, Michael Kiernan, 50, a computer network administrator, makes the 90-minute commute home from the Bronx County Courthouse, where he works, to suburban Long Beach on Long Island. Like a lot of New Yorkers, he has it down to a science. He leaves work at 4:45, walk-jogs across 161st Street, then hurries into the subway, where he gets into the first car on the D train. He stands by the door, riding two stops to 145th Street, then races up the stairs for the A train, a downtown express. Again he stands, in the first car, by the third door, which at 34th Street opens at the stairs to the Long Island Rail Road. If all goes well, he catches the 5:20 home.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Nov. 5
description: A Scottish soldier was laid to rest on Thursday, part of a toll in Afghanistan that has increased Britons concern about involvement in the war there.

title: Touradji Capital Sues 2 Ex-Employees
description: Touradji Capital Management has filed a countersuit against two former employees who sued the commodities hedge fund firm, contending that they were owed $50 million in unpaid bonuses. Touradjis suit accuses the two men, Robert Vollero and Gentry Beach, of lying about their abilities, stealing secrets and defaming the firm.

title: Army Doctor Held in Ft. Hood Rampage
description: An Army psychiatrist facing deployment to one of Americas war zones killed 13 people and wounded 30 others on Thursday in a shooting rampage with two handguns at the sprawling Fort Hood Army post in central Texas, military officials said.

title: Stimulus Is in the Eye of the Beholder
description: From ProPublicas accounting of some of the wackier stimulus-funded projects:

title: Crist, the Stimulus and White House Hugs
description: Though Republican Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida keeps distancing himself from support for the presidents economic stimulus package and the hug he shared with President Obama earlier this year, the White House sure hasnt forgotten that embrace.

title: Celebrating a Champion With Curry
description: Where better to celebrate the Yankees world championship and Hideki Matsuis most valuable player award for the series than at Go! Go! Curry, a shrine to Matsui (number 55, or go go in Japanese). During Thursday lunch, about 300 Matsui fans, Yankee fans and curry fans spilled out onto the sidewalk, waiting up to 40 minutes to get their food.

title: Does Technology Reduce Social Isolation?
description: Update | 11:19 p.m. Made slight clarifications throughout.Hundreds of daily updates come from friends on Facebook and Twitter, but do people actually feel closer to each other?

title: When a Star Takes a Turn Awaiting a Star Turn
description: Nobody does exasperated like Julie White, the Tony-winning actress (The Little Dog Laughed) currently fabricating bountiful laughs from a sumptuous display of strained nerves in The Understudy, a scattershot backstage comedy by Theresa Rebeck that opened on Thursday night at the Laura Pels Theater.

title: On Our Radar
description: 1) Is the Prius ugly?

title: 'The Understudy'
description: Mark-Paul Gosselaar and Justin Kirk in a scene from Theresa's Rebeck's new play. (Video: Roundabout Theater)

title: For Imax, a Wall Street Ovation
description: After struggling for years to be taken seriously in Hollywood, Imax has broken through in the last year, lining up one movie behemoth after another  Disneys A Christmas Carol on Friday, Avatar after that  for premium-price 3-D runs.

title: A Minuet Between Sexual Predators
description: Passion burns cold in Robert Wilsons trance-inducing production of Quartett, Heiner Mllers ruthless reimagining of Choderlos de Lacloss 18th-century novel Les Liaisons Dangereuses. Lights of many colors dye the all-too-mortal flesh of the figures assembled here to recall the blood-drawing games of lust they once shared. Sometimes their faces glow a reptilian green; on other occasions they are drenched in satanic red.

title: The Yankees Peaceful, Easy Feeling
description: The line that kept coming to me on Wednesday night as I tried to crystallize the Yankees 27th championship, was peaceful, easy feeling, from the song by the Eagles. Whether this was a subconscious yearning for my Philadelphia Eagles to someday win a championship, too, I dont know. But I think the words fit the moment.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Precious'
description: Lee Daniels, the director of "Precious," discusses a scene from the film.

title: State of Distress
description: An article on Oct. 25 about the race for governor in New Jersey misidentified the native state of Joel Benenson, a pollster who worked for Gov. Jon Corzine during the campaign. It is New York, not New Jersey.

title: Now Dishing | The Indochine Diaries
description: Indochine has proven that a true fashion restaurant never goes out of style. The palm-leaf wallpaper of the Lafayette Street bote, opened by Brian McNally in 1984, has been the background for 25 years of beautiful faces, from the supermodels to the Roitfeld-Restoin clan. The new book Indochine: Stories, Shaken and Stirred (Rizzoli) serves as both eye candy and social document: theres a photo of Andy Warhol, Jacqueline and Julian Schnabel, Kenny Scharf and Jean-Michel Basquiat at the opening; theres a quote from Anna Wintour on the model-fest that was Grace Coddingtons 50th birthday party in 1991. The index alone, organized by first name, reads like a downtown primer, hopping from Arthur Miller to As Four, Susan Sontag to Suzanne Bartsch.

title: Goodbye to Reforms of 2002
description: It took just five weeks after the WorldCom accounting scandal erupted in 2002 for Congress to pass, and President George W. Bush to sign, the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. That law required public companies to make sure their internal controls against fraud were not full of holes.

title: Private Equity Fires Back at Moodys
description: Moodys Investors Service seems to have touched quite a nerve with a new report that was critical of the private equity industry. The Private Equity Council, the main lobbying group for the industry, fired back on Thursday afternoon, noting that the reports conclusions were open to significant interpretation.

title: 99 Weeks
description: Ninety-nine weeks: thats the maximum length of time for which workers in high-unemployment states will be able to collect jobless benefits, under a bill that President Obama is expected to sign tomorrow.

title: A New Editor for The Observer
description: The New York Observer will have a new editor next month: Kyle Pope, a former reporter and editor at The Wall Street Journal and Cond Nast Portfolio.

title: Howls of a Life, Buried Deep Within
description: Claireece Jones, the Harlem teenager at the center of Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire, lives in a world of specific and overwhelming horror. She goes by her middle name, Precious, which seems like a cruel taunt, since nearly everyone around her thinks shes worthless and lets her know it.

title: The Audacity of Precious
description: I had the opportunity to watch the trailer for Precious and was immediately taken aback by the cast members and the overall theme. Mariah Carey was unrecognizable, and MoNique was just raw like Ive never seen her. I am so glad that Daniels has taken on this huge responsibility of showing us the seemingly insurmountable obstacles that affect others.

title: On Baseball With Jack Curry
description: Jack Curry talks about his impressions of the Yankees' victory in the 2009 World Series.

title: Obama Promises Help for Native Americans
description: President Obama promised Native American leaders on Thursday that he would give more than lip service to their concerns, and instructed Cabinet agencies to report back to him within 90 days on plans that would establish regular and meaningful consultation between the federal government and long-ignored tribal nations.

title: Faith and the Tempted Woman of a Certain Middle Age
description: Saints can be hell to live with. Thats part of the comedy of Creature, Heidi Schrecks absorbing new play about character and faith at the Ohio Theater, loosely based on the life of Margery Kempe, a medieval Englishwoman who, after a difficult childbirth, saw visions of the Devil and Jesus.

title: Video: Jack Currys World Series Recap
Stop Your Search Engines
description: Peggy Orenstein compares herself to Ulysses as she tries to resist the siren call of her online search engine, but the destructive force of the quest for knowledge antedates Homer. Go back to the very beginning of the Bible. When Eve ate from the forbidden tree and bit into the apple, she acquired the knowledge of good and evil and was cursed forever. And she didnt even have Google.

title: Simplifying One Life, Complicating Another
description: Richard Kelly, the writer and director of the much-loved Donnie Darko and much-loathed Southland Tales, has a thing for the apocalypse. Like those films, his latest, The Box, is sincere and sinister and inevitably ambitious, a serious work that insists on its own seriousness even when it edges toward the preposterous. As in his earlier films, he is again using genre (and pretty actors) as a vehicle to ask questions about the human condition (and conditioning) amid a thicket of high, low and trash cultural allusions and against a backdrop of impending doom. But the end isnt nigh in Mr. Kellys world. Its here.

title: Explaining the Origins of Ms.
description: Ben Zimmers On Language column about Ms. makes The Timess embrace of this honorific in 1986 sound gracious, if slow. The battle over Ms. was actually fierce because of in-house political resistance. The minutes of the Times stockholders meeting of April 30, 1986, show that the publisher at the time, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, recognized Paula Kassell, a stockholder and feminist publisher who had long been on this case. Kassell challenged the publisher to convene a debate with language experts to reach a rational decision on the question. He accepted the challenge.

title: Is That All There Is?
description: Readers who commented on Todd Mays post, Happy Ending, wrote the role that death plays in their attitudes towards life, and some posted final thoughts on the Happy Days series. Excerpts from some are below.

title: Ghosts of Technology Present
description: Disneys A Christmas Carol, written and directed by Robert Zemeckis, a branded piece of shiny seasonal entertainment, uses the digital technique of performance capture and the enhancements of 3-D projection to deliver a big, noisy and sometimes terrifying version of the Charles Dickens tale on which it is based. That much is to be expected, and the casting of Jim Carrey as Ebenezer Scrooge (and some of the ghosts who haunt him) might also lead you to expect rubber-limbed clowning and a motor-mouth barrage of semi-crude humor.

title: Money Transfers Between People Could Get Easier Soon
Appointment in Istanbul
description: Sometimes what you get is not what you thought you wanted. I had just broken up with my boyfriend of 10 years back in New York, and had flown to Istanbul to try to sightsee my heartbreak away. But then here, unexpectedly, was this very handsome Istanbul native sitting in the placid park just outside the Hagia Sophia: wed been staring at each other admiringly from our respective park benches. After our glances grew less furtive, he waved me over. I feigned surprise, introduced myself and sat down. His name was Zia, he said, and he had been studying English for three years. He proudly pulled a Turkish-English phrase book from his pocket. His slightly awkward manner seemed situational  but I couldnt tell whether the situation was that his English was halting, or that he was Muslim and flirting with a man, or that he was Muslim and flirting with a man in front of such a historic mosque.

title: Saint-Gaudens and Stanford White
description: A running theme in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art of the work of Augustus Saint-Gaudens is his enduring friendship with the architect Stanford White.

title: No Doubt Sues Maker of Guitar Hero Games
description: Courtney Love threatened to do it, but Gwen Stefani actually did it: Ms. Stefani and her band, No Doubt, have sued the makers of the Guitar Hero video game franchise, saying that their latest entry in the series misuses the likenesses of the group members, Reuters reported. In its lawsuit against the game publisher Activision Blizzard, No Doubt said it had agreed on Ms. Stefani and her band mates appearing in the new game Band Hero. But the rock group said that the game makers went too far by allowing Ms. Stefanis virtual counterpart to perform songs that No Doubt never recorded, including Honky Tonk Women by the Rolling Stones. This results in an unauthorized performance by the Gwen Stefani avatar in a male voice boasting about having sex with prostitutes, the lawsuit says. In a statement Activision Blizzard said it believes it is within its legal rights with respect to the use and portrayal of the band members in the game. Ms. Love, the widow of the Nirvana frontman Kurt Cobain, raised similar objections when she learned that a Cobain avatar could be used to perform other artists songs in the video game Guitar Hero 5.

title: Evocations of China, Rural, Romantic and Aquatic
description: In a distinctive blend of East and West, Tan Dun likes to superimpose unusual instruments and techniques on a Western orchestra. Thus, for example, his Water Concerto (In Memory of Toru Takemitsu), which David Robertson and the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra presented at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday as part of Carnegies festival Ancient Paths, Modern Voices, celebrating Chinese culture.

title: More Billy Elliots for Broadway Cast
description: Poor Mrs. Elliot may be gone to heaven, but somehow she keeps reproducing. On Thursday the producers of Billy Elliot the Musical said two more actors would be joining its Broadway cast to portray the title role. Dayton Tavares, 13, who has played the character in the musicals Sydney and Melbourne casts, will become the sixth member of the Broadway Billy club, and Liam Redhead, 14, a student of the National Ballet School in Toronto, will become the seventh, the shows publicists said in a news release. Also, Tommy Batchelor, who is leaving the Broadway cast to play Billy in the shows Chicago production, will play his final New York performance on Dec. 11. The Broadway role was originated by David Alvarez, Kiril Kulish and Trent Kowalik, who won Tony Awards for their performances. Starting dates for Mr. Tavares and Mr. Redhead were not announced.

title: Amaze Me, Mother Said, So Thats What She Did
description: In Lit, her searing new memoir, Mary Karr recalls that she and her impossible mother used to play a game, when they were driving or her mother was bored or sprawled on her bed with a hangover: Tell me a story she liked to say, meaning charm me  my life in this Texas suckhole is duller than a rubber knife. Amaze me.

title: Finding a Bit of Animal House in the Bauhaus
description: Ask most people what they think of when they hear the word Bauhaus, and theyre likely to come up with tubular steel furniture, prefabricated housing, ranks of nave utopians and Tom Wolfes withering disdain for all of the above. A show about the Bauhaus? No thanks. Who, after all, really needs to see another Breuer chair?

title: The Yankees Win, in Ratings, Too
description: The sixth and final game in the World Series helped Fox win another night in the ratings on Wednesday as an average of 22.3 million viewers tuned in to the broadcast, according to Nielsens estimates. This years World Series was the highest-rated in five years. CBS was a distant runner up for the night, drawing 12 million for Criminal Minds at 9 and 11.6 million for CSI: NY at 10. NBC ranked third on the night, just ahead of ABC.

title: Whats Good for the Kids
description: It has been apparent for a while now that we live in child-centric times. We approach parenting with a single-mindedness that baffles our own parents, and certainly their parents, who thought children should be seen and not heard. We think its just fine to put our kids ahead of our careers, our relationships, our social lives, and even if we arent doing so, everyone around us seems to be.

title: Slumdog Director Picks Next Project
description: Choosing ones next movie project after winning Academy Awards for best director and best film doesnt always come quickly  just ask James Cameron  but Danny Boyle, whose film Slumdog Millionaire won eight Oscars in February, has figured out his follow-up. Variety reported that Mr. Boyle (whose films also include Trainspotting and 28 Days Later) will next direct 127 Hours, a biographical film about the mountaineer Aron Lee Ralston. Mr. Ralston made headlines in 2003 when an 800-pound boulder fell on his right hand and crushed it while he was exploring Robbers Roost in southeastern Utah. After being trapped for several days, he sawed off the lower part of the trapped arm and hiked to his rescue. The project is expected to reunite Mr. Boyle with two Slumdog Millionaire colleagues: the screenwriter Simon Beaufoy and the producer Christian Colson. Production is to begin next year; no casting has yet been announced.

title: Dia Plans to Return to Its Chelsea Roots
description: After years of scouring Manhattan real estate for a base in New York, a troubled process that was bedeviled by setbacks, the Dia Art Foundation has found a new home on the site of its old home. It is planning to build a space on the footprint of one of its previous Chelsea exhibition sites, a former garage at 545 West 22nd Street.

title: Meeting to Weigh Future of Spider-Man
description: The producers of the multimillion-dollar Broadway musical Spider-man, Turn Off the Dark have scheduled a meeting in Manhattan on Friday with the director Julie Taymor and other members of the creative team to discuss the shows future, two executives involved in the project said Thursday. They said that the producers would update the creative team on the projects cash-flow problems, and that Ms. Taymor would say that it would be difficult to begin rehearsals before January. Even if the musicals financial difficulties are solved in time for rehearsals to begin this winter, the show is so technically complex  Spider-mans acrobatics and possible mid-air flight for instance  that Ms. Taymor and the producers may not be prepared to open the show by April 29, the cutoff date for Tony Award nominations, said the executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment publicly about the production. If the show is not ready to be considered for the Tonys this season, the reasoning goes, the production team and cast would be better off waiting to open later  assuming the producers arent faced with a huge financial penalty for delaying use of the Hilton Theater, which they have already ripped up to accommodate Ms. Taymors vision for the musical. The show is still scheduled to begin previews on Feb. 25 and open in March, but several people involved in the production said those dates would change.

title: Slatkin Recuperating After Heart Attack
description: Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, told The Detroit Free Press that he felt lucky to be alive after having emergency surgery on Sunday to unblock a clogged artery. Mr. Slatkin, 65, right, the former music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, had a heart attack and collapsed just after conducting the Rotterdam Philharmonic in the Netherlands and is now in a hospital there after undergoing an angioplasty and stent procedure. In an e-mail exchange with The Free Press, Mr. Slatkin wrote that he experienced chest pains earlier in the week but dismissed them as indigestion. At the Sunday concert, he wrote: I started having trouble with chest pain, and I was sweating more than usual. Again, I thought it would go away but it stuck around. I sort of collapsed in the dressing room, and a medical team from the hall was sent in. Five minutes later I was in an ambulance on the way to the hospital. The Detroit Symphony told The Free Press that Mr. Slatkin was still scheduled to conduct the orchestra in Detroit this month, but that contingency plans were being made.

title: Art in Review
description: INTERNATIONAL FINE PRINT DEALERS ASSOCIATION FAIR

title: Target Marketing
description: On some level, all stories of successful brands resemble one another: the competitors in some category of good or service seem interchangeable until one of them, often a newcomer, dreams up some way of standing out from the crowd. O.K., maybe its not always that simple, but differentiating one choice partly by way of advertising, packaging and other image-enhancing strategies has long been a way of persuading shoppers to reconsider what they had previously seen as a mere commodity. Even, it turns out, bullet shoppers.

title: Gaining a Voice and an Identity in Minimalism
description: Sometimes it seems as if Roni Horns art were considered the greatest thing since sliced bread, at least in certain regions of the art world. Right now, the Whitney Museum is one. It has accorded two full floors to Ms. Horns exhibition of sculpture, drawings, photographs and artists books, which is one floor too many. In places the show is so spaciously installed that her work looks lost.

title: Is This Bishop Catholic?
description: As the archbishop of the Anglican Church in North America, you are known as the leader of a conservative  and even ultraright  movement that was founded last year in a break from the Episcopal Church. Do you plan to convert to Catholicism now that Pope Benedict has opened his doors to Anglicans?  I wouldnt characterize us as ultraright. We dont beat up folks. We are sort of mainstream right. I am very pleased that the Vatican has done this, but my call now is to lead all those Anglicans who stand where Anglicans have always stood.

title: Top 10 Book List Is a Mans World
description: The trade publication Publishers Weekly probably wanted to provoke discussion with its annual list of the years best books, but not like this. In its issue of Nov. 2 Publishers Weekly compiled its PW Top 10, a decidedly subjective ranking of the best fiction and nonfiction published in 2009, including the biography Cheever: A Life, by Blake Bailey; the novel Await Your Reply, by Dan Chaon; and the graphic novel Stitches, by David Small. But as The Guardian reports, the ranking has drawn protests from a womens literary group that notes there are no female writers on the list. Cate Marvin, a founder of the group Women in Letters and Literary Arts, told The Guardian, The absence made me nearly speechless. In her introduction to the year-end list Louisa Ermelino, the reviews director of Publishers Weekly, wrote, We ignored gender and genre and who had the buzz. She added, It disturbed us when we were done that our list was all male.

title: New York State Official Moves to E.P.A.
description: Environmental groups were enthusiastic on Thursday about the appointment of the New York State deputy secretary for the environment, Judith Enck, as the Region 2 administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Waiting for the Lawn Tractor
description: The shop that services my lawn tractor told me to expect its return in a week. I want it back sooner and am considering giving the workers an up-front cash bonus to put my tractor at the head of the line. But this feels worryingly like covert bribery. Other customers wouldnt know about it nor could they bid against me with higher bonuses. Is such a payment ethical? DONALD DAL MASO, BANGOR, PA.

title: Citigroup Plans I.P.O. of Its Primerica Unit
description: Citigroup said late Thursday that its Primerica life insurance unit had filed plans for an initial public offering of its stock. The bank said it would sell the rest of Primerica after the unit goes public, as part of its efforts to divest itself of operations outside of its main banking business.

title: Cadillac Thrives as a Figure of Speech
description: The Cadillac division of General Motors has seen better days, with woeful sales figures even compared with those of other brands in the slumping luxury-car market. Yet the name Cadillac is thriving, at least on Capitol Hill. A centerpiece of legislation seeking to rein in health care costs is a tax on Cadillac plans, the favored shorthand for high-cost insurance policies. At the very high end are gold-plated Cadillac plans, or even super-gold-plated Cadillac plans, to use President Obamas turn of phrase. How has the Cadillac brand survived as a stand-in for luxury, even as the cars themselves have lost much of their cachet?

title: 18th-Century Furniture That Sincerely Flatters
description: Furniture makers in 18th-century Europe had to fend off competition from Asia. The Westerners, like their counterparts today, sometimes pleaded with their governments to impose tariffs that could stem the tide of imports, but more often they straightforwardly mimicked lacquered pieces coming in from China and Japan.

title: Met Asks if Statue Is Work of Genius
description: Is it or is it not? And if it is not, does it still warrant our attention? The object in question is Young Archer, a life-size marble carving of a naked boy that might or might not be the earliest known work by Michelangelo. It is now on display at the Metropolitan Museum in the bright and airy Vlez Blanco Patio, where viewers are invited to decide for themselves what to believe.

title: Ballet and African Moves
description: Karole Armitages reputation rests, in large part, upon the seismic shocks she caused in the early 1980s by putting ballet alongside screeching rock music. She was famously called (by Vanity Fair, no less; Ms. Armitage was trendy too) the punk ballerina, and an aura of outr provocation has clung to her ever since.

title: Precision Instruments Handled With Great Care
description: After the Mary Onettes first song Wednesday night at Union Hall in Brooklyn came a break, followed by an explanation, followed by some self-examination. Im sorry my guitar is sounding a little bit strange today, the frontman, Philip Ekstrom, said. We have never had a show without problems. Then, some rustling from the dark back corner of the stage. One minute more, pleaded the guitarist Petter Aguren. We have to restart the computer.

title: Can Modern Dance Be Preserved?
description: On July 27, the day after the choreographer Merce Cunningham died, there was an open house at the West Village studio in which his dance company has operated since 1971. A little before 6 p.m., some 40 current and former dancers, in warm-up clothes or street garb, drifted onto the wooden floor. As a pianist picked out strains of Bach, Robert Swinston, a longtime Cunningham dancer who was also the choreographers assistant, held an abbreviated class in Cunningham technique. In recent years, with the master crippled by rheumatoid arthritis, Swinston or another veteran often led students and company dancers through the steps. But Cunningham would still come to the studio every day; now the company was heading forth with lonely solemnity, like a riderless horse that misses the familiar hand on the reins. In this work space where Cunningham created and rehearsed his dances, the uncanny sense that he continued to watch lingered. At the end of the session, as Swinston pressed his hands together in the Namaste gesture of thanks, the dancers hugged one another, their cheeks streaked with tears.

title: Two Electronica Groups That Sprang From Africa
description: In the nonstop international remix that is disc-jockey club music, some African musicians have made themselves full participants rather than exotic samples.
