description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J.  For now, the nations biggest preparatory schools are protecting students like Ivy Alphonse-Leja, who depends on financial aid to attend the Lawrenceville School.

title: Bellevue Natural-Birth Center, Haven for Poor Women, Closes
description: The Bellevue Birth Center was celebrated as a landmark achievement for the natural-birth movement in New York City when it opened in 1998. The luxurious natural-birth center, designed to feel more like a home than a hospital, was the only one of its kind dedicated not to Manhattans trend-conscious set, but to poor, mostly immigrant women on Medicaid.

title: Job Cutbacks Rise by 1,200 at a Carrier in Britain
description: British Airways said on Friday that it would cut an additional 1,200 jobs in the coming months, raising the number of planned staff reductions to nearly 5,000 as the British carrier wrestled with what its chief executive called the toughest year in the history of aviation.

title: Ivory Coast: Judge Rejects Request in Toxic Waste Case
description: About $45 million intended to compensate 30,000 victims of a toxic waste dumping scandal in Ivory Coast will not be diverted to a self-appointed community representative, a judge in Abidjan ruled Friday. The sludge was dumped in and around Abidjan in 2006 by the international commodities trading firm Trafigura; over 100,000 people sought treatment and 15 died. A recent United Nations report said there was strong prima facie evidence that the reported deaths and adverse health consequences are related to the dumping of the waste. In recent weeks, a man claiming to represent the victims, Claude Gohourou, sought to divert the money to his organization; lawyers for the victims dismissed his claim as false. On Friday, Judge Antoine Bl ruled that the money should remain in the lawyers account.

title: Winner in Contest Involving Space Elevator
description: A start-up company from the Seattle area won $900,000 on Friday in a NASA contest to build a miniature prototype of a machine that could one day climb from Earth to outer space.

title: Taiwan: Swine Flu Vaccination Program Begins
description: The Taiwanese government announced that by starting vaccinations against the H1N1 virus this week, it had begun the largest immunization program in Taiwans history. The first people to receive the vaccines were survivors of Typhoon Morakot, which wreaked havoc across Taiwan in early August, killing hundreds of people. Schoolchildren are scheduled to receive shots this month. The government said it hoped to administer 12 million doses by Feb. 14, the start of the Lunar New Year.

title: Free for All
description: Chapter 1: Backstory 1921-42

title: Long-Delayed Opening for History of, and by, Joseph Papp
description: If Joseph Papp had had his way, Free for All, the newly published oral history about him and the Public Theater he helped found, would never have seen the light of day. The memory of how Papp, more than 20 years ago, inexplicably turned on the project he initiated even now causes its author, Kenneth Turan, to wince.

title: Israel: Ministry Assails U.N. Vote on War Conduct
description: Israel on Friday rejected a United Nations General Assembly vote endorsing a report accusing it of war crimes in Gaza last winter, saying the resolution did not have the support of the moral majority. The resolution, drafted by Arab member states, was approved Thursday on a vote of 114 to 18. The Israeli Foreign Ministry said in a statement that the Israeli Army had demonstrated higher military and moral standards in Gaza than any of this resolutions instigators. Israel said the report was one-sided and failed to take into account Israels right to defend itself against Palestinian rocket fire.

title: M.I.T. Considers Increase in Student Body by 300
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology is considering expanding its student body by more than 7 percent, or more than 300 students, if it is able to create additional student housing, the dean of admission, Stuart Schmill, said Thursday.

title: Versailles or Kykuit?
description: You have to spend money to make money goes the adage, but that has not been true this season at Kykuit, the Rockefeller estate in Pocantico Hills. Attendance there has risen 4 percent this year over last, despite a 5 percent drop in spending on marketing.

title: Spider-Man Is Given a New Lead Producer
description: A rock concert promoter with ties to the Rolling Stones and U2 said on Friday that he was taking over as the lead producer of the coming Broadway musical Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark, and that the troubled multimillion-dollar show would open sometime in 2010.

title: Pension Checks of Retired New York City Teachers Canceled
description: The pension checks of tens of thousands of retired New York City teachers and school staff members were electronically canceled as of Friday morning, just days after they had been deposited, according to city and union officials.

title: Rough Riders Easy Ride
description: Despite the troubled economy, Sagamore Hill, Theodore Roosevelts home, a federal historic site, is getting busier. Its staff members from the National Park Service conducted 36,400 tours there in 2007 and 39,500 tours in 2008, and they expect the number this year will be higher.

title: Stress Beyond Belief
description: The authorities will deal with Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist who is accused of bringing the nightmare of mass murder into the sanctuary of a military base on American soil. But the rest of us need to look very closely at the stress beyond belief that is being endured by so many other men and women in the armed forces  men and women who are serving gallantly and with dignity, who have not taken out their frustrations on one another, and who deserve better from the broader society.

title: Seeing Paris in 5 Boroughs of New York
description: Its longer than its Parisian counterpart (and closer to Yankee Stadium), lacks a Napoleonic triumphal arch and, thank goodness, never suffered the tramp of Nazi boots. But the Grand Concourse and Boulevard, celebrating its 100th year of traffic with a show at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, is often called the Bronxs Avenue des Champs-lyses.

title: Pelosi Faces Competing Pressures on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  As House Democratic leaders were assembling their health care bill last month, Speaker Nancy Pelosi left Washington on a political fund-raising tour.

title: Questions of Money and Tallies
description: Mayor Bloombergs top aides received generous bonuses after his 19.4-point victory in 2005. In light of Mr. Bloombergs not-so-big margin on Tuesday, will his campaign bonuses be as hefty?

title: To Retain Its Bankers, Citi Offers Option Plan
description: Hoping to encourage bankers and managers to stay, Citigroup began dispensing several million stock options this week to more than a quarter of its workers in a way that could result in a sizable gain for them.

title: Executives Are Wary After Arrests
description: Switchboards at law firms have been lighting up in recent weeks as hedge fund managers and technology executives deluge lawyers with one question: What information is safe to share, in case the feds are listening?

title: The Shooting at Fort Hood
description: Some of the events in the rampage on Thursday at Fort Hood, Texas, according to base officials and witnesses.

title: From Humdrum Day to a Scene of Chaos
description: FORT HOOD, Tex.   The Soldier Readiness Processing Center, a network of low buildings on Fort Hood, is as dreary as it sounds. It is where soldiers who are deploying overseas go to square away their medical paperwork. A visit means hearing tests, dental exams, shots and long, long lines.

title: Fine-Spun Leaves and Other New Clothes
description: The current issue of Audubon magazine has a fairly comprehensive article on sustainable fashion. Its worth checking out. Written by Gretel H. Schueller, the piece, From Hippie to Hip, looks at developments in new materials and focuses on the design companies that are doing interesting things. Ms. Schueller also has a sidebar that lists companies offering environmental friendly lines, like underthecanopy.com.

title: Bonuses Uncertain for Bloomberg Election Aides
description: Michael R. Bloomberg prides himself on importing traditions from Wall Street to City Hall. But he did not count on introducing this one: end-of-year bonus anxiety.

title: Questioning a Test for Cancer
description: Christopher Taylor says he never lasted more than a week when he tried to quit smoking in the past. But it has been four weeks and counting this time, since a genetic test indicated he had a much higher risk of developing lung cancer than the average smoker.

title: Not Even Ribcage Injury Stopped Rivera
description: Mariano Rivera, one of the most indispensable Yankees, pitched with a ribcage injury during the postseason. If Rivera had faltered in Game 6 of the World Series and the Yankees had lost, would he have been fit enough to pitch in a Game 7 against the Philadelphia Phillies?

title: Obamas to Fix
description: What a difference a year makes.

title: Young Broadway Debuts
description: Kids and teenagers new to the Broadway stage speak about their careers and get advice from more seasoned members of their casts.

title: Gauging the Risks From a Smokers DNA and History
description: To take Synergenzs Respiragene test, consumers swab the inside of a cheek to get DNA and send the sample to a laboratory in Kentucky. The Synergenz Web site says a physician is required to sign a form requesting the test. The Respiragene test looks at 20 spots in a persons genome where DNA varies among people. It uses that data, as well as nongenetic information like the persons smoking history, to compute a risk score.

title: Wondering What to Lead? Listen Closely to the Bidding
description: The North American Open Pairs title is decided at the Spring North American Championships, which will be in Reno, Nev., in March. Every district of the American Contract Bridge League sends two pairs to compete in each of three flights (A, B and C).

title: Following Many Famous Footsteps Through the 92nd Street Y
description: Seventy-five years is a lifetime for many people. But art, as the Donald Justice poem goes, keeps long hours.

title: Same Booms, Different Terrain
description: The attack at the U.N. guesthouse in Kabul last week began at the first olive moments of daylight. I lay in my bed, having just closed my eyes after a long night. Boom-boom-boom-boom. There wasnt much to do but wait for it to end. And as I closed my eyes and listened, I was transported to another place: Baghdad.

title: Turning Happy Hour Into a Global Job Search
description: A baseball game was on television, the mechanical bull was waiting to thrash and dozens of women in business suits and heels were partaking liberally of after-work drink specials at Johnny Utahs, a bar in midtown Manhattan.

title: Nien Cheng, Memoirist, Is Dead at 94
description: Nien Cheng, whose memoir, Life and Death in Shanghai, offered a harrowing account of the Cultural Revolution in China and her years of imprisonment and torture at the hands of the Red Guards, died on Nov. 2 at her home in Washington. She was 94.

title: The Forever War of the Mind
description: EVERY day I was in Vietnam, I thought about home. And, every day Ive been home, Ive thought about Vietnam. So said one of the millions of soldiers who fought there as I did. Change the name of the battlefield and it could have been said by one of the American servicemen coming home from Iraq or Afghanistan today. Wars are not over when the shooting stops. They live on in the lives of those who fight them. That is the curse of the soldier. He never forgets.

title: Muslims at Fort Voice Outrage and Ask Questions
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Leaders of the vibrant Muslim community here expressed outrage on Friday at the shooting rampage being laid to one of their members, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, who had become a regular attendee of prayers at the local mosque.

title: Stacy Rowles, Jazz Musician, Is Dead at 54
description: Stacy Rowles, a jazz trumpeter, fluegelhorn player and singer who had been active on the Los Angeles jazz scene since the 1980s, died on Oct. 27 at her home in Burbank, Calif. She was 54.

title: The Life and Career of Major Hasan
description: Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan was sentenced to death in the Fort Hood shootings.

title: Happy Times at the Dog Run, Now Coming to an End
description: Its considered impolite, yet everyone slips up occasionally. How can anyone be blamed for mixing up the name of a dog with that of its owner, especially when the dog is Henry and his owner goes by Rags?

title: Weekend Sports Lineup
description: Here we are at the big Health Care Bill Weekend! The House of Representatives is actually getting ready to vote on legislation. How long has this been in the works, anyway? Was Mad Men on TV when the debate started? Had TV been invented?

title: Lottery Numbers
Lombardis Life Heads for Broadway
description: The life of Vince Lombardi  one of the Seven Blocks of Granite at Fordham, the coaching saint, the mahatma of Green Bay  is the subject of a new play, and its producers plan to bring it to Broadway late next year.

title: Dust Has Yet to Settle Over New Concrete Plant
description: Once it might have seemed a match made in zoning heaven: a concrete plant dropped into gritty, tumbledown Red Hook.

title: Oh, I Dont Know
description: Ive been Klahned! It was a knock-down, drag-out fight with Bob Klahn the victor in round 1, round 2 and round 3, until battered and bruised, I dragged this brawler of a puzzle to the canvas, right alongside me. Could that description sum up your experience?

title: Paul C. Zamecnik, Biologist Who Helped Discover an RNA Molecule, Dies at 96
description: Paul C. Zamecnik, a molecular biologist whose determination to unlock the secrets of how a protein is made led to his co-discovery of transfer RNA, a molecule that is essential to the process, died on Oct. 27 at his home in Boston. He was 96.

title: John Mashek, Veteran Political Reporter, Is Dead at 77
description: John W. Mashek, a reporter and columnist who covered national politics for nearly half a century for U.S. News & World Report, The Boston Globe and other publications, died Tuesday in Rockville, Md. He was 77 and lived in Washington.

title: Broader Measure of U.S. Unemployment Stands at 17.5%
description: For all the pain caused by the Great Recession, the job market still was not in as bad shape as it had been during the depths of the early 1980s recession  until now.

title: Vows: Allyson & Gautam
description: Allyson and Gautam met when they were both working in a trauma unit at a Boston hospital. She knew he was special when he could make her laugh even at 5:30 in the morning after an all-night shift.

title: Virtual Goods Start Bringing Real Paydays
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Silicon Valley may have discovered the perfect business: charging real money for products that do not exist.

title: The View From the Wall
description: To mark the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, readers submitted their photos and memories.

title: In a Childs Company, Champions Become Gods
description: Before Game 5 of the World Series, in the visiting managers office at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, Joe Girardi admitted he had thought about the parade. His son Dante, then 7 years old, had been asking about it.

title: 'Free for All'
description: Kenneth Turan's long-delayed oral history about Joseph Papp and the Public Theater will finally have a release.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about Hillary Rodham Clintons sparring with the Pakistani press during a recent trip to Pakistan misstated, in some editions, Najam Sethis relationship to The Daily Times, an English-language paper. He is the former editor in chief, not the current editor. (As the article correctly noted in some editions he is the editor of The Friday Times, an English-language weekly.)

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Prescriptions column on Wednesday about civil rights groups unveiling a war room in Washington to push for a government-run health plan misstated the age of one of the groups, the Urban League. It is 99 years old, not 109.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Fugitive Safe Surrender, a government program that promises leniency to those wanted for nonviolent crimes, misstated the name of the Newark church where officers ran computer checks on participants. It is Bethany Baptist Church, not Bethel Baptist Church.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 29 about a blog by Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York misstated the given name of the bishop of Brooklyn, who does not have a blog. He is Nicholas DiMarzio, not Anthony (Anthony is his middle name).

title: Corrections
description: A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Schubert Ascending mini-festival presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center misspelled, at one point, the surname of a pianist who will perform. As noted elsewhere in the entry, he is Inon Barnatan, not Barnaton.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: Comedy

title: Events on Long Island
description: Comedy

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an experimental gene therapy procedure intended to improve vision misstated the name of a gene used in a treatment of five children and seven adults with a type of congenital retinal disease. It is RPE65, not REP65.

title: All Along Broadway, Pinstripes, Proposals and Chants to Go for 28
description: The Yankees took one last ride together to celebrate their championship. It was a slow, joyous journey up Broadway, an outdoor party attended by hundreds of thousands of their closest friends. For the first time in nine years  and time is measured in dog years in Yankeeland  the Yankees and their fans could brag about being the best.

title: Bloggingheads: Neglecting the Jobless?
description: David Corn, left, of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate President Obama's commitment to lowering unemployment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a conference at Hampshire College in Massachusetts on creationism in the Islamic world referred incorrectly to a comment by the events organizer, Salman Hameed. In noting that researchers did not have much information about the teaching and perception of evolution in Arab countries, Dr. Hameed was citing the example of textbooks used by private Saudi schools in the United States, not in Saudi Arabia.

title: 2,000-Year-Old Scrolls, Internet-Era Crime
description: Early one morning in March, the law banged on the door of an apartment on Thompson Street in Greenwich Village. Investigators had a warrant to arrest Raphael Haim Golb and seize his computer. He was caught red-handed.

title: In Scientologys Door, but Not Much Farther
description: For all the rumors that swirl around the Church of Scientology  the accusations that it is a cult, the hints about its supernatural teachings, the means by which it attracts so many celebrities  its center on West 46th Street, tucked between the soigne Paramount Hotel and the workaday Edison, is a rather straightforward presence.

title: The Long Toll of Missing in Action
description: THE big news on July 15, 1969, was the countdown for the Apollo 11 mission to the moon. But the writer Lary Bloom remembers it as the day his boyhood friend Harmon Polster, a 25-year-old United States Air Force navigator, went down in a nighttime crash in Laos. Airmen in nearby jets thought they saw the fiery end, but they couldnt tell whether Lieutenant Polster or the pilot had been able to eject. Their names were added to the countrys growing list of those missing in action.

title: Beauty From Sometimes Shaky Hands
description: Those who attend the annual Full Circle celebration at the Matheny Medical and Educational Center, which casts a spotlight on the facilitys Arts Access program for its patients, show up for a spectrum of reasons.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: A Division Through Time
description: A historical look at points along the border that separated East and West Berlin from 1961 until 1989.

title: Red Carpet: Latin Grammys
description: Glitz and heart-on-sleeve emotionality mingled, every so often, with political and social messages at the 10th annual Latin Grammy Awards.

title: Dont Worry, Be Happy: The Warranty Psychology
description: MANY people would not think of making a major purchase without doing research to find the best model and the lowest price. But at the checkout counter, all of that preparation often breaks down.

title: The Horror at Fort Hood
description: It is always a shock  and a cause for deep sadness  when a gunman fires malevolently at crowds of innocent people. We have seen it far too often: at Columbine High School in Colorado a decade ago; on the campus of Virginia Tech two years ago; at a center for immigrants in upstate New York in April; and in downtown Orlando, Fla., where a gunman shot and killed one person and wounded five others on Friday.

title: Investors Beware
description: Things turned Orwellian in the House Financial Services Committee this week when members  with the backing of the White House  passed an investor protection bill that would make it all too easy for thousands of publicly traded companies to cook their books.

title: Coup, Uninterrupted
description: The Obama administration has worked hard, if somewhat episodically, to try to resolve the political crisis in Honduras. Last week, it looked as if the administration had pulled it off. The deal is now unraveling because of the obstinacy of Hondurass ousted president, Manuel Zelaya, and the man who ousted him, Roberto Micheletti. But we fear Washington also miscalculated that obstinacy.

title: After 40 Years, Age Discrimination Still Gets Second-Class Treatment
description: After working for a vending machine company for more than 20 years, James OConnor was replaced with someone younger. He sued. He testified that his boss had disparaged older workers, including saying  two weeks before he was fired  OConnor, you are too damn old for this kind of work. A federal court was unmoved, ruling in 1995 that he had not connected the bigoted comments to his firing.

title: The Worlds Best Health Care System?
description: To the Editor:

title: War and the Rampage
description: To the Editor:

title: Payments to Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridging the Workplace Generation Gap: It Starts With a Text
description: IF we believe the advertisements, with plastic surgery and Spanx we can all look 25 until we drop. But apparently thats not enough anymore  looking young doesnt do you much good if you still act old.

title: A Sign, Perhaps, in a Fillys Victory
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  Horseplayers ignore omens at their own risk. And the ones who had been on the fence about the chances of the tough old mare Zenyatta beating a stout field of boys Saturday in the $5 million Breeders Cup Classic shivered with goose bumps Friday when Life Is Sweet rolled off the final turn, squared her powerful shoulders and took aim at the finish line.

title: James Brings Buzz to Garden, but Keeps Plans to a Murmur
description: In one of LeBron Jamess recurring Nike commercials, he played several characters simultaneously. The ad was merely fantasy for viewers, fodder for shoe aficionados.

title: Rodriguez Savors First Title
description: A few minutes after Alex Rodriguez jumped off a parade float Friday, he stopped to answer questions about an embarrassing, challenging and, ultimately, victorious season. But, before Rodriguez talked too much about this season, he referenced 2004, a season that ended shockingly for the Yankees.

title: Fans at Garden Were Thrilled, but Not by Knicks
description: LeBron James bade New York a warm hello and a fond farewell Friday, and in the hours between friendly greetings, pinned the Knicks with another defeat while soaking up their fans adulation.

title: Driver Said to Have Used Marijuana Regularly
description: The sister-in-law of the woman who killed herself and seven others when she hit another car head-on while driving the wrong way on the Taconic State Parkway in July, told investigators that the woman smoked marijuana regularly and was a heavy drinker, according to a lawyer for the family of two of the victims.

title: Womens Suffrage Campaign at Full Tilt
description: Sunday, Nov. 7, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Mourning the Victims at Fort Hood
description: A day after an Army doctor shot and killed 13 at Fort Hood in Texas, soldiers and families mourned and questions multiplied about the deadliest shooting on a U.S. base.

title: For Those Scoring at Home
description: O.K., policy wonks: fill a bowl of popcorn (or corn flakes), fluff the couch pillows and grab that remote control.

title: Curative Medicine
description: We didnt want to do Disney characters or wallpaper, says Diane Brown, the founder of RxArt, a New York-based nonprofit organization that brings contemporary art into hospitals and health care settings around the country. We want to offer challenging work to help get patients out of their heads, out of the hospital for a bit. Thats a tall order, since RxArt often works with facilities that treat children, some with life-threatening and terminal diseases. All the more reason that Brown, a curator and private art dealer before starting RxArt in 2000, enlisted artists like Will Cotton and Rob Pruitt to create works for St. Jude Childrens Research Hospital in Memphis, one of the worlds largest childhood cancer centers, which  miraculously in this day and age  covers the exorbitant costs of treatment for uninsured families. Pruitt made a series of his signature pandas out of shimmering, sequinlike discs; Cotton created two of his Candy Land-style paintings, having invited a 3-year-old girl with a rare brain cancer to help him build the gingerbread house maquettes. These pieces now hang in St. Judes bright new cafeteria, where staff and patients all get to enjoy them. Cotton, along with artists like Assume Vivid Astro Focus and Mark Grotjahn, has also contributed to an RxArt coloring book.

title: Reading List the Houses That Gehry Built
description: Frank Gehry is out of the house business, having moved on to bigger things. But it was a residential project  his radical revision of his own little Dutch colonial in Santa Monica, Calif.  that put him on the map in the late 1970s and allowed him to explore the ideas that came to define his architecture. This house and others are included in Frank Gehry: The Houses (Rizzoli), by Mildred Friedman, who in 1986, as the design curator at the Walker Art Center, mounted the first major museum exhibition of the architects work. (I contributed an essay to its catalog.) The book, which has an intimate, down-to-earth tone, features not only abundant visual material but also interviews with Gehry, his clients (including his wife, Berta), and current and former members of his firm. And seeing projects like his own home, the never-built extravaganza that he designed for the insurance magnate Peter Lewis or the guesthouse (right) that he completed in 1987 for Mike and Penny Winton in Wayzata, Minn., makes you hope Gehry still has another house (or two) in him.

title: Childs Play
description: Sitting on a shelf in the nursery at 2 Willow Road, in the leafy London suburb of Hampstead, is a wooden square containing cutouts of the 26 letters in the alphabet. It is slightly shabby, as if the letters have been pushed in and pulled out by lots of little hands over the years  which they have.

title: Block Party
description: Devoid as they are of nostalgia, kids wont really appreciate that the mustache included in the new wooden block set PlayShapes was inspired by Sgt. Pepper, nor that the toy has echoes of Alexander Girard, Enzo Mari and midcentury advertising illustrations. But what will please the little ones is that unlike that eras blocks, which mostly encouraged the dutiful construction of towns and landscapes, the strange contours of the 74 PlayShapes will let them build whatever animal, vegetable or psychedelic 60s pop star they please. We spent ages looking at old toys and seeing what had been done before, how we could make it new, says PlayShapes Brighton, U.K.-based co-creator Zoe Miller, who with her partner David Goodman also designs vintage-inspired kids toys and books for the Tate. For us it became about open-endedness, the fact that every child should feel that theyre an artist. $111; go to shhhop.com. [?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV

title: Tot Spot
description: In-Store Sweet William Bronagh Staleys two-year-old shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is filled with stylish clothing, accessories and toys for the seesaw set. Im drawn to small labels, especially European ones, that make traditional kids items with a little bit of an edge, says Staley, shown here with her son and muse, Fiontan. (112 North 6th Street; 718-218-6946; sweetwilliamltd.com) SANDRA BALLENTINE

title: Mothers Little Helper
description: Once upon a time, kids who showed an interest in culinary arts were given a packet of instant brownie mix and a miniature oven powered by a light bulb. But if your budding Jacques Ppin is begging for the latest Viking combi, indulge him instead with the latest cooking utensils from Curious Chef. The tools  including a whisk, spatula and rolling pin  are all bisphenol-A-free and scaled down to fit a childs hands; the nylon serrated knives are effective for chopping a tomato, not your little sous-chefs fingers. The 27-piece Foundation Set ($60; curiouschef.com) even comes with an apron and a chefs hat. Anyone for petits fours? [?][?][?] ANDREAS KOKKINO

title: Instant Gratification
description: Who doesnt have a digital camera these days? Not to mention a million unviewed images, eating up the memory on the hard drive? With that in mind, Fujifilm has introduced the adorable and already successful (in Europe and Asia) Instax Mini 7S camera. With its matte-white, bubble-shaped body, the camera was conceived not so much for those who pine for Polaroid as for the design-savvy iPod generation. The super-color-saturated, credit-card-size photos satisfy the current obsession for all things miniature  in a flash, no less. $96; go to fujifilmusa.com. [?][?][?] ANDREAS KOKKINO

title: House Proud
description: Until now, the world of dollhouses has thrived on Tudors and Georgians filled with wicker, Windsor and chintz, forcing dolls  and the children who love them  to dwell in a land that time forgot. Theyre all furnished like my grandmothers house, with terrible old brown chairs, says Linda Stenberg, the creative director for the new Danish company Minimii (minimii.com). She and her partner Claus Hojer Hansen have come up with an antidote: a 1/16-size reproduction of Arne Jacobsens own 1929 house, approved by Jacobsens family and scheduled for release early next year. There are Egg and Swan chairs courtesy of Fritz Hansen, tiny Vipp trash cans and a working lamp by the Danish studio Design by Us. New pieces commissioned just for the house so far include a childlike scribble by the artist Poul Pava and prospective inhabitants by the dollmaker Maileg. Stenberg has already noticed a change in her kids since she let them play with the prototypes: They recognize the furniture now, she says. When they see a Jacobsen, they say, Oh, Mommy, those are your chairs, only bigger.  [?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV

title: Family Planning
description: The extended family is a wonderful thing, but so is privacy. Its not easy to balance the two when designing a house, particularly if you dont have the land or budget, or both, to build a compound. But with ingenuity and a little luck, even a modest house on a small site can accommodate three generations with breathing room to spare.

title: Profile in Style: Cynthia Rowley
description: A CREATIVE MULTITASKER

title: Now Showing Design for Living
description: London is known for top-quality design exhibitions, and this season doesnt disappoint. Opening Nov. 18 at the Design Museum is a retrospective of the work of the German designer Dieter Rams, including his pioneering electronics designs for Braun, without which there might be no iPod (Apples Jonathan Ive is one of five designers who are interviewed for the show), and those for the furniture company Vitsoe. On Nov. 26, the Serpentine Gallery opens its first-ever contemporary design exhibition, Design Real, curated by the German industrial designer Konstantin Grcic. His selection focuses on objects (like Carlotta de Bevilacquas Yang light for Artemide, below right) that have a practical function, are accessible to all and have made a significant impact on the world. Grcics own work will be the subject of Konstantin Grcic: Decisive Design, starting Nov. 20 at the Art Institute of Chicago. [?][?][?] PILAR VILADAS

title: On Top of Spaghetti
description: Getting kids interested in eating good food is one thing. How about getting them interested in cooking? Phaidon, which published the translation of the Italian food bible The Silver Spoon, has chosen 40 bambino-friendly recipes from the original 2,000-plus to create The Silver Spoon for Children: Favorite Italian Recipes. The colorful, cleverly illustrated book teaches kids 8 and up kitchen fundamentals and provides step-by-step instructions for everything from a simple prosciutto and melon to spaghetti amatriciana. (Ask an adult to help you drain the spaghetti.) Making meatballs is apparently a great way to practice math and learn about fractions. And cooking your parents chicken breasts stuffed with mascarpone is a great way to make them happy. Buon appetito. [?][?][?] CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: Funny Money
description: Warren Buffett is now a cartoon character. The Oracle of Omaha has a starring role in Secret Millionaires Club, a Web series produced by AOL and A Squared Entertainment that goes live in January. This is not a move to stanch his declining fortunes  the mans still worth $40 billion, after all  but a pro bono effort to teach kids fiscal responsibility. (Adults, Buffett must think, are now beyond his help.) The club is made up of a group of young Nebraskans who sell baseball memorabilia online and use the profits to bankroll an investment business; an animated (and slenderized) Buffett serves as their adviser. Searching for a youth-friendly analogue, Andy Heyward, the shows producer, says, Its a little bit like Monopoly. Heyward first collaborated with Buffett on the animated introductions to Berkshire Hathaways annual shareholder meetings, in which the frugal tycoon has spoofed Batman and James Bond. Warren is amazing, Heyward says. He does everything in just one take. [?][?][?] STEPHEN HEYMAN

title: Jamie Gray | Design Daddy
description: Children may not be able to recognize good design, but according to Jamie Gray (photographed with his girlfriend, Olivia Sammons, and their children, Cy and Levi), they can recognize beauty. Gray, who owns the less-is-more New York design shop Matter, recalls once waking up at 5:30 a.m. to find the 3-year-old Levi gazing through the window of their Brooklyn apartment. Look at the sky, Papa, Levi exclaimed. Its beautiful. The first piece Gray ever built was a three-legged chair. His teacher told him it would never stand up. But I made it anyway, he said. And it worked! (Gray is seated above in a Victor armchair by Paul Loebach.) His companys Web address, MatterMatters.com, speaks to the challenge of creating objects in a world thats already glutted with them. Thats the daily quandary: Do you create more? he asks. But, ultimately, if theres a want, somebody has to take responsibility for it. My intention is to create heirloom pieces that wont end up at the bottom of a landfill. [?][?][?] STEPHEN HEYMAN

title: Nordic Track
description: Living in a winter wonderland.

title: Empty Nest Syndrome
description: There isnt much demand for minimalist design at my house. My 7-year-old twins have never seen a white surface they didnt think could use a little color. ( Sol LeWitt, because he got to draw on walls, is already the boys favorite artist.) As for furniture, none of those spare, Modernist chairs, like Karim Rashids Oh or even Gerrit Rietvelds Zig-Zag, will do. Their favorite place to sit is anywhere on Daddy, and that  they have explained just a bit too enthusiastically  is because Daddy is squishy all over.

title: Bright Young Thing Emily Pilloton
description: If the initiatives that Project H Design has taken on seem largely geared toward young people  Learning Landscape playgrounds and sustainable food programs for public schools, to name but two  it may have something to do with the fact that Emily Pilloton, the founder of the not even two-year-old humanitarian organization, is herself only 27. With the help of nine volunteer-driven cells from Austin, Tex., to Johannesburg, Pilloton, who started the company with a laptop and $1,000 while living at home with her parents, aims to create local design solutions and apply them globally. (The playgrounds, for example, were conceived in Uganda and have since been installed in North Carolina and the Dominican Republic.) Pilloton is also the author of the just-released book Design Revolution: 100 Products That Empower People (Metropolis Books), which gives well-deserved shout-outs to everything from the Hippo Water Roller (a portable vessel that can carry a weeks worth of water for a family of seven) and Braille-based Lego-style building blocks to D.I.Y. soccer balls (left) and SkySails (which are large enough to help propel cargo ships). If its any consolation, she insists, Ive aged a lot over the last year. [?][?][?] ALIX BROWNE

title: The Best-Dwessed List
description: Before I had children, I had this delusional idea that their clothes would cost less than grown-up clothes. The proportionately smaller the outfit, the proportionately less expensive. Plus, they would be self-reliant little creatures, like Keebler elves, cozying themselves away in a tree somewhere during the day and knitting their own stocking caps.

title: Short Orderers
description: Many moons ago I watched aghast as my young niece and nephew cheerfully masticated a lunch of French fries and ketchup during a family ski vacation in Utah. How can they be allowed to eat like that? I hissed sotto voce to my husband, who nodded in smug sympathy.

title: Cool for School
description: As you drive past downtown Los Angeles on the 101 freeway, one building grabs your attention, its concrete and steel tower swooping and twisting like a roller coaster. A multitiered group of oversize geometric structures arranged around concrete and grass courtyards, this complex is not, in fact, an amusement park. Its the new Central Los Angeles High School No. 9, which opened in September. The building, designed by the edgy Austrian firm Coop Himmelb(l)au, tosses aside any preconceived notion of what a school should look like.

title: Wild Thing
description: Bring out the beast  in a good way.

title: Family Planning
Mini-Mies (and Friends)
description: Now that more children are growing up with exquisite  if expensive  taste, the selection of minimodern classics keeps growing. Indeed, when Modernists preached that design should be accessible to all, they meant children, too. The Eameses created plywood elephants and kiddie stools, and designers like Verner Panton considered their furnishings equally viable at pint-size. Invest in these. MONICA KHEMSUROV

title: The New Collectibles
description: SWEET DREAMS Worried that your babys bed wont match your midcentury modern dcor? The Nest Collection bassinet, by Scott Wilson for Offi, is a sleek walnut-veneered design with a chrome base. $999. Go to minijake.com.

title: Just My Size
description: HAPPY HOME From Left: silhouette lamp by robert kuo for Mcguire, $3,791. Go to mcguirefurniture.com. cindy Lamp by ferruccio laviani for kartell,

title: Family Planning
description: The extended family is a wonderful thing, but so is privacy. Its not easy to balance the two when designing a house, particularly if you dont have the land or budget, or both, to build a compound. But with ingenuity and a little luck, even a modest house on a small site can accommodate three generations with breathing room to spare.

title: King of the Playground
description: When you think about it, the Rockwell Group has been in the business of playgrounds for years, creating a showy interior for a glamorous jeweler, a JetBlue terminal and Nobu restaurants from New York to Dubai. So the Imagination Playground at Burling Slip, which opens next summer in a former parking lot near South Street Seaport, is a logical next step. The peanut-shaped park is inspired by midcentury adventure playgrounds, where children used found objects and postwar debris. It features sand and water, Playground Associates to oversee the action, and more than 350 loose parts, including wheelbarrows, pool noodles and weather- and germ-resistant foam blocks (above, in Brooklyn). David Rockwell, the founder and C.E.O., has created a standard kit that can be deployed cheaply in open spaces across the country, but at Burling Slip he pays homage to its nautical past with pulleys, masts and periscope-like tubes through which children can talk from opposite ends of the park. Each place encourages a kind of cooperative, self-directed fantasy play, he says. Or you can just run around like a maniac. [?][?][?] JILL SINGER

title: Watch This Space
description: For Faye Toogood, Septembers London Design Festival was a coming-out party of sorts. After spending nearly a decade styling for the British magazine The World of Interiors and developing her signature raw-meets-refined look, she started quietly building her own full-service creative studio in 2008, remaining under the radar despite redesigning Dover Street Markets shoe department and creating fanciful window displays for Liberty. But following two buzzed-about installations that she curated at the London festival and her high-profile work for Tom Dixon  which includes a catalog and a new London showroom  the design world is beginning to take notice of this multitalented 32-year-old. There arent many stylists who have decided to transcend disciplines, says Toogood, who studied fine art and art history. Its been a natural course for me.

title: N.H.L. Scores: Leafs Beat Canes in Battle of Tail-Enders
description: Six games on Friday night, but without question the feature attraction is the showdown between the two worst teams in the league: the Leafs, with one regulation win in their first 13 matches, vs. the Hurricanes, with one regulation win in their first 14. Home teams listed first:

title: Obama Offers Sympathy and Urges No Jump to Conclusions
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, extending condolences to the community at Fort Hood, Tex., reminded Americans on Saturday that people of every race, faith and station serve in the military  an oblique attempt to prevent a backlash against Muslims in the wake of Thursdays shootings at the base that left 13 dead.

title: Walter Paytons Tribute
description: I had no luck searching for a YouTube clip of the halftime tribute to Walter Payton last Sunday in Chicago. It was the 10th anniversary of his death. CBS only showed a snippet of the ceremony in the game broadcast.

title: Saturday Word: Fort Hood and Health Care
description: President Obama uses his weekly address this week to express sympathy for those who lost loved ones at the Fort Hood shooting and also to hail the valor of those on the scene.

title: Stressing the Friend Part of Frenemy
description: The business card of Eric Schmidt says he is the chairman and chief executive of Google. But another part of his job is ambassador to the marketing, advertising and media communities, reassuring them that if Google is a frenemy, in the parlance of Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of WPP, it is more friend than enemy.

title: Ways to Avoid the Flu
description: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: I just want to mention, if anyone is here tonight for a flu shot, we ran out, so  I accidentally drank them, so sorry.

title: The Lead Players, as House Debate Begins
description: The health care debate is under way on Saturday morning. Representative John Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, and the Dean of the House, is presiding as the speaker pro tempore.

title: Abortion Fight Erupts in Health Care Debate
description: Updated After months of work by Congressional Democrats on major health care legislation, the floor debate on the bill was at risk of being overshadowed on Saturday by a fierce internal dispute among Democrats over the issue of insurance coverage for abortions.

title: Marooned on Sea of Iraqi Oil, but Unable to Tap Its Wealth
description: BASRA, Iraq  The orange glow of the giant natural gas flares in the oil fields around Basra represents this bustling citys wealth of natural resources. But for the impoverished people who live near them, the flames only serve as a reminder of their inability to share in the riches that lie beneath their feet.

title: Jeremy Morris, Who Proved Exercise Is Heart-Healthy, Dies at 99
description: Jeremy N. Morris, a British epidemiologist whose comparison of heart-attack rates among double-decker bus drivers and conductors in London in the late 1940s and early 50s laid the scientific groundwork for the modern aerobics movement, died Oct. 28 in Hampstead, London. He was 99 .

title: In the Bronx, Getting Back All 40 Winks
description: Poverty constricts how people live. For one family on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, it affected how they slept.

title: House Debate: Objections
description: Curtains up.

title: Ecosystem in Peru Is Losing a Key Ally
description: ICA, Peru  A small grove of huarango, the storied Peruvian tree that can live over a millennium, rests like a mirage amid the sand dunes on this citys edge. The tree has provided the inhabitants of this desert with food and timber since before the Nazca civilization etched geoglyphs into the empty plain south of here about 2,000 years ago.

title: European Puck: Forsberg, Blanked Again, Says He Played Better
description: Never has the Karjala Cup generated such interest in North America, but that interest continues to mount as Peter Forsberg furthers his comeback attempt in the Finnish tournament that until this week was virtually unheard of among hockey fans in Canada and the United States.

title: With Wall Just a Memory, German Divisions Fade
description: BERLIN  The Quiz of the Germans, a lighthearted entry amid a crush of serious examinations of the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, pitted three West German celebrities seated behind the sloping hood of an old Volkswagen Beetle against counterparts from the East perched above the front of a clunky Trabant.

title: Weighing Life in Prison for Youths Who Didnt Kill
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- There are just over 100 people in the world serving sentences of life without the possibility of parole for crimes they committed as juveniles in which no one was killed. All are in the United States. And 77 of them are here in Florida.

title: Spirally Rising Acrostic
description: Ive heard this quote but have never read the book. However, the act of writing out the passage has given me the motivation to look for the book next time Im at the library. Thanks Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon for the push!

title: Millionaires in Congress
description: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: The unemployment rate went above 10% for the first time since 1983. Last week, economists were saying that the recession is finally over, but this week, all of the economists were laid off. So, it is tough.

title: She Took That Money
description: Monologue | Aired Friday night on CBS: Sarah Palins new book, new memoir, is coming out next month. Its called Going Rogue. Ooh, she was like Rambo, out there on her own, hiding in the trees, swooping down on vines.

title: Isnt That Nice?
description: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on NBC: Yesterday at the White House, President Obama met with Native American tribal leaders and they gave Obama the Indian name He Who Cares. Isnt that nice? Then they gave Vice President Joe Biden the Indian name Big Chief Running Mouth.

title: Labels and Gay Benefits in Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Lower taxes for gay couples who receive health benefits from employers. Nutrition labeling requirements for snack food sold in vending machines and many restaurants. A new program to teach parents how to interact with their children.

title: The Real Winners
description: Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC: President Obama hosted a conference of all the Native American tribes. I dont want to say the U.S. economy is in bad shape, but Obama told the Indians, Look, you can have your country back. Okay, its fine.

title: In Republican District, National Party Takes a Hit
description: It is not often that a political party puts more than $750,000 behind a candidate in a high-profile Congressional race, only to see the intended beneficiary endorse the opposition.

title: Fort Hood Muslims React
description: Members of a mosque near Fort Hood expressed shock at the killings.

title: NATO Airstrike Said to Kill 7 Afghan Soldiers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan Defense Ministry and local officials in Badghis Province said on Saturday that seven members of the Afghan security forces had been killed in a NATO airstrike the day before that was part of an effort to aid a beleaguered Afghan and NATO operation against the Taliban.

title: Windfall Seen as Bank Bonuses Are Paid in Stock
description: Even as Washington tries to rein in Wall Street pay, bankers are likely to make unusually large gains on the stock grants and options they received after shares in their companies fell sharply during the financial meltdown.

title: UPDATED: Obama Rallies House Democrats
description: Update | 1:45 p.m.  President Obama made a last-minute appeal to Congress on Saturday, urging lawmakers to answer the call of history by casting their votes in favor of a health overhaul being considered on the floor of the House of Representatives.

title: Sweeping Health Care Plan Passes House
description: WASHINGTON  Handing President Obama a hard-fought victory, the House narrowly approved a sweeping overhaul of the nations health care system on Saturday night, advancing legislation that Democrats said could stand as their defining social policy achievement.

title: To Retain Its Bankers, Citi Offers Option Plan
description: Hoping to encourage bankers and managers to stay, Citigroup has begun dispensing several million stock options to more than a quarter of its workers in a way that could result in a sizable gain for them, The New York Timess Eric Dash reports.

title: When Soldiers Snap
description: Every man has his breaking point, said military doctors in World War II, believing that more than 90 days of continuous combat could turn any soldier into a psychiatric casualty.

title: US tariff history
description: Mostly a note to myself, since Im teaching trade policy at the Wilson School this spring. From the millennial edition of Historical Statistics,

title: House Jumps One Hurdle
description: The House approved the rule governing debate of the big health care legislation by a vote of 242 to 192, suggesting  but not guaranteeing  that Democrats would have the votes to pass the bill itself later on Saturday.

title: The President Whose Words Once Soared
description: WASHINGTON  As the most gifted orator of his generation, President Obama finds speechmaking perhaps his most potent political tool. It propelled him to national prominence in 2004 and to the White House in 2008. And whenever he needs to calm economic fears or revive stalled health care legislation, he takes to the lectern.

title: Awesome Train Set, Mr. Buffett
description: For $50 or so, you can buy a Thomas the Tank Engine train set and feel as powerful as Sir Topham Hatt, the somewhat wooden overseer of the mythical North Western Railway Company. Or, if you are the investor Warren E. Buffett, you can purchase the complete set of the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation, for $26 billion or so.

title: Invitation to Veterans and Families
description: The editors of Home Fires are requesting the participation of readers for a post on Veterans Day, Nov. 11. If you are a veteran, or friend or relative of someone who served during wartime and would like to share a written message or recollection, or a photograph recalling a veteran or their service, you can send it to Home Fires via e-mail at homefires@nytimes.com.

title: Who Is a Jew? Court Ruling in Britain Raises Question
description: LONDON  The questions before the judges in Courtroom No. 1 of Britains Supreme Court were as ancient and as complex as Judaism itself.

title: Medvedev Says Russia May Back Sanctions on Iran if Deal Falls Apart
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev said Russia might back sanctions against Iran if the Iranians did not take a constructive position on an international plan to temporarily diminish their stockpile of enriched uranium.

title: For Russias Communists, Ousting Putin Is a Priority
description: MOSCOW  Along with the perennial calls for land for farmers and factories for workers, Communists who marched in Moscow on the Saturday anniversary of the 1917 revolution offered a slogan of more recent vintage: Russia without Putin.

title: Heavier Americans Push Back on Health Debate
description: Marilyn Wann is an author and weight diversity speaker in Northern California who has a message for anyone making judgments about her health based on her large physique. The only thing anyone can accurately diagnose by looking at a fat person is their own level of stereotype and prejudice about fat, said Ms. Wann, a 43-year-old San Franciscan whose motto in life is also the title of her book: Fat! So?

title: Reagan! Reagan! Reagan!
description: Aha. I see that some commenters insist that I was unfair or, some insist, intellectually dishonest in my post on the fact that advanced economies actually grew faster in the era before modern finance took hold. There have been assertions that it was all about rebuilding from the war, or that the picture looks very different if you look at per capita real GDP, with some flat assertions that if you look at the numbers right growth has been better since 1980s.

title: The Recessions Over, but Not the Layoffs
description: The Great Recession is over  not officially, but by popular acclaim  and in this accepted fact we are invited to take comfort, even as the unemployment rate last week rose into double digits for the first time in a quarter-century.

title: N.F.L. Tries to Get a Grip on Tackling That Has Suddenly Gone Amiss
description: Jacksonville Coach Jack Del Rio was so disgusted by how many tackles the Jaguars missed last Sunday in a 30-13 loss at Tennessee that he took an unusual step in todays N.F.L.: he had his team practice in full pads. Del Rio even considered, but ultimately rejected, having his players actually tackle in practice.

title: Love in the Time of Cellphones
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 7, 2009
description: The midterm elections of 2010 are about a year away, but the guests on this Sundays talk shows will try to gauge whats in store for Democrats and Republicans on the next election day. Plus, the Armys highest-ranking officer talks about the shootings at the Army base in Ft. Hood, Tex.

title: Claude Lvi-Strausss Two-Part Harmonies
description: Millions of words have been written trying to explain or apply the theories of the French anthropologist Claude Lvi-Strauss since the publication of his work Structural Anthropology in 1958. More than a few of the resulting texts in disciplines as varied as sociology and philosophy are dense, turgid and jargon ridden, or so the complaint goes. But Mr. Lvi-Strauss himself could be simple, direct and elegant when he wanted to be. Structuralism, he once said, is simply the search for unsuspected harmonies across cultures.

title: Getting a Grip on Drugs and Horses
description: More than a half-dozen trainers who have been accused of doping their horses participated in this years Breeders Cup at Santa Anita Park in Arcadia, Calif., to compete in 14 races worth more than $25.5 million in purse money. Some of these trainers have been cited for multiple and serious drug violations; indeed, some have been barred and suspended from the sport for periods of time. But none of these punishments have deterred trainers from doping their animals.

title: Correction: Lessons From Iraq
description: An article last Sunday about lessons a correspondent learned while reporting on the war in Iraq offered an incorrect contrast to the difficulties Iraqis face when crossing from Kurdish Iraq into their countrys Arab southern provinces. A comparison that illustrates the ease of traversing a state border in the United States would be a crossing from Michigan into Indiana  not into Illinois, with which Michigan does not share a land border.

title: News of Hockey, 11/7/09: Canadian Women Beat U.S. to Win Four Nations Cup
description: Canada rallied from an early 1-0 deficit to beat the United States, 5-1, in the final of the Four Nations Cup in Tikkurila, Finland, the last international womens tournament before the Vancouver Olympics in February.

title: Britain and U.S. Clash at G-20 on Tax to Insure Against Crises
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The United States and Britain voiced disagreement Saturday over a proposal that would impose a new tax on financial transactions to support future bank rescues.

title: Manning and Rivers Share a Past, and Now the Present
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When San Diego chose Eli Manning first over all in the 2004 N.F.L. draft, the Chargers gave him a jersey that he handed to his mother.

title: The House Debate Over Health Care Legislation
description: Prescriptions, The Timess blog on the debate over health care reform, is following the floor debate over health care legislation in the House of Representatives throughout Saturday. Read the current coverage.

title: Obamas Remarks on the House Health Care Bill
description: Following is a transcript of President Obama's remarks on the health care bill being debated in the House of Representatives on Saturday, as released by the White House:

title: Boxings Pac-Man, Back Home
description: Manny Pacquiao and his trainer Freddie Roach took their training regimen to the fighters home country, the Philippines, as Pacquiao prepared for another title bout.

title: New Yorks Cabbies Like Credit Cards? Go Figure
description: New Yorks cabbies howled when the city began forcing them to take credit cards. Some even went on strike, calling the requirements a kowtow to tourists and a burden on drivers.

title: The Yankees and the Cubs
description: If baseball were a country, rather than a sport, the North Side of Chicago would be in an uprising right now. Are you kidding me? Cubs fans would cry angrily as they took note of the 27 championships for the Yankees in the last 87 years and the lack of even one for their team since 1908. There would be protests in the streets, calls for a federal investigation, boycotts of products made in New York.

title: Quotation of the Week
description: Im dumbfounded. After all these years, I still dont get how Broadway works, or what to make of our culture.

title: 4 Are Killed in 2 Fires in Queens and Brooklyn
description: Three people were killed and four were injured in a fire that started in the basement of an illegally subdivided house in Queens early Saturday morning, according to neighbors and Fire Department officials.

title: Prime Number
description: 58: The number of private colleges that now charge at least $50,000 a year for tuition, fees, room and board, according to The Chronicle of Higher Education. Last year, only five colleges charged that much. Generous aid packages mean many students pay far less, the Chronicle noted. Even so, the cost of a college education has grown much faster than the costs of other goods and services  up 4.3 percent this year at private colleges and 5.9 percent for in-state students at public schools.

title: Ask Not What You Can Steal From Your Country
description: Call to armed robbers: stop your crimes. Please. For a little while at least. Please.

title: Nov. 7, 1979
description: On the fourth day of the Iranian hostage crisis, the students seeking American extradition of the deposed Shah reported Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's refusal to meet with former Attorney General Ramsey Clark and William G. Miller, staff director of the Senate Intelligence Committee:

title: Florida A&M Coach Has Faith in His Rebuilding Program
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  When Joe Taylor took over as the football coach at Florida A&M, barely a month after the Rattlers lost six of their last seven games to finish 3-8 in 2007, he summoned every returning player for an individual conference.

title: Out of Chance Meeting, a Formidable Pairing
description: HOLLYWOOD  After the second typhoon hit, as the third crept closer, Freddie Roach had seen enough. Houses disappeared underwater. Boulders blocked the narrow, winding roads. Seventeen families packed into one room.

title: Lawmakers Join Protest Over Bill
description: As the House began debate on President Obamas top-priority initiative to overhaul the health care system, protesters outside the Capitol occasionally yelled or waved signs that said, Have you heard us yet?

title: The Calm After the Storm
description: Peace has returned to the Yankees universe. The Champagne celebrations are over, the confetti has been cleaned up along the Canyon of Heroes and for the first time since last spring, the urgency has vanished from Yankee Stadium.

title: Knock-Knock Joke?
description: Video | Quite possibly proof that the Internet has everything:

title: At Ruby Tuesday, Casual Dining Dons a Blazer
description: Maryville, Tenn.

title: Inside the Global Gold Frenzy
description: MENDRISIO, Switzerland

title: Hill Gives Glimpse of Knicks Future
description: There was an intense focus on the Knicks future Friday night, and yet it was easy to miss one of the most critical pieces of that future.

title: Ballets Mean Streets
description: Some movies you have to watch whenever theyre on.

title: A Way Out of the Deep Freeze
description: FOR many holders of auction-rate securities  investments that Wall Street once peddled as safe, sound and as fully liquid as cash  life in the frozen zone drags on.

title: Small Businesses Hunker Down to Survive
description: New data show that small businesses have battened down the hatches in response to the recession.

title: Watch the Walk and Prevent a Fall
description: FALLS are so harmful to the elderly and so costly to society that if falling were a disease, it would be deemed an epidemic.

title: Far From a Lab? Turn a Cellphone Into a Microscope
description: MICROSCOPES are invaluable tools to identify blood and other cells when screening for diseases like anemia, tuberculosis and malaria. But they are also bulky and expensive.

title: Lawyer Cites Mental Illness in Shooting
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The lawyer for the man accused of shooting six people, one fatally, at an Orlando office building on Friday told reporters after a court appearance on Saturday that his client was very, very mentally ill.

title: Johnson Has Turned Nascars Chase Into a Stroll
description: Jimmie Johnson will probably make stock-car history this month by winning a fourth consecutive championship, but his coronation will culminate an anticlimactic Nascar Sprint Cup Series season.

title: How to Stay Relentlessly Positive
description: Tobi Umodu is a junior fullback for the U.C.L.A. Bruins. He is blogging for The Quad periodically during the season.

title: Putting the Negro Leagues in Play
description: The Strat-O-Matic Game Company, an old warhorse in an age of computer-driven fantasy leagues and high-tech video games, usually relies on detailed statistics to create ratings and tendencies for hitters and pitchers. But in creating a new 103-card Negro leagues set for its board game, Strat-O-Matic found that the data was not easy to come by.

title: Hoisting Babies in Health Debate
description: Some lawmakers today used live props  infants and young children  to help make their arguments about health care as they take to the House floor on Saturday. As they did so, they were chastised by those presiding over the debate.

title: Budget Fights Are Brewing at the United Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS  The fact that it costs the United Nations an average of $2,473 per page to create every single document in its six official languages, while outside contractors complete the same work for around $450, prompts diplomats to accuse the organization of running amok during a global financial crisis.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Colonization
description: Robert W. Harris has taken a popular puzzling convention, inserting several letters into an existing phrase, and created a pleasant and amusing Sunday afternoon picnic. In this case, the presence of six-legged interlopers only adds to the enjoyment. All of the theme entries were good and several were unexpected in their origins, but for my money, the inspired standout of the bunch was MADAM, IM ADAMANT. Never has a palindrome been ruined to greater success.

title: An Island Shelter Meets Resistance From Locals
description: UNALASKA, Alaska  This was a tumble-down frontier town not so long ago, known for big catches of king crab on the Bering Sea and big trouble when the boats came back to shore, spilling their crews into a raucous redoubt of drink named the Elbow Room.

title: Call White House, Ask for Barack
description: The Israeli-Palestinian peace process has become a bad play. It is obvious that all the parties are just acting out the same old scenes, with the same old tired clichs  and that no one believes any of it anymore. There is no romance, no sex, no excitement, no urgency  not even a sense of importance anymore. The only thing driving the peace process today is inertia and diplomatic habit. Yes, the Israeli-Palestinian peace process has left the realm of diplomacy. It is now more of a calisthenic, like weight-lifting or sit-ups, something diplomats do to stay in shape, but not because they believe anything is going to happen. And yet, as much as we, the audience, know this to be true, we can never quite abandon hope for peace in the Holy Land. It is our habit. Indeed, as I ranted about this to a Jordanian friend the other day, he said it all reminded him of an old story.

title: Army Concludes Shootings Involved Only One Gunman
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Military investigators have concluded that there was only one gunman involved in the rampage at Fort Hood that left 13 people dead and dozens more injured, but they added that they were still trying to determine whether other people were involved in any plot, an Army spokesman said on Saturday.

title: Degree Required, but You Dont Have One
description: SOME job seekers harbor a secret that prevents them from applying for work they know they could do. Or they worry that if this fact comes to light in a job interview, it will explode and cause them to be led unceremoniously to the door.

title: Painful Stories Take a Toll on Military Therapists
description: Many of the patients who fill the day are bereft, angry, broken. Their experiences are gruesome, their distress lasting and the process of recovery exhausting. The repeated stories of battle and loss can leave the most professional therapist numb or angry.

title: In Fund Flows, a Caution for Stocks
description: MUTUAL fund investors have remained skeptical about the stock market rally over the last eight months, holding back on their purchases of domestic equity funds. That isnt a promising sign for the stock market.

title: Maybe a New Day for Doctors Pay
description: EVEN without a robust public option, any of the health care reform bills now under consideration would expand coverage greatly. But they would also start a competitive dynamic that would eliminate the fundamental conflict of interest that has made American health care so expensive.

title: Bouquets That Bear Fruit
description: I WAS born in Pakistan and came to the United States in 1981, when I was 11. My grandfather owned a farm in Pakistan and we had been fairly well-to-do. We started at the bottom when we came here. My father found a job as a machinist during the day and worked at McDonalds and Burger King at night.

title: Jobless Recovery
description: If you are looking for an economic recovery you can believe in, the October employment report is not for you.

title: Young, Talented and Unhappy Playing Basketball Overseas
description: HAIFA, Israel  Jeremy Tyler came to this scenic city overlooking the Mediterranean as a trailblazer. As the first American basketball player to skip his senior year of high school to play professionally overseas, Tyler signed a $140,000 deal to play for Maccabi Haifa this year. The grand plan revolves around his being a top pick, if not the top pick, in the 2011 N.B.A. draft.

title: Looking Abroad for Health Savings
description: No matter what Congress does with health care legislation in the next few weeks, one thing is already clear: the result will not do much to control the climbing costs of medical care in the United States.

title: Malcolm Gladwell, Eclectic Detective
description: Have you ever wondered why there are so many kinds of mustard but only one kind of ketchup? Or what Czanne did before painting his first significant works in his 50s? Have you hungered for the story behind the Veg-O-Matic, star of the frenetic late-night TV ads? Or wanted to know where Led Zeppelin got the riff in Whole Lotta Love?

title: The Benefit of a Boot Out the Door
description: This interview with Jeffrey Katzenberg, chief executive of DreamWorks Animation SKG, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Well, at Least the Phone Works Fine
description: HELLO and welcome to home-appliance madness week with the Haggler.

title: Army Releases Names of All 13 Killed in Shootings
description: Michael G. Cahill spoke to soldiers all the time in his job as physicians assistant, taking their histories and listening to their stories. In the times when he met soldiers who were too unstable to walk to psychiatric services, Mr. Cahill would walk them there himself.

title: Letters: The Price to Pay for Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Citys JobsNow Program Also Benefits Newsom
description: Arik Levy was not expecting to benefit from the federal economic stimulus package  until one day last summer when a city worker stopped him on Mission Street in San Francisco and offered to give him some money.

title: After a Swim, Enough Energy to Entertain
description: Barbara Mulas, 49, is chef and part-owner of Sidebar, a gastropub, as she describes it, in the Lake Merritt section of Oakland. The San Francisco Bay Guardian recently named Sidebar the best new restaurant in the Bay Area. Ms. Mulas lives in Oakland with her husband, Mark Drazek, who is her longtime business partner as well as the restaurants pastry chef. (Her words have been edited and condensed.)

title: Community Continues to Grapple With Rape
description: As Richmond High School tried to absorb the wrenching reality of a gang rape of a student on school grounds, the predominant reactions  horror or sympathy or even fear  were understood by the schools principal, Julio Franco.

title: Rangel and Boehner Tangle Over Ethics and Abortion
description: One of the sharpest exchanges in the House floor debate so far took place between Representative Charles Rangel, Democrat of New York and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Representative John Boehner, Republican of Ohio and the House minority leader.

title: Jeremy Tylers Rocky Overseas Trip
description: Brandon Jennings has emerged as perhaps the best rookie in the early going of the N.B.A. season His transition to the league has been seemingly seamless, and hes created a buzz that hasnt been seen around basketball in Milwaukee in years.

title: After 8 Years, Work Starts at a Sept. 11 Site
description: SHANKSVILLE, Pa.  More than eight years after United Airlines Flight 93 crashed into a field here as passengers fought the terrorists at its controls, family members, friends and officials who have joined their cause returned to the site on Saturday to break ground on a permanent memorial to the victims.

title: The Archbishops Blog
description: LATE last month, Paul Vitello, who covers religion for The Times, wrote a lighthearted feature about a new blogger: Archbishop Timothy Dolan, installed this year to lead the 2.5 million Catholics of the Archdiocese of New York. Little did Vitello know that before the day was out, Dolan would turn his blog on the reporter and his paper, citing news articles and a column by Maureen Dowd as examples of anti-Catholicism.

title: A Torah Scribe Pushes the Parchment Ceiling
description: In Hebrew the word for Julie Seltzers arcane profession is soferet; shes a scribe, a Hebrew calligrapher who writes sacred texts on parchment. A mere handful of women do what she does, and an even more select handful are practiced in the especially ritualistic craft of writing particularly holy scrolls, including the Torah, considered the foundation of Jewish life and thought.

title: Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Report
description: Condoning Rape | The story of the gang rape in Richmond two weeks ago has two acts. First, the horrific crime itself. Second, the reaction of a group of students who are indifferent to the brutality or even blame the 16-year-old victim for the attack. Said one: She got drunk one time and messed with the wrong crowd and provoked some dude and got raped, thats it.

title: A Classic Ending to Zenyattas Perfect Season
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  Zenyatta is a headstrong girl, and a big one, too. So when she balked entering the starting gate here Saturday, a gasp rippled through the grandstand. As she was awaiting the start of the Breeders Cup Classic, against the best male horses in the world at a distance she had never run, did she suddenly not want to race?

title: Pelosi Expresses Confidence Health Bill Will Pass
description: House speaker Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, expressed confidence a short while ago that the health care legislation being debated on the floor would pass.

title: Harvards Victory Sets Up Ivy League Showdown Against Penn
description: Harvard Coach Tim Murphy says he is still looking forward to the day when he can pour himself a cup of coffee, saunter into the Crimsons locker room and tell his team it played a perfect game. Saturday was not exactly that day, but Harvard seems to be getting closer.

title: Paced by a 19-Year-Old Star, France Revives Its Reputation
description: In the 18th and 19th centuries, France was a center, if not the epicenter, of chess. Two of the greatest players of the era, Francois-Andre Danican Philidor and Louis-Charles Mah de La Bourdonnais, were French, and the Caf de la Rgence in Paris was a gathering place for anyone who liked to play the game, including Benjamin Franklin and Napoleon Bonaparte.

title: Little Evidence of Terror Plot in Base Killings
description: WASHINGTON  After two days of inquiry into the mass shooting at Fort Hood, investigators have tentatively concluded that it was not part of a terrorist plot.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a deadly attack in October at a United Nations guesthouse in Kabul, Afghanistan, misstated the number of Afghan suspects arrested by that day. It was six, not eight.

title: Alabama Gains Berth in the SEC Title Game
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  No. 3 Alabama remained unbeaten Saturday and did more than assure itself a berth in the Southeastern Conference championship game against No. 1 Florida. The Crimson Tide also escaped the grip of an offensive slump and, once again, looked like a legitimate national championship contender in a 24-15 victory over No. 9 Louisiana State.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in some editions last Sunday about Bold, Cautious, True: Walt Whitman and American Art of the Civil War Era, at the Katonah Museum of Art in Westchester County, misidentified the institution that loaned two paintings by Sanford Gifford to the museum. It is the New York State Military Museum and Veterans Research Center, not the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Equalitys Ragged March
description: Last Tuesdays Election Day results showed how far the nation has traveled in the struggle for gay equality  and the distance still to go. The returns also added fresh urgency to promising efforts in New York, New Jersey and the District of Columbia to legalize marriage for same-sex couples.

title: Quick, Patent It!
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments Monday in a case about what kind of inventions deserve patents. The businessmen who came up with a method for hedging financial risk in energy trading sued the Patent and Trademark Office after it denied them a patent.

title: Congresss OMG Over the P2P Leak
description: Members of Congress who may enjoy sharing music on the Internet without understanding the technology behind it all are learning the hard way about the potential dangers of peer-to-peer software.

title: Voting Equipment and the Way Elections Are Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Yales Innocent Mistakes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Battleship at Rest
description: To the Editor:

title: Hawaiis Education Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: The Night They Drove the Tea Partiers Down
description: FOR all cable newss efforts to inflate Election 2009 into a cliffhanger as riveting as Balloon Boy, ratings at MSNBC and CNN were flat Tuesday night. But not at Fox News, where the audience nearly doubled its usual prime-time average. Thats what happens when you have a thrilling story to tell, and what could be more thrilling than a revolution playing out in real time?

title: Chemicals in Our Food, and Bodies
description: Your body is probably home to a chemical called bisphenol A, or BPA. Its a synthetic estrogen that United States factories now use in everything from plastics to epoxies  to the tune of six pounds per American per year. Thats a lot of estrogen.

title: Back From War, but Not Really Home
description: Holderness, N.H.

title: The Savage Detective
description: CLAUDE LVI-STRAUSS, anthropologist, writer and adventurer, died just over a week ago at age 100. He died discreetly, which was as he had lived, though he was the most eminent and probably the last French philosopher.
