His ideas had as much influence on his contemporaries as the work of Jean-Paul Sartre and Albert Camus.

title: Damned Yankees
description: IT is hard to find a bigger admirer of President George W. Bush than me. I support his policies; I believe in him; hes a really good guy to be around; and he throws a mean fastball. As his press secretary, I stood by him through thick and thin. But recent events require me to speak out about my former boss: For eight long years, President Bush put a curse on my New York Yankees.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about the Long Island Latino International Film Festival misstated, using information from Rolando Sanchez, one of the participating directors, the year he saw the film Saving Private Ryan, which he credits with inspiring his interest in film. He saw the film in 1998, the year it was released, not 1996. The article also omitted the original source of a comment by Mr. Sanchez: I dont make movies for Latinos. I make films with Latinos in them. Mr. Sanchez said he was repeating the words of another director, Franc Reyes.

title: One Week After Defeating U.S.C., Oregon Falls to Stanford
description: STANFORD, Calif.  Stanford running back Toby Gerhart has the thick arms of a logger and they were covered with scratches and red welts Saturday after he toppled Oregon. Gerhart rushed for a team-record 223 yards and 3 touchdowns in the Cardinals 51-42 upset of the seventh-ranked Ducks.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in some editions last Sunday about an exhibition of works by Avital Oz at Art Sites in Riverhead, on Long Island, referred incorrectly to the artists birthplace. Mr. Oz was born in 1942 in what was then the British mandate of Palestine, not Israel. (The modern state of Israel did not exist until 1948.)

title: The Abortion Debate Flares Again
description: Updated: The House voted 240 to 194 in favor of a restrictive abortion amendment that signaled a shift in the political center on abortion rights. Opponents of the measure  including many Democratic female lawmakers  called it the most regressive provision on the issue of reproductive rights since the Henry Hyde amendment.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the marriage of Mona Kelly and David Lopez misidentified the city in Mexico where the couple held a religious ceremony on Oct. 24. The ceremony was in Playa del Carmen, not Cancn. And also because of an editing error, the headline erroneously stated that the brides given name is Monica.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Zac Goldsmith, a multimillionaire environmentalist and Conservative Party candidate for Parliament in Britain, referred incorrectly to his campaign finances. Over the last 30 months, Mr. Goldsmith has spent 248,000, or about $400,000; he has not raised 248,000 this year.

title: Is That a Plastic Bottle Youre Drinking From?
description: My Sunday column looks at chemicals that the government has been slow to regulate, even though they are suspected of pernicious effects on our bodies by disrupting the endocrine system. The results appear to range from malformed genitalia to premature puberty to obesity and diabetes. I focus on BPA, a chemical variant of estrogen that is often used in plastics and other consumer products. Two billion pounds are manufactured in the US each year  and as a result it is found in 92 percent of us. Its one of a number of endocrine disruptors that appear to have adverse effects on the bodys hormone system.

title: From the Arab Press: Coverage of the Fort Hood Killings
description: A look at discussions inside the Arab world, as played out in Arabic newspapers.

title: Lawmakers Detail Obamas Pitch
description: In an odd coincidence, the House debate on Saturday to overhaul health care took place on the third anniversary of the 2006 election that gave Democrats majority control after 12 years of Republican dominance. It fell to President Obama and to Congressional leaders to persuade those Democrats still sweating the final vote that it would not prove the partys undoing in next Novembers midterm elections.

title: Chargers at Giants: What to Watch
College Football Replay: Nov. 7
description: Helmets were lost, balls were fumbled and touchdowns were celebrated on Saturday in college football.

title: Lottery Numbers
G.O.P. Tries Tactic to Derail Bill
description: Update: Largely along party lines, a move that would have derailed the bill was defeated by a vote of 247 to 187.

title: Led by Rookie, Bucks Prolong Knicks Sluggish Start
description: MILWAUKEE  For Mike DAntoni, the early season seems a mirage. He has trouble telling whether the Knicks, after falling behind early, start to play better or if it is that their opponents simply relax. He does not know whether his younger players are earning minutes or if he is simply allotting them garbage time.

title: All Afghan War Options by Obama Aides Said to Call for More Troops
description: WASHINGTON  Advisers to President Obama are preparing three options for escalating the war effort in Afghanistan, all of them calling for more American troops, as he moves closer to a decision on the way forward in the eight-year-old war, officials said Saturday.

title: House Passes Health Bill
description: Squeaking just two votes past the required 218, House Democrats passed a major overhaul of health care after a marathon 14-hour day of floor debate. See this related article by Carl Hulse and Robert Pear, and find a complete roll call here.

title: Robert Rines, Inventor and Monster Hunter, Dies at 87
description: Dollars to doughnuts, Robert H. Rines will be mainly remembered not for holding more than 800 patents, starting a law school or writing music for the stage, but for his dogged pursuit of the Loch Ness monster.

title: Abortion Was at Heart of Wrangling
description: WASHINGTON  It was late Friday night and lawmakers were stalling for time. In a committee room, they yammered away, delaying a procedural vote on the historic health care legislation. Down one floor, in her office, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi desperately tried to deal with an issue that has bedeviled Democrats for more than a generation  abortion.

title: Alice S. Rossi, Sociologist and Feminist Scholar, Dies at 87
description: Alice S. Rossi, a noted sociologist and feminist scholar who was a founder of the National Organization for Women, died on Tuesday in Northampton, Mass. She was 87 and lived in Amherst, Mass.

title: Life in Black and White
description: A three-volume book and two gallery exhibitions explore the growth of the photographer Bruce Davidson.

title: To Make South Republican, Deny Blacks the Vote, Senator Says
description: Monday, Nov. 8, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Windfall Seen as Bank Bonuses Are Paid in Stock
description: Even as Washington tries to rein in Wall Street pay, bankers are likely to make unusually large gains on the stock grants and options they received after shares in their companies fell sharply during the financial meltdown, The New York Timess Louise Story reports.

title: Health Bill Earns One Republican Vote
description: House Democrats were thrilled by the passage of their major health care legislation, but perhaps no development on Saturday tickled them more than winning the vote of a single Republican: Representative Anh Joseph Cao of Louisiana.

title: Long Day on the Hill, Big Victory for Democrats
description: Legislation that would transform the nations health insurance system won approval by a slim margin in the House.

title: Foot Notes
description: Can dancers and dances be disentwined in order to preserve the work?

title: In Separate Episodes, 2 Are Shot by the Police
description: Police officers were involved in two shootings Friday, one of a 15-year-old boy the police said was brandishing a fake gun, the other of a man they said was trying to steal an officers car.

title: Why Jerry Jones Cant Be Like Steinbrenner
description: A Web roundup of the week. No weak links here

title: Celebrating the Virtues of Vice
description: PARIS | For its 15th birthday, Vice magazine, a free worldwide publication famous for its crude images of rowdy teens, is presenting a photo exhibition dedicated to underground culture and, well, vice.

title: Jets and Bucs: No Guarantees When Rebuilding on the Fly
description: Fans who are frustrated with the Jets fall from a 3-0 start to 4-4 should take a look at the mess in Tampa Bay.

title: House Democrats Who Voted Against the Health Care Bill
description: Detailed table profiling the 39 Democrats who voted against a sweeping overhaul of the nation's health care system.

title: Taylor Swift Plays It Safe on Saturday Night Live
description: When Kanye West injected himself into Taylor Swifts acceptance speech during the MTV Video Music Awards in September, it wasnt a fair fight  Ms. Swift was shocked, Mr. West belligerent.

title: Why Ahmadinejad Voted Against Occupying the U.S. Embassy in 1979
description: This week, as opposition supporters in Iran marked the 30th anniversary of the takeover of the United States Embassy in Tehran by protesting outside the active Russian Embassy instead of the abandoned American one, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad failed to mention that, as a student leader in 1979, he had voted against the plan to seize the U.S. compound and suggested taking the Soviet Embassy instead.

title: Jamie Gray | Design Daddy
description: Children may not be able to recognize good design, but according to Jamie Gray (photographed with his girlfriend, Olivia Sammons, and their children, Cy and Levi), they can recognize beauty. Gray, who owns the less-is-more New York design shop Matter, recalls once waking up at 5:30 a.m. to find the 3-year-old Levi gazing through the window of their Brooklyn apartment. Look at the sky, Papa, Levi exclaimed. Its beautiful. The first piece Gray ever built was a three-legged chair. His teacher told him it would never stand up. But I made it anyway, he said. And it worked! (Gray is seated in a Victor armchair by Paul Loebach.) His companys Web address, MatterMatters.com, speaks to the challenge of creating objects in a world thats already glutted with them. Thats the daily quandary: Do you create more? he asks. But, ultimately, if theres a want, somebody has to take responsibility for it. My intention is to create heirloom pieces that wont end up at the bottom of a landfill.

title: Questions as Disneys A Christmas Carol Tops the Box Office
description: An expensive, six-month marketing push helped Disneys A Christmas Carol open at No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, selling an estimated $31 million in tickets. But the result was weak for a movie that cost about $175 million to make (not including marketing costs), starred Jim Carrey in a cluster of roles, and was given one of the biggest releases yet on higher-priced 3-D screens. Did families decide it looked too dark? Did the motion-capture filmmaking style lessen interest? Or did a lot of moviegoers figure they would catch the holiday movie in the weeks ahead? Disney, which noted that the film, directed by Robert Zemeckis, made an additional $12 million in 18 foreign markets, hopes the latter.

title: N.H.L. Scores: Rangers Lose Game, and Drury and Dubinsky to Injury
description: Thirteen games on Saturday night, starting with a matinee in L.A. where the Kings, just four points off the Western Conference lead, hosted the faltering Predators.

title: The Early Word: Bill Passage, Cao and Next Steps
description: Late Saturday night the House passed a health care bill. The final vote, 220 to 215, was Democrats attempt to answer what President Obama described as the call of history and marked the culmination of months of inter-party and intra-party squabbling, town hall meetings and tea parties, and 14 hours of passionate Saturday floor debate.

title: China Pledges $10 Billion to Africa
description: BEIJING  China offered African governments a multibillion-dollar package of financial and technical assistance on Sunday, stepping up a courtship that already has gained Beijing wide access to oil and minerals across perhaps the most resource-rich continent in the world.

title: Army Chief Concerned for Muslim Troops
description: General George Casey Jr., the Army chief of staff, said on Sunday that he was concerned that speculation about the religious beliefs of Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, accused of killing 12 fellow soldiers and one civilian and wounding dozens of others in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood, could cause a backlash against some of our Muslim soldiers.

title: Top Three Remain the Same in A.P. Poll
description: While there was little movement at the top of the Associated Press Top 25 on Sunday, there were a few interesting developments at the bottom.

title: Pakistan Blast Kills Anti-Taliban Mayor
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A mayor who publicly opposed the Taliban was killed in a suicide bombing in a cattle market near the northern city of Peshawar on Sunday, officials said, in what appeared to be an attempt to curtail grass-roots opposition to the militant group.

title: Best Sustains Concussion After Scary Fall
description: Update | 10:23 p.m. By far, the scariest moment in college football on Saturday came when Californias Jahvid Best flipped in the air and slammed to the turf after scoring a touchdown against Oregon State. (The video of the play, which is jarring to watch, is below.)

title: The Wedding of Melissa Johnson and Tim Lagasse
description: Melissa Johnson and Tim Lagasse were married Oct. 30 at the Picnic House in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

title: Iraq Passes Crucial Election Law
description: BAGHDAD  After weeks of political stalemate, Iraq approved a law on Sunday to administer a critical national election in January, a significant milestone for its fragile democracy and a step that will allow the rapid withdrawal of American combat forces early next year.

title: Obamas Statement on House Health Bill
description: President Obama praised the House Sunday on its passage of a health care bill. Read the news article here.

title: Edison the Inventor Revisited
description: The laboratory complex at the Thomas Edison National Historical Park in West Orange reopened last month after a six-year renovation.

title: Why Would a Young Adult Get an Ulcer?
description: Last week on the Consults blog, Dr. Neena S. Abraham, a gastroenterologist at the Michael E. DeBakey V.A. Medical Center and associate professor of medicine at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, took readers questions about ulcers, a potentially life-threatening condition increasingly tied to Nsaid pain relievers. Here, Dr. Abraham responds to a 24-year-old reader who wondered how she could develop an ulcer when she only took Nsaids a couple days a month.

title: Live Analysis: Chargers Beat Giants, 21-20
description: New York Times writers Joe Lapointe and William C. Rhoden will provide in-game analysis of the Chargers-Giants game at Giants Stadium on Sunday.

title: Bugatti Veyron 16.4 Grand Sport
description: Only 150 Grand Sports will be built, tacked onto 300 editions of the Veyron coupe, making it the automotive equivalent of a Faberg egg.

title: Agassi Basks in His Own Spotlight
description: Andre Agassi often says in Open that tennis is a lonely game. But the writing of this autobiography was a team sport. Mr. Agassis memoir was put together by J. R. Moehringer, who wrote The Tender Bar, a shapely and expert memoir of his own. The same gift of gab that colored Mr. Moehringers tales of being a boy in a barroom now magically finds its way onto the tennis court and into Mr. Agassis much-analyzed, follicularly challenged head.

title: 2010 Mercedes-Benz S400 BlueHybrid
description: The S400 BlueHybrid overcomes the shortcomings of previous mild hybrid cars.

title: Obama Presses Senate to Pass Its Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The White House, growing concerned that the Congressional timetable for passing a health care overhaul could slip into next year, is stepping up pressure on the Senate for quick action, with President Obama appearing Sunday in the Rose Garden to call on senators to take up the baton and bring this effort to the finish line.

title: Refreshing Ruby Tuesday
description: When people start to dine out again, Sandy Beall wants them to find his chain, Ruby Tuesday, transformed.

title: Northrop to Sell Consulting Unit in $1.65 Billion L.B.O.
description: Northrop Grumman agreed on Sunday to sell its TASC government consulting unit to the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and General Atlantic for $1.65 billion in cash, in another sign that private equity firms are back to their core business of deal-making.

title: Block Party
description: Devoid as they are of nostalgia, kids wont really appreciate that the mustache included in the new wooden block set PlayShapes was inspired by Sgt. Pepper, nor that the toy has echoes of Alexander Girard, Enzo Mari and midcentury advertising illustrations. But what will please the little ones is that unlike that eras blocks, which mostly encouraged the dutiful construction of towns and landscapes, the strange contours of the 74 PlayShapes will let them build whatever animal, vegetable or psychedelic 60s pop star they please. We spent ages looking at old toys and seeing what had been done before, how we could make it new, says PlayShapes Brighton, U.K.-based co-creator Zoe Miller, who with her partner David Goodman also designs vintage-inspired kids toys and books for the Tate. For us it became about open-endedness, the fact that every child should feel that theyre an artist. $111; go to shhhop.com.

title: Patriots Have Answer to Dolphins Offensive Tricks
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  A year ago, the Miami Dolphins unveiled the Wildcat against New England, sending the confused Patriots reeling. Coach Bill Belichick, bemoaning how often the Dolphins had given the Patriots trouble in the past, predicted last week that the Patriots would see more offensive wrinkles from the Dolphins when the teams met Sunday.

title: New CDs
description: BON JOVI The Circle (Island)

title: Creation in the Face of Intriguing Biography
description: What more do you want from Christopher Owens, anyway? Maybe a bloodletting, or some other sort of physical purge? A detailed retelling of the sadder days of his childhood growing up in the Children of God cult? For the tragedy underpinning his gamely optimistic songs to take over, corroding them and making them, and him, tougher?

title: European Puck: Forsbergs Future Unclear After Swedens 7-0 Loss
description: It was a sobering ending for Sweden in its finale at the Karjala Cup tournament in Helsinki as it fell to Finland, 7-0  and Foppas comeback with the Tre Kronor wound up a floppa.

title: Out of the Nursery, Movements of Desire and Narcissism
description: SYRACUSE  Nothing about dance is more mysterious than the diversity of ways in which it can connect with music. Paul Taylors latest work is set to Debussys Childrens Corner. But its characters arent children, and its stage incidents have nothing to do with the nursery exercises and lessons that Debussy had in mind.

title: Nightingale and Garden With Hints of China
description: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestras contribution to Carnegie Halls Ancient Paths, Modern Voices festival, on Saturday evening, looked at Chinese-Western musical hybrids in which the Western influence was dominant, the Chinese largely incidental.

title: As Existential as Jaunty Old Pals Can Be
description: Monsters of Folk started playing before the curtain rose on Friday night at the United Palace, and they were playing when it came down nearly three hours later. They wore suits and ties like early-1960s folkies or a classic country band; their lighting was subdued and soft-focus, conveying vintage glamour in the gilded room. Yet within that theatrical haze the songs radiated sincerity, as the band members sang about seeking truth, purpose, faith or just reasons to go on. The songs were, mostly, about solitary quests, but they were delivered by a band of old pals.

title: T.C.U. Is Fourth in B.C.S. Standings
description: Texas Christian moved up two spots to fourth in the latest Bowl Championship Series standings, released Sunday. Florida, Alabama and Texas remained the top three teams. The Crimson Tide and the Longhorns switched places for the second straight week.

title: A Good Effort, but Hardly Worth the Payoff
description: We have all heard of a Pyrrhic victory. My dictionary says that the expression derives from Pyrrhuss statement after defeating the Romans in the third century B.C.: Another such victory and we are lost.

title: An Ethical Question: Does a Nazi Deserve a Place Among Philosophers?
description: For decades the German philosopher Martin Heidegger has been the subject of passionate debate. His critique of Western thought and technology has penetrated deeply into architecture, psychology and literary theory and inspired some of the most influential intellectual movements of the 20th century. Yet he was also a fervent Nazi.

title: Mowing Down Bar Lines in Virtuosic Banter
description: Vijay Iyers trio lights up through improvised, viruslike rhythms. Its not a situation in which the drummers steady swing underpins whatever the pianist is doing; that did happen sometimes at the Jazz Standard on Friday, but it wasnt where the action was.

title: Indian Leader Forecasts Growth
description: NEW DELHI  Prime Minister Manmohan Singh pledged on Sunday to spend more on health care and education and make it easier for foreign investors to take part in Indias $1.2 trillion economy.

title: Gridiron Gladiators: Block That Metaphor!
description: Its too bad Bob Hope isnt part of the Fox NFL Sunday crew. He might have been able to do something with the odd incongruity of Sundays program, broadcast from Bagram Air Field in Afghanistan: a show glorifying fake warriors and their game, playing to a crowd of real warriors locked in an eight-year-old conflict.

title: Reborn: Neglected Work and City Opera
description: With the New York City Operas production of Hugo Weisgalls Esther, which opened on Saturday night at the David H. Koch Theater, this essential company, teetering on the brink of extinction not long ago, announced it was back. Not just up and running, but exuding purpose and confidence.

title: Go in Without a Suit
description: Its me, Jim Horne, back for another week. I confess Im a little worried about todays constructor. Lynn Lempel, anything we can do to cheer you up? Six weeks ago (Across Lite, Solution), you gave us TURKEY, DUD, BOMB, FLOP and BUST. Today, its literally another downer with five long answers that all lose altitude.

title: World War I, Online
description: Oxford University will open its first online collection of Siegfried Sassoons manuscripts on Wednesday, Armistice Day, the universitys press office has announced. The manuscripts of Sassoon, right, whose writing was transformed by his experiences in World War I, will help complete Oxfords First World War Poetry Digital Archive, www.oucs.ox.ac.uk/ww1lit/, begun last year and including the work of Wilfred Owen, Isaac Rosenberg and Vera Brittain. Technology has enabled us to virtually reassemble Sassoons manuscripts, which for years have been dispersed across the United Kingdom and United States, Stuart Lee, director of the archive, said. It is fascinating being able to see the corrections and crossings-out he made to the manuscripts, invaluable to researchers studying the literature of the war. The poetry archive was opened in conjunction with the Great War Archive, a digitization project involving World War I material collected from the public.

title: A Soft No. 1 for Disneys a Christmas Carol
description: An expensive six-month marketing push helped Disneys A Christmas Carol open at No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, selling an estimated $31 million in tickets, according to the Web site Hollywood.com, which tracks box-office results. But the result was considered weak for a movie that cost about $175 million (not including marketing costs); starred Jim Carrey as Scrooge, right, and other roles; and received one of the biggest releases yet on higher-priced 3-D screens. Did families decide it looked too dark? Did the motion-capture filmmaking style lessen interest? Or did many people figure they would catch the holiday movie in the weeks ahead? Disney, which noted that the film, directed by Robert Zemeckis, made an additional $12 million in 18 foreign markets, hopes it will do better as the holidays approach. The Michael Jackson concert documentary, This Is It (Sony), held up well in its second week, placing second with about $14 million for a new total of $58 million. The Men Who Stare at Goats, a comedy from Overture Films starring George Clooney and Jeff Bridges, was third with about $13 million. Two horror movies rounded out the Top 5: The Fourth Kind (Universal) earned about $12.5 million while Paranormal Activity (Paramount) drew about $9 million (for about $97 million so far). Also of note, Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire, the Lee Daniels film about an abused teenager in Harlem, grossed $1.8 million from just 18 theaters.

title: Morgan Freeman Settles in Mississippi Car Crash
description: Morgan Freeman, below, has reached an out-of-court settlement with his passenger over a lawsuit revolving around an August 2008 single-car crash, Reuters reported. Mr. Freeman was driving Demaris Meyer to his home near Charleston, Miss., when the car, a 1997 Nissan Maxima owned by Ms. Meyer, swerved off the road and flipped several times. Mr. Freeman was taken to the hospital, and Ms. Meyer later sued, accusing him of failure to operate a car properly. A spokesman for Mr. Freeman said no further details on the settlement would be given, and court records were not made public, Reuters reported, but Ms. Meyers lawyer said she was pleased that the matter is resolved and the case is settled. At the time of the accident, Sgt. Ben Williams, a Mississippi Highway Patrol spokesman, said there was no indication that alcohol or drugs contributed to the crash.

title: Michael Jacksons Father Asks for Allowance
description: In a motion filed in a Los Angeles court on Friday, Joe Jackson, below, the father of Michael Jackson, argued that the administrators of his sons estate should set up a monthly allowance for him, similar to the one established for the singers mother, Katherine Jackson, The Los Angeles Times reported. Mr. Jackson, 80, said that his son helped him with living expenses for years. Mr. Jackson suggested that a stipend should cover his estimated budget of $15,000 a month. Howard Weitzman, a lawyer for the estates administrators, John Branca and John McClain, told The Los Angeles Times: It was quite surprising to learn of the request. Mr. Jacksons petition will be considered, as are all requests for money from Michaels estate. The judge denied Mr. Jacksons request for an immediate hearing. The estate gives Katherine Jackson $26,000 a month.

title: In the Wings
description: Shakespeare on the Sound in Norwalk, Conn., announced that its summer 2010 production would be Othello. As with its staging this year of A Midsummer Nights Dream, the play will be directed by Joanna Settle and feature music and songs by Stew. ... The original Off Broadway cast of Next Fall will return when it moves to Broadway next year. The Geoffrey Nauffts play, about gay lovers with differing views on faith and love, will feature Patrick Breen, Maddie Corman, Sean Dugan, Patrick Heusinger, Connie Ray and Cotter Smith. It begins previews at the Helen Hayes Theater on Feb. 16 and opens on March 11. ... The Classic Stage Company has announced the lineup for its First Look Festival, which runs Nov. 16 to 30 and will feature the work of Luigi Pirandello. First up is Six Characters in Search of an Author, directed by Tony Speciale; next will be Right You Are if You Think So, directed by Craig Baldwin; and finally John Turturro will appear in Henry IV, directed by Brian Kulick. Details are at classicstage.org.

title: Footnotes
description: After canceling performances because of an illness caused by E. coli and influenza, Elton John has left the London hospital where he was recuperating, Reuters reported. His spokesman, Gary Farrow, said he planned to return to the stage with his tour partner, Billy Joel, on Saturday. ... Las Vegas is losing a star. Reuters reported that Bette Midler was ending her Caesars Palace production, The Showgirl Must Go On, after nearly 200 performances. The last show will be on Jan. 31.

title: Honolulu Symphony Cancels Concert Calendar
description: The 109-year-old Honolulu Symphony announced on Friday that it would cancel this years remaining concerts and file for bankruptcy protection, The Associated Press reported. Though ticket sales had been holding steady this year, they accounted for only 30 percent of the symphonys annual budget, and reduced donor contributions have left the company with almost $1 million in debt. In May 2008 the symphony was revived after receiving $1 million from an anonymous donor that covered back pay owed to musicians. And earlier this year $2.1 million was taken from the endowment as an advance. But on Oct. 30 the board of directors voted to file for protection under Chapter 11, and papers will be submitted to court next week. We made payroll, even in this economy, through October, said Peter Shaindlin, the boards chairman. But cash ran out and dried up. The symphony hopes to resume operations early next year, said a spokeswoman, Kristin Jackson, though perhaps, because of salary costs, not with all 64 musicians.

title: Musicians Who Poked at the Iron Curtain
description: Guitars, keyboards and drums did not topple the Berlin Wall. But for the young people who helped bring down Communist regimes across Eastern Europe in the fall of 1989, pop music was a profoundly subversive force, inspiration and vital tool of protest for challenging and undermining a totalitarian state stricter than any parent.

title: Nancy Pelosi delivers
description: Do you remember how, earlier this year, there were lots of stories about how hopeless Nancy Pelosi was as Speakere, how everything was going to be a failure, etc., etc.? Heres an example.

title: News of Hockey, 11/8/09: Another Resignation From the N.H.L.P.A.
description: Yet another official has resigned from the troubled N.H.L. Players Association, the union announces on Sunday. Interim ombudsman Buzz Hargrove informed the players association earlier on Sunday that he was stepping down from the position.

title: At 91, Mandela Endures as South Africas Ideal
description: JOHANNESBURG  The icon is a very old man now. His hair is white, his body frail. Visitors say Nelson Mandela leans heavily on a cane when he walks into his study. He slips off his shoes, lowers himself into a stiff-backed chair and lifts each leg onto a cushioned stool. His wife, Graa, adjusts his feet so theyre symmetrical, and gives him a peck, says George Bizos, his old friend and lawyer.

title: Refining the Twitter Explosion
description: DOES Twitter have a T.M.I. problem?

title: Economists Seek to Fix a Defect in Data That Overstates the Nations Vigor
description: WASHINGTON  A widening gap between data and reality is distorting the governments picture of the countrys economic health, overstating growth and productivity in ways that could affect the political debate on issues like trade, wages and job creation.

title: Sending a Message, Again and Again
description: The number of text messages transmitted in the United States grew by more than 80 percent over the 12 months ended in June, according to a report just released by CTIA, a communications industry group. That figure measures the number of messages sent or received, so a message sent from one person to another would count twice.

title: News Erupts, and So Does a Web Debut
description: On Thursday afternoon, when word came about the shootings that left 13 people dead at Fort Hood, just up the road from Austin, it seemed like a made-to-order test for The Texas Tribune, a brand new 12-person Web-based newsroom.

title: Young Offenders Locked Up for Life
description: Updated, Nov. 9, 5:15 p.m. |  Round 3: Kent Scheidegger and Marc Mauer on what the Supreme Court justices asked and what that might reveal.

title: Pac-10 Possibilities
description: With Oregons loss to Stanford on Saturday, the race in the topsy-turvy Pacific-10 will be one to watch over the final month of the season.

title: Technology in daily life
description: One theme Ive noticed in comments on my various posts on growth is the suggestion that the difference between more recent growth and growth in the postwar generation is that modern times have given us all these great things like cell phones and the Internet, which didnt happen in the past.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,349 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 903 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Sunday:

title: Obama Calls House Vote 'Courageous'
description: President Obama said the health care bill's passage in the House "was a courageous vote" and called upon the Senate to "take the baton and bring this effort to the finish line." (Video: MSNBC)

title: A Movies Budget Pops From the Screen
description: LOS ANGELES  Can a movie studio make money on a film based on an original and unfamiliar story, with no Hollywood superstars, a vanishing DVD market and a price tag approaching $500 million?

title: Bill Would Limit Needle Exchanges
description: BANGOR, Me.  For years, the location of this citys needle exchange program, in a nondescript strip mall close to highways and bus lines, was seen as a major asset.

title: Saudis Claim to Beat Back Yemeni Rebels in Border Area
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi Arabia said over the weekend that it had regained control of a border area seized by Yemeni rebels last week, and that it had halted its military campaign there.

title: Fate of Same-Sex Marriage Bill in Albany Unclear
description: After a major setback in Maine last week, gay rights advocates and their opponents are shifting their focus to New York, where Gov. David A. Paterson has called legislators to Albany on Tuesday and asked them to pass a bill legalizing same-sex marriage.

title: 24 Hour Plays: Pre-Gaming
description: The celebrity quotient is already pretty high on Broadway (Jude Law, Hugh Jackman, Daniel Craig, Sienna Miller, everyone in God of Carnage) but it is about to spike. The annual 24 Hour Plays event will take place Monday night at the American Airlines Theater, and the cast is especially luminous this year: Ashton Kutcher, Demi Moore, Jennifer Aniston and Julia Stiles are among the actors lined up to participate. Presented by Montblanc, the event this is the ninth  will once again benefit the nonprofit Urban Arts Partnership, which provides arts in education programs to public school students in New York City.

title: A Stratocaster for Max, and Other Mad Men Stories
description: PHOENIX

title: F1 Season Review, and a Mosley Coincidence
description: Just had a few reasons for wanting to link to my F1 season review story. One is just to spread the news onto the blog  ie, alert you. The other is because I wanted to draw attention to the great quote contribution in the story from a frequent and enthusiastic reader and participant in the blog, Toof Brown, whose quote is the first in the story, and I thought it was very pertinent. And the third reason for drawing attention to the story in the weekend edition of the International Herald Tribune was for the WONDERFULLY odd and serendipitous event that meant that while my season review story mentions the Max Mosley sex scandal of last year and his subsequent battle with a British newspaper  the whole idea there were Nazi role playing connotations etc.  well, on page two of the print version of the same paper in which my story appeared was also a little piece from the same newspaper 75 years ago, in which a certain Oswald Mosley, Maxs father, won a case against another British newspaper in a libel case, in the second item of the story. Wonderful how these things happen sometimes. Not so often seen in the new media, I think.

title: Zenyatta Shines Brightest in Sparkling Breeders Cup
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  What was there not to like about this edition of the Breeders Cup World Championships? The San Gabriel Mountains, haloed in rouge, were a perfect backdrop for the majesty of thoroughbred racing. Every horse came home safely, and the headlines belonged deservedly to a remarkable mare named Zenyatta, who in what might have been the last race of an undefeated career emphatically turned back some of the best male horses in the world in Saturdays Classic.

title: Louisiana Republican Breaks Ranks on Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  House Democrats were thrilled by the passage of their major health care legislation on Saturday, but were particularly tickled by denying Republicans a solid wall of opposition with the solitary vote of Representative Anh Cao of Louisiana.

title: An Oasis Is No Match for Bulldozers and Bureaucrats
description: MOSCOW  In the 1950s, the Soviet government set aside a bit of land on the Moscow River for Maria I. Gurlyninas family and several dozen others to grow food. It was a barren plot, nothing but sand and swamp, Ms. Gurlynina said. But it was theirs.

title: A Magazines Scoop Is Scooped by Its Reporter
description: When it was revealed that in a forthcoming autobiography, Andre Agassi would admit to using crystal meth, it caused a predictable stir in the space where sports and celebrity gossip intersect. It also caused commotions at Time Inc. and CBS News.

title: Lessons From the War Over Skype
description: From Brad Stone at Bits:

title: The Losing Streak Goes On, After All
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In his final moment on the field Sunday at Giants Stadium, San Diego quarterback Philip Rivers fired a dart through the heart of the Giants defense and maybe their hopes for the season.

title: The Legacy of 1989 Is Still Up for Debate
description: PARIS  The historical legacy of 1989, when the Berlin Wall fell and the cold war thawed, is as political as the upheavals of that decisive year.

title: Confusion on Where Money Lent via Kiva Goes
description: Last month, David Roodman, a research fellow at the Center for Global Development, pressed a button on his laptop as his bus left the Lincoln Tunnel in Manhattan and started a debate that has people re-examining the countrys latest celebrated charity, Kiva.org.

title: If Anything, the Senates Task Is Trickier
description: Dont tell the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, but that was supposed to be the easy part.

title: Anthony Flourishes, and So Do Nuggets
description: Carmelo Anthony wanted the personal accolades. To be selfish, though, he had to be less selfish. For much of his first six N.B.A. seasons, Anthony settled on the wrong side of great. Great scorer, not a great player. Great shooter, not a gracious passer. Great athlete, not a good defender.

title: After a Bosss Fraud, Training for a New Job and Holding on to Hope
description: Few may recall the spectacular downfall of Marc S. Dreier, the prominent Manhattan lawyer who pleaded guilty to running an elaborate fraud scheme, because his house of cards fell just days before Bernard L. Madoffs did.

title: A Netflix Model for Haute Couture
description: For many women, a $1,000 dress is something they admire in the pages of a glossy magazine or see draped on the frame of a celebrity  not an item hanging in their closet.

title: For Kelly, a Chance to Add to His Legacy
description: On a busy Sunday before Election Day, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg crisscrossed the city, even taking a hovercraft to board the U.S.S. New York. But perhaps the most visible vehicle used by the mayor that day was an old convertible, in which he greeted the crowds watching the New York City Marathon, sitting alongside his police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly.

title: A Short-Lived Partnership Helped Leetch Seal a Legacy
description: When Brian Leetch is inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame on Monday night, he will be celebrated for his many achievements as a Rangers defenseman and as a keystone player on what may have been the best United States national team ever assembled.

description: Wells Fargos

title: In Resilient Neighborhood, Morale Tumbles After Fire
description: A tilted plywood wall wraps around the northwest corner of Bainbridge Avenue and East 204th Street, where the air smells of smoke and the sidewalk glistens from broken glass. The wall tries to hide the ghastly sight of 10 storefronts burned to sooty brick and skeletal girders. But it only reminds all who pass of a local tragedy.

title: Medical Industry Grumbles, but It Stands to Gain
description: For any industry, there has to be at least some good news any time Congress votes to expand the market by tens of millions of customers.

description: When Bill Snyder was hired for a second stint as coach of Kansas State last year, the move was widely viewed as an act of desperation.

description: As a child, Kim Eun Mi Young hated being different.

description: A funny thing happened to the Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, on his way to the stars.

description: For years, college footballs commissioners and presidents have clung to their standard line about why the sport would not institute a postseason playoff model.

title: Drummer Dies After Fall in Elevator Shaft
description: Gerhardt Fuchs grew up playing the drums in Georgia and went on to perform with bands that toured across the country, but it was in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that he forged his reputation as a dynamic, driving drummer widely esteemed by his peers.

description: For magazines, it was a good year to be mass market.

description: Dont be surprised if the doctors on House say Doh! or the investigators on Fringe rename themselves Homer and Marge this week.

title: Firefighters Cite Error in Dispatch of Fatal Fire
description: The firehouse at Queens Boulevard and 65th Street was only a few blocks from a fatal fire that erupted early Saturday, killing three people.

title: Northrop Agrees to Sell TASC Consulting Unit
description: Northrop Grumman agreed on Sunday to sell its TASC government consulting unit to the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and General Atlantic for $1.65 billion in cash, in another sign that private equity firms are back to their core business of deal-making.

title: Inspired by Obama, Navy Quarterbacks Sights Are Set on 2040
description: Ricky Dobbs would walk up to classmates he did not know at Douglas County High School in Douglasville, Ga., and playfully scratch their backs. He wanted to be everybodys friend. Even with the students others ignored, he tried to get them out of their shells and make them feel comfortable.

title: New York Clinics See Few Crowds for Free Vaccine
description: Perhaps it was fear of crowds that kept the crowds away on Sunday from the clinics offering free swine flu vaccinations to schoolchildren. Or, maybe, as some of the few who did show up suggested, the small numbers could be attributed to wariness about the new vaccine or a lack of knowledge about the clinics.

title: Kramnik Surges Ahead at Tal Memorial
Intense Review Is Expected for NBC Deal
description: The Center for Digital Democracy, a public interest group, has already called the potential union of Comcast and NBC Universal the equivalent of Godzilla swallowing Rockefeller Center.

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Sober Mood at New York Post as Circulation Spirals Lower
description: Three years ago, Col Allan, the editor of The New York Post, pumped his fist and waded into a cheering crowd at a Midtown restaurant, celebrating The Posts overtaking its rival, The Daily News, in weekday circulation. The Post trumpeted the news on a Times Square billboard and in its pages.

title: Lottery Numbers
Samuel Heyman, a Corporate Raider, Dies at 70
description: Samuel J. Heyman, who stood out as a corporate raider who preferred to hold on to companies he bought and run them rather that sell them for a quick profit, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70.

title: Finians Children
description: Days can be hectic for the youngsters in the revival of the musical "Finian's Rainbow," another in a growing list of Broadway shows featuring child actors.

title: Iran Said to Ignore Effort to Salvage Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, attempting to salvage a faltering nuclear deal with Iran, has told Irans leaders in back-channel messages that it is willing to allow the country to send its stockpile of enriched uranium to any of several nations, including Turkey, for temporary safekeeping, according to administration officials and diplomats involved in the exchanges.

title: Complications Grow for Muslims Serving in U.S. Military
description: Abdi Akgun joined the Marines in August of 2000, fresh out of high school and eager to serve his country. As a Muslim, the attacks of Sept. 11 only steeled his resolve to fight terrorism.

title: Fort Hood Gunman Gave Signals Before His Rampage
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  It was still dark on Thursday when Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan left his aging apartment complex to attend 6 a.m. prayers at the brick mosque near Fort Hood. Afterward, he said goodbye to his friends there and asked forgiveness from one man for any past offenses.

title: Alleys of Wealth
description: A visit to Wall Street gets you a glimpse of high finance, encounters historic locations, and opportunities to sit down to a power lunch.

title: Which Way Will Wind Power Blow?
description: To the Editor:

title: Week 9 in Quotations: Nothing Beats That Winning Feeling
description: His age really doesnt matter at this point.  Buccaneers Coach Raheem Morris, after giving the 21-year-old rookie Josh Freeman his first start. Freeman led Tampa Bay to its first win of the season.

title: All They Need Is Love (and Freedom and Theater)
description: Luminaries of 17th-century England are resurrected and made to do the frug in Or, a playful, funny and inventive comedy by Liz Duffy Adams now playing at the Julia Miles Theater. The fruging is figurative, obviously. The pioneering female writer Aphra Behn, the celebrated actress Nell Gwynne and the king, Charles II, do not actually cavort in miniskirts, fringed vests and beads, making like Austin Powers and friends in this frisky historical romp produced by the Womens Project.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Africas diamond trade misstated the year that Venezuela suspended itself from the Kimberley Process, an international undertaking to halt trading in so-called blood diamonds. It was 2008, not 2004.

title: Corrections

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review on Oct. 14, about The War That Killed Achilles: The True Story of Homers Iliad and the Trojan War, by Caroline Alexander, referred incompletely to the translation of The Iliad used in the book. While most of it is Richmond Lattimores version, the book also includes translation by Ms. Alexander.

title: For Abortion Foes, a Victory in Health Care Vote
description: WASHINGTON  A restriction on abortion coverage, added late Saturday to the health care bill passed by the House, has energized abortion opponents with their biggest victory in years  emboldening them for a pitched battle in the Senate.

title: N.H.L. Scores: Oilers Prove Anderson Mortal in Win Over Avs
description: The Avs entered Sunday nights contest in Denver vs. the Oilers with an undefeated home record: five regulation victories and one shootout win. And they had October goalie of the month Craig Anderson in the nets, facing an Edmonton team that scored just eight times in their previous six games. For Colorado, it seemed like easy pickings. Home teams listed first:

title: Giants Lose Fourth Straight
description: The Chargers rallied to score the winning touchdown with 21 seconds to play.

title: Mouse Grounds Plane at Kennedy
description: A Delta Air Lines flight at Kennedy International Airport bound for London Heathrow Airport was delayed and the passengers were switched to another plane Sunday night after someone reported seeing an onboard intruder: a mouse in the cabin.

title: No Clear Map for Democrats on Path to New Energy Plan
description: On health care, President Obama and fellow Democrats face a straightforward calculus: sign an overhaul bill into law or suffer grave political damage.

title: No Clear Map for Democrats on Path to New Energy Plan
description: On health care, President Obama and fellow Democrats face a straightforward calculus: sign an overhaul bill into law or suffer grave political damage.

title: Imprisoning a Child for Life
description: The United States could be the only nation in the world where a 13-year-old child can be sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole, even for crimes that do not include murder. This grim distinction should trouble Americans deeply, as should all of the barbaric sentencing policies for children that this country embraces but that most of the world has abandoned.

title: Massenets Herodiade in a Brilliant New York Premire
description: Tuesday, Nov. 9, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Albany and the Budget
description: Gov. David Paterson of New York has commanded the Legislature to return on Tuesday. Fixing the budget must be their top priority. The state is in a fiscal crisis. There is no other word for it.

title: Rody Alvarados Odyssey
description: After 14 years, Rody Alvarado finally has the full support of the United States government in her struggle to find safe haven here. She fled Guatemala in 1995 after enduring years of horrific beatings and sexual abuse by her husband. Though the facts of her suffering were not disputed, her case took a tortuous route through immigration courts, where the question of asylum for battered women has long been muddled by controversy, indecision and inaction.

title: Last Act for the Bluefin
description: The international commission that sets fishing limits for tuna and other large migratory fish is meeting in Brazil. The commission faces a depressing reality: the bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean is headed toward commercial extinction.

title: At the Scene of the Shooting
description: Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan is accused of killing 13 people and wounding dozens Thursday in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood. Here is what is known so far about the events, according to accounts of base officials and witnesses.

title: Paranoia Strikes Deep
description: Last Thursday there was a rally outside the U.S. Capitol to protest pending health care legislation, featuring the kinds of things weve grown accustomed to, including large signs showing piles of bodies at Dachau with the caption National Socialist Healthcare. It was grotesque  and it was also ominous. For what we may be seeing is America starting to be Californiafied.

title: Life After the End of History
description: For most of the last century, the West faced real enemies: totalitarian, aggressive, armed to the teeth. Between 1918 and 1989, it was possible to believe that liberal democracy was a parenthesis in history, destined to be undone by revolution, ground under by jackboots, or burned like chaff in the fire of the atom bomb.

title: Thanksgiving Dinner With Coughlin and Snee
description: A reader, Chris, wrote in the comments section:

title: 20 Years of Collapse
description: TODAY is the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall. During this time of reflection, it is common to emphasize the miraculous nature of the events that began that day: a dream seemed to come true, the Communist regimes collapsed like a house of cards, and the world suddenly changed in ways that had been inconceivable only a few months earlier. Who in Poland could ever have imagined free elections with Lech Walesa as president?

title: Word of the Day | sluice
description: sluice  \sls\  noun and verb

title: Krafts Hostile Bid for Cadbury Expected
description: Kraft is expected to make a hostile bid for the British confectioner Cadbury on Monday, making official its attempt to create an international food giant after more than two months of posturing, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: A Magazine Promises Ads Will Register
description: The Week magazine is making a new guarantee to advertisers: that its readers will remember an ad in its pages more than ads in most competitive magazines.

title: The Timidity of Coughlin and Reid
description: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin and Eagles Coach Andy Reid left themselves open for second-guessing after settling for field goals late in their respective losses Sunday.

description: Lev L. Dassin, a former top federal prosecutor in Manhattan whose office won the conviction of Bernard L. Madoff for his huge Ponzi scheme, resulting in a 150-year sentence, is joining the New York office of the international law firm Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton.

description: Samuel J. Heyman, who stood out as a corporate raider who preferred to hold on to companies he bought and run them rather that sell them for a quick profit, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70.

title: J. Nicholas Counter III, Labor Lawyer, Dies at 69
description: LOS ANGELES  J. Nicholas Counter III, a lawyer who changed the face of labor relations in Hollywood during his long tenure as chief negotiator for hundreds of film and television companies, died on Friday after collapsing earlier at his home in the Bell Canyon community in Ventura County, California.

title: News Quiz | November 9, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Madoffs Prosecutor Is Joining Cleary Firm
description: Lev L. Dassin, a former top federal prosecutor in Manhattan whose office won the conviction of Bernard L. Madoff for his huge Ponzi scheme, resulting in a 150-year sentence, is joining the New York office of the international law firm Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton, Benjamin Weiser writes in The New York Times.

title: Intense Review Is Expected for Possible NBC Deal
description: The Center for Digital Democracy, a public interest group, has already called the potential union of Comcast and NBC Universal the equivalent of Godzilla swallowing Rockefeller Center.

title: Dance on Film
description: Dance movie fans are probably doing a pas de deux right now: two stellar examples of the genre are in theaters. A favorite of Martin Scorsese, the restored version of the classic Red Shoes has been the inspiration for countless bleeding feet and soaring artistic passions, writes Manohla Dargis, who calls it essential viewing. And the documentary La Danse: the Paris Opera Ballet, from the veteran vrit director Frederick Wiseman, is one of the finest dance films ever made, A.O. Scott writes  worthwhile even if you dont know a pli from a tutu. The substance of Mr. Wisemans particular genius is the way it transfixes you with the inner workings of an institution you may not otherwise care about.

title: Dare to Underachieve
description: Released just over a decade ago, Benjamin Anastass debut novel, An Underachievers Diary, about the lesser of a pair of twin boys, was a sort of precursor to the smart, funny slacker-hipsters of today. (See: Jonathan Ames and his alter-ego Jason Schwartzman in Bored to Death.) Now that its been reissued in paperback, Mr. Anastas, also a journalist, gets to overachieve in lit form. He reads from it tonight at the Half-King.

title: How to Rescue Wells Fargo From the Rescue?
description: John G. Stumpf, the chief executive of Wells Fargo, objected vocally to the federal injection of rescue funds into banks, saying taxpayers were benefiting at Wells Fargos expense. A year on, the government still owns $25 billion of Wells preferred stock. The banks boss has cooled his rhetoric, but still wants to pay back the Treasurys Troubled Asset Relief Program investment shortly. He also wants to avoid damage to his shareholders. Reconciling the two objectives is not easy, Breakingviews.com says.

title: Hedge Fund Hot Streak Cools in October
description: Hedge funds on average posted light losses in October, ending a seven-month winning streak, Reuters reported, citing new data.

title: AXA Asia-Pacific Rejects $10.2 Billion Breakup Plan
description: AXA Asia Pacific, the Australian unit of the French insurance giant AXA, rejected an unsolicited $10.2 billion takeover bid Monday that was led by its parent, a deal that could be one of the biggest in the financial services sector this year.

title: Krafts Hostile Bid for Cadbury Expected
description: Update | 8:59 a.m. Kraft made an official 9.8 billion ($16.3 billion) bid for Cadbury, setting up a potentially bruising fight for control of the British confectioner. Cadbury quickly rejected the offer.

title: Thread Counts | Comment of the Week
description: Every week we comb through the comments on The Moment, Facebook and our Twitter @replies to bring you something clever from readers.

title: Taiwan Firm Positioned for E-Reader Takeoff
description: With the market for electronic book readers set to take off, things are looking up for a little-known Taiwanese company that will probably supply most of the e-paper they use, The New York Timess Jonathan Adams writes.

title: Red Sox Owner Cuts Staff at His Hedge Fund
description: John Henry, the principal owner of the Boston Red Sox, has fired more than a quarter of the staff at his hedge fund firm in Boca Raton, Fla., a result of declining assets and the current market environment, a spokesman told The Boston Globe.

title: Executives Are Wary After Arrests
description: Switchboards at law firms have been lighting up in recent weeks as hedge fund managers and technology executives deluge lawyers with one question: What information is safe to share, in case the feds are listening?

title: With Avatar, Fox Works to Hedge Its Bet
description: Can a movie studio make money on a film based on an original and unfamiliar story, with no Hollywood superstars, a vanishing DVD market and a price tag approaching $500 million?

title: Buyout Shops Said to Bid for AXAs Taikang Stake
description: Foreign and domestic private equity firms have made offers for AXAs 15.6 percent holding in the Chinese insurer Taikang Life, valuing the stake at more than $1 billion, Reuters reported.

title: Sonova in Deal to Buy Advanced Bionics
description: Sonova Holding, a Swiss maker of hearing aids, said Monday that it had reached a deal to buy Advanced Bionics, an American developer of inner-ear implant devices, for $489 million in cash, The Associated Press said.

title: Can a Boy Wear a Skirt to School?
description: This question is the headline of an article by Jan Hoffman about how a growing number of teenagers have been dressing to articulate  or confound  gender identity and sexual orientation. Should schools prohibit kids from dressing like the opposite sex? Do you think kids today are less bound by rules about what boys should wear and what girls should wear?In Can a Boy Wear a Skirt to School? Jan Hoffman writes:

title: Blankfein Says Hes Just Doing Gods Work
description: The chief executive of Goldman Sachs, which has attracted widespread media attention over the size of its staff bonuses, says he believes banks serve a social purpose and are doing Gods work.

title: Haute Couture, Available Through Netflix Model
description: For many women, a $1,000 dress is something they admire in the pages of a glossy magazine or see draped on the frame of a celebrity  not an item hanging in their closet.

title: Sprint Plans to Spend $1 Billion More on Clearwire
description: Sprint Nextel is preparing to pump at least $1 billion more into Clearwire, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

title: In Madrid, a Season of Setting Suns
description: Anyone who thinks that the churning clouds and dramatically colored skies of an El Greco masterpiece like View of Toledo might be a bit of artistic conceit has likely never been to Madrid in autumn. During these months the late afternoon skies can blaze astonishingly bright with vivid colors and cinematic effects.

title: Gender Bias Bingo
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Giants Open Thread: No Game This Week, but Plenty of Questions
description: Ernie Palladino has been a Giants beat writer since 1989 and is the only fully credentialed independent blogger covering them. He writes about the team at erniepalladinosgiantsbeat.blogspot.com.

title: Wall Street Banks Wary of Rusal I.P.O., Report Says
description: Wall Street firms are reportedly in a quandary about getting involved with a planned public offering of United Company Rusal of Russia, the worlds largest aluminum producer, because its founder has been barred from obtaining a United States visa because of allegations that he is connected to organized crime.

title: Yemen Rebels Routed, Saudi Arabia Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Fighting continued for a sixth day on Monday between the Saudi military and Yemeni rebels on their countries border, with the rebels releasing a videotape of what they said was one of several captured Saudi soldiers.

title: Plowing Detroit Into Farmland
description: Todays idea: Detroits massive failure makes possible a radical transformation of the blighted city, an article says, including shrinking it down to its urban core and turning much of the place over to crops. And an ineffective government is actually a plus.

title: Punk History
description: Photos from the festival Rebel Waltz: Underground Music From Behind the Iron Curtain.

title: Opel Union Leader Sees Autonomy as Condition to Talks
description: Opels top German labor leader said on Sunday he was willing to hold negotiations over a restructuring of the European carmaker under its parent General Motors, so long as Opel gained greater independence, Reuters reported.

title: Britain and U.S. Clash at G-20 on Tax for Rescues
description: The United States and Britain voiced disagreement Saturday over a proposal that would impose a new tax on financial transactions to support future bank rescues, The New York Timess Julia Werdigier reported.

title: Britain and Australia Seeking Data From UBS
description: Authorities in Britain and Australia have requested information from UBS after the Swiss bank agreed in August to disclose some 4,450 client names to settle a United States tax case, the bank confirmed Sunday, according to Reuters.

title: Reynolds Said to Be in Talks for Nicotine Gum Firm
description: Reynolds American, which has been trying to get people to start smoking for decades, may soon also be helping them to quit.

description: An ache has hit the belly of investors who feasted on initial public offerings in Asia, in a sign that the primary equity window that saw a big revival two quarters ago is quickly beginning to shut.

description: Careful academic research on the business start-up process reveals that many entrepreneurs never write a business plan.

title: 24 Hour Plays: Meeting and Greeting
description: Somehow, Ashton Kutcher was able to stand up in front of a roomful people and say that his special skill is being a gifted model, and not sound obnoxious. It got a big laugh, in fact. He added I have been good looking for years, and guess what? More laughter. Good looking and charming, sheesh, some guys  but wait, were getting ahead of ourselves.

title: What to Watch Monday: Triple Crossover CSI, George Lopez and the Star of Precious
description: What happens in Vegas doesnt stay in Vegas in the beginning of a triple crossover on CSI: Miami (CBS, 10 p.m.). Ray Langston (Laurence Fishburne) of CSI travels to Miami when a leg found there turns out to belong to a woman who went missing in Las Vegas. The story plays out on CSI: NY on Wednesday and CSI on Thursday.

He will be covering initiatives like incubators, job training, competitions, investment funds, and efforts to encourage industries such as green technology, bioscience, fashion, media and technology, manufacturing and distribution, and the arts.

description: Berkshire Hathaway said the credit crisis has abated, bolstering the firms earnings potential after its chief executive, Warren E. Buffett, agreed to pay $26 billion and take on debt to finance Berkshires biggest takeover, Bloomberg News reported.

title: 24 Hour Plays: The Writing Hours
description: The celebratory mood of the first few hours of 24 Hour Plays activity at the American Airlines Theater Sunday night gave way to a more contemplative one shortly after 11:30 p.m. when only the writers, producers and a few others were left. After the actors took off, the writers had a chance to see the stage where their shows are to be presented Monday night. There is already a set on the stage, a big, English country house designed by Allen Moyer for After Miss Julie, and the writers will have to work with it or around it. This is not a simple matter, given the absurdly long wooden table, the abundance of what looks like delicate china and a number of other items that are not likely to fit every play that is being cooked up. It would be tricky to not use this set, Warren Leight said as the group of writers gapes at the big, crowded stage.

title: Kraft Makes $16.3 Billion Hostile Bid for Cadbury
description: Update | 10:43 a.m. The New York Timess Julia Werdigier and Michael J. de la Merced provide more details on Krafts bid for Cadbury.

title: Brazilian Wind Power Gets a Boost
description: Early this decade, a drought in Brazil that cut water to the countrys hydroelectric dams prompted severe energy shortages. The crisis, which ravaged the countrys economy and led to electricity rationing, underscored Brazils pressing need to diversify away from water power.

title: At The Post, Fewer Sales and Less Swagger
description: Richard Prez-Pea writes:

title: The Early Word: Calendar Crunch
description: The countdown is on. Excluding the Veterans Day and Thanksgiving recesses, lawmakers have just about four-and-a-half weeks to line up 60 votes in favor of the Senates plan to overhaul the health care system, hash out the differences  and there are plenty  between the two chambers versions and get a bill to President Obamas desk by the end of the year.

title: Buddy Holly Hunter S. Thompson Twins
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have deftly conjoined unlikely composite individuals, with diverting and droll results.

title: Bronx Neighborhood Struggles After Devastating Fire
description: A tilted plywood wall wraps around the northwest corner of Bainbridge Avenue and East 204th Street, where the air smells of smoke and the sidewalk glistens from broken glass. The wall tries to hide the ghastly sight of 10 storefronts burned to sooty brick and skeletal girders. But it only  reminds all who pass of a local tragedy.

title: TIPS and inflation expectations
description: Treasury inflation-protected securities  bonds whose payouts are indexed to consumer prices  are really useful for economic analysis: they give an objective, market-based measure of expected inflation. But you have to be a bit careful about using them to interpret recent events, because the same financial disruptions that wreaked havoc with many assets also did some funny stuff to TIPS.

title: 24 Hour Plays: Get Up and Go
description: At 7 a.m. Lou Moreno, one of the producers of the 24 Hour Plays was in the lobby of the American Airlines Theater looking energetic. I was reading scripts on the train on the way in at 5:30, he said, pointing out that the writers had indeed finished on time, some of them early in fact. The writers are nowhere to be seen at the moment, the room some of them used last night is empty. They have gone to bed.

title: Motorsports Links: Johnson Wrecks in Texas
description: Motorsports news from around the Web

title: Leaders in Berlin Retrace the Walk West
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel led a gathering of world leaders in Germanys capital Monday for a celebration of the night 20 years earlier when the Berlin Wall fell.

title: Debate: Modern Pork Production and H1N1
description: Until now, debate over the relationship between the H1N1 influenza virus and large-scale concentrated animal feeding operations  defined by the Environmental Protection Agency as agricultural operations over a certain size where animals are kept and raised in confined situations  has been simmering outside the limelight.

title: On Roosevelt Island, Less Work, More Babies
description: While Roosevelt Islands leafy streets and lower-priced apartments have long offered New Yorkers a respite from the endless concrete and shoe-box size homes of city life, residents there have not been sheltered from the recession.

title: Are These the 100 Best Movies of the Decade?
description: The decade isnt quite over yet, but The Times of London made an early effort on Saturday at tying a bow around the last ten years with its list of the 100 best films of the decade. The Timess proudly opinionated lineup feels more provocative than definitive, though it does make an effort to represent all sides of 2000s cinema, from art-house fare (The Diving Bell and the Butterfly at No. 28; Dancer in the Dark at No. 25) to hit crowd-pleasers (The Devil Wears Prada at No. 100; Wedding Crashers at No. 90) to cult favorites (Shaun of the Dead at No. 58), with at least one authentic Huh? moment in there (Bad Santa at No. 54?).

title: Learning How Animals Regenerate Body Parts
description: The best possible kind of regenerative medicine would surely be to entice the body to use natures own methods to regrow a damaged limb or organ. The genes that made the structure in the first place are still present in every cell of the body but somehow repressed. Could they not be reactivated to make the patient as good as new?

title: How to Hedge a (Potential) Bomb
description: Michael Cieply writes:

title: Digital Delights for Kids in the Caribbean
description: Kid-savvy resorts in the Caribbean, perhaps hoping to grab the attention of increasingly screen-addicted guests, are loading on the digital delights.

title: An End Game for the Forever War?
description: The battle between CF Industries, Terra Industries and Agrium looks to be near a conclusion after the events of the past week. CF raised its hostile offer for Terra to $40.61 a share in cash and stock, an offer that was rejected about 48 hours later by Terras board. Meanwhile, Agrium raised its hostile offer for CF to $92.99 a share in cash and stock, an offer that was rejected less than 24 hours later by CFs board.

title: Cold Response to Krafts Cadbury Bid
description: LONDON  Kraft took its $16.7 billion bid for Cadbury, the British chocolate and chewing gum maker, directly to shareholders on Monday after the Cadbury board rejected the offer as too low.

title: Ward Helps Biracial Youths on Journey Toward Acceptance
description: PITTSBURGH  Steelers receiver Hines Ward surrounded himself with old friends at the dinner table on a recent Saturday night. The bond was as obvious as the look on everyones faces  half Korean, half something else. The shared experience was far more than skin deep.

title: The View From the Wall
description: Today is the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, which signaled the beginning of the end of communism in Europe. Times readers submitted their photos and memories of the wall, before and after its fall.

title: The View From the Berlin Wall
description: BERLIN | Today is the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, which signaled the beginning of the end of communism in Europe. Times readers submitted their photos and memories of the wall, before and after its fall.

title: Monday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Ulcer Symptoms Can Be Hard to Decipher
description: Last week on the Consults blog, Dr. Neena S. Abraham, a gastroenterologist at the Michael E. DeBakey V.A. Medical Center and associate professor of medicine at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, took readers questions about ulcers. Here, Dr. Abraham responds to readers concerned about ulcer symptoms and foods or drinks that may make ulcers worse.

title: Can Ulcers Run in Families?
description: Last week on the Consults blog, Dr. Neena S. Abraham, a gastroenterologist at the Michael E. DeBakey V.A. Medical Center and associate professor of medicine at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, took readers questions about ulcers, a potentially life-threatening condition increasingly tied to Nsaid pain relievers. Here, Dr. Abraham responds to a reader who wondered whether she is at increased risk of ulcers if her father had one.

title: When Ulcer Drugs Dont Work
description: Last week on the Consults blog, Dr. Neena S. Abraham, a gastroenterologist at the Michael E. DeBakey V.A. Medical Center and associate professor of medicine at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, took readers questions about ulcers, a potentially life-threatening condition increasingly tied to Nsaid pain relievers. Here, Dr. Abraham responds to readers who had questions about drug treatments for ulcers.

title: Lessons in Oil for Groundwater Conservation?
description: Todd Jarvis, the associate director of the Institute for Water and Watersheds at Oregon State University, sees parallels between the planets dwindling oil supplies and groundwater depletion.

title: Aerosmith Says Steven Tyler Has Quit
description: The sweet emotions that the members of Aerosmith once felt towards each other have apparently come to an end. In an interview with The Las Vegas Sun, the groups lead guitarist, Joe Perry, said that the singer Steven Tyler quit after a concert in Abu Dhabi. Steven quit as far as I can tell, Mr. Perry told The Sun. I dont know any more than you do about it.

title: Special News Quiz | Berlin Wall History
description: New York Times reporter Robert McFadden called it the foremost symbol of East-West confrontation and a monument to political control, a scene of gunfire and drama and tragedy, the stuff of spy novels and a physical and psychic barrier that divided Berlin, Germany and Europe.

title: Street Smart | Aucklands Art Bandits
description: Street art in Auckland, New Zealand, is much more than just random acts of spray paint. Nearly every corner of the city is decorated with sophisticated graphic imagery, from stencil drawings (sharks, angels, aerosol-can characters) to murals (intergalactic space settings, muscle men portraiture) to throw-ups (elaborate, bubble-shaped letters forming the artists signature). The city council has even allowed electrical boxes to be used as 3-D canvases for street art. While some of the artists and collectives have achieved a certain visibility in the graffiti world  a local crew called TMD (The Most Def) has won the Write For Gold international competition in Germany for the past two years  many of the taggers are anonymous. And if you want to see their handiwork, youd better be quick. Most of the art (excluding the electrical-box mainstays) is either torn down or painted over within a few days. As Andrew Beck, from the Auckland collective Surplus Bargains, says: Thats what street art is  temporary.

title: Two Harlem Streets Named for Civil Rights Leaders
description: On Saturday, two streets in Harlem were named in honor of two civil rights leaders with ties to New York City: A. Philip Randolph and W. E. B. DuBois.

title: Iran Accuses U.S. Hikers of Espionage
description: Three American hikers who were arrested in Iran this summer after straying across its border with Iraq have been accused of spying, an Iranian state news agency reported on Monday.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this article misstated the number of stock options being issued and their total value. The bank will issue 200 million to 300 million options, worth about $1.1 billion, not two to three million worth $11 million.

title: China Executes 9 for Their Roles in Ethnic Riots in July
description: BEIJING  Nine people have been executed for taking part in ethnic rioting that convulsed a western regional capital in July and left nearly 200 people dead, a state news agency reported Monday.

title: Trial Begins for Baltimore Mayor
description: BALTIMORE  Mayor Sheila Dixon went on trial on corruption charges on Monday, the result of a state inquiry started in 2006 that has cast a cloud over Ms. Dixons administration despite her best efforts to keep the focus on running the city.

title: Musicians Locked Out at Tony N Tinas Wedding
description: Updated | 1:20 p.m. A long-running theatrical marriage has hit a major bump: a union that represents professional musicians has filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board, saying that the producers of the show Tony N Tinas Wedding fired its contracted musicians and replaced them with recorded music. The Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, said that in 2008 it renewed a three-year agreement with the previous producers of that show, which covered its performers through May 2011, and stipulated that it must be honored if new producers came onto the show. The union said that the producers Kim and Sonny Ricciardi of Broadway Entertainment, which recently took over Tony N Tinas Wedding, paid the musicians for the shows Oct. 10 performance and asked them to learn a new song for Oct. 17. On that date, however, the union said the producers locked the musicians out of the performance space and have denied them access to their instruments and other property. A representative for Local 802 said a meeting had been scheduled for Monday afternoon to address the dispute. A message left at Broadway Entertainment was not immediately returned.

title: The Fall of the Berlin Wall
description: NBC's Tom Brokaw returns to Berlin for the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall.  Brokaw was the only U.S. anchor in Berlin the night the wall fell.

title: Mad Men Recap: In the Season 3 Finale, Do We Take a Vote?
description: Season 3, Episode 13

title: Vatican Keeps Celibacy in Rules on Anglicans
description: VATICAN CITY  The Vatican said on Monday that its new rules facilitating the conversion of Anglicans, including married Anglican priests, did not signify any change in its rules for priestly celibacy.

title: High School Hot Rodder at SEMA Show
description: Race Safro played hooky from high school last week. Well, actually, the 16-year-old junior at Highland High School in Albuquerque, N.M., was away on a business trip.

title: Zambia and Tanzania Seek Legal Ivory Sales
