description: Zambia and Tanzania are requesting a reclassification for their African Elephant populations to enable legal sales of ivory.

title: Gourevitch Stepping Down at Paris Review
description: Philip Gourevitch, the New Yorker staff writer who for five years has been doing double-duty as the editor of The Paris Review, will leave his editors post in April, The New York Observer reported. In an interview with The Observer, Mr. Gourevitch (whose books include We Wish to Inform You That Tomorrow We Will Be Killed With Our Families and The Ballad of Abu Ghraib) said that he wanted to focus more on his writing and a new book project about Rwanda. I want to give that everything, Mr. Gourevitch said. You cant take time off when youre in charge. A committee run by Antonio Weiss, the publisher of The Paris Review, and Terry McDonnell, the director of the Paris Review Foundation, and including Bob Silvers, the editor of The New York Review of Books, and Peter Matthiessen, a founder of The Paris Review, will search for Mr. Gourevitchs replacement.

title: What High School Seniors Might Learn From a Survey of 360,000 College Students
description: Every year since 2000, the National Survey of Student Engagement has sought to take the academic pulse of tens of thousands of college students at several hundred colleges. To me, their answers are almost beside the point. Ive always thought the questions themselves provided an especially detailed road map for high school seniors and their parents, as they try to take the measure of a particular college.

title: A Lowlight-Reel Weekend
description: As tempting as it might be to focus on the good teams in the N.F.L., to marvel at the undefeated Colts and Saints, to start etching the name Peyton Manning or Drew Brees on a most valuable player trophy, the league keeps throwing us these fabulous train wrecks every week: Atlanta Coach Mike Smith nearly brawling with the Redskins DeAngelo Hall; Green Bay not only losing to Tampa Bay, but losing to the Buccaneers in their Creamsicle uniforms (oh, the humanity!); the Giants capsizing to the quarterback they traded away for Eli Manning.

title: Forward March | Desert Storm
description: Step into formation this fall with new slicker versions of the classic workaday desert boot. From top, Bottega Veneta boot, $580, bottegaveneta.com; Clarks Originals boot, $95, clarksusa.com; The Generic Man boot, $345 from Barneys, (212) 826-8900; Pierre Hardy boot, $430, barneys.com; Churchs boot, $380 from Churchs, (212) 758-5200.

title: Fort Hood Suspect Is Conscious, Hospital Officials Say
description: FORT HOOD, Tex.  Major Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist accused of shooting to death 12 soldiers and a civilian here at Fort Hood, is conscious and able to talk, officials at an Army hospital in Texas said Monday. But they declined to say whether Major Hasan had been interviewed by Army or law-enforcement investigators.

title: Infertility Film Diaries
description: The In The Know short film competition concluded last week, sponsored jointly by RESOLVE: The National Infertility Association, and the pharmaceutical company EMD Serono. Couples who have struggled with infertility submitted videos describing their journeys, and you can see the winners on the website www.fertilitylifelinesfilms.com.

title: R.I.M. Woos BlackBerry App Developers
description: BlackBerry owners may be able to type circles around their iPhone-toting friends when it comes to speeding through e-mails. But when the work is over and its time to play with the latest useful or silly applications, their speedy thumbs have nowhere to go. By the latest count, the Apple iPhone has 100,000 apps and the BlackBerry has just a few thousand.

title: 24 Hour Plays: Assignments and First Rehearsals
description: With only 24 hours to create six plays from start to finish, it is not surprising that things run on a strict schedule here at the American Airlines Theater. By 8 a.m. the directors had finished submitting their choices (Lucie Tiberghien said she thought the scripts were all good, and all funny. Nobody tried to do a dark drama, she said). It seemed only a few minutes had passed before Philip Naud, one of the producers, gave the directors their assignments. Leigh Kilton-Smith is to direct Stephen Belbers play, Ramen Noodle, and her reaction seemed unclear for a moment  was that pleasant shock or something more like horror that flashed across her face?

title: U.S. Roster for Slovakia and Denmark
description: Score 17 goals, go directly to the national team.

title: Travel Deals: Daily Discounts at Best Western
description: For the next five days, Best Western will be announcing special deals at noon that are available only until 4 p.m. E.S.T. that day. Heres a sneak peak at the Countdown to Savings deals that will be offered:

title: Big Poker Bet Falls Short for Former Bear Executive
description: A former Bear Stearns senior executive bet it all and lost his entire $22 million in chips during the finals of the World Series of Poker on Sunday, but he still managed to take home a $1.6 million prize for coming in sixth place. The move eerily parallels the fate of financial firms on Wall Street that bet big with their clients money and lost, but still ended up with a large chunk of change in their pocket.

title: Palestinian Authoritys Future Is in Question
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The collapse of the Palestinian Authority, Israels negotiating partner, was raised as a possibility on Monday, as several aides to its president, Mahmoud Abbas, said that he intended to resign and forecast that others would follow.

title: An Assignment Gets a Bronx Teacher Suspended
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Zo to Close After Almost 18 Years in SoHo
description: Stephen and Thalia Loffredo will be closing Zo in SoHo at the end of the week after almost 18 years in business.

title: A Private School Counselor Offers His Take on Independent Counselors
description: Editors Note: Ive finished my week-long run answering reader questions on The Timess home page, but I am hoping in the coming days to highlight a few of the exchanges for readers of The Choice.

title: HR 3962 and the Serpent of Pulp
description: When opponents of the House health care bill attack it, they often bring up the length of the bill, as if the number of pages signifies nefarious intent. Lawmakers have gotten in on the act: just look at the photo of two Republican representatives, Steve King of Iowa and Pete Hoekstra of Michigan, crumpling a copy of the House bill, looking a bit like modern-day Laocoons, struggling against serpents of paper.

title: Kind Cuts for the Jobless
description: During a two-day event called Hair Care, the Cristiano Cora salon in Manhattan offered free haircuts to unemployed New Yorkers.

title: In Google Book Case, a Request for More Time
description: The parties to the Google book settlement, which would legalize the creation of a vast library of digital books, have asked the judge overseeing a revision of the agreement for an extension to this Friday, Nov. 13.

title: An East Village Synagogue Gets a Jazzy Rabbi
description: At first glance, the term jazz rabbi might seem incongruous, but the recent installation of Greg Wall, a well-known jazz musician, as the rabbi at the Sixth Street Community Synagogue, a modern Orthodox congregation in the East Village, shows that the porkpie and the yarmulke are not necessarily mutually exclusive.

title: JPMorgan Chase Ends Salary Freeze
description: The people at JPMorgan Chase have received some good news about their paychecks: The bank is removing a salary freeze for employees earning more than $60,000 a year, with raises taking effect early next year. The freeze was put in place at the height of the financial crisis last year.

title: Update: A Shake-Up at The Washington Times
description: The Washington Times has fired three top executives, the paper announced on Monday, and it refused to say whether the papers top editor would also leave.

title: Did Unemployment Really Rise?
description: The economic reactions over the weekend to Fridays employment report all started from the assumption that things grew much worse in October. The unemployment rate leaped to 10.2 percent from 9.8 percent. Another 190,000 jobs vanished.

title: Cisco Extends Acceptance Period for Tandberg Bid
description: The network equipment maker Cisco Systems said Monday that it was extending the offer period for its $3 billion bid for the Norwegian video conferencing company Tandberg by nine days, to Nov. 18.

title: Reading Husseins Biography in Baghdad
description: One book not for sale on Mutanabi Street, this citys ancient strip of booksellers, is a new biography of Saddam Hussein, written by his lawyer based on Mr. Husseins diaries and conversations, that was published in Sudan last month.

title: Sasha Cohen Withdraws From Skate America
description: Tendinitis has again interrupted Sasha Cohens comeback to competitive figure skating, and is crimping her hopes to make the United States team for the Vancouver Olympics. Cohen announced Monday that she has withdrawn from this weekends event, Skate America in Lake Placid.

title: Smart People Conclude Twilight Sequel Will Be a Hit
description: With the help of a sophisticated mathematical formula, a group of highly trained academics has determined that the coming sequel to Twilight is going to make a lot of money. Thats the conclusion reached by a group of researchers who say they can predict how a movie sequel will perform compared to similar, non-sequel films, The Guardian reported.

title: EconoQuiz Results
description: Thanks to everyone who took part in the latest EconoQuiz.

title: Schotten Preise
description: Scottish prices  a term used in Germany to denote cheap prices.

title: Parties Seek More Time to Craft Google Books Deal
description: From our colleagues at Media Decoder:

title: Colts Game Should Provide Test of Bradys Health
description: Tom Brady looked a little weary and in need of a shave after the New England Patriots beat the Miami Dolphins on Sunday. Maybe he was just tired of everyone wondering if he was back to normal eight games into the season. Its time to answer that question honestly.

title: Metropolitan Home Will Close
description: The magazine Metropolitan Home will be closing, Hachette Filipacchi Media U.S. announced today.

title: Now Viewing | Eye Candy in Paris
description: Its clear that no food publication is recession-proof. Culinary photography, however, is bubbling over, with a new annual festival kicking off this month in Paris called the Festival International de la Photographie Culinaire. Its founder, a former cookbook editor named Jean-Pierre Stephan, has noticed a revolution in the quality of food photos over the past decade, thanks to the boom in cookbooks and foodie mags. I want to show that culinary photography has become a true art, he says, one that can make its way in the marketplace the same as any other form of art or photography. You can hang it on the dining room wall like a 17th-century Dutch still life.

title: Katt Williams Arrested After Home Break-In
description: The comedian Katt Williams has been charged with burglary and trespassing and remains held in an Atlanta jail after he was arrested on Sunday night for breaking into a home, The Associated Press reported. Major James Yarbrough of the Coweta County sheriffs department told The A.P. that the break-in occurred at a home in Newnan, about 38 miles southwest of Atlanta, where a homeowner called the police to say that Mr. Williams gained entry by breaking into the home, and items were taken from the residence. The name of the homeowner was not given. In July, gun charges against Mr. Williams were dropped after an incident in New York in November 2008 when the police pulled him over for driving a car without license plates and discovered a gun in the car. The comedian sought medical care later that month after he was seen behaving suspiciously in Sumter, S.C., where his family lives. The A.P. said that a magistrate was expected to set bond for Mr. Williams at an arraignment Monday afternoon.

title: The Home Buyers Tax Credit: What You Need to Know
description: The president signed legislation last week that extended the tax credit for first-time home buyers and added a new credit for some existing homeowners.

title: Man Arrested in Series of Subway Robberies
description: A man with a knife and wearing a Red Sox cap who robbed several young women on New York Citys subway system was arrested on Friday in Rocky Mount, N.C., according to the police.

title: Club for Growth Endorses Rubio
description: The Club for Growth PAC, an anti-tax organization with considerable financial resources, announced on Monday that it is endorsing Marco Rubio in his Florida Republican primary battle with Gov. Charlie Crist for the United States Senate.

title: Song of Remembering
description: Last week in Rome I walked through the Forum, parallel to the Via Imperiali, from the Colosseum to the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. I felt as if I were walking among the skeletal ruins of empire, one of historys vast museums. Huge Corinthian columns rose up in marble, holding nothing but the skys blue sphere above, the buildings they once belonged to vanquished by centuries of dust, lime burners, thieves. Slabs of marble lay on the ground with the fragments of names and pronouncements chiseled into them.

title: Big Bird Responds
description: On Tuesday, Sesame Street will celebrate its 40th anniversary with the usual array of songs and life lessons about numbers and nutrition and a special guest, the first lady, Michelle Obama, on hand to help out.

title: Carlyle Group Buying OpenLink Financial
description: The Carlyle Group said Monday that it had acquired OpenLink Financial, a maker of financial software products, from TA Associates, another private equity firm, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Fox Affiliate Leads the Yankees Parade
description: Which local station did fans turn to to watch the Yankees victory parade on Friday?

title: Reagan mythbusting, productivity edition
description: Another in my series about refuting the myth that Ronald Reagan, financial liberalization, or both ushered in an age of much faster economic growth.

title: Hands-Only CPR: Try It -- Its Effective
description: As Stuart Elliott travels on assignment, Jane L. Levere will write the Campaign Spotlight column. The Q & A and Webdenda will return next Monday with Stuart.

title: As Johnsons Suspension Ends, So Does His Time With the Chiefs
description: The Kansas City Chiefs released running back Larry Johnson on Monday morning, just as his two-week suspension for conduct detrimental to the team ended.

title: Bored to Death and  Curb Your Enthusiasm': One-Two Punch?
description: This post contains spoilers. Bored to Death, which ended its first season in a twist, has served all along as a comic counterpoint on HBO to Curb Your Enthusiasm  balancing Larry Davids ever more outr and disgusting plot points (backsplash on the image of Jesus) with odd grace notes and unexpected swerves to decency.

title: Disappointing Carol May Take Toll on Disney
description: The disappointing $31 million opening for Disneys A Christmas Carol over the weekend may force the company to take a hefty write down, according to Doug Creutz, a media analyst at Cowen & Company. At least $50 million and potentially as much as $100 million, he wrote in a research note. Doug Mitchelson of Deutsche Bank sent a similar advisory to investors.

title: Google Set to Acquire AdMob for $750 Million
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a push to expand its digital advertising empire to cellphones, Google has agreed to acquire AdMob, a fast-growing mobile advertising start-up, for $750 million in stock, the companies said Monday.

title: Finance mythbusting, third world edition
description: And another: one assertion I keep hearing in comments is that well, maybe China never got much capital from abroad, so you cant attribute its takeoff to modern finance, but lots of other fast-growing developing countries did.

title: Commemorating the Fall of the Berlin Wall
description: Hundreds gathered in Berlin to observe the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall.

title: European Puck: Remembering the Twilight of East German Hockey
description: Monday marks the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall and the beginning of the end of a divided Germany. That makes today a good time to remember the most successful sporting venture that emerged from the East and still thrives today: Eisbren Berlin, champions of the German DEL for four of the past five years.

title: Pear Upside-Down Cake
description: Mark Bittman bakes a pear upside-down cake.

title: Inverted Logic: Upside-Down Pear Cake
description: IVE always been a fan of tarte Tatin, the French dessert that features deeply caramelized apples on a light crust, often puff pastry. Im also partial to its simpler American cousin, the upside-down cake, which features a spongecake base.

title: Google Strikes $750 Million Stock Deal for AdMob
description: Update | 2:05 p.m. Google has agreed to buy AdMob, a fast-growing start-up that developed technology to place ads on mobile phones, for $750 million in stock, the company said Monday, The New York Timess Miguel Helft reported from San Francisco.

title: Monday Puzzle: You Cant Fight Density er, Destiny
description: Last week, we had you imagine yourself to be a perfect princess who had to choose from among the worlds most eligible princes. This weeks fictitious story, about the break-up of Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman, is a reminder that even unions between seemingly perfect people can go horribly wrong. And both stories perfectly illustrate another recent TierneyLab topic: why we love to gossip. We enjoy the first case by vicariously living our lives through people who seemingly have it all; in the second case, we just let our bottled-up envy loose and thumb our noses at them: Youre not so perfect, Mr. Celebrity. Nyah, nyah, nyah nyah nyah. Its something that we can enjoy with our baser instincts both going in and coming out.

title: A Shoe Box Full of New York Arrives in Afghanistan
description: The first word came early last week, flashed to Manhattan from a British Army forward operating base in Helmand Province in a Facebook message. Then confirmation arrived in a phone call Friday at lunchtime. There was a short delay on the line, but the message was clear: The ultimate New York care package had arrived in Afghanistan.

title: Former S.E.C. Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Dreier Case
description: Update | 4:00 p.m. A former lawyer with the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission pleaded guilty Monday to conspiring with Marc S. Dreier, a prominent Manhattan lawyer, to dupe hedge funds out of tens of millions of dollars.

title: Should Jahvid Best Play Again?
description: The results of this gut-wrenching fall were better than expected: Jahvid Best, the star running back for the University of California, Berkeley was released from the hospital Sunday after suffering a severe concussion.

title: U.S. Officer Revisits His Past in Vietnam
description: DA NANG, Vietnam  Cmdr. H. B. Le, the first Vietnamese-American to command a United States Navy destroyer, had just stepped ashore on a formal port call, making an emotional return to Vietnam for the first time since he fled as a young boy on a fishing boat at the end of the war in 1975.

title: On the Brink, New York Must Cut, Paterson Says
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson took the rare step on Monday of addressing a joint session of the Legislature during its traditional off-season and used the speech to underscore New Yorks deepening financial crisis.

title: Two Channels Buy Enthusiasm Reruns
description: Larry Davids fictional self is being sold to two cable channels. Both the TV Guide Network and TV Land have bought the rerun rights to Curb Your Enthusiasm, Mr. Davids acclaimed HBO comedy.

title: Dame Edna, Michael Feinstein Slapfest Continues
description: Since September, observant theater fans have been noting the ever-so-slight resemblance between the titles of coming Broadway productions featuring Michael Feinstein (whose new show, All About Me, begins previews on March 6) and Dame Edna Everage (who is returning next year in a new show called Its All About Me.) Last week, when Mr. Feinstein said he was very surprised to learn of the similarity of titles, perhaps he thought hed have the last word on the matter. But no.

title: Canada Breaks U.S. Womens Winning Streak
description: It was a winning streak that the United States womens hockey team hoped would continue until after the Vancouver Olympic Games, having not lost to their arch-rival, Team Canada, since 2007.

title: Skimming and Scanning: Using The Times to Develop Reading Skills
description: Overview | How can you quickly identify the main idea of a text? When and how do you skim a text, and how does skimming differ from scanning? In this lesson, students practice and explore the reading skills of skimming and scanning with the front page of The New York Times and come away understanding how and when to use these skills.

title: Against Time | Natalia Brillis Nolex
description: The Belgian designer Natalia Brilli puts a new spin on that old saw: If you have to ask how much, you cant afford it. Among her catalog of curiosities is this fake Rolex watch, called a Nolex, which she covers in soft buttery leather, suggesting that if you have to know the time, you also cant afford it.Brilli, who has designed accessories at Rochas, is hypersensitive to the conclusions people draw about the character and status of someone wearing a luxury product. So far, shes encased everything from skateboards to medical alert bracelets in black or silver leather. But sometimes, shell pick a bright electric hue, further scrambling the objects original associations. The Nolex is $295 at Project 8, (212) 925-5599.

title: Fannie Mulls $5.2 Billion Write-off for Tax Credits
description: Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance giant, said Monday that it was reviewing whether it would have to write off $5.2 billion in low-income housing tax credits after the Treasury Department rejected its request last week to sell the credits to Goldman Sachs, Bloomberg News reports.

title: D.C. Sniper Is to Be Executed on Tuesday
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday declined to block the execution of John A. Muhammad, the sniper who terrorized the Washington area seven years ago. The step cleared the way for Mr. Muhammad to be put to death on Tuesday unless Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia intervenes.

title: Public Grooming Stirs Vigorous Debate
description: More than 200 commenters chimed in on Lion Calandras complaints about grooming in public  the argument that people should not make public spectacles out of private moments clearly hit a nerve. Most had their own horror stories to share (often involving nail clippings or tossed dental floss), though some even confessed to their own grooming indiscretions.

title: Obscure Books, Part II
description: Last year, inspired by a piece in The Village Voice, I asked readers what their favorite obscure books were. Now The American Conservative, in its Special Books Issue, has asked 15 writers to name their favorite obscure books.

title: Chron Is Glossy-ish: What Do You Think?
description: At first, I missed it.

title: Universities Look for Heat Underground
description: In an effort to cut their carbon footprints, a handful of universities around the country are turning to ground-source heat exchangers and geothermal heating  sometimes with the help of federal financing.

title: Bardot, Frances Lasting Passion
description: PARIS | She is known for her unadulterated beauty, feisty temper and French je ne sais quoi. Brigitte Bardot first graced the cover of Elle magazine in 1950, at the age of 15, and has remained in the publics imagination ever since. Brigitte Bardot: The Carefree Years, an exhibition dedicated to the French star, now 75, celebrates her lasting popularity  which itself is a reflection of Frances own obsession with passion, rebellion and idealization.

title: Justices Hear Patent Case on Protecting the Abstract
description: WASHINGTON  Supreme Court justices took up a case on Monday that could reshape the realm of what can be patented, and expressed skepticism about giving protection to abstract business innovations.

title: When Jet Lag Comes With the Freebies
description: IT was really easy to convert my frequent flier miles into a free round-trip business-class ticket to Europe.

title: Tagged.com Settles Disputes Over Deceptive Invitations
description: Update | 5:38 p.m.   Corrected post and headline to note that the state attorneys general had announced their intent to sue Tagged.com; they had not actually filed lawsuits.

title: White and Davis Strong Season Picks Up Another Ice Dancing Victory
description: American ice dancers Meryl White and Charlie Davis qualified for their second Grand Prix final by winning their second competition of the season.

title: New Ideas for Winter Squash
description: These days you dont have to go to a farmers market to find several varieties of winter squash. Last week, as I walked into a Trader Joes, I passed bins of acorn squash, butternut, spaghetti squash and pumpkins of varying sizes. I bought one of each kind of squash, and Ive been exploring new ways of working with them.

title: Design Is the Key to Detroits Future, Study Says
description: In the 1920s, Alfred Sloan, who was the president of General Motors at the time, committed the automaker to the annual model change. But today, model changes are far less frequent than annual, and a recently released economic research paper argues that Detroit automakers have suffered because of it. Detroits share of the auto market fell from roughly 73 percent in 1996 to 47 percent in 2008.

title: Injured Right Calf Forces Cohen to Withdraw From Skate America
description: Sasha Cohen, the 2006 Olympic silver medalist in figure skating, ran into another setback Monday in her effort to make the 2010 United States Olympic team.

title: Dutch Views on Same-Sex Marriage
description: When I wrote about same sex parenting in the Times Magazine this weekend, one of the people I interviewed was M. V. Lee Badgett, who is both the director of the Williams Institute on Sexual Orientation Law & Public Policy at the UCLA School of Law and a professor of Economics at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst. She is also the author of When Gay People Get Married: What Happens When Societies Legalize Same-Sex Marriage, which focuses mostly on data from the Netherlands, where same-sex marriage has been legal for nearly a decade.

title: Vitaly Ginzburg Dies at 93; Worked on Soviet H-Bomb
description: MOSCOW  Vitaly L. Ginzburg, the Russian physicist who helped develop the first Soviet hydrogen bomb and went on to win the Nobel Prize, died in Moscow on Sunday. He was 93.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Ezra Klein on abortion and the Stupak amendment.

title: Findley Scores Salt Lake a Chance at the M.L.S. Title Game
description: Robbie Findley has the confidence of youth and the audacity necessary to be a successful striker.

title: Wait, Are These Actually the 100 Best Movies of the Decade?
description: Earlier on Monday we noted an effort by The Times of London to enumerate the 100 best films of the 2000s, defiantly published before the Dec. 23 release of the Alvin and the Chipmunks sequel.

title: Steroids Miracle Comes With a Caveat
description: Steroids  corticosteroids, that is, synthetic versions of the natural hormone produced by the adrenal glands  are indeed miracle drugs, capable of restoring the health and saving the lives of countless people with a wide spectrum of serious ailments. Prednisone may be the best known, but there are scores of others, some tailor-made to counter specific ailments.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Sun-Times has more on the Chicago roots of Sam Kass, the White House chef whos a food policy adviser for the Obamas.

title: Beckhams Contributions to the Galaxy Amount to More Than Celebrity Stimulus
description: CARSON, Calif.  David Beckham curled a beautiful 50-yard pass to Landon Donovan, beginning a sequence that ended with Donovans penalty-kick goal in the 73rd minute and a 1-0 playoff victory for the Los Angeles Galaxy.

title: Gathering at the Table, Bottles in Hand
description: FOR six consecutive years, the Dining sections wine panel has gathered for an early Thanksgiving meal. The mission: to taste potential holiday wines, to determine what works and what does not with a representative feast, and to offer coherent answers to the annual question of what to serve with the bird.

title: Wounded Soldier Recounts Shooting
description: N.B.C.'s Meredith Vieira interviewed Amber Bahr, a soldier who was wounded in Thursday's shooting at Fort Hood in Texas.

title: Metropolitan Home Will Close After Its December Issue
description: Another home magazine has been demolished.

title: The Morning Skate: A Headshot Hearing, a Union Adrift and a Lot of Hurting
description: TSN is reporting that the Flames Curtis Glencross has been suspended three games for this blindside head shot to Rangers captain Chris Drury:

title: Setting Sail Into Space, Propelled by Sunshine
description: Peter Pan would be so happy.

title: E.P.A. Intervenes on Video by 2 Employees
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has directed two agency lawyers to make changes in a video they posted on YouTube that is critical of the Obama administrations climate policy. But the original video has already been reposted several times by other YouTube users.

title: 24 Hour Plays: No Free Lunch
description: At noon there was an event in the lobby at the American Airlines Theater that the people in charge were referring to as lunch. Clearly there was a table piled high with food, but not a lot of actors spent much time sitting around eating. Some passed through quickly and went off to continue rehearsing, one cast was having its sole chance to be on the stage proper before tech and worked through lunch and others, well, who knows if all of these people even eat lunch.

title: Hotels Find Keeping Travelers at Home Can Be Good Business
description: If you cant beat em, join em, may be the best maxim to explain why travel companies are getting into the virtual meeting business, actually helping clients avoid flying halfway around the globe.

title: Brooklyn Kitchen Labs Is Set to Open
description: Brooklyn Kitchen Labs, the Williamsburg cooking school/butcher shop/brewing and winemaking supply store featuring the work of the celebrity butcher Tom Mylan, will open on Nov. 16.

title: U.S. Knew of Suspects Tie to Radical Cleric
description: WASHINGTON  Intelligence agencies intercepted communications last year and this year between the military psychiatrist accused of shooting to death 13 people at Fort Hood, Tex., and a radical cleric in Yemen known for his incendiary anti-American teachings.

title: On Our Radar
description: 1.) Harnessing bacteria to grow custom packaging.

title: Dutch View of Choice in U.S. Care: Its Limited
description: WASHINGTON  The health system in the United States may be twice as expensive as those in Europe, and the population may be less healthy, but at least Americans have access to many more choices of doctors and insurers. Right?

title: Fearing a Flu Vaccine, and Wanting More of It
description: When I tell nonmedical friends that our clinic is vaccinating children against the H1N1 flu virus, here is what they say.

title: Financial Regulations Chief Chides British Banks
description: LONDON  Many senior banking executives failed to accept responsibility for the financial crisis and neglected the need to change their behavior, Hector Sants, the chief executive at Britains financial industry regulatory body, said Monday.

title: Buffett to Sell Stakes in 2 Other Railroad Firms
description: Update | 4:16 p.m. As Warren E. Buffett takes on Burlington Northern Santa Fe in his biggest-ever deal, he is looking to sell off his stakes in two other big railroad companies, Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern.

title: The Claim: Magnetic Therapy Can Ease Arthritis Pain
description: THE FACTS For people with arthritis who seek an alternative to painkillers, magnetic straps and bracelets have become a popular option.

title: In Africa, the Flight Is Just a Trips First Leg
description: AFRICA fascinates me. The land itself is magnificent, as are its people. Despite the hardships they have endured, they are hopeful about a brighter future.

title: Seedy Lives of Citrus
description: Q. Lemons have lots of seeds, and most oranges, too. But Ive never encountered a seed in a lime. Why?

title: Stuck by a Needle, Not by a Decision
description: I didnt think it would happen to me so soon, just a few months after beginning my second career as a nurse. I stuck my thumb with a large-bore needle filled with the blood of a patient with hepatitis C who had come to the emergency room with abdominal pain.

title: Through 1 Woman, 20 Views of Lifes End
description: When Lance Armstrong learned he had testicular cancer, he assembled a top team of doctors for what he decided would be the race of his life. If he did not win, he would die.

title: Exercise: Treating Sleep Apnea With a Golf Club
description: Many middle-aged men who have sleep apnea either do not seek treatment or are inconsistent about using the airway pressure masks prescribed to them. But what if they thought treatment might improve their golf game?

title: Nutrition: Chocolate Milk May Reduce Inflammation
description: Move over, red wine. Make room for chocolate milk. A new study suggests that regular consumption of skim milk with flavonoid-rich cocoa may reduce inflammation, potentially slowing or preventing development of atherosclerosis. Researchers noted, however, that the effect was not as pronounced as that seen with red wine.

title: A Dream Interpretation: Tuneups for the Brain
description: Its snowing heavily, and everyone in the backyard is in a swimsuit, at some kind of party: Mom, Dad, the high school principal, theres even an ex-girlfriend. And is that Elvis, over by the piata?

title: Impasse Over, Lebanon Forms Cabinet
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  More than five months after holding parliamentary elections, Lebanon formed a new cabinet on Monday, ending a long period of gridlock that illustrated once again the myriad dysfunctions of this country's bitterly divided political class.

title: AIDS Divisions of 2 Large Drug Makers Form Company to Focus on the Disease
description: Two of the worlds biggest drug makers last week spun off their divisions that manufacture AIDS drugs and combined them into one company focusing on the disease.

title: Magnets for Arthritis
description: In todays Really? column, Anahad OConnor explores whether magnetic therapy can ease arthritis pain.

title: Parents Refusing the Flu Vaccine
description: When I found out my daughters school was offering the H1N1 vaccine last week, I quickly signed up. Given the scarcity of the vaccine in my community, I felt fortunate it was finally available through the school. But I was surprised how many parents chose not to have their kids vaccinated.

title: Wall St. Bonus Season Likely to Be Hit or Miss
description: Bonus time on Wall Street will be very hit or miss this year amid a growing divergence in incentive compensation across the financial services industry, according to projections from Johnson & Associates, a consulting firm.

title: Afloat in the Ocean, Expanding Islands of Trash
description: ABOARD THE ALGUITA, 1,000 miles northeast of Hawaii  In this remote patch of the Pacific Ocean, hundreds of miles from any national boundary, the detritus of human life is collecting in a swirling current so large that it defies precise measurement.

title: E.P.A. Intervenes on Video
description: At our sib-blog DotEarth, Leslie Kaufman and John Broder report that the Environmental Protection Agency has directed two of its lawyers to make changes in a video posted on YouTube that is critical of the Obama administrations climate-change policy. Read the full post.

title: A New Look for the Public Librarys Lion Logo
description: The library lion has shed its shaggy mane for the digital age.

title: Sandras Sources | Must-Visit Online Vintage Sales
description: T Magazines beauty/style director, Sandra Ballentine, opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.

title: Fewer Banks Tightening Standards, Fed Says
description: Fewer banks tightened their lending standards for companies and consumers in the third quarter as the economy grew for the first time in more than a year, a Federal Reserve survey showed, according to Bloomberg News.

title: Things Publicists Send Us: Up and Away
description: Walt Disney Pictures rarely does things small when it comes to marketing, but this piece of publicity material was as big as a house.

title: The Seducers New Clothes (and Bad Old Ways)
description: In planning New York City Operas comeback 2009-10 season, George Steel, the companys new general manager and artistic director, knew that the budget would allow him just one chance to make a statement with a new production of a standard repertory work. He approached the director Christopher Alden, known for revisionist stagings of the staples, filled with striking, often jarring modern imagery. They chose Mozarts Don Giovanni as a project. They chose well.

title: The Psychology of Needing a Touchdown
description: A reader, CA Giants Fan, made an interesting point in the comment section:

title: Electronic Arts Buys Playfish, a Social Games Start-Up
description: Electronic Arts, the video game company, announced Monday that it had acquired Playfish, one maker of the social-network-based games that have become so popular this year.

title: Power for U.S. From Russias Old Nuclear Weapons
description: MOSCOW  Whats powering your home appliances?

title: The Meaning of Fort Hood
description: The attempt to sort out the meaning of the murderous actions of Maj. Nidal Hasan has consumed numerous blog cycles since Thursday. Does Hasans rampage signal an internal jihadi threat were ill-equipped to thwart, or was it just another meaningless moment of American lone-gunman violence?

title: Shanghai Players Arrive, Driven On by Their Titan
description: SHANGHAI  Just over an hour into a rehearsal here last week, the maestros baton came down like the crack of a whip, and the music screeched to a halt. Long Yu, the imperious 45-year-old conductor of the Shanghai Symphony Orchestra, wanted perfection.

title: Pigs Prove to Be Smart, if Not Vain
description: Weve all heard the story of the third Little Pig, who foiled the hyperventilating wolf by building his house out of bricks, rather than with straw or sticks as his brothers had done. Less commonly known is that the pig later improved his homes safety profile by installing convex security mirrors at key points along the driveway.

title: Showing Them Some Love: Dreamgirls at the Apollo
description: There is a moment at the beginning of this latest revival of Dreamgirls when reality and fantasy mesh, when the actresses performing onstage at the Apollo Theater in Harlem are as excited and anxious about their chance at stardom as the fictional 60s-era singers they portray.

title: Update: Judge Grants Extension in Google Case
description: After the parties to the Google settlement requested an extension on the deadline to submit a revised agreement that would address the concerns of the Justice Department and others, Judge Denny Chin agreed to set a new deadline of Friday, Nov. 13.

title: From the House of the Dead as Literature, Theater and Music
description: With the New York City Opera safely (one hopes) up and running again, the spotlight swings back to the Metropolitan Opera in a season unusually thick with new productions. Next up is Janaceks From the House of the Dead, in a staging by Patrice Chreau that had its dress rehearsal on Monday morning and opens on Thursday evening.

title: Film From the Frontlines: New Glimpses of a War
description: When the Wehrmacht hanged 18 civilians in a World War II reprisal killing in Serbia, tugging on the victims ankles to hasten death, a German propaganda cameraman dutifully recorded the grisly sequence on color movie film. When Russian partisans executed a suspected German spy deep in the forest, that killing, too, was caught on camera.

title: In a Sketchy Hall of Mirrors, Nabokov Jousts With Death and Reality
description: Given the shape of Vladimir Nabokovs own life, its hardly surprising that death  and its cousin loss  permeated his fiction like a potent but noxious perfume.

title: Six Years of Thanksgiving Wisdom
description: Are we really discussing Thanksgiving? People, Im not only talking about it, but Ive already eaten it, and Ive already slurped it down.

title: Critics' Picks: 'The Red Balloon'
description: A. O. Scott reviews the classic 1956 short film directed by Albert Lamorisse.

title: Schuberts Brief Candle, Burning Bright
description: In nearly any consideration of the truly great works that Schubert produced in 1828, the year of his death at 31, worshipful awe and breathless hyperbole go hand in hand. The awe is understandable: it is hard to fathom that pieces like the last three Piano Sonatas, the String Quintet in C and the song collection Schwanengesang, among others, were created in so brief a time and by a composer who probably knew he was terminally ill. The hyperbole can be less fortunate: how does a mere mortal form a personal relationship with art so invariably beatified?

title: From the House of the Dead': Prisoner Dostoyevsky
description: One of the first and best questions about The House of the Dead, I think, is why Dostoyevsky wrote it as a novel, and not simply as autobiography.

title: Woman on Verge of Creating the New
description: It would be easy to reduce The Verge, Susan Glaspells 1921 play, to a feminist tract. Society forces Claire Archer into the boxes it deems acceptable; in attempting to escape those boxes, Claire goes mad. But that summary ignores the works wild heart, which, like its fragile, monstrous heroine, is somehow irreducible.

title: What ever happened to Commie?
description: A curious fact  one that I can attest to based on my own inbox, and is also borne out by more general observation  is that Nazi is the preferred term of abuse from todays right wing. We get signs saying Obama=Hitler, not Obama=Stalin. I get mail calling me a dirty Nazi scumbag, not a Commie or pinko.

title: Katt Williams Arrested After Home Break-In
description: The comedian Katt Williams has been charged with burglary and trespassing and remains in an Atlanta jail after he was arrested on Sunday night on suspicion of breaking into a home, The Associated Press reported. Maj. James Yarbrough of the Coweta County Sheriffs Department told The A.P. that the break-in had occurred at a home in Newnan, about 38 miles southwest of Atlanta, where a homeowner called the police to say Mr. Williams, above, gained entry by breaking into the home, and items were taken from the residence. The name of the homeowner was not given. In July gun charges against Mr. Williams were dropped after an incident in New York in November 2008 in which the police pulled him over for driving a car without license plates and discovered a gun in the car. The comedian sought medical care later that month after he was seen behaving suspiciously in Sumter, S.C., where his family lives. The A.P. said a magistrate was expected to set bond for Mr. Williams at an arraignment on Monday afternoon.

title: Aerosmith Says Steven Tyler Has Quit the Band
description: The sweet emotions that the members of Aerosmith once felt toward one another have apparently come to an end. In an interview with The Las Vegas Sun, the groups lead guitarist, Joe Perry, near right, said the singer Steven Tyler, far right, had quit after a concert in Abu Dhabi. Steven quit as far as I can tell, Mr. Perry told The Sun. I dont know any more than you do about it. Mr. Perry was responding to remarks that Mr. Tyler made in an interview with Classic Rock, a British music magazine, in which Mr. Tyler said he was preparing to focus on a solo career. I dont know what Im doing yet, he said, but its definitely going to be something Steven Tyler: working on the brand of myself  brand Tyler. Mr. Perry said he had had difficulty confirming this with Mr. Tyler because the singer had not returned his phone calls. Hes notorious for that, he told The Sun. Thats one thing Ive learned to live with. I try to overlook it. Aerosmith canceled several concerts over the summer after Mr. Tyler fell from a stage on Aug. 5. A publicist for the band referred questions to its management, which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

title: Easy Win for Football
description: A face-off between the Dallas Cowboys and the Philadelphia Eagles was the No. 1 draw on Sunday as NBCs football coverage easily led the night. Although final audience figures were unavailable on Monday, Nielsens preliminary estimates show the game drew considerably higher ratings than the previous Sunday Night Football game, two weeks ago. That matchup, which was broadcast opposite Game 6 of the American League Championship Series, earned 15 million viewers when final numbers were released, and estimates indicate that this Sundays game may have exceeded 20 million. CBS ranked second for the night with its line-up of 60 Minutes (19.1 million), The Amazing Race (12.9 million), Three Rivers (8.6 million) and Cold Case (8.2 million), as the network received a boost from an overrun of its afternoon football coverage. ABC was third, earning its best ratings for Desperate Housewives (13.3 million), while Fox finished in fourth place with its animated comedies.

title: Musicians Locked Out of tony N Tinas Wedding
description: A long-running theatrical marriage has hit a major bump: a union that represents musicians has filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board, saying the producers of the show Tony n Tinas Wedding had fired its contracted musicians and replaced them with recorded music. Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians said that in 2008 it renewed a three-year agreement with the previous producers of that show, covering its performers through May 2011 with the requirement that it must be honored if new producers came aboard. The union said that the producers Kim and Sonny Ricciardi of Broadway Entertainment, which recently took over Tony n Tinas Wedding, paid the musicians for the Oct. 10 performance and asked them to learn a new song for Oct. 17. On that date, however, the producers locked the musicians out of the performance space, the union said, and they have denied them access to their instruments and other property since then. A representative for Local 802 said a meeting had been scheduled for Monday afternoon to address the dispute. A message left at Broadway Entertainment was not immediately returned.

title: U.S. and Europe Disagree on Sun-Oracle Deal
description: European Union regulators told the Oracle Corporation that its $7.4 billion purchase of Sun Microsystems might break antitrust rules even though the United States authorities have approved the deal.

title: Gourevitch Is to Leave the Paris Review
description: Philip Gourevitch, the New Yorker staff writer who for five years has been doing double duty as the editor of The Paris Review, will leave his editors post in April, The New York Observer reported. In an interview with The Observer, Mr. Gourevitch, left (whose books include We Wish to Inform You That Tomorrow We Will Be Killed With Our Families, about the Rwandan genocide, and The Ballad of Abu Ghraib), said he wanted to focus more on his writing and a new book project about Rwanda. I want to give that everything, he said. You cant take time off when youre in charge. A committee to find Mr. Gourevitchs replacement will be run by Antonio Weiss, the publisher of The Paris Review, and Terry McDonnell, director of the Paris Review Foundation, and include  Robert B. Silvers, the editor of The New York Review of Books, and the author Peter Matthiessen, a founder of The Paris Review.

title: Two Channels Buy Curb Reruns
description: The fictional self of  Larry David, below,  is being sold to two cable channels. Both the TV Guide Network and TV Land have bought the rerun rights to Curb Your Enthusiasm, Mr. Davids HBO comedy. The deal illustrates the TV Guide Networks desire to transform itself from a channel listings service to an entertainment destination in its own right. It acquired repeats of the ABC series Ugly Betty earlier this year. Curb will begin on TV Guide in February. Three or more years later the rights will transfer to TV Land, a classics channel that is seeking 40-something viewers. The Hollywood Reporter said the channels were paying less than $600,000 per episode for the six seasons of Curb.

title: Footnote
description: The Public Theater said it was extending by one week its production of Idiot Savant, the Richard Foreman play that features Willem Dafoe, above, in a variety of coats, duck masks, mouth plugs and imitation rowboats. The play is now scheduled to end its run on Dec. 20.

title: Following in Famous Footsteps at the 92nd Street Y
description: Seventy-five years is a lifetime for many people. But art, as the Donald Justice poem goes, keeps long hours.

title: Five Development Projects to Receive Stimulus Money
description: City officials have chosen five more development projects, one in each borough, to receive tax-free financing through the federal stimulus program.

title: Uncompromising Iconoclast in All Her Forceful Glory
description: The dogged originality and eruptive energy encountered in the music of Galina Ustvolskaya, a Soviet-era Russian composer, are undeniable. Factor in the eccentricity and ego of her public pronouncements, as well as the spiritual streak that runs through her slender output, and you have the stuff of a formidable cult following. But so severe and uncompromising are the products of Ustvolskayas mature style that the Miller Theater, where the music of Iannis Xenakis and Elliott Carter draws capacity crowds, appeared to be just over half full for a Composer Portraits concert presented by the admirable Fifth House Ensemble of Chicago on Saturday night.

title: U.S. and Europe Disagree on Oracle-Sun Deal
description: Oracles acquisition of Sun Microsystems would not be anticompetitive and consumers would have a variety of database products from which to choose, the Justice Departments antitrust division said on Monday, a move that conflicts with a position taken by the European Union.

title: A Classic Minimalist Score, Played at Maximal (and Electronical) Length
description: If you went to Le Poisson Rouge on Sunday evening to hear the Grand Valley State University New Music Ensemble, of Michigan, perform music from its new recording, In C Remixed, you got either more or less than you bargained for, depending on your point of view. The recording, a two-CD set, includes 18 reconsiderations of Terry Rileys classic Minimalist score, In C (1964), by 16 composers, as well as a 20-minute performance of the work itself. Among the selections are new works built on allusions to In C and remixes, radically reconfigured, edited and electronically altered versions of the Riley work.

title: Stateside Home Is Proposed for South Pole Dome
description: A geodesic dome that sheltered scientists and support workers at the South Pole for three decades is due to be demolished in the next few months, having outlived its usefulness at the bottom of the world.

title: Senate Confirms Judge to 4th Circuit
description: The Senate on Monday voted 72-to-16 to confirm Judge Andre M. Davis to a seat on the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, which is based in Richmond.

title: White House, Lobbyists Still at Odds
description: The lobbyists who went to the White House on Monday to complain about the administrations policy of banning them from an international trade advisory board were all seasoned players in Washington. So it should hardly surprise them that the White House has used their meeting for its own purposes, as an opportunity to call attention to the virtues of its no-lobbyist ban.

title: For Elephant Seals, a Restful Downward Spiral
description: Northern elephant seals are long-distance mariners, voyaging for two to eight months at a time without making landfall. And when they are at sea, they spend up to 90 percent of their time on underwater dives.

title: The Table Is a Pedestal, as Performers Improvise
description: Improvisers are always getting themselves into jams. Often the fun of watching them is seeing how they get themselves out. Or fail to.

title: In Shake-Up, Washington Times Ousts 3 Executives
description: The Washington Times has fired three top executives, the paper announced on Monday, and it refused to say whether the papers top editor would also leave.

title: Potentially One Less Tax Penalty for Gay Couples
description: The health care bill passed by the House of Representatives over the weekend eliminates a tax penalty for same-sex couples who receive health benefits from employers, but whether the final legislation will include the provision is another story.

title: Hogwarts Namesake Faces Loss of Status
description: The world seems awash in new dinosaurs these days.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Red Balloon
description: In this weeks critics pick, A. O. Scott asks what it takes to entertain a child. Does it take 3-D, talking animals or CGI?

title: What If Youre Gay? A New Feature.
description: Last month, we explored the many extra costs that same-sex couples incur because their unions are not recognized by the federal government. But wed like that story to serve as a conversation starter. Now that we know the issues  extra health insurance costs, potentially higher tax bills, estate-planning hurdles, to name a few  we plan on exploring them in more detail. Right here.

title: Giants Wilkinson Out 6 to 8 Weeks
description: The Giants announced Monday that Gerris Wilkinson, a linebacker who plays mostly on special teams, dislocated his right wrist Sunday against San Diego and would be out six to eight weeks after surgery.

title: Jurors in Bear Trial  Ask for Evidence, and a Day Off
description: Jurors in the criminal trial of two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers have been deliberating less than a day, but they have already requested several pieces of evidence, the testimony of one witness and even a day off.

title: Womens Curling Team Opens Strong in Ontario
description: The United States womens Olympic curling team won its first tour event of the season, beating Ontarios Lisa Farnell rink 5-2 at the OVCA Fall Classic in Kemptville, Ontario, Canada.

title: A Hunt for Seeds to Save Species, Perhaps by Helping Them Move
description: CHICAGO  Pitchers thistle, whose fuzzy leaves and creamy pink puffs once thrived in the sand dunes along several of the Great Lakes, was driven by development, drought and weevils into virtual extinction from the shores of Lake Michigan decades ago.

title: News of Hockey, 11/9/09: Two Hits to the Head, One Suspension
description: As expected, the N.H.L. announced Monday afternoon that it had suspended Calgary forward Curtis Glencross for three games for a blindside hit that gave the Rangers Chris Drury a concussion on Saturday night.

title: How to Read
description: E-readers like Amazons Kindle have caught on with the small set willing to buy a device just for reading. But pretty soon, most of us will read books  or at least parts of them  on our ubiquitous smartphones. For example, Shortcovers, a Toronto-based company, has created free reading apps for the iPhone, BlackBerry and Palm Pre, as well as for Googles Android phones. There are many free books available. Newer best sellers cost $10.

title: All in the Family (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Mining Company Threatens to Sue a Paper
description: MOSCOW  A major Russian mining company has threatened to sue the countrys leading business newspaper for publishing leaked information before an initial public offering.

title: 24 Hour Plays: Got the Lines? How Bout the Lights?
description: The autograph seekers have been lurking on 42nd Street for quite some time already, one of the staffers at the theater informs me. This is no large gang, but rather just a trio of very eager-looking young men clutching envelopes we believe to be full of pictures of stars who are inside the theater. They stand obediently far enough from the door of the theater to seem nonthreatening, but the unblinking watching of the door is a little disconcerting anyway. Out of the blue, Emmy Rossum exits the theater to head back to her rehearsal studio next door and they bolt toward her (but not before she totally makes a point of saying hi to me!).

title: A Vanishing Diagnosis (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rules on Names Could Bend a Little
description: THE Transportation Security Administration and the airline industry are trying to address public anxiety over how the new Secure Flight identity-matching program will affect travelers. The program is rolling out smoothly, the airlines say.

title: Electronic Arts Plans to Cut 1,500 Jobs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Electronic Arts, the video game company, said it would lay off 1,500 workers and shrink its product lineup, even as it announced that it had acquired Playfish, a start-up that makes online games.

title: Travels in Cyberspace: The Monday Report
description: When it comes to the Sunshine State, coastal cities like Miami, Palm Beach and Fort Lauderdale usually hog the spotlight. That might explain why The Washington Post, in its Florida special issue, turned its attention to the lesser-known Gulf Islands.

title: A Weaker Storm Devastated El Salvador
description: MEXICO CITY  A devastating storm that struck El Salvador over the weekend was not the hurricane that roared through the region at the same time and, in fact, it did not even merit a name  which meant little after at least 140 people were killed when rivers burst their banks and hillsides collapsed under a siege of relentless rain.

title: Bill Clinton Headed to the Hill
description: Former President Bill Clinton will attend the Senate Democrats weekly caucus luncheon on Tuesday to talk about the pending health care legislation, senior Democrats said.

title: A Brand Favored by Muscle Men Wants to Appeal to More Women
description: SALES of vitamins and minerals are projected to grow more than 6 percent this year  to $11.2 billion, from $10.6 billion in 2008  according to Mintel, a market research firm, and that bump may come not in spite of the economic downturn, but because of it.

title: Women Ascend to Iraqs Elite Police Officer Corps
description: BAGHDAD  As one, the stony faces broke into a free-for-all of kisses, hugs and tears on Monday as the 50 women who called themselves the Lioness group became the first female graduates of Iraqs police officer training academy.

title: Poll: Americans Divided on Health Care Overhaul
description: Americans are feeling more doubtful about an overhaul of the health care system than they were in September, according to a new Gallup poll.

title: Tensions in an Iranian Exile Camp in Iraq
description: CAMP ASHRAF, Iraq  There seems, as with many problems in Iraq, no good answer for Camp Ashraf, as tensions here rise and American soldiers get closer to leaving: what to do with the few thousand Iranian dissidents here trained in explosives and proficient with tanks and machine guns who have sworn to overthrow the government in Tehran?

title: New York, Needing Cash, Pursuing Tax Delinquents
description: Desperate for cash amid the worst fiscal crisis in years, New York State is pursuing tax debtors more aggressively than ever before, doubling the number of cases it is investigating and seeking to collect from delinquents ranging from JPMorgan Chase to an out-of-business convenience store on the Bowery.

title: Connecticut Governor Wont Seek Re-election
description: Gov. M. Jodi Rell of Connecticut, who rose to the states highest office five years ago after her predecessor resigned amid a corruption scandal, said on Monday that she would not seek re-election.

title: From 19th-Century View, Desegregation Is a Test
description: WASHINGTON

title: Hinge Is Cited in Big Recall of Strollers
description: A baby stroller company voluntarily recalled about one million strollers Monday after reports that children had had their fingertips severed in a hinge, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said.

title: From the House Leadership, Sighs of Relief
description: From coast to coast, House Democrats on Monday trumpeted their victory in approving the big health care legislation, even as they acknowledged with some trepidation that the fate of the legislation in the Senate is far from certain.

title: As the Nation Grieves Over Fort Hood
description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Battleground in the Health Care Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Money to Fight AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Showcase: Falling Into Place
description: Patricia Lay-Dorsey, 67, wasnt fond of the way she looked. Her wrinkles  the dry creek bed on her face  made her feel uncomfortable. So she made a series of close up portraits of her face. Ms. Lay-Dorsey wasnt fond of her belly or her sagging breasts. So she photographed herself nude. Ms. Lay-Dorsey felt some shame over falling down because of multiple sclerosis. So she documented her daily routine. And, while exposing herself, Ms. Lay-Dorsey noticed something unexpected. Somehow, she said, I began to feel more beautiful.

title: For Taliban Fighters, a Fading Memorial
description: TARAKHEL, Afghanistan  The locals call the place The Taliban Cemetery, a weed-clotted memorial to the men who died for the movement during its fiercest campaigns in the years before 9/11.

title: Rubbish in the Pacific
description: The detritus of human life is collecting in a Pacific Ocean garbage patch that is believed to be twice the size of Texas.

title: Barclays Remarkable Bargain
description: When is a good deal too good?

title: On the Other End of a Hostile Takeover
description: Roger Carr, chairman of Cadbury, the British confectioner, was quick to dismiss Krafts $16.7 billion offer, calling it derisory. No less was expected from the leader of the Cadbury defense team. But its ironic that Mr. Carrs resolve in an earlier hostile takeover battle may well have helped inspire Krafts latest move on Cadbury.

title: Bloggingheads: Climate Change Odds
description: David W. Orr, left, author of "Down to the Wire," and Jim Manzi of National Review debate how much we should do to prevent climate change.

title: Sony to Offer Film on Internet TV, Then DVD
description: In a nod to its vision of the future, Sony will make its animated hit Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs available to consumers directly through Internet-enabled televisions and Blu-ray players before the movie is released on DVD.

title: Zimbabwe: Party Leaders Trial Begins
description: The trial of Roy Bennett, a leader in the Movement for Democratic Change and its choice for deputy agriculture minister, started Monday amid signs that President Robert Mugabe and his ZANU-PF party were continuing to crack down on independent groups they see as political adversaries. In Victoria Falls, where two prominent civic leaders were arrested last month, four trade unionists, including the president of the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions, Lovemore Matombo, were jailed on charges of holding an illegal gathering, said Japhet Moyo, deputy secretary general of the labor federation. In Mr. Bennetts case, his party claims that he is being persecuted and that he faces false terrorism charges. Mr. Mugabe has refused to swear him in as deputy minister in the power-sharing government with the M.D.C. unless he is acquitted.

title: Trustee Seeks Billions for Madoff Investors
description: Jeffry M. Picower, a longtime investor in Bernard L. Madoffs fraud scheme who died in his Palm Beach swimming pool last month, left an estate with assets far in excess of $1 billion  and that could be a spot of good news for Mr. Madoffs victims.

title: Striker Findley Stepped Up and Now May Get Shot With U.S.
description: Robbie Findley has the confidence of youth and the audacity necessary anywhere in the world to be a successful striker.

title: Offering Hope in Haircuts for the Jobless
description: It was clear that Sunday was shaping up to be a rare shot of Indian summer, the ideal day for wandering through a park or lazing around on stoops or eating outdoors. But Theresa Cheung, 27, a fashion designer, had somewhere to be at 9:45 a.m., and a warm, golden day would not deter her. Freakishly perfect days are hard to come by in November, but theyre probably not as hard to come by as a good, free haircut at a New York salon. Theyre also not as useful on a job interview.

title: Australian Insurer Rejects Takeover Bid
description: HONG KONG  AXA Asia Pacific, the Australian unit of the French insurance giant AXA, rejected an unsolicited $10.2 billion takeover bid on Monday that was led by its parent.

title: The Ban on Abortion Coverage
description: When the House narrowly passed the health care reform bill on Saturday night, it came with a steep price for womens reproductive rights. Under pressure from anti-abortion Democrats and the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, lawmakers added language that would prevent millions of Americans from buying insurance that covers abortions  even if they use their own money.

title: Foe of Gay Marriage in New York Says Its Nothing Personal
description: ALBANY  Every Sunday morning, the deep, melodious voice of State Senator Rubn Daz Sr. rumbles across the congregation at his Bronx church. On weekdays, it echoes across the Senate chamber as he rails against Medicaid cuts or abortion. Earlier this year, it enthralled thousands at a boisterous rally against same-sex marriage.

title: Buying One, Buffett Aims to Sell Off 2 Railroads
description: Warren E. Buffett is looking to sell off his stakes in two big railroad companies, even as he recently announced a takeover of Burlington Northern Santa Fe.

title: Week 9 Quick Hits: Skins Are Bad to Bone
description: Andy Benoit has been writing the N.F.L. preview book series Touchdown since age 11. He is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

title: Charles P. Sifton, Judge in City Case on Term Limits, Dies at 74
description: Charles P. Sifton, a federal judge in Brooklyn whose rulings paved the way for women to join the New York Fire Department and for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to run for a third term, died Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 74.

title: In Baseball, G.M.s Meet Amid Signs of Austerity
description: CHICAGO  Baseballs general managers and their staffs arrived throughout the day at the Hilton hotel in OHare International Airport on Monday, most of them walking through subway-style tunnels from the main terminals and up into the lobby. There, the view across the street was not of some lavish Pacific seascape, but of the two main concrete parking lots that serve the airport.

title: Obama Seeks Revision of Plans Abortion Limits
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama suggested Monday that he was not comfortable with abortion restrictions inserted into the House version of major health care legislation, and he prodded Congress to revise them.

title: A Squeeze on Customers Ahead of New Rules
description: Banks are struggling to make money in the credit card business these days, and consumers are paying the price. Interest rates are going up, credit lines are being cut and a variety of new fees are being imposed on even the best cardholders.

title: Opening Up a Crowded Home After a Sisters Death
description: The Fields household is jam-packed.

title: Health Care Debate Moves to the Senate
description: As the health care reform bill moves to the Senate, Democrats will struggle to get the 60 votes needed to open the bill for debate.  David M. Herszenhorn reports.

title: The Iron in the Fog
description: In the downtown dance world, the choreographer Tere OConnor is an essential figure, adored for his exquisitely constructed works, his mentoring and his fiercely articulated beliefs about all things related to dance, writes Claudia La Rocco. His newest work, Wrought Iron Fog, uses different movement styles and a delicately layered score to give a glimpse, the choreographer said, of the beauty you pass by quickly in the day, the iron in the fog. The show opens today at DTW.

title: Life Stories
description: The writer Zachary Lazar is adept at mingling real-life characters  like the Rolling Stones, the director Kenneth Anger and Manson family acolytes  in slightly tweaked situations; Sway, his second novel, reads like your parents nightmare idea of what would happen to you if you fell under the spell of rock n roll, Charles Taylor wrote. In his latest book,  Evenings Empire,  Lazar investigates his own life; its a memoir about the murder of his father. He reads from it tonight at the KBG Bars nonfiction night, alongside  Sonja Livingston, the author of  Ghostbread,  about growing up poor in upstate New York.

title: A New 'City'
description: Cue the farmboy extras:  Cedar City Falls,  a staged soap opera from  the Sex and the City writers, is the sassy, salty story of a Midwestern town, writes Patrick Healy, where neighbors fall in and out of friendship (and bed) with one another and squabble over extramarital affairs, church choir rivalries, missing goats, DNA paternity tests  you know the drill. Produced by Liz Tuccillo (a writer of  Hes Just Not That Into You) and three of her fellow SATC alums, it delivers snappy dialogue and special guest stars (like cast members from  Mad Men  and  Law and Order ) live every Tuesday this month at Galapagos. Go knock back a few beer-tinis.

title: Bible That Vanished on Kristallnacht Is Heading Home
description: On Nov. 9, 1938, a two-volume black-leather-clad Hebrew Bible vanished from a library in Vienna after that citys Jewish community came under assault from soldiers during Kristallnacht, the start of the Nazi pogrom against Jews.

title: Sweets, by Hand and From the Heart
description: Chocolatier  now there is a delicious word a writer doesnt get to use enough. But here is a chance, thanks to Kamila Myzel. A Polish asylum seeker who fled her countrys martial law crackdown before communism collapsed, Ms. Myzel, 50, opened her small sweets shop, Myzels Chocolate, at 140 West 55th Street, with her mother, Alina, in 1990 and has been provisioning Midtowns sucrose-deprived ever since.

title: Children Learn a Maxim in Case an Elevator Gets Stuck: Ring, Relax and Wait
description: It was the New York City version of elementary-school earthquake drills in small-town California: survival skills for vertical living.

title: A Word, Mr. President
description: If I were a close adviser of President Obamas, I would say to him, Mr. President, you have two urgent and overwhelming tasks in front of you: to put Americans trapped in this terrible employment crisis back to work and to put the brakes on your potentially disastrous plan to escalate the war in Afghanistan.

title: Leetch and Lamoriello Take Place in Hall of Fame
description: The longtime Rangers defenseman Brian Leetch; the Devils president and general manager, Lou Lamoriello; and the former Rangers broadcaster John Davidson were among the inductees into the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto on Monday night.

title: The Rush to Therapy
description: Were all born late. Were born into history that is well under way. Were born into cultures, nations and languages that we didnt choose. On top of that, were born with certain brain chemicals and genetic predispositions that we cant control. Were thrust into social conditions that we detest. Often, we react in ways we regret even while were doing them.

title: Justices Consider the Role of Age in Life Sentences
description: WASHINGTON  A majority of the justices at two Supreme Court arguments on Monday seemed inclined to find a way to take account of the age of young offenders in deciding whether they may be sentenced to life without the possibility of parole.

title: Lottery Numbers
Google and Authors Win Extension for Book Settlement
description: A federal judge in Manhattan on Monday granted an extension until Friday for a revised settlement of Googles effort to legalize its plan to create a vast library of digital books.

title: Financier to Head Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Unit
description: Joshua Gotbaum, an operating partner at the investment firm Blue Wolf Capital, is expected to be named director of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation by President Obama, the White House said Monday in a statement.

title: Trustee May Win Billions for Investors in Madoff
description: Jeffry M. Picower, a longtime investor in Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme who died in his Palm Beach swimming pool last month, left an estate with assets far in excess of $1 billion  and that could be a spot of good news for Mr. Madoffs victims, The New York Timess Diana B. Henriques reports.

title: Thought Experiment No. 1, and More Inappropriate Alarm Clocks
description: A short quiz, followed by responses to readers.

title: After Fatal Fire, Many in Queens Denounce Illegal Apartment Conversions
description: After a fire in an illegal basement residence killed three men in Woodside, Queens, on Saturday came the refrain from borough residents: Not again.

title: Associated Name
description: He was always very depressed. I think that if hed been a successful criminal, he would have felt better. You know, he never made the 10 most wanted list. Its very unfair voting; its who you know.  Janet Margolin in todays 1969 theme film

title: The Short Life of a Diagnosis
description: Cambridge, England

title: Surprising Victory in Seattle Mayors Race
description: SEATTLE  A former Sierra Club leader who rode his bicycle to campaign events and relied heavily on volunteer support claimed a narrow and surprising victory on Monday in the race for mayor of this environmentally friendly city.

title: Flames Glencross Suspended Three Games for Hit on Rangers Drury
description: The N.H.L. announced Monday that it had suspended Flames forward Curtis Glencross three games for a blindside hit to Rangers center Chris Drury on Saturday night in Calgary.

title: 24 Hour Plays: Intermission
description: Things got off to a very late start, and by the time introductions were over and the actual plays began it was close to 9 p.m.

title: Fort Hood Struggles With Stressed Troops
description: The attack at Fort Hood, Tex., has focused attention on the level of crime and violence around the base since the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: Giants Bye Week Comes at Opportune Time
description: If the Giants (5-4) keep playing the way they did against San Diego on Sunday, they could win more games than they lose over the final seven and might even make the playoffs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the large gains for Wall Street bankers on stock grants and options awarded last year in lieu of cash bonuses misstated, in some editions, the value of some anticipated compensation, which the Treasury Department mandated be almost entirely in the form of stock. If performance goals are met, 19 executives at Citigroup will split $113 million, not $133 million, in stock this year, and 12 executives at Bank of America will share in $75.6 million, not $78.6 million. The article also misstated, in some editions, the value of the Citigroup options should the share value, which was around $4 on Friday, rebound to $12. The shares would then be worth $340 million, not $400 million.

title: In So Many Words, the N.B.A. Redefined by Bill Simmons
description: It is nearly impossible to write about Bill Simmonss new work, The Book of Basketball, without noting its heft: 697 pages, longer than his hero Bill Russells three memoirs (648 pages), weightier than Wilt Chamberlains two autobiographies (614 pages), but probably less wordy than Hubie Browns verbiage in any single game.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the police officer who shot the suspected gunman at Fort Hood misstated, in some editions, the make of the sports utility vehicle she owns. It is a Chevrolet Tahoe; there is no Ford Tahoe.

title: At Army Base, Some Violence Is Too Familiar
description: FORT HOOD, Tex.  Staff Sgt. Gilberto Mota, 35, and his wife, Diana, 30, an Army specialist, had returned to Fort Hood from Iraq last year when he used his gun to kill her, and then took his own life, the authorities say. In July, two members of the First Cavalry Division, also just back from the war with decorations for their service, were at a party when one killed the other.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the victims of the shootings at Fort Hood omitted the given name of the father of one victim. He is Juan Velez.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a new stock option program for Citigroup employees misstated the total number of options to be dispensed. Citigroup granted between 200 million and 300 million options, not two million to three million. As a result, the article also misstated the value of the options as of the close of trading Friday. The options had an expected value of almost $1.1 billion, not $11 million.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about Rent the Runway, an online dress rental company, reversed the identifications of the companys founders in some copies. Jennifer Hyman is at the left and Jennifer Carter Fleiss is at the right.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions and credits in some editions on Monday with an article about the absence of a playoff system for college football were reversed in some copies. The top photograph showed Jordan Shipley of Texas and was by Brian Bahr of Getty Images. The bottom photograph showed Alabamas Julio Jones after a 73-yard touchdown reception and was by Dave Martin of The Associated Press.

title: Yanks Cashman Wont Be Swayed
description: CHICAGO  Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman made it clear Monday that even if Hideki Matsui and Johnny Damon had gone 20 for 20 in the World Series with 10 home runs apiece, it would not change the teams thinking about how it would deal with the two impending free agents.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a new lead producer for the coming Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, the troubled production that has ceased selling advance tickets, misidentified the firm that is handling those sales. It is Ticketmaster, not Telecharge.

title: N.H.L. Scores: A Goal From Toews in Return to Blackhawks
