description: One game on Monday, the night of the Hockey Hall of Fame induction ceremonies: the Los Angeles Kings, whose iconic player, Luc Robitaille, was among those being honored at the Hall in Toronto, vs. the Chicago Blackhawks, whose young captain Jonathan Toews was returning to action after missing the six previous games with a concussion. Home teams  er, home team listed first:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with a dance review about the Cave New York Butoh Festival misidentified the performer in Furnace, which opened the festival. She is Stephanie Lanckton  not Ximena Garnica, an artistic director of the festival.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a newly published oral history of Joseph Papp and the Public Theater misspelled the surname of a collaborator who helped Papp create the theater. He is Bernard Gersten, not Gerstein.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Saturday about New York City Operas opening-night gala, using information provided by the company, misstated the title of one of the songs performed. It was Soliloquy, not Billys Soliloquy, from the musical Carousel.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Navies of 2 Koreas Exchange Fire
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Naval patrol boats of North and South Korea exchanged fire in disputed waters off the western coast of the Korean Peninsula on Tuesday, the South Korean military said.

title: When Women Rule, Things Are Just as Complicated
description: In the future foreseen in What Once We Felt, a new play by Ann Marie Healy that opened on Monday night at the Duke on 42nd Street, men are extinct, but Makers Mark is still readily available.

title: Retirees Still Liable for Alimony, Massachusetts Court Rules
description: BOSTON  The highest court in Massachusetts ruled Monday that alimony should not automatically end when the paying spouse reaches retirement age and stops earning income.

title: Antonio Luis Alves de Souza, Brazilian Drummer, Dies at 54
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Antonio Luis Alves de Souza, who led Olodum, a Brazilian percussion band notable for its social work as well as its music, and who lent his distinctive rhythms to a Paul Simon album and a Michael Jackson video, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Salvador da Bahia, Brazil. He was 54.

title: Environmental Agency Warns 2 Staff Lawyers Over Video Criticizing Climate Policy
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has directed two of its lawyers to makes changes to a YouTube video they posted that is critical of the Obama administrations climate change policy.

title: Douglass Time May Have Arrived
description: Toney Douglas had his back turned to the news media as he slowly got dressed after the Knicks 95-93 loss to the Utah Jazz on Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Mets Will Look to Spend  On the Right Players
description: CHICAGO  Omar Minaya arrived at the general managers meetings with a specific shopping list for the off-season, and one that wont surprise many people. The Mets need a thumper and a starting pitcher, badly.

title: Democrats Raise Alarms Over Health Bill Costs
description: WASHINGTON  As health care legislation moves toward a crucial airing in the Senate, the White House is facing a growing revolt from some Democrats and analysts who say the bills Congress is considering do not fulfill President Obamas promise to slow the runaway rise in health care spending.

title: Counting Forward
description: More than three weeks after the official deadline, Iraqs Parliament has approved an election law. That is very good news. It will allow Iraqis to hold parliamentary elections in January. And it should make it easier for President Obama to meet his pledge to withdraw all combat troops by the end of August.

title: You Dont Want to Be Downwind
description: More than eight years after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the House of Representatives has passed a bill to shore up security at this countrys chemical plants. The requirements are reasonable, vital and long overdue. If terrorists were to attack a chemical plant near an American city or large town, they could unleash a toxic cloud that could endanger the lives of hundreds of thousands.

title: Promises on Open Space
description: In 1965, Congress came up with an elegant idea: Use some of the royalties from offshore oil and gas drilling to buy and conserve open space threatened by development. The dollars raised from depleting one natural resource would be used to protect another. Since then, the Land and Water Conservation Fund has invested more than $13 billion and added more than five million acres to the national parks, wildlife refuges and national forests.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Goes Public With Leukemia Fight
description: In addition to his signature sky hook and a legacy of winning at every level, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was known for his stamina and fitness. During a 20-year N.B.A. career that included six championships and six Most Valuable Player awards, Abdul-Jabbar had one serious injury, a broken wrist. Other than that he had enjoyed a healthy career.

title: As Knicks Look Ahead, the Present Sours Quickly
description: The Knicks are in a state of suspension, harboring a clear plan for the future with no one to bridge the gap. While they wait to sign someone from the heralded 2010 free-agent class, this season is quickly passing them by  even in its early stage.

title: On Assignment: Fowl, but Photogenic
description: Chickens?

title: Tweets Are Coming to LinkedIn
description: Twitter continues to spread its wings across the Web.

title: Korean Navies Skirmish in Disputed Waters
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North and South Korean naval vessels exchanged fire in disputed waters off the western coast of the Korean Peninsula on Tuesday, leaving one North Korean vessel engulfed in flames, South Korean officials said.

title: Are High-Tech Prostheses Fair?
description: The Issue

title: Suffragettes Stone Lord Mayors Inaugural
description: Wednesday, Nov. 10, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Few Can Avoid Deployment, Experts Say
description: No matter how much a member of the armed services dreads being sent to a war zone, there is no easy option for an early discharge  especially when deployment is near.

title: Trick for Democrats Is Juggling Ideology and Pragmatism
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats have displayed a striking degree of pragmatism in seeking to push the health care bill through Congress, embracing or rejecting ideological considerations as needed to keep the legislation moving.

title: Report Says Foster System Keeps Children Too Long
description: Margaret, a 15-year-old, was placed in five different foster homes in a single year. Calvin, 18, spent 15 years being shuttled among his mother, aunt and a residential treatment center. Devin, a 13-year-old, has been in foster care his entire life, even though he wants to be adopted.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,350 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 905 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

title: Evelyn Hofer, Subtle Photographer of People and Places, Dies at 87
description: Evelyn Hofer, a photographer whose searching, exactingly composed portraits imparted a grave serenity to her human and architectural subjects and who collaborated on a renowned series of travel books with eminent writers in the 1950s and 1960s, died on Nov. 2 in Mexico City. She was 87 and lived in Mexico City.

title: 24 Hour Plays: And That Was That
description: Three more short plays went off without any noticeable glitches in the second act of the 24 Hour Plays (a curious one, a funny one and a very naughty one), and then it was off to a huge post-show bash at a nearby club. How are these people still standing up?

title: 'Dreamgirls' at the Apollo
description: Backstage photos of the national tour of Dreamgirls, which opens at the Apollo Theater in Harlem.

title: Working From Memory
description: WHO is the man in this photo?

title: Amid I.P.O. Slide, Korean Bourse Attracts Listings
description: Even as Hong Kong begins to show signs of I.P.O. fatigue, several foreign companies have turned to Seoul, and are seeking to list their shares on South Koreas secondary stock market in a bid to tap liquidity there, the operator of the bourse said Tuesday.

title: California: Promise to Speed Naturalization Applications
description: Immigration authorities have agreed to complete 90 percent of naturalization applications from immigrants in Southern California within six months, in a lawsuit settlement that was approved by a federal judge in Santa Ana. The suit was filed in 2007 by the National Immigration Law Center and the American Civil Liberties Union, on behalf of immigrants seeking to become citizens whose applications had stalled for years because of delays with background checks. As a result of the suit, the court required the F.B.I. and Citizenship and Immigration Services to report regularly on their progress in reducing backlogs nationwide. Linton Joaquin, general counsel for the law center, said the agencies had significantly reduced the backlogs, with about 400 cases remaining in the Los Angeles area covered by the settlement.

title: Word of the Day | sanctimonious
description: sanctimonious  \saN(k)-t-mo-ne-s, -nys\  adjective

title: News Quiz | November 10, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Cadburys Cold Response to Kraft
description: Kraft took its $16.7 billion bid for Cadbury, the British chocolate and chewing gum maker, directly to shareholders on Monday after the Cadbury board rejected the offer as too low, Julia Werdigier and Michael J. de la Merced write in The New York Times.

title: Big Week for Small-College Players
description: Some of the biggest plays Sunday were made by players from some of the nations smaller football programs.

title: Morgan Stanley Seeks Buyer for Stake in China Bank
description: Morgan Stanley is seeking a buyer for its 34 percent stake in an investment bank, China International Capital Corporation, Wei Sun Christianson, the American banks China chief, said on Monday.

title: Cadbury Chief Knows Both Sides of Hostile Bids
description: Roger Carr, chairman of Cadbury, the British confectioner, was quick to dismiss Krafts $16.7 billion offer, calling it derisory. No less was expected from the leader of the Cadbury defense team. But its ironic that Mr. Carrs resolve in an earlier hostile takeover battle may well have helped inspire Krafts latest move on Cadbury, Breakingviews.com says.

title: Barclays Remarkable Bargain
description: In the panic that swept the financial world last year, Lehman Brothers went bankrupt, and Barclays bought its securities for about $45 billion in cash. Now, some creditors to Lehmans estate are saying that is about $5 billion less than they should have gone for, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: The TASC Deal: A New Old-Fashioned Buyout?
description: The private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and General Atlantic are going back to the future with their latest buyout. They are buying Northrop Grummans defense consulting division, TASC, for $1.65 billion.

title: South Korea Considers Allowing Poison Pills
description: South Korea, where foreign funds have increased their holdings in some large companies stocks, is seeking to introduce a poison pill scheme to protect companies from being taken over.

title: Japan Pledges $5 Billion in New Afghan Aid
description: HONG KONG  Japan said Tuesday that it would sharply increase its nonmilitary aid to Afghanistan, pledging $5 billion for a range of projects that include building schools and highways, training police officers, clearing land mines and rehabilitating former Taliban fighters.

title: Sands Seeks $3.3 Billion in Hong Kong I.P.O.
description: Shares of Las Vegas Sands rose 7 percent on Monday after the casino operator said it would look to raise up to $3.35 billion through an initial public offering of shares in its Macau business.

title: Tweets Are Coming to LinkedIn
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: BioVex Said to Raise Another $30 Million
description: BioVex, a Woburn, Mass.-based biotechnology company that raised $40 million in venture capital in March to develop a novel cancer-fighting treatment, plans to announce Tuesday that it has raised another $30 million, The Boston Globe reported.

title: Financial Regulations Chief Chides British Banks
description: Many senior banking executives failed to accept responsibility for the financial crisis and neglected the need to change their behavior, Hector Sants, the chief executive at Britains financial industry regulatory body, said Monday.

title: Electronic Arts Buys Playfish  and Plans Layoffs
description: Electronic Arts, the video game company, announced that it had acquired Playfish, a start-up that makes online games, even as it said it would lay off 1,500 workers and shrink its product lineup.

title: Talbots Said to Tap Perella to Advise on Debt
description: Talbots, the womens clothing chain, has hired the boutique adviser Perella Weinberg Partners to help it refinance about $225 million in debt, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people familiar with the situation.

title: Market Rally Continues in Asia
description: If the economy is getting stronger, why is the dollar getting weaker?

title: Soshokukei Danshi
description: A Japanese term  herbivorous males  used to describe men who choose to engage in traditionally female pursuits.

title: Are Dark Movies OK For Kids?
description: When it comes to the movies, many adults would like to shield children and teens from difficult material, while others believe that watching dark movies is entirely appropriate  and even beneficial  for kids. What do you think? What kinds of movies do you like to watch, and why?This seasons movies for children include Where the Wild Things Are, Fantastic Mr. Fox and Christmas Carol, all of which explore dark themes and contain scenes that some may find frightening. Times movie reviewer A. O. Scott wonders whether including darker content in childrens films is not only appropriate, but also desirable. He considers the interesting controversy that has enveloped Where the Wild Things Are, and expanded into the latest wide-ranging adult argument about the feelings of children:

title: Two to Fill Wassersteins Shoes at Lazard?
description: It seems Bruce Wassersteins shoes may be too big to be filled by just one person.

title: Former Wal-Mart Chief Joins P.E. Firm
description: Wal-Marts former chief executive, Lee Scott, has taken a position at the private equity firm Solamere Capital.

title: Blue Wolf Exec to Head U.S. Pension Agency
description: Update | Nov. 13, 5:29 p.m. Joshua Gotbaum, an operating partner at the private equity firm Blue Wolf Capital, is expected to be named director of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation by President Obama, the White House said Monday.

title: American Airlines Chief Brings JAL Battle Public
description: Gerard J. Arpey, the chief executive of the parent of American Airlines, said that Japan Airlines would take a risk and suffer financially if it broke ties with American to join an alliance with Delta Air Lines.

title: Attack of the Home Buyers Tax Credit
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: A New Home for Film in Amsterdam
description: On the harbor directly across from Centraal Station, a symbol of Amsterdams next cultural evolution is rising from the ground  and, by sometime in 2011, cinephiles in the city will be rejoicing.

title: Giants Stadium Countdown: Sehorns Interception
description: John Maxymuk, author of The 50 Greatest Plays in New York Giants Football History, is helping us count down to the final game at Giants Stadium. His latest book is Quarterback Abstract.

title: Cisco Announces $5 Billion Debt Sale
description: Cisco Systems, the worlds largest maker of computer networking equipment, said Monday it would sell three series of senior unsecured notes worth a total of $5 billion.

title: SAC Finds No Suspicious Trading, Report Says
description: SAC Capital Advisors, run by Steven A. Cohen, has reviewed trading documents cited in the Galleon Group insider-trading case, but the hedge fund has found nothing suspicious, Bloomberg News reported, citing one of SACs investors.

title: HSBC and Barclays Earnings On Different Tracks
description: Britains two largest banks painted a strikingly different picture of their businesses in the third quarter Tuesday when HSBC said earnings rose as loan provisions fell, and Barclays reported the opposite.

title: Qatar Fund to Sell Up to 25 Million VW Shares
description: Qatar Holding, part of the Gulf countrys sovereign wealth fund, plans to sell as many as 25 million of its preferred shares in Volkswagen, or about half its total stake in the carmaker, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Museum Piece
description: A look at the artwork of the Swiss artist Pipilotti Rist.

title: Why Paper Receipts Wont Die
description: Todays idea: Paper receipts are vestiges of the analog past and ought to go the way of the dodo bird, a writer says. But they probably wont any time soon because of the expense and privacy concerns.

title: Wild Kingdom | Barber Osgerby for the Rug Company
description: Our fun-for-all-ages winter issue of T Design and Living is out, but the great designs for the young, not to mention the young at heart, just keep coming. (Stay tuned for more later in the week.) Case in point: the four witty, whimsical rugs that the London designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby have done for the Rug Company. Colorful and graphic, each rug depicts a different member of the animal kingdom and reflects its nature, from the solitary owl against its night-sky background to an acid-green snake that seems to slither off the edge of its rug. A pair of butterflies and an adorable school of fish round out the designs, which cost $3,285 or $4,725, depending on size. Barber Osgerbys designs have the playful simplicity of childrens-book illustrations, but theyre so sophisticated that youll likely be seeing them in grown-up rooms, too.

title: In Trial, Marriage Settlement Haunts Ex-KB Chief
description: A federal judge in Los Angeles has rebuffed an effort by the former chief executive of the building giant KB Homes to exclude materials related to his marriage settlement and other evidence during his upcoming trial for allegedly manipulating stock options.

title: Cuban Says Fans Ask Him to Buy Dodgers
description: After failing to snag the Chicago Cubs, Mark Cuban is apparently still keeping his eye out for a baseball team to add to his stable.

title: Better Cards From Credit Unions
description: When I read articles about aggressive price increases among the big players in the credit card industry, like the one Andrew Martin and Lowell Bergman wrote for the front page of Tuesdays New York Times, I often wonder why consumers who borrow money using plastic are dealing with these card issuers in the first place.

title: Hedge Funds to Top $2 Trillion in 2010?
description: The hedge fund industry may streak past its $2 trillion record high by the end of next year, as improved returns have lured back investors, said Barry Bausano, Deutsche Banks global co-head of prime finance.

title: Sampler: S-Curve Warnings, No Library Fines in Hayward, Lion Eats Sheep
description: Bay Bridge Changes | After Mondays fatal big rig crash on the bridge, authorities will add more reflective striping and install radar boards telling drivers how fast they are going in an effort to slow them down.

title: Lloyds to Cut Another 5,000 Jobs by 2011
description: Lloyds Banking Group, the bailed-out British lender, plans to cut 5,000 additional jobs by the end of 2010 as it continues to overhaul its operations and integrate HBOS, Reuters reported.

title: European Antitrust Inquiry Into Reuters Data Feed
description: European Union antitrust regulators launched an investigation on Tuesday into news and financial data publisher Thomson Reuterss use of its real-time market data feed, saying it might block users moving to rival firms.

title: Accel Partners $1 Billion Day
description: Monday was a good day for Accel Partners.

title: Why McMahon Voted No on Health Care Bill
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. phoned him midafternoon on Friday. A few hours later, in the early evening, President Obama called, carrying the same message. The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, had been pushing him for days. So had the House majority leader, Steny H. Hoyer.

title: What to Watch Tuesday: Health Care Elsewhere, NCIS and Ghost-Hunting
description: PBSs Frontline offers a timely repeat of a 2008 program called Sick Around the World (PBS, 9 p.m. on most stations). In one fast-moving hour, it examines the health care and insurance systems of five countries, including Britain, Japan and Germany, and makes the case that supporters of health-care reform in America have failed to make over the last year. A review of the program is here.

title: Gloomy Energy Report Sets the Stage for Climate Talks
description: As the world heads for tough negotiations over a global climate deal next month, an influential forecasting agency said on Tuesday that current energy policies were not sustainable, and that a vast transformation of energy use was required to fend off the worst consequences of global warming.

title: Wanted: Grateful Dead Archivist
description: The unemployment rate may top 10 percent, but there is an opening at the University of California, Santa Cruz, for a Deadhead. The library is advertising for an archivist to handle the librarys Grateful Dead collection. A masters degree in archives management is required, as is expert knowledge in the history of and scholarship of contemporary popular music, or American vernacular culture, preferably the history and influence of the Grateful Dead.

title: More Weary Words
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: More Weary Words
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Blinkin
description: Parody | Malcolm Gladwell explains Christmas, in a sendup of the Tipping Point author by Craig Brown in Vanity Fair:

title: Wall St. Takes a Breather and Shares Close Flat
description: A day after a spirited rally sent the Dow to its highest levels since the beginning of the financial crisis, Wall Street took a moment to breathe, with stocks showing little or no gains on Tuesday.

title: Carrying On
description: Video | A grip quip that can nip a trip in the bud:

title: Early Word: Fort Hood Service
description: President Obama heads to Texas on Tuesday to attend a memorial service at Fort Hood, the site of last weeks shootings.

title: Connecting Cars to Avoid Speeding Tickets
description: PARIS  Car-to-car communication is a dream of traffic researchers. Radar, video and other sensors in a car would understand the environment around it and communicate such information as sudden braking, rainfall and speed to the receptors in other cars, enabling other drivers to avoid accidents and congestion.

title: Car Bomb Adds to Toll in Northwest Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  The third bomb in three days went off in a crowded intersection in a town in northwestern Pakistan on Tuesday, killing at least 34 civilians and offering a grim marker of the mounting violence around the northwestern Pakistani city of Peshawar.

title: Another View: A Smarter Way to Regulate
description: Ron Resnick, a co-founder of the financial consulting firm CounselWorks, contends there is a smarter way to regulate hedge funds.

title: Amazon and Agents: Friendly Chat or Workaround
description: On Monday, news came that Amazon, the behemoth of the book industry, was bumping knees with book agents. According to Matthew Flamm at Crains New York Business, the online retailer flew a dozen of New Yorks top literary agents out to its headquarters in Seattle for a friendly chat and to suggest that its aggressive discounting of books and sales of e-books is designed to help the business of publishing, not destroy it.

title: Financing Challenges for Geothermal Power
description: With just over 70 operating plants offering capacity of around 3,100 megawatts, the United States is the global leader in generating electrical power from geothermal resources, according to a recent report from Islandsbanki, an Icelandic bank that provides investment and financial services to the sustainable energy sector.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: The Rules on Names Could Bend a LittleThe Transportation Security Administration and the airline industry are trying to address public anxiety over how the new Secure Flight identity-matching program will affect travelers.

title: Rubn Daz Sr., Outspoken and Unpredictable
description: Every Sunday morning, the deep, melodious voice of State Senator Rubn Daz Sr. rumbles across the congregation at his Bronx church. On weekdays, it echoes across the Senate chamber as he rails against Medicaid cuts or abortion. Earlier this year, it enthralled thousands at a boisterous rally against same-sex marriage.

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, Nov. 10
description: Highlights from todays media coverage:

title: Entrepreneurs in Congress Say No to Health Care Reform
description: Yes, Virginia, there are entrepreneurs in Congress  11 of them, in fact, were elected to the 111th Congress,* as best as we can determine. And, whether Republican or Democrat, they overwhelmingly voted against the health care reform bill that passed late Saturday night. Heres a roll call:

title: The plural of anecdote is data
description: For various reasons Ive been doing a lot of walking around the past few days, in both Princeton and New York, visiting areas I havent looked at for several months. And Im not sure what to make of it, but casual observation suggests a stronger recovery than anything I see in published numbers. Lots of small-scale construction  home remodeling, tear-downs replacing old houses. Many new businesses and restaurants filling storefronts that were vacant a couple of months ago.

title: Twitter Book and Now Twitter TV Show
description: Justin Halpern, the author of a rather tartly named Twitter account, has landed a book deal and a deal with CBS for a comedy based on the premise. Mr. Halperns Twitter account, rendered here as (Stuff) My Dad Says, has 700,000 followers. According to The Hollywood Reporter, Mr. Halpern signed a book deal with HarperCollins last month and CBS decided there must be a television show in there somewhere.

title: In War There Are No Unwounded Soldiers
description: Long before Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan gunned down dozens of soldiers in Fort Hood, Tex., Cynthia Thomas had warned of the dangers of combat stress.

title: Answers About Investor Behavior  Part 5
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which youll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals on a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Chicken, Yes. Best, Maybe. Roasted, No.
description: On the sign outside Las Americas Restaurante on East 180th Street in the Bronx, three cartoon birds sizzle on a spit next to a promise spelled out in capital letters: BEST ROAST-CHICKEN.

title: Turnips, Lemons, and a New Contract With Finance
description: Across Europe, the financial regulators are getting louder in their criticisms of banks, not only for behavior that led to the financial crisis, but also more recent and ongoing activity.

title: Depression multipliers
description: Barry Eichengreen and Kevin ORourke have lately been scoring a series of research coups, based on the combination of historical perspective and a global view. Most famously, they showed that on a global basis the first year of the current crisis was every bit as severe as the first year of the Great Depression.

title: A City Block Draped in Masking Tape
description: Sam Bassett, an artist living in the Hotel Chelsea, hangs long strands of masking tape along city blocks and calls it art.

title: Wavering Congressmen
description: Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC:You sound like a bunch of people who heard they just got free health care.

title: Study Analyzes Food Waste in Britain
description: A new report from Britain has found that more than $20 billion of consumable food and drink is throw away in the country each year.

title: Timing Krafts Race for Cadbury
description: Krafts formal offer for Cadbury on Monday once again highlights the differences between the U.S. and British takeover systems I have previously highlighted.

title: Well, That Was Easy
description: Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: The health-care reform bill has passed by the House. Well, that was easy. And you know what that means  its just one step away to being defeated by the Senate.

title: A Big Episode
description: Monologue |  Aired Monday night on NBC: First lady Michelle Obama appears on Sesame Street to celebrate the shows 40th anniversary. Its going to be a big episode. Yes, sources say the episode gets a little tense when Ernie and Bert ask the first lady why her husbands dragging his feet on gay marriage.

title: Dimming Star of Giants Prospect, Now Out on Bail
description: Until this fall, Angel Villanola, 19, was living up to his potential  the same potential that other Dominican ball players have shown in the U.S. Then in September, he was accused of shooting and killing a man in a bar.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused stories appear in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Armey of ignorance
description: In the midst of a seriously disgusting interview with Dick Armey, the former House majority leader offers his analysis of the financial crisis:

title: Answers About the Home Buyers and Homeowners Tax Credits
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which youll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Excerpts of an Interview With Yu Long
description: By David Barboza

title: From the House of the Dead': What About Those Animals?
description: O.K., Dwight, Ill bite. Lets hear about those dogs and geese and the goat.

title: Wanted: New Lead Singer for Aerosmith
description: Know any dudes who look like ladies? Aerosmith is looking for a new lead singer, the band announced late Monday, via the guitarist Joe Perrys Twitter stream. The announcement follows an interview that the bands frontman, Steven Tyler, gave to a British music magazine in which he said he was interested in pursuing a solo career, working on the brand of myself  Brand Tyler.

title: Bronx Film Screening Fosters Nostalgia for the Coops
description: Eighty years ago, the United Workers Cooperative Colony in the Bronx was more than just a housing complex for an enclave of secular Jews  many of them communists, socialists, anarchists and their sympathizers. The Coops, as this community of two square blocks is commonly called, once housed their own restaurant, gym, youth clubs, grocery store and day care center. Built next to the spacious Bronx Park, the Coops still have lush gardens in their courtyards and the hammer and sickle adorning the doors.

title: From the House of the Dead': Dostoyevskys Beasts
description: Dostoyevsky and his animals! Theres a Ph. D. topic in here for someone.

title: An Uncomfortable Truth
description: JURM, Afghanistan  I got a lesson on a recent reporting trip in northern Afghanistan in what not to say to a mullah.

title: Fresh Demands From Front-Line States in Climate Fight
description: The climate divide between countries that are rich and poor, insulated from climate impacts and vulnerable to them, was on vivid display in the Maldives over the last few days. Countries that consider themselves most threatened by human-driven global warming  mainly places exposed to the sea or reliant on rainfall  concluded a forum there and issued a declaration of their concerns and demands. Mike Shanahan of the International Institute for Environment and Development sent the text, which I have included below.

title: Now Listening | The XX, Basic Space
description: How long does it take for the Next Big Thing to actually become a big thing? Weve been hearing whispers about the London band the XX since late summer, when they released their superb debut album, XX, in Europe  and a whisper is the appropriate register for this music, with its wispy vocals and sparse arrangements that echo a range of styles from old-school soul to modern-day trip-hop. The records October release stateside brought more praise (including this from The New York Times); and a month-long United States tour, kicking off tomorrow in New York, may be just what the band needs to bring the whispers to a roar.The four-piece band already seems wise beyond its years (each member is barely 20 years old), and for the video for their first single, Basic Space (above), they made a clever choice in hiring Anthony Dickenson, an up-and-coming British director and photographer. Dickenson recently picked up a UK Music Video Award for this music video from Speech Debelle and is currently at work on a photo project that will be exhibited next year. The Basic Space video warrants watching in high definition  its a cool experiment with light, speed and focus that fits perfectly with the XXs minimalist aesthetic.

title: Parade of Poor Play
description: Ever since the Yankees won the World Series, I have been receiving messages from fans around the world deploring the domination by New York and its cable television swag.

title: President, at Service, Hails Fort Hoods Fallen
description: FORT HOOD, Tex.  President Obama took on the role of national eulogist on Tuesday for the first time since assuming office as he led the country in mourning 13 active and retired soldiers gunned down not on a foreign battlefield but here on their home post by one of their own.

title: Sesame Street Fill-In
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first four paragraphs of this article from the Arts section, Same Street, Different World: Sesame Turns 40.  Use your own words, or click read more to choose from a scrambled list of the words that were removed.

title: Travel Deals: Holiday Fare Sale
description: Airline experts have warned that airfare will be soaring this holiday season. But there are exceptions: Expedia is offering a Holiday Fare Sale for travel between Nov. 19 and Jan. 4, with round-trip fares as low as $102.

title: Inside Out | Forging Ahead
description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

title: Hoodie Magic Wears Off for McDaniels
description: Perhaps the most significant development of the latest Monday Night Football game was the severe devaluation of the hoodie. Just a few weeks ago, Broncos Coach Josh McDaniels was the latest genius from the Bill Belichick family of geniuses and the one brave enough to mimic the masters taste for haute couture. Now, well have whatever Steelers Coach Mike Tomlin is wearing, please. If the master himself loses to the Colts this weekend, the hoodie might find its way back to the clearance rack at Big Lots. And the fashion world will rejoice.

title: Tropical Storm Ida Weakens as It Moves Ashore
description: MIAMI  Tropical Storm Ida brought heavy rain and gusty winds to the Gulf Coast on Tuesday, arriving in Dauphin Island, Ala., just before dawn then weakening as it moved northeast through the Florida panhandle.

title: City Prepares for Law Allowing Bikes in Buildings
description: In less than a month, office buildings in New York will begin to fill with bicycles. A new law requiring building managers to allow riders to take their bikes upstairs will go into effect on Dec. 11, and already, the citys Department of Transportation is offering commuters some guidance on what to expect.

title: The Massive Maclaren Recall
description: In announcing a recall of about one million strollers yesterday, the Maclaren stroller company has illustrated yet again that its not nice to mishandle parents online.

title: Fiasco Theaters Cymbeline, Round 2
description: At any given moment dozens of fledgling theater groups are trying to get noticed in New York City. Most fail. But a company called Fiasco (fiascotheater.com) made enough of an impression with its first full-scale production, a rousing Cymbeline in September, that it is already bringing it back for an encore.

title: Twitter Book and Now Twitter TV Show
description: Justin Halpern, the author of a rather tartly named Twitter account, has landed a book deal and a deal with CBS for a comedy based on the premise. Mr. Halperns Twitter account, rendered here as (Stuff) My Dad Says, has 700,000 followers. According to The Hollywood Reporter, Mr. Halpern signed a book deal with HarperCollins last month and CBS decided there must be a television show in there somewhere. Read more on Media Decoder. . .

title: What Is Next for Cals Jahvid Best After Horrific Fall?
description: The latest debate over how to treat concussions in football circulates around California running back Jahvid Best, who made a terrifying flop into the end zone during a game against Oregon State on Saturday.

title: The Rules of Cancer
description: Kathryn Gurland has learned about the intricacies of cancer through her work as a medical social worker and therapist. But Ms. Gurlands knowledge is also uniquely personal. Her older sister Judi learned that she had melanoma at age 46 and died eight months later. Her younger sister Peggy, who never smoked, received a diagnosis of nonsmall-cell lung cancer and died 14 months later, just shy of her 45th birthday.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Democrats raise alarms over health care costs.

title: Classical cloture
description: Apropos of nothing: for travel reading, Im currently working my way through Tom Hollands Rubicon: The Fall of the Roman Republic. And it turns out that back when men were men and women were property, they had ways of dealing with obstructionist tactics from the legislative opposition:

title: Masking-Tape Art, With One Vehement Critic
description: In the New York art world, it is hardly surprising that some young upstart artist is the talk of his neighborhood because of his public art project along 23rd Street, from Seventh to Eighth Avenue.

title: Sniper Who Killed 10 Is Executed in Virginia
description: WASHINGTON  John A. Muhammad, whose murderous shooting spree in the fall of 2002 left at least 10 dead, was executed at a Virginia state prison on Tuesday night.

title: Dodd Seeks Single Regulator for Banks
description: Update | 12:38 p.m. The New York Timess Stephen Labaton provides more details about Senator Dodds proposal.

title: Senate Plan Would Expand Regulation of Risky Lending
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Senate banking committee proposed a financial overhaul on Tuesday that included consolidating bank regulators, creating a consumer financial protection agency and imposing new restraints on exotic financial instruments and credit rating agencies.

title: Amys Bread Cookbook, the Bakers Cut
description: Amy Scherber is coming clean.

title: The Job Market in Charts, III
description: For your enlightenment, dark as the numbers may be, here are more visual representations of the job market, from around the Web.

title: Wrestler Director to Take on Ballerinas
description: The filmmaker Darren Aronofsky is moving from the ring to the barre for his next project. Mr. Aronofsky, who directed The Wrestler, will focus on ballet dancers in Black Swan, described as a supernatural thriller that stars Natalie Portman and Mila Kunis as rival ballerinas. The film will be co-financed and distributed by Fox Searchlight, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

title: The Big-Play Promise of DeSean Jackson
description: Chase Stuart, a lawyer, Jets fan and statistical analyst who writes for the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog, will contribute a weekly entry to the Fifth Down:

title: States Compete for Federal School Dollars
description: DENVER  Colorados lieutenant governor, Barbara OBrien, has been parsing every public statement by Education Secretary Arne Duncan for nuances that could help her position the state as a winner in the $4 billion competition for federal school dollars known as Race to the Top.

title: Olympus Debuts a Follow-Up to the E-P1
description: Olympus has launched a successor to the slick-looking (but flawed) PEN E-P1 that addresses some performance issues and includes new features like a bright electronic viewfinder (EVF) and much faster autofocus.

title: Dame Edna vs. Michael Feinstein, Continued
description: The brouhaha continues. Over the last few weeks, Dame Edna Everage and Michael Feinstein have been duking it out  or rather, their publicists have  over the similar names of their forthcoming Broadway shows. (Mr. Feinstein: All About Me; Dame Edna: Its All About Me. Both begin previews on March 6.)

title: Free Wi-Fi in the Sky
description: Flying during the holidays is never fun. But a couple of airlines are trying to brighten up the process with a gift of free Wi-Fi access at 10,000 feet.

title: Renovations for Adventure Playgrounds Completed
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: A Device Dedicated to Dedicated Tweeters
description: If you have an overwhelming need to tweet your every move, youll have a hard time resisting TwitterPeek, a device that looks like a little like those low-cost phones designed with texting in mind, but it only sends messages to Twitter (of course, it lets you read them too).

title: Dunn Leaves White House Communications Post
description: Anita Dunn, the White House communications director who has tangled very publicly with Fox News, is leaving the White House at the end of the month. Her deputy, Dan Pfeiffer, will replace her, a senior White House official said Tuesday.

title: In Americans Daily Diet: Nearly Five Hours of Television
description: These numbers never cease to amaze.

description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the chairman of the banking committee, on Tuesday proposed to dramatically overhaul the regulatory system by consolidating bank agencies, creating a consumer financial protection agency and imposing new restraints on exotic financial instruments and credit rating agencies. Read the story in Business Day.

title: Elizabeth Kolbert cant say that, can she?
description: Superfreakingly brilliant review of Superfreakonomics by Elizabeth Kolbert. She captures the essentially reprehensible aspect of the exercise perfectly:

title: The S-Curve: Must Engineers Assume Drivers Will Behave Badly?
description: The S-curve on the Bay Bridge: its one of those places where engineering logic intersects with human behavior. There are no stop signs and a lot of crashes at that intersection.

title: State Senate Delays Vote on Same-Sex Marriage Bill
description: ALBANY  The fate of same-sex marriage collided with the often-dysfunctional political process here on Tuesday as the State Senate delayed a vote on a bill that would make it legal for gay and lesbian couples to marry in New York.

title: Infinitis Essence, Designed by Marketing
description: In March, Infiniti unveiled the Essence concept car at the Geneva auto show. Like most concept cars, the Essence is sleek, sexy and stuffed with especially wistful machinery, including a 592-horsepower 6-cylinder engine and collision avoidance technology.

title: Denzel Washington to Star in Fences on Broadway
description: Another major film star is heading to Broadway: Two-time Academy Award winner Denzel Washington will play Troy Maxson in a revival of August Wilsons Fences in late spring of 2010, according to an executive involved with the production.

title: Poppy Palaces
description: Grand houses in Afghanistan, built on the profits of opium production and its associated corruption.

title: Powder Sent to 3 U.N. Foreign Missions
description: A white powder was mailed to three United Nations foreign missions in Manhattan office buildings on Monday, but no one was harmed by it, the police said.

title: Blankfein Says Goldman Is Simpler Than Rivals
description: Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, argued Tuesday that his bank was easier to manage than its bigger rivals, and he defended Goldman against proposals to break up the biggest banks.

title: Jock Art | Andy Warhol Polaroids
description: There is a small gem of a show at Danziger Projects right now, featuring a little-known trove of Polaroids by Andy Warhol of famous athletes. They were commissioned by one collector in the late 1970s and early 80s. The simplicity of Warhols method  straightforward portraits shot with the Big Shot camera  gives the tiny images (4 1/4 x 3 3/8) a purity and sincerity that belies the radiance and aura of greatness coming from the sitters. Even today, there is something tingle-inducing about seeing Muhammad Ali, Dorothy Hamill, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Chris Evert, Pel, Tom Seaver and Wayne Gretzky captured at the height of their youthfulness and fame. These portraits, made by the ultimate connoisseur of fame himself, have aged beautifully. The show is up through Dec. 12 at 534 West 24th Street.

title: An Evening Wine Bar Is Set to Open at Bouley Bakery
description: The white corner room of Bouley Bakery an elegant space where customers can eat breakfasts and lunches they purchased in the bakery, will morph into a wine bar during the evening, starting Nov. 17.

title: Minorities in Iraqs North Seen as Threatened
description: ERBIL, Iraq  The policies and tactics of Kurdish authorities could expose minority groups in northern Iraq to another full-blown human rights catastrophe unless the minorities receive better protection, according to a report released Tuesday by Human Rights Watch.

title: No Boost in PC Sales After Windows 7
description: Did you put off buying a new computer after the launch of Microsofts Windows 7 operating system?

title: Are Too Many Students Going to College?
description: The editors of The Chronicle of Higher Education have posed that potentially incendiary question and asked a collection of experts to engage in a rolling conversation in response. You can read the dialogue, which was posted Monday, by clicking here.

title: App of the Week: A Streamlined Social Mash-Up
description: Dedicated social networkers practically have a full-time job jockeying a phone browser around Facebook, Twitter, texts, and who knows what else. But app makers are building virtual assistants to streamline those tasks. You may have seen ads for the Motorola Cliq with Motoblur, which consolidates all your communications on one screen.

title: For G.M., Work at Opel Includes Mending Fences
description: A week after angering German politicians and labor leaders by calling off plans to sell Opel to a group backed by Berlin, senior General Motors executives promised more independence for the European unit.

title: Parting Glance: Evelyn Hofer, 1922-2009
description: Evelyn Hofer, 87, was a flawless technician and a much sought-after teacher, who searched for an inside value, some interior respect in the people she photographed. She favored carefully composed scenes with a still, timeless aura, William Grimes notes, in reporting her death on Nov. 2.

title: Divided Landmarks Panel Splits Decision on Midtown Buildings
description: After hearing objections from a property developer that is trying to build a tall luxury hotel opposite Carnegie Hall, a divided Landmarks Preservation Commission voted on Tuesday to give landmark protection to the century-old B. F. Goodrich Building in Midtown Manhattan, while shelving a proposal to give the same protection to a nearby eight-story building.

title: Opt-Out Proposal Puts State Leaders to the Test
description: ATLANTA  In the two weeks since the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, embraced a proposal that would allow states to opt out of a new government health insurance plan, state leaders have begun debating whether to take part, and the question has emerged as a litmus test in some campaigns for governor.

title: Update: Another Tough Night for Leno
description: Another Monday, another night of low ratings for Jay Leno.

title: Video of the Pikes Peak Audi TTS in Action
description: Last week, we reported on the autonomous Audi TTS being developed by a team from Stanford University, Volkswagens Electronics Research Lab and Sun Microsystems.

title: N.Y. Senate Delays Vote on Gay Marriage Bill
description: The Timess Jeremy Peters reports that the New York State Senate has indefinitely postponed a vote on the gay marriage bill. See full article.

title: A Rabbinical Student and the Ring
description: Yuri Foreman, an undefeated professional boxer who will fight for the World Boxing Association 154-pound title, is studying to become a rabbi.

title: Bomb Material Cache Uncovered in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With fertilizer bombs now the most lethal weapons used against American and NATO soldiers in southern Afghanistan, the bomb-making operation in Kandahar was something close to astonishing.

title: Letterman Suspect Wanted to Sell, Not Extort, Lawyer Says
description: Robert Joel Halderman was simply trying to sell a story, not extort money, when he delivered a one-page screenplay proposal and other evidence to David Letterman in September about Mr. Lettermans affairs with women who worked for him, according to Gerald L. Shargel, Mr. Haldermans lawyer.

title: Know Your Market Before You Leap
description: While it is hard to argue with Peter Druckers much-quoted aphorism that the purpose of a business is to create and keep a customer, it does raise a question. What is the best way to discover whether customers want what youre selling before you open your doors or before you add a new product or service to your line?

title: Ads That Pat on the Back, or Slap on the Wrist
description: Liberal interest groups in favor of overhauling the health care system are taking different tacks in trying to advance their goals, at least as far as advertising goes.

title: The Morning Skate: Will General Managers Act on Head Shots?
description: The N.H.L. general managers are meeting today and tomorrow in Toronto and David Shoalts in The Globe and Mail writes, Head shots will dominate the agenda, although he thinks that adopting an on-ice penalty directed at them is still a long shot.

title: New Models for Environmental Communication
description: Even as the old thats the way it is model of mass media is increasingly tested by the Web, there are interesting experiments under way that show how far-flung, yet important, issues like marine pollution can still be effectively covered. One surfaced today in a Science Times article by Lindsey Hoshaw, known on Twitter as @thegarbagegirl. The feature is an up-close examination of the Pacific Oceans vast patch of plastic flotsam, reported with travel money provided by readers of Spot.us.

title: The Dusenberry Diary: Living the Dream? Or Just Living?
description: As some of you will recall, I have been following the progress of (and offering advice to) Debbie Dusenberry, the owner of a home-furnishing and gift store in Kansas called Curious Sofa. You can read When Passion Meets Math to see how Ms. Dusenberry built her store, garnered lots of media attention for her merchandising, ran smack into the Great Recession and began the journey from artist to businesswoman. This small-business journey is far more common than most people understand. Ms. Dusenberry is so good at the artistry that she is envied by other owners, one of whom has called her retail royalty. But as you will see in a moment, her retail reality is very different.

title: Talks Begin to Move The 39 Steps Off Broadway
description: The Broadway producers of Alfred Hitchcocks The 39 Steps have opened negotiations to move the quick-witted play to the Off Broadway venue New World Stages next year, according to the shows lead producer, Bob Boyett. The 39 Steps is scheduled to close on Broadway on Jan. 10 after almost three years.

title: A Lift for a Planned  Financial Protection Agency
description: The creation of a Consumer Financial Protection Agency got another lift with its inclusion in a sweeping overhaul of the financial regulatory system proposed Tuesday by Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut and the chairman of the Senate banking committee.

title: Art Show Shines Light on Sex Traffickings Victims
description: The room is recreated with exquisite attention to detail: a scribbled price list for sexual services on a whiteboard. A large bowl with condoms spilling onto the end table. Half-used lipstick scattered among twisted thongs, high heels and toilet paper. A sickly perfume-type smell that clings to the torn wallpaper. A grimy stained bed designed to shudder under the weight of invisible, moving bodies. Mens voices that alternately issue commands and groans.

title: Can the World Reach an Agreement on Climate Change?
description: Over the last three months, The New York Times has been asking stakeholders for their thoughts and predictions for on the climate change meeting in Copenhagen.

title: Should the Government Pay People to Work Less?
description: My colleague Steven Greenhouse wrote last June about the record for work-sharing programs. Under such programs, employers reduce their workers weekly hours and pay. The government then pays workers some, or all, of their lost wages. The best-known work-sharing program is in Germany, but other developed countries have adopted it, as have many American states.

title: A Photo Essay of Multiple Sclerosis
description: The Lens blog is featuring a moving photo essay of self portraits taken by Patricia Lay-Dorsey, 67, who learned in 1988 that she has chronic progressive multiple sclerosis. James Estrin, a photographer for The New York Times who wrote an accompanying story about Ms. Lay-Dorsey, explains:

title: Remarks of President Barack Obama
description: Remarks of President Obama, as Prepared for Delivery for the memorial service at Fort Hood, Tex.

title: Judge Rules Shepard Fairey Can Get New Lawyer
description: The street artist Shepard Fairey has won the right to a new lawyer in his ongoing suit against The Associated Press over the image that became his celebrated Barack Obama Hope poster. In a pretrial hearing, U.S. District Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein also allowed that lawyers for The A.P. can depose Mr. Fairey and his outgoing lawyers before the end of the year, The A.P. reported. The agency and the artist are countersuing each other over the rights to the image, a photo taken in April 2006 at an event at the National Press Club in Washington. Mr. Fairey recently admitted that he had lied publicly and to his own lawyers about which image he had used, which caused them to abandon his case.

title: Former Astronaut Makes Plea Deal
description: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the former astronaut whose drive to Florida from Texas to confront a romantic rival briefly dominated the news and late-night comics routines, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to felony burglary of a car and misdemeanor battery as part of a plea bargain.

title: Officials: U.S. Aid Chief Chosen
description: After months of delays because of tangled vetting procedures, the Obama administration plans to name Rajiv J. Shah as the administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, officials familiar with the appointment said on Tuesday.

title: This Birth Annnouncement Coming to You Live from the Delivery Room
description: If you want to relive the magic or trauma  or both  of childbirth, you might want to check out the live streamed (now recorded) birth of Solveig, who was born on a live streaming video. Lynsee, his mother, is a former teacher and she decided to have her baby on live web video as an educational gesture. (She is a saint during the whole process, which may explain her generous nature.)

title: On Saturday, Rabbi-to-Be Throws Jabs
description: Yuri Foreman stepped up to the top bench of the banya to embrace the soothing power of the heat. The beads of sweat bubbled and greased his skin. He shuttered his eyes and felt the problem immediately. The sauna was too hot.

title: Cultural Bent Hangs Over Oracles Battle for Sun
description: Oracles battle with European regulators over its acquisition of Sun Microsystems boils down to a conflict about the importance of free software and the governments role in protecting it.

title: Getty Institute Will Work With Egypt to Conserve King Tuts Tomb
description: The Getty Conservation Institute in Los Angeles said on Tuesday that it had entered into a five-year partnership with Egypt to help conserve and manage the tomb of Tutankhamen, whose striking wall paintings have been pocked with brown spots at least since the tombs discovery in 1922.

title: Berth of a Cruise Ship: Worlds Biggest Gets a Home
description: When the Oasis of the Seas, the worlds largest cruise ship, departed Finland on its maiden voyage on Oct. 30, it barely squeezed under Denmarks Great Belt Bridge, with less than two feet to spare. There will be no such close calls when the Oasis, owned by Royal Caribbean International, docks in its new home, Cruise Terminal 18, a huge complex that opened Nov. 8, at Port Everglades, Fla.

title: A Minimalist Christens a New Space
description: PARIS | Lucio Fontana was so handy with a knife he could probably have made a living as an old-school hit man. Instead he became an artist, and a pivotal one at that. Through what he called his concetto spaziale, or spatial concept, he exerted a huge influence on 20th-century modernist art.

title: 10 Years of Selling Books in an Online Age
description: The seemingly endless recession, the growing attraction of Kindles and the steady shuttering of bookstores gave the owners of one bookstore in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, even more reason to celebrate today. Theyre still open.

title: There Are Three Kinds of Fool
description: Todays idea: There are three types of fool, an essay says, and no ones immune: Youre one, at one time or another. Sometimes its even smart to play the fool.

title: Now Serving | PDTs Humm Dog
description: What do you get when you cross a hot dog with a four-star chef? A Humm dog.

title: Phelps Falters at a Meet in Stockholm
description: Michael Phelpss presence on a United States team competing this week at a World Cup meet in Stockholm is akin to Meryl Streeps gracing a traveling production of Mamma Mia! Phelps, a 14-time Olympic gold medalist, is a headliner among up-and-comers on the national youth World Cup team.

title: Train the Mind to Run Right Through Winter
description: IN late summer, Sharon Henderson, the manager of the Lululemon athletic clothing store in my town, started organizing Saturday morning group runs. People had two options: three miles at a slower pace or six miles at a faster one.

title: Backwater Borders and the Hikers Accused of Spying on Iran
description: Three graduates of University of California, Berkeley have been accused by the Iranian governments top prosecutor of spying. The three were arrested after crossing into Iranian territory during a hike in northern Iraq at the end of July.

title: From the House of the Dead': And the Visuals for Dostoyevsky?
description: The goat and the dog would be easy enough to get on stage, if Janacek had written them into the opera (preferably without the slaughter), and even the horse.

title: Intel Sells Its Own Reader for the Health Care Market
description: Intels push into the health care arena has the company going some unusual places.

title: Obamas Remarks at Ft. Hood Service
description: On the eve of Veterans Day, President Obama spoke on Tuesday at the Ft. Hood memorial service for the victims of last weeks shootings. Here is the text of his remarks.

title: 2 Bear Stearns Fund Leaders Are Acquitted
description: It was, prosecutors claimed, a clear case of Wall Street crime  and a chance to bring to account two culprits of the subprime age.

title: From the House of the Dead': The Directors Style
description: To most culture-friendly Americans, Patrice Chreau, the French director of the Metropolitan Operas new production of Janaceks opera From the House of the Dead, is probably best known as a movie director with an eclectic, adventurous style and exotic tastes.

title: Bear Stearns Managers Acquitted of Fraud Charges
description: Louis Lanzano/The Associated Press The former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers Ralph Cioffi, left, on Monday and Matthew Tannin on Tuesday.

title: From Concrete to Memory: Scrapbooking the Berlin Wall
description: Overview | How can we best understand how and why historical events happened, as well as how and why they are significant? In this lesson, students consider how ordinary citizens contributed to and experienced the fall of the Berlin Wall. They then develop scrapbooks depicting how people experienced the wall and use the books as symbolic bricks in building a classroom Berlin Wall.

title: From Peaceful Gettysburg to the Battlefield of Iraq
description: Two surprises are in store for those who tune in to Return to Duty on Wednesday night on MTV.

title: So You Think You Can Balance the Budget?
description: So you think you can balance the budget?

title: Iraqi Skeleton Athlete Taking Another Shot
description: Faisal Faisal, who tried to qualify in skeleton as Iraqs only Winter Olympian in 2006, is racing again this season and trying to qualify for the Vancouver Games.

title: A Cheap Nest for Fledgling Firms
description: When Lindsay Napor expanded her Manhattan-based development company earlier this year  moving out of free work space provided by an investor  she turned to the most logical place for the companys new offices: New Jersey.

title: Blair Hails Economic Steps in West Bank
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Palestinians marked two significant economic breakthroughs on Tuesday, counterpoints to the growing crisis in peace negotiations with Israel: a second cellphone company opened, with a planned investment of hundreds of millions of dollars; and a long-closed crossing point from Israel opened to limited motor traffic.

title: Letterman Suspect Wanted to Sell, Not Extort, Lawyer Says
description: Robert Joel Halderman was simply trying to sell a story, not extort money, when he delivered a one-page screenplay proposal and other evidence to David Letterman in September about Mr. Lettermans affairs with women who worked for him, according to Gerald L. Shargel, Mr. Haldermans lawyer.

title: In the Caribbean, Good Deals but Not a Fire Sale
description: AFTER a year of dismal bookings and deep discounts, travel to the Caribbean is beginning to pick up, allowing resorts to be more selective with sales this year. But its still possible for travelers to nab a deal, especially if theyre flexible.

title: Bill Clinton Urges Fast Action by Senate Democrats
description: Former President Bill Clinton joined Senate Democrats for their weekly luncheon on Tuesday and urged them to band together and quickly pass health care legislation.

title: Plunging Though Musical Thickets and Open Plains
description: During chamber music concerts, even if the whole performance is first-rate, there is sometimes one riveting moment in which the ensemble seems particularly cohesive. When the excellent Keller Quartet made its debut at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday afternoon, that moment came in the slow movement of Beethovens String Quartet in F (Op. 135).

title: Kerik Released on Bail to Await Sentencing
description: WHITE PLAINS  Former Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik was released on bail Tuesday, five days after pleading guilty to eight felonies that included tax fraud and lying to White House officials.

title: Prognosis: Lingering Pain After Surgery for Breast Cancer
description: Breast cancer patients often experience pain that persists long after surgery, and a new Danish study has found that the problem affects a large proportion of women. Almost half the patients reported chronic pain two to three years after treatment, and more than half reported discomfort.

title: Kitsch of the Day | The Weezer Snuggie
description: No single piece of clothing says neutered invertebrate or cult member quite like the Snuggie (the blanket with sleeves!). For more than a year, these large, shapeless swaths of cheap fleece designed for lying on the couch and working the remote have inexplicably remained fixed in the kitsch cultural firmament. There are fan tribute sites, YouTube homages and pub crawls; Oprah, Ellen and Al Roker have worn them on camera. Most incredible of all, more than five million have been sold.

title: British Premier Is Bowed by Mother of Slain Soldier
description: LONDON  Some public figures seem to do no wrong, deflecting scandal and potential misfortune as adroitly as if they were sheathed in Teflon jumpsuits. Prime Minister Gordon Brown is a Velcro politician, the kind who, it appears, can do no right.

title: Performa 09: Tacita Dean and Merce Cunningham
description: In the second week of its three-week run, Performa 09 is unfolding at a fast and furious pace. Redefining the concept of over-booking, it is serving up more than any one person can see. The events Ive managed to attend have ranged from great to less than, and run the gamut in terms of production values. It was production values to fore on Saturday in Tacita Deans sleek, gorgeously majestic Craneway Event, a 16mm color film that was unexpectedly hypnotic at St. Marks on the Bowery. Her second collaboration with the choreographer Merce Cunningham is a slow-moving documentary (100 minutes) of a rehearsal in the cavernous, many-windowed craneway of a refurbished factory in northern California. Ms. Deans themes center on the ineluctable movement of light  and to some extent the camera  through time and space. A great artist still at work at the end of his career, surrounded by acolytes and ever-deepening shadows, is the perfect subject for her relentless, elegiac art.

title: Bill Clinton Urges Senate Democrats to Pass Bill Quickly
description: At our Prescriptions blog, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and David M. Herszenhorn detail the visit by former President Bill Clinton with Senate Democrats over the health care legislation. Afterward, Mr. Clinton described his message, saying that he concluded by noting that it would be worse to do nothing and that no bill is perfect.

title: Fly by Wire
description: Prologue: The Inquest

title: Correction:
description: The Practical Traveler column on Oct. 18, about deals available before the holidays in Mexico, Scottsdale, Ariz., and Florida, omitted part of the terms of a Walt Disney World offer of free dining with a five-night package from Oct. 1 through Nov. 24 and Nov. 29 to Dec. 17. The package had to be booked by Sept. 26.

title: The Author Artist
description: The new issue of the Web journal Open Letters Monthly features a cover portrait of Marguerite Duras by the Swedish artist Carl Khler, who died in 2006. Its a pretty cool image  a sketchy double exposure showing Duras both as an old woman and in the prime of her life, with blocks of color that make it appear as if shes emerging ghostlike from the gloom  but the main thing that caught my attention was the painters name. Ive been looking at a lot of Carl Khlers author portraits lately. Earlier this year, the Brooklyn Central Library mounted an exhibition of them, which I missed, but after the show left Brooklyn for Washington, I heard from its curator (and the artists son), Henry Khler, who forwarded a batch of his fathers work. Khler was a neo-modernist who especially liked to paint writers and intellectuals: Kafka, Beckett, Joyce, Gide, Beauvoir, all in a rough, haunting style that captured their writerly moods as much as their physical appearances. The exhibition will travel early next year to Toronto and Vancouver, but you can peek at some of Khlers paintings in a slide show, here.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 1 about libraries with rare-book collections open to the public misstated the period of time covered by Oscar Wildes college notebook, at the William Andrews Clark Memorial Library in Los Angeles. It was written during 1876 and 1878, not 1876 and 1978. And because of an editing error, the article rendered incorrectly part of the Latin title of Galileos Starry Messenger, at the Linda Hall Library of Science, Engineering and Technology in Kansas City, Mo. It is Sidereus Nuncius, not Sidereus Nucius.

title: Audrey Saunders Opening L.A. Bar with Mark Peel
description: In the four years since she opened the Pegu Club on Houston Street, Audrey Saunders has become the godmother of the New York cocktail scene. You could draw a diagram connecting every reputable young bartender in town back to either Pegu or one of Sasha Petraskes bars, or both. The whole scene can feel a little inbred. Not to mention self-serious.

title: A Cool Pilot, but the Plane Was Cooler
description: Uplift sells better than unpleasant facts, which is why, I suppose, William Langewiesches new book, Fly by Wire, has been published with an upbeat subtitle (The Geese, the Glide, the Miracle on the Hudson) rather than with the more cynical one its publisher initially intended to use. That original subtitle, The Truth About the Miracle on the Hudson, more accurately reflects this gripping books contents.

title: A Few Additions to Enhance Bits
description: We know you love Bits, but we also know The New York Times is not your only source of technology news.

title: Ahead of Copenhagen Climate Talks, Voices of Hope and Discord
description: With just under a month remaining before negotiations over a new global climate treaty get under way in Copenhagen, discord rules the day.

title: Wishful Drinking and Circle Mirror Transformation Extend Runs
description: Update | 12:08 p.m. Carrie Fishers one-woman Broadway show, Wishful Drinking, has been extended for two weeks and will now close on Jan. 17, 2010, the Roundabout Theater Company announced on Tuesday afternoon. Ms. Fishers autobiographical monologue, based on her book of the same title, opened on Oct. 4 to strong reviews and performed well, if not spectacularly, at the box office during most weeks.

title: Mary Travers Is Praised for Her Voice and Words
description: Mary Travers of the 1960s folk group Peter, Paul and Mary, who died on Sept. 16 at 72, was remembered on Monday night for both her music and her part in awakening the political consciousness of the baby-boomer generation.

title: Europes Challenge to Oracle Deal Has Deep Roots
description: Oracle has spent much of the past decade lobbying to get European Union regulators to force one of its biggest competitors, Microsoft, to loosen its iron-like grip on software code and other intellectual property.

title: Strong Starts for George Lopez and Wanda Sykes Shows
description: George Lopez created some big noise with his entry into the late-night competition Monday night, attracting more than 3 million viewers and faring better among many young audience groups than many of the established late-night stars.

title: Gongs, Bamboo Flute and the Unexpected From China
description: Coming to grips with a great deal of unfamiliar contemporary music is a lot to ask of any group of musicians, but the New Juilliard Ensemble seems to take such things in stride. Consider the concert the group presented on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall: Composers Living and Working in China Today, among the final offerings in Carnegie Halls extensive festival Ancient Paths, Modern Voices. The concerts placement made sense: when better to assess where Chinese composers are now than after several weeks of hearing what came before them?

title: Removing a Barrier
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  This city, which once moved rivers to create a new urban design, is now moving a major highway away from its downtown and opening up approximately 20 acres for development. This newly accessible area is within walking distance of Providences historic waterfront and commercial downtown.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Nov. 10
description: For all of the conflict that swirls around any legislature  particularly one as famously balky as New Yorks  there are relatively few images of direct confrontation; those moments that encapsulate all the battles waged behind the scenes. But Nathaniel Brooks captured such an instant on Tuesday (Slide 5), made even richer by the fact that one of the subjects, State Senator Rubn Daz Sr., had just been profiled on the front page of The Times because of his stand on gay marriage, the issue in question.

title: Flutist Evokes Poetry, Passion and Politics
description: To celebrate her 40th anniversary this season as a performer, the flutist Carol Wincenc devised a lively program for her appearance at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening, featuring works inspired by (among other things) the singing of a humpback whale, a nun who campaigns against the death penalty and Hasidic melodies.

title: Obama at Fort Hood for Memorial Service
description: President Obama addressed the Fort Hood community on Tuesday at a memorial service for the 13 current or retired soldiers killed in attack. (Video: MSNBC)

title: News of Hockey, 11/10/09: A K.H.L. Town Worse Off Than Detroit
description: If you think the Detroit Red Wings and the Nashville Predators have been buffeted by hard times, consider Lada Togliatti of the K.H.L. The club, from the southeastern city on the Volga, has been on financial life support the entire season because its main sponsor, the Russian automaking giant AvtoVaz, is near bankruptcy. Now Ladas players, whose paychecks are overdue for a second straight month, have threatened to stop playing until they get their wages.

title: Times Square Enters the Wi-Fi Age
description: Times Square is wallpapered with more than three dozen giant screens, which serve a range of functions, from disseminating news and streaming television to promoting earthly delights like candy and beer. But there hasnt been one that allowed visitors to check e-mail, read restaurant reviews or buy tickets to a Broadway show.

title: When Parents Disagree
description: Stephanie Klein and her husband, Phil, are at it again  fighting in public on her well-trafficked blog.

title: Tierneys Bid to Keep Control of Philadelphias Newspapers Gets a Boost
description: The struggle for control of the bankrupt Philadelphia newspapers took another sharp turn on Tuesday, as a Federal judge reversed an earlier ruling and removed a crucial advantage wielded by the bankers who want to become the papers owners.

title: Properties for $800,000
description: Properties in Burien, Wash., Lynchburg, Va., and in Albuquerque.

title: A Pairing of Bruckner and Glass Makes a Test
description: It takes only a moments reflection to recognize the musical appropriateness of juxtaposing works by Philip Glass and Anton Bruckner. Both composers trade in large-scale, sometimes numbingly repetitive explorations of rudimentary harmonies. Both tend to work in big structural blocks, often shifting abruptly from one to another.

title: Fort Hood Shooter
description: NBC reports on intelligence officials saying that they knew Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan had contact with a radical Muslim cleric overseas.

title: European Union Struggles to Select New Leaders
description: BRUSSELS  Days after securing the landmark treaty that will lead to the naming of the European Unions first president, the bloc has lapsed into horse-trading-as-usual over the position  the kind of maneuvering that has often yielded the kind of bland leadership that the new presidency was supposed to overcome.

title: Morgan Stanley Sees Possible M.&A. Rebound
description: Colm Kelleher, the chief financial officer of Morgan Stanley, said Tuesday that mergers and acquisitions appeared likely to rebound next year as the financial markets improve.

title: Saving New Orleans Culture, One Sandwich at a Time
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: What You Get for ... $800,000
description: BURIEN, WASH.

title: Lover of Birds and Opera Leaves Millions to Both
description: Mona Webster, a lighthouse keepers daughter who lived in Edinburgh and died in August at 96, had a love of birds, and warblers in particular  of the human kind. She demonstrated that affection by leaving most of her fortune to the Metropolitan Opera and a nature charity in Britain.

title: Ghost Hunters Seeks Spirits and Ratings
description: Jason Hawes and Grant Wilson are searching for ghosts. They walk toward a hallway inside Waverly Hills, a Kentucky sanatorium that attracts paranormal investigators like themselves.

title: Madoff Homes for Sale, Now at Discount Prices
description: While Bernard L. Madoffs beach house in Montauk, N.Y., sold quickly for more than the $8.75 million asking price, his other properties are not doing as well. After nearly 60 days on the market, the United States Marshals in charge of the sale of Mr. Madoffs home in Palm Beach, Fla., and his Manhattan penthouse have needed to cut their prices.

title: Honoring the Fallen
description: Victims of the Fort Hood tragedy will be honored Tuesday in a memorial service attended by President Obama and the First Lady. NBC Video.

title: Historic Sounds of Newport, Newly Online
description: As the future of the Newport Jazz and Folk Festivals continues to unfold, its recorded past has suddenly been thrown open.

title: Murdochs Google Gambit
description: On Sunday, the day before the 20th anniversary of fall of the Berlin Wall, Rupert Murdoch appeared in an interview on Sky News in Australia, and promised to erect pay walls around all his companys Web sites and then block Google from searching and linking to them.

title: Columbia Professor Charged With Punching University Employee
description: A Columbia University professor has been charged with assault and harassment after an another Columbia employee accused him of punching her in the eye at an Upper West Side bar Friday night.

title: A Home That's 'Something Different'
description: Roman Rutkowski, 37, an architect with his own practice in Wroclaw, Poland, built a two-story 120-square-meter (1,300-square-foot) house in the prestigious Krzyki neighborhood on the south side of town.

title: Senators Back Panel on Deficit Reduction
description: The Senate budget committee chairman said a group of lawmakers would agree soon to a proposal for a bipartisan commission to force reductions in federal deficits, hoping to attach it either to must-pass legislation raising the nations debt limit or, failing that, to the pending health care bill.

title: Blackwater Said to Pursue Bribes to Iraq After 17 Died
