description: WASHINGTON  Top executives at Blackwater Worldwide authorized secret payments of about $1 million to Iraqi officials that were intended to silence their criticism and buy their support after a September 2007 episode in which Blackwater security guards fatally shot 17 Iraqi civilians in Baghdad, according to former company officials.

title: In Poland, Modern Among Traditional
description: WROCLAW, POLAND  Set among prewar traditional villas and a smattering of 1970s boxy apartments is the architect Roman Rutkowskis home, a simple, rectangular bunker with an unpainted all-wood exterior, and even plainer interior with concrete floors and particleboard walls.

title: No Consensus on Financial Crisiss Legacy for City
description: The financial crisis that struck the country more than a year ago may have hit the hardest where it started: New York.

title: Abortion Debate Divides Democrats
description: NBC examines the central role of abortion funding in the heathcare reform bill.

title: A Prisoner With New Questions
description: Ian McKellen had already read the script of a new version of the late-1960s cult television series The Prisoner when he met the author, Bill Gallagher, last year at a London restaurant to discuss the project. As Mr. Gallagher recalls their first encounter, Mr. McKellen hugged him, then gently patted him on the head and asked, What goes on in that mind of yours, Bill?

title: No Regrets for Cao
description: The sole House Republican to vote in favor of the health care legislation, Representative Anh Cao of Louisiana, said in an interview Tuesday that he had been getting some pretty nasty responses.

title: Logitech Breaks Into Videoconferencing
description: In a move to break into the videoconferencing market, Logitech International has agreed to buy LifeSize Communications, a start-up that makes high-definition videoconferencing equipment, for $405 million in cash.

title: After the Bird, Everything Else Is Secondary
description: YOU know how it is with family during the holidays. One smart remark and someone leaves the table in tears.

title: Show-Off Sides to Rival the Pull of a Drumstick
description: A PERSON can only take so much.

title: Viewers Love Dancing
description: A two-hour installment of Dancing With the Stars attracted 17.6 million viewers on Monday, helping ABC rank No. 1 on the night as the most-watched network, according to Nielsens estimates. Although that reality show dominated the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots, ABCs Castle lagged behind CBSs CSI: Miami in the 10 p.m. hour with 10.7 million viewers compared with 13.8 million for the CBS crime show. ABC also struggled in the demographic most prized by advertisers, viewers 18 to 49, finishing third in that age group behind CBS and Fox, whose medical drama House delivered the nights top ratings in the 18-to-49 set. House earned a more modest 12.8 million total viewers at 8 p.m., while Foxs Lie to Me drew 7.5 million at 9. Second-place CBS garnered its highest ratings at 9 with its comedy Two and a Half Men (14.1 million). NBC was a distant fourth on the night with Heroes at 8 (5.3 million), Trauma at 9 (5.4 million) and The Jay Leno Show at 10 (4 million).

title: Getty and Egypt to Work on Tuts Tomb
description: The Getty Conservation Institute in Los Angeles said on Tuesday that it had entered into a five-year partnership with Egypt to help conserve and manage the tomb of Tutankhamen, above, in the Valley of the Kings, near Luxor, whose striking wall paintings have been pocked with brown spots at least since the tombs discovery in 1922. King Tut has magic that we must conserve for future generations, Zahi Hawass, secretary general of Egypts supreme council of antiquities, said in a statement. The first two years of the project will involve studying the condition of the tomb and examining the spots, whose nature and origin have never been determined. Then a conservation plan will be carried out and documented, along with a plan for long-term monitoring of the condition and maintenance of the entire tomb, including policies for regulating the number of visitors, said Tim Whalen, director of the conservation institute.

title: Faux Ma Po Tofu
description: Last week, everything came together for a weird, accidental, successful vegan take on ma-po tofu.

title: Twitter Book and Now TV Show
description: Justin Halpern, the author of a rather tartly named Twitter account, has landed a book deal and a deal with CBS for a comedy based on the premise. Mr. Halperns Twitter account has more than 700,000 followers. According to The Hollywood Reporter, Mr. Halpern signed a book deal with HarperCollins last month and CBS decided there must be a television show in there somewhere. David Kohan and Max Mutchnick, the creators of Will & Grace, are on board as executive producers, and Mr. Halpern, 29, a writer for Maxim who lives with his parents in San Diego, will serve as a writer and another executive producer. The name, which uses an unprintable word followed by the phrase My Dad Says, will need some retooling to meet network standards, but theres plenty of funny in the sensibility. Based on aphorisms and pearls of wisdom from Mr. Halperns father, the Twitter feed usually consists of his father telling his son that everything he thinks is wrong: Oh please, you practically invented lazy. People should have to call you and ask for the rights to lazy before they use it, said a post from Nov. 1.

title: Denzel Washington Is Broadway Bound
description: Another major film star is heading to Broadway: The two-time Academy Award winner Denzel Washington will play Troy Maxson in a revival of August Wilsons Fences next spring, according to an executive involved with the production. James Earl Jones played the role of Troy, a former baseball player now working as a garbage collector, in the original 1987 Broadway production of Fences, which won the Pulitzer Prize for drama and the Tony Award for best play that year. Fences was one of Wilsons biggest commercial hits on Broadway, running for 525 performances. Mr. Washington, 54, above, last appeared on Broadway in 2005 as Brutus in Julius Caesar, which was a box-office smash despite mixed reviews. He received an Academy Award for best actor in Training Day in 2002, and for best supporting actor for Glory in 1990. The dates of the revival have not been confirmed, said the executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the producers, Carole Shorenstein Hays and Scott Rudin, had not authorized comment. Kenny Leon, who directed A Raisin in the Sun and two Wilson plays on Broadway, Gem of the Ocean and Radio Golf, is in negotiations to direct.

title: Brewing Battle
description: Getting healthcare reform passed this year may be a challenge for the White House, NBC reports.

title: Alfred Hitchcock Steps Toward Off Broadway
description: The Broadway producers of Alfred Hitchcocks The 39 Steps have opened negotiations to move the quick-witted play to the Off Broadway theater New World Stages next year, according to the shows lead producer, Bob Boyett. The 39 Steps is scheduled to close at the Helen Hayes on Broadway on Jan. 10 after almost three years. Weve just started to have a conversation with them, but no decision has been made, Mr. Boyett said on Tuesday. The decision to move is going to be based on what kind of business arrangement we can come to. We think the show still has life in it. The 39 Steps has been playing lately to houses that are only about two-thirds full, but the lower running costs off Broadway could yield lower-priced tickets  and potentially more customers. ... In other news, the Roundabout Theater Company, the producers of Wishful Drinking, Carrie Fishers wry one-woman show about the perils of growing up famous (and famously hair-bunned), said the production has been extended. It will run through Jan. 17 at Studio 54. ... And the critically acclaimed Circle Mirror Transformation, a play at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater on West 42nd Street about students in a drama class, has been extended with five additional performances through Nov. 22, a spokesman for the Playwrights Horizons show said on Tuesday.

title: Shepard Fairey Wins Right to a New Lawyer
description: The street artist Shepard Fairey has won the right to a new lawyer in his suit against The Associated Press over the image that became his celebrated Barack Obama Hope poster. In a pretrial hearing Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the Southern District Court of New York also ruled that lawyers for The A.P. can depose Mr. Fairey and his departing lawyers before the end of the year, The A.P. reported. The agency and the artist are suing each other over the rights to the image, a photo taken in April 2006 at an event at the National Press Club in Washington. Mr. Fairey recently admitted that he had lied publicly and to his lawyers about which image he had used, causing the lawyers to abandon his case. Mr. Fairey later added that he still believed his work fell under fair-use guidelines and did not infringe on The A.P.s copyright, an assertion that his new lawyer, Geoffrey Stewart, supported, and that the agency rebutted.

title: Dancing in the Streets to Celebrate a Toppling
description: Twenty years ago on Monday, the Berlin Wall fell, but it wasnt only world leaders who celebrated the anniversary of its demise. The choreographer Nejla Y. Yatkin, a native of that city, offered her own site-specific homage, Dancing With the Berlin Wall, as part of Performing Revolution in Central and Eastern Europe, a festival in New York.

title: House Hunting in ... South Africa
description: A 530-SQUARE METER (5,700-SQUARE-FOOT) FARMHOUSE IN PLETTENBERG BAY

title: Making the Face of Modernism Familiar
description: The architect Eero Saarinen was often knocked for being the equivalent of a talented P.R. man. And on the surface at least, few architects did more to glamorize postwar corporate America. General Motors, I.B.M., CBS  all eventually came knocking at his door. His architecture offered them the veneer of a supremely confident, progressive America, with all the roughness smoothed away. It made it easier to forget about those Soviet warheads and mushroom clouds.

title: Networking No-Nos and Third iWheels
description: In the last installmentof Internet Protocol, we helped readers rein in their emoticon use and talked about whether its appropriate or not for tweens to be using Facebook.

title: In the Catskills, Holocaust Survivors Forge a Bond
description: The exuberant Jewish retirees gathering for their 26th summer at a modest Catskills bungalow colony in Andrew Jacobss documentary Four Seasons Lodge appear like any group of older Americans on vacation. They socialize, eat, argue, sing and dance, chortle at the risqu gags of cabaret entertainers, try their best to maintain the colonys aging physical plant, care for ailing spouses and  like most people in their 80s and 90s  look death in the face on a daily basis.

title: A Gossip Girl Look, Pronto!
description: ON an average day at his Robert G. Salon in the West Village in Manhattan, Robert Gioria fields a variety of requests. One woman wants her brown hair blond, another wants her straight hair shaggy. As different as these requests may seem, Mr. Gioria finds they are often generated by the same goal: to have Blake Livelys hair.

title: Recession Upends German Zeal for Fiscal Prudence
description: It has come to this: Germany will almost certainly have a bigger budget deficit next year than Italy will.

title: Dark Side of Heroism, Told in Four Wars
description: Picture a peacenik who in his private moments enjoys looking at pictures of horribly mutilated bodies. That is the vibe given off by The Good Soldier, a film whose benign-sounding title and Veterans Day release give a false impression of what it actually is: an attack on the military, drenched in blood.

title: When Style Wont Stay in Storage
description: Jamie Drake's temporary apartment faces south toward the still-under-construction "sky garage" designed by Annabelle Selldorf.

title: Stars of the Astronomy Quiz
description: We have a winner  two winners, actually of the prize for the Labs Beautiful Universe Astronomy Quiz. For the extra-credit questions, we asked you to expand the metropolis-sized model of the solar system that opened recently in Atlanta. In that model, which is scaled so that 1 kilometer represents 1 astronomical unit (the distance between the Earth and the Sun,) Neptune is located in a park 18 miles away from the Sun, which is at Bradley Observatory at Agnes Scott College.

title: A Designer Brings Personality to a Temporary Rental
description: THE view from the living room of Jamie Drakes temporary apartment on the 32nd floor of a glassy high-rise condominium on West 24th Street is due west. This means that Mr. Drake, the 52-year-old decorator to Michael R. Bloomberg and Madonna, has a birds-eye view of the glacial but ineluctably fascinating construction of what will eventually be his new home at 200 11th Avenue, the Annabelle Selldorf-designed tower in far west Chelsea.

title: Something to Argue About at Thanksgiving
description: I believe from a good turkey all Thanksgiving flows, says Kim Severson.

title: Writer Digs Up Gods From the Bayou
description: TARELL ALVIN McCRANEY enters. Miami, 1980s. He is a boy growing up in the Liberty City housing projects, among the nations worst. He stays with his father and grandparents on some nights. They feed him peanut butter and jelly, and he is content. They are devout Baptists and fill up the boy with Gods stories, and he is content.

title: American Sues F.B.I., Saying He Was Detained in Africa
description: WASHINGTON  A New Jersey man who contends that he was detained and mistreated in Kenya, Somalia and Ethiopia in 2007 with the approval of the United States filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against F.B.I. agents and other unidentified American officials who he says interrogated him and threatened him with execution.

title: Mourning the Victims of Fort Hood
description: President Obama played the role of national eulogist at a memorial service at Fort Hood, Tex., for the victims of a shooting rampage.

title: A Challenge of Innocence and Experience
description: WHAT Alan Ayckbourn remembers from Ayesha Antoines audition for his play My Wonderful Day is that she didnt look at him directly. That might not sound like a good thing, but since Ms. Antoine, who is 28, was reading with Mr. Ayckbourn for the role of an 8-year-old  and a thoughtful, reserved 8-year-old, at that  it definitely was.

title: Tips for Cooks and Waiters
description: SO exclusive is this restaurant on an industrial stretch of Queens Boulevard in Long Island City that it isnt open to the public and it doesnt even have a name.

title: Spaghetti Squash With Garlic, Parsley and Breadcrumbs
description: Spaghetti squash gets its name from the fact that once it is cooked, the flesh breaks down into long spaghettilike strands. I find spaghetti squash a bit dull on its own, as it does not have the sweetness and depth of many other winter squash. But it is hard to resist substituting spaghetti squash for pasta every once in a while, and the squash will pick up other robust flavors in the dish. Most spaghetti squash are pretty large; you will need only half of a 3 to 3 1/2-pound squash for this recipe. You can toss the leftovers with tomato sauce the next day.

title: A Kiss to the United States of Burgers, Fries and Sugar
description: CHARLIE PALMER opened a huge new restaurant in Manhattan this year, Aureole, a big, sprawling series of rooms on the ground floor of the Bank of America building on 42nd Street. He has around a dozen more, in Las Vegas, Reno and Californias wine country, among others, as well as a hotel, a catering outfit and a shop in Sonoma County that sells the sort of candles and bowls that you see in the homes of people who spend a lot of time shuttling among New York, Sonoma and Las Vegas.

title: Assault Charges for a Professor in a Bar Dispute
description: A Columbia University professor has been charged with assault and harassment after an another Columbia employee accused him of punching her in the eye at a Morningside Heights bar Friday night.

title: Lloyds to Cut 5,000 Jobs; HSBC Says Profit Improved
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group, the British lender bailed out by the government, said on Tuesday that it would cut 5,000 jobs in its insurance, retail and administration departments by the end of next year.

title: One-Year Term in Bribery Case
description: Frederic Bourke, a founder of the handbag maker Dooney & Bourke, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison and will have to pay a $1 million fine for conspiring to bribe leaders in Azerbaijan.

title: U.S. Tries to Salvage Honduras Accord
description: WASHINGTON  Under fire from allies in Latin America and on Capitol Hill, the Obama administration moved Tuesday to try to salvage the American-brokered agreement that had been billed as paving the way for a peaceful end to the coup in Honduras. Instead, the accord seems to have provided the countrys de facto government with a way to stay in power until a presidential election scheduled for the end of this month.

title: Prime Meats, Priced by the Ounce
description: PRIME MEATS

title: What Happens in Vegas
description: My review this week is of Aureole, a restaurant that Charlie Palmer first opened in 1988 on the Upper East Side. This summer he closed it and reopened in much larger quarters on the ground floor of the Bank of America building on 42nd Street. Its a very different restaurant, one that I feel better reflects Mr. Palmers experience cooking in Las Vegas, where he has yet another Aureole, than it does his past off Madison Avenue. What about you? Have you been to the new Aureole? Do you have memories of the old one, or of the high-flying wine sprites at the Las Vegas location? To join the conversation, post a comment below.

title: Influence of Egypt and Saudi Arabia Fades
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Even before Mahmoud Abbas announced that he would not seek re-election as the Palestinian president, throwing the Palestinian Authority into chaos, Americas closest Arab allies, Saudi Arabia and Egypt, had begun to despair over Washingtons Middle East missteps, government officials and political experts said.

title: How to Control Rising Health Care Costs
description: Updated, Nov. 11, 3:10 p.m. | Michael Chernew of Harvard Medical School joins the discussion. Scroll down to read his suggestion.

title: Where the Cocktails Steal the Show
description: YERBA BUENA PERRY

title: Motion Says Letterman Fostered Harassment
description: A lawyer for the man accused of trying to extort $2 million from David Letterman suggested on Tuesday that Mr. Letterman ran a workplace rife with sexual misconduct and contended that his client was simply trying to sell a story to the talk show host  not extort money from him.

title: And Now, Brooklyn Gets a Kitchen Lab
description: When Taylor Erkkinen, left, and Harry C. Rosenblum opened Brooklyn Kitchen, a cookware shop, in Williamsburg three years ago, they had no idea their classes on pickle-making, knife skills and such would be sellouts. So a few months ago they rented warehouse space two blocks away so they could expand. The 7,000-square-foot space, Brooklyn Kitchen Labs, is to open on Nov. 16. The old scale at left came with the building.

title: From Belize, and Extra Sweet
description: Laughing Bird shrimp are unlike many farmed shrimp, and that is a good thing. They are raised in the Caribbean, in inland ponds on the coast of Belize. They swim in filtered sea water, are fed a vegetarian diet, are not treated with additives or sulfites and are sold fresh and hand-peeled. The farm, the only one in Belize, has been given positive marks by the World Wildlife Fund.

title: Pumpkins Got a Brand New Trick
description: Thinking of retiring the cranberry sauce this Thanksgiving? Not so fast. How about offering a choice instead, namely pumpkin pickle.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Nissan Chief Plans a Low-Cost Car for India
description: NEW DELHI  The battle is heating up for bragging rights to the worlds least expensive car. On Tuesday, the top executive of Renault and Nissan said the companies would begin selling a small car in India in 2012 that would cost less than any other car sold in the country  and thus the world.

title: House Health Care Debate Heads Home
description: Still hoping to undermine support for a health care overhaul, Republican House members are preparing for town hall-style meetings in their home districts during the Veterans Day recess between now and early next week.

title: Online Ads Are Booming, if Theyre Attached to a Video
description: News Web sites are starting to look a lot less like newspapers and a lot more like television.

title: Al Cervi, Hall of Fame N.B.A. Player-Coach, Dies at 92
description: Al Cervi, a tenacious backcourt player in the early years of professional basketball and later a Hall of Fame coach who led the Syracuse Nationals to the 1955 N.B.A. championship, died Monday in Rochester. He was 92 and lived in Brighton, N.Y.

title: Female Hotel Workers Injured More Than Men, Study Shows
description: A new study of workers at 50 hotels in the United States found that women were 50 percent more likely to be injured than men, and that Hispanic women had an injury rate two-thirds higher than their white female counterparts.

title: Tastes of Authenticity
description: These places in and around New Orleans serve good po boys at a range of prices and styles.

title: Mahonys Beef Po Boys
description: Adapted from Benjamin Wicks

title: Sanofi Taps Biotech Firm to Bolster Its Pipeline
description: Increasing its bet on biotechnology, Sanofi-Aventis said it would pay an additional $1 billion over eight years to Regeneron Pharmaceuticals for the discovery of new drugs.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe for a green bean casserole with The Temporary Vegetarian last Wednesday omitted the oven temperature. It is 375 degrees. A corrected recipe is at nytimes.com/dining.

title: Prosecutors Say Students Paid Witness to Aid Case
description: CHICAGO  Prosecutors on Tuesday accused former journalism students at Northwestern University of paying a witness to record a video statement to help them prove that a man had been wrongfully convicted of a 1978 murder in a Chicago suburb.

title: Correction
description: An article last Wednesday about Sam Kass, the assistant White House chef who is closely involved with administration food policy and oversees the White House garden, referred imprecisely to the financing of the American Council on Science and Health, a consumer-education group that has criticized Mr. Kass for saying he would not use pesticides in the garden. The group is financed by various sources, including the food industry, foundations and private individuals; it is not solely financed by big food makers.

title: Reid and the Onside Kick Not Taken
description: A quick follow-up to Mondays entry about decisions by Tom Coughlin and Andy Reid in Week 9.

title: Young Veterans Form New Groups, and Old Posts Fade Away
description: Prisco De Angelis, 77, who earned a Purple Heart in the Korean War, remembers when Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 2652 in Brooklyn had several hundred members and its own building. He also remembers when the rank and file began dying off, and how the few who were left sold the building. Now he can count on only four or five others to attend post meetings. Often, the gathering place is his living room in Carroll Gardens.

title: Opposites on Ice Find a New Rhythm Together
description: DETROIT  It now seems like such a brilliant idea that it is a surprise no one had thought of it before: pairing figure skaters with hockey players for ice dancing routines in the ultimate ice rink reality show.

title: Blackouts Plague Energy-Rich Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  This country may be an energy colossus, with the largest conventional oil reserves outside the Middle East and one of the worlds mightiest hydroelectric systems, but that has not prevented it from enduring serious electricity and water shortages that seem only to be getting worse.

title: Calming the Black Friday Crowds
description: A year after an unruly crowd trampled a worker to death at a Wal-Mart store, the nations retailers are preparing for another Black Friday, the blockbuster shopping day after Thanksgiving. Along with offering $300 laptops and $99 navigation devices, stores are planning new safety measures to make sure the festive day does not take another deadly turn.

title: In Need of Cash, State Requiring Drivers to Buy New $25 Plates
description: ALBANY  New York drivers will start paying for new license plates next year  whether they want to or not.

title: From Justice Kennedy, a Lesson in Journalism
description: WASHINGTON  The school newspaper at Dalton, a private school in Manhattan, contained a cryptic note from its editors last Friday.

title: Stephen Curry Gets Rude Welcome on Warriors
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  After the worst game of his nascent N.B.A. career, Stephen Curry stood in the Warriors locker room and applied an ice pack to the knee of his extended left leg. He glanced warily over his left shoulder at his Golden State teammate Stephen Jackson, who was convivially holding court with reporters at his corner locker at Oracle Arena.

title: France: Court Rules a Lesbian Can Adopt
description: A court in Besanon ruled Tuesday that a lesbian known as Emmanuelle B. could adopt a child, overturning two previous rulings and ending a decade-long legal battle. The government of President Nicolas Sarkozy responded by declaring its continued opposition to adoption by gay couples. French law prohibits same-sex couples from adopting but allows adoptions by individuals. Emmanuelle B., 48, who is in a long-term relationship, began adoption proceedings as an individual in 1998.

title: Under Attack, Fed Chief Studies Politics
description: WASHINGTON  With the Federal Reserve under more intense attack than at any time in decades, Ben S. Bernanke, the professorial chairman of the central bank, was schooled last month in how to handle the increased political demands of his job.

title: Is Younger Gottis Teflon Suit Better Than His Fathers?
description: The prosecution of John A. Gotti  a jurisprudential marathon of four trials, five years, countless hours of testimony and a cast of characters as enduring as a syndicated sitcoms  is one of the citys longest-running dramas, a sort of criminal Cats, that is comparable in complexity and length perhaps only to the four trials of his father, John J. Gotti, the Gambino family don who died in 2002.

title: 3 Obama Advisers Favor More Troops for Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton are coalescing around a proposal to send 30,000 or more additional American troops to Afghanistan, but President Obama remains unsatisfied with answers he has gotten about how vigorously the governments of Afghanistan and Pakistan would help execute a new strategy, administration officials said Tuesday.

title: Italy: Berlusconi Builds Support to Cap Length of Trials
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi gained support on Tuesday for a change that would reduce the length of Italys long trials, including his own. After weeks of tension, the speaker of Parliament, Gianfranco Fini, appeared to support a bill that would cap the length of trials at six years, from first judgment through two rounds of appeals. Mr. Berlusconi faces trials on charges of corruption and tax fraud.

title: Powder Sent to 3 Missions Is Determined to Be Flour
description: Two United Nations foreign missions received envelopes containing white powder on Tuesday, a day after three others received mailings containing a similar substance that the police said was determined to be flour.

title: Falling Far Short of Reform
description: WASHINGTON

title: Administration Names Agriculture Official to Run U.S. Aid Agency, Ending Delays
description: WASHINGTON  After months of delays because of tangled vetting procedures, the Obama administration on Tuesday named a former executive with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation to run its main foreign aid arm, the United States Agency for International Development.

title: View of the Mayors Race From One Who Opted Out: I Could Have Won
description: Rep. Anthony D. Weiner wants to clear up a few things.

title: Maine Finds a Health Care Fix Elusive
description: BAR HARBOR, Me.  When his car repair shops health insurance premiums doubled between 2000 and 2002, David White saw the problem as akin to a sputtering engine. So he got under the hood of the states health system and tried to fix it.

title: Social Medicine
description: Wash your hands regularly. Cover your mouth when you sneeze. Throw away your used tissues. These are some of the exhortations currently posted around London in an attempt to reduce the spread of flu. But one day, perhaps well have public health campaigns of a different kind. Be jolly: its catching. Or, Eat less: do it for your friends.

title: 25 Chicago Students Arrested for a Middle-School Food Fight
description: CHICAGO  The food fight here started the way such bouts do in school lunchrooms most anywhere: an apple was tossed, a cookie turned into a torpedo, and an orange plunked someone in the head. Within minutes, dozens of middle-school students had joined in the ruckus, and spattered adults were ducking for cover.

title: Lives During Wartime
description: Last week, the editors of Home Fires invited readers to send their recollections and photographs of members of the United States Armed Forces in acknowledgment of Veterans Day. Below is a selection of those remembrances submitted by friends and family of veterans, and from veterans themselves.

title: Pension Bonus for City Correction Officers Is Questioned in Bruno Trial
description: Ten years ago, when the union for city correction officers persuaded Republican leaders in Albany to ignore the stern objections of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and approve a major bonus to their pensions, it looked like nothing more than a great political victory for the union.

title: Lottery Numbers
For All the Wrong Reasons, Womens Soccer Is Noticed
description: Fairly or unfairly, womens college soccer usually draws almost zero public attention. It is probably no exaggeration to say that most games produce more goals than news accounts.

title: Some Object as Museum Shows Its Trustees Art
description: One day in the mid-1980s, Dakis Joannou, a Greek Cypriot industrialist, was exploring the art galleries of the East Village in Manhattan when he came upon a basketball suspended in a tank of liquid. Captivated, he invested $2,700 in One Ball Total Equilibrium Tank by a little-known artist named Jeff Koons. It was, he said, as if a whole new world had opened up to him.

title: Damon May Face a Choice on His Next Contract
description: CHICAGO  In 2004, when the Red Sox finally broke all the hexes to win the World Series, many of their players became icons to the fans, and none more so than Johnny Damon.

title: Reid Says Health Bill Will Be Done by Christmas
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Tuesday that he expected to bring major health care legislation to the floor next week and to complete work on the bill before Christmas. But other Democratic leaders said it was unlikely that a bill could reach President Obamas desk by years end.

title: Leading the Way in a Different Kind of Transition
description: It is an unfortunate quirk of the media age that a career can be reduced to one play, one possession, one 10-second clip played on a maddening loop.

title: Kenneth, What Is the Frequency?
description: Most crosswords have themes. The New York Times alone publishes more than 260 themed puzzles a year. Thats a lot for an audience expecting innovation, but as weve seen, not too much innovation. Novelty alienates some solvers and is especially tough for newbies, so theres a balance.

title: Power in Paraguay and Brazil Fails
description: RIO DE JANEIRO   A problem with the Itaip hydroelectric power plant plunged Paraguay and large parts of Brazil into darkness on Tuesday night, virtually paralyzing the two countries.

title: Curry Takes Step Forward, and Knicks Hope to Follow
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Eddy Currys road to recovery after professional setbacks and personal heartbreak is tinged with caution. Although he cleared another hurdle on Tuesday, he has many more on the horizon.

title: Jeter and Teixeira Receive Gold Glove Awards
description: CHICAGO  Derek Jeter, whose defense has been criticized in recent years through statistical analyses, won a Gold Glove award for his defense, joining Yankees teammate Mark Teixeira on the list of American League recipients released Tuesday. No other team had multiple winners.

title: No Penalty for FedEx Over Contract Drivers
description: The FedEx Corporation said Tuesday that the government would not require it to pay employment taxes for contract drivers in its ground-delivery unit for 2004 through 2006, supporting the companys claim that they should not be treated as employees.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about difficulties for Muslims serving in the American armed forces described incorrectly the background of Michael A. Monsoor, a member of the Navy Seals. Mr. Monsoor was a Christian of Lebanese and Irish descent, not a Muslim. The article also described incorrectly the act that earned him a Medal of Honor. It was for falling on a grenade and saving at least three team members  not for pulling a team member to safety. (Saving a team member in an earlier incident earned him a Silver Star.)

title: No Longer a Soldier, Shinseki Has a New Mission
description: It was a sad homecoming of sorts. On Tuesday, Eric Shinseki, the secretary of veterans affairs, returned to Fort Hood, Tex., where he was a division commander in the mid-1990s, to pay tribute to two veterans affairs employees who died in the shootings there last week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about banks raising rates and fees on credit card customers ahead of new federal regulations misstated, in some editions, the current total of credit limits in the United States and those limits roughly a year ago. Total credit limits are now $3.4 trillion, not billion, which is a reduction from $4.6 trillion, not billion, a year ago.

title: A Man Who Loves to Clean, if Only He Could Find a Job to Do It
description: Telmo Cerezo watched intently as the headlines of Univisions news at 6 streamed across the muted television. I watch it in English too, he said quietly, adjusting his seat position so as not to be in the way.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Wednesday about Michael R. Bloombergs narrow victory in the New York mayoral race and a correction in this space on Friday misspelled the surname of a voter who said Mr. Bloomberg ran a smear campaign against a nonexistent opponent. She is Stav Birnbaum, not Brinbaum.

title: Corrections
description: A Congressional Memo article in some editions on Sunday about the race for Congress in the 23d District in New York misstated the circumstances of an endorsement in The Watertown Daily News. The papers decision to endorse the Democratic candidate, Bill Owens, after the Republican candidate, Assemblywoman Dede Scozzafava, withdrew was based solely on internal discussions, according to the editor, John B. Johnson Jr. He said the paper was not pressed for the endorsement by Democratic officials. (Mr. Johnson also noted that the decision had been made by the time Mr. Owens asked for the endorsement.)

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Friday about the distribution of the swine flu vaccine to some major New York companies even as shortages continue referred incompletely, based on information from the city health department, to the 27,400 doses requested by Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Those doses are meant for patients, workers and volunteers  not just workers.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading on Tuesday with an article about the use of old nuclear bomb cores to produce electricity misstated the source of the bomb material used to generate power in the United States. It comes from bombs dismantled by both the United States and Russia  not from Russian bombs alone.

title: Recalculating the Tally in Swine Flu Deaths
description: About 4,000 Americans  rather than about 1,200  have died of swine flu since the disease emerged in April, according to new figures being calculated by epidemiologists for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Week 9 Passer Ratings: Orton Seeks His Level
description: Luis DeLoureiro, a self-described schlep who is using a geeky Web site as a way to work through an early midlife crisis, is building a better passer rating at NFLStatAnalysis.net:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the planned Broadway musical Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark and a correction in this space on Tuesday misstated the status of advance ticket sales. While there has been no general advance sale, tickets are still available through Ticketmaster to holders of American Express cards; it is not the case that advance tickets are no longer being sold. (As the correction on Tuesday noted, tickets for the production are being handled by Ticketmaster, not Telecharge.)

title: Parade of Poor Play
description: A look at New York's other teams, which are not doing so well.

title: U.S. Navy Officer Revisits His Past in Vietnam
description: A boy who fled a war becomes a naval star, with stripes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a newly published oral history of Joseph Papp and the Public Theater misspelled the surname of one of Papps collaborators. He is Stuart Vaughan, not Vaughn.

title: Chairman Says G.M. Can Repay Taxpayers
description: The chairman of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., said Tuesday that the automaker would be able to repay all of its government loans and would begin doing so soon.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Saturday with a theater review of The Lilys Revenge at Here Arts Center omitted the surname of a cast member. She is Kayla Asbell.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the production of Dreamgirls in previews at the Apollo Theater before it goes on national tour misspelled the current name of the theater where the productions costume designer, William Ivey Long, was working in 1982 and which shared a wall with the Imperial Theater, where Dreamgirls was playing. (Mr. Long said that he had wanted to work on Dreamgirls since that time.) Formerly the 46th Street Theater, it is now the Richard Rodgers Theater, not Rogers.

title: Survey Finds Deep Shift in the Makeup of Unions
description: A study has found that just one in 10 union members is in manufacturing, while women account for more than 45 percent of the unionized work force.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Communications Director Leaves
description: Anita Dunn, the White House communications director who has tangled very publicly with Fox News, is leaving the White House at the end of the month. Her deputy, Dan Pfeiffer, will succeed her, a senior White House official said. The switch had been expected; Ms. Dunn took the communications director job this year on an interim basis. She will return to Squier Knapp Dunn, the media consulting firm where she is a partner, but will stay on as a strategic consultant to the White House. This development was first reported by The Washington Post. Ms. Dunn, a longtime Democratic strategist who worked for Mr. Obamas presidential campaign, kept a relatively low profile at the White House until recently, when she set off a war of words with Fox News by calling it the research arm or the communications arm of the Republican Party. Mr. Pfeiffer, 33, served as communications director for Mr. Obamas presidential campaign, communications director for Al Gores presidential campaign in 2000 and aide to Tom Daschle, the former South Dakota senator who was majority leader.

title: California: Immigration Conflict
description: Setting up a potential showdown with the mayor, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors reinstated an ordinance requiring that juvenile offenders who are in the country illegally be convicted of a crime before they are turned over to federal immigration authorities. The board passed the measure in October, but it was vetoed by Mayor Gavin Newsom, who said that it very likely conflicted with federal immigration law. On Tuesday, the board overrode that veto by an 8-to-3 vote. The mayor says that he has no intention of abiding by the boards action and that the current policy of turning over juveniles at the time of their arrest would stay in place. A spokesman called the ordinance unenforceable. Supervisor David Campos, who sponsored the measure, urged the mayor to follow the democratic process and put the ordinance into effect.

title: Two Share Lead in Elite Moscow Tournament
American Wages Out of Balance
description: American workers are overpaid, relative to equally productive employees elsewhere doing the same work. If the global economy is to get into balance, that gap must close.

title: At Christies, a Return of American Collectors, With an Eye on Price
description: Some of the great names in postwar and contemporary art were solid sellers at Christies on Tuesday night. And while American collectors were back, dominating the bidding, price mattered. Only one work  a 1996 painting by the Scottish artist Peter Doig  broke the $10 million barrier in a mixed sale that included property once belonging to Merce Cunningham, the dancer and choreographer, and his partner in life and work, the composer John Cage.

title: Potential San Francisco Showdown Over Immigration
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Setting up a potential showdown with the mayor, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors reinstated an ordinance on Tuesday requiring that juvenile offenders who are illegal immigrants be convicted of a crime before they are turned over to the federal immigration authorities.

title: Showcase: Dont Mention the Tomb
description: Ulysses Grant, 63, is a retired postal worker. Named after his father, he lives alone in an apartment on the Hudson River in Ossining, N.Y., next door to Sing Sing Correctional Facility. Sharing the name of the 18th president hasnt been easy, he said, as an alumnus of 12 anger management classes. His pride in the name has grown over the years. However, he added, When somebody says a joke about Ulysses Grant or Do you know whos buried in Grants tomb, I just fly off the handle.

title: Phys Ed: The Best Exercises for Healthy Bones
description: Several weeks ago, The Journal of the American Medical Association published a study that should give pause to anyone who plans to live a long and independent life. The study looked at the incidence of hip fractures among older Americans and the mortality rates associated with them. Although the number of hip fractures has declined in recent decades, the study found that the 12-month mortality rate associated with the injury still hovers at more than 20 percent, meaning that, in the year after fracturing a hip, about one in five people over age 65 will die.

title: Young John McCormack Makes New York Debut
description: Thursday, Nov. 11, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: 60 Years Later, Rosies Have Their Day
description: Nearly 60 years later, Garnet Kozielec still marvels at the journey that took her from a job wrapping porcelain dishes to doing so-called mans work making bombers and fighter jets and from her home in West Virginia to Michigan and then California.

title: Mildred Cohn, Biochemist, Is Dead at 96
description: Mildred Cohn, a biochemist who overcame religious and sex discrimination to advance the study of metabolic processes, research that contributed to the development of medical technologies like M.R.I.s, died on Oct. 12 in Philadelphia. She was 96.

title: A National Disgrace
description: Two courts, one in Italy and one in the United States, ruled recently on the Bush administrations practice of extraordinary rendition, which is the kidnapping of people and sending them to other countries for interrogation  and torture. The Italian court got it right. The American court got it miserably wrong.

title: The Trouble With Zero Tolerance
description: Congress took a reasonable step in 1994 when it required states receiving federal education money to expel students who brought guns onto school property, but states and localities overreacted, as they so often do. They enacted zero tolerance policies under which children are sometimes arrested for profanity, talking back, shoving matches and other behavior that would once have been resolved with detention or meetings with the students parents.

title: Cruel, Pointless Games
description: Irans mullah-led government seems determined to keep stoking tensions with the United States and the rest of the world. Despite President Obamas offer to negotiate, it has blocked serious talks on its nuclear program and other issues. It has backpedaled on its agreement to ship enriched uranium out of the country, and it continues to threaten and abuse its own citizens who dare to speak out.

title: Logitech Breaks Into Videoconferencing
description: In a move to break into the videoconferencing market, Logitech International has agreed to buy LifeSize Communications, a start-up that makes high-definition videoconferencing equipment, for $405 million in cash, The New York Timess Claire Cain Miller reported.

title: Homeless on Veterans Day
description: Gen. Eric Shinseki was famously shunned by the Bush administration for daring to state the true costs of occupying Iraq. As President Obamas secretary of veterans affairs, he is, thankfully, no less candid about the grinding problems veterans face at home. They lead the nation in depression, suicide, substance abuse and homelessness, according to data that Mr. Shineski is delivering in salvos in his current role.

title: Mideast Path: Step Up or Step Back?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fort Hood Tragedy, From Other Perspectives
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Virtuous Bankers? Really!?!
description: WASHINGTON

title: Trucks, Trains and Trees
description: Tapajs National Forest, Brazil

title: Revolutionary Road
description: WITH the unemployment rate at 10.2 percent and job creation creeping along despite increased spending on infrastructure, we should look with new eyes at a resource weve failed to take full advantage of: the Interstate highway system.

title: Prime Time
description: Prime Meats may not have a full dining room or menu yet; it may be cash-only, and its vintage-y bar may have no seats. But you will stand, and you will like it, because its still an excellent little spot, writes Sam Sifton, [LINK to Briefs] a happy extension of Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinellis mini-empire (Frankies 457 Spuntino, Frankies 17 Spuntino, et al). Go for the sauted wild mushrooms with a poached Amish egg, the fine hamburger or quality steak, the cured meats, cabbage salads and excellent house-made pretzel. Order up a crazy Prohibition cocktail ginned up by one of the mustachioed fellows behind the bar, some guy with absinthe in his eyes and a flaming goblet in front of him, and soon enough youll find yourself chatting with the cook, David Colston, about hippos and Canadian Thanksgiving till 3 a.m. Or maybe thats just us.

title: It Lasts Longer
description: In an era of digital manipulation and trickery, documenting something with a photo is a lot more complicated than it seems. The  New Photography exhibit at MoMA explores this to great effect, writes Karen Rosenberg, evoking the kind of debates about gesture, process and intent that used to coalesce around painting. You can get good and liquored up and argue tonight, when the museum is open late for its PopRally series.Andrew Kuo, digital artist extraordinaire, supplies the beats; photo booths will be installed; creative dress rewarded.

title: The Great Ghostdini
description: Ghostface Killah sings along to Billy Joel, refuses to smoke pot because it kills his mojo and hates ladies with rock-hard calves: these were the surprising facts we came away with when we sat with him in his car for an interview recently. Learn more about the erstwhile Wu-Tang Clanner tonight when he performs at BB King, in support of his new R&B-style album,  Ghostdini Wizard of Poetry in Emerald City.

title: Word of the Day | slacken
description: slacken  \sla-kn\  verb

title: A New Home for the Dome?
description: WHO are the people in this photo?

title: A Cheap Nest for Fledgling Firms
description: When Lindsay Napor expanded her Manhattan-based development company earlier this year  moving out of free work space provided by an investor  she turned to the most logical place for the companys new offices: New Jersey.

title: News Quiz | November 11, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Carl Ballantine, Slapstick Magician, Dies at 92
description: Carl Ballantine, an inveterate quipmeister whose stand-up comedy persona, an incompetent magician known as the Amazing Ballantine or Ballantine the Great, predated and influenced the antic characters of Steve Martin and others, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Hollywood. He was 92.

title: What Can Our Dreams Tell Us?
description: What do you think your dreams mean? Do you think they have a crucial psychological purpose in your life? What do you think of new research that argues that dreams are just the brain warming its circuits?Science Times writer Benedict Carey reports in A Dream Interpretation: Tuneups for the Brain on the latest findings by a sleep researcher:

title: Parsing the Verdict on Bear Fund Managers
description: The case against two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers, Ralph Cioffi and Matthew Tannin, was the closest anything came to a trial over Wall Streets role in the financial crisis. Their acquittal suggests that blame is not easily apportioned  and that mistakes, not conspiracies, offer the more likely explanation, Breakingviews.com argues.

title: Loss at Singapore Air Is More Bad News for Temasek
description: Temasek Holdings, which in September posted a record 67 percent drop in net profit for the year ended March 31, is still getting bad news from its investments.

title: Hong Kong Bourse Earnings Up, But Future Unsure
description: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing, the citys stock exchange, faces increasing competition from China, posing a challenge for the worlds second-largest listed exchange operator to keep up the momentum on robust third-quarter profits.

title: Wall St. Takes a Breather and Shares Close Flat
description: A day after a spirited rally sent the Dow to its highest levels since the beginning of the financial crisis, Wall Street took a moment to breathe, with stocks showing little or no gains on Tuesday.

title: Baer Says Tax Fears Are Slowing Client Inflows
description: Julius Baer Group said Tuesday that an international clampdown on tax evasion had slowed the pace of money flowing in from wealthy clients since the middle of the year, Reuters reported.

title: Curves and Surfaces
description: Images from Eero Saarinen: Shaping the Future, at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Cosmen Snubs National Express Rights Issue
description: National Express, the British bus and train operator, announced that it will raise about 360 million ($600 million) in a rights issue to pay down debt and avoid breaching loan terms, but said its largest shareholder, Jorge Cosmen, failed to back the cash call.

title: Sanofi Taps Biotech Firm to Help Pipeline
description: Increasing its bet on biotechnology, Sanofi-Aventis said it would pay an additional $1 billion over eight years to Regeneron Pharmaceuticals for the discovery of new drugs.

title: Boston Provident Executive Arrested for Fraud
description: Ezra Levy, the chief financial officer of Boston Provident Partners, was arrested Tuesday on charges of stealing more than $1.3 million from the Manhattan hedge fund, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Clawbacks Introduced at Commerzbank
description: Commerzbank, the second-largest German lender after Deutsche Bank, will introduce a clawback option to its bonus system next year as the banking industry tries to stop the short-term risk-taking that helped bring about the financial crisis.

title: Ambac Warns of Possible Bankruptcy
description: Shares of bond insurer Ambac Financial Group sank 33 percent on Tuesday after the company warned it may be forced to seek bankruptcy protection if it cannot fix its liquidity problems, Reuters reported.

title: F.D.I.C. Calls for Reserve Fund for Ailing Companies
description: A reserve fund must be established ahead of time to give the government the working capital it needs to dismantle large, troubled financial companies, a top United States bank regulator said Tuesday.

title: Jury Out on Appeal for Lloyds Hybrids
description: Lloyds looks set to get investor support for a hybrid bond exchange into 7.5 billion pounds ($12.5 billion) of new enhanced capital notes, but it is not clear how much wider appeal these new securities will command, Reuters said.

title: Military Divers Find Body of Missing American Soldier in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A week after two American soldiers disappeared in northwest Afghanistan, the body of one of them has been found by a military dive team, a NATO spokesman said Wednesday.

title: For G.M., Work at Opel Includes Mending Fences
description: A week after angering German politicians and labor leaders by calling off plans to sell Opel to a group backed by Berlin, senior executives at General Motors promised more independence for the European unit.

title: Grass Fed | Pop Some Coffee Cherries
description: Grass Fed features the culinary ramblings of the food writer Peter Meehan, the co-author of the Momofuku cookbook with David Chang and an all-around good eater.

title: John Paulson Doubles Bet on Cadbury
description: John Paulson, the hedge fund manager whose wagers against the United States housing market earned him billions last year, has doubled his bet on Cadbury, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Chairman Says G.M. Can Repay Taxpayers
description: The chairman of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., said Tuesday that the automaker would be able to repay all of its government loans and would begin doing so soon.

title: Senate Plan Would Expand Rules on Risky Lending
description: The chairman of the Senate banking committee proposed a financial overhaul on Tuesday that included consolidating bank regulators, creating a consumer financial protection agency and imposing new restraints on exotic financial instruments and credit rating agencies.

title: Under Attack, Fed Chairman Studies Politics
description: With the Federal Reserve under more intense attack than at any time in decades, Ben S. Bernanke, the professorial chairman of the central bank, was schooled last month in how to handle the increased political demands of his job.

title: A.I.G. Likely to Repay Bailout, Moodys Says
description: The American International Group has made progress on its restructuring and will likely be able to repay a taxpayer bailout and buy back much of the governments stake in the company, Moodys Investors Service said on Monday.

title: France and Germany Use the Remembrance of a War to Promote Reconciliation
description: PARIS  For the first time since the armistice that ended World War I with Germanys defeat in 1918, a German leader joined French officials here to mark the moment the guns fell silent on the Western Front after a war that killed millions.

title: A.I.G. Chief Is Said to Be Ready to Quit
description: After just three months as head of battered insurer American International Group, Robert E. Benmosche has threatened to leave his post as he struggles to deal with heavy government oversight and restrictions on what the bailed-out company wants to pay employees, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: How Does Prague Relax? Try Thai Massage.
description: After a day of traversing cobblestones, what could be better than getting jabbed in the back and pummeled on the head? Prague residents with that thought in their heads are in luck: the city is enveloped in a Thai massage craze. There are more than 40 Thai massage centers in the city, about half of which opened in the last five years.

title: Toyetic
description: The potential of a movie or TV show to support spin-off toys and similar merchandising.

title: TPG May Team With American for JAL Stake
description: TPG may be joining the fray in the battle over Japan Airlines.

title: Q&A With Jeanne Dee, the Nomadic Family Traveler
description: Stories about traveling with children  like my column last week on taking my daughter, Sasha, on a frugal day trip to Washington, D.C. always generate intense reader responses. For every positive comment (Thanks for the great post! wrote bklngirly), theres invariably a negative one (Maybe a visit from Child Protective Services is in order! wrote Ellen Domeir). Which is why Im amazed by SoulTravelers3.com, which chronicles the adventures of the Dee family  Jeanne, 57, Vince, 56, and their 9-year-old daughter, Mozart (they prefer not to give her real name).

title: ING Swings Back to Profit in Third Quarter
description: The ING Groep, the bailed-out Dutch financial services company, said Wednesday it made a profit in the third quarter, ending a year of heavy losses, as financial market conditions recovered.

title: A Jobless Recovery
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Kim Echlin
description: Kim Echlin is the author of several works of fiction, nonfiction and poetry. Her third novel, The Disappeared, will be published in January.

title: Sampler: Sanctuary Vote, Truckers Family Speaks, Urban Casino
description: Big Rig Truckers Family | The family of Tahir Sheikh Fakhar, 56, of Hayward, who died Monday when his truck went off the Bay Bridge, says that Mr. Fakhar was a careful driver and that the bridges S-curve is unsafe.

title: Does Silicon Valleys Spending Spree Signal a Recovery?
description: This week brought acquisitions of three high-profile technology startups, a welcome break in the gloom that has enveloped Silicon Valley for the past year.

title: Stroller Recall Stirs Unease in Park Slope
description: There are two major health threats in Park Slope at the moment, if you believe some of the neighborhoods innumerable young and hyper-conscientious parents.

title: I Believe License Plate Banned by Judge
description: A United States District Judge has struck down a Christian-themed license plate that had been approved by the South Carolina Legislature, reports the BBC.

title: Iran Executes Kurdish Activist Who Was Accused of Armed Struggle
description: TORONTO  Iran hanged a Kurdish activist on Wednesday morning in a prison in the Kurdish city of Sanandaj, his lawyer said.

title: Q&A With Jeanne Dee, the Nomadic Family Traveler
description: Living off savings and investments, the Dee family  Jeanne, 57, Vince, 56, and their 9-year-old daughter  have been traveling the world and chronicling their adventures since 2006.

title: Dollars Drop Lifts Shares, Gold and Oil
description: It was supposed to be a quiet day on Wall Street: the bond market was closed for Veterans Day, and there were no economic reports on the calendar.

title: Park Lark
description: Video | Aussie TV wisenheimers find the best parking spot at the mall:

title: G.E. Markets First Smart Appliance
description: Smart appliances are officially on their way to American households.

title: Justice Kennedys Journalism Lesson for Dalton Students
description: The school newspaper at Dalton, a private school in Manhattan, contained a cryptic note from its editors last Friday.

title: Mugged by Two Snails
description: Incoming | Reader submissions from the worlds funniest joke contest in Readers Digest. Help yourself:

title: Steven Tyler Says Hes Not Quitting Aerosmith
description: The shortest rift in rock music history has been healed as the estranged Aerosmith band mates Steven Tyler and Joe Perry reunited on Tuesday night on a New York stage, where Mr. Tyler announced that he was not leaving the group.

title: The Early Word: Soldiers and Wars
description: On Veterans Day, ceremonies around the country will honor members of the nations military who served in past and present wars.

title: Somali Pirates Seize Cargo Ship
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia    Somali pirates said Wednesday that they had seized a container ship with 22 crew members on board after a five-hour chase across the Indian Ocean, reflecting both an increase in pirate activity after the end of monsoon storms and signs of increasing boldness among the hijackers.

title: Spike Wants Viewers to Get Schooled With New Football-Themed Series
description: Guys and sports, sports and guys. For cable channels trying to reach younger men, the gridiron, field, pitch and rink are where its happening.

title: Switzerland Unveils Measures to Regulate Bank Pay
description: Switzerland announced watered-down measures to limit bank compensation Wednesday, imposing no caps on bonuses and excluding all but the countrys biggest financial services companies from mandatory compliance, David Jolly of The New York Times reported.

title: G.M. Can Repay Taxpayers, Chairman Says
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Crdit Agricole Profits Slide, and Chief Steps Down
description: Crdit Agricole, one of the largest French banks, said late Tuesday that it had taken in a profit of 289 million euros ($433 million) for the third quarter, down 21 percent from a year ago, and that its chief executive, Georges Pauget, would step down.

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Wednesday morning.

title: Study Says State Film Subsidies Underwrite Tobacco-Friendly Movies
description: A new report takes aim at state movie production subsidies for supporting films that depict smoking. Health researchers at the University of California, San Francisco, estimate that 60 percent of the $1.4 billion that states offered in 2008 to attract Hollywood filming went to movies with tobacco imagery.

title: Team of the 2000s: Patriots, Colts or Steelers?
description: The Steelers 28-10 win over the Broncos on Monday night was their 100th in the regular season since the start of the 2000 season. The Steelers are the third team to surpass the century mark in the 2000s, joining the Colts (109) and the Patriots (108), but they will probably not be the last. The Eagles, who have 97 wins, should reach the milestone. But Philadelphia will most likely be the only member of the group to emerge from the 2000s without a Super Bowl title. (They would join the Bills of the 1990s, who had 103 wins but no titles.)Most Wins by Decade

title: Forum Reflects Copenhagen Divisions
description: Speaking at a symposium organized by the Council on Foreign Relations in Washington on Tuesday, Atul Arya, the chief adviser for energy and climate policy for BP, the British oil company, said the odds of achieving a broad, global agreement at climate talks in Copenhagen next month were very, very low.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Executors Named for Jackson Estate Over Objection of Singers Father
description: A Superior Court judge in Los Angeles made two longtime associates of Michael Jackson the executors of the singers estate on Tuesday, dismissing a challenge filed by Mr. Jacksons father, Joe, Reuters reported. Judge Mitchell Beckloff named the lawyer John G. Branca and the music executive John McClain the executors of the estate, which is expected to take in $200 million this year in revenues from the Jackson concert documentary This Is It, as well as the accompanying soundtrack album and other business deals. Mr. Branca and Mr. McClain were already serving as the administrators of the estate. Joe Jackson had petitioned the court to say that it should set up a monthly allowance for him, similar to the one established for the singers mother, Katherine Jackson, but the judge said he had no standing to challenge his sons will.

title: The Good Wife Watch: Ethics Testing
description: The Good Wife is packed with paradox the way that Mad Men thrives on cigarettes and Manhattans. But its paradox as parable: in every episode, the heroine, Alicia, learns that things are not as they seem.

title: German Sentenced to Life for Killing in Court
description: BERLIN  The German man who stabbed a pregnant Egyptian woman to death in a Dresden courtroom was found guilty on Wednesday and given a life sentence.

title: Reinvented Galaxy and Dynamic Dynamo Benefit From Consistency
description: For all of the L.A. Galaxys success this season, built on the explosiveness of a resurgent Landon Donovan and the savvy of a recommitted David Beckham, its difficult to escape the all-too-painful and all-too-recent past.

title: Help Wanted: Operations Manager
description: In previous posts, Ive shared some of the hiring mistakes weve made over the years. I think we are finally learning how to ensure that we hire someone who is the right fit for our culture. Hiring someone with the right skill set, though, is a different story. Im still trying to figure this out  and learning a lot in the process. Ive been fortunate to have found some pretty special people for my team, one of which is my current operations coordinator.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Remembrance Day in Toronto
description: Six games on Tuesday night, but itd be hard to come up with a less intriguing slate of matchups; not a single contest featured two teams currently in a playoff position.

title: At Arafat Memorial, Abbas Pushes Independence Fight
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Thousands of Palestinians turned out Wednesday for a rally here on the fifth anniversary of the death of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and to show support for his successor, President Mahmoud Abbas, who recently expressed an intention to retire.

title: Obama Salutes Fallen Americans on Veterans Day
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama hailed the sacrifice and determination of the nations military on Wednesday as he delivered a Veterans Day tribute at Arlington National Cemetery, a hallowed place where he said the grief remains fresh.

title: Flashback: On Slow Drips, From Trash to CO2
Rupert Murdoch: Unalloyed, Unbound
description: Folks in the media are so used to considering Rupert Murdoch as a spectral presence that it is sometimes hard to remember that behind a name so freighted with meaning lurks a real actual guy. Thats why its fun spending time watching Sky News Australias 37-minute interview with him. There is no major news splash, but there is value in watching Mr. Murdochs mind and mouth work in the long on-camera interview with Skys David Speers last week.

title: What to Watch Wednesday: Glee, Country Music Awards, Return to Duty
description: What to Watch on Wednesday:

title: Job Woes Exacting a Toll on Family Life
description: THE WOODLANDS, Tex.  Paul Bachmuths 9-year-old daughter, Rebecca, began pulling out strands of her hair over the summer. His older child, Hannah, 12, has become noticeably angrier, more prone to throwing tantrums.

title: Sesame Street Producers Respond to Pox News Dispute
description: An executive for Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit organization that produces Sesame Street, said a segment on that show that upset political conservatives was equal-opportunity parody, making fun of CNN as much as it was making fun of Fox News.

title: Officials Search for Answers in Extensive Brazil Blackout
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A huge power failure involving the worlds largest operating hydroelectric plant this week was the worst in its 25 years of use, Brazilian officials said Wednesday, causing widespread blackouts that exposed the vulnerability of Brazils electricity infrastructure.

title: A Revelatory Upside-Down Cake
description: I well remember the first time I ate tarte Tatin; it was a revelation. The first time I ate upside-down cake, its close relative, was not so stunning, but I was much younger and, after all, its not as surprising a creation. I believe, though, that the pear upside-down cake that is the subject of this weeks Mini narrows the differences.

title: Performa 09: Dancing With Sculpture
description: Performas founder and prime mover, Roselee Goldberg, has great instincts for which artists might collaborate well together. Her instincts were right with Tamar Ettun and Emily Coates, who cooked up Empty Is Also, a dance with changing sculpture that was performed on Saturday evening at the X Initiative in Chelsea.

title: Gift Guide | Small Packages
description: Our Winter Design & Living issue proved that good design neednt be an exclusively grown-up affair. In that spirit, here we offer eight items perfect for discerning tots  theyll be warm, stylish and comfy from play group to picture day.

title: Going Vegetarian for Thanksgiving
description: Who needs turkey? Thanksgiving is an ideal time to test out new vegetarian recipes that could quickly become everyday favorites.

title: Obama Pays Tribute to Veterans
description: President Obama placed a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknowns on Wednesday as he paid tribute to Americas veterans at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Travel Deals: Discounts on Holland America, Virgin America and British Airways
description: Lots of deals today: Holland America has a three-day cruise sale, Virgin America has discounted cross-country fares, and British Airways has dropped fares from 19 cities in the United States.

title: Women in Charge at Tate Britain and Venice Architecture Biennale
description: The Tate Gallery said on Wednesday that it had appointed Penelope Curtis the director of its Tate Britain museum in London. In a news release, the Tate said that Ms. Curtis, who has served since 1999 as the curator of the Henry Moore Institute in Leeds, earned a masters degree and a Ph.D. at the Courtauld Institute of Art in London, and has overseen the acquisition of many works for the institutes sculpture collection, including pieces by Rodin, Epstein and Calder. Dr. Curtis also served on the the British Council Committee for the Venice Biennale in 2008 and the Turner Prize Jury. Of the four museums in the Tate Gallerys network, the Tate Britain is the oldest, with an emphasis on both historic and contemporary British art.

title: Kids or Young Adults? Facing Life in Prison
description: In Washington this week, the Supreme Court heard arguments over whether judges should take into account the age of a convicted juvenile offender when considering issuing life sentences. The court may be leaning in favor of this outcome, some reports indicate.

title: More Wordplay Changes
description: Now that our new co-blogger has settled in, its time to announce two more Wordplay changes.

title: His Facebook Status Now? Charges Dropped
description: Wheres my pancakes, read Rodney Bradfords Facebook page, in a message typed on Saturday, Oct. 17, at 11:49 a.m., from a computer in his fathers apartment in Harlem.

title: Veterans and Journeymen
description: On days like Veterans Day, sports like to wrap themselves in patriotism, roll pictures of military members across their video boards and try to make you forget the sheer silliness of commonly referring to games as wars and to luxury S.U.V.-driving professional athletes as warriors. Sometimes sports gets it right, and there are stories like the Giants heartwarming two-way relationship with the injured Iraq veteran Lt. Col. Greg Gadson, which got an appropriate update Wednesday from ESPN.coms Greg Garber, or the story of the Titans Marine turned fullback Ahmard Hall.

title: Chinas Tough Flu Measures Appear to Be Effective
description: CHANGGANG, China  Few farmers in this southern village gave much thought to the epidemic that had begun spreading rapidly in the United States early this summer until the authorities sealed its 100 residents off from the outside world for about a week. It turned out that a visitor from California had shown symptoms of the swine flu virus, or H1N1, when he arrived for a funeral.

title: Wealth Manager Faces Charges in Madoff Case
description: Update | 1:35 p.m. A Swiss court has charged the head of a large investment firm with criminal mismanagement in connection with the multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme run by the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff.

title: Carroll Shelbys New Oil Comes From Olives
description: Car guys and oil just seem to mix well  and not just motor oil.

title: Union Members Getting More Educated
description: My colleague Steven Greenhouse has an article today about this new report on the changing demographics of labor unions. The paper was released by the Center for Economic and Policy Research, a liberal research group in Washington.

title: From the House of the Dead': Janaceks Music
description: JIM OESTREICH: Were going to want to hear more from Charles about Patrice Chreau. But first lets close the loop and begin to delve into the musical aspects of From the House of the Dead. Tony, why dont you set the scene by telling us something about Leos Janacek, his career and this opera in particular. Maybe you could even let us a hear a sample or two.

title: Breast-Feed the Baby, Love the Calorie Burn
description: WHEN Jessica Jochim returned to work after her three-month maternity leave, she was the envy of her co-workers at Babies R Us. Mrs. Jochim, who had gained 40 pounds carrying her first child, steadily slimmed until she was a size 4 again. Yet, exercise was a pre-baby relic. She wasnt dieting, either. In fact, every two hours, she snacked as if on cue.

title: Floating Flotsam: Studying the Causes and Effects of the Pacific Garbage Patch
description: Overview | Why do scientists seek evidence to support cause-and-effect relationships that seem obvious to the casual observer? What is the value of studying environmental problems in depth before acting to address them? How do public awareness and economic factors affect what actions are taken with regard to waste and pollution? In this lesson, students reflect on the Pacific garbage patch and recent scientific voyages to study the effects of plastic and other debris on water quality and oceanic life.

title: Paris Dancers Headed to New York in Ballet Exchange
description: Over the years, France has given New York everything from the Statue of Liberty to Daniel Boulud, and now, in its latest act of trans-Atlantic generosity, it plans to lend the city a pair of dancers from the the Paris Opera Ballet. The New York City Ballet said that Aurlie Dupont and Mathias Heymann, both toiles with the Paris Opera Ballet, would perform at City Ballets opening-night benefit. Ms. Dupont and Mr. Heymann (who are among the dancers featured in the Frederick Wiseman documentary La Danse: The Paris Opera Ballet) are to perform the Rubies pas de deux from George Balanchines Jewels. The other half of the bargain (struck by Brigitte Lefvre, the dance director of the Paris Opera Ballet, and Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of City Ballet) is that Paris gets to borrow Ashley Bouder and Gonzalo Garcia, principal dancers from City Ballet, who will dance the leading roles in Rubies for the Paris Opera Ballet on Thursday at the Palais Garnier. The City Ballet benefit will take place on Nov. 24 at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Asked and Answered | Miss J of Top Model
description: J. Alexander, better known as Miss J on Americas Next Top Model, is a well-loved figure. We were in Savannah, Ga., together a few months ago for the SCAD graduation fashion show, and when we sat down at a quaint little ice cream parlor at least 10 people came up to our table, fumbling for cellphones to get a picture with the modeling coach diva. (He does not allow pictures taken with phones, only with cameras, thank you.) With the debut of his first book, Follow the Model, we are sure all those fans will be eager to learn a bit more about the man who modeled in drag in Japan, loves cake and hates the word fierce.

title: The Iraqi Elections: Same Names, Different Teams
description: After much delay, the Iraqi Parliament finally passed a law on Sunday allowing for national parliamentary elections  the third since the American invasion in 2003. Voting is scheduled to take place in the second half of January.

title: What War Is Good For
description: The confluence of the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall and Veterans Day (Armistice Day in Europe) has prompted numerous observations in opinionland, though perhaps none have proved so contentious as Robert D. Kaplans short meditation on The Fall of the Wall, at the Atlantic.

title: Motorola Is Seeking Buyers for Mobility Unit
description: Update | 2:30 p.m. DealBook has confirmed that Motorola has hired JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs to explore a sale of its home and networks mobility division, according to people briefed on the matter. Several private equity firms have been approached, but the process is in the early stages, these people said.

title: Answers About Entrepreneurship
description: Following is the first set of answers from Seth W. Pinsky, the president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation.

title: Tuning Out the Taliban
description: The lyrics and videos of some Pakistani rock songs reflect widespread views among educated young fans that the West is more of a problem than the Taliban.

title: Should School Newspapers Be Subject to Prior Review?
description: Many school papers are required to follow prior review. This means having to let their sources, and sometimes administrators, approve quotes and other coverage before going to print. Should student journalists be subject to different standards and practices than professional journalists? Adam Liptak reported today that the school newspaper at Dalton, a Manhattan private school, had to hold its coverage of a speech by Supreme Court Justice Anthony M. Kennedy:

title: The New Museums Web of Connections
description: An article on Wednesday described concerns in the art world over the propriety of a coming show at the New Museum that will feature the private collection of a museum trustee, Dakis Joannou, and be curated by Jeff Koons. Mr. Koons is an artist whom Mr. Joannou collects extensively, and the article noted that critics of the museum consider it to be enmeshed in what can seem like a dizzyingly insular circle of art world insiders.
