title: Seeking Revival, City to Buy Land in Coney Island
description: After a year of ultimatums, threats and stop-and-go talks, the Bloomberg administration has agreed to pay $95.6 million to a developer for seven acres in the heart of Coney Island, according to executives on both sides of the negotiations. It is a crucial step forward for the citys vision of turning the faded and mostly dormant seaside amusement district into an exciting destination reminiscent of its heyday.

title: Shooting the Last Episodes of NBCs Trauma
description: Correction | 11:30 a.m. Wednesday  An earlier version of this post and its headline incorrectly stated that the local shooting of Trauma had ended on Tuesday. The post now reflects NBCs confirmation that the canceled show is currently shooting the 11th of its 13 scheduled episodes.

title: Pogue & Friends 2009 Holiday Guide
description: The Times's personal technology columnist, David Pogue, teams up with Mark Bittman, author of The Minimalist column, to test gadgets for the kitchen.

title: Answers About Home Buyers and Owners Tax Credits: Part 2
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which youll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Hannity to Address Protest Video Questions
description: The Daily Show, which has become one of the medias prime monitors when it comes to calling out misuse or manipulation of video, caught the Fox News Channel and one of its hosts, Sean Hannity, Tuesday night, in what appeared to be a blatant example of doctoring a report with inappropriate video to enhance an argument.

title: Lessons From a Military Wife
description: Alison Buckholtz is spending this Veterans Day near home in Potomac, Md., with her son, Ethan, who is 6, and her daughter, Esther, 4, while her husband spends the day flying fighter jets in Iraq.

title: Harlem Program Could Close Education Gap
description: What were looking at on the Web today Roland Fryers research on education indicates that Harlem Childrens Zone provides an effective model for closing the black-white achievement gap. [Freakonomics]

title: Speech Gene Shows Its Bossy Nature
description: Of the 20,000 genes in the human genome, few are more fascinating than FOXP2, a gene that underlies the faculty of human speech.

title: Thursday Matchup: Bears at 49ers
description: Bears (4-4) at 49ers (3-5)Thursday, 8:20 p.m.Line: 49ers by 3

title: Bank of England Expected to Spend More
description: LONDON  The Bank of England said on Wednesday that it was open to pumping more money into the still-struggling economy, a warning to economists who had interpreted recent steps as a sign that the central bank would shift its focus to controlling inflation.

title: Waterfalls Artist Has a New Bridge to Sell You
description: Olafur Eliasson, the Danish-Icelandic artist who created the temporary waterfalls in New Yorks East River last year, is at work on a project that will give the residents of another city a different way of looking at a nearby body of water. On Wednesday, the city of Copenhagen said that Mr. Eliasson would create a bridge there, called Cirkelbroen (circle bridge), which would provide a winding path across the citys Christianshavns Kanal. In a news release, Mr. Eliasson said the bridge, whose design was inspired by the sailing ships that pass through the canal, would consist of five circular platforms with their own masts. In a statement, he said he hoped the bridge would reduce speed and turn focus. Rather than offering the fastest possible passage across the canal, Mr. Eliasson said, the bridge will create small variations in the way we see the city and open for a renegotiation of public space. The bridge is being given as a gift to Copenhagen from the Nordea-foundation, which promotes healthy living and outdoor activities. It is expected to be completed in 2012 and cost about $6.8 million; Copenhagen is contributing about $1.5 million.

title: Pakistan Rock Rails Against the West, Not the Taliban
description: While Pakistani journalists, playwrights and even moderate Islamic clerics have boldly condemned the Taliban, the nations pop music stars have yet to sing out against the group, which continues to claim responsibility for daily bombings.

title: Excerpt: 'The Prisoner'
description: Ian McKellen and Jim Caviezel star in this new version of the cult spy series from the 1960s, which begins Sunday on AMC.

title: Carrie Underwood Is No. 1; Billboard Chart to Include Older Titles
description: Carrie Underwoods new album, Play On (19/Arista Nashville), easily reached the top of the Billboard chart this week, outselling Michael Jackson and new releases by Andrea Bocelli and Weezer.

title: La Guardias Tough and Incorruptible Police Commissioner
description: The swearing-in of Lewis J. Valentine for a third five-year term as police commissioner took just minutes. Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, who conducted the 1944 ceremony, declared curtly, If it were necessary to make any speeches or statements you would not be reappointed.

title: S.C. Senator Gets Slammed Back Home
description: Senator Lindsey Graham, the Republican with a maverick streak, has been censured by local Republican Party officials in his home state of South Carolina.

title: Feeling for  80s Shades
description: It seems that with every fashion season there is a new 1980s moment  its become as predictable as a catfight between the strong-shouldered demon ladies on Dynasty. Having said that, an interesting 80s revival is happening on Abbot Kinney Boulevard, the nerve center for West L.A. style makers. Garrett Leight, a native of Venice, Calif., and the 25-year-old son of the Oliver Peoples eyewear founder Larry Leight, has started A. Kinney Court, a specialized eyewear gallery and boutique for men and women. The stores centerpiece is a rare assortment of vintage Oliver Peoples frames, dating as far back as 1987. Classic clip-on sunglasses, as well as the famous OMalley frame (based on retro shades from the 1950s), will be showcased along with a revolving selection of other rare finds rediscovered by Larry and Garrett after carefully sifting through boxes in multiple storage units. The frames come with original blue, green and brown vintage tint lenses to complete the period-perfect look; Garrett will soon complete his opticians license exams to make sure his customers vision is as sharp as their look. The store, which opened this week and is situated around a vast courtyard hangout, carries other design-minded optical lines like Mykita, Thierry Lasry and KBL Eyewear, as well as shoes and apparel for men and women from Becca Moon and LnA, a casual sportswear line. Im feeling for it!

title: Mormon Support of Gay Rights Statute Draws Praise
description: The Mormon Church has been a target of vituperation by some gay rights groups because of its active opposition to same-sex marriage. But on Wednesday, the church was being praised by gay rights activists in Salt Lake City, citadel of the Mormon world, for its open support of a local ordinance banning discrimination against gay men and lesbians in housing and employment.

title: The Self-Manufacture of Megan Fox
description: I.

title: A Gallery Gadfly Revives His Act
description: ONE drizzly Friday night last month dozens of people had crowded into Invisible-Exports, a gallery on Orchard Street, to celebrate the opening of a show by the conceptual artist Stephen Irwin. Works on paper lined the long, hallwaylike space, starting out with white Minimalist abstractions by the front windows and progressing to more figurative imagery at the back.

title: ABC Cancels the Kelsey Grammer Series Hank
description: Its not just Hank Pryor whos out of a job  Kelsey Grammer, who played that unemployed executive on the new sitcom Hank, will once again be seeking work. ABC has canceled the show, The Hollywood Reporter said. The network said it would halt production on the series after work is completed on a 10th episode. Five episodes have been broadcast, and ABC has not yet announced its plans for the five remaining episodes it will have on hand. Hank is the second short-lived series for Mr. Grammer, who played the unctuous Dr. Frasier Crane for 20 years on Cheers and Frasier. His sitcom Back to You, on which he and Patricia Heaton played rival television news anchors, ran for one season on Fox in 2007-8.

title: How About Skipping Turkey Completely?
description: While writing and plotting my freedom-from-turkey manifesto in theDining section, I admit that I forgot my most obvious constituents:vegetarians.

title: Snowboarding + Math = Olympic Success?
description: Who says that statistics and shredding dont mix?

title: Does Silicon Valleys Spending Spree Signal a Recovery?
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: A Sopranos Hat Trick: Puccini Triple Bill
description: LIFE is what happens while we are making other plans. Growing up in blue-collar Bedford, N.H., Patricia Racette sang jazz and played guitar, and when someone asked her to join the choir, her answer was No, I sing alone. Then she joined anyway, as a second alto.

title: Benmosche Says Hes Totally Committed to A.I.G.
description: The chief executive of the American International Group, Robert H. Benmosche, told employees on Wednesday that he was committed to leading the insurance giant despite disagreements with the Treasury Department over executive compensation, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

title: In Concert: Talent, Style and Sequins
description: BEFORE an October recital at the First Presbyterian Church in Germantown, a run-down Philadelphia neighborhood, the organist Cameron Carpenter wandered through the audience, shaking hands and signing programs. Then he changed from black jeans and boots into tight trousers and a shirt covered in Swarovski crystals, which glistened under the lights as he played works of Bach and his own transcriptions, including a remarkable version of Schuberts song Der Erlknig.

title: Photo of the Week
description: Members of a rare subspecies of giraffes known as Giraffa camelopardalis peralta walk through scrub brush near Koure, Niger.

title: Provocateur at Home, a Monarch Abroad
description: WHEN the American choreographer D D Dorvillier told her mother about an exciting new job she had taken in France, working with Anne Collod and a cast of European choreographers to revisit Anna Halprins seminal 1965 dance, Parades & Changes, her mother had just one question: Did this mean Ms. Dorvillier would be taking her clothes off again?

title: Sleazy Listening | Betty Davis Rides Again
description: Long before Lady Gaga, Beyonc or even Madge, there was Betty Davis. Not the smoky-eyed All About Eve star, but the preternaturally funky 1970s diva whose high-voltage performances could melt the black off tar. She was light years ahead of her leisure-suited contemporaries, who didnt get Daviss piercing growl, far-out fashions and sexually charged funk-acid rock amalgam. But now, with Light In the Attic Records releasing two of Daviss long-lost albums, Nasty Gal (1975) and Is It Love or Desire (1976), the time is right for us late adopters to catch up to this sassy soul sensation.

title: From the House of the Dead': From Theater to Opera
description: JIM OESTREICH: Charles, back to you. You were discussing Patrice Chreaus work in theater, film and opera. Does that kind of crossover happen often?

title: Overhaul at Disney Studios Picks Up Speed
description: The reorganization under way at the Walt Disney Studios accelerated on Wednesday with the promotion of several lieutenants and the jettisoning of over a dozen midlevel marketing, distribution and operations officials. The move comes after the dismissal of three top executives at the studio within the last two months: Dick Cook, the former chairman; Daniel Battsek, the president of Miramax Films; and, on Monday, Mark Zoradi, president of the Walt Disney Motion Pictures Group.

title: D.I.Y. Stardom in London
description: LONDON | If youre looking to get in touch with your inner performer, a handful of London venues are more than willing to provide you with a spotlight.

title: Looking at NFL Networks Lineup of Games
description: The NFL Network starts broadcasting its weekly game on Thursday.Heres a peek at the schedule (my comments in parentheses)

title: Brammo Cuts Price on Enertia Electric Motorcycle
description: The makers of the Brammo Enertia announced a significant price cut on Tuesday, dropping the electric-powered motorcycles price from $11,995 to $7,995. Subtracting the value of a federal income tax incentive, the company pointed out, can bring the price down to $7,195.

title: Sounds From Around the World, Some Dark, Others Delicate
description: Ithamara Koorax & Juarez Moreira

title: The Chronicler of Street Culture
description: For those who think that graffiti, such as the work of the recently-arrested tagger, Girafa, is vandalism, the work of Ari Marcopoulos is probably not for you.

title: A Big Drop in Ad Pages for Cond Nast
description: Cond Nasts ad-page numbers are in, and they explain why the company has had such a rough 2009.

title: Here Comes Another Poor Boy
description: Some say the po-boy, the signature sandwich of New Orleans, is imperiled.

title: Awed and Depressed by a Health Care Bill
description: Gail Collins: David, when I watched the House of Representatives pass the health care bill over the weekend, I felt the same combination of depression and awe I generally get when I watch Congress do something large. So ambitious! So deeply flawed! Why isnt it better? But how did they ever manage to get it done?

title: A Womans Tough Climb to the Police Force
description: The lot of police officers isnt easy, and for black women on the force its much harder. That would be the view of Savannah Black & Blue, the tale of one such officer in the New York Police Department. The playwright, Raymond Jones, knows the milieu. According to press materials for this Negro Ensemble Company production, Mr. Jones, a lieutenant in the Bronx district attorneys office, interviewed a number of women in the department for research.

title: Museum Directors on Collectors and Exhibitions
description: An article on Wednesday described concerns in the art world over the propriety of a coming show at the New Museum that will feature the private collection of a museum trustee, Dakis Joannou. In interviews, the directors of the Brooklyn Museum and the Metropolitan Museum of Art discussed their recent exhibitions featuring private collections.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Nov. 11
description: If Pictures of the Day may be said to have a theme  and sometimes they do  todays is most certainly: ritual. The observance of Veterans Day comes first and foremost, not just at Arlington National Cemetery but at Camp Eggers in Afghanistan (Slide 2). Elsewhere were the rituals of soccer ticket queueing  a dangerous contact sport in and of itself (Slide 3); of a visit from the Dalai Lama (Slide 4); and of parental anxiety over college admission prospects (Slide 8). There is also evidence, in Slide 12, of how rituals change to meet the realities of the day.

title: Exploring the Softer Side of a Choreographers Skills
description: Tere OConnor is a master of the quick fade, in which emotions and movement bubble up and vanish with little warning. In his dense choreography, transitions defy logic, meaning is made purposely hazy, and the art of subterfuge is omnipresent. As his new piece Wrought Iron Fog attests, this can work for and against him.

title: Window Watchers in a City of Strangers
description: WHEN Suzi Jones and her husband purchased an apartment on the fourth floor of a brownstone in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, two years ago, Ms. Jones, a freelance art director from Atlanta, thought what she would like most would be the hardwood floors, the tin ceilings and the renovated kitchen and bathroom.

title: Now Accessorizing | Ligia Dias for Club Monaco
description: Club Monaco has long been known for its no-frills basics, like affordable boyfriend blazers and mens-wear-inspired button-downs. Perhaps realizing that savvy downtown girls have been wearing Tom Binns jewelry with tees and jeans, Club Monaco is introducing a jewelry collaboration with Ligia Dias, who designed baubles for Lanvin for three years before starting her own line in 2005. (Rei Kawakubo snagged her to embellish the knitwear for the fall 2006 Comme des Garons collection.) The line for Club Monaco will consist of five pieces, combining the utilitarian with the refined  Dias mixed rope and brass with pearls and crystals. It is available at select Club Monaco stores and ranges in price from $149 to $399.

title: Entrepreneurs Press On, and Obstacles Fall
description: MOST entrepreneurs gauge success in numbers like dollars and market share. Jennifer VanDerHorst-Larson measures it, in part, in the words her son speaks and writes.

title: Producers of Tony N Tinas Wedding Say Unions Claim Is Untrue
description: The producers of the New York stage show Tony N Tinas Wedding disputed the account of a musicians union that said its members were locked out of the show, saying in response that the union is trying to force them to uphold an old contract using untrue words and accusations.

title: Sounds of China, Unveiled Like an Iris
description: Over the last three weeks ensembles of all kinds have dropped into Carnegie Hall to explore the exchange of musical influences between China and the West as part of the halls festival Ancient Paths, Modern Voices. The concerts have had colorful moments, some in performances by traditional ensembles of various kinds, but most in works for Western orchestra drawing on Chinese themes and timbres.

title: Farewell to the Dollhouse As Fox Ends Show
description: Update | 5:09 p.m.  That shudder you felt through your computer keyboard was the Internet responding all at once to the news that Dollhouse has been canceled. The Hollywood Reporter said that Fox was shutting down the series, created by Joss Whedon (of Buffy, Angel and Firefly fame) and starring Eliza Dushku as an enigmatic special agent whose memories and identity can be completely altered from mission to mission. The series suffered low ratings following its debut in February, but Fox unexpectedly picked up the series for its 2009-2010 season, and the show seemed to be building an online fan base. Fox had pulled the show for its November sweeps period, but the network said it would broadcast the remaining episodes it had ordered. In a message posted on the Web site whedonesque.com, Mr. Whedon wrote that he was proud of the show and the people who worked on it, adding: Im grateful that we got to put it on, and then come back and put it on again.

title: In the Holidays, Hope for the Jobless
description: For job seekers, the news that the unemployment rate has risen to 10.2 percent is dispiriting, and may even tip a few into the discouraged category  those who feel so hopeless that they stop looking and are no longer included in that statistic.

title: De-glitched, the C64s Up and Running Again
description: The on-again, off-again Commodore 64 app for Apple is on again in the iTunes app store, now improved over the original version that appearedbut only brieflyin September.

title: Bird-Watching Opera Lovers Gift to Met Confirmed
description: The executrix for an opera lover in Edinburgh who willed much of her fortune to the Metropolitan Opera confirmed reports about the extent of the gift: around $7.5 million (less 40 percent in taxes), according to a Met official. The executrix said she did not have a precise amount but said that accounts in British papers about the bequest, left by Mona Webster, who died last summer at 96, were accurate. The Met official, Gail Chesler, the director of planned and special gifts, said she had dinner with the executrix, a lawyer from Edinburgh who was in New York, before Tuesdays performance of Turandot.

title: Sweet and Sour Winter Squash
description: This dish is based on a Sicilian recipe that I learned from the food writer Clifford A. Wright. The sweet and sour flavors are typical of Sicilian cuisine, though I have changed the technique used in the authentic version, which entails sauting the squash in a lot more oil.

title: Baked Acorn Squash With Walnut Oil and Maple Syrup
description: Acorn squash has a mild flavor and goes well with sweet and nutty seasonings. This makes a nice Thanksgiving side dish, though you might want to cut the baked halves in half again for smaller portions.

title: Hands of Fate Diverge at Sealy and Simmons
description: Update | Nov. 12, 7:40 a.m. Divergent private equity strategies appear to be a big factor in explaining why two seemly identical mattress companies, Sealy and Simmons, came out of the financial crisis in such different shape.

title: Other Voices on the New Museums Exhibition
description: Update | 6:28 p.m. The New Museums decision to feature the private art collection of one of its trustees has prompted coverage in addition to The Times article Wednesday, including numerous postings by Tyler Green, on his blog, Modern Art Notes, Wiliam Powhidas graphic analysis of the insular interconnections of New Museum players on the cover of the November issue of The Brooklyn Rail, and an article, op-ed column and letter from the New Museum in The Art Newspaper.

title: Now Showing | Sharon Core at the Gallery at Herms
description: The photographer Sharon Core has accrued an almost cultlike group of followers, including yours truly and a handful of editors here at T. The Moment caught up with Core to talk about Early American, a new exhibition of breathtaking still lifes, which opens tonight at New Yorks Gallery at Herms.

title: Illegal Immigration May Be a Rift Issue
description: Abortion will not be the only social issue dividing Congress as it seeks to construct a compromise health care bill capable of passing both houses. The legislation the House passed on Saturday by a narrow margin also sets up a looming confrontation with the Senate over the extent to which illegal immigrants should have access to public resources.

title: Hewlett-Packard to Acquire 3Com
description: Hewlett-Packard said on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to acquire 3Com, a provider of computer network equipment, for $2.7 billion in a deal that H.P. plans as a springboard for an assault on the market leader in networking, Cisco Systems.

title: Canadian Literary Prize Goes to The Bishops Man, About Sexual Abuse by Priests
description: The Scotiabank Giller Prize, the annual Canadian literary award, was awarded to Linden McIntyre for his novel The Bishops Man. The novel, narrated by a priest who is charged with suppressing evidence of sexual abuse of children by other priests, was one of five finalists. Mr. McIntyre, a co-host of The Fifth Estate, an investigative journalism program on CBT, received an award of about $48,000. The prize garnered a flurry of attention in September when Alice Munro, widely considered a likely nominee for her short-story collection, Too Much Happiness, said she was withdrawing the book from consideration because she had previously won the prize twice and wanted to give younger writers a chance to win.

title: Screen Test: Megan Fox
description: Lynn Hirschberg talks to Megan Fox about swimming, the X-Men and her cats.

title: Candidates in Mass. Senate Race Spar Over Stupak Measure
description: Its not surprising that the health care legislation, which the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy spent years fighting for, has become a large issue in the campaign for his Senate seat. The unexpected part is that two candidates are fighting about whether or not to support the legislation.

title: For District 24 Qualifiers, One Deal Was a Standout
description: The three pairs that will represent District 24 (New York City and Long Island) in the North American Open Pairs Championship in Reno, Nev., next March will be Jared Lilienstein and Michael Polowan of New York; Alan Miller of New York and Alex Ornstein of Roslyn Heights, N.Y.; and Simon Erlich and Jeffrey Rothstein of New York. The qualifying tournament was played at the Vanderbilt Bridge Club in Lake Success, N.Y., on Sunday.

title: Hits to Head Pressuring the N.H.L. to Change
description: With a rash of head injuries sidelining a number of N.H.L. players, including the Rangers captain, Chris Drury, the leagues general managers, in a change of position, said they would study measures to eliminate blindside hits to the head and shoulder hits to the head.

title: Hewlett-Packard to Buy 3Com for $2.7 Billion
description: Update | 5:41 p.m. The New York Timess Steve Lohr has more details on Hewlett-Packards deal for 3Com.

title: A Team, but Watch How You Put It
description: LAS VEGAS  Andre Agassis new memoir, Open, is an unusual addition to the shelves of jock autobiography. For one thing its honest in a way that such books seldom are. Mr. Agassi famously admits that he took crystal meth and lied about it, and that he sometimes tanked matches he had no interest in playing. He also reveals that to amuse himself he lighted fires in hotel rooms, that his notorious mullet hairdo was partly a wig, that after 1997 he gave up wearing underwear on the court and that at his first wedding, to Brooke Shields, he wore lifts in his shoes so she could wear heels.

title: Now Reading | Prada
description: Prada addicts, rejoice: a 708-page catalogue raisonn of the nearly century-old brand has just been published. Prada, which was designed by Michael Rock and Sung Joong Kim of the New York firm 24, was fast-tracked over six months and orchestrated as a magazine would be, Rock said, in almost cinematic fashion.The book is slipcased in Pradas signature navy with an embossed logo and is divided into sections like Past, Inside, Stage and Product that outline the companys creative output from fashion design to runway shows, including Brigitte Lacombes black-and-white photographs of factory workers sewing, and lovingly cataloged swatches of fabrics and ensembles from seasons past. The Campaign section focuses on aspects like advertising, which, Rock explains, is the mediating factor between the fashion house and the public. The Place, Scene, Outside and Prada+ sections highlight the companys architectural epicenters in New York and Los Angeles that were designed by Rem Koolhaas/OMA, its iconic building in Tokyo by Herzog & de Meuron and branding strategies that encompass sailing regattas, nightclubs, exhibitions and the art-centric Fondazione Prada. The book has been painstakingly translated into Italian, English, Chinese, Korean and Japanese, though Miuccia Prada exclaims that fashion is instant language.

title: New Directors Named at Tate, Venice Biennale
description: The Tate Gallery said on Wednesday that it had appointed Penelope Curtis the director of its Tate Britain museum in London. The Tate said Ms. Curtis has served since 1999 as curator of the Henry Moore Institute in Leeds and has overseen the acquisition of many works for the institutes sculpture collection. Elsewhere, Artinfo reported that the Japanese architect Kazuyo Sejima was named director of the Venice Architecture Biennale for 2010. Ms. Sejima, who with Ryue Nishizawa founded the Tokyo architecture firm Sanaa, has helped design buildings including the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Manhattan. She will be the first woman to oversee the architecture biennale, which is to run from Aug. 29 to Nov. 21.

title: Disney Parks Releases Wait Time App
description: Want to find Mickey Mouse for an autograph? Want to know the wait time for Space Mountain? Well, theres an app for that  sort of.

title: Paris and New York to Swap Ballet Dancers
description: Over the years France has given New York everything from the Statue of Liberty to Daniel Boulud, and now, in its latest act of trans-Atlantic generosity, it plans to lend the city two dancers from the Paris Opera Ballet. The New York City Ballet said Aurlie Dupont and Mathias Heymann will perform at City Ballets opening-night benefit on Nov. 24. Ms. Dupont and Mr. Heymann (who are among the dancers featured in the Frederick Wiseman documentary La Danse: The Paris Opera Ballet) are to perform the Rubies pas de deux from George Balanchines Jewels. The other half of the bargain (struck by Brigitte Lefvre, the dance director of the Paris Opera Ballet, and Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of City Ballet) is that Paris gets to borrow Ashley Bouder and Gonzalo Garcia from City Ballet, who will dance the leading roles in Rubies for the Paris Opera Ballet on Thursday at the Palais Garnier. The City Ballet benefit will take place at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: V Audience Plunges
description: The audience for ABCs V on Tuesday fell substantially from its premiere a week ago, attracting 10.6 million viewers compared with 14.4 million for its debut, according to Nielsens estimates. The CBS show NCIS dominated the night with 20.2 million viewers as the network finished in first place over all, with a lineup that also included NCIS: Los Angeles (16.2 million) and The Good Wife (12.9 million). ABC was runner up, garnering 15.5 million viewers for Dancing With the Stars and 9.6 million for In the Spotlight With Robin Roberts, a news special featuring interviews with country music performers. NBC was third and Fox finished in fourth place with a two-hour installment of So You Think You Can Dance (5.7 million).

title: Tyler Says He Is Not Quitting Aerosmith
description: The shortest rift in rock music history has been healed as the estranged Aerosmith band mates Steven Tyler, far left, and Joe Perry, near left, reunited on Tuesday night, and Mr. Tyler said he was not leaving the group. Last week Mr. Perry, the bands guitarist, said Mr. Tyler quit, after Mr. Tyler gave an interview to a British music magazine saying he was preparing to focus on a solo career. Mr. Perry went so far as to announce on his Twitter feed on Monday that Aerosmith was looking for a new lead singer. But on Tuesday night, the British music publication New Musical Express reported, Mr. Tyler made a surprise appearance at a performance by Mr. Perrys band, the Joe Perry Project, at the Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza. There Mr. Tyler told the crowd, I just want New York  New York, I just want you to know I am not leaving Aerosmith, before a performance of Walk This Way with Mr. Perry and his group.

title: Underwood Is No. 1
description: Carrie Underwoods new album, Play On (19/Arista Nashville), easily reached the top of the Billboard chart this week, outselling Michael Jackson and new releases by Andrea Bocelli and Weezer. Play On, the third album for Ms. Underwood, below, and her second to reach No. 1, sold 318,000 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The soundtrack to Michael Jacksons This Is It (Epic), last weeks best seller, was No. 2 with 196,000 sales, a 48 percent drop, and the rest of the Top 5 was all new: Mr. Bocellis My Christmas (Sugar/Decca) opened at No. 3 with 149,000 sales; the soundtrack to the Fox show Glee (Columbia) reached No. 4 with 113,000; and Vol. 32 of Now Thats What I Call Music! opened at No. 5 with 102,000. Taylor Swifts Fearless (Big Machine), released a year ago and recently rereleased with more songs, fell three spots to No. 6 with 70,000 sales, for total sales of just more than 4.2 million. Weezers latest album, Raditude (DGC/Interscope), opened at No. 7 with 66,000.

title: Kingston: Trading Beach Chairs for Bar Stools
description: IT was a steamy Saturday night in Kingston, Jamaica, and the Sky Bar was jammed with its usual weekend crowd: professionals in their 20s and 30s, by all appearances fit for the next flight to South Beach. Ladies in strappy stilettos and sundresses mixed with men in jeans and crisp blazers while the R & B-heavy soundtrack veered from Stevie Wonder to Ne-Yo and Kanye West.

title: App of the Week: Tightening the Strands of Your Network
description: Dedicated social networkers practically have a full-time job jockeying a phone browser around Facebook, Twitter, texts, and who knows what else. But app makers are building virtual assistants to streamline those tasks, including a new free app called Asurion Mobile AddressBook, which was released in a test version last week.

title: Executors Named for Jackson Estate
description: A Superior Court judge in Los Angeles named two longtime associates of Michael Jackson as executors of his estate on Tuesday, dismissing a challenge filed by Mr. Jacksons father, Joe, Reuters reported. Judge Mitchell Beckloff named the lawyer John G. Branca and the music executive John McClain executors of the estate, which is expected to take in $200 million this year in revenues from the Jackson concert documentary This Is It as well as the accompanying soundtrack album and other business deals. Mr. Branca and Mr. McClain were already serving as administrators of the estate. Joe Jackson had petitioned the court to set up a monthly allowance for him, similar to one established for the singers mother, Katherine Jackson, but the judge said he had no standing to challenge his sons will.

title: Sesame Street Responds to Dispute
description: An executive for Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit organization that produces Sesame Street, said a segment on the show that upset political conservatives was equal-opportunity parody that made fun of both CNN and Fox News. The skit featured Oscar the Grouch, above, as a reporter for the Grouch News Network (abbreviated as GNN). When his work upsets a female viewer and fellow Grouch, she tells Oscar: From now on I am watching Pox News. Now theres a trashy news show! Some conservative bloggers called the comment a veiled shot at Fox News, and Michael Getler, the PBS ombudsman, wrote on his Web site, pbs.org/ombudsman, that Sesame Street producers should have avoided the joke. In a letter posted on Mr. Getlers site, Miranda Barry, an executive vice president at Sesame Workshop, responded that no political comment or comment about Fox News, subtle or overt, was intended. Having the grumpy, grouchy, contrarian Oscar on Sesame Street, Ms. Barry wrote, shows kids that you can listen to someone with a very different worldview, and even be friends with them, without losing your own perspective.

title: Moguls Skier Jeremy Bloom Retires
description: Two-time Olympic moguls star Jeremy Bloom, who aimed for a comeback in the Vancouver Olympics, has decided to retire from competitive skiing.

title: The Anguish of War for Todays Soldiers, Explored by Sophocles
description: The ancient Greeks had a shorthand for the mental anguish of war, for post-traumatic stress disorder and even for outbursts of fratricidal bloodshed like last weeks shootings at Fort Hood. They would invoke the names of mythological military heroes who battled inner demons: Achilles, consumed by the deaths of his men; Philoctetes, hollowed out from betrayals by fellow officers; Ajax, warped with so much rage that he wanted to kill his comrades.

title: On Holiday, Considering the Plight of Homeless Veterans
description: There are nearly 10,000 homeless veterans in New York City, on Long Island and in northern New Jersey, according to estimates in a new report from the Department of Veterans Affairs, which also found that veterans returning from Iraq and Afghanistan are falling into homelessness earlier than those who served in Vietnam.

title: A Satellite Radio Receiver That Works With the iPhone
description: Sirius XM Radio, always on the lookout for ways to attract fee-paying younger subscribers, is now after the Apple crowd.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) A new normal for unemployment?

title: Stephen Kings Latest Cast Feels Real
description: Under the Dome gravely threatens Stephen Kings status as a mere chart-busting pop cultural phenomenon. It has the scope and flavor of literary Americana, even if Mr. Kings particular patch of American turf is located smack in the middle of the Twilight Zone. It dispenses with his usual scatology and trippy fantasy to deliver a spectrum of credible people with real family ties, health crises, self-destructive habits and political passions. Even its broad caricatures prompt real emotion, if only via the damage they can inflict on others. Though the books broad conspiratorial strokes become farfetched, its ordinary souls become ever more able to break hearts.

title: Senate Candidates in Massachusetts Clash on Health Care Overhaul
description: Its not surprising that health care legislation, which the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy spent years fighting for, has become a large issue in the campaign for his Senate seat. The unexpected part is that two candidates are fighting about whether or not to support the legislation.

title: Weekend Swine Flu Vaccination Clinics Open to More People
description: Because of low demand among parents of school-age children, city health officials are opening their swine flu vaccination clinics to a broader group of people this weekend, city officials said.

title: A Prototype for Your Thoughts
description: THE guests who appeared to be most productively working the room at the opening of the Bits n Pieces design and digital technology show at Material ConneXion last week were four crickets in a glass-top box. They clambered up a thin wall, about four inches high, while their movements were captured by two cameras that converted them into graphic patterns.

title: The New Museums Position on Its Show From a Trustees Collection
description: Earlier this week, as Deborah Sontag and Robin Pogrebin were gathering information for an article, published Wednesday, that described concerns in the art world over the propriety of a coming show at the New Museum, the museum sent them the following statement:

title: French Embrace Sarkozy as Zelig Meme
description: In a development that may one day rank with The Onions shocking 2002 expos, Factual Error Found On Internet, French journalists have apparently discovered that on Sunday a middle-aged man posted a 20-year-old photograph of himself on his Facebook wall that may well have been taken a few days after the man said it was shot.

title: Lincolns History, Melded With a Choreographers
description: Past, present, future. History, memory, experience. The recasting of history through memory and experience. All of these slippery subjects are the matter of Bill T. Joness Serenade/The Proposition, an hourlong work that reaffirms this artists gift for creating powerful theater but reveals little of sustained choreographic interest.

title: One Handy Way to Join an Endless Conversation
description: If you have an overwhelming need to tweet your every move, youll have a hard time resisting TwitterPeek, a device that looks a little like those low-cost phones made with texting in mind, but it sends messages only to Twitter (of course, it lets you read them too).

title: Spike in 3Com Options Sets Wall Street Abuzz
description: Did someone know about Hewlett-Packards $2.7 billion deal for 3Com before it was announced?

title: More Answers to Your Sesame Street Questions
description: The landmark childrens series Sesame Street celebrated its 40th anniversary on Tuesday with a visit from the first lady, Michelle Obama.

title: Crossword | The Pilgrims
description: Play our new student crossword. You can find the answers here.

title: Under the Spell of a Mirror
description: MIDDLETOWN, R.I.

title: People Believe This Stuff
description: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: NASAs been on a campaign to ease peoples fears about the end of the world in 2012. Does anybody really think this is going to happen?  NASA announced that the movie 2012 is fiction and the Mayan calendar is wrong. And there is no mystery planet headed towards Earth thats gonna destroy it. People believe this stuff. They say the only thing that can really destroy the planet by 2012 would be, I guess, Countrywide Mortgage, A.I.G., and Wall Street.

title: New Cars for the Subway, Old Ones for the Deep
description: Why is it that in a program about the construction of brand-spanking-new New York City subway cars, the most satisfying moment comes when we see some old New York City subway cars being hurled into the ocean?

title: Whats the View Like From Your Window?
description: Matteo Pericoli has created an inside-out view of the vertical city.

title: New York City Will Be Broke
description: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Bad news for New York. Governor Paterson, the governor of New York, announced that by the end of the year, New York City will be broke. Yep. So were going to have to make lots of cuts. The Midtown Tunnel. That will be by appointment only. Call ahead. Let them know youre coming through. Metropolitan Museum has laid off three mummies. And the city temporarily has stopped constructing potholes.

title: Bing Adds Features, Including Results From Wolfram Alpha
description: Like the ringing sound it is supposed to evoke, Bing has resonated with many users and advertisers. Microsofts new search engine, first introduced in May, has made modest but steady gains in market share against Google and Yahoo.

title: White House Endorses Paid Sick Leave Bill
description: The H1N1 pandemic is raising concerns about people reporting to work sick and spreading the disease. The pandemic has given momentum to Congressional efforts to enact legislation that would guarantee paid sick days to tens of millions of workers  although it is far from clear that such legislation will be enacted. Those legislative efforts received added momentum on Tuesday when the Obama administration backed the Healthy Families Act, which would guarantee seven sick days a year to workers in companies with 15 or more employees.

title: Statistical Time Travel
description: Thats from a fascinating article in The Wall Street Journal on using math to ponder anachronistic scenarios. But forget sports heroes  the real accomplishment for these statisticians would be to settle, once and for all, the cultural arguments over W.W.J.D.

title: All Part of His Plan
description: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: CBS News is reporting that President Obama has decided to send 40,000 more troops to Afghanistan. Obama says its all part of his plan to finally deliver on the campaign promises made by John McCain.

title: The Next TV Technology Looms Ever Sharper, and Larger
description: Anyone whos seen an OLED television knows that the technology is simply extraordinary, with deep, rich blacks and an extremely sharp image.

title: Free Internet Access in Airports
description: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Google has announced that theyre going to give free Internet access in airports all across the country. Its fantastic! Up until now, the only way to see something pornographic at an airport was to follow a senator into the bathroom.

title: How to Market Your Business With Facebook
description: Business owner, you might want to friend Facebook.

title: Timothy Oulton Creates the British Man Cave
description: Timothy Oulton, a furniture maker who lives mostly in China, was in town earlier this month to oversee the setting up of his new store at ABC Carpet & Home, making sure the vintage regimental drums ($795 to $995) were stacked just so, eyeing the vintage steamer trunks ($395 to $1,995), tweaking the rows of naval flag pillows ($99.95 each). There were brass drums fashioned into chandeliers ($1,495), enormous mirrors made from reclaimed timbers ($3,295) and vast scuffed leather Chesterfield sofas ($3,995), as well as tufted sofas and ottomans ($2,995 and $1,595) upholstered in the Union Jack.

title: Gardens I Have Known
description: Books written by garden designers are often ersatz portfolios meant to promote the authors work. But the English landscape designer Dan Pearsons new book does something different: Spirit: Garden Inspiration (Fuel; $45) provides a gentle ramble not through Mr. Pearsons projects, but through his life and mind as a garden maker. The narrative can be hard to follow, and the photo captions are sparse or nonexistent, but the books impressionistic approach makes it stand out from its workaday how-to counterparts. And the photographs of gardens, art and landscapes  most taken by Mr. Pearson  have the feeling of something halfway between the introverted style of a diary and an idiosyncratic garden blog.

title: Chandeliers, Blazing With Recyclables
description: Lucy Slivinski, a sculptor in Chicago who makes lighting fixtures out of salvaged metal scraps, attributes her affinity for recycling to her grandparents, who recycled as a matter of necessity during the Depression. Wonder Bread bags, with their red, blue and yellow polka dots, she said, were crocheted into rugs; even stray pieces of string would be collected and crocheted into a container for a Kleenex box, she said. I was always picking up found objects, anything that caught my eye, little pieces of glass, pieces of metal wire.

title: Shaking It Out, in One Piece
description: Dolly, a new compact version of a salt and pepper shaker set, was designed by Ross McBride, an American who lives and works in Tokyo. The 1-piece porcelain shaker, which is 4 1/2 inches long and 3 inches wide, is casual and quirky enough to use in the kitchen but elegant enough to put on the dining table.

title: Arena Wins M.L.S. Coaching Honor
description: In his first full season in charge of the Los Angeles Galaxy, Bruce Arena led the club back to the playoffs in Major League Soccer for the first time in three seasons. Amid the hoopla and distractions that come with having a guy named David Beckham on the team, Arenas club won the Western Conference and is one game from playing for the league championship. For his efforts, Arena, who also coached the University of Virginia, D.C. United, the United States national team and the Red Bulls, was named the leagues coach of the year on Wednesday. Arena also won the award in 1997 and joins Sigi Schmid (Los Angeles in 1999; Columbus in 2008) and Bob Bradley (Chicago in 1998 and Chivas USA in 2006) as a two-time winner.

title: Settling Naturally Into a Stage of Comfort
description: The guitarist Jim Hall imbues his music with a deep, companionable rightness. His tone, dry and warm, suggests an extension of his personality. His deployment of notes, economical but fluid, complements an unassuming spirit of inquiry. And theres a naturalistic ease behind his relationship with the guitar, which partly explains his pull among inheritors like Pat Metheny and Bill Frisell, who have separately recorded with him. Everything about his playing is intuitive and rooted in modesty and humor.

title: Big Sensors, Shrinking Cameras
description: Why cant someone just build the perfect camera? I mean, come on  were not asking for the world, just a handful of prerequisites:

title: Be Careful of How You Sit on the Pillow
description: Furniture, rugs and lighting will be 50 to 80 percent off at Leperes showroom sale from Nov. 12 to 14 (an Artelano Milan Paris Chair, originally $2,514, will be $838); 20 West 22nd Street (Fifth Avenue), (212) 488-7000, lepereinc.com.

title: JetBlues New TrueBlue Program Arrives
description: JetBlue Airways marked a pair of milestones on Wednesday.

title: Choices in Infiltrating a Terrorist Cell
description: No game this year will be more controversial and more easily misrepresented than Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2. That is because it revolves around the most provocative, forcefully uncomfortable and emotionally disturbing scene yet built into interactive entertainment. Rather than survey the battlefield from a clinical distance, the game thrusts the player into the harrowing experience of modern terrorism.

title: Horse of the Year: Rachel or Zenyatta?
description: To give railbirds and racing fans a voice, The New York Times asks you to vote for one of the two standout horses in 2009, the filly Rachel Alexandra or the mare Zenyatta. Watch the special video feature making the case for each horse, cast your vote and discuss your selection in the comments area below.

title: Filly vs. Mare
description: Which horse, Rachel Alexandra or Zenyatta, deserves racings top honor? Watch the debate and vote.

title: A Better Day for Jay, a Slower Night for V
description: Tuesday again proved to be a bounce-back night for Jay Leno this week. After another weak Monday, facing opposition like Monday Night Football, Mr. Leno added almost two million viewers Tuesday night.

title: Museum Shows and Collectors: Readers Respond
description: An article on Wednesday described concerns in the art world over the propriety of a coming show at the New Museum that will feature the private collection of a museum trustee, Dakis Joannou.

title: Card-Carrying Movies
description: With video streaming an increasingly popular phenomenon, Blockbuster has apparently decided that theres still a market to rent video discs.

title: Modern Lines for the Eternal City
description: ROME  What would Pope Urban VIII have made of Maxxi, the new museum of contemporary art designed by Zaha Hadid on the outskirts of this citys historic quarter? My guess is that he would have been ecstatic.

title: Apps to Help Guard Against Flu, and Worse.
description: If just thinking about the H1N1 Swine Flu virus gives you the chills, Harvard Medical School may offer well, not a remedy, but a safeguard.

title: Weighing the Virtues of Credit Cards in Cabs
description: To all of the retailers who complain about how much it costs them to accept the credit cards, I always want to shout this: How much less would you be making if people couldnt use cards at all?

title: Performa 09: William Kentridge on Divided Selves
description: The South African artist William Kentridge was part of a successful puppet troupe before he became known as a visual artist who explored the painful legacy of apartheid in tragic-comedic stop-action animations. His films unfold in vigorously hand-drawn charcoal scenes that mutate as we watch, with images often emerging from and disappearing into small cyclones of sooty black. A frequent character in these tales was Soho Eckstein, a wealthy, sometimes guilt-ridden Johannesburg businessman with an active fantasy life who bears a striking resemblance to the artist.

title: He Shoots, He Scores  in 2 Seconds
description: First came what is reputed to be the worlds fastest goal, then came the entertaining celebration.

title: Bing, Now With More Wolfram
description: Microsoft today announced that it will begin integrating statistics and other data from computational engine Wolfram Alpha into its search engine Bing.

title: Week 10 in Fantasy Football Matchups
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 10. They also answered reader questions earlier this week. Read their answers below. Also, scroll down for reading tips from the Fantasy Football Librarian.

title: Lou Dobbs to Quit CNN
description: Lou Dobbs, the longtime CNN anchor whose anti-immigration views have made him a TV lightning rod, said Wednesday that he is leaving the cable news channel effective immediately.

title: New Fame for the Everyday Donor
description: AFTER years in the shadows, the everyday donor is emerging as philanthropys newest hero, the driver of a more down-to-earth approach to charity. Sure, Bill and Melinda Gates, Warren Buffett, Bono and other celebrity mega-donors still have their place, but now high-profile charities are homing in on smaller donations, while new charities are being organized around the principle of modest giving.

title: Searching for the Perfect Internet Business
description: Dan recently became an accidental entrepreneur  although my gut tells me it wasnt completely accidental. In any case, hes searching for an established Web site to call his own. And Ive been asked to help.

title: The Making of a Tintype
description: Using 19th-century guidebooks, a photographer uses the Civil War-era chemistry and technology to create his images.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Worlds Most Colorful Video Artist
description: In a dark, silo-shaped room in the upscale Jardim Europa neighborhood of So Paulo, Brazil, last month, an impassioned aesthetic debate was underway, though it would have been tough for anyone walking into the room to tell. I was at a place called the Museum of Image and Sound, lying on my back with seven other people, all of us completely silent in brightly colored hammocks that had been hung around a circular scaffolding. Our feet angled together toward the center of the room and our heads radiated out like lotus petals. We were all staring up at the ceiling, where two video works were being projected, both featuring a pale, red-headed woman who looked like a Nereid sprung to life. In the first video, she navigates her way through a candy-colored world  a birch forest; a long airportlike corridor; a leaf-strewn sidewalk that the camera scuttles along low and fast, as if from the vantage point of a bug.

title: Correction: Perversely Content, Ensconced in Chaos
description: An article on Oct. 22 about the writer Augusten Burroughss home in Battery Park City misstated a word in a quotation regarding his writing process. Mr. Burroughs said: I write from memory. And I have my diaries (not dairies).

title: Correction: A Dream Home Undone by Divorce
description: An article last Thursday, about the renovation of a TriBeCa loft and the subsequent divorce of the couple who owned it, misspelled the surname of one of the projects architects. He is Todd Rouhe, not Ruhe.

title: Getting Photos Off Broken Cards
description: Q. Is there any way to get the pictures off a broken Secure Digital card?

title: U.S. Envoy Urges Caution on Forces for Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  The United States ambassador to Afghanistan, who once served as the top American military commander there, has expressed in writing his reservations about deploying additional troops to the country, three senior American officials said Wednesday.

title: Dress Codes | New Victorians
description: Many of todays popular mens styles have their roots in the late 19th century.

title: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2
description: The game, developed by Infinity Ward and released by Activision this week, thrusts the player into the harrowing experience of modern terrorism.

title: Performa 09: Joan Jonas Does Dante
description: One of the highlights of Performa 09 is Joan Jonass Reading Dante II, which began its five-night run (with one matinee) at the Performing Garage Tuesday night. It amounts to a 60-minute multimedia collage in the round with moving parts and a smorgasbord of audio accompaniment. This includes music, loud crashes, traffic noises, and voices reading fragments of the works inspiration: the Inferno, Purgatorio and Paradiso of Dantes Divine Comedy.

title: "I Couldn't Agree With You More"
description: Excerpt from "I Couldn't Agree With You More," 1999. Courtesy of the artist and Hauser & Wirth and Luhring Augustine, New York.

title: "Pour Your Body Out"
description: Excerpt from"Pour Your Body Out (7354 Cubic Meters)," 2008, sound by Anders Guggisberg. Courtesy of the artist and Hauser & Wirth and Luhring Augustine, New York.

title: "I'm Not The Girl Who Misses Much"
description: Excerpt from "I'm Not The Girl Who Misses Much," 1986, video & sound by Pipilotti Rist. Courtesy of the artist and Hauser & Wirth and Luhring Augustine, New York.

title: "Ever Is Over All"
description: Excerpt from "Ever Is Over All," 1997. Courtesy of the artist and Hauser & Wirth and Luhring Augustine, New York.

title: "Homo Sapiens Sapiens"
description: Excerpt from "Homo Sapiens Sapiens," 2005. Sound by Anders Guggisberg and Pipilotti Rist. Courtesy of the artist and Hauser & Wirth and Luhring Augustine, New York.

title: Nabokovs Last Puzzle
description: In the late fall of 1976, the year before he died, The New York Times Book Review asked Vladimir Nabokov (along with a number of other writers, including John Dean) what hed been reading lately. He reported that while in a Lausanne hospital that summer, hed read Dantes Inferno, William H. Howes Butterflies of North America and The Original of Laura, the not quite finished manuscript of a novel which I had begun writing and reworking before my illness and which was completed in my mind. In his delirium, he continued, he kept reading it aloud to a small dream audience in a walled garden. My audience consisted of peacocks, pigeons, my long dead parents, two cypresses, several young nurses crouching around, and a family doctor so old as to be almost invisible. Perhaps because of my stumblings and fits of coughing the story of my poor Laura had less success with my listeners than it will have, I hope, with intelligent reviewers when properly published. I can take a hint: whod want to pan Nabokov and end up among the mediocrities on his enemies list, to which he might still be adding over on the other side?

title: For Causes, Its a Tougher Sell
description: THE wretched economy has forced many consumers to, well, consume less, or at least less avidly than they did before the bubble  or bubbles, if you count Wall Street and real estate  burst.

title: Performance Anxiety
description: But enough about you, Dear Reader, lets talk about Philip Roth. Or Nathan Zuckerman or David Kepesh or Mickey Sabbath. Or any of the maddeningly, entertainingly and sometimes tediously self-involved heroes whose lives and loves mirror those of their author. A Roth by any other name would still suffer the affliction identified by O. Spielvogel, the fictional psychiatrist an excerpt of whose imagined article, The Puzzled Penis, introduced the reading world to Portnoys Complaint. A condition marked by extreme sexual longings, compulsive sexual behaviors and overriding feelings of shame and the dread of retribution, particularly in the form of castration, Portnoys complaint outgrew its eponymous novel and manifested itself in one Roth protagonist after another.

title: The Morning After
description: You always knew Mary Karr wasnt telling you everything. There were tantalizing hints of adult life in her two coming-of-age memoirs, The Liars Club and Cherry. But Lit is the book in which she grows up and gets serious, as serious as motherhood, as serious as alcoholism, as serious as God. And it just makes her funnier. In a gravelly, ground-glass-under-your-heel voice that can take you from laughter to awe in a few sentences, Karr has written the best book about being a woman in America I have read in years.

title: The Silver-Screen Palate
description: I may be the only fan of The Last Waltz who regards it as a food movie. Directed by Martin Scorsese, it is an account of the Bands last concert at the Winterland Ballroom in San Francisco in 1976, which began after an audience of 5,000 had sat down to a full Thanksgiving dinner. True, you never see the turkey, but then you hardly see the audience either. The hodgepodge, communal November meal seems to set the tone for the whole movie, as the performers on the stage lay out a hodgepodge feast of American music, from the blues to Tin Pan Alley.

title: When All the Worlds a Staged Game
description: In his imagination, Greg Trefry is building a golf course right in the middle of Manhattan where he will make his fortune charging everyone to play.

title: Road Trip
description: Though many of us (Peter Ackroyd included) greatly would prefer common readers to learn just enough Middle English to begin enjoying Chaucers poetry in the original, that evades the way things are and the way they are going to be. Retelling Chaucer in our contemporary prose necessarily is a great loss, yet so rich is Chaucer that enormous value remains in Ackroyds robust versions of The Canterbury Tales.

title: Outreach in the Age of Pullback
description: WASHINGTON

title: Switzerland Limits Bank Compensation, but Not Too Harshly
description: Switzerland announced watered-down measures to limit bank compensation Wednesday, imposing no caps on bonuses and excluding all but the countrys biggest financial services companies from mandatory compliance.

title: Hank and Dollhouse Out, UneXpected In
description: The fall television season is winding down, which means that broadcast networks are beginning to clear out shows that have failed to attract audiences this year and scheduling some that they hope will do better.

title: Dobbs Explains Decision to Leave CNN
description: The text of Mr. Dobbs announcement about leaving CNN:

title: This Just in From the 1890s
description: ITS usually easy to distinguish between clothes and costumes: either youre Spider-Man, or youre not.

title: Japan Cools to America as It Prepares for Obama Visit
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will arrive in Tokyo on Friday, at a time when Americas relations with Japan are at their most contentious since the trade wars of the 1990s  and back then, the fights were over luxury cars and semiconductors, not over whether the two countries should re-examine their half-century-old strategic relationship.

title: Im Innocent. Just Check My Status on Facebook.
description: The message on Rodney Bradfords Facebook page, posted at 11:49 a.m. on Oct. 17, asked where his pancakes were. The words were typed from a computer in his fathers apartment in Harlem.

title: Leaving a Bank for a Foundation Proved Rewarding
description: IN 1994, Marley Kaplan saw an ad for a half-time job at a not-for-profit organization. The pay: $25,000 a year.

title: Swine Flu Clinics to Be Opened to a Broader Group of People This Weekend
description: Because of low demand among parents of school-age children, city health officials are opening their swine flu vaccination clinics to a broader group of people this weekend, city officials said.

title: Two-Year Colleges, Swamped, No Longer Welcome All
description: Sonja Taylor applied to LaGuardia Community College this summer with every expectation of being admitted. She planned to study business, bringing her closer to her dream of owning a restaurant.

title: At Christies, Return of American Collectors
description: Some of the great names in postwar and contemporary art were solid sellers at Christies on Tuesday night. And while American collectors were back, dominating the bidding, price mattered. Only one work  a 1996 painting by the Scottish artist Peter Doig  broke the $10 million barrier in a mixed sale that included property once belonging to Merce Cunningham, the dancer and choreographer, and his partner in life and work, the composer John Cage.

title: Motorola Said to Explore Dividing Into 3 Companies
description: Motorola, which has said it wants to split into two separate companies, is exploring a three-way split instead in order to raise cash and pay down debt.

title: Coming to Fox, Our Little Genius
description: Fox announced on Wednesday that it is seeking participants for a new game show that will allow parents of young geniuses  age 6 to 12  to put their kids knowledge to use winning life-changing money.

title: It Was No Walk in the Park
description: HIGH on the list of stock American fantasies  after winning the lottery, single-handedly saving the world from nuclear obliteration and telling off your boss  is becoming a model.

title: A Patchwork of Food Assistance for Pets
description: ANIMAL shelters have reported a steep rise in the number of cats and dogs being surrendered as owners face unemployment, home foreclosures, evictions and other financial hardships. But animal welfare groups and even churches are stepping up with bags of kibble and containers of cat litter to help owners keep their pets and to prevent more from being sent to shelters, and sometimes death.

title: John J. OConnor III, Husband of Former Justice, Is Dead at 79
description: John J. OConnor III, a lawyer whose struggle with Alzheimers disease was a large factor in the decision by his wife, former Justice Sandra Day OConnor, to retire from the United States Supreme Court, died Wednesday in Phoenix. He was 79.

title: Pull Up a Book and Have a Seat
description: THE last decade has seen such a glut of fashion monographs that it seems a designer is nobody if he or she has not yet been the subject of a 20-pound book. Like, its getting a little ridiculous when you have to ask what your coffee table is wearing.

title: Okinawans Grow Impatient With Dashed Hopes on U.S. Base
description: GINOWAN, Japan  Okinawans like Zenji Shimada, who have spent most of their lives under the thudding of helicopters from a busy American air base, are accustomed to disappointment. Decades of complaints about the base here and others on the island have gone largely unheeded, and a painstakingly negotiated plan to move the Marines from populated areas remains years from completion.

title: Senator Faces G.O.P. Rebuke Back Home
description: WASHINGTON    Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, has been censured by local Republican officials in his home state.

title: Lemony Snickets New Series and Young Adult Novel
description: Lemony Snicket, the notorious pseudonym of Daniel Handler and the author of the bestselling Series of Unfortunate Events sequence, has agreed to sell the North American rights to publish a new four-part series to Little, Brown & Co., moving from HarperCollins.

title: Something to Rah-Rah-Rah About for Christmas
description: GAP is celebrating the coming holiday season with glee  or perhaps that should be Glee.

title: Kramnik Pulls Ahead Again at Moscow Tournament
Offering a Helping Hand, and Then Needing One
description: Nannette Perkins, 61, has a catalog of health problems. After she had a heart attack last year, doctors used a stent to open a valve. Because of a long-ago work-related injury, she struggles with a bad back and walks with a cane. A diabetic, she checks her blood sugar daily.

title: Unlike Minaya, Cashman Stands on Solid Ground
description: CHICAGO  After two and a half days of meetings with colleagues and agents here, Omar Minaya and Brian Cashman were both headed back to New York on Wednesday, yet still somehow going in different directions.

title: North Korea Warns South After Naval Clash
description: SEOUL  North Korea said Thursday that South Korea would pay a dear price for the naval clash on Tuesday that was the most serious between the countries in seven years, while South Korea sent additional warships near the site of the confrontation in a disputed sea border.

title: Sanchez Returns to His Roots During Week Off
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Rex Ryan, the Jets first-year coach, is 46 years old. He came to work Wednesday with a gray stubble on his chin and cheeks. Mark Sanchez, the Jets rookie quarterback, turned 23 years old Wednesday. He came to work with much darker whiskers on his fresher-looking face.

title: The Chain Store as Patron of the Arts
description: WHEN Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts opens its new visitor atrium this month, it will also inaugurate Target Free Thursdays: free concerts featuring professionals from Lincoln Center organizations like the New York City Opera and the New York Philharmonic as well as performances by students from the Juilliard School and other artists.

title: Among Late-Night Writers, Few Women in the Room
description: In many ways, television today is about women more than men.

title: Rep. Kennedy and Bishop in Bitter Rift on Abortion
description: Representative Patrick J. Kennedy of Rhode Island was to meet Thursday with Thomas J. Tobin, the Roman Catholic bishop of Providence, and perhaps start healing a bitter rift over whether health care legislation now before Congress should restrict abortion coverage.

title: From an Idea by Students, a Million-Dollar Charity
description: THE titans of Wall Street are famous for star-studded galas that raise millions of dollars for a host of good causes. And for a tiny group of high school students on Long Island, taking a page out of these financiers books has made their own charity, A Midwinter Nights Dream, a million-dollar success.

title: San Francisco MoMA Finds a New Way to Expand
description: THE expansion of an art museum doesnt typically galvanize the building of a fire station. But philanthropy at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in recent months has been far from typical.

title: Thieves in Milwaukee Show a Patriotic Side, Declining to Rob Army Reservist
description: Kyle Windorski, a 21-year-old college student in the Army Reserve, was walking home Tuesday morning on the east side of Milwaukee when four men with stocking caps over their faces forced him into an alley at gunpoint and demanded cash.

title: A Big Splash From an Upstart Medical Center
description: TO many people who suffer from the poorly understood illness called chronic fatigue syndrome, a recent study linking the disorder to a virus was a victory for the little guys.

title: Charges Prompt Iraqis to Look Into Blackwater
description: WASHINGTON  A senior Iraqi official said Wednesday that he had ordered an investigation into whether top officials of Blackwater Worldwide approved of bribes to Iraqi government officials after shootings by Blackwater guards in 2007 left 17 Iraqi civilians dead.

title: Push to Build Mosques Is Met With Resistance
description: COPENHAGEN  Paris has its grand mosque, on the Left Bank. So does Rome, the city of the pope. Yet despite a sizable Muslim population, this Danish city has nothing but the occasional tiny storefront Muslim place of worship.

title: A Year After an Immigrants Death, Signs of Hope
description: PATCHOGUE, N.Y.

title: After Criticism, the Administration Is Praised for Final Rules on Education Grants
description: Three months after provoking an outpouring of criticism with preliminary plans for the nations largest competitive education grant program, the Obama administration has added flexibility in the final rules, released Wednesday, drawing praise from a state governor who was initially critical and from leaders of the national teachers unions.

title: Depression Haunted Goalkeeper Killed by Train
description: The official Web site of the Hannover 96 soccer club was blacked out Wednesday except for a simple statement: Wir trauern um Robert Enke. We mourn for Robert Enke.

title: For Some N.B.A. Players, Theres No Such Thing as a Slam Dunk
description: Jason Kapono doesnt dunk. That fact would be unremarkable were it not for his occupation and his height.

title: A Net Reaches Out to Fans, Wherever They Are
description: NEWARK

title: Lou Dobbs and the Facts
description: Look for the stories about Lou Dobbss departure from CNN to say that he was controversial figure. No doubt he is. But thats not really the main point about Mr. Dobbs. The main point is that he has a long history of not telling the truth.

title: Raising Real Money in a Virtual World
description: FOUR years ago, the visitors at SecondLife.com staged a virtual walkathon and raised $5,000 for the American Cancer Society by sending avatars walking in loops with mouse clicks and key strokes.

title: Dollars That Turn Into Bees, and Other Gifts Given Twice
description: THIS holiday season, consumers are expected to cut back both their spending on holiday gifts as well as their giving to charity.

title: Arbitrator Said to Doze During Teachers Hearing
description: The process of firing a New York City teacher on charges of incompetence could certainly be described as time consuming. Hearings take so long  hundreds of hours  and so many details are scrutinized that it might be enough to put someone to sleep.

title: Shopping for Clothing, Donating Time
description: IN the newly expanded Banana Republic store opening in New York Citys SoHo district this month, shoppers may be surprised to discover, amid the displays of red double-breasted peacoats and cowl neck sweaters, a representative from a local volunteer group asking if they would like to donate some time. Think of it as consumerism meets volunteerism.

title: Israeli and French Leaders Meet
description: PARIS  After meeting for 90 minutes, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France announced in a joint statement on Wednesday evening that they had agreed to work toward immediately reviving the peace process in the Middle East and discussed international efforts to stop Iran from enriching uranium.

title: Somalis Money Is Lifeline for Homeland
description: PARIS  As Somalis struggle to survive the chaos that has overtaken their country, a network of companies that distribute money from the nations large diaspora has quietly expanded, providing a crucial safety net.

title: Clicking for a Cause
description: BRAD SUGARS says he believes that cancer can be defeated, one birthday at a time.

title: U.S. Plans Raw Warm-Water Oyster Ban
description: A federal effort to ban the sale of raw oysters harvested during the warm months along the Gulf Coast has kicked up a hurricane of opposition from oystermen and members of Congress and threatened to derail a signature food-safety initiative by the Obama administration.

title: As Shipping Slows, Banks and Carriers Fear Loan Defaults
description: LONDON  When Eastwind Maritime, a medium-size carrier company, went bankrupt this summer, few banks in the United States took notice.

title: A.I.G. Chiefs Mission: Save Executive Pay
description: The American International Groups chief executive on Wednesday tried to calm fears that he was about to jump ship, with an open letter to employees announcing he was totally committed to leading A.I.G. through its challenges.

title: Raising Morale Far From Home
description: A SURVIVOR of World War IIs infamous Bataan Death March, Dr. Lester Tenney endured over three years of slave labor as a Japanese prisoner of war, with no word from home. I would have been so happy to get a package of any kind, Dr. Tenney said. I wouldnt have cared what was in it  just the fact that someone would think of me and send something. Oh Lord, that would have been exciting!

title: In Leaning on Karzai, U.S. Has Limited Leverage
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama delivered a rare and public call last week for President Hamid Karzai to crack down on corruption in Afghanistan, there was one glaring omission from his remarks  an or else.

title: Questions, Not Alarms, Met Exchanges With Cleric
description: WASHINGTON  Last December, the vast electronic net of American intelligence captured queries that Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan of the Army was sending by e-mail to a radical cleric in Yemen who has long been a target of American surveillance.

title: Galas Dispense With Some of the Froth
description: THE world of charity galas and fund-raising parties has always been a world of fantasy and illusion: white voile-draped dinner tents, towering long-stemmed centerpieces, big society bands and black tie or tails. A little buttery beef and champagne, a winning bid for a high-ticket auction item, and blow the check dry. From museums to hospitals to foundations and other not-for-profits, its New Yorks institutional gravy train  over 275 events last month alone, from Carnegie Halls opening night gala to Project Migrations wine-tasting party.

title: The agony of Fox Business
description: James Wolcott is made of sterner stuff than I am: he actually has the fortitude to watch Fox Business, where the talking heads manage to find nothing but clouds in the silver lining of a huge stock rally. To make their point they bring on such market experts as  John Bolton. As Wolcott writes, It takes more than a market rally to pull the wool over Boltons mustache. (Now thats writing!)

title: Cavaliers Looking Good in Return to Orlando
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  For more than two hours Wednesday night, Shaquille ONeal and Dwight Howard shuffled across the same polished floor boards, their paths similar but distant, like satellites traveling in separate orbits.

title: Lou Dobbs Abruptly Quits CNN
description: Months ago the president of CNN/U.S., Jonathan Klein, offered a choice to Lou Dobbs, the channels most outspoken anchor. Mr. Dobbs could vent his opinions on radio and anchor an objective newscast on television, or he could leave CNN.

title: U.S. Adviser to Kurds Stands to Reap Oil Profits
description: OSLO  Peter W. Galbraith, an influential former American ambassador, is a powerful voice on Iraq who helped shape the views of policy makers like Joseph R. Biden Jr. and John Kerry. In the summer of 2005, he was also an adviser to the Kurdish regional government as Iraq wrote its Constitution  tough and sensitive talks not least because of issues like how Iraq would divide its vast oil wealth.

title: The Betrayal
description: ST. LOUIS  So long as Budweiser, the King of Beers, was enthroned in this pleasant and nobly resilient middle American city, the blows of corporate condescension from the other giants who abandoned the Gateway Arch could be endured.

title: At Fort Hood, Witness Credits Second Officer
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley has been applauded as a hero across the nation for shooting down Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan during the bloody rampage at Fort Hood last week. The account of heroism, given by the authorities, attracted the attention of newspapers, the networks and television talk shows.

title: L.I. Harvests May Signal a Comeback for Scallops
description: GREENPORT, N.Y.  Bone-tired but grinning, Peter Wenczel and his son Ben eased their 26-foot work boat toward the dock here one recent afternoon, its deck piled high with bags of scallops.

title: Billionaires Learn Giving Is Only a Start
description: BILL GATES: The Real Secretary of Education, ran a recent headline on the state of education reform in America, prompted by the unhappiness of teachers unions about the growing influence of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation in Washington, D.C.. This reflects a new phase in the development of this generation of megadonors, in which the success or failure of their philanthropic agendas may be determined by their ability to master the dark arts of politics.

title: Charity Bankruptcy Leaves Many Donors in Distress
description: A CAUTIONARY tale for donors who entered into two time-tested, long-term giving arrangements  charitable gift annuities and donor-advised funds  has emerged from bankruptcy court.

title: As Foundations Close, Anxiety for Charities
description: FOUNDATIONS that increase grants to spend down their endowment and then close are proving to be a boon to charities in the short run, but the trend is also causing anxiety among the charities about their future fund-raising.

title: Gerrymandering, Pure and Corrupt
description: Of all the tricks that New Yorks legislators use to hang on to office, the one that works best  for the politicians, that is  is redistricting. Mapmaking in Albany is a dark art form designed to make absolutely certain that incumbents in the majority party are safe from electoral competition (a k a democracy).

title: In Charity Tax Filing, a Glimpse of Goldman
description: The latest tax filing for Goldman Sachss foundation is as thick as a phone book. The list of trades is more than 200 pages, single spaced. Goldman, it seems, invests like no other, even for its own charity.
