title: Liquid Marijuana Seized in Brooklyn
description: In what the police called an unusual drug arrest, a Brooklyn man was charged on Wednesday with selling liquid marijuana.

title: Lottery Numbers
Bloggingheads: Afghanistan as Duty
description: Christopher Preble, left, of the Cato Institute and Peter Beinart of the New America Foundation debate public support for the Afghanistan war.

title: Tycoon With a Reputation
description: Wah-wah-taysee, little fire-fly,Little, flitting, white-fire insect,Little, dancing, white-fire creature,Light me with your little candle,Ere upon my bed I lay me,Ere in sleep I close my eyelids! The Song of Hiawatha by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

title: Cozy Booths and Halls of Power: Peeks in Bruno Case
description: ALBANY  For decades, Jacks Oyster House has been a favored haunt of the capitals political elite, serving up healthy portions of gossip and deal-making along with its signature dish, sauted calfs liver.

title: Ad Pages Drop For Magazines Of Conde Nast
description: Cond Nasts ad-page numbers are in for its 2009 issues, helping shed light on why the company made sharp cuts this fall.

title: Shuffled Lineup Cant Avert Second-Half Slide
description: Mike DAntoni has kept his hand on the lever, tweaking and tinkering with his lineup in search of a winning combination or at least one that makes a respectable showing.

title: Mets Monitoring Safety of Prospect in Venezuela
description: CHICAGO  Amid kidnappings and war rhetoric in Venezuela, the Mets may recommend that the catching prospect Josh Thole return home from his winter league team there.

title: Video Bingo Has Alabamians Yelling Everything But
description: ASHVILLE, Ala.  Everybody knows what this is: dozens of people, mostly retirees, hunched over paper grids in a smoke-filled American Legion hall on a Sunday evening listening eagerly to a woman recite numbers.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a possible severe shortage of seasonal flu vaccine in the United States misattributed an assertion that Bush administration officials pressed Congress for money to develop vaccine technology but never got as much as they sought. The comment was by Michael T. Osterholm, director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota  not by William Hall, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about plans by the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Manhattan to present an exhibition of art owned by one of its trustees, Dakis Joannou, referred imprecisely, in citing similar arrangements, to a collector whose old master drawings were exhibited by the Metropolitan Museum of Art this year. The collector, Jean Bonna, is an honorary trustee of the Met, not a trustee.

title: Corrections
description: A Political Memo article on Saturday about the effect of last weeks elections on the health care debate in Congress misstated the middle initial for the Republican who is the governor-elect of Virginia. He is Robert F. McDonnell, not Robert H.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the election defeat of New Jerseys Democratic governor misspelled his surname at one point and misstated, in some copies, the number of political campaigns in which he spent more than $130 million of his own fortune. As noted elsewhere, he is Jon S. Corzine, not Cozine, and that sum was spent over three campaigns, not two  one for United States Senate in 2000, and two for governor, in 2005 and this year.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Itineraries page on Nov. 3 with an article about travel management companies negotiating rates for the coming year referred incorrectly to the Peninsula Hotel in Shanghai. It is a new hotel; it is not newly renovated.

title: Warhol Fetches $43.7 Million at Auction
description: It was the sale of the season. When a seminal Warhol  one of the artists first silk-screen paintings  came on the block at Sothebys auction of contemporary art on Wednesday night, the auctioneer, Tobias Meyer, opened bidding at $6 million and was stunned when a bidder instantly doubled it.

title: Corrections
description: The Mind column on Oct. 6, about the ability of nonsense to sharpen the mind, reported findings from a flawed statistical analysis. The authors of a study that was described in the column reported that subjects who read a Kafka-inspired short story were more accurate in seeing hidden patterns than people who had read a more coherent short story. After a reader questioned the analysis, the researchers repeated the experiment and found no significant difference between the groups. (A similar experiment reported in the same paper, in the journal Psychological Science, did hold up to re-analysis.)

title: Bush Emerging for Speech to Kick Off Public Policy Institute
description: DALLAS  Nearly 10 months after leaving office, former President George W. Bush plans to emerge from self-imposed political hibernation on Thursday as he starts a new public policy institute to promote some of the domestic and international priorities of his presidency.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an effort to collect seeds to save species, possibly by relocating them through a process known as assisted migration, misstated the surname of the plant conservation program manager at the Bureau of Land Management. She is Peggy Olwell, not Orwell.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: New York City Veterans Day Parade
description: Three servicemen attending the city's Veteran's Day parade shared opinions on the war in Afghanistan and the military's treatment of soldiers' mental health.

title: Here He Is ...
description: Hmm, which will be more macho, the 11th Annual Mr. Lower East Side pageant or the 32nd Annual Empire State Golden Arms Tournament of Champions? Both involve flexing and posing, beer and possibly pizza, but only one is held at the Port Authority. Point to arm-wrestlers.

title: Dress Code
description: Attention dandies and wannabes: you can outfit yourself and your man-cave on Thursday, just in time for, um, Call of Duty season. From Timothy Oultons naval flag pillows [LINK to Pulse in Home] at ABC Carpet to the tweedy vests, woolen trousers, henley undershirts, dark wool ties, scratchy cotton shirts that, David Colman writes, can be found in shops like Amoskeag XX or Hollander & Lexer, youll have all the accoutrements youd need to make your way to a Tweed Ride  or, at least, a reading about obsolete technology.

title: Author, Author
description: You think your relationship is complicated? Stephen Elliott, who chronicled his long-term San Francisco threesome, has covered murder, false confession and S&M in his new memoir,  The Adderall Diaries . >Brian DeLeeuw took on childhood bromances in his debut novel,  In This Way I Was Saved,  and inNancy Mauros imaginative mystery  New World Monkeys,  a couple travels to their upstate refuge  only to discover a grave site. The authors read from their work tonight at KGB Bar.

title: Breathing Room
description: Dawn Turro has cancer, but she still considers herself fortunate. Unlike many Americans who are sick, she has had good medical care and health insurance to help pay for it. Insurance covered her mastectomy, and when the cancer spread to her spine, it covered the cost of radiation and chemotherapy. After her husband, Robert, lost his job in December 2008, the company where he had worked for 27 years extended the familys medical coverage, allowing Ms. Turro to continue treatment.

title: Hannity Admits to Using Incorrect Video
description: On his show on the Fox News Channel Wednesday night, Sean Hannity admitted to using scenes from a different rally to illustrate a report on a health care protest last week.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,352 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 906 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

title: Azerbaijan: Bloggers Convicted
description: Two bloggers in Azerbaijan who regularly posted video political parodies were convicted of hooliganism on Wednesday, prompting criticism that the government was clamping down on independent media. The bloggers, Adnan Hajizade, 26, and Emin Milli, 30, were arrested in July after a fight at a restaurant that they said had been orchestrated by the authorities. It occurred soon after Mr. Hajizade and Mr. Milli appeared to poke fun at the authoritarian government of Azerbaijan, a former Soviet republic, by posting a video in which a donkey holds a news conference. The prosecution said the arrests had nothing to do with the video. Mr. Hajizade received a term of two years in prison, and Mr. Milli received two and a half years. In Washington, the State Department assailed the verdict.

title: New Levels of Inclusion at Country Music Awards
description: Its safe to say that this is the first year in which the most important people at the Country Music Association Awards were an African-American man and a teenage girl, but so it went Wednesday night at the 43rd edition of the awards, celebrating a year of increasingly porous borders in Nashville.

title: Where To Spend $100 Billion, Health or Helmand?
description: Im theoretically on vacation, peddling my book on book tour, but with health care reform in the balance I just couldnt bear to stay away from the fray. So I frantically sent last-minute word that I would file my column after all, and my Thursday column tries to compare the choices on health reform and Afghan troop deployments.

title: More Foreclosures to Come
description: After a few months of some better than expected housing news, home prices are likely to fall again, driven lower by a renewed surge in foreclosures. By conservative estimates, another 2.4 million homes will be lost in 2010, while prices will fall another 10 percent or so. This should be a wake-up call for the Obama administration. Foreclosures are expected to surge, in part, because lenders have been delaying the process during the long rollout of the administrations antiforeclosure plan. But according to Moodys Economy.com, most troubled borrowers ultimately will not qualify for help, and a backlog of bad loans will soon enter foreclosure.

title: The Search for the Why of Fort Hood
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Memorial Service, a Balm From Obama
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankers and Bonuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Vying for the Flu Vaccine
description: To the Editor:

title: Sacrifice, or Good Sense?
description: To the Editor:

title: Take a Deep Breath
description: In troubled times, it is important to try to maintain a certain level of serenity. Right now we citizens have quite a lot on our plate and there is no reason to go completely crazy about the least little thing.

title: Americas Defining Choice
description: President Obama and Congress will soon make defining choices about health care and troops for Afghanistan.

title: Trading Womens Rights for Political Power
description: Washington

title: How the Scapegoats Escaped
description: THE quick not guilty verdict reached Tuesday afternoon by a Brooklyn jury in the federal criminal trial of two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers was at once surprising  for its failure to comport with the zeitgeist  but also entirely understandable, based on a close reading of the prosecutions arguments and the evidence the judge allowed to be introduced. There was a reasonable doubt on every charge, one juror told The Times afterward. We just didnt feel that the case had been proven.

title: Showcase: See and Be Seen
description: Its a difficult time for young photographers trying to make their way into photojournalism. There are few assignments and fewer staff jobs. It is unclear what paths  if any  might lead to success.

title: One Lynching in Cairo, Ill.; Then, Another
description: Friday, Nov. 12, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Word of the Day | pacify
description: pacify  \pa-s-fi \  verb

title: A 40-Cent Wings Special and Gunfire
description: Its not uncommon for teenagers to flock to the mall at the end of a school day. But something went awry on Tuesday, when thousands of high school students descended on the Atlantic Center Mall in Brooklyn and a stabbing and shootings followed.

title: As G.E. Struggles, a Rival Steps Up
description: It is only fitting that United Technologies is poised to buy assets from its cross-state rival General Electric. At least in the eyes of shareholders, United Technologies  the manufacturer of Otis elevators, Pratt & Whitney jet engines and Sikorsky helicopters  has emerged as the more successful of the two industrial conglomerates, both based in Connecticut.

title: Mythical End for Legendary Route 66
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  The question of where the old Route 66 officially ended in the West has been the subject of debate among history buffs and roadsters. On Wednesday it was resolved in a quintessentially American way, by placing the terminus in a place where it can best be monetized.

title: A Salute to Fallen Americans
description: WHOM does Veterans Day honor? WHOM do you know who is a veteran of war?

title: Entrepreneurs Press On, and Obstacles Fall
description: Most entrepreneurs gauge success in numbers like dollars and market share. Jennifer VanDerHorst-Larson measures it, in part, in the words her son speaks and writes.

title: LeBron James Says Hes Done Talking About Free Agency
description: LeBron James has declared a moratorium on free-agency questions, a gesture that is arguably overdue and perhaps a little hollow.

title: Gene D. Cohen, Geriatric Psychiatrist, Dies at 65
description: Gene D. Cohen, a pioneer in the field of geriatric psychiatry who helped shift the emphasis in gerontological research from the problems of people as they age to their potential, died Saturday at his home in Kensington, Md. He was 65.

title: Sheldon Dorf, Founder of Comic-Con, Dies at 76
description: Sheldon Dorf, who turned his passion for comic books and newspaper strips into a vocation by founding one of the worlds biggest annual comic-book conventions, died in San Diego on Nov. 3. He was 76.

title: Donald Harington, Ozark Surrealist, Dies at 73
description: Donald Harington, who created a surreal rural mini-world in more than a dozen novels set in the fictional Ozark hamlet of Stay More, Ark., died Saturday in Springdale, Ark. He was 73 and lived in Fayetteville, Ark.

title: Thomas J. OMalley, Who Helped Launch Glenn Into Orbit, Dies at 94
description: Thomas J. OMalley, the aviation engineer who pushed the button that launched the rocket that carried John Glenn into orbit in 1962, and who five years later played a major role in reviving the Apollo moon program after a launching-pad fire killed three astronauts, died Friday in Cocoa Beach, Fla. He was 94 and lived in Cocoa Beach.

title: Dollars Drop Lifts Shares, Gold and Oil
description: It was supposed to be a quiet day on Wall Street: the bond market was closed for Veterans Day, and there were no economic reports on the calendar.

title: Citigroup Stands by Deferred Tax Asset Valuation
description: A senior Citigroup executive said the bank is comfortable with its valuation for an asset that one accounting expert expects to be written down, Reuters reported.

title: D.O.E. Hires V.C. to Run Loan Programs
description: The Department of Energy has tapped a venture capitalist to run its ts loan guarantee and green auto loan programs.

title: In Charity Tax Filing, a Glimpse of Goldman
description: The latest tax filing for Goldman Sachss foundation is as thick as a phone book. The list of trades is more than 200 pages, single spaced. Goldman, it seems, invests like no other, even for its own charity.

title: A Bad Night at the Board
description: Nobody told me there would be days like these, strange days indeed. (John Lennon)

title: China Merchants Says I.P.O. Subscribed at $161 Billion
description: China Merchants Securities, which plans to raise up to 11.1 billion renminbi through an initial public share offer in Shanghai, said its I.P.O. has been nearly 94 times subscribed, freezing up a huge 1.1 trillion renminbi ($161 billion), Reuters reported.

title: China Bank Said to Eye Hong Kong Brokerage
description: Taifook Securities Group, a brokerage house based in Hong Kong, saw its shares soar after it said in a filing to the citys exchange late Wednesday that its main shareholder might sell its controlling stake.

title: Britain Probes Dynamic Decisions Hedge Fund
description: Britains Serious Fraud Office said Thursday that it has begun an investigation into a Cayman Islands-based hedge fund run by fund firm Dynamic Decisions Capital Management, following a referral by the Financial Services Authority.

title: Small on the Outside, Big on the Inside
description: David Pogue tests the Panasonic Lumix GF1, Canon PowerShot S90 and Panasonic Lumix LX3: Three cameras that are coat-pocketable but have large image sensors.

title: Gates Says Pay Too High, but Hard to Tackle
description: Bill Gates said on Wednesday he believes Wall Street pay is often too high and that government ownership of American International Group worries him because it has devalued the giant insurer.

title: Bain Capital Is Said to Bid $1 Billion for BellSystem24
description: Bain Capital has made a bid of more than $1 billion for Japanese telemarketer Bellsystem24 in a deal it hopes to wrap up by the weekend, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the deal.

title: As G.E. Struggles, a Rival Steps Up
description: It is only fitting that United Technologies is poised to buy assets from its cross-state rival General Electric, Breakingviews says. At least in the eyes of shareholders, United Technologies  the manufacturer of Otis elevators, Pratt & Whitney jet engines and Sikorsky helicopters  has emerged as the more successful of the two industrial conglomerates, both based in Connecticut, according to the publication.

title: A.I.G. Chiefs Mission: Save Executive Pay
description: American International Groups chief executive on Wednesday tried to calm fears that he was about to jump ship, with an open letter to employees announcing he was totally committed to leading A.I.G. through its challenges.

title: Protesters Clash With Police in Nepal
description: HONG KONG  Communist protesters clashed with the police and surrounded the Singha Durbar, the seat of government in the center of the Nepalese capital, as they called for the resignation of the president, local news agencies reported Thursday.

title: Motorola Said to Explore Dividing Into 3 Companies
description: Motorola, which has said it wanted to split into two separate companies, is exploring a three-way split instead in order to raise cash and pay down debt, The New York Timess Saul Hansell and Michael J. de la Merced reported.

title: Soros Helps Longfor Raise $912 Million In I.P.O.
description: The Chinese property developer, Longfor Properties, raised $912 million, pricing its Hong Kong initial public offering at the top end of an indicated range on Thursday, Reuters reported, citing two sources close to the deal.

title: Calpers Chief Backs Rules for Placement Agents
description: The president of the California Public Employees Retirement System urged fellow board members at the biggest United States public pension fund on Wednesday to back his plan to require placement agents to be subjected to laws for lobbyists in response to events asserting their undue influence over investment decisions, Reuters reported.

title: Paulson Increases Cadbury Stake (Again)
description: It seems that the hedge fund manager John Paulson has a real sweet tooth for Cadbury, currently coveted by Kraft Foods.

title: Fte Accompli | Le Jardin Louis Vuitton
description: What: The debut of the Louis Vuitton 2010 ready-to-wear collection at its new shop-in-a-shop shop at Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: 3i Asset Values Lag Market Surge
description: The 3i Group, the private equity firm, said asset values increased just 2 percent in the first half of its fiscal year as the real economy failed to keep up with rebounding stock markets.

title: Dowd: Virtuous Bankers? Really!?!
description: The New York Timess Maureen Dowd has a bone to pick with Goldman Sachs.

title: Hollywood Reporter to Be Sold, Report Says
description: Several Nielsen entertainment titles, including The Hollywood Reporter, are about to be sold to News Communications, the media company run by James Finkelstein, The Wrap reported, citing an individual with knowledge of the negotiations.

title: Royal Boskalis Buys Salvager Smit for $1.7 Billion
description: Royal Boskalis Westminster agreed to buy Smit Internationale, the salvage company that lifted the Russian nuclear submarine Kursk from the bottom of the Barents Sea in 2001, for about 1.1 billion euros ($1.7 billion), capping a yearlong effort to combine the two Dutch companies, Bloomberg News reported.

title: News Quiz | November 12, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Chagalls Colors of Love
description: When the wintry wind and rain descend on Istanbul, its great to head indoors for a dose of warmth, color and even romance. All three can be found at the recently opened exhibit, Marc Chagall: Life and Love, at the Pera Museum (Mesrutiyet Caddesi No. 65; 90-212-334-99-00; en.peramuzesi.org.tr; closed on Mondays).

title: Sanofi May Launch Venture Fund
description: The top executive of the French drug maker Sanofi-Aventis reached out to Boston-area researchers and biotechnology start-up companies on Wednesday, offering partnerships for innovation that could range from investments in drugs to outright acquisitions, The Boston Globe reported.

title: Buyout Shops Bid for British Car Dealership
description: A group of private equity firms is expected to progress to the second round of the sale of second-hand car dealership British Car Auctions, Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: The Case for Keeping Al Qaeda Alive
description: Todays idea: Keeping Al Qaeda weak but alive for now is to the worlds advantage, an article argues, for if it dies, terrorism would be more fragmented, untrackable and lethal.

title: Bear Stearns Trial: How the Scapegoats Escaped
description: The quick not guilty verdict reached Tuesday afternoon by a Brooklyn jury in the federal criminal trial of two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers was at once surprising  for its failure to conform with the zeitgeist  but also entirely understandable, based on a close reading of the prosecutions arguments and the evidence the judge allowed to be introduced, William D. Cohan writes in The New York Times.

title: The Great Shrinking American Dollar
description: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention, a research associate at the London School of Economics Center for Economic Performance, and a principal in Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economic, is the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

title: The Confetti Machine Returns to Nasdaq
description: The recent flurry of start-up acquisitions could signal an economic recovery for Silicon Valley, as I recently wrote about. But is a real recovery possible without the return of initial public offerings?

title: Group Accuses China of Abuses in Secret Jails
description: HONG KONG  Chinas national government tolerates an extensive network of secret jails in Beijing operated by provincial and municipal governments to prevent citizens from complaining to national officials, according to a report released here Thursday by Human Rights Watch.

title: Sampler: Intel Settles, SF Police Get E-Mail, Acorns Rain Down
description: Intel to Pay | Chip giant Intel will pay its competitor Advanced Micro Devices $1.25 billion to settle disputes over patents as well as anti-trust issues.

title: Clues Emerge to Life of Irishman Buried Under Park
description: It is not easy to disappear in the age of the Internet. But, as the case of James Jackson shows, even in the age of the abacus, people sometimes left behind breadcrumbs marking the paths of their lives.

title: EBay Motors Offering Free Vehicle History Report
description: Those considering buying a used car or truck through eBay Motors will now get a free vehicle history report provided by Experians AutoCheck.

title: Do You Believe in a Crabtree Curse?
description: The Niners have nosedived since signing Michael Crabtree. Gregg Easterbrook, writing for ESPN, has taken to calling it the Crabtree Curse:

title: Egypt Welcomes Life Sentence for Killing in German Court
description: BERLIN  One day after a German court ordered life imprisonment for a German man who stabbed a pregnant Egyptian woman to death in a Dresden courtroom, the Egyptian authorities on Thursday welcomed the sentence as a deterrent to anyone who is incited by hate and bitterness to carry out such an outrageous crime.

title: Listen to an Interview With Brian Turner
description: The Army veteran, poet and Home Fires contributor Brian Turner appeared on the public radio program Here and Now. You can listen to the interview posted at their Web site.

title: Wal-Mart Profit Up, but Key Indicator Slips
description: Even as more consumers flocked to Wal-Mart the last few months for deals on brand-name electronics, the company cut prices drastically to keep up with competitors, undermining its sales.

title: E-Mailing Obama Backers in G.O.P. Districts
description: Democrats are trying to build popular support for health care legislation by enlisting people who voted last year for Barack Obama.

title: Thursday Puzzle: Whats Wrong (or Right) With This Picture?
description: Does the picture above look natural to you? If you were standing in a lodge at Glacier National Park, is this how a jigsaw puzzle and the scenery would appear to your eye?

title: Divorce, Google-Style
description: Sight Gag | College Humor imagines the Google logo guy running into marital problems:

title: G.E. Sells Security Unit for $1.8 Billion
description: General Electric said on Thursday that it will sell its fire alarm and security systems unit to United Technologies for $1.82 billion, continuing a sale of what the industrial conglomerate considers noncore businesses.

title: Week 10 Game Probabilities
description: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior. His game probabilities for Week 10 are below, and his team rankings can be found here.)

title: Aha Moment
description: A phrase that describes flashes of understanding, which has been the subject of a curious copyright battle.

title: Campaigning for a Cause (and Customers)
description: In an effort to reform federal regulation governing toxic substances  and no doubt gain some marketing exposure in the process  Seventh Generation, the green household cleaning products manufacturer, recently started an ambitious campaign dubbed the Million Baby Crawl.

title: Speed Read for Thursday, Nov. 12
description: Highlights from todays media coverage:

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Thursday morning.Swift Sweeps Country Music Awards: Jon Caramanica writes for The New York Times on Wednesday nights Country Music Awards, where Taylor Swift won four trophies including Entertainer of the Year. That made her the first female artist to win the award since 2000 and the youngest performer to do so. FunnyOrDie.com had a summary of the events on its Twitter feed, too.

title: Swamped, Community Colleges Close Admissions Early
description: Thousands of students were shut out this fall as most of New York Citys community colleges were forced to abandon their all-are-welcome admissions policies for the first time.

title: Stephen Colbert Mops Up Sesame Street
description: The latest salvo in the war between Sesame Street and political ideologues has been fired, this time by the comic firebrand conservative commentator Stephen Colbert. On the occasion of the 40th anniversary of Sesame Street, Mr. Colbert took the show to task as the most insidious socialist brainwashing program in our nations history. He also weighed in on the long-running Pox News dispute and showed some great vintage Sesame Street clips:

title: TomTom Adds Text-to-Speech to iPhone
description: A recent New York Times article on GPS Apps for the iPhone apparently got the attention of TomTom, the Netherlands-based navigation company. According to a company spokesman, the article was forwarded to the Amsterdam-based team of engineers to draw their attention to, among other things, the inability of its stand-alone units to properly pronounce place names, and the frustration of having the iPhone app announce an intersection after one has already driven through it.

title: Clicker Aims to Be the Path to TV Online
description: The Web is increasingly filled with television shows, but finding them can be hard. Clicker, a well-financed startup, believes it can help. On Thursday, the company is rolling out its service, Clicker.com, which it calls a TV Guide for the Web.

title: To Zell, the Commercial Real Estate Crisis Is a Myth
description: Is the pending commercial real estate crisis everyone seems to be afraid of nothing but a myth? Sam Zell thinks so.

title: Flush of New iPhone Apps
description: A flurry of travel iPhone apps have landed in recent weeks. Here are some of the noteworthy ones:

title: Californians Worry About Education, Sacramento Still Unpopular
description: Update | 1:54 p.m.  Our colleague over at The Choice blog, Jacques Steinberg, points out that Mark Yudof of the University of California system has been named one of Time Magazines 10 Best College Presidents. Sure, he walked into one of the toughest jobs in higher education last year, but the article, which ran with a photo of Mr. Yudof rolling up his sleeves, suggests hes the right man to guide UC to safe harbor. Thoughts on Mr. Yudof, anyone?

title: The Early Word: Asia Bound
description: President Obama is announcing on Thursday that he will convene a jobs summit in early December, at a time when the unemployment rate has surpassed 10 percent.

title: Cambodias Embrace of Thaksin Stirs Tensions
description: BANGKOK  In one of his most provocative moves since being ousted in a coup three years ago, Thailands fugitive former prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, is visiting neighboring Cambodia this week, stirring tensions between the nations and invigorating his political supporters at home.

title: A.M.D.-Intel Settlement Wont End Their Woes
description: The giant chip maker Intel, facing antitrust challenges around the world, announced on Thursday that it would pay $1.25 billion to settle its long-running disputes with its smaller rival, Advanced Micro Devices.

title: Audreys Frocks, Another Pop-Up
description: While I prepare to trot off to the Manolo Blahnik sample sale (the notices are coming fast and furious), I thought Id mention one or two strange and fantastic things. Some of you may have heard of the upcoming Audrey Hepburn sale. Dont get terribly excitedthey are still old clothesbut you might one to take a gander at the lots when they arrive in New York for a preview on Nov. 21 and 22 at Sothebys. Kerry Taylor Auctions will conduct the sale in London on Dec. 8. The sale will include 36 items of clothing, from 1953 to the late 60s, and, of course, there are quite a few by Givenchy.

title: For Children With Flu, a Trip to the E.R.?
description: This past week, several friends contacted me about their childrens fever, cough and body aches, as symptoms once dismissed as life with a preschooler now raise the often unsettling question: Could this be swine flu?

title: Obama Purposely Taking Time on Troop Decision
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has not made a decision about his new military strategy for Afghanistan. And the White House is happy to say so.

title: Acorn Sues Over Funding Vote in House
description: The antipoverty group Acorn filed a lawsuit against the federal government on Thursday, saying that the House violated the Constitution by passing a resolution barring the group from receiving federal aid.

title: Obama Announces Jobs Summit
description: Updated President Obama announced on Thursday that he will convene a jobs summit at the White House next month, saying the economic growth that weve seen has not yet led to the job growth that we desperately need.

title: Weekly Popcast: Wale, P.K. 14 and Carsick Cars
description: This week: Jon Pareles reviews Attention Deficit by the rapper Wale and, in a special segment, Ben Sisario talks to Yang Haisong of P.K. 14 and Shou Wang of Carsick Cars, both of Beijing, about the underground rock scene in China and their current United States tour.

title: Group Urges Protection of Northern Forests
description: A coalition of conservation groups are calling on international climate negotiators in Copenhagen next month to develop land-use policy incentives intended to encourage governments to protect natural carbon storehouses  especially those in northern boreal forests and peatlands found in Canada, Scandinavia and Russia.

title: Update: John King to Replace Lou Dobbs; Focus Will Be on Political News
description: John King will anchor an ambitious new 7 p.m. hour of political news for CNN beginning early next year, the network said Thursday.

title: Bill Clinton Endorses Mad Men
description: Forget the Emmy Awards, the critical accolades, the official Brooks Brothers suit  Mad Men may have just received its biggest boost yet, from Bill Clinton, who has turned out to be an avid fan of the show.

title: The i2-JDA Deal: Will History Repeat Itself?
description: Update | 12:35 p.m. The sudden return of the M.&A. market last week also heralded the resurrection of two deals terminated during the financial crisis: Landrys management buyout and JDA Software Groups $396 million acquisition of i2 Technologies.

title: Thursday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Housing Agencys Cash Reserves Down Sharply
description: The Federal Housing Administration, the government agency whose loan-insurance programs have become a crucial source of support for the housing market, said on Thursday that its cash reserves had dwindled significantly in the last year as more borrowers defaulted on their mortgages.

title: A First Taste of the Peach
description: As Midtown Lunch notes, M Pche, the Momofuku outpost in the Chambers Hotel, is serving a limited menu from 6:30 a.m. to midnight, with a $10 lunch special in the hotels mezzanine.

title: Barclays Capital Hires Co-Head of Global Healthcare
description: Barclays Capital said on Thursday that it had hired Rick Landgarten as the co-head of its global health care group, as the British banks investment banking arm continues to expand.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Detroit and New Jersey Reviving the Status Quo
description: Six games on Wednesday night, in which a couple of traditional powers continue to reassert themselves after slow starts this season. We are referring, of course, to the Devils and Red Wings. Home teams listed first:

title: A Legal Venue for Doing Doughnuts and Racing in Oakland?
description: J. Douglas Allen-Taylor, in his Berkeley Daily Planet column, takes up the idea floated by Mayor Ron Dellums of creating a legal alternative to sideshows, the impromptu, often dangerous, late-night car gatherings.

title: Divorce Risk Higher When Wife Gets Sick
description: When Dr. Marc Chamberlain, a Seattle oncologist, was treating his brain cancer patients, he noticed an alarming pattern. His male patients were typically receiving much-needed support from their wives. But a number of his female patients were going it alone, ending up separated or divorced after receiving a brain tumor diagnosis.

title: Oil Slides, and Wall Street Pulls Back
description: Wall Street stocks fell on Thursday as investors reacted with caution to a drop in the price of oil. An announcement by President Obama of a job creation initiative failed to motivate investors.

title: Response to the Head Scarf Martyr Verdict in Egypt and Germany
description: As our colleague Nicholas Kulish reports from Germany, reaction has been mixed in Egypt to the conviction on Wednesday of a man who fatally stabbed a pregnant Egyptian pharmacist to death in July.

title: Special Section on Giving
description: Todays New York Times contains a special section on giving. Links to some of the stories are below. (For more information and links, check out the Times Topics Page on Philanthropy and send questions on charitable giving to giving@nytimes.com)

title: Germany Ends Probe of Suspect in Litvinenko Case
description: MOSCOW  German prosecutors have abandoned investigations into one of the main figures suspected of involvement in the killing of a former K.G.B. officer in London three years ago without bringing charges, according to accounts on Thursday by the prosecutors and the man in question.

title: Dollhouse': Chronicle of a Cancellation Foretold
description: Reacting to the news Wednesday that Fox had canceled its science-fiction adventure series Dollhouse, viewers went through an abrupt grieving process. First, denial (see various blog comments and Tweets that take the form of NOOOOoooo!!!); second, hurling favorite expletives at the Fox network; third, a kind of acceptance, as if they had known from the start that Dollhouse was destined for a short run.

title: Long-Held Vision for Toy Museum Is Realized
description: After her 4-year-old daughter failed to catch a handmade porcelain doll she had tossed into the air, Marlene Hochman went on a mission to have it repaired, setting her on an unexpected journey into the world of playthings. Thirteen years and three books later, she runs New York Citys only toy museum.

title: Copia Is Set to Be Sold
description: Thursday is the deadline for bidders interested in buying Copia, the once-glamorous, now-defunct food and wine institute in Napa, Calif.

title: Intel to Pay $1.25 Billion to Settle With A.M.D.
description: The giant chip maker Intel, facing antitrust challenges around the world, announced on Thursday that it would pay $1.25 billion to settle its long-running disputes with its smaller rival, Advanced Micro Devices.

title: Vonn and Miller Prepare for Levi
description: The World Cup ski racing season resumes this weekend with mens and womens slalom races in Levi, Finland. The American Bode Miller has said he will make his season debut and it will be the first chance for Lindsey Vonn, the two-time overall World Cup champion, to show off her continued progress as a slalom skier.

title: What to Watch Thursday: How Subway Cars Are Built and Cheyenne Jackson on 30 Rock
description: Ever wonder how they were able to make those seats on the new F and Q trains that uncomfortable? Ultimate Factories (National Geographic Channel, 8 p.m.) visits the plants in Brazil and Hornell, N.Y., where the subway systems R160 cars are built. Neil Genzlingers review is here.

title: Russian President Says Modernization Is Needed
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev issued a sweeping call on Thursday for Russia to modernize its economy, wean itself from a humiliating dependence on natural resources and do away with Soviet-style attitudes that he said were hindering its effort to remain a world power.

title: Fun With Googles Auto-Suggestion Feature
description: It began innocently enough: someone e-mailed me about a quirk of Googles auto-suggestion feature. If you go to Google.com and type why wont into the Search box, the auto-suggestion pop-up menu includes some pretty bizarre suggestions, including a particularly gross one involving a parakeet (dont ask).

title: Another Web Video Face-Off: Roku vs. Boxee
description: Roku and Boxee are two radically different companies pursuing the same goal: to bring the wide-ranging world of Internet video to the living room TV.

title: Glee Watch: Wheelchair Antics
description: This post contains spoilers.

title: Bivalve Curious
description: There are two fascinating stories for the food-centric in Thursdays edition of The New York Times, one about oysters from the Gulf Coast, the other about scallops from Peconic Bay.

title: More Record Highs and Far Fewer Lows
description: Scientists sifting for trends in record high and low temperatures across the United States have found more evidence of long-term warming of the climate, with the biggest shift coming through a reduction in record low nighttime temperatures. That is a pattern long predicted by climate scientists using computer simulations. The researchers said they sifted data carefully to avoid possible distortion of trends related to changes in instruments or conditions at and around weather stations. The changing ratio of cold and hot records is shown below (copyright U.C.A.R., graphic by Mike Shibao):

title: When Type Was Poured Hot
description: Newsmen are by nature good storytellers, and no stories animate them quite so much as their own. Yes, they will say, that late-breaking piece turned the tide, and certainly that campaign against feckless bureaucrats landed nicely. But ask them how they got the goods in the first place, and be prepared to pull up a chair.

title: High School Can Perform Rent, Laramie Project
description: A ruling by a Nevada district court judge will allow a Las Vegas area high school to perform student productions of Rent and The Laramie Project, despite the objections of parents who were seeking an injunction to prevent them, The Las Vegas Review-Journal reported. Students at Green Valley High School in Henderson will be allowed to perform both shows, starting on Thursday with The Laramie Project, after Judge David Wall ruled against parents who objected to the productions content. Lawyers for the Clark County School District who represented the students said in arguments that the parents could not prove that performing the shows would cause irreparable harm. Lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union of Nevada filed a brief that supported the students as well, arguing that an injunction would violate the students right to free speech. Amanda Smith, a 16-year-old student who has a lead role in the Rent production planned for next year, told The Review-Journal, Im ecstatic.

title: The Confetti Machine Returns to Nasdaq
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: Palestinian Officials Push for Delay in Elections
description: JERUSALEM  Palestinian presidential and parliamentary elections cannot be held on their scheduled date in January, Palestinian Authority election officials said Thursday. The announcement removed some of the immediate uncertainty surrounding the future of the current president, Mahmoud Abbas, who said recently that he would not run for a second term.

title: The Octomom and Her Babies Prepare for Prime Time
description: The first thing you notice upon entering the house of a family with 14 children is  not surprisingly  the presence of 14 children. There was Jonah, jiggling around delightedly in his Deluxe ExerSaucer, staring up at me with big brown eyes and smiling with a cleft lip. Nariyah squirmed languidly in a second ExerSaucer next to the fake fireplace, drowsily listing to one side. Makai, Noah and Jeremiah were conked out on the carpet, like little sacks of beans. Maliyah, Josiah and Isaiah lay on the couch in varying states of gassy snuffling.

title: Seeing Things | Uniqlos New Paris Store
description: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.

title: How to Give the Gift of Charity
description: Just because consumers are cutting back on giving to charity and spending on holiday gifts, they dont have to be stingy. In The New York Times on Thursday, I wrote about ways to combine giving presents with giving to charity, part of a broader report about philanthropy in todays paper. (For more information and links, check out the Times Topics Page on Philanthropy and send questions on charitable giving to giving@nytimes.com)

title: Playing Below the Rim
description: In For Some N.B.A. Players, Theres No Such Thing as a Slam Dunk, I write about the N.B.A.s tallest players who have gone a full season without dunking the ball.

title: F.H.A. Says Cash Reserves Are Down Sharply
description: The Federal Housing Administration said Thursday that its cash reserves had dwindled significantly in the last year after a record drop in home prices, The New York Timess David Streitfeld reports.

title: Editors Choice
description: UNDER THE DOME, by Stephen King (Scribner, $35.) When an enormous transparent dome settles over a small town in Maine, separating its citizens from the world of Obama, its just fine with Big Jim, the local tyrant-in-waiting, and his pet goon squad.

title: After Auto Bankruptcies, Lawyer Goes Back to Work
description: After working on two of the biggest bankruptcies in history  the Chapter 11 cases of General Motors and Chrysler  what was Matthew Feldman to do?

title: Mythical End for Legendary Route 66
description: On the roads 83rd anniversary, an end of the trail sign was erected at the Santa Monica Pier, a more convenient if not historically accurate terminus. Read the full story.

title: Happy to Travel
description: Monologue |  Aired Wednesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: A huge week for the President. Obama leaves tomorrow for a ten-day trip to Singapore, China, South Korea and Japan. Meanwhile, today, Joe Biden ate breakfast, lunch and dinner at Panda Express.

title: Espionage in Iran
description: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Three young Americans have been charged with espionage in Iran after straying into the country while hiking in Iraq. Now, obviously, we all pray for their safe return. But hiking in Iraq? I mean  you know, if youre hiking in Iraq and Iran, you might want to get a you new travel agent. O.K?

title: New Rules Would Restrict Overdraft Fees on Debit Cards
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve announced new rules on Thursday that would sharply restrict banks and others that issue debit cards from charging overdraft fees without the express permission of the cardholder.

title: City Is Broke
description: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Welcome to New York City, first of all, but bad news  city is broke. Yeah. No more money. And theyre cutting back on garbage collection. And I want to tell you, New York City, by the way, has one of the finest collections of garbage youll see anywhere.

title: BA, Iberia Boards Meet Over Potential Deal
description: A merger between British Airways and Spains Iberia looked imminent on Thursday as their boards held separate meetings to discuss a deal to create the worlds third-largest airline by revenue, Reuters reported.

title: A Dangerous Drug
description: Monologue |  Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Former President Bill Clinton talked to Senate Democrats about the health-care bill. And he told them not to make the same mistakes he and Hillary did. Thats what he said, yeah. As a result, the senators all went home and got a divorce.

title: Evolution, Traced by the Lens
description: Photographic triptychs of New York buildings showing their evolution from the 1930s to today.

title: After Slow Start, DIP Lending Is in Full Swing
description: When Lyondell Chemical filed for bankruptcy in January, the restructuring world was abuzz that the company received debtor-in-possession financing at all.

title: Paperback Row
description: A QUIET ADJUSTMENT,  by Benjamin Markovits (Norton, $14.95.) I fear very much you will find out you have married a devil, Lord Byron confides to his new wife, Annabella Milbanke, at the start of their honeymoon  and she does. This eloquent novel, the second in a proposed trilogy, is presented in a third-person narration that seems to arise from Annabella, a beautiful 19-year-old. Her perspective is conveyed with a hesitant formality reminiscent of Henry James, and phrase after phrase winks for readerly attention, our reviewer, Jay Parini, said.

title: Did Dame Edna and Michael Feinstein Find a Gullible Reporter?
description: Well, folks, it looks like we got snookered by the oldest trick in the P.R. handbook: a celebrity feud. In this case, the celebrities in question are Michael Feinstein and Dame Edna Everage, who have been sniping back and forth in recent days about two similarly titled Broadway shows, All About Me and Its All About Me. (He: Titles are not copyrightable. I wish Ms. Edna well. Ive heard of her.) (She: Im sure Mrs. Feinstein is very proud of her son.)

title: The Alternative Medicine Cabinet: Marigolds to Soothe Skin
description: Anahad OConnor, who writes the Really column for The New York Times, explores the claims and the science behind various alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

title: A Chance to See the City Change, Site by Site
description: At the start of the 20th century, Henry James pronounced New York a provisional city, a phrase echoed decades later by Le Corbusier. The architectural historian Max Page suggested that creative destruction  the intentional razing and rebuilding of New York  represented a crucial dynamic of urban life. O. Henry summed it up more succinctly. Itll be a great place, he said, if they ever finish it.

title: Playboy Stock Surges on Report of Sale Talks
description: Shares of Playboy Enterprises shot up more than 30 percent on Thursday after Bloomberg News reported that the mens magazine publisher was in talks to sell itself to the Iconix Brand Group. It cited two unidentified people close to the situation.

title: A Battle in Canada Over Drive-Through Idling
description: Canadians are debating whether or not the drive-through lanes at Tim Hortons, a doughnut and fast-food chain, should be part of an anti-idling ordinance in Kingston, Ontario.

title: Big Bird on Birthdays and Tony Bennett
description: Tuesday represented the 40th anniversary of Sesame Street, and this week, Caroll Spinney, known to millions as Big Bird and Oscar the Grouch, and Carol-Lynn Parente, executive producer, have been answering readers questions about the show.

title: Sri Lankan General Resigns
description: The powerful army general who led Sri Lankas bloody but successful battle against the Tamil Tigers resigned abruptly Thursday, heightening speculation that he will run against his onetime ally, Mahinda Rajapaksa, for president in next years election.

title: Travel Deals: 50% off Starwood Hotels and Resorts
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts is offering up to 50 percent off stays through Jan. 18 at hundreds of hotels worldwide. Rooms must be booked by Nov. 17. Sample rates:

title: Scott Foundas Joins Film Society of Lincoln Center
description: The community of film critics just got smaller by one: Scott Foundas, the film editor and chief film critic for LA Weekly, will leave that role to become the associate program director at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the group announced in a news release. Working with the Film Societys program director, Richard Pea, Mr. Foundas will help organize film series and other programs, including the annual New York Film Festival. He is expected to start next year.

title: Guidance Office: Post a Question About Community Colleges
description: On Monday, The Choice will begin a weeklong Q&A for readers on the subject of community colleges. Each year, such institutions become a more crucial cog in the American higher-education system, as evidenced by the fact that nearly one of every two students in a for-credit undergraduate course is now enrolled in a community college.

title: Verizon: How Much Do You Charge Now?
description: Starting next week, Verizon will double the early-termination fee for smartphones. That is, if you get a BlackBerry, Android or similar phone from Verizon, and you decide to switch phones before your two-year contract is up, you'll be socked with a $350 penalty (it used to be $175).

title: New Overdraft Rules: What Consumers Need to Know
description: Big changes are coming to your checking account.

title: Why Kids Watch Movies Again and Again and Again
description: I know every word of every song in Les Miserables. I knew them long before I had a chance to actually see the show, because my kindergarten-age son stumbled on a PBS special years ago, then watched a videotaped version of that special over and over and over and over again.

title: Second Officer Gives an Account of the Shooting at Ft. Hood
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley has been applauded as a hero across the nation for shooting down Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan during the bloody rampage at Fort Hood last week. The account of heroism, given by the authorities, attracted the attention of newspapers, the networks and television talk shows.

title: Verizon: How Much Do You Charge Now?
description: Starting next week, Verizon will double the early-termination fee for smartphones. That is, if you get a BlackBerry, Android or similar phone from Verizon, and you decide to switch phones before your two-year contract is up, youll be socked with a $350 penalty (it used to be $175).

title: Acorn Sues Over Funding Vote in House
description: Saying a resolution by the House of Representatives that barred Acorn from receiving federal aid violated the Constitution by singling out the antipoverty group for punishment, lawyers for Acorn filed a lawsuit on Thursday that seeks to restore the financing. Read The Timess story.

title: Now Shopping | Monki and Weekday, Hamburgs Dynamic Duo
description: Monki and Weekday, the sister stores that are Swedens answer to Topshop and H&M, continue their march through Europe, most recently arriving in the German city of Hamburg, where the shops opened last week. Based in Stockholm, the company achieved international status with its Cheap Monday jeans  skintight numbers that the co-founder, Adam Friberg, says at first no one liked and then they suddenly became really popular. That kind of intuition is what led Friberg and his business partner, Orjan Andersson, to Hamburg: they just like the citys odd mix of grit and wealth, its asymmetrical architecture and its flea-market subculture.

title: Law School as an Investment
description: Is law school a good investment?

title: The Lost World of Creedmoor Hospital
description: Founded in 1912 as a Farm Colony of Brooklyn State Hospital, the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens became, by mid-century, a world unto itself. At its peak, it housed some 7,000 patients. They tended gardens and raised livestock on the hospitals grounds. The hospital contained gymnasiums, a swimming pool, a theater, a television studio, and giant kitchens and laundries where patients were put to work.

title: Q. and A. With O.H.L. Commissioner David Branch
description: If the N.H.L. general managers wind up asking for stricter rules regarding checks to the head when they make their recommendations to members of the N.H.L. competition committee this March, much of the credit for influencing them to change their longstanding opposition will ultimately go to someone outside the league: Ontario Hockey League Commissioner David Branch. The rules he has imposed and strictly enforced in his league  penalizing all hits to the head, enforcing stern and consistent suspensions for flagrant violations of all safety-related rules  created a climate that changed the conversation in Canada, opening the way for traditional fans to begin thinking about a game that tries to reduce catastrophic injuries and promote mutual respect among players on the ice. The N.H.L. G.M.s resisted that stance for a long time, but on Wednesday in Toronto they showed for the first time a willingness to consider adopting some of the principles Branch has championed.

title: G.M. Agrees to Recycle Mercury Switches, for Now
description: Mercury, the only metal element that is liquid at standard room temperature, is notoriously hard to handle  in more ways than one. Until 2003, automakers used highly toxic mercury in switches that controlled trunk and under-hood lights, as well as antilock brake systems. Since then, carmakers have switched to benign alternatives, but an estimated 38 million mercury switches still remain in cars.

title: Guilty Pleas Expected in Balloon Hoax Case
description: DENVER  The Colorado couple accused of lying to the authorities by saying that their 6-year-old son was aboard a runaway helium balloon last month have agreed to plead guilty, one of their lawyers said Thursday.

title: Comparing Veterans Experiences With War Poetry
description: Overview | How do authors depict the experiences of soldiers returning home from war? How do these literary portraits mirror reality? In this lesson, students explore literary depictions of veterans and compare them to the lived experiences of soldiers. They then use recent Times war coverage to create found poems that comment on the theme of returning from war.

title: F.A. Gives Sir Alex the Hair-Dryer Treatment
description: Sir Alex Ferguson, the manager of Manchester United, has two Premier League streaks going. His team has won three consecutive championships, and, for the third season in a row, the vocal Scot has been hit with a ban for berating the performance of referees.

title: Something New Under the Caribbean Sun
description: IF you build it, they will come.

title: Brother Gives New Meaning to Guitar Hero
description: Here is an update on what was perhaps the most surprising moment during the 99th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers.

title: Gates Says Afghan Plan Will Mix Various Proposals
description: President Obama hopes to combine the best elements from among the several proposals he is studying on sending additional troops to Afghanistan, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said on Thursday.

title: Behind the Fighter Manny Pacquiao, the Fight for His Favor
description: LOS ANGELES  The condominium looks like a fraternity house, not the resting place for boxing royalty. Stained carpets cover the floor. Dartboards hang from the wall. Bowls of food, half-eaten leftovers, line the kitchen.

title: 36 Hours in Turks and Caicos
description: DANGLING at the southern end of the Bahamas island chain like an after-thought, Turks and Caicos was often overlooked as a Caribbean destination. But thanks to some of the swankiest names in hotels  Regent, Amanresorts and Meriden, to name a few  Turks and Caicos is now firmly on the map of those seeking a beach vacation with heavy pampering and a splash of indulgence. It is the kind of place where hotel staff members adjust your beach chair umbrella as the sun shifts and pass out cool towels to keep you from overheating. And moderately priced hotels have maid service a mere two times a day, instead of providing guests with a small army of personal servants. Technically, the islands are in the Atlantic, but with this level of coddling  not to mention some of the bluest waters in the world  who cares?

title: Dont Count Your Chickens
description: Fantastic Mr. Fox is a proudly analog animated entertainment, making its handmade way into a marketplace glutted with digital goodies. Next to the three-dimensional, computer-generated creatures that swoop and soar off the screen these days, the furry talking animals on display here, with their matted pelts, jerky movements and porcelain eyes, might look a little quaint, like old-fashioned wind-up toys uneasily sharing the shelf with the latest video game platforms.

title: Two Disney Executives Will Switch Jobs
description: Two of Disneys top executives are switching jobs  a shift that Robert A. Iger, the companys chief executive, said in an interview had been in the works since last summer.

title: Editors Note
description: On Thursday, a news article in The Times reported on the ties between Peter W. Galbraith, a former United States ambassador, and a Norwegian oil company that operates in the Kurdistan region of Iraq. According to the Times article, Mr. Galbraith "received rights to an enormous stake in at least one of Kurdistan's oil fields in the spring of 2004."

title: First, a Tourniquet, then Preschool Pickup
description: A few months ago, we learned that when journalist Euna Lee was detained in North Korea, she asked her captors to allow her to send a most important message to her husband  a reminder to register their daughter for preschool.

title: A Street Where Old Is New, Again
description: Fifty years ago, the shops along Atlantic Avenue between Hoyt and Bond Streets in Brooklyn earned the block its nickname, Antiques Row, but with the rising rents, many of the sellers up and vanished. In the last five years, however, a new class of creative entrepreneur has moved onto the avenue with a stylish take on the same mission: using old things for new purposes.

title: Hotel Review: The Encore in Las Vegas
description: THE BASICS

title: Mercado de Dulces in Morelia, Mexico
description: If you didnt notice the concentration of bees near the Colegio de los Jesuitas, in Morelia, Mexico, you might think the complex was another one of the citys signature pink-stone churches. But the bees arent going to Mass  theyre headed toward 28 stalls of gooey and chili-sprinkled delights that fill the corridors of the old cloister: a bazaar of regional sweets called the Mercado de Dulces.

title: Paterson Is Counting on Obama
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: New Face of Mercado Santurce in San Juan, P.R.
description: BUSINESS isnt what it used to be, Ramn Tellado Rosa said from behind a pile of bananas at his stall at the Mercado Santurce in the Campo Alegre district of San Juan, P.R.  for decades the place where Sanjuaneros have come for fresh produce.

title: Underwater, Literally, With a $2 Million Bugatti
description: Eddie Griffin might finally be off the hook for the most ridiculous crash in a priceless supercar. On Wednesday, a man drove a Bugatti Veyron into a lagoon in Texas after avoiding a low-flying pelican.

title: Sailing the Caribbean, the Frugal Way
description: CONSIDERING that none of us newbies had any idea what we were doing, the voyage south from St. Lucia was going well. At 10:30 a.m., amid gray but not ominous skies, the S.V. Illusion  the 75-foot, two-masted schooner on which I and two others were novice sailors  had weighed anchor off the coast of Vieux Fort, a sleepy city at the islands southern tip, and steered into deeper waters. The sea was mild, with five-foot swells rocking us just enough to make walking a conscious effort, and when Norman Garnett, the Illusions 61-year-old English captain, gave the order, we scrambled to pull, feed, winch and cleat a series of ropes that unfurled our three sails, which caught and tightened in the wind. We were sailing!

title: Zimbabwe: Opposition Lawyers Ask for New Judge in Bennett Trial
description: Lawyers for Roy Bennett, a senior leader in the opposition party Movement for Democratic Change, asked the trial judge Chinembiri Bhunu to recuse himself on grounds that his earlier comments in a related 2006 case showed a bias for believing the states case.

title: Chef Dan Barbers Kale Salad and Creamy Parsnip Rice
description: Diners at the Blue Hill at Stone Barns restaurant in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., rarely forget their first bite. Mine was a tiny floret of purple cauliflower, served raw, lightly marinated and bursting with fresh flavor. Although pork also was on the menu, the evening ended up being a celebration of vegetables, including beets, wild mushrooms and tiny carrots, and finishing with an enticing fresh herbal tea.

title: Gates Angry About Defense-Related Leaks
description: OSHKOSH, Wis.  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates is normally a mild-mannered man, at least in public, but he unleashed a torrent on his plane on Thursday morning about leaks during the investigation of the Foot Hood shootings and President Obamas deliberations on sending more American troops to Afghanistan.

title: Senators Propose Prizes for Capturing CO2
description: Senators John Barrasso, Republican of Wyoming, and Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, have joined in introducing a bill that would establish awards for researchers who develop technologies that can economically extract carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and stash it away. In doing so, they are potentially upping the ante offered in 2007 by Richard Branson, the aviation and music magnate, for such an advance.

title: Letter: The Ridgeway Trail
description: To the Editor: This past spring we experienced a slice of Henry Shukmans walk (Hiking Into History, Nov. 1) along Englands ancient

title: A Battle in Canada Over Idling at Drive-Throughs
description: From our colleagues at Green Inc.:

title: Standing Room Only | LAvant Comptoir in Paris
description: If anyone can make Parisians stand up for good food, its the bistro maestro Yves Camdeborde, whose new LAvant Comptoir has been packed to the rafters since it opened a week ago. Just steps from the Odon, this short, narrow, standing-room-only space with white tile walls, a broad pewter counter and an open kitchen is what Camdeborde calls an hors doeuvres bar, and it serves up an array of delicious small-plate Basque- and Barnais-inspired nibbles and carving boards of superb charcuterie along with a great selection of wines by the glass (Lapierres luscious Morgon, great Ctes du Rhone, offbeat whites like UBY Colombard Ugni Blanc).

title: Major Held in Fort Hood Rampage Is Charged With 13 Counts of Murder
description: FORT HOOD, Tex.   Military officials charged Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan on Thursday with 13 counts of premeditated murder, accusing him of a brutal one-man attack here at Americas largest Army post last week and setting in motion what promises to be a momentous court-martial proceeding that could end in the death penalty.

title: Domestic Workers Unite in a Bad Economy
description: There is a movement afoot to organize domestic workers and improve their working conditions even as many face unemployment because of the weak economy. On Friday morning, people advocating better working conditions for such workers will gather at the 24th Street BART station for a march to the Womens Building on 18th Street. The march kicks off the West Coast Congress of the National Domestic Worker Alliance, to be held at Oaklands Laney College this weekend. Twenty-eight organizations will discuss how to better organize on national issues and get a domestic workers bill of rights passed in Californias legislature.

title: Feinberg Will Consider Competitive Pay Offers
description: The Obama administrations pay czar, Kenneth R. Feinberg, said on Thursday that he was concerned that pay cuts he ordered at companies that received the federal bailout could hamper their ability to retain talent, and that he would consider allowing new executives to be hired at competitive industry rates.

title: The Cheating Game
description: Richard Nixon played poker well. His winnings in the Navy (there is no evidence that they were stowed in a specially built footlocker with a false bottom) financed young Nixons first, successful Congressional election campaign in 1946 against the admired incumbent Democrat, Jerry Voorhis.

title: In Canada, a Royal Yawn for Prince Charles
description: PETAWAWA, Ontario  As things now stand, when Prince Charles succeeds his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, his many roles will include being the king of Canada.

title: The Lies They Told
description: When Sept. 11, 2001, dawned, the Northeast Air Defense Sector in Rome, N.Y., went on full alert  to prepare for a training exercise that envisioned a sneak attack by Russian planes flying over the North Pole to bomb the United States, a prospect that Defense Secretary Robert McNamara had dismissed as outdated in 1966. Later that morning, after American Airlines Flight 11 and United Airlines Flight 175 had hit the World Trade Center and American Airlines Flight 77 the Pentagon, three F-16 fighter jets were scrambled from Langley Air Force Base to form a combat air patrol over Washington. But degraded radio transmission quality meant that the pilots were left clueless about the nature of their mission. On seeing the Pentagon in flames, the lead fighter pilot later explained, I reverted to the Russian threat. . . . Im thinking cruise missile threat from the sea. You know, you look down and see the Pentagon burning, and I thought the bastards snuck one by us. . . . You couldnt see any airplanes, and no one told us anything.

title: The Way We Ate: Of Artichokes and Liberty
description: For more than a century and a half, The New York Times has been recording the pleasures and prejudices of the American palate. The Way We Ate is a weekly tasting menu of vintage food writing from the Times archives.

title: A Street Where Old Is New, Again
description: Fifty years ago, the shops along Atlantic Avenue between Hoyt and Bond Streets in Brooklyn earned the block its nickname, Antiques Row, but with the rising rents, many of the sellers up and vanished. In the last five years, however, a new class of creative entrepreneur has moved onto the avenue with a stylish take on the same mission: using old things for new purposes.

title: 10 Years Later, Looking at Repeal of Glass-Steagall
description: Update | 3:49 p.m. Ten years ago to the day, the government reversed one of the key elements of the Depression-era banking laws, knocking down the firewall between commercial banks, which take deposits and make loans, and investment banks, which underwrite securities. The repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 was seen at the time as a way to help American banks grow larger and better compete on the world stage.

title: More on the Ethics of Prostheses
description: The case most commonly made against allowing some prosthetics into able-bodied competitions holds that I lack an imagination. Its not hard to imagine, so this argument goes, that we could invent prostheses that would give the runner an advantage. Actually, it is. Unless we are adding energy artificially (robotics, engines, etc.), these prostheses replace what isnt there. There are ways to test whether they enable competitors to run or to run better than they otherwise might (the unilateral test subjects were chosen precisely because their one natural leg provided a control). When I was a kid, anyone who owned a Guinness Book of World Records will remember the arresting photo of the football player who lacked part of a foot and, with a shoe shaped like a brick, kicked the longest field goal in pro football history. After he won the world record, the league adjusted the rules to say that everybody, including amputees, had to kick with the same-shaped shoes. That seems fair.

title: Doom Loop
description: A virtueless circle in which banks take ever-greater risks to boost returns (secure in the knowledge the state will underwrite them), and governments are forced to break their promises never again to bankroll losses (further encouraging banks to take dangerous risks).

title: Primary Cares Image Problem
description: In my medical school class of 140, Kerry was one of the best and the brightest. Gregarious, unassuming and a dedicated fitness buff with a weakness for ice cream, she managed to sail through the weekly exams that most of us struggled with during the first two years. Later on, in the third year on the hospital wards, she quickly became what every one of us so wanted to be: the indispensable medical student.

title: Giving Primary Care More Respect
description: In todays Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline W. Chen writes about the image problem that primary care specialists face. Dr. Chen recounts the story of a respected medical school colleague who chose the primary care route, and the disparaging comments that followed.

title: Broken Glass(-Steagall)
description: From President Clintons statement, 10 years ago today, when he signed the bill that dismantled Glass-Steagall and allowed commercial banks to engage in the investment business.

title: Rational Irrationality
description: Two leading financial journalists have made worthy additions to the increasingly crowded shelf of books on our recent economic failure. In very different ways, John Cassidy and Andrew Ross Sorkin address the critical question of what exactly happened on Wall Street. Until we settle on at least a rough answer, we wont have a prayer of preventing the next crisis.

title: Warhols Eye for the Bucks
description: Whenever you stand back for a panoramic look at the contemporary art world  that confection of bucks, puff and street smarts  you realize afresh that Andy Warhol was the daddy of it all. And that was confirmed yet again at Sothebys on Wednesday night, when his 1962 silkscreen painting 200 One Dollar Bills sold for $43.7 million (including Sothebys fees).

title: Illness and Intimacy
description: Few people have written about their experience of manic-depressive illness from the inside as acutely as Kay Redfield Jamison did in her 1995 memoir, An Unquiet Mind. Among the things that distinguished that book was the fact that Jamison, a professor of psychiatry at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine and a co-author of the standard medical text on bipolar illness, knew the disease as both clinician and patient. Jamisons outing of her affliction involved considerable professional risk. Some of her colleagues recognized the advantage of her uniquely intimate knowledge of the illness she treated, but others believed it cast a pall over her professional judgment  a prejudice that would probably not have come to bear on a cardiologist, say, who happened to have undergone heart surgery.

title: Which to Preserve, the Chicken or the Egg?
description: IN the last 30 years, hundreds, perhaps thousands, of deteriorated high-stoop brownstones in New York have been restored as new generations of owners reinstalled stoops and recreated facades stripped off decades ago.

title: Love Crimes
description: As soon as you finish Paul Austers Invisible you want to read it again. And not because, as sometimes with his novels  as with the novels of Georges Perec, one of a handful of other real authors mentioned in the book  you suddenly suspect, at the very end, that you havent properly understood a word of what has gone before. You want to reread Invisible because it moves quickly, easily, somehow sinuously, and you worry that there were good parts that you read right past, insights that you missed. The prose is contemporary American writing at its best: crisp, elegant, brisk. It has the illusion of effortlessness that comes only with fierce discipline. As often happens when you are in the hands of a master, you read the next sentence almost before you are finished with the previous one. The novel could be read shallowly, because it is such a pleasure to read.

title: Quad Q&A: Tim Crothers
description: Tim Crothers is a former senior writer for Sports Illustrated and the author of The Man Watching, a biography of the North Carolina womens soccer coach, Anson Dorrance. Crotherss latest project was collaborating with Roy Williams on Williamss just-released autobiography, Hard Work: A Life On and Off the Court. Crothers recently answered some questions via e-mail about the book and Williams.

title: The Morning Skate: A Half-Step in the Right Direction
description: To demonstrate we havent lost what little sense of humor we have, heres the Maple Leafs fan blog Down Goes Browns version of the N.H.L.s top secret supplementary discipline policies for the regular season and playoffs  and you can even download your own copies (regular season here, playoffs here) and then e-mail them to your friends, who will think you, too, are a funny person, even if youre not (and thanks to our old friend Leon Friedrich for the link).

title: A Minimalist Designer on Display
description: PARIS | For aficionados of contemporary design, Paris has plenty to offer, but the legendary French decorator Jean-Michel Frank has largely been left out of the exhibition roster. Frank is finally getting his due with the first-ever French exhibition of his work.

title: Angels and Insects
description: We are all outlaws in the eyes of America! In order to survive we steal cheat lie forge fred hide and deal! Jefferson Airplane wrote these cheerfully absurd words for We Can Be Together, their 1969 anthem for a largely middle-class teenage audience playing at being revolutionaries; the lyrics would be a fitting epigraph for Rawi Hages second novel, Cockroach. Hage is a highly esteemed 45-year-old Beirut-born writer now living in Montreal. His first book, De Niros Game, won the 2008 Impac Dublin Literary Award, given for the best English-language book published anywhere in the world. Cockroach was a finalist for the Governor Generals Award and other Canadian prizes. Yet the Airplane anthem of teenage revolution is the perfect soundtrack for it.

title: November Song
description: Narratives, Aristotle suggests in his Poetics, work best if theyre arranged around some pre-existing unit of time: sunrise to sunset, January to December. In his view, at least, human beings love symmetry, and repetition. We like being reminded, in fiction, of what we already know in fact. Maureen Howard has taken this advice both literally and extravagantly in her tetralogy of fictions based on the seasons: her novel A Lovers Almanac (winter); a collection of three novellas, Big as Life (spring); another novel, The Silver Screen (summer); and now, finally, The Rags of Time, which comes described as a novel, but is more a kind of late, meandering overture, part meditation, part postscript, part appendix. Like autumn, it flares and fades, rages and dissembles, not wanting to give itself over to its inevitable end.

title: The Insider | Octavia Peissel
description: The Insider profiles emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the Paris-based filmmaker Octavia Peissel shares her essentials. Peissel is the assistant to director Wes Anderson. She recently finished work on Fantastic Mr. Fox and is planning her own childrens book and documentary for the spring.

title: Risks: 5 Pathogens Linked to Risk for Stroke
description: Many strokes cannot be explained by known risk factors like high blood pressure and smoking, and scientists have speculated that infection could play a role.

title: Rebuilding Its Economy, Iraq Shuns U.S. Businesses
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs Baghdad Trade Fair ended Tuesday, six years and a trillion dollars after the American invasion that toppled Saddam Hussein, and one country was conspicuously absent.

title: Military Charges Hasan
