description: Military prosecutors have charged Maj. Nadil Malik Hasan with 13 counts of murder. MSNBC video.

title: Down Time in Afghanistan
description: On a recent reporting trip to Afghanistans Helmand Province with Dexter Filkins, the photographer Peter van Agtmael captured images of American and Afghan soldiers during some down time.

title: Answers About Home Buyers and Owners Tax Credits: Part 3
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which youll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: G.M. to Position New Buick Regal as Premium Sport Sedan
description: Good thing General Motors held onto Opel, its German subsidiary. Otherwise, where would it get the platforms for new products?

title: Voices on Copenhagen and Beyond
description: Since the last relatively substantive meeting on a new climate treaty, in Bali, Indonesia, in 2007, there has been a steady stream of statements about the urgent need to seal the deal next month in Copenhagen, providing a firm new treaty curbing emissions from rich countries and emerging powers and buttressing poor ones against climatic and coastal hazards.

title: Nothing Was the Same
description: The love you gave me wasn't fresh and young, It didn't melt the sun or set the town aflame. But it was warm and wise as any street, Where hope and sorrow meet in bars without a name. I only know that one day was a drink And then the next was you and nothing was the same.

title: Introducing The Prize: On the B-Plan Circuit
description: Anyone familiar with Tom Cruises breakout role in Risky Business or the reality television series Shark Tank has a pretty good idea of what business plan competitions are.

title: State Workers Agree to Plea Deal in Man Cave Case
description: ALBANY  A warning to any slacker state employee who thinks it is wise to deal drugs, sleep and watch television just a few steps from the State Capitol while you are supposed to be working: You will probably end up in jail.

title: Hoping for a Rooftop Farm in Brooklyn
description: Ben Flanners 6,000-square-foot rooftop garden in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, seemed ambitious when Marian Burros wrote about it in June. But now, Mr. Flanner is working with the Bushwick locavores at Robertas restaurant to create a rooftop farm as much as six or seven times that size.

title: Apples Modest Addition to the Upper West Side
description: We are the most humble store on the Upper West Side, said Ron Johnson, the senior vice president of Apples retail effort, capping a 45-minute presentation filled with a staggering supply of stupendous superlatives about the first decade of the Apple Store.

title: Saturday Is National Gaming Day at the Nations Public Libraries
description: Over the last few years libraries have increasingly used video game tournaments as a way to persuade new users to come through the doors.

title: Cowboys Full
description: Pokerticians

title: Two-Wheeled Rambles, Even When Frost Is on the Pumpkin
description: EVEN when the days grow shorter and colder, the open road still beckons to motorcyclists. Weekend traffic is lighter, and heated gloves and jackets make it possible to venture out in comfort. A trip on scenic roads that in summer are clogged with motorists and other cyclists can be a serene exercise in solitude.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Nov. 12
description: In an all-too-virtual world, it is sometimes easy to forget how important a touch can be, how it links us to those who are present and those who are not. Todays report opens with two photographs, by Robert Stolarik and Jerry Lampen, that remind us.

title: Who Needs Miami or Los Cabos? Time Shares Move to the City
description: THERE is a new building on West 57th Street in Manhattan, a block from Bulgari and Bergdorf Goodman on Fifth Avenue, and about the same distance to Central Park and Carnegie Hall. Walking by, it looks like many of the luxury apartment projects that have recently sprouted in the city, with glass windows reaching up 28 stories, a fitness center visible from the street and well-dressed doormen in the lobby.

title: Vain Glorious | Maison Francis Kurkdjian
description: With Vain Glorious, The Moment breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

title: Separating Curds and Whey, City Life and Country Farm
description: Walpole, N.H.  FEW New York literary agents take business calls while milking cows. But Stephanie Cabot does. She has arranged her life so that on any given evening she is as likely to be at a Manhattan publishing party as on the farm here where she lives part time with her family, 300 cows and the ghosts of Cabots past.

title: Sullenbergers Passengers Say Hes a Hero, Despite New Book
description: In America today, the half-life of newly minted hero status seems to end the moment that Oprahs jaw drops. No sooner does someone amaze us than someone else seeks to diminish their splendor.

title: On Assignment: Liability, Meet Asset
description: Alone in a numberless crowd, Specialist Brian Hill seemed utterly lost to his own grief as he knelt on the ground while President Obama read the names of the dead during the memorial service at Fort Hood, Tex.

title: Freed Journalist to Write Memoir About Her Captivity
description: Euna Lee, a journalist who was arrested by North Korea and jailed for nearly five months, will write a book for the Broadway Books imprint of the Crown Publishing Group detailing her experiences. Ms. Lee, a producer for Current TV, was arrested with a colleague, Laura Ling, by North Korean soldiers on March 17 while they were filming at the border between China and North Korea.

title: Brady-Manning Is No. 2 on the QB Matchups Top 10 List
description: John Maxymuks latest book is Quarterback Abstract.

title: Corzine Says He Hasnt Spoken to Bank of America
description: Since Jon S. Corzine has been voted out of New Jerseys governor seat, many have been asking what he will do next.

title: The First Marriage
description: Because of the parallels between our families  I graduated from Harvard Law School, my husband and I have two daughters the same ages as Malia and Sasha and my husband lived away from us for business for years  I have followed the Obama family with great interest. At first it was because I wanted my daughters to see that all families are fundamentally alike. Now it is because of the profound wisdom Michelle Obama has about her marriage. All couples struggle, and many couples evolve in the roles they play; in the end, though, its about making our own contributions to the relationship. Thanks to the Obamas for being honest enough to acknowledge this difficult but universal truth.

title: Time Magazine on The 10 Best College Presidents in America
description: With its issue on newsstands on Friday, Time becomes the latest news magazine to attempt to quantify an aspect of the college experience that  The Choice would argue  defies easy categorization.

title: Metrobus of Mexico City Gets a Boost
description: Mexico Citys Metrobus  a so-called bus rapid transit system  received a prestigious award from Harvard on Thursday, and the country has announced plans to expand the system.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Fantastic Mr. Fox'
description: Wes Anderson, the director of "Fantastic Mr. Fox," discusses an early scene from the film, which is now on DVD.

title: Escalations
description: Matt Bai writes that President Obamas dilemma over Afghanistan has reached a crossroads similar to the one Kennedy was preparing to negotiate in 1963. While it is painfully evident that reflexive pacifism affected many Congressional antiwar Democrats in their vote for the 2002 Iraq war resolution, the legacy it leaves for Barack Obama is of strength rather than weakness, patience rather than haste. Our national obsession for militarism around the world doesnt work and brings only resentment. Barack Obama shares a common strength with President Kennedy  the audacity to envision a just world, not by exporting our militarymight but by the richness of our own values.

title: G.O.P. Resurrects Flip-Flop for Health Care
description: For Republicans, Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat, is the gift that keeps on giving.

title: Questions for John Baldacci
description: Im writing to congratulate you on returning to the full-length color photo that I found so interesting and informative. The reader gets considerable information about the subjects personality when you see the clothing, shoes and hair in color. Deborah Solomons interview is the first part of The Sunday New York Times that I read, and in recent weeks the interview has felt more complete with the return to the original photo format.

title: Collective Shrug
description: To the Editor:

title: Lives: Car Thief
description: Michelle Hunevens poignant portrayal of her aging fathers misadventures with driving is a tale that many more will be able to tell in the decades ahead. As people live longer, they drive longer. And in most communities, if you cant drive, your world shrinks, health declines and life is over, figuratively if not literally. So what is a concerned son or daughter to do? Getting your parents doctor to contact the D.M.V. is not the end of the story. Just as some states have instituted vision requirements for older persons to renew their licenses, a brief standardized screening for physical and cognitive fitness to drive deserves serious attention in our national-policy discussions, along with support for alternative transportation options that enable safe and convenient community mobility. This wont always be our parents problem.

title: Norway or Our Way?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pelosi to Back Capuano in Massachusetts Senate Race
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi will endorse Representative Michael Capuanos Senate bid in Massachusetts in Boston on Friday, Mr. Capuanos campaign has announced.

title: DauerWalden
description: WHAT Conservation-focused community.

title: The Latest on Swine Flu, and More
description: Here are some recent Times stories about children and parents, in case you missed them:

title: Boxing in the Shadow of Pacquiao
description: Young men in the Philippines, inspired by the light welterweight champion Manny Pacquiao, are training to escape poverty, boxing for a few dollars more than they make as subsistence farmers.

title: Counterpoint to Study Praising Charter Schools
description: When a Stanford economist, Caroline Hoxby, released a study in late September finding that students at New York City charter schools performed better on state exams than those who entered the same admission lotteries but did not receive a seat, charter school advocates rejoiced. They said it was the final proof that charter schools, which are publicly financed but privately run, produced better results than their traditional public counterparts, and not simply by choosing the best students.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Disney Posts Strong Profit Despite Weakness in Films
description: LOS ANGELES  The financial health of the Walt Disney Company is improving, notably in the area of television, which helped the company report a 18 percent increase in its fourth-quarter profit on Thursday. But a dismal quarter in movies weighed on the companys results, and its theme park division remained soft.

title: New York Fall Foliage
description: Its been a confusing few weeks. As we have entered Eastern Standard Time, the temperature has risen to levels not seen since, well, trick-or-treaters were sweating in their costumes two weeks ago.

title: 2 Sunken Japanese Subs Are Found Off Hawaii
description: Researchers on Thursday announced the discovery of two World War II Japanese submarines, including one meant to carry aircraft for attacks on American cities and the Panama Canal, in deep water off Hawaii, where they were sunk 63 years ago.

title: CNNs Klein Explains the Departure of Lou Dobbs
description: Jon Klein, the president of CNN/U.S., said Thursday that Lou Dobbs had himself made the decision to end his long association with the cable news network after months of conversations about the direction of the channel away from the kind of opinion-based reporting that Mr. Dobbs preferred.

title: Euro Disney Loss Is Up, Despite Rise in Visitors
description: PARIS  Euro Disney, operator of one of the most popular tourist destinations in Europe, said Thursday that it lost significantly more money over the last year than the previous one, despite a small rise in the number of visitors to its Paris theme park.

title: Matthew Takes Mannahatta
description: Thanksgiving today may bring no threats of marauding animals or Indian raids, but certain risks are inescapable. Now the wild beasts tend to lurk in the back seat of the family automobile, while the flying arrows, though verbal, still sting.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Saudis Efforts to Swat Rebels From Yemen Risk Inflaming Larger Conflict
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  For more than a week, Saudi Arabia has been carrying out a highly unusual military operation on its remote southern border, to punish a band of rebels from neighboring Yemen who crossed over and attacked a Saudi patrol.

title: A Good Week for SNL, Ferguson and Letterman
description: In a week for competitive firsts for several late-night shows, the stand-out success belonged to Saturday Night Live on NBC. It reached its biggest audience of the year with a show host by the singer Taylor Swift.

title: Beckhams Fealty to Galaxy Jeopardizes England Record
description: For one game at least, David Beckham has subjugated his self-interest for the good of a team that is not England or A.C. Milan. And his decision could cost him a shot at Englands career international appearance record of 125 caps, which is held by goalkeeper Peter Shilton.

title: Tree Is Planted in Memory of Slain Brooklyn Teenager
description: Family and friends of a teenager who died after a fight in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, returned to that same spot Thursday to honor him by planting a tree.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Who Can Bend the Cost Curve?
description: Which should we trust to rein in health care costs: the federal government or the private sector?

title: N.F.L. Blows Whistle on Promotion for Liquor Brand
description: The National Football League is calling a halt to a promotion for Captain Morgan rum after a player struck a pose during a game that invoked the rums brand character.

title: Answers to Questions on Philanthropy
description: Stephanie Strom answers your questions on charitable giving.

title: Theater Listings: Nov. 13-20
description: THEATER

title: Fte Accompli | The Corduroy Appreciation Clubs Grand Meeting
description: What: On Nov. 11, the day that most resembles corduroy, the Corduroy Appreciation Club hosted its fourth annual Grand Meeting at the American Can Factory in Park Slope, Brooklyn. The entrance fee was $11.11, the price that most resembles corduroy.

title: Read It Here: Goldman Foundations 2008 Tax Filing
description: The New York Times on Thursday caused a bit of a stir with Geraldine Fabrikants article about Goldman Sachss foundation and what it reveals about the banks charitable arm.

title: Police Have a Burglary Pattern and a Name, but Still No Suspect
description: The burglar has a penchant for squeezing through windows leading to the basements or kitchens  in the fronts or backs  of Staten Island homes, the authorities say. Sometimes, he simply enters through an unlocked door.

title: Performa 09 | Mike Kelley and Michael Smith
British Airways and Iberia Plan to Merge
description: LONDON  British Airways and Iberia of Spain agreed on Thursday to a $7 billion merger, ending 16 months of negotiations and creating one of the worlds largest airlines to compete with rivals like Air France-KLM and Lufthansa.

title: British Airways and Iberia Plan to Merge
description: British Airways and Iberia of Spain approved an agreement late Thursday setting out the basis for a $7 billion merger, a move that would conclude more than 16 months of talks, Julia Werdigier of The New York Times reports from London.

title: Bush Returns to Public Spotlight
description: DALLAS  He has gone out of his way not to criticize his successor, and former President George W. Bush stuck resolutely to that policy on Thursday as he dove back into the national conversation.

title: A Year Is Added to Sentence of Officer Who Robbed Banks
description: A former New York City police officer was sentenced on Thursday to 78 months in prison for robbing a Sovereign Bank branch in the East Village twice in 2007 with the help of his companion, who was a teller there.

title: From the House of the Dead': A Fresh Eye on Opera
description: I completely agree with Charles that opera companies have been smart to court directors from outside the field. Why not? Plays, musicals, spectacles, operas  theater is theater. Of course every genre has its own elements and peculiarities. And the idea of coming in fresh is no excuse for a director not to know the operatic text at hand thoroughly.

title: Delivering Bad News and Truths About War
description: At one point in The Messenger a soldier, just back from an overseas tour of duty, is telling a story during a welcome-home party with some friends. It starts out as a funny reminiscence of a local character he knew in Iraq, but when the anecdote takes a gruesome turn, the laughter is replaced by uncomfortable silence. Nobody gets the point of what hes saying, or maybe nobody wants to hear it, and the happy mood of the reunion fractures.

title: Rural India Gets Chance at Piece of Jobs Boom
description: BAGEPALLI, India  Under harsh fluorescent lights, dozens of heads bend over keyboards, the clattering unison of earnest typing filling the room. Monitors flicker with insurance forms, time sheets and customer service e-mail messages, tasks from far away, sent to this corner of India to be processed on the cheap.

title: Screen Memories
description: Many years ago, in an age of chaos and confusion, in a world where time was money and pleasure was work, I saw a movie that changed my life forever. It was called My Dog Skip.

title: When the World Hangs in the Balance, a Reliable Calendar Is Needed
description: I know what I have against Roland Emmerich  The Patriot, for starters  but what does he have against us? Hes bombarded Earth with alien death rays, big-footed it with a rampaging reptile and put it into deep freeze. Now in 2012, his latest apocalyptic folly, he cracks the planet like a nut, splitting its crust, toppling its mountains and cities, and laying its every creeping thing to inevitable tedious waste.

title: Apple to Open Upper West Side Store, Fourth in New York
description: We are the most humble store on the Upper West Side, said Ron Johnson, the senior vice president of Apples retail effort, capping a 45-minute presentation filled with a staggering supply of stupendous superlatives about the first decade of the Apple Store.

title: Podcast: Fort Hood, Corruption and Health Care
description: Click Below to Listen

title: Movies of Influence
description: Zodiac Other movies used computer-generated imagery to create spectacular worlds of fantasy or eye-popping action sequences, but in this film, David Fincher went further than anyone before in using this kind of digital technique in the service of heightened realism.

title: Movies of Quality
description: Wall-E (Andrew Stanton)and A.I. (Steven Spielberg): Visions of love in the post-human future.

title: A Lack of Rigor Costs MBIA
description: MBIA, the financial insurance company, used to hold itself out as a paragon of hard work and number crunching.

title: Chess for Change
description: A school chess program fosters analytical skills to encourage academic success.

title: The First Brownstone Renovations
description: In a new book, "The Row House Reborn: Architecture and Neighborhoods in New York City, 1908-1929," Andrew S. Dolkart argues that a whole new building type emerged in the early 20th century.

title: Pet Food Pantry
description: Specialized food pantries provide for animals whose owners face financial hardship. And they deliver.

title: A Reality Show That Eliminates Debt, Not Contestants
description: It was only a matter of time before reality television producers came up with a show that, pardon the pun, revolves around debt.

title: G.E. to Sell Security Unit
description: General Electric said Thursday that it would sell its fire alarm and security systems unit to United Technologies for $1.82 billion, continuing a sale of what the industrial conglomerate considers noncore businesses.

title: British Airways and Iberia Plan to Merge
description: British Airways and Spains Iberia agreed Thursday to a $7 billion combination, ending 16 months of negotiations and creating one of the worlds largest airlines to compete with rivals like Air France-KLM and Lufthansa.

title: Taliban Claim to Seize American Arms
description: This week Al Jazeera broadcast video of Taliban fighters displaying ammunition and mines the insurgents claim American forces left behind when they withdrew from two remote combat outposts in eastern Afghanistan last month, after a deadly attack that had killed eight Americans and four Afghan security officers.

title: A Shtick With a Thousand Lives
description: MEL BROOKS and Carl Reiner have been cracking each other up for nearly 60 years. The two met while working on Sid Caesars early television series Your Show of Shows, when they cooked up a routine in which Mr. Reiner played an earnest, unnamed TV interviewer, and Mr. Brooks, the 2,000 Year Old Man.

title: Bank Breakup Plan, Still Unseen, Draws Wall St. Ire
description: A legislative amendment set to be proposed by Representative Paul E. Kanjorski, Democrat of Pennsylvania, is creating quite a stir on Wall Street, even though a completed version has yet to be seen.

title: Editor of The Washington Times Resigns
description: The editor of The Washington Times has resigned, the newspaper announced on Thursday, three days after it confirmed that three top executives of the paper had been ousted.

title: Oreo, Dog Who Survived Roof Fall, Will Be Euthanized
description: Oreo, a pit bull mix, was hailed as a miracle dog when she survived being hurled off a Brooklyn rooftop last summer. She had two broken legs and a broken rib.

title: Could Electricity Be a Lifestyle Choice?
description: Could there be a Whole Foods of electricity?

title: Inside Maxxi
description: A look at Zaha Hadid's new contemporary art museum in Rome.

title: Eating By the Book | The Craft of Baking
description: This Sundays Times Magazine features a story by Pete Wells with a recipe for spicy caramel popcorn from Karen DeMascos first book, The Craft of Baking. I was eager to get my hands on it; DeMasco is one of New York Citys most celebrated and talented pastry chefs. She baked at Fore Street in Portland, Me., at Chanterelle in Manhattan and then under Claudia Fleming at Gramercy Tavern. In 2001, she relocated a block south, where she shaped her baking style as Tom Colicchios pastry chef at Craft, Craftbar and wichcraft. After a brief hiatus from the restaurant grind, she is back in it, this time as the pastry chef at Andrew Carmellinis Locanda Verde.

title: A Turning Point for Eminent Domain?
description: Updated, Nov. 13, 11:55 p.m. | Ilya Somin, a frequent contributor to The Volokh Conspiracy legal blog, and Thomas Merrill, a professor of law at Yale, join our discussion.

title: Long-Term Return: Warhols Money Factory
description: Whenever you stand back for a panoramic look at the contemporary art world  that confection of bucks, puff and street smarts  you realize afresh that Andy Warhol was the daddy of it all. And that was confirmed yet again at Sothebys on Wednesday night, when his 1962 silk-screen painting 200 One Dollar Bills sold for $43.7 million (including Sothebys fees).

title: Where Art and Design Meet
description: Art and design meet with a particular clarity at Modernism + Art20 at the Park Avenue Armory.

title: Conservatives Oppose Judicial Nominee
description: Conservative groups have been rallying their troops to urge senators to oppose the nomination of Judge David F. Hamilton of Indiana to the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals.

title: A One-Stop Eyeful of Mediums
description: Which is better: a mediocre work of art or an outstanding design object? This question buzzes about Modernism + Art20, the new two-in-one art and design fair at the Park Avenue Armory through Monday. An answer never emerges, possibly because there really isnt one, and therein lies some of the fun of this hybrid show.

title: Compassionate Masters of the Universe
description: First, do no harm. Thats the bottom-line rule of Jainism, one of the three major homegrown religions in India. To believers, all living things, from whales to humans to flu bugs, have souls and, karmically speaking, all souls are equal. If you go thrashing and stomping your way through the average day, as most of us do, youre bound to be injuring something. And if you injure something, you injure everything, including yourself. This is how karma works. So it pays to move with care.

title: Rolling Out Sarah Palins Side of the Story
description: Update | 11:35 p.m. The McCain campaign dissed Sarah Palin, muffled her, and then stuck her with a $50,000 legal bill  that, at least, is the version of events she tells in her new book, due to be released next week.

title: The Tale of the Deflowered Girl
description: Last January, an anonymous poster at LiveJournal put up a complete scan of what seemed to be a forgotten book by Edward Gorey, The Recently Deflowered Girl: The Right Thing to Say on Every Dubious Occasion, a retro etiquette manual credited to one Hyacinthe Phypps.

title: When Courageous Artists Ripped Holes in the Iron Curtain
description: IN 1985 a dissident troupe of Polish actors called Theater of the Eighth Day defied the ruling Communist Party and its censors by creating a play about the bleakness of daily life under martial law, imposed from 1981 to 1983. With ragged costumes and only a few props  most notably a sailboat that symbolized the dream of escape  the actors prepared to mount Wormwood, an unusually blunt and unvarnished work of protest theater.

title: Goodbye, Mr. TIPS?
description: Hmm. There have been a number of stories recently saying that inflation expectations are on the rise, and its true that the TIPS spread  the difference in yields between inflation-protected US bonds and ordinary, nominal bonds  has widened out to a bit more than 2 percent:

title: Brief, Productive Love Affair With Big Dog
description: When Christopher Columbus first came to America, there were no natives on horseback to greet him. That is not only because he landed on an island in the Bahamas. Its also because there were no horses in the New World. They originated here 40 million years ago and spread to other parts of the globe, but by 1492 horses had been extinct in the Western Hemisphere for 10,000 years. On his second trans-Atlantic voyage, in 1493, Columbus brought along 25 horses and reintroduced the species to America. Many more were brought later by French, English and Dutch colonizers.

title: W.H.O. Rushes Drugs to Nations Hit by Swine Flu
description: Emergency supplies of antiviral drugs are being sent to Ukraine, Afghanistan and other countries in Eastern Europe and Central Asia, where hospitals report that they are being overwhelmed by patients with swine flu, the World Health Organization said Thursday.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Hollywood Swoons Over That Hair, That Baton
description: LOS ANGELES  They drew the line at the bobble-head doll.

title: Lou Dobbs
description: I used to go on Lou Dobbs fairly often in the early years of this decade  and I liked him. We didnt agree on much, but the on-air discussions were always even-tempered and kind of fun. I would never have expected him to snap the way he did.

title: Unsnarling a Knotty Ball of Secrets, British Style
description: Collision, a two-week Masterpiece Contemporary mini-series beginning on Sunday on PBS, raises an old but always pertinent question: why are the British so much better at this sort of thing than we are?

title: A Sentimental Tug
description: Several years ago, I noticed my sisters daughter wearing two rings on her fingers. They were my childhood earrings, which I left with my parents for safekeeping. My sister took them and turned them into rings for her daughter. I felt really bad; those earrings have sentimental value. But if I confront my sister, Im afraid Ill lose the relationship. Should I just let the earrings go?

title: Film Series and Movie Listings
description: MOVIES

title: Trailer: 'The Prisoner'
description: Ian McKellen and Jim Caviezel star in this new version of the cult spy series from the 1960s, which begins Sunday on AMC.

title: Rethinking of a Number Between 1 and 10
description: There was no single archvillain in The Prisoner, which was one of the many distinctions of that legendary late-60s spy series.

title: Times News Service to Lay Off at Least 25
description: The New York Times News Service will lay off at least 25 editorial employees next year, and will move the editing of the service to a Florida newspaper owned by The New York Times Company, The Times and the Newspaper Guild said on Thursday.

title: Arts and Crafts Items That Arent Often Seen
description: John H. Bryan, a former chief executive of the Sara Lee Corporation, owns an estate near Chicago that looks like a museum of early 1900s design but is not, at least not yet. On a 150-acre former dairy farm in Lake Bluff, Ill., named Crab Tree Farm, he has spent two decades setting up period rooms in 1910s barns and other scattered outbuildings. Almost every chair, bookcase, table, vase and rug was made by Arts and Crafts innovators from Britain and the United States, including Gustav Stickley, William Morris and Christopher Dresser.

title: Laura Straus and John Alexander
description: SHAKESPEARES sonnets, Thomas Hardys poetry and Pasternaks Doctor Zhivago seem to have little in common, but all played a part in the romance between Laura Straus and John Alexander.

title: Workers Plead Guilty in Man Cave Case
description: ALBANY  A warning to any slacker state employee who thinks it is wise to deal drugs, sleep and watch television just a few steps from the State Capitol while you are supposed to be working: You will probably end up in jail.

title: White House Sides With C.I.A. in Turf Battle
description: WASHINGTON After a months-long turf battle between Americas top spies, the White House has sided with the Central Intelligence Agency in the dispute over who has the power to appoint the top spy in each country overseas, according to intelligence officials.

title: Country Awards on Top
description: The Country Music Association Awards, at which 19-year-old Taylor Swift won the Entertainer of the Year prize, earned its most viewers in four years on Wednesday and lifted ABC to No. 1 in the nights ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, an average of 16.8 million viewers tuned in to the awards show, nearly a million more than last year. CBS was second for the night, garnering its highest ratings for its crime dramas Criminal Minds (12.3 million) and CSI: NY (13.9 million). NBC was third with Law & Order: SVU (8.8 million) and The Jay Leno Show (4.6 million). Fox finished in fourth place as Glee attracted 7.3 million viewers.

title: Art in Review
description: REGINA JOS GALINDO

title: Journalist Gets Book Deal
description: Euna Lee, a journalist who was arrested by North Korea and jailed for nearly five months, will write a book for the Broadway Books imprint of the Crown Publishing Group detailing her experiences. Ms. Lee, a producer for Current TV, was arrested with a colleague, Laura Ling, on March 17 while filming at the border between China and North Korea. In June, the women were sentenced to 12 years of hard labor for committing hostilities against the Korean nation and illegal entry, but were pardoned in August after the intervention of former President Bill Clinton. In a statement on Thursday, Broadway Books said that Ms. Lees memoir, called The World Is Bigger Now: A Memoir of Faith, Family and Freedom, would detail her 140 days of imprisonment, her ongoing interrogation and her efforts to protect her sources and the subjects of her reporting, as well as the importance of her religious faith during this time. A publication date has not been announced. Ms. Ling is presently pitching her own book with her sister, the journalist Lisa Ling.

title: Alabamas Bingo Halls
description: Video bingo has become increasingly popular in Alabama in recent years, leading to a legal backlash led by gambling opponents.

title: American Art Fair at National Academy
description: A sale of paintings and watercolors by 19th- and early-20th-century American masters will be held at the National Academy, the artist-governed museum and school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan that provoked an outcry last year when it sold two Hudson River School paintings from its collection to shore up its finances. But this sale is different. The artworks, by the likes of Thomas Eakins, Thomas Hart Benton, George Inness and Whistler, are being offered by 11 dealers under the umbrella of the second annual American Art Fair, running Nov. 30 through Dec. 3. Part of the fairs proceeds will benefit the troubled academy.

title: Among Obama Aides, Debate Intensifies on Troop Levels
description: WASHINGTON  The disclosure that the United States ambassador in Kabul has expressed written opposition to deploying more American troops to Afghanistan lays bare the fierce debate within the Obama administration over the direction of the war, even after weeks of deliberations and with the president on the verge of a decision.

title: Gates Condemns Leaks on U.S. Afghan Policy and Ft. Hood
description: OSHKOSH, Wis.  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates is normally a mild-mannered man, at least in public, but he unleashed a torrent on Thursday about leaks during the investigation of the Foot Hood shootings and during President Obamas deliberations on sending more American troops to Afghanistan.

title: E. Coli Outbreak Traced to Company That Halted Testing of Ground Beef Trimmings
description: A deadly outbreak of E. coli has been traced to a large producer of ground beef that stopped testing its ingredients years ago under pressure from beef suppliers.

title: Paul Tagliabue, Former N.F.L. Commissioner, Selected to Lead U.S.O.C. Panel
description: The board of the United States Olympic Committee has appointed Paul Tagliabue, the former N.F.L. commissioner, to lead an independent panel that will examine whether the board, which has been criticized as being too insular, should change its governance structure.

title: 3 Right-Hand Men Take a Turn at Center Stage
description: WASHINGTON  While he is a relatively new senator, Ted Kaufman, Democrat of Delaware, is deeply familiar with Senate folkways. Dont talk too much too soon. Show great deference to committee chairmen. And always  always  treat staff members with the utmost respect.

title: A Tough Dad, a Weak Son, a Dead Mom: The Usual
description: As soon as Ray, a working-class English brute wearing a white mask of skin cream, finishes off the first scene with the zinger Let the freak show commence, its clear that Red Sea Fish doesnt take place in the dreary British flat onstage so much as in the imagination of the author. Would a thuggish thief say something so flamboyant? And would he use the word commence?

title: Ill Will Grows in a Former Colonial Region
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A waiter, reacting to the mosquitoes plaguing a customer on a recent hot night here, said sharply, Those arent mosquitoes; those are French people!

title: After Bankruptcy, G.M. Struggles to Shed a Legendary Bureaucracy
Two German Killers Demanding Anonymity Sue Wikipedias Parent
description: Wolfgang Werl and Manfred Lauber became infamous for killing a German actor in 1990. Now they are suing to force Wikipedia to forget them.

title: After Dobbs, CNN Makes a Bet on King
description: Replacing an anchor known for his outspoken political beliefs with a traditional Washington reporter, CNN on Thursday said a political news program led by John King would fill Lou Dobbss time slot early next year.

title: Lovers Cross a Bridge, in More Ways Than One
description: Uncertainty is a taut, skillful exercise in cinematic clockwork concocted by Scott McGehee and David Siegel, the talented directors of The Deep End and Bee Season. Written by the two men, with dialogue largely improvised by the actors, the movie splits into parallel stories after an opening scene in which young lovers, Bobby Thompson (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), a Canadian musician, and Kate Montero (Lynn Collins), a Broadway dancer, meet on the Brooklyn Bridge one Fourth of July morning.

title: Spurs Blair Is Lacking in Everything but Success
description: The unlikely phenomenon of DeJuan Blair begins with a checklist of everything that should disqualify him as an effective N.B.A. player.

title: Hot Warhols Help Sothebys Top $134 Million at Auction
description: It was the sale of the season. When a seminal Warhol  one of the artists first silk-screen paintings  came on the block at Sothebys auction of contemporary art on Wednesday night, the auctioneer, Tobias Meyer, opened bidding at $6 million and was stunned when a bidder instantly doubled it.

title: Newfangled Bank Capital
description: Contingent capital securities  known as CoCo bonds  have made their debut. The early reviews seem promising.

title: New Turn in Debate Over Law on Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  The fight over a proposed same-sex marriage law here heated up this week as the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington said that if the law passed, the church would cut its social service programs that help residents with adoption, homelessness and health care.

title: New York Times News Service to Cut Jobs and Relocate
description: The New York Times News Service will lay off at least 25 editorial employees next year and will move the editing of the service to a Florida newspaper owned by The New York Times Company, the newspaper and the Newspaper Guild said Thursday.

title: Detective Accused of Providing Tips to Informers Is Acquitted
description: A New York City police detective accused of tipping off confidential informers about aspects of a federal drug investigation was acquitted on Thursday of charges of hindering prosecution and official misconduct.

title: Motives, Choice and Fort Hood
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge in Brunos Corruption Trial Chastises Him Over a Remark
description: ALBANY  The judge presiding over the corruption trial of Joseph L. Bruno, the former State Senate leader, angrily admonished him on Thursday after Mr. Bruno appeared to challenge one of his rulings at the end of a grueling day in court.

title: Selling a Household Cleaning Product on Its ... Sex Appeal?
description: IN a new television commercial for Pine-Sol cleaner shot in an over-the-top film noir style, Diane Amos, who has starred in the brands ads for 16 years, drives a late-model convertible on the Pacific Coast Highway in California, moonlight dappling the ocean. When she reaches an opulent home, she climbs a stairway, then opens a door to reveal a shirtless, muscular man mopping the floor. Finally Ms. Amos, sprawled on a bed strewn with rose petals and bottles of Pine-Sol as the man mops beside her, purrs the slogan: Thats the power of Pine-Sol, baby.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) President Obama announces a jobs summit meeting.

title: An Around-the-World Trip to Ask an Age-Old Question
description: Celebrities  Ringo Starr, Hugh Jackman, Bob Geldof and Seal, among others  get pride of place in the credits of Oh My God?, Peter Rodgers picturesque but shallow inquiry into the meaning of God. The film, which Mr. Rodger directed, wrote, produced and photographed on location in nearly two dozen countries, is the documentary equivalent of a spiritually angled coffee-table book of world travels.

title: For Comcasts Chief, Content Led the Way
description: At a dinner 12 years ago in Redmond, Wash., Brian L. Roberts challenged the richest man in the world to invest in his business  cable TV.

title: CNN Cuts Back on a Web Video Project
description: CNN laid off its four Web anchors on Thursday and said it had stopped producing continuous live video for CNN.com, curtailing one of the Internets biggest news experiments.

title: Radical Lawyers Appeal (and Rebuttal)
description: For William Kunstler, the wild-haired, radical civil rights lawyer with the raspy voice who became a left-wing political star in the late 1960s, Michelangelos statue of David symbolized how he saw himself. A photograph of the statue that morphs into a drawing of David twirling his slingshot is a recurrent image in the crisply made, largely admiring documentary William Kunstler: Disturbing the Universe. To him, it embodied the moment everyone faces at some time or other when one has to stand up to injustice or keep silent.

title: U.S. Identifies 111,000 Immigrants With Criminal Records
description: Federal authorities have identified more than 111,000 immigrants with criminal records being held in local jails, during the first year of a program that seeks to deport immigrants who have committed serious crimes.

title: Despite Sales Slip, Nintendo Predicts Strong Season
description: Although October sales of Nintendos Wii console dropped 36 percent compared with the same period last year, company executives expect robust sales in the holiday season.

title: Free to Lose
description: Consider, for a moment, a tale of two countries. Both have suffered a severe recession and lost jobs as a result  but not on the same scale. In Country A, employment has fallen more than 5 percent, and the unemployment rate has more than doubled. In Country B, employment has fallen only half a percent, and unemployment is only slightly higher than it was before the crisis.

title: A New Cholesterol Study Puts Focus on Merck Drugs
description: Some of Wall Streets leading drug industry analysts are scheduled to fly to Orlando, Fla., on Sunday afternoon. A junket to SeaWorld it is not.

title: Meet John Thune
description: Some days the Republican Party seems to be going crazy. Its public image is often shaped by people who appear to have gone into government because they saw it as a steppingstone to talk radio.

title: Rock Boys Adventure, With BBC as the Enemy
description: Boys will be boys and often at top volume in Pirate Radio, Richard Curtiss fanciful fiction about rebel broadcasters who, in the mid-1960s, blasted British airwaves and eardrums with the Stones, the Kinks and the Who, among other youth-quaking greats of the era. Stuffed with playful character actors and carpeted with wall-to-wall tunes, the film makes for easy viewing and easier listening, even if Mr. Curtis, who wrote and directed, has nothing really to say about these rebels for whom rock n roll was both lifes rhyme and its reason.

title: Zimbabwe: Lawyers Seek New Judge in Terrorism Trial of Opposition Leader
description: Lawyers for Roy Bennett, a leader in the opposition Movement for Democratic Change who faces terrorism charges, asked the trial judge, Chinembiri Bhunu, to recuse himself on the grounds that comments he made in a related 2006 case showed bias. In that case, against the man who is now the states key witness, and who says he was tortured to implicate Mr. Bennett, the judge denied bail and said there was overwhelming evidence against the man, who was later acquitted by a different judge. Judge Bhunu will rule on Monday.

title: Pfizer to Leave City That Won Land-Use Case
description: From the edge of the Thames River in New London, Conn., Michael Cristofaro surveyed the empty acres where his parents neighborhood had stood, before it became the crux of an epic battle over eminent domain.

title: A Murder Raises Hard Questions in Kentucky
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Steve Nunn was something of a golden child in Kentucky politics. The son of a former governor, he was a successful and well-liked politician who served in the State Legislature for 15 years.

title: Georgia Techs Bedford Makes Time for Spread Option and DAlemberts Paradox
description: ATLANTA  It would be an easy ruse. Sean Bedford would belly up to a bar to watch a football game and wait for that inevitable moment when the fan on the next stool, a beer in one hand and a chicken wing in the other, sneered at the unfortunate offensive lineman who moved before the snap and drew a penalty flag.

title: Drama of High School, Starring Eros and Anxiety
description: Dare, written by David Brind, directed by Adam Salky and based on their short film of the same title, stakes out familiar territory and, true to its name, strikes out in some risky new directions. This high school semi-romance, which blends comic and tearful moods, is at once more provocative and more contemplative than most of its big-screen counterparts. On television and in young-adult novels, candor  or prurience  about teenage behavior is the norm, but Hollywood movies tend to keep one foot firmly planted in a more innocent world.

title: Wilpon Firm Challenges Finding by Trustee in Madoff Case
description: Lawyers for Sterling Equities, the investment firm controlled by Fred Wilpon, the principal owner of the Mets, said it lost money as a result of the Ponzi scheme orchestrated by Bernard L. Madoff, according to a filing Thursday in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.

title: Man Jailed for 91 Murder Is Cleared by Judge
description: A Manhattan judge ruled on Thursday that a man who had spent 18 years in prison for murder was innocent of the crime, sending a cathartic jolt through a courtroom packed with his friends and family members.

title: Pretty Village, Gloomy Boy
description: I wasnt born here. I only live here. And Im sure as hell not going to die here, declares James Powers (Donal Gallery), the hormonally supercharged 16-year-old narrator of Turning Green.

title: Scarred, Fort Hood Survivors Move On
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  It seemed unlikely that Christopher Royal was going to be delivering the sermon Sunday at Shiloh Baptist Church in the tiny town of Eclectic, Ala., as scheduled. Mr. Royal, a chief warrant officer in the Army, had been shot three times in the back during the rampage at Fort Hood.

title: Lottery Numbers
Getting Into the Zone at Cornell
description: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team. As he did last season, Jon will be blogging for The Quad throughout this season.

title: For Emily Hughes, an Opportunity to Impress at Skate America
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  When Emily Hughes received the news that she would be replacing the injured Sasha Cohen at this weeks Skate America, she could not help screaming into the phone.

title: Mad Men, Maddening Times
description: Has Congress become like an episode of Mad Men? California Congresswoman Linda Sanchez asked this week, after the House of Representatives approved a version of health care reform that contained what some pro-choice advocates are calling the toughest restrictions on womens access to abortion since the Roe v. Wade decision.

title: Eating by the Numbers
description: BURIED in the nearly 2,000 pages of the health reform bill passed by the House on Saturday is a provision requiring chain restaurants to post calorie counts on their menus. Given the worsening problem of obesity in the United States, and the superiority of disease prevention over treatment, calorie posting seems like a great idea. However, research by us and others suggests that it is unlikely to have much, if any, impact on eating or obesity.

title: Information Highway: Camel Speed but Exotic Links
description: You are about to make an unusual journey, a wall label proclaims at the beginning of an exhibition that opens on Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History. Normally that promise would provide reason enough to be wary. But this is something different.

title: Struggling With the Rent and Deferring a Dream
description: More than anything, Atavia Wilson wants to be Anthony Bourdain, the roving celebrity chef.

title: The Knicks Struggles Leave Walsh Mystified
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Donnie Walsh observes Knicks practices with a watchful eye from a chair so close to the sideline he can whisper in his players ears.

title: Pregame Tidbits: Slovakia vs. U.S.
description: One of the best things about an obsession with international soccer is the window it opens to the world. After all, how many Americans even knew where Slovakia was located before the announcement of the friendly match against the United States, which will be played in Bratislava on Saturday (10 a.m., Eastern, live on Fox Soccer Channel)?

title: Where Credit Isnt Due
description: SENATOR CHRISTOPHER DODD of Connecticut is trying to help consumers. Unfortunately, his plan is likely to backfire.

title: Reid Mulls Medicare Tax Increase for High Earners
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, is considering a proposal to increase the Medicare payroll tax on high-income workers to help offset the costs of providing health insurance to millions of Americans, Senate aides said Thursday.

title: Afghan Enclave Seen as Model for Development
description: JURM, Afghanistan  Small grants given directly to villagers have brought about modest but important changes in this corner of Afghanistan, offering a model in a country where official corruption and a Taliban insurgency have frustrated many large-scale development efforts.

title: Love, Sex, Whatever
description: To judge by the swelling bosoms spilling out of the frame, the lingerie bill for Women in Trouble must have been estimable. An ensemble piece that never coheres despite a clutch of appealing actresses  notably Carla Gugino and Emmanuelle Chriqui  this movie was written and directed by Sebastian Gutierrez, whose screenplay credits include The Big Bounce (the remake), Gothika and Snakes on a Plane. Its a discouraging list, true, but Ms. Gugino, an interesting actress who has yet to find a big-screen career worthy of her, seemed reason alone to take the chance. (And Robyn Hitchcock did the score.)

title: Critique of a Critic
description: Fans of the writer and musician Robert Palmer, who was chief pop-music critic of The New York Times from 1981 to 1988, should not come to the documentary The Hand of Fatima expecting a comprehensive look at his life, his writing or his role in American music. The films director, Augusta Palmer, is Robert Palmers daughter, and she has a different  though perfectly understandable  agenda.

title: How People Learned About Cholesterol
description: Although it is hard to imagine now, most people, doctors included, did not use to bother to have their cholesterol level checked or to take measures to lower it if it was high.

title: Business Boosterism
description: Mary Mazzios Ten9Eight: Shoot for the Moon, a tirelessly inspirational documentary about teenagers competing in a nationwide business contest, is playing in seven cities in the theaters of one of its corporate sponsors, AMC Entertainment. (The screenings are tied to Global Entrepreneurship Week, which begins on Monday.) Its the type of film you might expect to see at a fund-raising dinner or a convention banquet, not in a commercial theater. That said, its a very well-made piece of boosterism.

title: Medicines to Deter Some Cancers Are Not Taken
description: Many Americans do not think twice about taking medicines to prevent heart disease and stroke. But cancer is different. Much of what Americans do in the name of warding off cancer has not been shown to matter, and some things are actually harmful. Yet the few medicines proved to deter cancer are widely ignored.

title: A Possible Glimpse of Ebersols Future
description: Dick Ebersol has thrived under General Electric for 20 years as the head of NBC Sports. He has spent billions of G.E.s dollars on the rights to show eight Olympic Games, from Atlanta to London.

title: The U.S. Treasury Is on Their Backs
description: Why, oh why, oh why, oh Why did I ever leave 59 Across?Why did I wander to find what lies yonderWhen life was so cozy at home? Betty Comden and Adolph Green

title: Spitzer Talks About, Well, Ethics
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer was invited to speak at Harvard University on Thursday about what first made him famous: policing Wall Street. Mention of the prostitution scandal that made Mr. Spitzer infamous, however, preceded  and followed  his address, which was arranged by a university ethics center.

title: Councils in Jurm Valley Make Improvements
description: Recent successes in development projects in Jurm, Afghanistan, have raised hopes that it could be a model in a country where corruption and insurgency have impeded progress.

title: Breaking Down Economic Breakdown
description: Why Philippe Diaz has titled his new documentary The End of Poverty? is unclear, because this guilt trip/history lesson is really about the beginning of poverty: how the economic and social systems evolved that have kept parts of the world wealthy and large swaths of it poor. The film spends so much time detailing its thesis that the roots of modern poverty are 500 years deep  going back to the explorers and conquistadors who first supplanted indigenous economic systems with Western ideas of property ownership  that it only briefly mentions what might be done about the problem. And then it cops out by not dealing with the many practical barriers to that solution.

title: Brahms Alone, and With Schoenbergs Big Tweak
description: Just 22 hours after the last notes were sounded in Carnegie Halls adventurous festival of Chinese music, Carnegie returned to its bread-and-butter business of presenting international orchestras in mostly standard repertory. But for listeners who found that prospect less exciting than further explorations of new music and exotica might have been, the hall offered a reminder of how thrilling its version of business as usual could be.

title: U.S. Moves to Seize Properties Tied to Iran
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan began legal action on Thursday to seize properties in Queens and across the country where several mosques are located in a broad move against a nonprofit organization that was accused of illegally providing money and other services to Iran.

title: A Condemned Princess, Freed With Global Voices
description: Handel, an artist with a strong claim to being the greatest showman of the 18th century, was under the gun when he created Ariodante for the first production mounted by his Italian opera company at its new home, Covent Garden, in 1735. Faced with a waning English taste for Italian opera and challenged by a new rival company that had lured away his stars, Handel hired a fresh ensemble of international singers, some of them remarkably young. (One tenor was just 17.)

title: Bottomless Songbook With New Orleans Twist
description: Ten years ago, when the singer and producer Steve Tyrell released A New Standard, a modestly successful collection of pop chestnuts sung in a growly New Orleans style, who knew that it would be a cultural bellwether?

title: Intels $1.25 Billion Settlement
description: Intels antitrust and patent settlement with Advanced Micro Devices is good news for A.M.D., which now finds itself $1.25 billion richer, but it is less clear what it does for the general public. Intel has been accused of stifling competition and driving up prices through a wide array of anticompetitive practices, which may or may not continue now that Intel has agreed to write a large check. Government agencies that have sued Intel or are considering it should not back away.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: David Lloyd, 75, Dies; Wrote Chuckles Episode
description: David Lloyd, who wrote scores of scripts for some of the most popular television sitcoms of the 1970s, 80s and 90s  including the memorable Chuckles the Clown episode of The Mary Tyler Moore Show, which was revered by comedy connoisseurs for wringing belly laughs from a funeral  died Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 75.

title: C.I.A. Didnt Violate Rights, Court Says
description: The Central Intelligence Agency did not violate the free speech rights of a former operative, Valerie Wilson, when it prohibited publication of details of her work before 2002 for the agency, a federal appeals court ruled. Ms. Wilson, left, whose classified status was exposed by Bush administration officials, redacted portions of her 2007 book, Fair Game: My Life as a Spy, My Betrayal by the White House because of the ban, but argued that the information was already in the public domain and publication should have been permitted. The opinion from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, stated that When Ms. Wilson elected to serve with the C.I.A., she accepted a life-long restriction on her ability to disclose classified and classifiable information. Others may have disclosed it, and may well have warranted investigation for their disclosures, but these circumstances do not absolve Ms. Wilson of her own secrecy obligations. David B. Smallman, a lawyer for Ms. Wilson and her publisher, Simon & Schuster, said that an appeal was under consideration.

title: Halladay a Test for New Blue Jays General Manager
description: CHICAGO  The first time Alex Anthopoulos called a baseball general manager was nine years ago. When Jim Beattie, then the general manager of the Montreal Expos, answered the phone, Anthopoulos, just 23, panicked and hung up as if he were a kid making a crank call.

title: NASA Hopes Rover Will Rove Again
description: After six months of pondering their predicament, NASA engineers said that they would begin trying to drive the Mars rover Spirit out of a sand trap where it became stuck last spring. They acknowledged, however, that the odds were not good. This could end up where Spirit remains, said Doug McCuistion, director of the Mars Exploration Program at the headquarters for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Spirit and its twin, Opportunity, have been roving the surface of Mars since landing in 2004. Opportunity is still going strong, NASA says, but as Spirit was backing over some rocks in April near a feature known as Home Plate, a wheel broke through a crust on the planets surface and started spinning in the soft powder below. Fearful that the rocks could be a hazard to the undercarriage of the rover, the engineers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory stopped trying to extricate it while they studied the situation with a model in a sandbox. The strategy on Monday will be to try to drive Spirit out of the pit the way it came in, said Ashley Stroupe, a robotics engineer and rover driver.

title: Impresario of and for the People
description: One of the best lines in Free for All, the big, bouncy new oral history of Joseph Papp and the Public Theater, isnt about Papp at all. Its about the mesmerizing effect the director Mike Nichols had  and still has  on playwrights. I think if an Eskimo wrote a play, the playwright James Kirkwood says, hed put it on an ice floe and push it toward Mike Nichols.

title: Arizona: Desalting Plant Is Approved
description: A 17-year-old desalting plant, largely mothballed since it was built and to many a symbol of government waste, is expected to spring to life in May to finally help provide water for Western states. The federal government has approved a proposal by three water agencies, including those serving the Los Angeles, Las Vegas, Phoenix and Tucson areas, to operate the plant, in Yuma, for a one-year trial. The agencies will pay $14 million of the $23 million cost for the test-run of the plant. The test will help determine if full-scale operation is viable and cost-efficient. The plant will use drainage water that normally feeds a wetland in Mexico. The government has averted court fights by agreeing to replenish the water for the wetland. The only hurdle left is a permit from the State of Arizona.

title: Ed Hardys Tattoo Art Is Booty for Digital Pirates
description: Don Ed Hardy, the famed tattoo artist, must smell good. Make that really good. Ed Hardy-themed perfumes have become some of the most popular fragrances in the world with retailers buying $85 million worth of them so far this year.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a report on the adversities facing Iraqis who return home after having fled sectarian violence referred incorrectly to the International Organization of Migration, the group that compiled the report. It is an intergovernmental group, not a nongovernmental organization.

title: Tony N Tina in Union Talks
description: The musicians union and the producers of the New York show Tony n Tinas Wedding have made a preliminary move toward resolving a labor dispute, though the producers challenged the unions account that its members were locked out of the show. Performers with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians have not played in the show since Oct. 10 after a disagreement with the shows producers, Kim and Sonny Ricciardi of Broadway Entertainment, over a contract, which the union says is valid through May 2011. In an e-mail message, the Ricciardis said they have no contract or tie to Local 802 under the shows current terms. The Ricciardis also said the musicians were informed they could not play at the show until the dispute was settled, and allowed them to pick up their belongings from the Edison Hotel, where the show is performed. On Thursday, a union representative and the producers said there had been contact between each groups lawyers, which the union said we interpret as a very positive first step.

title: An Unfortunate Event for Harpercollins
description: Lemony Snicket, the pseudonym of Daniel Handler, right, and the author of the bestselling Series of Unfortunate Events books, has agreed to sell the North American rights to publish a new four-part series to Little, Brown & Company, moving from HarperCollins. The first volume in the new series is scheduled to be published by Little, Brown Books for Young Readers in 2012. Mr. Handler has also signed a deal with Little, Brown Books for Young Readers to publish his first young adult novel. The book, as yet untitled, will be illustrated by Maira Kalman, who composes an occasional visual blog for the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, and will be published in 2011. As part of the deal, Mr. Handlers longtime editor, Susan Rich, will join Little, Brown as an editor-at-large in the young readers group. The Series of Unfortunate Events books, which have sold 60 million copies worldwide, were published in North America by HarperCollins Childrens Books.

title: School Can Perform Rent and Laramie
description: A ruling by a Nevada district court judge will allow students at a Las Vegas area high school to perform Rent and The Laramie Project despite the objections of parents who were seeking an injunction to prevent them, The Las Vegas Review-Journal reported. Students at Green Valley High School in Henderson will be allowed to perform both shows after Judge David Wall ruled against parents who objected to the productions content. Lawyers for the Clark County School District who represented the students said in arguments that the parents could not prove that performing the shows would cause irreparable harm. Lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union of Nevada filed a brief that supported the students as well. Amanda Smith, a 16-year-old student who has a lead role in the Rent production planned for next year, told The Review-Journal, Im ecstatic.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Bloomberg News article on Tuesday about Joshua Gotbaum, President Obamas choice for director of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, misidentified Mr. Gotbaums mother. He is the son of Sarah C. Gotbaum, a retired sociologist and the first wife of Joshuas father, Victor Gotbaum, a former municipal labor leader; he is not the son of Betsy Gotbaum, the New York City public advocate and Victor Gotbaums current wife.

title: Waterfalls Artist to Create a Bridge
description: Olafur Eliasson, below, the Danish-Icelandic artist who created the temporary waterfalls in New Yorks East River last year, is at work on a project that will give the residents of another city a different way of looking at a nearby body of water. On Wednesday, the city of Copenhagen said that Mr. Eliasson would create a bridge there, called Cirkelbroen (circle bridge), which would provide a winding path across the citys Christianshavns Kanal. In a news release, Mr. Eliasson said the bridge, whose design was inspired by the sailing ships that pass through the canal, would consist of five circular platforms with their own masts. In a statement Mr. Eliasson said that Rather than offering the fastest possible passage across the canal, the bridge will create small variations in the way we see the city and open for a renegotiation of public space. It is expected to be completed in 2012.

title: Its All About Them
description: In recent days, Dame Edna Everage, below at top, and Michael Feinstein, bottom, have been sniping back and forth about their similarly titled Broadway shows, All About Me (his) and Its All About Me (hers). (He: Titles are not copyrightable. I wish Ms. Edna well. Ive heard of her.) (She: Im sure Mrs. Feinstein is very proud of her son.) Turns out the two performers will be working together  and, one assumes, were in cahoots all along. On Thursday, publicists said the two would appear in tandem in a show called All About Me, to be directed by Jerry Zaks and written by Christopher Durang. In a statement, Mr. Feinstein said, I have always been a huge fan of the Dame, and despite our previous friction, now that my mother has forgiven her, I couldnt be more excited to be joining her on Broadway. Dame Edna added, Michael Feinstein is a performer of the highest caliber, I believe, and I couldnt be more than excited to be sharing a Broadway stage with him, in moderation. The show is to begin previews at a Shubert theater on March 6 and open on March 23.

title: The Calipari Express, Baggage Included
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Coach John Calipari has held one of college basketballs highest-profile jobs for only a few months, and he has yet to coach the first regular-season game. But he has attracted nearly a million followers on Twitter, more than 64,000 friends on Facebook, and legions more who expect Kentucky to win its eighth national championship  as early as this season.

title: Dick Katz, 85, Jazzman of Many Gifts Over 6 Decades, Is Dead
description: Dick Katz, a pianist, record producer, educator and writer whose knowledge of jazz from the stride-piano era to 1960s modernism made him a valuable presence on New Yorks jazz scene for six decades, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the departure of the editor of Caijing, a top Chinese business magazine, misstated part of the name of its parent company. It is the Stock Exchange Executive Council, not the State Exchange Executive Council.

title: Residents Feel Victimized by Dealers, and by Housing Agency
description: 363 Noe Street was a haven for some of San Franciscos most vulnerable residents, a small housing project reserved for the elderly and the disabled. Its design may be spartan, but for 22 residents  many of them proverbial little old ladies  it was a safe home.

title: Small Signs of Optimism
description: If you live in the Bay Area, you hardly need reminding that you pay more for your home than most people. The region has the dubious honor of ranking No. 1 nationally in median home value, median monthly mortgage costs and median gross rent.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about efforts to make fund-raising galas less opulent misidentified the organization that held a spring ball at the Plaza Hotel in May. It was the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, not the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about increasing attention being paid by charities to individual donors misspelled the surname of the executive director of the Robin Hood Foundation. He is David Saltzman, not Salzman.

title: The Highly Qualified Teacher Dodge
description: Education Secretary Arne Duncan has been widely held in high regard since he was appointed in January, but no honeymoon lasts forever. Mr. Duncans came to an abrupt end earlier this week when he issued long-awaited rules that the states must follow to apply for his $4.3 billion discretionary fund, known as the Race to the Top Fund, and the second round of federal financing under the $49 billion federal stimulus package known as the state fiscal stabilization fund.

title: A Farewell to Lou
description: Lou Dobbs has left CNN, or maybe the other way around. Whichever it is, an old, odd, infuriating-to-many mismatch of sober network and strident host is over. CNN, for now anyway, changes back to something closer to the nonpartisan, straight-up news network it wants you to think of it as, different from its ideologically branded rivals Fox News and MSNBC. The real question is the effect the change will have on Mr. Dobbs.

title: Ethics Watchdogs Snarl at the Messenger
description: The House ethics committee is openly  and foolishly  sniping at its newly appointed ally in the difficult task of policing members behavior. A recent ethics committee report exonerated an accused congressman but blistered the new semiautonomous Office of Congressional Ethics, or O.C.E., for fundamentally flawed procedures in vetting the complaint for the committee.

title: Abortion and Health Care Legislation
description: To the Editor:

title: Medicare Doctor Payments
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about the corporate raider Samuel Heyman included several errors. Mr. Heyman took over his fathers real estate development business when his father died, not because his father needed him to take it over. The Partnership for Public Service, which Mr. Heyman founded, works to encourage young people to pursue careers in public service, but it does not provide fellowships. Mr. Heyman died on Saturday, not Sunday, and he graduated from Harvard Law School in 1963, not 1964.

title: The Value of Virtual Goods
description: To the Editor:

title: Phillips de Pury Limps to the Finish With a $7 Million Total
description: The evening sale of contemporary art at Phillips de Pury brought a vibrant week of auctions to an anemic close on Thursday night.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about John J. OConnor III, the husband of the retired Supreme Court justice Sandra Day OConnor, misstated the title that William H. Rehnquist held on the court. He was chief justice of the United States, not chief justice of the Supreme Court. The obituary also misidentified the publication that was the source of a story about the OConnors early days in Washington. It is The National Law Journal, not The National Law Review.

title: Torontos New G.M. Hits the Ground Running
description: Alex Anthopoulos just concluded his first general managers meetings as Torontos new man in charge, and he left an impression on more than a few people that he is a capable and intelligent young executive.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary about Gene D. Cohen, a pioneer in the field of geriatric psychiatry, gave the incorrect year in some editions that Dr. Cohen was shown with a patient. It was 1990, not 1960.

title: Corrections
description: OPINION

title: Short-Handed Rangers Cant Answer Kovalchuk
description: Normally an early-season visit from the Atlanta Thrashers is not a special occasion, but Thursday at Madison Square Garden was different. The Thrashers welcomed back Ilya Kovalchuk, their captain and talisman  and a pending free agent  who had missed the previous six games with a broken bone in his right foot.

title: Militants Hit Pakistan Spy Agency in New Escalation
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Militants stepped up their fight against the Pakistani government on Friday, striking a building belonging to the countrys main intelligence agency in the northwestern city of Peshawar, Pakistani television reported.

title: Jain Art
description: The two Jain shows currently in New York give an in-depth view of a great art tradition and a complex faith.

title: The Sights and Sounds of the Silk Road
description: Traveling the Silk Road: Ancient Pathway to the Modern World at the American Museum of Natural History succeeds with compelling vividness.

title: Making Google Maps
description: A time-lapse view of Google's map of Madurai, India, as users of the company's Map Maker software fill in the details over a period of about five months.

title: Guile and Militia Prevent a Third Cairo, Ill., Lynching
description: Saturday, Nov. 13, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Word of the Day | rife
description: rife  \rif \  adjective

title: Crystal Meth and Senior Housing
description: While doing the reporting for this weeks Barbary Coast columnabout a housing project for seniors invaded by methI interviewed the executive director of the San Francisco Housing Authority, Henry A. Alvarez III.

title: Craig Steps Down as White House Lawyer
description: WASHINGTON  The White House counsel, Gregory B. Craig, has told associates that he intends to step down from his post on Friday, putting to rest long-running speculation about whether he would remain as President Obamas top lawyer.

title: A Threatened Fruit, Preserved in Amber
description: Driving back to San Francisco through Sonoma the other day, it was clear that apple season was in full swing. Every few miles along the aptly named Gravenstein Highway (State Route 116) was a different roadside stand touting apples and every apple product imaginable. To my wifes dismay, I drove past them all.

title: Highlights From Fridays Bay Area Report
description: Art Theft | Thirty-five years after Don Ed Hardy opened his first San Francisco tattoo studio, his North Beach shop Tattoo City is known the world over as the place to go for vivid murals on flesh. The Ed Hardy moniker expect to move more than $700 million in merchandise this year. But now, writes Ashlee Vance, a business that was inspired by San Franciscos nautical past is being hijacked by its digital present.

title: Explosion Hits U.S. Base in Afghan Capital
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber struck Friday at a United States military convoy as it passed near a large American installation on the outskirts of Kabul.

title: World Cup Playoff: France-Ireland Preview
description: France vs. Republic of IrelandGame 1: Saturday, Nov. 14 in DublinGame 2: Wednesday, Nov. 18 in Paris

title: More Than Meets the Eye
description: Catch two movies this weekend that are more than what they seem. Though its beyond cute, Wes Andersons  Fantastic Mr. Fox  is not just a kid flick; it is in some ways his most fully realized and satisfying film, A.O. Scott writes. Once you adjust to its stop-and-start rhythms and its scruffy looks, you can appreciate its wit, its beauty and the sly gravity of its emotional undercurrents. And The Messenger is more than just an Iraq War movie; it is remarkably textured, with room for humor as well as anguish, Mr. Scott writes.

title: Retro Returns
description: The Numero Group is a Chicago-based label that reissues obscure, unusual recordings, scoured from thrift stores and garage sales. Tonight at the Music Hall of Williamsburg they present their debut tour, the Eccentric Soul Revue, with artists including 1970s Midwestern R&B crooners and an early-period, female hip-hop M.C. from Harlem. For more retro sounds, hit the 35th anniversary party for Afrika Bambaataa on Sunday at SOBs, with performances by Naughty by Nature and Grand Master Melle Mel.

title: Slide Shows
description: Part D.I.Y. and part pro, the  Slideluck Potshow offers photographers  many of them highly paid professionals  a chance to show the stuff they love in another context: at a  potluck party. Bring a dish, grab a drink and watch the images float by tonight.

title: Helping People By Helping Pets
description: WHO have had to surrender their pets to shelters this year and WHO are stepping in to help?

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Devils Win Again and Go Atop East
description: How about those New Jersey Devils? After beating the slumping Penguins at the Igloo, they have won all nine of their away games this season. The 2006-7 Sabres grabbed 2 points in each of their first 10 games via regulation, overtime or shootout wins, and thats officially the N.H.L. record  although a more stringent standard might be the 51-52 Red Wings, who went unbeaten in their first 15 games as visitors.

title: Editors Note
description: On Thursday, a news article in The Times reported on the ties between Peter W. Galbraith, a former United States ambassador, and a Norwegian oil company that operates in the Kurdistan region of Iraq. According to the article, Mr. Galbraith received rights to an enormous stake in at least one of Kurdistans oil fields in the spring of 2004.

title: Militants Hit Pakistan Spy Agency
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Militants stepped up their fight against the Pakistani government in western Pakistan on Friday, the same day the American national security adviser, Gen. James L. Jones, met with top Pakistani officials here in the capital.

title: International Speedway to Sell Staten Island Land
description: International Speedway Corporation said Thursday it has agreed to sell its 676-acre parcel of property on Staten Island, N.Y., where it had once planned to build a racetrack, to KB Marine Holdings for $80 million.

title: What Do You Think About Octomom?
description: Has the story of Nadya Suleman  widely known as Octomom after giving birth to eight children  interested you? Why do you think so many have been riveted by it? What do you think about family-oriented TV reality shows like hers  do they exploit the children, provide useful cathartic entertainment, or both?

title: Obama Says U.S. Seeks to Build Stronger Ties to China
description: TOKYO  The United States is not threatened by a rising China, President Obama said Saturday, but will seek to strengthen its ties with Beijing even as it maintains close ties with traditional allies like Japan.

title: Redfin, an Online Real Estate Brokerage, Raises $10 Million
description: Redfin, an online real estate brokerage, has landed $10 million in a fresh round of fund-raising.

title: For Comcast Chief, Content Led the Way
