description: At a dinner 12 years ago in Redmond, Wash., Brian L. Roberts challenged the richest man in the world to invest in his business  cable TV.

title: Ex-Bankers Said to Mull Bidding for Failing Banks
description: Some former bankers are planning to bid for failing banks in the Federal Insurance Deposit Corporation auction process, with financial backing from Wall Street firms like Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing sources.

title: TARP Likely to Be a Loss for U.S., Barofsky Says
description: Neil Barofsky, the special inspector general for the $700 billion U.S. financial-industry bailout, said the program will almost certainly result in a loss to taxpayers.

title: News Quiz | November 13, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Canadian Pacific Plans $379 Million Debt Offering
description: Canadian Pacific Railway is issuing about $379 million (400 million Canadian dollars) of notes that it could use for pension obligations and restructuring of debt.

title: Dollar General I.P.O. Is Priced at $21 Per Share
description: Investors looking to have a hand in the future of frugal will watch shares of the discount retailer Dollar General, which will begin trading Friday now that the company has priced its initial public offering.

title: Judge Delays Auction for Philadelphia Newspapers
description: The bankruptcy auction for The Philadelphia Inquirer and Philadelphia Daily News is on hold for one week while creditors appeal a key bidding rule.

title: Highland Capital Closes on Its Eighth Fund
description: Highland Capital Partners said it has raised $400 million for its eighth fund, Highland Capital Partners VIII Limited Partnership.

title: Is the Price Right on CoCo Bonds?
description: Contingent capital securities  known as CoCo bonds  have made their debut and the early reviews seem promising, Breakingviews.com says.

title: After Switzerland, U.S. Said to Aim at Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong is a new target of American prosecutors pursuing a global campaign against evaders of federal taxes, spurred by data acquired in their crackdown on Swiss banks, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Wilpon Firm Challenges Madoff Trustee in Finding
description: Lawyers for Sterling Equities, the investment firm controlled by Fred Wilpon, the principal owner of the Mets, said it lost money as a result of the Ponzi scheme orchestrated by Bernard L. Madoff, according to a filing Thursday in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.

title: Irish Bad Bank Plan Faces Public Backlash
description: A winter of discontent is in store, as the Irish fume at a bailout plan that could burden a generation and that they say is far too generous to the banks that lent so freely.

title: Oil Slides, and Wall Street Pulls Back
description: Wall Street stocks fell on Thursday as investors reacted with caution to a drop in the price of oil. An announcement by President Obama of a job creation initiative failed to motivate investors, The New York Timess Javier C. Hernandez reported.

title: Investor Group Also Said to Look at Playboy
description: Iconix Brand Group is not the only potential buyer reportedly sniffing around Playboy.

title: As Rules Loom, BlueCrest Said to Plan Swiss Office
description: BlueCrest Capital Management, the London-based hedge fund, is planning to open a Geneva office, as increased taxes and pending European Union regulations take the shine off London, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person familiar with the situation .

title: C.I.C. Taps Ex-Tudor Manager to Run Its Portfolio
description: The China Investment Corporation has hired a former manager at Tudor Investment to oversee its hedge fund portfolio, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

title: A New G.M. Struggles to Shed Its Bureaucracy
description: In the old General Motors, employees were evaluated according to a performance measurement process that could fill a three-ring binder.

title: Ed Hardys Tattoo Art Is Booty for Digital Pirates
description: Don Ed Hardy, the famed tattoo artist, must smell good. Make that really good. Ed Hardy-themed perfumes have become some of the most popular fragrances in the world, with retailers buying $85 million worth of them so far this year.

title: North Korea Issues New Threat After Naval Clash
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea threatened Friday to take merciless military measures along a disputed maritime border with South Korea, escalating tensions as President Obama began a weeklong visit to Asia.

title: Khan Tells Judge She Provided Insider Information
description: Roomy Khan, a central government witness in the insider trading case against Galleon Group founder Raj Rajaratnam, told a judge she tipped several people at hedge funds with inside information on companies to make money from trades, Reuters reported, citing a court document.

title: Global Financial Panic Is Over, Buffett Says
description: Warren E. Buffett, perhaps the worlds most admired investor, said on Thursday the financial panic that gripped the globe last year is a thing of the past, even as the United States economys struggles persist.

title: Big Japanese Banks Show Signs of Recovery
description: Corrected | Nov. 16, 2009, 9:25 a.m. Mizuho Financials first profit in five quarters and the doubling of profit by its rival, Sumitomo Mitsui, signal that major Japanese banks are recovering from the economic crisis, albeit slowly, Reuters reported.

title: Gift Guide | Flying American
description: This holiday season satisfy your locavore appetite the no-calorie way, by buying American-made goodies. The editors of T have picked a variety of classic pieces ranging from preppy knits and sleek briefcases to holiday-party-worthy jewelry. Made in the U.S.A. isnt just a political statement, its a fashion one, too.

title: Norris: A Lack of Rigor Costs MBIA
description: MBIA, the financial insurance company, used to hold itself out as a paragon of hard work and number crunching.

title: Bling Ring
description: A group accused of burglarizing the homes of several Hollywood celebrities.

title: European Proposal Takes Aim at Hedge Fund Pay
description: The European Union is planning to review new rules that could limit the pay of hedge fund managers, as soon as this week, a spokeswoman for the Swedish minister in charge of reaching agreement on the legislation told Reuters.

title: On Concussions, Cardinals Morey Doesnt Heed Own Advice
description: How hard is it going to be to persuade the players themselves that concussions need to be treated seriously and with the utmost care?

title: World Cup Berth for Some, Pay Day for Others
description: On Saturday, some teams will compete for the few remaining spots in the World Cup in South Africa next summer, and several others will use the international date to play friendly exhibition matches.

title: Getting the Most Out of the London Pass
description: LONDON | If you are the type of traveler who really likes to see the sights, the London Pass may be for you. Loads of special offers are at hand for reduced prices on theater tickets, accommodations, restaurants and attractions. You just have to know how to use it effectively.

title: Liberty Global to Buy Unitymedia For $5.2 Billion
description: Liberty Global, the international cable operator controlled by United States cable pioneer John Malone, has agreed to buy Germanys Unitymedia from a private equity group for $5.2 billion, its first German acquisition.

title: Britain Asks Allies for More Troops in Afghanistan
description: PARIS  As the Obama administration debates whether to commit more American troops to Afghanistan, Germany announced a modest increase in its contingent on Friday, and Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain said he was pressing European and other allies to deploy 5,000 more soldiers.

title: Rex Ryan and the Jets:  Back From the Bye
description: A blast of Rex Ryan-speak: What better way to welcome the Jets from their bye week?

title: The Dilbert Guide to Angry Investing
description: Todays idea: Maybe if we invested in the things that we hate, wed become rich, the creator of Dilbert muses.

title: The Most Important Films of the Decade
description: The first review A.O. Scott wrote as a film critic for The New York Times was in January 2000. The movie was My Dog Skip, which featured a Jack Russell terrier with a taste for bologna, Kevin Bacon, Luke Wilson and Frankie Muniz. Since then, he notes, more than 5,000 movies have come and gone and been reviewed in The Times. In The Magazine this week, Mr. Scott takes stock of the past decade in film and asks: Which movies are sure to be remembered? Which movies deserve to be? Are these really two different questions?

title: Dark Days for Cutler and Bears
description: Somewhere Rex Grossman is saying: I was never that bad, was I?

description: Kevin Brockmeier is the author of the novels The Truth About Celia and The Brief History of the Dead. His most recent book is a story collection, The View From the Seventh Layer.What are you working on now?

title: JPMorgans Dimon: Let Banks Grow, and Fail
description: As debate swirls around how to regulate banks and prevent another financial catastrophe, one prominent banker is recommending a change to the idea of too big to fail.

title: Complaint Box | The Hard Sell
description: On my way out of the bank after withdrawing some cash, I stopped by the customer service desk to ask about adding my new husband to my account and changing my name in their system. Are there forms to fill out? What documentation do I need?

title: Nissan Takes Leaf Electric Car on Tour
description: LOS ANGELES  The Leaf, an electric vehicle that Nissan plans to start selling globally next year, will be introduced here on Friday, which marks the start of a 22-city tour.

description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Friday that it would prosecute Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks, in a Manhattan federal courtroom, a decision that ignited a sharp political debate but took a step toward resolving one of the most pressing terrorism detention issues.

title: Europes Environment Chief Still Hopeful for Global Climate Cooperation
description: The European Union environment commissioner, Stavros Dimas, on Thursday named and shamed countries, including Austria, Canada and Australia, for emitting excessive greenhouse gases and failing to meet their goals under the Kyoto climate treaty.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens on Oil Imports
description: The trade deficit in the United States widened more than expected in September, to $36.5 billion, in part because of an increase in oil prices, the Commerce Department said Friday.

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Friday morning.

title: 9/11 Terror Suspects Will Be Tried in New York
description: The self-described mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, and four other men accused in the plot will be prosecuted in federal court in New York City, a federal law enforcement official said early on Friday.

title: For Forbes, Wall Streets Most Powerful Player Is
description: Update | 12:38 p.m. In Forbess latest list of the worlds most powerful people, some choices come as little surprise. President Obama, Hu Jintao of China and Vladimir Putin of Russia come out on top, and at No. 4 Ben S. Bernanke is confirmed as the worlds most influential central banker.

title: Travel Deals: Hotels.com Friday the 13th Sale
description: Hotels.com is having a Friday the 13th Sale, with up to 50 percent off on hundreds of properties worldwide. Book today for travel through Nov. 27. Sample rates include:

title: FlashForward Watch: Tattoos and Lingerie
description: So now were working on the assumption that the future  or at least the glimpse of it that everyone received in their flashforwards  can be changed, even negated. Thats the lesson people are taking from Agent Goughs swan dive off a building at the end of last weeks episode of FlashForward. If its true, does this new wrinkle make the show better  more complex and open-ended? Or does it drain the show of much of its dramatic tension and make the detective work, which has been more interesting than any of the relationships, seem irrelevant? Just asking.

title: Path to Alternative Therapies Is Littered With Obstacles
description: WHEN Diane Klenke was told five years ago that she had pancreatic cancer, she was given three months to live. The doctor told me to go home and put my affairs in order and that was it, Ms. Klenke, now 52, remembered.

title: The Chuckles Writer: A Little Seltzer Down Your Pants
description: In Fridays New York Times, Bruce Weber writes an obituary of David Lloyd, an incredibly prolific television comedy writer who contributed to programs like The Bob Newhart Show, Lou Grant, Rhoda, Phyllis, The Tony Randall Show, The Associates, Taxi, Dear John, Amen, Wings, Cheers and Frasier. Mr. Lloyd, 75, died of prostate cancer on Tuesday.

title: Presidents Top Lawyer Is Leaving White House
description: WASHINGTON  Gregory B. Craig, the White House counsel, said Friday that he would resign at the beginning of next year, ending a sometimes tumultuous tenure as President Obamas top lawyer after 10 months at the center of some of the toughest issues and stormiest internal debates that have confronted the administration.

title: S.F. Sanctuary Policy: Feds Not Going to Look the Other Way
description: San Francisco city employees may soon need a sanctuary policy of their own.

title: Two Are Charged With Helping Madoff Falsify Records
description: Two computer programmers who worked for Bernard L. Madoffs brokerage firm were arrested on Friday and accused of helping him sustain his long-running Ponzi scheme.

title: Quashing Credit Card Reform for Small Businesses
description: Last week, small-business advocates once more tried, and failed, to get new consumer protections for credit cards extended to small-business cardholders. They were defeated, according to aides on Capitol Hill and others observing the process, by a surprising foe: Representative Nydia Velzquez, the New York Democrat who is chairwoman of the House Small Business Committee  though her own aide insists the other aides are wrong.

title: Report on Yale Murder Outlines Suspicions
description: Raymond Clark III walked into Room G-13 in the basement of a Yale research center in New Haven and saw it sitting on a metal cart: a box of disposable wipes, splattered with blood.

title: Craig Resigns as White House Counsel
description: The White House said on Friday that President Obamas top lawyer, Gregory B. Craig, was stepping down from his post as the White House counsel, a departure that was timed to coordinate with a Justice Department announcement that five terrorism suspects held in Guantnamo Bay would face trial in New York.

title: 2 Programmers Are Charged With Aiding Madoff
description: Update | 1:51 p.m. The New York Timess Diana B. Henriques has more details here.

title: Graphic Books Best-Seller List
description: The merc with the mouth, as Deadpool, the wisecracking mutant mercenary, is billed, hits No. 7 on our hardcover list with the collected edition Deadpool: Suicide Kings. When Deadpool is accused of a crime that  for once  he didnt commit, he must avoid Daredevil, the Punisher and Spider-Man to prove his innocence.

title: Best Move for Byron Scott Might Be Los Angeles
description: After a lackluster 3-6 start the New Orleans Hornets decided a coaching change was in order, and fired Byron Scott on Thursday.

title: Two Debuts, Overdue and Overwhelming
description: After the Metropolitan Opera opened its season in September with Luc Bondys convoluted new production of Puccinis Tosca, widely deemed a dismal failure, Peter Gelb, the companys general manager, needed a comeback success.

title: Paying for Alternative Treatments
description: The debate about alternative therapies rightly focuses on whether a particular herb or remedy actually works. But in todays Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad explores a much-neglected aspect of alternative care: how do you pay for it? She writes:

title: Friday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Filmmakers Controversy: Their Dad
description: At the charmingly retro Waverly Restaurant on the Avenue of the Americas in Greenwich Village, not to be confused with the stridently exclusive Waverly Inn nearby, a color headshot of one of the best-known legal figures of the 20th century hangs on the wall. His name was William M. Kunstler, and this celebrated civil rights lawyer, who for nearly two decades lived around the corner, ate lunch here nearly every day.

title: Record Sales for Modern Warfare 2, but Gaming Business Declines
description: Like the start of a classic gaming cheat code, it was an up-and-down week of news for the video gaming business. On the upside, the debut of the highly anticipated shooting game Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 set a sales record for the industry, Variety reported: the game sold 4.7 million units in its first day of sale in the United States and Britain, taking in $310 million for the game publisher Activision Blizzard. (By comparison, the years highest grossing movie, Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen, earned $220 million in its first weekend.)

title: Deaths Hit Man
description: Maybe if he had one more drink theyd leave him alone. Thats the chilling opening sentence of THE GHOSTS OF BELFAST (Soho, $25), a first novel by Stuart Neville so bleak and despairing  noir in the genuine existential sense  it would rattle the composure of a saint. Gerry Fegan, the solitary drinker tossing back shots of whiskey and peering into the shadows for ghosts, is a hard man, an I.R.A. enforcer during the Troubles and still a legend in West Belfast. But unlike former colleagues who cynically retooled their skills for successful careers as politicians and crime bosses, Fegan is haunted by the people he killed  12 of them if he counted the baby in its mothers arms. The ghosts who stare back at him with accusing eyes may be only manifestations of his own guilt, but they wont let him alone until he takes vengeance by executing the men whose orders led to these deaths.

title: Mau-Mauing the Flesh Eaters
description: Back in 1990, when a scholar named Carol J. Adams published The Sexual Politics of Meat: A Feminist-Vegetarian Critical Theory, it was nominated for the Diagram Prize, an annual award given to the book with the most inherently ludicrous title. Its coming out in a new edition next March, and at the right moment, too. These days, the meaning of meat is anything but a boutique academic concern. Bookstores are full of titles like Jeffrey Moussaieff Massons Face on Your Plate and Michael Pollans Omnivores Dilemma, which ponder the ethics of flesh-eating, while books like Scott Golds Shameless Carnivore, Bill Bufords Heat and Julie Powells forthcoming memoir Cleaving  in which the author of Julie & Julia overcomes a marital crisis by training as a globe-trotting butcher (think Chop, Flay, Love)  explore what might be called its erotics. Rummaging around inside a pig carcass in gloves, Powell grumbles, Now I know why men hate condoms.

title: Inside the List
description: PRESEASONS GREETINGS: Its not even Thanksgiving, and some Christmas-related books are already creeping up the list, like genetically modified mutant mistletoe. Mike Huckabees Simple Christmas enters the hardcover nonfiction extended list at No. 18, two spots ahead of You Better Not Cry, Augusten Burroughss more acid take on the holidays. Over on the fiction extended list, weve got Knit the Season (No. 20) and Glenn Becks Christmas Sweater (No. 29), a holdover from last year. (A preshrunk version of Becks book is also on the hardcover childrens list.) Those with an allergy to wool (or Glenn Beck) can curl up with Jennifer Chiaverinis Quilters Holiday (No. 28) or Richard Paul Evanss Christmas List (No. 31).

title: Rajaratnam Moves to Unseal 2000 Case Against Informant
description: Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund executive accused of participating in a massive insider trading scheme, moved on Thursday to unseal a 2000 criminal case against the woman who admitted to giving him confidential information about a number of companies. (Read the motion after the jump.)

title: Media Vampires, Beware
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Now Seating | Danny Meyer on Maialino
description: Maialino, the Roman-style trattoria that is the first collaboration between two restaurant-world titans  the restaurateur Danny Meyer and the designer David Rockwell  opened this week at Ian Schragers Gramercy Park Hotel. T asked Meyer a few questions about the eagerly awaited project.

title: Saturday TV Funhouse: Barneys Does SNL
description: Holiday decorations seem to go up earlier every year, but in this case we dont mind: the shopping blog Racked NY reports that as of Friday morning, Barneys has filled its windows with papier-mch effigies of characters and cast members from Saturday Night Live. The display spans the 35-year history of that late-night show: we spotted versions of Roseanne Roseannadanna; King Tut; the Coneheads; Brian Fellows; Amy Poehler grasping the Weekend Update globe; the androgynous, long-forgotten Pat; and even Gilly, the badly behaved grade school student played by Kristen Wiig. (We couldnt find Toonces the Driving Cat, but we havent been there ourselves.)

title: Counting Ballots in N.Y.s 23rd District
description: Updated Could the conservative candidate who conceded on election night in one of the countrys most intensely watched races really still squeak to victory?

title: Sailing the Caribbean, the Frugal Way
description: This weekends cover story, Sailing the Caribbean, the Frugal Way, has been a long time comingthree years, to be exact. Back in September 2006 I visited Jost Van Dyke, a tiny island in the British Virgin Islands, for another Frugal Traveler story, and it was there, while staying on White Bay, that I met a Florida family of four whod rented a sailboat and invited myself and a friend aboard for gin and tonics. Impressed by both their generosity and their freedomwith the boat, they could go wherever they liked, whenever they wanted!I began to try to figure out how I, a non-sailor without sailboat-rental funds, could live their luxurious lifestyle.

title: Answers About Entrepreneurship, Part 2
description: Following is the second and final set of answers from Seth W. Pinsky, the president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, on citywide entrepreneurship. This week, he has answered readers questions in areas including job training, competitions, investment funds and efforts to encourage industries like green technology, bioscience, fashion, media and technology, manufacturing and distribution, and the arts.

title: From the House of the Dead': Misery, Hope and a Black Joke or Two
description: The new Metropolitan Opera production of From the House of the Dead had its premiere Thurday night. The review by Anthony Tommasini is here. Mr. Tommasini, Dwight Garner, Charles Isherwood and James R. Oestreich will be continuing their discussion of the production today on ArtsBeat.

title: Madness or Method? Tough to Tell
description: THERE are any number of characteristic Nicolas Cage scenes in Werner Herzogs Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans, interludes you watch with a now-familiar mixture of genuine appreciation and more than a touch of bewilderment. In one Mr. Cage, as the drug-addled cop of the films title, enters a room to join a stakeout. The cops are watching a house. And, crammed in the foreground of the shot, two iguanas are watching Mr. Herzogs low-lying camera, their bodies stretched across the image.

title: A Carrot for Real Comment Contributors
description: I was walking our dogs through a blanket of crisp oak leaves this morning, pondering the state of Dot Earth after two years, nearly 800 posts and tens of thousands of reader comments that reflect the variegated, and deeply divided, state of thinking on many issues, but especially global warming.

title: News From the Milan Motorcycle Show
description: Manufacturers and journalists met in Milan this week for the 67th International Motorcycle Exhibition, known as E.I.C.M.A., one of the largest motorcycle trade shows in the world, with scores of exhibitors and displays in six pavilions. Here are some highlights, garnered from the scattered coverage out there on the Web:

title: Banker Seeks to Put a Price on Nature
description: According to Pavan Sukhdev, a banker working with the United Nations Environment Program, putting a price on the worlds trees, water stores and other natural resources will be the most cost-effective way of tackling the challenges posed by climate change  at least until cleaner energy technologies become available.

title: Robert Johnsons House to Rise Again
description: The fabled crossroads where Robert Johnson is supposed to have sold his soul to the devil in exchange for his guitar prowess has not been definitively located, but the musicians birthplace has been determined and plans are in the works to restore it as a tourist attraction, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Johnson, the blues guitarist of Sweet Home Chicago and Love in Vain, who influenced artists from Muddy Waters to Eric Clapton, was born in 1911 in Hazlehurst, Miss., in a home built by his stepfather. The birthplace was verified in a letter from his half-sister, according to the cultural affairs office of Copiah County, which is seeking to raise $250,000 to restore the home as a destination for music fans and Johnson acolytes. He was so good that he would literally turn his back when they were recording him, said the screenwriter Jimmy White (Ray), who is working on a script about Mr. Johnsons life. He didnt want the other musicians to see his fingering technique.

title: A Post-Mortem on the Opel Deal
description: After a crushing defeat, the losing team stews over replays. In the wake of the collapse of the Opel deal, Germany is no exception.

title: False Colors: Bogus Military Honors Worn to School Reunion
description: You never know how people will turn out. But when some members of Alhambra High Schools Class of 88 who did not remember Steven Douglas Burton as the athletic type saw him at the 20th reunion at the Concord Hilton dressed in a Marine uniform decorated with a Navy Cross, the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart and other medals, they got suspicious.

title: Whats Old Is New Again
description: New Yorks new license plate, unveiled this week, quickly earned the ire of some motorists who balked at paying $25, the states mandated fee, for the privilege of owning something they already have.

title: Screening: One More Reason to Get Up Early
description: There are probably better ways to start the day, but a new study suggests that early morning is an ideal time to schedule a colonoscopy.

title: Inspired | Keeping Warm With Rag Wool
description: As you get older, you realize how right your mom was about everything. Just as brussels sprouts begin to taste good (albeit with lots of butter and bacon) and Fleetwood Mac finds a space in the playlist, Im starting to understand why I spent all those winters wearing bulky, Brillo pad-like sweaters. Nothing keeps you warmer.

title: Weekend Competition: Squiffy, Sozzled, Smashed
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share the words and phrases they use to describe being drunk, drummed, daffy, decanted, or utterly Dean Martoonied.

title: Reality Bytes
description: The action figures for James Camerons Avatar started appearing in stores last month. The movie wont be out until December, but the toys have their own multimedia selling point: an augmented reality feature. This phrase has become one of the pervasive buzz concepts of 2009, and as is often true in such cases, it seems to describe a variety of manifestations from the practical to the pointless to the pie in the sky.

title: The Cloak of Invisibility Comes Off
description: Franconia, N.H.

title: With Change, Suzuki Tries to Lift Profile
description: AS the 2010 Kizashi comes to market, American Suzuki is promising sweeping changes not only in its vehicles, but in the way it operates. The goal is to raise Suzukis low profile and put its products on the shopping lists of Americans.

title: That Hair, That Baton: Is Glitz Good for Classical Music?
description: Gustavo Dudamel has received a blast of publicity like few others in classical music in the past several years. He rode into Los Angeles as its orchestras music director last month on a wave of media and public relations hoopla. Mr. Dudamel, of course, is not the first classical musician to capture mainstream  read populist  attention. Yo-Yo Ma and Renee Fleming are exemplars now. Before them, we had Beverly Sills and Leonard Bernstein. Before them, John McCormack and Enrico Caruso. Before them, the castratos of Italy and superstar opera composers of the Viennese and Italian courts.

title: White House Plan on Immigration Includes Legal Status
description: The Obama administration will insist on measures to give legal status to an estimated 12 million illegal immigrants as it pushes early next year for legislation to overhaul the immigration system, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said on Friday.

title: Volvo Safety, 2011 Style: It Brakes for Walkers
description: Rockleigh, N.J.

title: Overhead View of Pole Impact Crash
description: Video provided by the N.H.T.S.A. showing its new crash test.

title: A Wall, a Shed and a Generator
description: Paul was busy most of last week picking up equipment and materials. He bought sheet rock for the kitchen wall behind the gas stove and sink, two-by-fours and concrete blocks to build a shed, and a beautiful eight-kilowatt propane-fired generator.

title: New Side-Impact Test to Be Added
description: ONE attractive survival strategy for automakers in todays strained business conditions is the development of a so-called world car. The plan is straightforward enough: create a versatile model that can be adapted for many world markets with minimal changes, allowing the cost of engineering, tooling and manufacturing to be spread over hundreds of thousands of automobiles.

title: Fire Forces Evacuation of Stuyvesant High School
description: A fire broke out in a third-floor bathroom of Stuyvesant High School in TriBeCa on Friday morning. The school has been cleared, and so far no injuries have been reported, a spokesman for the Fire Department said.

title: Dr. Andrew Weils Stress-Free Squash Soup
description: Dr. Andrew Weil is among the best-known doctors in America, an alternative health guru who espouses the power of healthful eating and stress reduction as the best way to improve health.

title: A Swedish Smorgasbord of Collectible Saabs
description: ANY early, well-preserved Saab is desirable. Here are a few with special resonance for collectors:

title: Stalking Saabs That Soared
description: SAAB is a relatively young and proudly offbeat automaker, and from the start it has appealed to those who appreciate the unconventional. For aficionados, Find your own road was more than a slogan.

title: Researchers at Dartmouth Assess Health Bills
description: Dr. John Wennberg, who pioneered the Dartmouth research that shows the wide variation in the practice of medicine in this country, has teamed up with some colleagues to assess how the health care legislation in the Senate and House addresses our dysfunctional, disorganized, and wasteful delivery system.

title: From the House of the Dead': Dostoyevskys Novel as M*A*S*H Set in a Siberian Gulag
description: Charles, youre definitely not alone in disliking Dostoyevsky when hes at his most moralistic. The more Dostoyevsky gets worked up about the tragic nature of the soul, D.H. Lawrence snarked, the more I lose interest. And Vladimir Nabokov praised Dostoyevskys flashes of excellent humor but deplored the wastelands of literary platitudes in between.

title: Key 9/11 Suspect to Be Tried in New York
description: Attorney General Eric Holder announced that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks, and four other men accused in the plot will be prosecuted in federal court in New York. (Video: NBC)

title: Correction: Behind the Wheel | 2010 Mercedes-Benz S400
description: A review of the Mercedes-Benz S400 hybrid sedan last Sunday misstated a difference between that car and the conventional nonhybrid S550. Adaptive cruise control is offered on the S400, though two other features available on the S550  an active body-control suspension and Attention Assist, which sends a warning to drowsy drivers  are not.

title: Do We Make Our Children Superstitious?
description: While our flight was taking off for a family vacation a few years back I noticed that my son had his fingers crossed on both his hands. I saw it as a tiny battle lost.

title: Water Found on Moon, Researchers Say
description: There is water on the Moon, scientists stated unequivocally on Friday.

title: Japans Budget Review May Rein In Whaling
description: There are hints that Japans review of government spending in a number of areas could diminish the billions of yen spent each year to sustain the countrys annual whaling excursions to the oceans around Antarctica. Greenpeace sent an alert around about the budget review just before President Obama flew to Japan. For the moment, its unclear whether the whaling program  which Japan has long cast as important scientific research but many biologists and activists decry  is in danger, according to our Tokyo reporters. Therell be updates here as needed. [UPDATE, 11/19: This years hunt got under way as the fleet headed south. Presumably the chasers below are gearing up, as well.]

title: World Cup Playoff Preview: Greece vs. Ukraine
description: Greece vs. UkraineGame 1: Saturday, Nov. 14 in AthensGame 2: Wednesday, Nov. 18 in Donetsk

title: From the House of the Dead': The Orchestra Tells the Story
description: Ill defer to Dwight as the house authority on the Dostoyevsky novel. What I do know from reading the book and studying the opera is that Janacek, who wrote his own libretto, took various characters and stories from the lives of the prisoners in the book and combined them into a smaller group of characters and incidents for the opera.

title: The Last Tuna?
description: Barry Estabrook  a former editor at (sigh) Gourmet, the founding editor of the original Eating Well, someone who has been doing great work in the world of real food for at least 20 years, and the author of the best non-cooking food story of the year  is the first person, to my knowledge at least, to say, There is a strong likelihood that someone in this generation will be the last human to eat a bluefin tuna. Read it (and check out his other posts) at Politics of the Plate.

title: Biden to Appear on Daily Show
description: Having hosted the likes of Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, and Ray Mabus, the secretary of the navy, The Daily Show With Jon Stewart will take another step up the White House chain of command on Tuesday: that night, the satirical news show is scheduled to host Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. Comedy Central announced the booking Friday in a news release. Its the first time that Mr. Biden has appeared on The Daily Show since he was elected vice president; he previously appeared on the show as a senator and presidential candidate on Aug. 8, 2007, and on Jan. 31, 2007, the day that Mr. Biden announced he was seeking the Democratic presidential nomination. Barack Obama last appeared on the show on Oct. 29, 2008, before winning the presidential election.

title: Deluge of Pleas to Spare Oreo, Dog Thrown Off Roof
description: Animal rights supporters have bombarded the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals with phone calls and e-mail messages in a frantic last-minute bid to save Oreo, a pit bull that survived being tossed off a roof and is scheduled to be euthanized Friday afternoon.

title: Dells Out-of-Town Tryout for Smartphones
description: Dell has finally confirmed what has been bouncing around the market for some time, that it is entering the smartphone business.

title: Foo Fighters Pilot Roosts With Vultures
description: IN November 1991 Nirvanas Nevermind was beginning its climb up the charts. The album had not yet sold more than 10 million copies, had not yet knocked Michael Jackson out of the No. 1 slot on the Billboard album chart, had not yet become the defining moment of the alternative rock movement or given Kurt Cobain the voice of a generation status that would help prove his undoing.

title: Danny Meyer on His New Dinner Companions
description: On The Moment blog, Danny Meyer talks about working with the designer David Rockwell for the first time, on his newly opened restaurant Maialino.

title: Readers Take Issue With Times 10 Best College Presidents
description: On Thursday, Time magazine published a package on its Web site that attempted to handicap the nations 10 Best College Presidents. In response to our post on that feature  in which we gingerly raised the question of how one could possibly establish an objective ranking of college presidents  nearly 100 readers of The Choice submitted comments. Most of you sent nominations of your own, and others mirrored our skepticism about the value of such a list.

title: Russian Story, German Director, Hollywood Film
description: SUMMER STORM

title: Trial Venue Leaves 9/11 Families Angry or Satisfied
description: To many, it felt exquisitely right: This is where it began. This is where it must end.

title: Corrections
description: A Living Here listing in the Escapes pages last Friday about a three-bedroom house in northeastern Pennsylvania misidentified the town where it is located. It is in Warren Center, not Warren.

title: Taking a Man, Then Removing His Myth
description: THE filmmaker Alexander Sokurov is best known to American audiences for Russian Ark (2002), a dizzying tour through the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg that sweeps up several centuries of Russian history and culture into a single 96-minute Steadicam shot.

title: The Roots of Fine Wine
description: Peter Liem is one of my favorite wine writers. He is meticulous in the best possible way, and always has something interesting to say. Most recently in the October issue of Wine and Spirits magazine he wrote a thought-provoking column in which he compared wines made from ungrafted vines with cheese made from unpasteurized milk.

title: From the House of the Dead': What About That Bird?
description: Guys, Id be curious to discuss the eagle. I may be being a bit literal-minded here, but it seemed to me the creature was so obviously mechanical that it was actually meant to be a toy rather than a living thing. Obviously this could just be a matter of stylization  you cant put a live bird onstage in an opera, let alone coach him to act wounded.

title: Is Solar Power Expensive or Competitive?
description: Solar is cheaper than coal today, asserts Jigar Shah, the founder of Sun Edison who now heads the Carbon War Room, a new nonprofit group.

title: Up Front: Steven Pinker
description: Malcolm Gladwell recently said that if he were trying to break into journalism today, he would start by getting a masters degree in statistics. The Harvard psychologist Steven Pinker, who reviews Gladwells What the Dog Saw on this weeks cover, might second this advice. Asked via e-mail what is the most important scientific concept that lay people fail to understand, he responded: Statistical reasoning. A difficulty in grasping probability underlies fallacies from medical quackery and stock-market scams to misinterpreting sex differences and the theory of evolution.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Nov. 1 with a review of Enemies of the People misidentified the books author, Kati Marton. In the photograph, showing her as a child with her sister and mother, she is sitting in the center, not at right.

title: Readers in Asia: Share Your Thoughts
description: To foster discussion of President Barack Obamas trip to Asia, the Times is inviting readers living in the countries he is visiting to share their views with us via video. If you live in Japan, Singapore, China or South Korea, we would like you to film yourself telling us what you believe Mr. Obama could do for your country.

title: A Trip to China
description: Monologue |  Aired Thursday night on NBC: President Obama is traveling to Asia this week. Hell be making a trip to China. While hes there, Obama plans to visit the Forbidden City, the Great Wall, and Americas money.

title: Ground Is Broken for New Barnes Foundation Home
description: After years of pitched battles over the Barnes Foundations plans to bypass its founding charter and bylaws and move its world-class painting collection from suburban Merion, Pa., to downtown Philadelphia, the foundation broke ground Friday for the Barness new home, to be designed by the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien.

title: Crazy Astronaut Lady
description: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: Remember the crazy astronaut lady who put on a diaper and drove cross country? She was in love with another astronaut. And I said to myself, well thats what happens when you mix vodka and Tang.

title: From the House of the Dead': Fright and Flight
description: That wounded eagle, in Dostoyevskys novel, is described as full of solitary malice and waiting for death, trusting and forgiving no one. The prisoners are in frightened awe of it. Few can get near it. The men debate trying to help it get out.

title: In Dollar Generals Debut, a 2009 High for I.P.O.s
description: Investors appear to be flocking to Dollar General on Friday after the discount retailer made its stock market debut, signaling that there is a lot of pent-up demand for initial public offerings. (Shares in the company were up nearly 8 percent in afternoon trading, reaching $22.70.)

title: Broke by Christmas
description: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: Gov. David Paterson made a shocking statement today. He said, New York will be broke by Christmas. Today, Gov. Schwarzenegger said: Christmas? Whats your secret? Howd you last so long?

title: EconoQuiz
description: Welcome to another installment of EconoQuiz, a regular quiz on economics issues in the news.

title: From the House of the Dead': Pity for the Bird
description: Well, Charles, your idea that the eagle is meant to be a toy did not occur to me and is intriguing. I thought that the toy-like look of the mechanical eagle was a pitiable image. It made the prisoners seem like eager children who manage not to fight over a toy because it is so wondrous and special. This, for me, is what prevented the moment from being sentimental.

title: Columns from Central America?
description: Im thinking about a trip to Central America next month, perhaps Nicaragua and Honduras and I dont know where else. I dont know the terrain and would welcome suggestions for columns. As always, Im looking for a micro example of a macro problem. For example, Im unlikely to write about Nicaragua as such, but might use a program in Nicaragua to illuminate a global development problem. If you have suggestions, post them below  and thanks.

title: Bought for a Song (Many, Actually)
description: THE entrance to the building on Anderson Avenue at 167th Street in the Highbridge section of the Bronx looks like something out of Hansel and Gretel. Two small stone guardhouses with peaked roofs frame a landscaped courtyard, with a mulberry tree hung with bird feeders in the center.

title: The Right Way to Change Your Name
description: If youre planning to change your name after getting married, making the change in a timely fashion is probably going to become even more important next year when a new program, called Secure Flight, will require that the name you use to make an airline reservation be exactly the same as the one you use on an ID, even if the rules may sometimes bend a little.

title: On Our Radar
description: 1.) The E.U. meets its Kyoto climate targets.

title: First Responders' Story
description: Senior Sgt. Mark Todd and Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley describe how they stopped the shooting that took place at Fort Hood, Tex., one week ago. (Video: NBC Nightly News)

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) An argument for a jobful recovery.

title: Can D.I.Y. Supplant the First-Person Shooter?
description: The face of the enemy flashed across a 20-foot screen. Thats right, Jason Rohrer announced. Its Roger Ebert. There were a few boos, as several hundred people stirred in their seats. The film critics cherubic face stared at the audience. Ebert said video games cant be art, Rohrer said. He issued all of us a direct challenge. And we need to find an answer.

title: A New Cast Doesnt Slow Peyton Manning
description: INDIANAPOLIS  After the season ended each year, Peyton Manning would walk into Tony Dungys office clutching a notebook with a list of his perceived weaknesses and things to work on.

title: Chrysler Is Recalling Jeeps for Transmission Issue
description: Chrysler is recalling about 161,000 Jeeps because their automatic transmissions were assembled without a system to warn if the fluid is overheating.

title: From the House of the Dead': Supertitles
description: Tony, Id be curious to hear your thoughts about the unusual projection of supertitles on the set itself. Id never seen this before at the Met, and understood that James Levine had a strong antipathy to supertitles; hence the creation of the Mets own title system, which has the titles on the seat back in front of every individual.

title: Dear Abby in Need of Advice
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Must See: Pakistans Anti-Yankee Rock
Teaching and Learning About Journalism
description: Occasionally, in lieu of a traditional lesson, well give you a page of useful resources on an oft-taught subject, issue or skill set, as we did for the National Day on Writing.

title: An Advocate for Prisoners Argues for Prisons, Too
description: There is a certain monastic quiet in the painters studio where the Rev. Stephen Chinlund sometimes spends hours at a stretch at his easel. Outside, along the streets of the garment district, noisy chaos reigns. But inside, in the soft light, he can easily slip into a trance as he paints.

title: Its Q & A With DP!
description: Hi David, Why do people (including yourself) use URL shorteners in anything other than Twitter? I think its an unnecessary and unpleasant layer of opacity between you and your readers. I dont know where the link goes to and I dont like getting in the habit of clicking these things. Why not just do it the regular way of a link with text? I can see at the bottom of my browser window where it really goes.

title: Weekly Matchups: Respecting the Horned Frogs
description: What have I learned this season? (Not much if you look at my record picking games.) One thing I have learned, however, is that Horned Frogs can shoot blood out of their eyes. I have learned this because for the second time this season, the Texas Christian Horned Frogs are playing in the biggest game of the weekend. Despite the fact that Iowa and Ohio State are playing for a berth in the Rose Bowl, ESPNs GameDay will be at Amon G. Carter Stadium and everyone seems to agree that the game to watch on Saturday is in Fort Worth.

title: Blogging Imam Who Counseled Fort Hood Gunman and 9/11 Hijacker Goes Silent
description: Anwar al-Awlaki, a radical, American-born cleric who knew at least one of the 9/11 hijackers and exchanged e-mail messages last year with the Army psychiatrist charged in the Fort Hood shootings, abruptly stopped blogging this week, just days after writing that he approved of the psychiatrists attack on American soldiers.

title: That Delicate Membrane, the Heart
description: I PULLED my eyes from the hospital window, from the view of snow-covered mountains, and watched as my father struggled to raise himself from his bed.

title: Moving Sustainability Forward in Portland
description: It was standing room only as leaders from government, nonprofit, academic and business groups gathered for two days of meetings in Oregon last week  part of the Portland Metro Climate Prosperity Project, which seeks to promote sustainability in the region.

title: Cottos Trainer Learned Outside the Ring
description: LAS VEGAS  Joe Santiago is 32 years old. He has never boxed, not once, never built a champion, never trained a fighter for a bout of the magnitude that awaits him Saturday.

title: Bidding Wars Resume
description: A TWO-BEDROOM apartment on the Upper West Side is listed at $1.595 million and sells within two weeks after nine prospective buyers race to outbid one another, ultimately pushing the price to nearly $1.8 million.

title: Lady Thatchers Dead (No, Not That One)
description: When it comes to text messages, sometimes less isnt more. On Tuesday night, word swept through part of a crowd of 1,700 at a fund-raiser for military families in Toronto that Margaret Thatcher, the former prime minister of Great Britain, was dead. Its source, according to the Canadian Press news agency, was a text message reading: Lady Thatcher has passed away.

title: The Price of Free
description: When, in late September, rumors surfaced that Comcast was trying to buy NBC Universal from General Electric, Wall Street reacted with dismay. Grandiose attempts to combine media production and distribution  programming and plumbing  are nothing new in the entertainment business, but they almost always end in disappointment. Witness AOL Time Warner. So what in the world could be prompting the Comcast chief executive, Brian Roberts, to start down this accursed path?

title: A Steal at 'Bronx Prices'
description: Janna Baty and Doug Wamble paid $180,000 for an apartment that has three bedrooms and two full baths in the Highbridge section of the Bronx.

title: Fourth-Wave Feminism
description: As the founder and editor of the blog Feministing.com, how would you rate the effectiveness of online activism compared to old-style models of political engagement like rallies and marches and displays of bra-burning?  Bra-burning never happened. It was completely made up by the media. A couple of women protesting a Miss America pageant threw some bras into a garbage can, and somehow that became this longstanding idea of feminists as bra-burners.

title: Job Losses Mount, Enduring and Deep
description: THE rise in unemployment that has occurred in the current recession has been hardest on young workers, while having a smaller effect on older workers than previous downturns. Women have been more likely than men to hold on to their jobs.

title: Samantha Morton in The Messenger
description: In The Messenger, out today, Samantha Morton plays an American woman whose husband is killed while fighting in Iraq. This dramatic turn is the latest in a motley succession of roles that began with Mortons 1999 breakout performance as the devilishly adorable mute in Woody Allens Sweet and Lowdown.

title: Vice President to Appear on Daily Show
description: Having hosted the likes of Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, and Ray Mabus, the secretary of the navy, The Daily Show With Jon Stewart will take another step up the White House chain of command on Tuesday: that night, the satirical news show is scheduled to host Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. Read more on ArtsBeat.

title: Pregame Huddle: Mountain West Showdown
description: All eyes are on the Mountain West as T.C.U. faces Utah while Florida and Alabama try to avoid upsets this weekend.

title: Deluxe Apartment in the Sky
description: A Classic 8 corner apartment on Park Avenue that was  impeccably renovated -- back in 1971.

title: A Quiet Start for Zach Lund
description: Zach Lund of the United States debuted the 2009-10 World Cup skeleton season with a fifth-place finish at the Utah Olympic Park in Park City, Utah.

title: Modern Classics
description: NYRB Classics, that series of highly craveable paperback reissues of works in translation, half-forgotten gems and titles you cant believe were ever out of print in the first place, celebrates its 10th anniversary, and 250th book, tonight at Greenlight Books in Fort Greene.

title: Hey, Good Lookin . . . Free Stuff!
description: I have a very attractive wife. When she is out with our two cute baby girls, she often receives free groceries, free fast food  the guy at Dunkin Donuts loves her  and free clothes. Frequently she does not realize she has the gifts (or stolen goods) until she is in the car, driving away. Is it ethical for her to keep these gifts, or must she return them (which may get the giver fired)? CHRIS ALTMAN, ATLANTA

title: Controllers Were Slow to Notify Defense Command of Errant Jet
description: WASHINGTON  Air traffic control supervisors delayed nearly an hour in notifying Norad, the military air defense command, that a Northwest Airlines jetliner was not responding to radio calls, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration said Friday. The delay was a violation of detailed procedures put in place after the hijackings of four airplanes on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: A Condo Hunter Remains True to the List
description: ERICA FRIEDMAN had a checklist. She knew exactly what she needed in her new home, and the importance of every feature. She went through her list methodically, dismissing buildings that didnt make the cut.

title: Maclaren Stroller Update
description: While we were discussing the Maclaren recall on Motherlode, The Harvard Business Review was offering online advice to the company.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Kristen Stewart, Nicolas Cage, Dave Grohl and More
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete stories.)

title: Changing Your Name After Marriage When Youre Gay
description: While changing a name after marriage can often be a struggle for heterosexual women and men, its a lot harder if youre gay.

title: Only Disconnect
description: Shortly after my girlfriend and I decided to rent a New Hampshire summer house together in 2007, we made a vexing discovery: Internet access wasnt going to be possible. We could get it, sure, but balked at the one-year contract required. We couldnt justify the expense and decided we would do without: surely our three acres of apple trees and old stone walls and wooded walks would offer ample distraction.

title: Financial Decisions to Make as You Divorce
description: Divorce may be one of the most damaging financial events in the lives of those who go through it, but that isnt always immediately clear to a couple about to split up.

title: F.D.A. Says It May Ban Alcoholic Drinks With Caffeine
description: WASHINGTON  Top federal food regulators threatened on Friday to ban caffeinated alcoholic drinks unless their makers quickly proved that the beverages were safe.

title: Book Review Podcast: Susan Cheever on Mary Karrs New Memoir
description: This week, Susan Cheever discusses Mary Karrs new memoir, Lit; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; David Carr tells us about the life and times of the British journalist Harry Evans; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Profiles of Four Terror Suspects
description: Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, mastermind of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, is believed to have had a cadre of al-Qaeda accomplices who were the money men, travel agents and deputies who enabled the hijackers in the United States from their posts overseas. These four will stand trial in United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: New Jersey Brokers Seeking a Rush From a Crawl
description: IN many communities, the pace of condominium sales is just crawling along these days.

title: Wireless Protocols Vie for Smart Grid
description: The market for smart appliances is in rapid development, and wireless companies want to make sure they get a piece of the pie.

title: What Unexpected Costs Did You Face in Your Divorce?
description: My Your Money column in Saturdays paper encourages people whose marriages are ending to consider all the costs they may face in the future, from taxes to damaged credit to therapy.

title: The Week Ahead: Nov. 15  21
description: Television

title: Still Trying to Lure New Yorkers Across the Hudson
description: Mass Exodus to New Jersey Underway one headline screams from a Web advertisement. Governor Plots Ginormous Tax Increases for New York City another blares. The front page of the newspaper in the ad looks like a warning from War of the Worlds, but dont panic. Its merely another volley in the Hudson River border wars between New York and New Jersey.

title: Filming a Friendship, Founded on Film
description: VILMOS ZSIGMOND and Laszlo Kovacs, whose cinematography would help change the look of American movies in the late 1960s and 1970s, first met in 1953 on a Budapest street corner near the Academy of Drama and Film, where both men were enrolled as cinematography students. Three years afterward  on Nov. 11, 1956, a week after Soviet troops poured into the city to crush the Hungarian uprising  they ran into each other again on the same corner.

title: Moved for the Space; Stayed for the Food
description: THE house that Michael and Lori Hiller planned to buy in South Park Slope, Brooklyn, was a good size for the neighborhood, and on a pleasant block. But then a problem developed with the buildings certificate of occupancy.

title: An Early Candidate for Dunk of the Year
description: Dwyane Wade might have made the dunk of the year this early in the season. While there have been some notable dunks early on, watch Wade sky over Anderson Varejao in Thursdays loss to the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Performa 09 | An Artistic Potluck
description: Thursday night, halfway through Performa 09s three week run, the curatorial collective Kunstverein NY opened the doors to their conceptual social club called the Prompt, which runs until Sunday evening at White Slab Palace, a Scandinavian gastropub (77 Delancey Street) on the Lower East Side.

title: Nobody Home but Us Gadgets
description: A NEW condominium conversion in southern SoHo celebrates 19th-century craftsmanship on the outside and 21st-century precision on the inside.

title: Loan Ceiling Extended
description: BUYERS of homes in high-priced markets have some reason to cheer: the federal government recently extended through 2010 the maximum dollar amount for conforming loans. This will probably mean better options for borrowers who might otherwise have had to take out jumbo mortgages.

title: The Best Way to Try Terrorists
description: Attorney General Eric Holder announced Friday that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other men accused in the 9/11 terrorist attacks will be prosecuted in federal court in New York City. Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, who is accused of planning the 2000 bombing of the Navy destroyer Cole in Yemen, and four other detainees also being held in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, will be tried before a military commission.

title: Ochocinco Fined for Bribe Joke
description: Tim Donaghy, scourge of N.B.A. officiating, apparently hovers over the N.F.L., too.

title: Fiscal perspective
description: Its truly amazing, and depressing, how completely deficit-phobia has swept the field in Washington. The economy remains in deeply dire straits: heres long-term unemployment:

title: Oreo Is Dead
description: Oreo, a dog that was nursed back to health after surviving being thrown off the roof of a six-story building, was killed Friday by lethal injection.

title: Directors Suite
description: BRETT MORGEN  AGE: 41  OCCUPATION: Filmmaker NEXT PROJECT: "June 17, 1994," his documentary about the day of the O.J. Simpson low-speed chase, will be shown as part of the ESPN 30 for 30 film series.

title: Robert Gladstone
description: Mr. Gladstone, 57, is the chief executive of Madison Equities, started by his parents, which has developed a wide range of buildings in Manhattan. Its most recent developments are two condominiums: Chelsea Modern and 57 Irving Place.

title: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Nov. 13
description: Correction appended | The aftermath of natural and human violence is depicted in the first five photographs of Fridays show, which chronicle the destruction caused by Tropical Storm Ida in Virginia and North Carolina and a suicide bomber in Pakistan. An older, aerial photograph of a Crowley Maritime Corporation barge gives some sense of the enormity of the vessel that has run aground in Virginia Beach.

title: The Use Changes; the Look Stays
description: UNTIL two years ago, the boarded-up Ossining National Bank on Main Street served as a nagging reminder that a once-thriving business district was sliding downhill. The last bank tenant vacated the building, a three-story Renaissance Revival-style structure, in 1966, and it had been vacant ever since.

title: Move Over Recliner, Here Comes the Snooker Table
description: If you can drive a leather recliner down the road, why not a snooker table?

title: Fte Accompli | NARS 15X15
description: What: A party for NARS 15X15, a book featuring 15 celebrities made-up and shot by the beauty extraordinaire Franois Nars for the brands 15th anniversary.

title: The View Inside the Gates
description: BETH TYNES wouldnt consider living in a community that isnt gated. From the very first, she said, I liked the sense of community.

title: Anything He Can Do, She Can Do
description: IN September 1998, David Buechner, then 39, a prominent classical pianist, came out as a transgender woman, explaining that from then on, she would live and perform as Sara Davis Buechner. The pianist had been accustomed to rave reviews (at 24, David, in his New York City concert debut, was called an extraordinary young artist by a New York Times critic). But the debut as Sara, reported in a Times magazine article, was not so well received, even by loved ones.

title: James Campaigns to Save No. 23 for Posterity
description: LeBron James of the Cleveland Cavaliers is calling on his N.B.A. comrades to join him in forsaking the No. 23 to honor Michael Jordan.

title: Crossing the Concourse
description: Just over a decade ago, David Buechner, a classical pianist, came out as a transgender woman, Sara Davis Buechner. On the eve of the 25th anniversary of her debut, Ms. Buechner reflects on her life.

title: Distilling the Best Comments From 100 Things Restaurant Staffers Should Never Do
description: Lord, I know this will end somedayPlease, please, no part three.  Jocko McTeague

title: Gallery Beat Meets Tracey Emin
description: Paul Hasegawa-Overacker interviews Tracey Emin at the Gramercy International art fair in 1995.

title: Leaving on a High Note
description: THROUGHOUT the real estate boom, one commercial property after another in the West Village was sold and transformed into an expensive condominium or house. At the same time, Danta C. Raso and Ricard de La Rosa went about their business, Pro Piano, supplying German-made Steinway pianos to concert pianists out of an office and warehouse on a cobblestone section of Jane Street, just off Washington Street.

title: A Stuffing Strategy Grandma Understood
description: CHESTNUT bread stuffing, thick with mushrooms and celery, has been such a fixture at my familys Thanksgiving table that, like the great fowl itself, its presence was never questioned.

title: Rooftop Ruckus
description: CONSTANCE HANSEN and her husband, Russell Peacock, both photographers, live and work in a loft in a co-op on West 31st Street, where they have long dreamed of building a rooftop extension made up in part of shipping containers hoisted up from the street.

title: They Have to Live Somewhere
description: PERHAPS too much has been said about those tiresome kings of finance, macho bankers and hedge fund executives who have swooped in and picked up some of New Yorks most valuable real estate in good times  and less good times.

title: Do You Use Twitter? How?
description: In February this year, Times tech columnist David Pogue wrote:

title: Chic in Review | Stella McCartneys Wardrobe Malfunction
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: "O Mio Babbino Caro"
description: Patricia Racette (Lauretta) sings O mio babbino caro to Paolo Gavanelli (Gianni Schicchi) at the San Francisco Opera.

title: Sharing News of a Childs Cerebral Palsy
description: David Sexton is a father coming to terms with the realities of his sons cerebral palsy. He is exploring this unexpected landscape in incremental steps, and, as he writes in a guest post today, the most recent challenge was telling family and friends who did not yet know this news.

title: Olives Irrigated With Blood
description: Earlier this year the NYTs Iraqi reporter in Diyala visited one of Al Qaedas former strongholds in the province, after years in which it was too dangerous to go there. He recalls the scene.

title: Philanthropy Thrives, Even With Reduced Resources
description: THE expectation in America is that people who do well give back to society. For the wealthy, it is one way to stave off charges of being greedy. And in the boom times, being seen as philanthropic seemed a social and political obligation.

title: Showcase: A Room of Everyones Own
description: At first, the rooms look unbearably cramped. The walls squeeze too tightly around the dwellers and their possessions. Then, some creative solutions emerge into view: a ventilation strip neatly covered with McDonalds wrappers, a raft of plastic bags hanging from clothespins, collapsible tables, stackable chairs.

title: Book Review Podcast: Susan Cheever on Mary Karrs New Memoir
description: This week, Susan Cheever discusses Mary Karrs new memoir, Lit; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; David Carr talks about the life and times of the British journalist Harold Evans; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.(Podcast Archive)

title: Accused 9/11 Suspects Face Federal Trial
description: Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other men accused in the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks will be prosecuted in federal court in New York.

title: Bubbles at a Discount for Consumers Trading Down
description: PERNAY, France  For generations of French Champagne makers, the threat of calamity has been a constant companion, whether it is winter freezes or spring frosts, phylloxera parasites or Nazi occupiers.

title: Your Dot: On Mobbed Owls and Blog Discourse
description: On Dot Earth, reader comments that are particularly intriguing or illuminating have sporadically been brought out front to this space for a fuller airing. As I wrote earlier today, that process will now become a regular feature, Your Dot, used to focus the discourse on constructive commentary by readers who prefer to stand publicly behind what they say. Im not endorsing the views expressed in these comments, and hope they will reflect a wide range of stances. Also, the full range of views and levels of anonymity will persist in the standard comment threads.

title: Japanese Form Mixes Discipline and the Elemental
description: Butoh, like flamenco, is one of those dance forms that are either all or nothing. If the performer is not imbued with both technique and (less quantifiably) the right spirit, you simply get no idea of what the experience of watching these arts can be like. Happily for the Cave New York Butoh Festival, which opened its Butoh-Kan Masters series at Dance New Amsterdam on Thursday night, Ko Murobushi is the real thing.

title: Sunday Preview
description: In this Sundays Caribbean issue, Matt Gross, who writes the weekly Frugal Traveler blog for The New York Times, sails the Caribbean on a shoestring budget. Without a boat to call his own or a budget to hire a yacht, he joins the crew of a 75-foot, two-masted schooner for a two-week immersion in the sailing world. For $55 a day, he learns the ropes, swims with sea turtles and, when all goes right, sleeps under the stars.

title: Weekly Pick Em: Can the Undefeated Stay That Way?
description: For those of you itching to see a top team in action, you wont have to wait for Saturday. Undefeated Cincinnati takes the field Friday night against West Virginia, hoping that its high-scoring ways will be enough to topple the Mountaineers. The marquee game of the weekend comes from the Mountain West, where unbeaten Texas Christian takes on Utah, which was the lone undefeated team at the end of last season. Will the Horned Frogs be able to make that claim this season? Elsewhere, Iowa travels to Ohio State for a game that could decide Big Ten supremacy, Notre Dame tries to bounce back from a loss when it faces surging Pittsburgh and Arizona takes on California in a pivotal game in the suddenly wild Pac-10. Our prognosticators have made their choices. If you agree, disagree or just feel the picks are laughable, feel free to chime in.

title: Zhang Returns, With the Familiar and Otherwise
description: During her five years as assistant and then associate conductor of the New York Philharmonic, Xian Zhang proved a substantial musician with an energetic technique and a lively interpretive spirit. Just as her tenure was coming to an end last season, she was appointed music director of the Orchestra Sinfonica di Milano Giuseppe Verdi. But she has kept her ties to the Philharmonic, and on Thursday evening she was back at Avery Fisher Hall to lead it in works by Haydn, Martinu and Sibelius.

title: Answers About Home Buyers and Owners Tax Credits: Part 4
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which youll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Violence Flares Ahead of Algeria-Egypt Soccer Match
description: Update | Saturday | 2:35 p.m. ET Egyptian Win to Keep Hopes Alive for World Cup 2010. A remarkable last-minute goal for Egypt in Cairo, scored by Emad Moteab, gave the hosts the 2-0 victory they needed to stay in contention for a spot in next summers World Cup. Egypt and Algeria end the qualifying period tied and will now face off in a one game playoff at a neutral venue (in Sudan) on Wednesday, to decide which country will go to the World Cup. The goal came in the fifth minute of added time, just seconds before the match was due to end.

title: Chief of NewYork-Presbyterian Will Retire in 2 Years
description: New York Citys largest private hospital announced Friday that its chief executive, one of the highest-paid hospital executives in the country, would be retiring in two years.

title: Now Installing | Francesco Vezzoli Gets Gaga to MoCA
description: LOS ANGELES  Petit-point embroidery plays an important part in the artistic career of Francesco Vezzoli: his best-known works are serigraphs in which details of the images are hand-stitched in shocking colors. His big media debut was presenting Veruschka and himself embroidering in a three-day performance at the Venice Biennale many years ago.

title: Charlotte With Dried Fruit
description: 12 ounces dried apricots

title: From the House of the Dead': Those Projected Supertitles
description: Ah, the pros and cons of supertitles.

title: Taking a Holiday From Rolling Out Dough
description: IS it Thanksgiving if there is no traditional pie with a traditional filling and a crust that the cook obviously fussed and worried over? Sure it is.

title: Invoking Departed Friends and the Flights They Took
description: Ulysses Dove, Rudolf Nureyev, Arnie Zane: these names and others fill a page in the program for Janis Brenners 5 Decades show, which opened on Thursday night at the Joyce SoHo. And this list accounts for just a very few of the choreographers and dancers who died of AIDS during the 1980s and 90s.

title: New York on Less: Making Choices
description: The city's unemployed have found more time for exercise.

title: Chart: The Very Bests Show
description: The Very Best is a band with a singer from Malawi and two D.J.s and producers from London, and its music is a catchy blend of African, hip-hop and dance music. The bands debut album, Warm Heart of Africa, was released last month and its one of the artist Andrew Kuos favorites the year. Heres his report on the Very Bests show at Santos Party House in Manhattan last week.

title: More Than Ever, You Can Say That on Television
description: LOS ANGELES  On many nights this fall, it has been possible to tune in to broadcast network television during prime time and hear a character call someone else a douche.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 13
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week. Subjects include an artist at a dog run, the Veterans Day Parade, and the anniversary of the crash of American Airlines Flight 587.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 13
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: In This Ring of the Circus, the Amazing Risk Tamers
description: How much you enjoy Inside Out, the moody blend of modern and traditional circus by the Swedish troupe Cirkus Cirkr depends to a large degree on whether youve recently seen Cirque du Soleil. This tastefully appointed spectacle, which imagines two risk-averse ordinary people loosening up upon meeting a talented troupe of acrobats, jugglers and clowns, once again polishes up sideshow antics with an arty sheen. But next to similar efforts by Cirque du Soleil, a French Canadian juggernaut that is a frequent visitor to this city, this new production can seem beside the point. By comparison, the bag of tricks of Cirkus Cirkrs jittery ringleader (Fredrik Deijfen, looking like Jeeves dipped in white paint) is skimpy, the shows pacing slack, and the leaps and stunts awfully modest.

title: Patricia Racette as Cio-Cio-San
description: Patricia Racette as Cio-Cio-San, with Maria Zifchak as Suzuki in Anthony Minghella's production of "Madama Butterfly," at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: New Web Services Turn Ticket Buying Into a Social Occasion
description: Nothing in the concert industry has evolved more significantly than how people buy tickets, from the days of walk-up box offices to Ticketmasters network of call centers to the almost entirely Internet-based technology of today, in which seats by the thousands can disappear in an instant.

title: Wanted: People Willing to Lead the European Union
description: BRUSSELS  The position will undoubtedly bring prestige, limitless travel and the chance to head a network of European Union diplomats stretching around the globe. Yet none of Europes big three powers in foreign policy  Britain, France and Germany  appear to want it.

title: Ex-Louisiana Congressman Sentenced to 13 Years
description: WASHINGTON  Former Representative William J. Jefferson, a New Orleans Democrat whose political career once seemed to hold high promise, was sentenced Friday to 13 years in prison for using his office to try to enrich himself and his relatives.

title: For Madoff Auction, Even Jewels Lack Luster
description: They came to see evil. Instead, they found a creamer shaped like a cow.

title: Classic Ad: Saab 95
description: In the Automobiles section this Sunday, Steven Rossi writes about the enduring appeal of vintage Saabs  Swedish cars that were well engineered (they came from an aircraft company, after all) and often delightfully unconventional. In that spirit, this weeks classic ad comes from Europe, complete with a starchy early-60s British-television voice-over.

title: To Remain Unbeaten, Know When to Play Low
description: The Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Teams is one of the most enjoyable events on the Greater New York Bridge Association calendar. Each team has to lose twice to be eliminated. The winners this year, for the second time in three years, were Franco Baseggio, Andrew Stark, Simon Erlich and Jeff Rothstein of New York; Arch McKellar of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.; and Ken Jacobs of Upper Saddle River, N.J.

title: Kenneth Lonergan: Part-Time Playwright
description: To the Editor:

title: Its the stupidity economy
description: OK, maybe a more polite way to say it is this: bad ideas are acting as serious constraints on policy.

description: To the Editor:
