title: Penn Back in Contention After Emotional Seasons
description: PHILADELPHIA  A blue stocking cap pulled over his ears, Al Bagnoli, the football coach at Penn, stood in the rain Wednesday at Franklin Field as he directed an important practice before the 282nd game of his career, a game that he said would feel different.

title: Correction: A New Attack on the Iraq War Film
description: An article last Sunday about the film The Messenger misstated, at one point, the rank of the character played by Woody Harrelson. As the article noted elsewhere, he portrays a captain named Tony Stone, not a sergeant.

title: EconoQuiz Results
description: Thanks to everyone who took part in the latest EconoQuiz.

title: JPMorgan Faces New Suit in Alabama Countys Woes
description: Even after a $700 million settlement with the federal government, JPMorgan Chase still faces troubles in Alabama.

title: Playing Connect the Dots, From Aphrodite to Lil Kim
description: In SoloShow, the second half of a diptych of solos, the choreographer Maria Hassabi plays with contrasting viewpoints so subtly that at first its difficult to see what has changed since the first piece. There are some cosmetic alterations: instead of the compact first-floor theater at Performance Space 122, where the first work, Solo, was presented in September as part of the Crossing the Line festival, the new dance takes place in the larger upstairs theater. A Persian rug is replaced by an austere platform stage, and gradually its apparent that the mood has painstakingly shifted from warm to cool.

title: Suspect in Ft. Hood Case Is Said to Be Paralyzed
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  The Army psychiatrist charged with killing 13 people in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood appears to be paralyzed from the waist down as a result of his bullet wounds, his lawyer said Friday.

title: That 1940s Feeling at a Poconos Roadhouse
description: Jim Farmer must have had some bizarre experiences in restaurants or in the Poconos  or both  over the years. At least that is the impression left by his daffy play The Supper Club of Lost Causes, a fractured look at faded glory that is being given a strange, smart production at Theater for the New City.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Events in Westchester
description: Film

title: Events on Long Island
description: Film

title: Robert Johnsons House to Rise Again
description: The fabled crossroads where Robert Johnson is supposed to have sold his soul to the Devil in exchange for his guitar prowess has not been definitively located, but the musicians birthplace has been determined, and plans are in the works to restore it as a tourist attraction, The Associated Press reported. Johnson, the blues guitarist of Sweet Home Chicago and Love in Vain who influenced artists from Muddy Waters to Eric Clapton, was born in 1911 in Hazlehurst, Miss., in a home built by his stepfather. The birthplace was verified in a letter from his half-sister, according to the cultural affairs office of Copiah County, which is seeking to raise $250,000 to restore the home as a destination for music fans and Johnson acolytes. He was so good that he would literally turn his back when they were recording him, said the screenwriter Jimmy White (Ray), who is working on a script about Mr. Johnsons life. He didnt want the other musicians to see his fingering technique.

title: Record Sales for Modern Warfare 2, but Gaming Business Declines
description: It was an up-and-down week of news for the video gaming business. On the upside, the debut of the highly anticipated shooting game Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 set a sales record for the industry, Variety reported: the game, which retails for $59.99, sold 4.7 million units in its first day on sale in the United States and Britain, taking in $310 million for the game publisher Activision Blizzard. (By comparison, the years highest-grossing movie, Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen, had earned more than $200 million domestically by the end of its first weekend.) On the downside, the industry saw its overall sales decline during October, compared with the same month last year, according to a report from NPD Group. Sales of hardware, software and accessories totaled $1.07 billion for October 2009, down 19 percent from the $1.32 billion in sales in October 2008. NPD predicted that the industrys revenues for the year would be from $20 billion to $21 billion, most likely down from last years tally of $21.3 billion, though coming releases like New Super Mario Bros. Wii and Assassins Creed 2 could still turn things around.

title: Its Official: MGM Is Back in Play
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is officially back on the block.

title: Biden to Appear on Daily Show
description: Having hosted the likes of Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, and Ray Mabus, the secretary of the Navy, The Daily Show With Jon Stewart will take another step up the White House chain of command on Tuesday: that night Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is scheduled to appear on the satirical news show, Comedy Central said on Friday in a news release. It will be the first time Mr. Biden has appeared on The Daily Show since he was elected vice president; he has previously appeared on the show twice, including on Jan. 31, 2007, the day he announced he was seeking the Democratic presidential nomination. President Barack Obama appeared on the show on Oct. 29, 2008, just before winning the election.

title: Barnes Foundation Breaks Ground For New Home In Philadelphia
description: After years of battles over the Barnes Foundations plan to bypass its charter and bylaws and move its art collection from suburban Merion, Pa., to downtown Philadelphia, the foundation broke ground on Friday for its new home, designed by the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. A 2004 court ruling permitted the foundation, which has struggled financially, to go against the wishes of Albert C. Barnes, who built the collection and stipulated that no picture in it could be lent, sold or moved from the walls of the galleries that he built for it in Merion. Judge Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans Court said in the ruling that he considered the move the only viable alternative to save the Barnes from bankruptcy. But opponents  a couple dozen of whom protested on Friday morning outside the groundbreaking ceremony, above, waving signs with messages including: Crime Scene. Do Not Enter. Destruction of National Historic Landmark in Progress  contend that the collections financial troubles are surmountable and that the move is motivated primarily by the Philadelphia political establishments desire to generate more downtown tourism. This is not about art  its about politics, said Evelyn Yaari, a member of Friends of the Barnes Foundation, which organized the protest.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: Comedy

title: Munch Work Is Stolen in Norway
description: Thieves in Norway stole a rare lithograph by Edvard Munch on Thursday, Agence France-Presse reported. A police spokesman said on Friday that the robbers broke an art gallery window, grabbed the work, called History, right, and escaped. Though several lithographs of the work exist, the one that was stolen had been hand-colored by Munch himself. It sold at an auction in 2001 for about $35,000, but Agence France-Presse reported the current value at more than 10 times that amount, about $355,000. Munch artwork has been targeted by thieves before: in 2004 two armed masked men burst into the Munch museum in Oslo in daylight and stole The Scream and Madonna paintings before escaping in a getaway car driven by a third man. Ten years earlier another version of The Scream was stolen from Oslos national gallery on the opening day of the Lillehammer Winter Olympics. The works were recovered in both cases.

title: Third Time Lucky for CSI
description: CBSs CSI earned its highest ratings of the season on Thursday with the conclusion of a crossover plot line that involved episodes of CSI: Miami and CSI: NY the same week. According to Nielsens estimates, the final episode of the CSI trilogy drew the largest audience of the three shows, with 16.9 million viewers at 9 p.m. on Thursday, enough to lead the night over all in the ratings. CBSs Survivor: Samoa also delivered its best ratings of the season, leading the 8 oclock hour with 13.2 million viewers. CBS won the night, and ABC placed second with FlashForward (8.3 million), Greys Anatomy (14.4 million) and Private Practice (10.2 million). Fox was third with Bones (9.8 million) and Fringe (5.9 million), and NBC was fourth with its comedy lineup.

title: Washington: Gateses Give to Own Foundation
description: Bill and Melinda Gates, the couple behind one of the worlds largest foundations, said they would give the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation $350 million to help cover the costs of building its new campus in Seattle. The foundation broke ground on the 12-acre campus more than a year ago, and it is about 40 percent complete, The Seattle Times reported. About 11,000 of its total 90,000 square feet will house a visitors center, and roughly 800 employees will occupy the rest. The gift will cover 70 percent of the projected $500 million cost of the new facilities and means the foundation will have $350 million more to devote to its work to improve global health, global development and American education.

title: Suicides Increase Among Troops
description: There have been 133 suspected suicides among active-duty Army troops this year, putting the service within reach of a new annual high. The suicides, between January and October and including the National Guard and Reserves, compared with 115 in the same period in 2008. That year the service recorded 140 by years end, an annual record, the Army said. The rate of suicide within the Army last year was 20.2 per 100,000 personnel, exceeding for the first time the age-adjusted rate in the civilian population, which was 19.2, according to the National Institute of Mental Health.

title: Beyond White Meat and Market Freezers
description: THE centerpiece of the original Thanksgiving table was probably not a 20-pound roaster, but a much smaller, leaner game bird  like the ones that Connecticut farmers and a few select stores around the state are offering as alternatives to the big birds now crowding supermarket freezers.

title: Food Agency Delays Ban on Oysters After Outcry
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration on Friday indefinitely delayed a ban on the sale of raw oysters harvested on the Gulf Coast during warm months in the face of opposition from the oyster industry and legislators from the region.

title: Home of the Mouse Finds Box Office Success in the Land of the Bear
description: MOSCOW  They were all there on screen: Ivan and the mountain queen; Baba Yaga, the witch, who lives in a cottage perched on chicken feet; and even Kashchei the Immortal, who keeps his mortality locked in a gooses egg.

title: Worried About Losing Tax Revenue, Congress to Investigate Airlines Fees
description: When airlines charge extra fees, are they really just another fare increase in disguise?

title: Bloggingheads: If Israel Strikes Iran
description: Joe Klein, left, of Time and David Frum of FrumForum debate the possible repercussions of an Israeli attack on Iran's nuclear sites.

title: Exotic and Familiar at an Afghan Grill
description: WE were on our way to the Afghan Grill Kabob House in New Hyde Park when one of our party admitted that he knew nothing about Afghan food and was worried about whether he would like it. In fact, anyone who likes Greek or Turkish cooking will find similar dishes here: grilled meats, kebabs, hummus, lots of eggplant and chopped salads. Yet there is enough exotic fare to make a meal exciting, and the food is delicious.

title: Struggling Japan Airlines Reports a $357 Million Loss
description: TOKYO  Japan Airlines posted a loss of 32.2 billion yen ($357 million) in the latest quarter and said it was in new talks to suspend loan payments as it awaited formal approval for a government-led bailout.

title: Big Juicy Steaks, Hold the Guilt
description: THOSE lush expense-account-driven power lunches and dinners of the 50s and 60s portrayed so accurately in AMCs popular TV series Mad Men may have something to do with a renewed interest in the steakhouse  the kind of place that was once de rigueur for carefree big spenders who favored them probably as much for the large portions of familiar ingredients (nothing hidden under fancy French sauces) as for the quality of the beef. A steakhouse meal in those days might include a tomato-and-onion salad, a mighty porterhouse, baked potato, creamed spinach and cheesecake, plus a few martinis to wash it all down.

title: Terrorists on Trial; Counterterrorism, Too
description: One great thing about the Internet is that there is virtually no issue on which you could say bloggers are unanimous. Flat earth? Has its defenders. (And not just in the Friedmanesque sense.) Man on the moon? Has its skeptics. Boxcar Willie is a reptilian pedophile intent on ruling the earth? Of course!

title: Saving Sea Turtles, One Nest at a Time
description: Global warming and coastal development are decimating Pacific sea turtle populations. In Costa Rica, a group of one-time poachers is giving baby sea turtles a chance at survival.

title: State of Desperation
description: This helps put things into perspective:

title: A World of Ways to Get That Grilled Taste
description: WHEN Carlos Teixeira bought Burnet BBQ in Union about 15 years ago, most of the customers for his heaping platters of flame-grilled chicken and ribs were Portuguese.

title: Kramnik Retains Lead at Tal Memorial; Carlsen Notches First Win
To Offset the Fall Chill
description: Right around the time that autumns deepening chill calls for a warming red wine, Macari Vineyards is introducing a new Bordeaux-style blend, Dos Aguas ($26.99), or Two Waters, from 2007, a good vintage.

title: Gooey, but Grown-Up
description: Provisions is a delightful eat-in and take-out cafe that specializes in made-from-scratch sandwiches like roast turkey with homemade cranberry sauce on apple-cranberry bread and tuna salad spread between thick slices of jalapeo cheddar. The only cold cut you will find in the place is the high-end prosciutto, served with roasted pears and goat cheese.

title: Swiss Say Googles Street View Is Too Revealing
description: Swiss officials said Friday that they had sued Google to try to require it to tighten privacy safeguards on its Street View online service. It is the latest of a series of European objections to the companys handling of personal information.

title: Recession Over in Euro Zone, Report Says
description: PARIS  After more than a year in the doldrums, the euro area emerged from recession during the third quarter, helped largely by export growth and improved industrial production in Germany.

title: Going for the Bling: Hollywood Burglars
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Outsourcing Jobs Arrive in Rural Areas
description: A handful of entrepreneurs are bringing outsourcing jobs to rural areas in India that have been largely cut off from its economic rise.

title: Finally, a Videophone Thats Practical for All
description: Over the years videophones have come and gone, like so many reruns of The Jetsons. But none has gained any traction among consumers because they have been impractical and costly. A couple of years ago, for instance, I was impressed with the $350 Motorola Ojo. Video call quality was great, but the device required that each user buy a videophone  and pay a monthly service fee.

title: Philips Moves Into High-Tech Skin Care
description: Do women want to discuss their skin problems with online strangers? Philips, the Dutch lighting, health care and electronics company, is betting they do. Social networking about skin care is a key element in the companys new consumer product, Crystalize.

title: Oreo the Abused Pit Bull Is Euthanized
description: Oreo, a dog that was nursed back to health after surviving being thrown off the roof of a six-story building, was killed Friday by lethal injection.

title: As the Rudes Get Ruder, the Scolds Get Scoldier
description: DO two rudes make a polite?

title: A Product (You Think) Youll Never Need
description: For middle-aged healthy adults, its disheartening the first time you realize you need reading glasses. Because once you do, you can no longer hide under the illusion that youre young.

title: 40 Miles of Creative Spaces
description: In 2001, six eastern Connecticut artists joined forces to do a little promotion, opening their studios to the public on the same weekend. Now, eight years later, their little promotion has become a big deal around Branford, Guilford and Madison.

title: Sending Up Show Business, Not to Mention Politics
description: Its tempting  very tempting  to share some of the laugh lines in the play Craig Wright has so tellingly named Mistakes Were Made. But it would be a mistake. Without the desperate delivery of the star of the Hartford Stage production, Will LeBow, the jokes would lose much of their zing. So I will refrain from quoting the text and quote the set instead.

title: Navys Vieques Training May Be Tied to Health Risks
description: The federal agency that assesses health hazards at sites designated for Superfund environmental cleanups said Friday that it had reversed its conclusion that contamination at a former United States Navy training ground in Puerto Rico posed no health risks to residents.

title: Fragile Care Worsened Swine Flu in Ukraine
description: LVIV, Ukraine  When patients began arriving in Vyacheslav Bonders intensive care unit two weeks ago, their lungs so saturated with blood that they could barely gasp, the only thing he could compare it to was a field hospital in wartime. As soon as he hooked one patient up to a ventilator, a second and third would appear in the doorway.

title: Quite Big in Britain, Not Quite in the U.S.
description: That the artist Tracey Emin had asked to be interviewed at her hotel swimming pool and showed up in a bathing suit would probably mean more to readers in her native England, where her self-revelatory and at times exhibitionist tendencies are well known. They have helped make her an object of public fascination there  a national celebrity, in fact  for more than a decade.

title: Deal on Quick Blood Test if Breath Test Is Refused
description: The New York Police Department and the citys five district attorneys have reached a preliminary agreement on a new procedure they believe will allow the police to more quickly get warrants to take the blood of drivers who refuse breath tests, a department spokesman said Friday.

title: Dell Will Introduce a Smartphone
description: Dell confirmed on Friday what has been bouncing around the market for some time: it is entering the smartphone business.

title: Late-Night Revolution? In Taste, Perhaps
description: The revolution starts right now! George Lopez proclaimed on Monday on the premiere of Lopez Tonight, his new 11 p.m. talk show on TBS. After watching the programs first week, it was hard to see what exactly the revolution consisted of.

title: Obama Walks a Delicate Tightrope on His 1st Trip as President to China
description: SHANGHAI  Against the backdrop of a tentative global recovery, President Obama and Chinas leaders will meet in Beijing next week to discuss how to improve relations between the worlds reigning economic superpower and its greatest challenger.

title: Online Visions by Long Island Public TV
description: Sweeping aerial views, a documentary on going green locally and a three-part series examining the exodus of young professionals from Long Island are among the offerings produced by WLIW available at a new video portal on the public television stations Web site.

title: After Independence, the Search for Self
description: Indian Art After Independence: Selected Works from the Collections of Virginia and Ravi Akhoury and Shelley and Donald Rubin, a small but engaging show at the Hofstra University Museum, illustrates how Indian artists embraced modernity after the end of British rule in 1947. About 20 paintings and drawings are on view, a few predating independence and all on loan from two private New York collections.

title: Mistrial Request Rejected in Ex-State Senators Trial
description: ALBANY  Lawyers for Joseph L. Bruno requested a mistrial on Friday, a day after the judge presiding over Mr. Brunos corruption trial scolded the former State Senate leader for appearing to criticize one of the judges rulings.

title: The San Francisco Green Festival: Windy Web Hosting and Fizzy Chai
description: In todays world of greenistential and omnivoric dilemmas, youre no longer just what you eat, but what you buy, what you wear and what you consume.

title: Vials of 5 Genzyme Drugs for Rare Diseases May Be Contaminated, F.D.A. Says
description: Vials of five different Genzyme drugs for rare diseases may be contaminated with tiny particles of steel, rubber or fiber that could potentially harm patients, the Food and Drug Administration warned Friday.

title: Minister Grows Up, Yet Ministry Stays Young
description: One Sunday morning in 1994, Din Tolbert brought his gangly frame to the altar of a chapel in Queens. Then 12 years old, he wore a blue suit from the Salvation Army, his only decent church clothes, and the white tube socks were his unwitting trademark as a geek. In most parts of his life, he willingly took on the positions of listener and watcher, what he later termed the back role in the back row.

title: Dysfunctional Delights
description: David Lee Whites Blood: A Comedy couldnt be cleverer as it deals with the onset of Alzheimers disease, a soap-opera-style family shocker and reflections on the existence of God.

title: Burdened by Billions in Debt, MGM Puts Itself Up for Sale
description: LOS ANGELES  Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is back on the block.

title: Violence Flares Ahead of Algeria-Egypt Soccer Match
description: On The Lede Blog, The New York Timess Robert Mackey examines the tense back-story behind the upcoming soccer match between Algeria and Egypt:

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 907 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following American on Thursday:

title: A Teachers Dream Gets to the Screen
description: SUMMIT

title: A Tribute to Kinship and Nostalgia
description: When the Smithereens play the Community Theater at Mayo Center for the Performing Arts in Morristown on Saturday, the front man, Pat DiNizio, expects the prevailing mood to be one of bonhomie and kinship.

title: China Focuses on Territorial Issues as It Equates Tibet to U.S. Civil War South
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government had a special message for President Obama on Thursday: He is black, he admires Abraham Lincoln, so he, of all people, should sympathize with Beijings effort to prevent Tibet from seceding and sliding back into what it was before its liberation by Chinese troops: a feudalistic, slaveholding society headed by the Dalai Lama.

title: Grieving, and Asking When the Pain Will End
description: Life looks normal at Beccas house in Larchmont. Shes standing at the kitchen table, folding freshly laundered childrens clothes and listening to her single sisters latest crazy anecdote.

title: Ohio Is First to Change to One Drug in Executions
description: Breaking ranks with the 35 other states that use lethal injections to execute prisoners, Ohio on Friday became the first state to say it would switch to a single drug, rather than a three-drug cocktail, in its death penalty procedure.

title: Young Star, Old Master and a Fresh Take on Mozart
description: AFTER more than four decades atop the musical food chain, Itzhak Perlman is not easily impressed. But when Mr. Perlman, the revered violinist and conductor, first heard the clarinetist Anthony McGill, he said, he was kind of blown away.

title: Changing Sex With a Step, a Wink and a Video
description: There are times when a money-back guarantee for a new show would seem not so much a philistine idea as a vital safeguard. It wouldnt apply to artists whose risks dont pan out; audiences have to take risks, too, if they are interested in following an art form as it zigzags forward.

title: A Recovery for Some
description: President Obamas strongest supporters during the presidential campaign were the young, the black and the poor  and they are among those who are being hammered unmercifully in this long and cruel economic downturn that the financial elites are telling us is over.

title: On the Street | Colors
description: Autumns last hurrah is to be seen all over the city, as pools of leaves fall to the ground. Stylish women are wearing many points of view -- so long as its black with a touch of white.

title: Concern at a School in a Building Tied to Iran
description: Outside the Razi School on Queens Boulevard, a television truck idled all day. Images of the ordinarily quiet school were beaming across the nation, spotlighting it as the tenant of a building that federal authorities were trying to seize because they believed the owner illegally funneled money to Iran.

title: 6 Therapists at Bellevue Forced Out Over Hours
description: Six therapists have been forced to resign from Bellevue Hospital Center, New York Citys premier public hospital, after an investigation into the falsification of time sheets, hospital officials said on Friday.

title: Marijuana Moves Into the Open in a Ski Town
description: BRECKENRIDGE, Colo.  High-altitude partying is a deeply carved tradition in ski country, where alcohol in the open and illicit drugs in the shadows have been intertwined for years.

title: Love for a Dog Thats No Bark and All Yodel
description: Donut the French bulldog was sitting outside Starbucks. Romeo was perusing the produce at the Korean market down the street, and Jack was going to see Oskar for a play date. Oh yes, Oskar was in his usual spot, sunning himself on his little red bed in the window of the Jumping Bulldog, the chic dog and cat boutique named after him.

title: 9/11 Trial Poses Unparalleled Legal Obstacles
description: WASHINGTON  How do you defend one of the most notorious terrorist figures in history?

title: Contract Talks Likely to Test Matsuis Calm
description: Hideki Matsui has always been the good son. When he lost his temper as a youngster and was upbraided by his coach, Matsui vowed never get angry in a game again. When he came to New York for the first time before joining the Yankees, he visited ground zero to pay his respects.

title: How New York May Tighten Security Vise
description: Convoys of heavily armed officers, fields of barricades and additional checkpoints are likely to sprout in and around the jail where the accused will be housed and the courthouse where they will be tried. Access to nearby streets and areas may be sealed off. And bands of plainclothes officers  people in civilian clothes with earplugs, as one former law enforcement official put it  will probably be scanning the crowds to spot anyone with ill intent.

title: Obama Chooses an Inner-Circle Man
description: WASHINGTON  In being named White House counsel less than a year into President Obamas tenure, Robert F. Bauer is reversing a longstanding trend.

title: Once Again, Into the Apocalypse
description: A lot of people are worrying about the world coming to an end in 2012.

title: Forces Aligning in Bid to Block Cuts in Albany
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson is imploring the Legislature to finally reckon with the states ugly financial reality.

title: On a Digital Refrigerator, an Art Gallery for the Young
description: Since March, The Times has run two hyper-local blogs, one about Brooklyn and one about New Jersey, creating virtual community hubs where neighbors report on their own neighborhoods. A regular feature on The Local is a virtual fridge displaying childrens art, held up with digital magnets. We promise they wont fall off when the magnets get old, and they wont get stained by the ice dispenser, Tina Kelley, the anchor of The Local in Maplewood, Millburn and South Orange, N.J., wrote in announcing the series.

title: An Arms Dealer Returns, Now Selling an Image
description: CAIRO

title: Dangerous Substance: Sample With Care
description: He captured the worlds attention and it intoxicated him.

title: The Passion of the Right
description: In 354 days, the dead will rise. Or so believe Republicans.

title: The Young and the Reckless
description: ON Monday, the United States Supreme Court heard oral arguments in two cases that ask whether sentencing a juvenile to life in prison without the possibility of parole is a violation of the Eighth Amendments prohibition of cruel and unusual punishment.

title: William Ganz, Catheter Inventor, Dies at 90
description: Dr. William Ganz, a cardiologist and medical inventor who helped develop a revolutionary catheter to measure blood flow and heart functions, died Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 90.

title: T.C.U. Fans Are Singing Football Coachs Praises
description: FORT WORTH  In seventh grade, Texas Christian Coach Gary Patterson was the lead singer and guitarist in a band named Walk On Easy.

title: Bruce King, 3-Term Governor, Dies at 85
description: Bruce King, who rose from a rough-hewn, rural upbringing on the family ranch to become the only three-term governor of New Mexico, died Friday at his ranch, larger now but still in the same place, in Stanley, N.M. He was 85.

title: Russian Deal on Afghan Supply Route Not Done Yet
description: WASHINGTON  When he met President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia in April, President Obama sought to open an important new supply corridor for Afghanistan by flying American troops and weapons through Russian airspace. Visiting Moscow in July, he sealed a deal for as many as 4,500 flights a year, in what he called a substantial contribution to the war and a sign of improving relations with Russia.

title: Breaks of the Game
description: THEATER dressing rooms are my home away from home  my second home, really, Cheyenne Jackson said, surveying his 14-by-8-foot nook after a curtain call for the Broadway revival of Finians Rainbow. A round bed embroidered with the name Zora, for his Rottweiler/Lab mix, lay beneath a counter crowded with makeup and hair products. A childhood photo of Monte Lapka, his partner since 1999, hung on a wall.

title: Polls Predicted a Bloomberg Blowout, but Expert Knew Better
description: More than three months ago, Bruce N. Gyory was telling anyone who would listen, including advisers to both mayoral campaigns, that while Michael R. Bloomberg was favored to win, his margin would not be more than five to seven percentage points.

title: Lottery Numbers
President Obama Speaks in Japan
description: On his inaugural trip to Asia, President Obama told the Japanese that the United States is "a nation of the Pacific."

title: A Return to American Justice
description: Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. took a bold and principled step on Friday toward repairing the damage wrought by former President George W. Bush with his decision to discard the nations well-established systems of civilian and military justice in the treatment of detainees captured in antiterrorist operations.

title: Never Too Old to Act Young
description: A JUGGLER on a unicycle wobbles past a cluster of clubgoers, deftly avoiding a collision that might spill their candy-color cocktails down the front of premium-label jeans. A clown on stilts hobbles past a table full of neatly coiffed men with untucked dress shirts who dont even look up from their drinks. Its hard enough to project an air of unwavering cool at New York nightclubs. Its even harder to do so in the presence of a clown.

title: Deserves a Deal
description: Joe Krozel is like a figure skater who is always adding just one more dangerous twist in order to boldly go where no cruciverbalist has gone before. Today he tries his own version of the Iron Lotus. Will he survive? More important, will the crossword survive as a viable puzzle, meaning a fair and fun experience?

title: Correction: Evening Hours | Lions in Autumn
description: The Evening Hours column last Sunday misspelled the surname of the longtime Manhattan district attorney, who was an honoree at a New York Landmarks Conservancy event on Nov. 4. He is Robert M. Morgenthau, not Morganthau.

title: Turtles Are Casualties of Warming in Costa Rica
description: PLAYA GRANDE, Costa Rica  This resort town was long known for Leatherback Sea Turtle National Park, nightly turtle beach tours and even a sea turtle museum. So Kaja Michelson, a Swedish tourist, arrived with high expectations. Of course were hoping to see turtles  that is part of the appeal, she said.

title: Campus Elections in Lebanon Mirror Societys Politics
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  For a brief moment, it looked as if civil war would break out on campus. Two clusters of excited young people faced off as the student election results came in: Hezbollah allies on one side, and right-wing Christian zealots on the other.

title: The Job of Finding a New Job
description: How do you know when its time to change careers? Perhaps you no longer feel energized about new projects or youve lost confidence in your boss.

title: After Lubavitcher Tragedy, Spiritual Rebirth
description: Emissaries of the Chabad-Lubavitch movement are a hardy lot  part envoys, part pioneers  who agree to settle anywhere in the world where their leaders decide that Jewish communities need bolstering, whether in Anchorage or Bangkok or northern Kyrgyzstan.

title: That $35 Cup of Coffee
description: Federal regulators have a long and distressing history of talking about predatory banking practices while doing little to end them. The Federal Reserve Boards new rules aimed at protecting unsuspecting holders of debit cards from multiple overdraft fees are, at best, half-measures.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about questions over the shooting of Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan at Fort Hood referred incorrectly to an appearance on the Oprah Winfrey Show on Wednesday by Senior Sgt. Mark Todd, a police officer who was involved in stopping Mr. Hasan. Sergeant Todd had been interviewed previously by The Associated Press and had appeared on CNN; his interview with Ms. Winfrey was not his first public comment.

title: Turkey Plans to Ease Restrictions on Kurds and Help End Decades of Conflict
description: ISTANBUL  After months of dialogue, the Turkish government announced a plan on Friday to help end the quarter-century-long conflict with a Kurdish separatist movement that has cost more than 40,000 lives.

title: Trauma Surgeon of Wall Street
description: IRVINGTON, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Friday with the continuation of an article about cancer prevention misstated the name of a widely ignored drug that has been shown to lower the risk of prostate cancer. As the article noted, it is dutasteride  not duasteride or cuasteride.

title: Wild Spaces, Street Patterns and a Splashdown
description: IF Ken Burnss recent television series on Americas national parks has you craving natural splendor, the city is a perfect if surprising place to look. For proof, look no further than to Legacy: The Preservation of Wilderness in New York City Parks (Aperture, $65), by Joel Meyerowitz.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the Los Angeles Philharmonics new music director, Gustavo Dudamel, gave an incorrect date in some editions for the orchestras first performance last week of Verdis Requiem. It was Thursday night, not Friday night.

title: Dallas Basketball Player Is Hero in Europe
description: TBILISI, Georgia  During the war between Georgia and Russia last year, many Georgians felt abandoned when their closest ally, the United States, did not enter the conflict. But they remained steadfast in their support of Tyrone Ellis, a basketball player from Dallas. On the court, Ellis did something his fellow Americans had not done during the war: He fought for Georgia, and he won.

title: Rockaways Surf and Downtown Turf
description: Steve Rodriguez, 38, started skateboarding on the streets of Greenwich Village as a kid and never put his board away. He still skates every day (barring major cold snaps) and is an advocate for the skateboard community. In 1996, Mr. Rodriguez founded 5boro, which makes and distributes skateboards, wheels and clothing. Sundays for Mr. Rodriguez, who lives in the Village, typically start with a trip to Rockaway Beach with his wife, Hiroko Rodriguez. LIZETTE ALVAREZ

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday with an article about General Motors efforts to change its corporate culture misidentified the automobile shown. It is a Camaro, not a Chevrolet Cruze.

title: Obama, in Japan, Says U.S. Will Study Status of a Marine Base on Okinawa
description: TOKYO  President Obama, seeking to mend fences with Japan, Americas most important Asian ally, announced Friday that he would establish a high-level working group on the contentious issue of the continuing presence of a Marine base on Okinawa.

title: Take That, E-Mail
description: Take That, E-Mail

title: Corrections
description: A report last Saturday in a roundup of vignettes about the cross section of people who attended the Yankees ticker-tape parade carried an erroneous byline. The entry about a student in Philadelphia who attended the parade in the spirit of his grandmother, a Yankees fan who died during the All-Star break, was by Ravi Somaiya  not by Daniel E. Slotnik, who contributed another entry.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Page 25 this weekend about the organist Cameron Carpenter misstates the time of his concert next Saturday at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin near Times Square. The performance starts at 3 p.m.; it is not Saturday evening.

title: Golfer Asks for Restraining Order on Doping Suspension
description: A lawyer for the suspended PGA Tour player Doug Barron said Friday that he was optimistic that a federal court judge would rule this weekend that Barron be allowed to compete in the second stage of PGA Tour qualifying school next week.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Page 8 this weekend, about deals and discounts on Caribbean hotels, using information from a publicist, refers incorrectly to the cost this year for the seven-nights-for-the-price-of-five deal at Parrot Cay in the Turks and Caicos. The price of $4,650 in January was the same as last years price  not higher. (The price quoted for last year, $3,875, omitted taxes and fees; with those, the cost comes to $4,650.)

title: Better to Have Loved and Lost? Dont Be So Sure
description: Its impossible to describe that sickening mix of restlessness and lethargy  that apathetic frenzy  that comes with the loss of love. Thats why screenplays, dramas, novels and, especially, poems are constantly written about such stuff.

title: Respect for Rape Victims
description: A promising bipartisan bill introduced this week in the Senate addresses a stubborn scandal: the enormous backlog of untested rape kits, which contain the physical evidence obtained from sexual assault victims.

title: Root Hold
description: This time of year, I nearly come to terms with entropy. The grass has stopped growing, and so has the wild mint and spotted touch-me-knot. The snow hasnt begun to fall. Most of the firewood is stacked, as is the hay. The thistle-down has blown, milkweed ditto. The leaves are down. Thats about as organized as it gets around here.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A listing on Page 9 this weekend with an article about Kingston, Jamaica, erroneously includes two specialties among those offered by Island Grill, a street vendor. While Island Grill serves jerk chicken and curry chicken, it does not offer goat and oxtail.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Closing Out a Season Farmers Want to Forget
description: MANCHESTER, Conn.

title: Connecticut: Profits Off
description: At Belltown Hill Orchards in South Glastonbury, Don Preli knows he was luckier than most farmers this year, but he still has some extra gray hair to show for it.

title: Lower Yield on L.I. Vines
description: When Jim Silver, general manager of Peconic Bay Winery, was asked about the 2009 growing season, he responded with a chuckle: If you could call it that.

title: Losing Shoppers in the City
description: This seasons inclement weather affected farmers markets as much as their crops, and customers lost early on never really came back. Just ask Michael Hurwitz, director of greenmarkets for the Council on the Environment of New York City.

title: New Jersey: A Bad August
description: With 500 acres of diverse crops and a quarter-century of experience, Kurt Alstede, owner of Alstede Farms in Chester, said hes accustomed to the kind of curveballs Mother Nature threw this season. Yes, its been weird, but weird is the norm, he said. Every year is measured by different extremes of one sort or another.

title: Westchester: Good Apples
description: Its a kind of year you put down the book on and dont want to open it again, said Bob Stuart, who has run his familys farm in Granite Springs since 1972.

title: Knicks Start Goes From Bad to Worst
description: Mike DAntoni cracked a postgame smile, in either disbelief or delusion. He saved his usual clichs and instead issued an early-season distress signal.

title: Terms of Digital Book Deal With Google Revised
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google and groups representing book publishers and authors filed a modified version of their controversial books settlement with a federal court on Friday. The changes would pave the way for other companies to license Googles vast digital collection of copyrighted out-of-print books, and might resolve its conflicts with European governments.

title: At Monmouth, Thomas Comes Close Enough to Hear Boos
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J.  Isiah Thomas is starting over, which is not the same as starting with a clean slate. But then, some slates require more scrubbing than others.

title: 400 Feared Dead in Cherry, Ill., Mine Disaster
description: Sunday, Nov. 14, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Mets Will Hire Backman to Manage Brooklyn Cyclones
description: After five years in exile, Wally Backman is making a return to a Major League Baseball affiliate with the Mets, the club that originally drafted him and brought him into professional ball. The Mets will name Backman, their fiery former second baseman, as manager of the Brooklyn Cyclones, their Class A affiliate, early next week.

title: A Troubling Time for Turtles
description: Climate change may deal the fatal blow to an animal that has lived in the Pacific for 150 million years.

title: Lysacek Heads American Field of Olympic Contenders
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  When the tall, dark and talented figure skater Evan Lysacek glided by a crowd of fans at Skate America during practice Friday, eyes and cheers followed him.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Kovalchuk on the Mend for Two More Goals
description: Six games on Friday the 13th  oooh  scary, kids! And four of them were interconference games, lone meetings of the season that carry a faint whiff of extraneousness. Oooh  even scarier!

title: China: Temple Web Site Attacked
description: The Web site of the famed Shaolin Temple was attacked this week by hackers looking to criticize the lifestyle of the temples abbot, Shi Yongxin, according to a report on Friday in China Daily, the official English-language newspaper. The temples home page was replaced with a fake home page early Wednesday that showed Mr. Shi sitting in yellow robes with text below him saying that he was apologizing for pursuing a material life. I traded the monasterys tranquillity and holy Buddhism for the fame of Shaolin and myself, said one line. Mr. Shi has led the temple, a venerable martial arts academy, for 10 years. He has established at least five businesses using the Shaolin name, and started a kung-fu reality television show in 2006, China Daily reported. EDWARD WONG

title: Earl Coleman, Publisher and Poet, Dies at 93
description: Earl M. Coleman was a fledgling short-story writer and poet fresh out of the Army when he got the idea for a custom translation business in 1946. At a poetry workshop he organized, he got to talking with two students, one a French teacher, the other a German engineer.

title: Jets Fans Guide to Week 10: Whom to Root For and Against
description: If the Jets (4-4) want to get into playoff contention, they cant worry about scoreboard watching.

title: Chabad-Lubavitch Emissaries Meet in Brooklyn
description: The annual International Conference of Emissaries brings Lubavitchers together.

title: 3 Wounded in Drive-By Shooting at Brooklyn Deli
description: A gunman in a sport utility vehicle opened fire on a group of people standing in a Brooklyn deli on Friday night, sending three people  one of them a pregnant woman  to a local hospital with gunshot wounds, the police said.

title: T.C.U.s Coach Patterson Had Rock Star Beginnings
description: In his reporting on the the rise of T.C.U. to a powerhouse program under Coach Gary Patterson, The Timess Thayer Evans discovered another side of the popular coach: musician.

title: Brian Jones Breaks Down Utah-T.C.U.
description: Brian Jones is a studio analyst for the CBS College Sports Network, which will televise the Utah-Texas Christian game at 7:30 on Saturday night.

title: Building a Living, Breathing Halfpipe
description: Pat Malendoski, of Planet Snowtools, describes the challenges of building and riding the halfpipe at Stratton Mountain, Vt., site of this years U.S. Open Snowboarding Championships.

title: Matt Kenseth, After Daytona
description: Matt Kenseth, who won the first two races of the Nascar season, talks about his Daytona victory and life off the track.

title: Lindsey Vonn
description: Lindsey Vonn, the defending World Cup overall and downhill champion, discusses her success, her family of cows and looks ahead to the 2010 Olympics in Vancouver.

title: Chicagos Rolfe Has One Eye on Seattle and One on Denmark
description: The Chicago Fire may play their last game of the season Saturday night and Chris Rolfe may play his last game for the Fire.

title: The Network Was Shocked
description: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Lou Dobbs quit his show at CNN. I know! Everyone at the network was shocked. Larry King said, Whos Lou Dobbs? What the hell is CNN?

title: The Political Landscape
description: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Hey, you guys its Friday the 13th. A lot of people are superstitious about the number 13. President Franklin Roosevelt refused to travel on the 13th of every month, would never host 13 guests at a dinner party either, and President Bush wasnt allowed to see any movie rated PG-13.

title: A Giant Spruce Tree
description: Monologue | Aired Friday night on CBS: Anyway, opening today, the movie 2012. Its about the end of the world, and fantastic computer generated special affects to show the destruction of every single living being and structure on the planet. The world is ending and the apocalypse has arrived and still no health-care reform. Well, thats too bad. Thats too bad.

title: So You Think You Can Mascot-Dance?
description: Video | This is all over the Web but details of who and where are scant:

title: His Historic Trip
description: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on NBC: President Obama has begun his historic trip to Asia. Excited about that. Very good. Next week, when President Obama is in China, hes going to hold a meeting where he takes questions from Chinese citizens. Isnt that cool? Yeah. Yeah. Their first question for Obama is expected to be, why would anyone have two daughters?

title: Leaders Will Delay Deal on Climate Change
description: SINGAPORE  President Obama and other world leaders have decided to put off the difficult task of reaching a climate change agreement at a global climate conference scheduled for next month, agreeing instead to make it the mission of the Copenhagen conference to reach a less specific politically binding agreement that would punt the most difficult issues into the future.

title: Impersonating Ron Jaworski
description: Imitation is flattery. Texans wide receiver David Anderson flatters Ron Jaworski, I think. Good stuff, via Awful Announcing.

title: Saturday Word: Fort Hood to Guantnamo
description: President Obama says he is confident justice will be served in the aftermath of the Fort Hood shootings, and has called for an immediate and thorough investigation that could bring accountability to those who failed to act on red flags.

title: Obama Backs Mandatory Sick Leave Law
description: This news from our colleague Steven Greenhouse, a Times reporter who posted on the Economix blog. Swine flu, he writes:

title: Katherine Koshetz, Oliver Price
description: Katherine Downes Koshetz and Oliver Garth Price were married Saturday at the Lanesborough Hotel in London. Tejal Patel, a superintendent registrar for the Westminster Registry Office, officiated.

title: Andr Caraco and David Azulay
description: Andr Diego Caraco and David Abbey Azulay affirmed their partnership on Saturday at the Parker Palm Springs, a resort in Palm Springs, Calif. A friend of the couple, Ricky Strauss, and a brother of Mr. Azulays, Ira, who became Universal Life ministers for the event, led the commitment ceremony.

title: In Cougar Territory, Cubs Take the Lead
description: IN the swirl of attention around older women coupling with younger men, it seems the guys are increasingly the ones on the prowl.

title: Robyn Appel, Adam Buchwalter
description: Robyn Beth Appel, the daughter of Cathy Appel and Dr. Arthur J. Appel of Marlboro, N.J., and Adam Seth Buchwalter, the son of Linda Buchwalter and David Buchwalter of Bayside, Queens, were married Saturday evening. Cantor Robert I. Weiner officiated at the Palace at Somerset Park, an event space in Somerset, N.J.

title: Nicola Mare, Dominick Usher
description: Nicola Carrie Mare and Dominick Wiley Usher were married Saturday at Alger House in Manhattan. The Rev. Sarah O. Usher, a minister with Alliance of Divine Love and an aunt of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: Aliza Rudman, Reid Stein
description: Aliza Deborah Rudman, a daughter of Miriam and Jack Rudman of Teaneck, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Reid Jordan Stein, a son of Barbara Brickman Stein and Sheldon I. Stein of Dallas. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at the Grand Hyatt in Manhattan.

title: There Are Seven in a Diagramless
description: You dont have to dig for the theme in this weekends diagramless crossword by Fred Piscop. Its right there in the clues, five of which are identical: There are seven  You can probably guess some of the answers right away, although you have to do some work to determine where to place them in the 17 by 17 grid.

title: Susan Aiello, Francis Lively Jr.
description: Susan Dever Aiello and Francis Patrick Lively Jr. were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Joseph P. Parkes, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. The couple met at Fordham, from which each received a law degree, he magna cum laude.

title: Millie Shin, Benjamin Tourtelot
description: Millie Ahrham Shin and Max Benjamin Tourtelot were married Friday. Rabbi Richard A. Davis officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan.

title: Melissa Gold and Adam Gottlieb
description: Melissa Greer Gold, a daughter of Terri J. Gold and Steven A. Gold of Hewlett Harbor, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Adam Brian Gottlieb, the son of Lila J. Gottlieb and David R. Gottlieb of Monroe Township, N.J., at Temple Bnai Sholom in Rockville Centre, N.Y. Rabbi Andrew Warmflash led the ceremony.

title: William Gorman, Joseph Nardone
description: William Bruce Gorman and Joseph John Nardone were married Saturday in Manchester, Vt. Cynthia A. Kilburn, a Vermont justice of the peace, officiated at the Equinox Golf Resort and Spa.

title: Your Dot: Turcios and Dougherty on Earth-Scale Ethics
description: In a recent comment on the discordant debate following my post on trends in record (hot and cold) temperatures in the United States, Jeff Turcios of New York made an interesting point:

title: High Costs Weigh on Troop Debate for Afghan War
description: While President Obamas decision about sending more troops to Afghanistan is primarily a military one, it also has substantial budget implications that are adding pressure to limit the commitment, senior administration officials say.

title: Discord in Milbridge
description: A small town in Maine, which once won acclaim for its efforts to welcome and integrate immigrants, is smarting from accusations of racism.

title: Chinas Role as Lender Alters Obamas Visit
description: When President Obama visits China for the first time on Sunday, he will, in many ways, be assuming the role of profligate spender coming to pay his respects to his banker.

title: Seeking a Shorter Path to New Drugs
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: Paying a Price for Playing in the Moment
description: Last week, Rex Ryan was asked about the line N.F.L. players and coaches must walk when violence in the game and its aftermath were being scrutinized. His answer was brief, but offered poignant perspective.

title: With Pacquiao-Cotto, Boxing Is Ready for a Rebirth, Again
description: LAS VEGAS  All week, as anticipation built for Saturday nights welterweight title fight between Manny Pacquiao and Miguel Cotto, those with a vested interest looked beyond.

title: Player Ratings: Slovakia 1, U.S.A. 0
description: The United States lost to Slovakia, 1-0, today in Bratislava. It was a close game but a disappointing result for the Americans, who were without several first-team regulars.

title: Paying a Price for the Thrill of the Hunt
description: IF a business school professor is running short on cash, there is a sure-fire solution: run a dollar auction game in class.

title: Home Builders (You Heard That Right) Get a Gift
description: ON Nov. 6, President Obama signed the Worker, Homeownership and Business Assistance Act of 2009 into law, extending unemployment benefits by 20 weeks and renewing the first-time homebuyer tax credit until next April.

title: U.S. Women Are Seeking a Contender for Skating
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  Fewer than three months remain until the opening ceremony of the Vancouver Olympics, but Rachael Flatt  the top-ranked American woman in figure skating  is not yet dreaming of becoming a star at the Winter Games.

title: Selling Lessons Online Raises Cash and Questions
description: Between Craigslist and eBay, the Internet is well established as a marketplace where one persons trash is transformed into anothers treasure. Now, thousands of teachers are cashing in on a commodity they used to give away, selling lesson plans online for exercises as simple as M&M sorting and as sophisticated as Shakespeare.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 15, 2009
description: Foreign policy will dominate this weeks Sunday talk shows as hosts and their guests discuss President Obamas trip to Asia and the issue of sending additional troops to Afghanistan, but they will also address the decision to hold terrorism trials in New York and the deadly shooting rampage at Fort Hood, Tex., more than a week ago.

title: A Celebrity Divorce Case Rocks the Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES  When the ceremonial first salvo had been tossed in McCourt v. McCourt, the principals in the divorce case, the Dodgers owner Frank McCourt and his erstwhile business partner Jamie McCourt, had at least put to rest a question that had dogged them since they bought the team nearly six years ago.

title: Job Security? Consider a Career in Health Care
description: For all the hand-wringing about the weaknesses of health care, one aspect of it has remained strong: its ability to provide jobs. In fact, health care employment has increased during the recession, while employment as a whole has declined, according to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Delicate Knee Surgery Saved Matsuis Season
description: When the Yankees fashion their diamond-crusted rings to commemorate their 2009 championship, they might consider making one for Dr. Scott Rodeo. Without his delicate surgical work, Hideki Matsui might not have been able to earn the World Series Most Valuable Player award.

title: Workplace Gossip? Keep It to Yourself
description: IM a technical service assistant at PrintingForLess.com, an online printing company based in Livingston, Mont. Im part of a three-person team. We provide quality control for print jobs, call local customers to notify them their orders are ready and send sample packs to potential clients. We also help other departments with special projects and take turns sitting at the front desk, greeting customers and answering the phone.

title: Is There a Method in Cellphone Madness?
description: HERES a consolation prize to the millions who recoil in bafflement from cellphone companies labyrinthine price plans, with their ever more intricate arrays of minutes, messages and megabytes: Economists dont understand them, either.

title: At Bloomberg, Modest Strategy to Rule the World
description: PLOPPED in a white leather chair in a small office in Bloomberg L.P.s Manhattan headquarters, Andrew Lack knows exactly how to articulate the aspirations of this 28-year-old media and technology company.

description: Before millions of television viewers, under the dewy and beneficent gaze of Oprah Winfrey, the two of them traded moony glances. They held hands. They spoke the language of sonnets and torch songs.

title: Big Ideas in a Small Room
description: WHEN I was about 10 years old, my father, an endodontist, bought a Radio Shack-brand TRS Model III computer in order to track billing. At first, it stayed in a guest bedroom that doubled as an office. Within a few months, I had moved it into my bedroom.

title: A Fulbright in Nigeria That Turned Into a Show
description: Many things have happened since Dan Hoyle performed in the premiere of Tings Dey Happen, his incendiary and brilliant solo show about Nigerian oil politics, nearly three years ago at the compact theater the Marsh in San Francisco.

title: Are You a Tigger, or an Eeyore?
description: This interview with Mindy Grossman, chief executive of HSN Inc., was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: No Parade for Hans
description: BERLIN  Often, as I have passed through the main train station here in the German capital, I have seen the sad, lone figure of a soldier, heavy pack on his back, waiting for a train like the rest of us, but separated from the crowd by the uniform he wears. No one would stop to thank him for his service or to ask whether he had been deployed to Afghanistan.

title: Apple Wouldnt Risk Its Cool Over a Gimmick, Would It?
description: SOME of the best-loved technology on the planet is how Apple describes its products when recruiting new employees. Its a fair description.

Rabbi Norman Janis officiated at the Harvard Faculty Club in Cambridge, Mass.

description: Nicola Alexandra Darrach, a daughter of Jane B. Darrach and Robert D. Darrach of Etna, N.H., was married Saturday to Matthew Edgar Ellar, a son of Michele A. Ellar and David J. Ellar, of Kingston, England. Magistrate Crawford E. McKee officiated at Green Turtle Club in Green Turtle Cay in the Bahamas.

Sebelius and K. Gary Sebelius of Topeka, Kan. The Rev. C. Read Heydt, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Gasparilla Inn and Club in Boca Grande, Fla.

title: Memoir Is Palins Payback to McCain Campaign
description: Going Rogue, the title of Sarah Palins erratic new memoir, comes from a phrase used by a disgruntled McCain aide to describe her going off-message during the presidential campaign: among other things, for breaking with the campaign over its media strategy and its decision to pull out of Michigan, and for speaking out about reports that the Republican Party had spent more than $150,000 on fancy designer duds for her and her family.

title: In Assessing Agassi, the Title Tells It All
description: Andre Agassi. The name is familiar. Seems to me I caught a glimpse of him on the tube the other day, or saw a snippet about him in the paper.

title: Five Thoughts On Early Games
description: 5. The Heisman Trophy race is even more muddled with Central Floridas upset of Houston. Houston quarterback Case Keenum had decent numbers, 33 of 57 for three touchdowns and an interception, but its unlikely a quarterback could win the Heisman after his team lost to Texas El-Paso and U.C.F. There had been a strong argument coming into the game that Keenum had been the most outstanding player in the country this year. But fair or not, team success has become a huge factor in the Heisman Trophy race.

title: In House, Many Spoke With One Voice: Lobbyists
description: WASHINGTON  In the official record of the historic House debate on overhauling health care, the speeches of many lawmakers echo with similarities. Often, that was no accident.

title: A Contemplation of War
description: It was a week to think about war, to talk about war; to thank those who fight  and grieve for those who might have had they not been gunned down on their own Army post in their own country. President Obama traveled to Fort Hood in Texas on Tuesday to stand as national eulogist for the 13 killed there, even as debate stirred over what to call the massacre: The act of a terrorist? The murderous rage of a misfit? On Wednesday, Veterans Day, Mr. Obama was at Arlington, walking among graves where grief remains fresh and meeting mourners. Later he met with his war council. Should he send 30,000 more troops to Afghanistan? Ten thousand? And on Friday, a reminder of what started it all: an announcement that five accused plotters in the 9/11 attacks would be tried in Manhattan.

title: The Evolution of the God Gene
description: In the Oaxaca Valley of Mexico, the archaeologists Joyce Marcus and Kent Flannery have gained a remarkable insight into the origin of religion.

title: How Old Is Old Enough?
description: This past week the Supreme Court heard arguments about whether children should ever be sentenced to life without parole for crimes that dont involve murder.

title: Quotations of the Week
description: Im sure there are a lot of people sitting in the shade at the Aspen Institute  my brother being one of them  who will tell you what the ideal plan is. Great, fascinating. You have the art of the possible measured against the ideal.

title: When Sartre Talked to Crabs (It Was Mescaline)
description: In a conversation in 1971 with John Gerassi, a political science professor at Queens College in New York, Jean-Paul Sartre recalled an experience with drugs in 1929 while attending the cole Normale Suprieure, where he met Simone de Beauvoir, also known as Castor. Talking With Sartre: Conversations and Debates, a selection of interviews from the 70s, is being published this month by Yale University Press. Here is an excerpt from Harpers:

title: Can Public Aid Really Help Business?
description: THE global financial crisis is prompting huge government interventions to stimulate the economies of the United States and many other nations. The burning question is this: Can public-sector initiatives in the private sector be successful, or are they inevitably doomed to failure?

description: Who knows where the time goes?

title: James R. Lilley, 81, Envoy in Tiananmen Era, Dies
description: WASHINGTON  James R. Lilley, a former intelligence officer and ambassador to China who viewed that country with a rare blend of pragmatism and love because of his childhood there, died Thursday at a Washington hospital. He was 81.

title: Norwegian, 18, Is Youngest to Be Ranked No. 1 at Chess
description: The chess world has a new No. 1 player, Magnus Carlsen of Norway, and he is only 18 years old  the youngest player ever to hold the rank.

description: The health care bill passed by the House isnt good for what ails Americans or their country, Representative Mark Kirk of Illinois said on Saturday on behalf of the Republican Party.

description: SHANGHAI  President  Obamas first official visit to China brings him this weekend to a country that, despite the global downturn, is increasingly wealthy, confident, ambitious  and perplexing.

title: Prime Number
description: 12.4: The percentage of workers in unions last year, down from 20.1 percent in 1983, according to "The Changing Face of Labor, 1983-2008," a study by the Center for Economic Policy Research in Washington. Union membership is far less blue collar and factory-based than it was during its glory days. Thirty-eight percent of union workers now have four-year college degrees. Just 11 percent work in manufacturing, down from nearly 30 percent in the 1980s. Women account for more than 45 percent of the unionized work force. And nearly half of all union members work in public-sector jobs, up from 34 percent in 1983.

title: In Congress, a Predicament for Abortion Supporters
description: The abortion issue has put members of Congress who support abortion rights in a quandary over the health care legislation.

title: Investigators Study Tangle of Clues on Fort Hood Suspect
description: WASHINGTON  When Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan took his two handguns and headed for Fort Hood on Nov. 5, he left behind in his spartan apartment his new business cards. Now they are one more clue for investigators of the 13 killings he is charged with, hinting at the road not taken.

title: Broaching Birth Control With Afghan Mullahs
description: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan  The mullahs stared silently at the screen. They shifted in their chairs and fiddled with pencils. Koranic verses flashed above them, but the topic was something that made everybody a little uncomfortable.

title: Forest People May Lose Home in Kenyan Plan
description: MARASHONI, Kenya  With the stroke of a pen, the last of Kenyas honey hunters may soon be homeless.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Devils Displace Capitals Atop East
description: Twelve games on Saturday, including a matinee in Ottawa. Heres an interesting factoid: since the N.H.L. installed the postgame penalty-shootout tiebreaker at the start of the 2005-6 season, the Senators have done worse at it than any other team. Going into Saturdays game against the Rangers, they had won 12 shootouts and lost 24. What would happen if they got into another? Hmm

title: Portrait of 9/11 Jackal Emerges as He Awaits Trial
description: WASHINGTON  Not long after he was rousted from bed and seized in a predawn raid in Pakistan in March 2003, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed gave his captors two demands: He wanted a lawyer, and he wanted to be taken to New York.

description: Tell her shes a foolShell say, yes, I knowBut I love him soAnd thats how it goesWhen a woman loves a man 115 Across

title: Unusual Partners Study Divisive Jerusalem Site
description: JERUSALEM  At the heart of this contested city, the holy site known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as Haram al-Sharif, or Noble Sanctuary, has become, for many, the epicenter of the conflict between Israel, the Palestinians and the wider Muslim world.

title: Group Warns of Failing Effort to Manage Tuna and Sharks
description: Officials from countries fishing for tuna, sharks and other denizens of the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas are gathered in Recife, Brazil, where they are wrapping up the 21st annual session of talks under an international agreement aimed at restoring depleted stocks. There are few signs that science is guiding their decisions, observers said on Saturday.

title: Penn Knuckles Down and Harvard Buckles
description: BOSTON  Harvard needed to shove aside the Penn defense late in Saturdays game to gain less than a yard, score a touchdown and extend the suspense. But these are precisely the situations in which the Quakers are at their surliest.

title: Mock Funeral for Venice Dramatizes Flight of Residents From Citys Heart
description: VENICE  At high noon on Saturday, a gondola bearing a hot-pink plywood coffin decked with yellow flowers made its way down the Grand Canal. Onlookers watched from the shore and shouted greetings from the Rialto Bridge before the boat alighted nearby in front of the Venice city hall.

title: 2 U.S. Soldiers and a Contractor Are Killed in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two American service members and an American contractor were killed in two separate bombing attacks in Afghanistan on Friday, according to a statement from a NATO spokesman.

title: Maine Town Is Riven by Housing Dispute
description: MILBRIDGE, Me.  Down a rural road where wood smoke spirals from chimneys in the settling twilight, a five-acre lot thick with spruce trees is the unlikely site of a dream deferred.

title: Changing Uniforms to Help Veterans
description: On Nov. 10, 2004, Staff Sgt. Dan Nevins was on a combat mission in Iraq when an improved explosive device detonated beneath his vehicle, killing the driver and necessitating the amputation of Nevinss left leg.

title: Having Little, but Thanking America for Every Bit
description: The small apartment in Midwood, Brooklyn, is sunlit and tidy, with unmistakable touches of home. Photographs on bookshelves and walls depict long lives, mostly lived somewhere else. A large television shows programs in Russian. And on the days when his knobby fingers are not swollen with arthritis, Lev Rotnitskiy, 86, hammers tunes on a piano while his wife sings.

title: Obama Backers Fear Opportunities to Reshape Judiciary Are Slipping Away
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has sent the Senate far fewer judicial nominations than former President George W. Bush did in his first 10 months in office, deflating the hopes of liberals that the White House would move quickly to reshape the federal judiciary after eight years of Republican appointments.

title: A Feast for Stomach and Eyes
description: By all rights, the narrow public plaza carved out of Broadway between 38th and 39th Streets should have been empty last week beyond the scurrying city walkers, their jackets buttoned and their collars turned high against a damp November chill. But Monday was an unseasonable 70 and sunny, and the makeshift pedestrian mall, with its tiny chairs and tables, was the perfect place to enjoy what easily might have been the last outdoor lunch of the year.

title: Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Report
description: Vistas: Lands End | A recovering techie finds a new way of looking at things  mostly avian things  when she goes to Lands End. Noreen Weedens preferred vista is a place where she goes 20 times a year and where, over time, she can see different moments in the migrations and life cycles of the birds she loves.

title: Fight Over Fischers Estate Is Taking Shape in Iceland
description: Bobby Fischer died in January 2008, but his long, strange story is not over.

title: A Once and Future Bay Area Redistricting Conundrum
description: Phillip Burton, the legendary San Francisco congressman, famously called it his contribution to modern art. Nearly 30 years later, Burtons quip is perhaps better remembered than the piece he was describing: a congressional district he drew after the 1980 census to keep a seat in the United States House of Representatives safe for his younger brother, John.

title: Universities Turn to Consultants to Trim Budgets
description: When Holden Thorp, the chancellor of the University of North Carolina, was looking for ways to cut the universitys budget, he did what many executives in private industry do  hired a management consultant.

description: Want a swine flu vaccination at a free clinic this weekend? Get in line.

title: Seals in San Diego Get to Remain at the Beach
description: SAN DIEGO  A long-running legal battle over whether to evict a colony of harbor seals that inexplicably took over a popular beach here like a gaggle of tourists overstaying their welcome appeared closer than ever to ending Friday when a judge ruled that they can stay put.

title: Belbin and Agosto Dont Need a Map to Excel at Skate America
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  The ice dancers Tanith Belbin and Benjamin Agosto of the United States did not even know where Moldova was when they signed up to perform a Moldovian folk dance in the original dance this season. But geography lessons were not necessary for them to nail the dance Saturday at Skate America.

title: One-Handed Player Makes Manhattan Debut
description: Kevin Laue, the 6-foot-11 freshman center born with a left arm that extends just below the elbow, made his regular-season college basketball debut in Manhattans 70-58 victory over the New Jersey Institute of Technology on Saturday at Draddy Gymnasium.

title: Female Heart Down the Homestretch
description: Racetrack touts and gamblers  and equine savvy feminists  are celebrating an extraordinary year in thoroughbred racing. It has been dominated and galvanized by not one, but two females  the mesmerizing filly Rachel Alexandra and the overpowering mare Zenyatta. Both are undefeated in supreme tests. Both displayed thrilling championship form in beating fields of the worlds best males, Triple Crown leg winners included.

title: Bidding on Madoffs Trove While Helping Victims
description: A blue Mets jacket that once belonged to Bernard L. Madoff was sold for $14,500 at a government auction at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers in Midtown Manhattan on Saturday, while a ring buoy from his yacht went for $7,500.

title: Reform and Medical Costs
description: Americans are deeply concerned about the relentless rise in health care costs and health insurance premiums. They need to know if reform will help solve the problem. The answer is that no one has an easy fix for rising medical costs. The fundamental fix  reshaping how care is delivered and how doctors are paid in a wasteful, dysfunctional system  is likely to be achieved only through trial and error and incremental gains.

So why, he asked, was I surprised when Bloomberg only squeaked by such a marginal opponent?

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about the late-season leader for the Nascar Sprint Cup Series points title misspelled, in some copies, the given name of the driver aiming for his fourth consecutive title and misstated the drivers final position in the 2005 standings. He is Jimmie Johnson, not Jimmy, and he finished fifth, not second. The chart also misstated, in some editions, Johnsons points total in 2009, with three races remaining. It was 6,248  not 6,284.

title: Dr. Tererai Trent
description: My Sunday column tells the extraordinary story of Tererai Trent, who grew up impoverished in northern Zimbabwe and was able  with the help of Heifer International and a number of other aid groups  to get an education. Next month she will receive her PhD from Western Michigan University.

title: Corrections
