description: Following up the post on Walter Paytons tribute:

title: No Formal Climate Deal in Copenhagen, Leaders Say
description: World leaders, clearly trying to limit political damage given the lack of progress in climate-treaty talks, made it next to official over the weekend that no new binding accord would emerge in Copenhagen next month. [UPDATE 9:14 p.m.: We have a story examining how an end to hopes of sealing the deal on a new climate treaty reflects the constraints on President Obama and the political hazards he faces in tackling this issue.] Meeting with the Danish prime minister on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Singapore, President Obama and other leaders said Copenhagen would be a steppingstone toward some final eventual accord, as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton had described the impending session last week. (Presumably the pressure came mainly from the two dominant players in the global greenhouse, the United States and China.)

title: The Onion on Oversensitive Quarterbacks
description: A few weeks ago, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin suggested that Eli Manning and the offense were overthinking defensive coverages, too preoccupied with the chess game before the snap.

title: In Punishing Fashion, Pacquiao Makes History
description: LAS VEGAS  Manny Pacquiao was fighting for those struggling in his home country, the Philippines, who were ravaged recently by a trio of typhoons. He was fighting for his family  for his father, who made a rare appearance  and for the millions of fans who follow his every move.

title: Kramnik Wins Tal Memorial, Carlsen Claims No. 1 Ranking
Hollywood Gets Honest at Governors Awards
description: The first annual Governors Awards banquet, created to bestow career-oriented Oscars on the worthy without taking up time on the annual awards broadcast, was loving, lustrous and long.

title: Run, Dont Walk, to Macaos Big Race
description: Gambling may be Macaos major activity for risk-takers, but every November, the city goes outdoors for a different set of thrills: the Macao Grand Prix, which runs this year from Nov. 19 to 22. The Macao GP is a Formula 3 race, essentially a feeder circuit for the elite F1 series. Although F3 cars are not as advanced or as fast as F1 cars, theres plenty of what you expect to see from spectator racing: sleek cars traveling at ridiculous speeds, as well as the inevitable crash or two. And the tickets will set you back far less than a few losing hands at the table games at the Venetian.

title: In China, Obama to Press for Tough Stance on Iran
description: SHANGHAI  President Obama, fresh from making progress in his efforts to get Russia on board for possible tough new sanctions against Iran, arrived in China on Sunday, where he will attempt the even more difficult task of prodding Chinas leaders to get tough on Iran.

title: Peyton Manning vs. Bill Belichick
description: Were not above hype on the Fifth Down  especially when its justified. So here are a few links to Patriots-versus-Colts articles in anticipation of tonights game:

title: Early Word: China, Detainees and K.S.M.
description: After a whirlwind Friday, its been a relatively quiet weekend in Washington. President Obama lands in Shanghai this morning (if youre in the United States) or tonight (in China). On Monday he will meet with the citys mayor and China President Hu Jintao.

title: Pacquiao Claims Seventh Title
description: Manny Pacquiao defeated Miguel Cotto to win the World Boxing Organization welterweight title.

title: Directors Suite
description: At home with the director Brett Morgen in his house on the beach in Rockaway, Queens.

title: Live Analysis: Jaguars 24, Jets 22
description: New York Times writers Joe Lapointe and William C. Rhoden are at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., and will provide in-game analysis of the Jaguars-Jets game, with an assist from Connor Ennis at the newspapers offices in Manhattan.

title: Giuliani Criticizes Terror Trials in New York
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, mayor of New York at the time of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, said on Sunday that the Obama administrations decision to try Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described mastermind of the attacks, in a civilian court in Manhattan would unnecessarily cost millions of dollars for security, create legal advantages for the defense and symbolically deny that the United States is at war with terrorism.

title: 2010 Suzuki Kizashi
description: While other Japanese automakers have grown into the American landscape, Suzuki has a profile so low that its products are not even on the radar of many Americans.

title: Collectible Saabs
description: As Saab engineers shifted from aeronautics to automobiles, they introduced some unorthodox approaches.

title: Shuttle to Haul Spare Parts to Space
description: The space shuttle has often been called a pickup truck to orbit, and the next flight of the shuttle Atlantis, scheduled for launching Monday afternoon, lives up to that description.

title: Swedish Trial: A Whole Lot of Squeezing Going On
description: The diagramed deal occurred during the Swedish trial played in Stockholm on Oct. 31 and Nov. 1. It was sent to me by Roland Wald, who was kibitzing at the right table at the right time.

title: 2012 Opening Earns $65 Million
description: After a quiet stretch at the North American box office, Hollywood discovered once again that audiences want to see the world and a cast of B-list actors ripped into pieces in a blitz of computer-generated effects.

title: Police Kill One Man and Wound Another at Brooklyn Bar Fight
description: Undercover police officers responding to a report of a brawl at a Brooklyn bar early Sunday fatally shot a 43-year-old security guard and wounded a 19-year-old man, both of whom were holding guns, the police said.

title: Michael Feinstein to Lead Jazz at Lincoln Center Series
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center is bringing classic American popular song into its fold with the appointment of the singer and pianist Michael Feinstein as director of its new popular music series. Mr. Feinstein will create three programs as well as a family event, all focusing on the relationship between jazz and songwriting, for the spring of 2011. The concerts will be in the Allen Room in Frederick P. Rose Hall, at Broadway and 60th Street.

title: As Optimism Rises, N.J.I.T. Is Hoping Wins Will Follow
description: The final buzzer sounded inside Manhattan Colleges Draddy Gymnasium, and the big green scoreboard hanging over the court laid out the progress in red numerals: 70 under the heading Jaspers, 58 under the heading Guest.

title: Dance and Art Play Off Each Other
description: BEACON, N.Y.  For the past two years the Merce Cunningham Dance Company graced the galleries of Dia:Beacon here, where the site-specific Beacon Events series was born. Now the torch has been passed to the Trisha Brown Dance Company, which, over the weekend, presented a sharply edited program of Ms. Browns early works (pieces created between 1968 and 1975) that took audiences on a fast-paced trip through seven galleries. The residency will include appearances in February and May.

title: JPMorgan Faces New Suit in Alabama Countys Woes
description: Even after a $700 million settlement with the federal government, JPMorgan Chase still faces troubles in Alabama, The New York Timess Mary Williams Walsh reported.

title: Mario and Luigi, Back to the Wii: The More Players, the Deadlier
description: Heres a warning that I hope will prevent a lot of frustration: Unless you are a serious console gamer with skills honed over years of play, New Super Mario Bros. Wii is probably not the game you think it is.

title: Burdened by Debt, MGM Puts Itself Up for Sale
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is back on the block, The New York Timess Brooks Barnes reported.

title: Some Kibitzing for Brahms From the Cape Verde Islands
description: For all the wondrous diversity Carnegie Hall has injected into its programming in recent years, the heart of its traditional mission lies in a few series of concerts each season: extended visits by the worlds great orchestras. The Berlin Philharmonic, any time it chooses to appear, must rank near the top.

title: Czechs Velvet Revolution Paved by Plastic People
description: PRAGUE  It has been called the Velvet Revolution, a revolution so velvety that not a single bullet was fired.

title: In Search of a Father in Search of the Blues
description: Music critics' lives  a blur of deadlines, headphone cords and modest payments by the word  dont often inspire much fascination.

title: Bengals Win With Little Offense, but Plenty of Control
description: PITTSBURGH  These are the new Cincinnati Bengals.

title: New CDs
description: NORAH JONES The Fall(Blue Note)

title: Bidding on Madoffs Trove While Helping Victims
description: A blue Mets jacket that once belonged to Bernard L. Madoff was sold for $14,500 at a government auction at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers in Midtown Manhattan on Saturday, while a ring buoy from his yacht went for $7,500.

title: I Hear America Singing, in Syncopation
description: Ragtime has lost weight since it was last on Broadway. The judiciously pared-down production that opened Sunday night at the Neil Simon Theater is a sprinting sylph compared to the opulence-bloated show that went under the same name a decade ago.

title: For Madoff Auction, Even Jewels Lack Luster
description: They came to see evil. Instead, they found a creamer shaped like a cow.

title: Rodge Cohen, the Trauma Surgeon of Wall Street
description: Earlier this fall, after a busy month of shuttling to Washington, H. Rodgin Cohen, the dean of Wall Street lawyers, settled into a table upstairs at the Red Hat, a favorite restaurant overlooking the Hudson River here in the Westchester village where he lives. He and his wife of 40 years, Barbara, ordered modestly (and identically)  salad, swordfish steak, glasses of Chardonnay  and the table talk was undemanding in a casual, nerdy way, The New York Timess Alan Feuer writes.

title: Sound and Vision: A Piano Recital With a Multimedia Heart
description: The remarkable Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes is a self-effacing, substantive and completely unflashy artist. You would not peg him as someone curious to explore multimedia and reinvent the piano recital.

title: Citi Sells Stake in Japanese Call Center to Bain
description: Citigroup said Sunday that it was selling its controlling stake in the leading call center operator in Japan, Bellsystem24, to the private equity firm Bain Capital in a deal that values the operation at $1.1 billion, The Associated Press reported.

title: Yowling and Yelping: Back-in-the-Day Soul Hits Become of the Moment Again
description: Some record collectors have moved from accumulating vinyl to salvaging careers. The Ponderosa Stomp in New Orleans, Dig Deeper in Brooklyn and the Light in the Attic label in Seattle have all tracked down fondly remembered names to perform again. On Friday night the Numero Group  a Chicago label that delves into obscure archives for meticulously researched reissues  brought its dapper, potent Eccentric Soul Revue to the Music Hall of Williamsburg in Brooklyn.

title: Law Seeks to Ban Misuse of Genetic Testing
description: The most important new antidiscrimination law in two decades  the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act  will take effect in the nations workplaces next weekend, prohibiting employers from requesting genetic testing or considering someones genetic background in hiring, firing or promotions.

title: Heisman Watch: The Picture Doesnt Get Any Clearer
description: Tim Tebow, Florida quarterback

title: And the Answer Is
description: Hi. Patrick Merrell back behind the Wordplay desk, which Ill be manning through Sunday. Todays puzzle is a debut by the team of James Mulhern and Ashton Anderson. Is it just a coincidence that the four theme entries revolve around the beginning of Mr. Andersons last name? If so, theyve compensated for that by giving Mr. Mulhern first billing.

title: Maradona Suspended for 2 Months
description: Diego Maradona, the coach of Argentinas national team, was banished for two months Sunday by soccers worldwide governing body because of his expletive-laced tirade unleashed after a victory that qualified the two-time champions for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.

title: Floridas Bizarro Season
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  In a fitting slice of symmetry that intertwines this most bizarre college football season and its top-ranked team, Florida is being perceived in some circles as an underachiever. The Gators are 10-0, finished the SEC regular season undefeated for the first time under Urban Meyer and are a favorite to win back-to-back national titles.

title: Ryan Reynolds to Read From the Book of Loggins
description: The heartthrob actor Ryan Reynolds (The Proposal, Definitely, Maybe) will make his debut next week in the New York edition of the theatrical comedy Celebrity Autobiography: In Their Own Words, where stars read humorous snippets from memoirs of the entertainment worlds A-list through D-list.

title: Common Grounds for Clinton and Palin?
description: Well skip straight to the obvious joke.

title: Its the Scent That Tickles the Memory
description: Only recently have companies begun assigning smells to everyday products: frangipani-scented sewing threads, tires that smell like roses. A paper soon to be published in the Journal of Consumer Research confirms the wisdom of this tactic, finding that scented products linger in the memory.

title: Hobbes in Hebrew: The Religion Question
description: Leviathan is arguably the most influential work of Western political thought, and one of the most analyzed. Yet the first full Hebrew translation of Thomass Hobbess work was only published last month. While the first two parts have long been available in translation, the third and fourth parts  in which Hobbes addresses religion and the state  had not appeared in Hebrew.

title: Jaguars Defeat Jets
description: A field goal as time expired gave the Jaguars a 24-22 victory over the Jets.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Canes Take 2 Points for First Time in 15 Games
description: Three games on Sunday, led off by a battle of bottom-dwellers in Raleigh. Home teams listed first:

title: Experts Outline Hurdles for Defense of Hasan
description: Defending the man accused of premeditated murder in the Nov. 5 shooting rampage at Fort Hood is the kind of test that many lawyers dread, and that some live for.

title: Prefatory Matters
description: Introductory posts are never terribly enthralling, so Ill try to keep this brief. To anyone who followed my blogging at The Atlantic, thanks for showing up again. To anyone who didnt, welcome  I hope youll stick around. And a heartfelt thanks to everyone at The Times who helped get this page off the ground.

title: Losing a Chess Match, and a Game
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets lost to the Jacksonville Jaguars, 24-22, on Sunday on a last-second field goal that ended a surreal two-minute drill filled with cold calculation by both sides.

title: Hollywood Dinner Has Oscars on Menu
description: LOS ANGELES  Lauren Bacall admitted she had a thing for Gregory Peck, but his wife got in the way. Kirk Douglas said he tried to seduce Ms. Bacall, but she wasnt interested. Warren Beatty confessed that all his best stories seemed to wind up serving himself.

title: Illinois Site May Be Path to Closing Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  Top Illinois Democrats on Sunday wholeheartedly embraced the idea of sending terrorism suspects from Guantnamo Bay to a maximum-security prison about 150 miles west of Chicago, raising the possibility of a major breakthrough in the Obama administrations efforts to close the military detention facility in Cuba.

title: Art Prices (and Mood) Inch Back Up
description: Oh the drama of auctions: the salesrooms packed with smartly dressed collectors; the tension of having to decide in seconds whether to drop another million dollars on an artwork or let it go; the steely smile of the auctioneer trying gently to squeeze another hundred thousand from bidders. And the final results of the last two weeks of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art auctions in New York, which saw the return of a surprising number of collectors, their wallets open, but only if the price was right.

title: MSNBC Presses Obama on Campaign Promises
description: If President Obama happened to glance at The Rachel Maddow Show last Monday, he might have winced.

title: Reunion of the Group That Put Atlanta on the Rap Map
description: Depending on who is writing the history book, 1995 was either a great or frustrating time for Goodie Mob. That year the Atlanta foursome released its debut masterpiece, Soul Food (LaFace), one of its citys defining hip-hop documents. The rest of hip-hop, though, was preoccupied with sounds from the coasts. While New York and Los Angeles were slugging it out, Atlanta was building its infrastructure, one that would eventually take over the genre.

title: Footnote
description: Clint Eastwood has been made a commander in the French order the Legion of Honor, The Associated Press reported. At a ceremony hosted by President Nicolas Sarkozy, Mr. Eastwood, 79, was cited for his body of work, his longevity and his ability to delight audiences around the globe. This isnt his first French title. In 2007 he was made a knight of the Legion of Honor by the president at the time, Jacques Chirac. The new appointment raises him to Grade 3 on the legions five-grade scale.

title: Winnie-the-Pooh Returns to Court
description: The estate of Stephen Slesinger, the producer who acquired licensing rights to the Winnie-the-Pooh works and characters from A. A. Milne in 1930, has been suing Disney for rights infringement since 1991, and isnt stopping now, according to BBC News. After a Los Angeles judge dismissed a case brought by the estate in 2004 (on the grounds that its legal team illegally obtained documents by trespassing on Disney property) and a federal judge dismissed another this September (ruling that Mr. Slesinger had transferred all rights to Disney), lawyers filed papers in Los Angeles last week arguing that Disney owes the estate hundreds of millions of dollars in royalties. The suit says that Disney combined profits from Pooh and Mickey Mouse merchandise, thereby concealing revenues owed to the estate. Describing the lawsuit as baffling, a Disney spokeswoman said that the issues had been settled with the September ruling.

title: Another Celebrity for Autobiography
description: The actor Ryan Reynolds will make his debut next Monday in the New York edition of Celebrity Autobiography, the theatrical comedy in which actors read snippets from memoirs of the entertainment worlds A- through D-list. Given Mr. Reynoldss popularity in films like The Proposal and on Sexiest Man Alive lists, two shows have been scheduled next Monday, one at 7:30 p.m. and one at 9:30 p.m. at the Triad Theater in Manhattan. Mr. Reynolds is to read from Kenny Logginss Unimaginable Life: Lessons Learned on the Path of Love. Other performers that night include Rachel Dratch, Carol Kane, Sherri Shepherd, Michael Urie and Kristen Wiig.

title: More Recovery Time for Conductor
description: The conductor Leonard Slatkin, who collapsed after leading the Rotterdam Philharmonic in the Netherlands on Nov. 1 and underwent emergency surgery to unblock a clogged artery, has canceled appearances with the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, for which he is music director, for the next two weeks on the advice of his doctors, The Detroit Free Press reported. Mr. Slatkin, 65, is back in America with his doctors, and theyve said, Go rest and come back at the end of November, and well do a check-up,said R. Douglas Sheldon, Mr. Slatkins manager, adding, We anticipate this will go smoothly and hell be back on the podium soon. Andrew Grams will replace Mr. Slatkin in performances of Ginastera, Michel Camilo, Berlioz and Debussy this week, and the Norwegian conductor Arild Remmereit will take his place conducting concerts of Bach, Mozart, Hindemith and Ravel on Nov. 27 through Nov. 29. Mr. Slatkin is expected to return for the world premiere performances of Wlad Marhulets Concerto for Klezmer Clarinet in December.

title: Iranian Musician Declares His Protest
description: Speaking out against the disputed presidential elections in Iran in June and the government crackdown that followed protests, the popular Iranian singer and composer Mohammad Reza Shajarian, left, a master of traditional Persian music,  has asked that state radio and television stop broadcasting his work, The Associated Press reported. After what happened, I said no way and threatened to file a complaint against them if they continued to use my music, Mr. Shajarian said in an interview with the A.P. Though the broadcast services complied with his request, the government has responded to hundreds of other artist protests  which have included boycotting state-sponsored awards and appearing at international events wearing green, the color of the opposition  by banning their work, detaining them or forbidding them to travel. Narges Kalhor, the daughter of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejads culture adviser, Mehdi Kalhor, sought asylum in Germany last month out of fear of repercussions after screening her documentary Rake, which was inspired by the human rights violations she says routinely occur in Iran.

title: Following Up Oasis
description: Liam Gallagher, former lead vocalist of Oasis, said that he and other members of the recently defunct band were forming a new group, Reuters reported. Not Oasis  Oasis is done, Mr. Gallagher said during a radio interview. Everyone except for Noel, he said, referring to his brother, Noel Gallagher, who left the group in August claiming he had been forced to leave through intimidation by his band mates. The new band will include most of the old one: Oasiss rhythm guitarist Colin Archer, bassist Andy Bell and drummer Chris Sharrock. Liam Gallagher founded Oasis in 1991, and a short time later Noel joined as lead guitarist and main songwriter.

title: Lou Dobbs to Visit OReilly
description: Lou Dobbs, below, the outspoken CNN anchor who abruptly resigned from his job last week, is scheduled to appear as a guest on Monday nights edition of The OReilly Factor on Fox News, Variety reported. Fox News said he planned to discuss his on-air resignation as well as his opposition to illegal immigration. Though the interview may heighten suspicions that Mr. Dobbs is being courted by Fox, representatives from the network said there had been no discussions. Jonathan Klein, president of CNNs domestic operations, agreed to release Mr. Dobbs from his Lou Dobbs Tonight contract after he refused to tone down his rhetorical style.

title: In the Wings
description: The Actors Theater of Louisville, Ky., has announced the lineup of its 34th annual Humana Festival of New American Plays. Full-length plays will include Ground by Lisa Dillman; The Cherry Sisters Revisited by Dan OBrien, with music by Michael Friedman; Fissures (lost and found) by Steve Epp, Cory Hinkle, Dominic Orlando, Dominique Serrand, Deborah Stein and Victoria Stewart; Phoenix by Scott Organ; Sirens by Deborah Zoe Laufer; and The Method Gun, created by Rude Mechs and written by Kirk Lynn. The festival runs Feb. 21 to March 28. ... Sarah Paulson (The Glass Menagerie) will join Linda Lavin (The Tale of the Allergists Wife) in Manhattan Theater Clubs Broadway premiere of Donald Marguliess Collected Stories, to be directed by Lynne Meadow. Ms. Paulson will play Lisa, a young protge of a celebrated New York author (Ms. Lavin). Previews begin April 6, with an opening scheduled for April 28 at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater. ... Debbie Reynolds will bring her one-woman show, Debbie Reynolds Alive and Fabulous, to Britain, beginning with a 15-date regional tour at Theater Royal in Norwich on April 7, and followed by a run in the West End of London at the Apollo Theater, opening on April 29.

title: Distortion With Pop Peeping Out
description: Seven songs, 20 or so minutes, several hundred musical punches to the head and midsection: Sleigh Bells concerts are beginning to find a rhythm.

title: Pacquiao-Mayweather a Match Made in Heaven (or Yankee Stadium?)
description: LAS VEGAS  Three hours after Manny Pacquiao dispatched Miguel Cotto on Saturday night to capture his record seventh title in seven weight divisions, he jogged onto the stage at the Mandalay Bay Events Center.

title: Writing a Sports Column Far From Print, and the Game
description: In 1998, a Boston Globe profile of an obscure online sports commentator began simply: Get used to this name: Bill Simmons.

title: U.S. Readies New Facility for Afghan Detainees
description: BAGRAM AIR BASE, Afghanistan  The Obama administrations effort to remake the notorious American detention system in Afghanistan will take a critical step forward at the end of the month, when detainees move into a new facility on the edge of Bagram Air Base.

title: In Detroit, Agencies Compete to Sell City as a Creative Haven
description: IT may not be the advertising version of Mission: Impossible, but it is certainly a challenging, if not daunting, task: produce a campaign to encourage young and creative people to consider Detroit as a place to live and work.

title: Pac-10 Race Remains in Doubt
description: The Pac-10 championship may end up being decided by the Civil War.

title: Antismoking Fight Proves a Pyramid-Size Task
description: CAIRO  Perhaps not since Egypt built the great pyramids of Giza, or more recently tamed the Nile with the Aswan High Dam, has the government embarked on as challenging a national project: wiping out smoking in public places.

title: About Half in U.S. Would Pay for Online News, Study Finds
description: Americans, it turns out, are less willing than people in many other Western countries to pay for their online news, according to a new study by the Boston Consulting Group.

title: At Checkout, More Ways to Avoid Cash or Plastic
description: For almost as long as Americans have been hearing about jetpacks and picturephones, they have been hearing that money  bills, coins and plastic cards  might cease to exist, or at least become a novelty.

title: For Some Smokers, Even Home Is Off Limits
description: The movement to ban smoking in New York City has grown so quickly that no place seems immune  certainly not restaurants or bars, and public beaches and parks may not be far behind. Now the efforts are rapidly expanding into the living room.

title: As A.L.-N.L. Gap Widens, General Managers Tread Cautiously
description: CHICAGO  His shoulders shrugged. His lips pursed. But Kenny Williams bit his tongue one syllable too late.

title: A Writer Tries to Take the High Road as the Low Jokes Fly
description: This much was learned at a panel discussion last week about The Future of Funny: It is not Ken Auletta.

title: Pushed on Budgets, Cities Push Back on House Cats
description: The question of whether to regulate the declawing of house cats has suddenly become a priority for lawmakers in several California cities, mostly because Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed a bill this summer to prohibit local bans on declawing beginning in 2010.

title: Glimmers of Progress at a Leaner Newsweek
description: Six months ago, Newsweek embarked on a bold effort to stanch its losses in a brutal economic time, with a major redesign, price increases, a steep reduction in circulation, and a continuation in a long series of steps away from weekly news and toward commentary and analysis. From the legion of people in the media who write about one anothers organizations, there was plenty of skepticism, even some derision.

title: Taking Aim at Student Muckrakers
description: Since 1992, Prof. David Protess at the Medill school at Northwestern University has worked with undergraduate journalism students to investigate cases in which prosecutors appear to have taken aim at the wrong people. That might be about to happen again, only this time the students themselves would be the targets.

title: In Fleurys Memoir, Rangers Years Are a Nightmare
description: When Theo Fleury was a Ranger, he said, he would stay out all night drinking, doing cocaine, going below the streets of New York City to party with freaks, transvestites, strippers or to hang out with homeless guys around a burn barrel on the West Side piers.

title: Is Palms Comeback Losing Steam?
description: In a land of cellphone giants, Palm is a mouse.

title: Obama Hobbled in Fight Against Global Warming
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama came into office pledging to end eight years of American inaction on climate change under President George W. Bush, and all year he has promised that the United States would lead the way toward a global agreement in Copenhagen next month to address the warming planet.

title: From Treasury, an Invitation to Financial Bloggers
description: The Treasury Department opened its doors to economic bloggers this month, and the meeting was productive in at least one respect: as John Jansen of the blog Across the Curve concluded, After meeting them, I feel I cannot refer to them as Timothy Geithner and his minions anymore.

title: Little Benefit Seen, So Far, in Electronic Patient Records
description: The nation is set to begin an ambitious program, backed by $19 billion in government incentives, to accelerate the adoption of computerized patient records in doctors offices and hospitals, replacing ink and paper. There is wide agreement that the conversion will bring better care and lower costs, saving the American health care system up to $100 billion a year by some estimates.

title: Sullenberger Takes Issue With New Book
description: A new book addressing the role of automation in US Airways Flight 1549 is wrong, according to the pilot who safely landed the plane on the Hudson River in January.

title: Stimulus and Exports Help Ease Japans Recession
description: TOKYO  Japans economy grew at a robust annual rate of 4.8 percent in the third quarter as stimulus spending and a rebound in exports appeared to bring the country firmly out of its worst recession in the postwar era.

title: In Nicaragua, Opposition Sees an End Run
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Magistrate Sergio Cuarezma, a member of the Supreme Court, spent Oct. 19 like any other Monday, quietly catching up on e-mail and fingering through stacks of rulings by sunlight when the courts power went down, as it tends to do without explanation here in Central Americas poorest country.

title: A Deck of Lives
description: After the murder of his son, Tom Lucas created a special deck of playing cards, now used in South Carolina prisons. He hopes they will bring clues to cold cases.

title: In Prison, Playing Just to Kill Time and Just Maybe to Help Solve a Murder
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.

title: Yemen Finds Dreamland of Architecture
description: SANA, Yemen  It has been almost 800 years since Saleh Qaid Othaims house in the heart of the Old City was built from hand-cut stones and traditional alabaster decorations.

title: U.S. Asks More From Pakistan in War
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is stepping up pressure on Pakistan to expand and reorient its fight against the Taliban and Al Qaeda, warning that failing to do so would undercut the new strategy and troop increase for Afghanistan that President Obama is preparing to approve, American officials say.

title: A Sweet Union for Liberty Global
description: A Sweet Union For Liberty Global

title: Governor Crist Becomes a Right-Wing Target
description: NEWBERRY, Fla.  In retrospect, even Charlie Crist admits that the optics of The Hug are not great.

title: Money Trickles North as Mexicans Help Relatives
description: MIAHUATLN, Mexico  During the best of the times, Miguel Salcedos son, an illegal immigrant in San Diego, would be sending home hundreds of dollars a month to support his struggling family in Mexico. But at times like these, with the American economy out of whack and his son out of work, Mr. Salcedo finds himself doing what he never imagined he would have to do: wiring pesos north.

title: After All That Bluster, the Jets Are Barely Breathing
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Grupo Mexico Wins Battle to Control a Copper Producer
description: A federal judge in Texas has issued final approval for Grupo Mexicos plan to regain control of a copper mining company, Asarco, ending a lengthy takeover battle with a rival suitor.

title: Drug Makers Raise Prices in Face of Health Care Reform
description: Even as drug makers promise to support Washingtons health care overhaul by shaving $8 billion a year off the nations drug costs after the legislation takes effect, the industry has been raising its prices at the fastest rate in years.

title: Outlook Grim in South Bend, and Dim for B.C.S.
description: The one theme of this college football season has been its predictability. Just take a peek at next weeks feeble slate of games. There are no games between top-25 teams in the Associated Press poll, something virtually unheard of this late in the season. The top three teams in the country  No. 1 Florida, No. 2 Alabama and No. 3 Texas  play Florida International, Chattanooga and woefully underachieving Kansas. That means three teams that are 30-0 will beat up on three teams that are 14-16.

title: At T.C.U., a Game Ball for Fashion
description: FORT WORTH  After his team trounced Utah on Saturday night, 55-28, Texas Christian Coach Gary Patterson had plenty of candidates to award the game ball to.

title: Kim Shaky in Free Skate, but Still Wins
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  Just before Kim Yu-na of South Korea began her long program at Skate America, she stopped to adjust the shoelaces on her left boot.

title: Senates Counting and Recounting Add Up to Delay
description: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, hopes to finalize the Senate version of major health care legislation this week.

title: Cuomo Wants to Shape Ticket in Run for Governor, Advisers Say
description: ALBANY  Quietly plotting his campaign for governor, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo and his advisers have been discussing potential candidates to run alongside him, to present the most appealing Democratic ticket to the electorate, people with knowledge of those discussions said.

title: Atlantic Avenue Entrepreneurs
description: In Brooklyn, a new class of creative business owners is reviving Atlantic Avenues commitment to old things.

title: Using Celebrity Wattage to Fight Citys Planned Garbage Garage
description: In the old days, the industrial neighborhood just above TriBeCa was so forlorn that if Martin Sheridan spied someone four blocks away, he could be pretty sure it was an approaching customer.

title: Lottery Numbers
$25 Fee for New License Plates May Be Repealed
description: A plan to start charging New York drivers $25 for new license plates will be scuttled, lawmakers said on Sunday. The fee had caused an uproar among upstate officials, who called it an unfair burden on drivers.

title: Skee Brooklyn
description: The Crown Heights bar Franklin Park  home to Hasidic philosophy meetings, skee-ball tourneys and plain old outdoor boozing  adds another twist with its reading series tonight. Catch Amy Sohn, author of the lightly fictionalized neighborhood novel Prospect Park West; Said Sayrafiezadeh, author of the memoir When Skateboards Will Be Free; Jobie Hughes, the writing partner of James Frey; and Lianne Stokes, a comedian, sharing their work; challenge them to a game of drunken skee-ball afterward.

title: Like a Cyclone Hit
description: Offstage, Neko Case can be shy; onstage, the flame-haired singer is a honky-tonk heroine, Nate Chinen writes, even if her lyrics reveal literary designs. Her latest album, Middle Cyclone and her shows feature songs of admonition, hurt and regret, delivered with a declarative gleam. See (and hear) for yourself tonight, when she plays at the Beacon with  Joey Burns and John Convertino of Calexico

title: Sex, Drugs and Rock n Roll
description: Follow two men with very distinct, if somewhat overlapping, obsessions tonight. The music critic Robert Palmer is the subject of the new documentary The Hand of Fatima, which explores his drug use and his family; his pioneering work [LINK to Palmer in Arts 11/16] will be honored at a tribute tonight at Le Poisson Rouge that benefits the Sufi musicians he championed. Meanwhile, at Petes Candy Store, the filmmaker Caveh Zahedi, who has investigated his own predilections forthrightly in I Am a Sex Addict, will present a lecture about his other love: psychotropic drugs.

title: Study Raises Questions About Cholesterol Drugs Benefit
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  For patients taking a statin to control high cholesterol, adding an old standby drug, niacin, was superior in reducing buildup in the carotid artery to adding Zetia, a newer drug that reduces bad cholesterol, according to a new study.

title: Fewer Hasidim Backed Mayor, Study Finds
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was getting an earful. He created this crisis so that he can take credit for fixing it and get our votes in exchange, one commenter wrote on a Brooklyn blog, Vos Iz Neias, Yiddish for What is News. Someone else remarked, I got to my store I got 2 tickets from the Sanitation police. I sure deserved it Bloomie. I will NOT vote for you.

title: Accounts, People & Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Programs to Certify Teachers May Grow
description: The State Board of Regents will consider letting alternative teacher training programs certify teachers, expanding the role that for decades has been exclusively performed by education schools.

title: At CUNY, Mission to Elevate Science Begins to Bear Fruit
description: The most visible manifestation yet of the billion-dollar transformation taking place at the City University of New York might also be the most unassuming: a so-called science cafe series in a Japanese restaurant on the Upper West Side. There, the public listened as faculty members described their work in fields ranging from the global water crisis to the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

title: Chase Is Said to Be Buying British Bank
description: JPMorgan Chase is in talks to take control of a prominent British investment bank after striking a deal for half the firm five years ago, a person familiar with the matter said Sunday night.

title: Palin Finds One Bond With Clinton
description: Could there be a coffee summit in the future between Hillary Rodham Clinton  the secretary of state, runner-up for the Democratic presidential nomination, former senator and author  and Sarah Palin, author, former Republican vice-presidential candidate and former governor?

title: Neediest | A Victim of Violence Recovers
description: Risto Prendzov, a Macedonian immigrant, is recovering after a violent robbery on the subway almost a year ago. He has received help from Catholic Charities, which is supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: After Brutal Mugging, an Immigrant Rebuilds His Life
description: For five days last November, the 29-year-old man was John Doe, lying in Jamaica Hospital Medical Center with a bashed-in skull, a punctured lung, a broken jaw and eye socket and a crushed hand. After a brutal mugging in Queens, he had no wallet, no identification and no shoes.

title: Stricter Transit Standards to Be Sought
description: WASHINGTON  Citing an increase in the number of subway and light-rail crashes and resulting passenger injuries, the Obama administration will push for legislation that would allow the federal government to set and enforce safety standards on the nations transit systems, officials said on Sunday.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: President Obama in China
description: Economy, Security and, Yes, Human Rights

title: Whistling Past the Deficit
description: New Yorks governor could not have spoken more plainly than he did last week before a joint session of the State Legislature. Quite frankly, we are running out of money, he said, as he asked members to help cut the budget. The plea has so far gone unanswered, even though, with each week, the fiscal problems get worse.

title: Dr. No and the Wounded Veterans
description: A creative plan to help wounded veterans and their exhausted families adapt to the strain of long-term home care is on the brink of bipartisan approval  but for the familiar obstructionism of Senator Tom Coburn. This is one of the most deplorable displays by the lawmaker-physician, an Oklahoma Republican who relishes playing the self-styled budget hawk by putting attention-grabbing holds on crucial legislation.

description: International travel by world leaders is mainly about making symbolic gestures. Nobody expects President Obama to come back from China with major new agreements, on economic policy or anything else.

title: Off the Chart
description: Ten months ago, at the beginning of the great stimulus debate, President-elect Barack Obamas economic advisers produced an unfortunate chart.

title: The Great Wallop
description: A FEW years ago we came up with the term Chimerica to describe the combination of the Chinese and American economies, which together had become the key driver of the global economy. With a combined 13 percent of the worlds land surface and around a quarter of its population, Chimerica nevertheless accounted for a third of global economic output and two-fifths of worldwide growth from 1998 to 2007.

title: Liberate Iraqs Economy
description: Bethlehem, Pa.

title: JPMorgan Nears Deal to Buy Rest of Cazenove
description: JPMorgan Chase is in talks to take control of a prominent British investment bank after striking a deal for half the firm five years ago, The New York Timess Eric Dash reported Sunday night, citing a person familiar with the matter.

title: G.M. Is Said to Soon Begin Paying U.S. Debt
description: General Motors, which emerged from a government-ordered bankruptcy restructuring earlier this year, will begin paying back its debt to the United States and Canadian governments earlier than expected, a person with direct knowledge of G.M.s plans said Sunday night.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Friday, about the credit-card law passed in May, misstated the date a provision of it became effective. While the full law will not take effect until February, its requirement that banks alert customers to rate increases 45 days in advance has been in force since August.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Oct. 29 about the photographer Roy DeCarava omitted five survivors. They include two sons, Leslie DeCarava of Playas del Coco, Costa Rica; and Vincent DeCarava of Paramount, Calif.; a grandson, a granddaughter and a great-granddaughter. (As the obituary noted, he is also survived by his wife, Sherry Turner DeCarava, and their three daughters, Susan, Wendy and Laura DeCarava, all of Brooklyn.)

title: Glyde Aims to Simplify Online Sales of Used Media
description: SAN FRANCISCO  People whose old books, CDs, DVDs and video games are collecting dust on their shelves will soon have another way to resell them on the Web.

title: Week 10 in Quotations: On Standing Tall and Taking a Knee
description: The best and worst from Week 10, in the words of the players and coaches who took part.

title: A Snapshot of Todays Community College Students
description: Update | 10:40 a.m. See below for a reference to an article in The San Jose Mercury News on the dashed hopes of many students at two-year colleges in California who had planned to transfer to four-year colleges.

title: Caruso Is Back and So Is the Met
description: Tuesday, Nov. 16, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Colts Pull Off Improbable Win as Patriots Gamble Backfires
description: INDIANAPOLIS  For most teams, failing to score after an interception and fumble recovery in the end zone on consecutive drives would signal disaster and send everyone home shaking their heads about squandered opportunities. Everyone left Lucas Oil Stadium shaking their heads Sunday night all right, but it was over one of the most confounding coaching decisions imaginable, a stunner by Bill Belichick that gave Peyton Manning a short field to engineer a stunning 35-34 comeback victory.

title: Showcase: The Sport of Photography
description: As Walter Iooss and Neil Leifer will tell you, sports photographers have good games and bad games. Like athletes, they get better through intense competition.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 4 about a lack of data on the benefits and relative performance of many medical devices described incorrectly the findings of a McKinsey Global Institute report on the rising costs of such devices. Current spending on the six highest-cost implanted devices alone is about $13 billion annually, not $76 billion. (While a chart in that report described current annual spending on medical devices as about $76 billion, McKinsey said that the figure reflected not just spending on implanted devices but also on other hospital products like X-ray film and surgical gloves.)

title: Big Victory in Alabama
description: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team. As he did last season, Jon will be blogging for The Quad throughout this season.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about accusations by the City Education Department that an arbitrator in a teacher competency hearing has on two occasions fallen asleep during testimony misstated part of the name of the union whose lawyers are representing the teacher, Darwin Bailey. It is New York State United Teachers, not the New York State Union of Teachers.

title: China Is Sending More Students to U.S.
description: American universities are enrolling a new wave of Chinese undergraduates, according to the annual Open Doors report.

description: NATIONAL

title: Defending Belichicks Fourth-Down Decision
description: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.)

title: John J. OConnor, a Times TV Critic in Years of Industry Upheaval, Dies at 76
description: John J. OConnor, who as a television critic for The New York Times for more than 25 years covered the medium as it expanded from a business dominated by three networks to a universe of hundreds of diverse cable and broadcast channels, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76.

title: News Quiz | November 16, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Maurice Jones-Drews  Very Smart Play
description: First, credit  Jaguars Coach Jack Del Rio:

title: Australian Leader Apologizes to the Lost Innocents
description: The children were gathered up by the tens of thousands, some of them as young as 3, taken from single mothers and impoverished families in Britain, then sent abroad for what was supposed to be a better start in life. What they found was isolation, physical and sexual abuse, and what the prime minister of Australia said Monday was the absolute tragedy of childhoods lost.

title: Infosys Buys U.S. Back-Office Firm
description: Infosys Technologies, Indias second-largest information technology provider by revenue, has acquired McCamish Systems, an American back-office firm, for up $58 million.

title: Co-Founder of Brevan Howard to Leave Firm
description: Jean-Philippe Blochet, a founding partner in Brevan Howard Asset Management, is leaving the $25.7 billion London-based hedge fund after seven years.

title: Hitachi to Raise $4.6 Billion
description: Hitachi, Japans biggest electronics firm by sales, will raise up to $4.6 billion to shore up its capital, joining a scrum of Japanese firms tapping equity markets before a possible economic slowdown.

title: A Sweet Union For Liberty Global?
description: John C. Malone, the American media mogul, has pulled off a piece of classic downturn deal-making, Breakingviews.com says. Mr. Malones Liberty Global agreed Friday to buy Unitymedia, Germanys second-largest cable operator after Kabel Deutschland, for 3.5 billion euros ($5.2 billion).

title: Glyde Aims to Simplify Online Sales of Used Media
description: People whose old books, CDs, DVDs and video games are collecting dust on their shelves will soon have another way to resell them on the Web.

description: General Motors, which emerged from a government-ordered bankruptcy restructuring earlier this year, will begin paying back its debt to the United States and Canadian governments earlier than expected, The New York Timess Micheline Maynard reported, citing a person with direct knowledge of G.M.s plans.

title: Dance and Art
description: Photos from the Trisha Brown Dance Companys performance at Dia:Beacon.

title: Pay Limits Said to Hamper BofAs Search for Chief
description: Bank of Americas search for a new chief executive has been hurt by federal pay limits that played a major role in the senior vice chairman of PNC Financial Services Group spurning overtures from the company, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Hong Kong Investors Boost Stake in British Gas Firm
description: Cheung Kong Infrastructure and Hongkong Electric said Monday that they would spend 76 million ($127 million) to increase their stakes in British gas distributor Northern Gas Networks.

title: Carlyles Forestry Unit in China to Go Public
description: China Forestry Holdings Group, a forestry plantation operator backed by the Carlyle Group, plans to raise up to $203 million via an initial offering of shares in Hong Kong late this month, Reuters reported.

title: Castle Harlan Sells United Malt for $655 Million
description: Castle Harlan said Friday that it had unloaded United Malt Holdings for $655 million, a deal that gives the private equity firm a nice return on its investment.

title: Brightcove Expands Web Video Service
description: Five years ago, when Jeremy Allaire founded Brightcove, an online video company in Cambridge, Mass., he predicted video would someday be as common as text on the Web.

title: Champion Seeks Chapter 11 For U.S. Operations
description: Champion Enterprises said on Sunday the company and its domestic operating subsidiaries filed for bankruptcy protection, and that it hopes to go through a court-supervised sale of its American operations.

title: Sands to Restart Macao Casino Work After I.P.O.
description: The American casino operator Las Vegas Sands plans to resume work in January on its multibillion-dollar gambling resorts in Macao after suspending construction last year amid a massive funding crunch, the company said Sunday.

title: Thread Counts | Comment of the Week
description: Every week we comb through the comments on The Moment, Facebook and our Twitter @replies to bring you something clever from readers.

title: Citi Said to Reject Terra Firma Bid to Save EMI
description: Citigroup recently rejected a proposal from Guy Hands private equity firm Terra Firma Capital Partners to restructure the debt of the music group EMI, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Who Walked Off With Warhols Bills?
description: Guessing who the winning bidder was for Andy Warhols 200 One Dollar Bills in a recent Sothebys auction is becoming something of a parlor game, with the names of several high-profile investors, including the hedge fund veteran Steven A. Cohen, being bandied about.

title: Bristol-Myers to Split Off Mead Johnson Nutrition
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb is splitting off its holdings in the infant-formula maker Mead Johnson Nutrition in order to focus on its biopharmaceutical business.

title: A New Ragtime
description: Photos from the new Broadway revival of Ragtime.

title: Paulson Puts Money on Citi, Ditching Goldman
description: John Paulson, the hedge fund manager, has continued to build his stake in Citigroup, while jettisoning his investment in Goldman Sachs, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Is Vivendis GVT Deal a Signal on NBC Stake?
description: Vivendi said Friday that it had gained control of GVT in a deal that valued the Brazilian telecommunications company at about 2.8 billion euros ($4.2 billion) and gave the French media conglomerate a foothold in Latin Americas biggest market.

title: South Korean Insurer Samsung Life Plans 2010 I.P.O.
description: Samsung Life Insurance, South Koreas largest life insurer, said it was aiming to go public in the first half of next year and planning to pick lead managers in December, Reuters reported on Monday.

title: Sun Capital Sells Off Timothys Coffee
description: As the markets improve, private equity companies continue to seek exits for their portfolio companies. Sun Capital Partners followed that trend by selling Timothys Coffees of the World, a specialty coffee supplier, to Green Mountain Coffee Roasters for about $157 million in cash.

title: Can Public Aid Really Help Business?
description: The global financial crisis is prompting huge government interventions to stimulate the economies of the United States and many other nations. The burning question, The New York Timess Harry Hurt III writes, is this: Can public-sector initiatives in the private sector be successful, or are they inevitably doomed to failure?

description: fetter  \fe-tr\  noun and verb

What are some of the things that drive you crazy?For example, maybe you agree with Tracey Lloyd, who writes in I See London:

title: In Beijing, Obama Calls for Strong Dialogue
description: BEIJING  President Obama and President Hu Jintao of China met in private off Tiananmen Square here on a frigid Tuesday morning to discuss issues like trade, climate change and the nuclear programs of Iran and North Korea, in a session that signaled the central role of China on the world stage.

description: South Koreas National Pension Service, the countrys biggest investor, agreed to put up 772.5 million ($1.29 billion) for HSBC Holdings London headquarters, Bloomberg News reported.

description: Warren E. Buffett admits that his $26 billion deal to Burlington Northern Santa Fe railroad is not a bargain.

title: Canon to Buy Oc, Biggest Printer Maker in Europe
description: Canon, the Japanese maker of cameras, copying machines and other electronics, will make a tender offer worth 730 million euros ($1.1 billion) for Oc, the biggest European printer maker, the two companies said Monday.

title: Cisco Raises Offer for Tandberg
description: Cisco Systems on Monday raised its bid for the Norwegian video conferencing equipment maker Tandberg by about 11 percent, gaining the acceptance of the targets two largest shareholders with the new offer.

title: G.M. Shows Signs of Recovery Despite New Loss
description: DETROIT  General Motors, whose very survival was in doubt this year, is showing signs of life after its brief tour through bankruptcy this summer.

title: Sampler: Cat Claws, Money Flows and Tree Trimmers
description: Wine Plea Deal | A former Sausalito bon vivant who police say was responsible for a fire that destroyed more than $200 million worth of wine may be changing his plea from not-guilty in a hearing today, according to court records, the San Francisco Chronicle says. Mark C. Andersons arson trial is set to begin Tuesday, a case that has drawn international attention.

title: Submit Your Funny Caption

title: Live-Blogging G.M.s Financial Results
description: General Motors reported Monday that it lost $1.15 billion in the third quarter on revenue of $28 billion. G.M. also announced it will start paying back $6.7 billion in senior debt to the American and Canadian governments, starting in late December, which is much earlier than planned.

title: G.M. Reports $1.15 Billion Loss, but Cites Progress
description: General Motors said on Monday that it lost $1.15 billion in the third quarter after emerging from bankruptcy in July 10, but it increased its cash reserves by $3.3 billion.

title: Chinas Growing Military Might
description: As President Obama makes his first visit to China, he has stressed that a rising China can be a source of shared strength. In his latest column for At War, Capt. Tim Hsia considers what a more powerful China might mean for Americas military.

title: Senate Begins Tackling Health Bill
description: With a Thanksgiving recess looming, the Senate this week will take steps to open debate on its own health care bill even though it remains unclear whether Senator Harry Reid, the Nevada Democrat and majority leader, has the votes to overcome even an initial procedural hurdle.

title: Evernote Raises $10 Million From Investors
description: Imagine you are at a dinner meeting. You receive a business card from your guest and scribble notes about your conversation. You enjoy the wine, so you peel off the label. On the way out, you have the best idea ever and you jot it on the napkin so you dont forget.

title: AltaRock Geothermal Gets New Boost
description: As part of a newly announced $338 million boost for 123 geothermal energy projects nationwide, the Department of Energy will sink $25 million into what is called an enhanced or engineered geothermal demonstration project in Oregon being developed in part by AltaRock Energy, which recently halted work on a similar venture in California due to drilling problems.

title: The Early Word: In China
description: Early this morning in a town hall style meeting with Chinese students, President Obama said that a free Internet was a strength. The comment was a rare challenge to the Chinese government during the presidents Asian tour.

title: Ask About Community Philanthropy
description: This week, Lorie A. Slutsky, president of the New York Community Trust, will answer questions on community philanthropy, the value of many different approaches to charitable giving, and their importance in maintaining a strong democracy.

title: Speed Read for Monday, Nov. 16
description: Highlights from todays media coverage:

title: Markets Rise as Traders See Growth
description: Wall Street traders latched onto signs on Monday that the dollar would continue to remain weak and that the global recession was easing, riding a rally on three continents that helped push stock averages to their highest levels in more than a year.

title: Landlords Move to Ban Smoking in Apartment Buildings
description: The movement to ban smoking in New York City has grown so quickly that no place seems immune  certainly not restaurants or bars, and public beaches and parks may not be far behind. Now the efforts are rapidly expanding into the living room.

title: Unemployment and the Midterms
description: My column today focuses on the politics of unemployment, and the role that joblessness is likely to play in the run-up to the midterms. Last week, though, Matt Yglesias noted that the historical data doesnt show a particularly strong correlation between unemployment and midterm election outcomes. Heres the chart, from Seth Masket:

title: Autos Help Spur Rise in Retail Sales
description: Retail sales in the United States increased by a higher-than-expected 1.4 percent in October from September, helped by a strong demand for cars, the government said Monday.

title: Media Equation: Taking Aim at Student Muckrakers
description: In todays Media Equation column, David Carr writes:

title: Can Academics Be Entrepreneurial?
description: In a recent op-ed piece in The Wall Street Journal, Carl Schramm, Robert Litan and Dane Stangler of the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation called on policy makers to unleash Americas academic entrepreneurs as a way to foster the creation and growth of new businesses.

title: Jets Open Thread: The Shoulda Won-Shoulda Lost Standings
description: If the N.F.L. had standings for shoulda won and shoulda lost, the Jets (4-5) would probably be tied for first in the A.F.C. East. New England (6-3) should have beaten the Colts last night, but the Patriots should have lost their season opener against Buffalo.

title: In Crowded N.L. Rookie Field, Coghlan Stands Out
description: Baseballs awards week begins Monday with the National League Rookie of the Year award, and if theres ever been a closer field, I cant think of it. Nobody stands out far above the pack, and thats why this will be a fascinating vote.

title: The Insider | Craig Thompson
description: The Insider profiles emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the Catskills-based pastry chef Craig Thompson shares his essentials. A self-taught baker, Thompson began his career making lemon meringue pies based on the paintings of Wayne Thiebaud for the cafe at the the Kemper Contemporary Museum in Kansas City. He moved to New York and worked with high-end event-planning companies before settling in the Catskills, where he founded his bespoke bakery, Shandaken Bake.

title: Talk to The Times: Editor for Digital Initiatives
description: Jim Schachter, editor for digital initiatives, answered questions from readers Nov. 16-20, 2009, in Talk to The Times.

title: Congress to Investigate Airlines Fees
description: The additional fees that irk travelers, for the most part, are not taxed. The government says that fare increases in disguise are costing it extra revenue. Read the full story.

title: The Morning Skate: Forbes Paints Bright Picture, New Florida Money and Ovies Return
description: Forbes magazine published its annual valuations of N.H.L. clubs last week accompanied by the usual package of articles on the hockey business. The team valuations always grab the headlines, and there were no real surprises at the top of the list, where the top five remained the same as last season (The Maple Leafs are first, followed by Rangers, Canadiens, Red Wings and Flyers).

title: Motorsports Links: Mercedes Takes Over Brawn GP
description: Motorsports news from around the Web

title: If Bank Account Is Flabby, Tighten the Body
description: Just because your bank account has lost some of its muscle doesnt mean your body has to suffer the same fate.

title: What to Watch Monday: Bon Jovi, Cooking School, a Giant Shark
description: Inside the Actors Studio with  Bon Jovi? Over the course of more than 200 shows, James Lipton has interviewed actors, directors, comedians and talk show hosts, with only a couple of exceptions for nonacting musicians (Billy Joel and Elton John, as long as you dont count Tommy). He breaks form to open his 16th season (Bravo, 8 p.m.) with a rock band. Jon Bon Jovi and Richie Sambora have done some acting (Mr. Sambora even got to play Eric Clapton on an episode of American Dreams); Tico Torres and David Bryan were not so sure about.

title: Britains Climate Goals Unrealistic Without Planetary Tinkering, Group Says
description: The Institution for Mechanical Engineers, a British professional body, argues in a new report that Britains goal of slashing emissions by 80 percent from 1990 levels by 2050 shows the government using ambitious, yet distant, targets to mask its failure to tackle the problem adequately in the near-term.

title: Five Questions for Justin Kirk
description: Justin Kirk would rather play an understudy than be one.

title: Doing the Math on News Corp.s Threatened Google Block
description: In a recent interview, Rupert Murdoch, the head of News Corporation, said that the company was considering blocking the searchbots of Google, making its content invisible or at least less visible to the search giant. So far its only talk, but Advertising Age decided to do some math to look at the implications of such a move.

title: For Farmers, a Season to Forget
description: Months of rain, cold weather and crop blight made 2009 one of the worst, if not the worst, growing seasons in memory, Jan Ellen Spiegel writes in The New York Times. Most counties in New York and New Jersey have been declared agricultural disaster areas, and Connecticut is awaiting word from the federal government on the same declaration for nearly all of its counties.

title: Ink Spot Strategy
description: A military maneuver whereby counter-insurgency and reconstruction efforts spread outwards from secured key areas  as an ink spot expands on paper.

title: ZEUS Computer Program Supports Belichicks Fourth-Down Bid
description: Frank Frigo and Chuck Bower, champion backgammon players and developers of the ZEUS computer program, have huddled with N.F.L. executives over the years, including with Bill Belichick. They can simulate hundreds of thousands of N.F.L. outcomes in seconds, and their program is customizable to account for the strengths and weaknesses of the offensive and defensive units of each team.

title: Byrd Will Set Another Record
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, who is already the longest-serving senator in United States history, is set to cross yet another milestone of longevity in the legislative branch. On Wednesday, hell surpass Carl Hayden as the longest-serving member of Congress in history, combining terms in both the House and Senate.

title: Oaklands Bailey Leads Strong Class of A.L. Rookies
description: Just like the N.L. field, the American League rookie class is crowded, too. When the A.L. award is announced on Monday, expect a flurry of debate.

description: Good for The New Yorkers Avi Zenilman for thinking to turn to Claremont McKenna Colleges Jon Shields, author of the excellent The Democratic Virtues of the Christian Right, for perspective on the Stupak Amendment and its attendant controversies. The whole interview is worth your time, but I wanted to pluck out this passage:

title: Monday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: The A.P. Fact-Checks Palins Book
description: The blogosphere has been busy truth-squading Going Rogue, the book by the former Alaska governor and vice-presidential candidate Sarah Palin. But The Associated Press decided it had some skin in the game and did, what was for a wire service, a very sharp-elbowed dispatch about the book.

title: More Coffee From California
description: Two more next-generation left coast coffee roasters just made their Manhattan debuts: Four Barrel Coffee and Ecco Caff, welcome to New York.

description: The New Yorkers annual food issue is out this week. Some highlights:

title: Evernote Raises $10 Million From Investors
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: Looking Back at the Morgenthau Legacy
description: At the end of this year, when Robert M. Morgenthau leaves his job as Manhattan district attorney  the position he has held since 1975  it will be not just the end of an era for the prosecutors office, but also the close of another chapter in the Morgenthau familys complex, century-long legacy of public service.

title: Stanford University and Google: Dissertation Process Goes Online
description: Students at Stanford University can now file their dissertations with the universitys registrar by uploading their dissertations and receiving approval online. Then, they can publish using Google and see their works accessible by anyone with a computer.

title: Foreign Teams Coming to Red Bull Arena
description: This year, the so-called Summer of Soccer made a detour around the New York metropolitan area, save for one game  the Gold Cup final. Next summer, however, promises to be different, with the 2010 World Cup in South Africa dominating the international headlines.

title: How to Listen
description: The sleek Zune HD should be a hit. It gives you choice: for a $15 monthly fee, the Zune pass service lets you subscribe to your music and stream it. Or download your music and own it. You can do both! Plus its pretty, and its got an HD radio. But pity the poor microsoft engineers who built this marvel. Its got everything a music lover could want. Alas, its from Microsoft. The end.

title: How to Surf
description: For 15 years, weve interacted with the web by leaning forward at our desks. But soon there may be a computer that departs from the metaphor of the typewriter. Theres a samizdat market in supposed spy photos of an Apple tablet computer, which is said to be a cross between An iPhone and a Mac. It looks like something you could use to surf the net while lying in bed. The primary market for tablets isnt office workers but teenagers.

title: How to Watch
description: Why figure out how to connect a snakes nest of cables to a bunch of boxes just to watch stupid old television? JVCs TeleDock line of TVs have an iPod dock on the front  right in the middle, where you cant miss it. If you carry your movie library around in your pocket, now you can plug it in and watch it from your couch.

title: Devon Energys Asset Sale May Draw Chinas Interest
description: Devon Energy, the independent oil and gas firm, surprised many on Monday by announcing its plans to divest all of its offshore and international energy properties to concentrate on its domestic onshore energy businesses.

title: Manufacturing Around the World
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics recently released updated statistics on job markets around the industrialized world over the last 40 years.

title: When Feedback Isnt Just Noise
description: Album cover art has long held a fascination for music and visual art fans alike. But what if the process were reversed, and the musician composed an album inspired by its cover art?

title: Proposed extensions of Godwins Law
description: Godwins Law  which says that in any sufficiently long online discussion, someone will compare his opponent to Hitler  is often interpreted to mean that if you do, in fact, start making Nazi comparisons, youve lost the argument and can no longer be taken seriously. Im all for that. (Does this mean that we should no longer take any significant figure in the Republican Party seriously? Yes, it does.)

title: Answers About Community Colleges, Part 1
description: Each day this week, the Guidance Office  the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts  will feature answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: Publication: Schotts Almanac 2010
description: Co-vocabularists in Britain might be interested to learn that Schotts Almanac 2010 has today been published.

title: Suntech to Open Plant in Arizona
description: Suntech Power, Chinas largest solar panel manufacturer, plans to open its first American plant near Phoenix, the company announced on Monday.

title: Now Emerging | Bermuda Triangle
Wine Arson Suspect Pleading Guilty in Federal Court
description: The Sausalito businessman who has denied for years that he played any role in setting the 2005 fire that destroyed $250 million of premium wine will plead guilty to arson today in federal court.

title: With Harry Carson
description: Harry Carson, the Hall of Fame middle linebacker, said he had about 10 concussions during his 13 seasons with the Giants in the 1970s and 80s. He was found to have postconcussion syndrome in 1990. Carson, who turns 56 this month, says he wants to be sure that other former players receive help and that current players are educated about head injuries. JOE BRESCIA

title: Vitamin D Shows Heart Benefits in Study
description: Got vitamin D? It may protect you from heart disease.

title: With a Victory, Wie Comes of Age
description: Entering the weekend, Michelle Wie had never won an L.P.G.A. title and Tiger Woods had never won a tournament in Australia. Thats all changed.

title: Paul McCartney Is Awarded Gershwin Prize
description: Update | 3:28 p.m. The Library of Congress has named Paul McCartney, prolific songwriter and former Beatle, as the third recipient of its Gershwin Prize for Popular Song. It is hard to think of another performer and composer who has had a more indelible and transformative effect on popular song and music of several different genres, the Librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, said in announcing the award on Monday. Mr. McCartney is the first non-American to win the prize, named for the songwriters George and Ira Gershwin: the previous honorees were Paul Simon and Stevie Wonder. The Library said that an all-star tribute concert is planned for the spring of 2010. Mr. McCartney, who has a new CD/DVD called Good Evening New York City coming out on Tuesday, said that as a great admirer of the Gershwins songs he was highly honored to be given the prize. The Library of Congress said that Mr. McCartney planned to perform at the tribute show.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this column contained an incorrect statistic for the October unemployment rate. The correct figure is 10.2 percent, not 10.4 percent.

title: Monday Puzzle: Conversion Factors
description: In a last desperate cry, a technician on an Antarctic expedition yelled out a temperature measurement he made as he fell into a crevasse. The number that he shouted out (covered by the penguin ) was clearly heard, but not the units. It turned out not to make a difference. What was the temperature?(Illustration: Justin Thyme)

title: Rules to Gorge By
description: A blog called Eating the Road has an extremely detailed guide to all-you-can-eat buffets and how to get the most from them. If you arrive just before the changing of the guard or the breakfast to lunch, lunch to dinner time-frames youll not only pay the lesser dollar amount (typically $2 to $3) but may also have a wider variety to choose from. And, Allow others the right of way, especially women, children and the elderly.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'The Darjeeling Limited'
description: Wes Anderson, director of "The Darjeeling Limited," discusses how a scene from the movie was created.

title: The Heartburn Ahead for Landrys Chief
description: Two events late last week predict two alternative realities for the management buyout of Landrys. The events show that the companys chief executive, Tilman J. Fertitta, may have a much rougher time  or at least have to spend more money  acquiring the shares of Landrys he does not already own.

title: Larry Charles Signs on for an NBC Pilot
description: After devoting most of his energy in recent years to feature films and cable, the writer, director and producer Larry Charles is returning to network television. Mr. Charles, who wrote numerous episodes for the NBC hit series Seinfeld and Mad About You in the 1990s, is to write and direct the pilot of an as yet unnamed series for NBC. In this decade, Mr. Charles has directed Sacha Baron Cohens Borat and Bruno films, and also directed, produced or written episodes for two hit HBO series, Curb Your Enthusiasm and Entourage. The new NBC show is to have an ensemble cast, be set in a small town and, as Mr. Charles told The Hollywood Reporter, will aim to depict contemporary American life through the prism of a do-it-yourself homemade aesthetic that will mix mediums.

title: Defying Mayor, Council Approves Grace Period for Parking Enforcement
description: Updated, 5:12 p.m. | The New York City Council voted overwhelmingly on Monday to grant ticket-fatigued drivers a five-minute grace period before parking-meter regulations and alternate-side parking rules are enforced, boldly defying Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who hours earlier vowed to veto the measure, saying it would lead to chaos.

title: The madness of the inflation hawks
description: Wow. Matthew Yglesias catches David Ignatius worrying that the Fed may not have enough political support in its efforts to raise interest rates and fight inflation. As Matt correctly notes, this is a remote issue  unemployment is high, inflation is low, and the Fed has no business raising rates any time soon.

title: Giants Win Without Playing
description: The bye week was going to be good news for the Giants: They couldnt lose again. It turned out they had a far better week than that.

title: Cuomo Still Dominating Paterson Among Voters, Poll Shows
description: The footsteps of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo are growing louder for Gov. David A. Paterson.

title: Amaranth Withdraws Lawsuit Against Touradji Capital
description: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that closed its doors three years ago after losing more than $6.6 billion on wrong-way bets on the price of natural gas, said on Monday that it had dropped its two-month old lawsuit against the hedge fund manager Paul Touradji and his firm, Touradji Capital Management.The suit claimed that Mr. Touradji breached two separate contracts signed in September 2006 that governed the transfer and purchase of Amaranths base metals portfolio. Mr. Touradji and his firm were accused of using confidential information about Amaranths trading strategy and its positions to unjustly profit.Touradji Capital denied Amaranths allegations, saying that its conduct in assuming the risk of Amaranths base metal portfolio was professional and lawful.Amaranth has received and evaluated additional information regarding the transaction, including trading records and other information voluntarily provided by Touradji Capital, that is consistent with Touradji Capitals position that it did not violate the agreement with Amaranth and did not misuse Amaranths proprietary information, Amaranth said in a statement. Accordingly, Amaranth has withdrawn its summons and notice and elected not to serve a complaint against Touradji Capital.Amaranths decision to withdraw its claims vindicates our position that we acted appropriately and with the utmost of professionalism, Mr. Touradji said in a statement. It also clearly validates our previous statement that the Amaranth suit was based on the misinformation of two disgruntled former employees involved in separate litigation with T.C.M.The two former employees are Robert Vollero and Gentry Beach. The men sued Touradji Capital last December, contending that they were owed $50 million in unpaid bonuses. The hedge fund filed a countersuit against the men this month alleging that the two men had lied about their abilities, stole company secrets and defamed the firm. Touradji Capital is seeking more than $250 million as compensation for financial and reputational damage

title: Godiva Rides in a New Direction
description: At a time when many consumers are drinking tap water rather than bottled water, shopping at Wal-Mart rather than department stores and eating in rather than dining out, a high-end chocolatier is making over its marketing to better fit in with the new mood.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences chose Media Storm, South Norwalk, Conn., as its media planning and buying agency of record for the coming Oscar broadcast on ABC, scheduled for March 7, 2010. Billings were not disclosed. The assignment had been handled by OMD, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: Obama Walks Chinas Great Firewall
