description: While some American Twitter addicts reacted with real and feigned outrage on Monday to President Obamas confession, during a forum with Chinese students in Shanghai, that he does not personally update the @BarackObama feed  which more than two million people follow on the social network  observers in China were more interested in what he said next: that he disagrees with Chinas censorship of the Internet.

title: F.D.A. Puts Off Oyster Ban
description: The Food and Drug Administration has indefinitely delayed a proposed ban on the sale of raw oysters harvested on the Gulf Coast during warm months in the face of opposition from the oyster industry and legislators from the region. The ban was intended to reduce the risk from Vibrio vulnificus, a bacterium that each year kills about 15 people in the United States each year.

title: Belichicks Latest Gamble Backfires
description: Forget the Barry Switzer references. Yes, Bozo the Coach, which is what The New York Post called Switzer in a headline in 1995 when his Dallas Cowboys failed to convert a fourth-down attempt at their 29 against the Eagles, made the same decision that Bill Belichick did Sunday night in New Englands 35-34 loss to Indianapolis.

title: Attacks Threaten Fragile Security Gains in Cradle of Iraq Insurgency
description: RAMADI, Iraq  Maj. Gen. Tariq al-Youssef caught a fleeting glimpse of the man who wanted him dead.

title: Coming Home for Thanksgiving
description: In about a week they will start to arrive &#8212 college freshmen home for Thanksgiving. They will be different people from the ones who left, re-entering families that have changed while they were gone. Home will feel embracing, yet confining. Parents will want to know everything, and not want to hear some things. It will be warm and wonderful &#8212 and stressful.

title: On USA, Four More Years of WWEs Raw
description: Pro wrestling will continue its long run as a staple of cable programming after World Wrestling Entertainment announced a new deal Monday to remain on the USA network for another four years.

title: Travel Deals: 25% off Christmas Spectacular in New York
description: The holiday season must be around the corner. A 76-foot Norway spruce arrived at Rockefeller Center on Thursday and The Radio City Christmas Spectacular kicked off shows the following night.

title: A Hearty Thanksgiving Raviolo
description: During a stint on Bravos Top Chef reality show, chef Ariane Duarte won raves for her Thanksgiving turkey. But while dining recently at her Montclair, N.J., restaurant, CulinAriane, it was a seasonal vegetarian dish that made the biggest impression.

title: S.E.C. Is Said to Examine 3Com Options Trading
description: Now that insider trading is again a hot topic on Wall Street, it is no surprise that the unusual trading in 3Com options before its $2.7 billion sale to Hewlett-Packard is being examined.

title: To the MAXXI | Zaha Hadids Museum in Rome
description: It may take the nation that invented Fellini to truly embrace Zaha Hadid, the whirlwind architect who is by turns sugar and spitfire. Italians stress the z in Zaha as they do in czarina, and treated her like one during last weekends opening festivities for the National Museum of the XXI Century Arts (MAXXI) in Rome, the patient realization of a public commission won by Hadid in 1999. At a kickoff event, Hadid warned that her Italian was nothing but could not dissuade a crowd of journalists from lunging at her like Anita Ekberg rushing into the Trevi Fountain. With nearly 65,000 square feet of exhibition space, however, it is the Italian Ministry of Culture and Heritage that underwent a $224 million baptism, in the hopes of refreshing the ancient fonts of western art and architecture.

title: College Ivy Sprouts at a Connecticut Prison
description: CHESHIRE, Conn.  In many ways it was just another day, another class of Wesleyan University, one of the more selective colleges in the Northeast. The topic was multiculturalism in schools. The discussion focused on methods of evaluating the rhetorical skills of various commentators, from Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. to Dinesh DSouza.

title: Balyasny Says Inquiry Found Nothing Improper
description: Balyasny Asset Management, the big Chicago hedge fund run by Dmitry Balyasny, discovered no signs of improper activity after conducting an internal review into trading records and communications of a former employee who recently surfaced in the insider trading case against the Galleon Group.

title: Obama Walks Chinas Great Firewall
description: From our colleagues at The Lede:

title: Unlocking the Mercedes With Your Smartphone
description: Bit by bit (or byte by byte), carmakers are connecting their vehicles not only to Internet-based services but also to owners smartphones. The latest is Mercedes-Benz, which announced a new telematics platform Monday that beefs up its navigation system with traffic and weather information and lets drivers lock or unlock their cars using an iPhone or BlackBerry.

title: In My Pantry
description: Kerri gathered up her garden and prepared it for the winter. MB

title: Q & A With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Study Ties Restrooms to Illnesses on Cruises
description: It is the perfect way to spoil a vacation, and it has happened 66 times since 2005: an outbreak of gastrointestinal illness aboard a cruise ship. Now a study suggests one possible culprit: dirty restrooms.

title: Continuing Unemployment Is Predicted by Fed Chief
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, warned on Monday that high unemployment and a continued reluctance by banks to make loans were likely to slow the economic recovery for the next year.

title: More New York High Schools Get As
description: In releasing the third annual round of A through F grades for New York City high schools on Monday, the Education Department produced a rather murky picture: The number of schools receiving As on the citys report cards increased this year, but more schools received Cs and Ds. And just one school received an F.

title: Small-Scale Butchers
description: Twelve rabbits lost their lives in Bushwick Sunday afternoon.

title: Taliban Militants Fire Rockets on Crowded Bazaar Northeast of Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban militants fired rockets on a bazaar northeast of Kabul on Monday, near the site of a meeting between French soldiers and local tribal leaders, and police officials said 10 Afghan civilians were killed and 28 wounded.

title: News of Hockey, 11/16/09: Ownership Change for Money-Losing Panthers
description: The Florida Panthers have new owners after it is announced on Monday that minority investors Stuart Siegel and Cliff Viner have bought control of the Cats from majority owner Alan Cohen. The pair take over a team that lost $14 million last season, the biggest loss from any club in the league other than the money-hemorrhaging Phoenix Coyotes.

title: Taint of Corruption Is No Barrier to U.S. Visa
description: Several times a year, Teodoro Nguema Obiang arrives at the doorstep of the United States from his home in Equatorial Guinea, on his way to his $35 million estate in Malibu, Calif., his fleet of luxury cars, his speedboats and private jet. And he is always let into the country.

title: Healthy Thanksgiving Favorites
description: Thanksgiving dinner doesnt have to be the kickoff to a month of holiday overeating, ending with a regretful New Years resolution and a January diet. The holiday can be festive, even indulgent, without dishes loaded with fats and salt.

title: Taking Questions on Money and Divorce
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Mercedes Grand Prix is Launched
description: The rumors were in the air, but Mercedes wanted to keep in quiet until the season ended, and no doubt the details were resolved. Now its news, now its done: Mercedes is leaving McLaren as a part owner of the team and going out alone as the principal shareholder of the Brawn team, relaunching as Mercedes Grand Prix.

title: Inspectors Fear Iran Is Hiding Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON  International inspectors who gained access to Irans newly revealed underground nuclear enrichment plant voiced strong suspicions in a report on Monday that the country was concealing other atomic facilities.

title: The Washington Blade and Several Other Gay Newspapers Are Shut Down
description: Gay newspapers in several United States cities, including The Washington Blade, shut down on Monday, as the company that owned them, Window Media, abruptly went out of business. Window Media had been in serious financial trouble, but employees said they had expected a reorganization or sale  not a liquidation.

title: Warriors Trade Stephen Jackson to Charlotte
description: The Golden State Warriors placated the disgruntled Stephen Jackson on Monday, trading him to the Charlotte Bobcats with Acie Law in exchange for Raja Bell and Vladimir Radmanovic.

title: Cant Complain? Writing About Pet Peeves
description: Overview | How can students express their complaints in articulate and constructive ways? In this lesson, students read The New York Times Complaint Box series and use descriptive and persuasive writing strategies to communicate their own pet peeves succinctly and productively.

title: Scientist Says She Was the Call Girl Who Wrote the Diary
description: The debate over the authorship and authenticity of the books and blog posts that eventually became the Showtime series Secret Diary of a Call Girl  criticized for supposedly glamorizing prostitution  seems to be over. A British scientist, Brooke Magnanti, told The Sunday Times in London that she was Belle de Jour, the escort whose sexual experiences were recounted in the blog and in three books. Ms. Magnanti, who works as a child health researcher at the University of Bristol in England, said she started in the sex trade in 2003, when she was finishing her Ph.D, and continued for more than a year. She explained that she had decided to go public now because she feared an ex-boyfriend was about to expose her. She added on her blog that she was relieved to be able to defend what my experience of sex work is like to all the skeptics and doubters.

title: A Climate Communicators Indian Journey
description: Eric Roston, a former Time magazine journalist and author of The Carbon Age, spent three weeks roaming India at the invitation of the United States State Department to explore and talk about north-south differences in talking about climate change. (He told me that his talks and interactions were not in any way shaped by government officials.) The journey wrapped up at a conference organized by the International Federation of Environmental Journalists.

title: Drug Activist Leaves Kunstler Fund for Senate Bid
description: Disturbing the Universe, a new documentary on the civil rights lawyer William M. Kunstler, opened Friday at Cinema Village, in the East Village.

title: Nuclear Plant Built for Iran Is Delayed, Russia Says
description: MOSCOW  Russia added a new note of discord to its relations with Iran on Monday, announcing that a Russian-built nuclear power plant in Iran would not come online at the end of the year as planned.

title: More Families Struggled to Put Food on the Table
description: The percentage of Americans households that had difficulty providing enough food for all their members due to a lack of resources rose to 14.6 percent in 2008 from 11.1 percent in 2007, according to the Agriculture Department. Thats an increase of 4 million households, 17 million in total.

title: An Adviser to Murdoch Is Leaving News Corp.
description: Gary Ginsberg, a close adviser to Rupert Murdoch for 11 years who often served as a liaison between the conservative Mr. Murdoch and the Democratic Party, will leave News Corporation at the end of the year.

title: Warhol Childrens Book Illustrations to Be Sold at Auction
description: They surely will not fetch anywhere the $43.7 million that someone paid last week for one of his seminal silk-screen paintings. But illustrations that Andy Warhol did for a childrens book series in the late 1950s are to be offered by Bloomsbury Auctions on Dec. 9, along with work by other childrens authors and illustrators, including Beatrix Potter, A.A. Milne, Maurice Sendak and Edward Gorey. The early Warhol illustrations, conventional in both style and subject, accompanied the Doubleday Book Clubs Best in Childrens Books series, like a version of The Little Red Hen that shows the title character sowing seeds in a field as a lazy cat, dog and mouse look on. The estimated price is $500 to $600 for each copy.

title: Bernanke Sees Tight Lending Weighing on Economy
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, warned Monday that high unemployment and a continued reluctance of banks to make loans were likely to slow the economic recovery for the next year, The New York Timess Edmund L. Andrews reports.

title: Work-Related Injuries Underreported
description: Employers and workers routinely underreport work-related injuries and illnesses, calling into question the accuracy of nationwide data that the Occupational Safety and Health Administration compiles each year, the Government Accountability Office said Monday.

title: Putting Jenningss 55 Into Perspective
description: Two days after the rookie point guard Brandon Jennings set the N.B.A. abuzz with 55 points against the Golden State Warriors, the feat is still being put into historical perspective.

title: Night and Day, in Tunisia
description: The North African country of Tunisia is known for its golden beaches, sunny weather and affordable luxuries. The new 280-room Radisson hotel, in the former French colonial port city of Monastir, is no exception.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) How hard is it to find a job in your city?

title: Reaction to Newlyweds Banking Complaint
description: Nicole Collinss tale of how bank employees resisted her request to add her new husband to her savings account brought in a deluge of opinions  some who saw it as an issue of female financial independence, others who saw it as a function of pushy banking salesmanship.

title: Community Cheers as New Library Opens
description: The opening of the new Lafayette Library and Learning Center on Saturday morning offered a needed respite from the doldrums of downbeat economic news along with some hope that communities can rise above the current bout of budget woes to create something amazing.

title: Shuttle Atlantis Lifts Off for 11-Day Mission
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Atlantis vaulted into orbit on Monday and set off after the International Space Station, carrying 15 tons of spare parts and equipment as a hedge against failures after the shuttle fleet is retired next year.

title: Have You Tried Marketing Your Business With Facebook?
description: We recently posted a guide to marketing with Facebook. One of the main points of the guide, written by Kermit Pattison, is that you now have the opportunity to target your customers at precisely the right moment. For example, from the guide:

title: Hunger in U.S. at a 14-Year High
description: WASHINGTON  The number of Americans who lived in households that lacked consistent access to adequate food soared last year, to 49 million, the highest since the government began tracking what it calls food insecurity 14 years ago, the Department of Agriculture reported Monday.

title: Solar Developer Abandons Water Plans
description: A solar developer caught in the crossfire of the Wests water wars is waving the white flag.

title: Indie Math: More Releases, More Market Share, Less Revenue Per Film
description: Roger Smith, a New York-based analyst with Global Media Intelligence, let slip some interesting numbers while chatting in Santa Monica, Calif., where he spent some time during the recent American Film Market. Back in 1993, Mr. Smith reckoned, small independent film distributors like, say, Samuel Goldwyn Entertainment, captured about 1.9 percent of the domestic box-office receipts, or $96.3 million, with just 63 pictures, which then represented about 24.3 percent of the films released in the United States.

title: YouTube + Univision = TuTube
description: YouTube said Monday that it reached an agreement with Univision, the most-watched Spanish language television network in the United States, to make a wide range of its programs available on the video sharing site.

title: Jay-Z, Will and Jada Pinkett Smith Have Joined Fela! as Producers
description: Jay-Z, Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith have signed on as producers of the new Broadway musical Fela! and will attend the shows opening night at the Eugene ONeill Theater next Monday, Nov. 23, a publicist for the production said.

title: Airline Tests Retail Sales at 35,000 Feet
description: Air travelers in the United States are already paying for sandwiches and drinks, pillows and headsets. So, as airlines look for more ways to help their bottom lines, they have started asking the next logical question: Why not sell limousine services or even tickets to Broadway shows?

title: An Exhibition Examines the Origins of Happiness
description: LONDON | Whatever we can achieve through merit and effort cannot make us truly happy, wrote the Italian philosopher Giorgio Agamben. Happiness can be ours only through magic.

title: Now Showing | Smoking in the Dressing Room
description: In the wake of our recent mayoral election, lets take a moment to remember New York before Bloomberg cleared the air in bars, clubs and restaurants by banning smoking. Sales of Febreze arent the only thing that plummeted in the city: according to the photographer Susanna Howe, no one wants to be pictured smoking anymore. Even those people who you wouldnt think would be all squeamish about it dash to put the cigarette out when you raise the camera to your face, she said.

title: The Claim: A Person Can Contract Two Colds at One Time
description: THE FACTS The rhinovirus that causes most cases of the common cold comes in many strains  at least 99, to be exact.

title: From Melrose Place to Broadway
description: After moving out of Melrose Place, Ashlee Simpson is ready to take on Broadway.

title: Is There Such a Thing as Agro-Imperialism?
description: Dr. Robert Zeigler, an eminent American botanist, flew to Saudi Arabia in March for a series of high-level discussions about the future of the kingdoms food supply. Saudi leaders were frightened: heavily dependent on imports, they had seen the price of rice and wheat, their dietary staples, fluctuate violently on the world market over the previous three years, at one point doubling in just a few months. The Saudis, rich in oil money but poor in arable land, were groping for a strategy to ensure that they could continue to meet the appetites of a growing population, and they wanted Zeiglers expertise.

title: Wesleyans New Satellite Campus? Cheshire Correctional Institution
description: Over on our sister blog City Room, my colleague Alison Leigh Cowan has just posted a fascinating article on an academic program that Wesleyan University in Connecticut is offering inside a nearby prison.

title: The Science of Mysterious Maple Syrup Odors
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Entertainment Industry Workers Urge That Nursing Home Stay Open
description: With the nursing home that has tended generations of actors, directors and crew members scheduled to close and evict many of its elderly residents at years end, a coalition representing entertainment industry workers has issued a public letter urging that the decision be reversed. We know there is enough money to fulfill existing commitments to the current residents, the coalition, Saving the Lives of Our Own, maintains. The groups letter, addressed to Jeffrey Katzenberg, one of several Hollywood heavyweights who serves on the board of the Motion Picture and Television Fund, came after the fund published ads in trade publications last week playing down the impact of the proposed closing. To fail to change the boards direction, the coalition also contends, would provide only further evidence of the moral bankruptcy of the existing board.

title: A New Reactor Concept Inches Forward
description: The Energy Department plans to announce on Tuesday a significant step toward building a new kind of nuclear reactor that could be used to replace the fossil fuels normally needed to complete high-temperature processing at chemical plants, fertilizer factories and oil refineries.

title: Behind the Retail Data, Cautious Consumers
description: The glory of the fall of 2009  at least when it comes to economic statistics  is that the comparisons are so easy.

title: Excerpt: 'Glee'
description: The Fox musical comedy, which follows a high school glee club, is a hit within the Broadway community.

title: No Tuna Surprise
description: [March 19 | Updated  Few were surprised when the United States could not muster support for its call to halt international trade in Atlantic bluefin tuna at this years meeting of parties to the international convention on trade in endangered species.]

title: A Few Final Tidbits From the Governors Awards
description: At Saturday nights Governors Awards, the brand new ceremony for those getting honorary Oscars, this reporter was happily seated at a table with John Lasseter  one of many film academy governors who were distributed around the room to entertain the rest of us. Mr. Lasseter seemed a bit flustered by a suggestion that, with all the job-switching going on at Disney these days, he might swap his Pixar duties for a stint at ESPN.

title: Now Shopping | Independents  Day
description: View Independent Retail Week in a larger map

title: Dobbs-Menendez Match in N.J.?
description: After Lou Dobbs quit his perch as an anchor on CNN last week, there has been speculation that he would run for public office, including a New York Post account suggesting that he could run for United States Senate in 2012 against Bob Menendez, the Democratic incumbent from New Jersey.

title: Congress Digs Deeper Into BofA-Merrill Deal
description: From Louise Story, a DealBook colleague:

title: Ken Ober, Remote Control Host, Is Dead at 52
description: Updated | 4:29 p.m. Ken Ober, a brassy comedian best known as the host of the 1980s-era MTV game show Remote Control, died this weekend, Mark Measures, an agent at Abrams Artists who worked with him, said on Monday. Mr. Ober, who lived in Santa Monica, Calif., was 52. The cause of death was not immediately known.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Flyers End Devils Quest for Record
description: A Monday night of uninteresting matchups, relieved only by Flyers-Devils, in which Jacques Lemaires men brought their eight-game unbeaten streak to South Philly. The Devils also went into the contest with a chance to make history by taking maximum points from each of their first 10 road games, matching a standard set by Buffalo in 2006-7. Could they do it? Home teams listed first:

title: Obama to Form Financial Fraud Task Force
description: President Obama will issue an executive order on Tuesday that will create an administration-wide financial fraud task force, according to an official who has been briefed on the matter.

title: Checking the Right Boxes, but Failing the Patient
description: The voice on the phone was authoritative, even brusque. A father was calling our after-hours line to ask about his teenage daughter.

title: FIFA Employs Age-Old Method to Ensure Playoff Fairness
description: Egypts stunning, hard-fought, last-minute victory over Algeria on Saturday, marred by violence on the eve of the game, forces the North African rivals to face off in another match of hate to determine which team will advance to the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.

title: How Will Your Philanthropic Giving Change This Holiday Season?
description: This weeks Wealth Matters column in The Times looks at some of the surprising ways giving is (and is not) changing amid the economic downturn.

title: Past, Present and Future of the Parking Garage
description: Yes, theres a parking meter  and parking time stamp machines and parking attendant hats. Just about everything you can imagine about the subject of parking is to be found in an exhibition at the National Building Museum in Washington.

title: A Double Dose of the Cold
description: In todays Really? column, Anahad OConnor explores whether a person can have more than one cold at a time.

title: Reducing Deforestation (and CO2) in Brazil
description: Brazil is among the globes top 10 greenhouse gas emitters  largely due to burning of forest land for other uses.

title: Learning Math From the Rubiks Cube
description: Can a Rubiks Cube boost student confidence?

title: A Powerful but Unknown Washington Player
description: The Congressional Budget Office and its mild-mannered director, Douglas W. Elmendorf, may not be well known, but they are playing a large role in the health care debate.

title: Breaching a Barrier to Fight Brain Cancer
description: Dr. Howard Riina threaded a slender tube through a maze of arteries in Dennis Sugrues brain, watching X-ray images on a monitor to track his progress. At the site where a previous operation had removed a malignant tumor, he infused a drug called mannitol and unleashed a flood of the cancer drug Avastin.

title: Capital Waits as Budget Chief Crunches Numbers
description: WASHINGTON  Most people have never heard of Douglas W. Elmendorf. But all of official Washington is waiting to hear what he has to say.

title: A Dental Shift: Implants Instead of Bridges
description: If I have one serious regret about my age, it is that my permanent teeth developed before New York, my hometown, got fluoridated water. I first lost a permanent molar to decay in my early 20s, and the resulting bridge has had to be replaced several times in subsequent decades, ultimately as a four-part apparatus.

title: G.O.P. Senator Supports a Filibuster for Judicial Nominee
description: Senator Jeff Sessions, the ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee, said Monday that he would support a filibuster on Tuesday in an effort to block an up-or-down vote on confirming David F. Hamilton to be a federal appeals court judge.

title: Congos Army Accused of Striking Villages as Refugees Waited for Measles Shots
description: The medical charity Doctors Without Borders has accused the Congolese Army of attacking the villages of Rwandan refugees as they waited for measles shots offered by the charity.

title: New Guidelines on Breast Cancer Draw Opposition
description: Karen Young-Levi has gone for a mammogram every year since she turned 40, and she would not skip the procedure any more than she would skip her spin classes at the gym or stop wearing her seat belt. Its my security blanket, said Ms. Young-Levi, 43, of Medford, N.J.

title: The 0-10 Nets Say Theyve Had Enough
description: The Nets are mad as heck and they arent going to take it anymore. They hope their fans are, too.

title: When Illness Spoils the Cruise Vacation
description: Cruise ships conjure up visions of fine dining, entertainment and relaxation. But as Nicholas Bakalar explains in todays Science Times, you may want to take special care to wash your hands thoroughly after visiting the restroom.

title: Performa 09 | Guido van der Werve
description: Chess masters may insist that kings and queens and rooks and knights speak to them, but at the Marshall Chess Club on West 10th Street on Friday night, the game actually sang  or, at least, plunked tunefully.

title: Fluoride, 1931
description: A dentist named Frederick S. McKay opened his practice in 1901 in Colorado Springs and soon noticed something odd about his patients: many of them had brown, mottled teeth, very ugly but also highly resistant to decay.

title: Shopping With Palo Samko
description: It's not hard to find well-designed folding chairs -- especially useful for the holiday season -- if you know where to look.

title: Dear Banker, Dont Call Me
description: IN any marriage, there is a natural division of labor.

title: To Park Your Pilgrims
description: WITH Thanksgiving fast approaching, many hosts face a perennial challenge: finding enough chairs so that a special someone isnt relegated to the floor.

title: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Nov. 16
description: What makes a photograph funny? The question can be debated endlessly, but let it suffice for this brief paragraph to note that Stephen Crowleys picture of security personnel attending the presidential visit to China is amusing; in a droll, understated, Crowlian kind of way. As your eye scans the picture, most likely from left to right, you pass over figures from two cultures that are as alike in their composure as they are different in dress. Then you reach the punchline: that last pair of hands, clasped in an ever-so-slightly anxious fashion; as who wouldnt be whose job was to protect the president of the United States? We can admire the formality of the first three figures and identify with the fourth.

title: Volcker Criticizes Accounting Proposal
description: A proposal to give banking regulators authority to block accounting standards is a terrible idea, Paul A. Volcker, a former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said Monday.

title: Double X Is Folded Into Slate Magazine
description: After only six months, the Slate Group is folding Double X, a Web site named after the pair of X chromosomes in women, and transforming it into one of the sections of the online magazine Slate.

title: GMAC Chief Resigns as Firm Prepares for More Aid
description: GMAC, the troubled former finance arm of General Motors, said on Monday that its chief executive, Alvaro de Molina, had resigned and would be replaced by Michael A. Carpenter, a former top executive at Citigroup.

title: BlogTalk: Detainees, Obamas Asia Tour
description: Federal authorities on Monday are touring a maximum security prison in northwest Illinois that the government might buy to house Guantnamo Bay detainees.

title: Video: Inside the Congressional Budget Office
description: The Congressional Budget Office is a serious player in the health care debate, but the people behind it are less well-known. Thats by design. They prefer working anonymously, and try to avoid much of the political back and forth that often characterizes deliberations in Congress.

title: Buffett Discloses Stakes in Exxon and Nestl
description: Warren E. Buffetts investment company, Berkshire Hathaway, on Monday disclosed its stakes in Exxon Mobil and Nestl, as well as in the waste disposal company Republic Services and the Travelers Companies.

title: Regulators File Lawsuit Against Alleged Green Investment Ponzi Scheme
description: Post updated | November 18

title: Panel Urges Mammograms at 50, Not 40
description: Most women should start regular breast cancer screening at age 50, not 40, according to new guidelines released Monday by an influential group that provides guidance to doctors, insurance companies and policy makers.

title: A Market Segment Glee Can Call Its Own: Theater Folk
description: Eleven oclock is late for teenagers to start a party on a weeknight, but this was a special occasion. The high school-age cast of Broadways Bye Bye Birdie had gathered to watch Glee, Foxs hourlong musical comedy series that has become a cult favorite among the theater community in New York.

title: U.S. Says Kuwait Company Overbilled It by Millions for Troops Food
description: ATLANTA  A Kuwaiti company defrauded the United States government of tens of millions of dollars by exaggerating the cost of providing food to troops in Iraq, Kuwait and Jordan, federal prosecutors here said Monday.

title: Cannabis Cafe Opens in Oregon
description: Update | Tuesday | 7:37 a.m. At precisely 4:20 p.m. last Friday afternoon, the Cannabis Caf, the first coffee house in Oregon catering to licensed users of medical marijuana, opened for business in Portland.*

title: After Microsoft, Bringing a High-Tech Eye to Professional Kitchens
description: BELLEVUE, Wash.  Inside a nondescript warehouse on a nondescript street of this Seattle suburb is a research laboratory that looks like it came out of a James Bond movie  had Q the gadget master been a gastronome.

title: Correction: A Fulbright in Nigeria That Turned Into a Show
description: In a previous version of this article, a quote was incorrectly attributed. The playwright, Dan Hoyle, did not say, "When he met me, it was like a light to his life." The man he was writing about, Williams Ajayi, said it. Also, a passage may have left the incorrect impression that the author interviewed Mr. Hoyle about his reunion with Mr. Ajayi. The author heard the story at a post-performance discussion, not in a personal conversation with Mr. Hoyle.

title: A Different Type of Senioritis
description: Alison Lacey is a 6-foot senior point guard for Iowa State. Alison, whose hometown is Canberra, Australia, is a communications studies major and, like she did last season, will give The Quad an inside look at the Cyclones this year.

title: Getting Screened for Breast Cancer
description: Most women can wait until theyre 50 to have a mammogram, then get screened every other year. Thats the latest recommendation from an influential task force that reviewed dozens of medical studies and determined that routine mammographs in younger women often resulted in unnecessary tests and unneeded treatments.

title: Perfect Fit: Young Actor and His Role
description: Franco Wicks is the sort of ferociously funny, privately pained character that any rising Hollywood star would love to play  and on Broadway no less, in this falls production of "Superior Donuts." Instead Franco is being played, to acclaim, by an actor who is virtually unknown in New York or Los Angeles, Jon Michael Hill. His is one of the few current Broadway play ensembles that lack a big-name star.

title: The Long Count
description: An interactive calendar for converting between Mayan dates and modern dates.

title: A Case in Antiquities for Finders Keepers
description: Zahi Hawass regards the Rosetta Stone, like so much else, as stolen property languishing in exile. We own that stone, he told Al Jazeera, speaking as the secretary general of Egypts Supreme Council of Antiquities.

title: A Stand-Up Approach to Abortion Rights
description: The setting for a new television commercial by supporters of abortion rights is an unexpected one: a comedy club.

title: On Our Radar
description: 1.) How to rev up the electric-car revolution.

title: Larry Charles Returning to Network Television
description: After devoting most of his energy in recent years to feature films and cable, the writer, director and producer Larry Charles is returning to network television. Mr. Charles, left, who wrote many episodes for the NBC hit series Seinfeld and Mad About You in the 1990s, is to write and direct the pilot of an as-yet-unnamed series for NBC. In this decade Mr. Charles has directed Sacha Baron Cohens Borat and Brno films, and also directed, produced or written episodes for the HBO hit series Curb Your Enthusiasm and Entourage. The new NBC show is to have an ensemble cast and be set in a small town. Mr. Charles told The Hollywood Reporter that the show would try to depict contemporary American life through the prism of a do-it-yourself homemade aesthetic that will mix mediums.

title: Writer of Secret Diary Comes Forward
description: The debate over the authorship and authenticity of the books and blog postings that eventually became the Showtime television series Secret Diary of a Call Girl, criticized for supposedly glamorizing prostitution, seems to be over. A British scientist, Brooke Magnanti, told The Sunday Times of London that she was Belle de Jour, the escort whose sexual experiences were recounted in the blog and in three books. Ms. Magnanti, who works as a child health researcher at the University of Bristol, said she started in the sex trade in 2003, when she was finishing her Ph.D., and continued for more than a year. She explained that she had decided to go public now because she feared an ex-boyfriend was about to expose her, and added on her blog that she was relieved to be able to defend what my experience of sex work is like to all the skeptics and doubters.

title: Football Rules TV
description: NBCs coverage of the New England Patriots-Indianapolis Colts game delivered the highest ratings for a Sunday Night Football broadcast since September. Although final figures were unavailable on Monday, Nielsens preliminary overnight numbers were higher than every other Sunday Night Football game this season except the Sept. 20 matchup of the New York Giants and Dallas Cowboys, which drew 24.8 million viewers when final ratings were released. ABC was runner-up, led by its 9 p.m. drama Desperate Housewives, which had 14.4 million viewers, Extreme Makeover: Home Edition (11.6 million viewers at 8 p.m.) and Brothers & Sisters (10.2 million at 10). CBS and Fox finished in a virtual tie for third place.

title: Women Earn Less Than Men, Especially at the Top
description: In most jobs, the gap between mens and womens earnings narrows greatly when you adjust for factors like career path and experience. But at the top of the income scale  jobs paying more than $100,000  the salary gap between equally qualified men and women is still vast.

title: A Gershwin Prize for McCartney
description: The Library of Congress has named Paul McCartney, below, the third recipient of its Gershwin Prize for Popular Song. It is hard to think of another performer and composer who has had a more indelible and transformative effect on popular song and music of several different genres, the Librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, said in announcing the award on Monday. Mr. McCartney is the first non-American to win the prize; the previous honorees were Paul Simon and Stevie Wonder. The library said an all-star tribute concert was planned for the spring. Mr. McCartney said that as a great admirer of the Gershwins songs he was highly honored to be given the prize, and the library said he planned to play at the tribute show.

title: Warhol Kids Drawings Get Their 15 Minutes
description: They surely wont fetch anywhere near the $43.7 million someone paid last week for one of Andy Warhols seminal silk-screen paintings. But illustrations that Warhol did for a childrens book series in the late 1950s are to be offered by Bloomsbury Auctions on Dec. 9, along with work by other childrens authors and illustrators, including Beatrix Potter, A. A. Milne, Maurice Sendak and Edward Gorey. The early Warhol illustrations (one is above), conventional in style and subject, accompanied the Doubleday Book Clubs Best in Childrens Books series, like a version of The Little Red Hen that shows the title character sowing seeds in a field as a lazy cat, dog and mouse look on. The estimated price is $500 to $600 for the four-book lot.

title: Entertainment Workers Plead for Nursing Home
description: With the nursing home that has tended generations of actors, directors and crew members scheduled to close and evict many of its elderly residents at years end, a coalition representing entertainment industry workers has issued a public letter urging the Motion Picture & Television Fund, which underwrites the home, to reverse its decision. We know there is enough money to fulfill existing commitments to the current residents, the coalition, Saving the Lives of Our Own, said. The groups letter, addressed to Jeffrey Katzenberg, one of several Hollywood heavyweights on the funds board, came after the fund published ads in trade publications last week minimizing the impact of the proposed closing. To fail to change the boards direction, the coalition contends, would only provide further evidence of the moral bankruptcy of the existing board.

title: Ashlee Simpson To Play Roxie Hart On Broadway
description: After playing the Orange Bowl and Saturday Night Live, Ashlee Simpson is ready to take on Broadway. Ms. Simpson, 25, announced on Monday that she would play Roxie Hart in the musical Chicago for 10 weeks, beginning on Nov. 30. Ms. Simpson, best known for the hit CDs Autobiography and I Am Me and a much publicized lip-synching episode on television, has played Roxie before, on the West End in London, but is to be making her Broadway debut. Most recently, she has been a regular on the revived version of Melrose Place on the CW network, but that shows producers announced last month that her character would be written out of the story.

title: Palin Onstage, Still Moving Off Message
description: There were no questions about the Bush doctrine, but Sarah Palins appearance Monday on The Oprah Winfrey Show to promote her memoir looked less like a celebratory comeback than a redo of the presidential campaign.

title: Travels in Cyberspace: The Monday Report
description: When a writer for the Travel section of The Washington Post was in Paris recently, he found culinary happiness in a somewhat unlikely place: a wine-shop-turned-bistro called Les Papilles, run by a man named Bertrand Bluy And he wasnt alone. During a recent lunch, all 15 wood-and-iron bistro tables were occupied mostly by Parisians stimulating their papilles (taste buds) with the delicately seasoned specials of the day  gazpacho of fresh mushrooms followed by slow-simmered duck flank in a sweet and pungent sauce with new potatoes and vegetables  as well as farm-made cheeses and Bluys inventive desserts, writes Robert V. Camuto, in an article that appeared this weekend.

title: Gruden Extends Contract With ESPN
description: Scratch Jon Gruden off your wish lists, N.F.L. owners and college athletic directors. At least for now, the former Bucs and Raiders head coach, who has made a widely praised debut this season as an analyst for Monday Night Football, plans to remain a talking head and stay off the sidelines. On Monday, ESPN announced that he had signed a multiyear contract extension with the network.

title: Liberty, Equality, Gastronomy: Paris via a 19th-Century Guide
description: A marvelous painting of a gourmand at his table hangs in the Muse Carnavalet in Paris  a portly, pink-faced figure happily gorging on a regal casserole, with a bottle of wine at one elbow and a luscious-looking souffl at the other. It is traditionally believed to be a portrait of Alexandre-Balthazar-Laurent Grimod de la Reynire, an aristocrat notorious in Napoleonic France for gratifying his palate with the same abandon as his contemporary the Marquis de Sade showed in indulging carnal desires. Whether or not the painting is actually Grimods likeness, it captures the eccentric, omnivorous spirit that made him not only a gustatory symbol in the Paris of his day, but the grand-pre of all modern food writers as well.

title: Christian Rock Borrows an Edge From iPhone
description: It only took a mere $8.97 for David Crowder*Band to demonstrate that its in a different league from its Christian rock peers. At Terminal 5 on Friday night, before playing Church Music  Dance (!), a surprisingly credible disco song, Mr. Crowder announced: This one has New York City all over it. This is like Studio 54 right here. (Give or take six blocks and three decades, but whos counting?)

title: Ponzi du Jour: S.E.C. Uncovers Green Scheme
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Monday that it had uncovered yet another Ponzi scheme, this time with a company that purported to invest in environmentally friendly, or green, projects. The agency has been focusing attention on such fraud cases ever since Bernard L. Madoffs multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme went undetected for years and years.

title: Auctions, Auctions Everywhere
description: In a column in The New York Times on Sunday, Richard Thaler explored what he called the diabolical economics of Swoopo, an online auction site. Swoopo sells merchandise, typically for below its price elsewhere, but charges 60 cents for every bid. Auction prices rise in one-cent increments, which means that Swoopo ends up making a lot of money off its bidders.

title: Desperately Seeking Dad: A Murder Mystery
description: Zachary Lazars father died in 1975 of distinctly unnatural causes in a stairwell at a Phoenix parking garage. His name was Ed Lazar, and he was an accountant with ties to the once-booming land-fraud community in Arizona. Though Ed Lazars younger son, Zachary, did not know his father well, he has written a pungent-sounding but maddeningly vague book about Eds murder. Thanks to Mr. Lazars strenuously literary efforts, total strangers can now find themselves baffled by the Ed Lazar story, too.

title: Hung Jury
description: Were certain to hear lots of arguments . . . all weekend long, wrote my weekend counterpart, Tobin Harshaw, on Friday evening, of the then-nascent debate on the administrations decision to try 9/11-plotter Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other men in federal court in New York City.

title: Google Lunch and Get David Chang
description: Most office workers have to be content with sandwiches at their desks or, if theyre lucky, something hot and not too awful from the company cafeteria.

title: Who Should Own the Rosetta Stone?
description: Should the British Museum return the Rosetta Stone to Egypt? Should the export of a nations cultural property be banned? Should there be laws giving national governments ownership of any antiquity unearthed today within their borders?

title: Why New Gift Card Rules Wont Take Effect Until Next Summer
description: The Federal Reserve Board proposed rules Monday requiring more disclosure of gift card fees and more restrictions on expiration dates. While the final rules wouldnt take effect until next August, an effort is already underway to get the rules in place in time for the holiday season.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Blazing Saddles'
description: A. O. Scott reviews Mel Brooks' 1974 film, which satirizes race relations both in Hollywood westerns and in American culture.

title: Howard Marks on Lessons of the Financial Crisis
description: In his latest chairmans letter, Howard S. Marks of Oaktree Capital Management takes a look back at the causes and lessons learned from the current financial crisis.

title: A Revolutionary War Widows Estate Becomes a Preservation Battleground
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  In the mid-1980s J. Dennis Delafield and his cousins faced a hard fact: They could no longer afford to maintain the estate established in 1802 by their distant ancestor, Janet Livingston Montgomery, widow of Gen. Richard Montgomery, a hero of the Revolutionary War.

title: Help for Gay Caregivers Who Look After Elderly
description: When Michelle Obama pitched the presidents health care reform efforts to a room of women at the White House last week, one group of New Yorkers present clung to every word.

title: Is Doomsday Coming? Perhaps, but Not in 2012
description: NASA said last week that the world was not ending  at least anytime soon. Last year, CERN, the European Center for Nuclear Research, said the same thing, which I guess is good news for those of us who are habitually jittery. How often do you have a pair of such blue-ribbon scientific establishments assuring us that everything is fine?

title: New GMAC Chief: We Need Less Aid Than Expected
description: For Michael A. Carpenter, stepping in as GMACs new chief executive is an assignment hes used to: nursing an ailing financial institution back to health.

title: Repetitive Guitar Strums Rooted in Metal but Not Confined by It
description: Black metal and doom metal are musical styles, but they are also modes of being. Theyre body and brain and nature. That furious black-metal clog of screams, strums and beats is rain or wind or anxiety or catatonic excitement. That deep-frequency doom-metal drone is the unfathomable drag of eternity: the Creators cello sawing away for a billion more choruses than youll ever get to hear. Ones a head sound, ones a chest sound. Theyre infinite wells of culture and meaning. They wont go away.

title: Cleric Reportedly Denies Ordering Fort Hood Attack
description: Last Friday The Lede reported that Anwar al-Awlaki  a radical, American-born cleric and blogger who knew at least one of the 9/11 hijackers and exchanged e-mail messages last year with the Army psychiatrist charged in the Fort Hood shootings  had suddenly gone silent, days after a post on his blog called the rampage the act of a hero.

title: Mixing Contemporary (Cough) With Difficult (Cough) Classical
description: The brilliant French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard enjoys giving recital programs that mix old and new works in ways intended to intrigue, delight and even rattle audiences. He did so again, with fascinating results, on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Music in Review
description: RUMI SYMPHONY PROJECT

title: Iridium Responds
description: A posting in this blog on Iridium caught the attention of the company, and its chief executive sends the following:

title: A Gallery of Heroes, Up for Sale
description: Joe Kubert, a comic book artist since 1938, has little interest in the accumulated work of his last seven decades; his focus is on new projects, he said recently. But comic book fans who feel differently about this celebrated illustrator will have a chance to peruse and even own some of that older work this week, when 18 covers and interior pages, published from the 1940s to 1990, are put up for sale.

title: Critics Picks Video: Blazing Saddles
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott discusses Mel Brookss controversial 1974 spoof Blazing Saddles, which looks at what happens when a black man (played by Cleavon Little) becomes the sheriff of a small town.

title: In Search of the Geep
description: Q. I have a soft-drink bottle cap with a trivia item printed inside that says that if a sheep and a goat mate, the offspring is a geep. Can this be true?

title: A Change at the Top of GMAC as It Negotiates for Another Government Bailout
description: DETROIT  GMAC Financial Services, the former lending arm of General Motors, replaced its chief executive on Monday as it negotiates for another round of bailout financing from the federal government.

title: Audit Faults New York Fed in A.I.G. Bailout
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York gave up much of its power in high-pressure negotiations with the American International Groups trading partners last year, according to a government report made public on Monday.

title: Palin on Oprah, Reloading Before 2012
description: Is she or isnt she running for president in 2012?

title: Obama Official and Goldman Assess Insurers
description: On the White Houses official blog, Nancy-Ann DeParle, the director of the Office of Health Reform, rebuts recent claims by the insurance industry that the proposed health care overhaul would actually increase the cost of premiums.

title: When Mountain Lions Hunt, They Prey on the Weak
description: Predators do not always play fair. Sometimes they choose their victims based on physical condition, preferring young, old, sick or injured prey.

title: S.M.U. Is Ready for a Luau
description: When Southern Methodist Coach June Jones lured the former Kansas City Chiefs coach Frank Gansz out of retirement last year to be his special teams coordinator, he made him a promise.

title: At Least They Disclosed It
description: Should this company receive an award for Accidentally Honest Disclosure?

title: City Ballet Names Chief to Oversee Business
description: In a reflection of the challenges many arts companies are facing, including a need to develop new audiences and balance the books, New York City Ballet on Monday announced that it was creating an executive director position to oversee all nonartistic matters and named Katherine E. Brown, chief operating officer of the public radio station WNYC, to the job.

title: That Face of Protest in Iran, Fading Fast
description: Neda Agha-Soltan died one of historys most-watched deaths. It was in the midst of the fury over the Iranian presidential election of June 12, and for a moment it seemed as if the young womans final moments  shot on a Tehran street on June 20 as a protest swirled around her, dying at the scene while a cellphone camera recorded it all in images soon flashed around the world  would be the start of something earthshaking.

title: Report Faults Handling of A.I.G. Bailout
description: Two days before the Federal Reserve Bank of New York paid 100 cents on the dollar to the American International Groups trading partners in return for tearing up contracts with the insurance giant, one bank volunteered to take a modest haircut  but never got the chance.

title: With New Presses, Daily News Is Betting on World of Print
description: WITH advertising and circulation falling, and with publishers pessimistic about their prospects of bouncing back, newspapers are slashing expenses these days, not finding new ways to spend enormous sums of money. Industry executives and analysts regularly field questions about how much longer ink-and-paper media will be with us.

title: Bristol Exchange Eases Downsizing
description: The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb has found a clever way to shrink. The company is offering its stockholders the chance to swap at a discount into shares of its publicly traded subsidiary Mead Johnson Nutrition. Reducing the number of outstanding shares would improve Bristols earnings per share, a move that should come in handy as patents expire and put up to a third of its revenue from drug sales at risk.

title: N.F.L. Quick Hits From Week 10: Why Passing Is King
description: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

title: After Quake in Italy, Seeking Greener Pastures
description: LAQUILA, Italy  On a recent autumn afternoon, half a year after a devastating earthquake struck here, a small flock of sheep and goats made its way through the ghostly, ravaged center of this ancient hilltop city.

title: Bloggingheads: American Anti-Scientism
description: Michael Specter, left, author of "Denialism," and Chris Mooney, author of "Unscientific America," discuss the power that unscientific beliefs hold in America.

title: Bobby Frankel, 68, Trainer of Champion Horses, Dies
description: Bobby Frankel, one of the most successful American thoroughbred trainers of the last 40 years, whose horses included the champions Bertrando, Ghostzapper and Empire Maker, the winner of the 2003 Belmont Stakes, died Monday at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 68.

title: Washington Blade Newspaper Closes
description: The Washington Blade and several other gay newspapers and magazines around the country learned on Monday that they had been shut down after a federal agency that oversaw them was unable to find buyers for them.

title: Digging Into the Science of That Old-Book Smell
description: If you have torn yourself away from the virtual library that is the Internet long enough to visit a real library, you know that the smell of old books  musty, slightly acidic, even grassy  is instantly recognizable. But is it quantifiable? And if so, might old-book odor prove useful to librarians and conservators charged with preserving collections?

title: Sharks Ortmeyer Keeps Playing Despite Risk of Blood Clots
description: When Jed Ortmeyer steps onto the ice, he shifts his focus to hockey  and those closest to him cannot help worrying.

title: An Air-Traffic Upgrade to Improve Travel by Plane
description: EGG HARBOR, N.J.  Up in the cockpit, Larry Van Hoy, a Federal Aviation Administration pilot, was flying low-tech. Radar showed a bit of nearby cloud cover, and to learn about other aircraft, he talked to the ground controller or looked out the window.

title: Changes in the Climate and a Windier Great Lake
description: Chalk up another effect of climate change: its getting windier over Lake Superior.

title: U.S. Attorney Nominee Criticized Over Raids
description: Eleventh-hour criticism is arising over President Obamas nomination for United States attorney in northern Iowa of a prosecutor who had a leading role in the criminal cases against hundreds of illegal immigrants arrested in a May 2008 raid at a meatpacking plant in Postville, Iowa.

title: Chinese Solar Panel Firm to Open Plant in Arizona
description: Suntech Power, Chinas largest solar panel manufacturer, plans to open its first American plant near Phoenix, the company announced on Monday. It would be the first time a Chinese solar company has built a manufacturing plant in the United States, experts said.

title: Making Cryoseared Duck
description: Nathan Myhrvold, a former chief technology officer at Microsoft, and Chris Young demonstrate how to cryosear and cryorender duck. (StarChefs.com)

title: Liberals Urge Reid to Keep Public Option
description: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, met on Monday night with a group of liberal Senate Democrats who urged him not to back down from his decision to put a government-run insurance plan, or public option, in the major health care legislation that he is working to complete.

title: Manipulating Nature (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Stockholders Really Know Whats Best?
description: When news of Krafts hostile bid for Cadbury broke in England a couple of months back, it caused intense debate, including whether an American company should, by all rights, really be the new home of a well-known British brand that dates back to 1824.

title: In Your Dreams (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Libyan Leader in Italy Seeks Tall, Leggy and Pious
description: ROME  The 200 women who answered a Rome modeling agencys advertisement for tall, attractive party guests thought they would be attending an elegant soire on Sunday. They were  only the host turned out to be the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and instead of hors doeuvres he offered them copies of the Koran and urged them to convert to Islam, the Italian news media reported Monday.

title: Solar Journeys (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Disagreement Over Goals at U.N. Meeting on Hunger
description: A United Nations summit meeting on combating hunger that opened in Rome on Monday underscored the split between rich and poor countries on the issue, with the industrialized nations balking at concrete targets.

title: Lehman Estate Sues Barclays Over 2008 Deal
description: Lehman Brothers bankrupt estate filed a lawsuit against Barclays Capital on Monday, saying Barclays improperly pocketed more than $5 billion when it bought most of Lehmans North American operations last year. (Read the lawsuit after the jump.)

title: Zambia Judge Clears Editor in Morals Case Over Photos
description: JOHANNESBURG  A Zambian newspaper editor was acquitted Monday on charges of distributing obscene materials with the intent of corrupting public morals, a case filed against her after she sent photos of a woman in childbirth to government officials and other prominent figures.

title: Britain: Police Arrest Five Men in Antiterrorism Operation
description: The police arrested five men on Monday in connection with what was described as the incitement of terrorism overseas. The men, ages 21 to 62, were arrested in raids before dawn in the northern cities of Manchester and Bolton, and at a hotel near Heathrow Airport in London. The police statement gave no further details of the plot or the mens identities. This is a complex and ongoing operation, which has now reached the point where it was necessary to make arrests, said Assistant Chief Constable Dave Thompson of the Greater Manchester Police.

title: China: Police Detain an Advocate for Victims of Tainted Dairy Items
description: Zhao Lianhai, a father who has been organizing parents whose children suffered from drinking tainted dairy products last year, was detained by the police on Friday in Beijing, according to a report published Monday in The Global Times, a popular newspaper. Mr. Zhao was taken from his home by about a dozen police officers, his wife, Li Xuemei, told the newspaper. The officers also confiscated two computers, a camera, a video recorder and an address book. Parents whose children were sickened or died from drinking dairy products tainted with melamine, an industrial chemical, have been waging a campaign for justice, but local governments and the central government in Beijing have repeatedly harassed them.

title: 30 Years After Murder, Is His Appeal Too Late?
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court agreed Monday to decide whether it is too late for an Alabama man to argue that the murder that sent him to death row was not a capital crime when he committed it.

title: Investors Seem Unshaken After Study of Merck Drug
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Such are the fortunes of the Merck cholesterol drug Zetia that a study reporting a lack of medical benefit is considered good news for investors.

title: Even in a Terror Attack, Seeing the Best of India
description: I FELL in love with India when I was a child. My parents were both born in Bombay, and we went back to India frequently.

title: SUNY Weighs the Value of Division I Sports
description: New Yorks state university system is among the largest in the country, but it has never been known for athletic prominence, unlike major public institutions in states like Florida, Pennsylvania and Michigan.

title: New Zealand Group Has Plans to Retrieve Explorers Whisky
description: Specialists from New Zealand plan to recover two crates of Scotch whisky left more than 100 years ago by the polar explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton and trapped deep in Antarctic ice. A spokesman for the New Zealand Antarctic Heritage Trust said the whisky trove had been found under a hut built at Cape Royds, a promontory on McMurdo Sound, during Mr. Shackletons first South Pole expedition of 1907-9. The expedition ended in failure when the explorer was forced to turn back about 100 miles from the pole. A trust spokesman said the crates and the bottles would undergo conservation work in New Zealand before being returned to the hut, which is being restored as a museum. The spokesman, Al Fastier, said there were no plans to sample the McKinlay & Co. whisky, but the distiller Whyte & Mackay, owner of the brand, said it hoped to acquire a bottle with a view to recreating the century-old blend.

title: A Constitutional Case in a Box of Cash
description: STEVE BIERFELDT had a little tin box, packed in plain view in his carry-on bag, when he went through airport security in St. Louis last March. He often carried the little box, he later told me. But this time, the box would become a big deal.

title: Rookie of Year Honor Can Be the Beginning or the End
description: The fickle nature of the rookie of the year award was displayed on the Yankees roster all season. Derek Jeter was the American League winner in 1996 and is still among the best players in baseball. But two subsequent winners rarely got off the bench: the utilitymen Eric Hinske (2002) and Angel Berroa (2003).

title: Get Your Samosa On
description: Start compiling those Hot Pocket jokes now: the  Samosa Crawl, starting off tonight near Curry Hill, should give you ample time to riff on the goodness of meat-stuffed pastry as you explore the citys many varieties. A samosa scorecard will be provided; an appetite for hot sauce is expected.

title: Jesus Lizard and Das Racist
description: There are still tickets available for tonights show by the Jesus Lizard, the recently re-formed 90s alt-rock champions, at Irving Plaza. Still bitter over their appearance at the beyond-raucous Vice Halloween party? Check out  Das Racist, the jokey hip-hop act (Combination Pizza Hut/Taco Bell) thats got art school cred. In a recent show, the duo was characteristically shambolic and characteristically entertaining, Jon Caramanica wrote, holding together a half-hour set of half-performed songs with hyperliterate reference points and self-aware charm. Theyll be at Santos tonight.

title: Funny Ha Ha
Scenes From a Marriage
description: Hello again from the land of sun and fun.

title: One Victory Makes the Future Brighter for Wie and the L.P.G.A.
description: It was a good cellphone signal that bounced off the satellite from somewhere outside Guadalajara, Mexico, on Sunday night. It carried a voice that sounded much the way Michelle Wies voice used to sound, before all the pressure got to it and drained the youthful spontaneity right out of it.

title: Lehmans Estate Is Suing Barclays Over Units Sale
description: Lehman Brothers bankrupt estate filed a lawsuit against Barclays Capital on Monday, saying Barclays improperly pocketed more than $5 billion when it bought most of Lehmans North American operations last year.

title: Another Late Loss Leaves Jets Baffled
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  As the Jacksonville Jaguars sliced up the field in the fourth quarter of Sundays game, the Jets defensive players signaled to one another and shouted between plays to restore some order. But the more they waved their hands and shifted before the snaps, the less effective they seemed.

title: Thomas Already Creating Waves at Florida International
description: Isiah Thomas is no stranger to controversy, and it certainly seems to have found him again as the coach at Florida International, the latest stop in his basketball journey.

title: A Racial Divide Is Bridged by Recession
description: McDONOUGH, Ga.  During the housing boom, Henry County, a suburb of Atlanta, had its share of racial tension as more and more blacks joined the tens of thousands of others pouring in, creating a standoffish gap between the newcomers and the countys oldtimers.

title: Can I Put You On Hold?
description: There is a class of utterances that, when encountered, produces irritation, distress and, in some cases, the desire to kill. You hear or read one of these and your heart sinks. Everyone will have his or her (non)favorites. Mine is a three-word announcement on the TV screen, To Be Continued, which says, I know that you have become invested in this story and are eager to find out how it ends, but youre going to have to wait for a few days or a week or a month or forever. In the great order of things, it is only a minor inconvenience, but it is experienced as a deprivation; you were banking on something and now it has been taken away.

title: Giants, Fresh Off Bye, Look for Turnaround
description: If quarterback Eli Manning needed inspiration during the Giants bye week, he received a double dose to go with some family football values to ease the pain of a four-game losing streak.

title: Chicago Schools Chief Commits Suicide
description: CHICAGO  The president of the Chicago Board of Education, who had served in a variety of prominent posts here over three decades, was found dead early Monday morning on the banks of the Chicago River, in what the medical examiner ruled a suicide.

title: A.I.G. - A Giant, Humbled
description: Once the world's dominant insurance company, American International Group has been diminished by disastrous bets on mortgage-backed securities to its current incarnation, one totally dependent on the Treasury and the Federal Reserve for survival.

title: A Co-Founder of Microsoft Has Lymphoma
description: Paul Allen, a private investor and co-founder of Microsoft, has been told he has non-Hodgkins lymphoma, according to an e-mail message sent to employees of his investment firm, Vulcan.

title: No Choice of Evils Defense in Oil Lease Case, Judge Rules
description: DENVER  A college student who bid on and won more than $1.8 million in federal oil and gas leases last year without the intent or ability to pay will not be allowed to argue in court that he acted out of necessity to protect the environment, a federal judge ruled on Monday.

title: Yo Jude: Strong Passwords
description: Q. and A. columnist J. D. Biersdorfer and Personal Tech editor Sam Grobart on how to strengthen your passwords.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Prods Obama on Job Losses
description: With unemployment among blacks at more than 15 percent, the N.A.A.C.P. will join several other groups on Tuesday to call on President Obama to do more to create jobs.

title: All Systems Go
description: I loved this puzzle. It was novel, fun and had a nice, crunchy helping of non-theme entries. We were seeing double with a pair of constructors yesterday. Today, its John Farmers theme that has us seeing double  and with an added bonus.

title: Commuters Overlooking Free Treasure
description: I might not have appreciated the marvel of the Grand Central Terminal water fountain if it hadnt been for the notebook.

title: Needing Proof She Had, Indeed, Embraced a New Home
description: It took all of three hours for Carmen Cruz to decide to leave her homeland behind in exchange for a new life in the United States.

title: Online Maps: Everyman Offers New Directions
description: SAN FRANCISCO  They dont know it, but people who use Googles online maps may be getting directions from Richard Hintz.

title: Knicks and DAntoni Appear to Be Undone by a Rebuilding Plan
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  If an expression, like a picture, conveys much more than words, then Mike DAntonis face reads like an encyclopedia of pain.

title: Backman and the Mets, Together Again
description: Wally Backman returned to the embrace of Major League Baseball after a five-year exile Monday when the Mets appointed him the manager of the Class A Brooklyn Cyclones. He will be introduced at a news conference Tuesday at KeySpan Park in Coney Island, less than 25 miles from where, as the feisty second baseman on the 1986 World Series championship team, Backman enjoyed his greatest glories.

title: Paterson Calls Obama Wrong on 9/11 Trial
description: Gov. David A. Paterson on Monday criticized the Obama administrations decision to try five men linked to the Sept. 11 attacks in a civilian court in Manhattan.

title: Despite Mayors Opposition, Council Approves a 5-Minute Grace Period on Parking
description: The City Council overwhelmingly approved a bill on Monday that would provide a five-minute grace period to drivers who are late to feed a meter or move their cars on street-cleaning days, setting the stage for a showdown with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who vowed to veto the legislation.

title: In Brooklyn, Her Farmers Heart Is Happy
description: Kristen Schafenacker, 26, has the rare title of New York City farmer. Born in Fort Wayne, Ind., she attended Mount Holyoke College, where her devotion to food took root, and is now the senior farm assistant at Added Value, an urban farm located opposite the Ikea in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

title: Lottery Numbers
In Albany, Inaction Trumps Spending Cuts
description: ALBANY  An agreement to cut more than $3 billion from the state budget remained well out of reach on Monday, as the governor and a top Democrat spent the day trading recriminations about bridging the budget gap.

title: Gunfire by Police Officers Declined 16% Last Year
description: New York City police officers fired their weapons about 16 percent less last year than in the previous year, according to a Police Department report released on Monday.

title: Ex-Secretary Describes How Brunos Jobs Intertwined
description: ALBANY  For nearly a quarter of a century, Patricia M. Stackrow was the self-described gatekeeper to Joseph L. Bruno, one of New Yorks most powerful elected officials: She controlled his schedule, arranged his meetings and drafted his official financial disclosure forms.

title: With Beckham in Final, No M.L.S. Regrets
description: David Beckham was conspicuously absent in the days before last years M.L.S. championship game, which was played at his teams home stadium. League officials said he had previous engagements, but for Beckham, the leagues marquee player and its highest-paid on-field employee, it simply seemed like bad form and a slap in the face to the league.

title: Retracing the Route of Shepherds, From L'Aquila
description: A small group of local activists, animal-lovers and dreamers have organized a 150-mile journey for a flock of sheep from the earthquake-ravaged L'Aquila to Foggia in the Puglia Region in Italy.

title: New Rules to Begin for Hudson River Airspace
description: New rules for airplanes, helicopters and other aircraft operating in the congested air corridor above the Hudson River will go into effect on Thursday, the Federal Aviation Administration announced on Monday.

title: Countdown Clocks for 3 Bronx Subway Stations
description: In London, Paris and Washington, subway riders need only look up at a digital sign to know how many minutes it will be until the next train arrives. New Yorks straphangers usually resort to peering into a darkened tunnel.

title: Coalition Vows Wage Fight Over Kingsbridge Armory Mall Proposal
description: Bronx Borough President Rubn Daz Jr. stood before a raucous crowd and vowed to continue fighting a new revolution.

title: Paying Extra for Green Power, and Getting Ads Instead
description: The solicitations have been flooding peoples mailboxes lately: pay a bit more on your electricity bill for 100 percent clean wind power. Or, the fliers say, buy green power certificates to offset your global warming emissions.

title: Iversons Time With Memphis Ends and Future Is Uncertain
description: Allen Iversons playing days in Memphis proved short-lived, and his next destination is unknown.

title: In the Wilderness, a New Frontier
description: Anchorage

title: Obamas Judicial Nominations
description: The Obama administration is off to a slow start on judicial nominations, but the Senate, which has delayed in confirming the choices President Obama has made, also bears a good part of the blame. The administration and the Senate leadership should pick up the pace of nominations and confirmations in order to restore some balance to a federal judiciary that was pushed sharply to the right by former President George W. Bush.

title: Their Future Is Ours
description: There are 16 million children in immigrant families in the United States, one of the fastest-growing segments of the population. Its an old American story made new in the age of globalization, when waves of human displacement in recent decades have led to immigration on a scale not seen since Ellis Island. But a country that has been so good for so long at integrating new Americans is stumbling under the challenge.

title: Puppets in Congress
description: For a depressing example of how members of Congress can be spoon-fed the views and even the exact words of high-powered lobbying firms, consider remarks inserted into the Congressional Record after the debate and vote on health care reform in the House.

title: The Human Moon
description: Over the past four months, NASAs Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter spacecraft, which is in a low polar orbit over the Moon, has returned a series of images of Apollo landing sites showing the vessels themselves at rest on the Moons surface.

title: A 9/11 Trial, in the Shadow of Horror
description: To the Editor:

title: Tension in Iraqi Kurdistan: An Officials View
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Marriage in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation of Futurity
description: When European settlers first came to North America, they saw flocks of geese so big that it took them 30 minutes to all take flight and forests that seemed to stretch to infinity. They came to two conclusions: that Gods plans for humanity could be completed here, and that they could get really rich in the process.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Tuesday about the scheduled execution in Iran of Ehsan Fattahian, a Kurdish activist who was accused of armed struggle against the regime, misstated his age. Mr. Fattahian was 26 years old, not 23. (He has since been executed, according to his lawyer.)

title: What the Future May Hold
description: What will the United States be like in 20 years when todays toddlers are in college or trying to land that first job or maybe thinking about starting a family?

title: Inventing a Better Patent System
description: Boston

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 7 about two Chinese governmental agencies vying for oversight of a popular online game misstated the title of an official, Tuo Zuhai of the Culture Ministry, one of those agencies. He is the deputy director of the ministrys department of Cultural Market, not deputy culture minister.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,353 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 909 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 5 about gay rights activists considering a change in approach after Maine voters blocked same-sex marriage described the federal Defense of Marriage Act incorrectly. It prohibits the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriage; it is not a ban on same-sex marriage.

title: Corrections
Iverson Leaves Memphis and His Future Is Uncertain
description: Allen Iversons playing days in Memphis proved short-lived, and his next destination is unknown.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit on Monday with an article about opposition to a planned garage for city sanitation trucks in an industrial neighborhood just above TriBeCa misspelled part of the name of one of the architectural firms that created a rendering of the citys proposal. It is Weisz & Yoes Architecture, not Weisz & Hoes.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Friday about Fantastic Mr. Fox referred incorrectly to the character Kylie, who becomes Mr. Foxs accomplice. He is an opossum, not a mole.

title: Corrections
Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Inquiry Into Labor Leader Is Requested
description: Two conservative groups, Americans for Tax Reform and the Alliance for Worker Freedom, formally asked federal prosecutors in Washington to investigate what they said were potentially illegal lobbying activities by Andy Stern, president of the Service Employees International Union. With Mr. Stern visiting the White House more than 20 times during President Obamas first six months in office, the two groups said he apparently had spent more than 20 percent of his work on lobbying, which would generally have required that he be a registered lobbyist. Michelle Ringuette, a spokeswoman for the union, criticized the move as an effort to deny working people a say in health insurance reform. Andy Stern spends less than 20 percent of his time talking to elected representatives, she said. He spends 100 percent of his time trying to help workers get a better life.

title: Showcase: 12,000-Faceted Diamond
description: By the time the Yankees rushed the field to celebrate their 27th World Series victory, Robert Caplin had photographed the action  12,000 times. The result is a romantic and captivating time-lapse presentation.

title: Study Foresees an Increase in Obesity and Its Costs
description: While Congress searches for ways to slow the growth of health care spending, a new study suggests that its efforts may be overwhelmed by the surging prevalence of obesity.

title: A.T.&T. Buys Dominant Stake in Western Union
