description: Wednesday, Nov. 17, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Free Speech and the Former Domestic Terrorist
description: The Issue

title: Edward Woodward, Star of Spy Series, Dies at 79
description: Edward Woodward, a British actor with a long rsum in television and theater who was best known in the United States as the star of The Equalizer, a dramatic series about an ex-spy turned righteous vigilante in New York City, died on Monday in Truro, Cornwall, England. He was 79 and lived in London and Cornwall.

title: Ken Ober, Host of Remote Control on TV, Dies at 52
description: Ken Ober, a brassy comedian best known as the host of the 1980s-era MTV game show Remote Control, was found dead on Sunday in his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 52.

title: Word of the Day | cloister
description: cloister  \kloi-str\  noun and verb

title: YouTube to Help Sites Gather News Clips
description: YouTube has signed up NPR, Politico, The Huffington Post and The San Francisco Chronicle for YouTube Direct, a new method for managing video submissions from readers.

title: Bill Belichicks Decision, in His Words
description: Bill Belichick addressed his controversial fourth-down conversion try  in his radio appearance on WEEI on Monday, via Gregg Rosenthal of ProFootballTalk:

title: Troubling Time for Turtles
description: WHOM do you know who might be interested in turtle tourism?

title: Zimbabwe: Judge Will Continue to Preside in Terrorism Case
description: Chinembiri Bhunu, the judge in the politically charged trial of Roy Bennett, a senator and former commercial farmer, on Monday refused to recuse himself, though Mr. Bennetts lawyers accused him of bias. The trial got under way with Mr. Bennett pleading not guilty to terrorism charges, as the prosecution began to make its case against him.

title: 1 Dead and 4 Hurt in Bronx Gunfire
description: One person was killed and four others were injured, two critically  including a 15-year-old girl whom the police called an innocent bystander  in two separate shootings in the Bronx on Monday, the police said.

title: News Quiz | November 17, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: When Should a Person Be Considered an Adult?
description: At 18? At 21? Should you be able to fight in a war before you can rent a car? Is it cruel to sentence a teenager to life without parole? Why are our laws and rules on this issue so inconsistent, and how do they affect you?As the Supreme Court considers the question of whether children should ever be sentenced to life without parole for crimes that dont involve murder, Catherine Rampell asks How Old Is Old Enough?:

title: Will Bristols Exchange Ease Downsizing?
description: The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb has found a clever way to shrink, according to Breakingviews.com. The company is offering its stockholders the chance to swap at a discount into shares of its publicly traded subsidiary Mead Johnson Nutrition. Reducing the number of outstanding shares would improve Bristols earnings per share, a move that should come in handy as patents expire and put up to a third of its revenue from drug sales at risk, the Web site says.

title: Cautioning JPMorgan on Cazenove
description: JPMorgan Chase and Cazenove appear to agree that the destination is better than the journey.

title: Golden Gate Denies Playboy Rumors
description: Golden Gate Capital wants to make it clear: it is most definitely not bidding for Playboy.

title: RockYou Rocks On With $50 Million
description: RockYou, a developer of social network applications, has landed a hefty $50 million in fresh funding, TechCrunch reported.

title: AOL Spin-Off Is Set for Dec. 9
description: The media conglomerate Time Warner said Monday that it would spin off its AOL unit to shareholders on Dec. 9, almost nine tumultuous years after one of the most disastrous corporate mergers in history.

title: India Energy Producer Set for $648 Million I.P.O.
description: JSW Steel, Indias third-largest steel maker, expects to open the initial public offering of its energy business next month, valuing the unit at about 200 billion rupees ($4.3 billion).

title: PPR, a French Retailer, Plans I.P.O. for African Division
description: PPR, the French retail and luxury group, said Tuesday that it planned to raise as much as 1 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in the initial public offering of its African distribution unit, CFAO.

title: Murdochs Democrat Liaison to Leave News Corp.
description: Gary Ginsberg, a close adviser to Rupert Murdoch for 11 years who often served as a liaison between the conservative Mr. Murdoch and the Democratic Party, will leave News Corporation at the end of the year, The New York Timess Tim Arango reported.

title: Volcker Criticizes Accounting Proposal
description: A proposal to give banking regulators authority to block accounting standards is a terrible idea, Paul A. Volcker, a former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said on Monday.

title: Wormonauts
description: Worms sent into outer space.

title: Vain Glorious | La Crme de lHomme from Absolution
description: With Vain Glorious, T Magazines beauty/style director, Sandra Ballentine, breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.Who: Absolution BioCosmtiques, a Parisian line of bespoke skin-care products.

title: Do Stockholders Really Know Whats Best?
description: Kraft Foods $16.7 billion hostile takeover bid for Cadbury, the British confectionery company, is an example of how shareholder democracy can go wrong, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: CIT Has $1.07 Billion Loss Before Bankruptcy
description: The CIT Group, the large U.S. consumer finance company, on Monday posted a $1.07 billion loss for the third quarter, the last full three-month period prior to its Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing.

title: Banking Group Warns Congress on Breakup Power
description: Some of the worlds largest financial firms on Monday urged a top U.S. lawmaker not to pursue big bank break-up legislation, an idea attracting interest in Congress and causing alarm on Wall Street.

title: Soros Fund Sees $2 Billion Increase
description: The hedge fund headed by billionaire investor George Soros reported holdings of $6.2 billion during the third quarter, an increase of $2 billion, after taking a stake in automaker Ford and boosting its holdings in communications services stocks.

title: Paul Allen, a Co-Founder of Microsoft, Has Lymphoma
description: Paul Allen, a private investor and co-founder of Microsoft, has been told he has non-Hodgkins lymphoma, according to an e-mail message sent to employees of his investment firm, Vulcan.

title: Blackstone Shuffles Stakes, Selling Calpine
description: The Blackstone Group, the private equity firm run by co-founder Stephen Schwarzman, bought a $7.8 million stake in Southwest Airlines, cut its stake in Eastman Kodak and sold its holdings in Calpine during the latest quarter.

title: Newmont Transfers Stake in Indonesian Venture
description: Newmont Mining has sold a 10 percent share of its Indonesian joint venture to a consortium of regional and local governments.

title: Ferrero Said to Consider Deal With Cadbury
description: Could a white knight be made of dark chocolate?

title: Pagliuca: Private Equity, Public Pain
description: Every politician, The Boston Globe columnist Steven Syre writes, knows theres one cant-miss campaign strategy this year: Run against Wall Street and Americas big banks.

title: Chris Johnson and the Race to 2,000
description: Chase Stuart, a lawyer, Jets fan and statistical analyst who writes for the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog, will contribute a weekly entry to the Fifth Down:

title: Group Calls for More Investment in Electric Cars
description: A group of businessmen formed a coalition on Monday to urge the federal government to make a major investment in electric transportation, pointing to electric cars as the best way to confront the nations dependence on imported oil, The Associated Press reported.

title: UBS Outlines Plan to Return to Profit
description: Presenting a plan to return UBS to profitability, the chief executive of the battered Swiss bank said on Tuesday that he expects the company to be earning nearly $15 billion a year no later than 2014, Julia Werdigier writes in The New York Times.

title: After 6 Weeks, Somali Pirates Free Crew of Spanish Vessel
description: MADRID  Somali pirates released 36 crew members and their Spanish fishing vessel on Tuesday, the government here said, even as authorities said pirates had seized a tanker with a crew of 28 North Koreans.

title: Macquarie-Oppenheim Talks Said to Collapse
description: Talks between Sal. Oppenheim and Australias Macquarie over the sale of Oppenheims investment banking operations collapsed late Monday, sources familiar with the matter told Reuters.

title: Did Zach Braff Kill American Music?
description: Todays idea: Ever since Natalie Portman popped headphones onto Zach Braffs head and said, This song will change your life, American music has been dying a slow death, an essay says.

title: Whitney Hasnt Been This Bearish in a Year
description: Prominent banking analyst Meredith Whitney said on Monday that the stock market run-up was not supported by fundamentals and that she expects a so-called double-dip recession, where the economy would slip again before fully recovering.

title: Obama Tours the Forbidden City
description: BEIJING  Millions of people come here to look at the delights of the Forbidden City. Now add President Obama to that list.

title: Will E.U. Lobbying Effort Backfire on Hedge Funds?
description: The hedge fund industry has incurred a backlash by lobbying aggressively against proposed European Union rules and now faces possible pay curbs that were not envisaged in the original legislation.

title: Dynamic Decisions Founder Denies Fraud
description: The founder of Dynamic Decisions Capital Management, Alberto Micalizzi, said that any fraud allegations being leveled at his hedge fund are unfounded and investors will recover close to 100 percent of their money, Bloomberg News reported.

title: PAI Partners Investors Said to Balk at Deal
description: Investors including the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board oppose PAI Partners latest offer to let them halve their obligations to the buyout fund, saying the plan does not go far enough, three people familiar with the talks told Bloomberg News.

title: The Accounting Paradox
description: My last post about Debbie Dusenberry and her business struggles evoked many passionate comments. It seems as if there are thousands of other small business owners in a similar place.

title: A Decade Later, Intels Itanium Chip Makes a Profit
description: Intels much-maligned and often ridiculed Itanium chip has finally started paying for itself.

title: Retailer Earnings Show Stabilization
description: Some of the nations largest retailers, discount and luxury chains alike, posted better- than-expected earnings on Tuesday and said they were seeing signs of broader stabilization.

title: What to Watch Tuesday: Neil Armstrong, Heather Locklear, Joe Biden
description: Now that the 40th-anniversary moon-landing specials produced by American television have come and gone, were getting to see some of the shows made for the occasion by the BBC. Theyre uniformly more inventive and interesting than the clip-show history lessons churned out here. In Being Neil Armstrong (BBC America, 8 p.m.), the writer Andrew Smith profiles the Apollo 11 commander by talking to childhood friends, fellow astronauts, space program employees and other acquaintances of the first recluse on the moon.

title: A Justice Shifts His Stance on Speeches
description: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy of the Supreme Court made headlines last month when his office insisted on approving any article about a talk he gave to an assembly of Dalton high school students in Manhattan on Oct. 28.

title: In the House, Doc Fix Redux
description: While the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, works to complete his version of health care legislation, the House this week will return to the issue of averting steep cuts in Medicare payment rates to doctors.

title: Group Wants Government to Jump-Start the E.V. Revolution
description: Calling for what amounts to a Marshall Plan to start manufacturing plug-in hybrids and battery-electric cars, a group of executives from the auto and utility industries, and prospective plug-in fleet buyers laid out a strategy on Monday at a roundtable in Washington.

title: Madoffs Mets Jacket
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below:

title: Sampler: Teen Vigil, Spokesman Gone, Cupcakes Gone Too
description: Police Questions | People attending a vigil Monday for an unarmed 16-year-old shot and killed by San Pablo police questioned police use of force in a sequence of events that involved a carjacking, gunfire and a crash.

title: House Watch: Things Get Blue in Plainsboro
description: This post contains spoilers and descriptions you might not want to read over breakfast.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: Airline Tests Retail Sales at 35,000 Feet Anytime you have customers who are captive, who have nothing better to do, theyll shop, says a marketing professor. And whos more captive than an airline passenger?

title: A Familiar Stop on the Road
description: Patrick Behan is a 6-foot-8 senior on the Bucknell basketball team. He is also an English major and an aspiring sportswriter. As he did last season, he will be blogging for The Quad throughout this season.

title: Murky Passages
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Murky Passages
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Why Economists Love to Study Cellphone Pricing
description: Have I tragically underestimated the ability of foreign cellphone companies to come up with devilishly complex pricing plans and the skill of economists to convert those schemes into pat theories that can be illustrated with neat charts and graphs?

title: No Peak in Oil Before 2030, Study Says
description: Few topics can inflame oil watchers more than the debate over peak oil  that difficult-to-predict moment when the worlds oil production reaches its highest level before beginning a long and irreversible path of decline.

title: Lazard Names Kenneth Jacobs as Its New Chief
description: Lazard on Tuesday named Kenneth M. Jacobs as its new chairman and chief executive, succeeding the late Bruce Wasserstein as the head of the independent investment bank.

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, Nov. 17
description: Highlights from Tuesdays media coverage:

title: Early Word: China Trip Notes
description: President Obama is wrapping up another full day in China, including meetings with President Hu Jintao followed by a quick session with the news media.

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Tuesday morning.

title: Inside Out | Pattern Recognition
description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

title: Presidential Bows, Revisited
description: The ongoing cable-and-blog dust-up over whether President Obama somehow dishonored Americas image by bowing to Emperor Akihito of Japan the other day was reminiscent of another argument over the exact same issue  20 years ago.

title: U.S. Wholesale Prices Show Few Inflation Pressures
description: Wholesale prices in the United States increased only slightly in October, the Labor Department said Tuesday, easing concerns that inflation might soon emerge as a threat to the economic recovery in a period of extraordinarily low interest rates.

title: More High Schools Get As (and Cs, and Ds)
description: In releasing the third annual round of A through F grades for New York City high schools on Monday, the Education Department produced a rather murky picture: The number of schools receiving As on the citys report cards increased this year, but more schools received Cs and Ds. And just one school received an F.

title: China Holds Firm on Major Issues in Obamas Visit
description: BEIJING  In six hours of meetings, at two dinners and during a stilted 30-minute news conference in which President Hu Jintao did not allow questions, President Obama was confronted, on his first visit, with a fast-rising China more willing to say no to the United States.

title: Summers, the Chinese and the Deficit
description: Lawrence Summers, the top White House economic adviser, made a point recently that I have not seen anywhere else. Speaking at the New York Economic Club a few weeks ago, he said:

title: Sophie Theallet Wins CFDA/Vogue Fund
description: The latest cash prize for talent has gone to Sophie Theallet, who won the $200,000 CFDA/Vogue Fund award last night. The prize, which includes a year of mentoring from a veteran in the industry, is especially deserved in Ms. Theallets case. Her clothes are not flashy or arty; shes not everybodys darling. But if you appreciate hand-done details like pin-tucking, if you like a certain friendliness in clothes, and if youre surprised and delighted by non-generic reds and blues, then you are surely on Sophies side.

title: A Solar Technology Seeks Its Day in the Sun
description: For years, concentrating photovoltaic technology, which uses mirrors or lenses to focus the suns rays on small, high-efficiency solar panels, has tantalized researchers as a potential source of low-cost, utility-scale solar power.

title: West Side Accident Snarls Morning Traffic
description: At least two cars were involved in a serious accident on Tuesday morning on the West Side Highway, causing extensive traffic delays, a Fire Department official said.

title: Stephen Colbert Wishes Aerosmith Well on Its Permanent Vacation
description: If last week you found yourself baffled by the rapid cycle of departures and reconciliations within Aerosmith, youre not alone. On Monday night, Stephen Colbert took to the bully pulpit of The Colbert Report to comment on the singer Steven Tylers recent announcement that he would take a hiatus from that rock group. (Mr. Colbert called it the biggest blow to the band since Alicia Silverstone quit in the mid-90s.) Mr. Colbert also named the guitarist Joe Perry his Alpha Dog of the Week and called him a rock god, adding, because, like God, you are rarely seen.

title: Some Mysteries in the BofA-Merrill Deal
description: Update | 1:29 p.m. For those who like mysteries, the testimony of Timothy J. Mayopoulos, the former general counsel of Bank of America, presents a few. Mr. Mayopoulos testified on Tuesday at yet another House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform hearing on the Bank of America-Merrill Lynch deal.

title: 14,700 Disclosed Offshore Accounts
description: Fear, apparently, can be a powerful inducement.

title: Analyst Doubts Health Overhaul Can Pass
description: Arguing that the political winds are shifting away from the support necessary for an overhaul, one Wall Street analyst is now predicting Congress will not pass any significant health care legislation anytime soon.

title: Celebrating Revolution With Roots in a Rumor
description: PRAGUE  It was a revolution that began with a lie.

title: The Uses of Defeatism
description: Theres a lot to chew on in John Judiss essay on anti-statism in America, but I thought it was particularly interesting as an example of what you might call a narrative of defeat  a kind of story that both liberals and conservatives sometimes like to tell about our politics, which emphasizes the other sides immense advantages, and their own sides struggle against overwhelming odds.

title: Giants Stadium Countdown: Tiki Honors Mara
description: John Maxymuk, author of The 50 Greatest Plays in New York Giants Football History, is helping us count down to the final game at Giants Stadium. His latest book is Quarterback Abstract.

title: On Climate Change Efforts, China Is Key
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.It is time to accept that the choices of China and India, not the United States, will determine the worlds future carbon emissions.

title: A New Way to Nab a Better Seat on the Plane
description: You dont have to settle for that dreaded middle seat on your next flight. With a new tool from ExpertFlyer.com, you can nab a better one.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Energy Plan From the Greenhouse Giants
description: President Obama and Chinas president, Hu Jintao, announced a slate of partnerships and plans on Tuesday in Beijing, including projects related to expanding energy options while constraining greenhouse gases. The list is below. (More background on Environmental Capital.)

title: Ausra Solar Looking for a Buyer
description: Disrupting trillion-dollar energy markets is expensive, as solar companies like OptiSolar and Solel have found. Both sold out to larger, deep-pocketed companies this year.

title: New Moon Fill-In
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first four paragraphs of this article from the Arts section, Media Vampires, Beware.  Use your own words, or click read more to choose from a scrambled list of the words that were removed.

title: Never Used Twitter
description: Monologue |  Aired Monday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Hey, during a town hall event in China, President Obama admitted that hes never used Twitter. Even John McCain was like, Get it together, grandpa.

title: Coffee With Hillary
description: Monologue |  Aired Monday night on NBC: President Obama was in Japan. Some people are upset that Obama bowed to the Japanese emperor. Its still better than when former President Bush high-fived the emperor and said, Give me some skin, Mr. Miyagi.

title: Plans for the Future
description: Monologue |  Aired Monday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: I was watching Oprah on the TV. She had Sarah Palin on the show. Sarah was promoting her book, where she talks about her plans for the future. I think she wants to be the next leader of the free world, which is ridiculous, because no one can replace Oprah.

title: When Cancer Muddles the Mind
description: Ive become one of those people who, by the time I walk from the couch to the kitchen, cant remember why Im standing in front of an open fridge. Some people can laugh off these memory blips as old-timers disease. But Im only 37. And it doesnt feel funny staring into an abyss of cartons and containers unable to remember that I want a glass of orange juice.

title: The Big Trial
description: Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: You know whos coming to New York City? Khalid Sheikh Mohammed is coming here. Hes coming to New York City for the big trial, and also, hes promoting his new book, Really Going Rogue.

title: Russian Figure Skater Arrested in Lake Placid
description: Andre Lutai, the Russian figure skater who finished 10th in last weekends Skate America competition in Lake Placid, N.Y., was arrested late Sunday night after allegedly stealing a car and driving drunk, The Associated Press reported.

title: A Very Strange Press Conference
description: Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC: President Obama in China this week, or as they call it, the Peoples Republic of Wal-Mart.

title: Gift Guide | Purely Cosmetic
description: When the holiday festivities begin, cameras will come out of hiding. Ensure that your loved ones are ready for their close-ups with our beauty gift picks for good boys and girls. (Weve included fragrances too, just in case you find yourself caught under the mistletoe.)

title: Josh Tyrangiel Named Editor of BusinessWeek
description: Josh Tyrangiel, who was an heir apparent at Time magazine, has been appointed the editor of BusinessWeek, its new owner, Bloomberg L.P., announced Tuesday morning.

title: Who Was Really Bailed Out? We Still Dont Know
description: Who were the ultimate beneficiaries of the Treasurys decision to make good on the credit default swaps written by the American International Group?

title: Disputes Continue Over Jackson Estate and Public Memorial
description: Last week, when John G. Branca and John McClain were named the executors of Michael Jacksons estate by a Superior Court judge in Los Angeles, one estate expert was quoted as saying the decision would ensure there wont be any further challenge. But now the singers father, Joe Jackson, is planning to challenge the decision, Agence France-Presse reported. Citing legal papers filed on Friday, Agence France-Presse said that Joe Jackson plans to appeal the appointment of Mr. Branca, a lawyer, and Mr. McClain, a music executive, in the California Court of Appeals. Joe Jackson was left out of his sons will, and the Superior Court had said he had no standing to challenge it.

title: A North African Battle for World Cup Glory
description: Stephen Constantine, 47, a native of England, is currently the coach of the national team of Sudan. He has also coached the national teams of Nepal, India and Malawi.

title: Answers About Community Colleges, Part 2
description: Each day this week, the Guidance Office  the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts  will feature answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: Taliban Blame Blackwater for Pakistan Bombings
description: On Monday, Al Jazeera reported that a spokesman for the Pakistani Taliban said the group accepted responsibility for only some of the recent suicide bombings in Pakistan, laying the blame for others, including a deadly attack on a market last month that killed more than 100 civilians, on the American security firm formerly known as Blackwater. The spokesman claimed that the firm, now called Xe, was involved in an attempt to discredit the militants by staging deadly attacks.

title: More Fathers Are Getting Custody in Divorce
description: Working Mother Magazine published a package of articles on Tuesday called Lost Custody, about the new reality of divorce and child custody for working mothers.

title: Crowdsourcing Comedy on Amazon Reviews
description: Every now and then, something for sale on Amazon.com seems so monumentally stupid that it inspires a spontaneous community comedy festival. One person after another leaves phony reviews, each more heartfelt and over-the-top than last, sardonically praising the Amazon item for its astonishing, life-changing abilities. Perfect strangers, entertaining each other in the comments, laughing their heads offuntil Amazon gets wind of the stunt and shuts it down.

title: Quinto Quarto Orders Takeout
description: Its hard to say that Tables for Two mini-reviews in The New Yorker go on for too long. But in her mixed assessment of the Italian restaurant Quinto Quarto, did Andrea Thompson really need to say anything more once she revealed that during dinner one night she saw the pizza-delivery guy who shows up with two large pepperoni pies for the staff?

title: A Spokesman Leaves: What Does It Mean for Gavin Newsom?
description: From afar, Nathan Ballard, who resigned yesterday as the director of communications for San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom, seemed at times to play Jeeves to Mayor Gavin Newsoms Bertie Wooster.

title: Hair Extends From Broadway to London
description: Update | 11:39 a.m. Its not quite Manchester, England, England, but the Broadway cast of Hair will soon be making its way across the Atlantic Sea to take the musical to London. In a news release, the Public Theater, the Hair producers and Cameron Mackintosh said they would transfer the production to the Gielgud Theater next year, along with the cast that originated the revival, which is now playing at the Al Hirschfeld Theater.

title: SmartyPig Savings Accounts Come With Discount Vacations
description: Earlier this year, I signed up for a SmartyPig savings account. Then, as now, it was paying what appears to be the highest rates in the land, currently 2.01 percent.

title: A Checklist for College Recruits
description: The N.C.A.A. basketball signing period ends on Wednesday and most of the big high school fish have already chosen a pond.

title: Strange Days Ahead for Bob Saget
description: Apparently the eight years that Bob Saget spent hosting Americas Funniest Home Videos, narrating clips of misbehaving kitties and people getting hit by footballs in tender areas, were simply a warm-up act. Now hes turning the camera on himself. On Tuesday, A&E announced that it had ordered a new reality series starring Mr. Saget, the comedian and former Full House star, that is tentatively titled Bob Sagets Strange Days. In a news release, A&E said that the new series would follow Mr. Saget as he explores some of Americas most fascinating and mysterious worlds; for Mr. Saget, that means an investigation of mail-order brides; meeting up with a survivalist cult that is preparing for the end of the world; and rushing a college fraternity. The show is expected to have its premiere next year; no word yet on which if any Olsen twin might be involved.

title: Mets Balancing Two Sets of Off-Season Priorities
description: The Mets two biggest off-season objectives, to paraphrase Captain Obvious, are to acquire another slugger and to add a No. 2 starter behind Johan Santana. Not so obvious is how  and if  they will accomplish these goals and find creative ways to bring in a starting catcher, resolve issues in the bullpen and in the back end of the rotation, and decide if they should deal second baseman Luis Castillo.

title: Below the Belt | Sparring in Y-3 Boxing Boots
description: Theres little in the boxing world that isnt exploited for maximum impact  babbles, tassels and bedazzles have all made their appearance on the fingers and feet of fleet-footed pugilists. Jack Dempsey, the gentleman boxer and heavyweight champion from 1919 to 1926, was, to put it into our terms, a fashion-forward tastemaker. In our era, Paulie Malignaggi, Floyd Money Mayweather and Rickie The Hitman Hatton have paraded down the aisle in Technicolor robes. Boxing has always found a way of muscling itself into fashion.

title: Day 2 of Second-Guessing
description: Because long ago the N.F.L. became the league that swallowed the rest of the sporting universe, we have surpassed the age of second-guessing. Now, second guesses have happened by halftime. By Tuesday, weve reached seventh or eighth guesses. Were wondering whether Bill Parcells hacked into Bill Belichicks headset system to call the fourth-and-2. Were asking who left Tennessees owner, Bud Adams, unattended long enough for him to make an obscene gesture at Bills fans. Were surmising that the H1N1 virus infected the brains of Cincinnati Bengals management when the thought hit them: were 7-2 and we need a struggling running back with a history of locker room conflict and arrests on charges of assaulting women!

title: Dr. James Will Make It Better
description: To be sure, as David Leonhardt describes, Intermountain HealthCares model of using evidence-based medicine, led by Dr. Brent James, offers much to improve our current medical-care system and is in part an answer to our health care crisis. What must be kept in mind, however, is the limit of evidence-based medicine: what is good for a group, as a whole, is not equally good for each and every member of the group. This is why our medical-treatment system will never be able to achieve the same evidence-based safety and efficiency as our air-transportation flight-safety system; human beings vary, sometimes dramatically. Ultimately, medical care always comes down to the individual.

title: Chinas War on Low U.S. Interest Rates
description: Updated, Nov. 17, 6:35 p.m. | Moritz Schularick, an economic historian, says China is partly to blame for Americans addiction to cheap money.

title: Secretary Describes a Scolding From Bruno
description: ALBANY  After 25 years as secretary to Joseph L. Bruno, the former Senate president and one of New Yorks most powerful politicians, Patricia M. Stackrow finds herself testifying against her old boss who is accused of improperly mixing his political and business interests and trying to deceive the public about it.

title: Lady Gaga Ineligible for Best New Artist Grammy
description: First, Blair Waldorf told us that Lady Gaga wrote her song Poker Face for her stepfather, Cyrus Rose, a revelation that were fairly certain is true only in the fictional world of Gossip Girl. Now comes more surprising (and authentic) news: Lady Gaga will not be eligible in the best new artist category at the Grammy Awards next year. Variety reported that although Lady Gaga (whose real name is Stefani Germanotta) has sold more than 1.5 million copies of her debut album, The Fame, her song Just Dance was nominated in the best dance recording category at this years Grammys, making her ineligible for new artist next year, according to the awards regulations. Previous winners in the best new artist category include Adele, Amy Winehouse and Carrie Underwood; nominations for the 52nd annual Grammy Awards will be announced on Dec. 2 and awards will be given out on Jan. 31.

title: Joining the Crowd at a College Fair
description: As we signaled to turn right into the high school parking lot, a man frantically waved his hands in the air alerting us that the lot was full. At 3:30 on a Sunday afternoon, I never expected thered be several hundred eager parents  and students  streaming into a high school gym for a glimpse of, and perhaps a quick chat with, admissions representatives and alumni from 70 colleges and universities. But there we were, searching for a parking spot so we, too, could join the throngs of college seekers on a crisp fall day.

title: Temporary Rape
description: Disturbing Chinese term for a sexual assault that was deemed to be less serious because it was apparently unpremeditated.

title: Travel Deals: AirTran Flight Sale
description: AirTran announced a R&R flight sale this morning, with one-way fares as low as $39. Book by Nov. 19 for travel through Feb. 20. The lowest fares can be found for Tuesday, Wednesday and Saturday departures. Fourteen-day advance purchase required.

title: Volvo Recalls XC60 for Seat-Belt Failure
description: Volvo is recalling 9,667 of its 2010 XC60s, most of them in the United States and Canada because in a crash test the drivers seat belt came undone.

title: From Dental Crowns to Implants
description: In this weeks Science Times, Jane Brody discusses the shift in dentistry away from bridges and crowns to permanent implants to replace decayed or missing teeth:

title: Police Raid Newspaper Printing Plants
description: Updated, 1:19 p.m. | The New York City police raided the offices of three major city dailies and El Diario on Tuesday morning as part of an investigation into allegations of corruption within the union that delivers newspapers in the metropolitan area.

title: Lawyer Held in Tax Case in Russia Dies in Jail
description: MOSCOW  A 37-year-old Russian lawyer for an international investment fund, Hermitage Capital Management, died in a pretrial detention center on Monday, nearly a year after he was arrested in an escalating feud between the Russian authorities and the company, Russias Interior Ministry announced on Tuesday.

title: Layoffs Begin at The Associated Press
description: Layoffs began today at The Associated Press, according to employees there, as the company follows through on a commitment made a year ago to lower its payroll costs by 10 percent by the end of 2009.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) The stimulus created jobs in Congressional districts that dont exist.

title: Bloomberg? Humble? Experts Suggest How Mayor Could Try
description: Perhaps Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg should spend more time in the Bronx and less in Bermuda, political analysts say. He could travel less like a rock star and more like a neighbor, showing up without television cameras to hear what is on the minds of residents, especially in poorer sections of the city.

title: Winner of Wasserstein Playwrights Prize Is Announced
description: A 28-year-old playwright from Chicago, Marisa Wegrzyn, has been named as the recipient of the third annual Wasserstein Prize for an emerging female playwright  a $25,000 award named for the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Wendy Wasserstein, above, who wrote The Heidi Chronicles and The Sisters Rosensweig.

title: Another Vongerichten Goes to Work for Dad
description: I guess Im making this a family business, said Jean-Georges Vongerichten, whose son, Cedric, is the executive chef at Perry St., and whose daughter Louise started working at Mercer Kitchen in the fall. A graduate of American University in finance, Ms. Vongerichten, 23, has held various jobs at the restaurant, including runner, and is now a junior manager there. Mr. Vongerichtens brother, Philippe, manages the flagship, Jean Georges.

title: Mia Dona Goes Chefless
description: Donatella Arpaia has had less to do with top chefs lately. Last year she left David Burke & Donatella (now David Burke Townhouse). And just before she closed Mia Dona for renovations last month, the chef and her partner in the restaurant, Michael Psilakis, left, saying he wanted to concentrate on their other places  Anthos and Kefi.

title: During Visit, Obama Skirts Chinese Political Sensitivities
description: BEIJING  Whether by White House design or Chinese insistence, President Obama has steered clear of public meetings with Chinese liberals, free press advocates and even average Chinese during his first visit to China, showing a deference to the Chinese leaderships aversions to such interactions that is unusual for a visiting American president.

title: Licensing Deadline Looms for Pedicab Owners
description: Get licensed or get out, is the message from the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs to the citys pedicab professionals, who have until Friday to obtain business licenses and register their vehicles or else close up shop. The Nov. 20 deadline marks the end of a 60-day period in which the city invited pedicab operators to apply to become licensed, a process that entails submitting their rickshaws to a rigorous inspection, and retrofitting them with things like seat belts and turn signals to bring them up to new safety standards outlined in the law.

title: Winter 2010 Dates Set for Kander and Ebbs New Musical, The Scottsboro Boys
description: Off Broadways Vineyard Theater announced performance dates on Tuesday for the world premiere production of a new musical, The Scottsboro Boys, with music and lyrics by John Kander and Fred Ebb (Cabaret, Chicago). It will be directed by Susan Stroman (The Producers, Contact).

title: 14,700 Taxpayers Disclose Offshore Accounts
description: Update | 3:51 p.m. More that 14,700 taxpayers have disclosed secret foreign bank accounts, the Internal Revenue Service said on Tuesday, under an amnesty program that let them avoid prosecution for tax evasion.

title: A Flood of Applicants to a Shrinking Police Dept.
description: After years of struggling to lure top-quality recruits, the New York Police Department has found that the prolonged recession  coupled with a significant increase in first-year salaries  has generated new interest in police careers.

title: Shaming Tax Delinquents
description: New York state legislators have recently proposed a measure to publish the names of the states biggest tax deadbeats.

title: Now Showing | Maremma, Italy
description: If the promise of the some of the best countrys best food and wine werent enough to make you book a plane ticket to the Maremma region of Tuscany right now, then these tantalizing images from Massimo Vitali and Albrecht Tbke will certainly do the trick. This coastal strip offers all sorts of sybaritic pleasures, from sunbathing to sipping Sassicaia  the award-winning wine is produced in the town of Bolgheri. These two photographers offer a lovely glimpse into the region with their traveling show Vintage Green, which is currently on view at the Core Club. While Vitali delivers his epic landscapes of the verdant area, the Leipzig-born Tbke offers endearing portraits of the local legends, from winemakers to hunters. The show continues until Dec. 9. Vitali has a new show opening at Bonni Benrubi Gallery starting Dec. 3.

title: Hooked on Hockey From a Young Age in Omaha
description: Some might second-guess Jed Ortmeyers decision to keep playing with a blood clotting disorder, but one would be hard-pressed to find someone who doubts his heart.

title: At Hearing, Questions About BofA C.E.O. Candidate
description: It appears even Congress is joining the Bank of America chief executive guessing game.

title: After Chinese Turbine Controversy, Companies Plan American Plant
description: Two companies that encountered political backlash for their plans to use Chinese-made wind turbines to build a giant wind farm in west Texas have announced plans to build a new turbine factory  in the United States.

title: David Waltuck Has Left Macao Trading Co.
description: David Waltuck is no longer involved with Macao Trading Co., the Chinese-Portuguese-inflected restaurant in TriBeCa.

title: More English Translations on the Way for Nobel Winners Novels
description: Curious readers clamoring for more work from this years Nobel laureate in literature will be able to get their hands on two more titles in the next three years. Metropolitan Books has acquired the North American rights to two novels by Herta Mller, the Romanian-born German novelist and essayist who was awarded the Nobel Prize last month.

title: Incivility, Indeed: Murdoch Insults Paterson
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: The 18 Million
description: Update: For a correction, and more on this topic, see above.

title: Meatballs, Chinese-Style
description: (Ed indirectly raises the question, Who invented ravioli nudi? MB)

title: Police Investigate Suicide of Chicago Schools Chief
description: CHICAGO  The president of the Chicago Board of Education, who had served in a variety of prominent posts here over three decades, was found dead early Monday morning on the banks of the Chicago River, in what the medical examiner ruled a suicide.

title: Deena Kastors Green Chile Pumpkin Pie
description: A Vegetarian Thanksgiving

title: Pedro Martinez Gearing Up for 2010
description: When the Phillies shelled out $1 million for a partial seasons worth of Pedro Martinez, they really didnt know what theyd get from the three-time Cy Young Award winner.

title: A Woman-to-Woman Talk With a Would-Be Suicide Bomber
description: BAQUBA, Iraq  As a translator for The New York Times, I have met a lot of different characters and been in many new situations, such as meeting politicians, election candidates, students, mentally ill people, disabled people, injured people, bereaved mothers.

title: Lynne Stewart Is Ordered to Begin Serving Sentence
description: A federal appeals court panel in Manhattan on Tuesday upheld the conviction of Lynne F. Stewart, the outspoken defense lawyer who was found guilty in 2005 of assisting terrorism by smuggling information from an imprisoned client to his violent followers in Egypt.

title: Language May Begin Before Birth
description: How early does language  a particular language  begin?

title: Richmond to Honor Teen Who Called Police in Gang Rape
description: At its meeting tonight, Richmond City Council will honor Margarita Vargas, 18, the woman who directed police to the victim of a gang rape outside the local high schools homecoming dance.

title: Oleanna to Close on Broadway
description: The overlap between two Broadway productions of David Mamet wont last very long. The Broadway revival of Oleanna, Mr. Mamets play about a university professor and the female student who believes he has harassed her, will end its run at the Golden Theater on Jan. 3, its publicists said Tuesday in a news release. The play, which stars Bill Pullman and Julia Stiles, was a transfer of a production that ran earlier this year at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. Directed by Doug Hughes, it opened at the Golden Theater on Oct. 11. Mr. Mamets new play, Race, which he is also directing, is to open at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Dec. 6.

title: Libbys Warns of a Canned Pumpkin Shortage
description: As if preparing for Thanksgiving wasnt stressful enough for cooks, now comes this news: there is likely to be a canned pumpkin shortage.

title: Inside Umi Nom
description: The chef King Phojanakon from the Kuma Inn brings his artfully composed Asian comfort food to Brooklyn.

title: Santa Monica Wants Eli Broad Museum
description: The City of Santa Monica is poised to join what is shaping up to be a high-profile contest in Los Angeles, competing with Beverly Hills and possibly another municipality to become the home for a new museum to house the art collection of the billionaire Eli Broad.

title: Is This Bishop Catholic?
description: I take issue with some of the statements made in Deborah Solomons interview with Robert Duncan. First, the name of Duncans organization, the Anglican Church in North America, may confuse some readers. The organization is not a part of the Anglican Communion. Duncan left the Episcopal Church, which is a constituent part of the Anglican Communion. The Episcopal Church is the sole Anglican presence in the United States recognized by the Archbishop of Canterbury.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 25 about the recent governors race in New Jersey misidentified the illegal activity that some Sephardic rabbis had been accused of and that the article characterized as part of the states infamous corruption. The rabbis were charged with money laundering, not with selling body parts and then using the money to bribe politicians. (There was a Brooklyn man accused of conspiring to broker the sale of a kidney, and several New Jersey politicians accused of corruption, all of whom were arrested the same day as the rabbis.)

title: Makeover for a Star (the Twinkling Kind)
description: In New York, a world capital of makeovers, even the star that goes on the tree in Rockefeller Center has some work done every once in a while. But what happened this time was different from, say, liposuction, which usually leaves the patient a little lighter. The star gained 220 pounds.

title: Details on U.S.-China Climate and Energy Plans
description: Appearing with President Hu Jintao, President Obama on Tuesday told reporters that the United States was determined to work with China and other countries to help produce a substantive agreement in Copenhagen climate talks next month:

title: The Next Oprah Spinoff: Her Interior Designer
description: Soon to join Dr. Phil and Dr. Oz: Nate Berkus? Oprah Winfreys production company is proposing a new daytime talk show starring Mr. Berkus, who is an interior designer and a regular on The Oprah Winfrey Show, Broadcasting & Cable reported Tuesday. The publication said Ms. Winfrey is finalizing plans with Sony Pictures Television to distribute the show next fall.

title: Correcting the Chatter: For Consumers, No Federal Tax Due on Clunkers Rebate
description: As we draw closer to the end of the year, theres a bit of chatter on the Internet about whether the cash for clunkers rebates are taxable income.

title: Q&A: Lyon for a 50th Birthday, a Festival and Food
description: Q.

title: Anthropologie Comes to Regent Street
description: LONDON | Anthropologie, the American fashion and housewares chain, has opened its first overseas branch, on bustling Regent Street in London. Owned by Urban Outfitters, the brand that sells sort-of-edgy street fashion, Anthropologie is often described as its older, more sophisticated sister, targeting creative types with a sense of humor.

title: The Morning Skate: Troubles in Hab-land, Blue in St. Louis and Hammer Time in Philly
description: Mount Royal shakes. The lava bubbles and steams, the smell of sulfur fills the air. Panic begins to grip the population as the volcano that is Montreal hockey is starting to erupt.

title: MTV Acquires TV Rights for This Is It
description: MTV Networks has acquired exclusive television rights to the Michael Jackson concert film This Is It for six years beginning in 2011, the company announced on Tuesday. The deal allows MTV Networks to show the film on all of its channels, including MTV and VH1, as well as on BET Networks, which like MTV is owned by Viacom. In its announcement, MTV said it would also work with Sony Pictures Entertainment to market the DVD of the film, due early next year. This Is It has grossed $67 million in the United States and $129 million overseas.

title: Jauron Is Dismissed as Bills Coach
description: The Buffalo Bills fired Coach Dick Jauron on Tuesday, making him the first coaching casualty of the season. In-season coaching changes are unusual in the N.F.L. because the short season means even a new coach can have little impact. The timing of the firing is especially odd because the Bills had a bye two weeks ago, a more natural time to make a change. But they were routed, 41-17, by the three-win Tennessee Titans on Sunday to drop to 3-6. Jauron was apparently surprised. He was called to a meeting with the teams owner, Ralph Wilson, in Detroit and fired.

title: New York Police Department Lures Recruits
description: The New York Police Department is now better educated and more qualified than in the past.

title: News of Hockey, 11/17/09: Shanahan Retires; Naslund Unretires and Joins Forsberg in Sweden
description: Brendan Shanahan makes it official and announces his retirement after 21 N.H.L. seasons. The full story from The Associated Press is at this link.

title: Millenniums Englander Examines Hedge Funds
description: Israel A. Englander is known for keeping a very low public profile, even for a billionaire hedge fund manager. But recently, the founder of Millennium Partners  shared his views on the state of the hedge fund industry in a keynote address at the Absolute Return Symposium in New York.

title: An Invitation to Read, Sniff and Taste
description: BOOKS about wine are no substitute for drinking wine. But these six new selections can help to better understand whats in the glass, and whats in the minds of those who make wine and consume it.

title: Training of Afghan Police by Europe Is Found Lacking
description: BERLIN  Two and a half years after it was started, the European Unions police training mission in Afghanistan is understaffed, lacks adequate security and transportation, and has yet to develop a uniform training program, according to diplomats and security experts involved in the mission.

title: Thanksgiving Under the Sun?
description: If you havent made any plans for Thanksgiving weekend yet, Miami Beach may be a surprisingly affordable option for a last-minute vacation.

title: Earning a Profit by Ending Energy Waste
description: The Community Preservation Corporation, a 35-year-old nonprofit lender that specializes in issuing mortgages to landlords of small buildings and properties receiving public subsidies, is offering $1 billion in credit to New York State apartment building owners.

title: For Some TV Time, St. Peters Bumps Breakfast for Basketball
description: JERSEY CITY  Never mind that it was 5:58 a.m. and the sun would not rise for another 47 minutes. St. Peters College had a big basketball game Tuesday morning, and the reserve guard Brandon Hall took a spot at midcourt to give each of his starting teammates a lusty chest bump during introductions.

title: Behind the Scenes: Lost Atlantis
description: The commenter GK was the only one who asked, but she or he couldnt have been the only reader who wondered why there were no slides of the shuttle launch on Monday in Pictures of the Day; especially one so spectacularly photogenic that NASA described it as picture perfect.

title: Indulging His Every Indulgence
description: WILLIAM FAULKNER once said: The aim of every artist is to arrest motion, which is life, by artificial means and hold it fixed so that a hundred years later, when a stranger looks at it, it moves again, since it is life.

title: New York Sees Quick Rebound on Wall Street
description: Wall Street is rebounding from the financial crisis and has returned to profitability faster than many expected, according to a report released on Tuesday by the New York State comptrollers office.

title: A Century of Bugaboos
description: Language may change, but pedantry is forever. And as Jan Freeman demonstrates in Ambrose Bierces Write It Right': The Celebrated Cynics Language Peeves Deciphered, Appraised, and Annotated for 21st-Century Readers, so too is the tradition of modern-day pedants picking apart the outmoded irritants of the quibblers who came before them. In the spirit of Theodore Bernsteins funny and edifying Miss Thistlebottoms Hobgoblins, Freeman, who writes The Boston Globes weekly language column The Word, has taken Write It Right, Bierces Little Blacklist of Literary Faults, published in 1909, and annotated it  thoroughly, fondly and wittily  for todays usage obsessives.

title: Who Knew I Was Not the Father?
description: I.

title: Tokyo Tops Paris in Michelin Three-Star Restaurants
description: Tokyo now has more restaurants with three Michelin stars than Paris.

title: Newly Renovated Paramount Hotel Is Now a Landmark
description: Updated, Nov. 18 | The Paramount Hotel, an ornate Times Square behemoth that is known for its double-height arcade along West 46th Street and was opulently revitalized this year, is the newest entry on New York Citys list of official landmarks.

title: Oprah Looks to Sony For Nate Berkus Spinoff
description: Oprah Winfreys production company is proposing a new daytime talk show starring Nate Berkus, who is an interior designer and a regular on The Oprah Winfrey Show, Broadcasting & Cable reported Tuesday. The publication said Ms. Winfrey is finalizing plans with Sony Pictures Television to distribute the show next fall.

title: South Africa Is Divided on Gesture by Educator
description: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa  For a speech about reconciliation it could hardly have been more divisive. Jonathan D. Jansen, the new head of the University of the Free State, spoke of the place of infamy just 100 yards behind him, the residence hall where four white students last year made a racist video that incited outrage across the country.

title: Brown Vows to Continue War Effort in Afghanistan
description: LONDON  As President Obama moves closer to a decision on the United States militarys request for more troops in Afghanistan, the British government has made an unflinching commitment to continue its role as the second largest troop provider in the 43-nation coalition fighting the war.

title: Biking Rules P.S.A.s
description: Selections from more than 40 short bicycle safety public service announcements from a contest being held by Transportation Alternatives, the cycling and pedestrian advocacy group.

title: A Better Way to Navigate the Mall This Season
description: If your holiday shopping routine involves hitting up a mall or 10, MEDL Mobile has created an application called Mall Maps designed to make navigating through the seasonal madness a tad easier.

title: J. B. Smoove on Curb Your Enthusiasm and Michael Richards
description: J. B. Smoove was happy enough to return this season to Curb Your Enthusiasm as Leon Black, the houseguest who moved into Larry Davids mansion and never took the hint that it was time to move out. But on Sunday nights episode, Mr. Smoove got to play a central role in a story line involving this seasons (fictional) Seinfeld reunion, and a memorable scene in which Michael Richards received his comic comeuppance for a notorious 2006 incident in which he was filmed shouting racial epithets at hecklers at a comedy club.

title: A Rustic Home in Ecuador
description: A three-bedroom, 3,000-square-foot house on a hilltop in Cuenca is on the market for $220,000.

title: Who Was Really Bailed Out? We Still Dont Know
description: From Floyd Norris on Notions on High and Low Finance:

title: How to Conserve Art That Lives in a Lake?
description: In 1972, a year before his death in a plane crash at 35, the artist Robert Smithson wrote, I am for an art that takes into account the direct effect of the elements as they exist from day to day. And with the creation of his greatest work  Spiral Jetty, the huge counterclockwise curlicue of black basalt rock that juts into the Great Salt Lake in rural Utah  he certainly put that conviction to the test.

title: Former SS Man Charged in 1945 Massacre
description: German prosecutors have indicted a 90-year-old man on 58 counts of murder over his suspected role in the March 1945 massacre of a group of Jewish laborers near the Austrian village of Deutsch Schtzen.

title: The Authors Hearts Beat Faster. Publishing Was So Close Now. . .
description: Got a romance novel in your desk drawer? Polish it up and get ready to become a Harlequin author.

title: House Hunting in ... Ecuador
description: A THREE-BEDROOM, 3000-SQUARE-FOOT HILLTOP HOME IN CUENCA

title: Swiss Textiles Award | Alexander Wang Wins
description: Winning the Swiss Textiles Award is always at the top of a young designers wish list. And these days, when even established houses are hurting, the 100,000 euro prize is sure to come in extra handy. Just ask Alexander Wang, this years winner, who beat out a talented field including Erdem, Ohne Titel, Peter Pilotto, Alexis Mabille and Thakoon.

title: Finding Bohemian Influences in Baroque
description: Baroque music and Gypsy tunes may seem unlikely bedfellows on a program, but Matthias Maute, artistic director of the period-instrument Ensemble Caprice, argues that Bach and Telemann may have been influenced by itinerant musicians.

title: Twice as Many Antics for the Duck, the Cat and the Wolf
description: The only problem with Prokofievs Peter and the Wolf from a theatrical point of view is that there is not enough of it. Or so, evidently, the London company In the Wings thought when it developed a 30-minute prequel to the 30-minute tale, with new music by Philip Feeney.

title: Acting Your Age: Considering the Age of Responsibility
description: Overview | What standard(s) should society use to determine when a person should be treated as an adult? In this lesson, students participate in a fishbowl discussion about various legal situations related to the age of responsibility and contribute their ideas and arguments on the matter to a Learning Network Student Opinion blog post.

title: Blankfein Sorry for Goldmans Role in Crisis
description: It must be the sorry season.

title: Starting a Chamber Series With a Bittersweet Brahms
description: Early in Pinchas Zukermans career, when he was best known as a star violin soloist and just starting to conduct, he carved out a place in his concert schedule for chamber music, often  though not always  with other headliners. More recently, the balance of his commitments has shifted from solo performance to conducting, as he has taken on music directorships, like that of the National Arts Center Orchestra in Ottawa, a post he has held since 1998. But he has maintained his devotion to chamber music, and as part of his work in Ottawa, he has established the Zukerman Chamber Players, drawing on members of the orchestra.

title: Living With Music: Bill Cotter
description: Bill Cotter is the author of a novel, Fever Chart.

title: President Obama Visits China
description: New York Times reporter David E. Sanger examines the success of President Obama's trip to China.

title: Donation Will Aid Storm-Ravaged Section of Central Park
description: During a fierce thunderstorm on Aug. 18, an estimated 508 trees were either felled or broken beyond repair in Central Park, while another 500 sustained serious, but not fatal, damage. The citys Parks Department and the Central Park Conservancy has called the storm the most severe destruction the parks trees had suffered in decades. The grim destruction yielded some 90 tons of wood chips.

title: Town Divided Over Terror Suspects
description: THOMSON, Ill.  Once federal officials said they might move terrorism suspects from Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to a nearly empty prison here, residents of this faded rural village began debating what they should fear most  the suspects or the downward spiral of the economy here.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Nov. 17
description: Beginning with Vadim Ghirdas picture of commuters in Bucharest (Slide 1), which would not look entirely out of place in a gilded frame on a museum wall alongside 17th- and 18th-century group portraits, todays report is particularly painterly, with tastes of modernism (Slide 5) and impressionism (Slide 14). One view (Slide 6), of the aftermath of a disastrous fire, even comes framed.

title: Leveraging the Obama Brand
description: Earlier this month, almost a year from the day when Barack Obama rode the wave of history into Grant Park, he had one of those weeks that makes his presidency seem, at times, so confounding. First Obama endured an electoral embarrassment, watching his party lose off-year gubernatorial elections in New Jersey and Virginia, in part because many of the voters he had so successfully engaged in his presidential campaign, particularly younger voters, stayed home and made popcorn for Dancing With the Stars instead. The president had been exposed, the pundits solemnly declared, as having no coattails, which are something you really need, they said, if you want congressmen and senators to go along with you on hard votes. Then, just five days later, as Obamas manifest political weakness was still being dissected on cable TV, the president stood in the Rose Garden and hailed the passage in the House of Representatives of the most comprehensive health care bill in the nations history  a bill he had helped pass, narrowly but solidly, by making a rare weekend visit to the Capitol to lobby for it personally. It was, as Obama acknowledged, just a first step, but it was a step no other president had managed to scale, and it seemed to confuse this issue of how powerful a president Obama really is. If Obama has no coattails, then how was he able to pressure nervous lawmakers into making such a perilous vote? And if he had enough influence to get health care reform done, then why were his coattails missing?

title: A Princess Treats Her Suitors (and Audience) With Unflappable Cool
description: LONDON  Soon after Princess Aurora, the heroine of The Sleeping Beauty, appears, she must dance with the four strange men her parents have just introduced to her as prospective husbands. That segment is known as the Rose Adagio, since each man presents the princess with a single rose as he partners her in slow extensions to the side and revolves her in attitude turns on point, her back leg bent at waist height behind her.

title: BlogTalk: Breast Cancer Screening, Magazine Covers
description: New guidelines that call for less frequent breast cancer screening for younger women are provoking anger and confusion on the blogs, with many people wondering if this is aimed at decreasing government costs just as Congress votes on a health care bill.

title: Plan to Expand Jerusalem Settlement Angers U.S.
description: JERUSALEM  Israel said Tuesday that it had advanced plans to expand a Jewish district of Jerusalem in territory that was captured in the 1967 war and that the Palestinians claim as part of their future state. The move is likely to further complicate the Obama administrations faltering efforts to restart peace talks.

title: Oleanna to Close
description: The overlap between two Broadway productions of David Mamet wont last very long. The Broadway revival of Oleanna, Mr. Mamets play about a university professor and the female student who believes he has harassed her, will end its run at the Golden Theater on Jan. 3, its publicists said Tuesday. The play, which stars Bill Pullman and Julia Stiles, was a transfer of a production that ran this year at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles; directed by Doug Hughes, it opened at the Golden Theater on Oct. 11. Mr. Mamets new play, Race, which he is also directing, is to open at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Dec. 6.

title: New Oprah Spinoff for Interior Designer
description: Soon to join Dr. Phil and Dr. Oz: Nate Berkus? Oprah Winfreys production company is proposing a daytime talk show starring Mr. Berkus, an interior designer and a regular on The Oprah Winfrey Show, Broadcasting & Cable reported on Tuesday. The publication said Ms. Winfrey was finalizing plans with Sony Pictures Television to distribute the show next fall. Mr. Berkus was the host of Oprahs Big Give, a reality series last year. The plans for Mr. Berkus will probably heighten speculation about the future of Ms. Winfreys own talk show, as her syndicator, CBS Television Distribution, said this month that negotiations about a new deal were continuing. Ms. Winfrey may change syndicators or move her show to her coming cable channel, OWN.

title: For Gay Couples, Traditional Divorce Isnt Always an Option
description: Its divorce week here on the Bucks blog. Ron Lieber recently explored the financial consequences of divorce in a series of columns, and readers can send their questions to Lili A. Vasileff, a certified divorce analyst, about the financial aspects of splitting up.

title: House Call
description: A first-term congressman from New Orleans, you are the one and only Republican in the House who voted in favor of the Democrats health care plan. Have you been scolded by the Republicans for breaking rank? Not my party leadership, but only by Republicans all over the United States who are disappointed with my vote. But not at all from the party leadership.

title: This Is It on MTV
description: MTV Networks has acquired exclusive television rights to the Michael Jackson concert film This Is It for six years beginning in 2011, the company said on Tuesday. The deal allows MTV Networks to show the film on all its channels, including MTV and VH1, as well as on BET Networks, which like MTV is owned by Viacom. In its announcement, MTV said it would also work with Sony Pictures Entertainment to market the DVD of the film, due early next year. This Is It has grossed $67 million in the United States and $129 million overseas.

title: Dates Set for Kander and Ebbs New Musical
description: Off Broadways Vineyard Theater announced performance dates on Tuesday for the premiere production of The Scottsboro Boys, with music and lyrics by John Kander and Fred Ebb under Susan Stromans direction. The musical, about the historic rape case in Scottsboro, Ala., involving a group of black teenagers who seek to prove their innocence, will begin previews at the Vineyard on Feb. 12 and open on March 10. The book is by David Thompson, and music direction will be by David Loud. The Scottsboro Boys, unfinished at the time of Ebbs death in 2004, had been slated for a development lab production in 2009-10, but instead will be given a fully staged production. Casting has not been announced.

title: Santa Monica Pushes for Eli Broad Museum
description: The City of Santa Monica is poised to join what is shaping up to be a high-profile contest in Los Angeles, competing with Beverly Hills and possibly another California municipality to become the home for a new museum to house the art collection of the billionaire Eli Broad, right. Several months ago Santa Monica officials approached Mr. Broad, who had already been in discussions with Beverly Hills about placing his museum there, The Los Angeles Times reported. In a report that was to be discussed Tuesday night by the Santa Monica City Council, P. Lamont Ewell, the city manager, said winning the museum, which would be built next to the Santa Monica Civic Auditorium, would significantly advance the citys goals of promoting the arts and enhancing cultural opportunities in the area with a relatively small expenditure of public funds. Under the plan the city would lease land to Mr. Broads foundation for a nominal amount and contribute about $1 million for design, construction, parking and other costs. Mr. Broads foundation would pay the rest to build the museum, and would establish an endowment to cover its operating costs.

title: More English Translations for Nobel Winner
description: Readers clamoring for more work from this years Nobel laureate in literature will be able to get their hands on two more titles in the next three years. Metropolitan Books has acquired the North American rights to two novels by Herta Mller, above, the Romanian-born German novelist and essayist who received the Nobel Prize last month. Only 5 of Ms. Mllers 20-some books have been published in English. Metropolitan Books, a unit of Macmillan that previously released her Land of Green Plums and The Appointment, has acquired rights to Everything I Possess, I Carry With Me, a finalist for the 2009 German Book Prize, and The Fox Was Always a Hunter (1992). Metropolitan will publish Everything I Possess  Atemschaukel in German  in September 2011 and The Fox Was Always a Hunter  Der Fuchs War Damals Schon Der Jager  in September 2012. Sara Bershtel, publisher of Metropolitan, said Philip Boehm would translate the books.

title: Hair Extends From Broadway to London
description: Its not quite Manchester, England, England, but the Broadway cast of Hair will soon be making its way across the Atlantic Sea to take that musical to London. In a news release, the Public Theater, the Hair producers and Cameron Mackintosh said they would transfer the production to the Gielgud Theater next year, along with the cast that originated the revival, which is now playing at the Al Hirschfeld Theater. The London production is to begin previews on April 1 and open on April 14, while a new Broadway cast will come into the Hirschfeld starting on March 9. A press representative said that the London production would be an open-ended run, but that the New York cast would remain with the show only through Oct. 2. Gavin Creel, above left, and Will Swenson, above right, among others in the New York cast, were expected to be part of the London transfer, but contracts had not yet been signed, representatives said.

title: Case Study | The Beauty of Duty-Free
description: Case Study is a bimonthly posting on all things alcoholic by Toby Cecchini, Ts spirits columnist.

title: Derring-Do Antics, All in Pursuit of Snow
description: Action is everywhere in Wintuk, the family-oriented holiday extravaganza from Cirque du Soleil. Emotion, however, is in somewhat shorter supply. Thats not necessarily a bad trade-off  not every show need be designed to stir deep feelings. Yet it does mean that those searching for a shot of adrenaline will have a far better time than those hoping to feel their heartstrings tugged.

title: $500 Million and Apology From Goldman
description: How much good will can an apology  and half a billion dollars  buy? A lot, Goldman Sachs is hoping.

title: Extending the Reach of a Great Yiddish Writer, Unto the Next Generation
description: The most moving part of Sholom Aleichem: Laughter Through Tears, Theodore Bikels one-man play with songs at the Baruch Performing Arts Center, comes near the beginning. Ver bet blaybn, vos vet blaybn? Mr. Bikel sings, and then translates: Who will remain? What will remain?

title: Period Piece, Modern Issues: Dealing With Financial Woes
description: The treasure hunters at the Actors Company Theater have unearthed another jewel with The Late Christopher Bean, a comedy seldom seen in New York since its Broadway premiere in 1932. Its a play that has remained fresh and funny, proving once again that a strong script is rarely tarnished by time.

title: A Town Hall to Discuss Toy Safety
description: With the safety and regulation of childrens toys in the news  and in anticipation of a surge in toy sales in the next week  the federal Consumer Product Safety Commissions chairwoman, Inez Tenenbaum, on Tuesday morning held a town-hall-style meeting in Manhattan to discuss toy safety hazards and to assure parents of the agencys efforts to protect American children this winter.

title: When Dusk Finally Settled on the Emperor
description: At one point in the Russian director Alexander Sokurovs beautiful and eccentric movie The Sun, the emperor Hirohito begins enthusing about a preserved hermit crab, the sounds of war planes having subsided. What a miracle! Hirohito (Issey Ogata) marvels, staring at the pale, pickled, seemingly unremarkable crustacean as an assistant transcribes the emperors comments. What heavenly beauty! As Hirohito gazes at the crab, you sense that he is acknowledging a fellow specimen, a communion accentuated by the smudged visuals and murky palette that suggest that all this is taking place inside a dirty aquarium.

title: Goldman Promotes Small Business, and Its Image
description: Criticized for its plan to pay billions of dollars in bonuses this year, Goldman Sachs took steps on Tuesday to improve its battered image, The New York Timess Graham Bowley reports.

title: Fed Busting
description: Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner is once again facing the wrath of opinionland, this time over his actions as head of the New York Federal Reserve last year, when he agreed to pay A.I.G.s partners 100 cents on the dollar to tear up their contracts with the insurance giant.

title: A Town Ponders Controversial Prisoners
description: A plan to move terrorism suspects from the detention center in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to a state prison in Thomson, Ill., has sparked debate among residents.

title: Sweet Potatoes With Prosciutto
description: Mark Bittman demonstrates how to prepare one of many dishes you can make in advance of Thanksgiving dinner.

title: Its Good Guys vs. Bad Guys on a China-Size Scale
description: In a six-year stretch beginning in 1986, John Woo released a series of balletic, ultraviolent crime thrillers that would rank among the most influential films of the last quarter-century. They took a hyperkinetic, Hong Kong style of action moviemaking out of the grind house and into the art house (and the suburban video store), from which it would eventually become the default mode for any number of big-budget Hollywood directors.

title: Tokyo Tops Paris in Michelin Three-Star Restaurants
description: In October, Kyoto was awarded 110 stars in the citys first Michelin guide and more three-star restaurants than New York.

title: Service Announcements Serve Cycling Rules With Humor
description: Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the pedestrian and cycling advocacy group Transportation Alternatives is showcasing more than 40 public service announcements about bicycling and bicycle safety.

title: Plot Twists Staged by a Choreographer
description: If you spend most of your time watching dance, its easy to feel taken aback by a certain staginess that actors can bring to performance, an I am acting now overtone that crops up even among the great and the good. (Recent experiences at After Miss Julie and Finians Rainbow spring to mind.)

title: False Demons
description: Some solid books on wine are out this fall. Been Doon So Long by Randall Grahm, The Chteauneuf-du-Pape Book by Harry Karis, The Finest Wines of Tuscany and Central Italy by Nicolas Belfrage and The Finest Wines of Champagne by Michael Edwards are among those books that I suggest in my roundup of wine books.

title: Mother and Child Reunion Onstage
description: Rhea Perlman can still remember when she realized her daughter Lucy DeVito was no longer her little girl. For years Ms. Perlman had bought her daughters clothes. But when she was 12, Ms. DeVito declared that shed had enough of the Gap and wanted to start trolling secondhand shops.

title: What Ails Public Schools? Better Ask, What Doesnt?
description: A shocking chronicle of institutional dysfunction, The War on Kids likens our public school system to prison and its disciplinary methods to fascism. At least now you know why little Johnny wont get out of bed in the morning.

title: The Needle Nexus
description: Of all the mysteries posed by AIDS, perhaps the deepest and most damaging is a human one: why have we failed so utterly to stop its transmission? Most people with H.I.V. in the world, including a vast majority of the 22 million who are infected in sub-Saharan Africa, caught it from a sexual partner. Despite billions of dollars spent to slow this form of transmission, only a few countries have had significant success  among them Thailand, Uganda and Zimbabwe  and their achievements have been unreplicable, poorly understood and short-lived. We know that abstinence, sexual fidelity and consistent condom use all prevent the spread of H.I.V. But we do not yet know how to persuade people to act accordingly.

title: Group Finds More Anti-Government Sentiment
description: The Anti-Defamation League, in a report released this week, has asserted that a current of anti-government hostility has swept across the United States since President Obama was elected just over a year ago.

title: Slim and Slimmest for Your New TV
description: Its one of lifes vexing little problems: youve just plunked down a sizable chunk of change for one of those super-slim LED side-lit LCD TVs, but when you go to mount it on your wall, it sticks out like a sore thumb.

title: A Great Flash Add-On for Pets (and People)
description: Every time I use flash to snap an indoor photo of my dog Patti, her eyes are transformed into fluorescent turquoise headlights. Its not a good look for a dachshund.

title: 101 Head Starts on the Day
description: FOR cooks, most Thanksgiving problems are brought about by the sheer number of dishes competing for the stove: Its not easy to roast a turkey and sweet potatoes for 20 at the same time. The best solution is to make food in advance, like one of the dishes that follow.

title: The Holdouts
description: Three centrist Democratic senators have yet to agree to procedural approval to begin debate on health care legislation in the Senate. A look at them and the states they represent:

title: Reid Says Hes Close to Unveiling Health Bill
description: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Tuesday that he was close to unveiling his health care bill and that Democrats remained committed to passing it. But when asked if he had the 60 votes needed to bring up the bill for debate on the Senate floor, Mr. Reid was not entirely certain.

title: Daschle Plans Move to Global Firm
description: Tom Daschle, the former Senate majority leader and confidant to President Obama who would have been his health secretary but for a tax controversy, is jumping from one law firm, Alston & Bird, to a bigger one with global reach, DLA Piper, to play a larger role in international issues.

title: B & Bs Seek to Be a Guy Thing
description: BED-and-breakfasts are starting to man up, doing away with the lace bedspreads and trading high tea for brewskies.

title: McCann Responds to Mad Men
