description: A real-life ad agency featured among the fictional ones on Mad Men is having a bit of fun with its central role in the final episode of season three.

title: Economists Letter to Obama on Health Care Reform
description: This afternoon a group of 23 prominent economists  including two Nobel laureates as well as previous members of both Democratic and Republican presidential administrations  sent a letter to President Obama about the priorities for health care reform. The letter appears below.

title: L.A. City Council and D.A. Spar Over Medical Marijuana Law
description: A haze continues to envelop state and local officials in California, as they try to figure out how to enforce drug laws in a state where medical marijuana is legal but there are no clear statewide rules for how its cultivation and sale should be regulated.

title: App of the Week: Navigation as Heavy on Show as Go
description: Ill admit that I have been less than impressed by recent offerings from the GPS maker Magellan. But all is forgiven.

title: Properties for $600,000
description: A house in Hollywood, a house with an adjacent cottage in Pahoa, Hawaii, and a converted barn in Westport, Conn.

title: Zino Attacks the Mini Space
description: Has the Mac Mini met its miniature match?

title: What You Get for ... $600,000
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Court Upholds Restriction on Fifth Avenue Parades
description: Since the St. Patricks Day Parade first clomped down it in the mid-19th century, Fifth Avenue has become the most desirable parade site in the city.

title: Overstock Amazes (Again)
description: Correction Appended

title: Studios Spying On Redbox Kiosks
description: As it turns out, Fox has had a very close eye on an effort by Redbox, the operator of dollar-a-day DVD rental kiosks, to stock its movies, despite a refusal by Fox, Universal and Warner to sell new releases to the company and a pending legal fight over the dispute.

title: Marcus Samuelsson To Cook White House State Dinner?
description: Citing unnamed sources in the food world, Marian Burros reports that Marcus Samuelsson has been invited to cook the state dinner being held at the White House on Nov. 24. He will work with the White House executive chef, Cristeta Comerford, Ms. Burros reports.

title: A Genetics Company Fails, Its Research Too Complex
description: DeCode Genetics, a pioneering company that used the Icelandic population as its guinea pigs in detecting disease-causing mutations, filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday.

title: Drake Hotels Prime Space Remains Undeveloped
description: Enclosed by a dark brown fence, the weedy lot at Park Avenue and 56th Street in Midtown Manhattan is a conspicuous reminder of how ambitions were shattered in the recent real estate debacle. This vacant site, where the Drake Hotel once stood, is likely to leave a gash in the middle of the nations costliest office submarket for years to come, real estate specialists say.

title: Ripe for the Plucking, but Fewer Dare to Try
description: PETTAH, India  As he approaches his first tree of the day, S. Mohan presses his calloused palms together and bows his head.

title: Gratitudes Grace Can Be Itself a Gift
description: It is a fact of life that people give dinner parties, and when they invite you, you have to turn around and invite them back, Laurie Colwin wrote in her bite-size masterpiece, Home Cooking, published in 1988. Often they retaliate by inviting you again, and you must then extend another invitation. Back and forth you go, like Ping-Pong balls, and what you end up with is called social life.

title: Lend Me Your Ear (and Some Money): Small Business Chats Up the Feds
description: Last month, when President Obama ventured out to a small storage company in suburban Maryland to announce new initiatives to free up capital for small business, he also made a less-heralded pledge: to hold a conference. The president intended to bring together regulators, Congressional leaders, lenders and small businesses to determine what additional steps we can take to get credit flowing to small businesses that want to expand and create more jobs.

title: Hershey Reviewing Its Options on Cadbury
description: Update | 6:37 a.m. Responding to reports that it was considering a bid for Cadbury, Hershey said Wednesday that it was reviewing its options, and at this stage there can be no assurance that any proposal or offer from Hershey will be forthcoming.

title: The Argument for Free Classes via iTunes
description: The music, videos and mobile applications available through Apples iTunes Store get all the attention, but it might be time to acknowledge the increasingly varied and popular offerings of iTunes U, Apples catalog of lectures from colleges and universities around the world.

title: Money for a Once and Future Candidate
description: LOS ANGELES  That the A-list of Hollywood would be supporting the Democratic candidate for governor of California is probably not surprising. But holding a big fundraiser for someone who is not yet officially a candidate indicates just how badly some big names here want to end years of Republican rule in the state capital.

title: Economic Insecurity and Bad Habits
Republicans Say Cancer Screening Guidelines Portend Medical Rationing
description: Call it death panel redux.

title: House to Turn Up the Heat on Jobs
description: With Congressional Democrats in near-panic amid forecasts that unemployment will remain high through next Novembers midterm elections, a party leader said on Thursday that the House will pass a new jobs bill before Dec. 18.

title: World Cup Field to Be Completed on Wednesday
description: By the end of the day Wednesday, the full 32-team field for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa will be set. Four European playoffs and the second leg of the South America-North/Central America playoff will be completed. And a one-game African playoff in Sudan will determine whether Algeria or Egypt will make the tournament. Players, coaches and fans endure controversy, anxiety and some disturbing violence on what should prove to be a dramatic final day of qualifying.

title: The Gift of Thanks
description: Today, we use paper to cover our gifts, and it is not primarily because they are in need of protection that we wrap them. If we mail a gift, we first carefully wrap it in special "gift" paper  the prettier, the better  and then enclose it, as a safeguard during the journey, in something sturdy and commonplace like brown paper or a plain envelope. Gift wrappings are folded with care. The string that binds a mere parcel becomes, for a gift, a ribbon, often with bows and rosettes added  anything to replace with embellishment the toughness of workaday knots. Extra trouble is taken because of the need to declare that, whatever it is, the thing thus enclosed is not a commodity.

title: Lives in the Bayou Tap All the Realism of Dreams
description: Spinning stories becomes a blessed biological process in Tarell Alvin McCraneys Brother/Sister Plays, as natural and necessary as breathing. It is said of one character in this gorgeous trilogy, which opened Tuesday night at the Public Theater, where it runs in repertory through Dec. 13, that she breathes like the wind. So do Mr. McCraneys plays, which are pumped full of a senses-heightening oxygen that leaves you tingling.

title: Deputy at Time Magazine to Be BusinessWeek Editor
description: Josh Tyrangiel, a longtime Time magazine editor and reporter, has been appointed the editor of BusinessWeek, its new owner, Bloomberg L.P., announced on Tuesday morning.

title: Trying Tenderness in Las Vegas
description: PERHAPS the most curious thing about Twist by Pierre Gagnaire in Las Vegas  the American beachhead soon to be established by a legendary seigneur of Parisian cooking  is its intended humility.

title: Storming Pariss Burlesque Stages
description: PARIS | From the Moulin Rouge to the Lido, Parisian cabarets have enthralled generations of crowds. But theres a new contender on the scene: Gentry Lane  stage name, Gentry de Paris  who has created one of the more ambitious and authentic burlesque shows in Paris.

title: Comfort Food the Southeast Asian Way
description: THE chef King Phojanakong certainly has the frontier spirit.

title: Come on in, the Waters Fine
description: IT was almost the last lunch service at the old Oceana, on East 54th Street, in mid-July, a quiet affair. For some there were oysters to start, for others an icy midday martini. One man had scallops, simply sauted. For dessert: plain fruit.

title: Red Cross to Seek Donations Through Online Gifts Catalog
description: WASHINGTON  Hoping to reduce its reliance on major disasters to raise money, the American Red Cross is embarking on a holiday fund-raising campaign, complete with an online gift catalog and advertising.

title: Pierre Harmel, Belgian Who Helped Reshape NATO, Dies at 98
description: Pierre Harmel, a Belgian statesman who advocated European disarmament in the late 1960s and was the leading proponent of a forward-looking NATO policy toward the former Soviet bloc that hastened East-West dtente, died in Brussels on Sunday. He was 98.

title: Nationalists Suspected in Russian Activists Death
description: MOSCOW  A young antiracist campaigner who frequently clashed with Russian nationalists has been killed in Moscow in what investigators and analysts suggest is probably part of an increasingly violent conflict between ultranationalists and groups that oppose them.

title: Medical Schools Quizzed on Ghostwriting
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley wrote to 10 top medical schools Tuesday to ask what they are doing about professors who put their names on ghostwritten articles in medical journals  and why that practice was any different from plagiarism by students.

title: Waterworld!
description: In this weeks restaurant review I take a look at Oceana, a venerable name in Manhattan seafood that moved this summer from small quarters on East 54th Street to enormous ones on the ground floor of the McGraw-Hill Building, across the street from City Lobster (which is looking a little quiet and drab these days, sadly). You can read my review here. If youve been to the place, you can tell us about your experience in the comments. You can also take part in a brief pop quiz, after the jump.

title: Ohio Finds Itself Leading the Way to a New Execution Method
description: Prison officials in Ohio never planned to become pioneers in death penalty protocol. But the failed effort on Sept. 15 to execute Romell Broom, a convicted killer, forced the state to rethink how people are put to death and led Ohio officials to be the first in the nation to adopt a new approach.

title: Before the Turkey Goes in the Oven
description: The 101s are not recipes, exactly, but recipe-like ideas. Putting together all of them is a chunk of work, believe me. But putting together one or two? Thats easy. Ill bet the collective efforts of the Bitten community could generate another several hundred beyond these 101 before Thanksgiving.

title: Traffic Agents and Politicians Debate Value of 5 Minutes
description: City Council members say that granting a five-minute grace period for alternate-side-of-the-street parking and certain meter violations would simply give wiggle room to drivers who may have lost track of time.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Dining Calendar
description: Notes and Notable Chefs

title: Little Progress in Freeing a Rover on Mars
description: The NASA rover Spirit, stuck in sand on Mars, tried to move Tuesday for the first time since May. In less than a second, it stopped.

title: Outfitting a Young Mother to Proudly Support Her Son
description: Four years ago, Jocelyn Moraless biggest concerns were cheerleading and the science club. Now she has one overriding preoccupation: being a mother.

title: Paterson Prepares Wage Bill for Construction Sites
description: ALBANY  In a bid to shore up his relations with labor unions, Gov. David A. Paterson is readying legislation that would require developers to pay prevailing wages on many construction projects that receive public financing, meaning that construction workers would have to be paid significantly more than minimum wage.

title: Cellphone Apps Challenge the Rise of E-Readers
description: With Amazons Kindle, readers can squeeze hundreds of books into a device that is smaller than most hardcovers. For some, thats not small enough.

title: Grandpa Loved Horses, or How a Filly Got Her Name
description: Grandpa loved the horses.

title: Conviction of Sheiks Lawyer for Assisting Terrorism Is Upheld
description: A federal appeals court panel in Manhattan on Tuesday upheld the conviction of Lynne F. Stewart, the outspoken defense lawyer who was found guilty in 2005 of assisting terrorism by smuggling information from an imprisoned client to his violent followers in Egypt.

title: Use of Statistics Helps Greinke to A.L. Cy Young
description: It might have been a watershed moment in baseballs statistical revolution. When the voting for the American League Cy Young Award was announced on Tuesday, Zack Greinke of the Kansas City Royals did not just win. He did it in a landslide.

title: New York Is Set for Strict Stand on D.W.I. Cases
description: ALBANY  New York State would make it a felony to drive while intoxicated with a child in the vehicle and would require first-time convicted drunken drivers to buy a device that prevents them from driving their cars if they have been drinking, under a bill passed by the State Assembly on Tuesday.

title: UBS Plans to Be Making Nearly $15 Billion a Year in Profit by 2014
description: LONDON  Oswald J. Grbel, the chief executive of the Swiss bank UBS, presented a plan on Tuesday to return it to profitability, saying that he expected the company to be earning nearly $15 billion a year by no later than 2014.

title: Officials Defend Handling of Flu Vaccine
description: As a nationwide shortage of swine flu vaccine stretched into its sixth week, federal health officials defended how they handled the program, arguing that the roots of the shortage were beyond their control and that they had made the right decisions on matters they could affect.

title: Buffalos Jauron First Coach to Be Fired
description: The Buffalo Bills fired Coach Dick Jauron on Tuesday, making him the first coaching casualty of the season.

title: Shanahan Retires After 21-Year Career
description: Brendan Shanahan, 11th on the N.H.L.s career goal list, announced his retirement Tuesday, bringing an end to his 21-year career. Last season, Shanahan returned to the Devils, the team he started his N.H.L. career with in 1987, but was released at the start of this season. He had not caught on with another team.

title: N.C.A.A. Lets Colleges Decide on a Protocol
description: The N.C.A.A. has no protocol with respect to concussion management; it allows each college that is a member to devise its own procedures, according to David Klossner, the N.C.A.A.s director of health and safety.

title: In Johnsons Signing, Talent Prevails
description: Neil Irvin has carefully monitored Larry Johnsons movement, from the time rumors began that he would sign with the Cincinnati Bengals until Tuesday, when the Bengals announced that they had signed Johnson, the problematic running back.

title: Iverson Is an Option the Knicks Will Probably Decline
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Allen Iverson is a free agent again, and the Knicks are having a conversation about him, albeit only with themselves so far.

title: Cash for Caulkers': The Details
description: At a meeting of President Obamas board of outside economic advisers two weeks ago, the venture capitalist John Doerr said the following:

title: Many Doctors to Stay Course on Breast Exams for Now
description: Despite new recommendations that most women start breast screening at 50 rather than 40, many doctors said Tuesday that they were simply not ready to make such a drastic change.

title: New Mammogram Advice Finds a Skeptical Audience
description: LOS ANGELES In a world with few givens, there have long been a few health guidelines that every American woman could follow. Dental exams annually, from the time you get teeth. Pap smears every year once you are in your 20s. After age 40, 10 minutes of unpleasantness with a mammogram machine, also on a yearly basis.

title: Coconut Pluckers in Short Supply
description: Kerala, India, is in the grips of an acute labor shortage that threatens to undermine one of its most important industries.

title: Pakistani Military Encounters Little Fight as Militants Flee
description: SARAROGHA, Pakistan  This windswept, sand-colored town in the badlands of western Pakistan is empty now, cleared of the militants who once claimed it as their capital. But its main brick buildings, intact and thick with dust, tell not of an epic battle, but of sudden flight.

title: A Stimulus That Could Save Money
description: WASHINGTON

title: Paying More for Flights Eases Guilt, Not Emissions
description: In 2002 Responsible Travel became one of the first travel companies to offer customers the option of buying so-called carbon offsets to counter the planet-warming emissions generated by their airline flights.

title: Germany Arrests Hutu Militia Leaders
description: The leader of a Rwandan rebel group accused of being responsible for the 1994 Rwandan genocide was arrested Tuesday in Germany. The leader, Ignace Murwanashyaka, left, has presided over the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda since 2001. He was arrested in the town of Karlsruhe on Tuesday afternoon by German police officers on suspicions of war crimes and crimes against humanity. One of his deputies, Straton Musoni, was arrested simultaneously in Stuttgart. Mr. Murwanashyakas group, known as the F.D.L.R., has been hiding out in pockets of eastern Congo since being driven out of Rwanda by the current government after the end of the genocide, in which nearly a million Rwandan Tutsis were killed in three months.

title: Kurdish Legislators Threaten Boycott of Iraq Election
description: BAGHDAD  Only a week after Iraqs leaders celebrated the passage of an election law that kept the country on course to hold its first national elections in four years, Kurdish lawmakers threatened Tuesday to boycott the election unless their demand for a greater share of parliamentary seats was met.

title: Siblings on Stage
description: Buy your tickets now for "Brother/Sister Plays,"  a trilogy by the talented young playwright Tarell Alvin McCraney, a onetime assistant to August Wilson. Set in a housing project in a Louisiana bayou, the plays, running in rep at the Public, "are pumped full of a senses-heightening oxygen that leaves you tingling," Ben Brantley writes. "Mr. McCraney, who turned 29 in October, writes with a passion and urgency that can't be faked and in a style that makes artifice feel like instinct, even as it invests ordinary lives with the grandeur of ancient gods."

title: Daft Brooklyn
description: The pioneering house music producer Todd Edwards, known for his contributions to the U.K. dance scene, also collaborated with Daft Punk and created a widely copied sampling technique. Tonight he makes a rare appearance in Brooklyn, at the free party at Littlefield. Go see what all the Euro-fuss is about.

title: Filipino Spice
description: Once home to a Laundromat, the Bed-Stuy spot Umi Nom is now an outpost of sleek design and adventurous cooking  a destination worthy of a trip on the G train, courtesy of the pioneering chef King Phojanakong, of Kuma Inn on the Lower East Side. The menu at Uni Nom (tagalog for "to drink") "consists of artfully composed small plates of Asian comfort food, elevated by technique but primal in appeal," Ligaya Mishan writes. She likes the delicate crispy chicken wings, "the nearly deliquescent pork-belly adobo" and "the dizzyingly hot" papaya salad. "If you're daring, Mr. Phojanakong can be a guide to the wild side," she writes, offering the Filipino delicacy balut, a fertilized duck egg. Bring whatever you want to wash it down with  the restaurant is BYOB for the time being.

title: Bio-Diversity
Lottery Numbers
A Scrapbook From the Tribal Areas
description: LADHA, Pakistan  These stunning photographs were seized in South Waziristan, the remote tribal area of Pakistan where Pakistani soldiers are fighting the Taliban. The vistas are beautiful. The terrain  rugged and hard to conquer  is rarely seen by outsiders.

title: Now, Pressure Is for Players Not to Play After a Concussion
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Messages sent to the University of California athletic office over the past two weeks have not implored team doctors to put the Bears star running back, Jahvid Best, back on the field to help Cal against archrival Stanford this Saturday.

title: Claims of Child Abuse Remembered Divide Town and Lead to Charges Against 6
description: BATES CITY, Mo.  On a dead-end dirt road, through frosted crops and bales of hay in this sleepy town about a half-hour east of Kansas City, state investigators spent much of last week excavating the yard around a farmhouse, looking for decades-old evidence of sex crimes against children.

title: Those Soccer Plays, in Context
description: ALBUQUERQUE  Nearly two weeks later, the University of New Mexico soccer player Elizabeth Lambert said she still could not fully explain what led her to yank an opponent from Brigham Young down by her ponytail in what has become a highly publicized incident of violent behavior.

title: Philadelphia Gives Homeowners a Way to Stay Put
description: PHILADELPHIA  Christopher Hall stepped tentatively through the entranceway of City Hall Courtroom 676 and took his place among dozens of others confronting foreclosure purgatory. His hopes all but extinguished, he fully expected the morning to end with a final indignity: He would sign over the deed to his house  his grandfathers two-story row house; the only house in which he had ever lived; the house where he had raised three children.

title: And Now, the Encore: Yanks Charting Off-Season Course
description: General Manager Brian Cashman started assembling his scouts on Tuesday, beginning the annual brainstorming sessions that chart the Yankees off-season.

title: Police Car Ahead of Biden Crashes
description: A police car assisting Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.s motorcade collided with another vehicle on the West Side of Manhattan on Tuesday as Mr. Biden was on his way to appear on a television show, the police said.

title: ESPN Rewards Jon Gruden Despite Flaws
description: On Monday afternoon, ESPN extended Jon Grudens contract as an analyst on Monday Night Football, affirming the deep affection the empire feels for the former coach midway through his first season in TV.

title: Shot That Hit Bronx Bystander May Have Been Fired in a Revenge Attack
description: Friends of a 15-year-old Bronx girl struck by a bullet intended for someone else held a vigil for her on Tuesday as the police questioned two men about the shooting.

title: Citys Largest Dailies Raided in Deliverers Union Inquiry
description: The police raided the offices of New York Citys three largest daily newspapers on Tuesday as part of an investigation into possible corruption within the union that delivers newspapers in the metropolitan area.

title: Schools Grades Reflect Persistent Disparity
description: Over the last three years, high schools that received the lowest marks from the city have been the ones with the highest percentages of poor, black and Hispanic students, despite an evaluation system that was meant to equalize differences among student bodies, according to an analysis by The New York Times of school grades released this week.

title: Like Some Cheddar
description: The theme of this puzzle by Paula Gamache remains veiled until arriving at the giveaway clue toward the end. When I got there, the crossings allowed me to piece together all but the first letter of its answer. I wasnt sure of the crossing Spanish eyes answer.

title: Prosecutors in Bruno Case Turn Heat on 2 Ex-Aides
description: ALBANY  Seeking to show that Joseph L. Bruno, the former State Senate majority leader, took steps to deceive the public about his private business while in office, prosecutors on Tuesday aggressively questioned two former Senate aides who helped draft official financial disclosure forms for him.

title: Wall Street on Track for Record in Profits
description: Ten months ago, President Obama said a time would come for Wall Street to make profits and pay bonuses, but nows not that time. But it appears that was exactly when Wall Street began to return to profitability.

title: Peru: Officer Says He Spied for Chile
description: Officials in President Alan Garcas government said an air force officer had confessed to spying for Chile, escalating a diplomatic dispute between Peru and Chile. Javier Velsquez, chief of Mr. Garcas cabinet, said Vctor Ariza, 45, a noncommissioned air force officer, had passed national security information to officials in Chiles armed forces. Additional proof included money transfers received by Mr. Ariza and Internet communications he had with contacts in Chile, Mr. Velsquez said. Chiles government has disputed the espionage claims, which surfaced this month amid tensions over a maritime boundary dispute.

title: 2010, Again
description: Allow me to reprise my role as The Man Who Stares At Votes to provide an addendum to my most recent column, The Passion of the Right, which warned that:

title: Labor Fight Ends in Win for Students
description: The anti-sweatshop movement at dozens of American universities, from Georgetown to U.C.L.A., has had plenty of idealism and energy, but not many victories.

title: After 5 Years, Backman Gets a Second Chance
description: As much as Wally Backman wanted to talk about his future, he knew he needed to discuss his past. So after showing off his new Brooklyn Cyclones uniform at his introductory news conference Tuesday, Backman, with little prompting, addressed the issues that cost him a job as a major league manager and kept him out of the majors for five years.

title: 3 Democrats Could Block Health Bill in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, says he is not sure he is ready to help a Democratic health care proposal clear even the most preliminary hurdle: gaining the 60 votes his partys leaders need to open debate on the measure later this week.

title: Another Round of Regulatory Reform
description: Throughout the fall, lawmakers in the House have been drafting and reworking legislation to reform the financial system. Senate Democrats weighed in last week with a plan that is stronger than the House bills on aspects of derivatives regulation and consumer protection. It also invites healthy debate on other issues, like the role of the Federal Reserve in a reformed system.

title: Hunger in the United States
description: Congress should make a priority of expanding federal nutrition programs that are aimed at helping millions of struggling families feed their children. The need to bolster these programs was underscored again this week in a dismaying Department of Agriculture study showing that a record number of households had trouble getting sufficient food at one time or another last year.

title: The Drug Industry Cashes In
description: The drug industry has been ramping up its prices in advance of any health care reforms that might clamp down on its profits. The industrys rapid price escalation over the past year threatens to make a mockery of its deal with the Senate Finance Committee and the Obama administration to contribute $80 billion over the next decade to help pay for covering tens of millions of uninsured Americans.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about testimony from the secretary to Joseph L. Bruno, the former State Senate majority leader, in his trial on corruption charges misidentified the court in Albany where the trial is being held. It is Federal District Court, not State Supreme Court.

title: The Controversy Over Mammograms
description: To the Editor:

title: Cast Heidegger Out?
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Drones in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Rogue American Woman
description: WASHINGTON

title: What They Really Believe
description: If you follow the debate around the energy/climate bills working through Congress you will notice that the drill-baby-drill opponents of this legislation are now making two claims. One is that the globe has been cooling lately, not warming, and the other is that America simply cant afford any kind of cap-and-trade/carbon tax.

title: Why We Should Put Jihad on Trial
description: THE Justice Departments decision to try Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-proclaimed mastermind of the 9/11 attacks, in a federal court in New York City has elicited several criticisms. Most are pointless, but one  the idea that it will give a terrorist a platform from which he could stir up support in the Muslim world for his radical views  is well taken.

title: Ben Franklin on Global Warming
description: Columbus, Ohio

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about General Motors early start to repayment of its debt to the United States and Canadian governments misstated, in some copies, the expected amount of the initial repayment at the end of December. It is $1.2 billion toward $6.7 billion in senior debt; the company will not pay the entire $6.7 billion.

title: Corrections
In Ovechkins Return, a Teammate Is Key
description: The Rangers got another taste of how good the Russian Olympic team may be Tuesday night when Alexander Ovechkin burned them for a goal and was instrumental in setting up another in Washingtons 4-2 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Tuesday with an article about quarterly earnings at the Lowes Companies misstated its results in some copies. The company reported a 30 percent lower profit; it did not report a loss.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with a review of Inside Out, a show by Cirkus Cirkr at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, misstated the given name of the performer shown. He is Andr Farstad, not Andr.

title: After Outcry, 2 Companies Shift Their Turbine Plans
description: Two companies that encountered political anger for their plans to use Chinese-built turbines on a wind farm in West Texas have announced plans to build a new turbine factory  in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about foundations that spend down their endowments and then close misstated the taxability of some foundation investment earnings. Private foundations are subject to an excise tax of 1 to 2 percent on the earnings; they are not tax exempt.

title: Transportation Dept. Bans Drug-Screening Company
description: Michael R. Bennett is not a doctor. But he played one when he signed off on thousands of drug tests for aviation and transportation companies, federal officials said Tuesday as they announced that his company had been banned from doing further tests for the industry for five years.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about John J. OConnor, a former television critic for The New York Times, referred incorrectly to his work for the Arts & Leisure section. Although he wrote essays for it under his own name, he did not also do so under the pseudonym Cyclops. That was the occasional pen name of another critic for The Times, John Leonard.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: New Sony Reader May Miss Christmas for Some
description: The Sony Daily Edition Reader might seem like a fine holiday gift. Unlike the other Sony e-reading devices sold in stores now, it has a spacious 7-inch touchscreen and wireless access to Sonys online bookstore and newsstand.

title: Republicans Seek Inquiry on Fort Hood
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee on Tuesday called for an immediate Congressional investigation of what they called systemic intelligence failures before the shootings at Fort Hood on Nov. 5, saying the Obama administration was trying to block a full inquiry.

title: Sacramento Utility Accuses Banks of Rigging Sales of Municipal Derivatives
description: A California utility, the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, has accused more than a dozen banks of rigging the sales of municipal derivatives and sharing illegal profits.

title: Army Addresses Soldiers Suicide Rate
description: The Army said there were almost certainly to be more suicides of soldiers this year than last. Gen. Peter Chiarelli, the Army vice chief of staff, said that as of Nov. 16, the Army had reported 140 suicides of active duty soldiers this year, the same number as in all of 2008. Despite the overall statistics, General Chiarelli said he believed the Army was making progress because in recent months the rate of suicide was down.

title: Movement on Federal Judicial Selection
description: The Senate voted to move forward on the nomination of a federal appeals court judge amid Democratic concern over the pace of filling judicial vacancies. The 70-to-29 vote will allow debate to begin on the appointment of David Hamilton, a federal judge in Indiana, to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago. The Senate has confirmed two appellate and four trial court judges nominated by President Obama. At the same point in George W. Bushs presidency, 5 appellate and 13 trial judges had been confirmed, according to the Judiciary Committee.

title: In Hollywood, Early Favorite for Governor
description: LOS ANGELES  That the A-list of Hollywood would be supporting the Democratic candidate for governor of California is probably not surprising. But holding a big fund-raiser for someone who is not yet officially a candidate indicates just how badly some here want to end years of Republican rule in the governors office  even if the incumbent, Arnold Schwarzenegger, is of Hollywood minting himself.

title: New Leader at Lazard Is an Insider
description: For much of the modern era, Lazard was known for the internal strife that at times threatened to wreck the now 161-year-old investment bank. Few issues were more contentious than the firms leadership.

title: This Poison Pill Aids Investors
description: Poison pills, or provisions to thwart takeovers, usually benefit management rather than shareholders. Mead Johnson Nutritions desire to enact anti-takeover provisions may be an exception.

title: Sy Syms, Founder of Discount Chain, Dies at 83
description: Sy Syms, who pioneered selling off-price clothing and built his retail chain, the Syms Corporation, into a national brand, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Hershey and Ferrero Hold Talks on Cadbury
description: Hershey and the Italian chocolate maker Ferrero have held talks over a potential bid for Cadbury that would rival Krafts $16.7 billion hostile offer, a person briefed on the matter said Tuesday.

title: Allen Hughes, Music and Dance Critic for The Times, Dies at 87
description: Allen Hughes, a longtime music and dance critic for The New York Times who was known for his encouragement of experimental dance companies and his love of the 20th-century French musical repertory, died on Monday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 87 and had lived in Sarasota since 2003.

title: Showcase: The Adams Families
description: John Quincy Adams is a preacher in Brooklyn. He founded the New Frontier Baptist Church in Bedford-Stuyvesant, where he has been a pastor for 45 of his 87 years. Mr. Adams  the father of two, grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of two  said he never gave much thought to sharing the name of a former president. My life has been fruitful, he said. Even though the presidents went further than I did, I think I kept pace with them.

title: Hulu Steps Into Music With EMI and Norah Jones
description: Hulu, the joint online venture between NBC, Fox and ABC that mostly offers free TV shows and movies, is about to start singing a different tune: music videos.

title: Harvard Officials Are Fossilized Mollusks, Suffragist Says
description: Thursday, Nov. 18, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Phys Ed: Why Exercise Makes You Less Anxious
description: Researchers at Princeton University recently made a remarkable discovery about the brains of rats that exercise. Some of their neurons respond differently to stress than the neurons of slothful rats. Scientists have known for some time that exercise stimulates the creation of new brain cells (neurons) but not how, precisely, these neurons might be functionally different from other brain cells.

title: A Local Push, Timed to Holidays, to Loosen Wallets
description: THROUGH the decades, marketers have veered between Think global, act local and Think local, act global. At one point, someone even coined a portmanteau word, glocal, which sounded like a variety of the Glo-Coat brand of floor wax sold by S.C. Johnson.

title: Irving Kriesberg, Artist of Dreamlike Landscapes, Dies at 90
description: Irving Kriesberg, a much-admired American painter whose work combined the intense colors of Abstract Expressionism with haunting images of human and animal forms, died on Nov. 11 at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Word of the Day | prude
description: prude  \prd\  noun and verb

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Ovechkin Returns With a Goal in Win Over Rangers
description: Two featured matches among Tuesdays six games, in a high-low kind of way. The high was Rangers-Caps, with Alex Ovechkin back in the Washington lineup after missing six games with an unspecified upper-body injury. And the low was Canadiens-Hurricanes, featuring the two teams with the leagues worst regulation records: Habs at 2-11-7, Canes at 1-12-6. Home teams listed first:

title: Silicon Valley Firm Raises Big Fund for Mix of Deals
description: Norwest Venture Partners has raised $1.2 billion for a new venture capital fund, an optimistic sign for technology start-ups.

title: Finders Keepers: Souvenirs on the Road
description: This Frugal Traveler is not big on souvenirs. Too often, the postcards, T-shirts and other tchotchkes hawked to tourists are kitschy and overpriced  the kind of junk that takes up space in your suitcase and gets filed away when you return home. Rarely do those things fulfill the French root of the word souvenir and help you to remember your adventure. Better, I say, to save your money and return home empty-handed but full of memories.

title: 50 Years of Comic Art
description: WHO is Joe Kubert?

title: News Quiz | November 18, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Love and Lore
description: Images from The Brother/Sister Plays at the Public Theater.

title: The Virtual Fridge
description: A slide show of childrens artwork submitted by readers. Masterpieces made of paint, popsicle sticks, crayons and even food.

title: Hermitage Capital Lawyer Dies in Russian Jail
description: A 37-year-old Russian lawyer for an international investment fund, Hermitage Capital Management, died in a pretrial detention center on Monday, nearly a year after he was arrested in an escalating feud between the Russian authorities and the company, Russias Interior Ministry announced on Tuesday.

title: Gold Continues Its Rise, While Asian Stocks Gain
description: Gold hit another all-time high on Wednesday on worries about future inflation and economic uncertainties, while Asian stocks rebounded as the generally bearish dollar kept riskier assets in demand, Reuters reported.

title: S.A.I.C. Reclassifies Shares Into Common Stock
description: Science Applications International Corporation, or S.A.I.C., the defense contractor, has completed the reclassification of its class A preferred stock into common stock.

title: Tokyo Drift
description: A perception that Japans new government is distancing itself from the United States.

title: The AIG report
description: At one level, theres not much news in the SIGTARP (YHTMAAAIYP) report on the AIG bailout: officials asked bankers to take a haircut, bankers said Ni!, and that was that. But the report has renewed the debate over whether officials could have extracted something. I say yes.

title: Will Mead Poison Pill Aid Investors?
description: Poison pills, or provisions to thwart takeovers, usually benefit management rather than shareholders, Breakingviews.com says. Mead Johnson Nutritions desire to enact anti-takeover provisions may be an exception, the Web site says.

title: California Utility Says Banks Rigged Derivative Sales
description: A California utility, the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, has accused more than a dozen banks of rigging the sales of municipal derivatives and sharing illegal profits, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Trump Settles for 10% of Casino Company
description: Donald J. Trump ended his war with bondholders of the casino company that bears his name, settling Tuesday for 10 percent of Trump Entertainment Resorts once it emerges from bankruptcy.

title: After Outcry, 2 Companies Shift Their Turbine Plans
description: Two companies that encountered political anger for their plans to use Chinese-built turbines on a wind farm in West Texas have announced they will build a new turbine factory  in the United States, The New York Timess Kate Gabraith reported.

title: Drake Hotels Prime Space Remains Undeveloped
description: Enclosed by a dark brown fence, the weedy lot at Park Avenue and 56th Street in Midtown Manhattan is a conspicuous reminder of how ambitions were shattered in the recent real estate debacle, The New York Timess Terry Pristin writes. This vacant site, where the Drake Hotel once stood, is likely to leave a gash in the middle of the nations costliest office submarket for years to come, real estate specialists say.

title: S.C. Johnson Considering Bid for Sara Lee Unit?
description: S.C. Johnson & Son may be eying Sara Lee Corp.s air-freshener business, in an auction that could fetch more than $700 million, according to a published report.

title: Vain Glorious | Byredos Stockholm Store
description: With Vain Glorious, T Magazines beauty/style director, Sandra Ballentine, breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

title: Silicon Valley Firm Raises Deal Fund
description: Norwest Venture Partners has raised $1.2 billion for a new venture capital fund, an optimistic sign for technology start-ups.

title: Veto of Iraqs Election Law Could Force Vote Delay
description: BAGHDAD  Iraq was thrown into a fresh political crisis on Wednesday after a vice president vetoed a newly passed election law, delaying the vote, setting off fresh sectarian wrangling and possibly complicating plans to withdraw American troops.

title: At Lazard, a Peaceful Transfer of Power
description: For much of the modern era, Lazard was known for the internal strife that at times threatened to wreck the now 161-year-old investment bank. Few issues were more contentious than the firms leadership.

title: Obama Ends China Trip With Visit to the Great Wall
description: BEIJINGOn his last day in China, President Obama went to see the Great Wall.

title: $500 Million, and an Apology, From Goldman
description: How much good will can an apology  and half a billion dollars  buy? Goldman Sachs is hoping it will be a lot.

title: European Regulators May Take Swift Action on Dark Pools
description: European Union securities regulators will complete their review of dark pool share trading venues by year end and may ask the blocs executive to take speedy action, a top supervisor said Tuesday.

title: Vivendi Said to Want More for NBC Stake
description: It seems Vivendi may be holding out for more in its negotiations to sell its 20 percent stake in NBC Universal to majority owner General Electric.

title: Lawmaker Opposes Fed as Super-Regulator
description: Congress ought to clarify if a proposed super-regulator of the U.S. financial system should be an overlapping overseer of securities and futures exchanges, the chief futures regulator said on Tuesday.

title: Obama Takes Stern Tone on North Korea and Iran
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Obama delivered a stern message on Thursday to North Korea and Iran that they risk further sanctions and isolation if they do not rein in their nuclear ambitions.

title: Citi Boosts Salaries of Some Senior Executives
description: Citigroup said on Tuesday it boosted the base salaries for its chief financial officer and a global markets co-head, but still plans to pay its chief executive, Vikram Pandit, $1 for the year, Reuters reported.

title: Review Period Expires for Xerox-A.C.S. Merger
description: Xerox is a step closer to acquiring Dallas-based Affiliated Computer Services, now that the U.S. antitrust review period for the deal has expired, The Associated Press said.

title: Judge Approves Charters Reorganization Plan
description: Charter Communications said Tuesday a bankruptcy judge has confirmed its reorganization plan, clearing the way for the nations fourth-largest cable TV operator to emerge from Chapter 11 in a few weeks.

title: Week 10 Passer Rankings: On the Bright Side With Cutler
description: Luis DeLoureiro is building a better passer rating at NFLStatAnalysis.net:

title: Filling a Hole in the Middle of Berlin
description: Smack in the middle of eastern Berlin is a grassy lawn measuring nearly five acres. Near it is a huge billboard showing a castle. What gives?

title: MySpace Said to Be in Talks to Buy Imeem
description: MySpace, the social networking platform, is in talks to acquire struggling free music streaming site  imeem, The Associated Press reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

title: Intrawest Sells Copper Mountain to Powdr
description: Intrawest, owned by the Fortress Investment Group, has agreed to sell its Copper Mountain ski resort in Colorado to Powdr, The Associated Press reported.

title: Germany Approves Extension for Afghan Mission
description: BERLIN  The government of Chancellor Angela Merkel on Wednesday approved a one-year extension of Germanys deployment of troops in the American-led coalition in Afghanistan, a government official said, but the number of troops will stay the same.

title: Delta Offers $1 Billion to Tempt Japan Airlines
description: Delta Air Lines offered $1 billion in aid to beleaguered Japan Airlines on Wednesday, a proposal that American Airlines quickly said it would top as the worlds biggest air carriers escalated a war for influence.

title: The Minimum Wage and Teenage Jobs
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: The Rise of Algorithmic Authority
description: Todays idea: More and more, we place our trust in algorithmic authority, a new-media professor writes. We regard as authoritative an unmanaged process of extracting value from diverse, untrustworthy sources.

title: Mitsubishi UFJ Plans $11.2 Billion Share Offer
description: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Japans largest bank, said Wednesday it would press ahead with plans to raise up to $11.2 billion to bolster its financial cushion even as it posted results that showed higher profits in the last six months.

title: Is Icahn Swooping Down on MGM?
description: Is Carl C. Icahn buying  Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer bonds like a bat out of hell? Thats the word, according to Hollywood blogger Nikki Finke.

title: Sampler: Dellums Trip, Palins Book, Jerry Browns A-List
description: Jerrys A-List | A fundraiser tonight in Los Angeles for Jerry Brown, Californias attorney general and likely Democratic candidate for governor, will include Steven Spielberg, Larry Ellison, Magic Johnson and others, all expected to raise $50,000 or more each.

title: Pirates Attack Maersk Alabama Again
description: LONDON  Seaborne raiders in a high-speed skiff tried again on Wednesday to commandeer the Maersk Alabama, the American-flagged ship seized by pirates in April, the United States Navy said.

title: Andy Groves Prescription for Health Care
description: Andrew S. Grove, the 73-year-old former chief executive of Intel, has long brought a piercing intellect and a personal passion to the subject of health care.

title: Ford Minivans Investigated for Transmission Failure
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has intensified its investigation into transmission failures on about 205,000 Ford Freestar and Mercury Monterey minivans from the 2004-2005 model years.

title: Your Childs Art on Our Virtual Fridge
description: Last weeks article, On a Digital Refrigerator, an Art Gallery for the Young, featured artwork from the  hyper-local blogs of The Times and included an invitation to parents to e-mail their own childs art for display on nytimes.com.

title: Is the Music You Listen to Dull?
description: Ever since Natalie Portman popped headphones onto Zach Braffs head and said, This song will change your life, [in the movie Garden State] American music has been dying a slow death, claims an essay quoted in the Idea of the Day blog. Do you agree that youth culture is now practically sponsored by iTunes and Starbucks and needs a jolt of something hungry and desperate and raw?

title: The Early Word: Health Bill Buzz
description: People who are closely following the health care debate might not have to wait much longer for Senate Democrats to release their bill and for the Congressional Budget Office to assess its cost.

title: On Our Radar
description: 1.) What cant you do with leftover food?

title: Houston to Convert Priuses to Plug-Ins
description: Houston is Americas oil capital, with its sprawling oil company headquarters and highways so densely trafficked at rush hour that they sometimes feel like endless parking lots. But Houstons city government and Reliant Energy are trying a modest new effort to green the citys image with a program called Power of the Plug-in.

title: Q.&A. With Kanjorski on Bank Breakup Plan
description: Representative Paul E. Kanjorski introduced his contentious amendment to the House financial regulatory reform bill on Wednesday that would allow the government to break up financial institutions that it believed were too big to fail, even if those firms appear well-capitalized and healthy.

title: Five Arrested in Shooting of Bronx Bystander
description: Updated, 2:08 p.m. | Five young people have been arrested in a shooting that critically injured a 15-year-old Bronx girl  a bystander struck by a bullet intended for someone else  the New York City police announced on Wednesday morning.

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Wednesday morning.RT @Pagliacci Vesti la giubba: The Culture Monster blog of The Los Angeles Times reports on a project recently started by the San Diego Opera, in which that company will recount the history of opera on its Twitter feed, at the rate of two posts a day. One recent post in the series reads: 1613: Monteverdi in Venice, maestro di capella at San Marco. Writes great church music, and more operas.

title: The Odd Couple | Heston Blumenthal at Shopsins
description: Hubris will get you every time. Why did I think I could take Heston Blumenthal to lunch at Shopsins and get away with it? The brilliant British chef behind the Fat Duck and the Hinds Head in Bray  just inked to open in the London Mandarin Oriental next fall with an Adam Tihany-designed space serving English food on a more historical scale  was in town on his way back from Venezuela, where he demonstrated his flaming sorbet. (First challenge: finding dry ice in a country with electricity shortages and an increasingly adversarial trade relationship with Colombia.) Where do you take a man known for snail porridge and bacon-and-egg ice cream? A chef so funny and articulate that you can basically print the transcript of his interview about roast chicken in the 14th century and call it a story? Duh.

title: Assembly Moves to Toughen Law in D.W.I. Cases
description: New York State would make it a felony to drive while intoxicated with a child in the vehicle and would require first-time convicted drunken drivers to buy a device that prevents them from driving their cars if they have been drinking, under a bill passed by the State Assembly on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Home Building Unexpectedly Slumps in October
description: Home construction slowed unexpectedly in October to the lowest level in six months, the Commerce Department said Wednesday, resurrecting fears that the housing market may be slow to recover.

title: American Express to Buy Revolution Money
description: American Express said Wednesday that it would buy Revolution Money, a provider of Internet-based payment services started by Steve Case, AOLs co-founder, for $300 million.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, Nov. 19
description: Highlights from Wednesdays media coverage:

title: Finders Keepers: Souvenirs on the Road
description: What makes a great souvenir, especially when you dont want to spend a lot of money? And how do you find unique items of real value?

title: The Conflicted Populists
description: Rod Dreher has one of the smarter reactions Ive seen to Going Rogue: He zeroes in on the tension between Sarah Palins account of her experiences fighting crony capitalism in Alaska  where she saw firsthand how badly Exxon screwed over the people of Alaska in the Exxon Valdez incident, and how the cozy relationship between Alaskas government and the oil industry worked against the interests of ordinary hardworking people  and the business good, liberals bad boilerplate (complete with a dig at Karl Marx) that she employs when it comes time to talk about national policy. Rod writes:

title: Piecing Together Neda Agha-Soltans Death
description: Updated | 4:06 p.m. As my colleague Neil Genzlinger wrote in a review on Tuesday, a new documentary on the protests in Iran, produced for PBS and the BBC, pieces together the death, and life, of Neda Agha-Soltan, the 26-year-old protester whose last moments were caught on video on June 20 and posted online within hours.

title: Ford Leads in Top Safety Picks
description: Ford leads automakers in the annual list of Top Safety Picks from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, which released its compilation of the safest passenger vehicles Wednesday.

title: Health Care Reform and McKinseys Client X
description: Jonathan Cohn gets his hands on a McKinsey & Company report analyzing what health care reform would mean for a typical employer (and thus for the medical system as a whole). The employer is called Client X in the report. The conclusion is that reform is indeed likely to have a significant  and positive  impact on health care.

title: The Role of Student Fees in Athletic Budgets
description: While the article in Tuesdays New York Times about SUNYs transition to Division I noted that the four State University of New York research universities have increased their contributions to athletics in recent years, it did not examine the role that student fees play in the athletic budgets, as Amy Perko of the Knight Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics noted in an e-mail message on Tuesday.

title: What Will the Goldman Sachs Plan Mean to You?
description: Update | 2:23 p.m. Weve received lots of requests from business owners who want to know more about the 10,000 Small Businesses initiative. Heres a Web site dedicated to the plan. And heres an e-mail address where you can send questions: 10000SmallBusinesses@gs.com.

title: New Greenpeace Chief Calls for Sustainable, Nuclear-Free Power Supply
description: Kumi Naidoo was appointed executive director of the environmental campaign group Greenpeace International this month after two decades leading civil society groups in Africa and internationally. Mr. Naidoo, 44, who is from South Africa, takes over the role at a time when environmentalism increasingly enjoys mainstream status, although the agenda of groups like Greenpeace remains at odds with those of many governments in critical areas like nuclear power and biotechnology. Mr. Naidoo, who is based in Amsterdam, answered questions on energy and climate policy in an e-mail exchange with Green Inc.

title: Shares Drop Slightly on Disappointing Economic Data
description: Hints of a slowdown in the housing market and a batch of dim forecasts from technology companies turned Wall Street traders cautious on Wednesday, with the major indexes retreating slightly from 13-month highs.

title: A Nice Break
description: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Sarah Palins new book came out today. Well, she did Oprah yesterday. She did G.M.A. this morning. Having her out on the road is a nice break, if you are a moose in Alaska.

title: Not on Her Radar
description: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Well, the President is in China now. And he had 71 cars in his motorcade drive from the airport to Beijing. Theres one car for the president, two for Secret Service and then 68 for Obamas advisers on the environment.

title: Obama Made a Faux Pas
description: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on NBC: The President of the United States is in China tonight. This is big. The Chinese president entertained President Obama by having a military band play I Just Called To Say I Love You and We Are The World. What I want to know is how did the Chinese president get hold of my college record collection?

title: In Cuba, a Jobless Person Is a Dangerous Person
description: A report released on Wednesday by Human Rights Watch on the human rights situation in Cuba takes the government of President Ral Castro to task for, among other things, jailing those without jobs. The report cited the cases of dozens of people charged with dangerousness for being unemployed.

title: Letters Lost, Meaning Found
description: The sign, more accurately, should have read U R HURT.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: More Than a Billion People
description: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Its a great day for America and a great day for one of our loveliest Americans, Sarah Palin. Her long-awaited book, Going Rogue, hit bookstores today. Last night, Sarah did a tell-all interview with Barbara Walters. I watched, but I couldnt understand what either one was saying. Did you cwy when you wost the election? You betcha.

title: You Play To Win the Game
description: This Joe Posnanski post should be the last word on the great should Bill Belichick have gone for it? controversy  and, indeed, on Belichicks entire career.

title: Touring Him Around
description: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Do you know where President Obama is right now? In China. Today he was over there. Theyre touring him around. He got to see where they keep all our money.

title: What to Watch on Wednesday: Modern Family and the Kingdom of Mustang
description: Its been a rough season so far for Det. Elliott Stabler (Christopher Meloni) on Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (NBC, 9 p.m.): he found out he sent the wrong man to jail, he was thrown off a roof and his groin was on the receiving end of an angry childs foot. Now its time for Olivia Benson (Mariska Hargitay) to take her lumps: a biker turns up dead and sexually mutiliated and the DNA evidence points to Olivia.

title: In the Mayan Calendar
description: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: President Obama arrived in China yesterday. And to foster the spirit of good will, he wore the traditional clothes made by the children of China. You know, L.L. Bean, J. Crew, Banana Republic, Nike, Reebok.

title: Home Starts Look Good  Compared With Apartments
description: Who would break ground on a new apartment building these days?

title: Playing the Health Care Lottery
description: In the short story The Lottery, the author Shirley Jackson describes a small farming community in 1940s America, as picturesque a scene as anything youd find in Norman Rockwell. Its Lottery Day, and families gather in the June sun, the adults chatting while their children play, gathering up small piles of stones.

title: Countdown to the 60th National Book Awards
description: As you busily compile your year-end best-of lists and plan your 2010 schedule around the Grammys, the Oscars or the start of American Idol, it may have escaped your attention that the National Book Awards, in their 60th year, are to be handed out on Wednesday night. If the National Book Awards, presented by the National Book Foundation, seem to have generated less buzz than in previous years, it might have something to do with a roster of finalists that arent likely to be known by wide audiences: among this years nominees for the fiction prize are Colum McCanns Let the Great World Spin, and Marcel Therouxs Far North; the nonfiction finalists include David M. Carrolls Following the Water: A Hydromancers Notebook, and Sean B. Carrolls Remarkable Creatures: Epic Adventures in the Search for the Origins of the Species.

title: In Africa, Capturing the Fight Against Climate Change
description: With the approach of the international climate talks in Copenhagen, the United Nations Development Program in conjunction with the Olympus Corporation and the Agence France-Presse Foundation created a photo competition aimed at profiling everyday Africans and their efforts to combat climate change. Below is a slide show of some of the winning photographs and the runners-up in various categories.

title: Can Crispy Green Go National?
description: The Company: Crispy Green of Fairfield, N.J., a maker of freeze-dried fruit snacks sold in silver packages that has seven employees and had 2008 revenue of $2.2 million. The snacks are a gluten-, dairy- and nut-free alternative to chips.

title: Feeling For  Brogues
description: Theyre chunky. Theyre clunky. They can chew your ankles when theyre being broken in. And yet Im completely feeling for brogues this fall. Theyre the 1960s wingtips with the heavy extended leather sole worn by businessmen in an era typified by philandering, booze and cigarettes in the workplace. They served as heavy anchors to the slender suits of the day that have been resurfacing thanks to Mad Men and the spinoffs hitting the floors at Brooks Brothers, J. Crew and Banana Republic. Duckie Browns brogue collaboration with Florsheim has reinvigorated its classic Royal Imperial collection with saturated colors and artful perforations; other stateside manufacturers like Alden and Allen Edmonds have classic versions of the shoe that originated in England with brands like Trickers, Churchs and Grenson. I prefer the cordovan color for the rich tone it adds to any gray suit, but black will do just fine. Best of all, brogues are not just suited for business  they are the perfect exclamation point for jeans, whether they are faded and worn, or dark and unwashed. Roll up those cuffs Im feeling for brogues.

title: Dueling Alliances Make Aid Offers to Japan Airlines
description: TOKYO  Delta Air Lines and its alliance partners offered $1 billion in aid to Japan Airlines on Wednesday, a proposal that American Airlines quickly said it would top as the worlds biggest airlines escalated a war for influence over the ailing Japanese carrier.

title: Patterns: Smoking in U.S. Declines but Not by Much
description: One in five Americans smoked last year, down from almost one in four a decade earlier. But the declines in smoking have recently stalled, with virtually no change in smoking rates since 2004 and even a hint of an increase last year, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are reporting.

title: Nicolas Cage Is Sued by Former Money Manager
description: For the Bad Lieutenant star Nicolas Cage, the week just got a little worse. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Cage, the actor whose lavish spending habits have been widely discussed since he filed suit against his former business manager, is being countersued by that same manager. In October, Mr. Cage sued Samuel J. Levin for fraud, saying that Mr. Levin led him down a path toward financial ruin. In his countersuit filed on Nov. 12, The A.P. reported, Mr. Levin said he told Mr. Cage he would need to earn $30 million a year to maintain his life style, and that he warned the actor not to buy castles in England and Bavaria. (Mr. Cage did not heed the advice.) Mr. Levin also said in his filing that he devised a fund-raising plan for Mr. Cage that included the sale of a dozen classic cars and a $1.6 million comic book collection. A lawyer for Mr. Cage said that Mr. Levin had breached Mr. Cages privacy by releasing details about his asset sales. The A.P. said that the Internal Revenue Service has filed more than $6.6 million in tax liens against Mr. Cage this year.

title: Obama Says Guantnamo Wont Close by January
description: President Obama acknowledged for the first time on Wednesday that his administration would miss a self-imposed deadline to close the detention center at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, by mid-January, admitting the difficulties of following through on one of his first pledges as president.

title: Setting the Table for Next Labor Negotiations
description: A decade ago, the N.B.A. and its players were embroiled in a labor dispute, culminating in a lockout which nearly led to the cancellation of the 1998-99 season. With the current collective bargaining agreement set to expire in 2011, the parties once again have begun to lay the groundwork for the negotiations toward a new agreement. The Los Angeles Lakers Derek Fisher, a veteran of the 1998-99 work stoppage and now the president of the N.B.A. Players Association, is the players chief representative.

title: No Free (CO2) Lunch for Frequent Fliers?
Answers on Community Colleges, Part 3
description: Each day this week, the Guidance Office  the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts  will feature answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: 3Coms Deal Maker of the Week?
description: The Am Law Daily named Michael Ringler of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati as deal maker of the week last week. The Web site did so based on his representation of 3Com in its $2.7 billion agreement to be acquired by Hewlett-Packard. Am Laws profile could only be described as glowing and based on his persistent lawyering.

title: Thursday Matchup: Dolphins at Panthers
description: Dolphins (4-5) at Panthers (4-5)Thursday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Panthers by 3

title: Heston Blumenthal at Shopsins
description: On The Moment, Christine Muhlke takes Heston Blumenthal to Shopsins. Clever. But bringing a camera and a notepad when youre about to dine with the notoriously cranky Kenny Shopsin? Not so smart. Theyre lucky they got to eat. Blumenthal enjoyed it.

title: Campuses Strike as U.C. Leaders Decide On Fee Hike
description: Today, the University of California Board of Regents meets to consider a 32 percent fee hike as well as fee increases for 44 graduate programs. The office of the student regent Jesse Cheng is live blogging the meeting, which is taking place at the universitys Los Angeles campus:

title: Caucus Chatter: New Comment Features
description: Dear Caucus readers,

title: 'My Wonderful Day'
description: Ayesha Antoine and Petra Letang in a scene from Alan Ayckbourn's play. (Courtesy of Applause Video)

title: Glitter and Be Essential
description: A WARNING to sticklers for strict narrative: this column is a blatant mashup.

title: In Basketball, Early Signs of Life
description: Perhaps we have been numbed by too many horrendous N.F.L. blowouts, or a baseball season that seemed to last an epoch, but the college basketball season already feels promising. Forget for a minute that Isiah Thomas is involved in any way, that tournaments are trying to outdo themselves with the ugliest courts ever conceived and that Memphis Coach Josh Pastner would be stopped and asked for a hall pass in most high schools. Heck, we can even live with a game at 6 a.m. on a crazy 24-hour television-conceived tipoff day when the season actually started last week.

title: Jobless Benefits Will Expire Unless Congress Acts
description: About one million laid-off workers will see their unemployment benefits end in January unless Congress acts quickly to renew existing federally paid extensions, according to a new survey and legislators and state officials.

title: Another View of Velvet Underground at New York Public Library
description: Got a burning question youve wanted to pose to the Velvet Underground since that down-and-out New York art-rock band broke up in the 1970s? Want to know whos coughing on the recording of Who Loves the Sun or when well see an official CD release for Squeeze? You may finally have a chance to get the answers: On Dec. 8, three members of the Velvet Underground will appear at the New York Public Library to discuss the groups music and history as part of the librarys Live From the NYPL series, Billboard reported. The musicians Maureen Tucker, Doug Yule and, of course, Lou Reed (who we understand just adores being peppered with random questions by his fans) are scheduled to appear at the event, at which they will be interviewed by the journalist David Fricke. The interview will take place at the Celeste Bartos Forum in the librarys Stephen A. Schwarzman Building, and tickets are available online at nypl.org ($15 and $25). The Velvet Underground singer-guitarist Sterling Morrison died in 1995, and the co-founder John Cale left in 1968, though he reunited with Mr. Reed for a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony in 1996.

title: Prospects for Large Houston Solar Plant Dim
description: Two months ago, the City of Houston announced that it planned to work with NRG Energy, the big wholesale power generation company, to build a $40 million solar power plant that would be the largest in Texas. But now The Dallas Morning News is reporting that prospects for the plant are dimming fast.

title: From Simple Noun to Handy Partisan Put-Down
description: Call it a vast linguistic conspiracy: proponents of the major conspiracy theories of the day  the truthers, the birthers, the deathers  share a suffix that makes them all sound like whackdoodles. It looks like conspiracy theorists might acquire a permanent suffix in -er, just like political scandals now have a permanent suffix in -gate, Victor Steinbok, a frequent contributor to the American Dialect Societys online discussion board, observed recently in that forum. But unlike -gate, which merely names a scandal, he later noted, -er makes fun of the participant as an obsessive, almost foaming at the mouth advocate of a fringe political belief.

title: Minister Says Iran Wont Ship Uranium Abroad
description: CAIRO  Irans foreign minister said this week that his government would not ship its stockpile of low-enriched uranium out of the country, making him the highest ranking official so far to declare that Iran would renege on a deal aimed at defusing a confrontation with the West over its nuclear program.

title: 101-Year-Old Man Buys a 426-Horsepower Camaro
description: Eight months older than General Motors, Virgil Coffman clearly is not whom Chevrolet had in mind when it decided to bring back the Camaro.

title: A Librarys Century of Hungering Imagination
description: The Seward Park branch of the New York Public Library opened 100 years ago this month, on Nov. 11, 1909, and the library will mark the centennial with a program of public events starting at 2 p.m. Thursday. Perhaps what is most remarkable about the branch, which was most recently renovated in 2004, is the continuity of the immigrant aspirations  then largely Jewish, now mostly Asian and Hispanic  it embodies.

title: Flush in a Recession, a Bronx Landlord Is Ready to Shop
description: In the feudal world of Bronx real estate, where a handful of landlords claim ownership to its skyline of cramped apartments, Jacob Selechnik is most certainly royalty.

title: On Assignment: Asia in the Blink of an Eye
description: President Obama, whose motorcade has been as long as 71 vehicles, is always at least 30 cars ahead of the four-person photo pool trailing him as he tours Asia. I really wanted a whimsical picture of the president as he walked past the No Smoking sign in the Forbidden City, but his Chinese police escorts blocked the shot as his entourage swept by. (Note: Lark cigarettes are very popular in Asia and the gift shop in the hotel where Mr. Obama stayed in Tokyo sells Che ashtrays). That done, we were escorted at a quick trot  with the 35 pounds of gear it takes to be a live news bureau operation  to set up at the other side of the nearly-empty complex to record the president as he signed the visitors log.Throughout Japan, Singapore and China, I have met friendly and industrious people. The young woman at the Starbucks in Beijing took my debit card with a smile and never once mentioned the nearly $1 trillion of U.S. debt held by China. A helpful American journalist based in Beijing pointed out the spot where an unknown Chinese man heroically faced down a line of tanks during the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.Theres little down time on these trips. Sleepless nights worrying about oversleeping take their toll. My hopes of going to the famous Silk Market in Beijing to haggle for Western cowboy wear  the exact item available in Aspen at four times the amount  have been dashed.

title: Precious to Be Honored With Kramer Award
description: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire took a step in the march toward Oscar recognition, as the Producers Guild of America chose to honor it with the groups Stanley Kramer Award, according to a person briefed on the decision who spoke on condition of anonymity because it had not been formally announced. Established in 2002, the Kramer award is given to a movie, program, studio, executive or entity that tackles provocative social issues in a constructive way. Precious, about a young womans struggles to succeed despite her troubled and impoverished family, fills the bill, and will join such past recipients as Milk and Good Night, and Good Luck, both of which were nominated for best-picture Oscars.

title: Hannah Returns: Responding to Comments on Womens Colleges
description: Hannah Smith is a senior at University Laboratory School in Baton Rouge, La., who is currently applying to colleges. Here she responds to the more than 300 comments on an essay she wrote about her interest in womens colleges, which was posted on The Choice.

title: No Free (CO2) Lunch for Frequent Fliers?
description: From our friends at the Dot Earth blog:

title: California Panel OKs New TV Energy Standards
description: California has become the first state in the nation to institute energy standards for television sets, a move that could lead to the removal of the most power-consuming television screens from store shelves.

title: Greetings Line in the Cards for Taylor Swift
description: Suppose youd like to send a friend a note in a time of need  perhaps she was recently embarrassed at a music awards show on national television?  but you cant think of the exact right words to say to her. Taylor Swift may be able to help you out. American Greetings said that it has signed a deal with Ms. Swift, the 19-year-old country music superstar, to produce a line of greeting cards centered around her, The Associated Press reported. In a news release, American Greetings said that it planned to release cards, as well as gift wrap, stationery and online photo products and greetings whose design will be overseen by Ms. Swift in the spring. In a statement, the companys chief executive, Zev Weiss, said that Ms. Swifts abilities as a storyteller and songwriter make her a natural at writing cards for consumers of all ages. Ms. Swift said in statement, My idea of a great song is a song that says how I feel better than I could. I feel the same way about greeting cards. Well see if they measure up to the Garfield product line, which we feel are the best greeting cards of all-time  of all-time.

description: Looking for a last-minute Thanksgiving vacation? Take your pick:

title: News of Hockey, 11/18/09: The N.H.L. in Russian, the K.H.L. in English
description: Relations between the N.H.L. and K.H.L. may be a bit rocky, but the cultural exchange between North America and Russia continues with announcements on both sides of the divide.

title: Defining What Makes a Father
description: Its a life-changing moment when you discover you are going to be a parent. Equally profound is when you learn you never really were.

title: Now Showing | Stuffed Animals, Cuddly No More
description: Youll never look at those cute little mechanical stuffed bunnies the same way again. On Thursday, Moss unveils Remains, an exhibition by the artist Cathy McClure, whose particular passion is taking these mass-produced, eminently disposable items and redesigning them as precious objects. McClure strips away the plush motorized creatures furry coats and fluffy stuffing and then casts the animals plastic bodies and limbs in bronze, while leaving most of their mechanisms intact but exposed. A rabbits ears, for instance, are reduced to their antenna-like spring supports, while a formerly cocky rooster drags his now-heavy body around, crowing as if he were still king of the barnyard. If the movie Mad Max had had a toyshop, these half-whimsical, half-disturbing animals would have fit right in. But theyre strictly for big kids now, with their sumptuous bronze bodies and five-figure price tags. The exhibition continues through Dec. 31 at 150 Greene Street.

title: Mark Bittmans Top 12 Make-Ahead Dishes
description: Recipe lovers will be eager to pore over Mark Bittmans 101 make-ahead recipes today in the Dining section of The New York Times. But for those who are having a tough time choosing a favorite, Mr. Bittman has offered his top 12 picks for Eat Wells Vegetarian Thanksgiving.

title: G.M. Is Beating Treasury Expectations, Rattner Says
description: The newly reorganized General Motors is exceeding the governments expectations by a large margin, Steven Rattner, the former head of the Obama administrations auto task force, said at a Fortune magazine conference on Wednesday morning.

description: Updated | 3:02 p.m. My colleagues at the Goal blog have coverage of the result of todays match  which Algeria won 1-0 to qualify for next summers World Cup in South Africa.

title: Unveiling the Hanging Gardens of Armenia
description: YEREVAN, Armenia  Some 20,000 Armenians turned up for the opening of the Cafesjian Center for the Arts last week. They jammed the new sculpture park and the terraced gardens and galleries, including the first exhibition ever in Armenia of the Armenian-born American great, Arshile Gorky.

description: Money sent to help immigrants struggling in rich countries (such as the U.S.) by friends and family in less-developed countries (such as Mexico).
