description: Once China and Taiwan had agreed on the substance of the financial cooperation deal they signed this week, they still had a few details to decide: Where should they sign the pact, what names should they use to sign it, and which Chinese script should they write in?

description: SEOUL, South Korea  For all of President Obamas laying claim to the title of Americas first Pacific president, Asia was always going to be a tough nut for him to crack.

description: The Vancouver Olympics are still more than two months away, but USA Hockey defenseman Caitlin Cahow feels like theyre nearly here.

description: Can the iPhone begin a new childrens entertainment franchise? One of Hollywoods leading character architects is banking on it.

description: Former New York governor Eliot Spitzer, who spoke last week spoke at Harvard and to the BBC, is on a rehabilitation tour. Unfortunately for him, so is Peter Florrick, the convicted former Illinois states attorney on The Good Wife.

title: Senator Byrd Honored
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, the fiddle-playing expert of Congressional procedure and history, became the longest-serving member of Congress on Wednesday, serving 20,774 days  56 years and 320 days of time in both the Senate and the House.

title: A Conversion Experience: Using the Metric System
description: Overview | Should Americans employ and embrace the International System of Units (S.I., or the modern metric system)? How does this system allow for an easy transition between orders of magnitude? In this lesson, students watch the documentary Powers of 10 and then document their own connections between daily objects and metric measurements to create metric anchors. They then develop ways to help others learn and remember metric units.

title: Bon Jovi Album Is No. 1
description: Bon Jovi has scored its second No. 1 album in a row  and the fourth of its career  with The Circle (Island), which sold 163,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Carrie Underwoods Play On (19/Arista Nashville), last weeks top seller, fell to No. 3 with 128,000 sales, a 60 percent drop, and Andrea Bocellis My Christmas (Sugar/Decca) climbed one spot to No. 2 with 136,000.

description: The filmmaker Oliver Englehart follows a local team working to clear mines from a residential area in Afghanistan, where buried explosives are a finite, but persistent problem.

title: National Book Awards: Conflict of Interest Question Arises in Young Readers Category
description: Its not Olympic figure skating, but even the National Book Awards can generate a judging scandal.

title: Ones to Watch | Bijoux Altamirano and Camille Vivier
description: The video artists Bijoux Altamirano and Camille Vivier are among a new breed of multihyphenate women blazing a path in the art world. Altamirano, based in New York, also performs with the band the Voluptuous Horror of Karen Black. She is currently part of the Inferno show at the Yautepec gallery in Mexico City, and in December her music video for the band Jessica 6 will premiere at New Yorks Deitch Projects. Vivier is a Paris photographer who shoots fashion for magazines like Purple and Dazed & Confused. The art-book publisher Seems will issue a collection of her work in the spring, and Maison Martin Margiela has commissioned her to direct a video for its new fragrance being released early next year. Here, a look at some of their recent works.

title: Supercomputers Are Still Fast, but Less Super
description: Update | 6:06 p.m.  This story was updated to correct a previous assertion that Jaguar was the first x86-based system to be the worlds fastest supercomputer.

title: Innovative Countries, Energized Campuses
description: Innovation Report Card. A new report on Innovation for Development out of the European Business School ranks countries ability to propel innovation in ways that advance societies. (The United States comes in a respectable third, behind Sweden and Finland.) The study assessed countries using an index that ranked factors like education, social inclusion, and regulations and laws that made it easier to propel a good idea to the market. A summary of the situation in the United States presents a more positive picture than some other recent assessments:

title: Ex-Military Officer in Pakistan Is Linked to 2 Chicago Terrorism Suspects
description: WASHINGTON  The arrests last month of two Chicago men accused of planning an attack on a Danish newspaper have widened into a global terrorism inquiry that has led to arrests in Pakistan and implicated a former Pakistani military officer as a co-conspirator, government officials said Wednesday.

title: Giants Boley to Cover Gonzalez?
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Linebacker Michael Boley will play his second game since recovering from knee surgery Sunday when the Giants play the Atlanta Falcons.

description: Wells Fargo said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy back $1.4 billion in auction-rate securities it sold to investors before the market for those securities dried up last year.

title: Put a Heisman in Stanford Backs Juggling Act
description: STANFORD, Calif.  Four Stanford graduates have become Supreme Court justices since the football team produced its only Heisman Trophy winner, Jim Plunkett, in 1970. Into this yawning gap burst Toby Gerhart, a senior tailback, who has insinuated himself into the Heisman conversation this month while leading Stanford to consecutive upsets of Oregon and Southern California.

title: Skier Lindsey Vonn Wants Your Artwork on Her Head
description: Designing is all the rage these days, from the budding fashionista divas on Project Runway to carpenter Ty Penningtons cross-country tearing down and rebuilding of houses on Extreme Makeover.

title: Sarah Palin Appearance Brings Oprah Winfrey Highest Rating in Two Years
description: Giving support to those who have suggested that she become a television talk-show host, Sarah Palin delivered the highest audience in two years to The Oprah Winfrey Show on Monday. The hourlong interview with Ms. Palin received an 8.7 household Nielsen rating.

title: Luxe Redux | The Techno Luxury Conference
description: The International Herald Tribune Techno Luxury conference in Berlin started with a bang from Burberry when the newly named chief creative officer, Christopher Bailey, revealed just how intricate new technology is to his company.

title: Seas Grow Less Effective at Absorbing Emissions
description: The Earths oceans, which have absorbed carbon dioxide from fuel emissions since the dawn of the industrial era, have recently grown less efficient at sopping it up, new research suggests.

title: Defending Small Business, Eyeing a Big Vote
description: Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, has been cagey on how she will vote on a motion to bring up the big health care bill for debate in the Senate. But in a speech on the Senate floor on Wednesday morning, Ms. Landrieu, chairwoman of the Small Business Committee, suggested that government action was urgently needed and that she was willing to negotiate a bill  provided that controlling soaring health care costs for small businesses was a top goal.

title: F.B.I. Kept File on Studs Terkel
description: While Studs Terkel was following around musicians, baseball players and other hardworking Americans in the course of his journalistic duties, it turns out that Mr. Terkel was being followed himself. The Chicago Tribune reported that Mr. Terkel, the prolific author, radio host and Pulitzer Prize winner, who died last year, was tracked for 45 years by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the suspicion that he was a Communist. According to a dossier obtained by the NYCity News Service of the City University of New York, the F.B.I.s file on Mr. Terkel began in 1945, noting that he spoke at a Paul Robeson rally and worked with the BBC on a piece about the sordid side of life in Chicago. The last entry in the file was a 1990 article from The Wall Street Journal in which Mr. Terkel was quoted on the junk-bond scandal of the financier Michael Milken. (We live in a corrupt, amoral moment, Mr. Terkel said.) The dossier also showed that Mr. Terkel had applied for a job in the fingerprints division of the F.B.I. in the 1930s.

title: Feeling Fluish? Call 311
description: Having flulike symptoms does not have to mean a call to the doctor or a visit to the emergency room. Beginning Thursday, you can call 311.

title: Who Fears a Free Mikhail Khodorkovsky?
description: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, once his countrys richest man, has resided in gulag lite, as he calls the Russian penal system under Vladimir Putin, for six years. Since the spring, on most working days he is roused at 6:45 in the morning, surrounded by guards and packed into an armored van for the drive to court. For two hours each way, the man who once supplied 2 percent of the worlds oil crouches in a steel cage measuring 47 by 31 by 20 inches. Convicted of tax evasion and fraud in 2005, Khodorkovsky now faces a fresh set of charges that add up to the supposed theft of $30 billion. In the dark of the van, Khodorkovsky tries to prepare for his trial, replaying in his mind his night reading, the daily stack of documents from his lawyers. But Russias most famous prisoner worries too about what would happen if a car slammed into the van. (Collisions are routine in Moscows clotted avenues.) Your chances of making it out alive, he wrote me one day this summer, at any speed, are next to none.

title: New Ad Campaign Aimed at 13 House Members
description: The onslaught of television commercials against health care legislation has prompted a liberal advocacy group and two labor unions to begin a $1.7 million advertising campaign in favor of reform.

title: Wade F. B. Thompson, Who Rebuilt Airstream Brand, Dies at 69
description: Wade F. B. Thompson, who revived the beloved Airstream brand of travel trailers and led a campaign to renovate the historic Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan, died on Nov. 12 at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 69.

title: Falcons Coach on Parting Ways With Boley
description: Before linebacker Michael Boley signed with the Giants this season as a free agent, he played for the Atlanta Falcons. The Giants will play the Falcons on Sunday and Boley will face his old team. This is what Falcons Coach Mike Smith had to say about him.

title: Our Bodies, Our Breast Exams
description: The big news for women this week was new set of recommendations that most women can wait until age 50, rather than 40, to begin screening for breast cancer with mammograms. But there was another surprise in the new guidelines: a thumbs down to teaching women a simple, low-tech way to check for breast cancer  the self-exam.

description: A disabled Canada goose in Prospect Park is missing the upper half of its beak, prompting concern among Brooklyn residents that it might starve to death, as some birds with similar disabilities have done.

Stern Architects, was officially unveiled in a ceremony on Wednesday The Dallas Morning News reported. In an interview, Laura Bush told The Morning News that a year was spent discussing and planning the design for a 225,000-square-foot building that will be home to Mr. Bushs presidential papers, as well as a museum and a policy institute.

title: No Victories, but Lots of Giveaways
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Brett Yormark, the chief executive of the Nets, knew something had to be done. Dwyane Wade of the Miami Heat had just hit a 3-point shot with a tenth of a second remaining to help send the Nets to their 10th consecutive loss to open the N.B.A. season. Yormarks 5-year-old son, Drake, who traveled with his father to Miami to see Saturdays game, was distraught.

description: The Manager of the Year awards were announced on Wednesday, and as usual, there were no surprises. The winners were Jim Tracy of the Colorado Rockies and Mike Scioscia of the Los Angeles Angels.

title: Obamas Soft Approach on Human Rights
description: Even before his trip to China, President Obama showed deference to Chinas leaders by postponing a meeting with the Dalai Lama until after his trip. During his visit, he did not meet with Chinese political activists and chose not to confront the Beijing government on human rights and its treatment of dissidents.

title: Tune In, Start Up, Drop Out

title: Answers About Community Philanthropy
description: Following is the first set of answers from Lorie A. Slutsky, president of the New York Community Trust, on community philanthropy, the value of many different approaches to charitable giving and their importance in maintaining a strong democracy.

title: Now Starring | Art in Los Angeles
description: For a city that often gets knocked for being starved for culture, Los Angeles served up an all-you-can-eat buffet this past week. For once the talk was focused on art and not on movies or on who is in rehab. The festivities began with an arty party on Thursday night for mindthegap, the inaugural show at Prism, a new three-story gallery on Sunset Boulevard. More stars than there are in paparazzi heaven  Carine! Dasha! Peaches!  showed up to support the owners, PC Valmorbida and Jared Najjar, and the featured artists, Barry McGee and Phil Frost. The following night Miuccia Prada held court at her Beverly Hills store for the publication of her new book, simply titled Prada, while the philanthropists philanthropist Eli Broad hosted an A-list dinner, which was in turn followed by an after-party at Benedikt and Lauren Taschens house. Tired yet? The bleary-eyed emerged the next day to make it to the Jeff Koons private reception and brunch at Gagosian before heading back to their hotels to get their glad rags on for MOCAs 30th anniversary gala. Over 1,000 guests  everyone from John Baldessari to Brangelina and Gore Vidal  turned out for the black-tie-soiree-as-performance-art, which raised over $4 million for the resurgent museum. The highlight of the evening was Ballet Russes Italian Style (The Shortest Musical You Will Never See Again), a five-minute act created by the artist Francesco Vezzoli, starring the evenings M.C., Michael York, dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet and Lady Gaga, who performed her new song, Speechless, on a rotating pink grand piano painted with blue butterflies by Damien Hirst. (Larry Gagosian later snapped up the piano at auction to the tune of $450,000.) As if that werent enough, what seemed like half of Los Angeles rallied for an after-party hosted by Pop magazine at Prism. By the end of the weekend, there were enough stories to fill a movie and more than one reveler looked in need of rehab.

title: Ben Nelson to Harry Reid: Show Me the Bill
description: Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska, who is one of three Democrats who have said they might not be in favor of starting debate on the big health care legislation, issued a statement on Wednesday seeking to clarify his view on procedural votes.

title: Mushroom Ragout Gravy
description: I never make gravy. Some people find that perplexing, but I dont like it  theres just too much fat involved. Instead, I make this mushroom ragout and spoon it over the turkey and on the side.

title: Group Says Push to Build Nuclear Power Plants Will Set Back Climate Change Efforts
description: To nuke or not to nuke: whether its kinder to the environment to suffer nuclear plant start-up delays and potential cleanup headaches or to take arms against (rising) seas of trouble through other, likely costlier, alternatives (think solar)? That is the question thats been haunting environmental circles for the past few years.

title: Fallout From Richmond High Rape May Lead to Change in Witness Law
description: Last night, the city of Richmond honored Margarita Vargas, the young woman who called 911 to report the gang rape of a girl outside of Richmond High Schools homecoming. Tonight, she will be honored by the West Contra Costa Unified School District.

description: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, has thrown his support behind an effort to keep the Pool Parties summer concert series at its latest home on the Brooklyn waterfront.

description: Patrick Byrne, the subject of a post yesterday, asks that I identify him both as the chief executive of Overstock.com and a writer with DeepCapture.com. Done.

title: A Surprise Gets Buzz for Oscars

Now, suddenly, this low-budget film about a washed-up country singer finds itself at the heart of the Oscar race, with some awards watchers calling its star, Jeff Bridges, a likely best actor candidate.

title: American Express Buys Online Payments Firm
description: The American Express Company said on Wednesday that it would buy Revolution Money, a provider of Internet-based payment services started by Stephen M. Case, AOLs co-founder, for $300 million.

title: Going to Battle Against Autism
description: Any parent of an autistic child will tell you that their life is forever changed by their childs condition. A recent study in The Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders quantifies exactly how different that life can be. Researchers from the University of Wisconsin at Madison followed a groups of mothers and their autistic children (adolescents and adults) for eight days. They were interviewed at the end of each day, and saliva samples were taken every four days.

title: Button at McLaren
description: For me, excuse me, but it was a no brainer. If Jenson Button was offered a drive at McLaren, he had to take it  with the millions of dollars difference to that offered at Brawn or not. Brawn could not pay up what he was asking for? McLaren could? Buttons manager was talking recently about how his decision hinged not so much on money as on some feeling of belonging or being wanted  unless I misunderstood his words. Think of it, though. A driver wins the title after half a decade with the same team, in a fluke year, a year no one could have predicted, a jackpot of a drive for him. Then, with his newfound freedom, he is offered a drive at one of the two greatest teams in the history of the sport. Does he refuse that?

title: Bush Library Design Chosen

Well, not entirely still, since this eye of a hurricane blinks from time to time, and kicks its legs and squirms ever so slightly.

description: The powerful Shubert Organization, which owns the most theaters on Broadway, has struck a new business deal with two respected theater producers that may lead to greater competition among other producers for the best Broadway houses and spur more entrepreneurial stage ventures.

title: Real Estate Shopping Is Used as Political Theater on Jerusalems Contested Ground
description: JERUSALEM  Dov Hikind, a member of the New York State Assembly, was in this disputed city on Wednesday looking for property to buy. He said he was most excited about a new apartment complex overlooking the Old City called Nof Zion.

title: Pieces From Robert Isabells Collection
description: The floral and event designers trove of mid-20th-century furniture and sculpture will be up for auction at Sothebys.

title: Leaving College to Start a Business
description: Our colleagues on the Youre the Boss blog have put up an interesting post about two young entrepreneurs who dropped out of college to start a new business that helps people get into college.

title: G.O.P. Women Attack Mammogram Guidelines
description: A group of female House Republicans used the upset over new guidelines on breast cancer screening issued by an advisory panel earlier this week to highlight what they view as the dangers of government-administered health care and the Democrats bill to revamp the system.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Nov. 18
description: Our show opens with President Obamas tour of a section of the Great Wall during his visit to China (Slide 1). It was part of a busy day of international dealings for the administration, as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived in Kabul, Afghanistan, for a stern discussion with President Hamid Karzai about corruption in his country (Slides 3 and 4). In East Jerusalem, family members stood solemn watch over their belongings on the ground where their home once stood (Slides 6 and 7). A couple of stray dogs  one in India, the other in Russia  appear (Slides 9 and 10) in contrasting scenes. And, finally, we return to China, where an American instructor went over the finer points of spreading holiday cheer and portraying Santa Claus (Slide 14).

title: Now Unloading | Yves Saint Laurents Country Estate
description: Yves Saint Laurents black-and-white French bulldog, Moujik, was at Christies in Paris this week, sniffing around the contents of his late masters country estate, which are up for auction in a four-day sale that begins today. (Proceeds of the sale are to benefit medical research on H.I.V.) Saint Laurent (who died in June 2008) and his partner in life and business, Pierre Berg, acquired Chateau Gabriel, a grand 19th-century house near Deauville on the Normandy coast, in 1983, and hired the interior designer Jacques Grange to recreate within its walls the hothouse atmosphere of a belle poque mansion.

title: Opening Arms and Ears to Cuban Music
description: The Cuban band Septeto Nacional de Ignacio Pieiro can legitimately claim to be inventors of salsa. But it last played in the United States when Franklin D. Roosevelt was president, and there was no telling when it might be able to return  until the very slightest hint of a thaw in cultural relations between the United States and Cuba quietly brought the band to New York early this month.

title: Guilty Plea in Multimillion-Dollar Wine Arson
description: A wine entrepreneur accused of setting fire in 2005 to a wine storage facility in Vallejo, Calif., has pleaded guilty to arson  in a federal courthouse in Sacramento.

title: UPDATED: Price Tag for the Senate Bill Is $848 Billion
description: Update | 12:38 a.m.  The official cost estimate is out, and the price tag is actually $848 billion with a reduction in future federal deficits of $130 billion.

title: Player Ratings: Denmark 3, U.S. 1
description: The United States saved its worst game for its last game of 2009.

title: Two Films, Two Routes From Poverty
description: AN African-American teenager, overweight and undereducated, a survivor of poverty and abuse, is rescued by the benevolent intervention of strangers. That, in a nutshell, is the plot of Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire, which has attracted fervent praise, as well as some controversy, since its debut in limited release two weeks ago.

title: Marvin Lewis on Larry Johnson
description: After a brief news conference on Tuesday to announce the signing of running back Larry Johnson, Cincinnati Coach Marvin Lewis spoke by phone with me about the controversial decision to make Johnson a Bengal after he was released by Kansas City, the subject of my column today. Lewiss comments reinforce the complexities of coaching in the N.F.L., which demands that coaches win but also requires them to be psychologists, counselors, father figures and enforcers. Here is more from the interview with Lewis.

title: K. Thomas Elghanayan
description: Q. Are you O.K. with the way the assets were divided up?

title: Building Around the Rock
description: Photos of the builder and real estate developer John Carsons Catskills home as it was constructed.

title: Ryan Hasnt Changed: He Still Believes in the Jets
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  As Coach Rex Ryan stepped behind the lectern for his Wednesday news conference, he placed a box of tissues next to the microphone.

title: Only Palins Stylist Knows for Sure
description: THE most elusive fashion stylist in America was nervous. Sitting on a reporters sofa, dressed in yoga pants and a hoodie, she tucked her slender legs underneath her, averted her eyes and explained why she had decided to out herself after avoiding the spotlight for so long.

title: Library Leader in Era of Change to Step Down
description: After 16 years at the helm of one of the worlds largest library systems, Paul LeClerc announced on Wednesday that he would step down as president of the New York Public Library in the summer of 2011 to give the institution plenty of time to search for a replacement.

title: Revealed: The Senate Bill
description: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, put forward his version of sweeping health care legislation on Wednesday, promising that it would reduce the federal budget deficit while covering most of the uninsured and adding new benefits to Medicare.

title: Apteras High-Flying Plans Are Temporarily Grounded
description: The money is nearly gone, and the same can be said of the co-founders, at the fledgling electric-vehicle manufacturer Aptera.

title: Money, Gender and Job Satisfaction
description: Sure, the typical woman earns less than the typical man, even when controlling for factors like career choice, education and experience.

title: In Ukraine, 04 Euphoria Has Turned to Despair
description: LVIV, Ukraine  It is not immediately clear why Vasily V. Humenyuk should be a candidate for president of Ukraine. A former customs official from the western city of Ivano-Frankivsk, he subscribes to no particular ideology, has the flimsiest of platforms and does not plan to tour the country before the vote, reasoning that these trips cost a great deal and the people are sick of them.

title: Senate Says Health Plan Will Cover Another 31 Million
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic leaders in the Senate on Wednesday unveiled their proposal for overhauling the health care system, outlining legislation that they said would cover most of the uninsured while reducing the federal budget deficit.

title: Water Feud in the White Mountains
description: ACHIN, Afghanistan  I had just bedded down for the night in this remote village near the Pakistani frontier when one of the American noncommissioned officers Id been traveling with walked into my hut and told me to put my flak jacket on.

title: Design for New Berkeley Art Museum Abandoned
description: The University of California, Berkeley, has decided to scrap its ambitious designs for a new Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, saying that it has been unable to raise enough money to pay for them, The San Francisco Chronicle reported.

title: BlogTalk: Parsing Palin
description: Even her detractors concede that Sarah Palin will sell a lot of books. But what the book and her publicity tour will do for Ms. Palins political future, and the future of the Republican Party or the future of the conservative movement, are subjects that bloggers of all political persuasions keep on debating even as party leaders also try to capitalize on all the publicity.

title: City Council Influences Landmarks Decision
description: Last week the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted 6 to 3 to give landmark protection to the 100-year-old B. F. Goodrich tire company building on Broadway just north of 57th Street, but not to a connected building around the corner designed by the same architect at the same time. Some commission members on both sides of that unusual divided vote cried foul, complaining that politics played an inappropriate role.

title: Exulting in the Orneriness of a Composers Composer
description: The ingenious, curmudgeonly American composer Ralph Shapey, who died at 81 in 2002, wrote flinty works of uncompromising complexity. He expected listeners to bring their brains as well as their humanity to the concert hall, as he often said.

title: Prizewinners Arrive, Displaying Their Energy
description: The Afiara String Quartet, a Canadian ensemble, won both the Concert Artist Guild International Competition and the Munich ARD International Competition in 2008 and became the graduate resident quartet at the Juilliard School this season. It clearly has something going for it. But at its concert at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening, it was not entirely clear what that something was.

title: France Dashes Irelands World Cup Dream
description: Update | 6:00 p.m. France is through to the World Cup in South Africa after William Gallass controversial goal in extra time helped Les Bleus dash the hopes of a stalwart Ireland side.

title: Dell Is Ready to Jump Into the Smartphone Market
description: Confirming longstanding rumors, the PC maker Dell has officially announced its entry into the smartphone market. The company announced last week that it would begin selling its first handset  the Mini 3  in China through China Mobile by late November. It will go on sale in Brazil through the wireless carrier Claro (part of the Amrica Mvil network) by years end.

title: Casio Gets Tough With a Rugged Camera
description: Casio believes even tough guys can look really good, and it has built a rugged camera to prove it. The companys first ruggedized point-and-shoot camera, the Casio Exilim G EX-G1, is a lean model thats heavy on tough features.

title: Week 11 in Fantasy Football Matchups
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 11. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below. Also, scroll down for reading tips from the Fantasy Football Librarian.

title: Where Punchlines Pay the Rent
description: CAROLITA JOHNSON, 44, an illustrator, model and New Yorker cartoonist, has lived in some appalling places in her lifetime.

title: In Marfa, Texas, Minimalist Art and Maximum Flavor
description: The big empty is how my seatmate describes the landscape as our plane makes its descent to El Paso. To me it is the opposite: this is a place Ive visited and lived in for the last 13 years, and it is a land filled with memories, adventure and possibility.

title: Building an Online Bulwark to Fend Off Identity Fraud
description: A clotheshorse racked up thousands of dollars in mystery charges on a friends credit card. Phantoms emptied your uncles bank account. Someone took out a car loan in your colleagues name and stuck her with the bill.

title: 2007 Memo Raised Concerns About Hasan
description: As my colleague Elisabeth Bumiller reported from Washington on Tuesday, it seems likely that the number of suicides by American soldiers will increase again this year. At the Pentagon, Gen. Peter Chiarelli, the Army vice chief of staff, said that as of Nov. 16, the Army had reported 140 suicides of active duty soldiers this year, the same number as in all of 2008. If that forecast proves accurate, this will be the fifth year in a row that suicides will have increased in the Army.

title: Sharing History and a Stage
description: True artists tend to follow their own internal systems. But there is something to be said about being of the same generation, which often prompts a certain kinship of values and ideas.

title: A Convergence, Somewhat Harmonic
description: ART and design collided, albeit gently, at the Park Avenue Armory on Nov. 12. Vladimir Kagan tables, Halston evening gowns, Chanel bracelets from the 1980s and some paintings by artists whose names you couldnt quite catch all clamored for attention that evening at the Modernism + Art20 shows opening party.

title: Answers About Divorce and Money
description: This week, Lili A. Vasileff is answering selected questions from Bucks readers about divorce and money. Ms. Vasileff is a certified divorce financial analyst and president of the Association of Divorce Financial Planners, and she and works out of an office in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Using Tapes and a Timeline to Trace the Mumbai Massacre
description: The first 360-degree view of terrorism  thats the promise the writer Fareed Zakaria makes at the beginning of Terror in Mumbai, a new HBO documentary about the attacks in that Indian city last November that left more than 170 people dead. In addition to the usual eyewitness interviews and surveillance videos, the film, which Mr. Zakaria narrates, makes use of hours of intercepted telephone conversations between the 10 gunmen and their controllers in Pakistan. This time you are with the terrorists, Mr. Zakaria intones.

title: Adding a Fee to the Shazam App Invites a Look at Competing Tools
description: Been to the iTunes App Store lately?

title: Post-Punk Returnees, Definitely Not Unplugged
description: Can we put to rest this Talmudic thing about band reunions? In the right circumstances, with the right people, they can be very, very good. Does it matter whether the band makes more records, whether it is still a going concern, whether it is part of contemporary culture? Is it desecrating a legacy, blah blah blah? Stop. A band walks on stage, does its thing well or badly or somewhere in the middle, and goes home. Forget the aura: thats your problem. Legit is as legit does.

title: A Table That Stands on Its Own 2 Legs
description: Marsia Holzers new side table was made in what she calls the George Nakashima style  without a handle on the drawer. The drawer front extends three-quarters of an inch beyond the table on either side, so it doesnt need one.

title: Bulbs for Any and All Occasions
description: Any gardener who couldnt put down Anna Pavords The Tulip, published by Bloomsbury in 1999, will probably devour Bulb (Mitchell Beazley; $39.99), which came out this month, just in time for planting some rare beauty before the ground freezes (or ordering summer-flowering bulbs for spring). The book includes 600 of her favorite bulbs, enough for a lifetime, writes Ms. Pavord, who gardens in Dorset, England. The gorgeous photographs are by Andrew Lawson.

title: Duck! Its the Holidays.
description: THE weather grows cold, the holidays are bearing down upon us and soon we will find ourselves in that seething caldron of unmannerly behavior: the family holiday gathering.

title: Talking the Talk in the Cash Room
description: On the 21st day (of October) President Obama said, Let there be a conference. And so there was. This morning, small-business owners, their representatives, their lenders, and their lenders representatives  some 70 people in all  gathered in the gilded and marble-clad Cash Room of the United States Treasury. The venue was appropriate, since, after all, the whole point of the exercise was to figure out how to get more capital in the hands of small business.

title: Marcel Wanders on Marcel Wanders
description: Marcel Wanders: Daydreams, a multimedia exhibition of works by the Dutch design star, opens at the Philadelphia Museum of Art on Sunday. The show, which includes personal objects, prototypes and various products Mr. Wanders created over the last 20 years (including the Soapstars bathtub, right), was curated and designed by none other than Mr. Wanders, who will receive an award from the exhibitions sponsors at an event on Saturday night.

title: For Dogs With Good Taste
description: The Inu House bowl ($95), left, hand-thrown ceramic dinnerware for dogs, is from a line of stylish pet accessories made by Mungo & Maud, a London company. Other items for modern cats and dogs offered by the company include beds (Igloo, in quilted cotton, is $250) and leashes (the leather Argyle is $150). Available at Bergdorf Goodman, 754 Fifth Avenue (58th Street), (800) 558-1855, or from mungoandmaud.com.

title: Schumer Gives Support to Pool Party Concerts
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, has thrown his support behind an effort to keep the Pool Parties summer concert series at its latest home on the Brooklyn waterfront. Jelly, the group that began putting on the free shows at McCarren Park Pool in Williamsburg in 2006 and moved to the East River State Park in Williamsburg this year, wants to stay at the park but announced on Wednesday that state parks officials said it might not be able to return next year. Senator Schumer, who attended two Pool Party concerts this year, said he would work with state authorities to allow the concerts to stay. When I heard that the concerts might be canceled, I couldnt understand why, given that this is exactly what our parks are supposed to be for, and I am going to do everything I can to see that they continue, he said. Not everything went perfectly smoothly at the Pool Parties this year. For a show in August featuring Girl Talk, an extension to the stage collapsed.

title: Even With Locklear, Melrose Lacks Bloom
description: The return of Heather Locklear, below, to Melrose Place did little to improve that CW dramas ratings. A meager 1.5 million viewers tuned in to the show on Tuesday, according to Nielsens estimates, though that was its largest audience in six weeks. On CBS 20.2 million viewers watched NCIS and the network easily won the night. ABC was runner-up with its science-fiction drama V (9.3 million), The Forgotten (7.7 million) and an hourlong Dancing With the Stars episode (15.9 million). NBCs lineup was led by a 90-minute edition of The Biggest Loser (9.5 million), helping The Jay Leno Show (6.1 million), which earned its largest audience in three weeks. Fox was fourth.

title: From Sharp Edges to Soft Pillows
description: Broadway Panhandler will have a sale on cutlery and cookware from Nov. 18 to 22, and will offer knife sharpening to benefit City Harvest on Nov. 21 and 22 (three knives for $12); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434.

title: Sarah Palin Generates High Ratings for Oprah
description: Giving support to people who have suggested that she become a television talk-show host, Sarah Palin delivered the highest audience in two years to The Oprah Winfrey Show on Monday. The hourlong interview with Ms. Palin  her first to promote her memoir, Going Rogue  was seen by 8.7 percent of households, according to Nielsen. Reflecting the curiosity about Ms. Palin, the former Alaska governor and Republican vice-presidential candidate, CBS Television Distribution said it was Ms. Winfreys highest-rated episode since the Osmond family came on her show in November 2007.

title: Nicolas Cage Sued by Former Money Manager
description: For the Bad Lieutenant star Nicolas Cage, right, the week just got a little worse. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Cage, whose spending habits have been widely discussed since he filed suit against his former business manager, was being countersued by that manager. In October Mr. Cage sued Samuel J. Levin for fraud, accusing Mr. Levin of leading him down a path toward financial ruin. In the countersuit filed on Nov. 12, The A.P. reported, Mr. Levin said he had told Mr. Cage that he would need to earn $30 million a year to maintain his lifestyle, and that he warned the actor not to buy castles in England and Bavaria. (Mr. Cage did not heed the advice.) Mr. Levin also said that he devised a fund-raising plan that included the sale of classic cars and a $1.6 million comic book collection. A lawyer for Mr. Cage said Mr. Levin had breached Mr. Cages privacy by releasing details about his asset sales.

title: Design Is Revealed for Bush Center
description: The design for the George W. Bush Presidential Center at Southern Methodist University, created by Robert A. M. Stern Architects, was officially unveiled in a ceremony Wednesday, The Dallas Morning News reported. In an interview Laura Bush told The Morning News that a year was spent discussing and planning the design for a 225,000-square-foot building that will be home to Mr. Bushs presidential papers, as well as a museum and a policy institute. We did not want this to be monumental like some other libraries are, Mrs. Bush said. Were very aware that the presidents are men. They are people. We wanted it to be human in scale. Mr. Stern said the building, which is scheduled to have its groundbreaking next year, was not designed to reflect on Mr. Bush personally. Its not a portrait or a defense of his policies, Mr. Stern told The Morning News. It is about the presidency, the dignity of the office.

title: In New World of Military Spending, Small Is Beautiful
description: AT one time, it may have been true that an army marches on its stomach. But with food supplies generally not a problem for modern armies, the proverb should probably be updated to something like this: an army marches on its laptops and the information flowing through them.

title: Bon Jovi Album Is No. 1
description: Bon Jovi has scored its second No. 1 album in a row  and the fourth of its career  with The Circle (Island), which sold 163,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Carrie Underwoods Play On (19/Arista Nashville), last weeks top seller, fell to No. 3 with 128,000 sales, a 60 percent drop, and Andrea Bocellis My Christmas (Sugar/Decca) climbed one spot to No. 2 with 136,000. The soundtrack to Michael Jacksons This Is It (Epic) fell two spots to No. 4 with 117,000 sales, and Taylor Swifts Fearless (Big Machine) was No. 5 with 91,000 sales. Besides The Circle, the only other new album on the Top 10 this week was Memento Mori (A&M/Octone) by the young Texas metal band Flyleaf, which bowed at No. 8 with 56,000.

title: At Library, a New View of Velvet Underground
description: Have a burning question youve wanted to pose to the Velvet Underground since that down-and-out New York art-rock band broke up in the 1970s? Want to know whos coughing on the recording of Who Loves the Sun or when well see an official CD release for Squeeze? You may finally have a chance to get the answers. On Dec. 8 three members of the Velvet Underground will appear at the New York Public Library to discuss the groups music and history as part of the librarys Live From the NYPL series, Billboard reported. The musicians Maureen Tucker, Doug Yule and, of course, Lou Reed, above, are scheduled to appear. The Velvet Underground singer-guitarist Sterling Morrison died in 1995, and the bands co-founder John Cale left in 1968, though he reunited with Mr. Reed for a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony in 1996.

title: Precious to Receive Kramer Award
description: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire, starring Gabourey Sidibe, above, took a step in the march toward Oscar recognition, as the Producers Guild of America has chosen to honor it with the groups Stanley Kramer Award. Established in 2002, the Kramer award is given to a movie, program, studio, executive or entity that tackles provocative social issues in a constructive way. Precious, about a young womans struggles to succeed despite her troubled and impoverished family, fills the bill, and will join past recipients like Milk and Good Night, and Good Luck, both of which were nominated for best picture Oscars.

title: The 18 Million Revisited
description: First, a correction. The concluding point in my earlier post is wrong: The House health care bill would not, in fact, effectively tax all 18 million of the remaining uninsured to pay for coverage for the other 36 million, because some percentage of that 18 million  in the draft of the Senate bill, its anyone who couldnt find a health care plan costing less than 8 percent of income; in the House bill its still unspecified  would be eligible for a hardship waiver exempting them from paying the fine if they cant afford coverage. And this exemption makes the House bill a better deal for the uninsured than I suggested.

title: From a District 24 Qualifier, an Example of Pair Tactics
description: Bridge is played in two basic formats. There are the times when you worry only about making or breaking a contract; the overtricks are small fry. This is the case in rubber bridge, Chicago or team events. (Also, you bid game with the flimsiest of excuses. The higher your score on a deal, the better.)

title: At Auction, the Secret Cache of an Icon
description: JAMES ZEMAITIS, the director of Sothebys 20th-century design department in New York, had been intrigued for years by the floral designer Robert Isabell and his adventurous auction purchases. But when he finally visited the West Village town house that belonged to Mr. Isabell in July, a few days after the designers death at 57 from natural causes, he said, he was simply blown away.

title: A Camera Thats Svelte but Ready for Roughhousing
description: Casios first rugged point-and-shoot camera, the Casio Exilim G EX-G1, is a lean model thats strong on tough features.

title: Dell Is Ready to Jump Into the Smartphone Market
description: Confirming longstanding rumors, the PC maker Dell has officially announced its entry into the smartphone market. The company announced last week that it would begin selling its first handset  the Mini 3  in China through China Mobile by late November. It will go on sale in Brazil through the wireless carrier Claro (part of the Amrica Mvil network) by years end.

title: App of the Week: RoadMate Is Easy to Use, but Costly
description: Magellans new RoadMate iPhone app ($100, but on sale for $80) is one of the easiest navigation apps available, and it has the sort of graphics that you usually see on a dash-top GPS unit. Problem is, it costs as much as one.

title: Skype via Videophone Rather Than PC
description: Asus is pitching its new videophone, the Asus Videophone Touch AiGuru SV1T, as a way to make free audio and video calls over Skype, no PC required. But theres a gotcha: While a PC isnt necessary, a broadband Internet connection and preferably a wireless network are.

title: Former Nickelodeon Chief Has iPhone Plans
description: From Media Decoder:

title: Conserving Power On a Netbook
description: Conserving Power

title: No System, but Music Housewide
description: Multiroom sound system? Theres an app for that.

title: Fifteen Documentaries Eligible for Oscar Nod
description: Fifteen feature-length documentaries, the so-called short list, have qualified as possible Oscar nominees from a field of 89 films that were eligible for consideration. The list, announced Wednesday by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, includes:

title: European Ombudsman Criticizes Inquiry Into Intel
description: The European Unions ombudsman on Wednesday criticized the antitrust inquiry that led to a 1.06 billion euro ($1.45 billion) fine against Intel, saying investigators failed to note statements that might have been relevant to the chip makers case.

title: The Queasy Side of Theodore Roosevelts Diplomatic Voyage
description: James Bradleys incendiary new book about Theodore Roosevelt is not really packed with secrets. Much of the material it discusses has long been hidden in plain sight. But Roosevelt biographers often subscribe to certain orthodoxies, and one of them is this: When Roosevelt made noxiously racist and ethnocentric remarks about Anglo-Saxon greatness, so what? He was just voicing the tenets of his time.

title: Wells Fargo to Repurchase $1.4 Billion of Securities
description: Wells Fargo & Company said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy back $1.4 billion in auction-rate securities it sold to investors before the market for those securities dried up last year.

title: 2007 Memo Raised Concerns About Hasan
description: Robert Mackey has an interesting post on our sister blog, The Lede, about reports that Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist who has been charged over the deaths of 13 people at Fort Hood, had received an evaluation that might have prevented him from finding work in his field outside the military.

title: A Taxing Time for Treasury Nominee
description: Its one thing to carefully vet people being nominated to a top post at the Treasury, especially to make sure theyve properly paid their taxes.

title: Is the Spirit of Competition in the Soul of Yoga?
description: THE competitors stood nervously on stage, awaiting the judges decisions. As each name was called the crowd cheered, and the winner stepped forward to claim a prize, bowing his or her head to accept a medal.

title: Seeking Wind Energy, Some Consider the Sea
description: LAST June in a fjord in southwestern Norway, a 213-foot-tall wind turbine did something large wind turbines normally dont do: it headed out to sea.

title: A Saudi Gamble to See if Seeds of Change Will Grow
description: THUWAL, Saudi Arabia  The $12.5 billion question is this: Can Ben Frevert change Saudi Arabia?

title: The Imperial Cruise
description: Chapter 1: One Hundred Years Later

title: Field of Documentaries for Oscar Consideration Narrows to 15
description: Fifteen feature-length documentaries, the so-called short list, have qualified as possible Oscar nominees, from a field of 89 films that were eligible for consideration. The short list, announced Wednesday by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, is chosen by a screening committee from the documentary branch of the academy. The full branch will now vote for the five Oscar nominees from that list. The list includes:

title: Newly Released Books
description: The tug of family life is the thread running through many of this months newly published books. Novelists (and a short-story writer) have given us parents who go too far for their children, those who dont go far enough and children whose relationships to each other are, well, complicated. Its enough to make you believe that Philip Larkin was right.

title: Companies Call Government Incentives the Key to Green
description: IN less than three weeks, world leaders will gather in Copenhagen to begin hammering out an agreement to cut greenhouse gas emissions and combat global warming.

title: Some Organizers Protest Their Unions Tactics
description: After six years working in the laundry of a Miami hotel, Julia Rivera was thrilled when her union tapped her to become a full-time union organizer.

title: Making Renewables Reliable
description: FOLSOM, Calif.

title: Senate Bill Would Require E. Coli Testing
description: Citing public concern that meat companies and federal regulators are not doing enough to make ground beef safe, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, has introduced legislation that would require companies to test for a deadly E. coli strain.

title: A Soccer Match in Sudan Includes Soldiers and Guns
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  The streets emptied at sunset. Twitchy-faced soldiers hit the pavement, literally thousands of them, wearing all stripes of camouflage, blues, greens, grays and browns. They twirled clubs and AK-47s and plastic pipes and ragged old beating sticks. Their giant trucks with four-foot-high wheels blocked the roads. This did not feel like a major sporting event. It felt more like a presidential coup.

title: Storm Over the Chamber
description: WASHINGTON

title: Surfs Up, Wastes Down
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.

title: A Surplus of Energy That Might Even Last
description: AFTER years of widespread concern over how to refine enough gasoline, how to deliver enough megawatts of electricity and how to keep from drowning in carbon dioxide, the United States suddenly has fuel and energy in surplus, and the country is looking greener.

title: Europe Haggles Over Filling Two Top Posts
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union has spent eight years trying to modernize its rules and become a bigger global player. But now, facing a vote on Thursday to finally pick a slate of new and more powerful leaders, it is falling back on old-fashioned backroom deal-making that critics say may produce two lackluster choices.

title: Post-Mortems Reveal Obvious Risk at Banks
description: The coroners report left no doubt as to the cause of death: toxic loans.

title: Slippery Definitions of Green-Collar Jobs
description: In the new, greener economy, some old jobs have simply been rebranded. A home builder who installs solar panels is suddenly green. So is the engineer who worked for the phone company and now installs parts of a smart grid.

title: The Rooftop Garden Climbs Down a Wall
description: ROCHESTER

title: Mideast Peace Talks Hang in Balance Over Abbas
description: JERUSALEM  Two weeks after the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, vowed not to run for re-election and hinted that he might resign, the Middle East peace process has sunk into a deep crisis amid urgent efforts to revive it.

title: Russia: Bloomberg Donates $125 Million to Promote Global Traffic Safety
description: On the eve of a high-level international meeting on road safety in Moscow, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York announced a donation of $125 million to organizations that promote road safety in a group of low- and middle-income countries that represent half of all yearly traffic deaths. The donation, to be paid out over five years, is part of a push to frame traffic deaths as a global public health risk. The countries include Russia, India, Vietnam, China, Brazil and Egypt.

title: California Imposes Rule for Efficiency on Some TVs
description: Recognizing that giant new flat-panel televisions have become major power guzzlers, California on Wednesday became the first state to impose energy efficiency standards on them.

title: Japanese Bank Plans $11.2 Billion Share Sale
description: Japans largest bank, the Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, said Wednesday that it would press ahead with plans to raise up to $11.2 billion to bolster its financial cushion, despite results that showed a sharp jump in profit in the July-September quarter.

title: Russia: Lawyers Friends Seek Inquiry
description: Colleagues of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a lawyer for the international investment fund Hermitage Capital Management who died this week in a Moscow prison hospital, have called on the authorities to open a criminal investigation. Dmitri Kharitonov, Mr. Magnitskys lawyer, told the Ria Novosti news agency Wednesday that his clients death in a pretrial detention center appeared to result from negligence by prison authorities who, he said, failed to provide needed medical attention. Mr. Magnitsky died of toxic shock and heart failure on Monday.

title: All Dressed Up for a Big Book Party
description: Putting aside worries about slipping sales, e-books and other would-be attacks on the literary establishment, the publishing industry put on its party face (and gowns) Wednesday night at Cipriani Wall Street, where the National Book Awards were being presented.

title: To Build a Smart Grid, Start With Smart Meters
description: FOR nearly 30 years, Itron has dominated the American market in what had been a profitable but unglamorous field, automating power, gas and water meters. But with $8 billion in government and private money devoted to modernizing the power grid, meter automation is suddenly a growth industry. Without millions of new smart meters, no smart grid is possible.

title: New York Regional Yoga Championship
description: Yoga as a competitive sport is on the rise, and an effort is under way to get yoga into the Olympics. Yoga enthusiasts recently competed at the New York Regional Yoga Championship.

title: Prosthetics Gave Runner Unfair Edge, Report Says
description: Oscar Pistorius, a double-amputee sprinter from South Africa, was cleared to race against able-bodied athletes in the Beijing Olympics a year and a half ago. Now, however, a new study argues that his prosthetic legs may give him an unfair advantage after all.

title: It Was Some Day in Court for Ampersands
description: Two commercial powerhouses regarded in New York as being the best at what they do came to share more than similar-sounding names on Wednesday. Both were slapped with allegations of wrongdoing.

title: Clients Fuzzy Over What Bruno Did for Them
description: ALBANY  In the summer of 2005, top officials at a telecommunications company in Illinois exchanged a stream of befuddled and increasingly urgent e-mail messages.

title: At This Market, Yankees Feeling No Rush to Buy
description: The baseball free-agent market opens Thursday night at midnight, but players will not have real estate agents on call for Friday morning. The market is expected to move slowly, and one reason is a lack of aggressiveness from the Yankees.

title: Seeking Jolt, Knicks Show an Interest in Iverson
description: INDIANAPOLIS  If Allen Iverson is on his way to New York, he will find a slightly happier locker room awaiting him.

title: Insurers Unlikely to Alter Policies in the Debate Over Mammograms
description: For years, breast cancer screening clinics have struggled.

title: Screening Policy Wont Change, U.S. Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration distanced itself Wednesday from new standards on breast cancer screening that were recommended this week by a federally appointed task force, saying government insurance programs would continue to cover routine mammograms for women starting at age 40.

title: Reid Proposes a 5% Tax on Cosmetic Surgery
description: Senator Harry Reids health care bill included an array of new provisions that are being scrutinized Wednesday night, but one particular tax proposal in particular already has attracted a buzz  a 5 percent levy on elective cosmetic procedures that was quickly dubbed the botax.

title: World Cup Fever for Algeria, in Paris
description: PARIS  Paris caught World Cup fever Wednesday night.

title: Glenn Remick, Darts Promoter, Dies at 58
description: Glenn Remick, a beer-loving former construction worker who played a leading role in transforming the barroom game of darts into a national sport, with league members competing in large venues (though they could always still toss back a brewski), died on Nov. 2 in St. Louis. He was 58 and lived in Foristell, Mo.

title: Scioscia and Tracy Are Managers of the Year
description: The Manager of the Year awards were announced Wednesday and, as usual, there were no surprises. The winners were Jim Tracy of the Colorado Rockies and Mike Scioscia of the Los Angeles Angels.

title: Obama Demands Results From Afghan Reforms
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama sent his top diplomat to Afghanistan on Wednesday to press President Hamid Karzai to deliver measurable results on governance and corruption as the White House prepared specific new demands to accompany an American troop buildup.

title: Rising Prices of Drugs Lead to Call for Inquiry
description: Democrats in Congress asked for two separate investigations of drug industry pricing Wednesday as they continue working on legislation to overhaul the nations health care system.

title: Hand of Henry Sends France to South Africa
description: ST.-DENIS, France  Celebrations rang out around France on Wednesday as the French national team and the team from Algeria, which used to exist under French rule, qualified for next years World Cup in dramatic fashion.

title: Mets Seeking Top Hitter, With Other Holes to Fill
description: The Mets need a new catcher, a starting left fielder, bullpen help and another quality starter and may try to upgrade at first and second base. Their general manager, Omar Minaya, has a busy off-season ahead, but he seems to have identified his priority: With a glut of starters and fewer sluggers available, the Mets appear more likely to make a free-agent splash on offense.

title: Savoring the Mayoral Victory With a Dinner by the Seine
description: PARIS  Aprs la victoire, les vacances.

title: Its All a Blur to Them
description: IVE heard that in Australia, men are wearing tights, Chuong Pham said. Tights for men, he acknowledged, may be extreme. But Mr. Pham, 28, an engineer in Manhattan, thought nothing of combining stalk-slim jeans with a sweatshirt pinched from his mom and sexily sheared  la Flashdance. Raking his fingers through a sheaf of hair that tumbled in waves past his collarbone, Mr. Pham said: There is a whole transition of men getting into womens wear. It used to be that the people who did it were just the edgier ones. Now its much more common.

title: A Bullet Takes a Toll in the Bronx
description: There were five young men in all, waiting on a street corner in the Bronx on Monday  two on bicycles, two with guns, and all with a specific target in mind: a 19-year-old rival who was inside a bodega.

title: Mixed Reviews on Senate Bill From AARP
description: AARP, the association representing millions of retired Americans, offered a qualified endorsement on Wednesday night of the new health care bill produced by Senate Democratic leaders.

title: Holder Defends Decision to Use U.S. Court for 9/11 Trial
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Wednesday defended his decision to prosecute five men accused as co-conspirators in the Sept. 11 attacks in federal court in Manhattan, declaring that while he believes we are at war, that the venue was the best place to pursue the case against them.

title: Bomb Suspect Cant Keep His Military Lawyers
description: A federal judge in Manhattan on Wednesday denied a request by a former Guantnamo detainee to keep two military lawyers who had been representing him now that his case has been transferred to federal court.

title: Lottery Numbers
Assembly Backs Stricter Oversight for State Authorities
description: ALBANY  The states vast, often-impenetrable public authorities will get stricter oversight than ever under a measure that the State Assembly approved on Wednesday.

title: Gore Vidal: Awardee, Storyteller, Godfather
description: Gore Vidal, the novelist, social critic, and bon vivant, received the award for distinguished contribution to American letters at the National Book Awards on Wednesday night.

title: New York Burger Stand on Bostons Seafood Turf?
description: BOSTON  First the reviled Yankees won the World Series; now Shake Shack, the New York burger stand, might stake a claim in one of Bostons most sacred spaces.

title: The Lineup
description: Photos from the New York Regional Yoga Championship, where yogis demonstrate seven postures.

title: On College Football Game Days, Efforts to Deter Binge Drinking
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Shortly before the kickoff of the Minnesota-Illinois college football game at the new TCF Bank Stadium this month, two Minnesota students  one male, one female  slipped into an unmarked entrance about five minutes apart. They dressed appropriately for the unseasonably warm and sunny day, in short-sleeve maroon-and-gold Gophers attire. And they greeted Amy Barsness, a university official, like an old friend.

title: Key Differences in the Health Care Plans
description: The health care proposals from the House and the Senate are broadly similar but differ on some major issues. Here is a look:

title: El Paso Neighbor
description: Sometimes the best trick is no trick at all  when you think there is one. That could be said of todays puzzle, a joint production from five-time crossword tournament champ Tyler Hinman and Jeremy Horwitz, who teaches math and computer science at Santa Clara University.

title: Luxury Stores Trim Inventory and Discounts
description: All around Saks Fifth Avenue, merchandise is sold out. The $2,520 Marni shearling vest? Gone. The $5,295 Brioni leather bomber jacket? Only one left. The $1,995 over-the-knee Christian Louboutin boots?

title: Bloggingheads: Terrorist Show Trials?
description: Dayo Olopade, left, of The Root and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate whether accused terrorists can ever receive a fair trial.

title: What Jayne Anne Phillips Did on Her Summer Vacations
description: Jayne Anne Phillips, a finalist for the National Book Award for fiction, stood in a corner of the pre-ceremony cocktail party, a long black emu-feather boa draped around her neck. No emu died to make it, she said. Its emu feathers.

title: Fine and Inquiry Possible for Blackwater Successor
description: WASHINGTON  The international security company formerly called Blackwater Worldwide is facing large government fines for unlicensed arms shipments to Iraq, as a key Congressional committee is asking for a separate investigation into whether the company bribed Iraqi officials.

title: A Touch of Luxury: Retro Bulb Atomizers
description: WITH overall fragrance sales down a good 10 percent, Noir, a midpriced perfume, has been a consistent top seller for Victorias Secret Beauty.

title: For Men: Rub in, Say Ahh
description: MEN care about their skin, and theyre spending money on it. Purchases of premium priced ($70 and above) mens skin-care face products increased by 8 percent in the first half of 2009 compared with the same period last year, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm. Luxury skin-care companies are taking note.

title: First Aid for Distressed Nails
description: WE all know about products for aging skin, but what about aging nails?

title: When a Laser Beats a Scalpel
description: WHEN it comes to treating aging skin around the eyes, laser resurfacing can often trump surgery, according to Dr. Michael McGuire, a Los Angeles plastic surgeon and president of the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. If the skin is mildly wrinkled and/or pigmented, the laser can be a good option, he said, adding that he frequently gives laser treatments to patients in their 40s to defer face-lifts.

title: Writing About Pakistan,  but No Beards, No Bombs
description: As announcers urged the crowd at the National Book Awards party to take their dinner seats, Daniyal Mueenuddin, the Pakistani-American author of In Other Rooms, Other Wonders, hung back to chat briefly about his work and the wonder of being nominated for a prestigious literary award.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about revised guidelines on breast cancer screening misstated a statistic from the United States Preventive Services Task Force, which released the recommendations. The task force concluded that one cancer death was prevented for every 1,339 women aged 50 to 59 who were screened for 10 years  not 50 to 74.

title: Ruling on Katrina Flooding Favors Homeowners
description: NEW ORLEANS  A federal judge found Wednesday evening that poor maintenance of a major navigation channel by the Army Corps of Engineers led to some of the worst flooding after Hurricane Katrina. The ruling was a major victory for homeowners who suffered damage in the aftermath of the storm.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Friday with an article about the tracing of an E. coli outbreak to AFA Foods, a large producer of ground beef, described the companys testing procedures incorrectly. It tests its finished ground beef, but stopped testing the beef trimmings that are mixed into the beef; it has not halted testing of ground beef.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Saturday with an article about the decriminalization of possession of small amounts of marijuana in Breckenridge, Colo., labeled a neighboring state incorrectly. The state directly south of Colorado is New Mexico, not Texas.

title: The Senates Health Care Calculations
description: CRITICS of the health care reform plan often refer to it derisively as ObamaCare. On the policy merits, this is highly questionable: the White House has taken a hands-off approach toward the legislation that recently passed in the House and the version that is being worked out in the Senate. But when it comes to politics, ObamaCare could hardly be more apt: lawmakers support for or opposition to reform generally has less to do with the views of their constituents and more to do with the issue of presidential popularity.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the new White House counsel, Robert F. Bauer, misstated the relationship between President Richard M. Nixon and his third counsel, Leonard Garment. Mr. Garment had known Nixon for nearly a decade and had been an aide and adviser to him before taking the White House job; it was not the case that he and Nixon were not close.

title: Deja Vu All Over Again
description: My Thursday column looks back at the arguments against Medicare and, before that, Social Security  and notes that they were the same as the arguments today against universal health care.

title: Born in U.S., a Radical Cleric Inspires Terror
description: WASHINGTON  In nearly a dozen recent terrorism cases in the United States, Britain and Canada, investigators discovered the suspects had something in common: a devotion to the message of Anwar al-Awlaki, an eloquent Muslim cleric who has turned the Web into a tool for extremist indoctrination.

title: Mr. Obamas Task
description: There is no doubt that the prospects for success in Afghanistan are so bleak right now because former President George W. Bush failed for seven long years to invest the necessary troops, resources or attention to the war. But it is now President Obamas war, and the American people are waiting for him to explain his goals and his strategy.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about support from Illinois politicians for a plan to send terrorism suspects from Guantnamo Bay to a prison in Illinois reversed the identifications of the two politicians shown. Senator Richard J. Durbin was at the left and Gov. Patrick J. Quinn at the right.

title: Individualism, Identity and Bicycles in Northern California
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: Altering How We Use and Pay Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children of the Recession, the Economy Hits Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Breast Screening: Making Sense of the New Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Breast Brouhaha
description: Everyone has been trying to come up with a good nickname for the 10 years were concluding next month. Terror Era really sounds like too much of a downer. How about the Decade of Medical Backtracking?

title: The Wrong Side of History
description: Critics storm that health care reform is a cruel hoax and a delusion. Ads in 100 newspapers thunder that reform would mean the beginning of socialized medicine.

title: Have Work, Will Travel
description: Whistler, Canada

title: Corrections
description: The Religion Journal on Saturday, about a church for young people in Queens, misstated the chapter of a biblical passage that was the subject of the first sermon by Din Tolbert, now the churchs youth pastor. The passage, which says that nothing will separate Christians from the love of God, is Romans 8, verses 35-39  not Romans 35. (Romans has only 16 chapters.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about virtual wallets and other ways to avoid carrying money and credit cards, misstated the billing procedure used by Boku, a start-up company that lets people purchase goods online using their 10-digit cellphone numbers. Boku applies charges to its customers cellphone bills, not to their credit cards.

title: Democrats Ask Republicans Wheres Your Bill?
description: The 2,074-page Senate health care bill, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, is now up on the Web available for public scrutiny.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about a decline in Champagne sales misstated the relationship between two of the people shown shopping for wine. Brenda Terris, at the left, is single; Ed Weltman is not her husband. (They were shown with Tamara Wick.)

title: Academic Researchers Conflicts of Interest Go Unreported
description: Few universities make required reports to the government about the financial conflicts of their researchers, and even when such conflicts are reported, university administrators rarely require those researchers to eliminate or reduce these conflicts, government investigators found.

title: Corrections
description: The Basics column on Nov. 10, about recent discoveries from the study of pig cognition, misstated the species of a wild boar. It is Sus scrofa, not Sus scrofus.

title: High Tech Tries to Lift Veil on 18  Tantalizing Minutes in Watergate
description: Stymied in its digital effort to fill in the mysterious 18 -minute gap in the Watergate tapes, the government will apply high technology to the paper trail to try to answer the scandals most intriguing question: What did President Richard M. Nixon know, and when did he know it?

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about foundations that spend down their endowments and then close misstated the percentage of the New York City Anti-Violence Projects budget that comes from the Paul Rapoport Foundation. It is 1 percent, not more than one-tenth. The article also paraphrased incorrectly from comments by Sharon Stapel, the executive director of the Anti-Violence Project, about the projects possible efforts to attract new donors. She said it might seek to broaden its base of donors, not to serve a broader audience.

title: Col. Lewis Millett, Who Led Bayonet Hill Charge, Dies at 88
description: Col. Lewis L. Millett, an Army veteran of three wars who received the Medal of Honor for leading a rare bayonet charge up a hill in Korea, died Saturday in Loma Linda, Calif. He was 88.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Sept. 30 and The Books of The Times Review on Monday about Going Rogue, by Sarah Palin, misstated the role of Lynn Vincent, Ms. Palins collaborator on the book, at World, an evangelical magazine. She is a senior writer and former features editor; she is not the editor or the features editor. (The editor of World pointed out the errors in an e-mail message this week.)

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: In Letters Gone Dark, A Message To Ponder
description: The sign, more accurately, should have read u r hurt.

title: Once Wary of the Web, Luxury Brands Embrace It
description: BERLIN

title: Fire, Possibly Caused by Incense, Kills Man and 2 Children
description: A fast-moving fire that may have been sparked by incense swept through the top floor of a six-story apartment building in Brooklyn on Wednesday, killing a man and his two small children, fire officials said.

title: Colum McCann, T.J. Stiles Win National Book Awards
description: Colum McCann won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night for Let the Great World Spin, a novel featuring a sprawling cast of characters in 1970s New York City whose lives are ineluctably touched by the mysterious tightrope walker who traverses a wire suspended between the twin towers one morning.

title: New Cases of Flu Drop on College Campuses
description: For the first time since fall began, new cases of flu among college students have started to drop, hinting that this wave of the swine flu pandemic has peaked, the American College Health Association reported. The association does weekly surveys of more than 250 colleges and universities with a total of three million students, and new cases of flu in the week that ended on Friday dropped by 27 percent from the previous week. About 80,000 of the students have had flu symptoms, about 150 have been hospitalized and last week there were two deaths. Only a tiny fraction have had swine flu shots.

title: Senate Wording Angers Abortion Opponents
description: In seeking to fend off a major revolt by supporters of abortion rights, Democratic leaders in the Senate have infuriated abortion opponents with their new version of health care legislation.

title: Eugene Cotton, Labor Union Lawyer, Dies at 95
description: Eugene Cotton, a labor lawyer whose negotiating savvy helped improve the wages and conditions of tens of thousands of meatpacking workers, died Nov. 11 at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

title: Obama Demands Afghan Reforms Produce Results
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas top diplomat privately pressed Afghan President Hamid Karzai to deliver measurable results on governance and corruption as the White House prepared specific new demands to accompany an American troop buildup.

title: Sunday Night Gives NBC No. 1 Prime-Time Program
description: NBCs Sunday Night Football has achieved what ABCs Monday Night Football never did, even in the 1970s: it is the No. 1 program in prime time. For now. It will almost certainly lose the race after the season ends and Foxs American Idol returns to the air in January.

title: Colum McCann Wins National Book Award
description: Colum McCann won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night for Let the Great World Spin, a novel featuring a sprawling cast of characters in 1970s New York City whose lives are ineluctably touched by the mysterious tightrope walker who traverses a wire suspended between the Twin Towers one morning.

title: A Tough Job Now, But a Big Upside
description: Whats the best job in financial services? The available chief executives seat at the troubled Bank of America may not spring to mind.

title: Zelaya Has Two Americans Shot in Nicaragua
description: Friday, Nov. 19, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: On Assignment: While Thousands Gather
description: Cloaked in a brown wool shawl and carrying a walking stick, the figure of a man emerges from a dense early-morning fog.

title: Iran: Doctors Death Raises Questions
description: Judicial authorities in Iran plan to investigate the death of a young doctor who had testified before Parliament about prisoner abuses in the aftermath of the disputed presidential election. Reformist Web sites said that Dr. Ramin Pourandarjani, 26, was killed in order to silence him, as he was the only independent witness to be able to corroborate the charges of torture.

title: Throw a Little Sauce on It
description: The Cuban band Septeto Nacional de Ignacio Pieiro can legitimately claim to have invented salsa, Larry Rohter writes . But though their music has flourished, because of political machinations, theyve had a hard time reaching our shores: the group last performed in the United States at the Chicago Worlds Fair in 1933. Tonight the musicians  fourth-generation descendents of the original line-up, including the sole female member of the Buena Vista Social Club  will play what may be a once-in-a-lifetime gig at SOBs. Dont miss it, or risk waiting another 76 years.

title: Gender Neutral
description: Girl? Boy? Boi? Gurl? It no longer matters, at least as long as style is concerned. Androgyny is in, according to Ruth La Ferla. [LINK to Andro in Styles] Outfit your new gender-neutral wardrobe at the Steven Alan sample sale ( at the showroom, 87 Franklin Street, TriBeCa), where you can get striped sweaters, leather jackets, slouchy T-shirts and printed scarves for more than 50 percent off, along with a decent sampling of the people youd want to attract while wearing them.

title: Scribe Smackdown
description: Opium Magazines Literary Death Match drives another stake into the notion of bookish politesse [LINK to Award in National] tonight at the Bowery Poetry Club. Watch as comedy writers  including Jon Friedman of Jimmy Fallon and The Rejection Show and Edith Zimmerman, of these hilarious Letters to the Editors of Womens Magazines  duke it out in the reading arena, which is a lot louder than you might think.

title: Word of the Day | realm
description: realm  \relm\  noun

title: The Senates Sense on Savings
description: A constant source of frustration for Democrats in their efforts to develop sweeping health care legislation this year has been the budget-scoring rules of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, which issues the official cost analyses of legislation pending before Congress.

title: For Her, the Long and Winding Road Led to the Street
description: Suzanne Kaplan did not become homeless overnight. It happened gradually, beginning in 1993 with her mothers death and becoming more or less a permanent condition four years later.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Yveta Synek Graff, a translator and longtime champion of Czech opera, misstated the nationality of Willard White, who is appearing in the current Czech-language production of Leos Janaceks From the House of the Dead at the Metropolitan Opera.
