Mr. White was born in Jamaica and is a British citizen; he is not American.

title: Review Finds Fraud in Contracts Awarded in Disabled Veterans Program
description: A program intended to help disabled veterans win government business awarded at least $100 million in contracts to firms that were either ineligible or committed fraud to obtain the work, a federal review has found.

title: Beaky, the Blighted Brooklyn Bird
description: WHO is Beaky? WHO feeds him?

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Wednesday, about the founders debates about climate, misstated the status of the United States in the winter of 1783. It was an independent country, not a collection of colonies.

title: Correction
description: The On Location article last Thursday about the Manhattan decorator Jamie Drake referred incorrectly to a building on West 24th Street where he is temporarily living. It is a condominium, not a rental building, although Mr. Drake is renting his unit.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about J. Alexander, who trains models to walk the runway, misspelled the given name of one of his students. She is Nadja Auermann, not Nadia.

title: News Quiz | November 19, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Pathology of a Financial Crisis
description: The coroners report left no doubt as to the cause of death: toxic loans.

title: Suicide Attack Is Pakistani Citys 7th in 2 Weeks
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A suicide blast near the judicial complex here on Thursday killed at least 17 people and wounded more than 30 others, a senior police official said.

title: Karzai Sworn In for Second Term as President
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Tainted by a flawed election and allegations of festering corruption in his government, President Hamid Karzai was inaugurated Thursday for a second term, promising to remedy the countrys problems and to have the Afghan Army assume full control of security within five years.

title: Gas Feud Escalates Between Russia and Ukraine
description: KIEV, Ukraine A dispute between Russia and Ukraine over natural gas supplies escalated on Thursday, with an aide to the Russian president calling Ukraines warnings of a possible gas crisis political blackmail.

title: IPWireless Raises $15.5 Million
description: IPWireless, a mobile network equipment company, has raised $15.5 million in what marks the firms first round of funding since being sold back to its founders in 2008.

title: BofA Chief: A Tough Job With a Big Upside?
description: Whats the best job in financial services? The available chief executives seat at the troubled Bank of America  may not spring to mind.

title: Dueling Air Alliances in War of Influence for JAL
description: Just after Delta Air Lines and its alliance partners  offered $1 billion in aid to Japan Airlines on Wednesday, aAmerican Airlines quickly said it would top the proposal, as the worlds biggest airlines escalated a war for influence over the ailing Japanese carrier.

title: Blackstones Pinnacle to Buy Birds Eye, Report Says
description: Pinnacle Brands reportedly has Birds Eye Foods in its sights.

title: Simon Said to Explore Bid for General Growth
description: Simon Property Group, the shopping mall giant, has tapped advisers to help it explore a possible bid for its bankrupt rival, General Growth Properties, The Financial Times reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Chinese Budget Hotel Chain Plans New York I.P.O.
description: As Chinas travel industry heats up, 7 Days Group Holdings hopes investors will see the promise in its public offering.

title: Fortinet Shares Soar on First Day of Trading
description: Shares of Fortinet rose sharply in the companys first day of trading on the Nasdaq, another sign that the recently moribund market for initial public offerings is coming back to life.

title: Koodie
description: A kid who is a foodie.

title: Goldman Could Have Suffered Big Losses on A.I.G.
description: Since the start of the financial crisis Goldman Sachs has appeared to have a fairly Teflon-like exterior, escaping relatively unscathed, at least in comparison with many of its rivals.

title: Vain Glorious | Dickson Hairshop
description: With Vain Glorious, T Magazines editors break down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

title: Jeanne-Claude
description: Images of the artist Jeane-Claude and her work.

title: To Build a Smart Grid, Start With Smart Meters
description: For nearly 30 years, Itron has dominated the American market in what had been a profitable but unglamorous field, automating power, gas and water meters. But with $8 billion in government and private money devoted to modernizing the power grid, meter automation is suddenly a growth industry, The New York Timess Roy Furchgott writes. Without millions of new smart meters, no smart grid is possible.

title: Do P.E. Shops Need to Mull Future as Asset Managers?
description: Private equity firms will need to become more like asset managers, offering buyouts as just part of their portfolio, or else focus tightly on specific sectors in order to prosper, industry veterans said during a conference Wednesday.

title: John Paulson Joins Gold Rush
description: Hedge fund managers, like a large swath of other investors, have gone cuckoo for gold recently.

title: Ambac Capital Exceeds Required Minimum
description: Ambac Financial Group said Wednesday that the statutory capital of its main unit was well above a regulatory minimum at the end of the third quarter, easing concerns the company would fall short of funds and risk being taken over by state officials.

title: G.M. I.P.O. Could Come in 4th Quarter of 2010
description: General Motors should focus on making money and repaying U.S. Treasury loans before turning to public markets to sell the taxpayers stake in the automaker, Ron Bloom, head of the Obama administrations auto task force, told Reuters.

title: Learning to Cook the Amsterdam Way
description: The Okura Hotel is already something of a gastronomic landmark in this city, housing the Michelin-starred restaurants Yamazato (Japanese) and Ciel Bleu (French), as well as Le Camelia Brasserie. On Dec. 9, the hotel hopes to firm up that status when it officially opens its new culinary center, Taste of Okura.

title: The Copenhagen Attendance Question
description: To go or not to go? That is the question.

title: Is There a Problem With Rex Ryans Crying?
description: Calling a reverse and putting the Extra Point first: Is everyone comfortable with the idea that Rex Ryan cried in front of his team?

title: Citadels Quest to Recover Investor Confidence
description: Hedge fund manager Kenneth C. Griffins Citadel Investment Group lost $8 billion in clients money last year, but is turning things around as markets recover and has made $5 billion in profits so far this year, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Bankers Poised to Help Chinas Richest Invest
description: The number of United States-dollar millionaires in China is expected to nearly double in five years, luring private bankers eager to help them invest an expected combined wealth over $7.6 trillion by 2013, the Boston Consulting Group said on Thursday.

title: Is Ameritrade Looking to Buy E-Trade?
description: E-Trade Financial shares surged late Wednesday after media reports fed speculation that rival online broker TD Ameritrade Holding could make a bid for the company.

title: Oak Hill Denies Interest in Playboy
description: Is Playboy in play? Yet another private equity firm has denied wanting to buy it.

title: JPMorgan to Take Over Cazenove for $1.7 Billion
description: Update | 7:42 a.m. JPMorgan Chase agreed on Thursday to buy the rest of Cazenove, its British investment banking joint venture partner, for $1.7 billion to strengthen its franchise in a country whose banks are either struggling to return to profit or looking abroad for growth.

title: Citis Auto Loan Unit Attracts Interest
description: Private equity firms are reportedly kicking the tires of Citigroups auto loan business.

title: The Importance of Silly Research
description: Todays idea: Frivolous academic research is serious business, its defenders say. It popularizes science, attracts new funding with the publicity it generates and thereby advances knowledge. Even if monkeys cant write like Shakespeare.

title: Claims Against Lehman May Hit $1 Trillion, Chief Says
description: Creditors of Lehman Brothers Holdings have filed $824 billion in bankruptcy claims against the collapsed investment bank, and the total may reach $1 trillion, Lehmans chief executive, Bryan P. Marsal, said.

title: How Would You Grade Your School?
description: New York City high schools received grades from the city this week, with the best schools receiving As and just one receiving an F. How would you grade your school?

title: N.F.L. Week 11 Probabilities, and a Forecast for Jets-Patriots
description: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior. His team rankings through Week 10 can be found here.)

title: What Did TARP Accomplish?
After Grilling, BofA Banker is Praised and Panned
description: Bank of America executives on Wednesday stood by the head of consumer banking, Brian Moynihan, a leading candidate to be the companys next chief executive, after two congressmen panned his performance at a hearing on the banks purchase of the troubled investment bank Merrill Lynch.

title: Nvidias Gamers Helped It Win Big Business
description: Nvidia critics will sometimes have fun knocking the company as being a slave to childs play.

title: Sampler: S.F. Budget Deficit, U.C. Fees, Lessons for Mobile Food Purveyors
description: S.F. Budget Deficit | The citys budget deficit will approach $500 million next year, according to the mayors budget chief who is expected to give more details today.

title: S&P Joins Moodys to Scale Back Australia Ratings
description: In a move that highlights the difficulty of regulating ratings agencies, Standard & Poors has joined Moodys in withdrawing its application to supply ratings of corporate bonds and other debt-based securities to retail investors in Australia, after new rules were announced this month by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission.

title: In Obama Interview, Signs of Chinas Heavy Hand
description: President Obama spent part of his last morning in Beijing giving an interview to Southern Weekly, a newspaper in Guangdong Province sometimes known for its push-the-envelope approach to the governments ever-present censorship.

title: There May Be a Smaller Ford in Your Future
description: Disarm the Patek Philippe. Park the Bugatti. Drain the last drops of Cristal. The partys over.

title: New York, From the Pages of Look
description: Stanley Kubrick wanted the grit. Still in his teens, the future director photographed New York Citys underbelly in the 1940s and 50s, shooting boxers and showgirls with stark shadows evocative of the citys shady side. First as a freelancer and then as a staff photographer for Look magazine, his images were a dark counterpoint to the work of others who depicted New York as a gleaming world capital.

title: Huge Global Sales
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below:

title: A Dim View of U.S.-China Electric Car Plan
description: Should the United States and China be teaming up on clean urban transportation systems instead of clean cars? After the announcement of a suite of new energy partnerships between China and the United States, I sought feedback on the electric vehicle project from Lee Schipper, an energy and transportation specialist who splits his time between the University of California, Berkeley, and Stanford. Hes quite worried that the program is looking at cars mainly from an energy-efficiency context, instead of how they will shape and affect Chinas fast-expanding cities in a larger sense. Creating a zero-carbon car for China tomorrow wont solve the much bigger problems of urban congestion, traffic fatalities and the paving over of once-beautiful cities to make room for more cars, Dr. Schipper said. The discussions should back up. Energy is only a means to an end. What are the ends, urban access and mobility, or cars for a small minority?

title: Feline More Secure?
N.H.L. Scoreboard: Surging Panthers Humble Sabres
description: Last season the Florida Panthers missed the playoffs because the N.H.L. awards as many points for tying a game and then winning a shootout as it does for winning a game outright. Because the Panthers did not do well in shootouts while Montreal did, it was the Canadiens who made the post-season while the Cats had to watch it on TV in the golf course snack bar.

title: Study: Asia Surging in Clean-Tech Manufacturing
description: If the United States government does not invest more money in clean technology, it risks losing out to China, South Korea and Japan, according to a new study from two American policy institutes.

title: JPMorgan Buys the Rest of a British Bank Partner
description: LONDON  JPMorgan Chase agreed on Thursday to buy the rest of Cazenove, its partner in a British investment banking joint venture, for $1.7 billion to strengthen its franchise in a country whose banks have either struggled to return to profit or looked abroad for growth.

title: The Early Word: Health Bill Digest
description: Less than 10 hours after Senate Democrats unveiled their health care bill, the reviews are flowing in.

title: Speed Read for Thursday, Nov. 19
description: Highlights from Thursdays media coverage.

title: In the Cash Room, the Obama Administration Is All Ears
description: Lani Hay, daughter of Vietnamese immigrants, retired from the Navy as an intelligence officer, and then with her American Express card and some savings, opened a technology consulting business serving the federal government. By 2007, just four years after it opened its doors, Lanmark Technology had grown to bring in $12 million in annual revenue and employ 100 people.* Then the recession hit. Along with L.M.T.s annual revenues dropping, L.M.T.s line of credit was also dropped, by a bank that bought out the bank that I was working with, Ms. Hay said Wednesday in a conference in Washington, convened by the Obama administration to address the problems small businesses have had finding capital during the recession. Worse, she said, the bank canceled the credit line just before she was to receive a $500,000 contract from the Defense Department  and she had needed the credit to tide her firm over until the government paid its bills.

title: What to Watch Thursday: Cameo Dads, Terror in Mumbai
description: Ralph Waite, best known for playing Pa on The Waltons, moves up to Grandpa on Bones (Fox, 8 p.m.), where he guest stars as the grandfather of Booth (David Boreanaz). Its also patriarch night on ABC: Frankie Faison appears as Baileys father on Greys Anatomy (9 p.m.) and Stephen Collins plays Addisons dad on Private Practice (10 p.m.).

title: Comparing the House and the Senate Health Care Proposals
description: In December, the Senate approved a sweeping legislation to overhaul the nations health care system. The House approved its bill in November. The proposals are broadly similar but differ on some major issues, like a new government insurance plan, abortion and how to pay for the expansion of coverage. A look at some key differences between the proposals:

title: On the White House Jobs Forum
description: The White House is still working on the invitation list for President Obamas recently announced Forum on Jobs and Economic Growth on Dec. 3, but it has decided on the six panels that the business owners, experts and plain folks will break into.

title: French Weigh $52 Billion Bond Issue
description: France moved a step closer Thursday to issuing billions of euros in bonds to raise money to promote growth industries, even as a leading research group warned it could damage the countrys long-term fiscal future.

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Thursday morning.

title: Morgan Stanleys Mack: We Cannot Control Ourselves
description: Wall Street is facing more scrutiny from Washington after the financial crisis last fall. For John J. Mack of Morgan Stanley, thats just fine.

title: Workmen in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan A worker carries a hose that is used to pump water out from an excavation site on the outskirts of Kabul. The earth excavated from this site is used for the production of cement and then sold to construction companies.

title: In Pursuit of a Smarter Grid
description: The so-called smart or super grid  terms that loosely describe an upgraded electricity transmission network augmented by digital communications technology  is championed by Al Gore, the former vice president and climate change crusader; endorsed by John Doerr, the visionary venture capitalist; and pursued by countless start-ups.

title: A Parisian Vacation for a Victorious Mayor
description: Aprs la victoire, les vacances.

title: Where Some See a ShackBurger, Others Just See a New Yorker
description: Shake Shack is considering a new location on Boston Common, but some locals there say that spot should be reserved for local talent.

title: AOL to Cut One-Third of Its Staff
description: In recent years, amid the fallout from its audacious merger with Time Warner, AOL Inc. has steadily become smaller through subscriber desertions and rounds and rounds of layoffs.

title: H & H Owner Indicted on Tax Charges
description: The owner of H & H Bagels has been indicted on tax fraud charges.The owner, Helmer Toro, 59, failed to pay nearly $370,000 in payroll withholdings to state and federal tax authorities, according to Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney.

title: Glee Watch: Paired Up
description: This post contains spoilers.

title: Q. & A.: The Real Cost of College
description: This is college-application season for a lot of teenagers, so we asked one of the economists who most closely follows college costs to sit down with us for a virtual chat. She is Sandy Baum, a former professor at Skidmore College and an economist at the College Board. Shes the lead author of the College Boards closely followed annual report on college tuition.

title: What Part of No Cellphones Dont You Understand?
description: An AirTran flight from Atlanta to Houston was delayed for two and a half hours on Tuesday because a passenger wouldnt get off his cellphone, according to The Atlanta Journal-Constitution.

title: Can I read the news off-line or in airplane mode?
description: Yes. The NYTimes application was designed to store content locally on your BlackBerry. Once you have completed the sync process, you will be able to access stored and saved content, even if your device is in airplane mode or you do not have cellular network coverage. Note that only articles that have been fully downloaded will be available for offline reading.

title: Court Upholds Recognition of Gay Marriages in Narrow Ruling
description: New York States highest court rejected unanimously a challenge on Thursday by opponents of same-sex marriage to policies that recognize such unions performed in other states, though the decision gave gay advocates a small victory because it was narrowly written and applied to a relatively small number of people.

title: An Experts View of College Costs
description: While the sticker price for attending college continues to climb, the net cost  after taking into account grants and discounts  is actually lower now than five years ago, according to Sandy Baum, a former professor at Skidmore College and an economist at the College Board.

title: The Oscar Race for Documentaries: Who Got Snubbed?
description: Its not Thanksgiving yet, but a few documentary filmmakers have good reason to be thankful while others may be wondering if theyve been snubbed by the Academy Awards.

title: Blackstone to Buy Birds Eye for $1.3 Billion
description: The Pinnacle Foods Group, a company controlled by the Blackstone Group, announced Thursday that it would acquire Birds Eye Foods for $1.3 billion.

title: Indexes Fall as Rising Dollar Lures Investors
description: Wall Street shares slid sharply on Thursday as a stronger dollar lured investors away from riskier stock markets and commodities like gold and oil.

title: Thursday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Computer Problems Cause Flight Delays and Cancellations
description: Updated | 11:10 a.m. According to the Associated Press, the Federal Aviation Administration said the problem was fixed around 10 a.m., but it was unclear how long flights would continue to be affected.

title: Another View: Unintended Consequences on Wall St.
description: Peter J. Solomon, the chairman of the Peter J. Solomon Company, looks at Wall Streets compensation and the unintended consequences of the banking bailout.

title: Weekly Popcast: Norah Jones, Radian and Alela Diane
description: This week: Jon Pareles reviews The Fall, the new album by Norah Jones; Ben Ratliff discusses Chimeric, the latest release from the Austrian experimental band Radian; and the California folk singer-songwriter Alela Diane talks to Ben Sisario about her new album, To Be Still, and performs her song Lady Divine. Sia Michel is the host.

title: South Africa Says Gender Controversy Is Over
description: On Thursday the South African government tried to end the controversy over the sex of Caster Semenya, the runner who was crowned world champion in August for the womens 800 meters, by declaring that an agreement had been reached to let her keep her medal and not release the results of gender tests carried out after her victory.

title: Psalm 109:8 Let His Days Be Few
description: An anti-Obama bumper-sticker slogan which seems to urge people to pray for an end to the Presidents days (in office?).

title: Rich or Poor, Nonsmokers Are Happier
description: Lest there be any doubt about the wisdom of smoking, new survey data has found that smokers are less happy than nonsmokers across all income levels.

title: Pogue & Friends 2009 Holiday Guide
description: David Pogue and media columnist David Carr team up at the New York Public Library to take a look at different electronic book readers.

title: Voters Choose Flannery OConnor in National Book Award Poll
description: Among the National Book Awards winners named on Wednesday night whose names may elude you, one honoree youve almost certainly heard of is Flannery OConnor. In an online poll conducted by the National Book Foundation, her collection The Complete Stories was named the best work to have won the National Book Award for fiction in the contests 60-year history. The competition was steep: other finalists in the poll were The Stories of John Cheever, William Faulkners Collected Stories, The Collected Stories of Eudora Welty, Ralph Ellisons Invisible Man and Thomas Pynchons Gravitys Rainbow. (Then again, the OConnor book bested some formidable contenders when it won the fiction prize in 1972, including John Updikes Rabbit Redux, Walker Percys Love in the Ruins and E. L. Doctorows Book of Daniel.) This years National Book Award for fiction was won by Colum McCanns Let the Great World Spin.

title: The Times to Begin Chicago Edition on Friday
description: The first Chicago edition of The New York Times, with added pages of local and regional news, will be published Friday, The Times announced Thursday, a month after the paper began publishing a similar regional edition in San Francisco.

title: Weighing the Toll of Contact in Practice
description: This week, an article on NFL.com suggested that a group led by the Hall of Fame coach John Madden, charged with formulating ideas to make the game safer for players, had discussed the idea of suggesting that teams sometimes practice without contact or helmets in an effort to pare down the hard hits players take long before game day.

title: U.S. Mortgage Delinquencies Reach a Record High
description: The economy and the stock market may be recovering from their swoon, but more homeowners than ever are having trouble making their monthly mortgage payments, according to figures released Thursday.

title: Popcorns Dark Secret
description: Sitting in a dark movie theater with your friends and a tub of buttery popcorn sounds like a perfect way to spend a Saturday night  and it could be, if you are willing to share your popcorn with the entire row of moviegoers around you.

title: Plan Ahead or Pay the Piper (and the Plumber and )
description: Everything is happening at once. With winter close at hand, we are rushing to enclose the building  to hang doors, insulate walls and create some heat so the pipes dont freeze. First, we need the pipes in place. And water to run through them. And R.P.Z. valves to regulate the water. And the D.E.P. to approve the R.P.Z. valves.

title: City Building Agency May Farm Out Tests
description: Even as it faces a $5 billion budget deficit, service cuts and possible layoffs, the Bloomberg administration is preparing to spend several million dollars to hire a private testing firm to administer construction industry licensing exams that are currently overseen by city employees.

title: Is This the Most Overpaid Man in Hollywood?
description: Will Ferrell may have had a lucrative season on Broadway in his George W. Bush show, but that comic actor is being called the most overpaid film star in a Forbes.com study, Reuters reported. In ranking the Top 10 movie stars who cost more than they deliver, Forbes.com looked at actors estimated salaries on their films, including DVD and television sales, and compared them to the revenues grossed by those films. According to this methodology, Mr. Ferrells films earned an average of $3.29 for every dollar he was paid. (The tally was dragged down by his 2009 release Land of the Lost, which cost $100 million to make and grossed $65 million worldwide.) The Forbes list of overpaid stars was rounded out by Ewan McGregor, Billy Bob Thornton, Eddie Murphy, Ice Cube, Tom Cruise, Drew Barrymore, Leonardo DiCaprio, Samuel L. Jackson and Jim Carrey.

title: Madison Ave. Sees the Writing on the Wall
description: Advertising is getting interested again in graffiti and other forms of so-called street art.

title: Still Senating
description: Monologue |  Aired Wednesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Im Jimmy. Im the host of this show. Dont worry. I got the whole night planned out. Were going to have drinks, were going to have appetizers, and then were going to roast a moose and split it up between us. I got the recipe out of the new Sarah Palin book.

title: Ancier to Leave BBC Worldwide America
description: BBC Worldwide America will announce later Thursday that Garth Ancier, a longtime broadcast network programming executive, will be stepping down as president after three years in the position.

title: The Sweep of History
description: Monologue |  Aired Wednesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Sarah Palin is still dominating the news here. Last night, she was in an interview with Barbara Walters. She was asked to rate Obamas performance as a president on a scale of 1 to 10. And Palin was like, Oh, thats easy, F.

title: Puttin on the Bisque
description: Which is the right life? asks the Cole Porter song. The simple or the night life? When, pray, should one rise, at sunset or at sunrise? Which should be upper, my breakfast or my supper? Which is the right life, which?

title: Bowing Before the Emperor
description: Monologue |  Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Earlier today, President Obama took a tour of the Great Wall of China. He said it was, quote, magical as opposed to two years ago, when former President Bush stood at the exact same spot and said, Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!

title: Gift Guide | Caffeinated Cheer
description: Take a break from your daily grind to browse our coffee-themed holiday gift guide assembled by Jill Santopietro. That ought to perk you up.

title: Palm Drops iTunes Workaround, for Now
description: Palms latest update to its mobile operating system now allows owners of the Pre and Pixi to use Yahoos instant messaging client and watch YouTube videos in wide screen view, among other things.

title: That Awful Guy
description: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on CBS: The big news here in New York City, that awful guy, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed  you know this guy? Terrorist mastermind, been down in Guantnamo Bay for seven years, bringing him to New York City, and hes going to be on trial here in New York City. Now, the good news is it should be pretty entertaining because Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin are hosting.

title: Guns on Amtrak
description: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on NBC: President Obama winding up his Asian tour this week. Theres a switch. Something American in China. You never see that.

title: Jeanne-Claude, Artist Who, With Christo, Wrapped Objects Large and Small, Is Dead at 74
description: Update | 12:59 p.m. Jeanne-Claude, who collaborated with her husband, Christo, on dozens of environmental arts projects, notably the wrapping of the Pont Neuf in Paris and the Reichstag in Berlin, and the installation of 7,503 vinyl gates with saffron-colored nylon panels in Central Park, died on Wednesday in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 74.

title: Travel Deals: Luxury for Less
description: Heads up luxury bargain hunters: the online discount retailer Gilt Groupe has created a series of flash holiday sales that combine upscale hotels and fashion duds from its invitation-only sites Jetsetter, Gilt Man, and Gilt  at 30 to 50 percent off retail prices.

title: Google to Add Captions, Improving YouTube Videos
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  In the first major step toward making millions of videos on YouTube accessible to deaf and hearing-impaired people, Google unveiled new technologies on Thursday that will automatically bring text captions to many videos on the site.

title: Fela! Broadway? Dance!
description: MOVE! Bill T. Jones commanded. Rhythm, rhythm, rhythm! He was airborne, being lifted and carried across the stage of the Eugene ONeill Theater by four dancers, perfecting their timing in a climactic ritual scene. It was hands-on choreography while an actor who would actually be carried, Kevin Mambo, observed from the wings. Mr. Jones, a pre-eminent modern-dance choreographer who won a Tony Award for his work on Spring Awakening, was rehearsing his full-scale debut as a Broadway director: Fela!, based on the life and music of the Nigerian bandleader and political rebel Fela Anikulapo Kuti.

title: Add Thierry Henry to List of Sports Villains
description: Move over Bill Belichick, the sporting world has a new lead villain. In the United States at least, he will seem an unlikely one, because beyond being the handsome soccer player in that Gillette ad with Tiger Woods and Roger Federer, Thierry Henry isnt exactly a household name. But in the tiniest second it took Henry to nudge the soccer ball with his hand toward his foot to set up Frances winning goal in a World Cup qualifier against Ireland, he became globally hated.

title: No Cheering, No Parade
description: President Hamid Karzais inauguration was a well-managed event. The Afghan presidential press handlers in their shiny tailored suits worked frantically to make sure that none of the local and foreign journalists and photographers got anywhere close to the president as he took the new oath of office.

title: AOL to Cut 2,500 Jobs
description: AOL Inc., the once mighty Internet company, will cut about a third of its workforce, or 2,500 jobs, to cut costs as it prepares to be spun off from its parent company, Time Warner.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) Remember the neediest: the United States government.

title: Are You a Twilight Convert?
description: In The Washington Post on Thursday, Monica Hesse reports on a previously unidentified group whose numbers appear to be growing: women who thought that they were above the Twilight phenomenon, only to find themselves getting sucked in by the Stephenie Meyer novels and their film adaptations.

title: Sexual Harassment Is No. 1 Quality of Life Offense on Subways, Police Say
description: Updated, 1:25 p.m. | The peak times in which women report sexual harassment or assaults on the subways are the late morning rush, roughly 8 to 10 a.m., followed by the early afternoon rush, 4 to 6 p.m.

title: News of Hockey, 11/19/09: Attorney Says He Has Yet to Advise Fleury on Filing Complaint
description: Despite Theo Fleurys declaration in New York earlier this week that he will file a complaint against Graham James, the hockey coach who sexually abused him when he was 14, Fleurys Calgary-based attorney says he has not yet spoken with Fleury and that no complaint has yet been submitted.

title: Europa League Referee System May Have Caught Henry Hand Ball
description: After Thierry Henrys admitted and blatant hand ball sent France to the World Cup at Irelands expense, you have to wonder if an innovation being used this season in the Europa League will gain new traction.

title: Trial Venue Decision in BART New Years Day Shooting
description: Update 3:48 P.M.| Judge Morris Jacobson just announced that that the Johannes Mehserle trial will be moved to the downtown Los Angeles County courthouse. A new presiding judge will be be assigned to the case, which is not likely to come to trial for at least six months, or, more likely, a year.

title: Answers on Community Colleges, Part 4
description: Each day this week, the Guidance Office  the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts  is featuring answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: University Weighs Tighter Limits on Stem Cell Research
description: LINCOLN, Neb.  In an unusual pushback against President Obamas expansion of federal financing of human embryonic stem cell research, the University of Nebraska is considering restricting its stem cell experiments to cell lines approved by President George W. Bush.

title: Fish Stories
description: Two responses to yesterdays Dining reviews may be worth hashing through here in the D.J. booth.

title: Correction
description: A chart accompanying this Op-Ed article mislabeled a category. The second line of maps reflects the support of Americans ages 30 to 44, not ages 30 to 34.

title: Free Music at Lincoln Center
description: Lincoln Centers new visitor center starts its Target Free Thursdays today with a program that includes the Asphalt Orchestra, a 12-piece street band; the Juilliard Jazz Ensemble; the Kubiak-Pakhomov Duo, a pianist and cellist; and the Sexteto Rodriguez Cuban-Jewish All Stars, who blend Cuban dance music with Jewish Klezmer. Target sponsors similar programs elsewhere around the United States.

title: That Cozy New Cafe? Its Starbucks
description: Yesterday, Roy Street Coffee & Tea opened in Seattle. It takes its name from its street location at the corner of East Roy Street and Broadway, but read the not-so-fine print and youll see the company behind the coffeehouse: its a Starbucks.

title: New York, in the Pages of Look
description: On City Room, Mike Reicher writes about a new exhibition, Only in New York: Photographs From Look Magazine, at the Museum of the City of New York. Based on a book with the same title, it is a compilation of the photojournalism magazines images published between 1938 and 1971, he writes. Editors and photographers at Look, which had its offices in New York, drew many of their subjects from the citys streets, stages and back rooms. Read more on City Room . . .

title: Quote Unquote | Us, Too
description: Alber Elbaz, sharing one of his fears at the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Gala. Boo!

title: Kerry Still Optimistic on Copenhagen
description: President Obama is undecided as to whether to attend the Copenhagen climate meetings.

title: The Daily Palin Fix
description: Just a few notes of interest on the Sarah Palin book tour that are out there early Thursday, in case youre following along. Before some of you groan about overexposure caused by too much coverage, the takes below are a little different than stories about speeches or the book itself.

title: Extensions for Brother/Sister Plays and Lady With All the Answers
description: The Public Theater said on Thursday that it was extending its run of Tarell Alvin McCraneys Brother/Sister Plays. The production will continue through Dec. 20, with all three plays running on Saturdays and Sundays.

title: Cast Announced for Lie of the Mind
description: Ethan Hawke has assembled an estimable gathering of downtown denizens and fellow actors to star in a coming revival of A Lie of the Mind, the Sam Shepard play that he will be directing for the New Group. The cast of the play, about a man who believes he may have murdered his wife, will feature Josh Hamilton (who starred in Jonathan Marc Shermans Things We Want for Mr. Hawke), as well as Marin Ireland (Broadways Reasons to Be Pretty), Deirdre OConnell (Circle Mirror Transformation), Alessandro Nivola, Maggie Siff and Frank Whaley. The production is to begin previews on Jan. 29 with an official opening planned for February, its publicists said in a news release.

title: Rock on the Block | The Phillips de Pury Music Sale
description: Phillips de Pury is an esteemed auction house dating back to 1796. Its clientele includes Napoleon and Beau Brummell. A different ilk of bidders, however, will be raising their paddles this Saturday as the firm holds its inaugural Music sale.

title: An Omnivores Mom: Corky Pollans Turnip and Pear Pure
description: The writer Michael Pollan, whose books Omnivores Dilemma and In Defense of Food have changed the way many of us think about food, has raved about his mothers amazing Thanksgiving cooking. Recently I asked Mr. Pollans mother, Corky Pollan, about the role of cooking and healthful eating in her home during Michaels childhood.

title: Coming to TripAdvisor: Easier Click-On Hotel Access
description: Finding that hotel you saw on TripAdvisor may soon get a little easier.

title: Childhood: U.S. Draws Low Marks on Premature Births
description: More than half a million babies, one out of eight, are born prematurely each year in the United States, prompting the March of Dimes to give the nation a D on its premature births report card.

title: Sustainable Surfing Rides the Waves
description: As I wrote in a New York Times article on Thursday, the $7.2 billion surf business has become the latest industry to ride the green wave. Call it sustainable surfing.

title: Giuliani Said to Decide Against Run for Governor
description: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided not to run for governor next year after months of considering a candidacy, according to people who have been told of the decision.

title: College for Convicts? Considering the Value of Education for Prisoners
description: Overview | How does education humanize us? Why offer college educations to convicted felons? What is the value of both punishment and rehabilitation for criminals? In this lesson, students explore an interactive Times feature about higher education for prison inmates and consider these questions through reading, writing, and debate, and then create annotated reading lists for student prisoners.

title: How Will Religion Evolve?
description: Does religion have a future? Who looks more like an evolutionary dead end: the religious American or the agnostic European? Or will both give way to some sort of compromise  people bound by new institutions that provide the social benefits of religion without belief in a traditional deity?

title: Toyota Says Safety Report Is Misleading
description: When the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety issued its top safety picks for 2010 on Wednesday, no vehicles from Toyota, Lexus or Scion were on the list.

title: European Puck: AIK Stockholm Entertains Invitation to Join K.H.L.
description: The board of directors of AIK Hockey Stockholm, one of Swedens most prominent clubs but one that is also strapped for cash and long stuck in the second division, has accepted an invitation from the K.H.L. to join the Russian league for the 2010-11 season. But the decision must first be approved by the clubs members  i.e., the dues-paying fans of AIK Stockholm  and by the Swedish Ice Hockey Association.

title: A $25 App Phone? Thats Crazy Talk.
description: In June, the once-downtrodden mess of a company called Palm shocked the world by thrusting its arm from the grave, holding a gleaming, compact capsule called the Palm Pre. The Pre, of course, is an app phone like the iPhone, in fact designed by many of the same ex-Apple engineers, but with a slide-out keyboard, removable battery, and joyous touch screen software all its own.

title: A $25 App Phone? Thats Crazy Talk.
description: In June, the once-downtrodden mess of a company called Palm shocked the world by thrusting its arm from the grave, holding a gleaming, compact capsule called the Palm Pre. The Pre, of course, is an app phone like the iPhone, in fact designed by many of the same ex-Apple engineers, but with a slide-out keyboard, removable battery, and joyous touch screen software all its own.

title: 36 Hours in Rajasthan, India
description: INDIA is modernizing rapidly, sometimes too fast. You have giant malls, but grandmothers afraid to use the escalators. There are villages in the middle of nowhere, with ornate temples soaring into the hot sky. Still, old Rajasthan endures, evoking rulers with giant mustaches, harems of beautiful women in the finest colored silks and some of the most spectacular palaces ever built. They can be found in the states three biggest cities: Jodhpur, Jaipur and Udaipur.

title: Low-Profile Leaders Chosen for Top European Posts
description: BRUSSELS  Leaders of the 27 countries of the European Union on Thursday night chose Herman Van Rompuy, the Belgian prime minister, as the European Unions first president, and Catherine Ashton of Britain, currently the blocs trade commissioner, as its high representative for foreign policy. The vote was unanimous.

title: Holiday Open House for the Sanfords
description: Call this another family reality show.

title: Jeanne-Claude, Christos Collaborator on Environmental Canvas, Is Dead at 74
description: Jeanne-Claude, who collaborated with her husband, Christo, on dozens of environmental art projects, notably the wrapping of the Pont Neuf in Paris and the Reichstag in Berlin and the installation of 7,503 vinyl gates with saffron-colored nylon panels in Central Park, died Wednesday in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 74.

title: Pirates Widen Range, Straining Naval Patrols
description: PARIS  Pirate attacks on shipping lanes around the Horn of Africa have shown no sign of relenting, and the nations policing the seas are struggling to find solutions in a mission that seems to be covering a growing area and time frame.

title: Conyers Derides White House Strategy on Health Care
description: Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan and the second-most senior member of the House, today ripped into President Obama and Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, accusing them of bowing down to nutty right-wing proposals just to get a health care bill passed.

title: The Morning Skate: No Olympic Head Shots and a No Goal Call in Detroit
description: Sometimes you just need a good laugh

title: Asian Governments Indicate They May Take Action to Deter Speculation
description: As a tumultuous year for Asian real estate comes to an end, it seems that regulators are likely to try to cool the market next year  as hard as that might be to believe.

title: A Lowly Grass Moves Up
description: The headquarters of the John Hardy jewelry house here surprises with carefully crafted, contemporary uses of bamboo: as furniture, structural detail and the basis for an unusual video wall in the reception area.

title: Happy National Geography Week!
description: Here is our list of fun and useful tools from The Learning Network, The Times and around the Web.

title: Iraq Sentences Sunni Leader to Death
description: BAGHDAD  A leader of a Sunni Awakening Council was sentenced to death for kidnapping and murder on Thursday, setting off charges that the Shiite-dominated Iraqi government was trying to weaken the Sunni movement, which is credited with much of the reduction of sectarian violence here since 2006.

title: For Ailing Hospital Sign, Recuperation Is Planned
description: It shined briefly as a strange beacon of commiseration: the hospital sign that declared in large neon lights something that looks a lot like, Im hurt.

title: Regents Raise College Tuition in California by 32 Percent
description: As the University of Californias Board of Regents met Thursday at U.C.L.A. and approved a plan to raise undergraduate fees  the equivalent of tuition  32 percent next fall, hundreds of students from campuses across the state demonstrated outside, beating drums and chanting slogans against the increase.

title: Google Says It Doesnt Want to Be a Utility
description: Ed Lu, the former astronaut and now program manager for advanced products at Google, wants to be clear: Google is not interested in competing with utilities.

title: Republican Governors Warn on Costs to States
description: LOST PINES, Tex.  There is one group of elected officials who are decidedly unhappy with the health care proposal unveiled by the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada  Republican governors.

title: Goldman Promotes 272 to Managing Director
description: Goldman Sachs on Thursday named 272 executives who will become managing directors next year, rising to the second-highest ranking within the firm and entitling them to a bigger share of its profits, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook. (Read the text of the memo at the end of this article.)

title: What the Law Commands
description: The ostensible topic of a recent argument before the Supreme Court was lawyering, but the real subject turned out to be judging. An exchange between Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and one of the lawyers was illuminating.

title: Now Showing | Marcel Wanders in Philadephia
description: The A/V team at the Philadelphia Museum of Art has been working double-overtime, installing Marcel Wanders: Daydreams, a multimedia exhibition that opens on Sunday. The exhibition, a retrospective of sorts of the Dutch design stars career, is Wanderss first solo show in the United States. Why Philadelphia? We asked him, said Kathy Hiesinger, the museums curator of European decorative arts. And to sweeten the deal, the museums modern design collaborative, Collab, will present Wanders with its Design Excellence Award on Saturday night.

title: Pain Relief Through Photography
description: Can looking at the photograph of a loved one make pain go away?

title: From the Left, Modest Praise for Senate Bill
description: Reaction to the Senate Democrats health care bill is starting to trickle in, now that various interest groups have had a little time to digest it. And even among some allies, the reaction is somewhat mixed.

title: K.S.M.s Day In Court
description: Im pretty sure I agree with Chuck Schumer on the subject:

title: Stimulus Under Scrutiny
description: The government official charged with monitoring the outlay of $787 billion in stimulus funds acknowledged on Thursday that he too found dubious the 640,000 jobs figure touted by the Obama administration as proof the stimulus was working.

title: Managing a Portfolio With Hedgeable.com
description: Update | 6:20 p.m. Mike Kane, Hedgeable.coms chief executive, said the company added a free rebalancing tool on Wednesday for investors who prefer to hold their investments for the long term. Investors can now receive email reminders  quarterly, annually, or another period  which will outline how much of each fund or security they need to buy or sell to rebalance back to their their original allocation.

title: Flat Holiday Hiring as Jobless Rate Holds at 10.3%
description: The usual preholiday hiring by stores did not happen in October as the citys unemployment rate held at 10.3 percent, its highest level in 16 years, the State Labor Department said on Thursday.

title: Intiman Theater Announces 2010 Season
description: Kate Whoriskeys first season as an artistic director of the Intiman Theater in Seattle will include a production of Ruined, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Lynn Nottage play that Ms. Whoriskey also directed in New York and Chicago. On Thursday, the Intiman announced that its 2010 season would open with a production of Clifford Odetss Paradise Lost, directed by Dmaso Rodriguez, which will begin previews on March 19 and open on March 26. The season will also feature Ruined (July 2 through Aug. 8) as the first play in a five-year International Cycle and Hawthornes Scarlet Letter adapted by Naomi Iizuka and directed by Lear deBessonet (Oct. 22 through Dec. 5) as the latest play in its American Cycle. Other productions include Molires A Doctor in Spite of Himself (Sept. 3-Oct. 10), adapted by Christopher Bayes and Steven Epp, and starring Daniel Breaker, a star of Shrek the Musical and Passing Strange (as well as Ms. Whoriskeys husband). Ms. Whoriskey is currently sharing artistic directing duties with Bartlett Sher, who is departing after this season.

title: Update: Cuts Come to BusinessWeek
description: While Bloomberg appears to be keeping a majority of the BusinessWeek workforce, about 100 of the magazines 400 or so employees have been cut.

title: U.C.s Fee Increase: Questions and Consequences
description: Today, the Board of Regents for the University of California voted to raise fees for undergraduates by 32 percent.

title: Sanford Sighting
description: LOST PINES, Texas  This has not been the easiest year for Mark Sanford, the governor of South Carolina. Mr. Sanford found himself entangled in a public tale about an affair. His wife ditched him. He is facing an ethics investigations back home. He has withstood calls to step down at home, instead deciding to wait out the end of his term (he is barred from seeing reelection by term limits). And he arguably has not been particularly good for the Republican brand.

title: A Reason to Check Your Withholding
description: Call it the case of a little tax credit that ended up a little too big.

title: Answers About Community Philanthropy, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of answers from Lorie A. Slutsky, president of the New York Community Trust, on community philanthropy, the value of many different approaches to charitable giving, and their importance in maintaining a strong democracy.

title: Suddenly, Iverson Could Be the Knicks Answer
description: Good news, Knicks fans: your team really is alive. It has a pulse and is actually breathing. The hierarchy has just been playing dead.

title: Trying to Outrun the Snow
description: Each passing day brings the hill country closer to a snow storm. Once it comes, the cabin will no longer be accessible by car or truck. The boots or snowshoes will have to come out.

title: Mia Feldbaum and Mark McGoldrick
description: MARK McGOLDRICK rocketed through his adolescence in Scottsdale, Ariz., on the highly combustible fuel of alcohol, drugs and trouble, he and his friends making impulsive trips in speeding cars. One ride ended in a car crash, leaving him paralyzed in his senior year in high school. Wiser but no less adventurous, he traveled extensively and graduated cum laude from Harvard Law School.

title: Opening Wide His (Repaired) Heart
description: IT was nearly midnight in an upscale Atlanta hotel room, and Robin Williams was decompressing after a show at the nearby Fox Theater. Reclining in his dimly lighted suite, he was weary but in good spirits; the mechanical key hidden in his back was winding down, and the flow of free associations and zany voices that relentlessly emanates from him was slowing to a trickle.

title: Leon Washington on Road to Recovery
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. - Jets running back Leon Washington has sought small victories during the early stages of rehab for his broken right leg. On Monday, he reached another milestone, taking his first shower in three weeks.

title: Manginos Seat Gets Hotter in Kansas
description: Kansas Coach Mark Manginos tenure seems a bit tenuous as the university looks into allegations that he verbally abused players and had physical contact with them, including poking linebacker Arist Wright in the chest during a walk-through practice in October.

title: Giuliani Is Said to Have Decided Against Run for N.Y. Governor
description: The Timess Danny Hakim learns that former New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani (and 2008 G.O.P. failed primary presidential contender) has decided not to seek the partys nomination in the 2010 gubernatorial race, citing people who have learned about his decision.

title: Lawmakers Call Ft. Hood Shootings Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON  A Senate committee on Thursday opened the first public hearings into the Fort Hood shootings, with several legislators asserting that the incident in which 13 people were killed was a terrorist attack by a homegrown extremist who may have slipped past law enforcement and military authorities.

title: Ireland Cites Uzbekistan-Bahrain Decision in Appeal
description: Seeking justice, and a spot in the World Cup in South Africa, the Football Association of Ireland has demanded a replay of the playoff with France, which ended in Frances favor after Thierry Henry handled the ball before passing to William Gallas for the score.

title: A New Term for Afghanistan's President
description: The Times's Kirk Kraeutler and Jane Bornemeier discuss the issue of corruption within President Hamid Karzai's administration.

title: Analyst Discounts Chances of Bank Breakup Plan
description: Representative Paul E. Kanjorskis amendment on government power to pre-emptively break up big banks may have passed a preliminary House committee vote on Wednesday, but Scott Valentin, the banking analyst at FBR Capital Markets, believes that there is little chance that the amendment in its current form will make it into the final bill that will go to President Obama.

title: Amsterdams Seedier Side Lands in London
description: An uninformed visitor entering Londons National Gallery might be a bit confused upon finding a dimly lit street with rubbish scattered about and bicycles on racks. But soon, that visitor becomes a voyeur of sorts: The Hoerengracht, an installation by Ed and Nancy Kienholz, on view at the Gallery until Feb. 21, is a life-size reconstruction of a section of Amsterdams infamous red-light district, complete with scantily dressed mannequins peering out of nicotine-stained rooms.

title: Edsel, 50 Years After Its Demise
description: It was 50 years ago Thursday that Ford announced it was ending production of the Edsel. Insert joke here.

title: Insurance Industry Criticizes Senate Bill
description: The insurance industry lobby is panning the Senate legislation.The lobbying group, Americas Health Insurance Plans, said in a statement on Thursday that the bill would increase costs for individuals, families and employers; reduce benefits for older Americans; and threaten employer coverage.

title: South African Runners Sex-Verification Result Wont Be Public
description: One of the most public and controversial cases of sex verification in sports has apparently been resolved, at least in part, but the answers to some important questions have not been made public.

title: Q&A: Hong Kong Highlights for Two 21-Year-Olds
description: Q.

title: Worth Saving | The Brixton Pound
description: In what is surely one of the more interesting convergences of economics and design in recent memory, the multiethnic, small-business-dominated London neighborhood of Brixton recently started printing its own currency. The idea for the Brixton pound was cooked up by Tim Nichols, who wanted to stimulate local commerce and study how wealth circulates when bank notes are confined to single districts. Transition Town Brixton, a community organization that addresses energy issues and climate change, also pitched in on the project, with the intention of encouraging local consumption and helping shrink carbon footprints.

title: Fox Apologizes for Second Incorrect Video Use
description: Fox News delivered an on-air apology to viewers Thursday after a second incident within a month when the news network illustrated a story by using video footage that was taken from a different event.

title: Performa 09: Mike Kelleys Extracurricular Activity
description: Mike Kelleys invigorating occasionally hilarious 75-minute performance piece Extracurricular Activity Projective Reconstruction #32, Plus, will play twice more (Thursday at 8 and 10 p.m.) at the Judson Church on Washington Square Park South. If you want to see the half-time entertainment at a high school basketball game through a glass darkly, or at least dimly, accompanied by a medley of popular musical styles, avail yourself.

title: Spots of Tranquillity Amid the Bustle
description: Emerge from the No. 7 train at Main Street in Flushing, and you will land on busy, jam-packed Chinatown streets with lots of colorful signs. You wont find much English, written or spoken, but you will find an oasis of great food and  odd, given all the bustle  plenty of opportunities to slow down and relax at herbal emporiums, tea shops and a tranquil botanical garden.

title: Performa 09: Black and White and Read in the Port Authority
description: In dire days for print journalism, it warms the heart to see a new newspaper appear. And one called, somewhat enigmatically, The First/Last Newspaper, began printing in Manhattan earlier this month. Its offices are a barren looking storefront on the Port Authority Bus Terminals Eighth Avenue side, as it happens diagonally across from The New York Times building.

title: Fidelity 401(k) Accounts Back to September 2008 Levels
description: Fidelity Investments said Thursday that the average balance for its customers 401(k) retirement accounts has returned to September 2008 levels.

title: Readers Confess: I Was an Adult Twi-Hard
description: Earlier on Thursday, we asked ArtsBeat readers if any would dare confess to being late-life Twilight converts. Amazingly, some of you admitted that you had been drawn into the romantic entanglements of Bella and Edward, despite your best efforts to resist. And some of you firmly insisted that neither a non-stop media blitz nor an all-out war between vampires and werewolves could get you to change your mind about the Twilight books and movies. Heres a sampling of the comments we received:

title: Senate Confirms Judge to Appeals Court
description: After a protracted partisan struggle, the Senate voted 59-39 on Thursday to confirm Judge David F. Hamilton to a seat on the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals.

title: The Sound of Music Turns 50
description: Fifty years ago this week, a nun-in-training, seven frisky kids and their grumpy but lovable father do-re-mid their way across a Broadway stage.

title: BigDeal Puts a New Spin on Entertainment Shopping
description: Update | 7:36 p.m.  Corrected spelling of Nicolas Darveau-Garneaus name in one instance.

title: General Growth Reaches Accord With Lenders
description: General Growth Properties, the giant mall operator that filed for bankruptcy in April, said Thursday that it had reached an agreement with its lenders to extend loan maturities on 70 loans and, in turn, those lenders would get all their money back.

title: Invisible bond vigilantes
description: Back in 1993, James Carville  frustrated over the way fear of rising interest rates was crimping the Clinton agenda  declared,

title: Study Shows Link Between Segregation and Subprime Loans
description: Researchers at New York University who examined the relationship between subprime lending and race released a report on Thursday that found that the probability that individual borrowers receive risky, high-cost subprime loans increases depending on the racial composition of the neighborhood or metropolitan area where they live.

title: Lets Go to the Tape
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuban Blogger Posts Interview With Obama
description: Cuban blogger Yoani Snchez.

title: Alicia Keys Finds Her Own Empire State of Mind
description: Hey, have you heard that Jay-Z song Empire State of Mind? Maybe at Yankee Stadium, if not in every subway station and loud avenue in the entire city? You know, its the one where Jay says how great he is, and talks about the rough old neighborhood in Brooklyn. No, not that one. No, not that other one, either. Its the one with the Alicia Keys chorus, soaring as high as a skyscraper: These streets will make you feel brand new/Big lights will inspire you/Lets hear it for New York, New York, New Yooooork!

title: A New Look at Overparenting
description: The many of you who nodded in agreement at my essay The End of Overparenting back in May will also find affirmation in the Time magazine cover story that reaches newsstands tomorrow. In Can These Parents Be Saved? Nancy Gibbs explores the same territory at greater length, concluding:

title: Stemming Drinking on College Game Days
description: In todays Sports section, Pat Borzi writes about a new program at the University of Minnesota to prevent binge drinking before football games:

title: Malcolm Gladwell Responds to Steven Pinker
description: Steven Pinkers recent review of Malcolm Gladwells What the Dog Saw prompted a flurry of response in the blogosphere.

title: A Walk Among Vanished Guideposts
description: IN the middle of fourth grade, the spring of 1960, my mother allowed me to walk home from the Browning School at 62nd Street and Park Avenue to our apartment house at 56th and Sutton Place.

title: Shrunken Cameras
description: David Pogue reviews two new cameras that have had camera aficionados' palms sweating for months: the Canon PowerShot S90 ($412) and the Panasonic Lumix GF1 ($870).

title: The Case for a Job-Creation Tax Credit
description: John H. Bishop, a professor at Cornell Universitys Industrial and Labor Relations School, was co-author of a recent proposal on temporary job-creation tax credit published by the Economic Policy Institute.

title: On Our Radar
description: 1) A dim view of the United States-China electric car plan.

title: A Permanent Theater Festival on Puget Sound
description: SEATTLE LIKE a reminder of theaters past, the face of the playwright August Wilson stares out from a gleaming glass door set in a 12-foot steel portal at the top of August Wilson Way here, a sloping side street behind the Seattle Repertory Theater.

title: Gauging the Thirst for Advance New Moon Tickets
description: How many sold-out screenings are there already for The Twilight Saga: New Moon? Its hard to say: MovieTickets.com and Summit Entertainment, the studio behind the wildly successful franchise, have made the unusual decision to stop releasing information.

title: Time Is Right for Hedge Funds, Manager Says
description: Despite a tough run for hedge funds last year, at least one manager believes a number of factors have combined to create an attractive environment for hedge fund investing.

title: A Dinner to Make Even Futurists Happy
description: I was lucky enough to be invited to this wacky dinner back in June, organized for Slate (and now featured in ReadyMade) by the writer Kate Bolick and the artist Karen Azoulay, with the idea of celebrating the 100th anniversary of the Futurist movement. The Futurists had ideas about food (and other things) that smack of Ferran Adria and Grant Achatz, and the two women had the idea not to recreate the actual recipes from the somewhat tongue-in-cheek Futurist Cookbook of 1932 (note very cool image here ), but the spirit of the same.

title: BlogTalk: Miranda Rights and Health Care
description: Much of the blog discussion today is about the Senate Democrats proposal to overhaul the health care system, which was released late yesterday. Coming in at 2,000-plus pages, the document, available here, would be hard for anyone to read in its entirety between now and Thanksgiving. So well lead you to some thoughtful discussions on the blogs about what to look for and how to analyze it in a while.

title: Patient Voices: Rheumatoid Arthritis
description: Pain, inflammation and severe joint damage - rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic disease that can affect both adults and children. Here, six men and women speak about their experiences.

title: A New Westin Each Week
description: The hotel industry may be suffering, but you wouldnt know it by looking at the lineup of new Westin Hotels. Starting today, the upscale chain is planning to open about one hotel a week for the rest of the year.

title: Large Hadron Collider to Restart
description: The champagne is in the refrigerator.

title: Attention Shifts to China for Private Equity Industry
description: SHANGHAI  A few weeks ago, Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chairman of the Blackstone Group, the worlds biggest private equity firm, signed a joint venture here with Shanghais municipal government, creating the first Blackstone fund denominated entirely in Chinese currency.

title: iPols
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  When the latest Sarah Palin sugar high wears off, leaving behind a new round of intraparty feuds and a woman with deep Nixonian grievances, Republicans can turn to California for a glimpse at another kind of future.

title: Western Men Are Doomed
description: David Brooks: Gail, I dont know if you had a chance to see my column Tuesday, but China always gets me thinking big. I look at the long history and bright future of that civilization-state and suddenly youve got to chase me down with a butterfly net to impose the grip of reality on my grandiose and free-floating ideas. Its runaway Spengler Syndrome.

title: Hoffman Claims Voter Fraud
description: The Conservative Party candidate who conceded defeat in New Yorks 23rd district is taking it all back.

title: The Guggenheim Grows a Restaurant
description: Details are thin on the ground at the moment, but based on an invitation to a preview that came by e-mail this afternoon its apparent that a new restaurant, named The Wright, is going to open in the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, at 1071 Fifth Avenue. Given the name, the location and the fact that they are going to the expense of giving a preview party, Im going to speculate that this will be something a little more grand than the cafeteria at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. (Although the food there is not bad.)

title: Introducing Opinionator
description: What is Opinionator?

title: Spots of Tranquillity Amid the Bustle
description: Emerge from the No. 7 train at Main Street in Flushing, and you will land on busy, jam-packed Chinatown streets with lots of colorful signs. You wont find much English, written or spoken, but you will find an oasis of great food and  odd, given all the bustle  plenty of opportunities to slow down and relax at herbal emporiums, tea shops and a tranquil botanical garden.

title: The Pregame Huddle: Coaches Under Fire
description: While Jim Harbaugh has Stanford flying high, other high-profile coaches like Charlie Weis and Rich Rodriguez are taking heat.

title: Though Dells Profit Slips, Its Outlook Turns Brighter
description: Once lauded for its nimble operations and quick decision-making, Dell continues to suffer from a sweeping reorganization that resembles something of an endurance test for investors.

title: CF Industries and Agrium Trade More Shots
description: The Forever War goes on  at least for now.

title: Sounds During Sleep Aid Memory, Study Finds
description: Science has never given much credence to claims that you can learn Chinese or French by having the instruction CDs play while you sleep. If any learning happens that way, most scientists say, the language lesson is probably waking the sleeper up, not causing nouns and verbs to seep into a sound-asleep mind.

title: History, Sun-Drenched
description: THERES old Florida  and then theres really old Florida. St. Augustine, the oldest permanent European settlement in the continental United States and a city of about 12,500 residents, was settled by the Spanish in 1565.

title: Crosby Enjoys the Lighter Side of the Olympics
description: Sidney Crosby was all smiles when he carried the Olympic torch in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Wednesday night, which is barely a torch run away from his hometown of Cole Harbour. He wore the official torchbearers sweatsuit, ran about 300 yards and lit the torch of the snowboarder Sarah Conrad.

title: Who You Gonna Call? Thanksgiving 911
description: Im preheating the oven up here in the Dining kitchen, getting ready for the Thanksgiving holiday, getting ready to man the battle stations for The New York Times Thanksgiving Help Desk. I will be with you through most of the big day itself. Need help with the bird, the stuffing, the sides, the gravy, the wine, how to say grace (whether to say grace!), the timing, the desserts, the fact that you said youd make butternut squash and now youre looking at the things and realize you have no idea how to make butternut squash? The New York Times Thanksgiving Help Desk is here to help. Post a question below. Ill answer it, until 3 p.m next Thursday. Watch for the later postings on Diners Journal for my responses.

title: The Fight Continues, on the Today Show
description: Kim Severson and Julia Moskin will make their cases for which matters more at Thanksgiving, the sides or the turkey, Friday morning at 8:45 on NBCs Today. The hosts will be their judges. Diners Journal hopes to have the video later on Friday.

title: Cranberry-Orange Relish
description: This sweet and tart relish, affectionately named pucker-up cranberry relish by my friends, is much more refreshing than commercial cooked relish and takes about as long to make as it does to open a can. Leftovers are great for breakfast, with plain yogurt. The cranberry-orange combo is very high in vitamin C, much of which is lost in cooked cranberry sauce.

title: At Ad Council Dinner, Tart Humor From Tina Fey
description: Despite, or perhaps because of, the serious messages of many Advertising Council campaigns  which focus on topics as varied as teen dating violence and hunger in America  the group offered some comic relief at its annual dinner Wednesday night by inviting Tina Fey to host the event, at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: New Data Shed Light on Large-Animal Extinction
description: Whenever modern humans reached a new continent in the expansion from their African homeland 50,000 years ago, whether Australia, Europe or the Americas, all the large fauna quickly disappeared.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Nov. 19
description: President Obama wrapped up his trip to Asia on Thursday, without reporting any major policy breakthroughs. Among other news throughout the world, a suicide bomber caused death and injuries in Peshawar, Pakistan (Slides 4-5), and Britain braced for severe weather (Slide 7). In the United States, the architect Frank Gehry attended a ceremony at the Beekman Tower in Lower Manhattan (Slide 10), with his building scheduled to be completed in 2011.

title: Private Equity Shifts Its Attention to China
description: A few weeks ago, Stephen A. Schwarzman, left, the chairman of the Blackstone Group, the worlds biggest private equity firm, came to Shanghai to sign a deal with the municipal government and create the first Blackstone fund denominated entirely in Chinese currency, a $732 million venture fund, The New York Timess David Barboza reports from Shanghai.

title: A People-Oriented Piece, Featuring Kierkegaard
description: Wally Cardona refers to Really Real, a new work performed on Tuesday night at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, as his people piece. Yet while there are many bodies in it, the idea mainly speaks to what is absent. In recent years Mr. Cardona has relied heavily on props, filling the stage with objects to create an architectural landscape; the dancers often seemed like accessories, and the choreography was dictated by their relationship to the set.

title: Senate Health Care Bill Faces Crucial First Vote
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate version of sweeping health legislation would cover five million fewer people than a companion bill passed by the House, but it would cost less, in part because Senate Democratic leaders felt they had to win support from fiscally conservative members of their party.

title: For the Volt, Hows Life After 40 (Miles)?
description: Milford, Mich.

title: Comeback for Furniture at Carnegie Museum
description: The furniture galleries at the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh used to plod chronologically from medieval chests and Renaissance tapestries to Rococo chairs and early-19th-century clocks. Material was separated by nationality (mostly British, French and American) and set on pedestals in rows. The galleries, closed for a decade and used for storage, reopen on Saturday and now explore design trends that spread globally during the last five centuries, as well as some unsung, innovative furniture produced in Pittsburgh.

title: An Upstart Art Scene, on Atlantas West Side
description: THE warehouses and industrial buildings to the west of Midtown Atlanta have not had the benefit of a concerted attempt by the city at urban revitalization. Instead, the West Side has lately given rise to a sort of ad hoc group of contemporary art galleries that have styled themselves as a more intellectual alternative to the citys designated downtown art district, Castleberry Hill.

title: A Place in Time, Not All Frozen
description: Matanuska Glacier, Alaska  THE temperature was soaring to 75 degrees, and I was walking on ice. Around me the Matanuska Glacier, about 100 miles from Anchorage, sparkled and shimmered in the afternoon sun. The only sound was an occasional rush of cool wind sweeping down from the towering Chugach Mountains and the crunch of my crampons as I made my way up a crevasse with a group of six other trekkers.

title: You Know That Chicken Is Chicken, Right?
description: When you sit down to eat sushi or grilled sea bass, do you stop and think about Nemo the cartoon fish and his chatty little friends? When you order Chicken McNuggets at McDonalds, do you picture Chicken Little fretting that the sky might fall? When you gorge yourself on spare ribs with barbecue sauce, do you pause to remember Babe the movie pig or Wilbur from Charlottes Web?

title: Challenging the Laws of Physics
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y.

title: An Intimate Concert, With Original Instruments
description: The American Classical Orchestra, an original-instrument ensemble celebrating its 25th anniversary this season, presented a concert on Wednesday night at the New York Society for Ethical Culture conducted by its founding director, Thomas Crawford. I liked almost everything about the program: the informed, earnest and lively if sometimes scrappy performances; the alluring tonal qualities of the period instruments, especially the mellow strings and the dark reedy woodwinds; the chance to hear a titanic work like Mozarts Jupiter Symphony played in an intimate hall.

title: A Newly Stylish Amman Asserts Itself
description: ARENT you going to check out the terrace? Madian al-Jazerah said to me.

title: Hopper Whopper | 400 Shots of the Sixties
description: One night in the mid-1970s, after fighting with his girlfriend, a drug-crazed Dennis Hopper picked up a machine gun and fired a few dozen rounds into the adobe walls of his house in Taos, N.M. We know about this incident because the longtime curator Walter Hopps was in Taos on that night, trying to secure a trove of Hoppers artwork for a charity auction. (At the time, Hopper was drowning in back taxes, and needed an I.R.S. deduction almost as badly as detox.)

title: Flashback! The Fastback Is Back
description: ROOFLINES, as important for car designers as necklines and hemlines are for fashion designers, are suddenly changing. The hottest new style did not show up simply on a whim.

title: Glass Looks to the Heavens, Again
description: Philip Glass clearly enjoys examining ideas from just about every angle, and that applies as fully to opera subjects as to specific musical moves. His earliest operas, for example, were about historical figures who changed the way their societies thought: Einstein, in Einstein on the Beach; Gandhi, in Satyagraha; and the monotheistic Egyptian pharaoh, Akhnaten, in the opera that bears his name.

title: Art in Review
description: CARL FREDRIK HILL

title: Museums Gems Go for a Spin
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Abstinence Makes the Heart ... Oh, You Know
description: The big tease turns into the long goodbye in The Twilight Saga: New Moon, the juiceless, near bloodless sequel about a teenage girl and the sparkly vampire she, like, totally loves. When last we saw Bella (Kristen Stewart) and her pretty dead guy, Edward (Robert Pattinson), in Twilight  the series hadnt been saga-fied yet  the two had pledged their troth, a chaste commitment solidified during moody walks in the woods, some exhilarating treetop scrambling and a knockdown fight with a pack of vamping vampires.

title: Brees to Obama, Touchdown
description: Heres something that doesnt happen very often to Troy Polamalu: he got beaten for a touchdown. By the president of the United States.

title: A Bit of Jive Stands Out at a Tribute to Mercer
description: Because it described Army life during World War II in bebop slang, Johnny Mercers G.I. Jive, one of the few songs for which he wrote both words and music, usually isnt regarded as one of his great perennials, although it was a No. 1 hit for Louis Jordan and his Tympany Five in 1944.

title: I Ordered the Ants!
description: While finishing a meal at a French restaurant that we frequent, I spotted a three-inch water bug making its way down a wall, inches from my 14-year-old daughters head. Happily, the bug ducked into a crevice.

title: Now Serving | When in Maialino  (Recipe Included)
description: At Maialino in the Gramercy Park Hotel, Danny Meyer, the C.E.O. of the Union Square Hospitality Group, rather bashfully explained that opening a restaurant is a lot like having a child: the conceiving is fun, but the pregnancy and birth arent easy. The first couple of weeks after the baby is born, when youre not sleeping through the night, you think, What the heck did I do? But in time, it becomes so gratifying that you actually consider doing it all over again. Meyer would know; he has opened 14 dining establishments and has four children.

title: Saints at a Cultural Crossroads
