description: At monasteries on Mount Athos in northern Greece, you wake in the night to the sound of Greek Orthodox monks chanting Byzantine prayers. Its an unforgettable sound, distant and unearthly, but also inside you, like a buzz in the blood.

title: Edible Walls of Green
description: Innovative planters enable efficient growth of vegetation on vertical surfaces.

title: Shelby Opposes Dodds Financial Regulatory Bill
description: Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, the ranking Republican on the Senate Banking Committee, said Thursday that he would vote against the financial regulatory bill proposed last week by Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat who is the committees chairman, setting the stage for what could be a contentious and drawn-out set of negotiations.

title: Twilight by the Numbers
description: Total number of books by Stephenie Meyer sold worldwide: over 70 million

title: Oreo, Abused Then Euthanized, Inspires Legislation
description: In the final hours before Oreo was put to death, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals was inundated with pleas to spare her life. Oreo, a pit bull, was nursed back to health after being thrown off the roof of a building only to later be deemed too dangerous to be kept alive.

title: Almodvars Happy Agony, Swirling Amid Jealousy and Revenge
description: Can there be such a thing as exuberant melancholy? I cant think of another way to describe the spirit of Broken Embraces, Pedro Almodvars latest film, the title of which carries a telling hint of paradox. It is grave and effervescent, tender and cruel.

title: Inside the List
description: STORMY WEATHER I: Im a sucker for tales of extreme weather, so my curiosity was piqued by Linda Howards Ice, new at No. 8 on the hardcover fiction list. (Amazon.coms recommendation algorithm apparently knows me well: When I looked up Ice, it also tried to sell me Howards Burn, Sandra Browns Rainwater and Julie Garwoods Sizzle.) Howard (inset), who lives in Alabama and is married to a professional bass tournament fisherman, has made almost a dozen appearances on the list, starting with Everlasting Love (1995). The new book is about a small-town cops son who finds himself trapped in the winter woods while protecting a local damsel in distress from a cold-blooded killer. Igloo-melting romance ensues, of course, not to mention the immortal line: Lollipop, can I lick you?

title: Mercurial Jester, Revealing and Concealing
description: One no longer remembers where Mr. Ray was born. After having been a coal merchant, a millionaire several times over and the chairman of a chewing-gum trust, he decided he was open to the Dadaists invitation to show his latest paintings in Paris.

title: Santa Claus at Risk of Swine Flu
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: and Little Optimism
description: In Kabul and in the provinces, those who watched President Hamid Karzais inauguration to a second term viewed the event with skepticism, and many did not watch at all.

title: K.K.R. Posts First Profit as a Public Company
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts began life as a publicly traded company by reporting a $656.6 million profit for its third quarter, a sharp turnaround from a $465.6 million loss one year ago.

title: Is Goldmans Charitable Gesture Enough?
description: When Goldman Sachs said this week that it was starting a $500 million charitable project to help 10,000 small businesses  a sum that represents 3 percent of the $16 billion the firm has set aside so far for employee compensation this year  the announcement was widely seen as a public relations move. The firms chairman, Lloyd Blankfein, who had earlier stoked popular anger when he said Goldman was doing Gods work in its business, also apologized for participating in things that were clearly wrong. A recent audit found that the government bailout of A.I.G., the insurance company, resulted in billions of dollars of benefit to Goldman Sachs.

title: A Green Wave
description: A California start-up uses recycled material in their surfboard blanks, from which finished boards are carved.

title: A New Orleans Mystery: A Cop So Bad, Hes Good
description: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans  what an ungainly title for a movie. What does it mean? What kind of sense does it make? You might ask the same questions of the film itself, directed by Werner Herzog and related, by some equally puzzling movie-business genealogy, to another Bad Lieutenant, Abel Ferraras 1992 tour of New York law-enforcement hell. Neither remake nor sequel, this Bad Lieutenant is its own special fever-swamp of a movie, an anarchist film noir that seems, at times, almost as unhinged as its protagonist.

title: Oprah Winfrey to End Her Talk Show
description: The media mogul Oprah Winfrey will end her daytime talk show, The Oprah Winfrey Show, in 2011 as she prepares to start a cable channel of her own.

title: Restaurant Review: Estado Puro in Madrid
description: A hotel tapas bar located smack in the middle of one of Madrids busiest tourist hubs? Easy to pass up, perhaps. But then I took a closer look. An artfully stylized pattern of filigree mantilla combs  the restaurants logo  covered the ceiling and swept down the wall. The menu promised the classics, but with more than a whiff of innovation. I was hooked.

title: Hotel Review: Copley Square Hotel in Boston
description: THE BASICS

title: Hotels Blossoming in Berlin
description: CASA CAMPER, a 51-room hotel in the Mitte district of Berlin, was fully booked when it opened on Sept. 15. The hotel, run by the Spanish urban clothing label Camper, drew a youthful clientele that included fashionable Europeans in party mode and Monocle magazine-toting business travelers who would never stay at a prosaic hotel.

title: Oscar Short List of Documentaries Draws Controversy
description: LOS ANGELES  Tyson, a critically acclaimed movie about the boxer Mike Tyson, was not among 15 feature documentaries that qualified on Wednesday for possible Oscar nominations, and James Toback, the filmmaker behind it, is fighting mad.

title: House Democrats Approve Doc Fix
description: The House on Thursday approved a $210 billion measure to avert steep cuts in Medicare payments to doctors.

title: Carlyle Group to Run Connecticut Rest Stops
description: The Carlyle Group said Thursday that it had signed a deal with Connecticut to refurbish and run the states 23 highway service stops in return for a share of their revenues over the next 35 years.

title: Lost to Return in February for Its Final Season
description: The sixth and final season of Lost, the ABC castaway mystery, will begin on Feb. 2, when the series moves to Tuesday nights for the first time.

title: Google Says It Doesnt Want to Be a Utility
description: From Green Inc.:

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 8 about the Alto Alentejo region of Portugal misidentified the person buried in a tomb at the Convento da Flor da Rosa, now a pousada, where guests can stay. The pousada houses the tomb of lvaro Gonalves Pereira  not Nuno lvares Pereira, who was one of his sons.

title: The Mets Finished Last in 2009 Draft Spending
description: How much money the Mets intend to lavish on free agents to fill their many needs is unclear. What is clear is that the Mets, during a dreadful season and increased criticism of their minor league system, spent less money on the 2009 draft than any other team in baseball, according to figures compiled by Baseball America.

title: Geithner Pledges a Quick End to TARP
description: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said Thursday that the government would end its $700 billion bailout program as soon as we can, and that part of the money would be used to lower the record deficit.

title: Bourgeois Bohemians, Theres a Price to Pay
description: Dont hate them because theyre beautiful. Dont hate them because theyre thin and young and glowing with health. Dont hate them because they live in a fabulous New York loft and have jobs that seem to give their lives meaning and, in one case, will soon make them wealthy. And especially dont hate them because they have a little girl and  because Mommy wants to work as hard and as much as Daddy does  they employ a live-in nanny. Well, go ahead and hate them a little because they have a nanny. In fact, hate them a lot.

title: Theater Listings: Nov. 20  26
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: P.E.T.A. Eyes Prison Makeover
description: An idea you dont see every day: The intersection of P.E.T.A. and Guantnamo Bay.

title: The Indie Music Pillars of Athens, Greece
description: DUSK was descending softly on Athens as the sounds of bass-heavy noise pop drifted across Karitsi Square, a tucked-away cobblestone oasis near the city center. In the outside seating area of Use Bar (Karitsi Square 5; 30-210-323-5993), two tables of artist types were discussing a recent show by the local dark-wave band Phoenix Catscratch. Later, throngs of young men and women sporting skinny jeans and asymmetrical haircuts would fill the square and seep down winding Kolokotroni Street into a slew of new bars, galleries and other spots catering to the citys growing indie and post-alternative scene.

title: Heart of a Small Town, Vast in Its Loneliness
description: Two fresh-faced fishermen, wearing solemn expressions and suspenders, sit on a riverbank, looking as if they were waiting for Norman Rockwell to show up with his easel. Youre on your own now, one of them says.

title: Letter: Library Treasures
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article Rare Books Dont Always Live in Glass Cases (Nov. 1) on lesser-known libraries with extraordinary collections. I was reminded of the detour-worthy art collection housed in the library of my hometown, Charles City, Iowa, population about 7,500. The public library was bequeathed an important collection of works on paper in 1941.

title: Letter: The Ridgeway Trail
description: To the Editor: The Ridgeway Trail (Hiking Into History, Nov. 1) in England has the mixture of nature, history, geology and village life that makes for extraordinary hiking and that seems to be missing in the trails in the United States. The United States seems to excel in wilderness trails that dont have a hint of the domesticity described by Henry Shukman. However, its the contrast between the exertion needed to hike and the luxury of a village inn that brings the greatest pleasure.

title: A World of Macabre Misfits
description: Tim Burtons career is the ultimate revenge of the art nerd. Mr. Burton, the self-professed alienated child of a dysfunctional family in Burbank, Calif., who funneled his loneliness, pain and grief into drawing cartoons, has found fame, fortune and a beautiful companion (Helena Bonham Carter) by telling cinematic tales of sensitive misfits triumphing over, or succumbing to, a world of repressive mediocrity.

title: Nickelodeons Stepchild, Eager for More Love
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.

title: Bloggingheads: Aimless War?
description: Andrew Bacevich, left, of Boston Univeristy and David Frum of FrumForum debate President Obama's Afghanistan strategy.

title: Gender Switch in Illyria, With Players 8 Inches Tall
description: Orsino emerges from a giant silver ice bucket. Sir Toby Belch and Sir Andrew Aguecheek straddle huge liquor bottles. Olivia makes an entrance in a loving cup big enough to hold her and a friend. Luckily, all the characters are played by eight-inch-tall marionettes; otherwise the set design budget would have been a monster.

title: Malone Wont Rule Out Phone Deal for DirecTV
description: John C. Malone, the chairman of the DirecTV Group, is not ruling out a possible takeover of his company by AT&T or Verizon Communications, saying they would probably have closer ties to DirecTV as they develop packages of phone and television service.

title: Crime Pays for CBS
description: CBS finished first in the ratings on Wednesday with a crime-filled lineup. The networks Criminal Minds drew 13.5 million viewers and CSI: NY grabbed 13.7 million, according to Nielsens estimates. ABC was second with its comedies, including Modern Family (9.2 million), as well as a news special, In the Spotlight With Robin Roberts, featuring an interview with Janet Jackson (6.6 million). NBC finished in third place with Mercy (7.8 million), Law & Order: SVU (8.4 million) and The Jay Leno Show (4.8 million). Fox was fourth with So You Think You Can Dance (5.7 million) followed by Glee (7.3 million).

title: China Helps the Powerful in Namibia
description: BEIJING  Like parents everywhere, mothers and fathers in Namibia, an impoverished southern African nation, worry about college costs and opportunities for their children. The Chinese government has stepped forward to help  for a select and powerful few.

title: U.S. Teaches Carmakers Capitalism
description: When the American auto industry was owned by investors, it acted like a government enterprise.

title: Panel Sees No Need for A-Bomb Upgrade
description: In a new report, a secretive federal panel has concluded that programs to extend the life of the nations aging nuclear arms are sufficient to guarantee their destructiveness for decades to come, obviating a need for a costly new generation of more reliable warheads.

title: Gateses Give $290 Million for Education
description: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation on Thursday announced its biggest education donation in a decade, $290 million, in support of three school districts and five charter groups working to transform how teachers are evaluated and how they get tenure.

title: Panel Votes to Broaden Oversight of the Fed
description: WASHINGTON  In a display of populist anger toward the Federal Reserve, a House panel voted on Thursday to let Congress carry out sweeping new oversights of the central banks policy decisions and operations.

title: On the Green or In the Park?
description: Could it be called Tavern in the Park?

title: For Tavern Name, a Backup Plan
description: Could it be called Tavern in the Park?

title: For Tavern Name, a Backup Plan
description: Could it be called Tavern in the Park?

title: Watchdog Urges Caution on Claims of 640,000 Stimulus Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  The government watchdog overseeing the federal stimulus program testified Thursday that he could not vouch for the Obama administrations recent claims that the money had saved or created 640,000 jobs. He suggested that the administration should have treated the number with more skepticism.

title: For Citi, Less Sting From a Painful Bet
description: Citigroup stopped dancing to the music of the credit boom shortly after it backed the leveraged buyout of EMI, the British music company, in 2007.

title: Not Taking Not Hiring for an Answer
description: BABY boomers have lived during an era of unparalleled prosperity. So when this deep recession hit  at a time when boomers were advancing to middle- and late-middle age  much was written about them being too spoiled to cope.

title: Japans Fleet Departs to Hunt 900 Whales
Fire Reveals Illegal Homes Hide in Plain Sight
description: For at least two years before a fire killed three men in an illegally divided house next door, Diane Ross and her family lived in an illegal apartment at 42-38 65th Street in Woodside, Queens.

title: The Jonas Brothers Promote Xbox 360
description: ITS all in the family, Madison Avenue style: a product aimed at families is teaming up with a famous name in family entertainment for an elaborate effort fronted by one of the biggest family acts in music.

title: Gay Spouses Due Benefits in the State, Court Finds
description: ALBANY  The states highest court on Thursday upheld policies giving some government benefits to same-sex couples who are legally married outside the state, but did not rule on whether gay marriage should be legal in New York, leaving that issue for the Legislature to decide.

title: Pentagon to Review Shootings at Fort Hood
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday announced a Pentagon review of the shootings at Ford Hood, Tex., to help ensure, he said, that nothing like this ever happens again.

title: Google Offers Peek at Operating System, a Potential Challenge to Windows
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Google began lifting the veil on its planned Chrome operating system on Thursday, but it said that computers powered by the software would not be available for a year.

title: Suit Accuses Hartford Courant of Plagiarism
description: Newspapers have tried many ways to cover the news with dwindling resources: dropping certain topics, having people do double duty, using more wire service work. Routine plagiarism is not usually an option, but a lawsuit contends that it was for a while at The Hartford Courant.

title: Industrialized Nations Unveil Plans to Rein in Emissions
description: With less than three weeks remaining before negotiators gather in Copenhagen to hammer out a global response to climate change, a rapid-fire succession of countries are unveiling national plans that serve as opening bids for reining in heat-trapping emissions.

title: Sex Offenses on the Subways Are Widespread, City Officials Are Told
description: The peak times in which women report sexual harassment or assaults on the subways are the late morning rush, roughly 8 to 10 a.m., followed by the early afternoon rush, 4 to 6 p.m.

title: South Korea Trade Pact Is Revived by Obama
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama opened a potentially bruising battle within the Democratic party on Thursday when he pledged to complete a long-stalled trade agreement with South Korea that he inherited from President George W. Bush.

title: Steamrolling Over Lifes Obstacles With Family as Cheerleaders
description: One of the many turning points in The Blind Side  a movie made up almost entirely of turning points and yet curiously devoid of drama or suspense  comes during a Memphis high school football game. Michael Oher, the offensive tackle whose remarkable life is the subject of the film (and of the nonfiction best seller on which it is based), is having trouble protecting his quarterback.

title: Air Defense Push Inspired by 9/11 Gets a 2nd Look
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  The commander of military forces protecting North America has ordered a review of the costly air defenses intended to prevent another Sept. 11-style terrorism attack, an assessment aimed at determining whether the commitment of jet fighters, other aircraft and crews remains justified.

title: The Pick-and-Roll Is the N.B.A.s Old Reliable
description: With the basketball in his hands, Orlandos Jameer Nelson performs the two-man two-step that the Magic and the entire N.B.A. have sought to perfect.

title: Governors Dont Call This Home
description: It is a 20-room Greek Revival mansion, with Italian gardens, a music room and a wood-paneled library. But no one seems to want to live in Drumthwacket, the governors residence in Princeton Township, N.J.

title: Film Series and Movie Listings
description: MOVIES

title: Can Iverson Restore Hope for Knicks?
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Four months ago, Allen Iverson was a free agent in search of a team. The Knicks were weak at point guard, devoid of star power and looking listless after a 32-win season. Yet Iverson never made their call list.

title: Pakistani Politics Take on a Nationalist Tone
It Figures: Lincecum Captures Cy Young
description: When the Cy Young Award was introduced in 1956, the voting was simple. Baseball writers voted for one pitcher, and that was that.

title: Treasury to Auction Off Big-Bank Warrants
description: A year after the federal government rescued the nations financial industry, the Treasury Department announced Thursday that it would auction off its remaining investments in three large banks, freeing the lenders from the federal bailout program.

title: In New Orleans, Elation Over Katrina Liability Ruling
description: NEW ORLEANS  Since the first days after Hurricane Katrina, when the streets were still under water, many residents of New Orleans and its surroundings have maintained that the flood that wrecked their lives was the governments fault, and that the government should pay for it.

title: Flights of Mind, Brought to Life
description: Some of the models have the comforting feel of old acquaintance: the twisting, screw-like sail of a flying machine; the armored revolving saucer with cannons protruding through its port holes; the arched bridge that can swing aside for ship traffic. These wood, rope and cloth reproductions, along with glimpses of mirror-reversed Italian script on sheets marked by doodles and sketches  who could miss the distinctive traces left by the artist, inventor and scientist for whom the term Renaissance man seems custom made?

title: Anglican Leader Defends Faith as Vatican Welcomes His Members
description: ROME  When the Vatican announced last month that it was creating a new Anglican rite within the Roman Catholic Church aimed at Anglicans uncomfortable with the ordination of women and gay clergy members, a headline in a British newspaper read, Rome Parks Tanks on Rowans Lawn.

title: A Misunderstood Alien, but Not as Smart as E.T.
description: The agreeable but flagrantly unoriginal Planet 51 belongs to the mix-and-match school of animated moviemaking that operates on the plaintive hope that familiarity is the surest path to the box office. Almost every element of the film, created by Ilion Animation Studios, based in Madrid, is borrowed from earlier films, then tweaked (and invariably softened) to become a reference rather than a copy.

title: Obama Has a Job for Dana Perino. Really.
description: From the Department of Unlikely Events: George W. Bushs press secretary has been asked to serve in the Obama administration.

title: The Big Squander
description: Earlier this week, the inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program, a k a, the bank bailout fund, released his report on the 2008 rescue of the American International Group, the insurer. The gist of the report is that government officials made no serious attempt to extract concessions from bankers, even though these bankers received huge benefits from the rescue. And more than money was lost. By making what was in effect a multibillion-dollar gift to Wall Street, policy makers undermined their own credibility  and put the broader economy at risk.

title: For Bruno, How Albany Works Is Also on Trial
description: ALBANY  The longtime secretary for one of the most powerful politicians in New York spent as much time on his private business, handling bills and correspondence, as she did on his public duties, like arranging meetings with lawmakers.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,354 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Thursday:

title: Michigan Football Facing Hard Times on the Field and Off It
description: Late last week, Bruce Springsteen took the stage at a sports arena north of Detroit and greeted his Michigan audience with a cheerful Hello, Ohio!

title: Ouster of N.F.L.s Voice on Concussions Sought
description: The National Football League Players Association is calling for the removal of Dr. Ira Casson as co-chairman of the leagues committee on concussions, saying that he is too biased to lead the research and policy group.

title: A Crown Jewel of Education Struggles With Cuts
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  As the University of California struggles to absorb its sharpest drop in state financing since the Great Depression, every professor, administrator and clerical worker has been put on furlough amounting to an average pay cut of 8 percent.

title: Reid, as Legislative Tactician, Takes Ownership of Health Care Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  Now it is Senator Harry Reids health care bill.

title: With F.H.A. Help, Easy Loans in Expensive Areas
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In January, Mike Rowland was so broke that he had to raid his retirement savings to move here from Boston.

title: With Ankle in a Brace, Wie Quits After a 72
description: RICHMOND, Tex.  Now that Michelle Wie had found her footing, not much was supposed to slow her down. She barely broke stride Thursday on the first fairway when she hiked up her left pant leg on the opening hole to show her playing partner, Christina Kim, the black brace wrapped around her ankle.

title: Strauss, Neapolitan Tunes and a Festive Singalong
description: A chorus of bravos greeted the soprano Aprile Millo as she swept regally onto the stage at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Tuesday evening. Ms. Millo was making her New York recital debut and celebrating the 25th anniversary of her first appearance with the Opera Orchestra of New York, which presented the concert.

title: Immigration Officials to Audit 1,000 More Companies
description: WASHINGTON  Immigration enforcement officials said Thursday that they were expanding a program for auditing companies that might have hired illegal immigrants and had notified 1,000 companies this week that they would have to undergo such a review.

title: A Tilt Away From Social Issues
description: LOST PINES, Tex.  After two bleak years, Republican governors gathered here on Thursday to assess their political future  and they liked what they saw. With 37 governors seats open in 2010, the party is looking to topple some big-name Democrats.

title: Facing Patriots, Jets Know Its Now or Never Mind Playoffs
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The season is in a free fall and with New England next up on Sunday, urgency has replaced normalcy at Jets headquarters.

title: What Geithner Got Right
description: Its amazing to go back and read what people were saying about Timothy Geithner in the spring. Many people said he looked terrified as the Treasury secretary, like Bambi in the headlights. The New Republic ran an essay called The Geithner Disaster. Portfolio magazine ran a brutal, zeitgeist-capturing profile that concluded by comparing Geithner to Robert Redfords hollow man character in The Candidate.

title: Bronzino Is Given His Museum Moment
description: Over the years, several European museums have tried to organize an exhibition devoted to the work of Bronzino, the poet who was also one of the most important Mannerist painters and draftsmen in 16th-century Florence. But none were successful because loans were so difficult to secure.

title: Winfrey Bets on Her Future With Cable
description: Oprah Winfrey is giving network television one of her trademark aha moments.

title: Feelings Close to the Surface
description: Lee Yoon-kis My Dear Enemy, which opens on Friday for one week at the Museum of Modern Art, may confound your expectations of a South Korean film: no convoluted flashbacks, no doppelgngers, no puzzling narrative leaps, no violence or sex or ghosts. Its an artful, slightly absurdist romance, reminiscent of the gender-war comedies of Hong Sang-soo (Woman on the Beach) but more straightforward, with its meanings, and its feelings, much closer to the surface.

title: The Days May Be Grim, but Heres a Good Word to Put in Your Pocket
description: The Waterfalls flowed in the East River. The Gates snaked through Central Park. Now New Yorks latest large-scale public art project is being exhibited in an even unlikelier space: your wallet.

title: Spare Times
description: THE ART OF ARCHIE COMICS

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: ICKYFEST!

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Free-Music Thursdays at Lincoln Center
description: A new series of free concerts started at Lincoln Centers new visitor center on Thursday with a program that included the Asphalt Orchestra, a 12-piece street band; the Juilliard Jazz Ensemble; the Kubiak-Pakhomov Duo, a pianist and cellist; and the Sexteto Rodriguez Cuban-Jewish All Stars, who blend Cuban dance music with Jewish klezmer. Sponsored by the Target retailing chain, the series, Target Free Thursdays, is based at the David Rubenstein Atrium, which will also serve as a discount-ticket site for Lincoln Center starting Jan. 7. The concerts are to be held every Thursday, including Thanksgiving (featuring the Majestic Marching Knights of Ballou Senior High School in Washington, a Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade band), Christmas Eve (the Ted Rosenthal Trio) and New Years Eve (Champian Fulton Quartet).

title: A Forceful Entry by Christie, and a Sober Exit by Corzine
description: ATLANTIC CITY  In a vivid contrast of their styles and standing, a soft-spoken Gov. Jon S. Corzine delivered a choked-up goodbye here Thursday while Governor-elect Christopher J. Christie vowed to force change on New Jersey even if it meant dragging his adversaries to the table.

title: A Seattle Premiere for ruined Next Year
description: Kate Whoriskeys first season as an artistic director of the Intiman Theater in Seattle will include a production of Ruined, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Lynn Nottage play that Ms. Whoriskey, right, also directed in New York and Chicago. On Thursday, the Intiman said that its 2010 season would open with a production of Clifford Odetss Paradise Lost, directed by Dmaso Rodriguez, which will begin previews on March 19 and open on March 26. The season will also feature Ruined (July 2 through Aug. 8) as the first play in a five-year International Cycle and Hawthornes Scarlet Letter adapted by Naomi Iizuka and directed by Lear deBessonet (Oct. 22 through Dec. 5) as the latest play in its American Cycle. Other productions include A Doctor in Spite of Himself by Molire (Sept. 3-Oct. 10), adapted by Christopher Bayes and Steven Epp.

title: University of California Drops New Museum Plan
description: The University of California, Berkeley, has decided to scrap its ambitious designs for a new Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, saying that it has been unable to raise enough money, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. The building, to have been designed by Toyo Ito and estimated to cost from $143 million to $200 million, was to be constructed in downtown Berkeley and replace the museums current on-campus home, which was declared seismically unsafe a decade ago. Lawrence Rinder, the museums director, told the newspaper that the decision was a consequence of the economic downturn. The museums capital campaign, whose goal was $200 million, raised only $81 million by this month. The gap was just too great, looking forward, Mr. Rinder said. The museum hopes to announce another plan by early January. While architectural plans are changing, Robert Birgeneau, the universitys chancellor, said in a statement, the goal of building a dynamic, welcoming and seismically safe new museum downtown is not.

title: Footnotes
description: The Public Theater said it was extending its run of Tarell Alvin McCraneys Brother/Sister Plays. The production of the trilogy will continue through Dec. 20, with all three plays running on Saturdays and Sundays. ... The Cherry Lane Theater said it was extending its production of The Lady With All the Answers. The David Rambo play, which stars Judith Ivey as the advice columnist Ann Landers, will run through Dec. 20.

title: Cast Is Set for Lie of the Mind
description: Ethan Hawke, below, has assembled an estimable gathering of downtown denizens and fellow actors to star in a revival of A Lie of the Mind, the Sam Shepard play that he will be directing for the New Group. The cast of the play, about a man who believes he may have murdered his wife, will feature Josh Hamilton (who starred in Jonathan Marc Shermans Things We Want for Mr. Hawke), as well as Marin Ireland (Reasons to Be Pretty), Deirdre OConnell (Circle Mirror Transformation), Alessandro Nivola, Maggie Siff and Frank Whaley. The production is to begin previews on Jan. 29 with an official opening planned for February, its publicists said in a release.

title: Raymond Carvers Life and Stories
description: Raymond Carver, surely the most influential writer of American short stories in the second half of the 20th century, makes an early appearance in Carol Sklenickas exhaustive and sometimes exhausting biography as a 3- or 4-year-old on a leash. Well, of course I had to keep him on a leash, his mother, Ella Carver, said much later  and seemingly without irony.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Gazing Longingly at Manhattan
description: The writer-director James DeMonaco is a native Staten Islander, and if his film Staten Island, New York is an ode to what it calls the forgotten stepchild of Manhattan, it is a barbed and quirky one. Using a nonlinear, Tarantino-esque narrative, Mr. DeMonaco adroitly weaves violence, absurdity and sentiment, even an environmental consciousness, into a modest, appealing fable.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Rush Hour Restriction
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Many people think its impossible to solve a Friday or Saturday Times puzzle. Im lucky if I can get five answers, they say. Sometimes, thats all thats needed.

title: Texas: Plant Will Not Take Waste From Mexico
description: A southeast Texas industrial disposal facility has suspended its plan to import and incinerate up to 20,000 tons of hazardous waste from Mexico, a company official said. The company, Veolia Environmental Services, dropped its request to the Environmental Protection Agency for a permit to import polychlorinated byphenyls from Mexico and burn them in a plant, said Mitch Osborne, general manager of the plant. The agency had notified Veolia of its intent to approve the permit in March 2008, but the decision stirred controversy. Mr. Osborne cited economic uncertainty in abandoning the permit.

title: Beyond Electricity, Toward Female Emancipation
description: Alert the authorities. Shocking sexual acts are taking place on the stage of the Lyceum Theater, right in the heart of the Broadway theater district, so recently scrubbed free of all smut and seeded with lawn chairs. Acts involving three people at a time, no less. A man and two women, a woman and two men, sometimes three men.

title: Modern Art for Modern Museumgoers
description: On a recent Thursday evening in Chicago a crowd was forming. Young women grasped the hands of balky children; aspiring artists with pierced eyebrows clutched pencils and sketchbooks. They were waiting to be granted entrance to the Modern Wing of the Art Institute. And they were getting restless.

title: South Carolina: Sanford to Release Travel Records
description: Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina plans to release records to state legislators about previously undisclosed flights that he took on planes owned by friends and campaign donors, his lawyer, Butch Bowers, said. That announcement came a day after the State Ethics Commission charged Mr. Sanford, a Republican, with unspecified ethics violations  a factor for legislators considering whether to try to impeach him. Ever since Mr. Sanfords five-day disappearance to Argentina and admission of an extramarital affair with a woman there in June, he has faced questions about his travel records. He took 35 flights, not including the Argentina trip, on private planes that he did not list on state ethics forms or campaign reports, The Associated Press has reported. But Mr. Bowers said the commissions findings were limited to minor matters that dont include any allegations of criminal conduct.

title: Hamilton Confirmed for Appeals Court
description: The Senate voted 59 to 39 to confirm Judge David F. Hamilton to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judge Hamilton, who sits on the Federal District Court in Indiana, was President Obamas first judicial nominee. Republicans opposed the nomination, announced March 19, because of decisions Judge Hamilton made relating to abortion and prayers in the Indiana Legislature. Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana was the only Republican to vote for his confirmation.

title: Probing Psychological Wounds
description: A moody, modern-day noir about derailed lives and suppressed memories, The Missing Person uses crime-novel clichs to probe psychological wounds.

title: The Wet Side of the Moon
description: Moffett Field, Calif.

title: Clinton Seen as Obamas Key Link to Afghan Leader
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  It is far from clear that President Obama can depend on President Hamid Karzai to bring order to this violent country, but it is becoming clear that he will depend on Hillary Rodham Clinton to be his go-between in dealing with the mercurial Afghan leader.

title: The Past in the Present
description: In his disorganized and somewhat annoying Defamation, Yoav Shamir, an Israeli filmmaker, tries to stir up a tempest with the notions that anti-Semitic has become an all-purpose label for anyone who dares criticize Israel and that some Jews preoccupation with the past  i.e., the Holocaust  is preventing progress in the here and now.

title: Honduran Leader Says Hell Briefly Step Down
description: MEXICO CITY  As the presidential election draws near in Honduras, the de facto leader, Roberto Micheletti, and the ousted president, Manuel Zelaya, continued their political jockeying on Thursday, with Mr. Micheletti announcing that he would briefly cede power to increase the votes legitimacy and Mr. Zelaya insisting that the election be pushed back.

title: A Single, Frantic Day
description: Propelled by an eccentric cast of characters and increasingly seamy locations, Fix dashes headlong through Los Angeles with a little charm and a lot of verve.

title: Russian Priest Killed in Church
description: MOSCOW  The Rev. Daniil Sysoyev, a priest in the Russian Orthodox Church who was known for promoting missionary work among Muslims, was shot and killed in his parish church late Thursday night, the RIA Novosti news agency reported.

title: Sir John Crofton, Pioneer in TB Cure, Dies at 97
description: Sir John Crofton, a pioneering clinician who demonstrated that antibiotics could be safely combined to cure tuberculosis, a dread disease that once killed half the people who contracted it, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Edinburgh. He was 97.

title: Teachers at Some Low-Performing Schools Get Bonuses
description: Teachers at W.H. Maxwell Career and Technical Education High School in Brooklyn were among those at 23 high schools citywide awarded a total of $3.5 million in performance bonuses on Thursday, even though the school received a D on its progress report earlier this week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the airline industrys use of so-called carbon offsets, which are fees paid by passengers for environmental projects meant to compensate for carbon dioxide emissions from their air travel, misspelled the surname of the executive who heads the Carbon Disclosure Project, a consortium of companies that have pledged to report and reduce their emissions. He is Paul Dickinson, not Dickenson.

title: Syracuse Feels at Home Again in Garden
description: When Syracuse was at Madison Square Garden in March winning its unforgettable six-overtime marathon against Connecticut in the Big East tournament quarterfinals, the Oranges big three announced their presence loudly.

title: F.A.A. Computer Problem Snarls Flights
description: WASHINGTON  Flights over much of the eastern United States were delayed Thursday by a pre-dawn failure in a fairly new communications system, which led to the shutdown of a computer that accepts flight plans from the airlines and feeds them to air traffic controllers.

title: Stiegler Hurt in Training
description: Resi Stiegler, 24, one of the United States ski teams most gifted slalom skiers, crashed in training at Copper Mountain, Colo., and was taken off the mountain on a sled with a left knee injury. The team said it would not announce the severity of the injury until Friday. After hitting a gate and tumbling forward, Stiegler lay on the side of the training course screaming in pain for several minutes.

title: Corrections
description: The Patient Money column on Saturday, about ways to pay for alternative medical procedures and nutritional supplements, misquoted Dr. David Riley, a medical doctor who is editor of the journal Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. Dr. Riley said he was not aware of any mislabeling problems involving the nutritional supplement glucosamine. He did not say that a supplement promoted as supplying 100 percent of a daily dose of glucosamine might actually contain only a microscopic amount of the ingredient. The article also referred incorrectly to the Food and Drug Administrations jurisdiction over nutritional supplements. The F.D.A. does in fact regulate nutritional supplements, although it does not oversee the supplements as extensively as it does prescription drugs.

title: Company Piles Up Profits From Citys Parking Meter Deal
description: After a rocky start hurt their bottom line, Chicagos new parking meter operators are raking in more than $1.1 million a week and expect even more revenue next year, according to internal company documents obtained by the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Census Bureau Opens Third Data Processing Center
description: The Census Bureau, along with Lockheed Martin, said that it had opened the last of its three data centers scheduled next spring to process the 10-question 2010 Census form. The 212,000 square-foot center will also operate as a call center for people who need help completing their forms. According to the Census Bureau, it will bring more than 2,800 new jobs to the Phoenix area. The other processing centers are located in Baltimore, Md., and Jeffersonville, Ind.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about an initiative to offer mortgages to landlords who fix wasteful energy and water systems misstated the frequency of energy audits for older apartment buildings under proposed New York City regulations. They would be conducted every 10 years, not annually.

title: The Lessons of the Cy Young Awards
description: The intrigue of the baseball awards is over now, because the only question about the M.V.P. awards to be announced next week is whether Joe Mauer and Albert Pujols will be unanimous. Im guessing they will.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the upgrading of sports programs in the State University of New York system omitted two state university systems that did not have athletics programs in Division I of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in the 1980s. Besides Alaska and New York, North Dakota and South Dakota also did not have any state universities or colleges in Division I during that period. The article also misstated the title once held by the person who is investigating the Binghamton University sports program. Judith S. Kaye, who was not identified by name in the article, was New York States former chief judge; there is no chief justice in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some editions on Wednesday with an article about Kansas City Royals pitcher Zack Greinkes winning the American League Cy Young Award misspelled the surname of the Detroit Tigers pitcher who had 31 victories in 1968, nearly twice as many as Greinkes 16 in 2009. He is Denny McLain, not McClain.

title: Corrections
description: An art review last Friday about Victorious Ones: Jain Images of Perfection, at the Rubin Museum of Art, and Peaceful Conquerors: Jain Manuscript Painting, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misspelled the Sanskrit term for the Jains commitment to nonviolence. It is ahimsa, not ahmisa.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Nov. 12 about the Sothebys auction of contemporary art in New York misstated Sothebys high estimate of sales before the auction. It was $97.7 million  not $67.9 million, which was the low estimate. (Actual sales totaled $134.4 million.)

title: The Pulse: As Bulls Hit the Road, Clowns Stay Home
description: The Chicago Bulls record on their annual circus trip in the 10 seasons since Michael Jordan retired was 10-56 before their game Thursday night against the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Outside a World of Wealth Stands the Reality of Hunger
description: You can drive past the lovely North Side house of Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, and smack into Chicagos invisible poor.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Tuesday about the pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, at Alice Tully Hall, misstated the Kchel catalog number of the Mozart Piano Sonata in D he performed. It is K. 284, not 282.

title: After a Fire in Brooklyn, the Anguish of a Mother
description: Shaking as two relatives helped her onto a sofa, Rose Danielle Etienne, 26, sobbed Thursday afternoon as she spoke of a fire that had swept through her apartment in Brooklyn the day before, killing her longtime companion and their two young sons.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Pierre Harmel, a Belgian diplomat who formulated a new strategy for NATO in the 1960s, misattributed a quotation from a NATO statement about Mr. Harmels career. It was Anders Fogh Rasmussen, the secretary general of NATO, who commented on Mr. Harmels distinguished and influential career  not Jaap de Hoop Scheffer, a previous secretary general.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Five Youths Arraigned in Shooting of Two on Bronx Street
description: She was already crying when the 16-year-old youth stepped before a criminal court judge in the Bronx on Thursday, a baby-faced gunman to some in the news media, but only a son to her.

title: Appeals Court Voids 93 Murder Convictions
description: New York States highest court on Thursday overturned the murder convictions of two men imprisoned for 19 years, ruling that a Manhattan prosecutor had misled the jury and improperly withheld information from defense lawyers at their trial.

title: Jobless Rate Got No Help From Hiring for Holidays
description: The usual preholiday hiring by stores did not happen in October as New York Citys unemployment rate held at 10.3 percent, its highest level in 16 years, the State Labor Department said Thursday.

title: Lottery Numbers
After Other Hardships, Trying to Bounce Back From Unemployment
description: Once Andrea Combs sensed that layoffs were imminent, she went to her caseworkers office with a sense of purpose.

title: Oscar Question of the Day: Who Chooses the Documentary Short List?
description: Nobody can accuse the documentary branch of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences of crass commercialism. In all, the 15 feature documentaries on the academys short list of those eligible for Oscar nominations appear to have had about $9 million in combined ticket sales. Thats less than half the roughly $20 million in sales accumulated by just four of the films  Capitalism: A Love Story, The September Issue, Tyson and Anvil!: The Story of Anvilthat were bypassed.

title: The Controversy Over Mammograms
description: An expert panels recommendation that mammography screening to detect breast cancer be scaled back has caused consternation among women and doctors and prompted some attempts to connect the results to the debate over health care.

title: Iraqs Election Law Morass
description: Iraqis have quickly learned to play hardball politics. That was evident on Wednesday when one of Iraqs two vice presidents, Tariq al-Hashimi, who is a Sunni, vetoed an important election law at the last minute. He demanded a change that would allocate more parliamentary seats for Iraqi Sunnis living abroad.

title: A Gift to Credit Card Companies
description: Congress left consumers extremely vulnerable when it gave the credit card industry as long as 15 months to end the deceptive predatory practices outlawed in the spring in the Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure Act. The credit card industry, which clearly wants to make a killing in the Christmas season, used this unnecessarily long grace period to intensify its predations, doubling interest rates on people who pay on time and driving up rates by an industry wide average of about 20 percent.

title: A Pill a Day to Keep Cancer Away?
description: To the Editor:

title: Iranian Dissidents in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Breast Screening Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Tehran States Its Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Confirming Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: Dimming Prospects for Mideast Peace?
description: To the Editor:

title: Addicted to Mammograms
description: Philadelphia

title: Tim Burton at the Modern
description: Images from the Museum of Modern Art's expansive retrospective of his noncinematic art.

title: Inside the Mind of Leonardo
description: Images from the exhibition Leonardo da Vincis Workshop, at the Discovery Times Square Exposition.

title: Icon Painting and Crete
description: A new exhibition at the Onassis Cultural Center is essentially a dual-purpose visual essay on the painter Domenikos Theotokopoulos, better known as El Greco.

title: MSNBC: The New York Times Edition
description: This week, John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times discusses the health care vote in the Senate, President Obama's upcoming decision on troops in Afghanistan, Sarah Palin's book tour and more.

title: Guidelines Push Back Age for Cervical Cancer Tests
description: New guidelines for cervical cancer screening say women should delay their first Pap test until age 21, and be screened less often than recommended in the past.

title: Screening Debate Reveals Culture Clash in Medicine
description: This week, the science of medicine bumped up against the foundations of American medical consumerism: that more is better, that saving a life is worth any sacrifice, that health care is a birthright.

title: Labor Denounces Judge in Gompers Case
description: Saturday, Nov. 20, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Ukraine: Putin Soothes Dispute Over Price of Sending Fuel
description: Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia took a more conciliatory stance toward Ukraine on Thursday in negotiations over the transit of Russian gas through Ukrainian territory. Mr. Putin suggested that Russia would be willing to renegotiate transit agreements so that they would be more favorable to Ukraine. He made his comments after a meeting in the Ukrainian city of Yalta with his Ukrainian counterpart, Yulia V. Tymoshenko.

title: Mammogram Debate Took Group by Surprise
description: The federal Preventive Services Task Force, the group that created a political firestorm this week with its recommendation that women get less-frequent mammograms, was created to be insulated from politics.

title: Moldova: Army Enlists Onions and Garlic to Ward Off Swine Flu
description: The Moldovan Army is issuing garlic and onions to help its soldiers ward off a growing epidemic of swine flu in Eastern Europe, The Associated Press reported Thursday. The chief medical officer for the Defense Ministry, Col. Sergiu Vasislita, was quoted as saying each soldier would get the equivalent of one small onion and two garlic cloves added to his diet as an immune-system boost. Moldova has about 6,500 troops.

title: Russia: Moratorium on Executions
description: Russias Constitutional Court extended the countrys moratorium on the death penalty on Thursday, though it stopped short of fully abolishing capital punishment. In a statement, the Constitutional Court argued that permitting capital punishment would violate Russias commitments as a member of the Council of Europe. The moratorium on executions was imposed in 1996 and was set to expire in January.

title: Rethinking the Pap Test
description: Days after new recommendations called for later, less frequent mammograms, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists has issued new guidelines for cervical cancer screening.

title: A Tour of Childhood Flavors, Then a Michelin Star
description: It was disconcerting to hear one of the top chefs in the Bay Area squeal like a child over a package of Filipino cheese cupcakes. But squeal Jennie Lorenzo did.

title: Christian Leaders Unite on Political Issues
description: Citing the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s call to civil disobedience, 145 evangelical, Roman Catholic and Orthodox Christian leaders have signed a declaration saying they will not cooperate with laws that they say could be used to compel their institutions to participate in abortions, or to bless or in any way recognize same-sex couples.

title: A Cal-Stanford Score, Off the Field
description: For 111 years, Stanford and Cal, which play on Saturday, have battled for supremacy on the football field. Still, there is more than one way to compete.

title: Word of the Day | resonant
description: resonant  \re-z-nnt, rez-nnt\  adjective

title: Learning to Teach to Bridge the Achievement Gap
description: Kathleen Martin stood in front of a white board covered with math problems, her class clustered at her feet. As they talked through the solutions together, the students repeated the headings over each problem on the board: Algebra and Function, Probability, Data Analysis.

title: Faith and Tolerance Collide in Vallejo
description: Drive through Vallejo and you will see a once-proud Navy town clearly down on its luck. A motel room goes for $30.99 a night, including HBO. Closed businesses proliferate; those that remain often have temporary vinyl signs held up by string, indicating a tentative investment in the future.

title: Bay Area Report Highlights for Friday, Nov. 20
description: Give em the Ax | On Saturday, the Stanford and Cal football teams will meet in a game crucial to both teams postseason dreams. But there are other fields and other dreams, and the universities vie with each other in many other ways. Jason Turbow offers his own brand of fantasy football: The Big Game, in other leagues.

title: News Quiz | November 20, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Sign of the Times?
description: WHO first noticed and photographed this sign to bring it to the hospitals attention?

title: The Burning Voice of Vallejo
description: While reporting this weeks Barbary Coast column on questions about religious and political influence in Vallejo, I found myself spending hours in the online pages of The Vallejo Independent Bulletin.

title: Radical Lawyer Convicted of Aiding Terrorist Is Jailed
description: Defiant to the end as she embraced emotional supporters outside the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan, Lynne F. Stewart, the radical lawyer known for defending unpopular clients, surrendered on Thursday evening to begin serving her 28-month sentence for assisting terrorism.

title: Does Exercise Reduce Stress For You?
description: How much do you exercise? What do you do? Do you notice that it makes you less anxious?

title: UrbanEye: The City Is A Stage
description: Melena Ryzik reports from the 2009 Performa Biennial, a Performance Art festival that inhabits New York City for three weeks.

title: Sears Holdings Narrows Its Loss
description: Sears Holdings on Thursday posted a smaller third-quarter loss than a year ago, helped by cost cuts and inventory controls.

title: A Pulpy, Glorious Mess
description: The Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans, Werner Herzogs sorta remake of the 1992 Abel Ferrara film, is a pulpy, glorious mess, writes A.O. Scott. And he means it in a good way: Its maniacal unpredictability is such a blast that it reminds you just how tidy and dull most crime thrillers are these days. The star, Nicolas Cage, is at the height of ravaged oddball: Sometimes his loose-limbed shuffle and sibilant drawl suggest Jimmy Stewart as a crackhead, Scott writes. Other times, he just freestyle-raps (to the break of dawn!). What may seem like random, dissociated bursts of energy are in fact the brilliant syncopations of a player with a sure, if unorthodox, sense of rhythm, Scott writes. Ditto for the movie itself. It has a warped sincerity, and an energy that keeps going and going. To the break of dawn!

title: Last Call
description: Its the final weekend for Performa, the interactive performance art festival thats been taking over the city for the last few weeks. You can join in a video  like we did [LINK to UR vid]  catch the premiere of a theater piece that involves a rare appearance by a South Korean magician or hear a whos who of experimental musicians perform their most out-there stuff. In any case, participation is part of the point, and much of the fun.

title: Misfits Are His Muses
description: Tim Burtons career is the ultimate revenge of the art nerd, Ken Johnson writes. -The animator of Pee-Wee and Beetlejuice, Edward Scissorhands and Jack Skellington, is the subject of a major retrospective at MoMA, which showcases the art  including drawings, sculptures and photos  that he has been making throughout his career. Freaks, of course, are his main subject (keep your eye out for Stainboy, a superhero whose only power is leaving stains); the exhibit also includes screenings of his films, from Batman to early shorts like  Frankenweenie.

title: Media Moguls Battle With Deutsche Bank Escalates
description: German prosecutors said Thursday that they had filed fraud charges against Rolf E. Breuer, the former chief executive and chairman of Deutsche Bank, the latest development in Leo Kirchs legal battle with the bank over the collapse of his media empire.

title: Panel Votes to Broaden Oversight of the Fed
description: In a display of populist anger toward the Federal Reserve, a House panel voted on Thursday to let Congress carry out sweeping new oversights of the central banks policy decisions and operations.

title: Schottcast: Oulipo
description: Co-vocabularists may be interested to know that the promised broadcast on Oulipo is now available online here.

title: Chegg Gets $57 Million in New Round
description: Chegg.com, the textbook rental site, has raised $57 million in a fourth round of financing.

title: BigDeal Puts a New Spin on Entertainment Shopping
description: From Brad Stone at Bits:

title: Could Citis Bet on EMI Come Out All Right?
description: Citigroup stopped dancing to the music of the credit boom shortly after it backed the leveraged buyout of EMI, the British music company, in 2007.

title: Ex-McKesson Chairman Is Found Guilty of Fraud
description: A federal jury found the former chairman of McKesson guilty of fraud on Thursday, nearly 10 years after he played a central role in a costly corporate accounting scandal, The Associated Press reported.

title: Exterminate! Exterminate!
description: Maybe you were feeling a bit safer now that evil megalomaniacs were no longer running U.S. foreign policy. Wrong! Be afraid, be very afraid: Catherine Ashton, who will be the EUs new foreign minister, has a full-size Dalek  a gift from her husband  in her sitting room.

title: Haute Lips | Delfina Delettrez Earrings
description: You can literally put your money where your mouth is with these enamel, silver and gold Seven Sins earrings by the Rome-based jeweler Delfina Delettrez, who must have accessories in her blood. (Shes a fourth-generation Fendi.) Her work, with its gothic bent and unusual combinations of colors and materials, is often inspired by the human body, especially as its depicted in paintings by Giorgio de Chirico and the work of Andreas van Vessel, the 16th-century anatomist. The earrings are about $1,600 at Opening Ceremony, 35 Howard Street, or go to openingceremony.us.

title: Can JPMorgan Guard Cazenoves Culture?
description: After 185 years on its own and five in shared accommodations, Cazenove, the British stockbroker, is moving into the House of Morgan.

title: ABN Amro Gets Another Cash Injection
description: The Netherlands government said Thursday that it would spend an additional 3 billion euros to clean up ABN Amro, as it sought to put the problems at the collapsed lender behind it, The New York Timess David Jolly reported.

title: Treasury to Auction Off Big-Bank Warrants
description: A year after the federal government rescued the nations financial industry, the Treasury Department announced Thursday that it would auction off its remaining investments in three large banks, freeing the lenders from the federal bailout program, The New York Timess Eric Dash reported.

title: AOL to Cut One-Third of Its Staff Ahead of Spin-Off
description: In recent years, amid the fallout from its audacious merger with Time Warner, AOL has steadily become smaller through subscriber desertions and rounds and rounds of layoffs.

title: Fidelity Begins Tool for Breakaway Brokers
description: Fidelity Investments has begun a service to help retail brokers determine how profitable it would be for them to leave their brokerage house and hang out their own shingle.

title: Wall Street Tax Must Be International, Pelosi Says
description: Any tax imposed on financial transactions would have to take effect internationally to prevent Wall Street jobs and related business from moving overseas, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Thursday.

title: Investors Sew Up Deal for Skype
description: EBay said on Thursday it had completed its sale of its Skype to a consortium of investors as it had vowed to do before the end of the year, Reuters reported.

title: Mixed Day For I.P.O.s
description: Investors proved to be selective as four United States-listed initial public offerings priced either below or at their expected ranges on Thursday evening, Reuters reported.

title: G.E. and Vivendi Said to Be $1 Billion Apart on NBC
description: A report saying that Vivendi was holding for more money in its negotiations to sell its 20 percent stake in NBC Universal to majority owner General Electric left industry observers wondering just how far apart the two firms were on price.

title: Burkle Said to Buy Barneys New York Debt
description: The supermarket mogul Ronald Burkle and his investment arm, Yucaipa, have purchased a large amount of the debt owed by Barneys New York, the luxury retail chain, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Goldman Investors Want a Bigger Slice of Profits
description: Some of Goldman Sachss largest shareholders have asked the company to cut the size of its bonus pool and pass along more of its profits to investors, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

title: Ferrero Said to Eye Gum Unit in Cadbury Bid
description: Ferrero, the Italian chocolate maker, could be interested in Cadburys gum and candy division, a unit worth about 5 billion euros ($7.4 billion), in a possible joint takeover bid, Il Sole 24 Ore reported.

title: Satchmo, Blacks and Jews
description: Todays idea: Louis Armstrongs memoir of a Jewish family includes blunt criticisms of blacks that are startlingly contemporary in tone and the source of considerable disquiet among his admirers, many of whom prefer to ignore them altogether, a biographer says.

title: S.E.C. Told to Change How It Chooses Inquiries
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission must tighten its process for deciding which investment advisers to inspect if it is to avoid colossal breakdowns like the one that allowed Bernard L. Madoffs multibillion-dollar fraud to go undetected for 16 years, the agencys inspector general said.

title: Harbinger Again Trims Stake in Times Company
description: Harbinger Capital Partners has once again trimmed its stake in The New York Times Company.

title: Week 11 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Chargers (6-3) at Broncos (6-3)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Chargers by 1

title: Gartmore Plans $412 Million I.P.O. Next Month
description: The Gartmore Group, which manages about 21.8 billion ($36 billion) in hedge and mutual funds, is preparing an initial public offering of at least 250 million next month to reduce debt, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Suicide Bomber Strikes Afghan Market, Killing at Least 15 People
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber on a motorcycle attacked a crowded marketplace in a relatively peaceful part of western Afghanistan on Friday, killing at least 15 people, while a well-known former warlord and member of Parliament narrowly survived an assassination attempt on the outskirts of Kabul.

title: Sampler: The U.C. Fee Increase and Reactions
description: The Fee Increase | The University of California Board of Regents raised fees by 32 percent.

title: Volkswagen Board Moves Closer to Porsche Merger
description: Volkswagen said on Friday that its supervisory board had approved certain agreement contracts for the planned merger with the German sportscar builder Porsche, taking the companies one step closer to completing the deal.

title: At Reunion, a Look Back at the Way It Was
description: The friends share a combined 494 years of life, 45 grandchildren and, as they demonstrated Thursday morning in a Manhattan diner, a seemingly bottomless well of stories about the colorful bygone days of this city.

title: The Uproar Over Mammography
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Lunch in Mumbai, Packed and Delivered
description: Among the wonders of Mumbai are the dabbawallas, deliverymen who ferry home-cooked meals  contained in multicompartment metal lunch boxes called tiffins  from residences to offices (and back) every day. It used to be that the meals would originate only with a mother, a grandmother or, perhaps, a wife. But with the startup of a handful of businesses catering to the tiffin crowd, the options have expanded.

title: Belkin Recalls iPhone Accessories for Fire Risk
description: Belkin International is recalling about 241,000 of its TuneBase devices sold in the United States and Canada because of a risk of fire if they are left in the lighter plug too long, such as overnight.

title: Awaiting Oprahs Announcement
description: On Friday morning, Oprah Winfrey will make it official.

title: The Early Word: Weekend Health Work
description: It looks like the Capitol will be open for a little more weekend business.

title: Can Soldiers Be Victims of Terrorism?
description: On Thursday in Washington, as my colleague David Johnston reports, several legislators declared at a Senate hearing that the murder of 12 soldiers and a retired guardsman at Fort Hood this month was a terrorist attack. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, who opened the hearing, said, We will look at the Fort Hood murders not as an isolated event, but as part of a larger pattern of homegrown terrorism that has emerged over the past several years.

title: U.N. Report Calls for More Environmental Protection in Wartime
description: A report released this month by the United Nations Environment Program and the Environmental Law Institute calls for stronger international laws to protect the environment during times of war.

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Friday morning.

title: Your MetroCard May Be Sending You a Secret Message
description: As part of an unannounced public art project, seven million MetroCards distributed this fall had a single printed word on the back: optimism. The work itself is the creation of Reed Seifer, a graphic artist and designer who first printed optimism on small buttons that he distributed as a college student.

title: Brush with Olympic Glory
description: The 2010 Winter Olympics dont start until Feb. 12, but fans can bask in the torch glow of games past at several resorts offering close encounters with prior medalists.

title: Gasols Return Lifts Lakers Back to Normal
description: LOS ANGELES At times, the Lakers have looked less than championship caliber in starting their bid to repeat last years title. That changed Thursday evening when Pau Gasol reclaimed his spot in the starting lineup and picked up right where he had left off in the N.B.A. finals.

title: FIFA Denies Ireland a Replay
description: Early Friday, FIFA issued a statement denying Irelands request for a replay of its World Cup qualifying match against France, in which Thierry Henry handled the ball seconds before William Gallas scored the winning goal.

title: Taking Time Off: An Option for California University Students
description: How do you cope with a 32 percent increase in tuition?

title: Ask About the Volt and Other Hybrid and Electric Vehicles
description: In this weeks Automobiles section, Lindsay Brooke writes about his experience driving a prototype version of the Chevrolet Volt. The hybrid Volt, which General Motors plans to begin selling in 2010, has been the focus of a great deal of interest as G.M. shifts its strategy to vehicles that are not primarily powered by internal combustion engines. The Volt can run on electricity alone for about 40 miles, according to the company. After that, it relies upon a gasoline engine to run a generator that provides electrical power to the batteries.

title: Off Script
description: Video |  From The Onion, the president has to skip his usual serving of teleprompter at mealtime:

title: The Voices of Rheumatoid Arthritis
FlashForward Watch: Cancerous Subplot
description: This post contains spoilers.

title: Raids Expose Soccer Fixing Across Europe
description: BOCHUM, Germany  European law-enforcement officials said Friday that they had arrested the leaders of a far-reaching gambling cartel that is thought to have conspired to influence the outcome of 200 soccer games in nine countries across the continent.

title: Shares Finish Lower on Doubts About Recovery
description: The stock market finished slightly lower on Friday as investors worried about the speed of the economic recovery and questioned the fast rise of technology stocks.

title: Senator Snowe Proposes Killing Her Own Loan Program
description: On Monday, with little fanfare, Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine introduced legislation to put the Americas Recovery Capital loan program out of its misery. Her legislation would repeal the program immediately, and return the unobligated balance of the original $255 million appropriation  as of Tuesday, $153 million, according to the Small Business Administration  back to the Treasury.

title: U.C. Fee Increase: Is Taking a Year Off Prudent?
description: How do you cope with a 32 percent increase in university fees? That is the question Ron Lieber asks on The New York Times Bucks blog.

title: The Twilight Saga: New Moon': Juiceless or Juicebomb?
description: After months of anticipation, the day has finally arrived when eager moviegoers can see the film that A. O. Scott of The New York Times called a film noir potboiler of jealousy and revenge that reveals an intricate and enigmatic structure, full of twists and reversals. But enough about Pedro Almodvars Broken Embraces.

title: A Rear Axle Pitches in to Steer
description: ENGINES, transmissions, chassis controls and cockpit infotainment systems have all had their turns as the must-have features that brought shoppers into showrooms. Could it now be time for the lowly differential  a vital drivetrain part seen by few drivers and understood by even fewer  to shine?

title: Graphic Books Best-Seller List
description: If there is one thing that pop-culture aficionados have learned over the past year, its that young women like stories about vampires. A lot. In that vein, the latest volume of Vampire Knight, a series aimed at female readers, tops our manga list this week. Created by Matsuri Hino, Vampire Knight follows the goings-on at Cross Academy, a school where the day class is composed of humans, and the night class is  yup  vampires. The series has always enjoyed a certain popularity, but with the fervor for Twilight now rivaling Beatlemania, more and more readers are discovering Ms. Hinos take on undead teenage drama. (Speaking of which, how long will it be before theres a graphic-novel adaptation of Twilight? Oh, wait  its already been announced. Whew!)

title: Doctors Debate: Should City Aid Growth in Palliative Care?
description: Just how far should medicine go in turning death and dying into a growth industry?

title: Sticking to Game Plan, Knicks Pass on Iverson
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Allen Iverson spent three days in the Knicks consciousness, without ever entering their locker room. He lingered long enough to stir extreme fits of intrigue and trepidation.

title: For the Soul
description: A FEW truths existed in my house growing up: baseball games were worth watching only when the Yankees won, lateness was inexcusable, and the chicken soup from Second Avenue Deli was the best cure for a cold.

title: Fears for the Future of the University of California
description: The University of California system has long been one of the gems of American education  a first-rate research university that was one of the most affordable in the country. But its future is uncertain, my colleague Tamar Lewin reports.

title: Senator Reid and the Power of Persuasion
description: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, having unveiled the Senate health care bill now needs 60 votes to stave off a Republican filibuster and begin formal floor debate. That means getting all 58 Senate Democrats and the two independents on board for a vote set for Saturday evening. But even among the Democrats, Senators Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, Ben Nelson of Nebraska and Mary Landrieu of Louisiana have been cagey about whether they will support the bill.

title: Ohio Sues Rating Firms for Losses in Funds
description: Already facing a spate of private lawsuits, the legal troubles of the countrys largest credit rating agencies deepened on Friday when the attorney general of Ohio sued Moodys Investors Service, Standard & Poors and Fitch, claiming that they had cost state retirement and pension funds some $457 million by approving high-risk Wall Street securities that went bust in the financial collapse.

title: Complaint Box | Picky Eaters
description: Having friends over for dinner used to involve a minimal and fairly unremarkable to-do list: There were groceries to buy, along with flowers and a couple of bottles of semi-respectable wine. I would put out some guest towels and a collection of fancy soaps that were off limits to blood relatives, and then  voil!  dinner was served. Preparing for a dinner party these days is far more complex, thanks to a vast and bewildering array of dietary needs that seem to have suddenly overtaken everyone I know.

title: Far From Field, Lawyers Blog Is Player in N.F.L.
description: Mike Florio refuses to fly, so he drove 15 hours last January to his first Super Bowl.

title: P.&G. May Slow Down Deal-Making, Financial Chief Says
description: Procter & Gamble does not see acquisitions as a core part of its growth plan and has started to buy back shares again, the consumer products conglomerates chief financial officer said on Friday.

title: Wanderlust | Istanbul
description: The international style crowd recently descended upon Istanbul for a three-day fashion extravaganza. Powerhouse labels like Roberto Cavalli, Salavatore Ferragamo, Vivienne Westwood and Missoni staged shows with A-list models like Jessica Stam and Lily Donaldson, and there was even the requisite celebrity appearance  Bruce Willis at Missoni. Still, one of the highlights was a student show by young Turkish designers from the ISMEK and LaSalle fashion academies, including up-and-coming stars like like Sule Simsek Yalcin and Rabia Koyun.

title: MetroCard as Art
description: The latest phase of Reed Seifers Project Optimism may not solve world hunger, or add much to the history of Conceptual Art. But it could brighten the mood of some New York City commuters  if they happen to look at the back of their MetroCards. This is a rarer occurrence than you might imagine, but give it a try. You may find the word optimism printed in sturdy black sans-serif lowercase letters, along with tinier blocks of type that say Arts for Transit and Reed Seifer, Artist. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has put seven million such cards in circulation since September, with another seven million to come.

title: UC Fee Hike: Shouts and Murmurs Outside Wheeler Hall
description: I am on the campus of the University of California at Berkeley, on the west side of Wheeler Hall, a building housing classrooms and lecture halls. Near me, one crowd of protesters, students and faculty are chanting and others are linking arms to form an ersatz picket line around the hall.

title: A Bully at Age 4?
description: Periodically readers will leave comments on posts from weeks or months earlier. These usually arrive in the middle of the night, and I imagine the writer, unable to sleep, turning to the wisdom of the Web for advice.

title: Jets Q. and A. With Greg Bishop
description: Greg Bishop, who covers the Jets for The Times, answered readers questions on Friday.

title: Friday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused articles appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: A Tearful Winfrey Explains Her Departure
description: After much prayer and months of careful thought, Ive decided the next season, season 25, will be the last season of The Oprah Winfrey Show,' the talk show host said on her television program Friday morning.

title: Buffett Cuts Sweet Deal for Burlington Northern Loan
description: Its no surprise that Warren E. Buffett can command enviable terms when it comes to bank loans. Thats the case with the $8 billion he is borrowing to take over the rest of the railroad operator Burlington Northern Santa Fe for $26 billion.

title: Answers About Community Philanthropy, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of answers from Lorie A. Slutsky, president of the New York Community Trust, on community philanthropy, the value of many different approaches to charitable giving and their importance in maintaining a strong democracy.

title: Putting the Bite on Twilight
description: Among the ancillary businesses that have benefited from Fridays release of New Moon: cosmetics companies that make mascara and eyeliner; manufacturers of plastic vampire fangs; and comedians who have delighted in satirizing the franchises moody Pacific Northwest atmosphere and breathless dialogue.

title: No Special Requests
description: On the City Room blog, a hostess who will be telling her Thanksgiving guests no special requests, unless you face anaphylactic shock.

title: Andre Agassis Hate of the Game
description: Even those not convinced that Andre Agassi was the best tennis player of his time will readily admit he outdid all others in attracting attention, beginning in the 1980s, when he was a teenage phenom from Las Vegas who blazed onto the pro tour in flamboyant, Nike-sponsored plumage  stone-washed denim, skintight Hot Lava compression shorts, midnight-at-the-roulette-wheel shades  that blinded many to the granite consistency of his game: the compact, bludgeoning ground strokes, the lethal service return, the lightning reflexes.

title: A Conversation With Andre Agassi
