description: The tennis great talks candidly about his life on and off the court with Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review.

title: E.U. Takes More Time to Review Oracle-Sun Deal
description: European Union regulators said Friday that they have extended until Jan. 27 a deadline to wrap up their antitrust review of Oracles planned $7.4 billion takeover of Sun Microsystems, The Associated Press reported.

title: Now Online | Ts Winter Travel Issue
description: In the new winter issue of T: Travel, our sights are set on the beach. (Its winter, where else?) First we head to Tobago for a fashion cover shoot and a glimpse of the slow (and sustainable) life on one of the Caribbeans least known islands. Then we go to Miami for sand and surf with a heavy side of scene, before heading way south of the border for a look at the real Buenos Aires through its food. But dont think weve forgotten the seasons cooler pleasures: we make a trip to the booming and beautiful ski town of Geilo, Norway, as well as to the tiny winter wonderland of Hollands Friesland, before we end up closer to home amid the lovable wackiness of Baltimore.

title: Ohio Sues Credit Rating Agencies
description: Update | 2:39 p.m.  The New York Timess David Segal provides more details of the Ohio lawsuit.

title: Haleh Esfandiari: Prisoner of Tehran
description: In 2007, Haleh Esfandiari, the Iranian-American director of the Woodrow Wilson Centers Middle East Program, told Iranian intelligence everything she knew. She was interrogated for almost eight months, nearly four of them inside Tehrans notorious Evin prison. During that time, she explained the institutional structure of the Wilson Center, identified its board members and described her work organizing conferences. She translated reams of material from the centers Web site into Farsi. But it was a dialogue of the deaf.

title: De Waart, Not Levine, to Conduct Remaining Rosenkavaliers
description: James Levine has relinquished the remaining performances of Der Rosenkavalier at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Levine, the Mets music director, canceled the first half of the run in October while recovering from back surgery. He is currently rehearsing Tales of Hoffman, which opens on Dec. 3, but the Met said he did not have time to rehearse properly for Der Rosenkavalier, which re-emerges Jan. 1, 6, 9 and 15. Edo de Waart, who took over for Mr. Levine in the October Rosenkavaliers, will conduct those performances.

title: Weekly Matchups: Digging Deep
description: This Saturday Florida is almost a seven-touchdown favorite against Florida International. Alabama is hosting Chattanooga, which isnt even a F.B.S. team. There havent been any blockbuster matchups over the last few weeks and Ohio State-Michigan isnt exactly getting anyone excited this weekend. (That No. 1 vs. No. 2 matchup from 2006 seem like a long time ago?) The top of the rankings saw lots of change over the first few weeks of the season (five top-five teams lost in the first four weeks), but the top of the rankings have been holding steady throughout November. People are getting bored.

title: Interest rates: the phantom menace
description: From various bat squeaks Ive put together a view of what I think lies behind the surprising  and damaging  deficit squeamishness of the Obama administration. So heres what I think theyre thinking  and why its wrong-headed. (Fairly wonkish stuff after the jump).

title: CF Claims 3 Seats on Terras Board
description: Update | 2:24 p.m. The final act of what the Deal Professor has nicknamed the Forever War may have just been written.

title: Handball Touches on Sportsmanship and Instant Replay
description: A day later, the Thierry Henry handball controversy has spun off into something entirely different from Thursdays woe-to-Ireland, Henry-the-thief themes. Now, its a lively discussion of sportsmanship.

title: Stray Questions for: Jennifer Gilmore
description: Jennifer Gilmore is the author of two novels, Golden Country and the forthcoming Something Red.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: A Night of Squandered Leads and Shootouts
description: Eight games on Thursday, and only three ended in regulation. The wildest match of the night was played in Raleigh, a basement bowl between cellar-dwelling Carolina and Toronto. The two teams battled mightily trying to throw away the game, and in the end it was the Maple Leafs who succeeded. In throwing away the game, that is. Home teams listed first:

title: Double Agency
description: The British edition of Typhoon came out one year ago. I was living in China then and ordered a copy from London. It never arrived, though the Royal Mails tracking system showed that it had made its way as far as a Beijing shipping depot. Did it disappear into the routine chaos of Chinese life? Was this a purposeful, pinpoint strike by Chinese censors who figured out that it raises touchy political questions about their country?

title: The Boundaries of a Breakup
description: WHEN I broke up with my live-in girlfriend of five years, we divvied up our things, helped each other move into our new apartments, and then stopped seeing each other altogether  a cold-turkey breakup that I was sure was for the best. We didnt send e-mail messages, call or meet for coffee, and we certainly didnt go out for drinks.

title: Video: Winfreys Announcement
description: Via the NBC affiliate in Chicago, video of Oprah Winfreys departure announcement:

title: Word Made Flesh
description: Mary Gordons Reading Jesus  a book of questions for, quibbles with and tributes to the sometimes inscrutable protagonist of the Gospels  begins in a cab stuck in New York City traffic and ends with the Resurrection. Gordon, the author of over a dozen works of fiction, memoir and nonfiction, is taken aback by the smooth haranguing of a radio preacher (There seems to be something slightly sexually perverse in the unctuousness, she writes) and realizes that as familiar as she is with the Bible thanks to a Catholic upbringing and an adulthood as an engaged  if skeptical  believer, she has never read the four Gospels recording Jesus life in succession: first Matthew, then Mark, then Luke and finally the polished latecomer, John.

title: Recipes for a Healthy Thanksgiving
description: Thanksgiving favorites can all be made in healthful, flavorful ways, as the columnist Martha Rose Shulman writes in this weeks Recipes for Health:

title: Disaster Epic 2012 Splits Earth and Audiences
description: We interrupt our wall-to-wall coverage of Twilight to revisit last weekends No. 1 movie, 2012, the last offering from the disaster auteur Roland Emmerich.

title: Study Says Air Cars Are Inefficient
description: Theres no question that people love the idea of compressed-air cars, which have long been under development by the French company Motor Development International and, according to a company spokesman, could be on American roads (after many delays) by 2012.

title: Answers on Community Colleges, Part 5
description: Each day this week, the Guidance Office  the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts  is featuring answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: Travel Deals: European Hotels From $74
description: For two days, more than 400 Best Western hotels throughout Europe and Egypt are offering rooms starting at 49 euros a night (about $74 at $1.50 to the euro), including breakfast. Family-size rooms and triple-occupancy rooms start at about $104 a night.

title: Disturbing the Comfortable
description: What can you remember from The Brothers Karamazov? Perhaps you recall the rampages of the drunken, leering father; the outraged pride of Katerina Ivanovna; the reeking wake of the saintly Father Zosima; or (the grad students choice) the speech of the Grand Inquisitor. The minds retention of plotlines, even those from the pillars of the literary canon, is often selective and uncertain. But heres a different question: What cant you forget? One paragraph has haunted English readers ever since Constance Garnett translated the novel from the Russian in 1912. Grushenka, a passionate fallen woman, tells the tale of a wicked peasant who dies and is dragged by devils into a lake of fire. The peasants guardian angel tries to save her by telling God of the single good deed the woman performed in her lifetime: she once pulled an onion from her garden and gave it to a beggar. Take that onion then, God replies, hold it out to her in the lake, and let her take hold. If the onion doesnt break, God continues, let her come to Paradise. But as the angel draws the peasant out, other sinners cling to her, seeking their own rescue, and she selfishly kicks them away. The onion breaks, and down she sinks. Dostoyevsky didnt invent this anecdote; a peasant told it to him. Lessons like this sometimes seem to emerge whole from the Russian soil, but not every writer has the instincts to grab on and hold tight when they surface. Ludmilla Petrushevskaya does.

title: Meeting Mr. Trump, and Paying the Price
description: Dont mess with the Donald.

title: My True Story
description: Finally, on the second-to-last page of his history of memoir, a tale packed from beginning to end with scandals, liars and cheats, Ben Yagoda asks the question weve been waiting for: How do we know when were being duped? The answer is almost worth the delay, even though its a quotation from nearly a half-century ago: Think of the memoirist as a person to whom you have just been introduced, a Times Book Review columnist named Raymond Walters Jr. wrote. Size up as best you can the personality of the man or woman who is talking and take it constantly into consideration as you judge the truthfulness of what he has to say.

title: City Hall Budget Maneuver Quietly Encourages Job Cuts
description: Even as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg says that he is trying to avert laying off city workers, his aides have quietly encouraged such job cuts through an internal budget maneuver, according to city documents and interviews with those who have viewed them.

title: What to Watch This Weekend: Bill Moyers, Taylor Swift and the Prospect of Oblivion
description: With events in Afghanistan in mind, Bill Moyers looks back at President Lyndon B. Johnsons decision-making as he stepped up the American involvement in Vietnam on Bill Moyers Journal (PBS, 9 p.m. Friday on most stations). Mr. Moyers served Johnson as White House press secretary.

title: Taking No Prisoners
description: Civil War generals usually come easily packaged: the brilliant, well-mannered Robert E. Lee, stoically erect, boots polished, a model of Southern manhood and elegant savagery; Ulysses S. Grant, also brilliant but a slouching product of the West, his boots unblacked, the faint smell of alcohol on his disheveled jacket, his manner taciturn, as if wearied by butchery and death. But the Tennessee-born Confederate general Nathan Bedford Forrest is harder to characterize, for even to this day he is a controversial figure. Widely regarded as an intrepid military genius, albeit barely literate and without formal training, whose mantra was to get there first with the most men, Forrest was at the same time the millionaire slave-trader considered personally responsible for the criminal atrocities in April 1864 at Fort Pillow, where black soldiers attempting to surrender were summarily shot and others were said to be burned alive in their barracks.

title: EconoQuiz
description: Welcome to another installment of EconoQuiz, a regular quiz on economics issues in the news.

title: How My Father Looked
description: I think I have a way of finding out what my father looked like. Yes, finally! Excuse my excitement. My father died when I was very young, and to this day, I have never seen a picture of him. My search for his face goes back to when I lived in a refugee camp in eastern Sudan.

title: What to Do With the Boat
description: Friends staying at our lakeside house found a small paddle boat washed up on our property and, thinking it was ours, tied it to our dock. It is not. We posted an announcement about it on the community bulletin board, but no one responded. The boat is damaged, and we think it was abandoned on purpose. Rather than incur the expense of disposing of it, my husband took it to the middle of the lake and cast it adrift. Should we be ashamed? NAME WITHHELD, MICHIGAN

title: Return to Progress
description: In August Barack Obama sought to reassure his supporters as they contemplated a plunge in the opinion polls, a possible defeat on health care reform and the nagging worry that Obama, master of the poetry of campaigning, was getting stuck governing in prose. The president recalled that there had been similar panic in the ranks a year earlier, when Sarah Palins nomination had delivered a Republican spike and the November election seemed to be slipping out of reach. Everybody was, you know, obsessed with it, the president said.  Obama has lost his mojo  and cable TV was, 24 hours a day. Do you all remember that?

title: Siemens Chief Discusses Green Initiatives
description: Siemens is going through a rough patch.

title: The Pain That Binds
description: Twisted Tree, Kent Meyerss fictional small town, is in rodeo country, somewhere on the eastern perimeter of the Black Hills in South Dakota, where the creased and broken land is vast and veined by dirt roads. Drive past ranches and mud lakes and bone-filled buffalo jumps and youll spot the local bar, Ruination. The towns inhabitants are still deeply haunted by the massacre at nearby Wounded Knee, and now, in Meyerss impressive third novel, their grieving continues with the disappearance of Hayley Jo Zimmerman, a onetime barrel racing champion and one of the towns young daughters.

title: Muffins From Mr. Reid, but Mums the Word
description: It was sort of like the message on one of those T-shirts that children get after mom and dad come home from a glorious weekend in the Caribbean.

title: Barnes & Nobles Nook Sold Out for the Holidays
description: Update | 1:56 p.m.  Added comment from a Forrester analyst on the e-reader shortage.Update | 3:00 p.m.  Added comment from Amazon.com.

title: A Jaundiced View
description: Is life worth living? The corny old answer, that it all depends on the liver, is one that Will Self, in this smart, beguiling and occasionally stomach-turning book of four linked stories, finds only partly adequate. Certainly his characters lives and livers are in very bad shape, but it would take more than a good detox, or even a transplant, to return them to health.

title: Ethics Panel Admonishes Senator Burris
description: Updated: The Senate ethics committee on Friday issued a sternly worded rebuke to Senator Roland Burris of Illinois, saying he had made misleading and inaccurate statements about the circumstances surrounding his appointment by disgraced Governor Rod Blagojevich. But it made no recommendation for punishment.

title: Into the West
description: President James K. Polk has languished in obscurity long enough to have become the subject of an amusing  and remarkably accurate  rock n roll song. In four short years he met his every goal, the alt-rock band They Might Be Giants sings in James K. Polk, which the group first released on an EP in 1990. The man secured the Oregon Territory, slashed tariffs, reformed the national banking system and seized the whole Southwest from Mexico. And yet, the song concludes, precious few have mourned the passing of / Mr. James K. Polk, our 11th president / Young Hickory, Napoleon of the Stump.

title: Watch The Big Brawl on Today
description: Kim Severson and Julia Moskin took their long-running Thanksgiving battle over the importance of turkey versus side dishes to television this morning. Watch for Kims blah, blah, blah gesture as Julia makes her case, and see how convincingly they pretend there are no hard feelings at the end.

title: A Soldiers Story
description: As he explains more than once in The Remains of Company D, James Carl Nelson is haunted, haunted by the experiences of his grandfather and the other soldiers of Company D, 28th Infantry Regiment, First Division, on the Western Front in 1918. John Nelson spoke little of his past; after he died, his grandson, fascinated by fragments, set off in search of his ancestors war, which he maintains has been forgotten. Nelsons devotion led him to official histories and archives, small-town newspaper accounts and private papers inherited by descendants of members of the regiment.

title: Trying to Sell Your Business? Think Like a Buyer
description: I hate making analogies between selling a business and selling a house. It offends me on many levels, but nevertheless, here I go. I was watching an episode of The Property Ladder on the Learning Channel, and it got me thinking about preparing for sale. I watched home owners spend months filled with 16-hour days of hard labor, ripping out walls, installing cabinets and laying tile. Every decision  from paint color to countertops to flooring  was made with a buyer and an asking price in mind.

title: Gibson Guitars Plant Is Raided
description: The chief executive of the Gibson Guitar company will take a leave of absence from an environmental group after a federal raid on the companys factory in Nashville, The Tennessean reported. On Tuesday, The Tennessean reported, agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service served a search warrant on company officials at a Gibson manufacturing plant where its acoustic and electric guitars are made. The agents did not say what they were searching for or if anything was removed from the plant. But some hardwoods used in making premium guitars, like rosewood from the rain forests of Madagascar and Brazil, have recently been banned under a federal law called the Lacey Act because of environmental concerns. In a statement to The Tennessean, Gibson said that it was fully cooperating with agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service as it pertains to an issue with harvested wood. The Rainforest Alliance, a conservation group, said the Gibson chief executive, Henry Juszkiewicz, would not rejoin its board until the federal investigation ends.

title: The Morning Skate: More on Twitter and Hockey
description: Because hockey does not receive anywhere near equal attention from most of the established media in the United States when compared to other major sports, it has consistently found a home in new and emerging media. When network TV lost its interest in the N.H.L., the league pioneered bringing major league sports to cable TV in the early 80s (and the teams followed on regional sports cable networks). If fans found that their local newspaper sports sections contained little news of hockey, they increasingly sought that news on the Internet, beginning on Web sites and then blogs.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: MOONLIGHT IN ODESSA  By Janet Skeslien Charles.  Bloomsbury, $25.

title: In Iraq, a Blunt Civilian Is a Fixture by the Generals Side
description: BAGHDAD  RARELY does the hulking commander of American forces in Iraq meet with Iraqis or go to a news conference without a slight, dark-haired woman standing just a little to one side  as if to give him space, but almost always in his line of sight and within earshot.

title: Sony Ericssons Infinite Hope for a Turnaround
description: Bored with the buttons on your current phone and their limited functions?

title: Senator Nelson Will Vote to Start Health Debate
description: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, and one of three members of his party who had expressed reservations about starting debate on the major health care legislation, has issued a statement saying that he will vote to bring the bill to the floor.

title: Payard Returns (Again!); L.A. Burdick Chocolate Shop Arrives
description: Pastry-loving Upper East Siders who have been bereft since Franois Payard closed his patisserie and restaurant in June can satisfy their sweet tooth once more. Many of his specialties, including macarons, cookies and chocolates are available at Butterfield Market. His bche de Nol, a Christmas mainstay for years, will reappear in December. (Mr. Payard started selling a more limited line of sweets in the Mauboussin jewelry boutique on Madison Avenue a few weeks ago.)Butterfield Market: 1114 Lexington Avenue (78th Street); (212)-288-7800.

title: Turkey vs. Sides on 'Today'
description: Kim Severson and Julia Moskin debate whether the turkey or the sides are more essential to Thanksgiving dinner.

title: Measy: Your Personal Shopper for Cameras
description: If youre having trouble figuring out which digital camera to buyor just want a second opiniontake a look at a new Web site called Measy. This site helps you make purchasing decisions on digital cameras by asking a series of questions and then presenting you with three top choices and professional reviews culled from a range of online publications.

title: How Can We Help the Worlds Poor?
description: The number of bleeding hearts has soared exponentially over the last decade. Celebrities embraced Africa, while conservatives went from showing disdain for humanitarian aid (money down a rat hole) to displaying leadership in the fight against AIDS and malaria. Compassion became contagious and then it became consensus.

title: The Beatles Stick It to Us
description: The ubiquitous, pocket-sized USB stick, in itself only one of several forms of digital storage devices, has quickly risen above the category of gadget. It is now an uber-gadget.

title: Michigan Again Has Highest Jobless Rate
description: Fourteen states and the District of Columbia had a least a 10th of their labor force unemployed in October, with Michigans rate of 15.1 percent leading the nation, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Can Meditation Curb Heart Attacks?
description: When Julia Banks was almost 70, she took up transcendental meditation. She had clogged arteries, high blood pressure and too much weight around the middle, and she enrolled in a clinical trial testing the benefits of meditation.

title: City Moves to Restrict Front-Yard Driveways
description: The Department of City Planning has proposed regulations that would restrict certain homeowners from paving over their front yards to create parking spaces, a move that could alter the residential streetscape, especially in boroughs like Queens and Brooklyn.Responding to residents complaints of unsightly concrete driveways and lost street parking, the new rules would restrict so-called curb cuts  the sidewalk indentations created to allow cars to move from the street onto the front yards of houses  and tighten front-yard planting requirements. They would also require certain residential building owners to add parking if they modify their buildings.These changes are key to fostering inviting, walkable blocks, the city planning commissioner, Amanda M. Burden, said when she announced the proposed new rules on Monday.Like the PlaNYC and other recent Bloomberg administration initiatives, the rules hold the potential for making the city more pedestrian friendly and create more green spaces. But if approved, they would inhibit homeowners who want to carve out parking spaces on their own properties.

title: Editors Choice
description: WHAT THE DOG SAW: And Other Adventures, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) This selection of articles from The New Yorker offers plenty of the indefatigably curious Gladwells stock in trade: counterintuitive findings from little-known experts.

title: A Waffle Shortage
description: Monologue |  Aired Thursday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: The reason our Speidi senses are tingling, Heidi Montag and Spencer Pratt will be here to talk about their new book. It is  I tell ya  its a major week for literature. Heidi and Spencer, Sarah Palin.

title: Shell Sell Enough
description: Monologue |  Aired Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: President Obama said he probably wont read Sarah Palins new book, because shell sell enough copies without him. Meanwhile, President Bush said he probably wont read Sarah Palins book, because its a book.

title: The Countrys First
description: Monologue |  Aired Thursday night on NBC: President Obama has lifted his ban on doing interviews with Fox News. Well, yesterday, President Obama was interviewed by a reporter from Fox News. Yeah. And you could tell the reporter was from Fox News because the first question was, How do you think youre doing as president on a scale from minus one to minus 10?

title: Confusing and Clumsy
description: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: Welcome to New York City. Beginning Monday, you know whos going to be here? Khalid Sheikh Mohammed will be here. Hes going on trial. And the time that hes in New York City, hes going to be very busy. Monday, for example  Monday morning  hell be on the Today Show, singing I Dreamed a Dream. Very busy schedule.

title:
Pacquiao-Cotto Bout
Was a Hit for HBO
description: Manny Pacquiaos 12th-round technical knockout of Miguel Cotto in their welterweight title fight last Saturday night generated 1.25 million pay-per-view buys, with gross revenue of $70 million, HBO said Friday.

title: BofAs Ideal Chief: The One Whos Leaving?
description: It is no secret that Bank of Americas board is having a tough time finding just the right person to run the company after the chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, announced he was leaving his position at the end of the year.

title: (Not) Accepting Defeat in Egypt and Ireland
description: Updated | Saturday | 9:38 a.m. International relations continued to suffer on Friday from the reverberations over two soccer matches played on Wednesday.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE WORLD IS WHAT IT IS,   (Vintage, $17.)Frenchs biography, one of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2008, is fully worthy of its subject, with all the dramatic pacing, the insight and the pathos of a first-rate novel, our reviewer, George Packer, said. It is also a portrait of the artist as a monster. It describes the sadomasochistic triangle  physical with his mistress, emotional with his first wife  that nourished Naipaul for 25 years. InA Writers People.Ways of Looking and Feeling: An Essay in Five Parts(Vintage International, $15), Naipaul looks, both bracingly and grandiosely, at some of the writers who influenced him.

title: The Geezer Bandit
description: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: One week til Thanksgiving. Very excited about that. Back in Washington, our Congressional leaders all preparing for the big Thanksgiving meal. I read today, Nancy Pelosi already taking her turkey in to have its neck tightened up.

title: The Continuing Car Key Debate
description: We will probably have debates about older drivers for as long as we use cars.

title: Up Front: Stephen King
description: Stephen King, who reviews Carol Sklenickas biography of Raymond Carver and Carvers Collected Stories on this weeks cover, had read most of those stories by the mid-1990s.

title: Familiar Faces Chasing Perps and Plots
description: IN the old days, the career path for a certain brand of celebrity, the kind who is more than a flash in the pan but less than a national treasure, had these three steps:

title: New Play About Muhammad Ali
description: As Broadway waits to see if a new play about Vince Lombardi takes flight next season, the McCarter Theater Center is announcing a world premiere production of a play about another sports legend, Muhammad Ali, starring Ben Vereen and Evan Parke.

title: Hospital Falters as Refuge for Illegal Immigrants
description: ATLANTA  Each had crossed the border years before, smuggled across the desert by a coyote, never imagining the journey would lead to a drab and dusty clinic on the ninth floor of Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta.

title: Ringo Starr Gets New Help From an Old Friend
description: Though they get together now only for Transcendental Meditation-themed concerts and Beatles Rock Band promotional events, Ringo Starr and Paul McCartney have recently reunited for an actual new piece of recorded music. Mr. Starr told The Guardian that Mr. McCartney, his long-ago band mate, provided bass and backing vocals for a song called Walk With Me that appears on Mr. Starrs coming solo album, Y Not. When Mr. McCartney visited his home around the time of the Grammy Awards, Mr. Starr said, I played him this other track and Paul said: Give me the headphones. Give me a pair of cans. And he went to the mike, and he just invented that part where he follows on my vocal. That was all Paul McCartney, and there could be nothing better. The song was written by Van Dyke Parks and Mr. Starr, who added that Mr. McCartneys contribution makes the song like a conversation between us, and that was Pauls idea to do his part one beat behind me. The two surviving Beatles previously recorded together on Mr. Starrs 1998 album, Vertical Man, which also featured contributions from George Harrison and George Martin.

title: Study Says Air Cars are Inefficient
description: From our friends at the Wheels blog:

title: Serving Up Rockers, Out of Their Shells
description: OWEN PALLETT, who makes music under the name Final Fantasy, has eaten brain stew in Morocco, vegan country-fried steak in Atlanta and bibimbap in more places than he can remember. If you do your research, you can eat really well, Mr. Pallett said recently on the phone from his tour bus in Washington State. The occasional misfire notwithstanding (he once ate ham with Arcade Fire in Texas that tasted and smelled like a toilet puck), he said good meals on the road vastly outnumber stomach turners.

title: A Tangible Times API
description: Our series of posts about external uses of Times APIs continues. Today were highlighting Infractor, a tangible user interface for the Times Article Search API.

title: Citizen Welles as Myth in the Making
description: RICHARD LINKLATER is keen to point out that his new film, Me and Orson Welles, is not a biopic. For starters, he said in a recent phone interview: Biopics are the lamest genre. No one should attempt them anymore.

title: Must See: Ancient and Imperiled
Whats Your Favorite Chicken Soup?
description: Recently, in the midst of this swine-flu fearing fall, I found myself home sick for the day (like so many others) and my body ached with craving for, what else, chicken soup. At first I considered ordering the elixir from Second Avenue Deli, my childhood go-to, but then chose Russ & Daughters for its proximity to my East Village apartment.

title: The View From the Summit: Holding a Symposium on China
description: Overview | What are the implications of Chinas growing strength and global power? Regarding China, what should the Obama administrations policies be? In this lesson, students develop their understanding of and knowledge about key issues in U.S.-China relations, and participate in a symposium on the subject. They then develop policy and diplomacy recommendations.

title: The House of Tolstoy, in His Winter
description: I FEEL that the attitude of people toward me is no longer an attitude toward a man but towards a celebrity, Leo Tolstoy wrote in his diary. Either complete devotion and confidence, or, on the contrary, repudiation and hatred. Tolstoys harried words, and the ripe melodramas they promise, come to life in The Last Station, a new film about his turbulent final months before his death nearly a century ago.

title: Whats Your Favorite Chicken Soup?
description: Recently, in the midst of this swine-flu-fearing fall, I found myself home sick for the day (like so many others) and my body ached with craving for, what else, chicken soup. At first I considered ordering the elixir from Second Avenue Deli, my childhood go-to, but then chose Russ & Daughters for its proximity to my East Village apartment.

title: Frustration as Iran Stalls on Deal
description: PARIS  Senior officials from Western powers discussed the possibility on Friday of new sanctions on Iran for flouting the United Nations Security Councils demands and expressed disappointment that Iran had not yet accepted a draft agreement to export most of its enriched uranium for nuclear fuel.

description: Building green could add hundreds of billions of dollars to the economy, according to a new report released by the United States Green Building Council.

title: New Moon Midnight Shows Take In $26.3 Million
description: The numbers are in: Summit Entertainment said its supernatural heartthrob thriller The Twilight Saga: New Moon took in an estimated $26.3 million at midnight shows on Thursday night. The total, from 3,514 theaters, set a record, topping the midnight shows for Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, which had $22.2 million in late-night ticket sales, and The Dark Knight, which had $18.5 million.

title: Living in Astoria
description: Astoria, Queens, would seem to have something for everyone: rentals galore, row houses and co-ops, new condominiums and a few Victorian houses; a quick commute to Manhattan, and close to every kind of food that civilization has put forth.

title: Kristen Stewart: Dodging the Limelight
description: To the Editor

title: Student Charged in Fire at Stuyvesant High
description: A 16-year-old junior has been arrested and charged with starting a fire at Stuyvesant High School in Lower Manhattan, one of nine small blazes set in the last week during school hours in trash cans, stairwells and paper towel dispensers. The authorities are still investigating whether he is connected to the others.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: How to Find Mental Health Care When Money Is Tight
description: IMAGINE this situation. You fall into a deep malaise. Friends say you need help, but you dont have insurance (or the insurance you do have has very limited mental health benefits), and you worry that extra bills will only add to your malaise. So you do nothing.

title: Comment of the Week
description: If anybody still has the delusion that life is fair, just think of these two. To be paid big bucks for having so much fun, for so long. The only smidgen of justice is that we get to watch, listen  and laugh.

title: Corrections
description: An art entry in the Week Ahead report last Sunday misidentified the institution in Los Angeles that is displaying manuscripts in its show Migrations of the Mind: Manuscripts From the Lawrence J. Schoenberg Collection. It is the Getty Research Institute, not the J. Paul Getty Museum. (Both are located at the Getty Center.)

description: An art entry in the Week Ahead report last Sunday misidentified the institution in Los Angeles that is displaying manuscripts in its show Migrations of the Mind: Manuscripts From the Lawrence J. Schoenberg Collection. It is the Getty Research Institute, not the J. Paul Getty Museum. (Both are located at the Getty Center.)

title: A 200-Year-Old Tour of Gastronomic Paris
description: A Revolutionary-era gourmand financed his appetites by writing about them.

title: Morgan Stanley Reaches Deal on Barclays Loan
description: Morgan Stanley is handing over Crescent Real Estate Equities to Barclays Capital, winning forgiveness of a $2 billion loan that financed its acquisition of the real estate business in 2007.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this column omitted part of the name of a financial adviser for Morgan Stanley Smith Barney. She is Lori Dolan Frymark.

title: India to Spend $900 Million on Solar
description: Ending months of speculation about exactly what it was planning to do to boost the use of renewable sources of energy, India said this week that it will spend about $900 million on solar energy.

title: Mental Health Care on a Dime
description: In todays Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman writes about how those with minimal or no health insurance can still find ways to get the psychological help they may need.

title: One Evening at the Close of Ramazan, Ere the Better Moon Arose
description: BAGHDADPigeons sit under a full Baghdad moon. Many Iraqis raise pigeons on their rooftops and fly them as a hobby. Some will race them, but the less sophisticated merely send their flock up to lure in single birds.

title: Boycott Microsoft Bing
description: Critics have accused President Obama of kowtowing to Chinese leaders, by failing to meet dissidents, toning down his criticisms and delaying a meeting with the Dalai Lama. On balance, I think that criticism is premature: Confrontation doesnt help with China and can hurt, and so engagement becomes a fine line to navigate. The Obama visit wasnt a ringing success, but neither was it a craven embarrassment.

title: Enter Laughing Is Bound for Broadway
description: Enter Laughing, the semi-autobiographical novel by Carl Reiner about a funny young actor juggling his girlfriends, career dreams and difficult parents, was turned into a play that was a hit on Broadway in the mid-1960s and then a musical that flopped in 1976 with the title So Long, 174th Street.

title: Bears to End Movie Theater Chain Boycott
description: Did their growl make a difference?

description: This week: Andre Agassi on his memoir, Open; Stephen King on a new biography of the short story writer Raymond Carver; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: The Reading Life: Remembering Ted Solotaroff
description: The editor and cultural critic Ted Solotaroff, who died in 2008, published two clear-eyed volumes of autobiography, Truth Comes in Blows (1998) and First Loves (2003). The new issue of New England Review, just hitting Americas swankier newsstands, contains a tantalizing excerpt of an unfinished and unpublished third volume. Its worth finding.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Fela!, Robin Williams, The Blind Side and More
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete stories.)

title: Weekend Competition: Thingummyjig
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit the its-on-the-tip-of-my-tongue words they use when they cant think of the word they want to use.

title: The Roving Runner: Running in the Dark
description: The shortest days of the year are almost upon us, leaving most of us who run after work with two options: darkness or the treadmill.

title: U.S. Fears Iraqis Will Not Keep Up Rebuilt Projects
description: BAGHDAD  In its largest reconstruction effort since the Marshall Plan, the United States government has spent $53 billion for relief and reconstruction in Iraq since the 2003 invasion, building tens of thousands of hospitals, water treatment plants, electricity substations, schools and bridges.

title: Asked and Answered | Uniss Eunice Lee
description: In 2000, Eunice Lee opened Unis, her mens store in Nolita. Since then, Unis has become the go-to brand for well-dressed guys who like well-worn chambray shirts, great chinos and peacoats that will last for years. Uniss ninth anniversary is today, and it will be celebrating with a 30 percent-off sale on fall items and a party at the store from 6 p.m. to 8 p.m. Lee shared some of whats on her mind with The Moment.

title: Regulation Ends Freewheeling Era for Pedicabs
description: New York Citys pedicab industry, by most accounts, began on an East Village side-street circa 1995, a close-knit collective of tricyclists squeezed into a garage next door to the Hells Angels. Tap dancers, morticians and striptease artists were counted among the first riders.

title: 1,000 Miles Through Argentina in an Austin-Healey
description: BARILOCHE, Argentina  I call it the Curse of the Gearheads. Its an inexplicable compulsion that drives otherwise sane men and women to spend long hours in primitive cars, barreling through rainstorms and snow, and exulting in the experience.

title: Europes Bank Tightens Loan Rules
description: The European Central Bank on Friday tightened the rules for the collateral it accepts against loans as it prepares to unwind emergency liquidity measures.

title: Holiday Meals, Ghostwritten
description: Whether you are cooking Thanksgiving dinner or looking for someone to cook it for you, Christinas Epicure in East Norwich is a handy place to know. With 24 hours notice, the store can assemble a meal for 8 to 10 people from the prepared foods section of its 8,000-square-foot market. A 12- to 14-pound roast turkey, gravy, cranberry relish, stuffing, steamed or grilled vegetables, mashed potatoes and a pie costs $189. (A similar meal for 10 to 14 people is $279.)

title: A Luxurious Oasis in a Downtown Hotel
description: In the center of the business district of busy White Plains, the Lobby Lounge at the Ritz-Carlton offers a luxurious oasis of serenity. Deep armchairs and sofas fill the handsome space and surround a glass-enclosed fireplace  the perfect setting for a leisurely time-out with a light dish or a beverage at any hour of the day. The food is first-rate, the service impeccable.

title: Hip-Hops New Steps
description: Los Angeles

title: Cornucopia of Baked Goodies
description: Like the plastic ficus by the door, the 11 multitiered wedding cakes in the front windows of Chimirris Pastry Shop look a bit like stage props. Yet wedding cakes are as much a part of the bakerys business as its giant fruitcakes, which serve more than a hundred.

title: Housing Authority Extends Deadline for Registering Dogs
description: Updated, 5:05 p.m. | The dogs of public housing  the focus of a controversial crackdown by the New York City Housing Authority  are catching a break. Sort of.

title: From Leader to Laggard in Just Over a Decade
description: THE American stock market has soared 64 percent since it hit bottom eight months ago.

title: Where to Fill Up the Table
description: Dearborn Market is on a commercial stretch of Route 35 in Holmdel, but this food store and garden center has a country feel, complete with its setting in a red barn-style building. Those cooking for Thanksgiving can find fresh turkeys and a produce section filled with falls harvest  pumpkins, squashes and apples, for example. The store also sells prepared side dishes, appetizers and desserts.

title: Take 4: Things to Do This Weekend (Other Than Watch or Avoid the Big Game)
description: Music | Crooked StillThis feisty ensemble pushes bluegrass traditions to their limits. They will be appearing this Saturday at the Freight & Salvage Coffee House in Berkeley.

description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government has held an American oil geologist on suspicion of stealing state secrets for nearly two years, prompting President Obama to raise the issue during his visit to Beijing this week, the American Embassy in Beijing said Friday.

title: Experienced in Love and Money
description: Nobody can relate to the raw, visceral experience of ending a marriage better than someone who has gone through it. So it only seemed right to end my series of columns on money and divorce with a few words of advice from financial experts about what they learned when their own marriages fell apart.

title: Shopping With Laura Guido-Clark
description: Skip the red bows and silver bells. A product designer shows her imaginative way of bringing a festive touch into the home.

title: When Customer Service Seems Anything But
description: MY husband and I spent most of our waking hours last week  or at least it seemed that way  on hold listening to tinny music and then being thoroughly frustrated because the customer service representatives whom we finally reached couldnt seem to help us.

title: Boundless Cheer
description: ARTIFICIAL snowflakes, red bows and plastic silver bells are common decorations this time of year. But Laura Guido-Clark, a product designer and consultant in Berkeley, Calif., has a more imaginative way of bringing a festive touch into the home.

description: A reinforcement of noxious stereotypes or a realistic and therapeutic portrayal of a black family in America?

description: The White House is once again distributing a statement from a Republican in support of health care reform.

description: While reporting this weekends Your Money column, the last in a series of articles about how divorce affects a familys finances, I was struck by the number of people I spoke to who had fired at least one lawyer or were unhappy with the legal process in general.

title: Accepting Defeat in Egypt and Ireland
description: International relations continued to suffer on Friday from the reverberations over two soccer matches played on Wednesday.

title: Bernankes Confirmation Hearing Scheduled
description: Ben S. Bernanke has finally been scheduled for a confirmation hearing for a second four-year term as Federal Reserve chairman. The Senate Banking Committee will question him on Dec. 3.

title: A Thai Offshoot With Ancestral Heat
description: SRIPRAPHAI in Williston Park is an offshoot of a place by the same name in Woodside, Queens, that has a reputation as one of the best Thai restaurants in New York City. Since the debut of the Williston Park restaurant in October, the place has been packed; at 8:30 on a recent Friday evening, 30 people were waiting for tables. (Reservations are taken only for groups of five or more.)

title: Signs Swine Flu Wave May Have Peaked in U.S.
description: Although federal health officials decline to use the word peaked, the current wave of swine flu appears to have done so in the United States.

title: On the Question of Brining
description: Q.

title: At Gracie Mansion, Bloomberg Deplores Youth Violence
description: Expressing alarm over a gang-related shooting that critically injured a 15-year-old bystander, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg met with community leaders on Friday to discuss the stubborn problem of youth violence.

title: Chic in Review | Brangelinas Jewelry Line
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: On the Question of Turducken
description: Q.

title: Returning a Car? G.M. Would Like a Word With You
description: Getting an unknown caller ID on your phone at night? If youve recently returned a General Motors vehicle through its new 60-day money-back guarantee offer, it could be G.M. calling.

title: Down the Stairs, Latin With a Twist
description: THERE are no windows at Ola, a Nuevo Latino restaurant that opened quietly about two years ago in Orange, and the place does not look promising from the outside. The front door opens onto one of those unfortunate strip malls that line Route 1 south of New Haven. But down the stairs  just past the fish tank  its another world.

title: A Bistro That Does Grand-mre Proud
description: AT Bistro Rollin on a blustery November night, I put the roasted half chicken grand-mre to the test. If youre going to reference someones grandmother on the menu, the hen in question had better be delicious. Golden skinned and rosy hued, surrounded by adorable button mushrooms and pearl onions, perfumed with smoky bacon, this was the chicken I only wish my grandmother had had the wherewithal to make.

title: Performa 09 | Double Trouble
description: Entertainment used to be anathema to performance art, which can often seem more like an endurance test. But Performa 09, which runs through this weekend, has given us a breed of less self-indulgent artists for whom audience pleasure is paramount. Witness the exhilarating, back-to-back appearances last night by Mike Kelley and Terence Koh. Though the title of his work, Extracurricular Activity Projective #32, Plus, suggested more of the same-old-same, Kelley brought nudity, horseplay and a Bourbon Street-style marching band to the basketball court at Judson Church, the epicenter of postmodern dance.

title: Speaking to a Big Crowd, With a Greek Accent
description: WHEN I first heard about Erini, a restaurant along the Delaware owned by a Greek family, I started craving taramosalata and octopus, moussaka and spanakopita. So it was a letdown when I arrived and found the menu consisted mostly of the typical upscale Italian/New American offerings: mussels, salmon, tuna, shrimp and crab, veal and steak, pork tenderloin and chops and one chicken dish.

title: Fairy Tales, but Strictly Adults-Only
description: THINK of the artist Paul McCarthy, and its hard not to imagine him the way he has appeared in countless videos and performances through the years  stuffing a bunch of mayonnaise-and-ketchup-slathered hot dogs in his mouth, as he did, say, in Hot Dog (1974), or wearing a clowns nose and muttering maniacally while sloshing paint on canvas (Painter, 1995), or running amok with a gang of elves in a filthy, chocolate-smeared Santa suit (Santa Chocolate Shop, 1996-97). Or else doing other things in projects over the years  things involving Barbie dolls, sausages, Vaseline and his own and other peoples bodily orifices  that cannot be described here.

title: Feeding a Runner With Miles to Burn
description: WHEN my husband, Daniel, took up distance running, I knew it would have an effect in our kitchen.

title: Are Sleepless Parents More Creative?
description: I have always had a complicated relationship with sleep. Back before I had children I was a night owl, not going to bed until single digits in the morning and sleeping as late as school, and then work, would allow. My brain didnt really fire on all cylinders unless it was dark outside.

title: Students Protest California Cuts
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Garage Sale This Weekend for Amuse Bouche Street Vendor
description: Make your mouth happy!!! That was the slogan of the Amuse Bouche table, which I first saw in the mornings at 24th Street Mission BART. Murat Celebi-Ariner wore his trademark bright orange jacket, standing there in the cold morning with a smile and a muffin.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Is the public shifting the blame for the recession?

title: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Nov. 20
description: Almost every account of bloodshed necessarily focuses on death and mortal injury. In that way, though, important stories are lost: those of survivors whose lives are forever changed in one traumatic instant. More than a dozen people were killed by a suicide bomber in Afghanistan on Friday. Others, like this boy, were merely injured (Slide 4). We do not know his prognosis  or even his name, for that matter  but we can see in that tender face just how high a price violence exacts. Reuters credited the photograph simply to a stringer.

title: This Time, Egyptian Riot Over Soccer, Not Bread
description: CAIRO  History has proved that there are two subjects that will move Egyptians to pour into the streets in riotous numbers, crashing windows, burning cars, battling one another and defying an army of club-wielding riot police officers.

title: Showcase: Framed by Imagination
description: Roger Ballen, 59, is a professional geologist, a mineral explorationist. For decades he traveled to nearly every African country looking for deposits of diamonds, clay, cobalt and coal.

title: The Lip-Syncher Catcher App
description: The smartphone app Shazam identifies songs you hear being played on TV, on the radio or in a store.

title: In a Giving Mood
description: And you thought it was all about the tax deduction.

title: 5 Post Offices in City, Not 14, Are Now at Risk of Closing
description: New Yorks snail mail devotees received an early holiday gift on Friday when the United States Postal Service announced that it would keep open 9 of the 14 post office branches it had considered shuttering.

title: The Debate Over Precious
description: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire, the new film about an obese, poor, illiterate, young black woman who is sexually and emotionally abused, has sparked a heartfelt and at times heated debate about its meaning in the two weeks since its limited release.

title: Weekend Miscellany
description: Chris Suellentrop and Alan Jacobs on the ethics of first-person shooter games.

title: White House Cites Bipartisan Support
description: On the eve of a key Senate vote on the health care bill, the White House cites statements supporting the legislation from a Republican and a Democrat, Sheryl Gay Stolberg reports.

title: A Country of Vast Designs

title: Democratic Query on Insurance Rates
description: So exactly why are health insurance premiums increasing so fast for so many small employers? Some Democratic members of Congress want to know.

title: Preview: 'Dinner With the Band'
description: On this new cooking show on the Independent Film Channel, chef Sam Mason builds menus around the tastes of his indie band guests and invites them to perform.

title: Becoming the Alpha Dog in Your Own Home
description: AS far back as Father Knows Best, television has been an unintentional teaching aid for parents. To watch Mike and Carol Brady labor tirelessly to boost Jans wobbly self-esteem, or Cliff and Clair Huxtable corral Denises rebellious impulses with affection and wisdom, was to learn how to raise happy, healthy children. After all those hours in front of the set, you couldnt help but absorb the lessons.

title: Answers About Divorce and Money: Part 2
description: This week, Lili A. Vasileff is answering selected questions from Bucks readers about divorce and money. Ms. Vasileff is a Certified Divorce Financial Analyst and president of the Association of Divorce Financial Planners. She works out of an office in Greenwich, Conn.

description: 1.) Is climate change a national security threat?

title: Turkey Curry
description: Mark Bittman answers the age-old question: "What should I do with all the leftover turkey?"

title: Sailors and Mates, at Liberty
description: Were the women in On the Town always so brazen? Two are voraciously man-hungry, and the third is a cooch dancer  but only to pay for her singing lessons. Female lasciviousness hasnt been this entertaining since Sex and the City went off the air. In fact, the Paper Mill Playhouses whole new production is high-class, hotsy-totsy, spiffy and just plain swell.

title: Devils Dream
description: Chapter 1: July 1861

title: The Turkey That Went to India
description: THERE is something important about the question of what to do with Thanksgiving leftovers, the aftereffects not only of bounty and abundance but also  lets face it  of overdoing it. Weve got all this stuff, what are we going to do with it now?

title: Jumbo A380 Makes Trans-Atlantic Debut to Paris
description: At a time when many airlines are postponing costly deliveries of the jumbo-size Airbus A380, Air France is ready for liftoff.

title: Play of Knicks and Nets Is Turning Off Viewers
description: The Knicks and Nets are not giving their fans much to enjoy on TV these days.

title: Hacked E-Mail Is New Fodder for Climate Dispute
description: Hundreds of private e-mail messages and documents hacked from a computer server at a British university are causing a stir among global warming skeptics, who say they show that climate scientists conspired to overstate the case for a human influence on climate change.

title: Start Small and Think Long-Term: Saving Energy
description: NEW YORKERS get to feel smug about a lot of things. We have great food, arts and culture, the Yankees. We can also feel good about our relatively low use of energy, thanks to public transportation and our small living spaces. But sometimes  sometimes  we fail to notice where theres room for improvement.

title: Sunday Preview
description: In the 19th century, a food-obsessed writer by the name of Alexandre-Balthazar-Laurent Grimod de la Reynire began writing a series of best-selling guidebooks about the restaurants of Paris. Earlier this year, another food-obsessed writer by the name of Tony Perrottet retraced his steps and meals.

title: Advance Troops of Cinema, Marching Through Time
description: ITS about time that someone came up with a more accurate and evocative term than avant-garde, particularly because it refers to a vast and widely varied tradition of films that fall outside the norms of feature-length narrative filmmaking.

title: Raymond Carver: A Writers Life
description: Introduction

title: Video Plea From Kidnapped British Couple
description: On Friday, Britains Channel 4 News broadcast a video appeal for help by Paul and Rachel Chandler, a British couple kidnapped by Somali pirates last month. The video of the two hostages, which was apparently shot on Wednesday in Somalia, showed them surrounded by heavily-armed men and was included in this report from Channel 4 News:

title: Her World on a String
description: BROOKLYN DECKER, the swimwear model, was hovering a foot over the mat, like Tom Cruise in Mission Impossible. With her feet resting in a rope hanging from the ceiling and her hands planted wide on the mat, she was attempting an aerial variation of a push-up, part of an exercise regimen called Jukari, inspired by Cirque du Soleil moves.

title: Lots to Spend, Little to Buy
description: PITY the long-suffering brokers of luxury Manhattan real estate. They endured a lonely spell, waiting for the phone to ring. Few properties sold and few buyers were even looking. Now with the Wall Street bonus season about to begin, they are suffering again, they say, but this time because of a drought in inventory.

title: A Look at Californias New TV Energy Rules
description: As our colleagues at Green Inc. noted on Wednesday, California has adopted stringent energy consumption guidelines for televisions. But despite a lot of hand-wringing from the industry, when it comes to the availability of various models and technologies in the marketplace, the sky will not be falling.

title: City Critic | Be Smart With a Good Heart
description: Setting out to ladle soup for the needy, the City Critic finds that charitable organizations are in need of other kinds of help.

title: Bill Moyers to Leave Weekly Television
description: The PBS mainstay Bill Moyers said he was retiring from weekly television and would end his Friday night public affairs show, Bill Moyers Journal, on April 30, 2010. That date will also be the last for Now on PBS, which has been canceled.

title: A Partly Cloudy Resolution
description: MUCH has been said about buyers at glassy new condominiums who signed contracts when the sun was shining on the market but demanded their deposits back when the weather turned.

title: Classic Ad: A.M.C. Javelin
description: American Motors was a little late to the pony car party, but its Javelin, introduced as a 1968 model, proved to be a respectable alternative to Mustangs, Camaros and Barracudas. The Javelin sold well for A.M.C. until the model was discontinued in 1974, a victim (like other pony cars) of the gas crisis and the resulting trend toward smaller, less powerful vehicles.

title: Hershey Considers a Counterbid for Cadbury
description: Hershey is considering bidding for Cadbury, a proposal that would top the $16.7 billion hostile bid from Kraft, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

title: Princess Prevails in Duplex Wrangle
description: AFTER years of legal wrangling, Princess Firyal of Jordan has gained control of the huge duplex apartment owned by the late Lionel Pincus, the financier, on the 30th and 31st floors of the Pierre Hotel, facing Central Park at East 61st Street.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 20
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week. Subjects include an annual gathering of Jewish emissaries, smoke-free apartments, and college classes for prison inmates.

title: Twisted Tree
description: Chapter 1: Chosen

title: Bill Moyers to End His Run on Weekly Television
description: The PBS mainstay Bill Moyers said he was retiring from weekly television and would end his Friday night public affairs show, Bill Moyers Journal, on April 30, 2010. That date will also be the last for Now on PBS, which has been canceled. Read more on Media Decoder . . .

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 20
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Shifting Priorities
description: FOR more than five years, Jack Wu and his wife, Chiyomi Uchino Wu, lived rent-free in a two-family house owned by Mr. Wus parents in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn. It was the perfect way to save money, Mr. Wu said.

title: Students Protest Tuition Increases
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  The day after the University of California Board of Regents approved a 32 percent increase in fees that are the equivalent of tuition, protests continued on several campuses, with students occupying buildings at Santa Cruz and Berkeley.

title: Dominance of Texas Is Harder to Define in a Softer Big 12
description: With little drama left in college football until the national championship game on Jan. 7, the biggest question in college football is this: How good is No. 3 Texas?

title: Studio in Stony Brook, Heart in the Desert
description: For more than three decades, Mel Pekarsky has devoted himself to painting the desert. This is especially interesting given that he lives in Port Jefferson Station and has his studio in Stony Brook, where for 35 years he was a professor of art at Stony Brook University.

title: Borrowing From the Dog Whisperer
description: A friend of mine has a theory that children are like cocker spaniels. You lavish them with affection, yes, but when you give a simple command  one of the basic and important ones, like sit or stay or no or dont run into the street or dont play with matches  they must be trained to obey without question.

title: Ron Paul Defends His Plan for Fed Oversight
description: Defending himself against critics, Representative Ron Paul of Texas played down continuing concerns on Friday that his amendment to give Congress sweeping new oversight powers over the Federal Reserve would compromise the central banks political independence. He asserted that the Fed was not truly as independent as it would like the public to believe.

title: Chic Magnet
description: It took a lot longer than the city had hoped, but the Miami Design District has finally boomed. Established businesses of all stripes have relocated here from South Beach, and with them have come international players like Marni, Y-3, Tomas Maier, Marimekko and Christian Louboutin. Theyre all settling in nicely with these local boutiques and restaurants.

title: Cocina Confidential
description: On a night swaddled in humidity, I made my way down to La Boca, an Italian working-class neighborhood in Buenos Aires. My guide for the evening was the prominent Argentine writer Uki Goni, and as our cab crawled along, half lost, we peered out at meagerly lit scenes of urban decay. Ive had taxi drivers who wouldnt take me down here, Goni said. Shirtless men carried infants in their arms; the elderly shuffled along without looking up; a well-armed group of policemen turned a corner. These last we asked for directions. They were gracious, but unable to help. Person after person could not point our way to El Obrero, the bodegn we were looking for, an ignorance that left Goni puzzled and slightly dismayed

title: Cold Rush
description: I didnt want to be famous, but the Norwegians insisted. The smiling weatherwoman, the thumbs-up cameraman standing in the snow, even the delighted caterer, who really should not have cared one way or the other, each wanted me to sit on a half log draped in reindeer fur and say things in English to their morning TV audience.

title: Bask Country
description: Theyd been sleeping on Pirates Bay beach for three days. About a dozen of them  white guys with dreadlocks, their bikinied girlfriends and a golden retriever. They had come from Tobagos busy south end, where they lived, to this quiet corner of the island for a long weekend of sleeping under the stars. A few hammocks were strung up between the mangroves, and bottles of Beefeater, cigarettes, food and supplies littered a folding table. They said they were originally from Trinidad, Tobagos sister island 22 miles away. A couple of them tended to the campfire while a group played Frisbee fetch with the dog. After a time, a few more friends showed up on a boat idling out in the pale green Caribbean water. Hey! one of them yelled from the deck. He held up a pair of flippers and a snorkel mask to the applause of the crowd onshore.

title: Warm Intentions, Meet Cold Reality
description: What is the sound of one eye rolling? Call Joel Berg, executive director of the New York City Coalition Against Hunger, and tell him you want to engage in that wonderful holiday tradition of volunteering on a soup line in the third week of November.

title: Reaching Out to Condo Buyers
description: CONDOMINIUM buyers in the New York area often paid little mind to Federal Housing Administration mortgages, either because these government-backed loans had relatively low dollar limits or because federal rules put them beyond the reach of most condo associations.

title: Private* Climate Conversations on Display
description: [* Nov. 29, 3:41 p.m. | Updated In the last couple of days, some conservative commentators have compared the treatment of the East Anglia climate files in this post with the dissemination of Wikileaks files by The Times and charged that a gross double standard exists.

title: Maestro Who Said No Returns to Philharmonic
description: When the news came in May 2008 that Riccardo Muti, who had resisted entreaties from the New York Philharmonic to become its music director, had accepted the directorship of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, many Philharmonic musicians went public with their bruised feelings.

title: Everyones Invited to This Block Party
description: IF one wanted to encapsulate everything that defines Queens into a single neighborhood  and who wouldnt, really  the result might very well be Astoria.

title: On Frying Turkeys, Smoking Them and Other Outdoor Matters
description: Ive heard suggestions of brining the turkey before deep frying. I wanted to get your thoughts on this versus injecting a marinade. Mark, Chicago

title: The Nature of Time, Ever Passing
description: By my count, it has been more than six years since the curators at the Yale University Art Gallery organized a show of contemporary art in all media. That is difficult to understand, given that the museum collects in this area and primarily serves students, including those studying at the nearby Yale School of Art.

title: Flashback to the 60s, With Clothes and Without
description: Its a funny thing, restaging a historical work that was meant in its time always to change: which original do you revisit?

title: No Coffee Breaks for These Doormen
description: DOORMEN have always been rarer in New Jersey than in Manhattan, appearing only at the largest and fanciest condominiums along the Hudson River. Now, some can be found at smaller buildings too  but only in virtual guise.

description: New York has joined more than a dozen other states in approving a fast-spreading new method of financing renewable-energy and energy-efficiency improvements.

title: The Right Time to Show an Apartment

title: Gates Says U.S. Could Withhold Aid if Afghanistan Cannot Curb Corruption
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Friday that the United States could start holding Afghanistans government accountable for corruption by withholding money for projects where we control the flow of dollars.

title: In Draft Resolution, United Nations Rebukes Iran for Rights Violations Since Election
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations criticized Iran on Friday for numerous human rights abuses in the wake of the disputed presidential election in June, including the arrests, intimidation and mass trials of members of the political opposition.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: BOOK CULTURE, on Broadway and 114th Street, across from Columbia University, is the latest in a long line of independent bookstores at this busy corner location. Preceded by Morningside Books, and by Papyrus before that, this store departs from their erudite inventory with more commercially viable best sellers, literary novels and mysteries. A co-owner, Chris Doeblin, 48, owns a scholarly bookstore, also named Book Culture, two blocks away. After Morningside closed in May, Mr. Doeblin contacted Columbia, which owns the space, imploring every professor he knew to put in a good word. The university offered a five-year lease at a slight increase from the previous monthly rent of about $9,000, he said. Soon to open is a basement level with Spanish-language and science fiction sections, childrens books and a play area with a spacious bathroom  our secret weapon, Mr. Doeblin said.

title: Still King of the Cinematic Slopes
description: No true fan of Warren Miller ski movies has a favorite, and its not because each of the 60 is special in its own way, but because they are all pretty much the same.

title: On the Question of In-Laws and Other Family Members
description: Q.

title: The Fine Art of Quitting While Shes Ahead
description: Oprah Winfrey delivered an oh-no moment on Friday, choking up as she told her audience that after a quarter-century on the yellow brick road of blessings that led me to you, she would shut down The Oprah Winfrey Show in September 2011.

description: LAST month Peter Martins sat in a conference room surrounded by 11 shining faces, all participants in the Student Choreography Workshop of the School of American Ballet.

title: Raw Theater, Reaching for the Young
description: Bars have no problem attracting 20-something crowds, but theaters sometimes do.

title: Rock Songs and Rubber Ducks
description: The Long Island Childrens Museum in Garden City exists to enchant children, not the grown-ups who escort them. But that is not to say the occasional adult doesnt come under its spell.

title: Free At Last
description: The baseball season is over, and now another game begins  the game of free agency. And this is where the rubber meets the road.

title: A Scene From "Painter"
description: An excerpt from "Painter," a video by Paul McCarthy.

title: High-Tech Ears Listen for Shots
description: BANG! The shot rang out after midnight, sending revelers who had spilled from a house party screaming and running down a scrappy Long Island street. Four miles away, in a concrete bunker 25 feet below ground, an emergency dispatcher jumped at the sound, and homed in on its source.

title: Weekly Pick Em: An Early-Season Schedule
description: Its late in the season, but you would not be able to tell by looking at the schedule. Top-ranked Florida is taking on Florida International, No. 2 Alabama plays Chattanooga and no top 25 teams play each other. It seems like a lineup fit for the first or second week. But even in this seeming desert of decent games, there are a few matchups worth watching. Two of them  Oregon at Arizona and California at Stanford  are in the wide-open Pac-10, which has defied expectations throughout the season. Mississippi State at Arkansas may not mean much in the larger context of the SEC, but it does give two programs which seem to be improving under relatively new coaches a chance to show where they stand. Kansas States game against Nebraska does matter in the Big 12, though the prize for winning this game will be a date with powerful Texas in the conference title game. And to round things out and keep the A.C.C. fans interested, well be keeping an eye on North Carolina and Boston College. Our band of prognosticators have made their picks, and now its time to hear from you. If you agree, disagree or merely find the predictions laughable, feel free to chime in with a comment.

title: Lets Take It Outside
description: IT all started pleasantly enough: Boy meets Girl.

title: Mostly, Its About Recovering From S.N.L.
description: Seth Meyers, 35, is in his ninth season on Saturday Night Live, his fourth as head writer as well as the snide anchor of Weekend Update, the irreverent, unrepentant mock news report. The co-writer of Tina Feys spot-on impersonations of Sarah Palin, he has twice been nominated for an Emmy Award for comedy writing. He lives alone in the West Village. A very single guy: no pets, no plants, no window treatments. ROBIN FINN

title: New Leaders in Japan Seek to End Cozy Ties to Press Clubs
description: TOKYO  Twice a week, Japans new minister of  financial services is forced to hold two back-to-back news conferences: one for the members of Japans exclusive press clubs, the second for other journalists.
