description: Comedy

title: News of Hockey, 11/20/09: A Golden Moment From the Fans in Anaheim
description: Scott Niedermayer was named the first star after his overtime goal gave the Anaheim Ducks a 4-3 victory against Tampa Bay Lightning on Thursday night, and when Niedermayer decided to give his stick to a young girl in the crowd, this is what happened:

title: Jobless Rate Up in 29 States, Hitting Records in 4 of Them
description: California, Delaware, South Carolina and Florida registered record rates of unemployment in October, the Labor Department said Friday.

title: Enter Laughing Is Bound for Broadway
description: Enter Laughing, the semiautobiographical novel by Carl Reiner about a funny young actor juggling his girlfriends, career dreams and difficult parents, was turned into a play that was a hit on Broadway in the mid-1960s, and then a musical that flopped in 1976 with the title, So Long, 174th Street. That musical was renamed with the original Reiner title and revived Off Broadway by the York Theater Company last season, earning strong reviews and warm endorsements from the likes of Jerry Seinfeld. Now the producer Dan Whitten plans to transfer the York show to Broadway during the 2010-11 season, according to an e-mail message he recently sent to investors. A spokesman for Mr. Whitten said that the transfer was about a year off and that no Broadway house had been lined up. The York production was directed by Stuart Ross (Forever Plaid) and starred Josh Grisetti, above, who had been on deck to star as Eugene Jerome in a revival of Neil Simons Broadway Bound. That show was canceled last month because of a weak advance and poor ticket sales for its companion production, Brighton Beach Memoirs.

title: Microphones Join Cameras in Westchester
description: Shortly before the end of October, ShotSpotter went live in Mount Vernon, blanketing the citys entire 4.5 square miles with its acoustic gunshot tracking technology. Using half of the $3 million earmarked by Westchester County for the system  the other half went to Yonkers, where ShotSpotter is expected to be running by years end  the Mount Vernon Police Department installed the system and synchronized ShotSpotters sensors with cameras that were installed in the roughest pockets of the city.

title: For Now, New Yorkers Are the Gunfire Sensors
description: There are no immediate plans to install gunshot listening sensors on New York Citys decreasingly mean streets, according to Paul J. Browne, a spokesman for the Police Department. This is not because New York is safer than ever, he said, but rather because New Yorkers tend to call 911 whenever they hear shots.

title: Tackling Gun Violence Many Ways on L.I.
description: On Long Island, one county said yes, and the other said no.

title: Finding Early Success on New Haven Streets
description: Using a federal grant, the New Haven Police Department has installed a ShotSpotter system in a one-square-mile area in the neighborhoods of Dixwell and Newhallville. According to Officer Joseph Avery, a spokesman for the department, the bulk of the citys shootings occur in those neighborhoods. By mid-November, there had been 142 shootings there this year, down slightly from the same time last year.

title: In Trenton, on the Scene Within a Minute
description: Five cities and townships in New Jersey have installed ShotSpotter, according to the company, and Trenton is the most recent. The system went live at the beginning of October, covering 1.1 square miles of the citys northern section, a crime hot spot where people are so desensitized to violence that few report gunfire, according to the police director, Irving Bradley Jr.

title: New Moon Sets Record for Midnight Opening
description: The numbers are in: Summit Entertainment said its supernatural heartthrob thriller The Twilight Saga: New Moon, starring Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson, right, took in an estimated $26.3 million at midnight shows on Thursday night. The total, from 3,514 theaters, set a record, topping the midnight shows for Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, which had $22.2 million in late-night ticket sales, and The Dark Knight, which had $18.5 million. According to Boxofficemojo.com, the record take at domestic theaters for an opening weekend was set by The Dark Knight, which took in $158.4 million for Warner Brothers and Legendary Pictures when it opened in July 2008. That picture played in 4,366 theaters, giving it a clear edge over New Moon. But Summit is well on its way to outstripping the $69.6 million in ticket sales for the first Twilight film, which was released in November 2008. Twilight, which took in $191.5 million at the domestic box office during its first run, was re-released in 2,057 theaters on Thursday night, and took in $1.3 million, Summit said.

title: New Play About Life of Muhammad Ali
description: As Broadway waits to see if a new play about Vince Lombardi takes flight next season, the McCarter Theater Center is announcing a world premiere production of a play about another sports legend, Muhammad Ali, starring Ben Vereen, below, and Evan Parke. Set in the mid-1960s as Mr. Ali, formerly Cassius Clay, began cementing his heavyweight champion status, Fetch Clay, Make Man, by Will Power, centers on the young boxers friendship with Stepin Fetchit, the stage name of the actor Lincoln Perry. The play deals with creating personas, a point of controversy for Mr. Perry, who, as Fetchit, came across as a lazy and foolish black man  an image that proved lucrative for him. Mr. Parke has been cast as Mr. Ali and Mr. Vereen as Fetchit in the production, which is scheduled to begin performances on Jan. 8, and to open on Jan. 15 and run through Feb. 14. The Tony Award-winning director Des McAnuff (Jersey Boys, 700 Sundays) is to direct. The cast also includes Richard Masur (Democracy, The Burning Bed), John Earl Jelks (Radio Golf), and Sonequa Martin (Loss of Shadows).

title: A Flash in the Pan?
description: Once one of the brightest hopes of the new fall schedule, the ABC series FlashForward declined to some of its lowest ratings of the year on Thursday night. According to Nielsens estimates, FlashForward, a science-fiction-flavored thriller that the network has been positioning as its new Lost, drew 8 million viewers, well below the 12.4 million who tuned in for its debut in September. The lead-in of FlashForward could also be hurting ABCs medical dramas Greys Anatomy (14 million) and Private Practice (9 million), which turned in some of their lowest-rated new episodes this season. ABC placed second as CBS won the night with Survivor (12.3 million), CSI (15 million) and The Mentalist (15.7 million). Fox ranked third with Bones (9.8 million) and Fringe (5.9 million), and NBC placed fourth as ratings for its sitcoms, including The Office (7.4 million) and 30 Rock (5.9 million), continued to erode.

title: De Waart to Conduct Rosenkavalier
description: James Levine will forgo the remaining performances of Der Rosenkavalier at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Levine, the Mets music director, canceled the first half of the run in October while recovering from back surgery. He is currently rehearsing Tales of Hoffman, which opens on Dec. 3, but the Met said he did not have time to rehearse properly for Der Rosenkavalier, which re-emerges Jan. 1, 6, 9 and 15. Edo de Waart, who took over for Mr. Levine in the October run, will conduct those performances.

title: Guitar Plant Is Raided
description: The chief executive of the Gibson Guitar company will take a leave of absence from an environmental group after a federal raid on the companys factory in Nashville, The Tennessean reported. On Tuesday, The Tennessean reported, agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service served a search warrant on company officials at a Gibson manufacturing plant where its acoustic and electric guitars are made. The agents did not say what they were searching for or if anything was removed from the plant. But some hardwoods used in making premium guitars, like rosewood from the rain forests of Madagascar and Brazil, have recently been banned under a federal law called the Lacey Act because of environmental concerns. In a statement to The Tennessean, Gibson said that it was fully cooperating with agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service as it pertains to an issue with harvested wood. The Rainforest Alliance, a conservation group, said the Gibson chief executive, Henry Juszkiewicz, would not rejoin its board until the federal investigation ends.

title: Bill Moyers to Leave Weekly Television
description: The PBS mainstay Bill Moyers, left, said he was retiring from weekly television and would end his Friday night public affairs show, Bill Moyers Journal, on April 30, 2010. That date will also be the last for Now on PBS, which has been canceled. Mr. Moyers said he had been planning for some time to retire the program on Dec. 25 but was asked by PBS to raise the funds to continue through April, which he did. I am 75 years old, he said of the decision to end the series, which began in April 2007. The program has recently been having a good run of it, he added in a telephone interview on Friday, so I feel its time. He said he was not quitting television work although he had no new projects planned. Now began in January 2002 and was originally hosted by Mr. Moyers. John Siceloff, the executive producer, said the program, currently hosted by David Brancaccio, has been a unique voice at a time when outlets for insightful journalism are diminishing. He added, Were all looking for places to continue that work. PBS said in a statement that it was in the middle of a review and reinvention of its news and public affairs programming and would announce plans for its lineup in January.

title: Two Heart Surgeries Strain a Couples Finances, but Not Their Bond
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y.  Rohan and Mary Ghansam, a couple for 10 years and married for the past six, worked in the once-resplendent Concord Hotel in the Catskills together. For eight years, they were also caretakers at a Jewish bungalow colony together. And this June, they had open-heart surgery. Together.

title: A Brazilian High Priest Looks Back
description: The great Brazilian singer-songwriter Milton Nascimento was a third of the way through his concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night before he addressed the audience, from within a cloud of reminiscence.

title: Construction Sights
description: Construction Sights

title: Citizen Bruno, Unbound
description: Too much about Albany can make a stone of the heart. But wait.

title: Poetry Series Spurs Debate on the Use of an Old Slur Against Latinos
description: The word sounds retro, but its corrosive power lingers. Once a cruelly common taunt that mocked the way Spanish speakers pronounced speak, it set off fights, shattered friendships and trampled feelings.

title: Whose Recession Is It, Anyway?
description: President Obama might not like the answer to that question, at least according to CNN:

title: University of California Approves Tuition Increase
description: The University of California Board of Regents approved a plan to raise undergraduate fees by 32 percent next fall to help make up for steep cuts in state financing.

title: When Death Visits a Popular Beauty Salon
description: The flowers and candles lent a soft touch to the sidewalk outside Jailina Salon Unisex on St. Nicholas Avenue. But the closer people got, the more the sight broke their hearts.

title: Mahlers Puzzling Seventh, Played With Chemistry
description: Mahlers Seventh Symphony is probably the least popular of his nine works in the genre. Completed in 1905, it was the last of his symphonies to enter the repertory of the Philadelphia Orchestra, which didnt perform it until 1978.

title: Bloggingheads: Palin and Truth
description: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The American Prospect and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin Law School debate the veracity of Sarah Palin's memoir.

title: Canada: Court Orders Refugee Board to Consider Dont Ask, Dont Tell in Army Deserters Case
description: The Federal Court ruled Friday that a refugee board must consider the treatment of homosexuals by the United States military when examining the case of an Army deserter who is a lesbian. The court ordered the Immigration and Refugee Board to again review the case of the deserter, Bethany Lanae Smith, who fled the Army for Canada in 2007 shortly before being posted to Afghanistan. Her initial application for refugee status was rejected. Ms. Smith said that she had received hundreds of threats of violence and death while stationed in Fort Campbell, Ky., where a gay serviceman had been killed in 1999. Officers at the base denied her request for a discharge under the militarys dont ask, dont tell policy after she disclosed her sexual orientation.

title: Panel to Consider Sanford Impeachment
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  A legislative committee will convene next week to begin preliminary impeachment proceedings against Gov. Mark Sanford, according to a letter sent Friday by the chairman of the states House Judiciary Committee.

title: From Moms Basement to the Top of the Chart
description: A year ago Adam Young was working at a Coca-Cola warehouse near his home in southern Minnesota, struggling to remember melodies in his head as he loaded delivery trucks.

title: Cadbury Bid Under Study at Hershey
description: Hershey, after months of internal debate, is now considering a bid for the British candy maker Cadbury, a move that would challenge Krafts existing $16.7 billion hostile offer for the company, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: U. of Nebraska Defeats Tighter Limits on Stem Cell Research
description: The University of Nebraska Board of Regents cast a tie vote on human embryonic stem cell research on Friday, defeating a rare effort to limit such research at a university system beyond what state and federal laws allow.

title: 15 Are Indicted in Chicago in Push on Mexican Cartel
description: Federal authorities said Friday that they had struck a blow against a major Mexican drug trafficking group operating in the Chicago area, indicting 15 members responsible for one of the more significant cocaine distribution networks there.

title: August Royal Ballet Bends Itself Into Contemporary Shapes
description: LONDON  Britains Royal Ballet, an august repository of tradition  the grand hierarchical company, the full-length narrative ballet, a pure English style  seems like an unlikely incubator for the new. But Wayne McGregors appointment as resident choreographer in 2006 has placed the company firmly at the forefront of balletic change. And even though Limen, his new work for the Royal Ballet, isnt as thrillingly inventive or coherent as either Chroma (2006) or Infra (2008), it still shows Mr. McGregor as a force for intelligence and innovation in classical dance.

title: Vizquel and Guillen Share a Number, a Hero and Maybe a Team
description: Omar Vizquel and Ozzie Guillen each wear No. 13 as a tribute to another slick-fielding shortstop from Venezuela, Dave Concepcion. One of them will have to change his number next season if the Chicago White Sox follow through on their plans to sign Vizquel as a reserve infielder and unite him with Guillen, their tempestuous manager, to form one of the more intriguing pairings in baseball.

title: U.S. May Add Money to Program for F-35 Jet
description: The Pentagon is considering adding more than $200 million to the Joint Strike Fighter program and providing more planes for flight tests to try to reduce the possibility of large cost overruns over the next several years, military and industry officials said on Friday.

title: Fight Over Jewish Symbol Heads to Trial
description: The case of the missing mezuzah will go to trial.

title: Pedicabs Will Now Be Inspected and Licensed
description: New York Citys pedicab business, by most accounts, began on an East Village side street circa 1995, as a close-knit collective of tricyclists squeezed into a garage next door to the Hells Angels. Tap dancers, undertakers and striptease artists were among the first drivers.

title: Audit Finds Acorn Received Some Federal Grant Money Through Its Affiliates
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has not awarded any federal grant money directly to the antipoverty group Acorn over the last seven years, but about $200,000 has made its way to the organization or its affiliates, according to an internal audit released Friday.

title: A Survivor of Idol With Heart
description: The former American Idol contestant Melinda Doolittle, who finished third on Season 6, knows who she is and what she wants. In my heart of hearts, I want to be Clair Huxtable (on The Cosby Show) she declared on Thursday evening at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, where she is appearing through Saturday. The man of her dreams, she added, would be someone like Bill Cosbys character, Cliff.

title: Recipe: Throat Coat Adapted from Drop Off Service
description: 1 teaspoon honey

title: Barkeep, a Placebo on the Rocks, Please
description: ON Oct. 11, 1918, during the flu pandemic, a Public Health Service physician in Baltimore, alarmed by a trend hed noted, sent an urgent note to Surgeon General Rupert Blue. Sir, he began, a strong and growing belief exists in the minds of the public in this city ... that alcoholic drinks act as a preventative of influenza. This belief, he went on, is now so strong among the laity that alcoholic drinks are being purchased and consumed in enormous quantities for the purpose of preventing influenza.

title: A Kids Idea, for Dogs to Savor
description: Dog ice cream.

title: A Hamster Is the Seasons Hottest Toy
description: Whos laughing now, Elmo?

title: Sounding Board for the Dancing That Would Be Music
description: Savion Glover, the tap dancer, has been performing this week at the Blue Note with four major figures in jazz. Its all being recorded for video, but also for audio. Audio? Does that make sense? Would you want to listen to it?

title: Letters
description: Rude Revenge

title: Proton Beams Are on Track at Collider
description: Physicists returned to their future on Friday. About 10 p.m. outside Geneva, scientists at CERN, the European Center for Nuclear Research, succeeded in sending beams of protons clockwise around the 17-mile underground magnetic racetrack known as the Large Hadron Collider, the worlds biggest and most expensive physics experiment.

title: Ex-Smoker Wins Against Philip Morris
description: Legal experts predict that thousands of tobacco lawsuits could gain momentum in Florida after a Fort Lauderdale jury ordered Philip Morris USA to pay $300 million to a former smoker who says she needs a lung transplant.

title: In New Jersey Twins, a New Generation of Runner
description: WEST WINDSOR, N.J.  When Joe and Jim Rosa, twins on the West Windsor-Plainsboro High School North cross-country team, were 5 years old, they would compete to see who could stay under water longer in the family pool. They always had great lung capacity, said their father, Larry, who swam internationally for his native Puerto Rico and then at the University of Pittsburgh. We were trembling until they came up. It was scary.

title: John Mayer Just Has to Please the Girls
description: I should be having sex with more girls. This is what John Mayer concluded, using slightly more colorful language, last Sunday night at his anonymously modern apartment in SoHo.

title: Catholic Bishops Confront Senate Bill
description: The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, fresh off their abortion victory on health care legislation in the House, has joined the battle in the Senate and called for the same amendment that it pushed through the House.

title: Tips for the Admissions Test ... to Kindergarten
description: Kayla Rosenblum sat upright and poised as she breezed through the shapes and numbers, a leopard-patterned finger puppet resting next to her for moral support.

title: G.O.P. Report Connects Official to Fiancs Case
description: WASHINGTON  A report by Republicans in Congress about the Obama administrations firing of a government agencys internal watchdog suggests that the school chancellor in Washington intervened on behalf of her current fianc, who was under investigation by the watchdog.

title: U.P.S. Sets 4.9. Percent Rate Increase for Next Year
description: United Parcel Service will increase ground-shipment rates in 2010 by 4.9 percent, less than this year, as volume drops. Average rates for goods sent by air will rise 6.9 percent, with a two percentage point cut in the fuel surcharge on those deliveries, the same as this year, U.P.S. said Friday. Fuel charges during 2010 also will be adjusted more slowly once the changes take effect on Jan. 4, U.P.S. said. The rate increase for U.P.S.s ground unit is smaller than 5.9 percent increase in 2009, which was the most in at least eight years as the company faced higher costs for labor, health care and pensions. U.P.S.s domestic business has contracted for seven consecutive quarters as the recession damped demand.

title: Home on the Range and on the Stage
description: Its probably best to check your wits at the saloon door to enjoy Girl Crazy, the Gershwin musical from 1930 that opens this years Encores! series of concert musicals at City Center. Trying to bring serious engagement to this scattered romantic romp about a handful of wiseacre New Yorkers plopped down in the Wild West would be bootless. Youd be better off trying to milk a horse.

title: Nebraska Senator Will Vote to Start Health Debate
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska, one of three wavering Democrats, said Friday that he would vote to start debate on a giant health care bill as Democrats and Republicans squared off over the legislation in advance of its first big test in the Senate.

title: Putting the Fond in Farewell
description: Few people have spent more time contemplating The Journey of Life than Oprah Winfrey, and on Friday she provided another useful tip in navigating it: Quit while youre ahead.

title: Iverson Isnt the Answer for Knicks, but What Is?
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

title: New Consensus Sees Stimulus Package as Worthy Step
description: WASHINGTON  Now that unemployment has topped 10 percent, some liberal-leaning economists see confirmation of their warnings that the $787 billion stimulus package President Obama signed into law last February was way too small. The economy needs a second big infusion, they say.

title: G.E. and Vivendi Halt Talks Over Stake in NBC
description: Talks between General Electric and Vivendi over the future of NBC Universal have stalled, according to people involved in the discussions who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were part of confidential negotiations.

title: On a Birthday, Revisiting a Double Squeeze
description: Bridge is a rare game in that experts can play to a very high standard throughout their lives. The oldest world champion is Boris Schapiro from Britain, who won the 1998 World Senior Pairs at 89.

title: Tour Unlikely to Pursue Case Against Agassi
description: Andre Agassi has admitted using crystal meth and then lying to tennis antidoping authorities in 1997 to escape sanctions after testing positive for the drug.

title: Voracious Invader May Be Nearing Lake Michigan
description: CHICAGO  Asian carp, the big, hungry fish that the authorities here have for years been desperately trying to keep away from the Great Lakes, appear to have moved closer than ever to Lake Michigan.

title: Texas: Hearing in Fort Hood Case
description: An Army psychiatrist charged in the mass shooting at Fort Hood will have a hearing on Saturday in his hospital room in San Antonio on whether he should be jailed before trail. The psychiatrist, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, was wounded in the attack on Nov. 5 and has been placed in pretrial confinement by his commanding officer. If the order stands, the Army could move Major Hasan to a jail as soon as he is discharged from the hospital, his lawyer said. Major Hasan is paralyzed from the waist down and cannot flee, the lawyer said. Christopher Haug, a spokesman for Fort Hood, did not return calls from a reporter. Bloomberg News has reported that Gen. Carter Ham, the Armys top commander in Europe, will lead the services investigation into what might have been done to prevent the shootings.

title: Bruno Wont Take Stand at His Corruption Trial
description: ALBANY  After prosecutors spent 13 days building a case against Joseph L. Bruno, the former State Senate majority leader, his federal corruption trial moved toward a surprisingly swift end on Friday, with his lawyers calling only seven witnesses and announcing that Mr. Bruno would not testify.

title: Troubled V.A. Agency Will Get a New Chief
description: WASHINGTON  The official responsible for the problem-plagued disability compensation system at the Department of Veterans Affairs will resign early next year, the department announced Friday.

title: An Unsteady Future for Broadcast
description: Oprah Winfrey is fleeing broadcast television for cable. NBC, once arguably the biggest cultural tastemaker in the United States, is being shopped to Comcast, the countrys largest cable company.

title: After 18 Years, Freed to a World With Cellphones
description: Moments after he walked out of Sing Sing prison on Friday after serving 18 years for a crime that a judge ruled he did not commit, Fernando Bermudez Jr. was handed a cellphone so he could speak with one of his lawyers. It was the first time he had held one.

title: A Rebuke, but No Penalty, for an Illinois Senator
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Ethics Committee issued a sternly worded rebuke on Friday to Senator Roland W. Burris, Democrat of Illinois, saying he had made misleading and inaccurate statements about the circumstances surrounding his appointment by Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich. But it made no recommendation for further punishment.

title: Lottery Numbers
Judges Ruling Keeps Alive Lawsuit Over Seat Licenses
description: From a sports fans perspective, private seat licenses to buy season tickets are about as popular as a root canal. Fans know they need to pay for the licenses to get season tickets, but they grimace at the thought of handing over thousands of dollars to the team.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,355 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 910 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: On the Street | Hues
description: Autumns splendor appeared on the backs of a few imaginative women in a city known for dressing in black.

title: An American Catastrophe
description: Detroit

title: Reading File
description: A Paparazzi Recession

title: Steps Taken to Reduce Mistakes on 911 Fire Calls
description: Amid complaints about flaws in the citys new 911 system, New York Citys Police and Fire Departments on Friday announced steps to reduce the likelihood of mistakes in handling emergency fire calls.

title: Party Time
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Before we get to the puzzle, theres a bit of celebrating to do. Today is the 16th anniversary of Will Shortzs reign as crossword editor at The New York Times. During that period, he has edited more than 6,500 puzzles and mulled over  well, I dont even want to think how many clues. (O.K., its like half a million.) So, lets hear it for our cruciverbalist in chief, without whom our days would be a lot grayer  and a little less black and white.

title: In Defense of New York
description: Representative John Shadegg of Arizona really knows how to put on a show.

title: States Credit Rating Could Be Lowered, Investors Service Says
description: ALBANY  Moodys Investors Service this week warned that the states credit rating could be downgraded if the Legislature does not take serious steps to close the $3.2 billion budget gap and revenue continues to lag.

title: Whatever It Was, It Wasnt Dull
description: A person could get a nasty case of whiplash tracking the Knicks on-again, off-again flirtation with Allen Iverson this week.

title: NY1 Reporter Guilty of Attempted Assault
description: Dominic Carter, the NY1 political reporter and program host accused of beating his wife in their home during an argument last year, was convicted on Friday of attempted assault, the Rockland County district attorney announced.

title: Excerpt: 'Conspiracy Theory'
description: Jesse Ventura, former professional wrestler and governor of Minnesota, seeks the truth about secretive government projects in this new TruTV series.

title: N.Y. View on Health Care, 15 Years Later
description: When former President Bill Clinton joined Senate Democrats for lunch last week to exhort them to pass sweeping health care legislation, he made a point of naming one senator whom he blamed for helping to kill Mr. Clintons own effort to overhaul the health care system in 1994: Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who was senior senator from New York.

title: Albert Crewe, Physicist, Is Dead at 82
description: Albert V. Crewe, the University of Chicago physicist who developed the high-resolution electron microscope that was able to capture images of an individual atom, died on Wednesday at his home in the Lake Michigan community of Dune Acres, Ind. He was 82.

title: The McCourty Twins, Divided Between Rutgers and the N.F.L.
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Devin McCourtys mother says he has always been a little quieter than his identical twin, Jason, who came into the world 27 minutes later on Aug. 13, 1987. Jason is more likely to call home and may still be a bit more outgoing, but Devin is catching up.

title: For Nets and Knicks, Shared Woe
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Knicks cross the Hudson on Saturday to take on the Nets, resistible force will meet movable object. Between them, the beleaguered teams have a total of two victories.

title: Thomas J. Graff, an Expert on West Coast Water Use, Is Dead at 65
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Thomas J. Graff, a leading environmentalist who championed the idea of offering financial incentives for environmentally friendly behavior, an approach that had far-reaching impact on state and federal policies, especially on water use in the drought-prone West, died Nov. 12 in Oakland, Calif., where he lived. He was 65.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Friday about recommendations that women should delay screenings for breast and cervical cancer misstated a statistic from the United States Preventive Services Task Force, which released the breast cancer recommendations. The task force concluded that one cancer death was prevented for every 1,339 women aged 50 to 59 who were screened for 10 years  not 50 to 74.

title: Court Orders Dissolution of Standard Oil Co.
description: Sunday, Nov. 21, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the increased use of vulgar language on prime-time broadcast television misidentified the court that struck down in 1976 the imposition of a family hour policy by the Federal Communications Commission. It was a United States District Court in California, not the United States Supreme Court.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Oprah Winfreys decision to end her daily talk show in 2011 to concentrate on her own cable channel misstated, in some editions, part of the name of the firm of Larry Gerbrandt, an analyst who commented on the potential effect of the move on broadcast networks. It is Media Valuation Partners, not Media Evaluation Partners.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about President Obamas visit to Japan, where he announced creation of a group to study the contentious issue of the Marine base on Okinawa, misstated, in some editions, the year in which a Japanese 12-year-old was raped on Okinawa by three American servicemen. It was 1995, not 1996.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 11 about recordings from the Newport Jazz Festival and Newport Folk Festival being made available at wolfgangsvault.com referred incompletely to the founding of the jazz festival. George Wein was a founder, along with Elaine and Louis Lorillard. Mr. Wein was not the sole founder.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about a production of Peter and the Wolf, at the New Victory Theater, misidentified the conductor. The conductor is Craig Barna  not Keith Levenson, who is the music supervisor. (His surname was also misspelled as Levinson.)

title: Syracuse Shows Off New Talent in Win
description: Four prime pieces from North Carolinas run to the national championship last season graduated to the N.B.A., led by the four-time first-team all-American forward Tyler Hansbrough. But Syracuse could relate. Point guard Jonny Flynn hit the N.B.A. lottery with the Minnesota Timberwolves, and two other starters from the Oranges Round-of-16 team left to chase their professional dreams.

title: Corrections
description: A Spare Times for Children entry on Friday about a performance by Mama Doni & the Mama Doni Band scheduled for Sunday at the Museum of Jewish Heritage  a Living Memorial to the Holocaust, in Lower Manhattan, misstated the ticket prices. They are $15 for adults and $7 for children 12 and younger; for members of the museum or the Jewish Community Project they are $12 for adults and $5 for children 12 and younger.

title: Corrections
description: A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about a recital by the pianist Nareh Arghamanyan scheduled for Sunday at the Frick Collection misstated the time. It will be at 5 p.m., not 6:45.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Nov. 13 about a new version of The Prisoner, on AMC, misspelled a stars surname at one point. As the review noted elsewhere, the actor who plays Six is Jim Caviezel, not Cazievel.

title: Assessing the China Trip
description: President Obama has faced a fair amount of criticism for his China trip. He was too deferential; he didnt speak out enough on human rights; he failed to press Beijing firmly on revaluing its currency; he achieved no concrete results. The trip wasnt all that we had hoped it would be, but some of the complaints are premature.

title: The Senate Health Reform Bill
description: The long struggle by Senate Democratic leaders to merge two versions of health care reform into a single bill was worth the wait. The bill that the majority leader, Harry Reid, hopes to bring to the floor soon for debate is an improvement in many respects from the Senate Finance Committees bill, which had previously been considered a possible template for what the Senate was likely to approve.

title: Herbert J. Miller Jr., Justice Dept. Leader, Dies at 85
description: Herbert J. Miller Jr., who as a Justice Department lawyer in the 1960s relentlessly pursued James R. Hoffa, the president of the Teamsters Union, on jury-tampering and other charges, and later helped negotiate the unconditional pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon for his role in the Watergate scandal, died last Saturday in Rockville, Md. He was 85 and lived in Boyds, Md.

title: Protect the Farm, Tax the Manor
description: Newton, Mass.

title: Sagging Rangers Arent Ready to Look at Standings
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Coach John Tortorella maintained that it was too early in the season to be looking at the standings, but it was hard to ignore where the Rangers found themselves as they prepared to play the Florida Panthers on Saturday at Madison Square Garden.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Habs Pull Upset in East, Heatleys Hat Trick Keys Rout in West
description: Some elite teams in action during Friday nights six games. The Capitals, standing atop the East, put their 10-4-7 regulation record up against the Canadiens dismal 2-11-8 regulation mark. And the league-leading Sharks played host to the Flyers, who had taken maximum points from seven of their previous eight games. Home teams listed first:

title: Albany Challenges Authorities
description: Gene Russianoff, a longtime advocate for New York City commuters, had a one-word reaction when he heard that state lawmakers had agreed to a measure reforming the states 700-plus public authorities, including his special interest, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Tunas Death Spiral
description: The international commission that sets catch limits for tuna and other large migratory fish has failed, once again, to do what is necessary to give the prized bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean a real chance to survive. Meeting in Brazil last week, the commission approved an annual quota of 13,500 metric tons for 2010, well below the present quota of 22,000 tons but not the complete moratorium recommended by the commissions own scientists.

title: The Risks and Benefits of Cancer Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Care Reform and the Rise in Drug Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Inciting Fear of Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice for Rape Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: A Band Meandering Down Memory Lane
description: Where was Alex Chilton on Wednesday night? At the Brooklyn Masonic Temple, he was onstage, more or less, standing at the far right, sometimes even near his microphone (and sometimes even using it). But as has been the case on and off for the last couple of decades, he was frustratingly hard to find.

title: Matching Wits and Bodies (and Drinking Beer in Between)
description: Heres a thought: what if the artists on future split bills were required to collaborate? If they couldnt come up with something at least as interesting as what Ishmael Houston-Jones and Dan Safer managed on Thursday night at Dance New Amsterdam, bye-bye split bill. Just think of all the odd-couple pairings the dance world would be spared.

title: Israeli Choreographers Celebrate the Virtues of Awkwardness
description: There are four prima dancers  or, at times, prima donnas  in the latest collaboration by the Israeli artists Lee Sher and Saar Harari. At the start of Prima, performed at Performance Space 122 on Thursday night, Hsin-Yi Hsiang arched her back and pressed her hands into her ribcage. With her rear sticking out in stark exaggeration, she made her way toward the back of the darkened stage by wiggling her hips in a manner more ferocious than sensual. At times, it was as if she were possessed by outside forces or aftershocks; in other moments, she seemed to be going through the motions.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Thursday, about senators and the health care plan, misstated the support for health care subsidies in Arkansas. It is four percentage points more than the national average, not six.

title: The Blind Side, the Movie
description: Reviewing a few of the reviews of The Blind Side, a movie about the unlikely rise of offensive tackle Michael Oher, who now plays for the Ravens.

title: When Your Business Becomes Your Life
description: I recently lost a longtime client, who was also a dear friend and valuable mentor, to prostate cancer. He was 52 years old and left behind his wife and two children. The other day I learned that another good friend was found to have skin cancer that had progressed to the point where he had to have glands removed. He was so busy running his company, he didnt notice the moles that had started to look different. My friend is only 38 years old.

title: How To Fight Global Poverty
description: I have an essay in the NY Times Sunday Book Review about fighting poverty and some of the literature that has arisen. Nobody fights like humanitarians, so there have been battles among the Jeff Sachs camp on the one hand and the Bill Easterly/Dambisa Moyo camp on the other. My take is that the critics have some valid points  money often is wasted, projects fail, and helping people is far harder than it looks  but that were also getting better at figuring out what interventions work, and more money definitely is useful for those. I love the work of the Poverty Action Lab at MIT in bringing rigorous evaluation to development, and I think that also helps in figuring out how to get the most bang for the buck. In any case, read the essay and post any comments here.

title: The Saturday Word: A Rare Senate Session
description: President Obama used his weekly radio address to tout what he described as the major successes of his Asian tour  progress in discussions with China and Russia about new clean energy initiatives and the efforts by the countries to rein in the nuclear programs in Iran and North Korea. (Mr. Obamas closeness with China may have rubbed Indian officials the wrong way days before Indias Prime Minister visits the White House, reports The Washington Post.)

title: Jenna Lee and Brian Kim
description: Jenna Jihyun Lee and Brian Andrew Kim were married Saturday in Flushing, Queens. The Rev. Thomas F. Brosnan performed the ceremony at St. Paul Chong Hasang Roman Catholic Church.

title: Christyn Moran and Michael Muscarella
description: Christyn Joelle Moran and Michael John Muscarella were married Saturday in Philadelphia. The Rev. George S. Rigby Jr., a Methodist minister, led a nondenominational ceremony at the Union League of Philadelphia.

title: Rainbow Corcoran, Andrew Partridge
description: Tanya Rainbow Corcoran and Andrew William Partridge were married Monday in Chicago. Judge Raymond W. Mitchell of the Circuit Court of Cook County, officiated at City Hall there.

title: Stephanie James, Marc Esquenazi
description: Stephanie Leigh James, the daughter of Ellen B. James and John P. James of Short Hills, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Marc Israel Esquenazi, the son of Fortuna I. Esquenazi and Dr. Rafael C. Esquenazi of Bellaire, Tex. Rabbi Matthew Gewirtz officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Falcons at Giants: What to Watch
description: Matchup to Watch: Linebacker Michael Boley Against His Former Team

title: Legislative Pileup Looms in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON  When Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic leader, heard a few weeks ago that the House took less than an hour to approve an unemployment bill that had languished for a month in the Senate, aides said he did not know whether to laugh or cry.

title: Helen Bailey and Farhad Manjoo
description: Dr. Helen Louise Bailey and Farhad Manjoo were married in San Francisco Saturday by Imam Junaid M. Kharsany at 1 Fort Mason, an event space.

title: Jessica Meller, Patrick Cranston
description: Jessica Suzanne Meller and Patrick Scott Cranston were married Saturday. Kim Kirkley, a Universal Brotherhood minister, led a nondenominational ceremony at Bridgewaters, a restaurant in New York.

title: Emily Theriault, Luca Laino
description: Emily Theriault and Luca Laino were married Saturday at The Racquet and Tennis Club in New York. The Rev. David T. Lewicki, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Norah Lawlor, Jeffrey Bradford
description: Norah Elizabeth Lawlor and Jeffrey Peter Bradford were married in New York Saturday by the Rev. George W. Rutler at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour, where he is the pastor.

title: Erika Savage, Philip Alberstat
description: Erika Lynne Savage and Philip Alberstat were married Saturday evening in Palm Springs, Calif. Rabbi Neal Weinberg officiated at the Parker Palm Springs, a resort.

title: Megan Brady, Michael Monforte
description: Megan Elizabeth Brady and Michael Angelo Monforte were married Saturday in a self-uniting civil ceremony under Pennsylvanias marriage statute at the Blue Bell Country Club in Blue Bell, Pa.

title: Carly Weiss, Jonathan Natko
description: Carly Brooke Weiss, a daughter of Susan P. Weiss and Paul H. Weiss of Blue Bell, Pa., was married Saturday evening to Jonathan David Natko, a son of Andrea Natko and Les Natko of Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Baht Yameem Weiss officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Naples, Fla.

title: Susan Mendik, Moe Tarkinow
description: Susan Mendik and Moe Tarkinow were married Saturday in New York. Dr. David M. Posner performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El, where he is senior rabbi.

title: Mara Sitomer, Daniel Seigerman
description: Mara Rebecca Sitomer, the daughter of Terry Sitomer and Jeffrey Sitomer of Upper Saddle River, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Daniel Allan Seigerman, a son of Robin Seigerman and Dr. David E. Seigerman of Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Lee Friedlander officiated at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan, with Rabbi Joel Mosbacher taking part in the ceremony.

title: On the Question of Questions
description: A point of procedure from Diners Journal headquarters: I have some restaurant reviewing to do. Ill be back on Monday to answer more Thanksgiving emergency questions, including the whole woodpile that landed this morning. In the meantime, you can put up comments (or your own answers) to the posts where Ive answered questions here, here, here, here and here, and, of course, you may continue to post questions here. Gobble, gobble!

title: Obamas New Stimulus Plan
description: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Big night at the movies yesterday; New Moon made a record $23.3 million at a midnight screening. In fact, earlier today president Obama announced his new stimulus plan. Its called Twilight 3.

title: Tired of Lou
description: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on NBC: According to a new poll, more Americans would like to have Thanksgiving dinner with Hillary Clinton than with Sarah Palin. Mainly because no one wants to eat elk pie. With caribou syrup on it.

title: Have You Seen the Sticker?
description: Monologue | Aired Friday night on CBS: On Friday, President Obama pardons the White House turkey. Dick Cheney didnt miss an opportunity. This proves that Obama is soft on poultry.

title: Afghanistans Traditional Clothing
description: Monologue | Aired Friday night on NBC: This has been quite a week for Sarah Palin. Shes been everywhere promoting her new book. She was on Oprah. She was on Good Morning America, ABCs World News, Nightline, Barbara Walters. Not to be outdone, next week, John McCain will be the guest corpse on CSI.

title: Sari Scheer, Samuel Kopel
description: Sari Scheer and Dr. Samuel Kopel were married Saturday evening at the Edmond J. Safra Synagogue in Manhattan. The rabbi, Dr. Elie Abadie, performed the ceremony.

title: Italian Prosecutors Ask for Life Sentence in Trial of U.S. Student
description: ROME  Prosecutors in Perugia, Italy, asked Saturday for life in prison, Italys stiffest sentence, for an American college student and her Italian former boyfriend accused in the death of her British housemate in 2007.

title: Nicole Pearl, David Kaplan
description: Nicole Beth Pearl, a daughter of Susan P. Pearl and Kenneth B. Pearl of Highland Park, Ill., and David Michael Kaplan, the son of Kathy Kaplan and Richard Kaplan of Chicago, were married Saturday evening in Hallandale Beach, Fla. William A. Rudnick, a friend of the couple who is also a Universal Life minister, led a ceremony at the Diplomat Golf Resort and Spa that was rooted in Jewish tradition.

title: Galaxy Wins MLS Cup  in FIFA 10
description: Simulation  the word many Europeans use to describe a player taking a dive on the field  has become the bane of the game (or at least it was until Thierry Henrys Hand of Gaul last Wednesday).

title: Bess Rattray, Paul Gartside
description: Bess Rattray and Paul Gartside were married Saturday on the island of Nevis in the West Indies by Magistrate Yasmine Clarke.

title: Pamela Aronstam and Samuel Buxton
description: Pamela Joy Aronstam, a daughter of Vicki Aronstam and Neil L. Aronstam of New York, was married in New York Saturday evening to Samuel Cary Buxton, the son of Dr. Judy Buxton of Villanova, Pa., and Dr. Alfred Buxton of Barrington, R.I. Dr. David M. Posner, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, performed the ceremony at Essex House.

title: To the Happy Couple, and My YouTube Clip
description: WEDDING toasts can be witty or raunchy. They can be shouted, mumbled or slurred. They can make guests laugh, cry or yawn. But in a video democracy in which guests are often armed with sophisticated cameras, toasts are becoming more like scripted performances.

title: Cleric Wields Religion to Challenge Irans Theocracy
description: CAIRO  For years, Grand Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri criticized Irans supreme leader and argued that the country was not the Islamic democracy it claimed to be, but his words seemed to fall on deaf ears. Now many Iranians, including some former government leaders, are listening.

title: A Museum That Roars Once a Month
description: In the Automobiles section of The Times this week, Dave Caldwell writes about Demonstration Days at the Simeone Foundation Museum in Philadelphia. On the fourth Saturday of each month, the museum rolls out some of the cars from its collection of vintage racers, fires them up and takes them for a spin on the three-acre grounds  making this a museum where the displays are anything but static.

title: Margaret Bruton, John McCardell III
description: Margaret McKissick Bruton, the daughter of Jean D. Bruton and John C. Bruton Jr. of Columbia, S.C., and John Malcolm McCardell III, a son of Bonita G. McCardell and Mr. McCardell Jr. of Middlebury, Vt., were married Saturday at St. Johns Episcopal Church in Columbia. The Very Rev. Dr. Philip C. Linder, dean of Trinity Episcopal Cathedral in Columbia, performed the ceremony.

title: Senate Votes to Open Health Care Debate
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted on Saturday to begin full debate on major health care legislation, propelling President Obamas top domestic initiative over a crucial, preliminary hurdle in a formidable display of muscle-flexing by the Democratic majority.

title: In Turkey, Trial Casts Wide Net of Mistrust
description: ISTANBUL  Few here doubt that the case began with something threatening: in June 2007, 27 hand grenades and fuses were found in the attic of a house in an Istanbul slum. Investigators claimed they were stashed there by an ultranationalist retired officer and they were later linked to an elaborate coup plot.

title: Sparring Begins in Health Care Debate
description: The Senates Saturday debate got off to a testy start that provided an exhibition of the media criticism skills of Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, and his Republican counterpart, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky.

title: Medvedev Says Backwardness Undermines Party
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia accused the governing party, United Russia, of backwardness on Saturday, warning its leaders that they must learn to win elections honestly if it is to survive.

title: Quotation of the Week
description: My patients tell me they can live with a little anxiety and distress but they cant live with a little cancer.

title: Benedict Woos Artists, Urging Quest for Beauty
description: VATICAN CITY  In 1512, Raphael finished his ruminative portrait of Pope Julius II, who commissioned Michelangelo to paint the Sistine Chapel ceiling. In 1999, the Italian conceptual artist Maurizio Cattelan produced The Ninth Hour, a wax sculpture of Pope John Paul II struck down by a meteorite.

title: Prime Number
description: 49 million: The number of Americans who lived in households that lacked consistent access to food in 2008, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. The number was up by 13 million Americans over the previous year and was the highest since the government began tracking what it calls food insecurity 14 years ago. In about one-third of those households, lack of money forced members to skip meals, cut portions or otherwise forgo food at some point. The rest had enough to eat, but only by eating cheaper or less varied foods or by relying on government or private help.

title: Dancers Perform Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  One thing that appeals to me about Hexs acrostics is that words like the answer to Fully realized condition are included. Such a word would be much less likely to show up in a crossword puzzle, maybe only in a tough Saturday puzzle. Frankly, Im not sure Id like it too much there, but here, I find it to be a bit of intellectual icing on the cake.

title: Wall Streets Spin Game
description: Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, the bank to bash on a resurgent Wall Street, is receiving a lot of advice lately, and its not just about money.

title: Afghan Militias Battle Taliban With Aid of U.S.
description: ACHIN, Afghanistan  American and Afghan officials have begun helping a number of anti-Taliban militias that have independently taken up arms against insurgents in several parts of Afghanistan, prompting hopes of a large-scale tribal rebellion against the Taliban.

title: Answers on Community Colleges, Last of 6 Parts
description: Each day this week, the Guidance Office  the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts  has featured answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: Italy Arrests 2 Over Attacks in Mumbai
description: ROME  The Italian police on Saturday arrested two Pakistani men accused of helping to send money to finance the terrorist attacks that killed 163 in Mumbai last November.

title: Landrieu Seems to Be Leaning Reids Way
description: Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana has been one of three Democrats to cause party leaders heartburn in recent days because of uncertainty over how she would vote on the major health care legislation.

title: Anglican Leader and Pope Hold Cordial Talks
description: VATICAN CITY  A month after the Vatican announced the creation of a new Anglican rite within the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Benedict XVI on Saturday held cordial discussions with the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, the archbishop of Canterbury and spiritual leader of the Anglican Communion, the Vatican said in a statement.

title: High-Tech Devices Help Drivers Put Down Phone
description: Dede Haskinss cellphone has been her constant companion for more than a decade. And she has always considered herself a careful driver  even using a hands-free set so she could keep both hands on the wheel.

title: For Martin, Finishing Second Wouldnt Mean Falling Short
description: The final event in a relatively unspectacular 36-race Nascar Sprint Cup season is likely to amount to little more than a 267-lap parade Sunday in Homestead, Fla., with Jimmie Johnson almost certain to cruise to an unprecedented fourth consecutive series championship.

title: Letters: The Archbishops Blog, Paying for The Times and Bloombergs Blowout
description: Re The Archbishops Blog (Nov. 8):The explanation for The Timess refusal to publish Archbishop Timothy Dolans letter is lame and defensive, as is the rest of your column. Your argument seems to be that because The Times gave the archbishop a lot of coverage and said some nice things about him when he first came to New York that it can with impunity publish imbalanced and biased articles about the Catholic Church.Likewise, you seem to argue that because some of the religion writers for The Times sometimes write articles that are not considered offensive, this makes the offensive ones O.K. With respect to Maureen Dowd, its difficult to see how The Times sponsors her vitriolic diatribes in general. Her work is short on reason and logic but long on venom and distortion, hardly a contribution to serious public discussion. Its no secret that The Times is steadily losing readership. Remaining in denial about its skewed coverage of the Catholic Church is just the latest example of how badly out of touch with reality the editors and writers for The Times continue to be. I suspect many will find your attempt to defend The Timess record on this matter to be thoroughly unpersuasive.MSGR. MICHAEL FITZGERALDPhiladelphia, Nov. 8, 2009 I write as a Catholic nun who is a daily reader of The Times, and I agree with your conclusion that The Times does not have a pattern of anti-Catholicism. Maureen Dowds column on nuns and the Vatican was compatible with my anger and anguish about the moral crisis in the church. If any group in the U.S. Catholic Church should be investigated, it is the bishops who presided over the pattern of moving troubled priests from parish to parish without disclosure  to parishioners or legal authorities  of actions that potentially constituted sexual abuse and required investigation. In January 2006, The Times wrote an editorial praising a Detroit auxiliary bishop, Thomas Gumbleton, for his advocacy of improved public policies to deal with sexual abuse by priests and others. Subsequent to the publication of this editorial, local church leaders remarked that the supportive editorial was proof that The Times had an anti-Catholic bias. This reactionary critique causes me to infer that the accusation of anti-Catholic bias on the part of The Times is an example of the Catholic Churchs being defensive and protective of itself, not an objective assessment of the attitude of the newspaper. SISTER SUE SATTLER, I.H.M.Detroit, Nov. 8, 2009 The New York Times has no sympathy toward the Roman Catholic Church and, in fact, is institutionally predisposed to find fault with the church wherever and whenever it may be found.The Times does not value churchgoing Roman Catholics as part of its constituency; as a result, we are fair game. The core audience of The Times  secularists, atheists, members of certain politically left-leaning Christian and non-Christian denominations, all enjoy it immensely when The Times uses its pages to kick the church. Archbishop Dolan is correct  other faiths (and, I might add, certain other favored segments of society)  get a bye from the writers and editors of The Times. Who knows? Maybe the Times and its Catholic-baiting political and cultural allies will eventually hound us into shutting down our charities, closing our hospitals, ending our school system and walking away from our colleges. But life in New York and this nation would be much poorer for it.THOMAS J. RICE Manhattan, Nov. 10, 2009  I see nothing in Archbishop Dolans screed that claims the facts of the reporting were wrong. Hes just upset that the wrongs were reported. It is asked: What is fair to report and criticize about the leadership of a religion? Everything is fair to be reported  the good, the bad, and the ugly, as long as the reporting is accurate. Dolan says that Dowd dug deep into the nativist handbook to use every anti-Catholic caricature possible. Virtually every Catholic in the country opposed the nativist anti-Catholic assault of the 19th century, but todays Catholics, on the other hand, support and praise the secular press coverage of the crimes and cover-up of the crimes of Catholic clergy  coverage that is almost totally absent in the Catholic press. Nothing is being reported today that the clergy has not brought on itself. For centuries the Catholic clergy has impressed on the laity the image of a clergy so superior that there slowly emerged the perception of a real ontological difference between the two. Accurate reporting in the secular press about sexual abuse, larcenous pastors stealing millions from their parishes, and now a Vatican investigation of our nuns is rightly tearing down this myth. B.M. BYRNEVienna, Va., Nov. 9, 2009  It is not surprising to me that the Catholic archbishop would see anti-Catholicism in the article by Maureen Dowd, coverage of the pedophilia scandal and other stories that didnt reflect well on Catholics or the Catholic Church. The church is and always has been an authoritarian hierarchy. As such, it is able to prohibit dissent or criticism from members of its hierarchy and, to a great degree, members of its congregations. It is reasonable for an archbishop to conclude that if he cant criticize, no one else should be allowed to either.In a secular, liberal democratic state, the cherished right of freedom of speech includes the right to criticize anybody and everybody. I hope these values persist for a long time to come. I have little hope that religions that depend on blind obedience will embrace them anytime soon.STEPHEN JONESVenice, Fla., Nov. 10, 2009  Im an 84-year-old Catholic who has been reading The Times since I was 17. I cannot agree with Archbishop Dolans outrage over Maureen Dowds column on the attitude of the church toward nuns. Women are just as intelligent and responsible as men. Many of them occupy the top positions in American business and serve in growing numbers in both houses of Congress as well as presidential cabinets. Indeed, one female recently almost achieved the office of president. Whats next  ordained female priests?TERRY ROEWarminster, Pa., Nov. 9, 2009   Re Recession, Revolution and a Leaner Times (Nov. 1):Doubtless the decision about charging online readers is an important one, but seldom are important business decisions arrived at by following a clear consensus. More often, when one finds a clear business consensus, it is often proved wrong and/or late, like American auto companies decision to play down smaller, fuel-efficient cars. No, this is a tough decision that will accurately be made by leadership choosing a path or paths that may appear questionable at the outset, but may be recognized as visionary later.GARY SWAYZEManchester, Mass., Nov. 1, 2009 Come on, throw us a bone here  give those of us who care about The New York Times an opportunity to support it. How about a We Love the NYT coffee mug, an All the News Thats Fit to Print umbrella, an Honorary Times Cub Reporter T-shirt, a Members Only spot on the Web site  you name it, well probably donate to get it.Like many Times supporters, my home page is The New York Times, and I read it (for free) every day. I send articles (for free) to friends and family by e-mail probably once a week. I get the Sunday Times delivered to my Toronto home but I cant justify getting the paper (or any newspaper) every day. But I rely on the kind of reporting that no one but The New York Times is doing, and Id be willing, even thrilled, to support it in the same way I support Minnesota Public Radio, which I listen to (for free) online. Just give me a premium or two and a convenient way to send a hundred bucks or so to keep this kind of journalism alive while it finds a new economic basis for survival.GERSHON SILINSToronto, Nov. 2, 2009  I am among those who hate seeing new organizations die by a thousand self-imposed cuts. At 39, I am on the younger end of the cohort that cant live without newspapers. But my wife and I have already dropped our subscription to The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, our local daily, because it has so deconstructed itself that theres no point in paying for it.After the last price increase by The Times, I reluctantly gave up the print edition for Times Reader. It was a difficult decision and a hard adjustment; Id still prefer to handle an actual newspaper, but it made no sense to pay over $800 per year when I can pay $15 per month for the same content. It seems to me that there ought to be something in between. Id obviously be willing to pay far more than $15 per month.I continue to believe that in the long run, the best model for a news organization will be that of a nonprofit, public-service organization. There will always be a readership, an increasingly small and specialized niche for newspapers, but the old business model will not last. In my opinion, The Times should essentially junk its junky free site and develop more along the polished, clean subscription service represented by Times Reader.DAVID TALLMANAtlanta, Nov. 2, 2009 Like other dedicated readers, I am worried. There is so much talk of newsroom cuts and elimination of bureaus and newspaper sections, I open the Sunday Times fearful that some section will be missing, or there will be some subtle change in the quality of the articles. Yesterday I was reminded that change and technological innovation will not necessarily lead to the demise of newspapers. I read The Times using the Times Reader for the first time and I was impressed by how easily I could work my way through in an efficient yet leisurely way  as a Sunday read ought to be. While nytimes.com is useful and a site Ill continue to use, its very different from the experience of actually reading the (print-version) paper. I tend to jump about, depending on what grabs my attention, and I rarely get through the days news. And I find pop-up ads irritating. But why is there no advertising in the Times Reader version of the paper? Wouldnt this be a perfect vehicle for print-style ads (NOT pop-ups!!)? The beauty of in-paper advertising is that it is seen, but if it is of no interest the reader can skip over and ignore it. It does not detract from the pleasure of reading the paper. Old-fashioned, perhaps, but effective. Surely there remain some advertisers out there who would see value in placing their messages here.CHERISSE BANDY Foster, R.I., Nov. 2, 2009 This morning, like every Sunday morning, I went out to the little coffee shop that charges $1 per cup for any size coffee, and picked up my New York Times. Five dollars for the paper is a lot of money for me at the moment  I am 69 years old, have been unemployed for almost a year, and things are very tight. However, not having the Sunday Times is like giving up a part of my history (I grew up in New York, and along with bagels and lox, The Times is Sunday morning), and giving up on the great tradition of print news. So, I pay my $5, buy cheaper food for the cat (just kidding) and enjoy the luxury of Sunday with the Times.Weekdays I mostly catch you online  and for the past few months I have been wondering why you do not charge at least a nominal fee for this service. I would be happy to pay it (Ill tell the cat to eat cake) if that fee would guarantee that the print version of The Times would stay with us. Our country needs real journalists  those guys that hold the governments feet to the fire and protect our interests. I hope you do go ahead with charging for online service, and I hope again to see reporters playing bridge and working crossword puzzles.SHARON RESNICKPrinceton, N.J., Nov. 1, 2009 Why dont you ask for voluntary contributions from online readers? I would be very glad to pay $300 per year. It is wonderful to read the paper here in Edmonton at the same time that someone in New York can. And many of your readers understand well how important investigative journalism is in keeping governments honest.BILL KELLY Edmonton, Alberta, Nov. 1, 2009 I am a faithful reader of The New York Times online, but if it were not free, I would not have become so faithful. I used to go to many different sites to get all the news. Now I start at your site and believe it is by far the best in the United States. My recommendation is to allow a one-year free subscription to new users. Then try to keep the yearly charge as low as possible to encourage the widest readership. Like the woman in your column, I have my credit card ready. STEVE MARTIN Seattle, Nov. 1, 2009 I encourage the debate on charging for The Times online, which The Wall Street Journal and The Economist are doing. But I have a problem if a subscription Web presence will still involve cookies and the related spying on my Web activity. I have debated this with people at The Times and The Economist.The Times suggests that the cookies make the Web easier to use. But there is nothing in the cookies I found that improves my Web experience; many of them are tracking cookies that allow someone to build a marketable profile of me.The argument in your column is that millions of online advertising dollars are at stake if charging for access reduces the number of viewers. That may be, but the advertisers should be aware that many Web users, like myself, do not allow cookies and work diligently to avoid any tracking. And a growing number of Web users are learning about tracking and how to block the intrusion into personal privacy.The decision to charge or not is, in my view, a decision on the long-term survival of The Times. I am concerned that in time the loss of print revenue will force the online version to support more and more of the papers operations. My larger concern is that the work of powerful newspapers  in keeping our governments and corporations in line with investigative reporting  will disappear without a decent revenue stream to pay the costs of such reporting. So I am willing to pay for access to a robust online New York Times, but I am not willing to surrender my privacy to get it.RAYMOND C. GRAYEaston, Pa., Nov. 1, 2009  Re About That Bloomberg Runaway (Nov. 15):  Your column suggests the correct and inescapable point that polls can serve as self-fulfilling prophecies, discouraging those who would otherwise vote if the polls were more promising for their candidates. The important point left out, however, is that pollsters should ask directly regarding the intensity of support for candidates, rather than relying on whether respondents may change their minds. That is a good question, but it is no substitute for also inquiring about how strongly poll respondents support specific candidates. If all polls asked about both the strength of support and the likelihood of voters changing their minds, fewer large disparities between poll support and election support would occur.RICHARD E. VATZTowson, Md., Nov. 15, 2009 The writer is a professor of political rhetoric at Towson University.

title: Republicans Eye the Tiger of Populism
description: WASHINGTON  Via Oprah, Facebook and a bus trip that resembled a campaign swing more than a book tour, Sarah Palin reappeared on the national stage last week, minus her governorship and running-mate status, but with a new role as principled rogue to add to her previous credits as plain-spoken patriot and hockey mom.

title: A Terror Suspect With Feet in East and West
description: PHILADELPHIA  The trip from a strict Pakistani boarding school to a bohemian bar in Philadelphia has defined David Headleys life, according to those who know the middle-age man at the center of a global terrorism investigation.

title: Get a Mammogram. No Dont. Repeat.
description: The current dispute over mammograms gives many people whove been around since the 1980s a sense of dj vu. Like archeologists arguing endlessly over the same set of bones, cancer specialists, it can seem, have been arguing endlessly over pretty much the same set of data.

title: Survey of Pakistans Young Predicts Disaster if Their Needs Arent Addressed
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Pakistan will face a demographic disaster if it does not address the needs of its young generation, the largest in the countrys history, whose views reflect a deep disillusionment with government and democracy, according to a report released here on Saturday.

title: Plotting Thrillers in the Fog of China
description: President Obama stood at a town hall meeting in Shanghai last week, fielding questions from eager Chinese students, an American leader demonstrating the give-and-take of democracy to a nation under one-party rule. Except that the students were mainly members of the Communist Youth League, hand-picked by the Chinese Communist Party, and the first question set the tone: What measures will you take to deepen this close relationship between cities of the United States and China?

title: Santa Still Lives at the North Pole
description: It turns out that children who send letters addressed to Santa Claus this year will get a response from the North Pole after all.

title: The Senate Health Care Debate
description: To Our Readers,

title: Not Your Grandfathers Stats: Baseball Redefined
description: As Zack Greinkes magical season rolled along, another Kansas City Royals pitcher, Brian Bannister, excitedly tracked his teammates progress. With the Royals long out of the pennant race, it did not matter to Bannister how many victories Greinke compiled, or how many points he shaved off his earned run average. To Bannister, it was all about WAR.

title: Best Soup Ever? Suits Over Ads Demand Proof
description: A diamond is forever? Prove it.

title: Advertising Foes Meet in Court
description: Companies are testing advertising claims by competitors, leading to lawsuits.

title: Go Ahead and Yell. Hes Everyones Punching Bag.
description: ESTERO, Fla.

title: Thanksgiving Recipe: Just Chill
description: This week, more than 200 million of us will feast, mostly in the homes of friends and relatives. In the kitchens of those homes will be cooks, and in the hearts of those cooks will be fear.

title: The Sarah Palin Roadshow
description: It was one part book tour and one part political festival as the former Alaska governor began her long-awaited bus tour.

title: Medical Marijuana: No Longer Just for Adults
description: At the Peace in Medicine Healing Center in Sebastopol, the wares on display include dried marijuana  featuring brands like Kryptonite, Voodoo Daddy and Train Wreck  and medicinal cookies arrayed below a sign saying, Keep Out of Reach of Your Mother.

title: Revisiting a Fed Waltz With A.I.G.
description: A RAY of sunlight broke through the Washington fog last week when Neil M. Barofsky, special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program, published his offices report on the government bailout last year of the American International Group.

title: Goldmans Response to Questions About A.I.G.
description: This memo from a Goldman Sachs spokesman, Lucas van Praag, was sent to Gretchen Morgenson, a business columnist for The New York Times, in response to questions she asked about the report issued Nov. 17 by the special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program (referred to in the memo as SIGTARP) on the governments September 2008 rescue of the American International Group, the giant insurance company. (The memo cites Ms. Morgensons questions in boldface.)

title: 65? Back of the Line for the Swine Flu Vaccine, Pal
description: Life is unfair. Or, at least, it sure can look that way.

title: From Browns to Jets, for More of the Same
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Even his Jets teammates feel extra sympathy for wide receiver Braylon Edwards.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 22
description: The Sunday talk shows are all abuzz with the morning-after chatter coming behind the Senates health care vote late Saturday that caps off an intense week in the debate.

title: From the Lab, a New Weapon Against Cholesterol
description: The particles that ferry cholesterol through the bloodstream are popularly known as bad or good: bad if they deposit cholesterol on vessel walls, potentially clogging them; good if they carry the cholesterol on to the liver for excretion.

title: Play It Again: Big 12 vs. SEC
description: Its hard to imagine comparing the 2008 college football season to the current one. But with essentially three weeks to go in this most bizarre season, the similarities are striking.

title: The Great Unknowns of Credit Card Bills
description: Three years ago, the Hagglers credit card bill seemed to stop showing up in the mail. Another month went by  no bill. The month after that, still nothing. Each month, the Haggler would call the issuer, Bank of America, and pay over the phone, then ask the same question: "Why did you stop sending me a bill?"

title: The Forest, the Trees and Your Portfolio
description: Buy low and sell high. It sounds simple. But if its that easy, why dont more investors do it?

description: Glenn Beck, the popular and outspoken Fox News host, says he wants to go beyond broadcasting his opinions and start rallying his political base  formerly known as his audience  to take action.

title: The Business Must Go On
description: Im one of nine sisters. My parents were dairy farmers in Wisconsin. My father didnt believe in girls doing farm work. Girls did housework, and he hired young men to do farm work. I would have preferred to be outside.

title: Thrust and Parry on the Senate Floor
description: Unless the Sunday morning news programs are buzzing about how the Senate health care bill was unexpectedly blocked on a procedural vote Saturday night, lawmakers have all headed home for Thanksgiving, and to rest up for what is likely to be a legislative floor fight of galactic proportions through much of December.

description: Perhaps the clearest indicator of the state of the Cleveland Browns came from the sign a fan carried at their Monday night game last week.

description: Q. You recently became pregnant and expect to continue working through the pregnancy and after maternity leave. Although the initial reaction has been positive, is it possible you will face negative repercussions in the office?

description: The Maple Leafs may be in dead last in the N.H.L. with 3 wins and 17 losses, but such is the peculiar mania in Hogtown that some 10,000 fans show up for a Leafs open practice at the Air Canada Centre on Saturday morning.

title: Correction: Chinas Sprint for the Gold
description: An article last Sunday about Chinas economic growth described the trade relationship between China and the United States incorrectly. China is Americas biggest source of imports, not its biggest trading partner. (Americas biggest trading partner, a category that takes account of American exports as well as imports, is Canada.)

title: A Friends Tweet Could Be an Ad
description: Tuesday was another typical day for John Chow, blogger and Internet entrepreneur in Vancouver, British Columbia. Mr. Chow treated his 50,000 Twitter followers to a photograph of his lunch (barbecued chicken and French fries), discussed the weather in Vancouver and linked to a new post on his Internet business blog.

title: Giants Ross Heals With Help From Fiance, a Gold Medalist
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Cornerback Aaron Ross hopes to make his season debut Sunday when the Giants host Atlanta in their 10th game of the season.

title: Correction: Naming the 00s
When a Coin Doesnt Pull Its Own Weight
description: Pennies are constantly proving their symbolic value. They are watched, pinched, exchanged for thoughts, and they keep our widely admired 16th president in view.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Cartoon characters filled the Izod Center on Saturday afternoon, with painted-on smiles that not even two bad basketball teams could erase.

description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Making a Living on the L.P.G.A. Tour Becomes Tougher by the Year

description: This interview with William D. Green, chairman and C.E.O. of Accenture, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.
