title: Enthusiasm for Palin, and Echoes of 2008 Divide
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind.  When tickets to see Sarah Palin in Michigan ran out, people drove to her appearance here, three hours away.

title: Man Fatally Stabbed on D Train in Manhattan
description: A passenger aboard a northbound D train in Midtown Manhattan was stabbed to death early Saturday after arguing with another man over a seat in the subway car, the authorities said.

title: Defensive Pit Bull Helped Galaxy Reach Final
description: CARSON, Calif.  The character of the Los Angeles Galaxys Dema Kovalenko  or is it Demon?  appears to have been carefully constructed. The days-old stubble, the piercing hazel eyes and the Russian accent are archetypical of a persona built around bone-crunching tackles and card-collecting rages.

title: Career Day Speaker Schedule
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Todays puzzle is by  well, me! What Ive decided to do is share a few thoughts about it, discuss some clues and their answers, and then let you talk among yourselves. Comment on the puzzle as you normally would, good or bad. Ill go read a book or something.

title: Miami Ponders Whether the Good Outweighs the Bad
description: MIAMI  The office of Mayor Manny Diaz smelled of fresh paint and departure. He had only a few hours left before term limits pushed him out, but when the citys planning director mentioned a development by a large Spanish bank, the mayors eyes lit up.

title: To Hang In, a Series Winner Must Learn to Let Go
description: More than any other team in American professional sports, the Yankees cannot afford to rebuild. The teams partnership with the YES regional sports network is too lucrative when the Yankees are winning, their hulking palace of a stadium is too much of a cash cow, the local and national news media are too demanding, and the fans are too hooked on success.

title: Athletes Struggle to Channel Aggressive Nature
description: A college soccer player retaliates against an opponent by pulling her down by the ponytail. A tennis champion has a tantrum on the court, costing her a shot at winning another major title. An all-star catcher throws an elbow, touching off a brawl that puts his teammates at risk for injury.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: At Least 92 Die in Chinese Mine Explosion
description: HONG KONG  A gas explosion at a coal mine in northeastern China early Saturday morning killed 92 people and left 16 more trapped in the shaft, Chinas worst mine disaster in nearly two years, Chinese official media said late Sunday night.

title: Chvez Offers Public Defense for Carlos the Jackal
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez is heaping praise on Ilich Ramrez Snchez, the Venezuelan better known as Carlos the Jackal and implicated in hijackings and terror attacks across Europe in the 1970s and 80s, describing him in a speech here Friday night as a revolutionary fighter.

title: Violent Plays Have No Gender Barriers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Survey Finds Hard Times Preceded Recession
description: Even before the recession, more than one in five Americans needed help from family, friends or outsiders to pay for basic needs, according to a survey by the Census Bureau.

title: After Katrina, Struggle for High Ground
description: In her dream, Jennifer Hero is walking down the same sunny New Orleans street. It is not until she reaches St. Charles Avenue that she realizes the city is destroyed, and she is walking among ruins.

title: An Accidental Reformer Takes on the Constitution
description: Jim Wunderman hardly seems like someone you would peg to be a founding father of a new California.

title: In Chant, Listening and Singing Become One
description: Chant, the practice of intoning sounds or words rhythmically and repetitively, has been a staple of spiritual systems for millenniums. Owing to the popularity of recordings like the 1993 album Chant by the Benedictine monks of Santo Domingo de Silos in Spain, and Enigmas 1990 crossover hit, Sadeness (Part I), which juxtaposed chant with a dance beat, Westerners have become familiar with Gregorian chant, the early Christian liturgical genre.

title: High-Wire Act, Above the Clouds
description: For Damian Cooksey, a walk on Mount Tamalpais is a barefoot balancing act. Mr. Cooksey, 32, the owner of Bridges Rock Gym in El Cerrito, has broken world records in slacklining  a sport developed by rock climbers that resembles tightrope walking, except the line stretches and sways  and was the first person to walk a line directly across the top of Yosemite Falls. He lives with his wife in Berkeley.

title: Bay Area Report Highlights for Sunday, Nov. 22
description: Cannabis Conundrum | Bay Area doctors have begun recommending that some teenage patients take marijuana to alleviate some of the tension and anxiety associated with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Doctors responses range from How many ways can you say One of the worst ideas of all time?  to Its safer than aspirin. A state assemblyman wants it stopped. Katherine Ellison has a detailed report on a latest battle in the medical marijuana wars.

title: Goldmans Non-Apology
description: Certainly, our industry is responsible for things. Were a leader in our industry, and we participated in things that were clearly wrong and we have reasons to regret and apologize for.

title: The Senates Duty on Climate
description: The news that world leaders have abandoned hope for a comprehensive, legally binding climate change treaty in Copenhagen next month inspired no end of finger-pointing. Environmentalists blamed eight years of inaction under George W. Bush. The Europeans noted that the Chinese and several other big developing nations had done little to move the ball forward.

title: A Ban on Genetic Discrimination
description: It is rare when antidiscrimination law is extended to a whole new group of people, but that happened on Saturday, when a federal ban on discriminating on the basis of genetic background took effect. The new law is an important step in protecting people who have inherited a predisposition to disease. It removes a significant obstacle to genetic testing, which can help prevent and treat serious illnesses.

title: Roll Your Own Tax Rate
description: There are no records kept on how fast loopholes can be uncovered in new federal law, but the roll-your-own tobacco industry is making a breathtaking run for this years shabby laurels. No sooner had President Obama signed the new childrens health insurance law last spring than the industry pried open a lucrative escape from the 20-fold tax increase levied on roll-your-own cigarettes to help support the program.

title: Other Views: The Columnists Voice
description: Re The Archbishops Blog (Nov. 8):

title: An Evolutionary Bent Toward Religion?
description: To the Editor:

title: End-of-Life Planning and the House Health Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Name That Decade
description: To the Editor:

title: Visceral Has Its Value
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Pit Bull in the China Shop
description: AT last the American right and left have one issue they unequivocally agree on: You dont actually have to read Sarah Palins book to have an opinion about it. Last Sunday Liz Cheney praised Going Rogue as well-written on Fox News even though, by her own account, she had sampled only parts of it. On Tuesday, Ana Marie Cox, a correspondent for Air America, belittled the book in The Washington Post while confessing that she couldnt claim to have completely read it.

title: At Work in Washington, at Home in Mannys Deli
description: In a Loop restaurant, David Axelrod smiles when shown a photo of the two of us as long-haired reporters hovering near a fur-coated female who resembles a polar bear with blond hair during a rough Chicago winter.

title: Advice From Grandma
description: President Obamas visit to China this week inevitably invites comparisons between the worlds two leading powers. You know what they say: Britain owned the 19th century, America owned the 20th century, and, its all but certain that China will own the 21st century. Maybe, but Im not ready to cede the 21st century to China just yet.

title: Animal, Vegetable, Miserable
description: Lewisburg, Pa.

title: My Chocolate Meltdown
description: TO investment bankers, its welcome news that Kraft Foods is offering more than $16 billion to acquire the British candymaker Cadbury: Maybe the frozen credit markets are thawing. As a chocolate fiend, bunkered in my kitchen alongside a simmering bain-marie, I find it an ominous prospect.

title: Avoidance by the Numbers
description: Philadelphia

title: Suspect in Ft. Hood Shootings to Remain in Hospital
description: The Army psychiatrist accused of killing 13 people at Fort Hood, Tex., in a mass shooting this month will be confined until his military trial, a magistrate ruled on Saturday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Sept. 11 Defendant Seeks a Trial, and a Platform
description: The five men the Justice Department has said will be charged in the attacks of Sept. 11 intend to plead not guilty so they can express their political and religious views during a trial, the lawyer for one of the men said on Saturday.

title: Senator Cements Role at Heart of Debate
description: WASHINGTON  No sooner had Senator Blanche Lincoln promised to deliver one crucial vote in support of a health care overhaul than she threatened to withhold the next one.

title: Frisco Feast
description: In the 1990s, boutiques and bars popped up between the Latino watering holes in San Franciscos Mission District. Now the neighborhood is experiencing another surge, as a handful of Italian restaurants are bringing culinary sophistication to an area known more for burritos as big as your head.

title: A Note About Opinionator RSS Feeds
description: Readers who subscribed to RSS feeds for the individual columnists and features that now appear in Opinionator may be receiving feeds for all the journalism published in Opinionator. We are working to restore individual feeds, and regret any inconvenience posed by these changes.

title: Mets Will Nod to Their Past With Images Outside Park
description: Mets fans had a lot to complain about during their teams first season at Citi Field, the sloppy play on the field and the high prices in the stands most prominently. Some fans were especially angry that more was not done to commemorate the teams past in its new home.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about H. Rodgin Cohen, the chairman of Sullivan & Cromwell, who played a significant role in the Wall Street bailout, referred imprecisely to the proximity of Minneapolis to Grand Rapids, Minn., where Mr. Cohen and his wife, Barbara, were married. Her hometown, Grand Rapids, is about 200 miles by car, so it would not be considered not far from Minneapolis.

title: Yale Fails on 4th-Down Risk, and Harvard Pulls Out Win
description: WEST HAVEN, Conn.  During his first year at Yale, Coach Tom Williams kept telling his football team that he would be aggressive. The Bulldogs ran two fake-punt plays earlier this season, and both worked.

title: Record-Setting Day in Division II Playoffs
description: The Division II playoffs generally fly under the radar. Unless, of course, two teams combine to put up 147 points, as West Liberty (W.Va.) and Edinboro (Pa.) did on Saturday afternoon.

title: A Call From Senator Kennedys Widow
description: Moments after the vote to begin debate on the major health care legislation, a reporter asked the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, if he had spoken with President Obama.

title: Police Struggle to Navigate New Gang Landscape
description: Almost a year from the day the Chicago Police Department unleashed a sweeping crackdown on gangs, its efforts crashed into stark reality Wednesday in a gritty area of the South Side that many in the neighborhood call Kill Town.

title: 3 Suspected Militants Blow Themselves Up in Pakistani Kashmir
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Three suspected militants blew themselves up on Saturday as police officers chased them in Pakistani-administered Kashmir, government officials said.

title: Queens Man Accused of Killing His Wife and Son
description: A Queens man was charged with killing his wife and 14-year-old son on Saturday after their bodies were found in a closet of the familys three-room apartment with their throats cut, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Social Qs column last Sunday misspelled the given name of a character in the TV show Dynasty. She is Krystle Carrington, not Crystal.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with the Generation B column, about Sara Davis Buechner, a transgender pianist, misidentified her current hometown. It is Vancouver, British Columbia; it is no longer the Bronx.

title: Notre Dames Loss Leaves Charlie Weis Hanging by a Thread
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  There was no blue-gray sky to provide the backdrop. No horseman, never mind four of them, to come to the rescue. There was no cosmic channeling of karma from Touchdown Jesus or a touch of luck from Fighting Irish legends like Knute, Ara or Lou.

title: College Football Replay: Nov. 21
Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: Elisabeth Soderstrom, Swedish Soprano, Dies at 82
description: Elisabeth Soderstrom, the Swedish soprano acclaimed for the plangent richness and intelligence of her singing and for her wide-ranging repertory, including influential portrayals of leading roles in the operas of Janacek, died on Friday in Stockholm, her native city.

title: Robert Cameron, High-Flying Above Photographer, Dies at 98
description: One of Robert Camerons thousands of vibrant color aerial photographs zeroes virtually straight down from above the south tower of the Golden Gate Bridge to its anchorage, the reddish hue of the majestic structure glowing in a setting sun.

title: Paul Wendkos, Director of Gidget Surfer Movies, Is Dead at 84
description: Paul Wendkos, a movie and television director best known for the frothy surfer film Gidget, but whose other productions ranged from thrillers to historical dramas, died Nov. 12 at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 84.

title: Jets at Patriots: What to Watch
description: Matchup to Watch: Darrelle Revis vs. Randy Moss

title: So Long, Charlie?
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  In the wake of a crushing double-overtime loss to Connecticut on Saturday, the Charlie Weis era appears to be drawing to a close at Notre Dame. After the game, Weis stayed mum on the subject, choosing to focus on the 33 seniors who were playing in their final game at Notre Dame Stadium.

title: Free Agency Means Free Choice
description: Brian Cashman, the Yankees general manager, has certain go-to phrases. For a while, especially around the holidays, he would respond to trade rumors by smiling and saying,  Tis the season  meaning the season for wild speculation. During the Yankees World Series run, Cashman enjoyed comparing his job to that of a chemist, mixing materials to see if they are combustible.

title: Chicago Bears New Identity Is Unrecognizable
description: In 2006, when his Chicago Bears were riding a stout defense and strong running game to a surprise Super Bowl appearance, Coach Lovie Smith disdained comparisons to the Bears 1985 forebears, almost scornfully. It was time, he suggested, for the franchise and its fans to put those memories aside and forge a new identity.

title: Decisions, Decisions
description: Congratulations, Bill Belichick, youre off the hook.

title: Despite a New Top Player, an Old Champ Is a Winner
description: Like some professional sports, chess seems to be in a state of parity. It has not always been this way.

title: The Pulse: Mayors Former Foe Puts On Friendly Face
description: Bensenville, the suburban enclave near OHare International Airport, long opposed plans by Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago to expand OHare. No more, though.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: In Metropolitan Hat Trick, Rangers, Isles and Devils Lose
description: Thirteen contests on Saturday night, and it seemed like every one included at least one amazing feat  like a single line being on ice for each one of a games five goals, for and against; a player injuring two separate opponents on a single shift; and all three New York-area teams falling to defeat. Home teams listed first:

title: Vows: Pam & Sam
description: Pamela never expected that Sam would propose to her in Bermuda. And she certainly didn't expect him to do it with a Boggle board.

title: Show Time
description: The culturati swoop in every December for Art Basel Miami Beach, but what of the arts beyond the fair?

title: New Moves, New Faces
description: An annual workshop at the School of American Ballet offers a rare opportunity for young dancers to test their choreographic ingenuity.

title: Paul McCarthy, Then and Now
description: In his recent works, the ribald, pop-culture-obsessed provocateur known as Paul McCarthy has suddenly revealed himself to be an old master.

title: Good Progress on Panama Canal Is Reported
description: Monday, Nov. 22, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Thin Attack Falls Short as Rangers Stumble Again
description: It cannot just be Marian and I, Vinny Prospal said at practice on Friday, referring to how he and Marian Gaborik were doing almost all of the Rangers scoring lately. But in the Rangers 3-2 loss to Florida on Saturday at Madison Square Garden, it was just Gaborik and Prospal all over again. Once more, it was not enough.

title: Californias Late Stand Spoils Stanfords Pac-10 Title Hopes
description: STANFORD, Calif.  Without waiting to see whether Oregon would beat Arizona in the desert, No. 14 Stanford took itself out of the Rose Bowl race.

title: Why Are Interim Coaches More Successful in Baseball Than In Football?
description: Last Wednesday, one day after the Bills announced they had fired Coach Dick Jauron and replaced him with the defensive coordinator Perry Fewell, baseballs Jim Tracy was honored with the National League manager of the year award. Tracys story was one of the best in baseball this season.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Tings Dey Happen, a solo show about Nigerian oil politics, misattributed a quotation about the shows playwright, Dan Hoyle. It was a Nigerian militant, Williams Ajayi  not Mr. Hoyle  who said, When he met me, it was like a light to his life, noting the effect Mr. Hoyle had had on his life. The article also may have left the incorrect impression that the writer and Mr. Hoyle discussed Mr. Hoyles being reunited with Mr. Ajayi in Abuja, Nigerias capital, during his recent visit. The conversation the writer was referring to was a post-performance conversation the writer had with the audience.

title: Khodorkovskys Rise and Fall
description: Once Russias richest man, Mikhail Khodorkovsky is now the countrys most famous prisoner.

title: Postscript
description: The Quick Bite feature in some editions on Nov. 1 referred to the Silver Spoon, an upscale deli that moved to Oradell, N.J., from Ridgewood, N.J., in July. The deli is now closed. The owner was contacted on Oct. 26 to confirm information about the deli; he now says he closed it on Oct. 31.

title: Role reversal
description: Many people on Wall Street are now warning that theres a huge bubble in government debt, that interest rates will spike any day now; its a warning that clearly has the Obama administrations ear. A good sample is this piece from Morgan Stanley, according to which Our US economics team expects bond yields to rise to 5.5% by the end of 2010  an increase of 220bp that outstrips the 137bp increase in the fed funds rate expected over the same horizon.

title: In Berlin, a Sexy, TV-Style Take on Mozart
description: Inside a former club in Berlin, Cos fan Tutte, Mozarts tale of complicated love and the fickleness of women, has gotten a TV-style treatment in the hands of the director Christoph Hagel. Warning: subtitled Sex, Lies & TV, this updating is not recommended for Mozart purists.

title: Advocacy Groups May Reshape Message During Holidays
description: The Senate debate on health care, set to begin the week after Thanksgiving, is now on course to collide with the holiday season. One question for advocacy groups on all sides will be whether to keep up their barrage of pointed commercials, even as chestnuts roast and stockings are hung.

title: The Magic Pen: Mozart Operas Up Close
description: SCHOLARS wishing to examine the manuscripts of the masters must expect to go out of their way, but since World War II several Mozart operas have required more effort than many other such treasures. Of the principal scores only two have come down in one piece: Don Giovanni in Paris and The Magic Flute in Berlin. The others are dispersed among various owners.

title: Street Smart
description: Chalk it up to rising rents in the Miami Design District, or the proximity to the Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA), but the stretch of NE 125th Street between NE Seventh and Ninth Avenues has emerged as the latest hub for collectible midcentury design, earning it the nickname 20th-Century Row.

title: Senator Lincoln Votes for Overhaul
description: Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas promised to vote in support of a health care overhaul but also warned that she would oppose the Democratic plan in its current form. (Video: MSNBC)

title: The Path to the Final Bill
description: As the Senate opens the health care debate, the path to the final bill is not entirely clear. (Video: MSNBC)

title: Nastia Liukin | High Flier
description: Watching the gymnast Nastia Liukin dismount the uneven bars, youre almost too busy counting the flips  was that five ?  to notice her daintily perfect landing. Raised in Texas by two Soviet gymnasts, Liukin, 20, dominated Beijing last year, where she won the all-around gold. Shes been cooling her pummeled heels lately, which doesnt mean shes traveling any less. This fall she visited London to blog from the world championships for USA Today, and she was in Copenhagen to promote Chicagos Olympic bid. Despite her past successes, Liukin is already dreaming about victory in the 2012 London games. Not that many people have really competed after they won their Olympic gold, she says. I want to achieve something that nobodys ever done.

title: The Sunday Word, Nov. 22
description: The votes are in and the debate is on. Again.

title: On the Question of Gravy
description: I know I said Id be back Monday. But Thanksgiving looms and the questions are piling up. People demand answers! Answers they shall have.

title: Live Analysis: Giants Beat Falcons, 34-31, in Overtime
description: Writers and editors for The New York Times will provide live updates and analysis throughout the Giants game against the Atlanta Falcons at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Centrist Senators Say They Oppose Health Care Bill
description: The morning after voting to commence debate on ground-breaking health care legislation, two centrist senators, Ben Nelson and Joseph I. Lieberman, said on Sunday that they were opposed to the bill as it is currently written, particularly its inclusion of a new government-run insurance program.

title: Timing Is Everything
description: Q.

title: Kennedy Discouraged From Communion by Bishop
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Patrick J. Kennedy of Rhode Island said on Sunday that the Roman Catholic bishop of Providence had instructed him to refrain from receiving communion because of his stance on abortion.

title: Democrats Step Up Push for Votes on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  Anxious that Saturdays party-line Senate vote to open debate on a health care overhaul gives them little maneuvering room, Obama administration officials and their Congressional allies are stepping up overtures to select Senate Republicans in hopes of winning their ultimate support.

title: Weis Says His Firing Would Be Understandable
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  There are essentially 66 programs in the Bowl Championship Series, which allows them to be among the big-money players in college football. Sixty-five of those teams are in the six so-called power conferences. The other is Notre Dame, a football independent with a role in the B.C.S. contract as a nod to its history, allure and ability to move the ratings dial and fill seats at bowl games.

title: Vile Heroes and High-Seas Swagger
description: The jacket copy for Pirate Latitudes states ambiguously that this book was discovered as a complete manuscript in his files after its author, Michael Crichton, died last year. Crichton was well known for putting his medical training (as the creator of the television series ER) and deep interest in science to expert dramatic use. He successfully used the prehistoric (Jurassic Park), contemporary (Disclosure) and future (Next) as storytelling fodder with equal ease. He was even given a dinosaur namesake (Crichtonsaurus bohlini). But the quaint, boyish, gee-whiz exploits that make up Pirate Latitudes were not hallmarks of his best work.

title: Son Objects to Moving Camuss Remains
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy wants to transfer the remains of the writer Albert Camus to one of the most hallowed burial places in France, but the plan has run into opposition from the Nobel laureates son, who does not think his father would have wanted the honor.

title: In Small Details, a Day That Stunned the Nation
description: Forty-six years after the fact it sometimes seems as if Nov. 22, 1963, were only 26 seconds long. That is roughly the length of the Zapruder film, the home movie that captured the shooting of President John F. Kennedy better than any other known footage.

title: Desperate Woman Times 3
description: A wife bereft over the loss of her infant son seeks carnal comfort in the embrace of a lover. A nun pines for a child she bore out of wedlock, a disgrace for which she was banished to a convent by her family. A young girl pleads with her father for permission to marry the man she loves. The heroines of Puccinis three one-act operas collectively known as Il Trittico have little in common; small wonder that the parts are rarely played by a single performer.

title: Shortage Slows a Program to Detect Nuclear Bombs
description: WASHINGTON  The Department of Homeland Security has spent $230 million to develop better technology for detecting smuggled nuclear bombs but has had to stop deploying the new machines because the United States has run out of a crucial raw material, experts say.

title: Twilight Dawns Bright at the Box Office
description: Jaws are dropping all over Hollywood: The Twilight Saga: New Moon, an inexpensive sequel from a three-year-old independent studio, sold a supernatural $140.7 million in tickets over the weekend in North American theaters.

So, a lot of the fear about a surge in interest rates seems to be motivated by supposed parallels to the situation in 1994, when there was a big spike in rates. Then as now there was a large carry trade motivated by the spread between long rates and short rates; when the long rate started to rise, there was a balance sheet squeeze that caused a stunning, albeit short-lived spike:

title: Joke Europeans
description: I gather that this chart confuses people:

title: Live Analysis: Patriots Beat Jets, 31-14
description: Writers and editors from The New York Times will be providing live analysis during the Jets game against the New England Patriots in Foxborough, Mass.

title: Paging Henry Higgins
description: Im in London, at a veddy intellectual conference sponsored by UCL, the New York Review of Books, and The Guardian. Actually, it has been a lovely event.

title: Crowded Streets, Hidden Gems
description: English, written and spoken, is scarce in Flushing, Queens. Whats plentiful is good food, and even opportunities to slow down, if you know where to look.

title: Garnett Beats Buzzer, and Celtics Beat the Knicks
description: Over the course of five days, the Knicks have slowly forged a new identity, of a team that can in fact shoot, defend and play hard to the final buzzer, which was essentially the script they followed Sunday.

title: Amnesty List Puts Pressure on Pakistan Leader
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In another blow to Pakistans president, Asif Ali Zardari, the authorities this weekend released the names of politicians, many from his own party, who benefited from an amnesty decree that dismissed past alleged crimes.

title: More Antarctic Ice Loss and a CO2toon
description: The East Antarctic Ice Sheet, long seen as the stable side of Antarcticas vast lode of ice, appears to have been losing mass, particularly in coastal regions, over the past three years, according to a new analysis using gravity measurements. The finding is preliminary and comes with substantial uncertainty, the researchers reported in Nature Geoscience. But the research is generally consistent with other recent studies on ice loss in Antarctica and Greenland using surface and satellite measurements. What this portends for sea levels remains somewhat murky in the short run (by 2100) but very clear over the long haul, polar specialists largely agree.

title: Camels, Claus, Nativity and Oh, Those Rockettes
description: If its a promotional clich to say that The Radio City Music Hall Christmas Spectacular is part of New Yorks holiday season tradition, its also a fact. Now beginning the 77th edition of its unique blend of Santa Claus, the Nativity and the Rockettes, the show continues to dazzle its gleeful audience.

title: Man of the Match, or Tottenhams Man of the Year?
description: London is a big town, but it would be hard to argue that anyone had a better day there Sunday than Jermain Defoe.

title: Refugees From a Flop, Broadway Bound Again
description: The actress Jessica Hecht was full of mixed emotions as the curtain rose for one of the final Broadway performances of Neil Simons "Brighton Beach Memoirs" this fall.

title: Those Amorous Lyrics, Borrowed From the Birds
description: The singer Ann Hampton Callaway wasnt always the pop-blues wailer who brought the house to its feet on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, where the New York Pops orchestra celebrated the centennial of the songwriter Johnny Mercer. Her rendition of Blues in the Night, with a lusty full-bodied arrangement by Harold Wheeler, gave this lament by Mercer and Harold Arlen the kind of top-to-bottom vocal coverage that few singers have the technical resources to deliver.

title: The Strategy of Angling for That Extra Trick
description: On Thursday I highlighted the need to bid cautiously in a match-pointed pair event; do not push aggressively for game. When you get to the card play, though, you should try to win as many tricks as possible (unless you are in a high-scoring contract that you expect the other pairs to miss).

title: Reuniting Lost Relations, Leaving Time for Tears
description: In June ABC ordered a new show called Lets Dance, based on a British reality series, in which celebrities would replicate famous dance routines. A programming executive said, The tone of this is fun. On Nov. 4 ABC announced that Lets Dance would make its debut this Monday, following Dancing With the Stars. Five days later ABC changed its mind and canceled Lets Dance.

title: The John Henry Who Might Have Been
description: Most listeners accept it as a given that folk song has been a powerful influence on composers of art music, from the authors of the parody Masses of the 1500s through Haydn, Beethoven and Bartok to Aaron Copland and George Crumb. Often composers drawn to folk melodies either provide accompaniments in their own styles or simply allude to them, weaving strands of their musical DNA into larger structures.

title: A Showman of the Organ Pulls Back the Curtain
description: Churches are mysterious places where you learn to take certain things on faith. And solo organ recitals can seem esoteric and forbidding to the uninitiated. But everything the organist Cameron Carpenter did during his concert at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin near Times Square on Saturday afternoon was meant to show his audience exactly what he was up to, without compromising the serious music he played.

title: Supple Limbs in a Sea of Energy
description: Back when Complexions Contemporary Ballet was known as Complexions  A Concept in Dance, it wasnt a given that the troupe would last. Now, 15 years later, the company, formed by Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson, two former Alvin Ailey dancers, is still thrashing, spinning and kicking along its merry way.

title: Au Revoir to the Old, Bonjour to the New
description: PARIS  Brigitte Lefvre, director of the Paris Opera Ballet, didnt let the grass grow under her feet when Wayne McGregor was appointed resident choreographer of the Royal Ballet in 2006. The next year Mr. McGregor created Genus for the French company, and the piece has been performed this month on a triple bill that ran at almost the same time as a Covent Garden program featuring Mr. McGregors new Limen.

title: A Stylistic and Geographic Traveler Savors His Homecoming
description: From one angle, the career of the saxophonist Steve Grossman might seem to have unfolded in reverse. He came onto the radar in 1969, playing state-of-the-art jazz-rock with Miles Davis; he was all of 18. From that sideman perch, among the most visible in jazz, he went on to play rugged, horizon-scanning postbop in the style of John Coltrane, notably with Coltranes former drummer Elvin Jones. Then came a more traditionalist stretch, followed by relative obscurity after he moved to Europe. Before his run at the Jazz Standard, which ended on Sunday, he hadnt played a New York club in well over a decade.

title: Michael Jacksons Glove, Saint Laurents Umbrella Stand
description: Items from Elvis Presley and the Beatles were on the block, but Michael Jackson was the star of a New York auction on Saturday. Fans cheered as bids for the bejeweled glove he wore when he introduced his moonwalk dance in 1983 rose higher and higher, finally reaching $350,000 (before taxes and fees) in a sale held by Juliens Auctions, The Associated Press reported. The glove had carried a high estimate of $60,000. But Hoffman Ma, who bought the rhinestone-studded golf glove on behalf of the Ponte 16 Resort Hotel in Macau, China, called the price a fairly good discount. ... Also going beyond the auctioneers expectations were artworks and furniture belonging to the fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent and his partner, Pierre Berg, which raised $13.22 million on Friday, twice the amount estimated by Christies, Reuters reported. This was the second of two sales of items that used to decorate various properties owned by Saint Laurent and Mr. Berg. The first, in February, raised almost $550 million, one of the biggest auctions Paris has seen. Among the surprise standouts in the recent auction was an umbrella stand from the couples Paris apartment that was estimated at $742 and sold for more than $160,000. All the proceeds went to an AIDS research charity.

title: Dreamworks Looks Under the Dome
description: Steven Spielberg, right, and DreamWorks Television are teaming up with the author Stephen King, below right, to produce a limited series for cable based on Mr. Kings latest novel, Under the Dome, Variety reported. Mr. Spielberg will serve as executive producer for the supernatural thriller about locals at a Maine vacation spot who battle one another when a force field suddenly surrounds their town. Producers are in the process of finding a screenwriter, after which the series will be offered to prospective buyers. Mr. King and Mr. Spielberg worked together to develop a feature film based on The Talisman, Mr. Kings 1984 novel, but that project was postponed because of a lack of financing.

title: Winnie Mandela, by Jennifer Hudson
description: Jennifer Hudson has been cast in the title role of Winnie, a film about Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, the activist and former wife of Nelson Mandela, Variety reported. The screenplay, based on a biography by Anne Marie du Preez Bezdrob, was written by Andr Pieterse, Paul L. Johnson, and Darrell J. Roodt, a South African filmmaker who will also direct. Production will begin in May in South African locations, including Robben Island, where Mr. Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years in prison. The film will cover not only Ms. Mandelas fight against apartheid but also her convictions for kidnapping, fraud and theft. Ms. Hudson told Variety, This is a powerful part of history that should be told.

title: Footnote
description: Nitro and Lace will be back, and in full-length feature form. According to Variety, Peter Iliff has been hired to write a live-action film based on American Gladiators. The script will incorporate characters adapted from the original television show, first broadcast in the 1980s, and turn them into superheroes. Scott Mednick and the Gladiators creator, Johnny Ferraro, are producing, with a release date anticipated in 2011.

title: Will Ferrell Tops Most Overpaid List
description: Using box-office returns and salaries among several other factors, Forbes has compiled a list of the 10 most overpaid Hollywood stars in the last five years, and the winner (or loser) is the comic actor Will Ferrell, right. Forbes said Mr. Ferrells films earned an average of $3.29 for every dollar he was paid. Successes like Elf and Talladega Nights raised Mr. Ferrells compensation in the last few years, but high-budget flops like Land of the Lost (which earned back only $65 million of an estimated $100 million budget) have lowered the value of this former Saturday Night Live star. Rounding out the list were Ewan McGregor, Billy Bob Thornton, Eddie Murphy, Ice Cube, Tom Cruise, Drew Barrymore, Leonardo DiCaprio, Samuel L. Jackson and Jim Carrey. By comparison, Shia LaBeouf, who topped the Forbes list of best actors for the buck, released in August, earned $160 at the box office for every dollar he was paid.

title: Testing the Chevrolet Volt
description: Chevrolet's flagship hybrid sedan is headed to the marketplace in nine months.

title: Oxfam and Booksellers Agree to Plan
description: Oxfam, the international charity that earns about $32 million annually from sales of used books, is trying to address the concerns of private bookstore owners, who in September accused the nonprofit group of taking away their business. According to The Guardian, representatives from Oxfam, the Provincial Booksellers Fairs Association and the Antiquarian Booksellers Association all met to create a plan to help redirect business back to the local secondhand booksellers. Oxfam, saying that not all of its staff members were qualified to evaluate rare books, agreed to contact either association when a valuable collection was donated and request that a bookseller make an offer. That sum of money would then go to Oxfam, while the bookseller could place the books privately. It cannot be expected that the plan will operate entirely smoothly and efficiently from the start, but it has been entered into in good faith as a way of defusing the ill feeling between the book trade and Oxfam which has been evident in recent months, said Peter Moore, the Provincial Booksellers chairman.

title: Justin Bieber Fans in Melee at a Mall
description: A Long Island mall appearance by the 15-year-old pop singer Justin Bieber, below, ended in minor injuries and one arrest after fans became unruly, The Associated Press reported. Some 3,000 people had gathered for the Friday afternoon event at the Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City, N.Y., but pushing and shoving broke out, and the police ordered the crowd to disperse. People started screaming, Justin! 13-year-old Aimee Macchi, who was knocked to the ground, told The A.P. And they ran forward, and the ropes collapsed. The news service said five people were sent to a hospital with minor injuries. James Roppo, a vice president of Island Def Jam Records, which is releasing Mr. Biebers first album, My World, this week, was charged with endangering the welfare of children and obstructing governmental administration for refusing to send a Twitter message asking the crowd to disperse. Mr. Bieber posted his own Twitter message to fans, saying that the police would not allow him to enter the building, and that they had threatened to arrest him if he did not leave. Island Records later apologized to fans in a written statement.

title: The Supremes and Others
description: Doesnt have a point of view,Knows not where hes going to,Isnt he a bit like you and me?

title: Neediest | A New Job and a New Outlook
description: Dion Lewis recently completed his green contracting certification with help from The Neediest Cases fund.  Formerly unemployed, Mr. Lewis now works helping others save energy and money.

description: Tim Tebow, Florida quarterback

description: RIHANNA Rated R (Def Jam)

title: BMW X6 M
description: The BMW X6 M looks like what Batman would drive, if Batman drove a crossover S.U.V.

title: Hopeful Divas Back Where It All Began
description: As befits a work about the essential art of repackaging in show business, Dreamgirls has known several distinct incarnations. First, there was the 1981 Broadway musical. Then came the 2006 movie. And now there is Dreamgirls, the comic strip, which opened Sunday night at the Apollo Theater in Harlem.

title: Fastback Cars
description: The fastback look may seem new to some consumers, but its origins go back decades.

title: Justice on Location
description: On a new television show, "Street Court," arguments are heard and disputes are settled where they occurred rather than in a courtroom.

title: At SAS, Taking Care of Employees Is Good Business
description: SAS Institute, the largest privately held software company in the world, is also widely known as one of the best places to work.

title: Irans Death Penalty Is Seen as a Political Tactic
description: CAIRO  A flurry of executions and death sentences in Iran has raised concern that the government is using judicially sanctioned killing to intimidate the political opposition and quell pockets of ethnic unrest around the nation, human rights groups and Iran experts said.

title: Haves vs. Have-Nots at Public Universities
description: The University of California, which has already received $716 million in federal stimulus funds to offset a $1 billion budget gap, announced on Friday that it is raising student fees by 32 percent. That works out to about $2,500 per student a year.

title: From Oregon to Pasadena
description: There will be a Civil War in Oregon to determine which Pac-10 team will play Ohio State in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 1.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Deal Will Turn a Los Angeles Hospital Private
description: LOS ANGELES  The role of public hospitals in America has been remarkably consistent over the decades, in spite of health care policy debates, insurance trends and shifting medical advice. They were centers of last resort, where the quality of care could be inconsistent and the finances often a disaster, but where the poor could always be served.

title: In Philippines Strife, Uprooting Is a Constant
description: DATU PIANG, Philippines  For most refugees here, the long-running conflict between the Philippine government and Muslim separatists on the island of Mindanao has become such a part of their lives rhythms that they have lost track of how often fighting has displaced them.

title: Coming Out for Going Rogue
description: On her book tour, Sarah Palin has skipped the big cities authors usually visit in favor of smaller places where she and Senator John McCain performed well on the presidential ticket.

title: Konstantin Feoktistov, a Soviet Spacecraft Engineer, Dies at 83
description: MOSCOW  Konstantin P. Feoktistov, a Soviet engineer who was one of the first civilian astronauts and a prominent spacecraft designer, died on Saturday in Moscow, the Russian space agency said. He was 83.

title: Cornhuskers Stand in Longhorns Way
description: Nebraska will probably be the last team with a chance to stop Texas from playing in the Bowl Championship Series title game.

title: Analysis: Voting With Bombs
description: BAGHDAD  Terrorism in Iraq has become the continuation of politics by other means. That came into sharp relief with last months bombing of three government buildings here by two suicide truck bombers. It was probably no accident that they chose to strike as Iraqs leaders bogged down on attempts to draft an election law.

title: White House Pushes Science and Math Education
description: To improve science and mathematics education for American children, the White House is recruiting Elmo and Big Bird, video game programmers and thousands of scientists.

title: In 3 Tacks for Afghan War, a Game of Trade-Offs
description: WASHINGTON  Should President Obama decide to send 40,000 additional American troops to Afghanistan, the most ambitious plan under consideration at the White House, the military would have enormous flexibility to deploy as many as 15,000 troops to the Taliban center of gravity in the south, 5,000 to the critical eastern border with Pakistan and 10,000 as trainers for the Afghan security forces.

title: Patriots Crush Jets Slim Playoff Hopes
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Woody Johnson, the Jets owner, walked toward the visitors locker room Sunday night, his head shaking more vigorously with each step. Behind him came the Jets, a team Johnson has paid handsomely to win games instead of lose them.

title: General Says Canada Fears for Afghans
description: OTTAWA  Canadas top military officer said Sunday that on more than one occasion, Canada did not turn over Afghan prisoners to the Afghan government, fearing for their safety. The acknowledgment by the officer, Gen. Walter Natynczyk, the chief of the defense staff, appeared inconsistent with Canadas assertions that such prisoners had not been tortured.

title: Hunting for Turkeys, for the First Time
description: YAPHANK, N.Y.  At around 5:45 a.m., armed with a Mossberg 835 12-gauge shotgun painted in camouflage colors and his sippy cup, a travel mug full of coffee, John T. Rauh pulled his big red Ford F-250 out of the driveway, his Navy dog tags swinging from the rearview mirror.

title: A Translator Tool With a Human Touch
description: HOW hard can it be, as the joke goes, to speak Chinese? (Six-year-olds do it all the time.)

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: How World War II Wasnt Won
description: Easton, Pa.

title: Hope for the Wrongfully Convicted
description: In a recent 79-page decision, a Manhattan judge could well have stopped after the first four sentences of his concluding paragraph and still conveyed his main point: that Fernando Bermudez was no longer guilty of murder.

title: Supercomputing for the Masses
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  For decades, the worlds supercomputers have been the tightly guarded property of universities and governments. But what would happen if regular folks could get their hands on one?

title: AOL Revamping Its Logo, Hoping to Revive the Brand
description: AOL is taking a cue from Boy George, hoping to improve its karma by becoming a chameleon.

title: Apology Opens Wounds of British Migrant Program
description: LONDON  Laurie Humphreys, at least, had the advantage of being a teenager  if anything about being uprooted from family and homeland in 1940s Britain and sent 12,000 miles to brutal and often sexually abusive orphanages in western Australia could be called advantageous.

title: Reliance Makes Bid for Chemical Giant
description: MUMBAI, India  Reliance Industries, the largest private company in India, said that it had made an offer to acquire a controlling interest in the worlds third-largest chemical company, LyondellBasell.

title: Looking for a Leader in the Post-Oprah Landscape
description: There is no single replacement for Oprah Winfrey.

title: Calming Sign of Troubled Past Appears in Modern Offices
description: To propel themselves through this economic downturn, media and advertising executives are turning to a phrase meant to soothe another troubled populace: the British during World War II.

title: Popular Authors Audiobook Tries a New Format: Vinyl
description: As physical formats and devices have shrunk, revenues for the audiobook industry have grown, since it is more convenient to listen to an iPod while exercising and commuting than fiddling with CDs. Digital downloads grew to 21 percent of the industrys total sales in 2008, from 6 percent in 2004, according to the Audiobook Publishers Association.

title: Brazil Elbows U.S. on the Diplomatic Stage
description: BRASLIA  Brazils ambitions to be a more important player on the global diplomatic stage are crashing headlong into the efforts of the United States and other Western powers to rein in Irans nuclear arms program.

title: The Phantom Menace
description: A funny thing happened on the way to a new New Deal. A year ago, the only thing we had to fear was fear itself; today, the reigning doctrine in Washington appears to be Be afraid. Be very afraid.

title: Pressure on Regions House Democrats to Back Health Care Overhaul
description: Union-backed groups are pressuring a handful of renegade House Democrats from New York and New Jersey to back the partys efforts to overhaul the health care system.

title: Some Rivals Weigh Bids for Cadbury
description: The contest for Cadbury could become a little more crowded.

title: How to Be an Acrobat Without Joining the Circus
description: Cypher Zero keeps the floors of his school covered with mats  from the ordinary gym variety to some that are as thick as a mattress  but years of experience have made him hypersensitive to the sound of a fall.

title: A Few Tight Spots, but Johnson Wins Fourth Title
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla.  Denny Hamlin drove his Toyota to victory in the Ford 400 on Sunday, but it was Jimmie Johnson who sped into Nascar history, winning a record fourth straight Cup series championship by surviving the season finale with a fifth-place finish at the Homestead-Miami Speedway.

title: They Chose Celebrity
description: Before the 2008 election, almost nobody outside Alaska and Arkansas had heard of Sarah Palin or Mike Huckabee. But in a long and crowded campaign season, they were the only Republican politicians who inspired any genuine enthusiasm.

title: Wave of Debt Payments Facing U.S. Government
description: WASHINGTON  The United States government is financing its more than trillion-dollar-a-year borrowing with i.o.u.s on terms that seem too good to be true.

title: Terrorism Trial May Point Way for 9/11 Cases
description: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, suspected of being a Qaeda terrorist, was captured in Pakistan in 2004, held in secret prisons run by the C.I.A. and then moved to the naval base at Guantnamo Bay. During about five years of detention, he says, he was confined in harsh conditions, abused during interrogation and denied a lawyer.

title: Giants Win in Overtime to End Losing Streak at Four
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Perhaps the Giants should budget another half a billion dollars for their new stadium to top it with a retractable roof or a fixed dome.

title: Toxic Waters:  Polluted Harbors
description: Aging sewer systems and urban storm runoff are two of the worst sources of water pollution in the United States.  In Newport, R.I., residents live with regular beach closings and sewage overflows.

title: As Sewers Fill, Waste Poisons Waterways
description: It was drizzling lightly in late October when the midnight shift started at the Owls Head Water Pollution Control Plant, where much of Brooklyns sewage is treated.

title: The Church and the Capital
description: Gay people will eventually win full civil rights  including the right to marry  throughout the United States. Between now and then, there will be many more disputes like the one unfolding between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington and the District of Columbia City Council over a bill recognizing same-sex marriages that could be voted on as soon as next week.

title: In Chicago, Ex-Editor Fights Back
description: James E. OShea spent most of his career at The Chicago Tribune, but he was ousted from the Tribune Company in a highly publicized clash over staff cuts, and these days hes finding plenty of fault with his old paper.

title: Week 11: Giants Win in Overtime
description: After losing a 14-point lead in the fourth quarter, the Giants win on a 36-yard field goal.

title: N.F.L. to Shift in Its Handling of Concussions
description: In a shift in the National Football Leagues approach to handling concussions, the league will soon require teams to receive advice from independent neurologists while treating players with brain injuries, several people with knowledge of the plan confirmed Sunday.

title: Concern at Governing Magazine Over Its Sale to Scientologists
description: Over the last several months, The St. Petersburg Times published a series of scathing articles on the Church of Scientology under the rubric The Truth Rundown. In 1980, the newspaper won a Pulitzer Prize for an investigation of the churchs inner workings.

title: Under Scrutiny, Rangel Is Frayed but Defiant
description: WASHINGTON  On the House floor during a debate over health care reform, he taunted a colleague who had been calling for his ouster. At a recent fund-raiser, he complained that the House speaker had made an end run around him and his committee. Confronted by a persistent conservative activist in a hallway, he let loose an expletive, telling the man to mind his own business.

title: Jets Sanchez Needs Time to Learn to Be an N.F.L. Quarterback
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

title: A Triumph of Avoiding the Traps
description: When you look at Oprah Winfreys multidecade run through daytime talk  most of it at No. 1  its easy to be impressed by what she did to make it happen. But her longevity and success (Forbes estimated her net worth at over $2.3 billion) probably has more to do with what she did not do.

title: Week 11: Patriots Avenge Loss to Jets
description: Another bad day for Mark Sanchez and another Jets defeat.

title: Two Cafes Mean Competition in Crown Heights
description: The coffee clash of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, began with an innocuous blog post promoting the opening of a new cafe on Franklin Avenue last month. That caught the eye of another business opening about the same time just two blocks away on the same avenue  by coincidence, it happened to be another cafe.

title: Bill Would Aid Relatives of 9/11 Immigrant Dead
description: Fourteen immigrants who were in the country illegally when their relatives were killed in the World Trade Center attacks are still waiting to gain permanent residency, and their lawyer said their tenuous immigration status could be imperiled if Congress does not act.

title: Lottery Numbers
Consumer Reports Warns of Price Add-Ons
description: Consumer Reports has a love-hate relationship with the holiday shopping season. If you are determined to spend a months income on a stove, for example, it wants to help you find the best one. But the magazine would just as soon warn you off inflated prices, features you do not need, credit card interest, extended warranties  in other words, caution against spending too much.

title: Executives Kept Wealth as Firms Failed, Study Says
description: Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers paid their executives largely in stock, and that stock lost most or all of its value when those companies collapsed.

title: Feeding a Hunger for Skills, and Finding a Future
description: This year, the numbers of those feeling themselves among the neediest have stretched, like the wallets of the city itself. To the ranks of those who have needed food, or clothing, or a place to live, or a prosthetic limb, or an electric wheelchair, add Dion Lewis. He needed a job. He needed training he could not afford. He needed to have his daughter see him reach a goal by sheer, stubborn persistence.

title: In Mississippi Delta, a Promising Summer Washed Away by the Fall
description: LEXINGTON, Miss.  It was a long day for John Hart, a farmer in the hills just east of the Mississippi Delta.

title: Your Dot: On Science and Cyber-Terrorism
description: In the new tradition of Dot Earth in which readers contributions are occasionally brought out front, Im introducing Raymond T. Pierrehumbert of the University of Chicago and the (hacked) RealClimate.org blog. His comment touches on issues raised by many readers of all stripes in the heated comment thread related to the emails and documents on climate extracted from the University of East Anglia:

title: Police Fatally Shoot Armed Man, 18, Near Queens Park
description: An 18-year-old Queens man was fatally shot by the police late Saturday after he pointed a loaded pistol toward three plainclothes officers who were pursuing him, the authorities said.

title: Toll in Chinese Mine Explosion Rises to 104
description: HONG KONG  A gas explosion at a coal mine in northeastern China early Saturday killed at least 104 people, Chinas worst mine disaster in nearly two years, Chinese official media said Monday.

title: After Bailout, the Haggling
description: So far, the United States has negotiated privately to sell back to banks the warrants it received in exchange for injected funds. Now it is starting an auction process to bring in a market price for a handful of companies warrants, including JPMorgans. Its sensible, but the Treasury will probably still be criticized.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a House committees approval of a measure that would expand Congressional oversight of the Federal Reserve misidentified the state represented by Paul E. Kanjorski, who offered an amendment that would expand government power over large financial institutions. It is Pennsylvania, not Ohio.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a letter last Tuesday from former Representative James W. Symington of Missouri about solar wind propulsion referred incorrectly to his legislative position in 1992 when he helped lead a competition to design three spacecraft with solar sails for a journey to Mars. He was no longer in Congress, having served from 1969 to 1977. (The trip to Mars never occurred.)

title: Cracking Down on Drunken Driving
description: The national effort to reduce death and injuries from drunken driving has received a major boost from New York State. Gov. David Paterson signed a law that made New York among the first states to make it a felony to drive while intoxicated with a child in the vehicle. The new law also made New York one of a dozen states to require all convicted drunken drivers to use an ignition interlock device that prevents them from driving their cars if they are drunk.

title: GPS and Privacy Rights
description: A federal appeals court in Washington, D.C., heard arguments last week about whether police should have to get a warrant before putting a GPS device on a suspects car. It is a cutting-edge civil liberties question that has divided the courts that have considered it. GPS devices give the government extraordinary power to monitor peoples movements. The Washington court should rule that a warrant is required.

title: Old Soldiers Never Cash Out
description: For all the stars of ranking generals and admirals in Washington, it turns out theres still a higher grade  senior mentor. These are retired brass enjoying lucrative compensation as part-time Pentagon advisers, who, in most cases, also draw V.I.P. pay from companies seeking defense contracts. The mentor cohort has quietly grown in recent years from a handful to at least 158 ranking retired officers  80 percent of whom hire on at the same time with defense contractors.

title: Behind Cancer Guidelines, Quest for Data
description: A few years ago, an independent group that issues guidelines on cancer screening decided to review its recommendations for breast cancer. It had last issued guidelines in 2002, but things had changed  there was new science and researchers had become more sophisticated in analyzing existing data.

title: Corrections
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Accounts, People & Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Catching Tuna and Hanging On for the Ride
description: YARMOUTH, Mass.  Dave Lamoureuxs kayak, named Fortitude, must be the only one in Massachusetts registered as a motor vessel. Thats because a powerboat registration is required to get a permit to fish for tuna here.

title: The Influence of Zealous Employees
description: Companies are minisocieties, and employees can have impressions of a company that differ sharply from those of its potential customers. For the last decade or so, academics have suggested that companies try to shrink this gap, arguing that a companys public image and its organizational culture should be similar.

title: L.P.G.A. Tours Finale Suspended by Darkness
description: RICHMOND, Tex.  Darkness chased Lorena Ochoa off the golf course Sunday before she was through, but she was not done. After making a bogey on the penultimate hole of a second round she had waited two days to start, Ochoa headed straight to the practice green and putted for several minutes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about turmoil within the United States Chamber of Commerce over its opposition to climate change legislation erroneously included one company among those that have resigned from the chamber over the climate policy. A spokeswoman for Levi Strauss & Company said that although the company had differed with the chamber over labor and the environment, the main issue over which the company resigned was trade, not climate policy. The article also misstated the year the company resigned. It was in 2001, not this fall.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a national surplus of energy misidentified the position and company affiliation of Bill Johnson, a utility executive who said that utilities would have to build new generating stations to replace old ones that were wearing out. Mr. Johnson is president and chief executive of Progress Energy in Raleigh, N.C.  not a planning executive at Florida Power and Light.

title: Opposing Claims Cloud the Debate on an Overhaul
description: Corrected | 8:09 p.m., Nov. 23  An earlier version of this article inaccurately reported the percent of the population that would have medical coverage under the Senate health care, if people age 65 and older were included in the calculation. That number would be 94 percent, not 98 percent. The reference has been corrected below. For a fuller discussion of the error, and its original source, read here.

title: Fehr Is Giving the N.H.L.s Union Advice and Hope
description: As it tries to emerge from months of dismissals, resignations and internal turmoil, the N.H.L. Players Association has called upon perhaps the only person with the credibility and experience to restore a sense of order to the troubled union: Donald Fehr, the departing executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association.

title: Rusty Kanokogi, Fiery Advocate for Womens Judo, Dies at 74
description: Rusty Kanokogi, considered the mother of womens judo after fighting for more than two decades to make it an Olympic sport, died Saturday at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. She was 74.

title: Europes Bank Tightens Loan Rules
description: The European Central Bank on Friday tightened the rules for the collateral it accepts against loans as it prepares to unwind emergency liquidity measures.

title: Fixing Wall Streets Spin Problem
description: Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, the bank to bash on a resurgent Wall Street, is receiving a lot of advice lately, and its not just about money, The New York Timess Graham Bowley writes in the Week in Review.

title: Revisiting a Fed Waltz With A.I.G.
description: A ray of sunlight broke through the Washington fog last week when Neil M. Barofsky (pictured), special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program, published his offices report on the government bailout last year of the American International Group, The New York Timess Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest Fair Game column.

title: Dell Hymes, Linguist With a Wide Net, Dies at 82
description: Dell H. Hymes, a prominent anthropologist, linguist and folklorist whose work mined the rich, often overlooked territory where language and culture intersect, died on Nov. 13 in Charlottesville, Va. He was 82 and lived in Charlottesville.

title: Goldmans Non-Apology
description: Certainly, our industry is responsible for things. Were a leader in our industry, and we participated in things that were clearly wrong and we have reasons to regret and apologize for.

title: N.F.L.s Division Leaders Have Come a Long Way in a Year
description: Schoolchildren are taught to try, try again. Maybe teachers should just show a weekly N.F.L. highlight reel to get the message across. The nine teams that entered Week 11 as the division leaders (Denver and San Diego were tied for first in the American Football Conference West) were a combined 63-18 (.778). That record was 22 wins better than the same nine teams records from a year ago at this time.

description: As millions of Americans struggle to hold on to their homes, Wall Street has found a way to make money from the mortgage mess, The New York Timess Louise Story writes.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Another Win Puts Blackhawks in 2nd Over All
description: Only two games on Sunday, but both were important. Atlanta and Tampa Bay met to try to break the nine-team logjam surrounding eighth place in the East. title: G.E. and Vivendi Halt Talks Over Stake in NBC
description: Talks between General Electric and Vivendi over the future of NBC Universal have stalled, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin and Tim Arango reported on Saturday, citing people involved in the discussions who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were part of confidential negotiations.

title: Obama Seeks Time for Policies to Take
description: President Obamas scramble for a health care overhaul, like his dash across Asia last week, obscures an irony of his first year in office.

title: Mauer Expected to Win M.V.P., but Thats the Least of the Twins Concerns
description: Monday afternoons scheduled announcement of the winner of the American League Most Valuable Player award comes with limited drama. The Baseball Writers Association of America guards the voting results judiciously. But if Joe Mauer of the Minnesota Twins beats out the Yankees Mark Teixeira and Derek Jeter for the award, industry observers will not be surprised.

title: Test Your Knowledge of First Lady Inaugural Gowns
description: Do you remember what Jackie Kennedy wore to the inaugural ball in 1961? Who designed Hillary Clintons gowns? Take a quiz on the first ladies inaugural gowns.

title: Ciena Said to Win Nortel Unit for $769 Million
description: Ciena will buy Nortel Networks optical networking and carrier ethernet business for $769 million after outbidding Nokia Siemens Networks in a three-day auction, Reuters reported Sunday, citing unnamed sources.

title: Robinsons Progress Continues to Work Backward
description: Nate Robinson made seven shots on Sunday, all of them in the correct basket. For that, the Knicks were grateful. Yet his performance was marred again by impulsiveness and immaturity  the same issues that have dogged Robinson throughout his career.

description: stodgy  \st-je\  adjective

description: SEATTLE  Robbie Russell, the 14th man to step into the box for penalty kicks, drilled a shot into the lower left corner of the goal, turned, fell to his knees and pumped his fists.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Did You See New Moon Over the Weekend?
description: Jaws are dropping all over Hollywood, reports Brooks Barnes about the weekend ticket sales of New Moon. It now ranks as the third-biggest movie opening on record, and its success was largely driven by teenage girls.

title: Chieftain Capital Said to Split Amid Conflicts
description: Chieftain Capital Management, an investment firm with about $3 billion in assets, is breaking up following a rift among its managers, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Deficit hysteria
description: Urg. Big piece on the front page saying that, on the one hand, some people say that were going to have a debt crisis any day now, while on the other hand  well, actually we never hear from the other side.

title: Miami Art Museum
description: Images of the proposed design for the museum.

title: Khmer Rouge Tribunal Enters Final Phase
description: BANGKOK  Closing arguments began Monday in Cambodia in the trial of the former Khmer Rouge prison chief who is accused of crimes against humanity in the deaths of more than 14,000 people in the Tuol Sleng prison and torture house.

title: Do a Lot for Doolittle
description: Do what you can to get tickets to the Pixies at Hammerstein Ballroom this week. Even if you saw the pioneering indie band at one of their last reunion tours , this one, writes Ben Sisario, is different: theyll be playing Doolittle in its entirety. Released 20 years ago, its a spiky and allusive thing that packs anxious, violent, erotic, religious and silly ideas  visions of the surrealist horror-comedy Un Chien Andalou, Old Testament vengeance, sexy girls  into tight, short blasts of pop, he writes. Hit Craigslist if you have to.

title: Cyber Monday Prep
description: Its Thanksgiving week, and you know what that means: shopping. (Also eating yourself into oblivion. Ask Sam Sifton about that here.) For shopping advice, follow David Pogues tips, which is to say, convene with Mark Bittman and David Carr for pointers on cooking thermometers and e-books. (More stuff here.) And then pop by the pop-up Wired Store  where you can get all sorts of futuristic gadgets.

title: Dad Humor
description: Need material for your family get-together? Go see Robin Williams at Town Hall this week. The comedian is sober now, and ready to laugh at his sensitive side, writes Dave Itzkoff. Need material for your esoteric hipster friends? Go see Billy the Mime, best-known for his silent but x-rated routine in The Aristocrats and the alter-ego of a writer for SpongeBob SquarePants who moonlights as a choreographer of shadows. He performs tonight only at the UCB.

title: After the Bailout, the Haggling
description: So far, the United States has negotiated privately to sell back to banks the warrants it received in exchange for injected funds. Now it is starting an auction process to bring in a market price for a handful of companies warrants, including JPMorgan Chases. Its sensible, but the Treasury will probably still be criticized, Breakingviews.com says.

title: China Broker Takes Over Hong Kong House
description: Haitong Securities, one of the largest Chinese stock brokerage houses, announced Monday that it would take a controlling stake in Taifook Securities of Hong Kong for 1.82 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $235 million  the first time a mainland broker has acquired a Hong Kong peer.

title: British Treasury Official to Join Rothschild
description: John Kingman, the chief executive of the agency that manages the British governments bank shareholdings, is set to join Rothschild in March as managing director, the investment bank said on Monday.

title: Reliance Makes Bid for Chemical Giant
description: Reliance Industries, the largest private company in India, has offered to acquire a controlling interest in the worlds third-largest chemical company, LyondellBasell.

title: Executives Will Testify in Airbus Inquiry
description: One of highest-profile insider-trading inquiries in Europe in recent years will enter its final phase Monday as more than a dozen current and former executives of the aerospace group European Aeronautics Defense & Space and its Airbus subsidiary testify before a French regulator that is weighing more than 12 million euros ($18 million) in fines, The New York Timess Nicola Clark reported.

title: Execs Kept Wealth as Banks Failed, Study Says
description: Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers paid their executives largely in stock, and that stock lost most or all of its value when those companies collapsed.

title: Rio to Pocket $741 Million From Cloud Peak I.P.O.
description: Rio Tinto, the global miner, expects to receive at least $741 million from the flotation of its U.S. coal-mining unit, Cloud Peak Energy, on the New York Stock Exchange, Rio said Monday.

title: Princess Prevails in Pincus Dispute
description: After years of legal wrangling, Princess Firyal of Jordan has gained control of the huge duplex apartment owned by the late Lionel Pincus, the financier, on the 30th and 31st floors of the Pierre Hotel, facing Central Park at East 61st Street, The New York Timess Josh Barbanel reported.

title: Goldmans Response to Questions About A.I.G.
description: This memo from a Goldman Sachs spokesman, Lucas van Praag, was sent to Gretchen Morgenson, a business columnist for The New York Times, in response to questions she asked about the report issued Nov. 17 by the special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program (referred to in the memo as SIGTARP) on the governments September 2008 rescue of the American International Group, the giant insurance company. (The memo cites Ms. Morgensons questions in boldface.) To read Ms. Morgensons take on the report, see her latest Fair Game column.

title: Saving on Art the Old-Fashioned Way
description: For those of you with a desire to collect art despite the recessionary pinch, here is a solution that doesnt require dipping into your wallet. The Art Barter Event, an art fair where you can pay in imaginative goods and services rather than cash, is taking place at the Rag Factory (16-18 Heneage Street, E1 5LJ; 44-20-7650-8749; www.ragfactory.org.uk), a former studio on Brick Lane, from Nov. 27 to 29.

title: 21 Reported Dead and 22 Missing in Mass Kidnapping Linked to Philippine Election
description: MANILA  In one of the worst episodes of election-related violence in the Philippines in recent memory, a group of more than 40 people  including lawyers, journalists and relatives of a local politician  were kidnapped by armed men on Monday, and military officials said at least 21 of them had been killed.

title: Dimon Seen as Successor to Geithner, Report Says
description: Several United States policy makers consider JPMorgan Chases chief executive, Jamie Dimon, as a potential successor to Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner, The New York Post reported, citing sources.

description: Todays idea: The publics deep ambivalence about Americas current wars seems reflected in a TV commercial for an Xbox 360 war game, featuring very unwarlike music. This is marketing to young men in the age of Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: Jets Open Thread: Was Ryan Right to Stay With Sanchez?
description: As the Jets season plods on, each loss seems to result in the pass-the-blame baton landing in the hands of a different player. Yesterday it returned to Mark Sanchez, who threw four interceptions five weeks after he threw five in a loss to the Bills.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Four United States soldiers died fighting in Afghanistan during a 24-hour period, NATO said Monday, as the Obama administration continued deliberations on increasing the number of American forces here.

title: School Construction Critic Gets Prison Term in China
description: BEIJING  A lengthy prison sentence for a rights activist shows the determination of Chinese officials to suppress any vestige of dissent related to shoddy construction and unnecessary deaths in last years devastating earthquake in Sichuan Province, fellow activists said.

title: BofA May Extend C.E.O. Search into 2010, Report Says
description: Bank of America may extend its search for a new chief executive into next year if its board is unable to pick a candidate in the next four days, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

description: Tuesday was another typical day for John Chow, blogger and Internet entrepreneur in Vancouver, British Columbia. Mr. Chow treated his 50,000 Twitter followers to a photograph of his lunch (barbecued chicken and French fries), discussed the weather in Vancouver and linked to a new post on his Internet business blog.

description: Putting a price on carbon dioxide emissions will not be enough to drive the innovation needed to clean up dirty energy systems, according to Bruegel, a think tank based in Brussels, and Harvard economists.

description: Chinese banking regulators are putting pressure on the countrys banks to raise more capital and temper their rapid growth in lending, in the clearest signs yet of official concern about the sustainability of the nations credit boom, senior Chinese bankers said Monday.

description: A new arena in the medical marijuana debate is the use of the drug for teenagers who have conditions such as attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, according to a story by Katherine Ellison in Sundays Bay Area Report.
