title: Prisoner Swap Appears Near in the Mideast
description: JERUSALEM  Israel and the Islamist group Hamas appeared Monday to be nearing a deal to exchange a captured Israeli soldier for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners, possibly including a popular leader, a move with far-reaching implications not only for stalled Middle East peace talks but for a range of regional relations.

title: The Way We Ate: The Year Harry Truman Passed on Pumpkin Pie
description: For more than a century and a half, The New York Times has been recording the pleasures and prejudices of the American palate. The Way We Ate is a weekly tasting menu of vintage food writing from the Times archives.

title: Some Cities See Rebate Money for Efficient Toilets Drying Up
description: Austin, Texas, has recently received requests for nearly 4,000 efficient toilets, costing nearly $800,000, according to The Austin American-Statesman. The toilets cut water use by 63 percent compared with 1980s models, and have resulted in a 1 percent drop in water usage, the city claims.

title: An Unsurprising Slide for Obama
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama returned from his trip to Asia facing some unsettling news: two new public-opinion polls showing that his approval rating has dipped below 50 percent for the first time. To many of his critics, who chafed as Mr. Obama enjoyed broad support among Americans even though many were critical of his handling of specific issues like the economy, this erosion is a tipping-point, the end of Mr. Obamas perceived near-invulnerability.

title: Fighting Back, Rangel Still Gloomy
description: On the House floor during a debate over the health care overhaul, he taunted a colleague who had been calling for his ouster. At a recent fund-raiser, he complained that the House speaker had made an end run around him and his committee. Confronted by a persistent conservative activist in a hallway, he let loose an expletive, telling the man to mind his own business.

title: Motorsports Links: Johnson Sets Record With Fourth Cup
description: Motorsports news from around the Web

title: Proud to Be an American: Remembering the 2009 American Music Awards
description: How will history record the pageant that was the 37th annual American Music Awards? Will the event, which took place on Sunday night in Los Angeles, be best remembered as the night that Michael Jackson picked up four posthumous awards (including favorite male artist)? The evening when Taylor Swifts acceptances speeches went uninterrupted as she picked up five statuettes of her own (including artist of the year)? The moment when audiences were treated to formidable performances by Lady Gaga and Whitney Houston, and got to see Jermaine Jackson share the stage with his sons Jeremy, Jaafar and Jermajesty?

title: Stellar Design | Astronomy Posters
description: Now that water has been found on the moon, it seems even more fitting that 2009 has officially been designated the International Year of Astronomy (who knew?). But lets be honest: spaces heyday was the summer of 69, when Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong brought a rugged, clean-cut appeal to the final frontier. It was perhaps with this in mind that Simon Page, a self-taught graphic designer, created a series of posters for the Year of Astronomy that are modeled on textbook covers of the 60s and 70s. The result is a beautiful exercise in conceptual minimalism, with a clear geometric bent that betrays Pages math-nerd origins. (He has a degree in applied mathematics and took up graphic design as a hobby two years ago.) Its hard to choose which to like best, but Im particularly fond of the deep blue poster, below, in which Page uses diagonal lines to create interstellar objects in relief  and calls to mind the gentle descent of a meteor shower.

The surge far outpaced expectations and nurtured hope that the stubbornly frail housing market might be on the upswing.

As President Obama nears a decision on those military options, John F. Burns, the chief foreign correspondent for The Times, will respond to readers questions about the possible plans.

title: Cook the Book | Moosewood Redux
description: The restaurant synonymous with leafy hippie cooking has a new cookbook: The Moosewood Restaurant Cooking for Health. Those who remember the original Moosewood Cookbook, by the onetime collective member Mollie Katzen, will recall the charming hand lettering, whimsical illustrations and casual instructions (Ok, so, you take four modest slices of good rye bread. ). The new book, published by the Moosewood Collective (members run the famous vegetarian eatery in Ithaca, N.Y.), is slicker, more comprehensive and, true to its title, healthier. That means more kale and less cheese.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: American Eagle Outfitters, Pittsburgh, named ABC Regional Sports and Entertainment Sales, New York, as the advertising sales representative for the 15,000-square-foot sign above its new store at 1551 Broadway and 46th Street. The sign has 12 panels and will operate 18 hours a day. The ABC unit is part of the ABC National Television Sales division of ABC, owned by the Walt Disney Company.

title: An Unsurprising Slide for Obama
description: In his On Politics column, Adam Nagourney analyzes the lower poll ratings confronting President Obama.

title: Let Me Down Easy Extends Its Run
description: Second Stage Theater said on Monday that it is extending its production of Let Me Down Easy, a one-woman show written and performed by Anna Deavere Smith, in which various characters deal with medical care and end-of-life issues in the United States. The play, which was scheduled to run through Dec. 6, has been extended by three weeks. It will not, however, be performed from Dec. 14 through 20 so that Ms. Smith can perform Hymn with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at New York City Center as she had previously planned. The run of Let Me Down Easy is now scheduled to run through Jan. 3.

title: With Land Evictions, Kenya Aims to Reduce Impacts on Important Ecosystem
description: The Kenyan government has begun forcibly evicting thousands of people in an attempt to halt environmental degradation in the Mau Forest, one of the nations most critical ecosystems.

title: M.L.S. Champions Not Always Winners
description: It took much longer than many anticipated, and made for late viewing Sunday night on the East Coast, but Real Salt Lake hoisted the Philip F. Anschutz trophy after a dramatic penalty shootout victory over the Los Angeles Galaxy.

title: Suspension Improbable: Bulls Interfere With Tom Cruise-Cameron Diaz Film
description: Shooting on a new film starring Tom Cruise and Cameron Diaz was halted by a stampede  not of paparazzi, autograph seekers or moviegoers who want their Vanilla Sky tickets refunded, but of bulls that accidentally got loose on the set. The Associated Press reported that seven bulls broke free on Sunday during rehearsals in the Spanish city of Cadiz for a film called Knight & Day. Mr. Cruise and Ms. Diaz were not on the set at the time, but two women, whose names were not given, were injured as the bulls ran through the citys streets to a nearby beach. The films director, Jose Luis Escolar, said that he did not know how the bulls escaped. A spokesman for the local government told The A.P. that production on Knight & Day has been suspended until further notice.

title: Travel Deals: Half Price at All-Inclusive Resort in Mexico
description: The Royal Hideaway Playacar, an adults-only all-inclusive resort in Playa del Carmen, on the Yucatn Peninsula of Mexico, is offering 50 percent off stays through Dec. 22. Stay four nights and pay for two; stay six and pay for three.

title: Dennis Cole, Felony Squad Actor, Is Dead at 69

title: Featured Recipe: Make-Ahead Gravy
description: Another way to get ahead (see this weeks Minimalist for 101 others) on Thanksgiving dinner is to make the gravy the night before. Start with a good strong stock, one you have made well in advance, preferably with roasted meat, a few aromatic vegetables and a bay leaf or two. Then make a roux, heating butter and flour together until they darken. Whisk the stock into the roux until its thick, then refrigerate. When you are ready to serve, just reheat it. Presto! Gravy without hassle.

title: Cheap for Christmas
description: Can you trust people to tell a pollster how much they will spend on Christmas presents?

title: A Pox on the Bengals
description: Its bad enough that the N.F.L. has stolen so much of baseballs thunder in the national pastime debate, but now it has taken over the colorful world of curses. Sure, baseball still has the Cubs  although their curse is arguably more of an incurable disease  but curses are sprouting up all over the N.F.L., usually transported by disgruntled, egomaniacal players whose arrivals should have been accompanied by something like an air raid warning.

title: For Search, Murdoch Looks to a Deal With Microsoft
description: News Corporation, the media conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch, has engaged in early-stage discussions with Microsoft about a pact to get paid by Microsoft to remove its news content from Googles search engine and be available on Bing, according to a person briefed on the matter who spoke anonymously to discuss confidential negotiations.

title: Waiting For The Reformers
description: My column today uses Sarah Palin and Mike Huckabee as a springboard to talk about how the Republican Partys biggest problem, increasingly, is less a dearth of creative conservative policy ideas than a dearth of politicians interested in embracing them and selling them. And by sensible policy ideas, I dont mean idiosyncratic notions cooked up by a couple of twentysomething journalists working at non-conservative publications; I mean politically plausible ideas being proposed by economists and think tankers with impeccable right-wing bona fides. If the Republicans were associated with, say, Michael Boskins stimulus ideas, Nicole Gelinass proposals for handling Wall Street, and some combination of the Miller-Capretta and Troy-Anderson health care plans, they would be a party worth taking seriously on domestic policy. But they arent, so they arent. And on this front, the wonks can only do so much: In the end, you need politicians capable of picking up policy ideas and running with them. Thats what the G.O.P. is waiting for. Hopefully it wont have to wait forever.

description: You grew up in Pennsylvania, and yet you fell in love with country music at a young age. What did you hear that attracted you to country?

description: The Olympic future of American skier Resi Stiegler is in doubt after a nasty crash on Copper Mountain Thursday.

title: After New Moon, Does Hollywood Need New Blood?
description: With its estimable opening-weekend ticket sales, The Twilight Saga: New Moon  which took in $140.7 million at the domestic box office  set a record for the third highest-grossing opening weekend in United States film history. (The No. 1 slot is held by The Dark Knight, which grossed $158.4 million in its opening weekend in 2008, and No. 2 goes to Spider-Man 3, which took in $151.1 million at its opening in 2007.)

title: American Beauty
description: The lines were clean and clear, the attitude fresh and simple, and the models so rangy and long-limbed that I felt inadequate beside them. This was the 1980s  the first time I came in touch with pure American sportswear.

title: An End to Open Admissions Looms at a Texas University
description: One of the two public universities in Texas that still offer open admission is considering changing that policy, The Houston Chronicle reports.

title: Neither Red State Nor Blue State, but Toy State
description: Billy Joel sings about a New York state of mind. Can a campaign centered on a brand character named Ripp help put children -- and the parents who shop for them -- in a Toy State state of mind?

title: Kiki Smith and Deborah Gans to Design Window for Eldridge Street Synagogue
description: The Museum at Eldridge Street has commissioned the artist Kiki Smith and the architect Deborah Gans to create a new east window for its 1887 synagogue, a National Historic Landmark on Manhattans Lower East Side.

title: Ms. Demeanor
description: "Everyone talks trash, said Wendy Williams, the television talk-show host with huge hair, size GG breasts and a mouth so big you could park a tractor-trailer between gums and tonsils. I just happen to have the moxie and a microphone.

title: Vain Glorious | Studio Beautymix in SoHo
description: With Vain Glorious, T Magazines beauty/style director, Sandra Ballentine, breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

title: Monday Puzzle: Whimsical Ahas!
description: The Fall Classic is done, the Yankees are World Champs, Thanksgivings round the corner, the Babes in His Heaven and alls right with the world! So for this short working week, were going to do some whimsical problems that require no deep mathematical concepts. After all, its not fair to tax our brains too heavily, when all our blood supply is being diverted to our turkey-laden stomachs, turning us too, temporarily, into turkeys. Whimsical though these problems are, when you do solve them, youll nevertheless experience the absolute certainty that is characteristic of the aha! experience weve discussed recently. Of course that is the answer, youll say. There can be no doubt. Like Helen Keller discovering language, or Einstein discovering relativity, youll need no external authority to validate your answer: youll just know it is right.

title: Sales Using Food Stamps Double at Greenmarkets
description: Food stamp purchases at the citys Greenmarkets have more than doubled in the last year, due in large part to publicity campaigns and the addition of more farmers markets to the program.

title: Beef Encounters
description: Fellow Americans: theres good news and bad regarding our national pastimes  eating, snacking and pigging out. The Samurai Shopper respects our constitutional entitlement to life, liberty and the pursuit of voluptuously stacked hamburgers, but those entitlements weigh heavily on us. Literally. Carnivores run amok may soon be unable to run at all. Though looming Golden Arches offer insuperable proof of American entrepreneurial genius, they dont exactly symbolize quality or nourishment. And weve systematically shoved these nasty little buns down everyones throats: we are the burger kings. Youre welcome, Finland!

title: The Genes of Our Fathers
description: At my sons very first check-up I had to fill out a form with his family history. As I scanned through the questions about cancer and heart disease and diabetes, and did a mental inventory of his relatives and their medical imperfections, I felt a rising sense of guilt  these were the genes I had passed along to this perfect baby boy?

title: For Search, Murdoch Looks to a Deal With Microsoft
description: From Media Decoder:

title: Prodded by Agrium, CF Pushes Terra for a Deal
description: The nearly yearlong, three-way takeover dance by the rival fertilizer makers Terra Industries, CF Industries Holdings and Agrium continued on Monday after Terra seated three CF elected directors on its board but rejected CFs offer as inadequate.

title: The Invisible Man
description: As certain celebrities become more visible, they also become less noticeable, almost merging with the media landscape. Instead of taking center stage, they somehow manage to become the stage. Theyre ubiquitous and anonymous at once.

title: Jerusalem Wins Top London Evening Standard Theater Award
description: Jez Butterworths play Jerusalem, a three-hour-plus dark comedy, won two London Evening Standard Theater Awards, which were announced on Monday, Reuters reported.

title: Henry Considered Quitting France Team
description: Racked by guilt and cloistered in private after his blatant hand ball helped send France to the 2010 World Cup, Thierry Henry considered ending his career with the national team.

title: Paging Mr. Driftwood
description: However exasperating the enforced togetherness this holiday season the gifts lovingly chosen for the person your family wishes you were, the zingers that come out of nowhere like crockery aimed at your head  keep in mind that it could have been worse: you could have been the child of a movie star. Every so often, one survives to tell the tale, confirming the fact that Hollywood is not only the home of people paid to be the center of attention; its also the capital of bad parenting. (Coincidence?)

title: Nope, Lady Gaga Is Still Ineligible for Best New Artist Grammy
description: Sorry, Gaga.

title: U.S. to Set Emissions Target Before Climate Talks
description: WASHINGTON  The United States will propose a near-term target for reducing greenhouse gas emissions before the United Nations climate change meeting in Copenhagen next month, a senior administration official said Monday. President Obama, the official said, will announce the specific target in coming days.

title: On Our Radar
description: 1.) Of wind turbines, pig farms and not-in-my-backyard sentiment.

title: The Voice That Helped Remake Culture
description: Louis Armstrong, a k a Satchmo, a k a Pops, was to music what Picasso was to painting, what Joyce was to fiction: an innovator who changed the face of his art form, a fecund and endlessly inventive pioneer whose discovery of his own voice helped remake 20th-century culture.

title: Core Values
description: Despite a record-setting, recession-proof box office, the movie business has lost its middle. Blockbusters, based largely on toys and comic books, which can be turned into hugely lucrative franchises for the studios, have all but replaced movies aimed at a smaller and perhaps more discerning audience. In the recent past, the studios wanted their slates to contain all sorts of movies at different budgets, but today certain equations seem to dominate. Will the movie have a star attached? (Add $20 million to your cost.) Will it play around the world? (Add a no-English-necessary action component.) Will it appeal to the widest possible audience? (Meaning, males 18-49.)

title: Football Upsets Increase Domestic Violence, Study Finds
description: Besides being a big day for eating, Thanksgiving is a big day for another American tradition: football-watching. A new working paper, however, makes this ritual a bit more ominous than turkey-stuffing.

title: Generation Gap
description: Ten days after Don Fishers death, it was not just the presence of the man you could feel in his office but also the power of his simple idea. The picture window on the 15th floor of the Gaps corporate headquarters opened onto a giant bow-and-arrow sculpture that Fisher and his wife had commissioned for Rincon Park as well as a million-dollar view of San Francisco Bay, where cargo ships as brightly colored as Gap T-shirts crossed under the Bay Bridge. His desk, an uncluttered Jules Leleu knockoff, was bare but for a phone, a mechanical pencil and a pad scribbled with lunch dates and unreturned calls. Also reclining there: an atypical wooden figure by Alexander Calder, circa 1928, the earliest piece in Fishers major collection of contemporary art. The founder of the largest American clothing company was as eager to make a competition of art expertise as he had been of the apparel business, and any visiting curator or sculpture maven could expect a pop quiz: who do you think made that? In 13 years, only two people had guessed correctly.

title: G.O.P. Considers Purity Resolution for Candidates
description: The battle among Republicans over what the party should stand for  and how much it should accommodate dissenting views on important issues  is probably going to move from the states to the Republican National Committee when it holds its winter meeting this January in Honolulu.

title: Louis Armstrong in 2 Minutes, 53 Seconds
description: Louis Armstrong, Dinah, filmed on a sound stage in Denmark, 1933: a very early item in his filmography. This is a short and efficient answer for why he was and is important. You sense hes building his brand  the stuff with the handkerchief, getting up in the viewers grill, popping his eyes at .55  but its still pretty extreme, and exciting. Look at how he felt music, and moved to it. (Especially .10-.20, that davening kind of thing: James Brown did that too.) Listen to the way he chopped up rhythm, sailing his phrases over the beat. You want to say hes imitating a trumpet when he sings, but then you want to say vice versa, so neither can be true. Hes continuous, playing or singing something nearly all the way through, making his body part of the performance.

title: As Charter Slots Dwindle, Competition Increases
description: In Albany, issues tend to get shunted aside until the last possible moment. The challenges facing charter schools are no different. As advocates have pressed lawmakers to raise the cap  that is, the maximum number allowed, now 200  many have said that the state is years away from reaching it, so no immediate action is needed.

title: A Simple Thanksgiving With Alice Waters
description: In many Thanksgiving side dishes, it can be tough to recognize the original vegetable. Can you find green beans in that casserole buried under the mushroom soup and crispy onions? Would you like a little sweet potato with your brown sugar and marshmallows?

title: When Is a Pizza Too Well Done?
description: At Always Hungry, Arthur Bovino pays his five bucks and assesses the state of the slice at the Brooklyn pizza temple Di Fara. He says, as Adam Kuban has noted, that the pies, particularly the ones used for slices, are often burned. Have you been lately? What do you think?

title: Michael Feinstein and Dame Edna Find a Home Together
description: Though weve been misled by them in the past, were fairly certain that Michael Feinstein and Dame Edna Everage are telling the truth when they say they have found a Broadway theater for their coming stage collaboration, All About Me. On Monday, publicists for the production said that it would be performed at the Golden Theater, with previews to begin on Feb. 19 and an opening night set for March 18. That theater has recently been home to the revival of David Mamets Oleanna (as well as Avenue Q), and was also where Mr. Feinstein performed his show Michael Feinstein in Concert  Piano and Voice. All About Me will be written by Christopher Durang and directed by Jerry Zaks.

title: A Missed Chance for a Ruling on Poison Pills
description: Royal KPN of the Netherlands and iBasis have kissed and made up. The two parties announced Monday that they had settled their litigation in Delaware Chancery Court. KPN will now raise its offer to $3 a share, from $2.25, and the iBasis board will recommend the offer.

title: Two Fewer Celebrities to Attend Fela! Opening
description: After efforts by publicists and producers to juggle three celebrity schedules into alignment, Will and Jada Pinkett Smith will not be joining Jay-Z at Monday nights Broadway opening of Fela! because of a sports injury suffered by Mr. Smiths oldest son.

title: Health Bill Revives Abortion Groups
description: WASHINGTON  Lobbying over abortion was turning into a sleepy business. But the health care debate has brought a new boom, and both sides are exploiting it with fund-raising appeals.

title: Readers Weigh In on Picky Eaters
description: Susan Goldbergs Complaint Box on the vast and bewildering array of dietary needs drew a deluge of more than 300 comments (the most ever for a Complaint Box). Some commiserated with her frustration, but others tsk-tsked her for being a less than gracious host. Many people with dietary restrictions explained how they tried not to impose; others offered strategies, whether through buffets or very simple recipes.

title: A Push for Science and Technology Learning
description: President Obama devotes a fair amount of time to sports. He plays golf most weekends. He filled out his N.C.A.A. championship bracket for all ESPN viewers to see. And he carefully follows his hometown Chicago teams: the White Sox, the Bulls and the Bears.

title: Required Reading | Argentine Soul Food
description: Two very different pieces of travel writing loom large in Cocina Confidential, Stephen Metcalfs foodie adventure story from our winter travel issue. The first, The Return of Eva Pern by V.S. Naipaul, was written more than 30 years ago, but its still talked about in more introspective quarters of the Argentine capital  and not always with affection. To Naipaul, Metcalf writes, Argentina was less a country than a staging ground for absurdist public traumas that never add up to an actual history. From dictatorship to hyperinflation to, more recently, the currency crisis, which plunged the economy into chaos in 2001, cataclysm seems to come naturally to Argentines.

title: A Critique of Helicopter Parents
description: The cover story in the latest issue of Time magazine is titled The Case Against Over-Parenting. Why Mom and Dad need to cut the strings. Its target is helicopter parents. In it, the author, Nancy Gibbs, argues for laissez-faire parenting  a let them grow by letting go method  while acknowledging that over-involvement can feel irresistible.

title: Thanksgiving Questions: A Monday Speed Round
description: Hope you got your shopping in this weekend, friends. Were coming up to the big event now. Ill be on hand on Thursday morning for all your last-minute freak-outs and emergencies. In the meantime, lets take a quick couple of questions from the in-box, dispatch them as if they were heritage birds. Later today, Ill be back with some more: On the Question of Pies and the like. Keep hitting refresh.

title: Bent Offerings
description: Pity the poor mum, which dare not show its face. And cast a smile upon the friendless carnation thats been permanently sidelined to the Korean markets. These are flowers, along with the stalwart daisy and the lowly gladiola (People associate them with funerals, says Todd Rigby, the co-owner of VSF, a tiny, charming floral outpost on West 10th Street), whose time has come and gone. Enter the calla lily, which can go for $35 a stem, and cymbidium orchids, which go for $60 to $75 a stem, the presence of which has become de rigueur in all the best arrangements.

title: The Morning Skate: Georgess Innocent Dance, Isles Move Forward and Holy Jumpin Santa!
description: The N.H.L. will most likely suspend Canadiens tough guy Georges Laraque today after this sequence, the early season contender for Bad Shift of the Year.

title: China Gains in U.S. Eyes, and India Feels Slights
description: NEW DELHI  The statement, on its surface, seemed like any other bland missive released at the end of a polite visit by a head of state. It was put out by the United States and China after President Obamas visit there, and said that the two countries would work together to promote peace, stability and development in South Asia.

title: News of Hockey, 11/23/09: Kellys New Job to Raise College Hockeys Profile
description: Paul Kelly, dismissed as executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association last summer, will be introduced at a news conference at Harvard University on Tuesday as head of a new organization, College Hockey Inc. The organization will operate under the supervision of the Hockey Commissioners Association, a grouping of the major N.C.A.A. hockey leagues.

title: Lighter Thanksgiving Desserts
description: Thanksgiving dinner is a runners delight, a meal packed with carbs followed by more carbs. But its the pies that always do me in. If youre not drunk on food by the time you get to them, you will be afterwards. Theres no resisting them.

title: Sanfords Ethics Charges Revealed
description: South Carolinas Ethics Commission on Monday released the details of more than three dozen ethics charges it has filed against Gov. Mark Sanford in the wake of his extramarital affair this year.

title: Handy Airline Surcharge Charts
description: Confused about the surcharges that airlines are tacking on for Christmas and other popular travel days? Farecompare.com, an airline shopping site, has created a handy breakdown of the new fees by date, airline and amount.

title: Chinese Drywall Linked to Corrosion
description: Federal investigators reported on Monday that a strong association exists between chemicals in Chinese drywall installed in thousands of homes during the housing boom and electrical problems in those homes.

title: An Ex-Quarterbacks Take on Cutlers Struggles
description: As the rift between the Denver Broncos rookie coach, Josh McDaniels, and his star quarterback, Jay Cutler, widened last off-season, more than a few executives in the N.F.L. suggested that McDaniels should make nice with Cutler for the good of the team. But McDaniels, it became clear, had something else in mind, and now we know why.

title: For Search, Murdoch Eyes Deal With Microsoft
description: From Ashlee Vance and Tim Arango at Media Decoder:

title: Police and YouTube: Responding to Arrest Videos
description: The above YouTube video (in which obscenities are shouted) is called Officer breaks window with drunks face. But it goes by other names, including BART POLICE PUT MANS HEAD THROUGH WINDOW.

title: White House Begins Campaign to Promote Science and Math Education
description: To improve science and mathematics education for American children, the White House is recruiting Elmo and Big Bird, video game programmers and thousands of scientists.

title: Game-Fixing Scandal Makes Many Poor Performances Suspect
description: PARIS  After F.C. Thun, a second-tier professional soccer club in Switzerland, was routed by 5-1 in April by a rival, Yverdon, officials were scratching their heads trying to figure out why their team had lost so badly.

title: Iraqs January Elections Face Near Certain Delay
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs tortuous effort to hold its parliamentary election on schedule in January collapsed Monday, raising the prospect of a political and constitutional crisis next year as the United States begins withdrawing the majority of its combat troops.

title: Shattered Glass on New Bay Area Video
description: The sound of shattering glass is the most chilling part of a video that has surfaced on YouTube, the latest one to raise questions about the use of excessive force by the Bay Area transit systems police officers.

title: Russian Leader Expresses Support for Nonprofits
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev called Monday for tax incentives and other measures to assist Russias beleaguered nonprofit groups, which have come under government pressure in recent years.

title: Home Fires: Life Lessons
description: Im occasionally asked what Ive learned from my experiences in the military.

title: Global Warming Basics
description: The role of newspapers and journalists is evolving as technologies and media markets change. Along with providing conventional coverage of the news, blogging, video reports and the like, media outlets are increasingly providing basic background on important enduring issues. The Times has put more effort recently into enriching and updating what are called topics pages  basic backgrounders on issues in the news. I recently had a go at our page on global warming. Heres the introduction and a link to the full page. Its followed by the steady feed of news articles and accompanied by links to other background. Henceforth, itll be a living document, with more features, links and content added as needed. I encourage you to identify any gaps and glitches. Our editors will keep track of the comments.

title: Global Warning
description: Why have you, a conservative senator from Oklahoma who has dismissed global warming as a hoax, announced that you plan to attend the United Nations Climate Change Conference, which opens in Copenhagen on Dec. 7 and seeks to reach a new agreement on limiting carbon emissions globally?  I dont want a group of people to tell the people of Copenhagen that the United States is going to pass some kind of a cap-and-trade bill. I want to be there, if Im a one-man truth squad, to say: No, that isnt true. They dont have the votes. Were not going to pass it.

title: How to Monitor Frequent-Flier Miles
description: I recently learned via a telephone call that my United Airlines frequent-flier miles were going to expire if I didnt use some of them immediately.

title: Cadillac Previews CTS Coupe Ahead of Los Angeles Auto Show
description: The on-again, off-again Cadillac CTS Coupe is back on again. Cadillac officially announced the 2011 model Monday morning, promising to show the car publicly  for sure, this time  next week at the Los Angeles auto show.

title: James Berg, 65, Dies; Negotiated Labor Peace for Citys Landlords
description: James F. Berg, who as the chief negotiator for most of New York Citys major landlords was given large credit for an era of labor peace in their buildings because of the trust he inspired on both sides of the bargaining table, died Nov. 18 in Manhattan. He was 65 and lived in Bay Shore, N.Y.

title: Carl Kasell to Retire as NPR Anchor
description: The renowned National Public Radio newscast anchor Carl Kasell will retire from the job at the end of the year, the organization said Monday. But Mr. Kasell will continue to keep score for NPRs weekly quiz show Wait, Wait Dont Tell Me! as that programs official judge.

title: Feingold Picks Up Fleece Mantle
description: Senator Russ Feingold on Monday launched a new Spotlight on Spending that recalled the long-running  and better-named  campaign against perceived government waste by an earlier maverick Democrat from Wisconsin, the late William Proxmire of Golden Fleece fame.

title: Gov. Sanford Faces 37 Ethics Charges
description: Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina will face formal ethics charges on 37 counts of using his office for personal financial gain, according to a list of accusations issued Monday by the State Ethics Commission.

title: Blame the Academy: Marc Shaiman Is Oscars Musical Director
description: If the coming Academy Awards show turns out to be teeming with original musical numbers or dirty sexual puns, now youll know who to thank or vilify. On Monday, the producers of the Oscars telecast said that Marc Shaiman, the composer and lyricist, would be the shows musical director. Mr. Shaiman, whose credits include the musical versions of Hairspray and Catch Me If You Can, is an Oscars veteran, having previously served as musical director of the show in 2004 and written musical medleys (with his longtime collaborator Scott Wittman) performed by the host Billy Crystal.

title: European Puck: K.H.L. Clubs Balk at Joining Revived Champions League
description: Tuesday is the deadline for European domestic leagues to inform the International Ice Hockey Federation whether they will participate in the 2010-11 Champions Hockey League, the revived competition featuring regular-season and playoff victors from the continents Top 7 hockey-playing nations.

title: Some Rediscover the Benefits of Business Travel
description: When the economy collapsed last fall, many companies had to make some quick decisions about travel, typically one of the first areas they trim when finances are tight. Should they cut back as most of their competitors were, continue business as usual or spend even more to get a leg up?

title: Stephen Colberts Wild Winter Olympic Ride Continues
description: First, Stephen Colbert got on board the United States Speedskating teams bandwagon as a team sponsor and then on Sunday Colbert went for an actual ride: in a four-man bobsled down Lake Placids course at Mount Van Hoevenberg.

title: More Rain for Britain After Floods
description: Parts of Great Britain and Ireland, already reeling from their worst flooding in decades, braced for more storms on Monday, as some residents were allowed back home to assess the damage of torrents that inundated streets, knocked out bridges and displaced hundreds of people.

title: War on Illegal Guns, Fought on Two Fronts
description: Against a backdrop of recent shootings of innocent bystanders, including a 13-year-old boy from Queens and a 15-year-old girl from the Bronx, city officials and activists each did their part on Monday in their fight against gun violence, albeit in different ways and at different venues.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) Democratic elections in developing countries usually improve economic policy  except when theyre not, uhh, democratic.

title: An Italian Lesson for the Overstuffed
description: CONSIDER your stomach. No, not as it is now, in repose before the feast, awaiting the pleasures to come. Consider it as it will feel Thanksgiving evening, after the nibbles and noshes, the hors doeuvres, the sides and the turkey, the rolls, the stuffing, all that wine, the second helpings, the oh, just a little more, the pies, the cookies and, of course, the chocolates without which no meal would be complete.

title: Seeking New Sensations
description: There are four prima dancers  or, at times, prima donnas  in the latest collaboration by the Israeli artists Lee Sher and Saar Harari. At the start of Prima, performed at Performance Space 122 on Thursday, Hsin-Yi Hsiang arched her back and pressed her hands into her ribcage. With her rear sticking out in stark exaggeration, she made her way toward the back of the darkened stage by wiggling her hips in a manner more ferocious than sensual. At times it was as if she were possessed by outside forces or aftershocks; in other moments she seemed to be going through the motions.

title: Stray Questions for: Roberto Bolao?!
description: The novelist Roberto Bolao died in 2003. What follows is an excerpt from his last interview, published in Playboy Mexico the month of his death and now appearing in English in Roberto Bolao: The Last Interview & Other Conversations (Melville House Publishing), which goes on sale tomorrow. The interview was conducted by Monica Maristain and translated by Sybil Perez. (It is also reprinted in the current issue of Stop Smiling, though not available online.)

title: Not Your Mothers Noodles
description: (Ed makes a pizzocheri like dish  starting with the noodles. MB)Buckwheat noodles with cabbage have been no stranger to The Times (see here, for instance), and when my wife, Jackie, recently remembered that a Savoy cabbage and some leeks were languishing in the refrigerator, that was what came to mind. It was a chilly, rainy day. Wed walked through a pleasant drizzle for an hour and a half and had just climbed into a taxi with our shopping bags when the drizzle turned to a downpour and finding a cab suddenly became impossible for other people  cause for smug triumphalism and hearty appetite.

title: Twitter May Seek I.P.O., but No Sale, Founder Says
description: Twitter, the social network built on 140-character musings, may eventually go to the stock market for financing, but it is currently ruling out a sale, Biz Stone, a founder, said on Monday.

title: Mauer Is Nearly Unanimous as A.L. M.V.P.
description: Not surprisingly, Joe Mauer of the Minnesota Twins was named most valuable player of the American League on Monday. Two Yankees followed him in the final results: Mark Teixeira was second and Derek Jeter was third.

title: Lost in the Mail
description: Depending on your sympathy for the bugle-beaded tragedies of what have become broadly known as Dreamgirls, the Marvelettes are either a big sigh or a windfall. Its hard to believe, but many people have had all they can take hearing about talented young black women having their lives shredded by greedy record labels in the 1960s. The same people find spending an evening with the Beatles video game more sustaining than putting the Marvelettes new three-CD set Forever on the changer and snuggling down with Marc Taylors tell-all The Original Marvelettes: Motowns Mystery Girl Group. I guess theres no accounting for how people spend their Tuesday nights.

title: Making Music Mightier Than the Sword
description: There should be dancing in the streets. When you leave the Eugene ONeill Theater after a performance of Fela!, it comes as a shock that the people on the sidewalks are merely walking. Why arent they gyrating, swaying, vibrating, in thrall to the force field that you have been living in so ecstatically for the past couple of hours?

title: Helping the Hungry: Researching the Causes of Hunger and Related Charities
description: Overview | What has caused an increase in hunger in the United States? How can individuals help to alleviate this growing problem? In this lesson, students consider the causes of rising hunger and use The New York Times to research the issue. The class then works together to choose a charitable organization and develop a fund-raising strategy.

title: Foundation Tied to Iran Donated to Columbia
description: Several months before the Iranian president made a controversial appearance at Columbia University in 2007, the Alavi Foundation  a nonprofit organization that had long supported educational programs related to Islamic and Iranian culture at schools and universities  donated $100,000 to Columbia.

title: The Choices Faced by UC, Students and the Public
description: Over at Room for Debate, there is a good discussion about public universities nationwide and the difficulty balancing fiscal responsibility and access to higher education.

title: Audience and Box Office Drops at God of Carnage as New Cast Takes Over
description: Carnage indeed.

title: A Vision Faces an Environmental Test
description: MICHES, Dominican Republic  From a development perspective, this town has a few problems.

title: Now Playing | A Piano Bar Grows in Brooklyn
description: Uptowners have Bemelmans. Maries Crisis, in the West Village, caters to a gay crowd. But what about the Brooklyn hipsters? Now they have the Manhattan Inn, a new old-timey piano bar on Manhattan Avenue opened by Brooke Baxter and Rolyn Hu, the ladies who started Glasslands Gallery on Kent Avenue in 2006. But the Manhattan Inn is different. Its a little older crowd, says Hu, maybe looking to have a quieter night. Instead of a massive art loft rocked by guitars and gritty marching bands, an intimate front bar opens to a larger back room, where, under a skylight and a chandelier, a lily-white baby grand  courtesy of Craigslist  awaits its player.

title: All Those Lonely Souls, Each Under the Same Night Sky
description: If this is what a disaster looks like, bring on the apocalypse. The early word on The Starry Messenger, the new play by Kenneth Lonergan, was so appalling it seemed that instant euthanasia would be in order. The theater chat rooms were dense with complaints about the productions excessive length, sloppy acting and fuzzy focus. Mr. Lonergan was reported to be overwhelmed by the unfamiliar task of directing his own work and changing the script daily. And the shows star, Matthew Broderick, made headlines for not being able to remember his lines.

title: How to Help a Baby With Colic
description: When we last heard from Kristina and Evan, they had just moved to a new town and were expecting their first child. Kristina wrote to Motherlode asking readers to share advice for a new parent, and you responded in force. (The collection of comments is a treasure trove for any new parent.)

title: Politics and Clan Warfare in the Philippines
description: Update | Tuesday | 12:41 p.m. As my colleague Carlos Conde reports from the Philippines, the death toll in a massacre there on Monday has risen to 46, as the remains of more victims were discovered on Tuesday.

title: The Dangers of Taking a Dip in the Hot Tub
description: A hot tub might not seem an especially dangerous place, but over a period of 18 years, 1990-2007, more than 80,000 people were injured in hot tubs or whirlpools seriously enough to wind up in an emergency room. Almost 74 percent of the injuries occurred at home.

title: Salon Starts a Food Section
description: As the world of food journalism in print shrinks, online efforts grow. First The Atlantic expanded its culinary coverage with its online food channel.

title: Norway Fires Peter Mueller as Speedskating Coach
description: Peter Mueller, who won a gold medal in the 1976 Olympics and went on to coach American skaters like Bonnie Blair and Dan Jansen to Olympic medals, was fired by Norway as its national speedskating coach on Monday after one of its skaters accused him of sexual harassment. It was startling for the timing  the Games begin in less than three months  and because Mueller was widely hailed for resurrecting a slumping program over the past six years.

title: Opel Reopens German Debate Over Aid
description: As executives of General Motors met Monday with European officials to ask for financial help in restructuring its struggling auto operations on the Continent, Germany reopened a bitter public debate over state aid and job protections that has sharply divided its government, Judy Dempsey of The New York Times reports from Berlin.

title: Toll in Chinese Mine Explosion Rises to 104
description: HONG KONG  A gas explosion at a coal mine in northeastern China early Saturday killed at least 104 people, Chinas worst mine disaster in nearly two years, Chinese official media said Monday.

title: Robinsons Wrong-Basket Swish Would Not Have Counted
description: Much outrage has been spent and many brows furrowed over Nate Robinsons bizarre decision to shoot at the wrong basket during the Knicks game against the Nets on Saturday. But it appears that the Knicks greatest concern - that he might have scored 3 points for the Nets - is misplaced.

title: Dominican Town Explores Ecotourism
description: In the Dominican Republic, a small town long troubled by poverty is fighting to hold onto its beaches and transform them into a low-key, environmentally sustainable tourist destination.

title: Back to the Vermont Inn Where the Snow Must Go On
description: Second-acters, those people who see half a show for free by sneaking in with the returning audience at intermission, might be kicking themselves for missing Act I of Irving Berlins White Christmas after they see the number that opens the second act, an eye-popping version of I Love a Piano. But no worries, cheapskates; you didnt miss much. The high point of the first act of this tepid seasonal offering, now at the Marquis Theater, was a gag provided by a character who was snoring.

title: A Nonbeliever Makes a Case Against Tempting Fate
description: I MIGHT run a network that focuses on science fiction and the extraordinary, but Im a very practical guy. For example, I dont believe in jinxes.

title: Law Raises Age for Children to Remain in Safety Restraints
description: More New Yorkers should be buckling their sons and daughters into booster seats this holiday weekend after a new state law extends the age that children must ride in child restraint systems.

title: Did the Pilgrims Serve Pork, Too?
description: I DIDNT think it would surprise my family to learn that I planned, this Thanksgiving, to change the menu a tiny bit to cut calories.

title: China Seeks to Slow Rapid Growth of Lending
description: Chinese banking regulators are putting pressure on the countrys banks to raise more capital and temper their rapid growth in lending, in a clear sign of official concern about the sustainability of the nations credit boom, senior Chinese bankers said on Monday.

title: Kennedys Widow to Appear on Oprah
description: After avoiding the public eye for three months, Victoria Reggie Kennedy, the widow of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, will appear on The Oprah Winfrey Show on Wednesday.

title: Judge Allows CIT to Borrow Up to $500 Million
description: The CIT Group, a leading commercial lender, won bankruptcy court approval on Monday to borrow as much as $500 million to issue letters of credit that guarantee its debt.

title: They Died, and Lived to Tell All About It
description: Electric circuits will break your heart every time. Take my cellphone (please): it went out in the rain a few weeks ago and then lay neglected in a sopping wet coat pocket overnight. The next morning, it was dead.

title: U.K. Documents Show Friction With U.S. on Iraq
description: LONDON  Official Defense Ministry documents leaked to a British newspaper have revealed a climate of stark animosity among senior British officers toward American military commanders after the 2003 invasion of Iraq, when Britain, as the second-largest troop provider, was cast as the United States principal ally among about 30 nations constituting the occupation force.

title: G.M. Seeks Assistance From Europe for Opel
description: BERLIN  As executives of General Motors met Monday with European officials to ask for financial help in overhauling its struggling auto operations, Germany reopened a bitter public debate over state aid and job protections that has sharply divided its government.

title: Exploring a Low-Acid Diet for Bone Health
description: The science of osteoporosis and its resultant fractures has long been plagued by some vexing observations. Why, for example, are osteoporotic fractures relatively rare in Asian countries like Japan, where people live as long or longer than Americans and consume almost no calcium-rich dairy products? Why, in Western countries that consume the most dairy foods, are rates of osteoporotic fractures among the highest in the world? And why has no consistent link been found between the amount of calcium people consume and protection against osteoporosis?

title: More Speed-Round Thanksgiving Questions
description: You know who writes a mean recipe for pie crust, apparently off the top of his head? That guy Choire Sicha at The Awl. He writes dirty, and I write for The New York Times, so I cant link to it. But you can find it through the magic of search. As we get closer to the madness of Thanksgiving Day itself, when control freaks start freaking and lazy cousins open another beer on the couch, or stand just outside the front door so that the smoke from their Vantages doesnt drift harmlessly up into the slate-gray sky, but directly back into the living room where the baby crawls, its worth remembering: Be calm. Its just dinner. Every little thing gonna be all right.

title: Jane Brody Explains Low-Acid Eating
description: In this weeks Personal Health column, Jane Brody explores the science behind a low-acid diet, a diet laden with fruits and vegetables but relatively low in acid-producing protein and moderate in cereal grains.

title: Near Geneva, Particles Finally Come Together With a Bang
description: Call it First Bang.

title: Israels Gamble in a Prisoner Swap
description: Updated, Nov. 24, 12:20 p.m. | Ronen Bergman, an Israeli investigative journalist, and Steven Simon of the Council on Foreign Relations join the discussion.

title: Adam Lambert Defends American Music Awards Performance
description: One day after Adam Lambert gave audiences an eyeful on the American Music Awards, ABC, which broadcast the awards show on Sunday night, is getting an earful from its viewers.

title: Shifting Vaccine for Flu to Elderly
description: Federal health officials are trying to shift supplies of the seasonal flu vaccine away from chain pharmacies and supermarkets to nursing homes, hoping to counter a shortage that threatens to cause a wave of deaths this winter among the nations most vulnerable population.

title: Artery Disease in Some Very Old Patients
description: The Book of Exodus in the King James translation of the Bible describes a pharaoh who hardened his heart against the exodus of the Jews from ancient Egypt. But if a research letter published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association is correct, the pharaoh may have been suffering from hardened arteries.

title: Why Women Cant Let Sarah Palin Go
description: Back before the Oprah interview and the resignation as governor of Alaska, before Tina Feys impersonation and the announcement of Bristols pregnancy, way back to the day John McCain named his running mate, Lisa Copeland was a Sarah Palin fan.

title: The Women Left on Earth When Space Called Men
description: The 10 women striding into an Arizona resort for a reunion are a group guaranteed to turn heads. Handsome, sharp and sure of themselves, mostly in their 70s, they look as if they met in college or were the members of a particularly effective Junior League.

title: How the West Was Worn
description: A few months ago, the mens-wear designer Adam Kimmel found himself 150 miles off the coast of Mexico, underwater, with a group of great white sharks circling him. Kimmel was looking out from a protective cage, but the entertainer David Blaine, a friend, was swimming in the open, breathing only occasionally through someone elses regulator. To make things more interesting, Blaine was wearing a black tuxedo and red cape made by Kimmel, and was being filmed by the director Bob Talbot as a diver pushed him toward the toothy behemoths.

title: Bronfman Wins Lawsuit Over Warner Music
description: Score another court victory for Edgar Bronfman Jr., chairman of the Warner Music Group, in the $100 million lawsuit filed against him two years ago by Simon & Schusters former chief, Richard Snyder.

title: AIDS: Study in Rural Uganda Finds Benefits in Treating AIDS Patients at Home
description: Treating AIDS patients at home is just as effective as having them come into a clinic  and considerably cheaper, according to a new study being published in The Lancet this week.

title: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Nov. 23
description: Its uncommon to find so many visual parallels within a single show, but Mondays Pictures of the Day presentation abounds in them. Unfiltered emotion is obvious in the two very different faces seen in Slide 3 and Slide 5. Foliage fills the frames of Slide 10, Slide 11 and Slide 12; playing a somber, ceremonial role in two of the pictures and a delightfully recreational role in the third. Then, there are three distinctive compositions that are largely white-on-white: Slide 9, Slide 13 and Slide 14, which also seems to have a coals-to-Newcastle theme, despite being set in Hamburg.

title: A Survey Shows Pain of Recession for Artists
description: A major new survey of American artists and how they are weathering the economic downturn has found that slightly more than half experienced a drop in income from 2008 to 2009, a blow to an already struggling group, two thirds of whose members reported that they earned less than $40,000 last year.

title: Yale-Harvard Fourth-Down Analysis
description: As we saw with Bill Belichicks controversial decision against the Colts, going for it on fourth down is often a more sound decision, at least going by the math, than many people think.

title: A Nuclear Reactor Shows Its Age
description: Almost every plan for limiting carbon dioxide output includes keeping old nuclear plants running. But as those plants age, they turn up new problems.

title: Beer-Guzzling Bravado With a Tender Touch
description: Heres a thought: What if the artists on future split bills were required to collaborate? If they couldnt come up with something at least as interesting as what Ishmael Houston-Jones and Dan Safer managed on Thursday at Dance New Amsterdam, bye-bye split bill. Just think of all the odd-couple pairings the dance world would be spared.

title: Varying Concerns About Climate Files
description: In response to Raymond T. Pierrehumberts Your Dot commentary on the hacked climate files, another reader, Geoff Smith, has weighed in with the following thoughts and questions.

title: A White House Split-Screen: Jobs and Afghanistan
description: President Obama convened a meeting of his Cabinet on Monday afternoon to generate good ideas for a jobs summit next month, the latest sign that the White House is employing an all-hands-on-deck approach to the economy as the midterm election year approaches.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Aguirre: Wrath of God'
description: A. O. Scott reviews Werner Herzog's 1972 film about the brutality and indifference of nature.

title: Renewing a Classic, Adventure Intact
description: LUDWIGSHAFEN, Germany  Artifact, the first ballet that William Forsythe created after becoming director of the Frankfurt Ballet in 1984, is a masterpiece, a work that definitively shows this choreographer as the most influential practitioner of the art form since Balanchine.

title: Cuban Musical Pioneers Celebrate an Islands Soul
description: Theres no antiquarian dust on Septeto Nacional Ignacio Pieiro, the Cuban band that got started in 1927 and performed on Thursday night at S.O.B.s on its first American tour in 76 years. The septet was a pioneer of the Cuban son (a dance style; son means sound), which is a foundation of modern salsa in this hemisphere and of Congolese soukous in Africa. The Septeto, which has replaced all its musicians through the years  Pieiro died in 1969  still plays the Pieiro repertory. Its Cuban son, and its rumbas and boleros, are music of transparency, tensile strength and phantom drive.

title: Snake Eating a Right-Handed Snail
description: Researchers found that snakes with more teeth in their right mandibles compared to the left were more efficient in extracting right-handed snails from their shells.

title: In Snails and Snakes, Features to Delight Darwin
description: Charles Darwin seems to have had a boundless interest in the many forms life takes on earth. He could find something about any animal or plant that piqued his insatiable curiosity, and masses of such observations fueled his prodigious output of books and scientific papers.

title: Kansas Rep. Moore Plans to Retire
description: In his sixth term, Representative Dennis Moore, Democrat of Kansas, officially announced his retirement at the end of next year.

title: BlogTalk: Grading Obama, Abortion Flares
description: On a day when news reports are out about President Obamas public approval ratings falling below 50 percent in two polls, some bloggers are reacting to some strong critiques issued in the last couple of days about Mr. Obamas trip to Asia and his overall job performance.

title: Poll: Public Option Not Publics Priority
description: Several lawmakers are staking their support for a health care overhaul on whether or not it creates a government-run health insurance plan  the so-called public option  to compete with private insurers. But a new poll by the Kaiser Family Foundation suggests that even as the public supports a public option, they have other, higher priorities for the health legislation.

title: Music Awards Strong, but CBS Is Stronger
description: The American Music Awards drew its largest audience in seven years on Sunday as ABC attracted 14.2 million viewers, more than 2 million better than last year, according to Nielsens estimates. Despite the strong ratings, ABC did not lead the night over all as NBC finished in first place. Although final ratings for NBCs live Sunday Night Football broadcast were not available on Monday, preliminary overnight figures show that the game earned higher ratings than any other program on the night. CBS had more than 20 million tuning in at the start of prime time to the final minutes of the networks afternoon football coverage. Following it, CBSs 60 Minutes earned approximately 15.6 million viewers, while its Amazing Race (11.8 million), Three Rivers (9.2 million), and Cold Case (7.7 million) rounded out the rest of the schedule.

title: Jerusalem Wins Award
description: Jez Butterworths play Jerusalem, a three-hour-plus dark comedy, won two London Evening Standard Theater Awards, which were announced on Monday, Reuters reported. Jerusalem, which opened at the Royal Court Theater under Ian Ricksons direction, was named best play, and Mark Rylance, who portrayed a tax-evading stoner nicknamed Rooster, received the best actor award. The New York Times critic Ben Brantley  called Jerusalem a great sprawling brawl of a play, and praised Mr. Rylance, right, for his astonishing performance. Mr. Rylance won a Tony Award last year for his performance in the Broadway revival of Boeing-Boeing. Rachel Weisz was named best actress for her performance in the Donmar Warehouses revival of A Streetcar Named Desire. The award was named after the actress Natasha Richardson, who died in March, and was presented by Ms. Richardsons mother, the actress Vanessa Redgrave.

title: Artist and Architect to Make Synagogue Window
description: The Museum at Eldridge Street has commissioned the artist Kiki Smith and the architect Deborah Gans to create a new east window for its 1887 synagogue, right, a National Historic Landmark on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. We were interested to make a piece that integrated into the building but would not mimic the structure, Ms. Smith said in an interview. The synagogue reopened in 2007 after a 20-year restoration, but there were no available records of the original window. We decided not to try to recreate something when we did not know what that something really looked like, said Bonnie Dimun, executive director of the museum. Instead Ms. Smith and Ms. Gans will reimagine the window, due to be completed by spring. While the design has yet to be released, Ms. Smith said it would feature the Star of David at the center in a field of blue five-pointed stars.

title: Carnage Hits a Bump
description: Carnage indeed. The new replacement cast of the Broadway hit play God of Carnage was off to a slow start at the box office last week, the first performances without the all-star lineup led by James Gandolfini and Marcia Gay Harden, who won the Tony Award for best actress for the production (which itself won best play). This new incarnation of Carnage grossed $497,779 last week, compared with $1,107,302 the previous week. The audience attendance last week was only 63 percent of capacity. Still, last weeks gross was among the largest for a play on Broadway (and bigger than grosses for some musicals last week). But by comparison, the plays former cast had helped catapult Carnage into the million-dollar club of top-grossing Broadway shows. The new cast  Christine Lahti, Annie Potts, Jimmy Smits and Ken Stott  has not had the benefit of major new reviews, or anything like the rush of pre-opening media publicity that greeted the original cast. A spokesman for the production, Chris Boneau, said on Monday that the producers had expected the fall-off and noted that the new cast had higher grosses last week than the original Carnage cast had in its first full week of previews ($396,470) in March. He added that the producers had a very healthy advance in ticket sales and were more than pleased.

title: NPR News Anchor to Retire
description: The National Public Radio newscast anchor Carl Kasell, right, will retire from the job at the end of the year, NPR said Monday. But Mr. Kasell will continue to keep score for NPRs weekly quiz show Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! as that programs official judge. A familiar voice for millions of morning listeners, Mr. Kassell has read the news on Morning Edition for 30 years. After 30 years of waking up at 1:05 a.m. to prepare for the newscasts, NPR said in a memo to employees, Mr. Kasell has decided the time has come to sleep in. He will anchor a final newscast on Dec. 30.

title: Lawyer vs. Lawyer in Polanski Case
description: Concerned by the public statements of a French lawyer, Herv Temime, about Roman Polanskis intentions regarding his possible extradition from Switzerland, Mr. Polanskis legal team in the United States said Mr. Temime was not authorized to speak for Mr. Polanski. Mr. Temime, who has represented Mr. Polanski in other matters, told Le Figaro newspaper last week that Mr. Polanski would not return voluntarily to the United States, which he fled in 1978 before sentencing for having sex with a 13-year-old girl. But three American lawyers who represent Mr. Polanski  Chad Hummel, Bart Dalton and Douglas Dalton  responded with a statement disavowing any statements by lawyers in France who purport to speak for Mr. Polanski. They said that only they and a Swiss lawyer, Lorenz Erni, represent Mr. Polanski in the case against him and in the Swiss extradition proceeding. Any statements made in the press to the effect that Mr. Polanski will not accept lawful orders of the courts, including relating to extradition, are not true, the lawyers said in their statement. They are preparing for a hearing scheduled before a California appeals court in Los Angeles on Dec. 10.

title: New Musical Director for Oscars Show
description: If the Academy Awards show in March turns out to be teeming with original musical numbers or sexual puns, now youll know whom to thank or vilify. On Monday the producers of the Oscars telecast said that Marc Shaiman, the composer and lyricist, would be the shows musical director. Mr. Shaiman, whose credits include the musical versions of Hairspray and Catch Me if You Can, is an Oscars veteran. He was the musical director of the show in 2004 and wrote for the musical medleys performed by the host Billy Crystal. In a phone interview on Monday, Mr. Shaiman said his job would entail being in all the rooms where anything having to do with the show is being discussed, to figure out how can music and lyrics play a part in it. He added that his longtime writing partner, Scott Wittman, would also be involved in composing original numbers and song parodies. Theres just so much you can do in advance, Mr. Shaiman said. But I am trying to think of what words rhyme with Precious.

title: Rising Bill in Unwinding of Madoffs Assets
description: The cost of unwinding Bernard L. Madoffs estate for the benefit of his victims is climbing, with a total of almost $25 million in new fee requests filed on Monday with the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan.

title: Food, Kin and Tension at Thanksgiving
description: For Thanksgiving dinner, what side dish would you prefer to accompany your turkey  a serving of well-marinated conflict over how much or how little you eat, or some nice, fresh criticism of your cooking skills?

title: Against Camel Case
description: As you probably know, the California-based company Apple makes a portable communication device  a device that an acquaintance of mine whose first language is not English distinguishes as a self phone. Though proper nouns conventionally begin with a capital letter, Apple spells the devices trademark with an initial lowercase i, followed by an uppercase P. Thus styled, the word has a hump in the middle. I could print it here to show you, but I refuse to allow my prose to be so disfigured.

title: Losses Are Mounting for Oklahoma
description: Oklahoma is sinking towards a new low during the Bob Stoops era.

title: Richard Branson to Open New Jersey Culinary Resort
description: Sir Richard Branson, the travel and entertainment mogul, is opening a resort in New Jersey next week with a cooking and wine school and a farm.

title: Turkey, With Family Drama on the Side
description: As I explore in todays Well column, many families gathering around the country this week for Thanksgiving dinner are bracing for the intense emotions of the holiday meal. Theres the mother who prepares a delicious spread, only to criticize her overweight daughter for eating it, a sister-in-law who refuses to serve seconds and a father on a campaign against all things chocolate.

title: Artist Arrested for 42nd Time, This Time on the High Line
description: A self-promotional vendor who has successfully used the First Amendment to challenge New York City restrictions on artists rights to sell was arrested on Saturday by parks police for hawking his wares on the High Line.

title: Morgan Stanley Hires Former Merrill Executive
description: Morgan Stanley has hired a former Merrill Lynch executive, David Moffitt, to prepare the firms capital markets division for a resurgence in securitized debt sales, according to an internal memo obtained by Bloomberg News.

title: Depressed Woman Appears Happy on Facebook, Trouble Ensues
description: A 29-year-old Canadian woman who says shes too depressed to do her job claims that her employers insurance company stopped paying her disability benefits because she posted some photographs of herself on Facebook in which she appeared to be happy.

title: Matching Architecture to the Art in a New Miami Museum
description: Why is it so hard to design a great contemporary-art museum?

title: On the Question of Pies
description: Pies? Check out this video made of me here at my desk at The Times, preparing to answer your questions about making Thanksgiving desserts.

title: Travels in Cyberspace: The Monday Report
description: After her frenetic appearance at the American Music Awards last night  which featured a vocally shaky performance of the song Louboutins, a decidedly unflattering outfit and hairdo, and an awkward, mid-song tumble to the stage floor (landing smack on her celebrated derriere)  Jennifer Lopez probably needs a vacation.

title: In Love Affair With Credit, Its Business as Usual
description: Creating compelling television out of jacked-up interest rates, compounded penalty fees and software code rigged to rip off credit card customers is no mean feat. The Card Game, a new production in the long-running Frontline documentary series on PBS, does a fine job of it.

title: Critics Picks Video: Aguirre: The Wrath of God
description: This week, A. O. Scott gives thanks for the filmmaker Werner Herzog and his 1972 film Aguirre, the Wrath of God, which looks at the 17th Century conquests of Spanish conquistadors in Peru. It stars Mr. Herzogs frequent collaborator Klaus Kinski. According to Mr. Scott, the film paints an unsparing picture of colonial greed and the brutal encounter between human ambition and the wildness of nature.

title: Bask Country
description: Theyd been sleeping on Pirates Bay beach for three days. About a dozen of them  white guys with dreadlocks, their bikinied girlfriends and a golden retriever. They had come from Tobagos busy south end, where they lived, to this quiet corner of the island for a long weekend of sleeping under the stars. A few hammocks were strung up between the mangroves, and bottles of Beefeater, cigarettes, food and supplies littered a folding table. They said they were originally from Trinidad, Tobagos sister island 22 miles away. A couple of them tended to the campfire while a group played Frisbee fetch with the dog. After a time, a few more friends showed up on a boat idling out in the pale green Caribbean water. Hey! one of them yelled from the deck. He held up a pair of flippers and a snorkel mask to the applause of the crowd onshore.

title: Museum Is Displaying Treasures of the Other Evolution Pioneer
description: One day in spring 1979, Robert E. Heggestad walked into a small antique shop in Arlington, Va. Mr. Heggestad, a young lawyer from Iowa, was looking for Chinese carpets. The selection of rugs in the small back room was disappointing, and he was about to leave when he noticed a handsome rosewood cabinet behind the cash register.

title: From Print to Film: Reflections on the Transition
description: Four Season Lodge  Trailer from First Run Features on Vimeo.

title: Regulators Push Safety Standards for A.T.V.s
description: For parents wanting to provide their children some good, clean off-roading fun, the Fushin, a smaller-than-normal all-terrain vehicle, seemed just the thing.

title: Book Calls Jewish People an Invention
description: Despite the fragmented and incomplete historical record, experts pretty much agree that some popular beliefs about Jewish history simply dont hold up: there was no sudden expulsion of all Jews from Jerusalem in A.D. 70, for instance. Whats more, modern Jews owe their ancestry as much to converts from the first millennium and early Middle Ages as to the Jews of antiquity.

title: Price War Brews Between Amazon and Wal-Mart
description: Ali had Frazier. Coke has Pepsi. The Yankees have the Red Sox.

title: Fact, Myth, History, Memory: New Book About Jews Stirs Old Debate
description: The book The Invention of the Jewish People, which spent months on the best-seller list in Israel, is now available in English. In an article in The New York Times on Tuesday Patricia Cohen writes:

title: Plan Is Revived to Repay Some Lehman Creditors
description: The administrator for Lehman Brothers said on Monday that it planned to seek support to remove claims against the investment bank from British courts and distribute assets directly to creditors by the first quarter of next year, provided enough of Lehmans hedge fund creditors go along with the plan.

title: Mauer Near-Unanimous Pick as American League M.V.P.
description: Joe Mauer spent last weekend at his log cabin north of the Twin Cities in Minnesota. He woke up Monday at his home in St. Paul and spent the afternoon at the Metrodome in Minneapolis, where his teammate Justin Morneau joined him to celebrate Mauers near-unanimous selection as the American League most valuable player.

title: Three Clergymen, Three Faiths, One Friendship
description: NASHVILLE  It sounds like the start of a joke: a rabbi, a minister and a Muslim sheik walk into a restaurant.

title: The Train to the Plane
description: A television commercial from the M.T.A. praised the safety and frugality of using its airport train service.

title: Enough to Make Your Hair Curl
description: Q. My son, who had pin-straight hair at birth, developed very curly hair at puberty. Is this because the hair follicles change shape, perhaps influenced by hormone shifts?

title: Fun With Nicknames for Ancient Crocodiles
description: Paul C. Sereno, a paleontologist at the University of Chicago, has fun naming the fossil crocodiles he has dug up from the Sahara.

title: A New Comment System for Opinionator
description: As part of the new Opinionator, weve made changes to the comment section intended to create richer and easier-to-navigate conversations among readers. Heres what you need to know.

title: By Happy Accident, Chemists Produce a New Blue
description: Blue is sometimes not an easy color to make.

title: U.S. Says Lockheed Must Pay Part of F-35 Cost Overruns
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagons top acquisition official said on Monday that Lockheed Martin, the prime contractor for the new F-35 fighter jet, would have to cover part of the increased costs of the huge program.

title: Is a Warranty on Laptops Warranted?
description: A study by SquareTrade, an online vendor of extended warranties, says 20.4 percent of laptops fail over three years. The study found evidence that netbooks fail at a higher rate, 5.4 percent in the first year of use compared with 4.2 percent for a premium-level laptop. But netbooks havent been around long enough to provide solid three-year data.

title: How Hummingbirds Get Their Nectar With Tiny Straws
description: It is harder to suck liquid through a thin straw than a wider one because of viscosity.

title: In Awards Season, Mets Likely to Be Shut Out Again
description: By any measure, 2009 was a disaster for the Mets. The year is not over yet, so there is still time for it to get worse, as the awards season has proven. The Mets have been reminded of their futility every time a National League honor has been announced. So far, they have been shut out in voting by the Baseball Writers Association of America for rookie of the year (maybe in 2011, Josh Thole), manager of the year (keep trying, Jerry) and Cy Young Award (uhh ).

title: Makeshift Home for Many
description: Fifty Afghans, from six families, share a damaged warehouse built in the 1980s in what has become a small, poor village.

title: The Biology Behind the Milk of Human Kindness
description: As the festival of mandatory gratitude looms into view, allow me to offer a few suggestions on what, exactly, you should be thankful for.

title: Data Show a Decline for Tigers in Russia
description: MOSCOW  Amid the torrent of bad environmental news in recent years, the story of Amur tigers in Russia offered a flicker of optimism. Nearly extinct half a century ago, the tigers rebounded when the government imposed protections, and their numbers remained more or less stable for much of the last decade.

title: Google Adds Kid-Safe Filters to Search
description: Parents, teachers and librarians now have a new reason to like Google.

title: Obama Issues Sharp Rebuke of Mugabe
description: WASHINGTON  In honoring Zimbabwes tenacious women protesters at the White House on Monday, President Obama gave his sharpest critique yet of President Robert Mugabe, the octogenarian who has ruled the southern African country with repressive zeal since 1980. Mr. Obama bluntly referred to him as a dictator.

title: For the Hotel Industry, Recovery is a Long Way Off
description: IN these uncertain economic times, I am wary when I hear someone proclaiming, We have finally bottomed out. After all, who knows how long we may stay on the bottom?

title: Air-Traffic Constants (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Right Stuff (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire, Ice or Pollution? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Boon at Any Age (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Emotions of Hersheys Bid
description: Hershey is smaller and brings less to the table than Kraft Foods in a potential takeover battle for Cadbury. But Hershey may have one distinct advantage over Kraft: a potentially irrational owner.

title: Toy State Spot
description: A new ad campaign for Toy State, a Chinese toy company.

title: The Auditor Disagrees With Overstock.com
description: When auditors and clients part ways, there is usually a dance in which they exchange letters that explain their actions, but do not question the veracity of the other sides version.

title: U.S.T.A. Head Was Paid More Than $9 Million in 2008
description: Arlen Kantarian was paid more than $9 million by the United States Tennis Association in his last year as its chief executive of professional tennis, according to tax documents filed by the organization and confirmed by the U.S.T.A.

title: Russia: 8 Die in Blast at Weapons Depot
description: An explosion at a navy weapons depot killed at least eight soldiers and injured several others on Monday, less than two weeks after a similar blast at the same depot killed two and forced the evacuation of thousands. The explosion in the Ulyanovsk region in central Russia occurred while soldiers were disposing of unexploded munitions left over from the first explosion on Nov. 13, a Defense Ministry spokesman said on Russian television.

title: Iran Sentences Journalist to Jail Time
description: Iran handed down a five-year jail term to Ahmad Zeidabadi, a prominent journalist and former student leader, an opposition Web site reported Monday, as part of a series of jail sentences the government has issued against activists and former officials in the past month.

title: Fees in Madoff Case Rise Nearly $25 Million
description: The cost of unwinding Bernard L. Madoffs estate for the benefit of his victims is climbing, with a total of almost $25 million in new fee requests filed on Monday with the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan, The New York Timess Diana B. Henriques reports.

title: Holiday on Thursday Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: Runaway Spent 11 Days in the Subways
