description: Day after day, night after night, Francisco Hernandez Jr. rode the subway. He had a MetroCard, $10 in his pocket and a book bag on his lap. As the human tide flowed and ebbed around him, he sat impassively, a gangly 13-year-old boy in glasses and a red hoodie, speaking to no one.

title: Nimble on His Feet, and Doing What He Loves
description: Ah, ha, ha, ha, stayin alive, stayin alive, ah, ha, ha, ha, stayin alive. It is a Tuesday morning at the Educational Alliance, a 120-year-old social service agency at 197 East Broadway, on the Lower East Side, and seven women of various ages are line dancing to the haunting anthem of Saturday Night Fever. Leading the weekly classes since 2007, and choreographing New York City Housing Authority shows since 2002, is their fast-stepping dance instructor, the trim and pony-tailed, Fu Manchu-mustachioed, gold-earringed and bracelet-bangled Bernard Dove, 69, a fixture  no, a blur  at New Yorks dance palaces since pre-disco days. He is divorced with grown children, none of them dancers.

title: More on That 98 Percent Coverage Claim
description: The Prescriptions blog has noted on several occasions that the Great Health Care Debate of 2009, on many levels, is a numbers game. And that makes it all the more crucial to get the numbers right.

title: U.S. Moves to Confiscate a Fortune in Ponzi Case
description: MIAMI  Scott Rothstein, the Fort Lauderdale lawyer accused of a $1 billion Ponzi scheme, certainly spread the money around. On Monday, federal authorities filed court documents seeking to seize his 87-foot yacht, more than a dozen properties and 20 luxury cars, including a 2009 Bugatti Veyron that sells for $1.5 million.

title: Judge Sees Vindication for a Man Jailed in Rape
description: A judge in Manhattan indicated on Monday that he would throw out the conviction and dismiss the indictment of a Bronx man who spent four years in prison for rape before his accuser admitted that her story had been a lie.

title: Swine Flu Vaccinations Rise While Infections Remain Low
description: More than 11,000 people received swine flu vaccines at free clinics last weekend, city officials said, while overall infection rates remained relatively low.

title: Start Date Is Critical in Ponzi Plan
description: Bernard L. Madoffs enormous Ponzi scheme ended on Dec. 11, 2008, when he was arrested at his Manhattan penthouse. But for some early victims, the date his crime started could matter much more than when it stopped.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 914 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans over the past week:

title: Whether Winning or Losing, Broncos Are Always Brash
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  During the Giants recent four-game losing streak, Coach Tom Coughlin did not exchange trash talk with opposing teams. His players were not seen arguing among themselves on the bench.

title: Charges Detail Road to Terror for 20 in U.S.
description: Federal officials on Monday unsealed terrorism-related charges against men they say were key actors in a recruitment effort that led roughly 20 young Americans to join a violent insurgent group in Somalia with ties to Al Qaeda.

title: Gun-Sales Ring in Brooklyn Broken Up, Officials Say
description: Against a backdrop of recent shootings of bystanders, including a 13-year-old boy from Queens and a 15-year-old girl from the Bronx, city officials and members of a civil rights group took action against gun violence on Monday, albeit in different ways and at different events.

title: N.F.L. Quick Hits, Week 11: Cowboys Dont Lose
description: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

title: In Closing Arguments, Bruno as Bully or Honest Worker
description: ALBANY  Joseph L. Bruno: Tiny the Bully, or just Uncle Joe?

title: News Corp. Weighs an Exclusive Alliance With Bing
description: This is not how business has been done on the World Wide Web.

title: Moving the Battlefield to the Page
description: He was a civilian again, four months back from Iraq. Yet he still wore his dog tags. The metal clinked against his chest, announcing that the Army remained part of him.

title: Foundation Tied to Iran Has Donated to Columbia
description: Several months before the Iranian president made a controversial appearance at Columbia University in 2007, the Alavi Foundation  a nonprofit organization that had long supported educational programs related to Islamic and Iranian culture at schools and universities  donated $100,000 to Columbia.

title: Signs of Hope
description: Detroit

title: Iran Expanding Effort to Stifle the Opposition
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  After last summers disputed presidential election, Irans government relied largely on brute force  beatings, arrests and show trials  to stifle the countrys embattled opposition movement.

title: Right and Left Join Forces on Criminal Justice
description: WASHINGTON  In the next several months, the Supreme Court will decide at least a half-dozen cases about the rights of people accused of crimes involving drugs, sex and corruption. Civil liberties groups and associations of defense lawyers have lined up on the side of the accused.

title: Pressure Builds Over Obamas Afghanistan Plan
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama nears a decision on a troop increase for the war in Afghanistan, he is facing increasingly vocal criticism from senior Congressional Democrats over the wars cost, the size of the United States troop commitment and the reliability of Americas allies.

title: Shows Online, Brought to You by ...
description: Jennie Garth of Beverly Hills 90210 fame has a new series. But dont look for it on a broadcast network or a cable channel.

title: Some Democrats Back Off Bid to Legalize Gay Marriage in New Jersey
description: It was not on the ballot, nor was it a top-tier issue in the New Jersey governors race this fall, but the push to legalize same-sex marriage in the state could become a casualty of the election results.

title: Albanys Ethics on Trial
description: Former State Senator Joseph Bruno, who dominated Albany politics for more than a dozen years, is fighting federal charges that he deprived citizens of the intangible right of honest services. Mr. Bruno is arguing that he did nothing unusual and broke no laws during those years when he controlled or influenced billions of dollars in state spending  and made millions on the side as a consultant for private companies.

title: Q. & A. With Kobe Bryant
description: The Los Angeles Lakers forward Kobe Bryant talked to Jonathan Abrams of The Times. Here is a transcript of the interview.

title: Another Loss for Pfizer in Drug Suits
description: Pfizer has been ordered to pay a total of $103 million in punitive damages to two women who were found to have breast cancer after they used hormonal drugs, state court officials in Philadelphia said Monday.

title: Beware the Result of Outrage
description: The biggest news story of last week?

title: A Warehouse Holds Families New Memories in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In his inaugural address last week, President Hamid Karzai proudly touted his countrys achievements in creating an Afghanistan with a rehabilitated economic infrastructure and budding free-market economy.

title: 2.1 Million Cribs Are Recalled in U.S. and Canada
description: Citing cases of infants being trapped and suffocated, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced a voluntary recall of more than 2.1 million Stork Craft drop-side cribs on Monday, the largest recall ever of cribs.

title: Ochoa Wins Player of Year in Battle That Lasted Until the Final Hole
description: RICHMOND, Tex.  Two of the more low-key players on the L.P.G.A. Tour turned into drama queens Monday, taking their battle for player of the year honors right down to the last hole of the final tournament on the 2009 schedule.

title: Conservatives Make a List to Measure Candidates Commitment
description: WASHINGTON  A group of conservative Republican leaders is proposing a solution to the internecine warfare over what the party should stand for: a 10-point checklist gauging proper adherence to core principles like opposing government financing for abortion and, more generally, President Obamas socialist agenda.

title: Lottery Numbers
At 99, Bronx Woman Still Hears Lifes Joyful Noises
description: Sarah Gellerts favorite word is wonderful. Her parents and friends growing up in the Bronx were wonderful. Her two husbands were wonderful. Her friends from the company where she worked for more than four decades were wonderful.

title: Senates Women Could Sway Health Bill
description: When Senate Democratic leaders first went behind closed doors to complete the health care legislation, the only women in the room were either committee staff members or officials from the White House. The senators there  Harry Reid of Nevada, Max Baucus of Montana and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut  reflected the Senates predominant history as an old-boys club.

title: Fine-Tuned With Age, Bryants Game Keeps Evolving
description: LOS ANGELES  En route to wedging himself between Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Jerry West among the Los Angeles Lakers leading scorers, Kobe Bryant connected with layups, free throws, jumpers, turnaround fadeaways and post-ups.

title: Instead of Firing Coach, Northeastern Ends the Program
description: Boston

title: Ex-Referee Donaghys Accomplice Says They Bet on Many Games
description: Tim Donaghy, the disgraced former N.B.A. referee, bet on far more games than previously disclosed and picked winners at a staggering 79 percent clip, according to a professional gambler who conspired with Donaghy.

title: A Teacher and His Students, Joined by a Hard Road to the Kitchen
description: Before his students learn to saut, braise and stir-fry, Keith Hill, a longtime cooking instructor, teaches them the basics of kitchen safety. Its important in any kitchen, but perhaps more so for an instructor who witnessed one student go after another with an eight-inch cooking knife.

title: And the Winner: No Problem
description: Im as mad as hell, and Im not going to take this anymore! That famous declaration by Howard Beale in the movie Network is the implicit and sometimes explicit message of the many hundreds of responses to last weeks column on phrases and announcements that make your heart sink and make you want to commit mayhem.

title: The End Comes for Northeastern
description: Northeastern announced on Monday that it was ending its football program after 74 seasons, saying that it could not spend the money going forward that the team would need to be successful. Dan Shaughnessy, a columnist for The Boston Globe, says the move is reminiscent of Boston Universitys decision in 1997 to disband its football team.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed essay on Monday, about General Motors, misspelled the authors name in the byline and accompanying biography. The author is Edward Niedermeyer, not Niedermayer.

title: Ryan Takes Lead Role in Guiding Sanchez
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Now that the Jets playoff hopes have all but vanished, the development of the rookie quarterback Mark Sanchez takes on paramount importance over the final six games.

title: Paparazzi Help Convict Police Chief of Break-In
description: ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio  By his own admission, what the police chief of Martins Ferry, Ohio, did in May was at the very least stupid. On Monday, a jury concluded that it was also illegal.

title: Public Database Is Urged to Monitor Drug Safety
description: What could be done to prevent another Vioxx? This pain medication for arthritis became a blockbuster after its introduction in 1999, only to be taken off the market in 2004 when a study linked the drug to an increased risk of heart attack and strokes.

title: The Values Question
description: Its easy to get lost in the weeds when talking about health care reform. But, like all great public issues, the health care debate is fundamentally a debate about values. Its a debate about what kind of country we want America to be.

title: Everything Considered
description: If youre having problems downloading the current crossword from Premium Puzzles, this page on XWord Info always lists the latest as soon as they are published.

title: Bloggingheads: Politics as Entertainment
description: Conor Friedersdorf, left, of True/Slant and Peter Suderman of Reason debate whether we should view American politics as entertainment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about ballooning debt payments for the federal government misspelled, in some copies, the surname of an economist who noted that the bill for debt service would be even higher were it not for current low interest rates. He is Alan Levenson, not Levinson. And a chart with the continuation of the article misstated, in some editions, the size of debt payments due within a year that are currently paying no more than 1 percent in interest. It is $1.9 trillion, not $2.5 trillion.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of American military deaths on Saturday misstated the number of confirmed dead in the war in Afghanistan as of then. It was 910, not 909. An updated list appears on Page A12 today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a report that the Washington school chancellor intervened on behalf of her fianc, now the mayor of Sacramento, who was under investigation by a government watchdog, referred incompletely to a complaint filed against that watchdog, Gerald Walpin, the inspector general of AmeriCorps. Although the acting United States attorney for Sacramento sent a complaint last April to a federal panel, saying that Mr. Walpin had withheld information when conducting his investigation, the panel found in October that there was no merit to the complaint.

title: Corrections
description: A Political Memo article on Friday about discussions among Republican governors on how the party could win elections in 2010 misstated the number of terrorism suspects facing trial in federal court in New York. The Justice Department has decided to place five  not four  suspects on trial, a decision that has been attacked by many Republicans.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about the National Book Award ceremonies, where the novelist Dave Eggers received an award for outstanding service to the American literary community, misstated his role in the founding of the independent publishing house McSweeneys. He was the sole founder, not a co-founder.

title: Yanks Film Is Shown; No Word Yet on Sequel
description: The two men stood next to the World Series trophy with a red carpet under their feet. As several flashes popped and photographers shouted their names, both men squinted. They wore jeans and sport coats and they did not smile.

title: Down 2-0, Rangers Respond to Timeout
description: Almost midway into the first period Monday night, it looked like another dismal night for the Rangers. They trailed Columbus, 2-0, and seemed headed to their fifth defeat in six games.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 13 about Atavia Wilson of the Bronx, a part-time health care aide who received rent assistance through The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, referred imprecisely to the change in benefits that will take place once she returns to full-time work, and referred incorrectly to her current allotment of food stamps. She will no longer be eligible for Medicaid and unemployment benefits once her work hours increase, but she will in fact still qualify for food stamps. And she now gets $100 in food stamps per month, not per week.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies on Nov. 14 with an article about Penns football program in the years after a popular player killed himself misidentified the teams opponent. The photograph showed the player, Kyle Ambrogi, being congratulated after scoring in a game against Villanova, not against Bucknell. (Ambrogi killed himself on Oct. 10, 2005, two days after a game against Bucknell.)

title: A Moveable Fast
description: ITS Thanksgiving  time to put our feedbags on, my family likes to say as we elbow for room next to the Pilgrim and Puritan ghosts the holiday summons to our table. Our colonial forebears probably would not disapprove of our having second and third helpings of sweet potatoes and stuffing, or even rushing off to watch football after the meal  the Pilgrims themselves played lots of games at that first Thanksgiving in 1621. But I imagine they would find fault with our binge for another reason: it is not accompanied by a fast.

title: Corrections
description: The Critics Choice column on Monday about new CDs misstated the title of Adam Lamberts album. It is For Your Entertainment, not For Your Consideration. The column, which included a review of Rihannas album Rated R, also misstated the timing of her beating by her former boyfriend, Chris Brown. It was after a pre-Grammy Awards party, not a post-Grammy party.

title: Turkey and the Kurds
description: In a show of courage and good sense, Turkeys government has announced a plan to grant long-denied rights to its Kurdish minority, and, it is hoped, finally end an insurgency that has cost more than 40,000 lives.

title: No No More Wilderness
description: In 2003, Gale Norton, then the secretary of the interior, and Michael Leavitt, then the governor of Utah, struck a deal that removed federal protections from about 2.6 million acres of public land in Utah that the Clinton administration had designated as potential wilderness. At the same time, Ms. Norton disavowed her departments longstanding authority to identify, study and recommend new areas for wilderness protection.

title: Today IHOP, Tomorrow the World
description: Senator Charles Schumer of New York  undefeated in 35 years of electoral contests  is well known for championing his New York City constituents, from cut-rate ferry fares for Staten Island residents to his care and coddling of Wall Street. But hes not all about downstate. Upstate, theres the signature Schumer obsession with maple syrup  his resolve to make New York nothing less than the Saudi Arabia of syrup.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Friday about The Twilight Saga: New Moon, in which the actor Michael Sheen appears, misidentified the creature he has played in other films. It was a werewolf, not a vampire.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Showcase: Kinship, Close Up
description: It would seem to be a long way from Hollywood and Washington to the home of the Hadza tribe in northern Tanzania. But for the portrait photographer Martin Schoeller, they are closer than you might think.

title: Missionaries From Congo Confirm Atrocities
description: Wednesday, Nov. 24, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Economy Is Forcing Young Adults Back Home in Big Numbers, Survey Finds
description: For more young adults, there is no place like home for the holidays, and for the rest of the year, too. Ten percent of adults younger than 35 told the Pew Research Center that they had moved back in with their parents because of the recession.

title: Slow Month for Retailers, but Strong Finish Is Seen
description: A few weeks into the holiday shopping season, consumers are still not reaching for their wallets.

title: Word of the Day | inductive
description: inductive  \in-dk-tiv\  adjective

title: Songs a Plenti
description: Julian Plenti is the alter-ego solo project of Paul Banks, the frontman of the dapper downtown band Interpol. But Julian Plenti is a darker, brasher and more sinister, writes Amanda PetrusichHe bears more resemblance  vocally, at least  to a heavy-metal frontman than to a tailored-suit-wearing art star. Otherwise, expect some of the post-punk sounds and adoring girls. Tonight at the Bowery Ballroom with Im In You.

title: Double Dare
description: Wonder Woman may flaunt her own jewelry, but she didnt do her own stunts. The documentary Double Dare traces the lives of a pair of stuntwomen, Jeannie Epper, 64 and still kickin, who filled in for Lynda Carter, and her colleague Zoe Bell, who landed Xena, Warrior Princess at just 19. This preternaturally cheerful daredevil crashes through a plate-glass window like some Tinker Bell turned Ninja assassin, Manohla Dargis wrote. And youll see it all in the film, a story about women who like to roll cars, throw punches and jump from gaspingly tall heights, while battling the Hollywoods greatest opponents: sexism, agism and thin-ism. It screens tonight only at the IFC Center.

title: Sexual Healing
Charis Wilson, Model and Muse, Dies at 95
description: Charis Wilson, who was lover, muse, model, amanuensis and wife of the photographer Edward Weston and the subject of many of his best-known nude portraits, died on Friday in Santa Cruz, Calif. She was 95.

title: Icahn Outbids Penn for Fontainebleau Las Vegas
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn has offered $156.5 million to acquire the partially built Fontainebleau Las Vegas resort, which has been stalled in bankruptcy court since June, according to the resorts chief operating officer.

title: News Quiz | November 24, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Outshot by 61-21, Isles Win in OT as Roloson Stops 58
description: Ten games on Monday night, but one game stands head and shoulders above the rest, because of a veteran goalie who stood on his ear. Home teams listed first:

title: Clemson Gets Money for Study of Wind Energy
description: Clemson University is getting nearly $100 million in federal stimulus money to study wind energy.

title: Toll Rises to 46 in Philippine Election Unrest
description: MANILA  The death toll in Mondays election violence nearly doubled to 46 on Tuesday, the Philippine authorities said, as the government declared a state of emergency in two southern provinces in an effort to head off further bloodshed.

title: Fed Said to Ask Banks for TARP Repayment Plans
description: The Federal Reserve asked nine of the banks that were part of this years stress tests to submit plans for repaying the governments capital injections, a person familiar with the situation told Bloomberg News.

title: Google Buys Display-Ad Startup, Escalating Competition with Yahoo
description: Google, the leader in Web search, said it is buying the Silicon Valley display advertising technology startup Teracent, a move that expands its competition with display leader Yahoo, Reuters reported.

title: Breaking Da Vincis Code
description: WHO was the the artist, inventor and scientist for whom the term Renaissance man seems custom made?

title: Beware the Result of Outrage
description: A 300-page bill to reform the financial industry is making its way around the House of Representatives, its amendments intended to help quiet some of the outrage over the bailout, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: LinkedIn Aims to Show Up in More Places Online
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: After Chegg, BookRenter Pockets $6 Million
description: Less than a week after Chegg.com, the textbook rental site, said it had landed a hefty $57 million in financing, the rival BookRenter announced that it had also snagged new funding, albeit a more modest sum.

title: KDIC Said to Offer $531 Million in  Woori Shares
description: The Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation was to offer as much as 614 billion won ($531 million) in Woori shares in a block transaction on Tuesday, according to an e-mail message to investors that was obtained by Bloomberg News.

title: Corel Says Takeover Needed to Prevent Collapse
description: Corel , the maker of WordPerfect and other software, on Monday justified an offer to take the company private, saying that complete ownership is necessary to inject capital quickly and avert a default on its loans, The Associated Press reported.

title: 2 Executed in China for Selling Tainted Milk
description: BEIJING  China executed two milk producers on Tuesday for selling more than three million pounds of contaminated milk products in connection with a food-safety scandal that killed six infants, shocking the country last year.

title: Fela!
description: Photos from the Broadway musical about the Nigerian musician Fela Anikulapo-Kuti.

title: Bizo, the B2B Platform, Lands $6 Million
description: Bizo, the business-to-business marketing platform, has nabbed $6 million in a round of funding, PaidContent reported.

title: Do You Know Someone Who Texts While Driving?
description: The Driven to Distraction series looks at the dangers of driving while using electronic devices. Do you know people who text or do other dangerous things while driving? What do you think would change their behavior?

title: Newmont Sells Additional Stake in Indonesia Mine
description: Newmont Mining has agreed to sell a 14 percent stake in an Indonesian gold mine for $494 million, ending a years-long dispute with the Indonesian government over how the mining company should sell shares as required under its contract to operate in the country, The Associated Press reported.

title: Informa Talks Give Springer Owners Hope
description: Informa, the British media company, said it was in talks to buy Springer Science and Business Media, reigniting hope among Springers private-equity owners that they might finally offload the debt-ridden business.

title: Obama Concept Stocks
description: Green stocks that traded well in China in the run up to Barack Obamas visit, because they chime with the Presidents attitude to the environment.

title: J.C. Flowers Appoints 2 to Lead in Europe and Asia
description: J.C. Flowers & Company is adding big names to its team in Europe and Asia.

title: The Emotions of Hersheys Bid
description: Hershey is smaller and brings less to the table than Kraft Foods in a potential takeover battle for Cadbury. But, Breakingviews.com argues, Hershey may have one distinct advantage over Kraft: a potentially irrational owner.

title: Wall Street Ends 3-Day Losing Streak
description: Wall Street held on to steep gains on Monday, channeling momentum from rallies in Europe and Asia and a renewed rush for gold.

title: Start Date of Ponzi Scheme Is Critical to Claims
description: Bernard L. Madoffs enormous Ponzi scheme ended on Dec. 11, 2008, when he was arrested at his Manhattan penthouse. But for some early victims, the date his crime started could matter much more than when it stopped, The New York Timess Diana B. Henriques writes.

title: Inside Out | Sweet Dreams
description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

title: Ciena Wins Nortel Unit
description: Ciena agreed to buy the optical networking and ethernet equipment businesses of the bankrupt Canadian company Nortel Networks for $769 million after trumping a bid from Nokia Siemens Networks.

title: Is John Paulson a Grump? Did It Make Him Billions?
description: Did the hedge fund manager John Paulsons metamorphosis from a fairly sociable individual into a grump help him transform his career from relatively lackluster to very successful?

title: Freddie Mac Says Loss at Home Lender May Grow
description: Freddie Mac, the American mortgage finance giant, said on Monday that it was seeking $595 million in loan payments and other funds hung up after the bankruptcy of the lender Taylor, Bean & Whitaker Mortgage Corporation, Reuters reported.

title: Hewlett-Packard Triples Stock Buyback Plan
description: Hewlett-Packard tripled the size of its share repurchase program to $12 billion as China sales and better profit margins on its services boosted quarterly earnings.

title: Lloyds Prices Worlds Largest Cash Call
description: Update | 8:55 a.m.  The New York Timess Julia Werdigier provides more details of the Lloyds rights offering.

title: Panel Asks How Britain Got Involved in Iraq War
description: LONDON  A long-awaited inquiry into Britains role in the Iraq war began Tuesday and immediately homed in on the question that seems set to dominate its work: whether the former prime minister, Tony Blair, and his government were drawn into the conflict  over the objections of Britains defense, intelligence and foreign policy establishments  by an eagerness to please the United States.

title: The Peseta Returns for One Menu Only
description: A turkey dinner might be just the thing for a pilgrim celebration, but if you happen to be in Madrid this Thanksgiving why not dine like a queen on stuffed partridge instead? The Westin Palace Hotel (Plaza de las Cortes 7; 34-91-360-8000; www.westinpalacemadrid.com) is offering a special celebratory menu in honor of the 200th anniversary of the peseta, which was first minted in 1809, only to be replaced by the euro in 2002. The seven-course menu, which is available through Dec. 19, is based on a banquet offered in 1866 by Queen Isabel II, the Spanish monarch whose paid mercenaries became known as peseteros.

title: No-Huddle Makes the Browns Go
description: How does a team as offensively challenged as the Browns (five offensive touchdowns in their first nine games) end up playing in one of the highest-scoring games of the season?

title: Revenge of an Edsel
description: Todays idea: The much-maligned Pontiac Aztek  practically the Edsel of our day  could get the last laugh as prototype for the crossover vehicle of the future, an article says.

title: Netanyahu Plays Down Talk of a Prisoner Exchange
description: JERUSALEM  Seeking to lower expectations of an imminent deal with the Islamic group Hamas to exchange a captured Israeli soldier for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Tuesday that no agreement had yet been reached.

title: PPR to Unload European Retail, Report Says
description: Franois-Henri Pinault, chief executive of PPR, is looking to unload the firms European retail business to focus exclusively on global consumer and luxury brands, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Notes on the dollar panic
description: Atrios notes that according to the financial press the dollar is always falling, even though it isnt. As Chris Hayes points out, hype about a falling dollar also feeds the story line that we mustnt do anything to upset the Chinese, because terrible things would follow if they sold some of their dollar reserves.

title: Why Are Some Cities More Entrepreneurial Than Others?
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.The success of a city is tied to the areas entrepreneurship, but what explains why some places are more entrepreneurial than others?

title: Sampler: Protests, Use of Force and Entrepreneurial Cities
description: U.C. Protest | A protest at the University of Californias administrative office in Oakland turned into a three-hour discussion between students and administrators about budget cuts and fee increases. (The universitys president, Mark Yudof, was off on a furlough day.)

title: Milo, a Site to Help People Shop Offline, Attracts Investors
description: As more and more people shop online, one start-up is pursuing a contrarian idea. Milo is a Web site where people can find out where to buy things offline.

description: Man Group, the publicly listed hedge fund giant, saw its shares take a hit Tuesday after Credit Suisse downgraded the firm to neutral from outperform, on valuation grounds.

description: Is Cadbury planning a so-called Pac-Man defense if no bid emerges to challenge Kraft Foods hostile offer?

description: The Bank of Montreal said on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy Citigroups Diners Club North American franchise, bolstering its own credit card business with Diners Club customers.

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, Nov. 24
description: Here are some highlights from Tuesdays edition of The New York Times:

title: Traversing Indias Highest Highway
description: Twisting some 295 miles through Himalayan peaks, the Leh-Manali Highway in northern India is one of the worlds highest and most remote highways.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: For the Hotel Industry, Recovery is a Long Way OffTravelers and investors should exercise caution in evaluating small recent indicators that might mean better times ahead for the still-troubled hotel industry.

description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Acid Attacks and IVAWA
description: The International Violence Against Women Act, IVAWA, is a fairly obscure piece of legislation that never gets anywhere. It has bipartisan backing  formerly Joe Biden and Richard Lugar, now John Kerry and Lugar  yet even this year it got nowhere. I think to most people it seems a bit remote or irrelevant.

title: Osmotic Power Debuts in Norway
description: The worlds first osmotic plant opened today in Tofte, Norway, harnessing the saltiness of the sea, along with freshwater, to produce electricity through a polymer membrane.

title: The Sound of Music at 50: Readers Respond
description: Last Monday was the 50th anniversary of the Broadway opening of Rodgers and Hammersteins The Sound of Music. In an interactive feature, four people with ties to the original production  the actors Theodore Bikel, Lauri Peters and Brian Davies, and Sam von Trapp, the grandson of Baroness Maria von Trapp  talked about their memories of the show.

title: What to Watch Tuesday: Mya by a Sequin?
description: Donny Osmond will dance for the honor of middle-aged men everywhere in the season finale of Dancing With the Stars (ABC, 9 p.m.). Of course, some of those middle-aged men may be inclined to vote for the athletic and extremely well-toned Mya. (She can also pull the female demographic with the frequently bare chest of her partner, Dmitry Chaplin.) The vote here is for the also-ran with the million-dollar smile, plucky, relatable Kelly Osbourne, but her fall in the freestyle Monday night may have made third place inevitable.

title: House Watch: Turkey and Fisticuffs
description: This post contains spoilers with all the trimmings.

title: Answering Your Questions About the Chevy Volt
description: Last Friday, we solicited you for questions on the Chevrolet Volt, which is scheduled to be released late next year. We forwarded some of your questions to Lindsay Brooke, who recently drove a preproduction Volt and wrote about his impressions for the Automobiles section last Sunday.

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading (and watching) on Tuesday morning.

title: Third-Quarter U.S. Growth Revised Lower
description: The United States economy grew at slower pace in the third quarter than previously reported, the government said Tuesday, as weak consumer spending and rising imports offset stimulus efforts.

title: Runaway, 13, Was Lost in Subway for 11 Days
description: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy with Aspergers syndrome vanished in the New York subway system for 11 days despite frantic search by his parents, relatives, police and the Mexican consulate to find him.

title: Rajaratnam Attacks Wiretap Use
description: Update | 8:58 a.m. Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund executive accused of masterminding a $20 million insider trading ring, responded to civil fraud charges on Tuesday, attacking investigators use of wiretaps and arguing that prosecutors omitted crucial facts in their original complaint.

title: The Early Word: Afghan Decision Looms
description: The Afghanistan decision is almost here.

title: Freeney and Mathis Chasing Passers and Records
description: Chase Stuart, a lawyer, Jets fan and statistical analyst, writes for the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog.

title: Russia to Investigate Fund Lawyers Death
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev ordered an inquiry on Tuesday into the death of a 37-year-old lawyer who died in pretrial detention last week after being swept up in a battle between the Russian authorities and the international investment fund he was representing.

title: Gee, thats De Pressing
description: Second estimate of third-quarter GDP out; growth rate marked down to 2.8%.

title: Tavern Creditors Say the City Is Hurting Their Interests
description: There are 452 of them  ranging from a powerful labor union to humble butchers, bakers and even balloon-animal artists. They are owed $8 million. Now, for the first time, they have a voice.

title: Interrogated About The Daily Show in Iran
description: As Politicos Laura Rozen points out, there is a remarkable moment of black comedy in the Newsweek reporter Maziar Baharis personal account of his recent captivity and interrogation in Tehrans Evin prison. Mr. Bahari, an Iranian-Canadian filmmaker and writer whose detention we discussed last month on The Lede, writes that during his confinement, at one point his interrogator asked him to explain his appearance in a fake news report (embedded above) that was filmed by Comedy Centrals The Daily Show in the run-up to Junes disputed presidential election.

title: Money, mouth
description: All the serious people agree that the United States faces a debt time bomb. Never mind those low, low interest rates  big trouble is just over the horizon.

title: Ruling Lets Atlantic Yards Seize Land
description: After enduring three years of delays, several lawsuits and the collapse of the real estate market, the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn took a major step forward on Tuesday when New Yorks highest court ruled that the state can seize private property for the 22-acre development.

title: In Bushs Footsteps
description: It should probably give liberals pause that the most persuasive case for trying Khalid Sheikh Mohammed as a civilian is that doing so is consistent with Bush administration precedent. Thus Jim Comey and Jack Goldsmith:

title: Home Prices May Be Nearing a New Dip
description: Home prices are enduring an early winter chill, raising the odds that the economy may suffer another jolt while it is still weak.

title: Homeless Organization Is Called a Fraud
description: Updated, 12:17 p.m. | They are a familiar sight on street corners across the five boroughs: Men and women standing behind folding card tables, urging passers-by to throw a little change into the empty plastic water jug marked U.H.O.

title: Can You Believe That?
description: Monologue |  Aired Monday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Over the weekend, the Senate voted to allow debate on the health care bill. Can you believe that? Its like fighting over whether or not to fight.

title: Fark and USA Today: Bedfellows in Oddity
description: Cube surfers have long turned to Fark.com for a break from the mundane. A news aggregator and a social networking news site, Fark has always placed an emphasis on idiosyncrasy when it comes to the days events. By its own definition, Fark is where you go for news that is not really news.

title: Viewers Who Saw Both
description: Monologue |  Aired Monday night on NBC: The ratings just came in for Sarah Palins appearance on The Oprah Winfrey Show. It earned Oprah her highest ratings since the episode where she reunited the Osmond family. Yeah, viewers who saw both episodes say Palins more likable but that Donny and Marie are more qualified to be president.

title: Nothing But Evil
description: Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: That evil guy, the evil masterminding terrorist Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, he is going on trial here in New York City. I will tell you something, this guy is nothing but evil. One time he called CNN and told him that his son was floating away in a balloon.

title: Recipes for a Vegan Thanksgiving
description: These days, it isnt enough to offer vegetarian dishes at Thanksgiving  some of your guests may adhere to a vegan diet. Vegan foods are meatless dishes prepared without dairy, eggs or any animal products.

title: The White House Turkey
description: Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC: President Obama is getting ready to pardon the White House turkey, the Treasury Secretary, Tim Geithner.

title: The Adam Lambert Fallout: Were You Not Entertained?
description: In what is probably a huge relief for Jennifer Lopez, the spotlight has remained firmly trained on Adam Lambert following his sexually charged performance at the American Music Awards.

title: Expert Answers on Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
description: Denise Grady, a science writer for The New York Times, recently explored the link between a recently discovered virus called XMRV and chronic fatigue syndrome, in Is a Virus the Cause of Fatigue Syndrome? Here, Dr. Nancy G. Klimas, who serves on the board of the International Association for Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, responds to readers questions. Dr. Klimas is a director of the department of immunology of the University of Miami School of Medicine and director of research for clinical AIDS/H.I.V. research at the Miami Veterans Affairs Medical Center. See her earlier responses in Readers Ask: A Virus Linked to Chronic Fatigue Syndrome and Fred Friedbergs responses to behavior-related questions in Behavioral Treatments for Chronic Fatigue Syndrome.

title: As Bank Failures Rise, F.D.I.C. Fund Falls Into Red
description: The government-administered insurance fund that protects depositors fell into the red for the first time since the fallout from the savings-and-loan crisis of the early 1990s as the pace of bank failures accelerated.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Some Days, You Eat the Fish. Other Days
description: I am having a bad day.

title: Home Green Home: Reality Check
description: The following is the latest in a series exploring the ways Americans are improving the efficiency and reducing the footprint of their homes. Green Inc. readers are encouraged to share their thoughts and experiences in the comments section or by sending e-mail messages to greeninc@nytimes.com.

title: A Closer Look at Rajaratnams Legal Defense
description: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, occasionally writes as a guest blogger for the Deal Professor. Mr. Henning specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and is a former editor of the White Collar Crime Law Prof Blog.

title: Thanksgiving Fill-In
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first four paragraphs of this Op-Ed from the Opinion section, A Moveable Fast. Use your own words, or click read more to choose from a scrambled list of the words that were removed.

title: U.S. Fund for Bank Deposit Insurance Falls Into the Red
description: The government-administered insurance fund that protects depositors fell $8.2 billion into the red for the first time since the fallout from the savings-and-loan crisis of the early 1990s as the pace of bank failures accelerated in the third quarter.

title: Google Chief Announces Plan in Baghdad to Put Iraqi Artifacts Online
description: BAGHDAD  Amira Edan, the director of Iraqs National Museum, says that soon she will no longer have to worry so much that the famous institution remains closed to the public for fear of violence.

title: New BMW 5 Series Has Hints of the 7 Series
description: What does the new BMW 5 Series have to do with a new Rolls-Royce Ghost? Each is being built on a modified BMW 7-Series chassis.

title: More Si ns Revealed by Readers
description: Last weeks article describing how a few dark letters on a sign at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens created the message Im Hurt attracted quite a few comments  and most of those were from readers who provided examples of what they claimed were other sign malfunctions, and the whimsical results. We could not publish more than half of them because they were, well, inappropriate for a family newspaper. (Or the Web site of a family newspaper.) But here are some of our favorites:

title: Play by British Wunderkind Gets New York Staging
description: The argument to stay in school and finish that college degree just got a whole lot harder to make: the 23-year-old British playwright Polly Stenham, who was just 19 years old when she dropped out of University College London to finish her critically acclaimed play That Face, will soon see the drama performed in New York, in a production staged by Manhattan Theater Club. In a news release, publicists for Manhattan Theater Club said that its production of That Face, about a family struggling with drugs, alcohol and dissolution, will star Elizabeth Marvel (above, of Broadways Top Girls) as the family matriarch, Martha, and will be directed by Sarah Benson (who directed Blasted for the Soho Rep, where she is artistic director). The play is scheduled to begin previews at New York City Center  Stage I on April 29, with an opening night planned for May 18. Additional casting is expected to be announced shortly.

title: Scandal and Corruption Cloud Champions League Restart
description: Update | 4:43 p.m. Barcelona defeated Inter Milan on Tuesday, 2-0, at the Camp Nou  in Spain. The victory, coupled with a 0-0 draw between Rubin Kazan and Dynamo Kiev, catapults the Catalan side to the top of Group F with 8 points and helps save the European champion from embarrassment. (The days results are here.)

title: G.M. to Decide Saabs Fate Next Week
description: DETROIT  General Motors said it could decide next week to close its Saab Automobile unit after the Swedish company that planned to buy the brand backed out.

title: Debating Haves vs. Have-Nots at Public Universities
description: The decision Friday by the University of California to raise student fees by 32 percent even as it is cutting its budget continues to reverberate in homes and classrooms across the state and around the country.

title: Clausen Is Punched, Reports Say
description: How frustrated are Notre Dame fans? Well, one was apparently upset enough about the Fighting Irishs season that he decided to take it out on quarterback Jimmy Clausen.

title: Obama Plans Afghan Address Next Week
description: President Obama plans to announce details of his strategy for the war in Afghanistan early next week in an address to the nation. Heres a look at Tuesdays developments as they unfold at the White House and beyond.

title: Crime Down, but Oakland Up in the Dangerous City Rankings
description: Its not a ranking you want to win or even place in the top 10. A new study by the CQ Press ranks Oakland as having the third highest crime rate among cities in the U.S. Camden, N.J. was ranked first followed by St. Louis, Missouri. (Richmond ranked 14th, an improvement from 9th).

title: Travel Deals: Holiday Hotel Discounts Near D.C.
description: Heading to the D.C. area for the holidays? Kimpton Hotels Lorien Hotel & Spa, in Alexandria, Va., is offering rooms for $119 a night through Jan. 31. The Spare Bedroom package also includes a $25 daily hotel credit. Use the code PSBR to book.

title: Green Business and Indigenous Rights
description: A new report released over the weekend calls attention to the plight of indigenous communities affected by climate change mitigation measures.

title: Swedish Buyer Terminates Deal to Buy Saab
description: General Motors confirmed Tuesday that the deal to sell its loss-making Saab Automobile unit in Sweden was off, The New York Times reported.

title: Adam Lambert Concert, Planned for Good Morning America, Is Canceled
description: Update | 1:02 p.m.  The fallout from Adam Lamberts provocative act on the American Music Awards continues: on Tuesday, ABC said that it had canceled a performance by Mr. Lambert scheduled for Wednesday on Good Morning America. An ABC spokeswoman said, Given his controversial American Music Awards performance, we were concerned about airing a similar concert so early in the morning. Mr. Lambert previously appeared on Good Morning America in August, when he performed the Muse song Starlight, and discussed his sexuality in an interview with 20/20 in June. The American Music Awards show was broadcast on ABC on Sunday night.

title: Waiting On Weis at Notre Dame
description: In the dwindling days of college football season, the usual topics of discussion have hardly captivated us. We should be busy parsing Urban Meyers proclamations about staying at Florida or squawking about the befuddling permutations  and maddening existence  of the Bowl Championship Series. Instead, there is a strange fixating pull to the implosion at Notre Dame, where Coach Charlie Weiss imminent demise has become the slow-motion car crash no one can stop craning their necks to watch.

title: The Way We Ate: The Americanization of The State Dinner
description: For more than a century and a half, The New York Times has been recording the pleasures and prejudices of the American palate. The Way We Ate is a weekly tasting menu of vintage food writing from the Times archives, with an extra installment this week in honor of tonights state dinner at the White House.

title: Tavern Creditors Say the City Is Hurting Their Interests
description: There are 452 of them  ranging from a powerful labor union to humble butchers, bakers and even balloon-animal artists. They are owed $8 million. Now, for the first time, they have a voice.

title: Jon & Kate Plus 8: The End
description: One thing never changed about Jon & Kate Plus 8: the kids were always a good time. Only the steeliest misanthrope could fail to be charmed by their squeals and romps. How you felt about the show, though, depended on how you felt about Jon and Kate Gosselin. If you found them boring, except for when they were irritating  what I like to think of as the silent majority position  then the show ran the gamut from vaguely embarrassing to borderline unwatchable.

title: What, No Flannel? | The Real Look of Grunge
description: Theres a perception that grunge emerged in the early 1990s. But with his photos in the new book Grunge, Michael Lavine shows us that the 90s wasnt the beginning of grunge; it was the end. Thats when Seattles best cultural brew was watered down, piped out to the masses and sold at a steep profit. Marc Jacobs appropriated flannel. The music of the Pacific Northwest commingled with So-Cal skate culture. And you could don the ready-made trappings of this amorphous alternative movement simply by slinking into the nearest Pacific Sunwear.

title: Twins in 2012 Slam in Manhattan
description: Let it never be said that Alexandre and Philippe Haussmann have forgotten the little people who helped get them to where they are today. There they were on Friday putting in a cameo at the Manhattan Monologue Slam in the West Village, just a week after the movie in which they have featured roles, Roland Emmerichs 2012, had opened with a dominating box-office performance.

title: Botax
description: A proposed tax to be levied on voluntary cosmetic surgery.

title: Giants Stadium Countdown: Loss Is a Victory
description: John Maxymuk, author of The 50 Greatest Plays in New York Giants Football History, is helping us count down to the final game at Giants Stadium. His latest book is Quarterback Abstract.No. 6: We Can Play With These Guys

title: American Symphony Orchestra Will Return to Carnegie Hall
description: The American Symphony Orchestra is headed back to Carnegie Hall, its longtime home. Beginning with its 2010-11 season, the orchestra, led by the conductor Leon Botstein, will resume playing its concerts at Carnegie Hall, a press representative for the orchestra said. At its founding in 1962 by the conductor Leopold Stokowski, the orchestra performed its concerts at Carnegie Hall. But in 1992, the orchestra moved to Lincoln Center, where it was invited by Nathan Leventhal, Lincoln Centers president at the time, to participate in the Great Performers series. In a news release, the orchestra said that all tickets to its 2010-11 season at Carnegie Hall will cost $25. The orchestra will also remain in residence at the Richard B. Fisher Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College, where Mr. Botstein is president.

title: Joost Sells Its Name and Most of Its Assets
description: Joost, the struggling video Web site, said on Tuesday that it was selling most of the company to the Adconion Media Group, an online advertising and marketing company, for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition ends a long sales process that at one point was thought to involve possible interest from the cable television operators like Time Warner Cable and Comcast.

title: Days After Hairstylists Death, Her Baby Dies, Too
description: Joselin Castro did not live long enough to cradle her baby girl. But on Tuesday, mother and child will be united at a Washington Heights funeral parlor.

title: The Sun Is Shining on Norwegian Skier Again
description: MIAMI BEACH  The nearest snow was more than a thousand miles away. The rest of the Norwegian Alpine ski team was training in Canada.

title: Father and Son Bond in Gloomy Aftermath of Disaster
description: Bang or whimper? Fire or ice? Happily, holiday moviegoers interested in pondering the end of the world can select scenarios far more elaborate than those simple, traditional choices.

title: A Professionally Funny Family
description: Abby Elliott claims that she dropped out of college because mice were urinating on her eyeballs. After graduating from high school in Danbury, Conn., in 2005, she enrolled at a college in New York City, where she was so unhappy to find mice in her dormitory  mice she blamed for giving her a case of conjunctivitis (via said urine)  that she quit before the first semester was over to move to Los Angeles and try to get into show business.

title: Murrays Cheese Will Open 50 Locations in Kroger Markets
description: People who complain about the lines at Murrays Cheese might want to just head to the supermarket instead.

title: Obesity and Health Care Spending
description: In the past weve talked about the connection between unhealthy lifestyles (in particular, obesity rates) and health care spending. Here are two maps that might further complicate that discussion a bit.

title: How to Compare Prices in Retail Price Wars
description: As part of their fight over the future of retailing, Amazon.com and Wal-Mart are engaged in an online price war this holiday season, according to an article in The New York Times on Tuesday.

title: Blog Posts for the Holiday
description: (From Mike Licht at Blogs With Bite. MB)

title: For Bruno, Politics and Business Intersected on the Golf Course
description: ALBANY  For Joseph L. Bruno, once one of the most powerful politicians in New York, the road to trouble was soft, grassy and green.

title: 'Fela!'
description: Sahr Ngaujah plays the title character in this excerpt from the new Broadway musical. (Video courtesy of "Fela!" on Broadway)

title: Whatever Works: Sarkozy Says She Is Cast in New Woody Allen Movie
description: Boy, if life were only like this. Woody Allen has landed another, shall we say, vivacious young actress to appear in one of his movies  in this case, the first lady of France. Bloomberg News reported that Carla Sarkozy, the model, singer, actress and wife of the French president Nicolas Sarkozy, said in a television interview that she had agreed to appear in Mr. Allens next film. He offered me a role in his next movie, Mrs. Sarkozy said in the interview with Canal Plus television. I dont know for what character, but I said yes. Im not an actress at all, she said, according to Bloomberg News. Maybe I will be terrible. But, in my life, I cannot let such a chance go. Under her maiden name, Bruni, Ms. Sarkozy has recorded three albums of music and contributed songs to the soundtracks of films including (500) Days of Summer.

title: Asana Aims to Change the Way We Work
description: Office work, filled with overflowing e-mail inboxes and pointless meetings, could be a lot more efficient and productive. One start-up, Asana, is trying to fix the problem. How? Well, that is still a secret.

title: Theres No Celery in Monrovia, Help!
description: Todays first question comes from someone posted abroad, looking for a taste of home, worried about provisions, worried about sterility, worried. Did you read my man Mark Bittman in the Week in Review on Sunday? Breathe deep. Be calm. Make like these dudes.

title: Raising Vegetarian Children
description: Surrounded as we are this week by yams and brussels sprouts and cranberries and turkey (and those mini hot dogs that have somehow also become a tradition at our familys Thanksgiving table), the moment seems right to write about vegetarian parents and children.

title: Obama May Add 30,000 Troops in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Tuesday that he was determined to finish the job in Afghanistan, and his aides signaled to allies that he would send as many as 25,000 to 30,000 additional American troops there even as they cautioned that the final number remained in flux.

title: Farm Union Aims Health Pitch at Key States
description: In a news conference on Tuesday aimed at pressuring swing-vote senators, leaders of the National Farmers Union, which represents about 250,000 farm and ranch families, stressed the importance of major health care legislation to agricultural workers in Arkansas, Maine and Nebraska.

title: G.O.P. Purity Test Could Trip Up Castle
description: One of the bright lights on the political horizons for Republicans in 2010 is the United States Senate seat that opened up in Delaware when Joseph R. Biden Jr. became vice president.

title: Pear and Apple Souffl
description: Fruit souffls are dramatic and impressive yet so easy to make. This one will impress everyone at your table. Make the fruit puree well in advance, and beat the egg whites before you sit down to dinner. Then, when youre too full to eat anything more, fold the two together and put the souffls in the oven. Just when youre beginning to think you could eat a little dessert, theyll be ready.

title: A New President at Disney Channels
description: Carolina Lightcap is the new president of Disney Channels Worldwide. She succeeds Rich Ross, who was named chairman of Walt Disney Studios last month.

title: Q&A: The Christmas Markets of Europe
description: Q.

title: Muti to Conduct Shanghai Symphony Orchestra
description: Riccardo Muti will be making his first conducting foray into China, which has become a major destination for Western musicians and orchestras in recent years. He will conduct the Shanghai Symphony Orchestra on Dec. 31 in what is billed as a New Years Eve concert (27 days before the Chinese New Year), an orchestra spokeswoman said. The program will consist of Verdis overture to La Forza del Destino, the ballet music from his Vpres Siciliennes, Martuccis Notturno and Respighis Pines of Rome. The concert will take place at the Shanghai Grand Theater.

title: Soccer in Iraq: Another Field for Argument
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs national soccer team has certainly endured hardship. Saddam Hussein had players beaten after losses. And the war that deposed him forced them into exile, after extremists started killing sports figures. Their first game at home in years was just this summer  against the Palestinians, the only team willing to come here during a war.

title: A Site to Help People Shop Offline Attracts Investors
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: A familiar feeling
description: Theres something disturbingly familiar about the current deficit hysteria. Theres the way that fear, and a demand for action against a supposed threat, has spread despite the lack of any solid evidence to support it. Theres the way that many news stories seem to present only one side of the argument, and suppress or neglect contrary evidence (e.g., writing articles about how nervous investors are turning on Japan while never mentioning that the current interest rate on Japanese long-term debt is, um, 1.3 percent).

title: A bizarre complacency
description: Even as the conventional wisdom seems to have converged on the view that despite the continuing willingness of bond investors to buy US debt at low interest rates, the deficit is terrible, scary, awful  you know were in herd behavior mode when phrases like time bomb start appearing in news stories  a weird complacency has settled in on the state of the actual economy. Were recovering, everyone says  no need to do anything more.

title: London Philharmonic Says Former Finance Director Embezzled $928,000
description: The London Philharmonic Orchestra said Tuesday that its former finance director embezzled $928,000 over four years. The executive, Cameron Poole, who also held the title of general manager, is accused of using the money for antiques, vacations and renovations to his London townhouse, according to British newspapers.

title: German Banker Sees Risk, Not Size, as Problem
description: Andreas Schmitz, president of the Federal Association of German Banks, said in a statement Monday in Frankfurt that a central problem of the financial crisis, in Europe at least, was not that certain banks were too big to fail, but that they were too connected to fail, or simply too risky.

title: Adam Lambert Headed to CBS Early Show After ABC Cancels His Concert
description: Hours after ABC said that it canceled a concert by Adam Lambert planned for its Good Morning America program on Wednesday, CBS said that Mr. Lambert would appear on its Early Show. In a statement, CBS said that Mr. Lambert, an American Idol finalist, will perform live on The Early Show on Wednesday and discuss his recent performance on the American Music Awards. That awards show was broadcast Sunday on ABC, which said it was concerned that Mr. Lambert would give another controversial performance if he appeared on Good Morning America.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) How worried should we be about the deficit?

title: Joost Sells Most of Its Assets to Adconion
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Web Site Honors Sustainable Cooking
description: Following its list of top young farmers bringing local, sustainable food back to the table, the environmental Web site Mother Nature Network has compiled a list of young chefs exemplifying sustainable cooking.

title: An Outlaw Street Race, for a Good Cause
description: Stepping off the Long Island Rail Road with his custom-made fixed gear folding bike early Saturday afternoon, Robert A. Butler planned a bit of riding before heading to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Consumers Are Still Glum
description: Consumer confidence rose slightly in November, but consumers are still looking quite depressed, according to the Conference Board Consumer Confidence Index.

title: Queens Murder Suspect Says He Has a Personality Disorder
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Terra Stands Firm in the Forever War
description: Update | 3:08 p.m. Terra Industries shows no signs of running out of breath in the Forever War.

title: Now Booking | A Boston Hotel Double-Play
description: Boston is one of those cities that cant seem to shake its reputation: forget all the cutting-edge biotech and the newfound fashion consciousness and the burgeoning food culture  for many this will always be Americas capital of the buttoned-up, where kicking it old school trumps looking to the future. Yet in the space of less than a month two important new hotels have arrived here, the W and the Ames, and between them theyve injected a healthy dose of the kind of modernity and style that typifies the new Boston.

title: After a Humbling Spiral, Kerry Returns to Form
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John Kerry was sounding almost giddy  and, as a general rule, John Kerry does not do giddy.

title: Higher Tide
description: Like the little black dress, the beach vacation will never go out of style. Indeed, the more uncertain the times, the more necessary it becomes to sun yourself beside a book and a pia colada. Only nowadays, travelers looking to get something extra out of their tropical idylls  a little more value with their vegging  are combining beach time with volunteer programs, spiritual discovery or immersion in a new culture. This trend has been going on for a while, but since the recession its even more pronounced, says Ann Mack, director of trend-spotting at the ad agency JWT. People are vulnerable and theyre seeking answers. Life-enriching trips can help put things in perspective.

title: Cowher Passes on Interview With the Bills
description: Bill Cowher, the former Pittsburgh Steelers coach, declined the opportunity to interview for the Buffalo Bills head coaching job last weekend, according to The Buffalo News, among other news organizations.

title: Let Me Cut Budget, Paterson Says; No, Lawmakers Reply
description: New Yorks budget impasse continues.

title: On Our Radar
description: 1.) An update on those hacked global warming e-mail messages.

title: Lots of Ritual, With Some Substance
description: Last week, the Obama administration hosted the first state dinner for a foreign visitor, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India. It is mostly ritual activities, but there is some chance for progress on issues.

title: The Morning Skate: Concussions, DiPietros Return and Sticks
description: Sports fans and observers often point to the N.F.L. as the industry leader in all sorts of things, but in some areas, the N.H.L. is ahead of pro football. One of those areas is video replay. Another is the N.H.L.s protocol on clearing players who return from concussion injuries.

title: Workplace Efficiency Start-Up Attracts Interest
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: A Big Crowd for Jon & Kate Finale
description: About 4.3 million viewers watched the final installment of Jon & Kate Plus 8 on Monday, Nielsen said, marking an emotional end to the TLC series about the Gosselin twins and sextuplets and their parents Jon and Kate.

title: Koons Sculpture for Los Angeles Museum on Hold
description: A train that is supposed to go nowhere seems to be going nowhere, at least for the time being. Plans by the artist Jeff Koons and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art to create an eye-popping piece of public art  a 70-foot replica of a 1943 locomotive engine designed to dangle nose down from a 161-foot crane  are in limbo because the museum cannot pay for it, Bloomberg reported.

title: Industrial Real Estate, a New Jersey Bulwark, Shows Some Cracks
description: Over the years, as the real estate markets for offices, residences and stores in New Jersey have gone through peaks and valleys, the market for industrial real estate has been like the buildings themselves  not flashy, but big, solid and reliable.

title: Airlines Pay for Stranding Passengers
description: WASHINGTON  The Transportation Department imposed its first penalties for runway delays Tuesday, collecting $175,000 from three airlines for leaving 47 passengers of a regional jet stranded overnight in Rochester, Minn.

title: The State Dinner Menu
description: Obama Foodorama has it.

title: Lessons From the Man in a Kilt
description: Readers may remember my longtime friend Brian Nelson as the moon-faced man in the kilt  his photo and an accompanying essay appeared on the Well blog in August. Cancer treatment had changed his appearance, leaving his face and eyes swollen and unrecognizable, his voice muffled and sometimes unintelligible.

title: Americas Next Top Stock Model
description: Lets say youre an investor who has been following Hewlett-Packard for ages. The companys slowing printer sales concerns you, largely because you think this may be a long-term issue rather than a short-term blip. Meanwhile, youre bullish as all get out about H.P.s services business.

title: The Reunion Tour, for Clothes Only
description: WHEN consumerism spends itself to death and the arteries of fashion are clogged with cheap, disposable and boring designs, its time to rediscover one-of-a-kind relics from bygone fashion eras.

title: Can A Wonk Win?
description: Matt Yglesias and Isaac Chotiner both suggest that if a Republican politician were to embrace serious domestic policy ideas, Republican voters wouldnt want anything to do with him. The conservative movement tends to fetishize stupidity, Yglesias writes, and believes that theres something actually un-American about being thoughtful, having respect for scholarship, or incorporating any kind of nuance into your discussion. If Sarah Palin and Mike Huckabee were interested in policy, then they would not be so appealing to the GOP base, Chotiner argues, adding that since movement conservatism sneers at intellectuals and elites, a conservative candidate who was interested in learning the ins and outs of the welfare state and health care policy is unlikely to ever achieve Palin/Huckabee levels of popularity with the grassroots.

title: Fed Cautious About Strength of Recovery
description: WASHINGTON  Policy makers at the Federal Reserve have become slightly more optimistic about the pace of the economic recovery, but they continue to predict that unemployment will remain well above 9 percent through 2010, according to new forecasts released on Tuesday.

title: Is There a Danger in Pestering an Admissions Officer?
description: The folks over at College Confidential are engaging their readership today on the question, What if you pester an admissions counselor? The thread began with someone who identifies herself as Wendy aka sometimes-hyper-mom asking, Is it possible to negatively impact a colleges impression of my daughter by sending too many emails to the admissions counselor.

title: After Cheney
description: When Vice President Biden travels to Iraq, which he does every two months or so, he flies on Air Force Two to an airbase in southern England and then transfers to a cargo plane, a C-17, retrofitted for vice-presidential comfort with an Airstream trailer bolted on to tracks in the center of the hold. With its porthole and shiny rivets and gleaming chrome, this strange conveyance looks like something out of Jules Verne. Captain Biden holds court in a wood-paneled galley just large enough for his half-dozen or so aides to pile into. Unlike Nemo, he is a gregarious knee-squeezer who has to be ordered by his staff to stop talking so he can get some rest.

title: Women Who Want to Want
description: At her group therapy sessions for women despairing of low sexual desire, Lori Brotto likes to pass around a plastic tub of raisins. The women, usually six to a group, sit around two pushed-together beige tables in a fluorescently lighted conference room at the British Columbia Center for Sexual Medicine in Vancouver. A little potted tree is jammed randomly in one corner. Ragged holes scar one wall where a painting used to hang. The dcor doesnt speak of sensuality. That is the job of the raisin.

title: Video: State Dinners, Past and Present
description: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India is making his way around Washington this week. Official visits like his are one of the most tradition-bound of all Washington rituals, complete with a state dinner on Tuesday night.

title: 7 Charged for False Building Documents
description: Federal and local authorities arrested seven people on Tuesday  including the owners of two construction testing companies, officials from three contracting companies, and an engineer  on charges they falsified testing documents at four New York construction projects.

title: State Dinner Highlights
description: The Fashion | 8:25 p.m.  For the dinner, Michelle Obama chose a sleeveless golden gown designed by the Indian-American designer Naeem Khan.

title: Now Showing | Art Dealer Archipelagoes
description: For his latest exhibition, the abstract painter John Zinsser has turned to representation. Gallery representation, that is. Art Dealer Archipelagoes, at James Graham & Sons Gallery through Jan. 5, is an installation of finely detailed drawings of maps that viewed together form an atlas of the artists 25-year love affair with the New York gallery scene. Several of the dealer states included in the installation are now defunct  including Holly Solomon and John Good  but Zinssers geographical juxtapositions remind viewers of their place in the pantheon. There is something inherently funny about the whole undertaking, Zinsser says about the exhibit. The groupings, the borders and implied territories, and a sense of the larger triumph and pathos  those artists who made it, and those who didnt. Also in the show: a series of Auction Lot drawings that trace the paths of iconic artworks into the market and, for better or worse, highlight the influence of auction houses and collectors on contemporary art history.

title: Again, a Question of What to Do With Pier A
description: Having lost the National Park Service as a prospective tenant, the city is now seeking ideas on what to do with Pier A, a dilapidated 123-year-old structure at the northern edge of Battery Park.

title: The Self-Manufacture of Megan Fox
description: Megan Fox is trying to reposition herself as everygirl, but she seems to have overlooked an important point: trash-talking women, while using the most tired and retrograde of stereotypes, sound stupid and hateful, and Fox cant do an interview without engaging in this sort of commentary. Half the ink Fox gets comes from putting down other women. She will never build a female fan base if she continues to do so.If moviegoers question Foxs intelligence, its not because of her beauty. Megan, heres some career advice: Turn off Say Yes to the Dress, and go out and make some female friends; youll be so glad you did.

title: How to Handle Adult Children Who Move Back Home
description: The economy has forced 10 percent of adults younger than 35 to move back home, according to a new survey from the Pew Research Center covered in this article in The New York Times on Tuesday.

title: New Spider-Man Producer Reaches Out
description: Update | 4:56 p.m. Michael Cohl, the new lead producer of the Broadway musical project Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark, has approached Kevin McCollum and Jeffrey Seller, the Tony Award-winning producers of Broadway musicals and revivals including West Side Story, In the Heights, Avenue Q, La Boheme and Rent, about investing in the show, according to three Broadway producers with knowledge of the conversations.

title: Octomom in Production
description: In 1934, five identical baby girls were born to a poor family in Canada; the world came to know them as the Dionne quintuplets. Within days of their birth, they became an international phenomenon and were placed in a human zoo known as Quintland, where curious people could come and ogle them while their parents and the community grew rich. The psychological damage inflicted by their freak-show existence was chronicled in two memoirs and in several other books and films. Self-esteem issues, depression and the inability to fashion normal lives plagued the girls. Their story should have served as a lesson to the world that multiples ought not to be treated as commodities. Yet, as John Bowe suggests, we continue to exploit them with a modern human zoo  the so-called reality show. Have we learned nothing from history?

title: 30 Thanksgivings
description: Few things are as predictable in the life of a food writer as this: sometime in October, September if your editor is on the ball (November if he or she is not), you will be asked, What are you writing about for Thanksgiving?

title: Dr. James Will Make It Better
description: In David Leonhardts article (Nov. 8), readers learn about standards of care to which all medical providers should aspire. Short shrift was given, however, to the role of the patient. Consumeruse of online quality-rating sites is not an accurate measure of interest regarding health care choices. Patients and families must become the center of care if we are to reform our system. Massachusetts is starting down a path toward health care payment reform and consumer engagement in their care through programs like shared decision making and chronic-disease management. Our health care system can only improve if medical providers learn how to engage patients so that they can make treatment decisions together.

title: Where Do You Stand? Responding to the Pending Health Care Legislation
description: Overview | What values are evident in the policy proposals coming out of the current health care debate? How do our own values shape our views on health care reform? How do the proposals now pending in Congress compare? In this lesson, students express their views about the pending health care reform and examine comparisons of the House and Senate bills.

title: The Price of Free
description: What surprised me about Nicholas Carrs analysis of the potential breakdown of broadcast TV as we know it was that he never considered how ads may factor into the equation. One of the few growth areas in media spending is in broadband TV ads. So-called preroll ads (15-to-30-second ads usually repurposed from TV) dominate the content on Hulu. Hulu has also been in testing mode on enabling users to choose which ads they watch or to answer a market-research survey rather than view the ads. Some of the most compelling ads have been from packaged-goods companies that appear as single-sponsor units for a program. The ads bookend the content and may appear within it too, and they have a story arcthat continues and pays off with the final ad after the episode.

title: Stimulus Funds Stock Pantries and Soup Kitchens
description: Thanks to federal stimulus funds, fewer New York City food pantries and soup kitchens have had to turn people away in the past year, reversing the trend of the past several years, according to a survey released by the New York City Coalition Against Hunger. However, much of that financing is scheduled to sunset within a year, potentially creating an even greater shortfall as the demand for food benefits soars in the downturn.

title: The Score: The End of Music
description: We seem to be on the edge of a paradigm shift. Orchestras are struggling to stay alive, rock has been relegated to the underground, jazz has stopped evolving and become a dead art, the music industry itself has been subsumed by corporate culture and composers are at their wits end trying to find something thats hip but still appeals to an audience mired in a 19th-century sensibility.

title: Quote Unquote | Carry On
description: Carolina Herrera, explaining the reality of real women wearing her signature creations. Thus explaining her longevity in the biz.

title: Can Modern Dance Be Preserved?
description: As a person who has dedicated her life to preserving movement and music  not specifically modern dance but African dance  I disagree with Arthur Lubows (Nov. 8) statement that dance is the most fragile of the arts. Happening in the moment, it evaporates after every rendering. Unlike drama and music, which also unfold in time, dance is not dictated by a written script or score. I emphatically state that any movement can be written with Labanotation, the leading system to document movement.

title: Correction
