description: An article on Nov. 15 about streaming TV programs directly from the Web, thereby bypassing cable service, referred incorrectly to Starz, a movie network. It is owned by Liberty Media Corporation  not by Showtime, which is owned by CBS.

title: The China Flu Blues
description: Late in August, while our 747 circled the Beijing haze, I prepared to ply both my boys with pink, chewable Tylenol. Id heard from friends that the capital had gone H1N1-quarantine-mad: locking up tourists in policed hotels, isolating children in hospital rooms. It was the start of our third year in China. Wed first come on my sinophile husbands consulting visa, and happily stayed, learning Mandarin and walking the hutongs.

title: We Are All Prisoners, Iranian Blogger Says
description: In Iran, as my colleague Robert Worth reported on Tuesday, the government seems to be expanding its efforts to crack down on even the virtual freedom of its population, creating a new police unit to sweep the Internet for dissident voices, trying to assert greater control over the media and stationing paramilitaries at kindergartens across the country.

title: Saab Deal Collapses
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: The High Low | A Dtacher Knee Socks
description: Good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant but affordable gets. In this column, Ts fashion team finds the cheap and the chic.What: A Dtacher ribbed woolen knee socksHow Much: $45 at A Dtacher (262 Mott Street; 212-625-3380) and Project No. 8 (138 Division Street; 212-925.5599)Who: Melissa Ventosa Martin, senior market/fashion editor

title: Thanksgiving 911: A Point of Reference
description: The AP just moved a story saying Butterball has 55 operators lined up to work the Thanksgiving rush; they expect to answer some 12,000 calls about turkey cooking on Thanksgiving Day. Well now! The Times has me and my Internet, my phone list (n.b., DO NOT CALL FLORENCE FABRICANT BEFORE 8 a.m.!),the books in the Charles Klaveness Library room, and a couple of duty editors and Web producers. And well be on duty from dawn on Thursday through to 3 p.m., which is when mom says I have to go home. Have a question before then? Post it here, or on one of my other question chains here, here or here.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Nov. 24
description: It seemed last Friday as if it would be difficult to find a much more disturbing photograph from this period of the war in Afghanistan than that of a young boy who had been injured and hospitalized by a suicide bomber. But just such a photograph, by Nishanuddin Khan for The Associated Press, was transmitted Tuesday (Slide 8).

title: U.S. Looks to Australia on Credit Card Fees
description: SYDNEY  When Steve Franklin bought four plane tickets on Qantas last June, he faced an unexpected expense: a surcharge of 7.70 Australian dollars on each of the 136.70 dollar ($126) tickets  just for using his Visa credit card.

title: Activists Take Aim at Insurance Democrats
description: Despite pleas from the White House, some Democratic activists are gearing up for a renewed onslaught against  Democrats.

title: A Body Transformed Through Dance
description: The choreographer Tamar Rogoff rehearses her new piece, Diagnosis of a Faun, with Gregg Mozgala, who has cerebral palsy. After a year of working with Ms. Rogoff, Mr. Mozgala has changed how he moves.

title: Barn-Raising
description: When a brush fire destroyed two chicken houses at Soul Food Farm in Vacaville, Calif., in September, killing 1,200 chicks that would have been cooked rather differently at Chez Panisse, Alexis Koefoed was sure her business wouldnt survive. The loss of two weeks income would put her young farm over the edge, especially since her husband had lost his job in June.

title: Chicken Soup
description: Recipes adapted from Camino in Oakland, Calif.

title: Learning His Body, Learning to Dance
description: Gregg Mozgala, a 31-year-old actor with cerebral palsy, had 12 years of physical therapy while he was growing up. But in the last eight months, a determined choreographer with an unconventional rsum has done what all those therapists could not: She has dramatically changed the way Mr. Mozgala walks.

title: BlogTalk: Taking Sides on Afghanistan
description: In the next couple of days, as we prepare and then devour our sage and cornbread stuffing and cranberry relish, many of us will decide if were for the war in Afghanistan or against it, or whether we were for it before we were against it, or  Well, you get the picture.

title: Tax Burdens, Around the World
description: Think you pay a lot of taxes in the United States? Try moving to Denmark.

title: Census Workers Hanging Death Called Suicide
description: The Kentucky census worker found hanging from a tree with the word fed scrawled on his chest staged his death to look like a homicide so that his son could collect his life insurance, the authorities said Tuesday.

title: Boho Tokyo
description: STYLE MAP DAIKANYAMA While Tokyos Aoyoma district is the place for supercharged shopping (Prada! Comme des Garons! Gucci!) and Harajuku is devoted to fast fashion (H&M, Topshop), this hilly neighborhood offers a more mellow experience, with smaller shops on quiet, mazelike streets. The low-key backdrop is perfect for the countrys current obsession with all things earthy and indie. MAURA EGAN

title: Avoiding Thanksgiving Travel Hassles
description: Traveling during Thanksgiving doesnt have to be a nightmare if you know what to expect and what to avoid.

title: Must Haves | Power Puff
description: Chanel bag, $1,295. Go to chanel.com.

title: Violence in the Philippines
description: The death toll in Monday's election violence is 46. President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo has declared a state of emergency in two southern provinces.

title: Injury to Bradshaws Other Foot May Limit Him More
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants running back Ahmad Bradshaw has a new injury. The Giants announced Tuesday that Bradshaw, who was on crutches and not in uniform when the teams practice began, has a sprained left ankle that forced him out of last Sundays 34-31 victory over Atlanta.

title: How to Cut Costs in Bad Times (and Good)
description: It doesnt matter if the economy is going to improve quickly, slowly or not at all for the foreseeable future, saving money on the costs of running your business is always a good thing.

title: Apps for the iPhone: A Travelers Companion, Pocket Size
description: ITS a quarter to five in the morning, and I have a plane to catch in two hours. But why rush out the door if my flight is already delayed? To check its status, I turn to my iPhone, tap on an application called FlightTrack and pull up my flight. Its on time. Better get out of bed. At the airport, I check for Wi-Fi and update all my newspaper apps (NYTimes, WSJ, USA Today and so on) so I have something to read onboard. And when I arrive at my destination, I use the iPhone to pull up the Yelp app, and its built-in mapping feature, to find the most highly user-rated bars and restaurants.

title: In Iran, Fending Off Accusations of Ties to  New Jersey?
description: So now we know what really gives the Iranian regime nightmares.

title: Short List | Claus Sendlinger
description: With his network of 180 independent lodgings, the founder of Design Hotels (designhotels.com) has created a one-stop shop for savvy travelers on the hunt for cool accommodations. When hes not scouting new members (next up: the Park Hyderabad, India) and publishing glossy books (the newest is out next month), Sendlinger decompresses on Koh Tao, in Thailand. T asked him for a quick guide to the islands charms.

title: Sanford Impeachment Considered
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Over the protests of Gov. Mark Sanfords lawyers, South Carolina lawmakers on Tuesday began the preliminary steps of a process that could lead to the governors impeachment and removal from office.

title: Ski Patrol | Whet Your Whistler
description: The hordes wont descend on Whistler and Blackcomb mountains until February, when the 21st Winter Olympic Games get under way. But the event has spurred a renaissance in the British Columbia resort town that the rest of us can enjoy before  and long after  the pros have come and gone.

title: Right Anglo
description: Camden Passage, a narrow, stone-paved street in Londons Islington neighborhood, was once one of the citys main antiques hubs, home to more than 350 shops. But in 2001, trading in antiques hit a wall, as one local proprietor put it, and businesses shut down or moved away. Then slowly the street came back to life, with a restaurant here, a chocolate shop there. (And not without controversy, as many Passage settlers feared that newcomers would mean higher rents.) Now Camden Passage has fully diversified, with a mix of stylish new shops and restaurants snug against the handful of antiques stores that held on.

title: Atlas Shrugged
description: Artists have toyed with maps before  theres Salvador Dals Surrealist Map of the World and Jasper Johnss splotchy sendup of the Lower 48, for starters. But The Map as Art (Princeton Architectural Press; $45), a new coffee table curiosity by Katharine Harmon, shows how much traction the idea has with artists today. Theres been an exponential increase in map-related art in gallery and museum shows. Harmon says. The reason, I think, is that this is a time when were all disoriented. Instead of collecting real maps, she compiled more than 350 works that deal with representations of place: Maya Lins Baltic birch plywood sculpture of the Caspian Sea, Ruth Watsons globe made of animal tissue (with Antarctica done in brains), Vik Munizs six continents forged from old computer parts. Rand McNally seems a world away. [?][?][?] STEPHEN HEYMAN

title: Gentry Points
description: IN-STORE F. M. ALLEN Those in the know call Franklin, Tenn., just outside Nashville, the Malibu of Tennessee. A small city with a lot of spending power  thanks to locals with names like Keith, Nicole and Wynonna  Franklin recently got a boost with the arrival of Will Woodss mens-wear shop F. M. Allen. (He also has a New York store.) Woods calls the brand rugged yet elegant, just right for the genteel country life. RIMA SUQI

title: Bavarian Rhapsody
description: In 1914, The New York Times reported that Mary Portman, a freewheeling English aristocrat living in Germany, faced prison in Munich for unpaid debt on a lavish Arts and Crafts house in the Bavarian countryside. (British wartime laws prevented her from paying the $100,000 bill.)

title: Now Ticking Earth Watch
description: When Charles Darwin landed on the Galpagos Islands in 1835, the 19 islands had a few hundred settlers. Today, the 30,000 people who live there pose a threat to its fragile biodiversity. In an effort to help pause time, if not reverse it, the Swiss watchmaker IWC Schaffhausen has pledged $500,000 per year to the Galpagos conservation group the Charles Darwin Foundation, and to raise awareness has created the Aquatimer Chronograph Edition Galpagos Islands ($6,500). Its one of six new divers watches in the Aquatimer family, which was born in 1967  the same year tour groups first visited the islands. [?][?][?] JOSEPH PLAMBECK

title: Talk
description: Value/ (val y) /n. / A principle or quality that someone holds dear. In the world of travel, value is often used in its monetary sense (i.e., a good experience at the right price), but increasingly it speaks to an even more important trend: people choosing trips that tie into their personal value systems, as in,We went to Tobago for our beach vacation because it reflects our values  local ownership, ecological preservation, sustainable development.

title: Oriole Kooky
description: Barack Obama, microphone in hand, stares off into the distance of a nearly empty room, a bemused grin on his face that seems to say, Where is everybody? Suddenly, a woman beelinesto the president, climbs to join him on his platform  theres no security around to stop her  and leans in for a kiss. The guy shes with laughs and says, Dont mess up his face! before snapping a picture. Im at the National Great Blacks in Wax Museum in Baltimore, where Obama recently joined figures like Colin Powell, Zora Neale Hurston and Malcolm X, amid three floors of displays.

title: Duly Noted
description: When I quit my job to work on a novel, my partner, Adam, agreed to support me  which was great, until his birthday loomed on the horizon. I didnt exactly relish buying him presents with his own money. Id have to get creative, but my last artsy phase ended in college, notwithstanding a glass-blowing workshop that yielded a pair of dysmorphic paperweights. Then I remembered our collection of hotel notepads.

title: White Party
description: Correction Appended

title: Miami Social
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Brand New Heavies
description: In addition to real-estate-market chaos, Miamis construction boom also ushered in nine important new hotels. From boutique to behemoth, these new properties all have one thing in common: vacancies.

title: Cuba Libre
description: Nowhere in Miami is the Latino flavor as strong as in Little Havana. The long, sometimes chaotic Calle Ocho (SW Eighth Street) is the neighborhoods heart  and not for the unprepared. Heres a primer:

title: Chino Latino
description: A host of high-end Asian restaurants have opened around town in recent months  almost as many as the citys dozens of divey but delicious Latino-food joints. Here, a dish-by-dish comparison of Miamis two great international cuisines, and where to sample the best of each.

title: The Late Show
description: If New York is the city that never sleeps, then Miami just disco-naps. Whatever your idea of a party, theres a spot to boogie or imbibe right through to breakfast.

title: Prep School
description: BOOKS Miami Babylon: Crime, Wealth, and Power  A Dispatch From the Beach, by Gerald Posner (Simon & Schuster, 2009). An in-depth history of one of the weirdest cities in the world. Fools Paradise: Players, Poseurs, and the Culture of Excess in South Beach, by Steven Gaines (Crown, 2009). A snapshot of the vibrant characters  love them or loathe them  who made Miami Beach what it is today.

title: ABC Drops Adam Lambert, and CBS Picks Him Up
description: Two days after giving a sexually charged performance at the American Music Awards, the singer Adam Lambert found himself abruptly dropped by one network morning show and just as abruptly booked on another.

title: Emperor Jones to Transfer Off Broadway
description: The reign of The Emperor Jones continues. The Irish Repertory Theaters production of that Eugene ONeill play will transfer Off Broadway to the Soho Playhouse next month, its press representatives said on Tuesday. The play, which stars John Douglas Thompson as Brutus Jones, the prison convict turned island autocrat, will have a seven-week run at the Soho Playhouse, with previews scheduled to begin on Dec. 15 and an opening night set for Dec. 22. The production, directed by Ciaran OReilly, is slated to end its run at the Irish Rep on Dec. 6.

title: This Is Your No-Hitter on Drugs
description: Animation |  An animated retelling of Dock Elliss legendary 1970 LSD no-hitter. The creators say the narration comes from an NPR interview the former major league pitcher gave a year before his death last December.

title: Real Estate Executive Returns to Morgan Stanley
description: Devin Murphy has returned to Morgan Stanleys real estate division five years after he left to run Deutsche Banks real estate investment banking division. Mr. Murphy will serve as a managing director and vice chairman in the investment banking division of the firm.

title: From McSweeneys, Part Newspaper and Part Ode to Newspapers
description: Due out on Dec. 8, the publication San Francisco Panorama promises to be part newspaper, part extravagant ode to newspapers. The 320-page broadsheet will include a magazine, food and art sections, comics and fiction, a 96-page book section and work by notable writers like Michael Chabon, Stephen King, Andrew Sean Greer, William T. Vollmann and Junot Daz.

title: Chris Bangle Recalls Controversial BMW 7 Series Design
description: Since leaving BMWs top design post in March, Chris Bangle has been uncharacteristically quiet and out of the spotlight. He has been renovating a house near Turin, Italy, and setting up a design consultancy. But recently he emerged to speak at an event for the Wolfsonian-Florida International University Museum in Miami.

title: GLAAD Reacts to Adam Lambert Controversy
description: Following the announcements on Tuesday that Adam Lambert had been dropped as a performer on ABCs Good Morning America and subsequently booked as a guest on CBSs Early Show, the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation has issued the following statement from its president, Jarrett Barrios:

title: The N.F.I.B. Reconsiders Credit Card Reform
description: A couple of weeks ago, The Agenda reported that a measure intended to extend recently enacted consumer credit card protections to small business borrowers had been stymied by none other than the chair of the House Small Business Committee, Representative Nydia Velzquez. But Ms. Velzquez was not the only small-business advocate reluctant to get on board: The National Federation of Independent Business also declined to endorse the latest effort, a bill proposed by Representative Neil Abercrombie, of Hawaii.

title: Facebook Will Form 2 Classes of Stock
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook is taking a rudimentary step down the path to becoming a public company.

title: Dancing to the Top
description: For the sixth time in seven weeks, ABC earned the most viewers on Monday night as Dancing With the Stars drew a season best: 20.5 million from 8 to 9:30 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. But that reality shows ratings could not lift the debut of ABCs new comedy Find My Family (12.9 million) ahead of its 9:30 competitor, The Big Bang Theory on CBS (14.2 million). CBS also won the 10 p.m. hour with CSI: Miami (13.2 million), which easily outperformed both Castle (10.5 million) on ABC and The Jay Leno Show on NBC (4.5 million). CBS was runner-up on the night, garnering strong ratings at 9 for Two and a Half Men (13.9 million). Fox was third and NBC was fourth.

title: Curtains Are Drawn at the Gosselin House
description: For now, well will see the Gosselin children only in repeats. About 4.3 million viewers watched the final installment of Jon & Kate Plus 8 on Monday, Nielsen said; it was the end of the TLC series about the Gosselin twins and sextuplets and their parents, Jon and Kate Gosselin. Millions of new viewers flocked to TLC as the parents marriage unraveled earlier this year, temporarily creating a reality-TV sensation that some critics said was exploitative of the young children. The dispute between the Gosselins led to dueling lawsuits and a halt in production that all but forced TLC to pull the plug. Its sad its cut short, Ms. Gosselin said on the episode that was shown Monday. Its been a great run. TLC had planned to produce a new show, Kate Plus Eight, with a limited role for Mr. Gosselin, but the lawsuits have placed that idea on hold. The channel is still developing a separate project with Ms. Gosselin. It has not announced details, but the program is scheduled to have its premiere in the spring.

title: A Hanging Locomotive Needs a Rich Friend
description: A train that is supposed to go nowhere seems to be going nowhere, at least for now. Plans by the artist Jeff Koons and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art to create an eye-popping piece of public art, a 70-foot replica of a 1943 locomotive engine designed to dangle nose-down from a 161-foot crane  are in limbo because the museum cannot pay for it, Bloomberg reported. The sculpture, estimated at $25 million, shown at right in a model, was expected to be completed in 2011 or 2012 in the museums entrance plaza. But the museum said the project had been pushed to 2014-15 because of the damage the economic downturn had done to its finances. Figures recently released show that its investment portfolio lost nearly a quarter of its value during the 2008-9 fiscal year, shrinking to $196 million from $254 million the previous year. Barbara Pflaumer, the museums associate vice president for communications and marketing, speaking of Mr. Koonss engine project, told Bloomberg: We wouldnt do it unless someone funds it. Someone has to write us a check. She added: This is a very tough economy. Everyone has revised timetables.

title: Singing, Leaping Spider-Man Goes for Help
description: Michael Cohl, the new lead producer of the Broadway musical project Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark, has approached Kevin McCollum and Jeffrey Seller, the Tony Award-winning producers of Broadway musicals and revivals including Avenue Q, La Bohme and Rent, about becoming producers of the show, according to three Broadway producers with knowledge of the conversations. The producers, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the conversations were private, said Mr. Cohls communications were in an initial phase and that Mr. McCollum and Mr. Seller did not have full financial details of the show. They have expertise in mounting large-cast shows (including Mr. McCollums new revival of Ragtime) and entertainment spectacles like Avenue Q, which features puppets. Spider-Man, which has had work stoppages this fall because of cash-flow problems that preceded Mr. Cohl, has been conceived as an extravaganza, complete with the S-Man himself swinging above the audience. Mr. Cohl, asked about Mr. McCollum and Mr. Seller in a telephone interview, said he was talking to a lot of people, and hoped to have news in December.

title: In Stock Shift, Facebook Lays Ground for I.P.O.
description: Facebook is taking a rudimentary step down the path to becoming a public company, The New York Timess Brad Stone reports from San Francisco.

title: Sharing Family Tales on Thanksgiving
description: At their core, families are collections of stories. As generations disappear and as relatives spend more time apart than together, what makes a family are shared histories, shared tales.

title: Urea Is Heading Out of Town
description: Alex Urea, who made a name for himself at Suba and Blue Hill, but couldnt make a go of it at his restaurants Urea and Pamplona, is heading to Philadelphia.

title: Kelsey Grammer Is in Talks for La Cage aux Folles
description: Kelsey Grammer, best known as the star of the former NBC hit Frasier, is in talks to play Georges in the coming Broadway revival of La Cage aux Folles, according to two executives involved in the production. The British actor Douglas Hodge is set to reprise his role as Albin from the current London production of the show. The executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity because no contract had been signed, said they were optimistic that Mr. Grammer would be on board in the role, which was played by Robin Williams in the 1996 movie adaptation, The Birdcage.

title: Report Aims to Clarify Climate Risk for Diplomats
description: A team of climate scientists, seeking to remind the negotiators who will hammer out a new climate treaty of what is at stake, has produced The Copenhagen Diagnosis, a summary of the latest peer-reviewed science on the anticipated impacts of human-driven global warming. In an interview, Richard Somerville, a climatologist at the University of California, San Diego, and a past contributor to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said the case for climate change as a serious risk to human affairs was clear, despite recent firestorms over some data sets and scientists actions.

title: Not Pictured: African-American Customers
description: I am a consultant on the redesign of the Web site of a company with local franchises across the United States. A franchisee in San Diego mentioned that posting a generic picture of an African-American customer could deter potential business. He has never had an African-American client nor does he anticipate one. His clientele is 70 percent white, 29 percent Hispanic and 1 percent Asian. Each local office will have a Web page and could have its own generic customer photo. May race be a factor in choosing it? TERRY KAVANAUGH, BIRMINGHAM, MICH.

title: Extra, Extra
description: The buzz is building for McSweeneys Issue 33  or, as theyre calling it, The San Francisco Panorama, a Sunday-edition-sized newspaper with reporting from William Vollmann and Nicholson Baker, comics from Chris Ware and Daniel Clowes, and a book review section to make us advertising-based life forms jealous: 100-plus pages, including new fiction from George Saunders and a report about romance-novel cover models.

title: CNN Explains Policy on Political Consultants
description: CNN responded Tuesday to criticism about one of its political commentators, Alex Castellanos, by saying it maintained the same policy for him that it has had for other paid political analysts.

title: Lets Not Get Crazy, Now
description: Tuesday afternoon and realitys starting to kick in a little: those people related to you are preparing to come to your house, expecting to be fed. Those friends you invited because? Theyre coming too. Day after tomorrow. Its time. Dont lose it now.

title: In Mumbai, Reinforcing a Resilient Spirit
description: Mumbai, India  Divya Thakur, the founder of Design Temple, a product, furniture and graphics firm based in Mumbai, lives in a three-bedroom three-bathroom apartment behind the Taj Mahal Palace & Tower hotel. A year ago, the hotel and several other city landmarks were the targets of terrorist attacks. Some people living so close to such tragedy and violence may have considered moving, but Mumbai and its people are known for their hardy spirit. Ms. Thakur, 38, didnt let it faze her.

title: What You Get for ... $300,000
description: STUYVESANT, N.Y.

title: Inhofe Seeks Probe of Climate Science
description: After hackers obtained and disclosed the e-mail correspondence of numerous prominent climate scientists last week, Senator James Inhofe of Oklahoma, the most outspoken global warming skeptic in Congress, said Tuesday that hed begun an investigation into what he alleges to be the manipulation of global warming research.

title: With New Route, Thanksgiving Parade Gets a Few New Twists
description: Three hundred extra steps. Three extra turns. Two new avenues.

title: Confirmed Black Friday Phone Deals
description: With Black Friday on the horizon, the seasonal deals are begging to leak out. Here are some of the Friday phone offers I have confirmed.

title: Magazine Publishers to Build an Online Newsstand
description: A consortium of magazine publishers including Time Inc. and Cond Nast are jointly building an online newsstand for magazines in multiple digital formats, according to people familiar with the plans.

title: A Widget for Sky-High Wi-Fi
description: Airlines have made it easy for travelers to do just about everything on line except reserve seats for Red Sox games, and now American has added a new twist for flyers with laptop computers.

title: Zagat Releases 2009 Airline Survey
description: If there was any less legroom, Id have to check my legs, said one reviewer. Another wrote, Should I have to pay extra for my knees?

title: A Story So Complicated It Needs Two Playwrights
description: The Trojan War, the monumental conflict that spanned a decade (doesnt seem so long at the moment, does it?) and has inspired artists for a few millenniums, essentially boils down to a lot of smack talked in a sandbox in The Age of Iron, a labored epic adapted and directed by Brian Kulick for the Classic Stage Company from two separate plays from the early 17th century.

title: Bay Bridge Shows Literal Signs of Life
description: The Bay Bridge never ceases to preoccupy Bay Area minds. In the extreme, The Chronicle wrote yesterday, bad thoughts about the bridge may seriously affect your life by forcing some to take the long way around (an extra 16 miles) every time they want to go from the city to the East Bay or Oakland to the West Bay (as some in Oakland call San Francisco).

title: Pixies Celebrate Milestone for Fans of a Cult Album
description: Doolittle, a 1989 album by the Pixies, is an arty, violent, candy-striped record. It has surf musics reverb serenity, backed by cool and steady-drip eighth-note rhythm patterns. Its singing comes in babbles, yells and coos, its lyrics in drownings, bleedings and hangings. Compressed into short songs, those eerie elements become eerier still.

title: State Dinner: List of Attendees
description: Approximately 300 people were expected to attend Tuesday night's state dinner in honor of Manmohan Singh, the prime minister of India. The following list of attendees was released by the White House:

title: A Three-Bedroom Apartment in Mumbai
description: Divya Thakur, the founder of the Design Temple, created her own rendition of an Indian courtyard, with plenty of natural light.

title: Spare Change for Homeless? Cuomo Sees a Sham and Sues
description: In Manhattan, they are as common a sight as the homeless themselves: the United Homeless Organizations street-corner donation tables, operated with little more than a large plastic jug and a worker pleading for coins and bills for the needy.

title: 1 New Car = 30 Vacations
description: In honor of the approaching holiday shopping season, Dan Ariely, a behavioral economics professor at Duke, explains how to think about your purchases in terms of opportunity costs. He also offers a few tips for ways to become a more conscientious penny-pincher:

title: Rihanna: Fiercely Introspective
description: LOS ANGELES  Barf! Rihanna squealed, at the sight of a pair of pale pink satin Brian Atwood stilettos. In her world this is a compliment. Usually its ill or I want to throw up on it, she explained. But barf is the worst, meaning the best. Barf is 10 out of 10.

title: Philippine Government Blamed for Creating Monster to Battle Insurgents
description: As more bodies were recovered after a massacre on Monday on the Philippine island of Mindanao, bringing the death toll to 46, an expert on the region blamed the government of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo for arming the powerful clan accused of carrying out the killings in the countrys southern region.

title: When a Bombastic Young Man Bestrode the Boards of the Mercury Theater
description: The action in Me and Orson Welles takes place in 1937 during a single hectic week bookended by two moments of relative tranquillity in which a boy (Zac Efron) meets a girl (Zoe Kazan). In the films final scene, as they stroll out of the New York Public Library, the girl, an aspiring writer, bubbles with enthusiasm about the world of music, art and literature that seems to be opening up all around them. So much is going on! So much to be part of!

title: For Samsung, Its Black Week. But is it a Bargain?
description: Black Friday may come only once a year, but that day of seemingly extra-low prices is getting longer and longer. Samsung, Amazon, Costco, and others are now offering lower-than-usual prices for several days surrounding Thanksgiving.

title: The Remains of the Day
description: SUE MADEN was peeling and slicing apples for the double-crusted pie she planned to take as her contribution to dinner at a friends house, but a worry was nagging her.

title: The Urban Deerslayer
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.

title: Trailer: Borderlands
description: The combat shooter game, developed by Gearbox Software and published by 2K Games for the PlayStation 3, Xbox 360 and Windows, is not edifying but it is hardly mindless either.

title: House Hunting in ... Germany
description: A SIX-BEDROOM 17TH-CENTURY HOUSE IN HATTINGEN

title: Hero Who Cant Keep His Shirt On
description: The best thing about Ninja Assassin is its refreshingly honest title: unlike those few, unwary souls who rush to Precious solely on the strength of its twee title and happy-go-lucky television trailers, no one who sees Ninja Assassin can reasonably complain about the violence.

title: Power and Style, in the Ring and the World
description: In the late 1930s, when he was still an amateur fighter, Sugar Ray Robinson began lugging an old Victrola record player around with him on the road. Hed bring a stack of records too, the good stuff: some Jelly Roll Morton and Duke Ellington and Fats Waller.

title: The Thrills in the Gunplay, With Lots of Guns to Play With
description: People go through life looking for different things. Some want money. Others crave fame or are driven by sex. Many are motivated by family. And a few just want love.

title: Chief of I.M.F. Urges Continued Stimulus Efforts
description: PARIS  The chief of the International Monetary Fund urged the worlds major economies on Tuesday to retain their economic stimulus programs until there were durable signs of a recovery, including an end to rising unemployment.

title: The Insider | Luis Venegas
description: The Insider profiles emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, Luis Venegas, the Madrid-based publishing phenom behind the magazines Fanzine137 and Electric Youth, shares his essentials. Last week, Venegas introduced Candy, which is billed as the worlds first transversal (a catchall for transvestism, transsexualism and androgyny) style magazine. The cover features Luke Worral, a k a Mr. Kelly Osbourne, in drag.

title: A Bit Mangy, but Up for New Tricks
description: To describe the knockabout family comedy Old Dogs as a ramshackle mess doesnt begin to evoke the confusion and sloppy continuity of a movie whose disconnected parts sometimes appear to have been randomly assembled from a cutting-room scrap heap. Chaos reigns, the apocalyptic catchphrase from Lars von Triers Antichrist, might be more accurate. Even those professional charmers John Travolta and Robin Williams have their hands full trying to infuse some levity into their stick-figure characters.

title: Triathletes, on Your Mark ...Whoa!
description: RICK MOTTER remembers the first twinge.

title: Teenage Hero Wears His Powers on His Wrist
description: MTV and VH1 gave up on music. The Learning Channel gave up on learning. Lately, Cartoon Network has been giving up on cartoons. Chunks of its schedule are consigned to nonanimated fare like Survive This (Survivor for teenagers), The Othersiders (Ghost Hunters for teenagers) or Dude, What Would Happen? (Mythbusters for teenagers).

title: Phone Deals From a Store You Have Never Heard Of
description: Traditionally, mobile phone carriers like T-Mobile, AT&T, Verizon and Sprint dont offer many Black Friday specials. After all, phones arent especially seasonal, and if youve got a two-year contract, unless you purchased the phone during the holidays originally, youre not in the market now.

title: A Voce Columbus
description: THERE are two A Voce restaurants in New York City. One opened in 2006, off Madison Square Park. It is dark and almost romantic, loud when crowded, pretty after a fashion, perfectly good. The other opened in September on the third floor of the Time Warner Center, in the space that used to be Caf Gray. The second restaurant is bright and airy, loud when crowded, pretty after a fashion, also perfectly good.

title: That Old Bayou Magic: Kiss and Ribbit (and Sing)
description: Its not easy being green, the heroine of The Princess and the Frog discovers. But to judge from how this polished, hand-drawn movie addresses, or rather strenuously avoids, race, it is a lot more difficult to be black, particularly in a Disney animated feature. If you havent heard: Disney, the company that immortalized pale pretties like Snow White and the zip-a-dee-doo-dah of plantation living in Song of the South, has made a fairy tale about a black heroine, a character whose shoulders and story prove far too slight for all the hopes already weighing her down. Its no wonder shes soon jumping into the bayou, green legs and all.

title: With Stents Help, Medtronics Profit Increases 59%
description: Medtronic, a maker of heart rhythm devices, said its quarterly profit rose 59 percent, helped by sales of a new heart stent, and it raised its forecast for full-year earnings.

title: The State Dinner Guest List
description: The official guest list is out. Many of the names have already leaked out  Katie Couric, for example, sent the news out herself hours ago via Twitter  but the roster released by the White House contains several names not previously known.

title: A.I.G. Moves Ahead With Pay Package for Chief
description: The American International Group said Tuesday that it had moved ahead with a previously announced compensation package for its new chief executive, Robert H. Benmosche, giving him $7 million in cash and stock, after he reaffirmed his commitment to stay at the bailed-out insurance company.

title: Closer to the Bone
description: Urban food lovers learn how to hunt, butcher and cook venison in a class called "Deer Hunting for Locavores" taught in Charlottesville, Va.

title: 3rd M.V.P. Puts Pujols in Select Company
description: Albert Pujols said he does not think about his place in history. But whether he worries about it or not, he has already entered velvet-rope territory, a realm occupied by the sports elite.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,356 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

title: A Bed Where Comfort Is Not the Point
description: STOCKHOLM  A Hindu spirit is stalking the streets of Stockholm, armed with this Nordic capitals latest fad: the nail bed.

title: Bills Bar and Burger
description: Bills Bar and Burger

title: Gulluoglu
description: Gulluoglu

title: Indias Guard Is Up, but Weaknesses Remain
description: MUMBAI, India  A year after the deadly assault here by Pakistan-based militants that killed 163 people, this sprawling mega-city is a more cautious and safer place, but it remains vulnerable despite government pledges to overhaul security.

title: App of the Week: TGI Black Friday
description: I have a friend who awaits the annual e-mailing of the Black Friday Excel Spreadsheet with greater anticipation than the gifts that may come from it. The coveted list is a compilation of leaked deals coming up on the Friday after Thanksgiving.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Sushi Class With Sake

title: Off the Menu
The Word of Mouth
description: Remember restaurants? I review them for a living, when Im not answering readers questions about cooking for the forthcoming Thanksgiving holiday. This week I write about A Voce Columbus. Its an Italian place on the third floor of the Time Warner Center, an uptown version of the A Voce off Madison Square Park where Andrew Carmellini was chef. Mr. Carmellini left before the new restaurant opened (hes now at Locanda Verde); the chef at both A Voce restaurants is Missy Robbins. Shes very good  better perhaps than the stage upon which she cooks. Have you been to either A Voce? To both of them? Which do you prefer? Lets talk about food this week, restaurant locations and the culture of dining out. Post a comment below.

title: Putting Her Baking Skills to the Test
description: When ciabatta, the chewy yet airy Italian bread, became a food trend in New York 15 years ago, Sarah Black, above, was busy turning the loaves out at her company, Campanio, in Queens. She sold the bakery 10 years ago and is now in charge of the baking at Fairway markets. She is training the stores 30 bakers in her artisanal techniques, like being picky about ingredients and hand-shaping breads. They are now baking muffins, scones, cookies, brownies and yes, ciabatta, and have turned out 12,000 Thanksgiving pies.

title: Potato Tortillas
description: EDER MONTERO would like to set one thing straight regarding potato tortillas: they should not be as brown as, well, a plate of hash browns.

title: A Pretzel Shop With a Zesty Twist
description: Lina Kulchinsky, a lawyer turned pastry chef, did not want to open an everyday bakery. One day her husband brought her a pretzel from a street cart and an idea clicked.

title: Comfort in a Pot
description: Steaming bowls sustain body and soul in the cold months. Your grandmother probably knew how to fill this need and the Japanese certainly do, as Tadashi Ono and Harris Salat so deftly demonstrate in Japanese Hot Pots: Comforting One Pot Meals (Ten Speed Press, $25).

title: Lou Dobbs Weighs Senate Run, as a Steppingstone
description: The Lou Dobbs-for-Senate rumor had barely crested when the Lou Dobbs-for-president rumor suddenly overtook it this week.

title: Modern Flourishes at Obamas State Dinner
description: WASHINGTON  It is an old tradition, a White House dinner governed by ritual and protocol that happens to be this citys hottest social event. But at their first state dinner on Tuesday night, President Obama and his wife, Michelle, made sure to infuse the glittering gala with distinctive touches.

title: Obama Writes to Brazils Leader About Iran
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  President Obama sent a letter on Sunday to President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva of Brazil reiterating the American position on Irans nuclear program, a day before Irans president made his first state visit to Brazil, an aide to Mr. da Silva said Tuesday.

title: Citation for Gesture Costs Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH  The City of Pittsburgh has agreed to pay $50,000 to a man who sued after being issued a disorderly conduct citation for gesturing offensively at a police officer.

title: Bar Owner Stood Firm and Won Lower Fees
description: SYDNEY  The Merivale Group, Sydneys largest operator of upscale restaurants and bars, sees itself as the company that fought American Express and won.

title: Schumer Faults Adidas for Overseas Production
description: Adidas is planning to move most production of N.B.A. players official jerseys and shorts out of the United States, managers of the main factory producing the gear said on Tuesday.

title: Washington Post to Shut U.S. Bureaus
description: The Washington Post will close its last three remaining national bureaus in a cost-cutting move, Kris Coratti, the papers director of communications, said Tuesday.

title: Cant Cut the Budget? Let Me Do It, Paterson Tells an Unmoved Legislature
description: ALBANY  New Yorks budget impasse will last at least another week.

title: Giants Find Something Elemental Is Missing
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Last season, the consistent strength of the Giants offense was a combination of three running backs known as Earth, Wind and Fire.

title: In Holiday Season Adjusted for Recession, Chicago Finds a Tree to Fit
description: CHICAGO  This citys Christmas tree, which by tradition will be lighted by Mayor Richard M. Daley on Wednesday, has already suffered slights.

title: Abe Pollin, Team Owner and Philanthropist, Dies at 85
description: Abe Pollin, the owner of the N.B.A.s Washington Wizards, who built the sports arena that revitalized downtown Washington and was known for his wide-ranging philanthropy, died Tuesday. He was 85.

title: A Pretty Darn Valuable Player
description: Chase Utley, the Philadelphia Phillies second baseman, might very well be considered the National Leagues best player but for the presence of Albert Pujols. Utley, who hit five home runs in the World Series, finished eighth in the voting for this years N.L. Most Valuable Player award, won by Pujols, and that is nothing new. He and Pujols are the only two players who have finished in the top 15 of the N.L. voting in each of the past five seasons. Pujols has three awards, Utley none.

title: Theodore Roosevelt IV Opts Out of G.O.P. Race for Senate
description: Few people knew that he was thinking about it in the first place, but Theodore Roosevelt IV, a wealthy investment banker with serious credentials on environmental issues and in foreign policy  and of course, that famous name  now says he will not seek the Republican nomination for the Senate from New York in 2010.

title: Johnson and Damon, a Nascar Fan, Share a Victory Lap in Manhattan
description: Less than 48 hours after winning an unprecedented fourth consecutive Nascar Sprint Cup championship in Homestead, Fla., Jimmie Johnson took a private elevator Tuesday to the observation deck of the Empire State Building with Johnny Damon, the stock-car racing fan (and Yankees left fielder).

title: Contenders Are Circling, Even Before Fight Is Set
description: The calls started two days after Manny Pacquiao bloodied and battered Miguel Cotto to capture his record seventh title in seven weight divisions. They came from representatives of sites across the country, from stadiums in Los Angeles, Texas, Louisiana and New York.

title: Seeking Deals, Holiday Fliers Get Early Start
description: CHICAGO  Airports big and small will be packed on Wednesday, just as they are every year on the day before Thanksgiving.

title: Mets Complete Coaching Staff
description: A busy day in Mets-land on Tuesday. No, they didnt make any trades or sign any free agents. Rather, they announced a new retro pinstripe home uniform and completed the coaching staff that will assist Jerry Manuel in 2010.

title: From the Hospital to Bankruptcy Court
description: NASHVILLE  Some of the debtors sitting forlornly in this citys old stone bankruptcy court have lost a job or gotten divorced. Others have been summoned to face their creditors because they spent mindlessly beyond their means. But all too often these days, they are there merely because they, or their children, got sick.

title: After Some Requests, Bruno Jury Chooses to Reconvene Monday
description: ALBANY  After one day of deliberation, the jury in the corruption trial of Joseph L. Bruno, the former State Senate majority leader, left the federal courthouse here on Tuesday without reaching a verdict, and opted to resume on Monday.

title: When Dreams Take Flight
description: Weston, Conn.

title: James Berg, Landlords Peacemaker, Dies at 65
description: James F. Berg, who as the chief negotiator for most of New York Citys major landlords was given large credit for an era of labor peace in their buildings because of the trust he inspired on both sides of the bargaining table, died Nov. 18 in Manhattan. He was 65 and lived in Bay Shore, N.Y.

title: Even in Recession, Some Small Businesses Grow
description: Many small businesses have found themselves treading water, at best, during the recession. But, that is not true for everyone. In fact, a significant minority of resilient companies have been able to do the seemingly impossible and increase revenue in these troubled times. According to a recent survey of 300 small-business clients conducted by SurePayroll, a payroll service based in Chicago, about 30 percent of respondents said their sales increased over the last year.

title: N.F.L. Head Injury Study Leaders Quit
description: In the latest indication that the National Football League will redirect its approach to players concussions, the co-chairmen of the leagues committee on brain injuries resigned from the group Tuesday, the league announced.

title: Housekeeping
description: UrbanEye will be in a food coma until (at least) Friday, and will return on Monday. And when it does, it will have new hands on deck: Melena Ryzik will be off bagging carpets, and the inimitable Julie Bloom will be taking over e-mail duties. Send her a wink at urbaneye@nytimes.com.

title: Breaking It Down
description: There has never been anything on Broadway, writes Ben Brantley, like Fela! about the Nigerian musical revolutionary Fela Anikulapo-Kuti. Choreographed and conceived by Bill T. Jones, produced by Jay-Z and Jada Pinkett Smith, this musical throbs with a stirring newness that is not to be confused with novelty, Mr. Brantley writes. In transferring from Off Broadway, it acquired greater focus, clarity and intensity, but its Afrobeat sound, as performed by Antibalas still makes you want to dance in the street. Get your tickets now.

title: Brush With Greatness
description: Me and Orson Welles, the story of a teenager (Zac Efron, avec hair) who encounters Welles at work in a theater in 1937, is necessary viewing for anyone whose imagination has been seduced by the charms of art, writes A.O. Scott. Directed by Richard Linklater, the movie deals with some classic scenarios: boy meets girl, the vagaries of backstage life and the fun of having an oversize ego. Art is a fairy tale we choose to believe in, Mr. Scott writes, and this movie, a fiction confected about real people, is too good not to be true.

title: Pre-Feast Fete
description: You may not be able to volunteer on Thanksgiving, but you can party on Thanksgiving eve. Head to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, tonight for a proper warehouse party courtesy of MeanRed. There will be D.J.s and drinks and, you know, space  all the things you wont get when you visit your family.

title: Notre Dame Athletic Director Welcomes the Glare
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  As dusk gave way to darkness here Saturday night, Athletic Director Jack Swarbrick sang the alma mater on the field at Notre Dame Stadium in the aftermath of the Fighting Irishs double-overtime loss to UConn.

title: Afghan Strategy Will Contain Messages to Several Audiences
description: WASHINGTONIn declaring Tuesday that he would finish the job in Afghanistan, President Obama used a phrase clearly meant to imply that even as he deploys an additional 30,000 or so troops, he has finally figured out how to bring the eight-year-long conflict to an end.

title: These Rates Would Shock a Loan Shark
description: Just in time for Thanksgiving last year, a credit card offer arrived in the mail. The (introductory) rate was 2 percent. Malcolm S. jumped. A student at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn, Malcolm was looking after the affairs of a grandfather in a nursing home.

title: Uzbekistan: Opposition Leader Sent to U.S. After Early Release From Prison
description: Sanjar Umarov, an Uzbek opposition leader imprisoned on charges that his supporters said were fabricated, returned to freedom in the United States over the weekend. Mr. Umarov, who led the Sunshine Uzbekistan opposition movement, was granted amnesty and released from a labor camp on Nov. 7. His wife and three of his children are American citizens, and he is recuperating at a family home in Tennessee, his family said. After the crackdown on antigovernment demonstrators in Andijon in 2005, Mr. Umarov emerged as a vocal critic of President Islam A. Karimov. He was arrested that fall and charged with tax fraud and other violations and was sentenced to more than 12 years in prison. His lawyers and family said he was tortured and perhaps drugged during the trial. His release followed extensive lobbying by his family, human rights groups and the American government.

title: Crack Pipes Found After Fire That Hurt Ex-Knicks Player
description: Fire marshals are investigating whether crack pipes discarded in a Bronx row house played a part in sparking a fire on Sunday that critically injured Dean Meminger, a former player for the New York Knicks.

title: California Takes Step to Limit Emissions
description: WASHINGTON  California has taken a major step toward creating a broad-based trading system to limit emissions of pollutants blamed for harmful climate change.

title: Galleon Chief Attacks Governments Case Against Him
description: Five weeks after he was arrested on charges of masterminding a vast insider-trading scheme, Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire money manager, answered his accusers on Tuesday with a sharp-edged attack on the governments case against him.

title: Lottery Numbers
An Evolve-By Date
description: Yesterday, Tuesday, Nov. 24, was The Big Day: it was exactly 150 years since Charles Darwins On the Origin of Species was first published. In this book, Darwin described how evolution by natural selection works  and presented a huge body of evidence, drawn from every field of biology then known, that evolution can account for the patterns we see in nature.

title: Poland: Former Leader Sues President
description: Lech Walesa, Polands former president and leader of the Solidarity movement, took President Lech Kaczynski to court on Tuesday. Mr. Walesa is seeking about $36,000 in damages over Mr. Kaczynskis charge that Mr. Walesa collaborated with the state secret service under Communism. Neither man was in court. The proceedings were adjourned until Dec. 18, the newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reported on its Web site. A court cleared Mr. Walesa in 2000 of the persistent charge that he had worked as an agent known as Bolek for the secret police.

title: Counting Blessings
description: A fire, deliberately set, at Hope for the Future Ministries in East Farmingdale, N.Y., took away a reliable source of food for the needy in Manhattan and on Long Island. But word of the fire brought in a host of donations.

title: Same Team, Dressed Differently
description: First minor league coaches, then planters with orange and blue flowers, and now new old uniforms: The Mets havent signed any players this off-season, but they are busy nonetheless.

title: Nets Have Dug a Big Hole, but Their Foundation Is in Place
description: The Nets have lost their first 14 games in a start that is threatening to make their season irrelevant before the calendar turns to 2010. The long-term future, however, looks a lot brighter.

title: On The Biggest Loser, Health Can Take Back Seat
description: LOS ANGELES  When more than 40 former contestants from The Biggest Loser gather Wednesday for a reunion television special, the winner of the programs first season, Ryan C. Benson, who lost 122 of his 330-pound starting weight, will be absent. Mr. Benson is now back above 300 pounds but he thinks he has been shunned by the show because he publicly admitted that he dropped some of the weight by fasting and dehydrating himself to the point that he was urinating blood.

title: Toasts by the President and the Prime Minister
description: Following is a transcript of toasts by President Obama and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India at the state dinner on Nov. 24, provided by the White House.

title: M*A*S*H Extra
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  There was a recent discussion among some crossword constructors about how to clue the word NURSE. Past descriptions have included Surgeons assistant or M*A*S*H extra. The former clue seems to relegate the nurse to a mere supporting role. The latter is particularly troublesome because in both the movie and the TV show, some of the main characters were nurses and extras could be found with any job description. The implication was that all this was borderline demeaning to a noble profession and perhaps even sexist. (Constructors are overwhelmingly male. Solvers, as far as I can tell, split more or less evenly.)

title: Redevelopment Project Doubles as Social Experiment
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  This city of elegant luxury condominium towers and grand public spaces won the right to hold the 2010 Winter Olympic Games in part because of a promise to create the inclusive Olympics. But critics have long complained about a blotch on the citys self-image as an urban utopia: the Downtown Eastside, a notorious high-poverty neighborhood known for its concentration of homeless people and drug and crime problems.

title: Independent Skype Set for Executive Shakeup
description: Last week, Skype became a newly independent company, formally separating from its parent of the last four years, eBay. Now the Internet phone company, with major offices in Luxembourg and London, is set for a significant reorganization of its management team.

title: Overcoming Fire and Ice, a Food Pantry Perseveres
description: When a church food pantry burns down 10 days before Thanksgiving, many problems arise  most of them bad, a few of them good, though problems just the same.

title: Holiday on Thursday: Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article on Saturday about an increase in test preparation programs for New York City preschoolers misstated the occupation of Meredith Resnick of Bright Kids NYC, who helped a 3-year-old with a visual analogy, and referred incorrectly to Robin MacFarlane, who said she expected to sell more than a thousand prep kits for a reasoning exam this year. Ms. Resnick is a supervisor of tutors, not a tutor herself, and Dr. MacFarlane developed a test study system for kindergartners; she does not work for Thinking to Learn, a company that sells enrichment materials.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about President Obamas strategy for committing more American troops to the war in Afghanistan misidentified the office held by Angela Merkel of Germany, whose country supplies troops for the American-led coalition. She is chancellor, not prime minister.

title: Q. & A. With Jack Swarbrick
description: Notre Dame Athletic Director Jack Swarbrick talked to Pete Thamel of The Times. Here is a transcript of the interview.

title: Official Charged With Closing Guantnamo Quits
description: WASHINGTON  The Defense Department official in charge of closing the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, has resigned after only seven months in the job, the Pentagon said Tuesday.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Habs Tattoo Blue Jackets
description: Only one game on Tuesday night, and it was hardly a classic matchup: the Canadiens, with their grim 3-11-9 regulation record, playing host to the Blue Jackets, who had taken at least a point from eight of their previous 10 games. Unfortunately, the Jacks two fruitless outings were a 9-1 loss at home to Detroit and a 7-4 loss in New York on Monday.

title: Budget Hawks Have a Buffet of Options With Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the second round of the rain-shortened L.P.G.A. Tour Championship in Richmond, Tex., misidentified the home state of Kristy McPherson, who was the leader in the clubhouse after play was suspended on Sunday. McPherson was born in Conway, S.C., and now lives in Tampa, Fla.; she is not a Texan.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits and schedule information on Tuesday with a review of Fela! at the Eugene ONeill Theater misstated the timing of its run. It is open-ended; it is not scheduled to close on April 4.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Escapes pages on Friday about theater in Seattle, where the playwright August Wilson lived for more than a decade and worked at the Seattle Repertory Theater, misstated the history of the production of his 10-play cycle about African-American life in the 20th century. The Seattle Repertory Theater is not the only one in the nation to have produced the entire cycle. The article also misstated the name of one of the small and midsize theaters that have closed in Seattle. It was the Empty Space Theater, not the Empty Stage.

title: Corrections
Spotlight on Schwarzeneggers No. 2
description: It was the type of Must See TV that NBC was no doubt hoping for when it handed over its 10 p.m. slot to Jay Leno. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, a big star facing an even bigger state deficit, was there on the Leno show on Monday, smiling, as he announced his selection for lieutenant governor.

title: State Courts at the Tipping Point
description: State courts are not just another government agency. They are at the center of the nations legal system and enforcement of the rule of law, handling more than 95 percent of all civil and criminal litigation. This vital institution  constitutionally, an independent, co-equal branch of government  has been spiraling into crisis as cash-starved states struggle with huge deficits.

title: Keeping Personal Data Private
description: In 2006, a Veterans Affairs Department analyst lost a laptop and external drive with Social Security numbers and other personal data from more than 26 million veterans and active duty troops. There was a national call for a federal law to protect this sort of data  as there has been after other big data breaches  but nothing was done. Finally, a bill is moving in the Senate that would put more protections in place for personal data.

title: Dont Forget the Gulf States
description: The recession has wreaked a special kind of havoc in the Katrina-ravaged Gulf states, where the effort to rebuild housing for low-income workers and their families is in danger of coming to a halt. Unless Congress acts quickly, more than 70 different housing developments totaling more than 6,000 units might never get built. That would be terrible for the Gulf region, which needs a lot more affordable housing and a large low-wage work force to drive its recovery.

title: At Ao Nuevo Point
description: Something about a sea otter looks so insouciant. Drifting on its back, bobbing up and down in the waves, it looks over at the humans standing on the rocks as if to exaggerate its ease in the water, its complacent, buoyant virtuosity. There is not merely one sea otter here on the north side of the point at Ao Nuevo State Park, a couple of dozen miles north of Santa Cruz, Calif. There are perhaps 20 in sight, parents and young.

title: Fighting Hunger in Difficult Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Rep. Kennedy, Not Welcome to Receive Communion
description: To the Editor:

title: Governor Paterson and the 9/11 Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Thanks for the Memories
description: WASHINGTON

title: You Say Potato, I Say Yam
description: ON Oct. 3, 1863, President Abraham Lincoln declared the final Thursday of November to be a national holiday of Thanksgiving. That came just over a year after Lincoln made another more historic proclamation, one that directly concerned my family and their future: the Emancipation Proclamation, which had freed the enslaved in any territory in rebellion.

title: False Alarm on Abortion
description: Wellesley, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary and a headline on Saturday about Albert V. Crewe, the University of Chicago physicist who in 1970 designed an electron microscope that captured images of individual atoms, attributed a distinction to him erroneously. While he was indeed a pioneer in showing individual atoms, he was not the first physicist to do so. That feat had been accomplished at least once before, in 1955, when the Pennsylvania State University physicist Erwin Wilhelm Mller, with his graduate student Kanwar Bahadur, used a field ion microscope to view images of single atoms. Because of an editing error, the obituary also referred incorrectly to the Chicago Cyclotron, to which Dr. Crewe contributed. It did not contain superconducting components.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 8 with an obituary about Robert Rines, a scientist and inventor who pursued the Loch Ness monster, misstated the source of the photograph that he believed showed evidence of the monsters existence. It was taken automatically by a camera connected to a strobe-light system; it was not taken by his wife, Carol Rines.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Cheap and Cheerful for the Holidays
description: MADISON AVENUE is dancing the limbo for the holiday shopping season as advertisers ask each other, How low can you go?

title: Former Leader of Troopers Admits Guilt
description: ALBANY  One of four former Spitzer administration officials implicated in what became known as the Troopergate scandal resolved his case before a state ethics panel on Tuesday and agreed to admit that he had violated the conduct laws governing public officials.

title: Alone in the Past, but Not Anymore
description: Serenity, in the form of a baby girl, finally arrived in the life of Melissa Rosa, who was orphaned as a child, bounced in and out of foster care and group homes as a teenager and struggled to balance work and school as a young woman.

title: Group of Magazine Publishers Is Said to Be Building an Online Newsstand
description: A consortium of magazine publishers including Time Inc. and Cond Nast plan to jointly build an online newsstand for publications in multiple digital formats, according to people with knowledge of the plans.

title: Lloyds Group Stock Sale to Be Britains Largest
description: The Lloyds Banking Group, the troubled British lender, said Tuesday that it planned to raise 13.5 billion to keep the government from taking a controlling stake.

title: Corrections
description: The Minimalist column last Wednesday, about 101 suggestions for Thanksgiving dishes that can be made in advance, omitted an ingredient for recipe No. 12, for garlic-rosemary figs. Rosemary should be added to the garlic and olive oil, then heated.

title: The Swaps Market Is Too Big to Ban
description: Is the market for credit-default swaps in for a renaissance? George Soros, for one, reckons credit derivatives should be banned. But trading in swaps has so far survived the crisis and market reforms are on the way. Barring unexpectedly draconian regulatory changes, a comeback looks likely.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe for caramelized apple-pecan cake last Wednesday omitted instructions for using one-half teaspoon vanilla extract. In Step 4, add the vanilla after beating the eggs into the butter and sugar. A corrected recipe is at nytimes.com/dining. And a picture with the recipe depicted the cake incorrectly. As the recipe said, the cake should be inverted after it is unmolded, with the apples and pecans on top; it should not be served crust-side up as shown.

title: Chief Reinforces Commitment to A.I.G.
description: Robert Benmosche, chief executive of the American International Group, reaffirmed his commitment to the bailed-out insurer and signed a noncompete agreement with the company.

title: Showcase: This Wall, Too?
description: In 1953, when Ronald Reagan was born, the other Ronald Reagan was a reasonably well known Hollywood actor who was about to ascend to national fame as a television show host  still more than a decade away from beginning his political career. In any case, Mr. Reagan, a retired auto worker and union member in Syracuse, said he didnt mind sharing the name of the 40th president.

title: Phys Ed: How Necessary Is Stretching?
description: For research published earlier this year, physiologists at Nebraska Wesleyan University had distance-running members of the schools track and field team sit on the ground, legs stretched before them, feet pressed firmly up against a box; then the runners, both men and women, bent forward, reaching as far as they could past their toes. This is the classic sit-and-reach test, a well-established measurement of hamstring flexibility. The runners, as a group, didnt have exceptional elasticity, although this varied from person to person.

title: Sleeper Team of 2009: The Ravens?
description: New Orleans, New England, Minnesota and Indianapolis are the runaway leaders in point differential through 10 games.

title: Wright Brothers to Open Aeroplane Factory
description: Thursday, Nov. 25, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Efforts to Defuse Tensions Between Algeria and Egypt
description: Updated | 7:43 a.m. As readers of The Lede will be aware, North Africa has been facing a new source of strife in recent weeks  soccer. Last Wednesday, after the Egyptian national soccer team lost its World Cup bid to rival Algeria 1-0 in Sudan, 32 police officers and 21 Egyptian fans were reportedly injured in violence. The next day, Egyptian demonstrations outside the Algerian embassy in Cairo turned violent.

title: Families Declare Medical Bankruptcy
description: At the bankruptcy court in Nashville, lawyers provided a spectrum of estimates for the share of cases in Middle Tennessee where medical debt was decisive, from 15 percent to 50 percent. But many said they felt the number had been growing.

title: Congo Army Helps Rebels Get Arms, U.N. Finds
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  A new United Nations report says that the Congolese Army continues to funnel weapons to rebel groups that are smuggling millions of dollars in gold and other minerals out of Congo, helping sustain one of Africas bloodiest and most complicated wars.

title: Word of the Day | effusion
description: effusion  \i-fy-zhn, e-\  noun

title: A Stylish State Dinner, With Typos
description: The White House pulled out all the stops in preparation for President Obamas first state dinner on Tuesday night, hiring a new florist, selecting a renowned guest chef and even inviting a number of high-profile musicians to perform.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 15 about whats new this year in the Caribbean misspelled the name of an island and referred incorrectly to the location of a resort. The Sandals Emerald Bay resort is in Great Exuma in the Bahamas, not Exhuma. And the Renaissance Aruba Resort & Casino is situated in Oranjestad, Aruba, and has a 40-acre private island. It is not on a 40-acre island.

title: Hot Holiday Hamsters
description: WHO do you know who might want a Zhu Zhu Pet, the toy pictured here and described as the hottest toy this holiday season?

title: Canada: Bank of Montreal Buys Diners Club
description: Citigroup agreed to sell a credit card unit, Diners Club North America, to Bank of Montreal for an undisclosed price, ending its 28-year-old ties to the worlds first charge card. The sale will reduce Citigroups assets by about $1 billion, representing about 0.05 percent of the lenders total global assets of $1.89 trillion. The deal will not have a material impact on Citigroups net income or capital ratios, the bank said. Bank of Montreal said in a separate statement that the acquisition would more than double its business in corporate credit cards, adding $7.8 billion in card transactions and net receivables of $1 billion.

title: India: Satyam Managers in Fraud Bought Property
description: Managers and insiders who orchestrated an extensive fraud at the Indian outsourcing company Satyam Computer Services bought more than 1,000 pieces of property with the money they diverted, the Central Bureau of Investigation in India said. The bureau also said the 10 people accused in the case had forged board resolutions, obtained unauthorized loans and created more fake customers and generated more fake invoices than previously discovered. Satyams founder admitted in January to faking $1 billion in cash on the companys balance sheet.

title: Vietnam: Export of Puffer Fish Is Approved
description: A government ministry in Vietnam is starting a pilot project to revive the export of puffer fish, known for its toxic skin and internal organs, after a ban of six years, according to The Vietnam News, an official newspaper in English. The goal of the project is to produce 800 to 1,000 tons of products worth up to $10 million by the end of 2012. In 2003, the government prohibited the processing, trade and use of puffer fish because of a high number of poisoning cases.

title: Knicks Arrive Late, and Leave Disappointed
description: LOS ANGELES  Mike DAntoni entered Staples Center at a joggers pace Tuesday evening, hurrying into the locker room. He preached calmness and readiness to his players, but his gallop and arrival time hinted otherwise to reporters.

title: Magazine Publishers Team Up for Online Newsstand
description: A consortium of magazine publishers including Time and Cond Nast are plan to jointly build an online newsstand for publications in multiple digital formats, The New York Timess Brian Stelter reported, citing people with knowledge of the plans.

title: News Quiz | November 25, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Suspect in Philippine Election Killings Surrenders
description: SALMAN, the Philippines  As the toll in what is now considered the Philippines worst case of election violence rose to 57, the authorities on Wednesday focused their suspicions on a powerful clan allied with President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

title: Dancing in Kabul
description: French soldiers dance to Michael Jacksons Billie Jean on the military side of the Kabul airport.

title: A Postwar City Emerges
description: The Courtauld Gallerys exhibition of Frank Auerbachs paintings from the 1950s and early 60s conjures up early postwar London.

title: Newly Independent, Skype Set for Executive Shake-Up
description: From Brad Stone at Bits:

title: G.M. to Decide Saabs Fate Next Week
description: General Motors said it could decide next week to close its Saab Automobile unit after the Swedish company that planned to buy the brand backed out.

title: Do You Find Family Holiday Gatherings Fun or Stressful?
description: Do you gather with your family this time of year? What traditions or rituals do you have? Do you generally look forward to them or dread them? Why?

title: Correction: Mau-Mauing the Flesh Eaters
description: An essay on Nov. 15, about books that explore the ethics of eating meat, misstated the publishing history of The Sexual Politics of Meat, by Carol J. Adams. It has been available ever since it appeared in 1990; it isnt coming back into print next March. (An expanded 20th-anniversary edition will be published then.)

title: Is the Swaps Market Too Big to Ban?
description: Is the market for credit-default swaps in for a renaissance? George Soros, for one, reckons credit derivatives should be banned. But trading in swaps has so far survived the crisis and market reforms are on the way. Barring unexpectedly draconian regulatory changes, a comeback looks likely, Breakingviews.com says.

title: Warner Music Posts a Surprise Loss
description: Warner Music Group, one of the largest American record companies, on Tuesday posted an unexpected loss in the fourth quarter as severance costs weighed on results despite a strong slate of music releases from artists including Jay-Z and Madonna.

title: G.M. to Present Unions With Strategy for Opel
description: General Motors will present to unions on Wednesday a restructuring plan for its Opel unit, with up to 9,500 jobs expected to be cut, the carmakers top official in Europe said Tuesday.

title: Wall Street Struggles to Find Traction
description: A disappointing report on consumer confidence and a more sober read on the economy pulled stocks down on Tuesday from 13-month highs, The Associated Press reported.

title: Ex-Fund Manager Pleads Guilty to Fraud
description: The former manager of a shuttered hedge fund pleaded guilty Tuesday to charges of fraud that cost investors more than $10 million, The Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune reported.

title: Ji-Hobbyists
description: Jihad hobbyists  those who seek out jihadi content online, becoming more radical as they do so.

title: China Ship Parts Maker Plans Shanghai I.P.O.
description: China Shipbuilding Industry, the nations largest maker of vessel equipment, plans to raise at least 6.4 billion renminbi ($937 million) selling shares as China tries to pare its reliance on Japanese and Korean marine engines.

title: Gruner + Jahr Sells Russia Operations to Springer
description: Gruner + Jahr, the German publisher, said Tuesday that it was selling its Russian operations to Axel Springer after concluding that it would need to make too many expensive acquisitions to gain a leading market position.

title: E.U. Drops Antitrust Case Against Qualcomm
description: The European Commission closed antitrust proceedings against Qualcomm as big technology companies dropped their four-year old complaints against the United States mobile chip supplier, Reuters reported.

title: S.E.C. Wins Insider Case Against Ex-Fidelity Trader
description: Federal securities regulators won an insider trading case when a jury in Boston ruled that a former employee of Fidelity Investments illegally profited from trading stocks that the mutual fund company was buying, Reuters reported.

title: Half of Bank Losses May Be Hidden, I.M.F. Chief Says
description: Half of the losses suffered by banks could still be hidden in their balance sheets, more so in Europe than in the United States, the International Monetary Funds managing director, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, told the French newspaper Le Figaro.

title: J.C. Flowers in Pursuit of U.K. Bank Assets
description: J.C. Flowers is circling Britains weakened banking industry, prepared to swoop down on forced divestments over the next 12 months, according to the U.S. private equity investors new boss for Europe and the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Tesla to Build Model S in a Plant Near Los Angeles
description: Tesla Motors is close to a deal to build an electric car factory at the site of a former NASA manufacturing plant in Downey, Calif, a blue-collar city south of Los Angeles, Mayor Mario Guerra said Tuesday.

title: Designer Sweet | Papabubble x Cappellini
description: The cherry-red interior of the Cappellini flagship store in SoHo has always reminded me of candy  its the color of Red Vines, Swedish Fish, Atomic Fireballs, Hot Tamales, Abracabubbles, Cinnamon Discs, Red Hots and candy apples. So it seems fitting that from now until Jan. 3, the Italian furnishings shop will also be in the sweets business. The Candy Shoppe: Papabubble x Cappellini is this years holiday installation by the curators Tobias Wong and Josee Lepage, who asked the artisanal candy makers Papabubble to create what they call a shoppe-in-shop just inside Cappellinis front doors. At an opening party last weekend, filled with fashionably dressed tots and their design-loving parents, limited-edition confections were stored in jars and honey pots on Cappellinis Passepartout shelves and piled high in the polished acrylic drawers of a staircase-like cabinet by Shrio Kuramata.

title: F.B.I. Raids Midwest Offices of Investment Firms
description: Federal agents have searched the Indiana and Ohio offices of two companies owned by an Indianapolis businessman, serving warrants a month after a newspaper questioned whether the Ohio firm is capable of repaying some $168 million owed to investors, The Associated Press reported.

title: Hedge Funds Set For Rebound to Pre-Crisis Levels?
description: Investment flows into hedge funds have turned net positive and the sector is heading toward having assets under management of around $1.75 trillion by year-end, according to Morgan Stanley.

title: Adding Third-Down Proficiency to a Passer Rating
description: Luis DeLoureiro is building a better passer rating, among other statistical pursuits, at NFLStatAnalysis.net:

title: An Indie Epicenter in Paris Reopens
description: PARIS | Six months of tranquil nights for neighbors of Pariss most famous indie rock venue are over. The Flche dOr (102 bis, rue de Bagnolet, 75020; 33-1-44-64-01-02; www.flechedor.fr; Metro: Gambetta or Alexandre Dumas), a longtime meeting point for unsigned bands and music lovers, opened Monday night with a celebration that included performances by Evan Dando, Chris Brokaw and Anoraak.

title: Nomura Fined 1.75 Million by Britain
description: Nomura, the Japanese brokerage, has been fined 1.75 million, or $2.92 million, by Britains Financial Services Authority after one of its Hong Kong traders helped trigger an overvaluation of complex financial instruments.

title: Calpers May Jettison BlackRock as Adviser
