description: The California Public Employees Retirement System is considering jettisoning BlackRock, its real estate adviser, after the firm steered the pension plan into an investment in Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, a pair of gigantic Manhattan apartment complexes now considered to be one of the biggest real estate flops of the boom, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: The Tajik Way for Afghanistan?
description: Todays idea: Foreign peacekeepers and outside powers helped stabilize Tajikistan by cutting deals with warlords, scaling back their aims and concentrating on order. The same cheap, simple approach could work in neighboring Afghanistan, an article says.

title: UBS and Ernst & Young Sued Over Madoff
description: UBS and Ernst & Young may face hundreds of damage claims if investors who lost millions of dollars in mutual funds linked to Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme win a group of Luxembourg test cases, Bloomberg News reported.

title: The Frugal Travelers Holiday Gift Guide
description: As you may have gathered from my souvenir-hunting post last week, the Frugal Traveler is somewhat reluctant to buy, well, things. Its not stinginess on my part  its that I dislike spending money on needless, often useless objects. Waste is the antithesis of frugality, and unnecessary belongings can make travel more difficult than it already is.

title: Australia Serves TPG With $628 Million Tax Bill
description: TPG has been slapped with a $628 million tax bill by Australian authorities in a dispute over how to tax the United States private equity firms gains from the initial public offering of the department store Myer.

title: Sampler: Golden Gate Bridge Climb, Growing Dumps, Bird Watchers Wanted
description: Competitions Victims | The more than 4,500 workers at New United Motor Manufacturing, which is co-owned by General Motors and Toyota and is based in Fremont, are victims of foreign competition and eligible for federal financial help, said Labor Secretary Hilda Solis.

title: One Minimum Wage Increase With a Side of Fries, Please
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Emergency Loans Secrecy Defended in Britain
description: The British government defended the right of the Bank of England to make secret loans to struggling banks after belatedly disclosing that the Bank of England had lent almost 62 billion pounds to two institutions last year.

title: Calpers Investigates Hedge Fund Oversight
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System, the nations biggest pension fund, with $200 billion, has started an internal investigation into its own oversight of hedge fund deals, The Los Angeles Times reported.

title: Ericsson Buys Another Part of Nortel
description: Ericsson and Kapsch CarrierCom will buy the GSM business of Nortel Networks of Canada, which is bankrupt, for $103 million in cash, the giant Swedish maker of telecommunications equipment said Wednesday.

title: London Exchanges First-Half Net Profit Drops 40 Percent
description: The London Stock Exchange posted a 40 percent drop in first-half earnings on Wednesday on the back of lower trading and warned that market conditions remain uncertain.

title: If You Took the Train to the Plane, Sing the Jingle
description: Imagine Midtown to J.F.K. in one hour, eight stops, for $3.50 a ride. This Shangri-La of New York City travel was once a reality  and it came with its own catchy theme song. So on this, traditionally known as the biggest travel day of the year, lets take a look back.

title: Toyota Is Recalling Tundras for Rust Problem
description: Toyota said it was recalling 110,000 of its 2000-3 full-size Tundra pickups because of rust problems with the frames, the second time the automaker has had such a problem on its pickups.

title: What to Watch Wednesday: Losers and Lambert
description: The Biggest Loser (NBC, 8 p.m.) offers a Where are they now? episode, revisiting more than 40 contestants from previous seasons to see what theyve been doing since their appearances and, of course, how they look.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, Nov. 25
description: Here are some highlights from Wednesdays The New York Times:

title: Travel Forms for All Occasions
description: Is your child flying overseas? Or are you taking a business trip, and want to leave behind a medical consent form?

title: Toyota Will Fix or Replace 4 Million Gas Pedals
description: DETROIT  Toyota said Wednesday it would have to fix the gas pedals of about four million vehicles, including the Camry, to resolve a widespread problem with unintended acceleration.

title: Adam Lambert: Im Not a Baby Sitter. Im a Performer.
description: As his performance at the American Music Awards continues to stoke controversy, even costing him a booking on Good Morning America, Adam Lambert acknowledged in a television interview that he did get carried away during his awards show appearance. But the singer declined to apologize for his act, saying that it was ultimately up to the parents to discern what their childs watching on television.

title: Agribusiness Chief Slams Organics
description: When Michael Mack, the chief executive of Syngenta, a Swiss agribusiness giant that makes pesticides and seeds, hears people say that organic food is better for the planet, he has one response: Au contraire.

title: Pakistan Charges 7 Terrorism Suspects a Year After Attacks That Shocked Mumbai
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Seven Pakistanis accused of planning last years attacks in Mumbai, India, were formally charged Wednesday, the eve of the first anniversary of the assault. The attacks left 163 people dead and have become a major sticking point in relations between India and Pakistan.

title: Early Word: Afghan Rollout
description: President Obama is finalizing his decision on how to proceed in Afghanistan. Now, he gets to explain it.

title: No exit
description: The latest Fed minutes, together with the forecast, are out. What do they tell us?

title: State Emergency Alert System Now Includes Xbox and Wii
description: In the event of an emergency, the state of New York may seize control of your Xbox or Wii, under a new notification system set to go live next year, The New York Post reports. Video games will pause and warnings about imminent danger, severe weather or Amber alerts will appear on the screen, under a new voluntary notification system for Xbox, Wii and PlayStation.

title: New-Home Sales Rise, but Factory Orders Slip
description: Sales of new homes reached their highest level in October in more than a year, the government said Wednesday, but the pace was sluggish and unsold homes lingered for the longest time on record.

title: Ramsay MacDonald
description: Ramsay MacDonald was Britains first Labour Prime Minister. After a brief first stint in the first half of the 1920s, he led a more solid coalition to power in 1929. One might have expected big changes in a country that was, at that time, still deeply class-ridden and marked by huge inequality.

title: Thursdays N.F.L. Matchups
description: Packers (6-4) at Lions (2-8)Thursday, 12:30 p.m.Line: Packers by 10 1/2

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Wednesday morning.

title: Rethinking Clean Energy Innovation
description: Meeting the challenges of global climate change will require a more open and collaborative approach to technology innovation, according to a new report from two public policy groups focused on clean energy and development strategies.

title: As Travelers Cut Costs, Holiday Jaunts Grow Longer
description: The holiday crush at the nations airports has taken hold several days earlier as travelers sought less expensive flights. Read the full story.

title: Bryant Believes Knicks Will Get a Star, Just Not Him
description: LOS ANGELES  Kobe Bryant has avoided discussion of free agency in 2010, saying he will not discuss scenarios hypothetically.

title: The Frugal Travelers Holiday Gift Guide
description: A list of gifts perfect for the frugal travelers in your life that will inspire them to cross oceans and deserts  and give them the tools to do so easily, cheaply and with style.

title: Obama Will Go to Copenhagen
description: President Obama will travel to Copenhagen next month for the United Nations meeting on climate change, a White House official confirmed Wednesday.

title: The Bitter With the Sweet
description: Two quick pieces of business before I sign off for the Thanksgiving holiday:

title: Canada and India Resume Nuclear Energy Trade
description: Thirty-five years after Canada placed sanctions on India for using a Canadian-made  reactor to help detonate a nuclear warhead, the two countries agreed this month to a cooperation pact that will see a resumption in fuel-grade uranium sales.

title: Obama to Address Nation From West Point
description: President Obama will address the nation on his Afghanistan strategy at 8 p.m. on Tuesday from the United States Military Academy at West Point.

title: Pompidou Center Workers Extend Strike
description: Update | 3:54 p.m. Staff members on strike at the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris decided on Tuesday to extend their protest as that modern art museum weighs job cuts, Agence France-Presse reported. On Monday, museum employees and security guards walked off the job, amid fears that more than 400 jobs will be cut at the museums Beaubourg building over the next 10 years. The French government could reduce the museums payroll by not replacing retiring staff members; more than 40 percent of the staff at the Pompidou Center is over the age of 50, and the legal retirement age in France is 70. On Tuesday, representatives of the museum staff met with aides to Frdric Mitterrand, the French culture minister, but a union official told Agence France-Presse that the meeting did not go well.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Bail Offer for Roman Polanski Is Approved
description: Update | 3:12 p.m.  PARIS  A Swiss court on Wednesday granted bail to the filmmaker Roman Polanski, who was being detained as he fights extradition to the United States to face sentencing on child-sex charges.

title: Home for Thanksgiving, and Managing Meds
description: If your parents kitchen counter or, worse, bathroom medicine chest is crammed with pill bottles  old, new, rarely used, barely remembered, emptied and never refilled  a new brochure from Consumers Union and the Eldercare Locator, a service of the United States Administration on Aging, might prove useful.

title: Meet Your Meat
description: In Wednesdays Dining section I wrote about urban food lovers growing interest in the worlds oldest meat procurement method: hunting. Perhaps not surprisingly, many people exploring hunting for the first time are already steeped in the ethos of the farmers market and locavorism.

title: Families of Military Suicides Seek White House Condolences
description: Since at least the time of Abraham Lincoln, presidents have sent letters of condolence to the families of service members killed in action, whether the deaths came by hostile fire or in an accident.

title: Should Start-Ups Pay to Pitch?
description: Updated | 11/30/09

title: Israel Offers a Pause in Building New Settlements
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Wednesday announced his intention to halt new residential construction in West Bank settlements for 10 months as part of an effort to revive stalled Middle East peace talks.

title: Week 12 N.F.L. Game Probabilities
description: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior. His team rankings through Week 11  can be found here.

title: A 17th-Century Home in Hattingen, Germany
description: This six-bedroom house has original stone floors and exposed oak beams.

title: Theater Mishaps, at Home and Abroad
description: Eat your heart out, Patti LuPone: a British theater actor who was irked by an impolite audience member not only halted his performance but also stepped off the stage to confront the theatergoer in question. The Guardian reported that Ian Hart, an actor whose credits include the first Harry Potter movie, climbed off the stage of the Duke of Yorks Theater in the West End at the curtain call of Speaking in Tongues, the Andrew Bovell play, to run up to Gerard Earley, an audience member he believed had been talking during the performance. Mr. Earley told The Evening Standard of London that Mr. Hart had been swinging his arms and shouting as he came after him, but may not have made physical contact with him. Mr. Hart, who is continuing to appear in the play, told The Evening Standard that the incident was just a lot of silliness.

title: She Changed Her Vote
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on NBC: President Obama just had his first official state dinner in honor of Indias Prime Minister Singh. See, pretty smart of the Obamas. Not only do they get to have a state dinner for an ally, all night long they get free tech support.

title: Properties for $300,000
description: A Greek Revival with Hudson River views, a two-bedroom in Miami Beach, and a brick town house in Cincinnati.

title: So Many Dark Sides
description: CULTIVATE the appearance of contrition, the character Jack Lawson, a lawyer, tells a white client accused of raping a black woman in Race, a new play opening on Broadway next Sunday. As uttered with dont-waste-my-time iciness by the actor James Spader, the clipped and merciless directive telegraphs not only that this is dialogue by David Mamet, but also that it is set in the kind of up-for-grabs moral universe that Spader characters have been occupying in Hollywood for years.

title: The Holiday Travel Crush Begins
description: Late Afternoon Problems | 5:28 p.m.  Its now afternoon rush hour for East coast airports, and delays are taking place from New England to Florida. Up north, the problem is low ceilings, which are causing delays of more than two hours in Philadelphia and more than an hour at Newark. New Yorks other airports also have delays and flights also have slowed down in Boston. Thunderstorms are the issue in Miami, West Palm Beach and Fort Lauderdale.

title: The Good Wife Watch: Enter the Call Girl
description: Tuesday nights episode of The Good Wife posited that Peter Florricks downfall on corruption charges may well have been trumped up  maybe. Alicias source, the firms senior partner, has friends in high places. On the other hand, he also has dementia.

title: European Puck: Champions League in Peril Again as Bidders Pull Out
description: Its back to the drawing board for the Champions League, as the I.I.H.F. confirmed on Wednesday that potential investors have withdrawn their bids and the effort to revive the pan-European club competition must begin anew.

title: At Lucalis, an Irregular Regular
description: If you go to Lucalis, the pizza favorite in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, ask for Dominick Dionisio. Seems like hes bound to be around.

title: Obama to Go to Copenhagen With Emissions Target
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is pledging a provisional target for reductions in greenhouse gas emissions in the United States, the first time in more than a decade that an American administration has offered even a tentative promise to reduce production of climate-altering gases, the White House announced Wednesday.

title: Just Google Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  A day after Googles chief executive, Eric Schmidt, announced a virtual library of Iraqs National Museum, the government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki inaugurated its own YouTube channel.

title: Report Offers Plan for Reducing Chinas Carbon Intensity
description: China has much to gain from getting an early start in the development of a low-carbon economy and should seriously consider carbon intensity targets in its next five-year plan, according to a report from the China Council for International Cooperation on Environment and Development.

title: Human Toll of a Queens Mortgage Fraud
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: LinkedIn Founder Foresees an I.P.O., but Not Now
description: LinkedIn, the big professional social network, will probably pursue an initial public offering some time but not in the near future, Reid Hoffman, executive chairman and a founder, said on Wednesday, according to Reuters.

title: On Fox, 24 and Idol Return; Glee Takes a Break
description: After a far better fall than the network usually experiences, Fox Broadcasting is gearing up for a number of prime-time schedule changes in January that could pile-drive its competitors into the turf  and Fox doesnt even have the Super Bowl this season.

title: Sleeping Gag
description: On April 1 of each year since 2001, ThinkGeek, the online retailer, has devoted its home page to products that dont exist. The names sound unlikely  Squeez Bacon, Surgestix Inhalable Caffeine Stix, p-Teqs USB Pregnancy Test Kit, etc.  but they are presented as any item on the site would be: catalog description and list of features, pictures, maybe a video, price, Buy Now button. Click that and . . . ThinkGeek wishes you a happy April Fools Day. The joke is on you for believing that someone is making and selling a Betamax to HD-TV Converter.

title: Obama Confirms Copenhagen Stop
description: President Obama ended speculation on whether he would visit Copenhagen to help in talks on a new climate treaty with an announcement describing his plan to stop at the talks on Dec. 9 with a pledged near-term reduction in emissions, the day before he receives the Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo. Clearly, the political risk of attending the talks was greatly reduced by the recent announcement, during an Asian summit, that the talks would not produce a legally binding deal. Theres little chance he could be blamed for failure, and every chance he could be credited for any breakthroughs. The announcement follows word that the United States will also unveil a near-term target for emissions reductions. The news release below lays out a list of activities planned by the United States during the talks: [UPDATE 11/26: China has anted up a Copenhagen target slowing growth in emissions relative to growth in the economy.]

title: Instead of Watching TV, Giants Will Be on TV
description: In Thanksgiving games before World War II, the Giants faced teams like the Brooklyn Lions, the Staten Island Stapletons and the football version of the Brooklyn Dodgers.

title: Mayor Says Student Scores Will Factor Into Teacher Tenure
description: WASHINGTON  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Wednesday that New York City public schools would immediately begin to use student test scores as a factor in deciding which teachers earn tenure, a proposal that has been bitterly opposed by the teachers union and criticized as putting too much weight on standardized exams.

title: Abe Pollins Legacy
description: In a random collision of events, the tales of two N.B.A. owners intersected Tuesday and broadcast a clear message about owning sports teams: above all else, fans really want you to care. If you knew anything about Abe Pollin, it was that he cared about the Washington Wizards. When he died Tuesday at the age of 85, thats what people talked about. No, the Bullets-turned-Wizards didnt win all that much, but Pollin tried and he cared and he built an arena that rejuvenated a D.C. neighborhood because he cared about that too.

title: Dubai World Asks for Time to Reorganize Debts
description: Update | 5:31 p.m. The New York Timess Landon Thomas Jr. has more details on Dubais restructuring efforts here.

title: Oil Sharks
description: Oil tankers anchored off the coast of Britain, said to be awaiting a rise in oil prices.

title: Fuel Economy Is Up Again, but Why Not More?
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has some good news to share: Between the 2007 and 2008 model years, auto fleet fuel efficiency improved [pdf] (and average carbon dioxide emissions retreated) for the fifth consecutive year. Thats not surprising, especially considering the $4 per gallon consumers paid for gasoline last year. But what is rather startling is the small size of the fuel economy gain: just 0.4 miles per gallon.

title: Q&A: Insurance for a Long-Distance Backpacker
description: Q.

title: Law Protecting Workers From Retaliation Takes Effect
description: A law that increases penalties for companies that retaliate against employees who complain about labor-law violations takes effect this week, at a time when the state has stepped up enforcement of minimum-wage standards and other labor standards.

title: Stray Shots and Children: Living With the Wound
description: They are the luckiest of the unlucky: survivors of gunshots meant for someone else.

title: Blue-Collar Botox
description: Via Tyler Cowen, it turns out that the proposed tax on cosmetic surgeries might be highly regressive:

title: John Mayer Is No. 1 in Pre-Holiday Sales Week
description: John Mayers latest album, Battle Studies (Columbia), easily topped the Billboard chart this week with 286,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In a week heavy with prominent new releases as the music industry gears up the for the holiday-shopping period, Andrea Bocellis My Christmas (Sugar/Decca) held at No. 2 with 185,000 sales, beating out Norah Jones (No. 3 with 180,000 sales), the Christian rock band Casting Crowns (No. 4, 167,000), 50 Cent (No. 5, 160,000) and the 15-year-old pop heartthrob Justin Bieber (No. 6, 137,000).

title: Obama to Visit Denmark With CO2 Targets
description: From our colleagues at the Caucus:

title: Photolog | Norway on Ice
description: When my editor asked me to go to Norway to write about skiing for Ts winter travel issue, I figured, Why bother? I had just returned from a 10-day trip to Kitzbhel, in the Austrian Alps, and I was still tingly from the steep alpine runs and fast-paced night life. How could I top that? Then I looked up the little resort town of Geilo, in Norway, and saw how stupid I was. Geilo is a charming and gentle place. It serves as an entry to the Hardangervidda, the largest eroded plain in Europe and one of the most alien worlds I have ever encountered. Combine that with a stay in Bergen (the countrys former fishing capital and its second-largest city), a corkscrew train ride past storybook Hobbit villages to the mouth of a magical-looking fjord, and a ferry ride along mountains plunging into the sea, and heres what I told my editor when I got back: Thank you. That was one of the best trips of my life.

title: Going Rogue Goes to Top of Book Sales Chart
description: Update | 3:34 p.m.  Going Rogue, the newly released memoir by Sarah Palin, the former Alaskan governor and Republican nominee for vice president, sold 469,000 copies in its first week of release, according to sales figures released Wednesday by Nielsen BookScan. That made Going Rogue the top-selling book of the week on Nielsen BookScans chart, putting it ahead of new releases from authors like James Patterson (whose novel I, Alex Cross was No. 2) and Stephen King (whose novel Under the Dome placed at No. 3), as well as Dan Browns best-selling potboiler The Lost Symbol. The book will also make its debut at No. 1 on the New York Times best-seller list for nonfiction on Dec. 6.

title: Pestering Parents: The Admissions Office Perspective
description: Tuesday on The Choice, we picked up and expanded a conversation that began on College Confidential in response to a mothers plaintive question: What if you pester an admissions counselor?

title: Five-Time Olympic Speedskating Champion Loses Blood-Doping Appeal
description: Germanys most successful winter Olympian will miss the Vancouver Games. Claudia Pechstein, the five-time Olympic speedskating champion and winner of nine medals, lost her appeal against a two-year ban for blood doping. Interestingly, she never failed a drug test.

title: A Look at the Medal Contenders: Snowboarder Torah Bright
description: Torah Bright takes the resume of your typical Olympic snowboarder and turns it on its head. First, she is from Australia, hardly a winter sports mecca, which also means she had to leave home at age 14 to pursue a snow-based career. She says she actually prefers skiing to snowboarding. Bright is unabashed about the importance of the Olympics in a sport that worships the X-Games first and foremost. And she is a devout Mormon, which means she forgoes drinking, caffeine and premarital sex.

title: Answers About Divorce and Money: Part 3
description: For the last week, Lili A. Vasileff has been answering selected questions from Bucks readers about divorce and money. Ms. Vasileff is a Certified Divorce Financial Analyst and president of the Association of Divorce Financial Planners. She works out of an office in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Science (Class) in Pictures: Photographing Scientific Discoveries
description: Overview | How do photographs help convey complex scientific concepts and ideas? How can students use and learn from scientific photography in the classroom? In this lesson, students learn about recent scientific developments by viewing The New York Times slide show Science in Pictures. They then become scientific photographers and create their own slide show documenting the research, discoveries and ideas they are learning about in science class.

title: Vallejo Rumblings: Fallout Over Mayors Comments
description: The mayor of Vallejo has apologized for comments he made in a New York Times column by Scott James, a Bay area writer.

title: Going Rogue Goes to Top of Book Sales
description: Sales of Going Rogue, the book by former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska, are brisk, reports Dave Itzkoff at our ArtsBeat blog. See the full post.

title: UEFA Cites Cancer in Soccer
description: On the same day that some of Europes top teams in its most glamorous leagues will play in the lucrative UEFA Champions League, the continental federation cited five teams in four countries for fixing matches.

title: Young Bystander, Shot in Head, Might Make Full Recovery
description: Vada Vasquez, a 15-year-old girl who was walking home from school with friends when a stray bullet fired by gang members struck her in the head, could make a full recovery, her doctor said Wednesday during a news conference at Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center, where she has been treated since the Nov. 16 shooting.

title: The Temporary Vegetarians Thanksgiving
description: Earlier this year, The New York Times dining section launched the Temporary Vegetarian column, an occasional series that shines the spotlight on bold and flavorful vegetable dishes that you can build a meal around.

title: Autistic Man, Wrongly Jailed, Wins Settlement
description: A 31-year-old autistic man who, after 17 hours of questioning from detectives, confessed to murdering his sister in 2006, only to be released later when it turned out he was innocent, will receive $190,000 and payments from a $150,000 annuity under a settlement with the city.

title: Living With Music: Dean Bakopoulos
description: Dean Bakopoulos is the author of two novels, Please Dont Come Back From the Moon and the forthcoming My American Unhappiness. He is now on the faculty of the M.F.A. program in creative writing and environment at Iowa State University and has just moved to Ames, Iowa.

title: We Made It Ourselves | Meat Sweets in San Francisco
description: In her new column, We Made It Ourselves, Charlotte Druckman will write about restaurants and small businesses with interesting house-made treats.

title: Complaint Box | Air Conditions
description: Flying on Jet Blue out of Newark? Beware. Be aware. And be early!

title: Slow the Trains: Palo Alto Looking for Ways to Stop Youth Suicides
description: Palo Alto has been grappling with ways to prevent youth suicides in the wake of the four deaths since May of Gunn High School students who were hit by high-speed trains.

title: Download the Face of Your Dreams
description: TAYLOR DISHER, a 22-year-old marketing student in Toronto, recently found a useful way to shorten her beauty routine. Rather than try on sticky layers of lip gloss in a drugstore aisle, she leisurely tested 20 different shades of gloss on her train commute to school using an iPhone app called MakeUp.

title: You Too Can Be as Pretty as a Pixel
description: MAKEUP Released in early November for 99 cents, MakeUp offers users nearly 100 blush and lipstick colors to try on downloaded images, in addition to various shades of eyeliner, eye shadow, mascara and foundation. Also, users can compare before and after photos side by side.

title: Pittsburgh Welcomes Back a Working-Class Star
description: PITTSBURGH  Some of the loudest cheers in Mellon Arena on Wednesday were not for one of the Penguins A-list of stars, center Sidney Crosby or center Evgeni Malkin or goalie Marc-Andre Fleury, but for a much more unlikely star. They were for Maxime Talbot, largely unknown outside Pittsburgh before the Penguins Stanley Cup championship last spring, who played his first home game of the season.

title: The Pause Button on FlashForward
description: There will be no FlashForward recap this week: apparently Thursday is some sort of holiday, so ABC is serving up a Charlie Brown appetizer and a couple of musical-special entrees. (For the record, theyre Beyonc: I Am  Yours and Paul McCartney: Good Evening New York City. ABC isnt providing screeners, so we cant tell if theyre turkeys.)

title: Is the Senate Health Care Bill Better Off Dead?
description: Gail Collins: David, since this week is all Thanksgiving all the time, I think today Ill be thankful for having you to converse with.

title: Dobbs in 2012
description: Politico has the story; Rasmussen and Democracy Corps have the polls; Allahpundit and David Frum have analysis.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) The economics of pinball.

title: Giants Bradshaw Will Not Play Against Broncos
description: The Giants announced Wednesday that running back Ahmad Bradshaw was officially out of Thursday nights game in Denver and would not make the trip.

title: How Many More Casinos Does Vegas Need?
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below:

title: Burgers With Sides Built In
description: As Midtown Lunch points out, Midtown is no stranger to weird new fast-food concepts, but the up-and-coming 4Food, set to open on March 1 at 40th and Madison, may set a new standard:

title: Producers Say They Wont Close Their Play to Let Emperor Jones In
description: Among those in the theater industry who were surprised on Tuesday by the announcement that the Irish Repertory Theaters production of The Emperor Jones would be transferring to the Soho Playhouse are the producers of Made in Heaven, the show that is currently playing at that Off-Broadway theater.

title: Toyota Says Cars to Get Smart Gas Pedals
description: If there is a lesson from the unintended-acceleration dilemma that resulted in Toyotas new plan to modify about 4 million vehicles, it is the need for all vehicles to have a smart gas pedal, said Clarence Ditlow, the executive director of the Center for Auto Safety.

title: KLM Tests a Biofuel Made From Weeds
description: With airline passengers getting increasingly concerned about their carbon footprint, the Dutch airline KLM has turned to oil made from the seeds of the camelina plant. On Monday, a KLM Boeing 747 that was partly fueled by camelina oil flew over the Netherlands in a test flight with about 40 passengers aboard.

title: Paper Trails
description: This stop-motion advertisement from the New Zealand Book Council is a delight for ink-on-paper fetishists everywhere. Check it out. (Acquisition editors take note: the Kiwi classic featured in the video, Maurice Gees 1993 Going West, hasnt been published in the United States.)

title: Artifacts From Old Europe
description: Sampling the visual language of an ancient Danube Valley culture that was ahead of its time in art, technology and long-distance trade.

title: Even Oscar Has Money Woes
description: Like a lot of us, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has had a down year.

title: Another Take on the G.O.P. Purity Test
description: A few more threads are developing on the idea proposed by some conservative Republicans for what has been called a purity test to help define candidates.

title: Your Senator Is (Probably) a Millionaire
description: About two-thirds of United States senators were millionaires in 2008, according to a recent analysis of politicians fortunes conducted by the Center for Responsive Politics.

title: Not Shy in the Way She Works a Lyric
description: Baby Jane Dexter, a singer with a mighty contralto, makes a persuasive case for uncovering new meanings in songs by wielding lyrics like blunt instruments. There is no beating around the bush for this longtime cabaret performer, whose new show at the Metropolitan Room is aptly named All About Love because it covers so many aspects. Her interpretations of everything from Bob Dylan to Rodgers and Hammerstein have the force of body blows.

title: Glam Rock Muppets
description: Video | Roll over, Freddie Mercury:

title: Pop Go the Holidays
description: BARNEYS New York wants us to Have a Witty Holiday this year, or so its witty holiday windows declare. Yes, please! A little whimsy is exactly what we need. Perhaps thats why were seeing reflections of the artist Jeff Koons in the shiny holiday decorations, metallic gift wrap and Pop-y bright fashion accessories.

title: The Morning Skate: Offense vs. Defense, Drury Returns and Bad Luck
description: After having only one game on last nights schedule, the N.H.L. has 28 teams skating tonight in a pre-Thanksgiving Day feast. All three local clubs are in action (the Islanders host Philadelphia, the Devils host the Senators and the Rangers play in Florida) and most of the matches are good ones.

title: 36 Hours in Austin, Tex.
description: THE citys unofficial motto, Keep Austin Weird, blares from bumper stickers on BMWs and jalopies alike, on T-shirts worn by joggers along Lady Bird Lake and in the windows of independently owned shops and restaurants. Its an exhortation for a city that clings to eccentricity, even in the face of rapid development  downtown Austin, for one, is being transformed with a fleet of high-rise condos and a W Hotel, scheduled to open late next year. But this funky college town, known for its liberal leanings and rich music scene, has little to worry about  at least as long as its openhearted citizens, with their colorful bungalows and tattoos, do their part to keep the city endearingly odd. As one local put it: As long as Austinites keep decorating their bodies and cars, were going to be fine.

title: The Latest Entrepreneurial Fantasy Is Selling Cupcakes
description: Move over restaurants and bed-and-breakfasts. A new fantasy seems to have taken hold for people who long to own their own business: the cupcakery.

title: Finnish Composer Bursts Some of Her Own Myths
description: One of the perils of conducting a public interview with a composer is that you are likely to have your deeply held beliefs about your interviewees work shrugged off. That happened to the composer George E. Lewis during his interview with Kaija Saariaho during a Composer Portraits concert at the Miller Theater on Sunday evening. Mr. Lewis observed that some of Ms. Saariahos music struck him as a kind of synesthesia: that the sound of her music seemed almost to invoke pictures.

title: Week 12 in Fantasy Football Matchups
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 12. Also, scroll down for reading tips from the Fantasy Football Librarian.

title: Chicagos Great Culinary Middle Ground
description: PAUL KAHAN is one of Chicagos best chefs, and his restaurants are reliable bellwethers for whats going on in the citys dining scene. When Blackbird, his first restaurant, opened 12 years ago, it presaged Chicagos rebirth as one of the planets most dynamic restaurant cities  a promise fulfilled by restaurants like Alinea, Schwa and L20. Mr. Kahan followed Blackbird with Avec and the Publican, restaurants that are less formal, better suited to a city that needed less pomp and polish to go with good food.

title: In Iraq, 2 Attacks Raise Fears of Sectarianism
description: BAGHDAD  During the darkest days of the sectarian bloodletting that swept Iraq several years ago, few terrors equaled the rise of the death squads  men in the guise of the Iraqi security forces who killed with impunity.

title: Views From Twin Peaks
description: Emilie Raguso, a journalist who created Capturing Twin Peaks, shared her thinking about her subject. The peaks tower over San Francisco and can be seen throughout the Bay Area:

title: Obama Saves Courage
description: A day after hosting his first state dinner, President Obama indulged in another presidential tradition  pardoning a turkey named Courage.

title: Two Hours of Free Food From Michael Psilakis
description: Michael Psilakis will be working a food cart at Gansevoort Street and Ninth Avenue in Manhattan from midnight until 2 a.m. on Dec. 4, serving free chicken shish kebabs, lamb burgers and vegetables with couscous.

title: You Lie! No, You Lie!
description: Patrick Byrne, the chief executive of Overstock.com, has fired back at Grant Thornton, which essentially said the company lied about whether Grant Thornton had approved some accounting.

title: Family Didnt Sue After Balloon Fell, and Still Wouldnt
description: The injuries themselves were unremarkable, a chipped tooth, a cut requiring nine stitches, a bruised forehead. But the reaction to the accident that caused them provoked disbelief.

title: Court Upholds Willets Point Redevelopment Plan
description: A federal judge on Wednesday upheld New Yorks $3 billion redevelopment plan for Willets Point, an industrial section of Queens dominated by car-repair shops and waste-management businesses, finding that although the city had neglected the neighborhoods infrastructure for decades, the constitutional rights of the businesses there  many of which will be forced to relocate under the plan  were not violated.

title: Living on Museum Mile
description: First-rate paintings, photos and films offer plenty of reasons to duck inside the nine cultural institutions lining Museum Mile, a narrow slice of Upper Manhattan fronting Central Park.

title: Coal Plant Stirs Passions in Cambodia
description: Last week, executives from Leader Universal Holdings, a Malaysian company angling to build Cambodias largest coal-fired power plant, met with Cambodian government officials and environmentalists to discuss the companys impact analysis for the proposed 100-megawatt facility.

title: Letter: Sailors Haven on Mayreau
description: To the Editor: Matt Grosss article Sailing the Caribbean, the Frugal Way (Nov. 15) brought back great memories of our stay on Mayreau but missed out on the treasure of Saltwhistle Bay, a charming sailors haven  deep harbor, secluded white sand beaches accessible only by boat, delicious alfresco dining and great snorkeling. And for those who choose to stay overnight, beautifully appointed stone cottages with covered roof-top terraces overlooking the sea. Saltwhistle is a short hop to Tobago Cays, home to sea turtles  and around the corner from where Johnny Depp was filmed in a Pirates of the Caribbean movie.

title: People Hear With Skin as Well as Their Ears
description: We hear with our ears, right? Yes, but scientists have known for years that we also hear with our eyes. In a landmark study published in 1976, researchers found that people integrated both auditory cues and visual ones, like mouth and face movements, when they heard speech.

title: Taking on Midlife and All Its Crises
description: HOLLYWOOD

title: Letter: Bjagos Islands
description: To the Editor: In the article Tranquil Haven in a Troubled Land (Nov. 8), about the Bijags islands off Bissau, I was surprised that you did not mention the art of the Bidyogo, which has two forms: the ox head helmet masks with glass eyes; and the crowns, sculptured headpieces that frame the face and usually have raffia trailing down on both sides. They are considered highly valued by some collectors.

title: Russia Denies Knowing That Man Who Died in Jail Was Ill
description: MOSCOW  Russias Interior Ministry held a rare news conference on Wednesday to deny that its investigators had been aware of health problems that led to the death of a 37-year-old lawyer at a ministry detention center last week.

title: Debussys Homage to Poe, With the Blanks Filled In
description: What should be done with the unfinished works left behind by master composers at their deaths? This question has long dogged musicians and scholars of later eras, and the debate goes on. Maybe the proper way to respect the masters is to leave their incomplete scores alone. How can we presume to know what an ingenious composer might have intended?

title: Rehousing a Miami Collection
description: THE annual Art Basel Miami Beach dinner parties hosted by Rosa and Carlos de la Cruz, two of the areas most prominent art collectors, were once the fairs most coveted ticket. But so many guests would arrive at the couples Key Biscayne mansion  one year, over 1,000 party-crashers tried to talk or sneak their way inside  that the bash has since been drastically scaled down. But this week Basel party people will find the de la Cruz home not only quiet but relatively empty.

title: Fed Tightens Regulations on Its Regional Directors
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, under attack in Congress for being too entwined with big banks, closed a loophole on Wednesday that allowed a director at Goldman Sachs to be a director of the New York Fed as the agency was bailing out Wall Street during the financial crisis.

title: Giving Thanks for Great-Grandparents
description: When we become parents, our parents become grandparents, and each generation bumps on up the ladder. With each passing Thanksgiving, Larissa Kosmos has become more keenly aware of the love of her grandparents, whom she made great-grandparents twice over. In a guest post today, she sends her love long distance. She wont be seeing them until Christmas this year, but they will be joining her nonetheless at her Thanksgiving table.

title: Trader Joes Confirms It Is Coming to the Upper West Side
description: Folks on the Upper West Side have been teased for months by the possibility that Trader Joes might be coming to the neighborhood. After a Trader Joes representative said in September that the company had no confirmed plans to locate at Broadway and 72nd Street, Curbed noticed last month that Trader Joes was mentioned in a submission to the local community board by the developers of a retail and rental development at 2075 Broadway.

title: Hotel Review: The Hotel Astoria 7 in San Sebastin, Spain
description: THE BASICS

title: Goodbye, Hello: Resuscitating a Sitcom
description: LOS ANGELES

title: When Desire Fades
description: Have you lost interest in sex? The problem of low sexual desire in women is common, but little understood, an issue explored by Daniel Bergner in this weeks New York Times Magazine.

title: At Gucci, Shopping Guilt-Free
description: For Guccis fifth annual holiday campaign to benefit Unicef, the creative director Frida Giannini commissioned the author and illustrator Michael Roberts to create Snowman in Africa, a sequel to his 2004 childrens book Snowman in Paradise. Filled with Robertss signature cutout drawings, the book costs $25, with 100 percent of proceeds going to the charity. Roberts (wearing a winsome Santa beard) signed copies of the book last night at Guccis Fifth Avenue flagship, while adult guests sipped Champagne and their tots munched on colorful cookies and drank milky peppermint punch. Stylish mommies cooed over Gianninis coordinating accessories, including a logo bag appliqud with a snake-wrapped snowman ($2,250), a sporty bag printed with elephants and snowmen ($695) and cute key chains ($195 to $245). The pieces will be sold through Dec. 31 at Gucci stores and Gucci.com, with 25 percent of proceeds donated to Unicef.

title: Dubai Fund Asks for Stay on Debt Payments
description: LONDON  The government of Dubai, in a blunt acknowledgment of the severity of its financial position, said on Wednesday that it had asked its banks for a six-month stay on its schedule of debt repayments.

title: Economic Tips for Limiting Your Pumpkin Pie Intake
description: On Tuesday we posted a neat video with Dan Ariely, a Duke behavioral economist, about tips for limiting your spending. As it turns out, Ezra Klein at The Washington Post wisely asked Professor Ariely how to apply those same economic principles to help readers limit another kind of consumption: Thanksgiving food.

title: Where Ghost Passengers Await Very Late Trains
description: THE Bronx stations of the old New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad are like a string of pearls  a very broken string. Some have been lost, and others are being slowly crushed by the boot of time.

title: Brad Pitts Gifts to New Orleans
description: AL ANDREWS, who lives on Tennessee Street in the Lower Ninth Ward of New Orleans, said he didnt mind the tour buses coming through his neighborhood, but he wished the visitors would give some of what they pay to the community. Mr. Andrews lives in one of the brightly colored, modernist houses rising on a small patch of the Lower Ninth, four years after it was devastated by Hurricane Katrina.

title: Off-Season F1 Happenings  and then Some
description: I have been noticing myself what you have probably been noticing: That I have not been reporting on every movement in the driver market and team doings over the past several days. Its the off-season, sure, but there has been so much news in the past week that it looks like a big, bright middle of a summer or something. Especially in whats happening in the driver market. In fact, Im working on a story I hope to publish in the next few days rounding up that unusual driver market situation.

title: Obama Will Pledge Emissions Cuts
description: President Obama will speak at the climate change conference in Copenhagen next month, offering to reduce greenhouse gas emissions about 17% below 2005 levels by 2020.

title: Making Room for a Healthful Dessert
description: Most Thanksgiving meals end with the declaration, I couldnt eat another bite. But then the pumpkin pie and other desserts show up, and somehow, we manage.

title: Excerpt: 'Men of a Certain Age'
description: The new bittersweet TNT series centers on middle-aged buddies played by Ray Romano, Scott Bakula and Andre Braugher.

title: Photo of the Week
description: Women wearing the traditional garb of the Toucouleur people in Dakar, Senegal.

title: Yes, Were Open
description: SELF EDGE is the name of a good-looking store on Orchard Street that opened in July. It sells classic examples of American work-wear, like chambray shirts, that are produced in Japan with old American machines and the deadstock of American button and zipper makers. With the geeky solemnity of a rare seed catalog, the stores Web site declared of Flat Head, one of its lines: Probably the finest construction ever seen on button-down shirts.

title: Muppet News Flash: Spill OReilly Enters the No-Spin Zone
description: Has there finally been a ceasefire in the war of words between Sesame Street and political conservatives? On his Fox News program, The OReilly Factor, Bill OReilly was introduced to his Muppet counterpart, Spill OReilly, who asserts that Grouches are totally unbiased. You want to know the truth about us Grouches? says Spill OReilly. We cant stand anybody! You all drive us crazy.

title: Walking Into the Earths Heart: The Grand Canyon
description: I HAVE heard rumors of visitors who were disappointed, J. B. Priestley once said of the Grand Canyon. The same people will be disappointed at the Day of Judgment.

title: Ben Nelson Explains His Health Care Vote
description: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, has offered up an interesting explanation for his vote to move forward with debate of major health care legislation: he stopped his fellow Democrats from playing parliamentary hardball that he said would have led to a fast-tracked bill and sidelined centrists like himself.

title: App of the Week: A Guide to Where the Deals Are
description: I have a friend who awaits the annual e-mailing of the Black Friday Excel spreadsheet with greater anticipation than the gifts that may come from it. The coveted list is a compilation of leaks involving deals that will be offered the Friday after Thanksgiving.

title: Dells Zino May Be Square, but It Doesnt Lack for Color
description: The Dell Zino (full name Inspiron Zino HD) comes in a box a bit bigger than Apples Mac Mini, and adds some cosmetic flavor to the category of compact desktop computers. While the Mini is available in any color as long as its white, Zino has a selection of 10 replaceable, colorful lids you can purchase if you change the curtains or the sofa or just get bored with pink.

title: Are Cupcakes a Viable Business?
description: We just published a story by Elizabeth Olson that takes a look at the Great Cupcake Rush of 09, an almost inexplicable spread of cupcakeries around the country. As Ms. Olson reports, a handful of chains  Magnolia Bakery in New York, Sprinkles Cupcakes in Beverly Hills  seem to be thriving but for many others its a struggle.

title: This Nosy Matchmaker Helps Camera Shoppers Decide
description: If youre having trouble deciding which digital camera to buy  or just want a second opinion  take a look at a new Web site called Measy.com.

title: A Holiday Dilemma: What to Do if a Restaurant Undercharges You?
description: We had agreed when we started doing this blog that we would explore the issue of when you cross the line from being financially savvy to being unethical. I hadnt expected to have an example so soon.

title: A Lock for Browsers Thats Nearly Childproof
description: Parents, teachers and librarians now have a new reason to like Google.

title: Tailoring the Image to Fit the Clothes
description: LOTS of people in fashion are better at communicating their ideas with needle and thread than with nouns and verbs.

title: A True Repeat Customer: Becoming Jewish 3 Times
description: It would be easy to label Circumcise Me, at the Bleecker Street Theater, as merely the latest in the ever-stocked stream of Off Broadway solo acts that are heavy on jokes and seasoned lightly with social commentary.

title: Trout Amid the Cows and Willows in Iowa
description: DECORAH, Iowa  We cant fish my favorite trout stream today, because theres a Jersey bull in the pasture there that hates me.

title: The meaning of Thanksgiving
description: Wednesday Addams explains it all.

title: Thanksgiving Questions Answered, Part XVI
description: What would you serve as appetizers on Thanksgiving? I am invited to someones home but I offered to take care of the apps. AG, NYC

title: Corrections: For Some Parents, Shouting Is the New Spanking
description: An article on Oct. 22 about parental guilt over reprimanding children quoted incorrectly from a survey published in the book Mommy Guilt: Learn to Worry Less, Focus on What Matters Most and Raise Happier Kids in which two-thirds of respondents named yelling  not working or missing a school event  as their biggest guilt inducer. The survey, as well as the rest of the book, did not mention spanking.

title: Corrections: Its All a Blur to Them
description: A picture caption last Thursday with an article about gender blurring in fashion misspelled the middle name and omitted the surname of the woman shown with Christian Brylle and Sheila Marquez. She is Hanne Gaby Odiele, not Hanne Goby.

title: Book Review: The Fourth Part of the World and Strange Maps
description: The Fourth Part of the World By Toby Lester Free Press, 462 pages, $30 hardcover

title: Old Rockers Harnessing the Old Power
description: Sonic Youth has dismantled and reassembled so many rock-band strategies over the years that it can begin to feel unnerving when a simple, durable idea takes hold. Concision, for example. Theres nothing inherently deep or mysterious about a three-to-four-minute pop song, but with the right balance of nerve and craft, the possibilities can usually overwhelm the constraints.

title: Hiking the Australian Desert Near Ayers Rock
description: THE rigors of trekking across a dusty, rock-strewn desert are repaid with certain quiet pleasures  like falling asleep while gazing through the mesh roof of your tent at an imponderably big sky smeared with starlight. Who needs a tent fly when the average rainfall for the month is a third of an inch?

title: Still Asking for Help, the Day After the Bad News
description: One man walked in silence, making a shame-on-you gesture with two fingers. Another muttered a skeptical uh, huh beneath his breath. A woman stage-whispered to her friend about the scam that was on TV last night. Two men in suits wanted to inspect the paperwork. One man, clearly agitated, yelled: Didnt you get busted? How do you hold your head up?

title: In Warhols Head, Where Something Surreal Ensues
description: New Haven

title: Talking Turkey Under Slate Gray Skies
description: We are deep-frying a turkey and are worried about it exploding as I have been told could happen? Is this a real threat? Should we have a backup plan? Joe, Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

title: Beer Connoisseurs Defy Hurdles to Start Breweries
description: Like scores of other avid home brewers, Shane C. Welch has turned his personal passion into a commercial enterprise. But he has followed his own path in marketing his beers.

title: Doubting a Locked-In Mans Words
description: Update | 8:45 p.m. Rom Houben, a Belgian man who spent 23 years lying motionless in bed, suffering from complete paralysis that was misdiagnosed as the result of a coma, was discovered to have been fully conscious three years ago by a doctor using new brain-scan technology.

title: City, and Artist, Under Construction
description: LONDON  Some of the brass outside the clubs on Pall Mall needs a little buffing these days, a minor sign of something maybe, but London is still prosperous. A single-fare subway ticket costs a whopping $6.60.

title: Key Players in the Afghanistan Decision
description: White House staff, military leaders and members of Congress have had significant roles in the discussions over the war in Afghanistan.

title: Ever a Huckleberry Friend, Come Rain or Come Shine
description: To attend an Andrea Marcovicci cabaret show is to participate in a communal rite in which it is tacitly understood  at least during the duration of the performance  that nothing today can match the magic and romance of old Hollywood and Broadway. An audience of a certain age agrees to gorge retrospectively on the illusions of youth from an era long before the proliferation of viral gossip and reality television. As the ceremonial priestess, Ms. Marcovicci plays a grand, smiling Hollywood hostess  a Loretta Young-like figure  throwing open doors to a rose-colored mythology.

title: An Alaskan Village in Crisis
description: Nikolski, a village of 30 people in the Aleutian Islands, is losing its school. The fate of the entire village is uncertain.

title: Travel Deals: Black Friday Hotel Sales
description: For the traveler on your Christmas list, several hotels are offering Black Friday deals. And, of course, the sales start early.

title: Pratfalls at the Palace, Upstairs or Downstairs
description: The only thing missing from the Metropolitan Operas latest revival of Mozarts Nozze di Figaro on Monday night was a starters pistol, or so you might have thought during a breakneck overture. Fabio Luisi, the conductor, drove the music so hard at times that split ends clearly showed among Mozarts silken strands. Mr. Luisi, it bears saying, is a very fine conductor. When the pace was reined in slightly, the orchestral performance was impressively even and lively.

title: The Bronx Stations
description: Cass Gilbert won the commission for a string of Bronx railway stations, all built about 1908. Those that have not been demolished have seen better days.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Nov. 25
description: Holiday travelers rushed through New York Citys transit hubs ahead of Thanksgiving (Slides 1, 2 and 3), but one family had no line to wait in at Kennedy International Airport (Slide 4). Id al-Adha, which commemorates the end of the Islamic pilgramage (Slide 5) to Saudi Arabia, will take place this weekend. While news about President Obamas decision on Afghanistan strategy made headlines before the long weekend, Afghans themselves were preparing for their own holiday feast (Slide 6).

title: Iranian-American Faces New Spying Charge
description: TORONTO  An Iranian-American scholar, Kian Tajbakhsh, already serving a 15-year prison sentence for spying, is facing a new charge of spying, a family member said Wednesday.

title: But Im on the List ...
description: THE invitation that arrived on fashion editors desks this week looked like the tab landing on the table at the end of dinner. It came in a fancy faux-leather folder and offered them the chance to join a select group of individuals who are apparently the only ones allowed to buy clothes from this new German brand, which is sold, as its handlers say, by invitation only.

title: Inside Nikolski
description: More than 30 schools in Alaskas rural areas are at risk of closing because of dwindling populations.

title: Greenberg and A.I.G. Settle Legal Disputes
description: The American International Group said on Wednesday that it had settled long-running legal battles with Maurice R. Greenberg, the companys former chief executive, in an attempt to move past years of costly fighting.

title: A.I.G. Settles Legal Disputes With Greenberg
description: Update | 8:45 a.m. The American International Group said Wednesday afternoon that it has settled its long-running legal battle with Maurice R. Greenberg, the companys former chief executive, in an attempt to move past years of contentious fighting.

title: Robin Williams: A Good Role Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Gustavo Dudamel: Keeping Up the Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: Alaskas Rural Schools Fight Off Extinction
description: NIKOLSKI, Alaska  This distant dot in the Aleutian Islands needed just 10 students for its school to dodge a fatal cut from the state budget. It reached across Alaska and beyond but could find only nine.

title: When Is a Restaurant Bill Too Little?
description: On the Bucks blog, a question of ethics in a restaurant: After dinner with her husband and his aunt at a well-known restaurant in the San Francisco Bay area, Jennifer Saranow Schultz writes, we realized that the restaurant had undercharged us for wine by somewhere between $10 and $30. But we also felt the food had been underwhelming. The aunt, who was paying, opted to add about half the difference to the tip. In the end, she said, I dont think we should have equated disappointment with the meal as a right to take half the undercharge in silence.

title: New M.L.S. Team Picks 10 in Expansion Draft
description: The Philadelphia Union, the 16th Major League Soccer team, which will begin play in 2010, selected 10 players in Fridays expansion draft.

title: Technology to Help Navigate Black Friday Sales
description: Earlier this week, I received the kind of frantic text message that makes your heart drop into your stomach. It simply read: Please call home ASAP  URGENT!

title: Greater Use of Vaccine for Infection Is Urged
description: There has been a worrisome spike in secondary bacterial infections among Americans with swine flu, federal health officials said Wednesday, urging more people at risk to get the underused vaccine that prevents some of those infections.

title: From Electronicas Infancy, When Computers Filled Rooms, Not Laps
description: In the early 1960s composers who had been fascinated with electronic music in the 50s were seeking ways to combine the synthetic sounds they were producing on room-size computers and early synthesizers with the more familiar timbres of acoustic instruments. The Argentine-born American composer Mario Davidovsky, then in his late 20s, was a star of this movement: his Synchronisms No. 1, for flute and electronic sound, appeared in 1962, and new installments turned up periodically through 2006, when he wrote Synchronisms No. 12, for clarinet and tape.

title: After 5 Years, Cortlandt Street Station Partly Reopens
description: The Cortlandt Street station on the R and W lines, which was closed for one year after the 9/11 attack and then shut again in August 2005 to accommodate construction of the Fulton Street transit complex in Lower Manhattan, was partly reopened on Wednesday. For now, the station will only accommodate northbound service on the R and W lines, which travel to Midtown and then Queens. (The W runs only on weekdays, and the N makes stops at the station late at night.)

title: Operas Night to Take New Voices Into the Fold
description: The annual concert of the Richard Tucker Music Foundation, which was created in 1975 to offer emerging singers awards, grants and performance opportunities, took place at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening. Fabio Luisi conducted members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and the New York Choral Society, opening with a rousing rendition of the overture to Verdis Nabucco.

title: Get Aboard, Wise Guy. Next Stop, the Bada Bing.
description: FOR a guy who claims he was sort of whacked in the pilot episode of The Sopranos, Marc Baron has had quite an afterlife.

title: Resetting the Tables at Le Cirque
description: TUCKED into a corner where his friend the D.J. Francesco Civetta manned the turntables, Julian Lennon waxed mellow. I love to sit and watch the world go by, said Mr. Lennon, one in a sprinkling of notables at a private party at Le Cirque on Nov. 20. A drink might give him enough courage, he said, to check out the lounge that has been set aside for weekly invitation-only parties, an area that seemed to him filled with so many great characters from all walks of life.

title: Novel Now, but Not for Long
description: We like to think were so advanced, you know? Were so modern. Were not like our ancestors, whom we picture exclusively in black-and-white, running around in jerky fast motion. How quaint they were with their Model Ts and gas lamps!

title: The Pregame Huddle: Intrastate Rivalries
description: Thanksgiving weekend brings us some key rivalry games, including Florida against Florida State. Plus, the latest coaches to come under fire.

title: How to Use Thanksgiving 911
description: Update | 7 a.m. The New York Times Thanksgiving Help Desk is open for business on Thanksgiving. I am sitting at it, armed with coffee, reference books, source lists, phone lists and all that the World Wide Web provides, prepared to answer your emergency questions about the bird, the stuffing, the sides, the gravy, the wine, how to say grace (whether to say grace!), the timing, the desserts, the fact that you said youd make butternut squash and now youre looking at the things and realize you have no idea how to make butternut squash, whatever you need.

title: Scene Stealers at City Ballets Gala Night
description: Every principal dancer with New York City Ballet performed in Tuesday evenings gala, save for Albert Evans and Sbastien Marcovici, who are out with injuries. In a high-wattage cameo the Paris Opera Ballet toiles Aurlie Dupont and Mathias Heymann did their darndest to Frenchify Balanchines Rubies. There were films, a Peter Martins premiere and a speech by David H. Koch, whose $100 million helped remake the theater that now bears his name.

title: Thanksgiving Miscellany
description: Jim Manzi on the hacked climate emails.

title: KFC Has Consumers Remembering KGC
description: An annual survey of memorable new products gave the top honor for 2009 to the Kentucky Grilled Chicken menu item, which was introduced by the KFC unit of Yum Brands.

title: Shaking Off the Shame
description: MUNCY, Pa.

title: Correction: Two Films, Two Routes From Poverty
description: A film column last Sunday about the different stories of poverty in two new films misstated, at one point, the title of one of the movies. As the article noted elsewhere, it is The Blind Side, not The Blind Spot. (The other film that examines issues of poverty is Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire.)

title: A Director Who Gives Business the Business
description: EVEN though Jason Reitmans last film, Juno, was nominated for a best picture Oscar and his forthcoming film, Up in the Air, is among the most buzzed about this year, you probably wouldnt notice this bearded young man walking by you in an airport.

title: On Assignment: Ceiling Briefly Unlimited
description: I was elated to be going to Alaska again. Id made several trips there in recent months and looked forward to one that wouldnt involve beehive hairdos or backyard views of Russia.

title: Community Standard or Double Standard?
description: It wasnt really the man-on-man kiss or the simulated oral sex that marked Adam Lamberts performance on the American Music Awards on Sunday as shocking. Mostly it was ABCs reaction. By rescinding Mr. Lamberts invitation to sing on Good Morning America, ABC self-protectively drew a line that networks usually prefer to keep blurred.

title: Correction: Filmmakers Controversy: Their Dad
description: An article on Nov. 15 about the creation of the documentary William Kunstler: Disturbing the Universe, part of a genre of films about figures made by their relatives  which includes Heir to an Execution, by Ivy Meeropol, a granddaughter of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg  misstated the crime for which the Rosenbergs were convicted. They were convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage, not for spying for the Soviet Union.

title: Correction: The Week Ahead: Nov. 15  21
description: Because of an editing error, a pop entry in the Week Ahead report on Nov. 15 about the Cuban band Septeto Nacional Ignacio Pieiro misidentified the country that bore the music embraced in Havana in the early 20th century. It was the Oriente region of Cuba, not the Oriente region of Ecuador.

title: Two Ways to See Friends
description: Two Ways

title: Holiday Cheer, or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Swiss Court Approves Bail for Polanski
description: A Swiss court on Wednesday granted bail to the filmmaker Roman Polanski, right, who was being detained as he fights extradition to the United States to face sentencing on charges of having sex with a 13-year-old girl. The Swiss Federal Criminal Court granted Mr. Polanskis appeal against detention in exchange for $4.5 million, along with other guarantees like the surrender of his identity papers to ensure he does not leave the country, the federal tribunal said. The three judges of the court estimated that the bail amount was a substantial portion of Mr. Polanskis fortune and that given his advanced age  he is 76  the possibility of reaccumulation of fortune in this amount would not be certain. The court considered the bail and the supporting measures as being sufficient to avert the risk of flight, it said. The Justice Ministry has 10 days to submit an appeal to the Swiss Federal Supreme Court. If it does not appeal, Mr. Polanski would be allowed to leave his jail cell and remain under house arrest and electronic monitoring at his holiday chalet in the resort of Gstaad.

title: John Mayer Is No. 1 in Pre-Holiday Week
description: John Mayers latest album, Battle Studies (Columbia), easily topped the Billboard chart this week with 286,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In a week heavy with prominent new releases as the music industry gears up the for the holiday shopping period, Andrea Bocellis My Christmas (Sugar/Decca) held at No. 2 with 185,000 sales, beating out Norah Jones (No. 3 with 180,000 sales), the Christian rock band Casting Crowns (No. 4, 167,000), 50 Cent (No. 5, 160,000) and the 15-year-old pop heartthrob Justin Bieber (No. 6, 137,000). Michael Jacksons This Is It (Epic) fell three spots to No. 7 with 96,000, The Twilight Saga: New Moon (Chop Shop/Atlantic) jumped two to No. 8, with 93,000 sales.

title: Settling In Nicely
description: With lower storefront rents to contend with, some designers take control, carve out a niche and forge ahead to relate to today's consumers.

title: Pompidou Center Workers Extend Strike
description: Staff members on strike at the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris, at left, decided on Tuesday to extend their protest as that modern art museum weighs job cuts, Agence France-Presse reported. On Monday museum employees and security guards walked out amid fears that more than 400 jobs will be cut at the museums Beaubourg building over the next 10 years. The French government could reduce the museums payroll by not replacing employees who retire; more than 40 percent of the staff members at the Pompidou Center are older than 50, and the legal retirement age in France is 70. On Tuesday representatives of the museum staff met with aides to Frdric Mitterrand, the French culture minister, but a union official told Agence France-Presse that the meeting did not go well. After a meeting Wednesday with Alain Seban, president of the Pompidou Center, Franck Guillaumet, who heads the cultural section of Frances major union, the Confederaton Gnrale du Travail, said, The strike must go on. He added that the job cuts would also affect other big cultural institutions, including the Louvre, Versailles and the National Library.

title: Rethinking Home Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Rogue Tops Book Sales Chart
description: Going Rogue, the newly released memoir by Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor and Republican nominee for vice president, sold 469,000 copies in its first week of release, according to figures released Wednesday by Nielsen BookScan. That made Going Rogue the top-selling book of the week on Nielsen BookScans chart, putting it ahead of new releases from authors like James Patterson (whose novel I, Alex Cross was No. 2) and Stephen King (whose novel Under the Dome was No. 3), as well as Dan Browns best-selling potboiler The Lost Symbol. Ms. Palins book also pulled the second-best first-week sales of any memoir by a current or past president, or vice presidential or presidential contender, Nielsen BookScan said. The No. 1 book on that list, My Life, by Bill Clinton, sold 606,000 copies in its first week in 2004. HarperCollins, which released Going Rogue, said the books overall first-week sales totaled 700,000 copies. Nielsen BookScan does not track sales at some mass market retailers, like Wal-Mart and Sams Club.

title: You Call That Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: Show Wont Close to Let Emperor In
description: Among those in the theater industry who were surprised on Tuesday by the announcement that the Irish Repertory Theaters production of The Emperor Jones would be transferring to the SoHo Playhouse were the producers of Made in Heaven, the show that is playing at that Off-Broadway theater. On Wednesday the producers of Made in Heaven, a comedy that opened at the SoHo Playhouse on Nov. 2, said that they had no intention of vacating the theater to accommodate The Emperor Jones, starring John Douglas Thompson, above, which is supposed to begin previews there on Dec. 15. The Made in Heaven producers said that their contract with the playhouse stated that they must give the theater four weeks notice before closing the show. In a statement, Barbara Ligeti, the shows lead producer, said, I am bemused at the image of the cast of Emperor Jones sitting in the laps of the company of Made in Heaven on that small stage. The (conjoined) twins will love it. It was unclear whether the shows contract with the SoHo Playhouse included an out clause that permitted the theater to close the show if its grosses dipped below a certain dollar amount. Representatives for Darren Lee Cole, the plahouses general manager, and Ciarn OReilly, the producing director of the Irish Rep, said that both men were traveling and could not be reached for comment.

title: Ever Hear of Curtains?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pity the Poor Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Harnessing Darwin to Push an Ancient Intellectual Center to Evolve
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt  It is not that Charles Darwin and the theory of evolution are unknown here. But even among those who profess to know something about the subject, the common understanding is that Darwin said man came from monkeys.

title: Oh, the Places Youll Go After Barging In
description: AS a child in north St. Louis, pretty much the only jumping Antonio Douthit did was to leap out a window and land on a mattress.

title: Either One by Itself Is Rare. But Both in the Same Deal?
description: Most Americans are celebrating Thanksgiving with their families. But numerous bridge players are currently traveling to San Diego for the American Contract Bridge Leagues Fall North American Championships, which get under way in earnest on Friday.

title: A Power Couple Set to a Melody Thats Domestic
description: NOVEMBER has been a typically busy time in the Murphy household. The Murphys of opera circles in New York and abroad, that is: the soprano Heidi Grant Murphy, celebrating her 20th season at the Metropolitan Opera, and her husband of 18 years, the pianist Kevin Murphy, formerly a valued coach at the Met and now the director of music administration at the New York City Opera.

title: Bringing Big Smiles to iPhone Shutterbugs
description: A basic tenet of photography is that the best camera is the one you have on hand when you need it. For many people these days, that means an iPhone.

title: Intimate Ella Fitzgerald, Rediscovered
description: WITH all the multi-disc jazz boxes that have come out in recent years  the complete Miles Davis on Columbia, the complete Charlie Parker on Savoy, the complete Duke Ellington on RCA and so on  its hard to believe that any significant tapes by any major musician might still be languishing undiscovered in a record companys archives.

title: Dinner With the Stars?
description: Photographs from recent parties at Le Cirque, a restaurant trying to revamp its image.

title: G.M. Wont Close Germanys Opel Plants
description: General Motors said on Wednesday that it would not close any of its four Opel plants in Germany, a decision that appeared to be intended to earn favor with the officials in Berlin who control billions of euros in aid for the units reorganization.

title: The Week Ahead: Nov. 29  Dec. 5
description: Theater

title: The Anatomy of a (Fourth-Down) Decision
description: Frank Frigo, along with Chuck Bower, developed the Zeus computer program, which can simulate hundreds of thousands of N.F.L. outcomes in seconds.

title: Vietnam Raises Rates and Devalues Currency to Check Inflation
description: Vietnam raised its benchmark interest rate Wednesday and reset its official exchange rate, moves intended to help rein in lending, control inflation and stabilize its currency.
