description: ART

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Iranian Militiamen Try to Cow Opposition Figure
description: TORONTO  About 60 members of the hard-line Basij militia force demonstrated Thursday outside a house in Qum, Iran, where the opposition leader Mehdi Karroubi was staying, in an effort to intimidate him before a large opposition rally planned for next month, according to officials in Mr. Karroubis party.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Rivalry Alone Is a Feast, but Texas Has More Flavor
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  The annual Texas-Texas A&M game is such a storied rivalry that is has been known to cause strife at Thanksgiving dinners in this state.

title: Ali Kordan, Iranian Official Fired Over Fake Degree, Dies at 51
description: TORONTO  Ali Kordan, a hard-line ally of Irans president who was dismissed a year ago as interior minister for lying about having received an honorary doctorate from Oxford University, died Sunday in Tehran. He was 51.

title: Ohio Looks to Replace a Capitol Delegate
description: CINCINNATI  For more than 100 years, Gov. William Allen and President James A. Garfield have represented Ohio in the National Statuary Hall Collection in the United States Capitol in Washington.

title: Wagner Seeks to Fill Role as United States Favorite
description: Some of the worlds best figure skaters will compete in Tokyo next week at the Grand Prix Final, a key event as the Vancouver Winter Games draw near.

title: 4 Vie for Kennedys Seat, but Only 3 Seek His Mantle
description: BOSTON  Ask not how the Democratic candidates to succeed Senator Edward M. Kennedy would blaze a new path: most are too busy trying to prove themselves his ideological twin as the Dec. 8 primary draws near.

title: Testing Bloombergs Grip on the Budget Ax
description: As he sought to persuade wary voters that he deserved a third term as mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg sold himself as a no-nonsense financial watchdog who was ready to swing the budget ax.

title: Abortion in Health Plan Tests a Pennsylvania Senator
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania wants to talk about health care, Medicare, childrens insurance, a public option  anything but abortion.

title: Trying to Explain a Drop in Infant Mortality
description: MADISON, Wis.  Seven and a half months into Ta-Shai Pendletons first pregnancy, her child was stillborn. Then in early 2008, she bore a daughter prematurely.

title: Retailers Take a Wait-and-See Approach to Holiday Hiring
description: The traditional kickoff of the holiday shopping season normally coincides with a flurry of seasonal hiring in the city, amounting to as many as 25,000 extra jobs. But last years financial crisis caused holiday hiring to fall off, and this years recession had a similar effect

title: HSBC Returns to Its Roots in Hong Kong
description: HSBC is so tied to Hong Kong that when the banks shares dropped sharply earlier this year a local television commentator burst into tears while reporting the news.

title: Faces in the Crowd
description: Crowds of people lined the streets to see the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: Back to the Land
Unforgettable Books for Those You Remember
description: Theres a good reason why the three daily book critics for The New York Times dont make 10-best lists at the end of the year: we cant. None of us has read everything. Our reviewing assignments dont overlap. None of us has an objective overview of the years best and most important books, but this is what we do have: favorites. They are books we have not only admired in the abstract but also enjoyed, recommended and given to friends.

title: Dollar Hits a 14-Year Low Versus the Yen
description: TOKYO  The dollar tumbled to a 14-year low against the yen on Thursday, reinforcing concern in Tokyo that Americas already-strapped consumers would buy even fewer Japanese cars and gadgets.

title: Taliban Open Northern Front in Afghanistan
description: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  Far from the heartland of the Taliban insurgency in the south, this once peaceful northern province was one place American and Afghan officials thought they did not have to worry about.

title: Ex-UBS Banker Seeks Billions for Blowing Whistle
description: Bradley C. Birkenfeld was sentenced to 40 months in prison for helping rich Americans dodge their taxes. Now he is hoping for a bit more  a few billion dollars more.

title: Taxing the Speculators
description: Should we use taxes to deter financial speculation? Yes, say top British officials, who oversee the City of London, one of the worlds two great banking centers. Other European governments agree  and theyre right.

title: No Rookie of the Year, but a Cornerstone Player
description: As a San Francisco Giants rookie in 1982, Chili Davis batted .261 with 19 home runs, 76 runs batted in, 24 stolen bases and 16 outfield assists in 154 games. As a Giants beat writer that year, I saw every one of them.

title: Poverty Could Imperil the Amnesty in Niger Delta
description: ALUU, Nigeria  A wary peace has settled over this strategic region, a major world oil supplier and for years a combustible nexus of third world militancy, deprivation and government corruption.

title: Surgery for Mental Ills Offers Both Hope and Risk
description: One was a middle-aged man who refused to get into the shower. The other was a teenager who was afraid to get out.

title: Stalemate in Albany as State Nears Its Last Dollar
description: ALBANY  New York State is running out of cash.

title: For Athletes in Motion, Real Estate Can Be a Burden
description: Last season, the veteran fullback Tony Richardson came to the Jets as a free agent, but he remained tethered to Minnesota by real estate. As the house Richardson bought during his two seasons with the Vikings languished on the market, he began paying rent in New York.

title: The Other Education
description: Like many of you, I went to elementary school, high school and college. I took such and such classes, earned such and such grades, and amassed such and such degrees.

title: Lottery Numbers
Dubais Move on Debt Rattles Markets Worldwide
description: Global financial markets swooned Thursday, with London seeing its most precipitous drop in nearly nine months, a day after Dubai stunned investors with the news that it was asking banks to allow its main investment vehicle, Dubai World, to suspend its debt repayments for six months.

title: On a Mission to Banish the Saggy Bottom
description: WHEN women try on pants, the first thing they do is turn around and look over their shoulders into the mirror. If Andy Dunn has his way, men will soon do the same.

title: Palin Goes Gracious
description: I got a lesson in civility, grace under pressure and general human fellowship recently from, of all people, Sarah Palin.

title: On a Spectacles Sidelines, Watching and Hoping for a Crowd of Shoppers
description: As crowds began to gather Thursday under the glare of Times Square on an otherwise flat, gray morning, the doors to a small Seventh Avenue souvenir shop swung open at 7 a.m.

title: The Names Ring a Few Bells
description: Whitney Houston and Brittany Spears shared a college dorm room two years ago. It was a unique pairing that quickly evolved into a strong friendship, but there were no albums or Grammy Awards to show for it, and no paparazzi lurking when they went out to eat.

title: U.S. Unlikely to Use the Ethanol Congress Ordered
description: WASHINGTON  Two years ago, Congress ordered the nations gasoline refiners to do something that is turning out to be mathematically impossible.

title: Hope Born of Desperation
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Ed Sessas fine previous puzzle was about dropping letters from theme clues (Across Lite, Solution). This seems to be a personal theme for him as well. In his debut puzzle, a Monday I also enjoyed (Across Lite, Solution), he billed himself as Edward M. Sessa. By puzzle No. 2 he was down to Edward Sessa, and today hes a mere Ed Sessa. Letters are starting to get critical at this point, so who knows what hell be next. In any case, you now have links to all his puzzles and you can solve his entire oeuvre. And remember, you can find the entire New York Times daily and Sunday puzzle archive organized by constructor here, so look up your favorite and print out a set of puzzles for a rainy weekend.

title: Subway Killing Captured by a Photo Student
description: It began with a startling, inexplicable explosion of anger over a seat on a D train. And then the passenger who had resisted giving up his seat was bleeding from stab wounds, staggering through the car, collapsing, dying.

title: Knicks Feel Young Players Growing Pains
description: SACRAMENTO  Mike DAntoni has played his rotation like an accordion, compressing it sometimes and widening it at others in search of a middle ground with his veteran placeholders and younger players.

title: Keeping Derivatives in the Dark
description: Opaque markets breed insider profits and abuse of investors. Sunshine can bring competition and lower costs even if regulators do little beyond letting the sunlight shine.

title: Again, Debt Disqualifies Applicant From the Bar
description: Mind how you handle your student loans aspiring lawyers, or you could find your debt hurting more than your bank accounts. Loans could derail your career before it can start.

title: Career Begun in London Is Flourishing in Desert
description: The ball was in Eric Boatengs hands near the basket, but he shuffled his feet before he could go up against the defender and was whistled for a walk. His pass from the lane toward a teammate on the baseline sailed out of bounds. His hook shot hit nothing but air.

title: Limit on Bank Fee Wont Be Painless
description: Regulators and politicians are competing to rein in bank overdraft fees. The Federal Reserve decided this month that banks must receive customers consent before allowing them to overdraw their accounts. Other proposals in Congress go even further, limiting charges or prescribing the structure of fees.

title: Doormen and Residents: Under One Roof, Yet Far Apart
description: The contradictory relationship between building residents and doormen is an unspoken reality under the awnings of East 74th Street. Doormen have an intimate knowledge of residents comings and goings. They are trusted not only with security but often with confidences from weary residents at the end of a work day. They watch the buildings children grow up.

title: Weekly Pick Em: A Thanksgiving Rivalry Weekend
description: On a holiday rivalry weekend like this one, one game seems to stand out above the rest: Alabama at Auburn. But, since the No. 2 Crimson Tide are favored and a victory by the Tigers, while possible, would be a major upset, were staying away from that matchup in this weeks picks. Besides, there are plenty of other intriguing games this weekend, beginning with Fridays Backyard Brawl between Pittsburgh and West Virginia. Oklahoma and Oklahoma State, and B.Y.U. and Utah will face off in tense in-state rivalry games, while Les Miles will try to put his last-minute time mismanagement debacle behind him when Louisiana State faces Arkansas. But the coach whose seat is at the highest temperature right now is Charlie Weis. Notre Dame faces Stanford on Saturday, and has a chance to get a victory for Weis in what may be his last game as the Irishs coach. Will Jimmy Clausen and crew come through for Weis? Our prognosticators have made their selections, and you can let us know what you think of them. If you agree, disagree or merely find the picks laughable, feel free to drop a comment below.

title: Bay Area Chefs Dodge New York Knives
description: Bay Area foodies have been up in arms lately over a series of critical comments from chefs in New York. Most recently, Momofukus David Chang, in a New York conversation with Anthony Bourdain, said of Bay Area chefs: They dont manipulate food, they just put figs on a plate. Food blogs exploded; the San Francisco Asia Society even canceled a cookbook signing by Mr. Chang.

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: Man Charged in Hit-and-Run That Killed Couple Outside Staten Island Church
description: A Staten Island man with a history of traffic violations was charged on Thursday in a hit-and-run accident that killed an elderly couple, who were struck outside their church the night before as they walked to a Thanksgiving Mass with cans of food for the poor, the authorities said.

title: Hugh Morgan Hill, the Storyteller Brother Blue, Dies at 88
description: Hugh Morgan Hill, who as the storyteller known as Brother Blue captivated passers-by on the streets of Boston and Cambridge, Mass., with his parables, life stories and idiosyncratic retellings of Shakespeares plays, and who became a fixture at storytelling conferences and gatherings in the United States and abroad, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Cambridge. He was 88.

title: Chronicling a Life and Honing Job Skills
description: A lot of people cry over their hard-luck stories. Dominique Wright wants to write about hers.

title: Bay Area Highlights for Nov. 27
description: Powerful Force | Terrance Alan and the San Francisco entertainment commission have taken day-to-day control over the rowdy, popular clubs that, owners estimate, represent $1 billion of the citys $8 billion in annual tourist revenue.

title: Yes, You Owe That Tax
description: As many Americans gird themselves for the Black Friday shopping crush, we can think of a lot of reasons to stay home and do holiday shopping online. Not having to pay sales taxes should not be one of them.

title: Immigrants, Criminalized
description: A bedrock premise of smart immigration reform is the sharp distinction it draws between criminal aliens and Americans-in-waiting. While it acknowledges that illegal immigrants need to get right with the law, it treats illegal status as a civil matter to be resolved by the machinery of naturalization, not by the police and prisons.

title: A Big Loss for Big Tobacco
description: A Florida jury has ordered Philip Morris USA to pay $300 million to a former smoker who developed severe emphysema and may need a lung transplant. The verdict may encourage more plaintiffs and lawyers to bring similar claims. There should be more lawsuits seeking not only monetary damages, but changes in how the tobacco industry markets its products.

title: Fly the Sleazy Skies
description: The Federal Election Commission  the supposed referee of fair campaigning  has just created an ethics loophole big enough for lobbyists to fly a corporate jet through. The commission has taken upon itself to reverse the Senates self-restriction against lawmakers cozy cut-rate travels on corporate jets.

title: No Appeal on Polanski Bail
description: Swiss officials said on Thursday that they would not challenge a court ruling permitting Roman Polanski to be freed on bail as he fights extradition to the United States to face sentencing for having sex with a 13-year-old girl. On Wednesday the Swiss Federal Criminal Court granted Mr. Polanskis appeal against detention in exchange for $4.5 million, along with other guarantees like the surrender of his identity papers to ensure he does not leave the country. Still, Interpol issued an advisory to its 188 member countries saying that Mr. Polanski should be arrested if he tried to travel. He fled the United States in 1978 before being sentenced. The Justice Ministry had 10 days to submit an appeal to the Swiss Federal Supreme Court, but said on Thursday that it had decided not to. The development means that Mr. Polanski may leave his jail cell and remain under house arrest and electronic monitoring at his holiday chalet, above, in Gstaad, a Swiss resort town.

title: Insured, but Not Covered
description: Adrienne Schroeder recently moved to Richmond, Va., from Bozeman, Mont., to care for her aging father. Medical expenses  not his, but hers  are a concern.

title: Broncos Beat Giants, 26-6.
description: Denver passed and ran effectively while also harassing Eli Manning.

title: Taking the Health Care Debate to the Mall
description: Advocates of health care legislation are facing many challenges in getting their messages across to the public over the holidays. So one advocacy group is essentially moving its campaign to where the consumers are: stores and shopping malls.

title: Black Friday 2009
description: For Black Friday this year, some stores increased security for the anticipated holiday shopping frenzy.

title: If It Looks Like Poe and Sounds Like Poe . . .
description: Saturday, Nov. 27, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Broncos Bury the Giants
description: DENVER  With five games remaining in the Giants deteriorating season, defensive end Justin Tuck offered an optimistic take on the teams chances in the race for the N.F.C. East title.

title: One Foot in the Past
description: Inwood, the northernmost neighborhood in Manhattan, is a place of hills and history. Inwood Hill Park, 196 acres of tree-filled landscape, dominates the scene, and traces of Lenape Indians and Dutch settlers abound. But there are relative newcomers, too, including opera singers and others who are attracted to Inwoods burgeoning arts community. One artist who lives there  and grew up there  is Lin-Manuel Miranda, the Grammy- and Tony-winning creator of the Broadway musical In the Heights. The expedition begins at the 207th Street station, the terminus of the A train.

title: Rogers Communications to Cut 900 Jobs in Canada
description: Rogers Communications, the largest wireless carrier in Canada, said it was eliminating about 900 jobs nationwide as the company reorganized its wireless and cable units. The company, based in Toronto, said the cuts affected about 3 percent of its 30,000 employees. Rogers made the move to adapt to the way consumers buy and download entertainment, using wireless devices like Apples iPhone to watch movies and TV shows.

title: Readers Digest Turnaround Plan Advances
description: The Readers Digest Association won bankruptcy court approval for an outline of its turnaround plan after revisions prompted bondholders, a pension trustee and the United States to withdraw their objections. Judge Robert D. Drain of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan said on Tuesday that he would approve the so-called disclosure statement, which explains terms of the reorganization to creditors.

title: Scenes From Around the Bay
description: Chloe Veltman, our Bay Area culture correspondent, took this photo on Market Street in San Francisco. Can you name the people in this impromptu mural?

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Folignos Goal Boosts Senators
description: Thursday was American Thanksgiving, so there were only two games on the schedule, both in Canada and both involving exclusively middle-of-the-pack clubs. Home teams listed first:

title: Take 5: Things to Do This Weekend
description: Wondering what to do this weekend? Weve got you covered:Festival: The Great Dickens Christmas FairNow 30 years old, a favorite Bay Area Yuletide tradition returns to the Cow PalaceThrough December 20, the Cow Palace, San Francisco

title: Longhorns Slip by Aggies, but Maybe Not by Critics
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  The weakened Big 12 has been more of a coronation tour than a challenge for Texas this season.

title: News Quiz | November 27, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Khmer Rouge Warden Asks to Be Freed
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Testimony in the nine-month trial of a former prison chief for the communist Khmer Rouge ended Friday when the defendant unexpectedly asked to be set free despite his repeated admissions of guilt.

title: Fine Print | A Love Letter to the Letterpress
description: The first time I met the bookmaker Jon Beacham, he was living in Beacon, N.Y., with a woman who was then his girlfriend, in a century-old house on the wrong side of the tracks from Dia/Beacon. The pair ran the Hermitage, a combination bookstore, press and gallery specializing in small-press American poetry from the 1950s through the 1970s. But Beacham recently moved back to the city to reopen the Hermitage in a desolate stretch of Bushwick, Brooklyn. It was too hard to be doing something so esoteric and to be stuck in a small town on the Hudson, he explained. Oh well. Beacons loss is Brooklyns gain.

title: Celebrating Miles Davis in Sight and Sound
description: PARIS | Examining music in a museum space is no simple task; exhibitions about musicians tend to downplay the music itself. But We Want Miles, an ambitious show about the life and music of the jazz great Miles Davis, at Cit de la Musique through Jan. 17, is a remarkable exception. In this exhibition, the music is central.

title: Q. & A. on Match Fixing With Declan Hill, Author of The Fix
description: It wasnt until after Declan Hill published The Fix: Soccer and Organized Crime in September 2008 that European soccer authorities were ready to confront head-on the scourge of match fixing.

title: Giants Open Thread: The Denver Debacle
description: Ernie Palladino has been a Giants beat writer since 1989 and is the only fully credentialed independent blogger covering them. He writes about the team at erniepalladinosgiantsbeat.blogspot.com.

title: Philippine Official Says Victims Were Sexually Mutilated
description: DAVAO CITY, the Philippines  Most or all of the 22 women among the 57 people massacred Monday in the southern Philippines were sexually mutilated, the authorities said Friday, adding grim details to the catalog of horrors that has already emerged.

title: The Death of Uncool
description: Todays idea: There are so many cultural trends today that the distinction between cool and uncool doesnt matter anymore, says Brian Eno. Were all hipsters now.

title: Russia and China Endorse Agencys Rebuke of Iran
description: WASHINGTON  The United Nations nuclear watchdog demanded Friday that Iran immediately freeze operations at a once secret uranium enrichment plant, a sharp rebuke that bore added weight because it was endorsed by Russia and China.

title: Palinized
description: A term used to describe the vilification of female Republicans (as well as other associations with Sarah Palin).

title: Health Care Rationing, American-Style
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Some Jostling, but Less of a Frenzy Among Shoppers
description: A year after an unfolding economic crisis sent consumers into shock, they ventured out Friday and opened their wallets a bit  still hunting bargains, but no longer quite so afraid to spend.

title: A University Takes Aim at Obesity
description: You might worry about your body weight fluctuating in college, but did you ever think that gaining the notorious freshman 15 could keep you from graduating?

title: Saab Faithful Remember Some Favorites
description: The announcement that General Motors proposed sale of Saab to Koenigsegg has fallen through may mean the death of the Swedish automaker. Talking to the Saab faithful following the news was like discussing the death of a favorite relative who had experienced a long decline before the inevitable end.

title: Seeking a Statue Fit for a Star  Again
description: Louis Moreau Gottschalk was the 19th centurys idea of a rock star: a composer and performer so famous that when he went on tour, he took two pianos with him, size extra long. He called them my mastodons.

title: Dubais Investment Fund Crisis Unnerves Investors for a Second Day
description: The debt crisis facing the Dubai investment fund rattled investors for a second day on Friday, rekindling doubts about the vitality of emerging economies. Investors, however, said they had anticipated the deterioration of the countrys real estate bubble, and they considered Dubais troubles an isolated case.

title: Speed Read for Friday, Nov. 27
description: Here are some highlights from Fridays edition of The New York Times:

title: Sampler: Football Player Head Injury, Same-Sex Couple Benefits, Panhandlers Pets
description: Football Head Injury | A 16-year-old San Jose high school football player was in critical condition Thursday night after suffering a head injury at a Thanksgiving Day football game between two rival San Jose schools.

title: German Minister Resigns Over Afghan Airstrike
description: BERLIN  A German cabinet official resigned Friday, saying he accepted political responsibility for accusations that the military withheld information about an airstrike in Afghanistan in September that killed civilians as well as insurgents.

title: Assessing Algal Blooms Economic Impact
description: Toxic algae is not only physically harmful, it can do major damage to local economies, according to a new study by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the University of Washington.

title: Big States Dominate European Commission Posts
description: BRUSSELS  The biggest European countries on Friday scooped up the most sought-after leadership positions in a new commission that is expected to press for more regulation in areas like financial services.

title: Obamas Climate Goals vs. the Senates
description: Updated, Nov. 27, 4:50 p.m. | Ryan Alexander, the president of Taxpayers for Common Sense, joins the discussion, arguing against new subsidies for energy producers.

title: Week 12 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Steelers (6-4) at Ravens (5-5)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.No line

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Friday morning.No Release Yet for Polanski: A spokesman for Switzerlands Justice Ministry said that the director Roman Polanski will not be released from a prison near Zurich until at least Monday because the jailed filmmaker has not yet met all the conditions of his bail, The Associated Press reports. Under the bail agreement that was accepted on Wednesday, Mr. Polanski must post $4.5 million, which he has not yet paid; the director must also surrender his identity papers and be fitted with a monitoring bracelet.Not Ready for Prime Time: If an American television presentation can be edited for showing two men kissing, what does it take for a British television broadcast to provoke the scissors of the censors? The BBC reports that BBC4 has dropped its plans to show the ballet Eternal Damnation to Sancho and Sanchez by the Venezuelan choreographer Javier de Frutos because it depicted, among other things, a hunchback Pope strangling a pregnant nun with rosary beads. (The ballet also features nude scenes.) When we announced we were showing it, at the time we werent fully aware of the details of the ballet, a BBC spokesman said.Snowin in the Wind: In an interview in a British magazine called The Big Issue, Bob Dylan explained his motivation for recording his first holiday-themed album, Christmas in the Heart, Reuters reports. Though Mr. Dylan was raised Jewish in Minnesota, Christmas was one of his favorite holidays  a time, he recalled, of plenty of snow, jingle bells, Christmas carolers going from house to house, sleighs in the streets, town bells ringing, nativity plays. Asked what faith he practices now, Mr. Dylan told the magazine, I am a true believer.Had Your Fill of Turkey Yet? On this day after Turkey Day, it seems only appropriate for The Guardian to recount the tale of Divine Rapture, a notorious 1995 film project that never got off the ground. The movie was to star Johnny Depp, Marlon Brando and Debra Winger in the story of a woman who is hailed as a saint in her village when she miraculously rises from her coffin during her own funeral. (It turns out she had a rare disorder that slowed her heart-rate.) After six weeks of preparation in the Irish town of Ballycotton, the production ran out of money; Mr. Brando was nonetheless paid $1 million for his time.

title: When Your Spouse Is Your Business Partner
description: If you have to be a little crazy to be an entrepreneur, going into business with your spouse must represent a special kind of lunacy. My husband, Chris, and I have been business partners for more than six years. In that time weve started two businesses, sold one of them, had two kids and gotten more or less used to the daily roller coaster ride of entrepreneurial life.

title: The Wagon of Cadillacs
description: FOR most of us, the classic American station wagon  with its acres of fake woodgrain siding, sticky vinyl bench seats and lazy-revving V-8 engine  is a fixture of our collective automotive consciousness. It is also extinct. The gas crises of the 70s hobbled it, the minivans of the 80s dealt a knockout blow and the S.U.V.s that followed stomped on its grave.

title: Rashomon in the desert
description: Dubai or not Dubai  that is the question. Dubais sorta-kinda default (a state-owned enterprise seeking a rescheduling of its debts) is, by itself, not that big of a deal. But who else looks like Dubai? What kind of omen is this for the next stage in the financial crisis?

title: Which New Hybrid Has 10 Wheels and Flies?
description: IT sounded like a garbage truck and smelled like one, too. Aside from the giant pastoral scene on its side, it even looked like a standard-issue New York City garbage truck.

title: Cures for Noises That Nag
description: STICKY Ford and General Motors ignition keys and trouble with Infiniti air-bag connectors are among the maladies listed in recent technical service bulletins.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) How your religious identity affects your economic behavior.

title: Inaction Brings State to Brink of Cash Crisis
description: New York State is running out of cash.

title: When Black Friday Comes
description: Dont know how youre spending your Black Friday  and were not talking about the stock market  but were heeding the advice of Steely Dan: weve dug ourselves a hole and are about to spend the day lying in it.

title: Graphic Books Best-Seller List
description: Green Lantern: Agent Orange, written by Geoff Johns and illustrated by Philip Tan, is the top-ranking new hardcover on our list this week. It arrives at No. 2 and tells the story of Agent Orange, the latest light-based warrior to encounter Green Lantern. The story can be enjoyed on its own merits, but it also serves as a tie in to Blackest Night, the latest event mini-series from DC Comics, in which many of its long dead superheroes mysteriously (and unpleasantly) rise from the dead. Though some comic-book fans say they are coming down with event fatigue, that eight-issue mini-series, also written by Mr. Johns, is proving popular. The first issue, which went on sale in July, sold over 175,000 copies. Its also proving to be the gift the keeps giving: other titles connected to the storyline have also received a boost in sales.

title: Deficits: the causes matter
description: Jim Hamilton has a post challenging my optimistic view about current deficits. I wont go through it in detail, except to notice that Jim seems to be slightly rewriting history about his earlier analysis, which I critiqued back in August. What was then a seeming demonstration of the impossibility of servicing the debt  but in fact demonstrated no such thing  has now become just an effort to personalize the issue. OK, I guess.

title: I Think the Death Panels Are Back
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below:

title: Jackman, Craig Unload Their Garments for Charity
description: How much would you pay for two sweaty vests that have been worn out by weeks of use in a Broadway play? Wait, dont answer yet: How much would you pay if those two sweaty vests had been worn for weeks by Daniel Craig and Hugh Jackman, the stars of A Steady Rain? Audiences got their answer on Wednesday when Mr. Craig and Mr. Jackman sold their apparel (and any lingering pheromones they might contain) at a post-performance auction at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. BBC News reported that the vests were sold for $3,500 each; originally only one vest was going to made available, until a female audience member shouted at Mr. Jackman, How much for the pants? (Mr. Jackman offered up a second vest instead of his trousers.) The clothing and other items, including autographed posters and programs, were sold to raise money for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

title: Seeking the Best Medical Care Prices
description: CAN you really shop for doctors and hospitals the way you would for airfares and flat-screen TVs?

title: Israeli Military Says Air Force Thwarted a Gaza Rocket Attack
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military said the air force attacked a group of Palestinian militants in northern Gaza early Friday as they were about to fire rockets at Israel, a week after the Hamas rulers of Gaza announced that they had secured the agreement of other groups to halt rocket fire in order to prevent retaliatory attacks.

title: Short Film Wins Huge Audience on Giant Screen
description: As a student filmmaker, Fred Guerrier usually sees what he does through the cameras tiny viewfinder or the editors smallish screen  or on YouTube. But for the last couple of weeks, a short film he made has been showing on a screen bigger than the ones in most movie theaters.

title: The BMW Sauber Move
description: The announcement today that BMW has decided to sell the team back to Peter Sauber is good news for anyone concerned about the direction the buying of new teams may be going in F1. Its also reassuring to see a car manufacturer behaving a little more responsibly than we have begun to expect. BMW has dropped the deal with the previous somewhat shady buyer, and has decided to accept a sale of the team back to Peter Sauber, the original owner.

title: Weekend Competition: Novel Eponyms
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to devise new eponyms  words named after people.

title: Bargain Shopping for Medical Care
description: Recently, while scheduling a doctors visit for my daughter, the receptionist asked for a credit card to secure the appointment. The specialist didnt take insurance, charged $600 a visit and would charge my credit card if I canceled with less than 48 hours notice.

title: When the Air Must Be Spared: Fireplaces as Art Installations
description: Gathering around a warm hearth did not happen in many Bay Area homes on Thanksgiving Day, due to a Spare the Air warning that banned wood burning both inside and outside the home. The ban applied to the 1.4 million fireplaces and wood burning devices in the Bay Area; violators risked receiving a warning (for first-time offenders) and a fine of up to $400 for subsequent violations.

title: Alice Munros Object Lessons
description: The Germans must have a term for it. Doppelgedanken, perhaps: the sensation, when reading, that your own mind is giving birth to the words as they appear on the page. Such is the ego that in these rare instances you wonder, How could the author have known what I was thinking? Of course, what has happened isnt this at all, though its no less astonishing. Rather, youve been drawn so deftly into another world that youre breathing with someone elses rhythms, seeing someone elses visions as your own.

title: More Adam Lambert Fallout
description: When CBS had Adam Lambert as a guest on its Early Show Wednesday morning, it may have believed it would placate viewers who were upset when Mr. Lambert had his invitation withdrawn by ABCs Good Morning America. Instead, the booking has led to further complaints from those who say Mr. Lambert has been subjected to a double standard.

title: The Holiday Shopping Crush
description: Bargain-hunters amassed outside stores with dreams of discounts -- and electronic pets -- in their heads.

title: A Climate Scientist Who Engages Skeptics
Iranians Defend Freezing of Assets of Nobel Laureate
description: TORONTO  Iran denounced charges by the Norwegian government that it had illegally confiscated a Nobel Peace Prize winners medal and frozen her bank account, the IRNA news agency reported Friday.

title: Would G.M.O. Apples by Another Name Taste Sweeter?
description: Consumers might be more willing to bite into genetically modified apples if they were labeled differently, according to research published this month in The Journal of Food Distribution Research.

title: Special Op: A Postwar Tale Retold
description: THE director Jim Sheridan approached his new film, Brothers, with a Hippocratic attitude: Do no harm, he said with a laugh. Like a doctor, you know? Fitting enough, since he was delivering a twin.

title: Celebrating Id al-Adha
description: This holiday weekend Afghans and Iraqis  like millions of Muslims around the world  will be celebrating Id al-Adha.

title: The Reading Life: Out of Louisville, a Letterpress Magazine
description: The Louisville-based literary magazine The Lumberyard, the most physically beautiful new journal Ive seen this year, is a brother-and-sister operation. Its the product of Jen and Eric Woods, collaborators who describe themselves on the magazines Web site as rural kids  their father was a carpenter  who grew up climbing the rafters and rolling in the sawdust of a lumber supply shed in the 1970s.

title: Voluptuary Stuck in a Box
description: ITS odd and amusing  in a dry, British sort of way  that James Whale, the best director of Hollywood horror movies in the 1930s, was born and raised in a Midlands mining district known as the Black Country. (Would romantic comedy have been his destiny if hed grown up in, say, Mayfair?) But everything about his life and career was  as a man of the theater, like Whale himself, might say  passing strange. Between 1930 and 1941 he directed 20 feature films, including the hit spooky-movie classics Frankenstein (1931), The Invisible Man (1933), and Bride of Frankenstein (1935); a lone musical, Show Boat (1936); and the period swashbuckler The Man in the Iron Mask (1939). And then he quit.

title: Reverse Mortgages for Co-op Owners
description: Q.

title: Ferraris Unusual Recall
description: Last week, Ferrari issued a recall on about 2,400 199599 355 and 355F1s in the United States. The reason? A nonfactory mechanic improperly installed certain screw clamps that are located in close proximity to the fuel lines and that fasten the water sleeve to the thermostat connection.

title: A Restriction on Front-Door Keys
description: Q.

title: Imposing Limits on Co-op Sublets
description: Q.

title: Editors Choice
description: RAYMOND CARVER: A Writers Life,  by Carol Sklenicka (Scribner, $35.) Sklenickas biography is invaluable as a chronicle of Carvers growth as a writer, particularly in its account of his difficult, ultimately poisonous relationship with the editor Gordon Lish.

title: Whos Playing the Super Bowl? Yes.
description: To you football fans who were hoping that Super Bowl XLIV would be headlined by Lady Gaga: better luck in 2011. The National Football League announced that The Who, the long-lived British rock act led by Roger Daltrey and Pete Townshend, will perform at the halftime show, that annual occasion for bathroom breaks and (hopefully) not ripping off anyones clothes. The Whos booking had been reported on Sports Illustrateds Extra Mustard blog, but the N.F.L. did not officially confirm it until Thursday, during a game between the Oakland Raiders and the Dallas Cowboys. Super Bowl XLIV is scheduled for Feb. 7 in suburban Miami; previous halftime performers have included Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, and Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, though the only ones you probably remember are Janet Jackson and Justin Timberlake.

title: H. Henry Elghanayan
description: Mr. Elghanayan, 69, is the chief executive of the Rockrose Development Corporation, which he ran, until recently, with his younger brothers, K. Thomas and Frederick. The companys assets were split among the three, with Henry receiving several apartment buildings and development sites. He also kept the Rockrose name.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE ASCENT OF MONEY: A Financial History of the World,  by Niall Ferguson (Penguin, $16.) Behind each great historical phenomenon there lies a financial secret, Ferguson writes. It was Nathan Rothschild as much as the Duke of Wellington who defeated Napoleon at Waterloo by selling bonds for the British Army, and Continental bankers unwillingness to invest in Confederate cotton that assured the Souths Civil War defeat. The ascent of money has been essential to the ascent of man, Ferguson says in this tour of the underside of great events, and he worries that American financial overreach and the global crisis may represent a  great dying in the financial world  one of those mass extinctions of species.

title: Nutty Professor in Prime Time
description: The Jerry Lewis Show

title: Working With Andy the Auteur
description: WARHOL and I were very uncomfortable together, the playwright, novelist, screenwriter and professional wit Ronald Tavel said of Andy Warhol, who often seemed uncomfortable with everyone. I never knew what to say to him, and he never knew what to say to me. In fact we almost never said anything. Whether this discomfort was real, the words he wrote for Warhol films  hilarious, abrupt, lewd, illogical, artlessly artful words  contributed to a sense of unease that even now makes the films seem radical, even a bit dangerous.

title: Googles Earth
description: Im fond of Google, I have to say. I like Larry Page, who seems, at least in the YouTube videos Ive watched, shy and smart, with salt-and-pepper bangs; and Sergey Brin, who seems less shy and jokier and also smart. Ken Auletta, the author of this absorbing, shaggy, name-droppy book, doesnt seem to like either of them much  he says that Page has a Kermit the Frog voice, which isnt nice, while Brin comes off as a swaggering, efficiency-obsessed overachiever who, at Stanford, aced tests, picked locks, borrowed computer equipment from the loading dock and once renumbered all the rooms in the computer science building. Googles leaders are not cold businessmen; they are cold engineers, Auletta writes  but cold seems oddly wrong. Aulettas own chilliness may be traceable in part to Brins and Pages reluctance to be interviewed. After months of my kicking at the door, they opened it, he writes in the acknowledgments. Googles founders and many of its executives share a zeal to digitize books, he observes, but dont have much interest in reading them.

title: Up Front: Nicholson Baker
description: Surely no other software company has built a cluster of products that are anywhere near as cleverly engineered, as quick-loading and as fun to fiddle with as Google has, all for free, Nicholson Baker writes in his review of Ken Aulettas Googled.

title: Please Mr. Postman
description: Sometimes you write an elegy without meaning to. In the early 1990s, when Thomas Mallon began his book on people and their letters, you were marveling at your spiffy new dial-up modem, if you so much as knew what one was. His fine meditation on the art of letter-writing  he intended it as a companion to A Book of Ones Own, his study of people and their diaries  naturally reads differently today: The very physics of our universe, Mallon notes, have fundamentally altered. Time and distance are no longer what they once were. With them have gone, to varying degrees, privacy, eccentricity, suspense, your local stationer and, very nearly, the United States Postal Service. Intimacy has yielded to oversharing.

title: Judge O.K.s Some Parts of S.F. Bike Plan
description: In a ruling (PDF) issued on Wednesday, California Superior Court Judge Peter Busch gave San Francisco the go-ahead to proceed with several aspects of the citys proposed bike plan to make its streets more hospitable to bicyclists.

title: Chile Saved From World Cup Expulsion
description: Chile has saved its spot in the 2010 World Cup in South Africa after a domestic relegation dispute threatened FIFA action.

title: Friday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Domestic Dysfunction
description: Every family is charged with small acts of brutality. One child will flail about with scissors, another must bite or shove, and theres always the pulling of hair or the tearing of skin. Someone will decide to experiment with matches or lock the door of a dark closet and abandon the sister cowering inside. A grown-up might pretend to be a lion and roar so hard that a child wets himself in panic. Banal but terrifying things happen. Then we forget them. Somehow, though, they dont forget us. Memories lie buried, yet remain forceful enough to shape our lives. In its infinite dimensions, this is the subject Penelope Lively, the British author of more than two dozen childrens books and numerous adult novels, has explored throughout her long and impressive career. In her haunting new novel, Family Album, the act of forgetting is as strange and interesting as the power of remembering.

title: When Detroit Never Slept
description: One of the challenges inherent in writing about Detroit, especially its past, is that the overwhelming nostalgia for everything  the once bustling downtown, shopping at Hudsons, streetcars, corner drugstores, work  can overwhelm the narrative. Imagine Pliny the Younger writing about post-Vesuvius Pompeii without occasionally veering into the realm of the sentimental. It cant be done.

title: Accessorized With Stroller and Rake
description: JULIE SIMONSON, a research pharmacist whose flat accent reveals her Chicago-area roots, grew up in a forest. Her childhood home was surrounded as far as the eye could see by towering deciduous trees whose names and characteristics she knew so well that she could identify virtually every one by its leaf.

title: A Colleges Effort to Fight Obesity: One Students View
description: This mornings post on Lincoln Universitys fitness requirement, one linked to a students body mass index, has drawn more than 40 comments. Some readers are outraged by what they see as a discriminatory policy; others are heartened by the universitys efforts to promote healthy habits.

title: Couples Retreat
description: Like the great British wits her writing recalls, Jane Gardam has a talent for picking names. The Man in the Wooden Hat features the fastidious Sir Edward Feathers, an expatriate judge known as Filth (for failed in London, try Hong Kong); a striver called Terry Veneering (whose last name is borrowed from Dickens); a Chinese dwarf, Albert Ross, known suggestively as Albatross; and Betty Feathers, ne Elisabeth Macintosh. To those who know her later in life, shes as sturdy and dependable as a raincoat, the perfect judges wife. But Macintosh turns out to be as deceptive a descriptor of Betty as Filth is of the spotless Feathers. Underneath that impervious surface is a woman cut from unusual cloth.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: James Spader, Up in the Air, Ray Romano and More
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)Im most drawn to characters who are compelling and repellent at the same time, very often right at the same moment, and who are frightening and funny all at once. Mamet writes these characters better than anyone.James Spader explains what attracts him to his roles, including the character he portrays in the new David Mamet play Race

title: One Foot in the Past
description: Inwood, the northernmost neighborhood in Manhattan, is a place of hills and history. Inwood Hill Park, 196 acres of tree-filled landscape, dominates the scene, and traces of Lenape Indians and Dutch settlers abound. But there are relative newcomers, too, including opera singers and others who are attracted to Inwoods growing arts community. One artist who lives there  and grew up there  is Lin-Manuel Miranda, the Grammy- and Tony-winning creator of the Broadway musical In the Heights. The expedition begins at the 207th Street station, the terminus of the A train.

title: Improv Tonight
description: According to the actor and director Betty Thomas  one of two women who were members of Chicagos Second City comedy troupe in 1973  if nature called in the midst of the groups manic brainstorming, she had no qualms about leaving the restroom door open while she answered. You dont want to miss a single thing! she says. You have to be able to shout out!

title: A New Nation
description: In the aftermath of the American Revolution, no question haunted the founders more than whether the young, precarious United States could survive. Would the country last in perpetuity? Or was it fated to be a bold experiment in republicanism that would ignominiously fail?

title: One Moment in Time
description: The images that make it into our long-term collective memory are few. One that has escaped the maws of oblivion, though, dates from the athletic circus that was the 1968 Summer Olympics. I am, of course, referring to the photos of Tommie Smith and John Carlos standing shoeless at a medal ceremony. On Oct. 16, Smith won the gold and Carlos the bronze in the 200-meter race. There they stood on the podium, heads hanging almost humbly and gloved fists raised in a defiant black power salute. Something in the Air, Richard Hoffers skillfully told tale of the Mexico City Olympics, revolves around this arresting image.

title: More Museums Facing Strike in France
description: PARIS  Frances major tourist attractions, including the Louvre, the Muse dOrsay, the Cathedral of Notre-Dame and Versailles, could be shut down next week because of a strike over planned job cuts, the General Confederation of Labor union warned on Friday.

title: Helicopter Service to Airports Faces Uncertain Future
description: Scheduled helicopter service between Manhattan and local airports will not resume before early next year  if ever.

title: Report Outlines Best Practices for Connecting Renewables to the Grid
description: A new report on state renewable energy regulations gives California, Colorado, New Jersey and Oregon top marks and failing grades for Georgia, Idaho and Texas.

title: A Home Among Trees
description: Julie Simonson, her husband, Jesse Nover, and their year-old daughter, Maya, live in Sunnyside Gardens, Queens, surrounded by considerably more in the way of trees and other greenery than many New York dwellings.

title: Beyond the Absurd
description: Images from the retrospective of Andy Warhol and Ronald Tavel's films.

title: The Story of a Landing
description: Few words are more overworked than hero, but try avoiding it when talking about US Airways Flight 1549 and its dominant figure, Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III. By now you surely know the highlights of what instantly came to be called the miracle on the Hudson: How on Jan. 15, 2009, Sullenbergers plane, bound for Charlotte, N.C., smacked into a flock of Canada geese less than two minutes after taking off from La Guardia Airport. How both its engines conked out. How Sullenberger, with mere seconds available to make a decision and act on it, glided the plane to a flawless landing on the river. How all 155 on board got out alive.

title: Spin of Wheel May Determine Judge in 9/11 Case
description: At first glance, the wooden wheel looks as if it might have been used to call out bingo numbers in a church fund-raiser. But sometime soon, a federal magistrate judge in Manhattan could be spinning the wheel in open court, unlocking a small door on one of its sides, and pulling out a sealed envelope containing the name of a judge.

title: The Case for an Overhaul, State by State
description: Stuffed with data and bristling with footnotes, a new report on the federal HealthReform.gov Web site argues in favor of a health insurance overhaul.

title: What to Watch This Weekend: Its Trudy Time
description: In the next-to-last episode of Monk (USA, 9 p.m. Friday), the crime scene is familiar: it was the site of Trudys murder 12 years before. Were pretty sure that before next weeks finale is over, Monk (Tony Shalhoub) will solve the case thats been hanging over his head the entire series.

title: Justice Department Says Acorn Can Be Paid for Pre-Ban Contracts
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has concluded that the Obama administration can lawfully pay the community group Acorn for services provided under contracts signed before Congress banned the government from providing money to the group.

title: More Holiday Shopping Strategy Help
description: In a Bucks post Thursday, we wrote about readings and resources for planning your Black Friday shopping strategy. With consumers still worried about the economy and cutting back this holiday shopping season, here are a few more shopping strategies, resources and tips to help you make the most of your bucks. What cost-saving strategies and resources do you plan to use this holiday season?

title: Southern Deviations
description: John Grisham, shake hands with Michael Jordan. And then get back to what you do best, as His Airness did, more or less before it was too late.

title: She Who Must Be Obeyed
description: There is a bull market these days in Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek (1887-1975) and his wife, Soong Mei-ling (1897-2003), usually called Madame Chiang Kai-shek. When I was studying in Taiwan in the late 1950s, then-President Chiang was regarded by most of the Western students on the island  and many of the Chinese as well  as the remote, cruel man who lost China; his wife was the austere, once-glamorous Dragon Lady who had helped him lose it. Although Chiang alone, or both Chiangs, had appeared numerous times on the cover of Time magazine, those illustrious days seemed over. But now that Jay Taylor has written his comprehensive book The Generalissimo: Chiang Kai-shek and the Struggle for Modern China, we are able to see Chiang as a man of considerable cunning, brutality and patience who skillfully played a weak hand against the Japanese and Maos forces while extracting huge sums from the Americans. Similarly, in her latest biography, The Last Empress, Hannah Pakula presents Madame Chiang as far more complex, awful and brilliant than we had imagined.

title: Working Off the Turkey Feast by Shopping
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: You Be the Judge
description: Not long ago, at a reception in Washington, I found myself talking to a prominent conservative commentator who was spitting mad because, he said, the Obama administration had blatantly, possibly criminally, favored unions over bondholders when dictating bailout terms to the automotive industry. Just the kind of lawless cronyism that had given liberalism a bad name!

title: Battling the Skeptics
description: The optimistic view of science is that the theories advanced with its methods will have self-evident appeal to an educated public. Why, then, do people so often behave unscientifically? A sitting congressman claims hes seen a U.F.O.; a former Playboy model insists, against overwhelming evidence, that childhood vaccines cause autism; Las Vegas vacationers expect to beat the casinos; former British Prime Minister Tony Blair treats his children with homeopathic remedies.

title: Mr. Pamuks Neighborhood
description: Most tourist trips to Istanbul center on Sultanahmet, the neighborhood of the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace. Although visitors may imagine a magical age of sex slaves and tulips, Sultanahmet often feels like a modern Ottoman theme park: Turkish hustlers screaming in precise English, enormous buses disgorging tourists in red fezzes. But Sultanahmet is a center of the citys religious life and home to many of its most observant citizens. During Ramadan, it is the site of a vast public picnic, where hundreds of Turks break the fast every night. This year I saw conservative ladies sitting cross-legged on the grass with pizza boxes, and nonreligious people munching cheap kebabs and humming to live Turkish bands. It felt so much like an American county fair, I half expected to see face-painting booths. Then I saw a girl with her face painted, a guy selling cotton candy and teenagers whod clearly used the holiday as an excuse to go on a triple date.

title: Inside the List
description: SECRET SANTA: Planning on stimulating the literary economy this holiday season but at a loss for ideas? We asked a few best-selling novelists what books theyll be giving as gifts this year. Kathryn Stockett replied: David Benioffs City of Thieves is the book I have been raving about to everyone. It is a brilliant killer adventure. Michael Connelly is going to be wrapping up Joseph Wambaughs Hollywood Moon, the last and best entry in his fabulous Hollywood Station trilogy. Patricia Cornwell is bullish on Bruce Liptons Biology of Belief, a favorite of her heroine Kay Scarpetta. Its a fascinating and inspiring look at the connection between science and spiritual principles, reminding us of the enormous power we have to change ourselves and the world, Cornwell said.

title: Pilots Were Distracted, Transcripts Show
description: WASHINGTON  After radio contact was finally re-established with the Northwest Airlines plane that flew 150 miles past its destination last month, a controller twice asked the pilots why they had stopped answering radio calls, according to transcripts and audio files released Friday by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: The White House Christmas Tree
description: Update:When the tree arrived, reporters were on hand to record the moment for posterity. The big question, according to the Associated Press: Was this the biggest tree that the first lady had ever seen? The answer: Yeah, I think this wins.

title: Site-Hopping for Holiday Savings
description: Remember the old game show where contestants could choose which door was hiding the best prize? A variation of that is happening online this holiday shopping season.

title: Baghdad Garden Becomes Graveyard, Full of Grieving
description: BAGHDAD  In the gardens of the living and the dead, the war goes on; not so much with enthusiasm as with resignation.

title: I.Q.s Well Below 911
description: Video | Emergency calls of the daft and ridiculous:

title: Selling Serenity and Sustainability
description: HOW do you sell sumptuous condominiums on a ho-hum block in a skittish residential market? For Michael Namer, a veteran downtown developer, the answer at 311 East 11th Street is one word: calm.

title: Alison Greenberg, Leo Esses
description: Alison Meredith Greenberg and Leo Lloyd Esses were married Wednesday in Manhattan. Rabbi Dale Polakoff officiated at the Pierre.

title: Colt McCoys Heisman Moment
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  This seasons Heisman Trophy competition took another twist Thursday night with Texas quarterback Colt McCoys spectacular performance.

title: Feeling for  CHCM
description: This past Sunday I stopped by the Pop-Up Flea, a temporary mens-wear-centric collection of clothing and accessories stands curated by the guys at the blog A Continuous Lean. The vibe was decidedly vintage Americana, with temporary stores by brands like Gitman Brothers, Jack Spade, Rogues Gallery, Schott, J. Crew, Bill Amberg and Alexander Olch. The wares were cool and the shoppers even cooler: off the charts in hip per square inch. Tucked away in a corner among all the old favorites was a booth whose name I didnt recognize. I went in for a closer look after spotting some camel toggle coats from Gloverall and heavy knit cardigans from the obscure Danish seafaring knitting company SNS Herning. The stand belonged to a brand new online-only mens-wear shop called CHCM, which stands for Clinton Hill Classic Menswear. It was started in March 2009 by Sweetu Patel, a former furniture designer whose selection is skewed heavily toward classic brands like Borsalino, Saint James, Mackintosh and Drakes, as well as other finds like Northern Waters, a Canadian-based knitwear company, and Individualized Shirts. Look for a pop-up shop of its own in January at Audiovisual Arts on First Street in the East Village, where it will break out new spring merchandise. Kick off your shoes because Im feeling for online shopping at CHCM.

title: How Do You Save Money When Shopping Online?
description: The online holiday shopping season officially begins Monday. So in this weeks Your Money column, I explored different ways to get cash back on your online purchases, earn extra credit-card rewards, or land other discounts.

title: Russia and France Reach Agreements on Autos and Natural Gas Pipelines
description: PARIS  Moscow signed several deals in autos and energy with French companies on Friday at a meeting described by Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as a breakthrough in economic ties between the countries.

description: To the Editor:

title: In Rural Indiana Town, Even Basketball Suffers
description: MEDORA, Ind.  Players for Medora High School have taken the court wearing work boots because their families cannot afford basketball shoes. Most smoke cigarettes. Some talk openly of drug use. All but a few come from broken homes.

title: Apartment Hunter Lucky With No. 13
description: WITH housing prices declining in New York City, Lori Leach figured it would be easy to persuade her landlord to reduce her rent.

title: Asked and Answered | Annie
description: For loyal fans of the Norwegian pop star Annie, its been a long four years since the electro-songstress won critical acclaim and achieved cult status with her debut album, Anniemal. But the dry spell is over: Annie is back with Dont Stop, a record that manages to move her into more musically complicated territory while still keeping her firmly planted on the dance floor. As she juggled D.J. gigs and rehearsals for her spring tour (Maybe in March or April, she says. Im not sure if Im starting in Europe or the U.S., but Im definitely coming back to the U.S. for some shows), The Moment sat down with the Scandinavian chanteuse to talk about inspirations in and out of the studio.

title: Jocelyn Kirsch and Evan Guggenheim
description: Jocelyn Ricci Kirsch, a daughter of Claudia J. Ricci and Richard J. Kirsch of Washington and Spencertown, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Evan Ross Guggenheim, a son of Deborah Guggenheim of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Robert K. Guggenheim. Rabbi Deborah Zecher officiated at Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Bloomberg Spent $102 Million to Win 3rd Term
description: To eke out a narrow re-election victory over the citys understated comptroller, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent $102 million of his own money, or about $183 per vote, according to data released on Friday, making his bid for a third term the most expensive campaign in municipal history.

title: Wars Other Enduring Videos
description: EARLIER this month at the Jacksonville Jaguars Military Appreciation game, Brandon Becar, 11, and relatives proudly stood on the football field in front of 45,000 people. The stadiums giant video screen flashed a prerecorded greeting from his father, stationed in Iraq. Brandon grinned and flexed his muscle.

title: Talks on Deal for Warship Upset Nations Near Russia
description: MOSCOW  Among the loose ends left after Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putins visit to Paris was one that has proved particularly difficult to ignore: the 23,700-ton French warship that docked in the middle of St. Petersburg this week as part of an extended sales pitch to the Russian government.

Seeing the Glass as Mostly Empty

description: After many false starts, the cabins generator is now operating - or so Im told by the electrician who drove out this week to have a look.

title: The Sunday Preview
description: In summer, the Grand Canyon is the Disney World of national parks, with crowds and traffic jams. But as Henry Shukman discovers in this weeks cover story, its a different word in the winter, a peaceful retreat with a small smattering of visitors hiking down to the canyon floor to spend the night in a rustic lodge. Its a place where the ranch bell rings for dinner and where guests while away the evening playing card games, swapping life stories and congratulating themselves for being here in December and not July.

title: Crashers Met Obama; Secret Service Apologizes
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and his wife, Michelle, had a face-to-face encounter with the couple who sneaked into a state dinner at the White House this week, White House officials acknowledged on Friday. The revelation underscored the seriousness of the security breach and prompted an abject apology from the Secret Service.

title: Tiger Woods Out of Hospital After Car Accident
description: Tiger Woods, the worlds No. 1-ranked golfer, was injured early Friday in a one-car accident in front of his home, according to the Florida Highway Patrol. His wife broke the back window of his vehicle with a golf club to help get him out of the car, according to a local police chief.

title: Strike Threatens Louvre and Other Paris Sites
description: PARIS | Frances major tourist attractions, including the Louvre, the Muse dOrsay, the Cathedral of Notre-Dame and Versailles could face closure next week because of a strike over planned job cuts, the General Confederation of Labor union warned on Friday. Read more on ArtsBeat

title: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Nov. 27
description: Shoppers across the nation lined up late Thursday to take advantage of deep discounts that started the holiday shopping season (Slides 1, 2, 3 and 4). Muslims around the world celebrated Id al-Adha, the festival that signals the end of the hajj (Slides 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10). And Rafael Nadal of Spain lost his round robin match against Novak Djokovic of Serbia at the Barclays ATP World Tour Finals (Slide 16).

Their brokers  Natalie C. McCray and Eileen B. Heimer of Daniel Gale Sothebys International Realty  had cooked it during the event, between visits from potential buyers.

title: The Man in the Wooden Hat

description: AT the far end of a deserted street in Scarsdale is a bright, glowing glass cage of humanity, drinking and dining and clearly enjoying the crush and the noise that the newly minted Chat encourages.

title: A Near-Perfect Taste of the Mediterranean
description: IVE never met Bennie Hamade in person, but Ive spotted him a couple of times about 9 p.m., slumped down on a banquette at the rear of his namesake restaurant  a compact man in his 50s, chatting with his wife, Fadia, who often helps in the kitchen, and his daughter, Zenna, the patient and gracious headwaiter.

title: Days of Wine and Tapas as a Mini-Empire Grows
description: WHEN Barcelona Winebar opened in Stamford a short time ago, it was the latest in a mini-empire of five restaurants, the first of which began in South Norwalk some years ago.

title: No Meat, No Butter, and No More Obscurity
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE

title: Trailer: Left 4 Dead 2
description: In the new zombie game from Valve, your job is simply to survive and kill nearly everything that moves.

description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week. Subjects include a homecoming for a man released from prison, Long Island turkey hunters, and the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: Vocal Versatility, in a Familiar Form
description: First came the Three Tenors  Luciano Pavarotti, Plcido Domingo and Jos Carreras, singing up a storm in programs that flirted with Broadway, pop and folk. Then came the spinoffs  among them the Irish Tenors and Three Mo Tenors, a show featuring three African-American singers that opened in New York in 2000.

title: Stage Performance in Search of a Miracle
description: It would be nice, in this holiday season, to report a miracle on Main Street in Northport, where a musical version of Miracle on 34th Street is playing at the John W. Engeman Theater. A talented cast under the considered direction of Erick Devine almost pulls off the wondrous task of making a silk purse out of a sows ear  or, in this case, a tin ear. But Douglas M. Smiths tuneless music and Vernon L. Stefanics meandering book and flat lyrics prove difficult to transcend.

title: Divergent Styles and Inspirations of Coastal Art Colonies
description: The art colonies of New England played a valuable role in fostering Modernism in American art in the early 20th century. But they also contributed to the creation and promotion of a sense of regional identity, the subject of Call of the Coast: Art Colonies of New England, a delightful exhibition at the Florence Griswold Museum developed in collaboration with the Portland Museum of Art in Maine.

title: Romeo and a Boy Named Juliet
description: You have to buy in. Whether youre watching a singing nun in prewar Austria or a mad old king on a stormy heath, theater depends on your buying into what the actors onstage are telling you. And experienced playgoers know how little it takes  the old definition of theater as two planks and a passion still applies.

title: Book Review Podcast: Alice Munro
description: This week: A conversation with the short story master Alice Munro; Clyde Haberman on Capt. C. B. Sullenbergers miracle landing on the Hudson River; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: An Environmental Benefit, Set to the Jazz of Sonny Rollins
description: WHEN Sonny Rollins lifts his legendary horn high and launches into Global Warming, listeners unfamiliar with his ironic sense of humor are sometimes confused. The cheerful melody sits comfortably atop a jaunty calypso beat and can seem at odds with the seriousness of the subject.

title: Behind the Curtain, a Peek at Creation
description: MENTIONING the name Tennessee Williams usually prompts theatergoers to think of A Streetcar Named Desire or Cat on a Hot Tin Roof before Camino Real comes to mind.

title: At the Intersection of Art and Nature
description: FIRST-RATE paintings, photos and films offer plenty of reasons to duck inside the nine cultural institutions lining Museum Mile, a narrow slice of Upper Manhattan fronting Central Park.

title: Unchanging, Yet Never the Same
description: The low-lying buildings just east of Eighth Avenue are my foothills; the brown and gray offices of the flower and garment districts are my mountains; and the Empire State Building, with its many moods and many faces, is my distant peak, a rival to Mount McKinley, Mount Kilimanjaro and Mount Fuji.

title: Forgotten by Time and Termites
description: MARY COLE lives in an old wood-frame house, all yellow paint and green trim. It has a peaked roof with a tall chimney. Set back from the street on a small hill, her home feels private and peaceful.

title: Solace for the Spirit, and the Pocketbook
description: On Dec. 6, arts and cultural groups throughout the county are welcoming visitors free of charge as part of ArtsWestchesters ninth annual Free Arts Day.

title: Rabbi on the Go, Even While Relaxing
description: Rabbi Shmuley Boteach, 43, calls himself Americas rabbi. He even has his own bobblehead doll, which sells for $14.95 at his Web site, www.shmuley.com. The rabbi has written more than 20 books, including Kosher Sex and The Kosher Sutra, not to mention the recently released Michael Jackson Tapes. He and his wife, Debbie, live in Englewood, N.J. They have nine children: six girls and three boys, ranging in age from a year and a half to 20.

title: That Fuddy-Duddy Guy Really Put the Bomp Ba Bomp in His Variety Show
description: For anyone watching PBSs compilation on Saturday of 1960s performances by rock and pop stars, one conclusion will be inescapable: Whoever was dressing these people needs to be found and brought to justice. Some crimes have no statute of limitations.

title: 63 Windows and What They Show
description: A HOUSE without books is like a room without windows, said Horace Mann, the educator. Matteo Pericoli, the Italian-born architect, illustrator and author, wittily provides both in his delightful paean by 63 famous New Yorkers to the views from their houses and apartments. Its called The City Out My Window (Simon & Schuster, $21.99).

title: Hiring Is Rising in One Area: Low-Paid Interns
description: On-the-job training has its roots in the Middle Ages. Apprenticeship, it was called then, and it generally was for the young.

title: Shopping With Jonathan Adler
description: With Hanukkah approaching, the designer found menorahs that are playful and eye-catching while keeping an eye on tradition.

title: Foreclosure Protections for All
description: LAST year, a new law was put into place in New York to help protect subprime mortgage borrowers from foreclosure. Now the state is on the verge of extending similar protections to prime borrowers, too.

title: The Cancer Lounge
description: The cancer patient racked them up and broke. Clackety-clack. Seven ball in the corner pocket. Five ball in the side.

title: Country Houses in the Midst of Brownstones
description: Houses with regular amenities, like lawns and driveways, sometimes exist in between brownstones and apartment buildings in New York City.

title: Pasta With Chicken, Risotto Style
description: Mark Bittman cooks pasta with chicken and mushrooms employing a similar technique to the one used for making risotto.

title: Keys, Wallet, Phone... Wheres My Phone?
description: Deep underground, in locked, windowless chambers below 34th Street, hundreds of cellphones are waiting. Dozens of pairs of eyeglasses, 20 or so musical instruments, a half dozen bicycles and a four-foot-long space heater. They tumbled out of your bag as you fought your way off a crowded bus or got left behind as you leapt for the subway doors. And now theyre sitting on a shelf in the M.T.A.s Lost Property Unit, waiting for you to redeem them, reunite with them, set them free.

title: The Ephemera of Protests, Carefully Hoarded, Is Going to an Archive
description: More than 20 years ago a Lower East Side plumber turned environmental apostle named Bill DiPaola founded an activist group called Times Up and began organizing parties meant to publicize the dangers of acid rain, nuclear power and pesticides.

title: The Origins of That Famous Carnegie Hall Joke
description: Practice, Mr. Benny

title: Allowing Pasta to Drink to Its Fill
description: COOKING pasta the way you would make risotto may sound new and hip. But its at least old enough to have been demonstrated to me in Rome in 1976, and I imagine as old as pasta itself.

description: Melissa Dlin and Chris Mottola were married Saturday by Ronald D. Castille, the chief justice of Pennsylvania, at the Ritz Carlton in Philadelphia.

title: Anne Mazzeo, Nicholas Baldwin
