Mazzeo of Clarkston, Mich., was married Saturday to Nicholas Horatio Baldwin, the son of Roberta Plutzik Baldwin and Neil E. Baldwin of Glen Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Christopher Maus, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Daniel Catholic Church in Clarkston. Later in the evening, Rabbi Tamara Kolton led a symbolic ceremony that incorporated Jewish traditions at the Indianwood Golf and Country Club in Lake Orion, Mich.

title: Lynn Brouwers, Mark Upfal
description: Lynn Brouwers and Dr. Mark Joe Upfal were married Friday evening at their home in Detroit. Rabbi Miriam S. Jerris officiated.

title: Some Indians Find It Tough to Go Home Again
description: NEW DELHI  When 7-year-old Shiva Ayyadurai left Mumbai with his family nearly 40 years ago, he promised himself he would return to India someday to help his country.

title: Alabama Rallies Late and Remains Unbeaten
description: AUBURN, Ala.  The machinery of college football  the polls, the projections and the politics surrounding the Bowl Championship Series  could not distract or unsettle No. 2 Alabama during the regular season. The Crimson Tide always seemed steady and poised, but that was before it ran up against the slot-machine offense of the Auburn Tigers, with its unpredictable misdirection.

title: Got Zombies? You Need Your Friends
description: When someone starts talking about a sequel, the last thing you usually want to hear is more of the same. That is, unless your idea of a good time is mowing down thousands of preternaturally fast, agile and of course ravenous undead as you and three friends try to escape the zombie apocalypse.

title: To Light the Nights
description: THE designer Jonathan Adler is known for bringing whimsy and exuberance to the interiors and objects he creates. But when it comes to decorating his home for the holidays, he takes a more minimalist approach. Because both he and his partner, Simon Doonan, the creative director of Barneys New York, work in the world of stuff and holiday dcor, he said, they tend to express most of their seasonal creativity at the office.

title: Classic Ad: 1969 Plymouths
description: This being Thanksgiving week, it might seem an appropriate time to post a vintage commercial for one of the auto industrys fabled turkeys. But that would be too easy, and a cheap shot to boot.

title: A Salsa Star Is Reborn After a Break for Politics
description: Rubn Blades has a very specific reason for calling his current tour Todos Vuelven, or Everybody Returns. After suspending his music and film career for five years to serve as a cabinet minister in Panama, his homeland, Mr. Blades is back, on the road and with a new album, testing the waters and trying to figure out whether the entertainment business still has a place for him.

title: Long-Distance Romance
description: To the Editor:

title: Vows: Boris & Lauren
description: Lauren met tall, boisterous Boris on the first day of her freshman year at Georgetown. The two quickly began dating and have been together ever since.

title: When Trees Fall Next Door, Neighbors Make the Noise
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y.

title: New Jersey Rules Differ
description: The town of Madison has rejected a proposed ordinance to protect trees on private property. But the adjacent town of Chatham has taken the opposite route.

title: Few Rules for City Residents
description: Trees might seem especially rare and precious in New York, but unlike many suburbs, the city generally imposes no restrictions on its residents removal of them.

title: A Westchester Patchwork
description: The regulations governing privately owned trees in Westchester County are a patchwork. The village of Mamaroneck has no such rules, for example, but the town of Mamaroneck does.

title: City Critic | Lost in Transit
description: Deep in Penn Station, Ariel Kaminer seeks out New York City Transit's elusive Lost Property Unit, and finds it surprisingly organized and efficient.

title: On L.I., Approaches Vary
description: In Nassau County, restrictions on the removal of trees on private land vary greatly by town. Some towns have no rules, some towns that do have rules take different approaches, and some towns are revising their rules.

title: Efforts in Connecticut
description: Greenwich has no regulations on the removal of trees on private property, except for trees in or around wetlands, said Bruce Spaman, the towns superintendent of parks and trees.

title: Significant (Little) Moments Pulled From Obscurity
description: A glass of wine had just arrived when Colum McCann, who won the National Book Award for fiction last week with Let the Great World Spin, leaned forward with a story to tell.

title: Montreal Grand Prix Is Back On for 2010
description: Automakers may be leaving Formula One, but Montreal wants to come back on board.

title: Montreal Grand Prix Is Back On for 2010
description: From our colleagues at the Formula One blog:

title: From 1994, a Prime Example of Knowing When to Duck
description: The Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams is the premier event at the Fall North American Championships taking place in San Diego. The 2008 winners were Nick Nickell, Richard Freeman, Bob Hamman, Zia Mahmood, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell. They will be defending the title, except that Ralph Katz will replace Freeman, who died in June.

title: Shuttle Ends 11-Day Mission With a Perfect Landing
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Atlantis glided to a flawless landing in Florida on Friday, wrapping up an 11-day space station delivery mission and bringing a flight engineer, Nicole P. Stott, back to Earth after 91 days in space.

title: The Cheesecake Lightens Up
description: Stockbridges Gourmet Cheesecake carries 10 types of cheesecake at a time  and thats only a quarter or so of its repertoire. Recent efforts included eggnog and pumpkin, but its New York style outsells all the others by two to one.

title: Giving Us Their Daily Flatbread
description: Newark Avenue in the area of Jersey City known as Little India is crowded with confectioners shops, small groceries and clothing stores selling colorful saris. Here Paratha Junction, a sleek storefront restaurant that opened in May, is already popular for its classic yet modern take on the dense flatbread called paratha.

title: Three Cheers for Cheese
description: Most grand openings involve a ribbon-cutting and dignitaries, but in early November at Dobbs & Bishop, a new cheesemonger in the village of Bronxville, not only was the mayor on hand with a pair of scissors, but so was a Guernsey cow named Annie (and an assortment of goats and sheep).

title: In Search of Their Own Elixir of Love
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Mike DAntoni Searches for a Winning Formula for the Knicks
description: MIKE DANTONI, the head coach of the New York Knicks, started a tradition this season: a catered dinner in a private room at Madison Square Garden, players and coaches only, a couple of hours before each game.

title: Would My Heart Outrun Its Pursuer?
description: I AM near quadriplegic, a result of polio, and I cannot stand. I have limited strength in my arms, enough to function once Im in my chair but not enough to get into or out of the chair.

title: Las Vegas Wins U.F.L. Title
description: Did you even know there was a U.F.L. season?

title: No Autographs. Just Initials, Please.
description: IN a city where stargazing is a ruthless sport, the prey are always in search of a hideout to escape prying eyes, a place to cavort with their own oh-so-fabulous kind. These days, that place is Simyone Lounge, or simply SL to those in the know.

title: My Rich Stepdaughters
description: My husbands ex-wife is extremely wealthy, and his daughters have recently come into multimillion-dollar trust funds. We, on the other hand, are struggling; my husband has been out of work since the economy fell apart. My stepdaughters visit regularly, in expensive clothes and accessories. I cant help but resent that they will never have to work a day in their lives. And I fantasize about asking for financial help, but dont want to seem like a beggar. What to do? Anonymous

title: Hello, Collections? The Worm Has Turned
description: The phone rang. A woman from a law firm representing a collection agency wanted to know if Mark Hoyte was Mark Hoyte, and he said he was. They were calling to collect $919 on a Sears-Citi card.

title: Forget Car Insurance, Does It Have Medicare?
description: MY son, Jordan, who is 9, desperately wanted a pet that might be more interactive than the fish in his aquarium. But I am severely allergic to most animals with fur. I am so asthmatic that, unlike the Obamas, who went with famously hypoallergenic Bo, our family wound up choosing something less huggable though no less lovable: a gecko.

title: Easing Into the Day Where Night Life Reigns
description: When you serve breakfast in a neighborhood known more for late-night prowling than early rising, things start slowly some days. But Life Caf, which opened in 1982, when Alphabet City was a drug-fueled frontier town all its own, has seen worse than slow mornings. A haven for vegans and baconistas alike, Life Caf displays work by local artists and maintains an homage to Rent  a scene in the musical was set there  on a side wall. On Tuesday at the crack of 10 a.m., a bustling HBO film crew shot a scene for a planned series across the street, but the first two customers were tourists, followed, more than an hour later, by two locals.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Alomar Heads 2010 Hall of Fame Ballot
description: Roberto Alomar was a slick-fielding second baseman who was proud of the way he could beat teams with his bat, his glove and his legs. Alomar will soon learn if what he accomplished in a 17-year career will be enough to earn him election into the Baseball Hall of Fame on his first ballot.

title: Happy Campers Command Stage in Macys Parade
description: Everything was fine with Macys Santa-sleigh float until the elves showed up.

title: On NYTimes.com
description: In San Francisco, the ice cream wizard Jake Godby, of Humphry Slocombe, and offal-meister Chris Cosentino, of the restaurant Incanto and the salumeria Boccalone, have pooled their talents to create lard caramels.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: Comedy

title: Events on Long Island
description: Film

title: Salaries Cut for 2 Bank of America Executives
description: Bank of America said its chief financial officer, Joe L. Price, and head of mortgages, Barbara J. Desoer, would receive less in salary for 2009, citing a review by the governments special master for compensation, Kenneth R. Feinberg. Mr. Price and Ms. Desoer had their annual salaries set at $500,000, the company said in a regulatory filing. The two executives also received stock unit awards valued at $5.25 million for Mr. Price and $3.95 million for Ms. Desoer. The banks March 18 proxy statement said their 2008 salaries were $800,000.

title: Peru Signs Free Trade Deal With European Countries
description: Peru formally concluded a joint free trade agreement with Switzerland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Iceland, the trade and tourism minister, Martin Perez, said Friday. The four countries make up the European Free Trade Agreement trading bloc. Peruvian exports to the block were worth $3.4 billion last year, Mr. Perez said in a statement. Imports from the bloc totaled $1.3 billion. In the first nine months of the year, Peruvian exports to those countries rose by 18 percent, compared with the same period last year, Mr. Perez said. Sectors that will benefit the most from the new agreement are fishing and industry, Mr. Perez said.

title: Evangelical, and Young, and Active in New Area
description: WHEATON, Ill.

title: Madonnas Man-tourage
description: Madonnas love interests have always attracted media attention, but not all of it wanted.

title: In Matchup of Top Coaches, Duke Easily Handles UConn
description: Mike Krzyzewski and Jim Calhoun, the elder statesmen of college basketball coaches, stood together, smiling on the court Friday evening before they stood apart, scowling on the sidelines.

title: For Grace in Motion, Look to the Canvas
description: Frederick Wisemans new documentary film La Danse has been widely praised by movie critics as one of the finest dance films ever made. A. O. Scott was absolutely right in these pages when he said that its greater virtue, and the substance of Mr. Wisemans particular genius, is the way it transfixes you with the inner workings of an institution you may not otherwise care about.

title: For Madonnas Boyfriend, Fame by Association
description: THROUGH the penthouse windows, New York City, foggy and soft-looking, was spread out in every direction. Jesus Luz, best known as the 22-year-old Brazilian model who is dating Madonna, was about to step up to the D.J. station in a club atop a Lower East Side hotel.

title: CBS Is Criticized for Blurring of Video
description: An appearance by the singer Adam Lambert, below, on The Early Show, the CBS morning program, on Wednesday has led to further complaints from those who say Mr. Lambert has been subjected to a double standard. At issue is a video package that was used to introduce the interview with Mr. Lambert, the American Idol finalist who gave a sexually charged performance at the American Music Awards on Sunday. When CBS rebroadcast a clip from that show, it blurred a scene of Mr. Lambert kissing his male keyboardist. But it did not blur a scene of Madonna and Britney Spears kissing at the 2003 MTV Video Music Awards. In a statement, Jarrett Barrios, the president of the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, said, I would have hoped CBS would provide the same treatment for images of gay and lesbian people and not create an unfair double standard that treats our community differently. A representative for CBS told the entertainment program Extra that the image of Madonna kissing Ms. Spears is very familiar and has appeared countless times including many times on morning television. He added, The Adam Lambert image is a subject of great current controversy, has not been nearly as widely disseminated, and for all we know, may still lead to legal consequences.

title: Jackman and Craig Offer Charity Items
description: How much would you pay for two sweaty vests that have been worn out by use in a Broadway play? Wait, dont answer yet: How much would you pay if those two sweaty vests had been worn by Hugh Jackman, above left, and  Daniel Craig, above right, the stars of A Steady Rain? The answer came on Wednesday when Mr. Craig and Mr. Jackman sold their apparel (and any lingering pheromones those items might contain) at a post-performance auction at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. BBC News reported that the vests were sold for $3,500 each; originally only one vest was going to be made available, until a female audience member shouted at Mr. Jackman, How much for the pants? (Mr. Jackman offered a second vest instead of his trousers.) The clothing and other items, including autographed posters and programs, were sold to raise money for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

title: More Museums Facing Possible Strike in France
description: Frances major tourist attractions, including the Louvre, the Muse dOrsay, the Cathedral of Notre-Dame, in the background at right, and Versailles, could be shut down next week because of a strike over planned job cuts, the Confdration Gnrale du Travail union warned on Friday. We think awareness is growing in all the major public institutions, said Franck Guillaumet, who heads the culture section of the union, Frances second largest. This includes the Louvre, the Muse dOrsay, the palace of Versailles, the Arc de Triomphe and Notre Dame church. The Confdration Gnrale du Travail and seven other unions sent a letter to the Culture Ministry on Thursday evening, warning that they would go on strike on Wednesday if the government pursued its plan to reduce the budget deficit by replacing only one out of every two retiring civil servants. The announcement came after a strike that kept the Georges Pompidou Center closed for a fifth day on Friday. Workers at that museum are protesting the governments plan to cut more than 400 jobs there over the next 10 years. More than 40 percent of the workers at the Pompidou Center are older than 50, and the legal retirement age in France is 70.

title: Polanski Will Not Be Released Before Monday
description: A spokesman for Switzerlands Justice Ministry said the director Roman Polanski would not be released from a prison near Zurich until at least Monday because the conditions of his bail had not yet been met, Agence France-Presse reported. Under the terms of a bail agreement that was accepted by the Swiss Federal Criminal Court on Wednesday, Mr. Polanski, 76, must post $4.5 million, surrender his identity papers and be fitted with a monitoring bracelet. (He will spend his house arrest in his chalet in the Swiss resort town of Gstaad.) The justice ministry spokesman, Folco Galli, told Agence France-Presse that the authorities had not yet received Mr. Polanskis bond, and that his transfer from a prison in Winterthur, northeast of Zurich, would not happen on Friday or over the weekend. Mr. Polanski is awaiting possible extradition to the United States, which he fled in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl.

title: Thanksgiving Parade Draws Viewers for NBC
description: NBCs morning broadcast of the Macys Thanksgiving Parade delivered the highest ratings for that program in three years, according to preliminary overnight figures. Although Nielsens final audience figures were unavailable on Friday, NBC estimated that more than 45 million viewers tuned in for at least some portion of the broadcast. In prime time a new installment of CBSs Survivor: Samoa earned the nights largest audience with 10 million viewers. Fox was second with the 2006 movie Night at the Museum (6.6 million). ABC ranked third with A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving (6.4 million), followed by specials featuring performances by Beyonc (5.1 million) and Paul McCartney (4.7 million). NBC was fourth with a repeat of The Office (2.8 million), followed by a news special, People of the Year (5.2 million) and The Jay Leno Show(5 million).

title: Boos Cap a Bad Week for British Rapper
description: Nothing seems to have gone right for Speech Debelle, below, the British rapper, since she won pop musics prestigious Mercury Prize in September. On Tuesday, BBC News reported, the hip-hop performer (whose real name is Corynne Elliot) said in a radio interview that she had quit the independent record label Big Dada after her Mercury Prize victory did not significantly increase sales for her debut album, Speech Therapy. I wasnt disappointed that it didnt sell well, she told the BBC. I was disappointed in the people I was working with. And on Thursday, BBC News reported, she was booed by audience members at a promotional event honoring the British boy band Take That, when she tried to perform that groups love ballad Pray as a rap. In October, Speech Debelle canceled a planned United States tour, including appearances at the CMJ Music Marathon, because of visa problems.

title: John Burns Q. and A. on Obamas Options in Afghanistan
description: John Burns, the chief foreign correspondent for The New York Times, is answering questions about a New York Times primer on some possible force options available to President Obama as he considers bolstering the 68,000 American troops already in Afghanistan.

title: Bloomberg Spent $102 Million to Win 3rd Term
description: To eke out an election victory over the citys low-key comptroller, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent $102 million of his own fortune  or about $174 per vote  according to data released Friday, making his bid for a third term the most expensive campaign in the citys history.

title: At Odds Over Land, Money and Gas
description: CHENANGO, N.Y.  Chris and Robert Lacey own 80 acres of idyllic upstate New York countryside, a place where they can fish for bass in their own pond, hike through white pines and chase deer away.

title: Some Help in a Transition and a Recovery From Eye Surgery
description: There are moments in the telling of his story, particularly when he tries to describe the excruciating pain he suffered as a result of eye surgery gone awry, that Raul Mejia must stop and gather himself before going on.

title: From Shadow to Limelight for a Governors Wife
description: As the political standing of Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina continues to crumble, the career of his wife, Jenny Sanford, seems to be taking off.

title: In New York, a Parking Gift on a Holiday
description: For many in New York City, the Friday after Thanksgiving is a day to digest turkey, jostle with shopping hordes  and curse the fresh parking tickets tucked beneath untold thousands of windshield wipers.

title: Experts Say Swine Flu Mutations Do Not Warrant New Alarm
description: The World Health Organization tried this week to dampen fears about mutations seen in the swine flu virus in several countries, noting that both mutations had been found in very few people.

title: China Jails Environmentalist Wanted in U.S.
description: DALI, China  Justin Franchi Solondz, an environmental activist from New Jersey who spent years evading charges of ecoterrorism in the United States by hiding out in China, was sentenced to three years in prison by a local court on Friday on charges of manufacturing drugs in this backpacker haven.

title: On the Street | Thanksgiving Week
description: This year New Yorkers could show off their autumn finery before the weather called for coats.

title: Chinas Impolitic Artist, Still Waiting to Be Silenced
description: BEIJING

title: Dubai Debt Woes Raise Fear of Wider Problem
description: Of the many economies that gorged on debt in the boom years, Dubai stood out. In the space of a few years the emirates investment arm, Dubai World, racked up $59 billion in debt, borrowing to build lavish developments like a giant island shaped like a palm tree to entice celebrities like Brad Pitt, and to invest in glittery properties like the MGM Grand Casino in Las Vegas.

title: In a Home to Free Speech, a Paper Is Accused of Anti-Semitism
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  For the last six years, The Berkeley Daily Planet has published a freewheeling assortment of submissions from readers, who offer sharp-elbowed views on everything from raucous college parties (generally bad) to the war in Iraq (ditto).

title: Serenity Prayer Skeptic Now Credits Niebuhr
description: A Yale librarian who cast doubt last year on the origins of the Serenity Prayer, adopted by Alcoholics Anonymous and reprinted on countless knickknacks, says new evidence has persuaded him to retain the famed Protestant theologian Reinhold Niebuhr as the author in the next edition of The Yale Book of Quotations.

title: To Get Halladay, Mets Should Offer to Take Wells, Too
description: The Mets need many things this holiday season  a left fielder, a catcher, a healthy Jose Reyes and, perhaps most important, a really good starting pitcher to team up with Johan Santana and give the team some renewed credibility.

title: Zimbabwe: Trial of Opposition Leader Suspended
description: As the High Court shut down Friday for the holiday season, the judge in the trial of Roy Bennett, a senior leader in the opposition Movement for Democratic Change who is facing terrorism charges, suspended proceedings until Jan. 12. Though both the prosecution and the defense were prepared to work during the vacation, the judge said he was not willing to do so after a key witness for the state did not show up in court, said Beatrice Mtetwa, Mr. Bennetts lawyer.

title: Championship Skiers, Bound as Rivals and Friends
description: ASPEN, Colo.  Lindsey Vonn talks about her friendship with Maria Riesch in simple terms.

title: Bringing Big Band Jazz Back to the Theater District
description: There you are, texting away as you walk down West 46th Street in Midtown, and you nearly bump right into the big, bright gramophone on the sidewalk outside the Hotel Edison.

title: Buying, Selling and Twittering All the Way
description: Once upon a time, people mailed their holiday wishes to the North Pole and hoped for a reply on Christmas Day. Nowadays they are sending their wishes into cyberspace and are apt to get a reply in minutes.

title: 4 Killed at Dinner; Florida Police Seek Gunman
description: JUPITER, Fla.  The police and federal marshals fanned out across South Florida on Friday in the hunt for a man they said had left a Thanksgiving dinner crowded with relatives in this upscale beachfront community and returned with a handgun, opening fire and killing his twin sisters, an aunt and a 6-year-old cousin. Two other people were wounded.

title: B.C.S. Just Ho-Hums Along
description: With Texas looking shaky in giving up 39 points to Texas A&M on Thursday night and Alabama looking mortal in a come-from-behind victory at Auburn on Friday, two thirds of college footballs so-called Big Three were threatened in a 24-hour span.

title: For Some, a Search for Celebrity Is Worth Any Risk
description: In totalitarian regimes, some people take huge risks for the freedom to be themselves; in this democracy, some people take huge risks for the freedom to be someone else  a celebrity.

title: A Day of Discounts, Even for Knockoffs
description: The best, or at least the most unbelievable, day-after-Thanksgiving deals in New York this year were not at Macys or Saks Fifth Avenue. There were a few little places on Canal Street  you may have heard of them  where $100 Swatch watches sold for $15, and so did the $15,000 Patek Philippe models.

title: Fully Feather-Footed Flier
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Donkey, two things, O.K.? Shut  up! Hey, I know that movie. In fact, I was able to get several answers first time through, which is unusual for a Karen Tracey puzzle. Pooh-Bah is from a delightful operetta. The libretto is worth reading even without the music. W.S. Gilbert was a genius. Topsy-Turvy is an entertaining film about the creation of 32 Down.

title: Afghans Offer Jobs to Taliban Rank and File if They Defect
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  The American-backed campaign to persuade legions of Taliban gunmen to stop fighting got under way here recently, in an ornate palace filled with Afghan tribal leaders and one very large former warlord leading the way.

title: Hale Smith, Who Broke Borders of Classical and Jazz, Is Dead at 84
description: Hale Smith, a classical composer who also worked as a performer and arranger with jazz greats like Dizzy Gillespie and Chico Hamilton, died Tuesday at his home in Freeport, L.I. He was 84.

title: Region Finds U.S. Lacking on Honduras
description: WASHINGTON  Drug cartels are running amok in Mexico, Ral Castro is tightening his grip on Cuba and Hugo Chvez of Venezuela is making mischief with Russia and Iran, but it is a relatively obscure backwater, Honduras, that has provided the Obama administration with its first test in Latin America.

title: U.S.C.-U.C.L.A.: Rivalry Crosses Family Borders
description: LOS ANGELES  For years, recruiting trips to the University of Southern California included dinner at Papadakis Taverna, where, between the souvlaki, dancing waiters and the obligatory smashing of plates, prospective football players would be served an impassioned speech from the proprietor, John Papadakis, about how wonderful it was to be a Trojan.

title: Jan Leighton, Actor Who Played Everyone, Dies at 87
description: Jan Leighton, an actor who conjured a career by dressing up as historical figures, appearing in so many commercials, print advertisements and industrial films as George Washington, William Shakespeare and Christopher Columbus that he was both ubiquitous and anonymous, died on Nov. 16 in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: At a Yankees Shop, Buzz; At a Mets Store, a Hush
description: It was a tale of two Black Fridays for New Yorks baseball teams.

title: Diplomacy 101
description: We were thrilled when President Obama decided to plunge fully into the Middle East peace effort. He appointed a skilled special envoy, George Mitchell, and demanded that Israel freeze settlements, Palestinians crack down on anti-Israel violence and Arab leaders demonstrate their readiness to reach out to Israel.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Hand That Moves the Masses
description: The international sign language for stop does not seem to mean much to Wall Streeters trying to charge across Vesey Street, the busiest pedestrian thoroughfare in all of New York City.

title: Six Degrees of Climate Separation
The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 27
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: A Strength of the Giants Is Slowed by Injuries
description: With big running backs and small ones, through perennial playoff appearances and a Super Bowl season, the Giants could trust one element of their game to lead them toward the top of the standings: running the ball.

title: The Department of Lucrative Athletics
description: Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: Who Has a Chance in the B.C.S.?
description: Both No. 3 Texas and No. 2 Alabama remained on track for a possible appearance in the Bowl Championship Series title game with uninspired victories this week.

title: Hacked E-Mail Data Prompts Calls for Changes in Climate Research
description: Some prominent climate scientists are calling for changes in the way research on global warming is conducted after a British university said thousands of private e-mail messages and documents had been stolen from its climate center.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Letdown for Chicago, Recovery for San Jose
description: Twelve games on Friday night, including a record-setting performance for the Devils, a huge win for the Islanders and yet another frustrating loss for the Rangers. But perhaps the biggest eyebrow-raisers involved the Blackhawks and Sharks, fresh off a seemingly apocalyptic clash just two nights ago. Home teams listed first:

title: Readers Photos: Burning, but Breathing
description: A Hunts Point sunset. A slender, wrinkled hand gently tugging at an overcoat. Fires and smoke. Kids dashing down the street. The boardwalk at Orchard Beach.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph on Wednesday with an article about Senator John Kerry carried an incorrect credit. The photograph, of Mr. Kerry with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, was taken by Paula Bronstein of Getty Images, not Paul Bronstein.

title: U.S. Is Said to Land Force in Nicaragua
description: Sunday, Nov. 28, 1909(use this link to access todays entire issue)

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday about digital tools to enhance the iPhone camera misstated the features of one such app, Best Camera. It has a variety of filters and special effects and a sharing feature; it does not have a full-screen shutter release, an antishake feature or a shutter timer.

title: Housing Weighs on the Economy
description: All roads into and out of the recession run through the housing market. During the summer, that road seemed to be heading toward recovery. These days, it seems to be headed back toward hard times. A reversal would have big implications for the economy and, by extension, the policies now being pursued by the administration, Congress and the Federal Reserve.

title: Even a Penny Helps
description: We doubt that too many New Yorkers were shocked to be told that the United Homeless Organization, which collects coins in those big blue jugs on card tables in mid-Manhattan, was not a humble charity using direct appeals by disadvantaged workers to aid and empower the poor, but something simpler: a scam. Sidewalk transactions in the city, like sidewalk wristwatches and handbags, usually look more legitimate than they are.

title: When Prisoners Phone Home
description: New York States highest court has rejected the last vestiges of a lawsuit by families of inmates who claimed that the prison system overcharged them for telephone calls from their loved ones. The good news is that this suit  and an accompanying lobbying effort  has already succeeded in reforming a terribly unfair system.

title: A Fresh Look at Patents and Innovation
description: To the Editor:

title: Defending Phil Donahue
description: To the Editor:

title: Abortion, Insurance and Health Care Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Reducing Obesity Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Sewage in the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Iraqs Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Stacking the Deck Against Kids
description: Every year at Thanksgiving, parts of the Upper West Side of Manhattan become like a paradise for children. Theres the exciting preparation of the balloons and floats for the Thanksgiving Day parade, and then, on Thursday morning, the parade itself.

title: A Growing Disaster
description: Midland, Mich.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column on Tuesday, about online series created specifically for certain advertisers, referred incorrectly to the profession of Candace Bushnell, who is involved in one such series. She is a writer, not an actor. The column also misspelled part of the name of a product that sponsors one such series. It is Marie Callenders, not Callendars.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Nov. 16 about plans by some members of the recently defunct band Oasis to form a new group included several errors. Liam Gallagher was the lead vocalist for Oasis, not guitarist and vocalist. Noel Gallagher, his brother, was the lead guitarist and main songwriter, not lead singer and songwriter. And while Colin Archer, known as Gem, did at times play keyboard, he was primarily the rhythm guitarist and sometimes played lead guitar.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Nov. 9 about the Paul Taylor Dance Companys premiere of the work Brief Encounters, at Syracuse University, misidentified the dancer who used a mirror in the Serenade for the Doll section. She was Amy Young, not Annmaria Mazzini.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Benchmarks in Wartime: As Reliable as Promises
description: BAGHDAD  Watching Iraqs Parliament debate an election law last week, inside a conference center still decorated with mosaics of Saddam Husseins wartime delusions, ought to have been reassuring to those who wish the countrys nascent democracy well. It wasnt.

title: A Conflicted Celebration
description: Muslims in Afghanistan, Iraq and Pakistan find ways to celebrate Id al-Adha.

title: In Support of Abortion, Its Personal vs. Political
description: WASHINGTON  In the early 1950s, a coal miners daughter from rural Kentucky named Louise McIntosh encountered the shadowy world of illegal abortion. A friend was pregnant, with no prospects for marriage, and Ms. McIntosh was keeper of a secret that, if spilled, could have led to family disgrace. The turmoil ended quietly in a doctors office, and the friend went on to marry and have four children.

title: Health Care Savings Could Start in the Cafeteria
description: Steven Burd isnt a doctor or a medical specialist. But he sure can talk like one.

title: Comment of the Week
description: We saw Robin in Syracuse this past week and laughed for two straight hours. We all have issues. To be able to give joy to other people is a gift. To utilize ones own issues in order to bring joy to other people is the mother lode. I think we can all learn a little something when we see someone crash and burn, then arise from the ashes a better person.

title: Yang Xianyi, Translator of Chinese Works, Dies at 94
description: Yang Xianyi, a translator renowned for his skill at rendering both classic and contemporary Chinese literature into English, died on Monday in Beijing. He was 94.

title: Anthonys 50 Points Too Much for Knicks
description: DENVER  As Carmelo Anthony transformed from pudgy prodigy to the refined basketball player with the body to showcase it, he shed his quest for a scoring trophy in favor of one for an N.B.A. title.

title: 2 Found Dead in a Van in Sunset Park
description: Firefighters found two men dead in a van that had caught fire in Brooklyn on Friday near the Gowanus Expressway.

title: As Top Coaches Meet, Duke Beats Connecticut
description: Mike Krzyzewski and Jim Calhoun, the elder statesmen of college basketball coaches, stood together, smiling on the court Friday evening before they stood apart, scowling on the sidelines.

description: Mike Krzyzewski and Jim Calhoun, the elder statesmen of college basketball coaches, stood together, smiling on the court Friday evening before they stood apart, scowling on the sidelines.

title: A Libertines Reckoning
description: If D. H. Lawrence and his wife, Frieda, ever had a battle about which of them was the more colorful personage, Frieda must have given her famous novelist husband a run for his money.

title: A Difference of Opinion on the Giants Running Game
description: A fairly large gap seems to be developing among the Giants about their offensive philosophy, but its not clear if the teams backs could run through it.

title: Damaged by my 60s childhood
description: When I saw that Calculated Risk had a post titled Flipper in Trouble, my first thought  honest!  was that it had something to do with a heroic dolphin.

title: A Trip to the Jazz Age, in Times Square
description: Every Monday night, Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks turn back the clock at Club Cache, in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Russian Train Derailment
description: Passengers of the Nevsky Express, perhaps the most illustrious train in Russia, reported a scene of panic and devastation.

title: The Saturday Word: When Guests Drop In
description: With Thanksgiving behind it, the White House now turns to the important foreign and domestic questions that will define the coming week  the least of which is how a pair of aspiring reality-show stars ended up face-to-face with President Obama in the receiving line at his first state dinner.

title: Goodbye, Dubai?
description: Whats tiny, dry and poised to bring down the entire global economic system? If you answered Dubai, youve been reading the papers over this extended holiday weekend. Landon Thomas Jr. of The Times sets the stage:

title: Afghans Detail Detention in Black Jail at U.S. Base
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An American military detention camp in Afghanistan is still holding inmates, sometimes for weeks at a time, without access to the International Committee of the Red Cross, according to human rights researchers and former detainees held at the site on the Bagram Air Base.

title: Puns and Anagrams for the W = E
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Mel Taub is back with another PandA puzzle. If youre not used to these cryptic-like conundrums, give this one a try. This is the favorite variety puzzle for many people.

title: Growing, Yes, but India Has Reasons to Worry
description: PONDICHERRY, India  During President Obamas recent visit to China, many in India speculated that an emerging G2 would leave their nation out in the cold.

title: Thoughts on Alabamas Victory
description: AUBURN, Ala.  Some more thoughts on the Iron Bowl and Alabamas 26-21 win over rival Auburn on Friday.

title: Roethlisberger Out With Concussion Symptoms
description: Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger will miss Sunday nights critical game against the Baltimore Ravens with symptoms from the concussion he sustained last week. Roethlisberger passed concussion tests early in the week, according to Coach Mike Tomlin, and he practiced Wednesday and Thursday. But he apparently started having headaches after the practices, and he took very few snaps at Fridays practice.

title: Senate Report Explores 2001 Escape by bin Laden From Afghan Mountains
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama vows to finish the job in Afghanistan by sending more troops, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has completed a detailed look back at a crucial failure early in the battle against Al Qaeda: the escape of Osama bin Laden from American forces in the Afghan mountains of Tora Bora in December 2001.

title: Entering the Superproject Void
description: Generation after generation, giant public works projects have altered the American landscape. The Erie Canal and the transcontinental railroad come to mind. So do massive urban sewer and sanitation systems, the Tennessee Valley Authority, rural electrification, the Hoover Dam, the Interstate System, the subway networks in San Francisco and Washington, the Big Dig in Boston ... and the list abruptly stops.

title: Winning Lower Payments Takes Patience, and Luck
description: On the day in June when her mortgage company finally agreed to lower her monthly payments, Yolanda Thomas felt a twinge of hope that she would hold on to her Queens apartment, the first home she had ever owned. The loan modification extended by Chase Home Finance was technically a trial, not a permanent alteration, but this fact seemed of lesser significance.

title: U.S. Will Push Mortgage Firms to Reduce More Loan Payments
description: The Obama administration on Monday plans to announce a campaign to pressure mortgage companies to reduce payments for many more troubled homeowners, as evidence mounts that a $75 billion taxpayer-financed effort aimed at stemming foreclosures is foundering.

title: Higher Schooling in Michigan
description: Last November, Michigan became the 13th state to legalize medical marijuana. One young entrepreneur sees it as a business opportunity.

title: Prime Numbers
description: 26.9: The total tax revenue of the United States as a percentage of its gross domestic product, according to the Organization for Economic Development and Cooperation. Denmark had the highest tax burden, at 48.3 percent; Mexico, the lowest, at 21.1 percent. The overall tax burden for the 30-member economic-development organization was estimated at 35.2 percent of G.D.P.

title: Cannabis 101
description: Med Grow Cannabis College in Southfield, Mich., teaches the history, horticulture and legal how-to's of Michigan's new medical marijuana program.

title: The Wild Boar Is Multiplying and Less Lovable
description: Europes wild boar population is exploding because of climate change and increased biofuel production from corn and rapeseed  crops boars like to gorge upon, David Crossland reported in Der Spiegel.

title: At This School, Its Marijuana in Every Class
description: SOUTHFIELD, Mich.  At most colleges, marijuana is very much an extracurricular matter. But at Med Grow Cannabis College, marijuana is the curriculum: the history, the horticulture and the legal how-tos of Michigans new medical marijuana program.

title: Nov. 25, 1909
description: RIOT AGAINST SUFFRAGETTES

title: Dont Ask How Are You? Unless You Mean It
description: This interview with Judith Jamison, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, was conducted by Adam Bryant.

title: Quotations of the Week
description: He reminds me of a chess grandmaster who has played his opening in six simultaneous games. But he hasnt completed a single game and Id like to see him finish one. Henry Kissinger on President Obama

title: Get Ready for Half a Recovery
description: A ROBUST economic recovery in 2010 is certainly on most investors wish lists as this year draws to a close. A return to prosperity would not only mean an end to our long financial nightmare, but it would also buttress a rebounding stock market, one of 2009s few bright spots.

title: South Carolina Rift Highlights Debate Over G.O.P.
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  When Senator Lindsey Graham joined forces last month with Senator John Kerry on a compromise to the climate change legislation known as cap and trade, it was the last straw for the Charleston County Republican Party.

title: Wines, With Notes of M.B.A.
description: Rutherford, Calif.

title: From Fritos to Cranberries
description: MY father owned a small chain of soft-serve ice cream stands and fast-food restaurants outside of Boston. I worked in the family business from the time I was a toddler running around parking lots picking up discarded cups and utensils. Later I helped prepare food.

title: Over 60, and Proud to Join the Digerati
description: IN the summer of 2008, just before I turned 61, I went to work at FLYP, an online digital publication that combines text with Flash animation, motion graphics and streaming audio and video to tell stories. Its part of a larger effort to explore new forms of multimedia journalism.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Nov. 29, 2009
description: After weeks of talk about health care, the Sunday shows turn to the speech President Obama will deliver at West Point on Tuesday night detailing his plan for Afghanistan with legislators from the armed services and foreign relations committees in both chambers weighing in.

title: Road Rage at the Kremlin
description: MOSCOW  Every society has a breaking point. In Boston it was the tea tax; in France it was Marie Antoinettes wigs. If youre curious where the breaking point may lie in Russia, try slamming the door as you get out of a taxicab  even the most rickety Soviet-era Lada. What will pass across the drivers face is an expression of such exquisite suffering that you will first apologize and then run. Russians love their cars.

title: When Names Change to Protect the Future
description: APPLE dropped the word computer from its name in January 2007, soon after it introduced the iPhone. Likewise, Fuji Photo Film shortened its name to Fujifilm in 2006, when sales of its photography products slipped to less than one-third of total revenue.

title: Bernanke Warns of Risks in Push to Revamp Fed
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board warned bluntly on Saturday that provisions in financial legislation before the House and Senate would seriously impair the Fed as it struggled to maintain financial and economic stability.

title: A Reality TV Head Count
description: Its Jimmy Durantes worst nightmare: everybody does want to get into the act.

title: The Manly Art of Museum Curating
description: The other week I took my son Dean to see the Arts of the Samurai show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. As we walked around admiring the many gleaming sword blades, fantastic helmets and braided suits of iron armor, I detected something unfamiliar in the air, at least in this museum. I couldnt quite figure out what it was until we were standing at the cash register in the gift shop.

title: Large Victory Likely for Namibia Governing Party
description: JOHANNESBURG  Voters in Namibia went to the polls on Saturday for the second and final day of national elections, a balloting most likely to lead to another landslide victory for the South-West African Peoples Organization, or Swapo, the party that has governed since independence in 1990.

title: Civil Suit Hearing Held in Chinas Milk Scandal
description: BEIJING  A hearing began Friday in the first civil suit to be heard in court involving parents suing a dairy company and a supermarket over selling tainted milk, The China Daily, an official English-language newspaper, reported Saturday.

title: Golfer Is Ready for One More Comeback
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Ken Green knows comebacks. In three tumultuous decades as a professional golfer, he has been a star and star-crossed. He has basked near the top of the money list and has cleaned out his checking and savings accounts. He divorced his first wife and started winning; he was divorced by his second wife and lost everything.

title: Dont Take This Bait (but Youre Safe if You Do)
description: THE e-mail message from the bank looks real. It isnt.

title: A Rally That Needs More E
description: IN the first leg of a bull market, when optimism and euphoria are ascendant, investors are willing to bet that the economy will improve and that corporate profit growth is just around the corner. This faith manifests itself not just in rising share prices, but also in rising price-to-earnings ratios.

title: Dangers of an Overheated China
description: PRESIDENT OBAMAS recent trip to China reflects a symbiotic relationship at the heart of the global economy: China uses American spending power to enlarge its private sector, while America uses Chinese lending power to expand its public sector. Yet this arrangement may unravel in a dangerous way, and if it does, the most likely culprit will be Chinese economic overcapacity.

title: Baby Boom of Mixed Children Tests South Korea
description: YEONGGWANG, South Korea  Just a few years ago, the number of pregnant women in this city had declined so much that the sparsely equipped two-room maternity ward at Yeonggwang General Hospital was close to shutting down. But these days it is busy again.

title: Volunteering? Its Easy to Avoid the Waiting List
description: During the holidays, many a warm-hearted persons thoughts turn to volunteering. While most volunteers seek mainly to help others, their work also aids the economy by providing free labor  so important to organizations suffering from the recession.

title: Letters: Avoiding the Platitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: A Severe Recession by Any Other Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Rail Engineers Begin a Strike
description: OTTAWA  About 1,700 locomotive engineers with the Canadian National Railway went on strike early Saturday morning. The walkout, which may create difficulties for manufacturers and resource companies, followed a decision by Canadian National to impose a new contract on its workers.

title: Carolina at Jets: What to Watch
description: 1 p.m. Eastern at Giants Stadium, Fox

title: Devils Brush Off Injuries and Roll On
description: NEWARK  An unusually nasty rash of injuries has sidelined important players on almost every team in the N.H.L. Some teams, like the Rangers, have struggled as a result.

title: A Wrestling Great Calculates His Next Big Move: Dynasty
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  They turn cartwheels and mime acrobatic moves to the techno beat pumping through the sound system until sweat begins to glisten on their bodies. They are muscled and agile and could pass for Cirque du Soleil performers except that most of them have mangled ears, a telltale giveaway that they are wrestlers.

title: Addressing Spending in College Athletics
description: In an Op-Ed in Saturdays New York Times, Gilbert Gaul writes that the out-of-control spending in college athletics is caused by two factors: universities allowing athletic departments to operate independently and the taxes, or lack of them, on income generated by college sports.

title: Listening to Wisdom From a 10-Year-Old Son About His Head Injury
description: Dad, Im scared. I only have one brain, and I dont want to hurt it playing football.

title: With Fourth Concussion, Roethlisberger to Sit Out
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers starting quarterback, Ben Roethlisberger, will miss Sunday nights critical game against the Baltimore Ravens because of symptoms from the concussion he sustained last week. Roethlisberger passed concussion tests early in the week, according to Coach Mike Tomlin, and he practiced Wednesday and Thursday. But he apparently started having headaches after those practices, and he took few snaps Friday.

title: To Prepare for War, G.I.s Get a Dress Rehearsal
description: FORT POLK, La.  A firefight with heavily armed insurgents near a gold-domed mosque. A helicopter evacuation of bloody car bomb victims. A meeting with tribal elders upset about security.

title: For a Budding Fan, Basketball the Way It Ought to Be
description: My older son, Gabe, turned 3 in May, and I knew this would be the season I would finally take him to his first basketball game. I wanted the experience to be fun, the start of what I hoped would be a lifetime of basketball fandom.

title: Interviews With Detainees
description: Following are excerpts of interviews with former detainees held at a military jail at American air base in Afghanistan.

title: N.B.A. Shows Are Better Than the Previews
description: It is late November, and the season-preview magazines are a little frayed, their predictions coated in dust. The best N.B.A. guide now might be the TV guide.

title: Kayakers Looking for Remote Regions in Bhutan
description: Land Heflin seems to divide his life story into two stages. The first stage was unique enough: his father, David, was an outdoor educator at Delta State University in Mississippi, and Heflin began kayaking by the age of 10.

title: Does the Public Care About the Public Option?
description: As the Senate begins debate this week on health care legislation, the question of whether to keep the bills provision for a government-run health insurance plan, known as the public option, will be one of the most contentious.

description: The number of recipients has risen by 10 million in two years.

description: Mashobra, India

title: Protecting the Forests, and Hoping for Payback
description: SISTERS, Ore.  A patch of ponderosa pines here in the Deschutes National Forest has been carefully pruned over the last few years to demonstrate the United States Forest Services priorities in the changing West: improving forest health and protecting against devastating wildfire while still supporting the timber economy.

title: Cued Up
description: Wunst they wuz a little boy wouldnt say his prayers,An when he went to bed at night, away up-stairs,His Mammy heerd him holler, an his Daddy heerd him bawl,An when they turnt the kivvers down, he wuznt there at all!  Little Orphant Annie by James Whitcomb Riley

title: The Year the Davis Cup Felt Empty
description: Four men who dreamed of sipping Champagne from the Davis Cup finally had their hands on it, but there would be no celebration.

title: Amid Family Misfortune, Jets Snapper Finds Distraction on the Field

title: Titans Young Rebounds, With Help From a Friend  Kobe Bryant
description: HOUSTON  After Vince Young led the Titans past the Texans last Monday night, Kobe Bryant sent a text message saying: Good game V. Way to kick butt!

title: Problems and Discontent Bedevil Chicago State
description: When the Chicago State University basketball team opened its season on Nov. 13 against Concordia University, almost everything pointed to success. The Cougars, wearing crisp white and green uniforms, took the court in the sparkling, recently completed, $38 million Emil and Patricia A. Jones Convocation Center.

title: Weary of Political Crisis, Honduras Holds Election
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras  Rony Gmez will stay home when Hondurans go to the polls on Sunday to elect a new president, five months after the military and Congress ousted the last one. I wont vote, he said. It would be endorsing the coup.

title: Plane Crash in China Kills 3 Americans
description: SHANGHAI    A cargo plane crashed shortly after taking off from the Pudong International Airport here on Saturday morning, killing three American crew members and injuring four others, including an American.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: PARIS  France, a nation endlessly fascinated with itself since at least as far back as the Gauls, is again engaged in a bizarre and deeply political debate over its identity.

title: Hard Hats Dont Deflect Union Workers Hardships
description: In a dank basement on Michigan Avenue, a 24-year-old apprentice plumber strained on a ladder, gripping a claw hammer as he struggled with a storm pipe.

description: [Update | 7:00 p.m.  The Phoenix Coyotes confirm that they have loaned Tikhonov to the K.H.L. The article below has been revised to reflect the announcement.]

title: Lino Lacedelli Dies at 83; One of First to Scale K2
description: Lino Lacedelli, one of the first two climbers to reach the summit of K2, the worlds second highest peak and among the most treacherous, died on Nov. 20 in the house he had lived in since his birth in Cortina dAmpezzo, Italy. He was 83.

title: Denmark in the Wind
description: Copenhagen

title: Food Stamp Use Soars, and Stigma Fades
description: MARTINSVILLE, Ohio  With food stamp use at record highs and climbing every month, a program once scorned as a failed welfare scheme now helps feed one in eight Americans and one in four children.

title: The Penguins of Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO    I had set my umbrella and chair near the water in the early hours of what would soon become a perfect summer day. Like most people, I prefer the beach when it is deserted, and I had the place all to myself, no vendors to be seen, parading their sunglasses and suntan oils; no drinks, sandwiches or sweets offered in singing voices. Above all, no kids kicking balls or sand in my face. I held a book and was intent on doing some serious reading.

title: Villagers Rushed to Help in Frigid Russian Crash
description: LYKOSHINO, Russia  Rudolf Denyayev climbed over a small ridge on Friday night and saw the whole disaster spread out before him: train passengers wandering blindly, luggage tossed in all directions, screams coming from the derailed cars.

title: Climbing to Success, and Helping Others Along
description: Patrick Alvarez made sure the tables of children were eating their turkey while he directed a group of volunteers to the kitchen, nodded thanks to a mentor and shook hands with a well-wisher grateful for the meal.

title: In Japan, Concerns Blossom
description: Tokyo

title: 17-Year-Old Is Held in Fatal Chinatown Stabbing
description: Detectives have arrested a 17-year-old youth in the fatal stabbing of a young man in Chinatown nearly two weeks ago, the police said on Saturday.

title: World Cup Offers an Opening for Players With Ambitions
description: The top 30 players in the world can earn good livings. But it is considerably more difficult for the players ranked just below them. Their appearance fees are lower, and they rarely are invited to the tournaments that offer the best prize money.

title: South Africas Fire Kingdom
description: Weltevredenpark, South Africa

title: Before the Climate Conference, a Weather Report
description: President Obama and other world leaders will gather in Copenhagen next week to discuss climate change. Though this is a global issue, its also a profoundly local one. For this reason, the Op-Ed editors asked writers from four different continents to report on the climate changes theyve experienced close to home. Here are their dispatches.

title: White House Intruders Want Money for Tale
description: WASHINGTON  As White House officials fended off new questions about how a fame-seeking couple finessed their way into the presidents glittering state dinner last week, the aspiring reality-TV stars themselves began trying to sell their story for hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: Pakistans Leader Cedes Nuclear Office
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Asif Ali Zardari has ceded his position in Pakistans nuclear command structure to his prime minister, in a sudden political maneuver widely seen as a fresh sign of turmoil on the eve of President Obamas strategy announcement for the region.

title: Correction: Nov. 22 Cover Illustration
description: A cover illustration on Nov. 22 carried an incomplete credit. While Ruth Gwily was indeed the illustrator, her portrait of Raymond Carver was based on a photograph by Bob Adelman/Corbis.

title: Correction: Review of Cowboys Full
description: A review on Nov. 15 about Cowboys Full: The Story of Poker, by James McManus, misidentified the cards in a televised hold em deal that are face down yet visible to viewers through a glass panel in the table. They are each players hole cards, not the five shared cards, which are dealt face up and visible to all.

description: The republic of Rwanda was admitted to the Commonwealth on Saturday, becoming the 54th nation to join the post-colonial group.

title: In a Big Beer City, Makers of Spirits on Parallel Paths
description: The phrase Chicago distilleries tends to elicit visions of cinematic gunfights and bullet-pocked Cadillacs  not hyper-educated Gen Xers surrounded by 60 pounds of raw ginger. Welcome to the new era of boutique spirit making in Chicago.

title: Speculation Fills Gap Left by Tiger Woodss Silence
description: Each hour that passes without word from Tiger Woods about the details of his car crash early Friday morning may prove damaging to his image by allowing an online rumor mill to produce conjecture and opinion, according to experts who advise high-profile athletes and celebrities.

description: Paying jobs have been scarce these days for Jeff Horwitz, a building contractor from Campbell, but last weekend he went on a Christmas shopping spree.

title: Holy Cross Falls Short, but Holds Hope Its Program Is Rising
description: VILLANOVA, Pa.  His helmet off and hands on his hips, Holy Cross quarterback Dominic Randolph stood on the sideline and watched Villanova end his collegiate career with a game-sealing first down. He clasped his hands behind his head and turned away.

title: A Modest Public Plan
description: It is astonishing, but the question of whether a small slice of Americans should be able to choose between a government-run health insurance plan and private health insurance plans is threatening passage of much-needed health care reform.

title: Over-Punishment in Schools
description: New York City joined a national trend in 1998 when it put the police in charge of school security. The consensus is that public schools are now safe. But juvenile justice advocates across the country are rightly worried about policies under which children are sometimes arrested and criminalized for behavior that once was dealt with by principals or guidance counselors working with a students parents.

title: Stayin Alive
description: We can try/to understand/The New York Times effect on man, the Bee Gees once sang, to which we would say great. You might have at least as much fun just listening or singing or dancing to the rest of Stayin Alive, which we bet has just wormed into your ear, where it will stay until at least bedtime tonight.

description: If Joe Lieberman or other senators came across John Brodniak writhing in pain on the sidewalk, they presumably would jump to help him and rush him to a hospital.

description: Washington

description: Washington

title: Tebow Says Farewell With a Flourish
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Like fishing stories told on front porches at dusk or tall tales traded around bar stools after last call, the legend of Tim Tebow seems likely to only grow larger in this part of the country.

title: Kicking Back and Kicking Off the Heels
description: Vicki Marlane, 75, is a transgender drag queen. Every Friday and Saturday night she performs with The Hot Boxxx Girls at Aunt Charlies Lounge, a postage-stamp-sized bar in the citys Tenderloin District, where she is known as The Girl with the Liquid Spine. Ms. Marlane started entertaining as a female impersonator at 17. (Her words have been edited and condensed.)

title: An American Export Comes Home, Still Popping
description: Krumping, clowning, strobing, turfing, breaking, locking. Few art forms boast as many subgenres as hip-hop dance. Though the differences between its various styles may be inscrutable to most people, mavens like Popin Pete of the seminal West Coast hip-hop dance crew the Electric Boogaloos have been known to split hairs over its terminology. There are people who wave, and there are people who tut, he told Dance Spirit Magazine last year. Theyre not popping.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Grand Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri of Iran, who has emerged as the spiritual leader of the political opposition, misstated, in some editions, the surname of an Iranian scholar who said Ayatollah Montazeris criticisms were especially hurtful to the government because they attacked its assertion of Islamic legitimacy. The scholar, a former seminary student who is now senior fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, is Mehdi Khalaji, not Khaliji.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Long Island Calendar in some editions on Nov. 15 and last Sunday misidentified the version of Miracle on 34th Street being performed at the John W. Engeman Theater in Northport. It is the musical adaptation by Douglas M. Smith and Vernon L. Stefanic  not the play by Will Severin, Patricia Di Benedetto Snyder and John Vreeke. Both are based on the story by Valentine Davies.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Nov. 15 with a Sports of The Times column, about Andre Agassis recent tour to promote his new memoir, Open, carried an erroneous credit in some editions. The photograph showing Agassi and his collaborator on the book, J. R. Moehringer, was by Isaac Brekken for The New York Times, not by Stuart Isett for The New York Times.

title: Bay Area Highlights for Nov. 29
description: A Good Deal | Some in the Bay Area who have seen paying jobs vanish with the recession have turned to barter to keep themselves employed and to be able to shop. Groups like International Monetary Systems are making a comeback, and with the Christmas shopping season officially under way, the shadow economy, with its ersatz currency, is a growing force in the Bay Area.

title: Home Course Holds No Advantage for the American Team in Aspen
description: ASPEN, Colo.  Julia Mancuso received a winners welcome when she skied into the finish corral here Saturday afternoon after her second giant slalom run in a World Cup event.

description: Patrick Alvarez and Isaias Garcia overcame odds that would overwhelm most teenagers.  Together they help feed the needy through a nonprofit group Mr. Alvarez founded, Project Feed Me.

title: Bowden Contemplates His Future
description: Florida State Coach Bobby Bowden took some of the attention away from the Tim Tebow love-fest on Saturday by saying that he was contemplating retirement.

title: The Human Toll of our Health System
description: Opponents of health care reform periodically argue that legislation is unnecessary because anybody can get medical assistance through the emergency room  or that those who get in trouble have only themselves for blame by not buying insurance. My Sunday column tells the story of John Brodniak, a young man who had insurance with his job, but lost both when he developed a benign tumor in his brain. Read his story and see if you still think the need for universal coverage isnt urgent. His story seems to me the best rebuttal of the skeptics.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
description: A report on Nov. 15 in the In Transit column, about the new Cruise Terminal 18 at Port Everglades, Fla., misstated the month that the Oasis of the Seas, heading for the terminal on its maiden voyage, departed Finland. It left on Oct. 30, not earlier this month.

description: A crowded and indistinct Heisman Trophy race did not get much clearer this weekend.
