description: Images from the new musical about Andy Warhol.

title: Traumatized Russians View Their Dead After Luxury Train Bombing
description: TVER, Russia  All day on Sunday, families from Moscow and St. Petersburg arrived at the salmon-colored morgue here where their dead had been laid out. They clutched one anothers hands on the way in, and on the way out they looked different, whether from relief or dread, it was not always clear.

title: Let the Games Begin! (No, Not the Olympics.)
description: Hong Kong is not exactly a city of sport-lovers. Sure, theres the Hong Kong Rugby Sevens and horse racing at the Jockey Club, but competitive shopping is typically how locals show off their athletic endurance. So it was hardly surprising that Hong Kong seemed to emit a collective yawn upon hearing the news that the city would host the 2009 East Asian Games from Dec. 5 to 13.

title: Matthew Stafford Had Most Dramatic Player Wiring
description: NFL Films has been putting microphones on players since 1965. Its president, Steve Sabol, said recently that no players wiring had ever been as dramatic as Matthew Staffords in a comeback victory against the Browns.

title: International Firsts, and Foot-in-Mouth Play-by-Play
description: The N.B.A. is one of the most international of the North American leagues, and as more and more nationalities are represented there are inevitably going to be some interesting juxtapositions as well as some growing pains.

title: Woods Says Car Accident Is His Fault, but Private
description: Tiger Woods said on Sunday that the car accident that sent him to the hospital early Friday was his fault and it was embarrassing to him and his family.

title: The Creepy Id
description: Images of some of James Spaders film and TV performances.

title: Final: Jets 17, Panthers 6
description: David Waldstein provided live analysis from the Jets game against the Carolina Panthers at the Meadowlands.

title: Keeping the Warriors Lineup Trim
description: Don Nelson, the coach of the Golden State Warriors, has been playing around with his lineup all season, averaging 9.3 players a game, including 11 in a loss to the Kings on Nov. 8. That served to make his absence because of pneumonia all the more noticeable during Tuesdays win over the Dallas Mavericks. Filling in for Nelson, the assistant Keith Smart had only eight healthy players. He apparently considered that two too many; he used just six in beating Dallas, 113-103.

title: Giants Manning Dealing With Injury
description: Giants quarterback Eli Manning has been treated for a stress reaction in his right foot that is a result of a continuing problem with plantar fasciitis, a person with knowledge of the condition confirmed Sunday.

title: Moving Beyond Khmer Rouges Ghosts
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  The first trial to showcase the atrocities of the Khmer Rouge three decades ago concluded with the regimes chief torturer still seemingly unable to grasp the magnitude of his actions. Yet despite that surprising end, the trial may have helped Cambodia begin to move beyond the horrors of its past.

title: Israel to Recruit More Building Inspectors to Enforce a Freeze on West Bank Construction
description: JERUSALEM  Israels defense minister, Ehud Barak, instructed his staff on Sunday to recruit dozens of new building inspectors to supervise the governments temporary construction freeze in West Bank settlements, while some settler leaders vowed to defy the building ban.

title: Senators Show Doubts on Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  With President Obama scheduled on Tuesday to explain his new Afghan strategy  calling for up to 35,000 additional American troops to battle insurgents, stabilize the government and help train Afghan security forces  senators of both parties laid out on Sunday a range of reservations. They cited the questionable reliability of the Afghan government and security forces, the steep costs of a larger involvement, and the advisability of any exit strategy.

title: The Delicate Arithmetic of Love and Independence
description: Too Much Happiness, the title story of Alice Munros latest collection, is a brilliant distillation of her Chekhovian art. Though its based on the life of the 19th-century Russian mathematician Sophia Kovalevsky, and takes place in Europe rather than the authors native Canada, the tale showcases all of Ms. Munros gifts as a master of the short story form, while recapitulating many of the themes that have animated her fiction over four decades: the complicated arithmetic of familial relationships, the freedoms and constraints imposed by marriage, the competing claims of love and independence that women must balance in trying to forge identities of their own.

title: Sri Lankan Who Led Fight Against Tamil Tigers Seeks Presidency
description: NEW DELHI  The former chief of Sri Lankas army formally announced Sunday that he would seek to replace his onetime ally, President Mahinda Rajapaksa, in elections to be held in January.

title: New Moon Leads at Box Office; The Blind Side Surprises at No. 2
description: LOS ANGELES  As expected, The Twilight Saga: New Moon led at the movie box office for the second weekend in a row, with $42.5 million in domestic ticket sales for a 10-day total of $230.7 million. But the weeks surprise came from The Blind Side, a sports and family drama that was close behind with an estimated $40.1 million in sales, making it poised to become Sandra Bullocks highest-grossing film to date.

title: Singing for Their Supper Underground
description: Mando Alvarado doesnt have nearly as much to say as he thinks he does in Post No Bills, his new play with music at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater. And his director, Michael Ray Escamilla, is in no hurry to have him say it, which makes the two-plus hours seem awfully long.

title: Swiss Ban Building of Minarets on Mosques
description: GENEVA  In a vote that displayed a widespread anxiety about Islam and undermined the countrys reputation for religious tolerance, the Swiss on Sunday overwhelmingly imposed a national ban on the construction of minarets, the prayer towers of mosques, in a referendum drawn up by the far right and opposed by the government.

title: Visions of Sugar Plums
description: All real ballets, W. H. Auden wrote in his essay Ballets Present Eden, take place in a world where there is no memory and no anticipation; the joys of life are those of the immediate and eternal present. Auden, a friend of George Balanchine, was referring to The Nutcracker, but he might as well have been talking about childhood. Drawing us into that pure present state of being is just part of what Balanchines Nutcracker, which opened Friday night at the David H. Koch Theater for New York City Ballets annual run, does so brilliantly.

title: At 0-17, the Nets Tie an Unwanted Record
description: LOS ANGELES  As the Nets have become a team in transition, from conference contender to doormat, from established stars to burgeoning ones and from their Meadowlands home toward Brooklyn, they had few constants.

title: Shes Writing Her Tell-All Memoirs, Guys
description: Was S. N. Behrman one of those women who wrote under a masculine pen name? Of course not. But you might think so, considering the strong feminist viewpoint in his 1932 play Biography.

title: B.U.s Six-on-Three Advantage
description: There was a full house at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night to watch Boston University, the defending national champions, and Cornell play to a 3-3 draw. For those in the crowd who mainly follow professional hockey, it was indeed a pleasure to see a game end without a penalty shootout, as well as some other advantages of the college game: enthusiastic crowds that dont need prompting from scoreboards, touch-up icing, officials who jump in immediately to stop fights and, of course, pep bands.

title: That Bellow, That Beard: An Actors Life and Hair
description: In a biographical solo play about a celebrity, you can usually count on a few things. The conceit designed to get the famous person to narrate a highlights reel of a lifetime is going to be strained. The performance will be theatrical. And at some point the actor will pause dramatically, holding back something that the author has no intention of keeping hidden.

title: The First Winners Are Crowned at the Fall Championships
description: At the Fall North American Championships in San Diego, the first two national championships were decided on Saturday. The winners of the Helen Sobel Smith Life Master Womens Pairs were Sue Picus and Shawn Quinn. Picus lives in Manhattan, and Quinn is temporarily in Texas. She lived the last few years in Poland and is about to relocate to Switzerland. They finished one-sixth of a board ahead of Victoria Gromova and Tatiana Ponomareva from Moscow. Third were Margie Gwozdzinsky of New York and Kathleen Sulgrove of Twinsburg, Ohio.

title: New CDs
description: R. KELLY Untitled (Jive)

title: Exit, Pursued by Swells and Lowlifes
description: Lauras horrible secret has been exposed. Beautiful in her white 19th-century gown, she exits the party, stricken. Spontaneous applause breaks out at the Metropolitan Playhouse. Clearly, 142-year-old melodrama can still be fun.

title: Coming Next Year: Nutcracker Competition
description: In this ring, the Mouse King takes on the Nutcracker Prince.

title: An American in Zurich, or Dont Let the Door Hit You in the Back
description: A 12-man-strong American contingent is headed to Cape Town, South Africa, for Fridays World Cup draw. The United States will be playing in its sixth consecutive World Cup and is regarded as an emerging power, on the field and economically, in the worlds game.

title: A Tabletop Conjurer, Rediscovered
description: We lose good artists to the past all the time, because their work was ephemeral, or difficult, or fashion wasnt on their side. The performance artist Stuart Sherman, who died of AIDS in 2001, was a candidate for disappearance on all three counts. But thanks to two exceptional exhibitions, one at the New York University 80WSE gallery, the other at Participant Inc., an alternative space on the Lower East Side, hes back in a big way, big at least for him.

title: A Night Curtain at Baghdads National Theater
description: With He Who Seeks Sweet Things Must Also Endure Bitterness, the Iraqi National Theater in Baghdad is trying to return to the evening performance schedule it maintained before the American invasion in 2003, Reuters reported. The play, which follows two tribes opposed to a marriage, is also about loving Iraq and returning to it, its producer, Issam al-Abbasi, told Reuters. In the past, of course, when there was stability in the country, there was always a big turnout. Now just being able to stage a play is an achievement. The 1,300-seat theater tried to reopen last year with a comedy, but that effort lasted two months. A recent decrease in sectarian violence as well as sealed blast walls and police protection have encouraged performers and audiences to try again. On days when huge bombs kill dozens, the theater is all the more packed, said one actress, Inaam al-Rubaie. Its as if the spectators want to send a message to the attackers they are not afraid, and life goes on. (Above, the actors Zuhoor, left, and Majid Yaseen.)

title: Queen of the Muppets
description: Miss Piggy, above, has finally received the popular acclaim she has always believed she deserved. As a tribute to Freddie Mercury, the Queen frontman who died 18 years ago, the Muppet clan covered his band Queens hit Bohemian Rhapsody. The new clip, produced and posted by the Disney unit Muppets Studio at youtube.com/user/MuppetsStudio, was the most-watched video on YouTube last week, with more than 4.5 million views, according to The Independent, the British newspaper. Besides Miss Piggy, who contributed her own flourish  Nothing really matters but moi  the videos cast of dozens includes Gonzo leading his chorus of chicks, accompanied, of course, by the Dr. Teeth and the Electric Mayhem band, Fozzie Bear, Statler and Waldorf, Sam the Eagle and the Swedish Chef. But Animal sums it up best with his repetitive cries of Mama! We know how you feel, Animal.

title: A Defiant Iran Vows to Build Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON  Iran angrily refused Sunday to comply with a demand by the United Nations nuclear agency to cease work on a once-secret nuclear fuel enrichment plant, and escalated the confrontation by declaring it would construct 10 more such plants.

title: One Is the Loneliest Number
description: And then there were none.

title: 35 Across: Not Too Soft, as Pasta
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Themes that require a clue like Word that can follow the ends of  are not the most intriguing ones in the crossword construction bag of tricks. However, any puzzle that can weave BLUE-FOOTED BOOBY into its theme is O.K. by me. The other theme phrases are nice as well, and the fill seems especially crisp and interesting, so the arrow on the cruciverbal meter is pointing solidly into the green zone for this Oliver Hill creation.

title: Leftist Wins Uruguay Presidential Vote
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay  Jos Mujica, a brash former guerrilla fighter, was elected president of Uruguay on Sunday, further cementing the hold of a leftist government credited with improving economic conditions in one of South Americas smallest countries.

title: Local Stop: Inwood
description: Nestled in the northern reaches of Manhattan, the neighborhood of Inwood is a place of hills and history.

title: Selling Wine With Notes of M.B.A.
description: A wave of M.B.A.'s, bankers, chemists and others are taking over or starting wineries and infusing them with a level of business expertise usually found only at big brands.

title: Conservative Poised to Win in Honduras
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras  Porfirio Lobo, a longtime conservative politician, appeared headed toward victory on Sunday in the Honduran presidential election, which many hoped could help the country emerge from the crisis caused by last summers coup and end its isolation.

title: Dylan on the Record About Christmas
description: Bob Dylan, below, surprised fans and critics in October when he released a holiday album, Christmas in the Heart, a compilation of carols and traditional songs. But in an interview with The Big Issue, a British weekly entertainment and current affairs magazine that benefits the homeless, Mr. Dylan said the tunes on the album were part of my life, just like folk songs, Reuters reported. Mr. Dylan spoke about why he wanted to donate the proceeds of his album to charities for the homeless in the United States, Britain and 80 other countries: They get food straight to the people. No military organization, no bureaucracy, no governments to deal with, he said. Mr. Dylan, who was raised Jewish and embraced Christianity in the late 1970s and early 1980s, would not discuss his faith other than to say, I am a true believer. He did talk about his boyhood, saying his memories include snow, jingle bells, Christmas carolers going from house to house, sleighs in the streets, town bells ringing, nativity plays.

title: Footnote
description: It didnt take long for the producers of Howard Shores live music version of Peter Jacksons Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring to book the next installment. The Lord of the Rings: the Two Towers will open at Radio City Music Hall for two performances on Oct. 8 and 9 next year. Beneath a 60-foot screen showing the film, Mr. Shores original score will be performed by more than 300 musicians, conducted by Ludwig Wicki. Tickets go on sale Monday at ticketmaster.com.

title: Area 51 at Paramount
description: Area 51, the next film from Oren Peli, who directed the horror hit Paranormal Activity, has been acquired for distribution in the United States by Paramount Pictures, the studio said Sunday. Paramount made a hit of Paranormal Activity by using unconventional marketing tactics, including a Web campaign urging fans to demand the film before it was shown. That movie has taken in about $107.1 million at the domestic box office. A studio spokeswoman, Katie Martin Kelley, said last month that Paramount was not involved in discussions for Area 51, a thriller about a military base at the center of U.F.O. conspiracy theories. The Creative Artists Agency and IM Global, an international sales company, were seeking about $10 million  far more than the $300,000 Paramount paid for Paranormal Activity. Reached on Sunday Ms. Kelley declined to discuss terms of the deal. But a person briefed on the sale, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the studio has not authorized comment, said the final price approached the $10 million originally sought.

title: Bilbao Museum Official Sentenced
description: The former financial director of the Guggenheim Bilbao Museum was found guilty of embezzlement and falsifying documents last week and was sentenced to 32 months in jail, Agence France-Presse reported. After an audit in 2008 revealed that money was missing from accounts, the official, Roberto Cearsolo Barrenetxea, confessed to having stolen more than $750,000 from two museum funds. The money was taken in small amounts between 1998 and 2008, through forged checks and bank transfers. Mr. Barrenetxea, who had been in the job since the Spanish branch of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum opened in 1997, also made changes to the 2005 annual accounts report as well as other documents to disguise his theft. After the audit last year Mr. Barrenetxea wrote to the museums director, saying, Since I could no longer live with this situation, I have decided to confess the facts to you.

title: BBC Cuts Lurid Ballet
description: Scenes from a Venezuelan ballet have been pulled from a British program to be broadcast by the BBC because of what critics called their lurid and deliberately offensive nature. According to BBC News online, a scene from Javier de Frutoss Eternal Damnation to Sancho and Sanchez, in which a pope abuses an altar boy and strangles a pregnant nun, was cut from a program of four works titled In The Spirit Of Diaghilev, part of a celebration of the centennial of Sergei Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes. Scenes from other works will be televised from Sadlers Wells Theater in London in December.

title: Joyce Theater Lists Spring Season Works
description: Four world premieres will be on the schedule when the Joyce Theaters spring season gets under way on Feb. 23. Besides the new works  from Keigwin & Company, the Lyon Opera Ballet, Lar Lubovitch and Stephen Petronio  the season will feature the latest pieces by Dance Brazil, the John Jasperse Company and Pilobolus. The choreographers Monica Bill Barnes, Camille A. Brown, Andrea Miller and Kate Weare will make their individual Joyce debuts during a week of alternating programs, ending with a collaborative performance by all four women on Aug. 14. Other highlights include a centennial celebration of the choreographer Alwin Nikolais, three weeks of Savion Glover and the Martha Graham Dance Companys 21st century adaptation of American Document, her 1938 work inspired by works like the Declaration of Independence, to be directed by Anne Bogart.

title: In Rain, in Snow, but Not on Saturdays?
description: Although your mailbox may be overflowing with catalogs and a few holiday cards may have started to appear, the United States Postal Service is in crisis. For fiscal year 2009, the Postal Service reported a net loss of $3.8 billion, despite more than $6 billion in cost cuts. Meanwhile, total mail volume fell by nearly 26 billion pieces, or 13 percent.

title: Muti Indulges a Love of Honegger: Whos to Say No?
description: If you are the New York Philharmonic, and you hire a guest conductor with a big enough name, you dont need a fancy soloist. And if that name is Riccardo Muti, you dont even need an overture. Whats more, if one of the two works on the program is going to be Beethovens sure-fire Eroica Symphony, you can let Mr. Muti indulge his fondness for relatively obscure 20th-century works with the other. (But expect some muttering in the aisles at intermission.)

title: An Artist Turns People Into His Marionettes
description: In the short video 80064, the artist who made it, Artur Zmijewski, persuades an elderly Auschwitz survivor to have the faded number on his forearm refreshed by a tattoo artist. The befuddled old gentleman had evidently agreed beforehand to have this done, but on camera he is having second thoughts. He doesnt see the point and worries about the consequences. But he eventually surrenders to Mr. Zmijewskis implacable urging, and the tattooist retraces the digits. Afterward the old man seems ambivalent; its hard to tell whether hes glad he let it be done or not. Maybe he is just relieved that the ordeal is over.

title: Secret Service Agents Interview Intruders
description: WASHINGTON  As part of a broadening inquiry into presidential security, Secret Service agents have interviewed the Virginia couple who sneaked into a White House state dinner last week, a senior federal official involved in the investigation said Sunday.

title: Forest Kindergarten
description: The 23 pupils at the Waldorf School of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., spend three hours a day outdoors, rain or shine, in what the school calls a forest kindergarten.

title: Online Shoppers Spend Over the Weekend, but Will It Last?
description: After finishing the turkey and doing the dishes, many more people than last year turned on their computers and went shopping. But will Thanksgiving weekend spending continue through the holiday season?

title: Crashing the B.C.S.
description: The once unthinkable could be on the verge of happening in the Bowl Championship Series.

title: A Museum Hails Caesar, Even if Some Antiquarians Dont Agree
description: ARLES, France  Dredged up from the murky depths of the Rhne River, beneath a heap of wrecked cars, rotting tires and more than 20 centuries of silt, the statues white marble visage was plain as day.

title: A Tax on Nips and Tucks Angers Patients, Surgeons
description: Last week, a 41-year-old woman who had recently had her first child walked into the office of Dr. Steven Teitelbaum in Santa Monica, Calif., for an operation that tens of thousands of women like her have undergone this year: a breast lift.

title: Tree Harvester Offers to Save Indonesian Forest
description: TELUK MERANTI, Indonesia  From the air, the Kampar Peninsula in Indonesia stretches for mile after mile in dense scrub and trees. One of the worlds largest peat swamp forests, it is also one of its biggest vaults of carbon dioxide, a source of potentially lucrative currency as world governments struggle to hammer out a global climate treaty. The vault, though, is leaking.

title: Sanchez Limits Risk; Color Jets Impressed
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Jets plod their way through the first year of the Mark Sanchez era, perhaps the best they can hope for are games like Sundays.

title: Open Source as a Model for Business Is Elusive
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In many ways, MySQL embodies the ideals of the populist software movement known as open source, in which a programs creator releases it to the world free of charge, and legions of volunteers contribute improvements that are also freely shared.

title: Britain Presses Pakistan and Afghanistan on Militants
description: LONDON  Highlighting themes likely to be taken up by President Obama in his military policy speech on Tuesday, Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain has demanded that Afghanistan and Pakistan match plans for increased allied troop levels in Afghanistan by taking tough actions of their own, including, in Pakistan, a stepped-up effort to capture Osama bin Laden.

title: After War, Finding Peace and Calm in a Garden
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J.

title: Stressing the Web, NewsHour Begins an Overhaul
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Until recently, the employees who worked on the Web site of The NewsHour With Jim Lehrer on PBS were based in a building a brisk five-minute walk through city traffic from their on-air colleagues. The Web and television staffs interacted only at Mr. Lehrers annual holiday party. They were all the recognizably young ones, said Linda Winslow, the shows executive producer.

title: Heisman Polling: Is McCoy in the Lead?
description: In a very informal and unscientific quest for some insight on the Heisman Trophy race, I queried a jury of my peers Sunday. The basic feel I have for the Heisman race right now is that Colt McCoy is in the lead, but most voters are still undecided. (Kirk Bohls in Austin and the famed Heisman Pundit, Chris Huston, echoed this thought. Huston said he was tempted to declare McCoy the winner.) Here are 10 other journalists I polled about the Heisman and their thoughts on where they were with their vote.

title: Vital Tests for Obama on Mandate for Change
description: WASHINGTON  In a narrow sense, President Obamas handling of the critical issues of health care and Afghanistan in the weeks ahead will test the depth of his support among Democrats and determine whether he can draw Republicans to his foreign policy.

title: In Japan, an Odd Perch for Google: Looking Up at the Leader
description: TOKYO  In 2001, a fledgling Internet company named Google opened its first overseas office in Japan, eager to tap a huge technology market.

title: Ready for an SEC Rematch
description: The hype for a rematch of the Southeastern Conference title game Saturday really began before the season, when it was obvious that Florida and Alabama were again the class of the league.

title: The Fall and Rise of Media
description: Historically, young women and men who sought to thrive in publishing made their way to Manhattan. Once there, they were told, they would work in marginal jobs for indifferent bosses doing mundane tasks and then one day, if they did all of that without whimper or complaint, they would magically be granted access to a gilded community, the large heaving engine of books, magazines and newspapers.

title: Tying Up Loose Ends With Oprah, Mad Men, Wine Clubs and More
description: IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing, the media and popular culture.

title: For Forest Kindergartners, Class Is Back to Nature, Rain or Shine
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Fat, cold droplets splashed from the sky as the students struggled into their uniforms: rain pants, boots, mittens and hats. Once buttoned and bundled, they scattered toward favorite spaces: a crab apple tree made for climbing, a cluster of bushes forming a secret nook under a willow tree, a sandbox growing muddier by the minute.

title: Business Titans, and Others, Expected at Jobs Summit
description: The invitations went out just before Thanksgiving, but by the end of the holiday weekend the White House has confirmed that President Obamas jobs summit on Thursday will include about 130 business leaders, union chiefs, academics, mayors and representatives of nonprofit groups.

title: Debate on Creating Jobs, Without Raising Deficit
description: WASHINGTON  As Democrats renew their push to create jobs, they are at odds over the timing, cost and scope of additional measures, with the White Houses concern about high budget deficits pitted against the eagerness of many in Congress to spur hiring before next years elections.

title: A Takeover Movie for Hollywood to Watch
description: LOS ANGELES  Not long ago, a first meeting between Hollywood executives and the potential new owners of their studio might have turned on Oscar prospects, this years ingnue or the exact dimensions of Russell Crowes salary.

title: Citys Schools Share Their Space, and Bitterness
description: Suzanne Tecza had spent a year redesigning the library at Middle School 126 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, including colorful new furniture and elaborate murals of leafy trees. So when her principal decided this year to give the space to the charter high schools that share the building, Ms. Tecza was furious.

title: Vote Recount in Nassau Approaches Completion
description: MINEOLA, N.Y.  Nearly three weeks after Election Day, the recount in the race for Nassau County executive is expected to conclude on Monday. Edward P. Mangano, the Republican challenger, has a slight lead over the Democratic incumbent, Thomas R. Suozzi.

title: Rough Race to the Finish for Senate Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  Even if lawmakers do not take a day off until Christmas, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, has just 25 days to meet his own goal of finishing the Senate version of the bill by the holiday. And then he must iron out differences with the House bill.

title: Cosby Takes a Web Plunge, Sweaters in Tow
description: At the end of the first decade of the third millennium, it is not unexpected that a veteran comic would plant a flag on the Internet: Shecky Greene has a Web site, and Shelley Berman has a Facebook fan page.

title: Shoppers Fill Streets, if Not Their Bags
description: So much for the job losses, the foreclosures and the disintegrating dollar. Standing on the corner of Prince and Mercer Streets in SoHo, you might think the recession had never happened.

title: Upstart Chinese Telecom Company Rattles Industry as It Rises to No. 2
description: When the telecommunications company Telenor decided to upgrade its mobile phone network in Norway, the job drew bids from the companies that had built its original grid: Ericsson and Nokia Siemens Networks.

title: Less Diversity in Supervisors of Foster Care
description: More than two decades ago, New York started down a path that was considered a hallmark of child welfare reform by creating and strengthening its minority-governed, neighborhood-based foster care agencies.

title: Shoppers Showed Up, but Spent on Bargains
description: More consumers flooded the nations stores on Thanksgiving weekend in search of bargains. But with retailers dangling rock-bottom prices and consumers only biting at less expensive merchandise like small appliances and winter clothes, the average amount spent by each shopper declined from last year.

title: Bad Times Do Not Bring More Crime (if They Ever Did)
description: Unemployment has reached 10.3 percent in New York City, higher than it is in the state and nationally. The Bloomberg administration is weighing cuts from every city agency to help close a $4.1 billion deficit next year. Homelessness among families is at a record high, with more than 28,000 men, women and children now in the citys shelter system.

title: A Bumpy Road for Alligator Farms
description: Alligator farmers in Louisiana are struggling with lower prices for the raw material that often ends up in expensive handbags.

title: For Novice Journalists, Rising Risks in Conflict Zones
description: OTTAWA  Amanda Lindhout was a waitress at an Irish pub in Calgary, Alberta, with a dream of becoming a journalist. But Ms. Lindhout, who has no formal journalistic training, did not join the ranks of citizen journalists who blog about their communities. Instead, she used her earnings from the bar to finance reporting trips to several of the worlds most dangerous war zones.

title: Its All About the Money
description: Twenty years ago, the widely respected Feerick Commission on Government Integrity declared that campaign finance laws in New York are a disgrace.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: New Name for the Oregon-Oregon State Game
description: Thursday nights Civil War between No. 13 Oregon State and No. 7 Oregon has a new name.

title: Reversal Haunts Federal Health Agency
description: Earlier this month, a federal health agency backed away from its earlier findings that decades of explosive detonations by the Navy on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques posed no health hazards to residents.

title: LED Bulbs Save Substantial Energy, a Study Finds
description: Does the latest generation of energy-saving light bulbs save energy? A comprehensive study conducted by Osram, the German lighting company, provides evidence that they do.

title: Helping Dubai, but Only So Far
description: Abu Dhabi is preparing a pick n mix bailout of Dubai. The richest of the United Arab Emirates seems set to support its struggling neighbor, which shocked markets worldwide last week by calling for a standstill on $59 billion of debt at Dubai World, its investment arm. But helping only on a case-by-case basis sounds sensible. Abu Dhabis priority is to stop a bank run, rather than undertake a wholesale rescue of Dubai World.

title: Obamas Speech on Afghanistan to Envision Exit
description: WASHINGTON    President Obama plans to lay out a time frame for winding down the American involvement in the war in Afghanistan when he announces his decision this week to send more forces, senior administration officials said Sunday.

title: Advocating for Girls Sports With a Sharp Tongue
description: HAVERFORD, Pa.  Few girls who play sports in suburban Philadelphia would recognize Robert H. Landau, but many coaches and athletic directors know that spotting him in the bleachers could spell trouble.

title: A Fall Was Instant, but Recovery Drags On
description: Leslie Jackson is ready for her close-up.

title: Lottery Numbers
Arab Emirates Aim to Limit Dubai Crisis in Pledge to Banks
description: Trying to prevent a run on its banks and stem financial turmoil that some fear could spread globally, the United Arab Emirates helped calm markets Monday by pledging to lend money to banks operating in Dubai. But the action comes amid concerns about excessive borrowing around the world.

title: As Sales Vanish, Skins Stay on Alligators
description: RACELAND, La.  After five years, Tommy Fletcher and his alligator farming business are facing irreconcilable differences.

title: Crisis Puts Focus on Dubais Complex Relationship With Abu Dhabi
description: This article is by Robert F. Worth, Heather Timmons and Landon Thomas Jr.

title: For Golfs No. 1 Pitchman, Silence Doesnt Sell
description: Tiger Woods is not available. He will talk in his own sweet time.

title: New Jersey Man Who Shot Family Had Been Barred From Seeing Wife
description: A New Jersey man who was killed by an off-duty police officer after he shot his estranged wife and two sons, one fatally, on Saturday morning in Paterson, had been barred from seeing his wife since September because of a restraining order, the authorities said on Sunday.

title: Man Who Spoke About His Father Being a Priest Dies at 22
description: Nathan Halbach, who decided to speak out as he was terminally ill with brain cancer about how it felt to grow up knowing that his absentee father was a Roman Catholic priest, died at home in Missouri on Friday. He was 22.

title: In Kansas, Affirmation of Values Even as Winning Streak Ends
description: HAYS, Kan.  The standing ovation erupted as soon as the Centralia defender emerged from the pile with the ball. It was over, finally, in overtime: the Panthers had defeated Smith Center to win the Kansas state Class 2-1a championship game, 20-12, and had ended the longest active winning streak in high school football at 79 games.

title: Still Outnumbered, but Council Republicans Count on More Clout
description: One minute, Councilman Lewis A. Fidler, a Brooklyn Democrat, drops by. The next, two other Democrats from Brooklyn, Simcha Felder and Domenic M. Recchia Jr., show up. Then, a couple of Democrats from Queens: Melinda R. Katz, who is leaving office soon, and Leroy G. Comrie Jr., who may replace Ms. Katz as the leader of the Land Use Committee.

title: Bears, Bugs and More Bumbling
description: A few weeks ago I had a Dr. Doolittle encounter with the local bear. A solitary two-year old was sitting in the middle of my dirt road as I drove to work. I slowed down, turned off the radio, rolled down the window and had a three-minute conversation with this potential hoodlum. It went something like this: I hope you have a nice day. I hope you find mushrooms and plenty of grubs and apples. But leave the beehives alone. The bees have their own issues to deal with and dont need any interference from you.

title: A Generation in the Balance
description: Do downturns create Democrats? The Great Depression certainly did: The generation that came of age in the 1930s has cleaved to the Democratic Party like no population before or since. And it makes intuitive sense that experiencing a recession at a formative age could inspire lifelong sympathy for the party of the welfare state and lifelong suspicion toward the party of free markets.

title: Media Equation: All the Young News
description: In todays Media Equation, David Carr writes:

title: Saints Brees Debunks Notions of the Quarterback Prototype
description: Drew Brees stepped onto the scale at the N.F.L.s scouting combine in 2001 and was quickly reminded of his biggest  and smallest  problem.

title: Week 12: Jets End Three-Game Losing Streak.
description: Mark Sanchez did just enough and the Jets defense did the rest in a victory over Carolina.

title: Elections in Honduras
description: Hondurans went to the polls in a presidential election that many voters hoped would allow the country to emerge from the political crisis caused by last summers coup.

title: Cash in the Forefront for the Holidays
description: Holiday shoppers say they have put away their credit cards and pared down their ambitions on gifts, so there might be more fruitcakes than diamonds under the tree this year.

title: Wine and Song
description: Diane Birchs songs are retro-leaning in a nonspecific way (think Zooey Deschanel meets Joni Mitchell, with the tiniest dash of Norah Jones), writes Amanda Petrusich and her rich, husky vocals go down soft and easy. Sip slowly while Ms. Birch plays City Winery at 8 Monday night. The set will likely feature songs from her new album, Bible Belt (S-Curve), a promising debut, full of honest proclamations and golden horns.

title: Lights, Please
description: The lighting of the Christmas Tree in Rockefeller Center wont happen until next Wednesday, but for those of you who cant wait until then for an extravagant public display of fir and electricity, head to the Upper West Side Monday night for Winters Eve at Lincoln Square. The free program along Broadway from Columbus Circle to 68th Street includes music, street performances, food tastings from local restaurants and activities for children. The festivities begin at 5:30 p.m. with a tree lighting, hosted by Joy Behar of The View, at Dante Park. Stay to listen to the hot sounds of the Brooklyn Afrobeat band Antibalas, on break from the hit show Fela! and the cool jazz of the bassist and composer Ben Allison, who will be holding court at the American Folk Art Museum. Part of the proceeds will benefit City Harvest.

title: All the Lonely People
description: If this is what a disaster looks like, bring on the apocalypse, Ben Brantley writes in his review of The Starry Messenger. The new play by Kenneth Lonergan was plagued by bad publicity before it opened, with particular scorn directed at Matthew Broderick for his apparent inability to remember his lines. But thats all just water under the bridge now. Mr. Brantley writes that the gentle, compassionate comic drama at the Acorn Theater has the sweet taste of redemption. The story about a middle-aged man swept up in a affair with a younger woman, re-establishes Mr. Lonergan, who hasnt had a new play on the boards since 2001, as a possessor of all the crucial parts of a good dramatists anatomy: a critical mind, an empathetic heart and a musical ear that hears whole lives in sentences. And Mr. Broderick delivers his finest, most affecting performance in years. Redemption indeed.

title: Accounts, People & Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: With a Week to Go, the Heisman Trophy Is Up for Grabs
description: The most storied award in college sports, the Heisman Trophy, has fully embraced the digital age just in time. This is the first year that the Heisman voting will be completely done electronically; the 925 voters are required to cast their ballots online by 5 p.m. Dec. 7.

title: Bemidji State Gets Its Revenge
description: Nobody expected great things from Bemidji State when they entered the N.C.A.A. tournament last April as the 16th and lowest seed, but with upsets over Notre Dame and Cornell the Beavers played the underdog role right into the Frozen Four. Unfortunately for them, another team making a sudden rise to the top was waiting in the semifinals, as Miami University sent Bemidji home early from Washington.

title: Unemployment and Midterms
description: If they crave comfort, Democratic candidates can grab onto this: political science research finds little historical connection between unemployment and midterm Congressional elections.

title: News of Hockey, 11/29/09: Tretiak Sees K.H.L.-N.H.L. Olympic Team

While Tretiaks statement creates surprise in Canada, that makeup of the roster has pretty much been Russian national team procedure in winning the last two I.I.H.F. World Championships, in 2009 and in 2008.

title: Commuters Beware
description: The train wreck last summer that killed nine commuters and injured 80 in the nations capital laid bare a deadly paradox: the safety failures at the heart of the collision occurred on a subway track devoid of the strong federal crashworthiness standards in place on Amtraks immediately adjacent railroad line. Regional systems of light-rail and subways are not subject to the federal governments more stringent safety requirements.

title: Kevons Choices
description: Kevon Simpson was 10 months old when his mother was gunned down. His grandmother, who raised him, was determined that he transcend the low expectations of so many people in their Bronx neighborhood.

title: The Jobs Imperative
description: If youre looking for a job right now, your prospects are terrible. There are six times as many Americans seeking work as there are job openings, and the average duration of unemployment  the time the average job-seeker has spent looking for work  is more than six months, the highest level since the 1930s.

title: Wins Count; DAntoni Isnt Counting
description: Mike DAntoni acknowledged the two sides of his situation with a scrunching of his forehead and laughter Sunday. He finds himself in the N.B.A.s version of being between a rock and a hard place. His record has been mostly in a tailspin since he began coaching the Knicks last season, but DAntoni said he cared little about it.

title: Showcase: Iran, Beyond Stereotype
description: Paolo Woods arrived in Tehran in 1999 with a bag full of black-and-white film. Like many photojournalists before him, he headed to the former American embassy, where the hostage crisis had begun 20 years earlier; a landmark of Irans tumultuous political past.

title: For Vonn and U.S., a Disappointing Trip to Aspen
description: ASPEN, Colo.  World Cup skiers are accustomed to hard, icy tracks, but the womens slalom on Aspen Mountain on Sunday gave rise to the argument that there can be too much of a hard thing.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Sharks Mending From Blackhawk Debacle
description: Last week the league-leading San Jose Sharks were clobbered by the No. 2 Chicago Blackhawks, 7-2, in a game that seemed to crush the Sharks spirit as soundly as they were crushed on the scoreboard. But since then the Hawks were shut out in one game and beaten on penalty shots in another, while San Jose prevailed on penalties in their one outing. Does that mean the Sharks have recovered from their beating? Hard to say, but a good result on Sunday night would help. Home teams listed first:

title: Arab Emirates Move to Limit Crisis in Dubai
description: Update | 7:43 a.m. Trying to prevent a run on its banks, and financial turmoil that some fear could spread globally, the United Arab Emirates helped calm financial markets Monday with its pledge to lend money to banks operating in Dubai, an action that came amid concerns about excessive borrowing around the world, Vikas Bajaj and Graham Bowley reported in The New York Times.

title: News Quiz | November 30, 2009
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: France Telecom and Sunrise Merge Swiss Mobile Units
description: France Telecom said Wednesday it would pay 1.5 billion euros to merge its Swiss subsidiary with Switzerlands No. 2 mobile phone operator, Sunrise, in an effort to challenge the state-run market leader, Swisscom.

title: Markets Rally Across Asia as Dubai Fears Recede
description: Asian stock markets rallied Monday as investors nervousness over potential fallout from a debt-repayment delay in Dubai faded, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

description: WHOM do you know who went shopping on Black Friday?

title: C&C to Buy Constellations British Cider Brands
description: C&C, the Irish drinks group, said it agreed to buy all the British cider assets of Constellation Brands  including the Blackthorn, Olde English and Gaymers brands  for 45 million ($74 million) in cash.

title: Sina Managers Win Backing for Investment Plan
description: A trio investors including Sequoia Capital are backing a management-led plan to invest $180 million in Chinas leading Web portal, Sina, Reuters reported, citing two people familiar with the plan.

title: Dropbox Says It Raised $6 Million Last Year
description: Dropbox, a start-up that allows users to back up, synchronize and share files, revealed that it has raised $6 million in a first round of funding.

description: Have you been following news accounts about professional football players and head injuries? Do you know anyone who plays football and has had a concussion?

title: Will Abu Dhabi Impose Conditions for Dubai Bailout?
description: It was the most subtle of gestures, but looking back, many in Dubai now see it as a sign of their salvation. At the grand opening of the Dubai Air Show this month, the crown prince of Abu Dhabi, Sheik Muhammad bin Zayed al-Nahyan, placed his hand over the hand of Dubais ruler, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum. That was widely viewed among people here as a sign that Abu Dhabi, by far the largest and richest member-state of the United Arab Emirates federation, would take care of Dubai.

title: A Takeover Movie for Hollywood to Watch
description: Not long ago, a first meeting between Hollywood executives and the potential new owners of their studio might have turned on Oscar prospects, this years ingnue or the exact dimensions of Russell Crowes salary.

title: Dubai Woes a Blow to Banks Pride?
description: British banks have always fancied their chances in the gulf region. So it is no surprise they would be more exposed than counterparts in the United States to Dubai World, the Dubai government vehicle whose ability to repay $59 billion of debt was called into question in a Thanksgiving eve bombshell, Breakingviews says.

title: Philippine President to Run for Congress
description: MANILA  Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, the deeply unpopular Philippine president, announced Monday that she would run for a seat in Congress in elections scheduled for next year, ending months of speculation about her plans when her term ends in June but also raising questions about her long-term intentions.

title: Ari Kiev, Psychiatrist to Traders, Dies
description: Ari Kiev, a psychiatrist whose early work on depression and suicide prevention led to a career helping Wall Street traders and athletes achieve peak performance, died Nov. 18 in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: Six Flags Bondholders Submit Alternative Plan
description: A group of noteholders of the bankrupt regional theme park operator Six Flags said on Sunday it had submitted an alternative reorganization plan that transfers most of the equity to them.

title: Hochtief Reserves Right to Delay Units I.P.O.
description: Hochtief reserves the right to postpone the initial public offering of its infrastructure unit if stock markets remain unsettled because of the Dubai debt crisis, its chief executive said in an interview on Sunday.

title: Nakheel Seeks Trading Suspension For Bonds
description: Nakheel of Dubai asked for three of its listed Islamic bonds worth $5.25 billion to be suspended pending details of restructuring plans at its parent company, a move that appeared to be aimed at dampening speculation on the bonds.

title: Man Tied to Death Camp Goes on Trial in Germany
description: MUNICH John Demjanjuk, a retired American autoworker, went on trial here Monday, accused of helping to force 27,900 Jews to their deaths during the Holocaust.

title: Lachlan Murdoch Said to Bid for Nielsen
description: Lachlan Murdoch, the eldest son of Rupert Murdoch, is joining a swath of media investors preparing to bid for the lions share of Nielsen Business Media, which includes The Hollywood Reporter, The Financial Times reported.

title: Fed Tightens Regulations on Its Regional Directors
description: The Federal Reserve, under attack in Congress for being too entwined with big banks, closed a loophole on Wednesday that allowed a director at Goldman Sachs to be a director of the New York Fed as the agency was bailing out Wall Street during the financial crisis.

title: Tough Times Turn Newspaper Lenders into Owners
description: Newspaper headlines have skewered money lenders for dubious decisions that stoked the recession. Now, The Associated Press writes, the financiers are starting to headline newspapers in a new way  as the owners.

title: UBS Threatens to Leave Switzerland, Report Says
description: UBS is threatening to move its headquarters out of Switzerland if the authorities impose too many new regulations after the global financial crisis, the Swiss weekly newspaper Sonntag CH reported.

title: Eponymns
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have been hard at work inventing novel eponyms.

title: Regulators Said to List Systemic Risk Institutions
description: Thirty global financial institutions have been selected for crossborder supervision exercises by regulators, The Financial Times reported.

title: Jets Open Thread: Can They Make December Meaningful?
description: When a team wins only two games in October and November  as the Jets did this season  it is hard to call it a playoff contender.

title: China Charges 58 With Covering Up Deadly Mine Blast
description: BEIJING  Ten journalists and 48 officials have been charged with taking bribes to cover up a mining disaster last year, according to a report published on Monday in China Daily, an official English-language newspaper.

title: Londons Oyster Cards Now Available Online
description: Heading for London and want to avoid the queues for tickets on the citys bus and tube lines? Now you can be ready to roll  literally  with a new online service that allows overseas visitors to purchase passes in advance of a trip and have them delivered to their home.

title: Irish Banks Set to Unload $42.5 Billion in Bad Loans
description: Bank of Ireland and Allied Irish Banks may receive a combined 28.2 billion euros ($42.5 billion) for the faulty property loans they are selling to the countrys bad bank, the National Asset Management Agency, Blooomberg News reported.

title: M&B Says Rebel Shareholders Trying to Take Control
description: Mitchells & Butlers, the British pubs operator, will ask the countrys takeover watchdog to rule whether rebel shareholders are trying to gain control of the group after they blocked the appointment of a chairman.

title: Sands Falls 10% on Hong Kong Debut
description: Sands Chinas weak stock market debut in Hong Kong on Monday signals a lack of investor appetite for a casino gaming company with a high valuation and an uncertain outlook, with mixed interest in the sectors long-term prospects, Reuters reported.

title: The Latest Business Plan: Cupcakes
description: Move over restaurants and bed-and-breakfasts. A new fantasy seems to have taken hold for people who long to own their own business: the cupcakery.

title: Bid May Be Close for A.I.G. Unit, Report Says
description: A group of private equity investors may be close to making a bid for half of the International Lease Finance Corporation, a unit of the American International Group, The Financial Times reported.

title: Reality TV Makes Reality Its Victim
description: Todays idea: Reality TV degrades real life itself, an article says. It has not only ruined network values, destroyed the classic documentary, and debased the art of bad acting, but also fomented class warfare, antisocial behavior and murder.

title: A Defiant Iran Vows to Build Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON  Iran angrily refused Sunday to comply with a demand by the United Nations nuclear agency to cease work on a once-secret nuclear fuel enrichment plant, and escalated the confrontation by declaring it would construct 10 more such plants.

title: Government Not Guaranteeing Dubai World Debt
description: Dubai Worlds debt is not guaranteed by the government, Abdulrahman al-Saleh, director general of the emirates Department of Finance, said in an interview with the state-run Dubai TV on Monday, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Salaries Cut for 2 Bank of America Executives
description: Bank of America said its chief financial officer, Joe L. Price, and its head of mortgages, Barbara J. Desoer, would receive less in salary for 2009, citing a review by the governments special master for compensation, Kenneth R. Feinberg.

title: Tacoma Suspect Said to Threaten to Shoot Officers
description: SEATTLE  The search for a man suspected of fatally shooting four uniformed officers south of Tacoma, Wash., expanded to this city and beyond on Monday with a flurry of police sweeps and SWAT team investigations. Details also emerged that the suspect had told people that he planned to shoot some cops, the police said.

title: Dubai Crisis Could Give Investors Control of Barneys
description: Dubais debt crisis could end up being good news for the hedge fund manager Richard Perry and the supermarket mogul Ronald Burkle, two United States investors in the Dubai-owned Barneys New York, The New York Post reported.

description: Wendell Jamieson, deputy metropolitan editor for the Web, is answering questions from readers Nov. 30-Dec. 4, 2009. Questions may be e-mailed to askthetimes@nytimes.com.

title: On Climate Data, Trends and Peer Review
description: The reverberations continue from what the University of East Anglia says was the illegal dissemination of thousands of files from its Climatic Research Unit (CRU). Over the weekend university officials put out an update saying 95 percent of the raw land-surface temperature data in question have been available to scientists and skeptics for several years, although Roger A. Pielke Jr. of the University of Colorado, Boulder, said he was told differently as recently as August. (Realclimate.org posted the locations of various data sets.) He credited the university and climate center for moving now to be clearer about the data archives and to provide more access. When the data is available in its original form those skeptical of climate science can then do the temperature math themselves out in the open where everyone can see their work, Dr. Pielke wrote on Sunday. If the global numbers come out as CRU has presented over the years, then it will strike a blow to skepticism about global temperature trend records produced by CRU and restore a good deal of credibility to this area of climate science.

title: Frederick Joseph, 72, Former Drexel Chief, Dies
description: Frederick H. Joseph, who as the chairman and chief executive of the investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert helped create the modern junk-bond market in the 1980s before the firms collapse, has died. He was 72.

title: Submit Your Funny Caption
description: On, Francis! | Tell us whats going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned images were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Congress Faces Busy Legislative Month
description: Congress would be returning from its Thanksgiving break this week for a legislative pileup even if the Senate was not beginning its landmark debate on a health care overhaul.

title: Bernanke Warns of Risks in Push to Revamp Fed
description: The Federal Reserves chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, warned bluntly over the weekend that provisions in financial legislation before the House and Senate would seriously impair the Fed as it struggled to maintain financial and economic stability.

title: Travel Deals: Cyber Monday Sales
description: Missed the travel deals for Black Friday? Thanks to the marketing gurus who cooked up Cyber Monday, the kick-off to the online shopping season, theres still time to book a discounted winter getaway.

title: Hydro-Quebecs Green Power Export Plans
description: Hydro-Quebecs move last month to boost its power exports to the United States by acquiring New Brunswick Powers transmission lines has raised eyebrows in New England, where renewable energy ventures would face stiff competition from low-cost hydro generated north of the border.

title: The Early Word: Speech Prep
description: Washington emerges from the Thanksgiving holiday on Monday with health care and Afghanistan on the mind.

title: What to Watch Monday: Wilson vs. House
description: Joshua Malina (Sports Night, The West Wing) guest stars as the patient of the week in an episode of House (Fox, 8 p.m.) devoted to Houses best friend and punching bag, Wilson (Robert Sean Leonard). Wilson, working with Houses team, tries to outdiagnose House; were guessing that House will, as usual, be both wrong and right.

title: Markets Rise, With Spending and Dubai Weighing In
description: Wall Street spent Monday trading in a narrow range but managed to push higher at the close.

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Monday morning.Preparing for Polanski: Roman Polanski could be released as soon as Monday from a Swiss prison and be placed under house arrest at his 19,000-square-foot chalet in Gstaad, The Associated Press reports. Mr. Polanski, the 76-year-old filmmaker who is awaiting possible extradition to the United States, still needs to pay $4.5 million in bail; hell also have to pay a $2,000 installation fee and and a $200 monthly maintenance cost for the security monitoring device he will wear. He will have no prison regime, a Swiss justice ministry spokesman told The A.P. He is completely free to determine his daily schedule. Its also up to him to get in food and other supplies. Mr. Polanski fled the United States in 1978 before his sentencing for having sex with a 13-year-old girl.Stephen Gately Is Remembered: Agence France-Presse reports on a tribute concert held in London on Sunday night for Stephen Gately, a member of the Irish pop band Boyzone, who died in October. Among the notables who came to pay tribute to Mr. Gately, 33, who died from natural causes stemming from excess fluid in his lungs, were Cherie Blair, Ian McKellen and Graham Norton, as well as the singers former bandmates Ronan Keating, Mikey Graham, Keith Duffy and Shane Lynch. I am just still walking around in a daze really, the British pop singer Chesney Hawkes told Agence France-Presse. Such a shock, so young, so vibrant, such a lovely guy.Gaga as Theater: Is a Lady Gaga concert a pop-music event or a work of theater? To answer this question, The Guardian enlisted Kelly Nestruck, the theater critic for The Globe and Mail in Canada, to review Lady Gagas new tour, called the Monster Ball, in Toronto. His verdict? The Monster Ball aint Gypsy,  Mr. Nestruck writes. During a performance of her song Boys, Boys, Boys, he writes that Lady Gaga removed tufts of her costume until she was down to a thin landing strip of apparel. Not even La Cage Aux Folles and Priscilla: Queen of the Desert could beat this wardrobe.Everyone Wants to Get Into the Act: In The New Yorker, Michael Schulman reports on the resourceful staff members at Orso, a restaurant in Manhattans theater district, who have joined together to stage a production of the S. N. Behrman comedy Biography while they await other acting jobs. (Anita Gatess review of the play for The New York Times can be found here.) I wish them well, Joe Allen, the restaurants owner, tells The New Yorker. And, if they get, as they say, discovered, good for them. Therell be someone else to take their jobs.

title: Pirates Seize Oil Tanker, U.S.-Bound, Off Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Somali pirates have struck again, seizing an oil tanker loaded with $150 million in crude that was headed from Saudi Arabia to the United States, naval authorities said Monday.

title: Growth in Charter Schools Leads to Tensions Over Space
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made charter schools one of his third-term priorities, and that means that in New York, battles and resentment over space  already a way of life  will become even more common. He and his schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, have allowed nearly two-thirds of the citys 99 charter schools to move into public school buildings, officials expect two dozen charter schools to open next fall, and the mayor has said he will push the Legislature to allow him to add 100 more in the next four years.

description: Citigroup said on Monday that it had hired Willem Buiter, a professor at the London School of Economics, as its chief economist, effective in January.

description: A new study has found evidence of a link between temperature and conflict in Africa.

title: Netherlands Bolsters Search for Tax Evaders

title: Q. and A.: On the Death and Life of Languages
description: According to the French linguist Claude Hagge, twenty-five languages die each year; if this rate of decline continues, half the worlds current languages will disappear by 2100.

title: The Dogbert theory of the debt
description: When I was on This Week yesterday, George Will tried his hand at the debt scare thing, saying that were in terrible shape because by 2019 the interest on the debt will be SEVEN HUNDRED BILLION DOLLARS. (That should be read in the voice of Dr. Evil). I get that a lot  people who talk about the big numbers which are supposed to imply that things are terrible, impossible, were doomed, etc.

description: Caterpillar plans to buy a subsidiary of a South Korean manufacturer of components for earth moving and other machinery, The Associated Press reported.

title: Protectionism and the Great Depression
description: One thing you hear all the time is that protectionism caused the Great Depression. Ive always seen this as an attempt at a Noble Lie; theres no good reason to believe that its true, but it has been used to scare governments into maintaining relatively free trade.

title: El Clsico  and the Derbies
description: The Thanksgiving weekend in the United States is awash in traditional rivalries in high school and college football.

title: How One College Evaluates a Transcript
