title: Reader Reaction to Hines Ward
description: Hines Ward was less than supportive of Ben Roethlisberger and the decision to sit him out of Sundays loss to Baltimore because of postconcussion symptoms. Were interested to hear what readers have to say:

title: Is It Too Early to Start Thinking About a Rebound?
description: I have a friend who recently told me that, as the recession took hold, he was forced to stop all capital expenditures for his wholesale distribution company, and I mean all. He even put off spending $2,500 to replace the server that runs his entire company. He has been hit hard, and I understand why he stopped all expenditures. He had no choice. But I suggested to him that if the old server went down, it would be the most expensive $2,500 that he ever saved. Clearly, the damage caused would far exceed the money saved. He agreed, and hes now setting aside cash to get a new one.

title: The Music of the Rides: Phantom Does Coney Island
description: The last time we checked in on Love Never Dies, Andrew Lloyd Webbers long-gestating sequel to The Phantom of the Opera, we offhandedly remarked that the new musical (which is set in Coney Island) probably would not see the Phantom and Christine reunited while waiting in line for the Cyclone.

title: Monday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Poli-Book Best Sellers
description: To no surprise, Sarah Palins book Going Rogue debuts at No. 1 on the Caucus Poli-Books list and The Timess overall national best-seller list. Advance sales and the small-cities tour by Ms. Palin, the former Republican vice-presidential nominee, have helped set a brisk pace for moving thisautobiography off the shelves.

title: Two Veterinary Products Distributors to Merge
description: Henry Schein, the health care products distributor, and Butler Animal Health Supply agreed to merge their animal health businesses on Monday, creating a big new distributor of veterinary products.

title: Taking Questions on Holiday Gift Giving and Tipping Etiquette
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Russian Police Release Sketch of Bombing Suspects
description: MOSCOW  The police on Monday released the sketch of a suspect in the bombing of a luxury train that killed 26 people, along with a description of an accomplice. Both were spotted in the remote area of the attack in the days before it occurred, officials said.

title: Has Holiday Entertainment Become a Luxury Item?
description: As the dancing toys, fairies and rodent royalty of The Nutcracker arrive at the David H. Koch Theater for New York City Ballets annual production of the classic Balanchine version of that Tchaikovsky work (which Roslyn Sulcas reviews here in The New York Times), many of the citys best known  and most expensive  holiday-themed shows have started their year-end runs.

title: Monday Puzzle: Remember Your Password
description: In these days of heightened computer security, an average computer user has to manage a hundred passwords in his or her head, or so it seems. Every computer system you use at work, and every Internet site you use regularly (or even once in a blue moon) wants you to create an account with a password. Not only that, the requirements for the passwords are becoming more stringent: mix up letters and numbers they say, and sometimes non-alphanumeric symbols too. Dont include any words that can be found in the dictionary, or the names of your children and pets. Change the password every ninety days. And dont write it down anywhere.

title: Q & A With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: San Leandro Seeks to Name a New School
description: San Leandros newest learning institution, a campus for high school freshman opening next year to ease overcrowding at San Leandro High, is looking for an identity. To that end, they are thinking about naming the new campus after a famous figure.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Catherine Balsam-Schwaber joined iVillage, New York, in a new post, senior vice president for marketing. She had been vice president for integrated marketing at MTV Networks, New York, part of Viacom. IVillage is part of the NBC Universal Women and Lifestyle Entertainment Networks Group division of NBC Universal, part of the General Electric Company.

title: For Sesquicentennial, Cooper Union Puts Artifacts on View
description: An 1852 contract  a delicate sheet of paper, with tinges of yellow  outlined plans for the Cooper Union foundation building. On it are the signatures of the colleges founder, Peter Cooper, and the architects Frederick A. Petersen and F. H. Knevitt.

title: What Were Reading
description: Consumer Reports finds that most chickens are still not safe to handle. In our latest analysis of fresh, whole broilers bought at stores nationwide, two-thirds harbored salmonella and/or campylobacter, the leading bacterial causes of foodborne disease. Thats a modest improvement since January 2007, when we found that eight of 10 broilers harbored those pathogens. But the numbers are still far too high, especially for campylobacter. Though the government has been talking about regulating it for years, it has yet to do so.

title: The Krauthammer Prescription
description: Insuring the uninsured is a moral imperative, Charles Krauthammer wrote last week. But the Democrats, he went on, have chosen the worst possible method  a $1 trillion new entitlement of stupefying arbitrariness and inefficiency. What should we do instead? Krauthammers answer: Pass targeted measures that attack the inefficiencies of the current system one by one  tort reform, interstate purchasing and taxing employee benefits.

title: Ethics of E-Mail Misfires and Facebook Complications
description: In the previous installment of Internet Protocol, we dove into a duo of dilemmas dealing specifically with social media in the workplace.

title: Chelsea Clinton Is Engaged
description: Chelsea Clinton, the 29-year-old daughter of former President Bill Clinton and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, is engaged to her longtime boyfriend, Marc Mezvinsky, Mr. Clintons office said Monday.

title: Waterford Toasts A New Beginning
description: Editor's Note: The advertising newsletter for Nov. 30 has been re-sent to fix an incorrect link in the article "People and Accounts of Note."

title: Kia Cadenza Will Make Debut in Saudi Arabia
description: A Google search for Kia Cadenza, the would-be luxury debutante for the Korean automaker, returns the following links: Office Credenza Sale, Credenza and Hutch Sets and Furniture Kia.

title: British Banks May Feel Most Pain if Dubai Defaults
description: The news last week of Dubais faltering finances sent shudders throughout the world, though the impact was perhaps most felt in London.

title: Bad Reviews? Blame the Booze
description: In the latest round of the continuing dispute known as Artists vs. Critics, a British playwright has suggested that reviewers who gave bad notices to her latest show had spent the afternoon drinking before seeing the play that night. The playwright, Timberlake Wertenbaker, told The Guardian that several of the critics who reviewed her play The Line, which began performances on Nov. 18 at the Arcola Theater in London, attended an evening performance that followed the presentation of the London Evening Standard theater awards that afternoon - a four-hour ceremony at the Royal Opera House that included a Champagne reception and wine service at lunch. Ms. Wertenbaker said that the critics werent all drunk but its hard to get through something like that without being tired, adding that The Line is a complicated play, its difficult, you have to pay attention to it.

title: Chinks in the New iMacs Armor
description: Apples reconfigured iMac desktopa bright, shiny, widescreen example of a home computerworks beautifully  unless it doesnt work at all, or arrives out of the box with a cracked display.

title: Saabs Uncertain Hour
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Fed Begins Testing a Strategy to Exit a Securities Program
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve said Monday that it would begin testing its strategy to shrink its trillion-dollar portfolio of mortgage-backed securities and eventually unwind its biggest program to prop up financial markets.

title: Fed to Test Strategy to Exit Securities Program
description: The Federal Reserve said Monday that it would begin testing its strategy to shrink its trillion-dollar portfolio of mortgage-backed securities and eventually unwind its biggest program to prop up financial markets, The New York Timess Edmund L. Andrews reports from Washington.

title: The Claim: Exercise More During the Day, and You Will Sleep Better at Night
description: THE FACTS It has long been said that regular physical activity and better sleep go hand in hand. Burn more energy during the day, the thinking goes, and you will be more tired at night.

title: Gangs Turn to the Tweet Life
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: The Doctors Were Real, the Patients Undercover
description: EDE, the Netherlands  It had all the markings of a television detective show. Posing as patients, three undercover observers got themselves admitted as patients to a locked psychiatric ward to investigate conditions on the inside.

title: A Wedge Between Woods and the Public
description: After Tiger Woods said in a statement on Sunday that his Friday morning car accident was his fault but private, media outlets have demonstrated it considers the episode anything but private. And the Internet did not exactly roll up its tubes and go away.

title: Obama Issues Order for More Troops in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama issued orders to send about 30,000 additional American troops to Afghanistan as he prepared to address the nation Tuesday night to explain what may be one of the most defining decisions of his presidency.

title: Internet Etiquette: E-Mail and Facebook Relationships
description: Jenna Wortham, a Times technology reporter who contributes regularly to Bits, writes a technology etiquette column for our sister blog, Gadgetwise.

title: Nine Inch Nails Auctions Its Equipment
description: Though it is the prerogative of rock stars to announce that they are breaking up their band and then reconstitute it months (or weeks or days) later, Nine Inch Nails seems to be serious when it says that it will no longer perform as a group. After playing what it said were its final shows in August and September, the hard-core rock group led by Trent Reznor said on its Web site, nin.com, that it was auctioning off its instruments and other touring equipment on eBay, The Guardian reported. Weve been going through the NIN touring and studio rigs and are getting rid of a large selection of gear and equipment the band is no longer in need of, the band said in a statement on its site, adding: We do not know which (if any) tour these items are from unless specified, nor can we get any items autographed, so please do not ask. Among the pieces that the band has put up for sale are a Gibson banjitar (a half-banjo, half-guitar hybrid) that was selling for more than $1,500, and a guitar decorated with artwork from the Nine Inch Nails album The Fragile, whose bidding price had passed $2,250.

title: Regimens: Cancer Concerns in Big Doses of Folic Acid
description: Grains and cereals have been fortified with folic acid in the United States since 1998, as part of an effort to reduce the incidence of neural tube birth defects in babies. But a new study has raised safety concerns, linking megadoses of the vitamin to increased cancer rates, particularly lung cancer.

title: Will Bryant Enter the Free-Agent Market in 2010?
description: Many N.B.A. teams are preparing to go on a spending spree next summer, some with the objective of landing two or even three blockbuster free agents. The list of potentially available players reads like an All-Star roster, and includes LeBron James, Dwyane Wade, Chris Bosh, Amare Stoudemire, Dirk Nowitzki, Yao Ming, Ray Allen, Paul Pierce and Carlos Boozer.

title: Patterns: Teaming Up to Control High Blood Pressure
description: Most patients with high blood pressure have a hard time keeping it under control, and a new study suggests they may get better results if a team of a physician and a pharmacist manage their care.

title: Appetizer-Size Spa Treatments
description: Not sure you want the full, four-hour spa treatment with hot stones, salt rub, rose-petal bath and aromatherapy candles? Then try the 30-minute appetizer version.

title: Probation and Fine for Serena Williamss Tirade
description: Fair or too lenient? The question was worth posing after the announcement Monday that Serena Williams would be fined but not suspended for her threatening, profanity-laced tirade against a lineswoman at this years United States Open.

title: Prognosis: Numbers Rise in a Diabetes Forecast
description: The number of Americans with diabetes will nearly double over the next 25 years, while the cost of care will almost triple, as patients live longer and develop more of the diseases long-term complications, a new analysis said.

title: Collaborative Video Editing, Without Software
description: Peer deep into the recesses of that closet in the hallway, and youll probably find a pile of old VHS home videos from the 1980s. Several years ago, you and your good intentions may have considered sending these tapes to a video-conversion service to transfer them to DVD. You might have even thought about converting them to digital yourself.

title: A Times Reporters Stormy Friendship With Georgia OKeeffe
description: Edith Evans Asbury was a famously pertinacious reporter for The New York Times. Georgia OKeeffe, the renowned painter, was press-shy.

title: Europe Reacts to the Swiss Minaret Ban
description: When Swiss voters overwhelmingly approved a ban on construction of minarets in a referendum on Sunday, they surprised some pollsters and disappointed many European leaders, including those of their own government, who opposed the ban and now must find a way to implement it.

title: A Whistle-Blower Says His Concerns About Safety Were Met With Scorn
description: Marshal Greenberg is an odd, unlikely whistle-blower.

title: Taking Stock After Thanksgiving
description: After Thanksgiving, I use the turkey carcass to make a rich-tasting stock that I can pull out of the freezer in the months ahead to use in risottos, soups and stews. The stock is easy to make but requires a long simmer, six hours if possible. So during the long weekend following Thanksgiving, I try to set aside an afternoon at home to simmer a pot of turkey stock on the stove.

title: One More Reason to Be Thankful: NCOs
description: The U.S. Army named this year  the year of the noncommissioned officer (NCO).

title: Christopher Walken and Kelsey Grammer Returning to Broadway
description: One of Christopher Walkens trademark performances was his monologue as Captain Koons in Quentin Tarantinos Pulp Fiction, where his character described hiding a gold watch in his rectum for two years as a prisoner of war in Vietnam. Mr. Walken, veteran of the spooky and the strange, sure can tell a good body-part story  which hell be doing in his return to Broadway this winter after 10 years, as a man searching for his missing hand in the play A Behanding in Spokane.

title: City Hall Aide Is Named Environmental Protection Commissioner
description: After a 13-month nationwide search for a new commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday appointed a City Hall insider who sits just a couple desks away from him: Caswell F. Holloway IV, the chief of staff to Edward Skyler, deputy mayor for operations.

title: Vietnamese-Style Turkey (or Chicken) Noodle Soup
description: This soup is inspired by a classic Vietnamese chicken ph. You can give it a Thai twist by adding minced green peppers to the list of condiments.

title: Pulp Fiction Writer Sent From Furlough Program to Prison
description: Was Roger Avary, the incarcerated screenwriter of Pulp Fiction, moved from a prison work furlough program to a county jail because he was Tweeting about his prison experience? Depends on whom you ask. Mr. Avary, who, with Quentin Tarantino, shared an Academy Award in 1995 for Pulp Fiction, was sentenced in September to one year in prison after pleading guilty in August to charges of vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving that stemmed from a 2008 car accident. In October, posts began appearing on Mr. Avarys Twitter account, in which he described his jail setting (The building is an imposing example of the Brutalist architectural movement, he wrote) and details of his furlough program.

title: Ravioli or Tortellini in Broth
description: There are many different kinds of freshly made ravioli available, and this is a great way to present any of them. I prefer this approach over a tomato sauce, because a reduced broth doesnt have a strong flavor that competes with the ravioli filling. This is an easy way to put together an elegant meal.

title: Featured Recipe: Simple Chocolate Layer Cake
description: When its my turn to make a dessert for a holiday gathering I head straight for chocolate layer cake. Since I refuse to compromise on ingredients, a certain amount of work is involved, but I streamline the process as much as possible.

title: Vain Glorious | Billy Jealousys Whipped Cream Shave Lather
description: With Vain Glorious, The Moment breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

title: Audi to Unveil A8 at Art Fair, Not Auto Show
description: MIAMI  Audi unveils its new A8 flagship here Monday evening before the opening of Art Basel Miami Beach, a swank art fair that attracts the worlds top galleries.

title: Treasury Pushes Mortgage Firms for Loan Relief
description: The Obama administration disclosed a plan on Monday intended to increase pressure on mortgage companies to permanently reduce monthly payments for troubled homeowners.

title: Pogue & Friends 2009 Holiday Guide
description: David Pogue and the sports columnist Bill Pennington look at a few gadgets designed to help keep you in shape, and improve your game.

title: Comprehending a Deadly Crash
description: The Bay Area is reeling over a car crash Saturday night in Sonoma County that left a family of four dead. The driver of another car, who appears to have been the cause of the crash at the intersection of Highway 37 and Lakeville Highway, was also killed.

title: How Woods Wins a Major
description: While most players succumb to the tougher courses and heightened nerves, Tiger Woods shows less of a decline.

title: Readers Speak Out About a Missed JetBlue Flight
description: Charles DeLaFuentes account of paying a stiff penalty for missing a JetBlue flight drew more than 100 comments, though they were noticeably critical of the complainer, saying he pulled it much too close by arriving only 30 minutes before departure time. Still, some sympathized with him for having to pay extra to be booked on the next flight, which had many free seats, though at least one reader noted that the discount carriers have different rules.

title: Continental Showcase
description: To get a better sense of place, some armchair travelers eat ethnic food or page through coffee-table books of glossy photographs; I have one uncle who likes to read geographical histories of any area before he visits. But Im a fiction reader, so I was thrilled to learn that Dalkey Archive Press  the Illinois publisher that specializes in (among other things) high-quality translations of challenging fiction  has started a Best European Fiction series modeled on the familiar Best American books. Best European Fiction 2010 went on sale last week, featuring 35 stories from 30 countries, and it offers an appealingly diverse look at the Continents fiction scene: from prominent authors like Hungarys George Konrad and Spains Julin Ros to relative newcomers like Croatias Neven Usumovic and Irelands Julian Gough. The book was edited by the Bosnian Aleksandar Hemon, who now lives in Chicago and says he considers himself both a European writer and an American one. In an e-mail exchange last week, Paper Cuts asked him about Best European Fiction 2010.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) The Fed looks to downsize its mortgage-backed securities portfolio.

title: Taking Taxpayers for a Ride
description: Portland, Ore.

title: House Panel to Hold Hearing on State Dinner Breach
description: A House panel has announced it will hold a hearing on Thursday examining the security breach that allowed a Virginia couple to slip into a White House state dinner last week.

title: Chicken Little cometh
description: Readers of classic science fiction may remember the character of Chicken Little in Pohl and Kornbluths The Space Merchants  a giant hunk of vat-grown meat from which slices were periodically removed to feed the masses.

title: How to Tell if a Cyber Monday Sale Is a Good Deal
description: The online holiday shopping season officially kicks off today with online retailers offering Cyber Monday deals ranging from from free shipping and free gift cards to limited-time discounts.

title: Another View: Two Thumbs Up for Medias Future?
description: Peter Rip of Crosslink Capital explores one path to a brighter future for media, although not one for everyone.

title: How Safe Is Your Chicken Dinner?
description: A new study by Consumer Reports has found that two out of three whole broiler chickens are contaminated with illness-inducing bacteria, while certain types of organic chicken posed the lowest risk.

title: Evaluating Polling Methods and Results
description: Overview | What basic skills are needed to read a poll? How are scientifically sound polls conducted? How can one gauge the reliability of poll data? In this lesson, students learn terms associated with polling as well as how to read and evaluate poll methodologies and results. They then practice administering and interpreting polls.

title: Premiums for Employee Health Coverage May Change Little, Budget Study Finds
description: The large number of Americans who currently have employer-sponsored medical insurance would not see much change in their premium costs as a result of the health care legislation pending in Congress, according to a widely awaited budget analysis.

title: Things to come
description: Whats going to happen, economically and politically, over the next few years? Nobody knows, of course. But I have a vision  what I think is the most likely course of events. Its fairly grim  but not in the approved way. This vision lies behind a lot of what Ive been writing, so it might clarify things for regular readers if I laid it out explicitly.

title: Treasury Presses Banks for Mortgage Relief
description: The Obama administration said Monday that it would increase the pressure on banks to help troubled homeowners permanently lower mortgage payments, The New York Timess Peter S. Goodman reports.

title: Supreme Court Overturns Decision on Detainee Photos
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday vacated a lower court ruling that would have required the government to release photographs showing the abuse of prisoners in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: The Morning Skate: Shaky Rangers, Solid Brodeur and Cracked Bones
description: After four games on the road, the Rangers return home Monday night for another crack at the Penguins. This follows Saturdays 8-3 demolition in Pittsburgh, which included a hat trick by Sidney Crosby.

title: A Times Reporters Stormy Friendship With Georgia OKeeffe
description: Edith Evans Asbury was a famously pertinacious reporter for The New York Times. Georgia OKeeffe, the renowned painter, was press-shy.

title: Humanities Chairman Starts Civility Tour
description: While Rocco Landesman, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, has grabbed the lions share of headlines for his travels to Peoria, Ill., his colleague Jim Leach, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, is planning a road trip of his own. On Monday, the N.E.H. said that Mr. Leach would begin a 50-state civility tour on Tuesday in Concord, N.H., where he plans to address a group of civic, political and academic leaders on the subject of hate speech and its dangers. Mr. Leach, the former Republican congressman from Iowa, mentioned the tour in a speech he delivered on Nov. 6 in Omaha, in which he lamented a political setting that is bordering on a civility crisis at home and a civilization crisis abroad. Following his appearance Tuesday at the Lincoln Financial Group Insurance Company auditorium, Mr. Leach plans to visit Augusta, Me., on Wednesday, and to visit all 50 states over the next 18 months to discuss civil discourse in American society.

title: Chelsea Clinton Plans a Merger
description: From Peter Baker at The Caucus:

title: Jeter Wins Sportsman of the Year
description: The first Sports Illustrated issue I ever received was the last one of 1984. It was a Sportsman and Sportswoman of the Year issue, celebrating Edwin Moses and Mary Lou Retton. Ever since, Ive looked forward to that issue because I love the whole concept.

title: With Futility Record at Stake, Ticket Sales Are as Cold as the Nets
description: The Nets are on the verge of establishing an N.B.A. record, yet their fans want no part of it. If the Nets lose Wednesday nights showdown against the Dallas Mavericks, they will have the most losses to start an N.B.A. season (18).

title: U.S.A. All the Way
description: American style  basic American style, the American style that goes back to Henry Fords cars, James Deans T-shirt and the Timex watch  is not a pose but an adaptation to basic, fundamental challenges. Take jeans, our sartorial signature and our most influential contribution to the modern global wardrobe. They may sell for hundreds of dollars in swank boutiques from Boston to Buenos Aires, but it must be remembered that they originated as work wear for 19th-century laborers who valued them not for their color or silhouette but for their riveted ruggedness. Cowboy hats, truckers wallets, nylon windbreakers and Converse high-tops, to mention just a random sampling of the wearable artifacts that have come to define our nations aesthetic, were inspired by necessity rather than an intent to catch the eye. Design for designs sake, our history suggests, is not an American priority. Instead, we design things to do a certain job (whether its in a mine, an office or a basketball arena), and when we devise a solution to the challenge, especially one thats ingenious, simple or cheap, the result is a forward leap in style that may not even seem like one at first. (Until the Japanese trend scouts come along and hawk it in Tokyo department stores.)

title: Swiss Ban on Minaret Building Meets Widespread Criticism
description: GENEVA  Switzerlands political leaders faced a chorus of criticism at home and abroad on Monday over a ban on the construction of minarets that passed overwhelmingly by referendum on Sunday.

title: City Hall Aide Is Named Environmental Protection Commissioner in N.Y.C.
description: From our friends at the City Room blog.

title: Steelers Have a Surprising Problem: Defense
description: Forget that Pittsburgh Coach Mike Tomlin may have a fissure to fix in his locker room over the players confusion about the decision not to play quarterback Ben Roethlisberger against the Baltimore Ravens. The Steelers more difficult job may be fixing their defense.

title: Creating New Holiday Traditions
description: Amid the swirl of shopping and decorating and photos with Santa, Allison Swope, a mother of two young children in Massachusetts, is looking for something more.

title: Hotel Chains Try New Ways to Earn Loyalty
description: When Greg McHale checks into his hotel room after a day of business travel, he expects what he calls the wonderful and bizarre, namely complimentary Snickers bars, Diet Pepsi and, sometimes, a compact disc of his favorite electronic dance music.

title: SAT v. ACT, as Chronicled by Fortune magazine
description: In a short article posted on its Web site, Fortune writes of the undeclared war for market share and mind share between the College Board (which owns the SAT) and American College Testing (maker of the ACT).

title: Senior Cleric Denounces Iranian Militia for Crackdown
description: TORONTO  Irans most senior cleric denounced the role of the volunteer militia force known as the Basij in the crackdown against protesters, saying the forces actions were against religion and in the path of Satan.

title: After Adam Lambert, Disney Wants Fewer Surprises
description: Whether or not Adam Lambert gets booked on another ABC television program, the networks parent company has said that his sexually provocative performance at the American Music Awards has changed the way that it will approach live broadcasts. In an interview with Reuters, Anne Sweeney, the co-chairwoman of Disney Media Networks and president of the Disney-ABC Television Group, said that Disney would seek assurances  as well as contractual stipulations  that artists on-air performances would closely reflect their rehearsals. We certainly dont want to suppress artistry at any level, but we also have to be very cognizant of who our audience is, Ms. Sweeney told Reuters.

title: Notre Dame Fires Weis and Starts Its Search
description: Notre Dames firing of Charlie Weis on Monday afternoon continued to fuel what was already the hottest question in college sports: Who will be the next coach to attempt to revive the Fighting Irish?

title: On Our Radar
description: 1) A tree harvester offers to save an Indonesian forest.

title: Adopted Children, by the Numbers
description: Whenever the subject here is adoption, readers point out that while the difficult cases make the news, most adoptive families are happy, and most adopted children are healthy and well adjusted.

title: Britain to Send 500 More Troops to Afghanistan
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Brown announced Monday that Britain will send 500 additional troops to Afghanistan in early December, raising the number of British troops there to 10,000.

title: FlightTrack: My Personal Travel Assistant
description: I gotta start reviewing more app-phone apps. What could be better suited for the short format of a blog?

title: Box-Office Records for Wicked, Billy Elliot and Lion King
description: Wicked, the hit musical that imagines the back story of Ozs Wicked Witch of the West, totaled gross revenues of $2,086,135 for its eight Broadway performances during Thanksgiving week, the first time that a Broadway musical or play has passed the $2 million mark for an eight-performance week. The shows previous record of $1,839,950 was set during New Years week during the 2007-08 season.

title: Who Should Be Notre Dames Next Coach?
description: Now that the Charlie Weis era has officially ended at Notre Dame, the question of who his replacement will be will be the focus of the college football world.

title: New Faces in Top European Climate, Environment and Energy Posts
description: The guard is changing at the European Commission in Brussels where, President Jose Manuel Barroso has named his new 27-member team  including a newly created post for climate action. The European Parliament still must approve the decisions during hearings in January.

title: BlogTalk: Police Shootings, Huckabee and 2012
description: The big topic of discussion on the political blogs this morning, especially conservative ones, is the news that the man suspected of gunning down four uniformed officers on Sunday near Tacoma, Washington, was granted clemency nine years ago by Mike Huckabee, when he was the governor of Arkansas. And many have been wondering whether this will be one of those events that would haunt Mr. Huckabee far into the future.

title: Comedy Will Close to Make Way for Emperor Jones
description: The producers of the Off-Broadway play Made in Heaven have relented on their claim to the Soho Playhouse, announcing on Monday that they would close down their show so that the theater can host a transfer of the Eugene ONeill play The Emperor Jones. Last week, the Irish Repertory Theater said that it planned to bring its production of The Emperor Jones, starring John Douglas Thompson in the title role, to the Soho Playhouse beginning on Dec. 15  an announcement that startled the producers of Made in Heaven, a comedy about conjoined twins that opened at that theater on Nov. 2. The Made in Heaven producers said last Wednesday that their contract with the Soho Playhouse gave them the discretion to close down their show after giving four weeks notice. But on Monday, they said they would close the show after its Dec. 7 performance. In a statement, Barbara Ligeti, the lead producer of Made in Heaven, said, We agonized over this decision, adding: The Soho Playhouse made us a very favorable offer, and we felt that sparring with them, to the detriment of the Irish Reps wonderful production, would be counterproductive and mean-spirited.

title: We May Be Born With an Urge to Help
description: What is the essence of human nature? Flawed, say many theologians. Vicious and addicted to warfare, wrote Hobbes. Selfish and in need of considerable improvement, think many parents.

title: Improved Acoustics Benefit City Opera
description: Despite the naysayers, New York City Opera has rebounded. At least for now.

title: Charter Emerges From Bankruptcy
description: Charter Communications, the nations fourth-largest cable operator, said Monday that it has emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

title: Neighborly Stuffed Cabbage
description: AS Saturday morning dawned the other day, the sounds of the impending battle filled my neighborhood: The clanging of pots. The clatter of cans of whole tomatoes being arranged on Corian countertops. The steaming of the cabbages.

title: In Dubai Crisis, a Test of Law and Islamic Banking
description: The debt crisis in Dubai is about to test one of the fastest-growing areas in banking  Islamic finance  and put the emirates own opaque judicial system on trial, according to bankers and experts in finance, The New York Timess Heather Timmons reports.

title: Pakistani Journalist Critical of the Military Is Threatened
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A gunman strafed the house of a liberal columnist over the weekend and an anonymous caller threatened to kill him, warnings the journalist said he believed had come from the fringes of Pakistans security establishment.

title: Iran Seized a Yacht and Its 5-Member British Crew Last Week
description: A sleek 60-foot sailing yacht and its five-member British crew en route to a race were seized by Iran last week after the vessel accidentally crossed into Iranian waters, British and racing officials said Monday. The episode could further strain the volatile relations between Iran and Western nations.

title: Speculation Grows Over a Tense Rift, With Billions at Stake
description: This article was reported by Robert F. Worth, Heather Timmons and Landon Thomas Jr.  and written by Mr. Thomas.

title: The Digital Ramble | Typography
description: The Digital Ramble explores aesthetic topics through materials found online.

title: Chip Caray and TBS Part Ways
description: UPDATED: 10:30 p.m.

title: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Nov. 30
description: The work of Mahmud Hams, which leads Mondays report, has been seen frequently on Lens in the last month: in the Pictures of the Day of Nov. 12 (Slide 8), Nov. 17 (Slide 11) and Nov. 23 (Slide 7) and in Showcase: Stirring Images, No Names (Slide 10).

title: Contractor Gets 3 Months for Bribes to Assemblyman
description: Santo Petrocelli Sr., the former owner and chairman of a company that received millions of dollars to install and maintain city street lights and traffic signals, was sentenced on Monday to three months in prison for making tens of thousands of dollars in payments to Brian M. McLaughlin, the former assemblyman and union leader who is now serving a 10-year federal prison sentence for racketeering.

title: Abu Dhabis Silence Raises the Heat on Dubai
description: Corrected | 8:32 a.m. As the financial markets reopened in Dubai on Monday after several days of uncertainty over the emirates debt crisis, many were expecting a reassuring statement from the federal government in Abu Dhabi, trusting that the United Arab Emirates would be eager to stem further fears in markets around the world, The New York Timess Robert F. Worth, Heather Timmons and Landon Thomas Jr. report.

title: A Cold Shoulder
description: Q. I was always told normal body temperature is 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit. If ones temperature is always lower than that, what does it mean?

title: Story? Unforgettable. The Audience? Often Not.
description: If a friend is someone who laughs at our stories, then a good friend is one who enjoys them even the second time around. But anyone who gasps with delight on hearing a story for the third time is faking it. Or, its a relative: some poor nephew Will or aunt Emily, sitting captive at the holiday table, being polite, perhaps covering a shudder of dread that life is caught in some endless loop where the punch lines never change.

title: A Bigger, Bolder Lennon Tribute
description: Just because an event is in its 29th year doesnt mean it cant do anything new.

title: Todd English Will Create a Food Hall at the Plaza
description: Todd English will be coming up with a plan for a European-style food hall in the lower level of the Plaza Hotel this spring where food will be prepared, served and also sold retail.

title: Top 10 List: Quarterbacks Win on Final Play
description: John Maxymuks latest book is Quarterback Abstract.

title: To Curb Repeat Hospital Stays, Pay Doctors
description: A recent study in The New England Journal of Medicine found that one in five Medicare patients discharged from the hospital was readmitted within a month. One in three was readmitted within three months.

title: Salmonella: Drug-Resistant Strain of Bacteria Gains in Africa, With High Death Rates
description: A new drug-resistant strain of bacteria has emerged in the last decade in Africa and is causing unusual numbers of deaths there, British and African researchers said on Monday.

title: Mike Huckabees Burden
description: Update | Dec 1, 2009; 11:00 a.m.

title: Euro-Area Inflation Rose Above Zero in November
description: PARIS  Inflation in the euro area moved above zero in November for the first time in five months, according to a preliminary report Monday, as higher energy prices pushed the index higher.

title: Manning Says He Will Play Against Cowboys
description: Giants quarterback Eli Manning said Monday that continuing discomfort in his right foot will not prevent him from practicing regularly or playing next Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys.

title: In Hospice, Care and Comfort as Life Wanes
description: I spent a day last month shadowing hospice workers from the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. With each visit to the homes of four patients whose lives were ebbing, the caring, patience, attention and expertise I observed left me wondering why all medicine is not like this  focused on the whole person, not just a disease.

title: Lessons From Hospice Care
description: In todays Personal Health column, Jane E. Brody chronicles her experiences visiting with four patients in hospice care.

title: Gibbs Defends Scope of Party Crashing Inquiry
description: The White House faced fresh questions on Monday about how two aspiring reality television celebrities crashed a state dinner in honor of Indias prime minister  and whether President Obamas social office, in addition to the Secret Service, deserves a share of the blame.

title: Chevrolet Says 2011 Cruze Will Get 40 M.P.G.
description: Yes, this is the company that got into hot water for declaring that the Chevy Volt will get 230 miles a gallon. But theres no fuzzy logic when it comes to the Cruze, a gas-engine compact car meant to replace the Cobalt at the low end of the General Motors product line.

title: E-Mail Fracas Shows Peril of Trying to Spin Science
description: If you have not delved into the thousands of e-mail messages and files hacked from the computers of British climate scientists, let me give you the closest thing to an executive summary. It is taken from a file slugged HARRY_READ_ME, which is the log of a computer experts long struggle to make sense of a database of historical temperatures. Here is Harrys summary of the situation:

title: What Will Be President Obamas Katrina?
description: What will be President Obamas Katrina?

title: The CBO on insurance premiums
description: The Congressional Budget Office has released its much-awaited estimate on how the Senate health care bill would affect premiums. Its good news from the point of view of reform advocates: premiums would stay about the same for people with group coverage, while falling significantly for most of those in the small-group or individual markets. Jon Gruber has crunched the numbers, and produces this convenient chart (via Yglesias):

title: Does Exercise Help You Sleep?
description: The relationship between exercise and sleep is a confusing one. Does exercise rev you up and keep you awake? Or does it relax you and help your sleep?

title: Policy statement
description: I am not now, nor have I ever been, interested in writing about Tiger Woods.

title: Steelers Ward Voices Conflict Between Team Goals and Player Safety
description: BALTIMORE  In the visitors locker room after the Pittsburgh Steelers 20-17 overtime loss to the Baltimore Ravens on Sunday, receiver Hines Ward tried repeatedly to explain his stance on the absence of quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, who had shown postconcussion symptoms last week.

title: Report Cites Big Shortfall in Reserves at A.I.G.
description: An independent analysis of whether the insurance industry has been setting aside enough money to pay its claims estimates that the American International Group has a shortfall of $11.9 billion in its property and casualty business.

title: Developmental Psychologist Says Teenagers Are Different
description: Laurence Steinberg, a developmental psychologist at Temple University in Philadelphia, is one of the leading experts in the United States on adolescent behavior and adolescent brain biology. Dr. Steinberg, 57, has won the $1 million Klaus J. Jacobs Research Prize, which will be awarded to him at a ceremony in early December in Switzerland. Here is an edited version of two conversations with Dr. Steinberg last month:

title: Somebodys Got a Case of the Sundays
description: If you listen to any pop music, youd probably conclude that Mondays are really, really awful. But youd be misguided: according to a new economic study, Sundays are actually much worse  at least in Germany.

title: One Sisters Mmm Is Anothers Um, No Thanks
description: IN the last year I havent spent much alone time with my sister, which is no surprise considering she is the mother of a 5-year-old and a 2-year-old. Weve grabbed a bite or a cup of tea around town, but to hunker down for serious yakking and snacking, no. One reason is we arent eating the same things. Phoebe has been vegan on and off for years, and recently, shes been more on.

title: Go For Broke | Celine Skirt, $1,400
description: Go for Broke is a column about purchases worth rationalizing.

title: Woods, Not Talking to Police, to Skip Tournament
description: Tiger Woods withdrew from his own golf tournament in California on Monday afternoon, citing injuries he sustained in a car accident outside his home early Friday. The direction and status of the police investigation into the incident remained unclear.

title: The Tale of Another Accused Nazi Criminal
description: As the trial of John Demjanjuk, a retired autoworker accused of helping to kill Jews during the Holocaust, began Monday in Germany, the case of another American accused of Nazi war crimes grinds on in Massachusetts.

title: More Time for Bars to Request Later Close on New Years
description: Each New Years Eve, hundreds of bars and clubs are permitted to keep the Champagne flowing and customers drinking to an hour more commonly associated with breakfast than last call.

title: Yesterdays Shaky Residents Are Todays Put-Upon Professors
description: In May the stop-and-start hospital sitcom Scrubs had what sure looked like its final episode: parade of past characters, teary walk-off, blooper reel, production shots of the lead actors doing their series wraps.

title: Assessing Dubai's Debt Crisis
description: Graham Bowley, a New York Times reporter, discusses the latest news surrounding Dubai's financial crisis.

title: Saving a Childs Pet
description: There are those of us who will do anything for our pets. And among us there is a subset who will do anything for our childrens pets  because, after all, we wouldnt have pets in the first place if not for their promises to feed him and walk him and take care of him all by myself.

title: In Month of Giving, a Healthy Reward
description: When Cami Walker of Los Angeles learned three years ago that she had multiple sclerosis, her health and her spirits plummeted  until she got an unusual prescription from a holistic health educator.

title: A Lost European Culture, Pulled From Obscurity
description: Before the glory that was Greece and Rome, even before the first cities of Mesopotamia or temples along the Nile, there lived in the Lower Danube Valley and the Balkan foothills people who were ahead of their time in art, technology and long-distance trade.

title: Senate Debate Begins With Baitsmanship
description: The Great Health Care Debate of 2009 is under way on the Senate floor, and it took just a scant few minutes for the partisan skirmishing to begin in full force.

title: A Prescription for Giving
description: Is it really better to give than to receive? In todays Well column, I explore the science of giving, as well as the extraordinary story of Cami Walker, a Los Angeles woman with multiple sclerosis.

title: Present-Day Soapbox for Voices of the Past (With a Web Site)
description: Lewis H. Lapham leans forward behind his wide wooden desk and within minutes of speaking has mentioned Mark Twain, Arthur Schlesinger Jr., Goethe, Cicero, John Locke, Hamilton, Adams and Madison. A laptop on a side table is piled high with papers.

title: For the Holidays, White House Uses Barneys Decorator
description: Simon Doonan, famous for creating naughty yuletide window displays of Margaret Thatcher (as a dowdy dominatrix) and Madonna (not the holy one), has a new stage on which to present his brand of mistletoe mischief: he is decorating the White House for Christmas.

title: Report Cites $11 Billion Shortfall in A.I.G. Business
description: An independent analysis of whether the insurance industry has been setting aside enough money to pay claims has found that the American International Group has a shortfall of about $11 billion in its all-important property and casualty business, The New York Timess Mary Williams Walsh reports.

title: Bewitched by Bach, Bewildered by His Masterpiece
description: There is a good reason Johann Sebastian Bachs six cello suites strike Eric Siblin as irresistibly exotic. Mr. Siblin is not a seasoned Bach aficionado. He spent years as a pop music critic before suddenly becoming bewitched by the Cello Suites, their mysterious provenance and the manner in which Pablo Casals famously rediscovered, recorded and popularized this long-forgotten music. Thus mesmerized, Mr. Siblin has written about the Cello Suites from a wide-eyed newbies point of view.

title: Mr. Bayh Reassured by Budget Office Study
description: It was Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, who insisted that the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office study the potential effect of health care legislation on premium costs for the majority of Americans who already have health benefits. Mr. Bayh has issued a statement saying that he is reassured by the analysis unveiled by the budget office earlier Monday.

title: The Joys, and Lessons, of Traveling to Brazil
description: IVE been flying since I was a child. I was only 8 years old when I had my first solo flight to Europe. I had to wear my passport around my neck, and I always got a lot of attention from the flight attendants. Many of them would put me in the business-class section, even though I belonged in economy.

title: Disabled, and Seeking Acceptance in Fashion
description: The fashion world may be the last bastion of prejudice, a field that overtly discriminates against people because of their looks. So there is something both bold and troubling about Britains Missing Top Model, a reality show that begins on Tuesday on BBC America that pits disabled women against one another to compete for a photo spread in the U.K. edition of Marie Claire magazine.

title: A Conversation With Ken Salazar
description: John Broder of The New York Times interviewed Ken Salazar, the secretary of the interior, about the challenges facing the federal agency.

title: Senators Begin Offering Amendments
description: Senators are beginning to submit a torrent of amendments to the big health care legislation.

title: Critics' Picks: 'La Jetee'
description: A. O. Scott looks at Chris Marker's 28-minute rumination on time, love and the apocalypse.

title: Travels in Cyberspace: The Monday Report
description: Thrill-seeking travelers already making their vacation plans for next year might want to check out what Gadling picks as its Top 10 (+2) Adventure Destinations for 2010. The list isnt exactly revelatory (Antarctica, New Zealand and Peru all make the cut), but the travel blog makes a strong case that its top-rated pick  the Himalayas  is well worth the trouble and expense of getting there.

title: Christmas Dog Trampled by Football
description: A warmhearted holiday-themed movie  with a dog, no less  showed no teeth on Sunday night against that other seasonal tradition: football. According to Nielsens estimates, NBC ranked first for the night with its Sunday Night Football coverage of the Pittsburgh Steelers playing the Baltimore Ravens. Preliminary overnight estimates show it drew more viewers than last weeks game between the Philadelphia Eagles and the Chicago Bears, which averaged 17.3 million. CBS was second with 60 Minutes (14.3 million), The Amazing Race (11.7 million) and A Dog Named Christmas (12.3 million). Best in show for ABC was Desperate Housewives (12.6 million), while Fox drew 9 million for The Simpsons and 8.5 million for Family Guy.

title: Nine Inch Nails Auctions Its Equipment
description: Though it is the prerogative of rock stars to announce that they are breaking up their band and then reconstitute it months (or weeks or days) later, Nine Inch Nails seems to be serious when it says that it will no longer perform as a group. After playing what it said were its final shows in August and September, the hard-core rock group led by Trent Reznor said on its Web site, nin.com, that it was auctioning off its instruments and other touring equipment on eBay, The Guardian reported. Among the pieces put up for sale are a Gibson banjitar (a banjo-guitar hybrid) that was selling for more than $1,500, and a guitar decorated with artwork from the Nine Inch Nails album The Fragile, whose bidding price had passed $2,250.

title: Pulp Fiction Writer Is Sent to Jail
description: Was Roger Avary, a screenwriter of Pulp Fiction, moved from a prison work furlough program to a county jail in California because he was tweeting about his prison experience? Depends on whom you ask. Mr. Avary, who shared an Academy Award in 1995 with Quentin Tarantino for Pulp Fiction, was sentenced in September to one year in prison after pleading guilty to charges of vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving. In October posts began appearing on Mr. Avarys Twitter account in which he described his jail setting (The building is an imposing example of the Brutalist architectural movement, he wrote) and details of his furlough program. On Friday, The Ventura County Star reported, Mr. Avary was taken off the work furlough program, owing to what Capt. Ross Bonfiglio of the Ventura County Sheriffs Department called a security-related issue. I wouldnt doubt that it had something to do with those tweets, Captain Bonfiglio told The Star. But on Monday he told The Associated Press that Mr. Avarys Twitter posts had not played a major role in Mr. Avarys incarceration.

title: A Show Doesnt Go on So That Another Might
description: Producers of the Off Broadway play Made in Heaven have relented on their claim to the SoHo Playhouse, saying on Monday that they would close their show so the theater could host a transfer of the Eugene ONeill play The Emperor Jones. Last week the Irish Repertory Theater said it planned to bring its production of The Emperor Jones, starring John Douglas Thompson, to the SoHo Playhouse beginning on Dec. 15  an announcement that startled the producers of Made in Heaven, a comedy about conjoined twins that opened at that theater on Nov. 2. The Made in Heaven producers said that their contract with the theater gave them the discretion to close their show after giving four weeks notice. But on Monday they said they would close after the Dec. 7 performance. In a statement, Barbara Ligeti, the lead producer of Made in Heaven, said, The SoHo Playhouse made us a very favorable offer, and we felt that sparring with them, to the detriment of the Irish Reps wonderful production, would be counterproductive and mean-spirited.

title: Walken and Grammer Returning to Broadway
description: Christopher Walken, a veteran of the spooky and the strange, sure can tell a good body-part story  which hell be doing in his return to Broadway this winter after 10 years, as a man searching for his missing hand in the play A Behanding in Spokane. Mr. Walken will be joined by Zoe Kazan and Anthony Mackie as two con artists, and Sam Rockwell as a hotel clerk, in the new black comedy by Martin McDonagh, whose plays on Broadway have included The Lieutenant of Inishmore, The Pillowman and The Beauty Queen of Leenane. Mr. Walken last appeared on Broadway as Gabriel Conroy in James Joyces The Dead, for which he was nominated for a Tony Award for best actor in a musical. A Behanding in Spokane is scheduled to run for 16 weeks, with previews beginning on Feb. 15 and the opening scheduled for March 4 at the Schoenfeld Theater. ... The producers of next springs revival of La Cage aux Folles confirmed that the Emmy Award-winning actor Kelsey Grammer (Frasier) would play the nightclub owner Georges opposite the British actor Douglas Hodge as Albin, his partner and the clubs leading drag queen. Mr. Grammers last outing on Broadway was as the title character in the 2000 revival of Macbeth, which received poor reviews and closed after 8 previews and 13 regular performances. La Cage aux Folles is to start previews on April 6 and open on April 18 at the Longacre Theater.

title: After Lambert, Disney Seeks Fewer Surprises
description: Whether or not the singer Adam Lambert is booked on another ABC television show, that networks parent company has said that his sexually provocative performance at the American Music Awards has changed the way it will approach live television broadcasts. In an interview with Reuters, Anne Sweeney, the co-chairwoman of Disney Media Networks and president of the Disney-ABC Television Group, said that Disney would seek assurances  as well as contractual stipulations  that artists on-air performances will closely mirror their rehearsals. We certainly dont want to suppress artistry at any level, but we also have to be very cognizant of who our audience is, Ms. Sweeney told Reuters. Mr. Lambert, the American Idol finalist, set off a torrent of criticism with his Nov. 22 appearance at the American Music Awards, which were broadcast on ABC, in which he simulated sex acts, kissed his male band mate, above, and extended his middle finger to a television camera. Mr. Lambert later said that he got carried away and that he had not performed those same moves during a rehearsal for the awards show. In the fallout over his performance, ABCs Good Morning America withdrew its invitation to host a free concert for Mr. Lambert last Wednesday.

title: No Country for Old Typewriters: A Well-Used One Heads to Auction
description: Cormac McCarthy has written more than a dozen novels, several screenplays, two plays, two short stories, countless drafts, letters and more  and nearly every one of them was tapped out on a portable Olivetti manual typewriter he bought in a Knoxville, Tenn., pawnshop around 1963 for $50.

title: For Poe, This Has Been the Year to Die For
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Edgar Allan Poe took good care of his corpses. They are neatly cut up and craftily stowed beneath floorboards (The Tell-Tale Heart); they are walled into ancient catacombs where nothing is likely to disturb their well-earned eternal slumber (The Cask of Amontillado); they are encased in coffins that somehow permit them to emerge to take care of unfinished business (The Fall of the House of Usher). But the living  some of whom become those corpses  have a much harder time of it. They obsess, brood and hate; they are possessed by bizarre impulses; they wrestle with inchoate forces and often succumb, scarcely knowing the scope of their perversities.

title: F.A.A. Clarifies What Can Be Stowed in Seat Back
description: COMMON sense has prevailed, for once. The Federal Aviation Administration recently issued new guidelines that clarify formerly confounding policies on whether passengers may put personal items in airplane seat-back pockets.

title: One Microbe as a Group of 200 Protein Machines
description: Molecular biology for years meant breaking down living cells to their smallest component parts, the genes and proteins that govern what a cell does. But a list of parts tells only so much. To understand how living cells really work, biologists are now trying to visualize how the parts are assembled into operational units.

title: Dubai Inc.s Holdings May Go Up for Auction
description: Much of the billions of dollars that Dubai borrowed during the boom years went to help build grandiose trophy real estate projects at home like an indoor skiing arena, the worlds largest airport, artificial palm-shaped islands and the worlds tallest building. But the emirates state-owned companies also went on a spending spree abroad, acquiring properties and companies that could now wind up on the auction block  potentially at fire-sale prices  to pay off its creditors.

title: Critics Picks: La Jetee
description: This week, A. O. Scott discusses the abundance of apocalyptic films that have made their way to theaters in recent years. But none of these visions of catastrophe, he says, is quite as haunting or as effective as one put forward in a movie called La Jetee. The 28-minute film consists of voice-over narration, a score and a series of photographs. Please share your thoughts on La Jetee and what you consider to be the best apocalyptic film.

title: Council Curtails Stores Use of Roll-Down Security Gates
description: Citing high rates of graffiti, the City Council voted unanimously on Monday to gradually ban the use of roll-down metal security gates, a move that would eliminate what has been an enduring if forbidding feature of the urban streetscape.

title: Subject, Meet Verb
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Subject, Meet Verb
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Marion Jones Aims for a Comeback, in Basketball
description: SAN ANTONIO

title: And Now They Sing the Fiddle Electric
description: As a member of the enterprising new-music ensembles Ne(x)tworks and Ethel, the violinist Cornelius Dufallo runs into plenty of composers. He has coaxed new solo works from some and taken up older scores by others. He is also a composer himself: Dream Streets, his new CD (for Innova), is devoted to his own imaginative works for violin and electronics.

title: Looking for Balloons and Insights to Online Behavior
description: The prize is $40,000, and it goes to the first person or group to determine the locations of 10 red balloons that can be anywhere in the continental United States.

title: A Beetle, Its Eggs and the Secrets of a Glue
description: Wax is slippery stuff, a characteristic that many plants employ to keep nasty things off them. The needlelike branches of asparagus plants, for example, are covered with wax crystals, which make the branches practically unwettable and keep things from sticking.

title: A Program of Songs to Explore the Shades of Love
description: The appealing Austrian mezzo-soprano Angelika Kirchschlager is in New York to prepare for her overdue return to the Metropolitan Opera. She will sing Hansel in Humperdincks Hansel and Gretel this month. If she has been missing in action from the Met since 2002 (when she appeared as Cherubino in Mozarts Nozze di Figaro), Ms. Kirchschlager, a vivid interpreter of lieder, has made New York a regular stop on her song recital tours.

title: Plume of Pollutants From a Small Airport
description: For people who live near an airport, noise is a major concern. But air quality can be an issue, too: after all, aircraft engines produce emissions on the ground as well as in the air.

title: Emperor Jones Director Says Misunderstanding Almost Halted Transfer
description: Ciarn OReilly, the producing director of the Irish Repertory Theater, said on Monday that a massive communications breakdown between the owners of the Soho Playhouse and the producers of the comedy Made in Heaven had nearly prevented Mr. OReillys company from transferring its production of The Emperor Jones to that theater.

title: Still Smoking (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Kindness Hormone (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Defense of Bridges (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Hacking the Climate Debate
description: How much concern should there be over the revelations about

title: Snails, Left and Right (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghanistan Vets: Send Your Thoughts on Obamas Plans
description: At War is looking for American service members who have spent time in Afghanistan, preferably on more than one deployment, for a Times article about President Obamas decision on troop levels there. If interested, please use the comment box below to tell us a little about yourself, your time in Afghanistan and the best way to reach you. The comments will not be published but will be forwarded to the Times reporter writing an article that will appear later this week. Some of those who respond will be asked if they are willing for their reactions to be taped for an audio presentation on the Web.
